headline: Verboten, a New Dance Club in Williamsburg, Opens
text: Hit any club along Wythe Street in Williamsburg and you’re sure to see packs of cigarette-slim Continentals who order “water with gas,” stay in AirBnb apartments and dance till sunrise. But with March’s opening of Verboten, a 10,000-square-foot, open-till-6 a.m. dance club with a Teutonic theme and a strong European lean, this newly anointed night life concourse is truly starting to feel like a Little Berlin.

headline: F.A.A. Computer Problem Delays Flights in the West
text: A computer failure at an air traffic control center forced the Federal Aviation Administration to hold planes on the ground at Los Angeles International Airport and other airports in the region on Wednesday afternoon.

headline: Fans Lose Soccer Team, Then Build Their Own
text: TAMPERE, Finland — When the referee’s whistle sounded at the end of the first half on Saturday, Juha Kumara’s hamstring ached so badly that he took himself out of the game and limped into the stands.

headline: New York City Approves 30¢ Surcharge to Pay for Accessible Taxis
text: The de Blasio administration on Wednesday approved a 30-cent surcharge on all yellow and street-hail livery taxi rides as part of a plan to make half of New York’s yellow cabs wheelchair accessible by 2020.

headline: Senator Urges N.F.L. to Change Name of Redskins
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Harry Reid of Nevada on Wednesday called on the N.F.L. to change the name of the Washington Redskins, urging the league to respond to charges that the name is offensive by following the example set by the N.B.A. in punishing the owner of the Los Angeles Clippers.

headline: Outrage Across Ideological Spectrum in Europe Over Flawed Lethal Injection in U.S.
text: LONDON — Europeans largely consider the death penalty a particularly brutal American anachronism, but the prolonged death of Clayton D. Lockett in Oklahoma, after a botched execution by lethal injection, produced more than the usual horror on Wednesday.

headline: Illinois Republicans Object to Plan to Spend $100 Million to Lure Obama Library
text: CHICAGO — The Democrats, who run this state, regularly fret over Illinois’s financial woes — the unpaid bills, the mortifying credit ratings, the benefits cuts to save one of the nation’s most underfunded pension systems. But then there is the dream of becoming home to Barack Obama’s presidential library, which is, it seems, a whole different matter.

headline: Before Ink Dries on Army Rules, Soldiers Rush to Get Tattoos
text: LAKEWOOD, Wash. — An Army soldier walked into Brass Monkey Tattoo last month and told Dan Brewer, the tattoo artist, to go for it.

headline: Alibaba Said to Be in Talks to Regain Stake in Alipay
text: The Alibaba Group, the Chinese e-commerce giant on the cusp of going public in the United States, is in talks with its Alipay payment affiliate about regaining a stake in the business, a person briefed on the matter said on Wednesday.

headline: Gerry Adams Questioned Over Murder From 1972
text: LONDON — The president of Sinn Fein, Gerry Adams, was arrested and questioned Wednesday night about the 1972 abduction and murder of a widowed mother of 10, whose body was found on a beach in the Irish Republic in 2003, according to the Sinn Fein website and the police in Northern Ireland.

headline: Candidate for President in Egypt Tempers His Expectations
text: CAIRO — Hamdeen Sabahi says he does not really expect a fair race against his opponent for president of Egypt, the former military officer who led the takeover of the elected government.

headline: Good-Looking Colt. Nice Story. 5-2 Odds. What’s Not to Like?
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — It is hard not to like California Chrome. He has run away with four stakes races by nearly 25 lengths combined. He is a handsome and agile colt with muscles bulging beneath his gleaming chestnut coat and a stride as effortless as a glider skipping on clouds. He has an interesting back story as well.

headline: Dylan’s Handwritten Lyrics to ‘Like a Rolling Stone’ to Be Auctioned
text: For the giver, who is famously unsentimental about his past, it may have seemed just a sheaf of papers that had outlived their usefulness. For the receiver, a collector of rock memorabilia who met the giver, Bob Dylan, through a non-musical connection, that sheaf was a prized possession for many years. It may soon become his retirement fund.

headline: With Security Tight, Iraqis Cast Votes in Unaccustomed Peace
text: BAGHDAD — Millions of Iraqis voted for a new Parliament on Wednesday, defying threats from Islamist extremists, in an election that was carried out, by Iraq’s brutal standards, in remarkable peace.

headline: State Backs More Cameras to Catch Speeders Near New York City’s Schools
text: State lawmakers agreed on Wednesday to add 120 speed-tracking cameras to New York City’s streets, providing a significant addition to the city’s automated enforcement devices as the de Blasio administration seeks to improve traffic safety.

headline: A Ghost Town, Going Green
text: NIPTON, Calif. — Gerald Freeman leaned on a walking stick on a dusty hill near the four rows of his solar arrays, talking about it like an apostle on a mission. Down the road are the eucalyptus trees he planted as a potential source of biomass. And not far away, he said, he hopes to install a hydrogen system, another source of renewable fuel.

headline: Email Suggests White House Strategy on Benghazi
text: WASHINGTON — A newly released email shows that White House officials sought to shape the way Susan E. Rice, then the ambassador to the United Nations, discussed the Middle East chaos that was the context for the attack on the American diplomatic mission in Benghazi, Libya, in 2012.

headline: Hundreds in Albuquerque Voice Distrust of the Police
text: ALBUQUERQUE — For the third consecutive day Wednesday, Justice Department officials sat in rooms big and small here listening to disgruntled people pour out their frustrations about the Albuquerque Police Department, which was castigated in a Justice Department report in April for systemic and unconstitutional use of excessive force.

headline: Job Crushing or Lifesaving?
text: Speaker John Boehner blasts “job-crushing regulations.” The House majority leader, Eric Cantor, prefers a variant: “job-destroying regulations.” That mantra has been repeated so much that we might think that all regulations do is crush, destroy, annihilate, maim, gut, crucify and extirpate jobs.

headline: State-Sponsored Horror in Oklahoma
text: At 6:36 p.m. on Tuesday in McAlester, Okla., Clayton Lockett started kicking his leg, then twitching, then writhing and moaning in agony, and everyone watching knew something had gone terribly wrong. Mr. Lockett, a convicted murderer, was strapped to a gurney in the death chamber of the Oklahoma State Penitentiary, about to be executed by lethal injection, but the untested combination of a sedative and a paralyzing agent had failed.

headline: Famous Faces Cross Over to Online Video
text: THE creators, producers and distributors of online video are cranking up the star power as they seek to woo viewers and advertisers, particularly as they offer digital programming in what is being called “the new living room,” where people may watch a clip or show on a TV set, a smartphone, a tablet, a desktop or a laptop.

headline: The Dark Side of the Sharing Economy
text: Proponents of the “sharing economy” say websites like Airbnb that make it easy for people to rent a spare bedroom or an apartment on a short-term basis are a boon to cities like New York and San Francisco because they generate income for residents while giving visitors a cheap place to stay. But advocates often ignore or casually dismiss big problems with these short-term rentals, including the fact that they are making housing less affordable in big cities by restricting supply. And in some cases the rentals may be illegal, which is one reason the New York state attorney general, Eric Schneiderman, has begun an investigation.

headline: Stronger Action Required on Syria, Aid Chief Warns
text: UNITED NATIONS — When the Security Council passed a legally binding resolution two months ago to provide relief to Syrians trapped behind front lines, Western delegates pledged “further steps” if the warring parties blocked aid deliveries by United Nations agencies. They specifically warned the Syrian government about its use of barrel bombs, the improvised mix of shrapnel and explosives that aircraft crews have dropped on civilian areas to devastating effect.

headline: Director and Deputy of Intelligence Agency Are to Retire by Fall
text: WASHINGTON — The director of the Defense Intelligence Agency, Lt. Gen. Michael T. Flynn of the Army, and his civilian deputy, David R. Shedd, will retire by early fall, the agency said in an email to its employees on Wednesday.

headline: It’s Only a Million
text: It’s sad what a million dollars has fallen to.

headline: For McIlroy, a Sudden Transformation From Prodigy to Role Model
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Two days before his 21st birthday, Rory McIlroy outpaced his elders at Quail Hollow Club to become the youngest winner on the PGA Tour since Tiger Woods. Four years later, McIlroy has gone from big deal to big brother.

headline: Man and Woman Killed Her Uncle Then Jumped From Bridge, Police Say
text: SUFFERN, N.Y. — The couple arrived at the George Washington Bridge on Monday morning, traveling in a green Chevrolet Malibu taken from a dead man.

headline: Qaeda Affiliates Gain Regional Influence as Central Leadership Fades
text: WASHINGTON — Al Qaeda’s affiliates in Somalia, Syria, Yemen and West Africa are exerting increasing influence in their regions, posing new challenges for American counterterrorism officials even after a decade of allied attacks that have weakened the group’s leadership in Pakistan, according to a State Department report released Wednesday.

headline: Jewish Coalition Rejects Lobbying Group’s Bid to Join
text: American Jewish leaders on Wednesday voted to deny membership in an influential national coalition to a lobbying group that has at times criticized the Israeli government.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for April 30, 2014
text: April 30, 2014

headline: Not All Health Care Premiums Are Paid Up, House Panel Says
text: WASHINGTON — A House committee said Wednesday that only two-thirds of people signing up for private health insurance in the federal exchange had paid their premiums by April 15. Without payment, consumers will not have coverage.

headline: Doctors in the Death Chamber
text: Doctors have participated in lethal injections since they were first used, despite professional guidelines that proscribe this. Should they be allowed to participate in executions without being disciplined?

headline: As New Shipping Rules Are Studied, Another Oil Train Derails
text: In the latest accident involving rail cars carrying crude oil, a CSX train derailed and erupted into black, smoky flames on Wednesday in downtown Lynchburg, Va., forcing scores of people to evacuate and causing a spill in the James River.

headline: Mice and Mothers
text: The needle penetrated my latex glove and slipped into the soft skin of my finger. It was quick and painless. I was in the animal lab of Children’s Hospital Los Angeles, buried under Sunset Boulevard. Despite the thousands of mice within, the lab was peaceful. I was alone.

headline: Mets and Yankees Have Identical Records, if Not Identical Expectations
text: The Mets and the Yankees arrived at the soggy end of April on Wednesday with identical 15-11 records. Twice in the last decade they have finished the season with the same mark: in 2006, when both made the playoffs, and in 2008, when both missed.

headline: Bill Clinton Defends His Economic Legacy
text: Former President Bill Clinton, who has grown increasingly frustrated that his economic policies are viewed as out-of-step with the current focus on income inequality, on Wednesday delivered his most muscular defense of his economic legacy.

headline: 2 Law Students Get a Lesson on the First Amendment, Complete With Subpoenas
text: Let’s give credit where due: A New York University Law School trustee has devised a terrific First Amendment lesson for students.

headline: Changed Life of the Poor: Better Off, but Far Behind
text: WASHINGTON — Is a family with a car in the driveway, a flat-screen television and a computer with an Internet connection poor?

headline: Mr. Poe, Over Here! Do ‘Raven’
text: “I think you folks are in for a real treat,” says the guy in the Smokey Bear hat and trim park ranger’s get-up. With his genial aw-shucks manner, Ranger Steve, played by Jeremy Wilhelm, would seem to make a rather odd narrator for “Red-Eye to Havre de Grace,” a new musical theater work about the grim last days of Edgar Allan Poe that opened on Wednesday at New York Theater Workshop.

headline: Subject of an Eerie Rural Legend
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Ew. That’s not an opinion about Brandon Hensley’s debut puzzle; It’s an opinion about the legend it highlights.

headline: How the Execution Went Wrong
text: What should have happened in the execution of Clayton D. Lockett.

headline: From a Playoff Scratch to a Standout for Boston
text: BOSTON — By the time Dougie Hamilton reached high school in St. Catharines, Ontario, he had found his sporting passion. The child of two Canadian Olympians, he tried all sports and excelled in most of them before concentrating on hockey.

headline: Few Options for Those Who Missed Health Insurance Deadlines
text: If you don’t have health insurance through your employer and haven’t enrolled through a government insurance exchange, your options for getting coverage this year are dwindling.

headline: Protester Says She Doesn’t Recall Hitting Officer With Elbow
text: Cecily McMillan, the Occupy Wall Street protester charged with assaulting a New York City police officer, testified on Wednesday that she has no recollection of blackening the officer’s eye with her elbow. Having watched a video of the episode, though, she does not deny doing it.

headline: The Derby Draw
text: Post positions for Saturday’s 140th running of the Kentucky Derby.

headline: Scion of Art Family Gets a Year in Prison
text: With a stinging rebuke, a federal judge on Wednesday sentenced Hillel Nahmad, an Upper East Side gallery owner and scion of a powerful art family, to a year in prison on a gambling charge, saying that money could not prevent his incarceration.

headline: L.I.R.R. President Is Being Replaced
text: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority said on Wednesday that it would remove the longtime president of the Long Island Rail Road, upending the leadership of an agency mired in labor negotiations.

headline: Top State Judge Tightens Rules on Debt Collection
text: New York State’s chief judge announced on Wednesday that he would institute new court rules and protocols that would make it more difficult for debt collection companies to win default judgments and would offer more protection to debtors.

headline: Claiming a Copyright on Marx? How Uncomradely
text: The Marxist Internet Archive, a website devoted to radical writers and thinkers, recently received an email: It must take down hundreds of works by Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels or face legal consequences.

headline: Toronto Mayor Said to Seek Help
text: Citing “a problem with alcohol,” Mayor Rob Ford of Toronto said late Wednesday that he was temporarily stepping aside from his mayoral re-election campaign and seeking “professional help.” His statement followed the online posting of a still photograph from a video that The Globe and Mail said appeared to show him smoking crack cocaine last weekend. The video’s appearance may undermine Mr. Ford’s hopes of re-election in October.

headline: Video Captures Students on Sinking Ferry
text: Cellphone video from one of the passengers aboard the ferry Sewol, Park Su-hyeon, before it capsized. Pictured, the ferry going down on April 16, 2014.

headline: Second Man Sentenced for 2011 Murder of High School Basketball Star
text: A second man received a sentence of 25 years to life in state prison for the 2011 murder of a high school basketball star in Harlem, the Manhattan district attorney’s office said on Wednesday.

headline: ‘The Americans’ Recap: Eight Things About the Show That Don’t Make Sense
text: In Episode 10 – three episodes away from the season finale – Philip and Elizabeth face encroaching threats on many fronts. Agent Stan Beeman is getting closer to their operation. He has had an artist rendering of them for some time, but now he’s shown it to Jared, the son of their murdered colleagues, Emmett and Leanne. Jared seems to recognize Elizabeth, who recently visited disguised as a social worker.

headline: As Pressure Reaches a Peak, So Does Lundqvist
text: Heading into Game 7 against the Philadelphia Flyers on Wednesday, the Rangers had to feel confident with history and Henrik Lundqvist on their side.

headline: Nets’ Exhilarating Rally Ends in Excruciating Fashion
text: TORONTO — Roughly three and half minutes remained in the third quarter here Wednesday when a familiar sound bubbled up in a slow crescendo from the arena’s upper tiers. Within seconds, the noise was deafening.

headline: Walter R. Walsh Dies at 106; Terrorized Gangsters and Targets
text: Walter R. Walsh, a world-class marksman who shot clothespins off laundry lines as a boy and went on to become an F.B.I. legend in shootouts with gangsters in the 1930s, an Olympic competitor and a trainer of generations of Marine Corps sharpshooters, died on Tuesday at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 106.

headline: Keenan Takes Home K.H.L. Title
text: Mike Keenan became the first North American coach to win the Kontinental Hockey League championship as Metallurg Magnitogorsk defeated Lev Praha, 7-4, on Wednesday in Game 7 of the finals. With the score tied, 2-2, in the second period, Metallurg scored twice in a minute to pull away from the visiting team from Prague.

headline: Corrections: May 1, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: A Haunting Display of Specimens Large and Small
text: In this weekly series, T’s photo editors share the most compelling visual projects they’ve discovered.

headline: Stefanie Zweig, Author Who Fled Nazis to Kenya, Dies at 81
text: Stefanie Zweig, the author of “Nowhere in Africa,” a best-selling autobiographical novel about the life of a Jewish family in Kenya after their escape from Nazi Germany and the inspiration for an Oscar-winning film, died on Friday in Frankfurt. She was 81.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: The 18-Year Rash
text: The Challenge: Can you figure out what can cause a rash that lasts 18 years?

headline: Word of the Day | clangor
text: clangor•\ˈklaN-ər also -gər\• noun

headline: India Election Digest: May 1
text: What you need to know on Thursday about India’s elections: A selfie gets the Bharatiya Janata Party’s candidate for prime minister into trouble, it’s tough to pin down the reasons for the high voter turnout, and a village in Uttar Pradesh abstains from the vote out of protest.

headline: Times Minute | Minimum Wage Politics
text: Today on the Minute, the minimum wage is at the heart of debate between Democrats and Republicans.

headline: Times Minute | Minimum Wage Politics
text: In the Video

headline: Envisioning the End of Employer-Provided Health Plans
text: The days of Americans getting health insurance through their employers may be numbered — and the change could be just as profound as the shift of employers forcing employees to manage their own retirement savings.

headline: Atlanta Hawks Stress Their System While Leading Their Series
text: ATLANTA — They are the accidental playoff participant, a team whose management has stressed winning its players’ acceptance of a fresh system more than winning games this season.

headline: Al Feldstein, the Soul of Mad Magazine, Dies at 88
text: Al Feldstein, who took over a fledgling humor magazine called Mad in 1956 and made it a popular, profitable and enduring wellspring of American satire, died on Tuesday at his ranch in Paradise Valley, Mont. He was 88.

headline: Frank Budd, Once Known as World’s Fastest Human, Dies at 74
text: Frank Budd, a former Olympic sprinter who for a time was considered the world’s fastest human after he set a record in the 100-yard dash in 1961, died on Tuesday in Marlton, N.J. He was 74.

headline: Hunger Striker Ends Fast, but Not Fight, Against Nuclear Power in Taiwan
text: A former head of Taiwan’s Democratic Progressive Party has announced that he is ending his hunger strike, but not his campaign, against nuclear power on the island.

headline: What’s on Thursday
text: 8 P.M. (NBC) IHEARTRADIO MUSIC AWARDS More than 13.2 million votes were cast by iHeartRadio listeners to determine favorite artists and songs in this first-time awards ceremony, broadcast live from the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles. Nominees include Imagine Dragons (above), Justin Timberlake, Macklemore & Ryan Lewis, Maroon 5 and Rihanna for artist of the year; Florida Georgia Line, Icona Pop, Imagine Dragons, Lorde, Macklemore & Ryan Lewis, and Passenger for best new artist; and, in the most voted-on category, “Holy Grail” and “Suit & Tie,” both by Jay Z and Mr. Timberlake; “Stay,” by Rihanna and Mikky Ekko; “The Monster,” by Eminem and Rihanna; and “Timber,” by Pitbull and Kesha, for best collaboration. Blake Shelton, Drake, Kendrick Lamar, Pharrell Williams, Pitbull, Shakira, Thirty Seconds to Mars, Luke Bryan, Arcade Fire, Ed Sheeran and Ariana Grande will perform at the auditorium and in locations around Los Angeles, including the Roxy and the Hotel Cafe. Red-carpet coverage begins at 7 on E!

headline: Caught Again on Camera, Rob Ford Leaves for Treatment
text: TORONTO —  Rob Ford, Toronto’s troubled mayor who acquired international notoriety for his drug use and a seeming inability to experience shame, quietly took a break from public life on Thursday.

headline: A Former Chief Minister Turns on the Heat in Amritsar
text: This is the second of a two-part series on the crucial parliamentary race in Amritsar, India. You can read the first part, a profile on Arun Jaitley of the Bharatiya Janata Party, here.

headline: At Least One Killed as Blasts Hit Indian Train Station
text: NEW DELHI — Two small explosions tore through an express train at Chennai’s central railway station on Thursday, killing one woman and injuring more than a dozen bystanders, some of them critically.

headline: Profit Drops at Lloyds Bank, but Outlook Improves
text: LONDON – The Lloyds Banking Group said on Thursday that its first-quarter profit declined 24.7 percent, but that its outlook continued to improve as it cut costs and avoided additional charges for legacy problems.

headline: Putin Demands That Ukraine Pull Its Troops From Southeast
text: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia told Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany on Thursday that Ukraine must remove its military from the southeastern region of the country to resolve the showdown there with pro-Russian militants who have seized several official buildings, the Kremlin said.

headline: Test Yourself | English, May 1, 2014
text: Take the Quiz

headline: After Obama Visit, Planned Naval Drills With Russia Reported
text: China and Russia will soon hold joint naval exercises near islands disputed by Beijing and Tokyo in the East China Sea, the Jinghua Times newspaper reported on Thursday, quoting China’s Ministry of National Defense.

headline: Online, a Censored Reaction to Urumqi Bombing
text: With May 1 a national holiday in China, and censorship heavy, reaction to the deadly bomb and knife attack late Wednesday at a train station in Urumqi, in the western region of Xinjiang, appeared slow to take off.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Suddenly Everyone, It Seems, Wants to Buy the Clippers
text: In “Suddenly Everyone, It Seems, Wants to Buy the Clippers,” Billy Witz and Mary Pilon write about how the Los Angeles Clippers franchise suddenly finds itself the toast of Los Angeles and a coveted commodity in professional sports.

headline: On the Brink in Brownsville
text: In a typical game of skelly, two children flick homemade plastic pucks into numbered squares drawn on the asphalt. It’s a quaint and simple contest — a mix between shooting marbles and playing shuffleboard — that New Yorkers have played for generations. On warm days in Brownsville, Brooklyn, when there is no school, teenage boys pour out of the housing projects to play. It’s a curious thing to see, boys their age, with the freedom to roam, so captivated by this elementary pastime. But there they sit, with new tattoos on their arms and new hair on their faces, channeling their energy into their fingers and thumbs.

headline: No Choice but to Protest and Take Pictures
text: Although he made a career photographing protests in the 1960s, Benedict J. Fernandez was a young man without a cause growing up in East Harlem in the 1950s.

headline: Turkish Protesters Defy Government’s May Day Ban
text: ISTANBUL — Thousands of demonstrators took to the streets of Istanbul on Thursday in May Day rallies, confronting riot police officers to protest a government mired in a corruption scandal and accused of imposing a creeping authoritarianism in Turkey.

headline: What Movies Do You Watch, or Reference, Over and Over?
text: “Mean Girls” turns 10 this week, but, according to a recent Times article, it’s still a “go-to source of shorthand for female — and human — dynamics” because young women everywhere continue to quote the lines and create memes around it.

headline: Its PC Sales Tailing Off, Sony Now Expects Loss
text: Sony slashed its profit outlook for the third time in a year on Thursday, putting increased pressure on its chief executive, Kazuo Hirai, to show he can still engineer a turnaround.

headline: New York Today: Waterlogged
text: Good morning on this sodden Thursday.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: Photos: There’s Always the Kentucky Derby, in Good Times and Bad
text: Horse racing’s fortunes have taken turns soaring and ebbing in the 140 years that the Kentucky Derby has been its crown jewel, and with the current state of the sport ranging somewhere from lagging to collapsing, depending on your point of view, it is tempting to look backward longingly.

headline: A West Virginia Democrat Battles Extinction
text: It was a vote intended to split along party lines; instead, it revealed just how worried some House Democrats are about re-election.

headline: BG Aims to Speed Up Deals to Bring Its Riches to Market
text: LONDON — The British oil and gas company BG Group said on Thursday that it would most likely accelerate the pace of deal-making to raise money and help develop its rich holdings in countries like Brazil and Australia.

headline: China’s Leader Warns of Long-Term Terror Fight After Blast
text: HONG KONG — President Xi Jinping of China said the government must prepare itself for a long-term fight against what he called separatist forces in the country’s restive Xinjiang region after assailants with knives and a bomb killed one person and injured at least 79 on Wednesday evening at a railway station in Urumqi, the regional capital.

headline: How Not to Be Misled by the Jobs Report
text: We obsess far too much on the Labor Department’s monthly jobs report.

headline: Daily Report: Facebook to Enhance Privacy Controls
text: Trying to become even bigger — and make more money — Facebook will allow users to reveal a little less, Vindu Goel reports.

headline: Covering the Greatest Two Minutes in Sports
text: Joe Drape learned about horse racing from his father, who taught him to read the Daily Racing Form as a child.

headline: Sex Abuse and China's Children
text: BEIJING — When I was 13, living in the outskirts of Nanjing, China, in the ’70s, my math teacher molested all the girls in our class, including me. Under the pretense of checking my work, he would lean over me, his face so close that I could smell his garlic breath, and he’d move his hand up my shirt, touching my chest.

headline: Britain Bars Former UBS Senior Trader From Financial Industry
text: LONDON – Britain’s Financial Conduct Authority on Thursday barred John Christopher Hughes, a former senior trader at UBS, from working in the financial industry, but did not fine him for failing to report a slush fund of money used to help manage his desk’s daily profit and losses.

headline: Snapchat Goes After Mobile Messaging With a New Design
text: The last few years have been a roller coaster for Snapchat, the ephemeral photo-messaging service. Since it started in 2011, the company has made headlines for turning down billions from potential buyers and luring heavyweight talent from Facebook, Google and Amazon, facing criticism over gaping security vulnerabilities, and finding itself in a legal battle over ownership of the company’s original concept.

headline: The Dresses of Charles James
text: A forthcoming show at the Met’s new Anna Wintour Costume Center analyzes James’s sculptural designs.

headline: No Choice but to Protest and Take Pictures
text: A retrospective of Ben Fernandez’s images of the 1960s reveals a man who not only documented protests, but also educated a generation to follow his lead.

headline: A Stroll Through Kips Bay
text: Finally, the Kips Bay show house gets the showplace it deserves.

headline: In Korea, Grieving Over Hundreds of Young Lives
text: Ansan has been suffocating in grief since a ferry disaster left 250 students dead.

headline: Derby Day
text: For the 140th straight year, Churchill Downs in Louisville will stage the Kentucky Derby, where the first Saturday in May retains a timeless feel.

text: 1914: British Resorts Advocated

headline: Lazard’s Earnings More Than Double on Jump in M.&A. Activity
text: The strong burst of deal-making this year has been good to Lazard.

headline: Hey, Evildoers, Here’s Webbing in Your Eye
text: The last time Spider-Man swung into sight, it was to fight a lizard man in a lab coat and cozy up to a living doll. The lizard landed in the clink, but the doll, Gwen Stacy, is back for the good of Spider-Man (Andrew Garfield) and the franchise. As played by Emma Stone, who has the zing of a screwball heroine and the depthless eyes of an anime character, Gwen brightens “The Amazing Spider-Man 2,” a sequel that, until a late, lamentably foolish turn, balances blockbuster bombast with human-scale drama, child-friendly comedy and gushers of tears.

headline: A Dinner Among Survivors of the Financial Crisis
text: Call it the financial crisis survivors’ club.

headline: Awaiting Alibaba’s I.P.O.
text: The Alibaba Group, the Chinese Internet giant that is about to go public in the United States, is said to be in talks with its Alipay payment affiliate about regaining a stake in the business, Michael J. de la Merced writes in DealBook. The two sides have been in talks for nearly a year and a half, and no agreement is imminent. In any case, the possibility that Alibaba could be formally reunited with its payment division would be of great interest to the company’s future shareholders.

headline: A Royal Rejection
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Pentagon Study Finds 50% Increase in Reports of Military Sexual Assaults
text: WASHINGTON — A Pentagon study released Thursday showed a sharp increase last year in reports of rapes and sexual assault — they were up by 50 percent — but the study immediately came under fire for what critics said were significant limitations.

headline: In Golf Digest’s Bid for Younger Readers, It’s Less Faldo, More Fallon
text: Golf Digest was founded in 1950 and soon became an authoritative voice of the game, swept along by Americans’ migration to suburbia and the popularity of transformative golf figures from Arnold Palmer to Tiger Woods. The magazine flourished, as golf did, on the backs of a devoted cluster of baby boomers.

headline: Listen Up | Winsome Rock Hits Wisconsin
text: In the sleepy college town of Eau Claire, Wis., a folk hero has emerged in Justin Vernon (above center) — the bearded, pleasantly helium-voiced singer-songwriter who, in 2007, retreated to a cabin in the woods to record songs under the name Bon Iver. The resulting album, “For Emma, Forever Ago,” earned Vernon widespread acclaim, but instead of taking his newfound fame elsewhere, he set up April Base Studios, which has served as an incubator for the state’s emerging indie music scene. That includes Bon Iver’s drummer, S. Carey (above left), whose gorgeous sophomore album, “Range of Light,” was released last month; the Milwaukee-based folk outfit Field Report, led by the singer-songwriter Chris Porterfield (above right); and Phox, a six-piece indie pop group from Baraboo, Wis., whose self-titled debut is out next month. Despite a growing profile and their home state’s reputation as a harbinger of hipster culture (see: Pabst Blue Ribbon, artisanal cheese, taxidermy), the musicians insist that what makes them distinctly Wisconsin is their obliviousness to being cool. “A lot of us were in the marching band,” Phox frontwoman Monica Martin says. “It’s sort of a rite of passage.”

headline: Explosion at Florida Jail Kills 2 Inmates
text: PENSACOLA, Fla., — One day after nearly two feet of rain swamped Pensacola in the Florida Panhandle, causing severe flooding, a gas explosion ripped through a local jail late Wednesday night, killing two inmates and injuring about 150 inmates and corrections officers.

headline: Editorial Contest Winner | Short-Changing Canada’s Veterans
text: We are honoring the Top 10 winners of our Student Editorial Contest by publishing an essay each day.

headline: A Complete U-Turn
text: DEARBORN, Mich. — One of the first questions asked of Alan R. Mulally when he joined Ford Motor as its new chief executive in 2006 was what kind of car he drove.

headline: Washington, D.C., the Most-est Place in the Country
text: The nation’s capital: It’s the richest, gayest, most educated, most expensive and most economically optimistic place in America.

headline: How to Make New York Cheaper for Travelers
text: Search for a room in New York City on Hotels.com and most of the top results will be for rooms that cost more than $300 a night. Go over to Airbnb.com, and you will find many options under $200 a night and some in Queens and Brooklyn for less than $100.

headline: Diane Keaton: By the Book
text: The actress and author of “Let’s Just Say It Wasn’t Pretty” describes listening to Patti Smith’s audiobook of “Just Kids” as “a revelation” — “What is it about her voice? The way she uses her words and makes them sing?”

headline: Loved the Book. Felt the Character.
text: LAS VEGAS — Back in 1999, Shailene Woodley and her mother, Lori, could be found in a tiny dressing room trailer on the set of “Replacing Dad,” the television movie in which Ms. Woodley had her first speaking role. If the pair were hoping to pass themselves off as anything but novices, they failed miserably, especially when it came to availing themselves of the lunch provided by the production.

headline: One Woman’s Wish List Against Street Harassment
text: Sometimes Valerie Granzo ignores the comments about her appearance that strangers yell to her on the streets of New York City. Sometimes she yells back.

headline: Eight Tips for Parents Who Have Saved Nothing for College
text: A couple of days ago, a post here by a mother in Maine lamenting her lack of savings for her son’s college education inspired an outpouring of comments. A number of people questioned her and her husband’s decision to raise six children. Others thought she might have been better off putting money aside years ago instead of paying for music lessons and sports.

headline: ECO 348, The Great Recession: Links to Slides
text: Wrapped up the class yesterday. Here, in one place, are links to the lecture slides (all pdfs). If you’re wondering about lecture 3, it was snowed out, and the material folded into other classes.

headline: Florida Advances Tuition Aid for Children Brought to U.S. Illegally
text: MIAMI — After weeks of hand-wringing in the State Legislature and last-minute attempts by Senate leaders to scuttle the effort, the Florida Senate on Thursday voted to make students who were brought to the United States illegally as children eligible for in-state college tuition, an issue dominated by political calculations at least as much as policy ones.

headline: Mark Josephson of Bitly, on Leading With a Compass
text: This interview with Mark Josephson, chief executive of Bitly, the web link shortening service, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Coffee Tied to Lower Diabetes Risk
text: Drinking more coffee may decrease your risk of Type 2 diabetes, while cutting down may increase your risk, a new study has found.

headline: Television Revenue Helps Profit at Viacom to Rise 4%
text: Viacom, the media powerhouse that includes the movie studio Paramount and cable television channels like MTV, Comedy Central and Nickelodeon, generated $502 million in profit for its latest fiscal quarter, driven by increased advertising and higher affiliate fees for its television outlets, the company reported on Thursday.

headline: Art Matters | A Decommissioned Catholic Church in Berlin is Reborn as a Hub of Creativity
text: To the 32-year-old German gallerist Johann König, art is religion. His father, Kasper, is one of the most respected curators in Europe; his mother, Ilke, and uncle, Walter, are leaders in art-book publishing and his older half-brother, Leo, is a noted Manhattan art dealer. And so, when several years ago, the architect Arno Brandlhuber approached König with the idea of leasing a decommissioned Catholic church called St. Agnes — a striking example of Brutalist architecture in the Berlin neighborhood of Kreuzberg — König signed a nearly century-long lease, despite the fact that the building (which included a nursery school, offices and a courtyard along with the church itself) was too big for his gallery alone.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘Sweeping the States’
text: This week’s Poetry Pairing features “Sweeping the States” by Jacob Saenz and the article “Drought Takes Its Toll on a Texas Business and a Town” by Manny Fernandez.

headline: Who’s Frequenting the Tattoo Parlor
text: The United States Army has changed its rules and now restricts tattoos above the neckline and below the elbows and knees. Luckily for many members of the military, tattoos in these visible places are grandfathered in. Current and former members of the military are among the most tattooed members of American society, with 36 percent having at least one, according to a recent Fox News poll. That tattoo rate exceeds the rate for liberals (26 percent), conservatives (18 percent) and nonveterans (18 percent).

headline: S&P Capital IQ Report
text: A report from S&P Capital IQ projects that by 2020, about 90 percent of American workers who now receive health insurance through their employers will be shifted to government exchanges.

headline: Spring Has Sprung
text: TIMES INSIDER — Welcome to the May 2014 Times Premier Puzzle Pack. This month, we’re celebrating the arrival of spring.

headline: Can You Afford Your Medicine? Doctors Don’t Ask
text: From the doorway, my patient looked pregnant — but his protuberant belly was actually a sign of serious liver disease that had quickly worsened. Given the fluid pressing on his abdomen, he was no doubt in pain. Yet his spirits were high, and raucous laughter often accompanied his nearly toothless smile.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘Belle’
text: The director Amma Asante narrates a sequence from her film.

headline: 17-Minute Delay Found in Reporting Missing Plane
text: HONG KONG — Seventeen minutes passed after Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 disappeared from civilian radar screens before air traffic controllers in Vietnam and Malaysia raised any concerns about it, according to a Malaysian government report released on Thursday that described confusion and miscommunication in the hours that followed.

headline: South Sudan May Receive Peacekeepers From Africa
text: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia — With violence escalating in South Sudan, Secretary of State John Kerry said Thursday that African troops could soon be sent to the strife-ridden country to augment the United Nations peacekeeping effort.

headline: Lonely Writers in the Movies
text: In this week’s Bookends, Thomas Mallon and Dana Stevens discuss why it’s so difficult to capture a writer’s life on film. If the movies have a hard time with the act of writing, they do better with the stark isolation the craft can demand.

headline: Cadillac Recalls 51,000 SRX Crossovers for Acceleration Problem
text: General Motors is recalling almost 51,000 Cadillac SRX crossovers from the 2013 model year because the powertrain might balk when the driver wants to accelerate, the automaker informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration in a report posted Thursday on the agency’s website.

headline: Connecticut Allows Medical Marijuana, but Sellers Encounter Hurdles
text: BRIDGEPORT, Conn. — This state’s law approving the sale of marijuana for medical purposes has been on the books for two years, but the drug is still not available.

headline: Chvrches and Titus Andronicus Among Highlights of Northside Festival
text: The Northside Festival, a Brooklyn showcase devoted mostly to indie bands – but with films and panels on innovation and a trade show as well – has quickly become a northeastern version of South by Southwest. Northside’s founders, Scott and Daniel Stedman, have described its mission simply as “to showcase what’s next,” and this year, the festival’s sixth, that will include performances by 400 bands, along with 50 films and 100 speakers in its Northside Innovation series. The festival runs from June 12 to 19.

headline: May Day Protests in Turkey
text: In Istanbul, the police fired tear gas and used water cannons to disperse May Day protesters, some of whom fired back their own tear gas canisters.

headline: Dennis Kamakahi, 61, Hawaiian Guitarist and Composer, Dies
text: Dennis Kamakahi, a prolific Hawaiian songwriter, an influential slack-key guitarist and a central figure in the 1970s cultural movement known as the Hawaiian renaissance, died on April 28 in Honolulu. He was 61.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of ‘Belle’
text: In this video, the director Amma Asante narrates a sequence from her period film “Belle,” featuring Gugu Mbatha-Raw. The movie explores the life of Dido Elizabeth Belle, an 18th-century black woman raised in an aristocratic family who may have helped influence the British debate over ending slavery.

headline: Disney Keeps Focus on ‘Star Wars’ With a New Line of Apps
text: LOS ANGELES — Disney’s steady trickle of “Star Wars” announcements continued on Thursday as the company and its Lucasfilm unit unveiled a line of at least six apps aimed at helping younger moviegoers catch up with the story line ahead of the 2015 release of “Star Wars: Episode VII.”

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 42
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Teacher Accord Gives City a Map for Other Deals
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio, confronting the unsettled labor agreements that have loomed over his first months in office, announced a deal on Thursday with New York City’s largest teachers’ union that would raise wages by 18 percent over nine years in exchange for a $1.3 billion reduction in health care costs.

headline: California Fines Ford $3 Million Over Defective Pollution Control Equipment
text: Ford is being fined $2.96 million because the pollution control system on 2011-12 Fiestas sold in California are not working properly, the state’s Air Resources Board said late Wednesday.

headline: On Beauty | Talking Blues
text: Favored by 4-year-olds, misfits and drag queens, wearing cobalt eye shadow means forsaking good taste for a welcome jolt of indiscretion.

headline: Today in Small Business: $100 Billion in Lending
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Thursday released the names of 55 colleges and universities under investigation for their handling of sexual assault complaints, an unusual step meant to increase pressure on the institutions to crack down on the problem on their campuses.

headline: Acting Like an Ape
text: Actors from “Dawn of the Planet of the Apes” receive ape-like movement training near the film set in New Orleans.

headline: Exxon Mobil Profit Falls for a Fourth Straight Quarter
text: HOUSTON — For the fourth quarter in a row, Exxon Mobil on Thursday reported lower year-over-year profit because of falling production volumes and disappointing earnings from its international refining and chemicals businesses.

headline: A New Way to Stir Up Benghazi Anger
text: A member of Congress plans to introduce a measure that would at long last amend the Authorization for the Use of Military Force, passed after the 9/11 attacks and warped over time to excuse all manner of executive overreach, including electronic surveillance without a warrant.

headline: K.K.R. Seeks to Attract Investments as Small as $10,000
text: Updated, 8:00 p.m. | Only the wealthiest and most sophisticated investors are allowed to put money into the leveraged buyouts done by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts. But that may be changing.

headline: Auditing Ape School
text: We started with the breathing: low, deep, yogalike. Our eyes closed, our bellies unflexed.

headline: The Posture, the Gestures, the Thoughts
text: NEW ORLEANS — The actress Judy Greer was trying to find her animal self. She stood in an awkward crouch, pelvis pitched forward, arms aloft. “No desire to be tall at all,” Terry Notary, a stocky former gymnast, instructed her. “Your power comes from rooting yourself down.”

headline: Image of the Day: May 1
text: Two small explosions tore through an express train at the busy Chennai Central railway station in Tamil Nadu, killing a woman and injuring several others.

headline: A Mother on Her Deathbed, Tape On
text: When Monique Sindler was dying in her bed in Paris in 2006, Sophie Calle, her daughter and the renowned French conceptual artist, set up a video camera and began taping. The artist, 60, has explained that her reason for the camera was that she didn’t want to be out of the room when the moment of death came. She wanted to hear her mother’s last word and see her last breath, but she had heard that the dying often wait until nobody is around to let go.

headline: Being Careful Out There? Hardly
text: Cop shows had never looked like this.

headline: Lawrence Lessig Starts a Super PAC
text: Lawrence Lessig, a Harvard law school professor who has long opposed “big money” in politics, wants to start a super PAC “to end all super PACs.”

headline: N.A.A.C.P. Scrutinizes Branch Over Honor for Clippers Owner
text: When the racist words of the Los Angeles Clippers owner Donald Sterling spilled out in a recording last week, the incident not only caused the N.B.A. to ban Mr. Sterling for life, it also drew attention to the N.A.A.C.P.’s small Los Angeles branch, which had been planning to honor him with a lifetime achievement award this month.

headline: Kids Need More Structured Playtime, Not Less
text: The cover story of last month’s Atlantic magazine struck a nerve with many parents. Written by Hanna Rosin, an Atlantic national correspondent, and titled, “The Overprotected Kid,” it describes a generation of children who have experienced hardly an unsupervised or unstructured moment in their lives. Looking for an alternative to America’s risk-averse culture of child rearing, the author takes her 5-year-old son, Gabriel, on a trip to North Wales, where an “adventure playground” called the Land opened two years ago.

headline: The Artistry of Plants and Pots
text: Mutant cacti in pots with unconventional, often imperfect, glazes. Sounds strange? Strangely beautiful is more like it. “A Tale of Plant & Pot” — an exhibition on view at the Venice, Calif., design shop Chariots on Fire — pairs the plant artistry of Kohei Oda with the ceramics of Adam Silverman. The 36-year-old Oda owns Qusamura, an award-winning plant shop in Hiroshima, Japan, and he’s like a rock star in the horticulture world. His specialty is the grafted cactus, the art and science of connecting two pieces of living plant tissue together to grow as one composite plant. He is drawn to, as he says, “plants with personality,” and using grafting techniques to salvage damaged plants and to create new, and often unexpected, forms.

headline: Audio From Malaysian Flight 370
text: Audio recording of the conversations between the cockpit of Flight 370 and Kuala Lumpur air traffic control.

headline: U.S. Will Host Expanded Copa América in 2016
text: The Copa América, South America’s soccer championship, will play its centennial tournament in the United States in 2016 and include six teams from North America, Central America and the Caribbean, officials from those two regional confederations announced Thursday.

headline: Suicide Attack Kills 12 in Afghanistan’s Panjshir Valley
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A suicide car bombing killed at least 12 people, including at least five security force members, in Panjshir Province on Thursday, in an attack that struck at the symbolic heart of resistance to the Taliban’s rule and the Soviet occupation.

headline: Searching for Yield, at Almost Any Price
text: When buyers demand something, the supply will be created.

headline: Sinn Fein Braces for Fallout After Arrest
text: DUBLIN — When Gerry Adams became president of Sinn Fein more than three decades ago, the party was regarded as an irrelevant apologist for Irish Republican Army atrocities. Now, it shares power in Northern Ireland’s Parliament, and in the Republic of Ireland it is riding high in the polls ahead of local and European elections this month.

headline: Nasty Rivalries Spice Playoffs’ Second Round
text: As in the first round, the conference semifinals of the N.H.L. playoffs feature intense rivalries, some with long postseason histories and some starting fresh.

headline: Theories on Why Housing Is Stalled
text: Last week, we explored the fact that housing remains one of the major weak spots in the economy, with building activity far below its longer-term averages. Economic commentators around the Web had a range of reactions; here are some of the more interesting ones and a few thoughts on the critiques of our article.

headline: A Late Rush to Sign Up for Insurance
text: WASHINGTON — The number of people signing up for health insurance through the federal marketplace soared in March, exceeding the number who signed up in the previous five months, the Obama administration said Thursday in its final report on enrollment under the new health care law.

headline: In Paris, Showcasing Films About Dance
text: Cinephiles passing through Paris often have the Cinémathèque Française on their list of “musts.”

headline: Thriving on a Dash of Audacity
text: On a warm night, the door to Dotory is propped open under the J, M and Z tracks, and cold glasses of barley tea, tasting like toasted water, are handed round. There is soju, too, steeped with dill and cucumber, cleaner than vodka and deadly, poured into cups so small that the mildest of gestures sends them flying. Jazz piano rustles from the speakers, and then the train crashes by and we all quake awhile.

headline: Tributes and Mourning on Social Media as an Egyptian Voice Goes Silent
text: Last Updated, 6:51 p.m. | In the time he spent chronicling events in Egypt since the 2011 uprising, Bassem Sabry gained a reputation as a prescient and astute commentator on the transformation and turmoil of his country’s political scene.

headline: California Analysis Pours Cold Water on Expanded TV and Film Subsidies
text: LOS ANGELES — The California legislative analyst’s office on Wednesday offered what it called “preliminary observations” on the push for expanded film and television subsidies in the state — and its that initial advice was to proceed with a great deal of caution.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
text: In the news: walking’s benefits, nail salon risks and a new vaccine. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Art Matters | A Powerhouse L.A. Gallery Heads East
text: While it seems like a foregone conclusion that many of New York’s most successful contemporary art galleries will join the ranks of those that maintain outposts in Los Angeles — like Gagosian (whose empire began in L.A. in 1979) and Matthew Marks (whose West Hollywood space opened in 2012) — perhaps it comes as a surprise that a bit of reverse migration is now also taking place, with some of best of the west heading east. Today Blum & Poe, one of L.A.’s top art galleries — it anchors the strip that snakes along La Cienega Boulevard through Culver City — opens its new exhibition space in a renovated townhouse at 19 East 66th Street, off Fifth Avenue.

headline: Do Statins Change Our Eating Habits?
text: Are statins giving people license to eat? A 12-year study has found that people who use statins gradually increase their consumption of fat and calories.

text: Update | Sept. 2: This contest has ended, but you can find all of this summer’s winners here

headline: The Gun Report: May 1, 2014
text: Is trespassing a capital offense? No, the German government says, and it wants justice for one of its citizens, who was shot and killed in Montana on Sunday.

headline: Baseball Shakes Up Its Investigative Unit
text: In the wake of the Alex Rodriguez doping case, which drew accusations of unethical behavior by Major League Baseball’s top investigators, the league has fired some members of its investigative team and moved to restructure the unit.

headline: A Timely Call for Bike Trails
text: The Times is converting all of its 1964 issues into a digitized, searchable format. Each week, The Upshot will unearth an item from 50 years ago and put it in the light of today. “Udall Urges More Bicycle Paths” appeared on page 29 on May 2 and can be seen in its original format on TimesMachine.

headline: Queens New Music Festival to Offer Eclectic Works
text: Move over Brooklyn, Queens is staking its claim for new-music street cred. Random Access Music, a composers’ collective founded in 2006, is presenting eight concerts of new and recent works in three days this month, under the banner of the Queens New Music Festival at the Secret Theater in Long Island City.

headline: Pfizer Looks for a Quick Strike on AstraZeneca
text: Time often benefits bidders rather than targets — that’s why Kraft left its British rival Cadbury flailing for months after making a takeover approach. But the dynamics of Pfizer’s interest in AstraZeneca are unusual. Pfizer has good reason to seek a quick negotiated deal.

headline: Nan Rosenthal, Curator Who Championed Modern Art, Dies at 76
text: Nan Rosenthal, a curator who helped bring the 20th century to the National Gallery of Art in Washington and the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 76.

headline: 36 Hours in Zanzibar, Tanzania
text: The name Zanzibar conjures up visions of sultans’ palaces, paradisiacal beaches and winding alleyways leading to spice-filled bazaars. Indeed, this coral archipelago in the Indian Ocean, 23 miles off the eastern coast of Tanzania, still has many of the features that it did when it was an important trading center and its historic Stone Town served as the capital of an Omani sultanate. Zanzibar’s largest island, Unguja, is home to most of the cultural attractions, many of them found in beguiling Stone Town, which was awarded Unesco World Heritage status in 2000. In recent years, there’s been a concerted effort to restore and give new life to the city’s distinctive structures. Palaces have been turned into museums and cultural centers, and grand Swahili mansions have been reborn as restaurants and boutique hotels. Yet the coast still offers the “delicious view” that the explorer Sir Richard Burton recorded, of a “cocoa-fringed shore of purest white, and the sea blue as a slab of lapis lazuli.” (Note: Prices in Zanzibar are routinely quoted in dollars — alongside, or occasionally instead of, the island’s official currency, the Tanzanian shilling.)

headline: Walking Tours in the Spirit of Jane Jacobs
text: Jane Jacobs’s 1961 book, “The Death and Life of Great American Cities,” a sweeping critique of the modern metropolis, was both a best seller and quite contentious. What set Jacobs apart from many of her critics, including her archnemesis Robert Moses, was that as lofty as her ideas and prose could be, they sprang from, and remained rooted in, the street. So it’s easy to imagine her feeling honored to have inspired Jane’s Walk, an annual series of free guided walking tours across all five boroughs, organized by the Municipal Art Society of New York.

headline: Hangups of the Heterodox (Vaguely Wonkish)
text: Thomas Palley and Simon Wren-Lewis have been having a back and forth over heterodox economics versus garden-variety saltwater economics, and their role in making sense of the economic crisis. Palley accuses Wren-Lewis and me of “flimflam”; Wren-Lewis wonders what he’s talking about.

headline: Yankees’ Attendance and Ratings Rebound, but the Mets’ Are Mixed
text: The Yankees, built on winning and the star system, are benefiting from the return of Derek Jeter and the addition of Masahiro Tanaka and Jacoby Ellsbury.

headline: Eurocentric Beauty Ideals in the Military
text: People of African descent have been tyrannized for centuries by a Eurocentric aesthetic that deems light skin and straight hair beautiful and that casts dark skin, African features and kinky hair as undesirable, if not ugly. This bias is less potent than it was, say, 50 years ago. (Movies, advertisements and prime-time television clearly show that.) But it still weighs heavily in judgments about what is beautiful  and what is not; it also limits the opportunities of people whose appearances place them far from the Eurocentric ideal.

headline: Wheelies: The Police Truck Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Revisiting Familial Territory
text: The past seems to haunt the writer-director Diane Kurys — and to tempt her to reimagine events, testing out versions of her parents and stretching their emotional contours by placing them in different dramatic situations.

headline: Unto the Next Generation, Cinematically
text: By most counts, Gia Coppola — whose first film, “Palo Alto,” opens May 9 — is the fourth generation in her famous Hollywood family to enter the world of film.

headline: The Mysterious Adventure of the Good Night’s Sleep
text: The protagonist of “Altered States of Plaine” suffers from an affliction that causes him to teleport to unexpected places. The condition also apparently affects the movie, which has somehow appeared in a commercial theater, despite betraying few signs of visual, aural or narrative control.

headline: From Childhood to a Soccer Career, Much Has Stayed the Same
text: I often write about change — the constant fluctuations in my thought process and reinvention of myself as a person and a soccer player. My environment and situation are constantly in flux. This year in the National Women’s Soccer League is no different.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Ukraine, Turkey, Cuba and Italy.

headline: Donald Sterling and the Inequality Debate
text: Turning from the controversies of Roman Catholicism back to the ongoing inequality conversation, I highly recommend this post from Reihan Salam on Donald Sterling, the disgraced owner of the Los Angeles Clippers, and the interesting ways that Sterling’s career as a Southern Californian slumlord is entangled both with the phenomenon of “petits rentiers” (Thomas Piketty’s term for the capital-accumulating mass upper class) and with America’s ongoing debates (which Piketty’s “Capital” seems to have gotten a bit wrong) over whether and how high to raise the minimum wage.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Ukraine, Turkey, Cuba and Italy.

headline: The Best Way to Organize Bookshelves?
text: In the magazine’s most recent Riff, Mireille Silcoff notes that although e-books are outselling their physical counterparts on Amazon, the latter still remain objects of desire for the average consumer — just not for the reasons you might think.

headline: F. Scott Fitzgerald, Uncut, in a New Edition of Short Stories
text: When “Taps at Reveille” was published in 1935, it marked the end of F. Scott Fitzgerald’s career as a short-story writer. It was his fourth collection and his last. Now, it turns out, a lot of the words were missing, excised by editors at The Saturday Evening Post, where all 18 stories in the collection first appeared.

headline: A Life Story of Glitter and Tragedy
text: If Jobriath, a would-be star of glam-rock during the genre’s 1970s heyday, is recalled at all, it’s because of his monster billboard, which loomed over Times Square despite a debut album that failed to sell.

headline: Call for Limits on Web Data of Customers
text: WASHINGTON — The White House, hoping to move the national debate over privacy beyond the National Security Agency’s surveillance activities to the practices of companies like Google and Facebook, released a long-anticipated report on Thursday that recommends developing government limits on how private companies make use of the torrent of information they gather from their customers online.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: Power Outage
text: Is there a company on earth that has been more thoroughly examined at ponderous length than Apple? There are books about its early years, books about Steve Jobs’s ouster from the company in 1985, and books about his triumphant return in 1997. Recently there was a book dissecting Apple’s internal culture; another profiling its design wiz, Jonathan Ive; and a third charting Apple’s tempestuous relationship with Google. All these volumes now orbit around Walter Isaacson’s “Steve Jobs,” the definitive chronicle, considering the imperious co-founder himself opened the door to his secretive empire as he battled pancreatic cancer.

headline: American Architect
text: Lynne Cheney, a historian and the wife of former Vice President Dick Cheney, believes it is time to “clear away misconceptions” about the founder and fourth president, James Madison; to “brush off cobwebs that have accumulated around his achievements” and recover his “fine reputation,” which somehow has gotten lost over the past two centuries. “He is popularly regarded today — when remembered at all — less as a bold thinker and superb politician than as a shy and sickly scholar, someone hardly suited for the demands of daily life, much less the rough-and-tumble world of politicking.”

headline: History’s Stranglehold
text: On June 5, 1978, the Congolese dictator Joseph-Désiré Mobutu stood on a hot grassy bluff in the south of his vast country — then named Zaire — and watched as the engines on a space rocket ignited. “Slowly, the rocket rose from the launching pad. A hundred kilometers into the atmosphere, that’s where it was headed, a new step forward in African space travel.” After a few moments, though, “the rocket listed, cut a neat arc to the left and landed a few hundred meters away, in the valley of the Luvua, where it exploded.” For David Van Reybrouck the rocket represents Mobutu’s regime: “A parabola of soot. . . . After the steep rise of the first years, his Zaire toppled inexorably and plunged straight into the abyss.”

headline: Donors Weigh Jilting Christie for Jeb Bush
text: Jeb Bush’s increasingly serious and public examination of a run for president has shaken the ranks of establishment Republican donors and fund-raisers who had planned to back Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey in 2016, forcing many of them to rethink their allegiance to the embattled governor.

headline: Whitney Edits a Tale of a Nation
text: A year away from opening, the new home of the Whitney Museum of American Art is still a construction site, but it is already a vivid presence in Manhattan’s meatpacking district, and curators have mapped out months’ worth of exhibitions there.

headline: Seth MacFarlane and Charlize Theron on ‘A Million Ways to Die in the West’
text: Q. Were you surprised, Charlize, at how easily you fit into the world of this film that Seth directed, co-wrote and co-starred in?

text: To the Editor:

headline: Voter Fraud: a) Real. b) Imagined. c) Insufficient Data.
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Investigation of the Horrific Oklahoma Execution Will Not Be ‘Independent’
text: Did anyone really believe that Gov. Mary Fallin of Oklahoma would allow a truly independent review of the “execution” —  death by torture is more like it — that shocked the conscience of the nation and the world on Tuesday night?

headline: Tower on the Palisades
text: To the Editor:

headline: Philadelphia School Cuts
text: To the Editor:

headline: Maritime Treasures Surface at Museums
text: Antiques from New York’s vanished coastal workplaces are coming to light in museum and gallery displays in the next few months. Pier A at Battery Park City, the 1880s Lower Manhattan building that once housed the city’s harbor police, is being turned into bars, restaurant spaces and a visitors’ center, with period steamship gauges and other nautical memorabilia incorporated into the décor.

headline: Seth Rogen and Rose Byrne on ‘Neighbors’
text: Q. When did you two first meet?

headline: EBay Settles No-Poaching Antitrust Case
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The auction site eBay has settled a federal antitrust case that accused it of having a secret deal with Intuit not to try to hire each other’s employees.

headline: Former Auteur in Love With Outrage
text: In 1998 the German artist Christoph Schlingensief organized the Last Chance Party, a deliberately absurdist mix of art and politics that encouraged ordinary people to nominate themselves as candidates for the coming parliamentary elections.

headline: Melissa McCarthy and Ben Falcone on ‘Tammy’
text: Q. Did meeting each other in a professional setting forever determine your relationship?

headline: Old Paint and Built-In Sticker Shock
text: Ask Real Estate is a weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: Secret Power of Synonyms
text: Words have been the subjects and primary constituents of the enigmatic yet acerbically provocative paintings Mel Bochner has been creating over the past 12 years. “Mel Bochner: Strong Language,” an elegantly produced exhibition at the Jewish Museum, gives them their due and traces their roots back to text-based works that Mr. Bochner created in the ’60s and early ’70s, when he was one of New York’s pre-eminent Conceptual artists.

headline: Split Day in Court, as Defendant and Counsel
text: As often occurs in busy courthouses, lawyers appear repeatedly on the same day, before different judges, in different courtrooms.

headline: Yin and Yang, Now Breathing as One
text: The singer-songwriter Sufjan Stevens thought he disliked ballet until the New York City Ballet dancer Justin Peck asked him for permission to choreograph a piece to his electronic song cycle, “Enjoy Your Rabbit.” The ballet, “Year of the Rabbit,” was a raging success in 2012, and Mr. Stevens — famous for his folk-inspired melodies, haunting narratives and eccentric large-scale projects — became a convert.

headline: Cameron Diaz and Jason Segel on ‘Sex Tape’
text: Q. This is the second comedy you’ve made together, after “Bad Teacher.” Are you more comfortable working with each other now?

headline: Meagan Good and Romany Malco on ‘Think Like a Man Too’
text: Q. Before playing Zeke and Mya in the “Think Like a Man” movies, you were paired up in “The Love Guru.” What were those earliest encounters like?

headline: A Shoulder for Buildings to Lean On
text: Hudson Yards, the 26-acre urban hub rising from obscurity on the Far West Side, some of it on a customized platform deftly suspended above an unlovely rail yard, is the genesis of a vibrant neighborhood and skyline where now there is none. As is usual in her line of work, the input of the structural engineer Aine M. Brazil won’t be visible once the finished product is. She’s the quintessential behind-the-scenes player.

headline: Ford Names New Chief Executive Officer
text: Ford Motor Company announced that Alan R. Mulally, the president and chief executive officer, will retire July 1 and be replaced by the chief operating officer, Mark Fields.

headline: This Weekend: ‘Deadly’ and Funny Musical
text: “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder,” which just received 10 Tony nominations, is still on Broadway; a rooftop exhibition at the Met is now open; and celebrities are still cheating on one another.

text: Kai Matsumiya

text: Callicoon Fine Arts

text: Petzel

headline: Low-Down-Payment Loans
text: Loans insured by the Federal Housing Administration offer first-time home buyers the advantage of a down payment as low as 3.5 percent. But rising premiums for the required mortgage insurance have made the loans prohibitively expensive.

text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Archie Isn’t Dead. He’s Free. (For One Day.)
text: COMIC book characters are now a staple of prime-time television and blockbuster films. But Free Comic Book Day, an annual effort to promote the comic-book industry that began in 2002, shifts the focus back to the printed page and the stores that sell them.

headline: An Innocent Awakened
text: Though it takes place in Poland in 1962 — a weary, disenchanted country grinding along under gray, post-Stalinist skies — Pawel Pawlikowski’s “Ida” has some of the structure and feeling of an ancient folk tale. It concerns an orphan who must make her way through a haunted, threatening landscape, protected only by her own good sense and a powerful, not entirely trustworthy companion.

headline: Jazz Listings for May 2-8
text: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.
