text: In the Video

headline: Where the Password Is Deco
text: NIGHT and day, New York reveals itself as the Art Deco capital of the world. I don’t mean just the obvious treasures — the Chrysler Building, Radio City Music Hall, Rockefeller Center — but the Deco surprises that decorate just about every other block.

headline: If These Walls Could Speak, They’d Say Her Name
text: HOW many worshipers, at the 1920s Temple Emanu-El in Manhattan, or St. Bartholomew’s Church, the Episcopal bastion nearby, realize — if they notice them at all — that the intricate mosaic ornamentations in these contrasting houses of faith were produced by a singular vision? The same sensibility distinguishes an altar in St. Patrick’s Cathedral, and the glistening red mosaic walls at One Wall Street, which turn to orange the higher they go. If audiences dashing to Radio City Music Hall tilted their heads back, they would suddenly be struck by brightly colored figurative roundels on the 50th Street facade. From one coast to the other are many more instances of the same artist’s remarkable decorative work, forgotten in plain sight.

headline: When Ghosts Have Hobbies
text: The premise of Howard Norman’s new novel is eerie enough to make the skin crawl. “Next Life Might Be Kinder” is narrated by a blocked, troubled writer named Sam Lattimore, who delivers an opening sentence worthy of the Noir Hall of Fame.

headline: Opera & Classical Music Listings for May 2-8
text: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: To the Manner Born?
text: No bodices seem to have been harmed, much less ripped, during the making of “Belle,” a period film at once sweeping and intimate, about an 18th-century Englishwoman who transcends her historical moment. Even so, peekaboo bosoms tremble throughout the movie amid the rustle of luxurious gowns and the gasps of polite company as conventions are crushed underfoot. Melodramatic and grounded in history, “Belle” is enough of an old-fashioned entertainment that it could have been made in classic Hollywood. Well, except for one little thing that would have probably given old studio suits apoplexy: The movie’s prettily flouncing title character is biracial.

headline: Netanyahu Plans to Promote Legislation on Jewish State Designation
text: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said on Thursday that he intended to promote legislation bolstering the status of Israel as the nation-state of the Jewish people, anchoring the principle as one of the basic laws that serve as the country’s Constitution.

headline: The Lord of Gondor, Taking Manhattan
text: For decades, John Noble told no one, not even his wife, of the career he dreamed of having when he was 20-something and unknown, living in his native South Australia.

headline: Attackers Use Microsoft Security Hole Against Energy, Defense, Finance Targets
text: SAN FRANCISCO — By the time Microsoft warned customers of a nasty security hole in its web browser Saturday, a sophisticated group of attackers were already using the vulnerability against defense and energy companies, according to FireEye, the security company.

headline: Dance Listings for May 2-8
text: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: A Group Show in TriBeCa Explores Black Identity Today
text: The curator Nicola Vassell has a blue-chip art-world pedigree as a former director at both Deitch Projects and Pace. And perhaps because her gallery work positioned her in contexts where glitz and glamour are currencies of their own, media coverage of Vassell has often focused on her taste and style — her former modeling career, her wardrobe, the social goings-on at her SoHo loft. But Vassell has lately gone independent — she left Pace in 2012 to found Concept NV, which she describes as an art ideation lab — and it’s clear she’s got more pressing social concerns on her mind. “Activism is important to me,” she says. “I find that sometimes the art world is too busy with its art-world view to consider that.” Her latest show, “Black Eye,” underscores the continuing need for increased diversity in a still narrow art world. The wide-ranging exhibition, which opens tomorrow night in TriBeCa, features paintings, photographs and collage by 26 emerging and established black artists, including Wangechi Mutu, Jacolby Satterwhite, Steve McQueen and Kerry James Marshall.

headline: Art Listings for May 2-8
text: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Out of Japan, Rising
text: Ranking the great Japanese filmmakers of the mid-20th century is an easy parlor game, made convenient by the long, prolific and amazingly consistent careers of the major contenders. The big three of the Japanese golden age are traditionally acknowledged to be Akira Kurosawa, Kenji Mizoguchi and Yasujiro Ozu, born within 12 years of one another around the turn of the 20th century.

headline: Bursting the Democrats’ Midterm-Turnout Bubble
text: The Democratic midterm turnout problem is no secret. Young and nonwhite voters tend to stay home in off-year elections, leaving the electorate older, whiter and more Republican than in a presidential election.

headline: The Future Is So Dark, Pack a Lamp
text: Geography is destiny. Even in the land of opportunity, the place you are born and brought up has a lot to do with determining your future. And if that place is Van Buren, Me., a dingy, fading agricultural town on the Canadian border, there is not much of a future to look forward to.

headline: This Week’s Movies: May 2, 2014
text: The New York Times film critics review “Ida,” “Belle” and “The Amazing Spider-Man 2.”

headline: Spare Times for Children for May 2-8
text: ‘FLUFF: A STORY OF LOST TOYS’

headline: On the Trail of a Gene That Kills
text: “Decoding Annie Parker,” Steven Bernstein’s useful, high-minded docudrama about breast cancer, is a gawky mixture of medical tutorial and personal history. Ms. Parker, played by Samantha Morton with an air of crumpled dolefulness that masks a core of ferocious determination, is a Canadian living in Toronto whose mother and sister succumb to breast cancer, which she eventually develops herself. It was the first of her three bouts with cancer, all of which she survived.

headline: Timeline Describes Frantic Scene at Oklahoma Execution
text: McALESTER, Okla. — Early on the morning of Clayton D. Lockett’s scheduled execution, he defied prison officers seeking to shackle him for the required walk to get X-rays. So they shocked him with a Taser, Oklahoma’s chief of corrections stated in an account released Thursday of Mr. Lockett’s final day, before his execution went awry.

headline: Spare Times for May 2-8
text: Wall to Wall Cabaret (Saturday) One of the largest assemblages of New York nightclub talent in recent memory will gather at Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, for this free eight-hour musical marathon. (Select premium seats are available for the afternoon and evening sessions for $100 each.)

headline: Game Legend Carmack at Center of Oculus Dispute
text: John Carmack is one of the most celebrated technical wizards in the video game business, known for pushing the boundaries of the medium with Quake, Doom and other pioneering games. Most recently, he took up virtual reality as a cause, seeing in it a way to make games more immersive than those played on computer and television screens.

headline: Curse of the Abominable Snow Mutants
text: For anyone who still associates Austrian cinema with Michael Haneke’s dour, stringent visions, “Blood Glacier,” from the Vienna-born filmmaker Marvin Kren, presents a rousing alternative, complete with giant flying insects. In Mr. Kren’s enjoyably committed and splattery creature feature, scientists and visitors at an Alpine weather station fend off mutant beasts that materialize after the discovery of a sprawling, rust-colored hunk of ice.

headline: Possible Flight Paths
text: The Malaysian government released a map Thursday showing several possible flight paths for the missing Malaysia Airlines Flight.

headline: Merck Said to Be Near Closing Deal With Bayer
text: Updated, 8:01 p.m. | Merck, the big health care company, is close to a deal to sell its consumer unit to Bayer for about $14 billion, a person briefed on the matter said on Thursday.

headline: Finding a Survivor, or Perhaps a Fraud
text: The flashier of the two stories in “Unclaimed,” Michael Jorgensen’s intensely moving documentary, is about a man claiming to be a long-missing Vietnam War veteran. Quietly shadowing this central identity quest, however, is a less attention-grabbing but perhaps even more compelling tale of how one man from a broken home finds peace and purpose in reconstructing the home of another.

headline: Capturing an Elusive Troubadour
text: According to the singer-songwriter Bill Callahan, performing in front of an audience is “the realest me that there is.” Taking him at his word, the director Hanly Banks makes his live shows the meat of “Apocalypse: A Bill Callahan Tour Film,” allowing her introspective subject to reveal as much, or as little, as he pleases.

headline: Sports, the Most Progressive Force in America
text: In the capital of the old Confederacy, Richmond, Va., on a boulevard of elegantly aged homes and muscle-limbed trees, stands a string of large statues honoring a nation that enshrined human bondage in its founding document. Generals and politicians, these heroes of the Civil War South are well known.

headline: Insert an Emoticon Here
text: Movies have struggled to make social media cinematic, but judging from “Friended to Death,” the revolution can wait. The feature debut of the director Sarah Smick, this bubble gum comedy gambles on a noxious protagonist — and fails to find much humor in him.

headline: Ares Management Set to Go Public, Joining Rivals
text: The biggest private equity firms were widely known to investors by the time they first sold their shares to the public.

headline: A Man and His Elephant, and Flying Fists
text: Again with the elephant?

headline: Love? These Couples Lust for Laughs
text: Whether it’s a volley of verbal repartee or a flurry of custard pies, the best comedy bits seem to require two people to pull them off: one person to give, and the other to give back just as good.

headline: Q & A: Jeffrey Wasserstrom on History, Dissent and the Power of May 4 in China
text: The political tumult that erupted in China in 1989 was a struggle over rival views of the country’s future, often fought through rival views of the past, and no date mattered more than May 4, an anniversary claimed by both the student protesters and the Communist Party.

headline: ‘Bridges of Madison County’ to Close on May 18
text: The new Broadway musical “The Bridges of Madison County” will close on May 18 after months of modest ticket sales and little help at the box office from the four Tony Award nominations for the show on Tuesday.

headline: Kevin Spacey and Company Hit the Road
text: The first image that appears in “NOW: In the Wings on a World Stage” is the “Spacey Presents” logo. That’s Kevin Spacey, the benefactor and, more or less, the focus of this entertaining documentary — entertaining for a select audience, which pretty much means fans of theater or Mr. Spacey, or both. I’m both. Your results may differ.

headline: A Penis With a Mind of Its Own
text: A man’s worst nightmare isn’t that an ex posts an Internet rant about him or that beer is found to cause impotence. It’s that his penis takes human form. Oh, the stories it could tell.

headline: A Vision of the Future From Those Likely to Invent It
text: In a series of interviews, seven people who are driving this transformation provided a glimpse into the not-too-distant future

headline: Broderick and Lane Heading Back to Broadway Together
text: Matthew Broderick and Nathan Lane, who made comic gold out of showbiz shenanigans in “The Producers,” will team up again in another stage-world comedy — an updated version of Terrence McNally’s “It’s Only a Play,” with Jack O’Brien directing.

headline: New York Through a Lens Instead of a Windshield
text: As we learn in “More Than the Rainbow,” Matt Weber has retired from driving a cab to devote himself to snapping pictures of New York’s streets. But this scattered, earthy documentary from Dan Wechsler, featuring Mr. Weber, along with a colorful gallery of fellow photographers and associates, has the ramble and scramble of a crosstown conversation with an opinionated driver.

headline: Looking for a Welcome in the American Melting Pot
text: After years of working as a reporter in the United States, Jose Antonio Vargas performed the journalistic equivalent of a scientific experiment on himself. He publicly revealed his status as an illegal immigrant through an article in The New York Times Magazine in 2011. In the film “Documented,” which is part get-out-the-message tour, part personal reckoning, Mr. Vargas argues on behalf of liberalizing immigration policy and confronts others — and himself — about his predicament.

headline: A Life in a String Quartet, and Beyond
text: Allan Miller wisely keeps the hagiography to a minimum in “Speak the Music,” his documentary about Robert Mann, the longtime violinist for the Juilliard String Quartet. Though colleagues and former students chime in, Mr. Miller lets Mr. Mann and his violin do most of the talking, drawing on assorted interviews and vintage performance clips that convey both the skill and the enthusiasm underpinning his subject’s long career.

headline: Healing Sought (Bring Your Own Magic)
text: At 42 I had never loved someone who loved me back. Recovering (still) from childhood sexual abuse by a neighbor, I couldn’t transcend romantic failure.

headline: A Melting Pot in the Sun
text: Is there any spot on earth with higher densities of flesh, noise, salt, fat and naked, hormonal humanity than Coney Island? Only in New York would people choose this as a place to unwind.

headline: Something Borrowed
text: I am an academic yuppie and am getting married soon. Typically, women like me keep their maiden names. But the catch for me is that I share a surname with several high-profile terrorists. I am not related to any of them, but my name often brings worried frowns during introductions and extremely thorough airport searches. I think taking a husband’s name in 2014 is regressive, but my fiancé’s surname is discrimination-proof and it sounds classy with my first name, too. Any advice?

headline: A Piano Great Is Back, Singing a Gusty Blues
text: ON a recent Sunday night at Smalls, the Greenwich Village basement club, Johnny O’Neal sat at the piano drawing lush clumps of harmony from the keys as he shouted a blues standard. “She puts whiskey in her coffee, whiskey in her tea,” he sang, his voice craggy and windblown. “Whiskey in her whiskey, too much whiskey for me.”

headline: A Troupe in Lock Step With the Wit of a Master
text: SARASOTA, Fla. — People have flown here from all around the world to see a four-day festival of works by the British master-choreographer Frederick Ashton. The 2013-14 season commemorates the 25th anniversary of Ashton’s death; this festival brings it to a climax.

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: In Mayweather’s Corner, and in the Corner Office
text: Bad blood flowed between Floyd Mayweather Jr. and Oscar De La Hoya during the news media tour to promote their fight in 2007, but the promoter Richard Schaefer feared that tensions could reach new heights.

headline: Steering for Laughs, in a Roar or a Whimper
text: Lewis Black, a screamer, and David Spade, more of a sniveler, are worlds apart in comedic style but both are likely to incur the wrath of driver-safety groups with their endorsements of texting while driving in their latest stand-up specials.

headline: Faulted in Medicaid Fraud, Company Keeps Contract
text: For nearly five years, a state contractor allowed workers with limited expertise to approve dental claims for Texas’ Medicaid program, the joint state-federal insurer. State spending on orthodontic services spiraled out of control; by 2012, federal and state auditors found that the contractor’s actions had opened the door for a “massive Medicaid fraud scheme” that cost taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars.

headline: In Some Places, a Lot of Voters Aren’t Enough
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: State Politicians Find Fertile Turf in Federal Land Dispute
text: State Representative James Frank has been hearing from constituents since February about goings-on along the Red River: The United States Bureau of Land Management, citing a series of court rulings dating to the 1920s, had decided that a 116-mile stretch of land belonged to the federal government.

headline: Events in New Jersey for May 4-10, 2014
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Howard Smith, Trend-Spotting Columnist, Dies at 77
text: Howard Smith, a journalist whose long-running Scenes column in The Village Voice was the message board of the hippie counterculture in the 1960s, and who later produced and directed “Marjoe,” an Oscar-winning 1972 documentary about another subculture, Christian evangelism, died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 77. The cause was cancer, his son Cass said.

headline: Why Economics Failed
text: On Wednesday, I wrapped up the class I’ve been teaching all semester: “The Great Recession: Causes and Consequences.” (Slides for the lectures are available via my blog.) And while teaching the course was fun, I found myself turning at the end to an agonizing question: Why, at the moment it was most needed and could have done the most good, did economics fail?

headline: Seattle Mayor Details Plan for $15 Minimum Wage
text: SEATTLE — Mayor Ed Murray presented on Thursday what he described as an imperfect but workable plan to increase the city’s minimum wage to $15 an hour, more than twice the federal minimum wage and one of the highest anywhere in the nation, through a series of complex and phased-in stages. Just as crucially, he said, the plan has broad political support, with a coalition of labor and business groups ready to push hard for it at the City Council, starting with the first hearings next week.

headline: Spending and Pay Gains Suggest Better Economy
text: WASHINGTON — After a winter that seemed endless, has the long-awaited spring economic thaw arrived?

headline: When It’s Good to Talk to a Stranger
Open-Source Software Specialist Selected as Executive Director of Wikipedia
text: The foundation that runs Wikipedia, the free online encyclopedia, has named a new executive director, Lila Tretikov, a software engineer in Silicon Valley.

headline: Hoping to Fend Off Suits, G.M. Is to Return to Bankruptcy Court
text: An unusual meeting took place this week at a law office high in a Times Square skyscraper. Lawyers from about 100 law firms participated, either in person or by phone. The agenda: solidifying a strategy for taking on General Motors in bankruptcy court.

headline: Love Story
text: Eight months ago, I came across a passage in a book that has haunted me since. It was in Michael Ignatieff’s biography of Isaiah Berlin, and it concerns a night Berlin spent in Leningrad in 1945. Berlin was hanging out when a friend asked if he’d like to go visit Anna Akhmatova. Not knowing much about her, Berlin said yes.

headline: HOW THE INDUSTRY FARED IN APRIL
text: Overall vehicle sales in the United States rose 8 percent last month.

headline: Patients Fear Mt. Sinai Will Drop Low-Cost Insurance Plans
text: For four months, Yitzchok Shuster felt secure in the knowledge that he had signed up for a health insurance plan on New York’s Affordable Care Act exchange, and that he was still able to see his longtime doctor, who was employed by the Mount Sinai Health System.

headline: G.M. Sales Increased 7% in April, Apparently Unaffected by Recalls
text: Despite a steady drumbeat of negative news surrounding the recall of 2.6 million small cars with a deadly defect, General Motors continues to be unaffected in its showrooms.

headline: Fair-Housing Collision in Westchester
text: Politicians’ bitterly defying the federal government over racial desegregation is an old American story, but not a dead one. You can find it in 50-year-old black-and-white newsreel clips. Or you can go to YouTube and see an angry campaign video posted this week by the Westchester County executive, Rob Astorino.

headline: U.S. and Germany Fail to Reach a Deal on Spying
text: WASHINGTON — The effort to remake the intelligence relationship between the United States and Germany after it was disclosed last year that the National Security Agency was tapping Chancellor Angela Merkel’s cellphone has collapsed, according to German officials, who say there will be no broad intelligence sharing or “no-spy” agreement between the two countries when Ms. Merkel visits the White House on Friday.

headline: A Surge Forward on Marriage Equality
text: In a landmark 5-to-4 ruling in June, the Supreme Court struck down the Defense of Marriage Act’s denial of federal benefits to lawfully married same-sex couples — but, in another case from California, declined to say whether the Constitution requires states to allow such marriages to begin with. Now, just 11 months later, the battle for marriage equality has turned an important corner, with a new round of cases beginning to reach federal appellate courts for review. This creates the potential for a speedier-than-expected return to the Supreme Court, perhaps as early as next term.

headline: U.S. Looks Into Wagers, Pro and Con, on Herbalife
text: Three federal agencies and one billionaire hedge fund manager have placed Herbalife under the microscope, scrutinizing whether the diet-supplements company is a pyramid scheme.

headline: At Least 3 Die in Collapse of Gold Mine
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — At least three people were killed in the collapse of an illegal gold mine in western Colombia, and rescuers were searching for other miners believed to be missing, officials said on Thursday.

headline: Little Recourse for Sterling
text: N.B.A. Commissioner Adam Silver handed down a lifetime ban to the Los Angeles Clippers owner Donald Sterling this week for racist comments he made during a recorded conversation. Silver also vowed he would force Sterling to sell the team and fined him $2.5 million. No one knows quite where it will lead. As Alan Rothenberg, a longtime sports lawyer who has known Sterling for decades said, “Donald is hugely litigious.” He added, “He’ll fight as hard as can legally.”

headline: The Right Lessons From Chernobyl
text: Twenty-eight years after Unit 4 at the Chernobyl power plant in what was then Soviet Ukraine erupted into a volcano of radioactivity, its name has become synonymous with the nightmarish side of nuclear power. It is also the site today of an extraordinary international project, the construction of a vast steel shield to cover the leaky concrete ‘‘sarcophagus’’ in which the highly radioactive remains of the reactor are to be entombed for at least 100 years.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 1, 2014
Events in Connecticut for May 4-10, 2014
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Professional Pompom Problems
text: How can cheerleaders keep their competitive edge as they enter the working world?

headline: Three-Drug Protocol Persists for Lethal Injections, Despite Ease of Using One
text: Terminally ill people who want to die can take drugs to end their lives peacefully. Ailing pets are put down humanely every day. Clearly, the technology exists to bring about a quick and painless death.

headline: Scratched From the Kentucky Derby
text: Mike Smith, the jockey for Hoppertunity, talks about the horse’s injury.

headline: Israeli Military Officials Caught Off Guard by a ‘Digital Rebellion’
text: JERUSALEM — Thousands of photographs poured onto Facebook: uniformed Israeli soldiers in elite units, office workers on lunch break, a beachgoer in a bikini, a right-wing politician, toddlers and even puppies, all holding signs in Hebrew: “We are with David the Nahlawi.”

headline: Helmets Do Little to Help Moderate Infant Skull Flattening, Study Finds
text: Pediatricians have long urged parents to put newborns to sleep on their backs to help prevent sudden infant death syndrome. While the practice undoubtedly has saved lives, it also has increased the numbers of babies with flattened skulls.

headline: Derby Dreams Meet an Early End
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — The saying goes that there is no cheering in the press box, and presumably that sort of restraint applies to crying, too. Yet Thursday morning, as word spread around the Churchill Downs backside, crying is exactly what I wanted to do.

headline: Reaction to the Dockery Arraignment
text: Marcell Dockery’s lawyer and the president of the Patrolmen’s Benevolent Association spoke after Mr. Dockery was arraigned on charges of setting a fire that killed a police officer.

headline: Lawyer Says Confession in Fatal Fire Was Coerced
text: The defense lawyer for the Coney Island teenager charged with murder for starting a fire that led to a police officer’s death signaled on Thursday that he would argue his client gave a false confession.

headline: 4.1% Are Said to Face Death on Convictions That Are False
text: Some 4.1 percent of death row defendants are falsely convicted, according to a widely cited study published this week. The figure concerned but did not surprise opponents of the death penalty.

headline: As Netflix Resists, Most Firms Just Try to Befriend Comcast
text: In the middle of an otherwise routine earnings report last week, Netflix took an unexpected detour into the realm of antitrust enforcement: It opposed Comcast’s proposed purchase of Time Warner Cable, it said, because the deal would create a powerful giant with “anticompetitive leverage.”

headline: Ferdinand and Imelda, Back on the Disco Floor

headline: Dozens Are Killed in Airstrike at a Bustling Market in Syria
text: A bustling outdoor market area in Syria’s battleground city of Aleppo was turned into a mass of bloody rubble and body parts on Thursday by missiles and improvised barrel bombs that killed at least 33 people and wounded many others. Antigovernment activists described it as another deliberate attack on civilians by President Bashar al-Assad’s military aircraft.

headline: V.A. Hospital Officials in Phoenix Are Placed on Leave
text: Two top administrators at the Department of Veterans Affairs health care system in Phoenix have been placed on leave at the request of the department’s inspector general, who is investigating allegations that the hospital created a secret waiting list for patients intended to hide long wait times for appointments. Congressional officials have said as many as 40 veterans may have died while awaiting care, though none of the deaths have explicitly been tied to longer wait times.

headline: For the Rangers, an Unfavorable History Against the Penguins
text: The Rangers have faced the Pittsburgh Penguins four times in the postseason, and each series ended badly. Mario Lemieux and Company swept the Rangers in 1989, knocked them out in six games in 1992 and ousted them in five in 1996. In 2008, Sidney Crosby was at the controls as the Rangers fell in five.

text: There were plenty of skeptics when the Chicago White Sox signed the Cuban slugger Jose Abreu for $68 million over six years. But it turns out that Abreu, with no major league experience, was one of the few batters no one needed to worry about.

He had been pummeled in the head more than 32 times and stabbed repeatedly with a fork. One ear had been cut in half.

headline: Classic Met Gala-Worthy Looks
text: Next week, the Metropolitan Museum of Art reopens the doors to its Costume Institute, now dubbed the Anna Wintour Costume Center, with a show dedicated to the works of the Anglo-American couturier Charles James. The inaugural exhibition, “Charles James: Beyond Fashion,” will of course inform the dress code for the fashion flock attending the opening gala on Monday evening — the designer’s classic style (think: society balls and Hollywood starlets) marking a complete departure from last year’s garbage-bag gowns and safety-pin-fastened concert tees for the “Punk: Chaos to Couture” event. In anticipation of one of fashion’s biggest nights of the year, we’ve curated some modern black-tie-appropriate designs that nod to the midcentury glamour that James helped define. In case your golden ticket got lost in the mail, now’s as good a time as any to make Monday evening plans worthy of floral-printed opera gloves and statement diamond earrings.

headline: India Election Digest: May 2
text: What you need to know on Friday about India’s elections: A public broadcaster defends itself from criticism of its interview with Narendra Modi of the Bharatiya Janata Party, voter turnout has risen among women and young people, and the Election Commission goes to great lengths to make sure every Indian can vote.

headline: Mets Are Doomed by a Pitcher at the Plate
text: DENVER — The Mets have become accustomed to struggling on offense, relying instead on strong starting pitching to establish themselves as one of the surprise teams of the young season. But on Thursday night at Coors Field, their starting pitcher did not last through the fifth inning and their offense did not wake up until the ninth, resulting in a 7-4 defeat to the Colorado Rockies.

headline: Interest Grows in Animal Testing Alternatives
text: With China planning to relax its requirement that cosmetics and other personal care products be tested on animals before they can go to market, a government training program in alternative testing methods is suddenly so popular it has had to turn away applicants.

headline: North Korea: Activity at a Missile Site
text: New commercial satellite imagery shows that North Korea is expanding its main rocket-launching site and testing engines of what is believed to be its first road-mobile intercontinental ballistic missile, a website specializing in the North said Thursday. The reported activities at the Sohae Satellite Launching Station in Tongchang-ri near North Korea’s western border with China come amid fears that the North may be preparing for another nuclear test. In recent days, more activity has been reported at an underground nuclear test site in Punggye-ri in northeastern North Korea. The website, 38 North, which is run by the U.S.-Korea Institute at Johns Hopkins University, said its analysis of satellite images of Tongchang-ri showed that North Korea conducted “one and maybe more engine tests of what is probably the first stage of a KN-08 road-mobile intercontinental ballistic missile” in late March to early April. “With this latest activity, three KN-08 rocket engine test series have been identified for the first and possibly second stages dating back to mid-2013,” the website said. “As this effort progresses, the next technically logical step in the missile’s development would be a flight test of the entire system.”

headline: ‘Pagliacci,’ by Appointment Only
text: The Italian heritage of Brooklyn’s Homecrest is evinced by the Virgin Mary statuettes on the block that is home to the Enrico Caruso Museum of America. A tidy house at 1942 East 19th Street, owned by Aldo Mancusi since 1956, doubles as a shrine to the opera icon. “A hobby gone crazy,” Mr. Mancusi said, his silver mustache as neatly pruned as the yard’s hedges.

Championship to Trump National Golf Club in Washington, and the 2022 P.G.A. Championship to Trump National Golf Club in Bedminster, N.J. This week, Trump agreed to acquire the Turnberry Resort in Scotland, which is part of the rotation of courses that host the British Open.

headline: So Far, U.S. Sanctions Over Ukraine May Be Inflicting Only Limited Pain on Russia
text: WASHINGTON — As it tries to punish Moscow for its intervention in Ukraine, the White House asserts that the sanctions it has imposed have had a “significant impact” on Russia’s economy, but their real effect so far, according to economic specialists, appears to be more psychological than tangible.

headline: What’s On Friday
text: 8 P.M. (ABC) SHARK TANK: SWIMMING WITH SHARKS Lara Spencer anchors this special, which ventures behind the scenes of the reality show to reveal what happens after the deals are made. The series’ “sharks” (above from left, Kevin O’Leary, Barbara Corcoran, Ms. Spencer, Daymond John, Mark Cuban and Lori Greiner; not pictured, Robert Herjavec) discuss their strategies for landing deals and making the most money, lament their regrets and divulge what they think of one another. This show will also follow up with the entrepreneurs Mark and Hanna Lim of Lollacup, a sippy cup; Rick and Melissa Hinnant of Grace & Lace, a sock company; Al Baker of Bubba’s Q Boneless Ribs; Lani Lazzaro of Simple Sugars, a sugar scrub; and Johnny Georges of Tree-T-Pee, an irrigation device, and reveal its most successful business in the show’s five seasons.

headline: Warriors Hold Off Clippers to Force Game 7
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — In a playoff series destined to be remembered for the off-court drama of the N.B.A.’s decision to force the expulsion of the Los Angeles Clippers’ owner, Donald Sterling, the on-court fight between the Clippers and Golden State Warriors will end with a Game 7.

headline: AstraZeneca Rejects a Higher Bid From Pfizer

headline: China Criticizes U.S. Terrorism Report
text: Days after a deadly attack in the western region of Xinjiang, China has criticized the United States State Department’s annual terrorism report, saying it wrongly plays down China’s counterterrorism efforts and accusing the United States of holding double standards on terrorist assaults in China.

headline: Ukrainians Strike Rebel-Held City as Fighting Spreads
text: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine — Two days after Ukraine’s interim government declared itself all but helpless to control events in the eastern part of the country, Ukrainian military and police forces on Friday resumed their effort to retake this rebel-controlled city, forcing armed separatists from the city’s outskirts with armored vehicles, helicopters and ground troops — and seemingly pushing ever closer to a confrontation with Moscow.

text: JUBA, South Sudan — Secretary of State John Kerry said Friday that he had secured a commitment from Salva Kiir, South Sudan’s president, to open talks with his rebel opponent as early as next week.

headline: The Eye Has to Travel
text: An avid Instagrammer, the fashion designer Julia Leach chronicles unexpected treasures hiding in plain sight, from sky-blue vistas in Athens to smooth stones in the sand in Riviera Nayarit, Mexico. “When I travel, pure moments that have graphic sensibility and emotional simplicity always catch my eye,” the former creative director of Kate Spade says. These discoveries serve as inspiration for Chance, Leach’s nascent line of breezy basics, including striped boat-neck T-shirts, cotton caftans and woven hats — the kind of clothing that makes one want to head off and seek the sun.

headline: Q & A: Nicholas Bequelin on Why Tensions Are Rising in Xinjiang and Beyond
text: Wednesday evening, at least two assailants armed with knives attacked a crowd of people outside a train station in Urumqi, the capital of the far western Chinese region of Xinjiang. At least 79 people were wounded and three died, two of them believed to have been the attackers, who also set off an explosive device. The one suspect the police identified, a 39-year-old man, has a name that suggests he belonged to the Uighur ethnic group, once the dominant people in Xinjiang, who after decades of migration by ethnic Han Chinese are now a minority.

headline: The Jobs Report Isn’t as Good as It Looks

headline: Debut Novels
text: THE BOOK OF JONAH  By Joshua Max Feldman  Henry Holt, $28.

headline: Paperback Row
text: ROBERT OPPENHEIMER: A Life Inside the Center, by Ray Monk. (Anchor, $20.) Monk emphasizes Oppenheimer’s psychological complexity and his contributions to physics as he brings the “father of the atomic bomb” vividly to life — from his tenure as the director of the Los Alamos laboratory to his exile under McCarthyite anti-Communism. THE GIRLS OF ATOMIC CITY: The Untold Story of the Women Who Helped Win World War II, by Denise Kiernan. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $16.) In 1945, the town of Oak Ridge, Tenn., had 75,000 residents and used more electricity than New York City. As Kiernan explains in this engaging history, Oak Ridge was home to the Manhattan Project’s top-secret uranium enrichment facilities, staffed by young women who learned the true nature of their work only after the first bomb fell on Hiroshima.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: FORCING THE SPRING: Inside the Fight for Marriage Equality,  by Jo Becker. (Penguin Press, $29.95.) A fly-on-the-wall account of the 2013 Supreme Court case that led to the overturn of California’s ban on same-sex marriage.

headline: Facts & Figures: Environmental Racism
text: Three environmental organizations released a study Thursday on the demographics of the 134 million U.S. residents living with the danger or “vulnerability” zones of 3,433 chemical facilities, and the 3.8 million living with the “fenceline” zones closest to potential harm, with the least time to react in the event of a catastrophe.

headline: Adventures of a Somebody
text: All she did was dab a little rouge on her cheeks to disguise her wan complexion and provide a rosy contrast to the black gown she would wear. But her husband strongly disapproved. Grabbing a towel, he pulled her onto his knee and wiped her face clean. It did not matter to John Quincy Adams that Queen Louise of Prussia had given his wife the cosmetic and expected it to be used.

headline: Blight and Flight
text: What does the essayist David Giffels have in common with LeBron James, Chrissie Hynde, the Professional Bowlers Association and Devo? They all originated in the Rubber Capital of the World. Born at the end of the baby boom in a city cloaked in smoke, Giffels came of age just as Goodrich, Firestone and General Tire were high-tailing it out of Akron, Ohio, chasing nonunion labor and sunnier climes. Almost a third of the city’s population fled after the closures, along with the pop stars, the bowling association and, most crushingly, LeBron. But Giffels stuck around to document every empty Main Street storefront and every piece of the region’s postindustrial detritus, down to a dirty diaper frozen atop a Lake Erie swell.

headline: Are You My Father?
text: The lost or unknown parent tantalizes from behind the drape. The child cast off or left behind spins absence into myth. Most of us are given little to imagine about our mothers and fathers; they stand squarely before us on their fallen arches. We know from whom we got our own flat feet. The forsaken child, though, can hope for better, also that a bit of the mystery has been passed on to him, a secret compartment holding an untapped talent, an innate courage, a sensitive nature. And, against the evidence, love may also wait.

headline: Spy Anxiety
text: Mai Jia is the pen name of Jiang Benhu, perhaps the most widely read writer you’ve never heard of. Jiang enrolled in a military college in China in 1981 and stayed in the Chinese Army after graduation, writing and editing. Since returning to civilian life in 1997, he has produced a number of novels with military intelligence themes that have sold millions of copies. Some have been made into popular television productions and films. Today Jiang is president of the state-sponsored writers’ association in Zhejiang Province.

headline: Gomorrah by the Bay
text: Emma Donoghue’s novel “Room,” published in 2010, was rightly celebrated for its terse depiction of love in a dark place. Narrated by a small boy, it’s a claustrophobic and sparsely furnished exercise in horror and redemption. A mother and her young son, held captive for years in a locked room, do not go mad and destroy each other. Instead they make a sort of world, a private civilization of tenderness and warmth, population two. The novel is a triumph of the obsessed imagination thriving on a real paucity of resources.

headline: Train of Jewels
text: In 2005, the settlement of a notorious case of postwar liability took place in a federal court in Florida. Sixty years previously, the so-called Hungarian Gold Train had arrived near Salzburg, Austria, bearing property requisitioned by the Nazis from Hungary’s estimated 800,000 Jewish citizens. Making its way to Germany as the Allies closed in, the train was intercepted by the Americans. Some of its cargo — jewelry, glassware, carpets, bed linen, cutlery, furs, furniture, gold coins, watches and much else from households whose occupants had vanished into the concentration camps — was subsequently commandeered by the generals working on the Marshall Plan, who needed to furnish their headquarters. Numerous items were irretrievably lost, never to be seen again by their rightful owners or by their owners’ heirs. It would take more than half a century for Hungarian survivors of the Holocaust to settle a lawsuit that eventually granted $21 million as compensation to a number of Jewish social service agencies.

headline: In for Nasty Weather
text: “ ‘Life on the planet Earth. . . . Wars and strife and surprises and love and children and art. . . . This is our parade and I’m marching in it.’ She squeezed my hand and we went back to writing on our postcards and eating croissants and being here, glad to be alive in the only world there is, alive and eating and still breathing and not afraid really of anything that might happen next. We were Americans, for God’s sake, we weren’t in the habit of being afraid.”

headline: Inside the List
text: Je Ne Sais Quoi: “Everybody’s Got Something,” a new memoir by the “Good Morning America” anchor Robin Roberts, makes its debut on the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 3. Roberts’s book is like one of those packets of heavily sweetened instant oatmeal — you can pretend it’s healthy even as you search out the sugar bombs of drama (her medical crises, her mother’s death, her ratings war with the “Today” show) and celebrity gossip (her 10-year relationship with the girlfriend she met on a blind date: “I liked the fact that she had no idea who I was”). Roberts delivers all of this in the soothing, upbeat voice that has made her so formidable a presence on morning TV. “I’m no Pollyanna,” she says in the current issue of Good Housekeeping, “but I believe optimism is a choice — a muscle that gets stronger with use. Right foot, left foot . . . just keep moving.” This spirit of levelheaded resolve is widely credited with helping Roberts topple “Today” from its perch in 2012. But she almost didn’t get the chance. “She was a woman of great personal dignity, stately beauty and, what’s most important in her mysterious genre, a certain je ne sais quoi that you can’t just order up by the ounce from human resources,” the media reporter Brian Stelter wrote of Roberts in “Top of the Morning,” his 2013 best seller about the competition for breakfast-hour viewers. “Naturally, because morning TV still comes down to a group of elite men trying to guess the needs of a mass audience of mostly women, many of the powers that were at ABC wanted to fire her” as soon as feasible.

headline: Today in Small Business: 288,000 Jobs
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Tony Awards 2014: Nominees’ Plan Bs
text: Tony nominees talk about what they would be doing for a living if they didn’t work in the theater.

headline: More Senior Departures Expected From Barclays in Upheaval at British Firm
text: Updated, 8:03 p.m. |

headline: Artistic Director of Pennsylvania Ballet to Step Down
text: Perhaps 35 years feels like enough. Roy Kaiser, who joined the corps de ballet of the Pennsylvania Ballet in 1979 and rose through its ranks to principal before eventually becoming artistic director of the company in 1995, has announced that he is stepping down.

headline: Legal Fight Over Nursery School Admissions Keeps Delhi Kids at Home
text: NEW DELHI – It has been over a month since the new semester began at nursery schools in India’s capital. Yet at Springdales School the corridors are silent, the swings and see-saws are motionless and the classrooms are empty.

headline: Tony Awards Video: ‘If I Weren’t in Show Business …’
text: On Wednesday several of this year’s Tony Award nominees gathered at the Paramount Hotel for the annual meet-and-greet, where they chatted with the press, schmoozed with one other and sized up the competition.

headline: Wall Street Embraces a Rule It Hates
text: Wall Street banks have a special loathing for a new and arcane rule, and they have gone to extraordinary lengths — like helping write a bill that is currently in Congress — to neuter it.

headline: Militants Kill 11 in Northeastern India, Police Say
text: NEW DELHI — Eleven people were killed in two separate attacks on western villages in the northeastern Indian state of Assam on Thursday night, where long-simmering tensions have pitted members of the Bodo tribal group, who are demanding a separate state, against non-Bodo residents.

headline: My, What Lovely Flowers. Who Lobbied for Them?
text: WASHINGTON — There was something different about the iris and quince blossoms in the flower arrangements at the state dinner for France at the White House this year: They were grown in the United States, not overseas.

headline: New-Music Concerts for Mother’s Day, Kids Welcome
text: The violist and composer Lev Zhurbin, who performs under the name Ljova, is experimenting with a new approach to presenting concerts that, if it works out, will expand audiences and, at the same time, save parents a small fortune in babysitting fees. On Mother’s Day, May 11, Mr. Zhurbin is presenting two double-bill programs at the National Opera Center, which has two adjacent halls, both of which figure into Mr. Zhurbin’s plans.

headline: Ares Management Slumps in Trading Debut
text: The stock market is greeting the initial public offering of Ares Management, a private equity and debt investing firm, with a shrug.

headline: Going It Alone
text: I have always disliked brokers. When my husband and I first set out to buy an apartment in 2004, we felt harassed by the pushy hoverers who chased us with sign-in sheets and referred to closets as “baby nooks.” It seemed their only goal was to create an unwarranted frenzy over each unit as a way of getting some idiot to pay far too much.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘Love and Treasure’
text: This week, Ayelet Waldman talks about her new novel, “Love and Treasure”; John Williams on the week’s literary news; Thomas Mallon and Dana Stevens discuss movies about writers; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: In Champions League Final, a Battle for the Hearts of Madrid
text: After another season of big occasions and very big spending, the most important club soccer competition in the world has boiled down not to an international duel between economic equals but to an intercity “derbi” between neighbors of disparate means.

headline: A Voice of Dissent in Egypt Is Muffled, but Not Silent
text: CAIRO — CRITICS here called his films “vulgar” and “damaging to the public’s taste.” When the Muslim Brotherhood came to power last year, one Islamist preacher called him “Satan’s prayer caller.” But after two decades of mocking the powerful as a popular columnist and screenwriter, only now has Belal Fadl been blacklisted.

headline: A Reading of “Cunning and Greed” by Robert Pinsky
text: The American poet reads his meditation on agricultural greed.

headline: My Civil War
text: As a teenager growing up in the piney woods of Winn Parish, La., I frequently looked out our front window to see an old man in well-worn overalls gingerly climb over the fence and walk up the hill toward the house.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘Love and Treasure’
text: This week, Ayelet Waldman, Thomas Mallon and Dana Stevens.

headline: Movie Review: ‘The Amazing Spider-Man 2’
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “The Amazing Spider-Man 2.”

headline: Movie Review: ‘Belle’
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Belle.”

headline: Late-Morning Jolt: Subway Derailment in Queens Injures 19
text: The F train slithered across Woodside, Queens, without incident at first, its passengers bound for jobs and late-morning appointments in Manhattan and Brooklyn.

headline: A Principled Warrior
text: On Feb. 22, 1848, Representative John Quincy Adams of Massachusetts collapsed over his desk on the House floor and slumped toward the carpet. He was carried to a nearby sofa and eventually transported upon it to the speaker’s office, where he died the next day. His only words upon that sofa were: “This is the end of earth. I am composed.” It was a fitting death scene for someone who had served 17 years in the House and emerged as one of his era’s most magnetic men of conviction.

headline: Word Wide Web
text: Earlier this year, one of those BuzzFeed quizzes that tempt the idle with spurious but irresistible personality tests asked web surfers to click a box to identify their worst fear, choosing among nine popular forms of dread. Many of the choices in the Fear category were unsurprising — Failure, Cancer, Dying Alone — but one stood apart: Suddenly Becoming Stupid. Who would have thought, in this age of gung-ho, market-driven anti-intellectualism, that anxiety about fading brainpower was sufficiently potent and widespread to go viral? Who knew it was even, as millennials say, a thing?

headline: Residents Sue to Halt Closing of Brooklyn Assisted-Living Home
text: A group of residents of the Prospect Park Residence, an assisted-living center for older people in Brooklyn that is scheduled to shut down in June, filed a lawsuit on Friday against it and the State Health Department, seeking to halt the closing.

headline: Tea Party Candidate in Kentucky Hits Snags
text: LEXINGTON, Ky. — For Matt Bevin, the main challenger in the Republican primary to topple Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the campaign could be boiled down to this, his one chance to try to confront his opponent in person, in the crowded ballroom of a Marriott hotel.

headline: Introducing The Data Boss: Making Smarter Decisions
text: I helped start RJMetrics in 2009 with a simple mission: to inspire and empower data-driven people. Today, our software helps hundreds of online businesses use their data to make smarter decisions and grow faster.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Ida’
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Ida.”

headline: Honda Recalls 25,000 Odyssey Minivans for Air Bag Defect
text: Honda is recalling almost 25,000 Odyssey minivans from the 2014 model year in the United States for an air bag problem, according to a report the automaker posted Friday on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration website.

headline: Italian Confidence Undimmed by Statistics
text: THE Italian economy has been a laggard for years. In the final quarter of 2013, it registered scant growth of just 0.3 percent at an annual rate, and that was a great improvement. Before that, it had shrunk for nine consecutive quarters. The economy remains smaller than it was 14 years ago. Unemployment has climbed to nearly 13 percent, twice its level in early 2008.

headline: Upper East Side Rowhouse Growth Spurt
text: When does a coherent row of brownstones become a miscellany of masonry? That point is nearing or even past for the rowhouses on the south side of East 69th Street, from Second to First Avenues. Thirty years ago they were a nearly uniform group of charming dwellings. Now the string has broken, and these little pearls are skittering across the floor.

headline: Next Week on Retro Report
text: After the 1998 N.F.L. draft produced one of the greatest busts in history, what have we learned about the science of evaluating human talent? Visit NYTimes.com on Monday for the full story.

headline: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
text: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

headline: Making Men Marriageable
text: Continuing my recent series of posts offering what I hope is constructive criticism for anti-inequality liberals, let me address this recent piece from Naomi Cahn and June Carbone, two sociologists I’ve both learned from and differed with in the past, in which they make a case for the wisdom of working-class single motherhood in an age of downscale male underemployment. Using the pseudonymous case of “Lily,” a single mom for whom the father of her baby, “Carl,” is more a burden than a helper, they argue that it’s often much more sensible for women who want children to get pregnant and raise them on their own than to hold out for a decent, productive, reliable man who may never actually materialize:

headline: In Latest Government Shuffle, North Korean Leader Removes No. 2 Official From Top Posts
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Kim Jong-un, the North Korean leader, has removed an official who was widely considered No. 2 in his government from top military and party posts, according to reports in the country’s state-run news media over the weekend.

headline: Moogfest: Avant-Pop and Analog Geekery
text: Ben Ratliff and Jon Pareles discuss why analog synthesizers and techno-futurism makes for an agreeable festival.

headline: Exposing the Hypocrisies of the New York Liberal
text: This month is the 100th anniversary of the death of Jacob Riis, the Danish immigrant and celebrated chronicler of social malady whose outrage over turn-of-the-century inequities left him with plenty of psychic space to accommodate a full catalog of bigotries. Riis’s compassion for the underclasses was of the kind never distant from disdain. In “How the Other Half Lives,” his classic exploration of slum life in New York City, he evinces equal horror at the conditions in which new immigrants are forced to live and the cultural characteristics he believes contribute to their depredations. “Chinamen” are lost in their opium haze; Southern Italians are complacent idiots.

headline: Nissan Tests Self-Cleaning Car
text: Washing cars is enough of a chore that many people simply don’t bother. But what if the car didn’t have to be washed, but would still look clean?

headline: Shelter From the Storm
text: The seaside neighborhood of Rockaway, Queens, still piecing itself together a year and a half after Hurricane Sandy, has found its patron saint in Klaus Biesenbach, the most hospitable grill master in the art world.

headline: Tips for Choosing Care for an Aging or Ailing Family Member
text: UNLIKE other areas of health care, the cost of hiring someone to help tend to an aging family member at home has been relatively stable.

headline: Moogfest: Avant-Pop and Analog Geekery
text: This week on the Popcast, we check in on Moogfest, the annual festival in Asheville, N.C., that is named after the Moog (rhymes with vogue) brand of analog synthesizer. The company’s founder, Bob Moog, lived in Asheville from 1978 until his death in 2005. (The instruments are still manufactured at the Moog factory there.)

headline: Advice for Parents Touring Colleges: Don’t Talk
text: Ask my son, who is a junior in high school, if he remembers the Great College Schlep of 2011 with his big sister and he will still fume that it was no kind of summer vacation. Maybe not, but on that virgin tour through 1,200 miles of Anywhere, U.S.A., my husband and I learned a lot about our daughter, the college applicant. She dreaded going away from home more than we realized. She worried about the transition from high school to college, panicking over whether she would she make friends there. She was also consumed with worry in equal parts over whether her roommate would be a psycho, and how she might handle Starbucks withdrawal.

headline: Drink Your Greens
text: I’ve never been one to eat or drink a particular food just because it’s good for you. So for years I’ve been rolling my eyes whenever anyone starts talking about green smoothies or green drinks. I love greens, but not in my morning smoothie.

headline: The Monster of Kings Island
text: The monsters of Southern Ohio had long wait lines and strict height requirements. But one behemoth in particular — a roller coaster called the Beast — served as a rite of passage for us kids of Cincinnati. Even before I saw the roller coaster, its infamy was scored in my mind by way of the Beast’s ubiquitous logo: two manacled claws straddling a railroad track that disappeared into a fiery hellhole.

headline: Who Made That Food Truck?
text: In 1872, a vendor named Walter Scott cut windows into a small covered wagon and parked it in front of a local newspaper office in Providence, R.I. Sitting on a box inside, he sold sandwiches with pies and coffee to journalists and pressmen working late.

headline: Brother, Can You Spare Some Emphysema?
text: I don’t smoke, but once or twice a year I have a cigarette with old friends. I bought a pack for one such evening, and only a few were consumed. On my way to work the next morning, I was about to throw it away, but then I saw a group of homeless people on the sidewalk. I gave the pack to the only woman in the bunch, and she accepted it with gratitude. Should I have thrown them away? MARK LESSARD, BROOKLYN

headline: Reply All: The 4.20.14 Issue
text: HOW OBAMA GOT TO ‘I DO’ ON SAME-SEX MARRIAGE

headline: Dunkin’ Corn Pone
text: Talking birds and bees; King Solomon’s hot dog.

headline: Where Brazilians Go to Splurge
text: Flush with time and money to spend, the well-to-do beneficiaries of Brazil’s recent boom times are eagerly traveling abroad. In 2013, an estimated 895,000 Brazilians visited New York, shopping for clothing, appliances, baby goods and electronics, while staying in high-end hotels and taking in Broadway shows. Fred Dixon, the chief executive of NYC & Company, the city’s marketing and tourism organization, says Brazilians average about a week per visit; a few who were in town last month can be seen on the following pages. Because of sky-high taxes on imported goods in Brazil, many there find that shopping sprees in New York can pay for themselves. “They’re creating a love affair with New York,” Dixon says, adding that the high-fashion, celebrity-oriented culture in the city “fits right in” with their lifestyle. “They feel at home here.” Julie Bosman

headline: Ruth Reichl Ditches the Wigs for a New Disguise: Fiction
text: I see on your Twitter that you ate lobster for breakfast. I did. They were claws left over from dinner the other night.

headline: Pfizer Has Yet to Make a Compelling Bid to AstraZeneca’s Shareholders
text: Pfizer’s courtship of AstraZeneca looks like a hate-hate relationship. In January, the British pharmaceutical firm AstraZeneca viewed its larger rival’s takeover proposal of 46.61 pounds a share as too low on cash, too risky, and too cheap to even talk about. Pfizer’s latest proposal, an effort to get AstraZeneca to begin friendly talks, hasn’t moved the needle much.

headline: New ‘Princess Diaries’ Books Coming, for Older and Younger Readers
text: When Meg Cabot published “Forever Princess,” the 10th volume (a few of them  published in multiple parts) of her “Princess Diaries” series, in 2009, she announced that she would give her young princess, Mia Thermopolis, an indefinite break, and would take one herself. It made sense: the series had become a young adult megahit, with sales reportedly around five million copies, and had a couple of films in its wake; and now Mia was 18 years old, with her romantic life sorted out, and cracking the books at Sarah Lawrence College.

headline: Keeping It on the Road
text: Writing used to be a lonely business, but not anymore because of my friend Siri. What I especially like is how she is so nonjudgmental.

headline: Image of the Day: May 2
text: A man walking across parched land on the outskirts of Bhubaneswar, Odisha.

headline: Times Minute | Behind Sterling’s Ouster
text: The role of Kevin Johnson in ousting the Clippers owner Donald Sterling. Also on the minute, a highly positive jobs report and the origins of the food truck.

headline: Simplicity in the Midst of Complexity
text: Let’s take a moment to consider the 10 artists in New York City Ballet’s exciting Festival of 21st-Century Choreographers at the David H. Koch Theater: Mauro Bigonzetti, William Forsythe, Benjamin Millepied, Justin Peck, Angelin Preljocaj, Alexei Ratmansky, Liam Scarlett, Richard Tanner, Christopher Wheeldon and the company’s ballet master in chief, Peter Martins. (Does the French street artist J R, the mind behind the flashy new “Les Bosquets,” make 11?)

headline: The Tale of Two Schools
text: Fieldston and University Heights are in the same borough but are worlds apart. How much understanding between their students can a well-told story bring?
