text: In the Video

headline: A Botched Execution, 155 Years Ago
text: This week, the execution of a man in Oklahoma went wrong. On May 11, 1859, The Times reported the death of Michael McNamee, another botched execution.

headline: Video Purports to Show Downed Helicopter
text: A leader of Pro-Russian separatists attempted to rally the citizens of Slovyansk against the government, as reports circulated of a downed Ukrainian helicopter.

headline: One $10,000 Martini, Please
text: What 22 items can tell us about inequality in New York.

headline: Hagel Urges European Allies to Increase Military Spending
text: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel made a forceful case on Friday for European members of NATO to increase their military spending, calling Russia’s intervention in Ukraine a “clarifying moment” for the alliance.

headline: A Preview of the Kentucky Derby
text: California Chrome is the early favorite to win the 140th running of the Kentucky Derby.

headline: Edgar Awards Handed Out for Top Mystery Works
text: William Kent Krueger walked off with the award for best novel for his “Ordinary Grace” (Simon & Schuster/Ataria) on Thursday night as the Mystery Writers of America presented the 2014 Edgar Awards at their annual banquet in New York. The awards honor the best mystery writing in several categories, including fiction, nonfiction and television. Mr. Krueger’s book is about a man’s look back at the summer of 1961 in Minnesota, when he was 13, and death “assumed many forms.”

headline: All the Rage | Graffiti Made of Plants, Not Paint
text: In recent years, city walls have become fertile artistic ground — quite literally — for a new wave of graffiti art that uses live plants instead of paint. Many such artists borrow their secretive practices from tagger tradition, jealously guarding their walls and rarely revealing their locations. But as in the spray-can graffiti world, many also accept commissions from public or private organizations to spruce up the streetscape.

headline: Exclusive Clip of ‘The Double’
text: Richard Ayoade’s new film is an adaptation of Dostoevsky’s ‘The Double’, starring Jesse Eisenberg as a man whose exact double and opposite shows up to work alongside him.

headline: West Village ‘Farmhouse’
text: A historic five-story Federal-style brick townhouse at 21 West 10th Street, one of the most picturesque residential blocks in the West Village, is poised to enter the market at $23.9 million.

headline: Countdown to the 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 41
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Merkel Signals That Tension Persists Over U.S. Spying
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama tried to mend fences with Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany on Friday, calling her “one of my closest friends on the world stage.” But Ms. Merkel replied tartly that Germany still had significant differences with the United States over surveillance practices and that it was too soon to return to “business as usual.”

headline: On Court or Off, He Savors Assists
text: In “Gang Related,” Ramon Rodriguez portrays Ryan Lopez, the adopted son of a crime lord who infiltrates the Los Angeles Police Department to help his family keep ahead of the law. But while Mr. Rodriguez’s real life doesn’t have the heart-stopping close calls, underworld gore or angsty divided loyalties that riddle this new Fox series, starting May 22, his childhood was a textbook example of how a father figure — or three — can help put a troubled boy on the right path.

headline: Spring Vegetable Stew With Artichokes and Fennel
text: This is inspired by a lush Sicilian springtime stew called fritteda that also includes peas and fava beans (and much more olive oil). This one is simpler, but equally sweet and heady because of all the fennel and the spring onions. I like to serve it with bow-tie pasta and a little Parmesan as a main dish, or with grains as part of a meal in a bowl. It also makes a delicious side dish with just about anything.

headline: Inequality Has Been Going On Forever ... but That Doesn’t Mean It’s Inevitable
text: We have been living with rising income inequality for so long — in good times and bad, under Republican presidents and Democratic ones — that it has come to seem inevitable. It is no longer news that the affluent did better than everyone else during the booms of the 1980s and ’90s and through the mediocre growth of this century’s first years. Or that the rich have recovered from the financial crisis far better than the rest of country.

headline: Baked Frittata With Yogurt, Chard and Green Garlic
text: Inspired by the signature Provençal chard omelet called truccha, this beautiful baked frittata incorporates thick Greek yogurt and lots of green garlic. It will puff up in the oven, but then it settles back down. Use a generous bunch of chard for this – green, red or rainbow – and save the stalks to use in the chard stalk and chickpea purée that I’m also posting this week. I like to serve the frittata at room temperature, or I grab a cold slice for lunch. It’s a wonderfully portable dish.

headline: Timeless Papua New Guinea
text: When the newsmagazine “Vice” made its debut on HBO last year with fast-paced segments on child suicide bombers in Afghanistan and Dennis Rodman in North Korea, some critics cried sensationalism.

headline: Quinoa Bowl With Roasted Artichokes, Spring Onions, Peas and Garlic Yogurt
text: There’s a lot going on in this springtime meal in a bowl – the onions and peas are sweet, but the onions also have that lovely bitter-edged char, as do the artichokes, from roasting. I first roasted artichokes for a bulgur salad not too long ago, and now I’m roasting them all the time. Roasting intensifies their flavor. Bulgur is also a great grain choice for this bowl.

headline: A Mystery Endures in Beijing’s Old Legation Quarter
text: On a freezing January morning in 1937, the mutilated body of a beautiful 19-year-old British woman was found lying at the base of Fox Tower along old Peking’s Ming dynasty protective wall. Her heart had been ripped out, her face slashed with a knife. Her head lay to the west, her feet to the east. Strangely, there was little blood.

headline: Squid: Make It Tender, Make It Quick
text: If you are a calamari fan and you also care about choosing sustainable seafood, look no further. Get thee to a fishmonger and buy some squid. It won’t set you back much; a pound of squid costs only a few dollars. By rights, something that tastes so good should cost a lot more.

headline: Solo in Paris
text: Some go to La Coupole, the 87-year-old Art Deco brasserie in Montparnasse, to commune with friends; others, to dine with ghosts — Picasso, Piaf, Sartre, all former patrons. I went alone, to live in the present.

headline: Stir-Fried Baby Turnips With Spring Onions, Green Garlic and Tofu
text: The fresh ginger I’m finding at springtime farmers’ markets is new and juicy, like the spring garlic and onions. I’m sure this is going to be just one of many springtime stir-fries, but right now it’s a favorite. It’s inspired by an irresistible bunch of baby turnips I bought at a Sunday farmers’ market. The turnips were no bigger than a small round radish, but their greens were lush – I had about 6 cups of leaves after I’d stripped them from the stems. Sweet spring onions and green garlic contrast beautifully with the bitter flavor of the turnip greens.

headline: Chard Stalk, Chickpea, Tahini and Yogurt Dip
text: When you’ve bought a bunch of Swiss chard and used the leaves for another dish, like an oven-baked frittata with yogurt, Swiss chard and green garlic, save the stems. Then you can make this dip, which is a cross between hummus and classic Middle Eastern dip called silq bil tahina, made with chard stalks and tahini. I’ve added lots of yogurt to the mix. I love to use some red chard stalks because they give the dip a beautiful pale pink hue.

headline: Billions Not Required for Angel Investing
text: JUST about every major tech success — from Facebook to LinkedIn to Instagram — started with angel investors taking a chance. These risk takers ended up being richly rewarded for their early investments, and no doubt they have inspired would-be angels to search for the next big thing.

headline: See It, Feel It, Touch It, Be Healed
text: Though she was one of Brazil’s most celebrated artists of the post-World War II era, Lygia Clark (1920-88) is not well known in the United States, a circumstance that should be corrected by “Lygia Clark: The Abandonment of Art, 1948-1988,” beginning Saturday at the Museum of Modern Art. Clark started out as a maker of geometric abstractions under the influences of Klee, Mondrian and Léger. In the 1960s she was associated with Neo-Concretism, the Brazilian movement that insisted on the sensual and material — as opposed to intellectual — properties of paintings and sculpture, sometimes encouraging viewer interaction with objects and installations. After 1966, Clark claimed to have abandoned art. She shifted her approach away from creating conventional forms and toward a kind of art therapy that involved the application of materials and devices directly to the people’s bodies. Art was treated as a form of psychological healing. Her late works should be of particular interest to fans of socially engaged and otherwise participatory types of art making. (Through Aug. 24, 11 West 53rd Street, 212-708-9400, moma.org.)

headline: Two Generations of New-Music Stars
text: A new-music great and a rising star both have tantalizing concerts on Saturday. The pianist Peter Serkin, 66, fresh off a recent Bartok triumph with the New York Philharmonic, arrives at the 92nd Street Y with a characteristically varied program. Stretching from the early Baroque composer Jan Pieterszoon Sweelinck to three recent works by Charles Wuorinen, the evening also includes Carl Nielsen and Beethoven. (8 p.m., Lexington Avenue at 92nd Street, 212-415-5500, 92y.org.)

headline: In the Footsteps of the Founder
text: Since its founding in 1961 by Ellen Stewart, La MaMa has been a home to, and champion of, brash and venturesome artists. This month, that East Village theater presents its annual La MaMa Moves! Dance Festival, now in its ninth year, featuring more than 50 local and international artists (through May 25). In the first week, the festival hosts a benefit concert, “Dancing for Japan 2014” (Wednesday), to support victims of the 2011 Tohoku earthquake and tsunami. Next, Miki Orihara, a longtime dancer for the Martha Graham Dance Company, will perform “Resonance,” a series of solos by modern-dance pioneers and contemporary choreographers (Thursday through May 11).

headline: Onstage in Harlem, a Week of Jazz
text: The Harlem Jazz Shrines Festival, in its fourth year, rallies around a sense of place and the past, from a vantage that feels convincingly like the present. Running from Sunday through Saturday at more than half a dozen locations, it finds common ground for concert premieres, tributes and academic talks. On Monday at Minton’s, for example, a 7:30 p.m. conversation about the bebop progenitor Charlie Parker, with the critic and biographer Stanley Crouch and the scholar Farah Jasmine Griffin, will be followed by a 10 p.m. jam session led by the alto saxophonist Antonio Hart, one of Parker’s many heirs.

headline: In Estate Planning, Family Isn’t Always First
text: WHETHER it’s treasured pearl earrings or a vintage camera, a house or what’s left of your life savings, deciding who should inherit your worldly goods means making sometimes wrenching choices. For older people without children, stepchildren or grandchildren, the decision can be even more complex.

headline: Dirty Dancing Encouraged Here
text: Who needs two tickets to paradise when a spicy shimmy will do? Mario Lopez, the Season 3 runner-up on “Dancing With the Stars,” and his wife, Courtney, a Broadway hoofer, are proof. Their chemistry ignited while performing in a revival of “A Chorus Line.” Now the Lopezes are testing their theory in “Love & Salsa,” a new dating competition produced by him and hosted by her and having its debut Tuesday night at 10 on NUVOtv.

headline: Kaboom!
text: Are all explosions the same? The Decorative Destruction Index.

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: An African Safari for Families
text: Most safari camps in Africa either don’t allow young children or they don’t cater to their interests, but the New York- and Hong Kong-based outfitter Asia to Africa Safaris is offering a new family-friendly animal viewing trip.

headline: Obama Orders Policy Review on Executions
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama declared this week’s botched execution in Oklahoma “deeply disturbing” and directed the attorney general on Friday to review how the death penalty is applied in the United States at a time when it has become increasingly debated.

headline: Teaching and Titillating, No Matter the Instrument
text: Sonny Rollins

headline: Springtime at Carnegie Hall
text: Spring for Music, the annual weeklong festival of North American orchestras at Carnegie Hall, begins and ends with requiem settings: the New York premiere of Christopher Rouse’s Requiem, performed by Alan Gilbert and the New York Philharmonic on Monday, and a little drama built around Mozart’s Requiem, performed by Manfred Honeck and the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra on May 10. Whether that framing came about by happenstance (unlikely, given the jesting proclivities of the festival’s chief executive and artistic director, Thomas W. Morris) or by design, it is, alas, all too appropriate. Spring for Music, in only its fourth season, is evidently a goner.

headline: A Choreographic Cross-Pollination
text: Sophie Claudel was living in Paris and working at the Pompidou Center when France Moves took over New York City. “I heard a lot about it,” she said over coffee, referring to the 2001 dance festival of French choreography. Her eyes widened with curiosity. “I always thought, why shouldn’t we try to do something?”

headline: Rivka Galchen on Comic Strips, Lucille Ball and What She’s Reading Now
text: Rivka’s Galchen’s 2009 debut novel “Atmospheric Disturbances” was filled with pleasurably twisty sentences and casually engaging intellectualism, earning her effusive praise and comparisons to Jonathen Lethem, Thomas Pynchon and Jorge Luis Borges. Her new book, “American Innovations” (out May 6 from Farrar, Straus and Giroux) gathers 10 short stories — each written from a female perspective in response to a canonical work like Gogol’s “The Nose” and Borges’s “The Aleph” — that are sharp and rich, astutely observed and wildly imaginative.

headline: A Great War Reading List at PEN World Voices Festival
text: July is the centenary of the outbreak of World War I, but publishers got a major jump on the anniversary last year. Christopher Clark’s “The Sleepwalkers,” Margaret Macmillan’s “The War That Ended Peace,” Max Hastings’s “Catastrophe 1914” and Sean McMeekin’s “July 1914” were just four of the hundreds of books to mark the moment a year early. The deluge continues in 2014, with, well, “The Deluge” by Adam Tooze (coming in November), David Reynolds’s “The Long Shadow” and many more.

headline: A Love for the Classics That’s More Than Skin Deep
text: An old Ford and a young woman who appreciates tradition prove an ideal match.

headline: New Inquiry Sought on Benghazi Attack
text: WASHINGTON — House Republicans on Friday escalated their battle with the White House over the continuing investigations into the 2012 attack that killed four Americans in Benghazi, Libya, ensuring that the issue will not recede in the midst of a fierce partisan fight for control of Congress.

headline: Car Bombs in Central Syria Kill at Least 19
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — In the latest strike in a rapid-fire series of bloody attacks on children and other civilians in Syria, two car bombs exploded in the central province of Hama on Friday, killing at least 19 people, including 11 children, Syrian state news media reported, blaming insurgents.

headline: Readers Get to Weigh In on Apologies
text: When Andrew Ross Sorkin and I came together to start “Apology Watch,” our goal was to elevate the conversation about authentic apologies. In that vein, we are introducing an “Apology Metric” survey to give readers an opportunity to share their insight. Through these surveys, we hope to change the shortsighted lens through which apologies are typically viewed. People review them as theatrical performances for a few days and quickly forget about them. Instead, as I’ve argued before, we ought to track the apologizer’s behavior over time to see whether he or she has genuinely committed to a new course of action, which is why we are offering these surveys.

headline: G.M. Talks to Families With Claims Over Defects
text: The lawyer hired by General Motors to explore compensating victims of cars with a defective ignition switch met on Friday with a representative of hundreds of people and their families who say they were affected by accidents involving the vehicles.

headline: Life Sentence Is Imposed in ’08 Killing of Therapist
text: Slouching over the defense table in the stained, gray sweat clothes he wore throughout his trial, David Tarloff finally got a chance to speak on Friday in the Manhattan courtroom where his sanity had been debated for weeks.

headline: Audi Sticks With a Winning Formula
text: Audi’s A3 sedan, new for 2015, is a car that buyers think they already know, one that instantly elicits warm and cuddly expectations.

headline: Yet More of the ‘Wait and See’ Strategy on Ukraine
text: As the situation deteriorated further in Ukraine on Friday, the American president and Europe’s most powerful leader met at the White House.

headline: On Kentucky Derby Weekend, a Tea Party Julep for Mitch McConnell
text: If Senator Mitch McConnell has to hear one more ad saying he has “betrayed Kentucky’s conservative values,” he’ll probably want a drink. Fortunately, in addition to being a symbol of conservative activism, tea is also an infusion that pairs well with bourbon. At least, that’s what we heard from Sachin Hasan of Manhattan’s Pierre Hotel, who discussed tea-bourbon drinks with T Magazine back in January.

headline: Penguins Discuss Line Strategy and Tiring Out the Rangers
text: PITTSBURGH — For an N.H.L. coach, the Pittsburgh Penguins’ Dan Bylsma is refreshingly open about tactics.

headline: Listen Up | A Ghostly Hymn From Your New Swedish Obsession
text: Alice Boman wrote and recorded her new song, “Over,” alone in her apartment in Malmo, Sweden. “I didn’t know it was going to be released,” she says of the hauntingly spare recording, which will appear on her new release, “EP II,” out June 3 via the Control Group. This intimate, lo-fi approach is characteristic of the soft-spoken singer-songwriter’s work. Her first EP, last year’s “Skisser” (Swedish for “sketches”), earned raves for its minimal arrangements and simple, heartbreaking lyrics. She tried to capture the same magic with “EP II,” cutting more tracks at home and, at one point, holing up in a cabin in the Swedish woods to record her ethereal sounds. The rustic setting — Boman says she had to trek to a neighbor’s to fetch water each day — proved a fitting backdrop for the 26-year-old’s elegiac, if oddly uplifting, tunes. “It was beautiful,” she says.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Ayelet Waldman’s ‘Love and Treasure’
text: In The New York Times Book Review, Catherine Taylor reviews Ayelet Waldman’s new novel, “Love and Treasure.” The book features the so-called Hungarian Gold Train, which held property requisitioned by the Nazis from Hungary’s Jewish citizens. Ms. Taylor writes:

headline: For This Wedding, the Roundtable Reconvenes
text: When Shaun Cherewich, a retired high school teacher and coach, says he’s old-fashioned, he’s not talking raccoon coats and jitterbugging. He’s talking about going way back — all the way to Europe’s medieval period.

headline: Taking a Spin: Everything Comes Up Republican
text: My inaugural weekly spin of the wheels on The Upshot’s Senate model, named Leo, gave Democrats a dream outcome: 54 Senate seats. In perhaps the surest indication of the uncertainty that remains at this early stage, my spin this week yields the exact opposite result: 54 seats for Republicans.

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: Black Tie? How About Black Mouse Ears?
text: When LeslieAnn Dunn was married in Central Park last July, she asked her guests to wear “summer black and white with a splash of yellow” so her wedding photos would have a cohesive look. Most guests followed her color scheme, and yellow popped up in nail polish, bow ties and flowers.

headline: New Faces Bringing the Heat in Summer Movies
text: Ellar Coltrane, ‘Boyhood’

headline: A Love Letter to Fiamma Ferragamo
text: The women of the Ferragamo family pay tribute to Fiamma, the iconic designer, beloved daughter, sister and aunt who died in 1998.

headline: With Hindsight in the Rearview Mirror
text: In Unhitched, longtime couples tell the story of their relationships, from romance to vows to divorce to life afterward.

headline: The Gun Report: May 2, 2014
text: This week, a firearms investigation unit of the N.Y.P.D. and a unit from the Brooklyn district attorney’s office shut down a weapons pipeline from Georgia to New York. Among the hundreds of guns seized were an AR-15, a MAC-11, two TEC-9 semi-automatic handguns and a Taurus .380-caliber semi-automatic pistol.

headline: Hip-Hop’s New New York
text: When I ventured into the underground rap world of New York City, I discovered a tight community, a new wave of artists, the New New York. Many of them performed on the Beast Coastal tour. They grew up together or met through hip-hop and have now created something of a family. Their sense of brotherhood inspired me to start photographing rap shows.

headline: Hundreds of Afghans Are Killed in Landslides
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Huge landslides caused by heavy rainfall buried hundreds of houses in a remote area of northeastern Afghanistan on Friday. As many as 2,500 people were said to be missing in the disaster, one of the worst to hit the war-torn country in at least a decade.

headline: Memos to Hollywood
text: Summer is sequel season, when the movie studios celebrate their lack of imagination by disguising it as populism. Why should movie critics be any different? Five years ago, we published the first installment of our “Memos to Hollywood,” in which we presumed to give advice to everyone involved in the making, distributing and watching of movies. And now we’re back with another spectacular, game-changing, blockbuster episode. This time, they’ll pay attention.

headline: A Long and Questionable Record in Sales
text: The sign on the door of the building on Eighth Avenue hard by Pennsylvania Station reads “Vigilant Hotel.” It is handwritten on cardboard. The Vigilant is a men’s-only, single-room-occupancy dwelling, the sort that lined the Bowery and its skid row a generation ago. Rooms go for $150 a week.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: How Not to Pick Judges
text: ROCHESTER — RESEARCH has long shown that female judges vote differently from men on issues of sex discrimination, harassment and sentencing, while black judges vote differently from whites on issues involving civil rights and affirmative action.

headline: Singing an Ode to the Naked City
text: In 2006, while the Irish writer-director John Carney was promoting his indie musical film “Once,” he fell hard for New York City. Literally. “Cycling around, going the wrong way down one-way streets, I got the feel of living here,” Mr. Carney said, adding that when he crashed that bike, he admired the efficiency with which New Yorkers stopped “for the minimal amount of time to make sure I wasn’t dead.”

headline: Naismith’s Choices on Race, From Basketball’s Beginnings
text: At the end of a week in which the Los Angeles Clippers owner Donald Sterling became, for a moment, the most talked-about man in basketball, let’s rewind the historical videotape and remember the Canadian-born farmer-chaplain-physician who invented the game. Here is James Naismith in 1928, holding a peach basket for his wife, Maude, to make a shot. Naismith seems now like an anachronistic figure, yet even nearly a century ago he too had to make serious choices about issues like race and money in basketball.

headline: Big Ticket | For $26.6 Million, a Penthouse in SoHo With a Lawn on the Terrace
text: A SoHo artist’s studio that underwent a radical transformation from an airy but spartan loft to a sybaritic 7,200-square-foot luxury penthouse sold for $26,580,000 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Weekend Reading: Targeting Big Banks. No, Not Those Big Banks.
text: The news this week that federal prosecutors were nearing criminal charges against a French bank and a Swiss bank received a mixed reaction from a public weary over the mantra that Wall Street is “too big to jail.”

headline: The Peripatetic Physician
text: Dr. Bernt Nesje, 67, says he has two guidelines for taking on patients: They must live in or around Greenwich Village, “and they have to be older than me.”

headline: Think Like a Doctor: 18-Year Rash Solved!
text: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to figure out why a 40-year-old woman had a rash on her hands for nearly two decades. I thought this was a really tough case. Apparently, so did my readers. Nearly 300 of you wrote in with some very thoughtful suggestions, but only five were able to make the diagnosis.

headline: Inequality Is Not Inevitable
text: We have been living with rising income inequality for so long — in good times and bad, under Republican presidents and Democratic ones — that it has come to seem inevitable. But inequality is not inevitable. Many societies, including the United States, have found ways to reduce inequality and lift living standards for the middle class and the poor.

headline: Small and City-Smart, Microvans Proliferate
text: If Americans found the arrival of the Ford Transit Connect in North America in 2009 a bit unsettling, by now they have become accustomed to its upright and somewhat ungainly shape. In just a few years, small cargo vans have become a familiar sight in American cities — and Ford’s competitors are taking notice.

headline: If Your Bucket List Includes a Taco Truck
text: TESTED 2014 Ram ProMaster

headline: Pictures of the Day: New York and Elsewhere
text: Photos from New York, Sudan, Ukraine and Washington.

headline: A Fraud Case Offers a Cautionary Tale of Finance
text: TWO decades. Twenty-six million dollars. Almost 2,000 victims. Seven guilty defendants.

headline: Wheelies: The Car Show Season Opener Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Review: 2014 Ford Fiesta ST
text: For those who love to drive, the ST truly is a Fiesta. Party on!

headline: In the Moment, Connecting and Questioning
text: Jess Dugan’s portraits engage her subjects in a visual conversation and ask viewers to rethink their notions of identity and community.

headline: Consider It a Sequel to a Hit From the ’90s
text: Reruns are comforting. Gilligan always screws up the rescue, Lucy gets smashed on Vitameatavegamin every single time, and no characters on “Seinfeld” remain masters of their domain. At some point it’s not about laughing at all the jokes, it’s the satisfaction of knowing all the jokes.

headline: Jil Sander’s New Creative Director, Diane Keaton’s Kooky Sale and Stella McCartney’s Designs for Kids
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: More Pickup Buyers Opt for V6s
text: It’s much too soon for a retirement party, but the V8 engine seems to be losing its clout with buyers of full-size pickup trucks. For the first time in about 50 years, many big-truck customers no longer consider a 6-cylinder engine to be a downgrade.

headline: Her True Colors, in Plain View
text: EAST MEADOW, N.Y. — Over a lunch of grilled cheese sandwiches at Panera Bread on Hempstead Turnpike here, Kim Schreier told the stories behind the tattoos that, she said, covered some 60 percent of her body.

headline: The New Firefox Is Fantastic. So Is Every Other Web Browser.
text: Mozilla has just released the latest upgrade to Firefox, its popular open-source browser. We’re at version 29 now, which as software goes is pretty long in the tooth.

headline: Obama and Merkel on Ukraine
text: The president and the visiting Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany delivered remarks on finding a diplomatic solution to the crisis in Ukraine.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: Week in Pictures for May 2
text: .media.slideshow.in-page-player .headline { display: none; }

headline: A Teachers’ Contract for New York
text: There was no snarling at City Hall when Mayor Bill de Blasio and the teachers’ union announced a very significant labor agreement on Thursday. Dispensing with the unproductive tension that tarnished the Bloomberg administration, the two sides showed that real progress can be made — on both the fiscal and the educational sides of the contract — when there is good will instead of disdain. On the whole, the agreement represents a good deal for the city and its students, though there were several missed opportunities and unanswered questions.

headline: Friday Night Music: Alison Krauss
text: Too busy to post much. But on Wednesday there was a lovely memorial event for Jerry (George W) Goodman, aka Adam Smith, that among other things highlighted his love of music, and included performances of some of his favorites — including this piece.

headline: Now Screening | A Comedy Director Gets Serious
text: In Richard Ayoade’s film, “The Double,” the quiet, self-conscious office clerk Simon James (played by Jesse Eisenberg) is struggling through a work day when he is suddenly confronted with his doppelgänger: exact in physique, but opposite in temperament. Arrogant, suave and irresistible to women, James Simon (also played by Eisenberg) glides into Simon’s life, throwing light on his weaknesses and self-loathing, and preying on his love interest Hannah (played by Mia Wasikowska). Nothing ever seems to go right for Simon, while everything is perfect for James. Based on Fyodor Dostoyevsky’s novella, the story delves into questions of identity, psychosis and self-preservation with absurd and sometimes agonizing humor. A seasoned comedian, the British director can draw a link between Dostoyevsky’s piercing insight and Larry David’s brazen style: “He’s really willing to go to un-noble places in people.”

headline: Outdoor Trips With a Fitness Focus
text: Travelers who can’t sit still have a new outings option. Two high-profile brands in the active lifestyle and fitness worlds are teaming up to offer Reebok Fitness Vacations by Austin Adventures.

headline: A New Benefit for Heart Failure Patients
text: The number of older heart failure patients who qualify to enter a cardiac rehabilitation program paid for by Medicare has just been vastly expanded. About two million people are newly eligible, Medicare officials estimate.

headline: Suspenseful Last Note for a Tribute to Britten
text: Last fall Carnegie Hall commemorated the centennial of Benjamin Britten’s birth with a substantive festival highlighted by an inspired concert performance of the opera “Peter Grimes.” That event, featuring an outstanding cast of singers and David Robertson conducting the St. Louis Symphony, took place on Nov. 22, 2013, the 100th anniversary of the composer’s birth.

headline: Troubles for Icarus and His Father
text: We’re No. 1! We’re No. 1!

headline: Sass of a Blues Mama, the Skill of a Stage Star
text: As her big eyes widen, and her lusty voice peels away protective layers of pop decorum, Lillias White expresses the drive and critical intelligence of a 62-year-old dynamo who needs extra space to reveal her full, complicated self.

headline: What Is the Role of Nurse Practitioners?
Why Religious Literacy Is Important in Our Culture
