headline: Cheering a Revival of Interest in James Baldwin
Video: The Ford Fiesta ST Is a Party on Wheels
text: A 197-horsepower car is not the kind of machine that gets acceleration addicts excited. A basic V6 Mustang delivers 305. The V8 GT has 402. But 197?

headline: Support for Casinos
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bill Cunningham | Seasoned
text: Fashion is unfolding, just like nature.

headline: Revenge, My Lovely
text: OSLO — I WAS lying in bed thinking about how I tortured the man who had raped my partner, how I made sure he didn’t die at once but still experienced some of the fear and physical suffering he had inflicted upon this innocent woman beside me, who had escaped by the skin of her teeth. Half-asleep, I smiled, warmed by the duvet and the glow of revenge and slept like a baby. The latter, I hope, because there had in fact been no rape, no rapist, no torture.

headline: Now That ‘Sugar Man’ Is Found, Lawsuit Focuses on Missing Royalties
text: The documentary “Searching for Sugar Man” tells the story of Rodriguez, an obscure singer-songwriter from Detroit whose albums were commercial flops when released in the early 1970s, but — unknown to Rodriguez and everyone around him — later became gigantic hits in South Africa.

headline: Selling a Fake Painting Takes More Than a Good Artist
text: The recent arrest in Spain of two brothers accused of passing off forged paintings as the work of America’s greatest Modernist masters has refocused attention on the people behind an art fraud that has lasted 15 years, garnered $80 million and helped bring down New York’s oldest gallery, Knoedler & Company.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Seasoned
text: Fashion is unfolding, just like nature. The spring coat has disappeared, replaced with the short jacket. Most popular is the biker style, worn with fluid trousers or distressed jeans. No fashion trend dominates, but the haberdasher’s look, with a masculine hair style, left, is strong. Black remains popular with city women, but light pastels have their own fashion force. The parks are spectacular with flowers, and trees with leaves as fresh as new grass.

headline: Evening Hours | Dodging the Raindrops
text: A wet spring couldn’t slow down the whirl of parties.

headline: Summer Movie Release Schedule
text: Yes, Scarlett Johansson wakes up with superpowers and takes no prisoners, but the season isn’t totally about would-be action blockbusters. Philip Seymour Hoffman gifts us with two posthumous performances, as a blue-collar American loser and as a powerful German spy. Documentaries explore a dizzying range of topics, including legal marijuana, the war in Afghanistan, breast-feeding and the Koch brothers. And climate change rears its plot-driving head, ready to replace midcentury nuclear testing as the villain in sci-fi and futurist fantasies.

headline: Under Cover: Body Language Tells the Story
text: This week’s cover features two students from schools that are located in the Bronx but exist worlds apart.

headline: Taking Fares, and Writing in Between
text: CHICAGO — In the Arab world, the Syrian writer Osama Alomar has a growing reputation as the author of short, clever parables that comment obliquely on political and social issues. But here, where he has lived in exile since 2008, he spends most of his time as the driver of Car 45 at the Horizon Taxi Cab company.

headline: Cruelty, Class and Corruption
text: Ugly is as ugly does, and ugliness is everywhere in Anurag Kashyap’s new film, which opens the 14th-annual New York Indian Film Festival on Monday. With “Ugly,” part of last year’s Directors’ Fortnight at Cannes, Mr. Kashyap, an interesting if uneven director, delivers a damning, noirish tale about the corruption that comes after a 10-year-old girl’s kidnapping.

headline: Torch Solo, Then Jammy Time
text: A few months ago, a little girl with a big voice grew too tall to be Matilda on Broadway anymore.

headline: A Concert for Characters
text: A rat who dreams of cooking haute cuisine. A more or less silent robot in a post-apocalyptic wasteland. A grumpy old widower nursing a demented notion. These are just a few of the improbable heroes that Pixar, the animation studio, has brought to astonishing, and astonishingly profitable, life since its first full-length picture, “Toy Story,” in 1995.

headline: Hey, Jack, You’re Back! Anything New?
text: There is a Persian custom that could probably improve television.

headline: First U.S. Case of MERS Virus Is Found in Indiana Man Who Visited Mideast
text: A virus that has killed more than 100 people in the Middle East has been found in the United States for the first time, in an Indiana health care worker who recently returned from Saudi Arabia, federal health officials said on Friday.

headline: Art Bound by Its Time
text: One of the most pervasive issues in modern dance is relevance. How does a company formed in 1946 find meaning in today’s world? The Limón Dance Company, created by José Limón and Doris Humphrey, is an integral part of American dance history, yet the troupe, performing at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday, is trapped in another age.

headline: Done In by Décolletage and Defeatism
text: A beautiful woman leaves a bar and goes home with James Marsden. And that is just about the only thing that makes sense in “Walk of Shame.”

headline: Vying for Bragging Rights, Prancing Pros and Amateurs
text: As the famed house music D.J. Todd Terry was playing Thursday night, it was difficult to know what direction to look in. On one part of the floor of the Brooklyn Night Bazaar, a circle of people watched dancers working quick, smooth routines before ceding the floor. Nearby, another circle oohed and aahed over a man who made a lighted cigarette disappear and reappear in his mouth.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted April 30 and May 1 with 1,054 adults throughout the United States. Of these, 534 said they were interested in following professional basketball.

headline: New York Times/CBS News Poll
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted April 30 and May 1 with 1,054 adults throughout the United States.

headline: Sinn Fein Leader’s Time in Jail Is Extended, as Party Sees Political Motives by Police
text: LONDON — The Northern Ireland police were granted permission on Friday to keep Gerry Adams, the leader of Sinn Fein, in custody for another 48 hours for questioning about a gruesome 1972 murder. His party claimed that the police were playing politics before the local and European parliamentary elections this month.

headline: Defining an Online Phenomenon: Virtuoso or a Wedding Band Star?
text: One of the most unlikely music phenomena of recent years has been Lindsey Stirling, whose classical-meets-dance music has catapulted her to huge online popularity, with her videos having been viewed hundreds of millions of times. This week Ms. Stirling released her second album, “Shatter Me” (Lindseystomp). In an email exchange, two critics for The New York Times — Jon Caramanica, whose specialty is pop, and Zachary Woolfe, whose area is classical — discussed Ms. Stirling, her gifts and where she fits into the music world. Here are excerpts from the conversation.

headline: Oakland: Brooklyn by the Bay
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — On a recent Tuesday afternoon, a group of well-dressed and soon-to-be well-groomed men sat patiently in the sun outside Temescal Alley Barbershop waiting for $25 haircuts and $30 straight-razor shaves. Some idly pecked at their phones, while others wandered into Standard & Strange, a men’s clothing store that stocks rugged-looking American-made apparel and accessories as well as some carefully selected items from overseas like Tender jeans, which are handmade and dyed by one guy in Britain and sell for $350. (A leather belt thick enough to harness a thoroughbred, also from Tender, will set you back $240.)

headline: Norman Kay Platinum Pairs
text: DALLAS — The International Bridge Press Association hands out annual awards for excellence in bidding and play. The diagramed deal is a front-runner for the defense of the year. It occurred on the last day of the Norman Kay Platinum Pairs during the Spring North American Championships and was described by the victim, Sartaj Hans from Australia (South).

headline: Lizzy Plapinger of MS MR: The Melody Maker
text: AGE 25

headline: In the Spin Zone, Word’s Around
text: D.J. Cassidy, who might call himself the first D.J. of the United States (he played at both inaugurations for President Obama, as well as the 50th birthday parties for both of the Obamas) began his night like any music impresario: in the back of an S.U.V.

headline: With Bravado and Bravos
text: In the kitchen of a 1940s-era diner in Jersey City, the rapper known as Le1f swayed beneath ancient photos of Sylvester Stallone and Mike Tyson.

headline: Life Is Streaming Past You
text: When Beyoncé released, without warning, 17 videos around midnight on Dec. 13, millions of fans rejoiced. As a more casual listener of Ms. Knowles, I balked at the onslaught of new material and watched a few videos before throwing in the towel.

headline: The Piano, More Than a Partner in These Dances
text: Ballet companies usually like to tuck contemporary work safely between some tutus, carefully sheltering their audiences’ delicate sensibilities. Not New York City Ballet. (Hooray.) Program 3 of the Festival of 21st-Century Choreographers on Thursday was fairly austere, notable for its impressive musical range, with several scores commissioned by City Ballet.

headline: Does ‘Sperm Donor’ Mean ‘Dad’?
text: LOS ANGELES — He is a movie star who shot to fame on a motorcycle in “The Lost Boys.” She is a California massage therapist from a prominent East Coast family. Four years ago, with his sperm, her eggs and the wonder of in vitro fertilization, they produced a child.

headline: They Feel ‘Blessed’
text: Here are a few of the ways that God has touched my social network over the past few months:

headline: Subversive, but Colorfully So
text: The phantasmagorical works created by the Brazilian-born installation artist Eli Sudbrack, who goes by the acronym AVAF (for Assume Vivid Astro Focus), are dense with connections: sexual, geographic, macroeconomic, social and political.

headline: Rule 1: No ‘I Do’ via Twitter
text: After accepting her boyfriend’s marriage proposal, Sarah Nolting of Columbus, Ind., did what most modern brides do: She announced her engagement to her Facebook friends.

headline: Vatican Dialogue: ‘Man is a Technical Giant and an Ethical Child’
text: VATICAN CITY — “Birth control.”

headline: A Divided Country
text: As the separatist movement in eastern Ukraine grows, the divisions within Ukrainian society become deeper as both sides prepare for a potential confrontation.

headline: Our Lonely Home in Nature
text: THE tornadoes that have been devastating parts of the South and Midwest, just weeks after a deadly mudslide in Washington, demonstrate once again the unimaginable power of nature.

headline: At Princeton, Privilege Is: (a) Commonplace, (b) Misunderstood or (c) Frowned Upon
text: It is a familiar phrase on college campuses, often meant to serve as conversational kryptonite, the final word in an argument to which there is no response.

headline: Michigan: Retirees Agree to Cuts
text: Leaders of a group of retired Detroit workers have agreed to accept pension cuts, the latest in a series of tentative settlements secured by the city as it tries to emerge from bankruptcy this fall, officials said Friday. Directors of the Detroit Retired City Employees Association, representing nearly 8,000 municipal retirees, have agreed to cuts of 4.5 percent to retirees’ pension benefits, a likely end to cost-of-living increases and changes to health care coverage. The cuts were smaller than the city had initially proposed.

headline: Can Technology Save the World? Experts Disagree
text: In Silicon Valley, there is a sense that tech companies are doing God’s work. Software can solve the world’s biggest problems, many tech entrepreneurs believe, if only it is put to the right use.

headline: Don’t Ignore Northern Ireland’s Ghosts
text: BELFAST

headline: A Lost Boy, Trying to Find His Way
text: If you have a very good eye, you might recognize Harry Melling as the fine young actor who made such a tender Fool to Frank Langella’s King Lear at the Brooklyn Academy of Music this year. More likely, Mr. Melling looks familiar — grown-up and slimmed down though he is — for having played Dudley Dursley, Harry Potter’s beastly Muggle cousin, in the film series adapted from J. K. Rowling’s books.

headline: Accident Leads to Scrutiny of Oil Sand Production
text: CALGARY, Alberta — In the annals of oil well blowouts and pipeline disasters, the 7,400 barrels of oily slush that oozed out of the mossy bogs of the boreal forest in northeast Alberta last summer may seem like a trivial matter.

headline: Democrats Struggle to Turn Economic Gains Into Political Ones
text: WASHINGTON — April’s sharp and unexpected drop in the nation’s unemployment rate is a springtime gift to President Obama, whose sagging political fortunes could brighten if the burst of job creation holds by the midterm elections this fall.

headline: Plying Social Media, Chinese Workers Grow Bolder in Exerting Clout
text: DONGGUAN, China — The call to action, carried by social media to thousands of smartphones across this bleak factory town, roused the workers from their jobs making Nike and Adidas sneakers.

headline: A Play’s View of a Bigoted Past Holds a Mirror to a Violent Present
text: OVERLAND PARK, Kan. — Kate Haugan was standing backstage early that afternoon about three weeks ago, waiting to be fitted with a wireless microphone. In less than an hour, she and the rest of the cast members would take the stage at the Jewish Community Center here for the final performance of “To Kill a Mockingbird.”

headline: Juan Formell, 71, Cuban Dance-Band Leader, Dies
text: Juan Formell, the Cuban composer, arranger and bass player who founded the group Los Van Van and made it into one of the world’s greatest dance bands, died on Thursday. He was 71 and lived in Havana.

headline: End Corporate Taxation
text: AFTER years of post-recession somnolence, corporate takeovers and mergers have ballooned to their highest level since 2007, fueled in part by American companies’ fleeing the United States to save tax dollars.

headline: Fans Weigh In on the Donald Sterling Controversy
text: This New York Times/CBS News poll is based on nationwide interviews with 534 basketball fans conducted on landlines and cellphones from April 30 through May 1.

headline: Mixed Verdict in Apple-Samsung Patent Fight
text: SAN JOSE, Calif. — A federal jury said on Friday that Apple and Samsung had infringed on each other’s patents in some mobile devices but awarded most of the damages to Apple, in the latest court fight between the two technology giants.

headline: Teachers Question Pay-for-Performance Element in Proposed Contract
text: It is a concept sprung from the marketplace, and was long a gleam in Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s eye: offering extra pay for the city’s best public school teachers.

headline: Washington Weighs in on Campus Assaults
text: It keeps happening. One student sexually assaults another on campus. College administrators discourage the victim from opening a case against her assailant or take their time launching an investigation; meanwhile, the two keep living together in the same dorm. Eventually the victim speaks out or files a Title IX complaint and attracts national media attention. The administration pledges to improve its handling of these situations.

headline: Let Mr. Erdogan Fight His Own Battles
text: Not long ago, Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey and Fethullah Gulen, a Turkish preacher in Pennsylvania, were the best of allies. Mr. Erdogan heads an Islamist government, and Mr. Gulen promotes a moderate, pro-Western brand of Sunni Islam that appeals to many well-educated and professional Turks. The two men had a common purpose in confronting and weakening the country’s once-dominant secular military and political leadership.

headline: Long Journey to a Rivalry’s Signature Series
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — A 30-mile stretch of Interstate 5 separates the home arenas of the Anaheim Ducks and the Los Angeles Kings, but it has taken 20 years for the teams to meet in the Stanley Cup playoffs.

headline: Democratic Group to Return Donations
text: MIAMI — The Democratic National Committee, faced with the possibility that it had accepted illegal campaign contributions from straw donors, decided Thursday to return sizable donations made last fall in the names of the children of a Florida cardiologist whose lucrative medical practice has caught the attention of Medicare regulators.

headline: Marcel Van Ooyen: Helping Flowers, Herbs and Sons Grow
text: Marcel Van Ooyen is the executive director of GrowNYC, a nonprofit group that operates more than 50 greenmarkets and builds community and school gardens around the city. Previously legislative director for the City Council under former Speaker Gifford Miller, Mr. Van Ooyen, 49, lives in a brownstone in Park Slope, Brooklyn, with his wife, Cheryl, 48, an executive creative director at an advertising agency, McGarryBowen, and their two sons, Jack, 11, and Jude, 7. They have a rescue dog, Bubba. They think he is an Italian mastiff.

headline: Teenager Pleads Not Guilty in Killing on Bus
text: The 14-year-old accused of murder for firing a gun aboard a New York City bus asked investigators whom he had shot, according to court documents released on Friday.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 2, 2014
Government Nurtures Innovation
text: Jim Manzi is the founder and chairman of Applied Predictive Technologies, and one of the originators of cloud computing. He is also a well-known libertarian/conservative thinker, a senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute, and a contributing editor to the National Review. Between his tech background and his politics, he’s about the last person you’d expect to praise the historic role government has played in the critical business of innovation — or to call for that role to be stepped up in the here and now.

headline: In Surveillance Debate, White House Turns Its Focus to Silicon Valley
text: WASHINGTON — Nearly a year after the first disclosures about the National Security Agency’s surveillance practices at home and abroad, the agency is emerging with mandates to make only modest changes: some new limits on what kind of data about Americans it can hold, and White House oversight of which foreign leaders’ cellphones it can tap and when it can conduct cyberoperations against adversaries.

headline: Where Pedestrians and Bicyclists Are Injured, and Why
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s goal of eliminating pedestrians’ deaths on New York streets will have to overcome a volatile mix of harried drivers, fast-moving bikers and distracted walkers.

headline: Struck on the Street: Four Survivors
text: “Dance with me, baby,” the night nurse crooned to me. Despite the morphine-induced fog clouding my brain that first week after the accident, I understood that she meant I was to collapse into her arms. Then, holding me like a limp rag doll, she lifted me upright and held my full weight. The new perspective was dizzying, since I’d been on my back, looking up, since the cops and the medics got to me.

headline: Bidders Lining Up Lobbyists in Fight for New York Casinos
text: ALBANY — The 22 entities vying to build casinos in New York State include operators of some of the flashiest gambling palaces, from Las Vegas to Singapore. Others are mysterious paper-only creatures with no websites, no offices and not so much as a slot machine to call their own.

headline: Celebrating Sainthood and Witnessing Barbarity
text: The Catholic Church’s canonization of two of its recent popes and the grotesquely botched execution of a murderer in Oklahoma last week stood at opposite ends of the moral scale. Yet there was something about the two events — the public affirmation of a religious order in the one and the medieval barbarity of the other — that seemed to challenge the popular image of a linear march of human progress.

headline: Spit It All Out, Tour Golfers: Few Speak of Tobacco Habit
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — What crosses the lips of PGA Tour players, but makes them hold their tongues?

headline: For ‘Game of Thrones,’ Rising Unease Over Rape’s Recurring Role
text: From its very beginnings, “Game of Thrones” has been riddled with sexual brutality. The franchise, which started as a series of fantasy novels by George R. R. Martin about a bleak, feudal world, has at various times included a warrior king who claims his child bride on their wedding night, and the gang rape of a young woman by “half a hundred shouting men behind a tanner’s shop.”

headline: Death Stalks Muslims as Myanmar Cuts Off Aid
text: SITTWE, Myanmar — By the time the baby girl was brought to the makeshift pharmacy, her chest was heaving, her temperature soaring. The supply of oxygen that might have helped was now off limits, in a Doctors Without Borders clinic shut down by the government in February.

headline: George R.R. Martin on ‘Game of Thrones’ and Sexual Violence
text: The fantasy series “Game of Thrones” has set off a wide-ranging debate about rape, and whether this popular franchise — which includes  best-selling novels, a hit HBO television adaptation, a line of comic books and more — trivializes sexual violence with its frequent and often graphic depictions.

headline: Anthony Drexel Duke, 95, Dies; Scion of Wealth Aided Underprivileged
text: Anthony Drexel Duke, a scion of three of America’s wealthiest families who nearly 80 years ago was prompted by a chance encounter to found what became Boys & Girls Harbor, an educational and social service agency that has helped tens of thousands of New York’s disadvantaged children, died on Wednesday in Gainesville, Fla. He was 95.

headline: Derby Dawns for Two Sons Seeking Win Fathers Missed
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — To anyone who follows horse racing, Allen Jerkens is known as the Giant Killer. He is the Hall of Fame trainer whose horses beat the Triple Crown champion Secretariat twice and the great Kelso three times. He is a legend who is rightfully on the short list in the discussion of history’s greatest horsemen.

headline: Kid Getting Into Treble
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — This one was a tough one to get into, but sublime once gotten. Thank goodness for the comforting familiarity of Beatles lyrics. “SHE” cracked the puzzle open for me.

headline: How The Industry Fared In April
text: Overall vehicle sales in the United States rose 8 percent last month.

headline: Aboard Untapable, Jockey Napravnik Wins a Second Oaks
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — After a blunder at the starting gate unnerved the fillies and unseated a few jockeys Friday, Rosie Napravnik displayed the kind of steady nerves that allowed her to make history two years ago in the Kentucky Oaks.

headline: Assi Dayan, a Celebrated Actor and Filmmaker in Israel, Dies at 68
text: JERUSALEM — Assi Dayan, an actor, director and screenwriter who was celebrated for his contributions to Israeli film and culture and infamous for his turbulent personal life — much of it, he complained, spent in the shadow of his father, the general and statesman Moshe Dayan — died on Thursday at his home in Tel Aviv. He was 68.

headline: The Race to Beat ‘Best Before’
text: At 7:45 one recent Wednesday morning, in front of Entenmann’s Bakery Outlet on the corner of 34th Avenue and 41st Street in Astoria, Queens, five people stood in a sloppy but unmistakable line, waiting for the store to open.

headline: As Game 7 Nears, Rivers Takes Time for Workers
text: PLAYA VISTA, Calif. — As the Los Angeles Clippers players tried to forget, for a few hours, the events of the last week and focus on Game 7 of their first-round series against Golden State, Coach Doc Rivers was tending to 50 to 75 other members of the team.

headline: Marsha Mehran, Writer of Iranians’ Irish Experience, Dies at 36
text: DUBLIN — Marsha Mehran, an Iranian-born author who wrote a hugely successful debut novel centered on Iranian expatriates in Ireland, was found dead on Wednesday at her home in the village of Lecanvey in County Mayo, on Ireland’s northwest coast. She was 36.

headline: Sotheby’s Poison Pill Is Upheld by Delaware Court
text: A Delaware state court judge on Friday blocked efforts by the hedge fund mogul Daniel S. Loeb to overturn a crucial corporate defense at Sotheby’s, the auction house.

headline: Mets’ Young Game Manager Continues to Build a Rapport With His Pitchers
text: DENVER — Every moment Travis d’Arnaud slides on his catcher’s mask and squats behind home plate, he is entering a nine-inning battle and partnership with the Mets’ pitching staff.

headline: Ex-Official of Port Agency to Rebuff State Inquiry
text: The former chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey will cease cooperating with the legislative investigation into the closing of lanes to the George Washington Bridge, his lawyers said on Friday, dealing the inquiry another setback after a judge ruled that two aides did not have to comply with its subpoenas.

headline: Hobbled With Ankle Injury, Williams Carries Nets to Game 7
text: Deron Williams let out a groan late Friday while stepping onto a raised platform to conduct a postgame interview. The pain in his left ankle, which he had so effectively ignored on the court at Barclays Center, was throbbing through the joint again.

headline: Shredded, Sliced and Covered Up
text: Ordinarily, as she will tell you, Janet Goleas, the curator of the exhibition “Redacted” at the Islip Art Museum, is not much of a political animal.

headline: A Nets Reserve Recovers His Game
text: Andray Blatche is not the type to ruminate on bad games, although Game 5 was a big one. The ball had been in his hands in those final, achingly dramatic seconds, with the Nets trailing. And Blatche threw it away.

headline: An Apocalyptic Vision Unfurled
text: An urban nightmare that grows increasingly bleaker for its young heroine, “Marisol” is a dark fantasia that reflects a number of the social and spiritual troubles of the early 1990s. José Rivera wrote this grimly imaginative drama in 1992, and it is sobering to observe how some of his fiery themes still smolder with relevance in the smart production currently being presented by Luna Stage in West Orange.

headline: Virginia Senator Pledges Support for Clinton in 2016
text: Senator Tim Kaine, Democrat of Virginia and an early supporter of Barack Obama in the 2008 primaries, is expected to announce on Saturday that he is joining Ready for Hillary, a “super PAC” that is trying to build grass-roots support for a potential presidential run by Hillary Rodham Clinton in 2016.

headline: Nicholas Martin, 75, Stage Director in New York and New England, Dies
text: Nicholas Martin, a prominent director in New England regional theater who was nominated for the 2013 Tony Award for best director for his production of Christopher Durang’s farce “Vanya and Sonia and Masha and Spike,” died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 75.

headline: With Touch of Zaniness, Rangers Defeat the Penguins in Overtime
text: PITTSBURGH — Fresh off their exhilarating elimination of the Flyers in Game 7 on Wednesday, the Rangers stunned the Penguins on Friday in overtime, 3-2, on Derick Brassard’s goal at 3 minutes 6 seconds in Game 1 of the Eastern Conference playoffs.

headline: The Brady Quadroons
text: Oh, look, it’s Masha, Olga and Irinia. The first time the three sisters in Marcus Gardley’s “The House That Will Not Stand” retire together to their upstairs Louisiana bedroom, those Russian sisters may come to mind. But Mr. Gardley has not written a Chekhov drama. Those who know “The House of Bernarda Alba” may think of Angustias, Martirio and Adela. And Mr. Gardley was indeed inspired by that Spanish drama, written by Federico García Lorca in 1936. But as the new work, having its world premiere at the Yale Repertory Theater in New Haven, unfolds, the young women may seem more like Marcia, Jan and Cindy.

headline: Mets’ Streak of Quality Starts Is Disappearing Into Thin Air at Coors Field
text: DENVER — The Mets and their starting pitchers began the season with a franchise-record 26 consecutive starts of five or more innings. However, for the second consecutive game, the Mets failed to receive a quality start as the Colorado Rockies erupted for six runs in the first two innings and went on to a 10-3 victory on Friday night.

headline: What’s On Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (HBO) WE’RE THE MILLERS (2013) A drug dealer (Jason Sudeikis) in trouble with his boss (Ed Helms) recruits a stripper (Jennifer Aniston) and a couple of street urchins (Will Poulter and Emma Roberts, above, with Mr. Sudeikis and Ms. Aniston) to impersonate an all-American family known as the Millers. Their mission: to transport a few tons of marijuana from Mexico to Denver in their camper. And in no time at all, they’re caring about one another more than they want to admit. “ ‘We’re the Millers,’ a loose, halfheartedly raunchy, occasionally hilarious new comedy, is about a lot of different things; it’s the usual grab bag of jokes about drugs and body parts,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “But what really drives the movie is its own search for something to make fun of, and for a comic style that can feel credibly naughty while remaining ultimately safe and affirmative.” Nick Offerman and Kathryn Hahn play the Fitzgeralds, R.V. enthusiasts with a teenage daughter who “are beyond square, which is to say that they are stranger, kinkier and more interestingly individual” than the Millers — and funnier as actors, too — Mr. Scott added. “A movie about the Fitzgeralds would have been more rewarding than ‘We’re the Millers,’ and also much riskier.”

headline: Seasonal Dishes, and Romance, in a Castle
text: Born too late, our country is short on castles. Nineteenth-century wealth on the East Coast built instead many Victorian Gothic mansions, some of them on the breezy, wooded land of the Hudson Valley. In Westchester a few still stand, like Lyndhurst and Glenview.

headline: A Milestone for Girardi in a Game With a Bit of Everything
text: Entering Friday, only five managers in the 114 seasons of the Yankees franchise had accumulated at least 1,000 games on the bench. Despite all their success, the Yankees have also employed managers who were either not good enough to last very long, or simply had fallen in the way of a cantankerous and impatient owner like George Steinbrenner, who would fire someone at the slightest hint of failure.

headline: Corrections: May 3, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Efrem Zimbalist Jr., Star of ‘77 Sunset Strip’ and ‘The F.B.I.’, Dies at 95
text: Efrem Zimbalist Jr., an actor whose mellifluous voice and air of European sophistication left a distinctive stamp on two popular television crime series, died on Friday at his ranch in Solvang, Calif. He was 95.

headline: 20 Are Held and Curfew Is Imposed After Attacks on Muslims in India
text: NEW DELHI — The police said Saturday that they had arrested 20 people suspected of being associated with attacks that left at least 29 Muslims dead in western villages in the northeastern Indian state of Assam, where tensions between members of the Bodo tribal group and non-Bodo residents, including Muslims, have been simmering for years.

headline: ‘No Hope’ for Those Buried by Mudslide, Afghanistan Official Says
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A day after landslides buried much of a village in northeastern Afghanistan, local officials said they feared that more than 2,000 people were dead, entombed in a blanket of earth nearly 30 feet deep.

headline: Analytics: Is Doomsday Coming?
text: The following Analytics appears on the letters page in the May 4 issue of the magazine.

headline: Ukraine Presses Pro-Russia Militants After Fighting Spreads to a Port City
text: KIEV, Ukraine — Ukraine’s security forces pressed their assault to try to reclaim the pro-Russian stronghold of Slovyansk on Saturday, even as the rebels freed seven European military observers and the Kremlin cited the deaths of dozens of people in Odessa as proof that Ukraine could no longer protect its citizens.

headline: Valuable Humans in Our Digital Future
text: In the spirit of college commencements, here is some advice to the class of 2014: Be human. It pays.

headline: Celebrity Rich, Cash Poor
text: Teri Polo, a B-list star, filed for bankruptcy last month. In doing so, she became the latest in a long list of celebrities who went from fame to financial ruin. Here are six in the celebrity bankruptcy hall of fame.

headline: Berkshire Hathaway’s 2014 Shareholder Meeting
text: OMAHA — Thousands of shareholders flocked to listen to Warren E. Buffett at Berkshire Hathaway’s annual meeting at the CenturyLink Center in Omaha, and DealBook had live reports throughout the day.

headline: Media Slant: A Question of Cause and Effect
text: Consumers of the news, both from television and print, sometimes feel that they are getting not just the facts but also a sizable dose of ideological spin. Yet have you ever wondered about the root cause of the varying political slants of different media outlets?

headline: Video Notebook: Nets Win Game 6
text: Kevin Garnett talks about Deron Williams’s play against the Raptors and what the victory meant for the Nets.

headline: Video Notebook: Andray Blatche on Game 6
text: Andray Blatche discusses the Nets’ strong start in the first half Friday night against the Raptors.

headline: Teacher and Student Meet Again on the Ice, as Foes
text: PITTSBURGH — Brad Richards helped teach Sidney Crosby to play hockey. That may seem hard to believe as they line up across from each other in the Stanley Cup playoffs, but they said it was true.

headline: Variety: A Tactile Acrostic
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — Today’s quote is from a fascinating look into the world of synesthesia, a neurological condition that involves a blending of sensations that are normally experienced separately. Some synesthetes, for example, report that they experience numbers as “colors, shapes or motions,” as the author of “Born on a Blue Day” confirms.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s Money Talking: May 1, 2014
text: New York-based pharmaceutical giant Pfizer revealed a multi-billion dollar offer to acquire British rival AstraZeneca, and if the acquisition is successful, Pfizer plans to reincorporate in the United Kingdom. Doing so would lower the company’s tax rate by 7 percent and allow it to avoid paying U.S. taxes on profits made overseas. This week on Money Talking, Rana Foroohar and Joe Nocera discuss whether Pfizer could inspire other U.S.-based, international companies to pursue a similar path.

headline: Condoleezza Rice Backs Out of Rutgers Speech After Student Protests
text: Former Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, who had been invited to give the commencement address at Rutgers University in New Jersey this month, said on Saturday that she would no longer give the speech. Her announcement came after weeks of protests by some students and faculty members over the university’s decision to invite her.

headline: The Flavor of a Family Business
text: Eric Bassett , 20, works for  Bassetts Ice Cream, at the Reading Terminal Market in Philadelphia. Bassetts also distributes its products in the Philadelphia area and other markets.

headline: Pondering Whether to Make Amends
text: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

headline: Guantánamo Prosecutor Fights Handing Secrets Over to Defense
text: WASHINGTON — The chief prosecutor at the Guantánamo Bay war-crimes court has asked a judge to set aside an order that requires the government to give defense lawyers sweeping amounts of classified details related to the Central Intelligence Agency’s treatment of Abd al-Rahim al-Nashiri, a Saudi detainee accused of orchestrating the 2000 bombing of the destroyer Cole.

headline: A Path to Retirement, for Those Far From It
text: There is a big retirement problem in America, maybe even a crisis. Many working people won’t have enough money to leave their jobs and live in comfort and security. How many are in jeopardy is debatable, but the problem’s existence is not.

headline: Paying a Premium to Cross the Pond
text: Why does it cost so much more to fly from New York to London than from New York to Los Angeles? Sure, the distance across the Atlantic Ocean is about 3,500 air miles, about 40 percent farther than going to the West Coast. But it costs three to four times as much.

headline: Learning to Love Bikers
text: THIRTY-TWO THOUSAND bicyclists are expected to ride in the annual Five Boro Bike Tour in New York City this morning. About half the registrants are from out of state and won’t be familiar with riding in the city. They’ll be getting their dose of it on its best day, when cyclists seize thoroughfares like Avenue of the Americas and the Belt Parkway from quotidian traffic terrors like the garbage truck and the wide-turning bus.

headline: A Whole New Chapter for a Writing Pitcher
text: The Houston Astros practice victory celebrations every spring training. It may seem like a futile exercise for a struggling team, but Bo Porter, the manager, wants to establish a winning mind-set.

headline: Where a Desk Just Gets in the Way
text: Urban rescue

headline: Nets’ Fate May Rest With Backcourt
text: Heading into a Game 7 in Toronto on Sunday, the Nets should feel about as good as any team can before a winner-take-all matchup on the road. The Nets and the Raptors may have won the same number of games, but the Nets have controlled most of their first-round N.B.A. playoff series.

headline: Six Seconds of Loopy Creativity, and Millions of Fans
text: When Twitter last year introduced Vine, a slick app that lets people shoot and share short videos, I did what I always do when a buzzy, high-profile service makes its debut: I immediately downloaded it and started playing.

headline: Countdown to the 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 40
text: After he sustained a knee injury last November, the German news media all but ruled out Sami Khedira from being fit for next month’s World Cup in Brazil. Thing is someone apparently forgot to inform Sami Khedira.

headline: With Many Gaps to Fill, Giants Pose a First-Round Draft Mystery
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Since last year’s N.F.L. draft, the Giants suffered through a humiliating 0-6 start to the 2013 season, missed the playoffs, lost their starting running back to a serious neck injury and watched as a big-name receiver and two of the team’s most productive defensive linemen left via free agency.

headline: The Great Unwatched
text: Some of the biggest names in Internet media have been gathering in New York City at the third annual Digital Content NewFronts, a pitch-a-thon where companies like Yahoo, AOL and Crackle — and, yes, The New York Times — trumpet their digital platforms to brands eager to reach consumers via online video ads.

headline: Loans That Avoid Banks? Maybe Not
text: It was that rare thing, scarcely seen in the financial world since the debut of the A.T.M. or microfinancing: an innovation to help regular people. When peer-to-peer, or P2P, lending began in the middle of the last decade, it offered an easy way for people to lend money to each other over the Internet.

headline: Calm in the N.B.A. After the Sterling Storm
text: By the weekend, the elation surrounding the lifetime ban issued Tuesday to the Los Angeles Clippers’ owner, Donald Sterling, had given way to pragmatism.

headline: At Bank of America, a $4 Billion Wet Blanket on the Party
text: If you’re a bank executive, it’s never going to be easy to tell your shareholders: Oops, we made a $4 billion mistake!

headline: Ron Kaplan of Trex, on Making Judgments Instead of Decisions
text: This interview with  Ron Kaplan, chief executive of Trex, a manufacturer of outdoor decks, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, May 3
text: “I knew we could do this. Every week I got more and more confident, even through the toughest of times.”

headline: Behind the Masks in Ukraine, Many Faces of Rebellion
text: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine — The rebel leader spread a topographic map in front of a closed grocery store here as a Ukrainian military helicopter flew past a nearby hill. Ukrainian troops had just seized positions along a river, about a mile and a half away. The commander thought they might advance.

headline: ‘Dripping’ and E-Cigarettes
text: Trey Hudson of Oklahoma City, Okla., demonstrates how he drips nicotine solution onto the heating element of his tank-system e-cigarette.

headline: Safety Sometimes Prevails Over Accuracy in Calling the First Out of a Double Play
text: Runner on first, one out. Ground ball to the second baseman. He flips the ball to the shortstop, who seamlessly catches it, leaps above the sliding runner and fires to first base for a double play.

headline: Some E-Cigarettes Deliver a Puff of Carcinogens
text: Electronic cigarettes appear to be safer than ordinary cigarettes for one simple — and simply obvious — reason: people don’t light up and smoke them.

headline: For Florida Grapefruit, One Blow After Another
text: VERO BEACH, Fla. — In the nearly 100 years that Rusty Banack’s family has been growing Florida’s world-famous grapefruit, the industry has lurched from years of bumper crops to the devastation of tree-toppling hurricanes.

headline: China Upends the Global Economy
text: Uncle Sam faces a new heavyweight.

headline: After a Few Stumbles, the Blackhawks Regain a Champion’s Swagger
text: CHICAGO — There was a championship parade for the Blackhawks in June through the streets of downtown Chicago. By October, as this season began, there was talk of a dynasty. Then came a 20-4-4 start followed by the selection of 10 Blackhawks from five countries for the Sochi Olympics in February. No other N.H.L. team sent more players.

headline: Race and Politics in Oklahoma
text: If he can earn the Republican nomination in Oklahoma’s June primary, T.W. Shannon could be the second enrolled Native American elected to the United States Senate in nearly 100 years.

headline: Behind the Masks of Pro-Russian Militants in Ukraine
text: A deeper look at one group of rebels in eastern Ukraine offers a murky picture of their aims, motivations and connections.

headline: N.B.A.’s Coveted Trait: Well-Tuned Ears
text: It’s no secret that rap and the N.B.A. have a long history, from Shaq and the Fu-Schnickens to Iman Shumpert rapping Migos’ street hit “Versace” to Drake and Jay Z sitting courtside with team owners.

headline: G.O.P. Hopeful Finds Tribal Tie Cuts Both Ways
text: BARTLESVILLE, Okla. — T. W. Shannon will be Oklahoma’s first black senator if he wins the Republican nomination and is elected this November, but the quiet campaign stirring here about Mr. Shannon’s racial loyalties is not aimed at the African-American branch of his family tree.

headline: Falling Behind in N.H.L. Playoffs Is No Reason to Lose Hope
text: The Stanley Cup playoffs’ wild first round was a reminder of just how improbable hockey can be. San Jose trounced Los Angeles in their first three games, and then the Kings trounced the Sharks in the last four. The Pittsburgh Penguins advanced, even though Sidney Crosby did not score a goal. The Rangers extended their 12-game losing streak while holding a series lead, but then won their fourth straight Game 7.

headline: Gardening for Climate Change
text: COLUMBIA, S.C. — THIS past winter was a tough one in our backyard. Where we live, about a hundred miles inland from the South Carolina coast, winter is normally a good time to make changes, like the swath of turf I removed from our front yard this year and replaced with perennial flowers and small tufts of native grass. But what is normal now in the garden? One week I’m sweating, the bees are buzzing, buds are breaking; the next, the birdbath is frozen and there’s snow on the ground.

headline: English Class With Mr. Roth
text: MALVERN, Pa. — DO you want to know what it was like to have Philip Roth as a professor?

headline: Energy Incentives
text: Readers discuss an editorial criticizing efforts to impose surcharges on solar installations.

headline: Going Mobile
text: Few stereotypes are as well entrenched — and wrongheaded — as the perception of mobile homes as the marginal housing choice of the destitute and downtrodden.

headline: Why People Don’t Donate Their Kidneys
text: WASHINGTON — THE national transplant list just passed a morbid milestone: More than 100,000 people now wait for kidneys.

headline: Do Our Kids Get Off Too Easy?
text: THE conventional wisdom these days is that kids come by everything too easily — stickers, praise, A’s, trophies. It’s outrageous, we’re told, that all kids on the field may get a thanks-for-playing token, in contrast to the good old days, when recognition was reserved for the conquering heroes.

headline: Beyond the Damaged Brain
text: UNTIL the past few decades, neuroscientists really had only one way to study the human brain: Wait for strokes or some other disaster to strike people, and if the victims pulled through, determine how their minds worked differently afterward. Depending on what part of the brain suffered, strange things might happen. Parents couldn’t recognize their children. Normal people became pathological liars. Some people lost the ability to speak — but could sing just fine.

headline: President Obama and the World
text: Two years after winning an election in which foreign policy was barely mentioned, President Obama is being pummeled at home and abroad for his international leadership. The world sometimes seems as if it is flying apart, with Mr. Obama unable to fix it. Through a combination of a few significant missteps, circumstances beyond his control, unreasonable expectations and his maddeningly bland demeanor, Mr. Obama has opened himself to criticism that he is not articulating a strong, overarching blueprint for the exercise of American power and has not been able to bend authoritarian leaders to his will.

headline: When Sources Set the Ground Rules
text: SOMETIMES a single sentence can be a window into a world.

headline: Gary Beauchamp
text: Gary Beauchamp is a biopsychologist and the director of the Monell Chemical Senses Center in Philadelphia, which is a nonprofit scientific institute dedicated to basic research on the senses of taste and smell.

headline: Clear Rules Eyed on Church Sex Abuse
text: VATICAN CITY — The Vatican commission advising Pope Francis on sexual abuse policy will develop “clear and effective protocols” to protect children from pedophile priests, including procedures to hold church authorities accountable if they neglect to act on cases of abuse, Vatican officials said Saturday.

headline: America the Shrunken
text: NOT long ago I asked a good friend of mine — one of the smartest men I know, and one of the most devoted dads — if he thought that his children would live in a more prosperous America or at least enjoy the same bounty of opportunities that we had.

headline: It’s Not Just About Obama
text: THERE has been a festival of commentary of late bemoaning the pusillanimous foreign policy of President Obama. If only we had a president who rode horses shirtless, wrestled a tiger or took a bite out of a neighboring country, we’d all feel much safer. Your Honor, I rise in — partial — defense of Mr. Obama.

headline: 42 and 45 Overpower 44
text: WASHINGTON — THE First Family is all over the news, discussing the management of the economy, income inequality, raising the minimum wage, the vicissitudes of press coverage and the benefits of healthy eating.

headline: College, the Great Unequalizer
text: NO doubt by now you’ve finished last month’s assigned reading, Thomas Piketty’s “Capital in the Twenty-First Century,” for our spring-semester course on Stratification in America. I’m sorry about the length (and the Amazon back-order problem), but I’m sure that the 696 pages of inheritance-data analysis and Émile Zola references flew by. And the good news is that you don’t need to worry about the term paper, because my fellow Elite Media Pundits and I have written about 330,000 words on the book that you can just crib, copy and repurpose.

headline: ‘Bring Back Our Girls’
text: DOZENS of heavily armed terrorists rolled into the sleepy little town one night in a convoy of trucks, buses and vans. They made their way to the girls’ boarding school.

headline: In Spite of the Law, Afghan ‘Honor Killings’ of Women Continue
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — An 18-year-old runaway named Amina agreed two weeks ago to leave the women’s shelter in which she had taken refuge in northern Afghanistan and go home with her brother and her uncle.

headline: Out of Print, if Not Off Clock
text: I have been bracing myself for this news for some time. Despite considerable evidence to the contrary, Mel Kiper Jr., ESPN’s lead N.F.L. draft expert, is, after all, only human. Kiper has produced his N.F.L. draft report since 1979, and I always knew that at some point, he would type his last word, hit send and that would be that.

text: To the Sports Editor:

text: Officials were expected to designate the site, in earth nearly 30 feet deep, a mass grave.

headline: Students and Data Privacy
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, May 4
text: An email released this week put the spotlight once again on the 2012 attack in Benghazi, Libya, showing that the White House wanted to shape the way Susan E. Rice, then the ambassador to the United Nations, would discuss the violence. In response, House Republicans announced plans to form a committee to examine whether the Obama administration misled Congress about the attack.

headline: Fairways From the Air
text: ABOARD SNOOPY ONE, above Charlotte, N.C. — Like scores of other golf spectators at a PGA Tour event, Andrew Murray chooses where to position himself by consulting a course map. By the end of the week, his legs are leaden from the effort of tracking the leaders.

headline: Partial Service Resumes After Subway Derailment in Queens
text: Partial service was temporarily restored to subway lines running along Queens Boulevard on Saturday afternoon, a day after 19 people were injured in the worst derailment in the New York City subway system in over two decades.

headline: Study Reveals Sizable Increase in Diabetes Among Children
text: For years doctors have warned of a rising epidemic of diabetes among children. Yet there has been surprisingly little firm data on the extent of this disease among younger Americans.

headline: Standing with the Kidnapped Girls in Nigeria
text: My Sunday column is about the girls kidnapped from their school in northeastern NIgeria nearly three weeks ago. I wrote the column partly to apply more pressure on the Nigerian authorities, who seem uninterested in the case, to try to rescue these girls, and partly because I’m offended by the contrast between the global media focus on the missing MH370 flight and the uninterest in the even greater number of missing schoolgirls in Nigeria. It’s also important to note that what’s at stake isn’t just these girls: If they’re not recovered soon, then no parents are going to send girls or boys to school in the area again. And the area, where as it is only half of adults are literate, will slide into greater illiteracy, economic difficulty and backwardness. Education isn’t just about building schools, it’s also about ensuring security so that parents feel safe sending their children to school.

headline: Islamic Jihad on Defending Gaza
text: Abu Malek, 25, the commander of a band of Al-Quds Brigades — the armed wing of Islamic Jihad — discusses his troops’ readiness to respond to any Israeli incursions.

headline: Islamic Jihad Gains New Traction in Gaza
text: GAZA — Shortly before midnight, seven black-masked young men in camouflage stood in a field of waist-high weeds, Kalashnikov rifles pointed toward the Mediterranean Sea a half-mile away.

headline: A Predecessor of Hamas Asserts Itself
text: Islamic Jihad has long shunned electoral politics to focus on military resistance against the Israeli occupation, and it has gained the support of Gaza residents.

headline: A Clinton In-Law Seeks Office, but Where Are the Clintons?
text: To hear Marjorie Margolies tell it, she essentially gave up her seat in Congress to cast a tiebreaking vote that saved President Bill Clinton’s 1993 budget. But it is unclear whether the Clintons will be able to save her as she tries to win it back some 20 years later.

headline: Game 7s Abound in the First Round of N.B.A. Playoffs
text: When the Nets step onto the court to face the Raptors on Sunday in Toronto, they will be taking part in one of five Game 7s during the opening round of the N.B.A. postseason.

headline: Fight Against Sexual Assaults Holds Colleges to Account
text: Emma Sulkowicz said she knew it would be awful to go before a disciplinary panel and describe being raped by a fellow student, but nothing prepared her for what came next. She said one of the two women on the panel, a university official, asked her, repeatedly, how the painful sex act she described was physically possible.

headline: Highlights and Analysis: California Chrome Wins the Kentucky Derby
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — California Chrome, the speedy colt who established himself as the 5-2 morning-line favorite after winning four straight races by a combined 24 1/4 lengths, blew away the field in the 140th running of the Kentucky Derby on Saturday under blue skies and 70-degree weather at Churchill Downs.

headline: At Peace With a Certain Level of Renown
text: Smiling serenely and speaking in modulated tones, Anthony Newman looked back without anger at his life’s course. The keyboardist and composer, who will be 73 on May 12, did not dwell on how his vibrant readings of early music, once criticized in certain quarters, were now widely copied. Nor did he ponder how fame — the recording mogul Clive Davis once enlisted him to bring Bach to the counterculture masses — in the end proved a bit of a mirage.

headline: Groggy Yankees Lean on Tanaka Until Their Offense Ends Its Slumber
text: When Masahiro Tanaka left Yankee Stadium in the second inning of Friday night’s game, he could not have known how important his job would be Saturday.

headline: A Barnlike Haven for Meat Lovers
text: The South Shore BBQ Company looks just as it should: a casual place with wood-plank and brick walls, sturdy wooden chairs and bare wooden tables holding rolls of paper towels and squeeze bottles of assorted barbecue sauces. The barnlike spot, which opened in Patchogue in March, also resembles the sports bar it replaced. A big U-shape bar with 28 stools and 16 overhead TV screens dominates the restaurant.

headline: Joined Sides
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Hands up if you’ve ever had a RAMOS gin fizz. Neither have I. I’ve had a sloe gin fizz, which also fits, not that I’m bitter. I’m not sure I’d want to try a RAMOS gin fizz because the recipe calls for an egg white, which I typically eschew in my adult beverages for the slime factor. In my head, eggs belong on a plate, fizzes belong in a glass. And no, I’m not a nog drinker either.

headline: Call of Nature Becomes a Call to Arms in Hong Kong
text: HONG KONG — A mainland couple’s decision to let their child urinate in public last month set off a video-recorded tussle on a street here, igniting a social media uproar that became a proxy battle for a larger question: Is Hong Kong, a former British colony, now being colonized by mainland China, whose visitors increasingly flood the territory with their money and alien manners as Beijing seeks to impose its political control?

headline: Lebanese Comfort Food on a Budget
text: Kibberia Restaurant and Cafe opened in Westport in late August 2013. This modest Lebanese place, more of a cafe than a restaurant, fills a need for falafel, hummus, kibbe (the ground meat and bulgur wheat patty from which the cafe derives its name), kebabs and other Mediterranean and Middle Eastern favorites — all while keeping prices low enough to entice families on a budget.

headline: Coming From Humble Beginnings, a Favorite Defies the Odds
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — There are few rules in racing, but one that is considered inviolable is never to turn down a suitcase full of cash. Steve Coburn and Perry Martin understood that, but two months ago, when one of the sport’s far wealthier owners offered them $6 million for 51 percent of the first horse they had bred, the offer just did not sit well.

headline: Embrace of Atheism Put an Indonesian in Prison
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Growing up in a conservative Muslim household in rural West Sumatra, Alexander Aan hid a dark secret beginning at age 9: He did not believe in God. His feelings only hardened as he got older and he faked his way through daily prayers, Islamic holidays and the fasting month of Ramadan.

headline: Dumplings to Sip From
text: You’ve got to be looking for Shanghai Bun to find the place, set unobtrusively in the far corner of a modest strip mall in spitting distance of New Jersey Transit’s Princeton Junction station — unless you are in the market for bath fixtures, and stumble upon it. In that case, lucky you.

headline: Winter Survivor, Sunbathing
text: The dark maroon wings of the mourning cloak butterfly match the vast and subtle browns of the early spring woods. Velvety and saturated with color, the wings are bordered with a warm yellow band and dotted with a row of unexpected iridescent blue spots. This butterfly is both handsome and cryptic; while resting or feeding, it folds its wings to create a gray, ragged-edged silhouette — the perfect imitation of a dead leaf.

headline: In Azerbaijan, Carlsen Wins When It Counts
text: In winning the Shamkir 2014 chess tournament in Azerbaijan, Magnus Carlsen was able to exact revenge in the last round against Fabiano Caruana, one of two players who defeated him earlier in the event.

headline: On Top at the Derby
text: At the Kentucky Derby, outrageous hats are as much of an attraction as the horses.

headline: Gerald Guralnik, a ‘God Particle’ Pioneer, Dies at 77
text: Gerald Guralnik, one of six pioneering physicists who in the 1960s came up with a theory that nearly 50 years later would lead to the discovery of a subatomic particle that helped explain a perennial mystery about the universe — why it contains life and diversity — died on April 26 in Providence, R.I. He was 77.

headline: Rabbi Myer Kripke, Early Buffett Friend and Investor, Dies at 100
text: When they were younger men, Rabbi Myer Kripke and Warren E. Buffett belonged to the same Rotary Club and lived a few blocks from each other in the Happy Hollow neighborhood of Omaha. They played bridge together with their wives. The Buffetts would invite the Kripkes over for Thanksgiving.

headline: When Hitting ‘Find My iPhone’ Takes You to a Thief’s Doorstep
text: WEST COVINA, Calif. — After a boozy Saturday night, Sarah Maguire awoke the next morning to find that her iPhone was gone. Her roommate’s phone was gone, too. Were they at the bar, she wondered, or in the cab?

headline: Video Notebook: Game 7 for Nets-Raptors
text: Alan Anderson talks about the expectations of the Nets playing the Raptors in Toronto for Game 7.

headline: At Berkshire Annual Meeting, Questions for Buffett About Coca-Cola and Deals
text: OMAHA – Every spring without fail, tens of thousands of investors flock to Berkshire Hathaway‘s annual meeting here, hoping to ask just one question of its famed chief executive, Warren E. Buffett.

headline: In Cases of Smuggled Cellphones, Few Prosecutions
text: Armed with shovels, corrections officers at a prison in East Texas last summer unearthed a cache of hundreds of smuggled items, including 45 cellphones and 52 chargers. Nearly a year later, no arrests have been made in the elaborate trafficking attempt.

headline: Rangers, Stuck in 0-for-25 Drought on Power Play, Consider Lineup Changes
text: PITTSBURGH — Although a productive power play is not mandatory for victory in the playoffs, it certainly helps. With that in mind, Rangers Coach Alain Vigneault said Saturday that he might change the personnel on the team’s lackluster power play despite a Game 1 win over the Penguins.

headline: Music Shift Fuels Effort to Preserve a Tradition
text: One recent Sunday afternoon, Dale Watson, the Austin country singer and guitarist with a signature white pompadour, zipped along winding wooded roads near Dripping Springs in his 2012 Mini Cooper.

headline: For Legislators, Race Correlates to Party, Mostly
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: Dominant Stretch and Touch of Bravado Bring Mickelson Close to Ending Drought
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Phil Mickelson and his caddie, Jim Mackay, have a telepathy that comes from having spent 22 years — nearly half their lives — working together. So Mackay assumed he and Mickelson were thinking 6-iron Saturday for a downwind, 216-yard tee shot on the par-3 13th during the third round of the Wells Fargo Championship at Quail Hollow Club.

headline: Some Time Away Helps the Old Teixeira Return
text: When Mark Teixeira squarely makes contact, his swing appears tight and compact, and it often sends the ball high and far. He looks like the old Teixeira and not like an old Teixeira.

headline: Easily Dismissed, Democrat Who Criticizes Obama Runs On
text: Addressing a group of veterans recently in El Paso, David Alameel spoke like a candidate with only one opponent: United States Senator John Cornyn, Republican of Texas. It was only after Mr. Alameel was asked about Kesha Rogers, his opponent in the May 27 Democratic primary runoff, that he spoke directly about her.

headline: Scenes From the Finish Line
text: The race favorite California Chrome won the 140th Kentucky Derby on Saturday. He is the fifth California-bred winner of horse racing’s most prestigious event.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 3, 2014
Hibbert Goes From Scoreless to Relentless, Helping Pacers Win Game 7
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Roy Hibbert wanted the ball early in Game 7. Hibbert camped out in the post, his arms in the air to signal to his teammates. Then he yelled at them for the ball, and they obliged.

headline: Coors Field Lifts the Rockies’ Already Potent Lineup
text: DENVER — Opposing pitchers have always dreaded, in some cases even feared, taking to the mound at 5,280 feet above sea level at Colorado’s Coors Field.

headline: ‘Orphan Black’ Recap: Please, Let’s Not Imagine the Worst
text: For this week’s recap of “Orphan Black” on BBC America, let’s fast forward to the last part of the episode, where, in a fairly disturbing scene, a drugged Helena (Tatiana Maslany) is an unwilling participant in a marriage ceremony with Henrik (Peter Outerbridge), the leader of the Proletheans. After the two characters are joined in matrimony, Henrik carries Helena over the threshold to an unknown room, with the tone of the scene strongly suggesting she is about to be raped or violated in some way.

headline: Teenager Who Fell Asleep on Subway With Gun Visible Is Arrested, Police Say
text: A teenager was arrested on Saturday morning after a woman saw him holding a handgun while asleep on a subway train in the Times Square station, the police said.

headline: Derby Winner Gives Co-Owner a Birthday Gift to Remember
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Steve Coburn’s co-workers held an early birthday party for him a week ago. There was pizza and a cake, which bore the words “Happy Birthday” as well as “California Chrome, 2014 Kentucky Derby.”

headline: League Is Set to Appoint a C.E.O. for the Clippers

text: The jockey Victor Espinoza rode the favorite to a convincing victory on Saturday in the 140th Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs.

headline: Comedian in Chief’s New Punch Line: Obamacare

text: Georgia Kelly Faircloth and Nicholas Beale Webb were married Saturday evening at the Yale Club of New York City. Judge William J. Corbett, who retired as the acting village justice of Floral Park, N.Y., officiated.

text: Christopher Bengt Kissel and Donald Patrick Nienas Jr. were married Saturday at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Eric Benn, a friend of the couple and a Universal Life minister, officiated.

Jim DeKornfeld, a Universal Brotherhood minister, officiated at the Green Boundary Club, a private dining club in Aiken.

text: Brigid Julia Ryan and Jyoti Bhasker Chowdhury were married Wednesday at the Superior Court of the District of Columbia. Avrom D. Sickel, the director of the Family Court Operations Division in Washington, officiated.

text: Lillie Ashton Werner, a daughter of Marie A. Friend and Peter H. Werner, both of Los Angeles, was married Saturday to Dr. Arun Sayram Singh, the son of Haymwantee P. Singh and Seeram Singh of Sayreville, N.J. Pandit Harry Persaud, a Hindu priest, officiated at the Newhall Mansion in Piru, Calif.
