headline: The Long Hello
text: Sophie Dora Waskow and Drew Harris Rifkin were married Saturday evening at City Winery in Manhattan. Rabbi Bruce Elder officiated.

headline: A Ninth-Inning Blast Trumps the Mets’ Powerful Night
text: DENVER —  After two lifeless losses to open their four-game series against the Colorado Rockies, the Mets endured their most deflating defeat this weekend at Coors Field, watching a 6-0 lead turn into an 8-6 deficit and two late rallies go for naught as pinch-hitter Charlie Culberson hit a two-run homer in the bottom of the ninth to give the Rockies an 11-10 victory Saturday night.

headline: Corrections: May 4, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Mayweather, Bloodied but Still Unbeaten, Defeats Maidana by Decision
text: LAS VEGAS — Floyd Mayweather Jr. has made such an art of dominance that anything less is quite puzzling. And his opponent Saturday night was not expected to challenge that mastery.

headline: Sometimes, the Video Doesn’t Have to Go Viral
text: In the early days of my company, RJMetrics, we didn’t have much to stand on: no funding, a fledgling product, and about 50 square feet of space in my attic. So we did what any self-respecting Internet start-up would do: We made a rap video.

headline: In Our Pages: May 5
text: 1914: Suffragette Hacks Academy Picture

headline: Reasons for Hope While Applying to College
text: The bad news for students applying to selective colleges is that getting accepted to any one of them really is harder than it used to be. Many colleges have reduced the number of American teenagers they accept (in order to globalize their student bodies) at the same time that the American teenage population is growing, as I wrote last week.

headline: As Traffic Deaths Fall, Pedestrian Deaths Do Not
text: The decline in vehicle-accident deaths in recent years has been nothing short of remarkable. But there is one disturbing exception to the trend: pedestrian deaths.

headline: Lackeys of Youth Soccer, That ‘Arrogant’ Sport
text: The edict from my daughter’s soccer team manager arrived Monday morning: A state cup match had been rescheduled for 2 p.m. Sunday in Vancouver, Wash., a two-and-a-half hour drive from our home in Seattle. Families were expected to travel and check into a hotel Saturday night. Players were required to appear at a breakfast and pregame strategy session with the coach at 9 a.m. on Sunday.

headline: Incumbent’s Party Loses Presidency in Panama
text: MEXICO CITY — Panamanians, enjoying one of the fastest-growing economies in the hemisphere but wary of corruption and growing executive power, rejected the governing party’s choice for president on Sunday — on a ticket with the president’s wife for vice president — and instead hewed to tradition by electing an opposition candidate.

headline: Devices That Know How We Really Feel
text: Admit it: Sometimes you just want to punch your PC, or slap your smartphone, or knock your notebook.

headline: Clippers Regroup After Tough Series and Off-Court Maelstrom
text: LOS ANGELES — The buzzer had not sounded. There was still two seconds left, but the Golden State Warriors needed more than one basket, so Los Angeles Clippers Coach Doc Rivers finally let loose. He stood near midcourt and shook his fists. He waved his arms. He smiled.

headline: Obama Jokes at Correspondents’ Dinner
text: President Obama joked about the Healthcare.gov rollout and Republican praise of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in his comments at the White House Correspondents’ Association dinner Saturday.

headline: Bloomberg Gains 2 Veteran Political Journalists
text: John Heilemann and Mark Halperin, political journalists known for their detailed, gossip-filled books on the past two presidential campaigns, will join Bloomberg in the coming days to start a new site that will focus on American politics and policy.

headline: U.S. Urges Congo Leader Not to Run for Third Term
text: KINSHASA, Democratic Republic of Congo — Secretary of State John Kerry on Sunday publicly urged the president of the Democratic Republic of Congo to respect his nation’s Constitution and not run for another term in 2016.

headline: What’s On Sunday
text: 9 P.M. (Discovery) EVEREST AVALANCHE TRAGEDY On April 18 an NBC News team waited at the base camp on Mount Everest as it prepared to produce “Everest Jump Live,” a special about the climber Joby Ogwyn’s attempt to make the first wing-suit flight off the 29,029-foot summit of the world’s tallest mountain. That morning an avalanche struck the Khumbu Icefall, killing 13 Sherpa guides and leaving three missing — the highest death toll in a single day in the mountain’s history. This documentary covers the weeks leading up to the tragedy and the subsequent rescue and recovery efforts through real-time film footage and witness accounts. Among those interviewed are Mr. Ogwyn, above; Garrett Madison, the expedition leader; and Todd Burleson, the president of Alpine Ascents International, which lost five guides. It also pays tribute to the Sherpas and their families; the network will make a contribution to the American Himalayan Foundation’s Sherpa Family Fund, from which all donations will flow to relatives of the deceased. In “Bear Grylls: Man vs. Everest,” leading in at 8, Mr. Grylls presents stories of the greatest Everest attempts, using archival footage and interviews with climbers and support crews. In “Bear Grylls: Everest After the Avalanche,” at 10:30, he draws on his own experience — scaling the peak in 1998 at the age of 23 —to explain the allure of the mountain, and the danger.

headline: Stranded for Hours in Hudson, Cruise Ship Docks at Manhattan Pier
text: A cruise ship that was stranded in the Hudson River for several hours made it to shore on Sunday morning, docking at Pier 88 on the West Side of Manhattan, officials said.

headline: Young Blood May Hold Key to Reversing Aging
text: Two teams of scientists published studies on Sunday showing that blood from young mice reverses aging in old mice, rejuvenating their muscles and brains. As ghoulish as the research may sound, experts said that it could lead to treatments for disorders like Alzheimer’s disease and heart disease.

headline: No Charges as Leader of Sinn Fein Is Released
text: LONDON — Gerry Adams, the leader of the Irish political party Sinn Fein, was released from police custody without charges on Sunday after four days of questioning into a gruesome 1972 Irish Republican Army murder of a widow with 10 children. But the police will hand over a file of potential evidence against him to prosecutors, police officials said.

headline: Break Found in Queens Subway Track; Normal Service for the Morning Rush
text: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority expected to resume normal subway service from Queens into Manhattan at 5 a.m. Monday along the four lines — the E, F, M and R — affected by a derailment  on Friday, officials announced on Sunday night.

headline: Train Derails in India, Killing at Least 18
text: NEW DELHI — A passenger train traveling through the Western Ghats mountain range on a route connecting Mumbai and Goa in western India derailed on Sunday, killing at least 18 people and injuring more than 125 others.

headline: Signaling Interest in 2016, Perry Talks of ‘Second Chances’
text: WASHINGTON — Gov. Rick Perry of Texas on Sunday sent some of his clearest signals of interest in a 2016 presidential bid, joking wryly about his “botched” run in 2012 but then adding that “I think America is a place that believes in second chances.”

headline: Rangers’ Crumbling Power Play May Have a New Piece
text: PITTSBURGH — The Rangers hope defenseman Anton Stralman is the tonic that restores their ailing power play to health.

headline: Spreading the A.P. Gospel to Nurture Scientists and Engineers
text: PITTSBURGH — Even before the first day of class in August, Maura Fritzley had second thoughts about taking Advanced Placement physics.

headline: Twin Faces of Desire in Movement
text: By the sound of it, Nrityagram, a village in southern India dedicated to the study, practice and teaching of the classical form Odissi, is a dance paradise. There live the incomparable Surupa Sen — the first student to graduate from Nrityagram, she is now its choreographer and artistic director — and Bijayini Satpathy, its spellbinding veteran dancer.

headline: A Minimalist Master Returns
text: Carl Andre is one of America’s greatest living sculptors. He has been mostly absent from the American art scene for decades, but recently returned to oversee the installation of a new retrospective.

headline: Ask Me Anything
text: I’ll be taking reader questions this week on any topic. Simply post your question in the comments section here and I’ll sift through and choose the most interesting and relevant ones to answer (I’ll probably pick 10 to 15). We’ll notify you by email if your question was chosen, and all my answers will be posted later this week.

headline: In a Flourishing Queens, Prosperity Eludes Some Asian Families
text: By now, you may have heard the buzz about Queens. You may have marveled at the gleaming new high rises and the pricey penthouses, at the influx of young professionals and the blossoming post-recession economy.

headline: A Desert Spider With Astonishing Moves
text: A spider newly discovered in the Moroccan Sahara can do powerful, acrobatic flips through the air.

headline: ScienceTake | Tumbling Spider
text: For one desert species, doing flips is a way to escape predators.

headline: Nets Move On With a Swat at the Buzzer
text: TORONTO — As precious seconds ticked off the game clock here Sunday afternoon, Kyle Lowry was scampering away from Deron Williams and Kevin Garnett, desperate to find any free space to fling up a final shot.

headline: Fans Boo Sabathia; He Can’t Blame Them
text: Last week, C. C. Sabathia was asked if he thought fans had been too harsh in booing the former Yankees star Robinson Cano during his return to the Bronx. Sabathia simply responded, “It’s New York.”

headline: A Show About Nothing Begets Something You Can Play Online
text: What if new episodes of “Seinfeld” were still on television?

headline: Music That Must Speak for Itself, Now That Its Composer Is Staying Quiet
text: The musical life of William Onyeabor has had at least three measurable and increasingly breathless stages of afterlife.

headline: Can You Hear Me Now? Turn That Thing Off!
text: Despite continuing efforts to ward off the problem, the intrusive ringing of cellphones at concerts has become almost commonplace. Institutions do what they can to remind audiences to turn the things off. I am usually reluctant to mention a cellphone incident, since I don’t want to suggest that a passing disturbance can ruin the overall experience of a great performance.

headline: Insanely Pursuing Love, Be It Opera or Reality Show
text: To a listener familiar with Haydn’s opera “Orlando Paladino” only from recordings — a 1977 Philips release conducted by Antal Dorati and a 2006 Deutsche Harmonia Mundi release led by Nikolaus Harnoncourt — it has never been clear exactly how well the opera could be made to work onstage. A new production by the Manhattan School of Music Opera Theater, which opened on Wednesday evening in the school’s John C. Borden Auditorium, does little to provide answers.

headline: Playwrights Know That Kinfolk Are Such Characters
text: “It’s weird to become a part of someone else’s family,” a man complains after a visit with his girlfriend’s parents.

headline: Not Quite Amazing, but Spidey Does Swing
text: LOS ANGELES — “The Amazing Spider-Man 2” took in $92 million over the weekend, ushering in Hollywood’s all-important summer blockbuster season and validating a sizable gamble by its maker, Sony Pictures Entertainment.

headline: This Way Back to His Discomfort Zone
text: Comedians keep pushing at the boundaries of offensive humor. Louis C.K. tests the limits of sensitive humor.

headline: Minimalist Retrospective Gets a Master’s Touch
text: Carl Andre, a father of Minimalism and one of the greatest living American sculptors, decided to retire a few years ago, in his mid-70s. And for an exacting artist who usually insisted on arranging and installing most of his pieces himself, on site, retirement had a special ring of finality.

headline: Three Stars Who Navigate on High C’s
text: The Three Tenors are back.

headline: 9 Circus Performers Injured in Fall in Rhode Island
text: As thousands of parents and children watched, eight women dangling high above a ring at a Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey circus performance in Providence, R.I., on Sunday crashed some 30 feet to the ground when the harness from which they were hanging suddenly collapsed.

headline: They’re Really Into Dylan, Maybe a Little Too Much
text: Bob Dylan said it best, in a 2012 Rolling Stone interview timed to the release of his “Tempest ” album: “Why is it when people talk about me, they have to go crazy?” More than 50 years after he first started attracting fanatical followers, Mr. Dylan was facing down a more brutal and dangerous species of devotee than he had seen before. The fans had social media, and the scholars had computers; en masse, they could track every move he made and every word he wrote, said or sang. “Dylanologist,” once a derisive term for the self-styled expert who sifted through the Dylan family’s garbage cans, was now a word with wide colloquial meaning, if not yet a dictionary definition.

headline: What’s the Deal With This Puzzle?
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — I have a long-standing theory that for all experiences in life, there is an equivalent “Seinfeld Moment.” Anything you might go through has probably been covered at least once in the sitcom “Seinfeld.” The only exception I can think of is solving a puzzle about NOTHING that is clued to the sitcom itself. That’s way too meta even for the television show.

headline: What Do Guns Say?
text: Earlier this month, in Bunkerville, Nev., representatives of the Bureau of Land Management withdrew from a tense standoff with supporters of Cliven Bundy, a rancher who owes the federal government over $1 million in unpaid fees for allowing his cattle to graze on public land. The hundreds of self-appointed militia and “states’ rights” activists who flocked to support Bundy, many in full tactical gear and openly carrying assault rifles, blockaded a federal interstate and trained their weapons on B.L.M. employees who sought to negotiate with the rancher and his family. Fearful of a pitched gun battle, the B.L.M. departed, leaving Bundy and his supporters to celebrate, emboldened, with a barbecue.

headline: An Impressive Defensive Move Online
text: As mentioned in Saturday’s column, the International Bridge Press Association hands out annual awards. The diagramed deal will probably make the defense shortlist. It was played online and was described by Ron Klinger after he was shown the deal by David Wiltshire, both from Australia.

headline: Buoyed by Exports, Portugal Chooses Clean Exit From Bailout
text: LISBON — Portugal on Sunday announced its exit from a three-year bailout program that has forced deep spending cuts and set off mass protests — but has also helped the country clean up its public finances and return to the bond markets after halving its budget deficit.

headline: Footnotes
text: Rihanna, below, Pharrell Williams and Lorde were among the winners at the inaugural iHeartRadio Music Awards, which were presented by Clear Channel last week in Los Angeles. Rihanna was named the artist of the year, and her song “Stay” featuring Mikky Ekko won best song. Mr. Williams received the Innovator Award, and Lorde was named best new artist. ... The Glaad Media Awards honored the actor George Takei and named Netflix’s “Orange Is the New Black” outstanding comedy series in a ceremony on Saturday in New York. Two films — “Concussion,” written and directed by Stacie Passon, and “Philomena,” directed by Stephen Frears — also received awards.

headline: Picking a Winner: The 1998 N.F.L. Draft
text: After the 1998 N.F.L. draft produced one of the greatest busts in history, what have we learned about the science of evaluating human talent — on and off the field?

headline: Manning or Leaf? A Lesson in Intangibles
text: Say the name Bobby Thomson and before long someone is sure to bring up his 1951 partner in baseball history, Ralph Branca. Ever since the 1986 World Series, Mookie Wilson and Bill Buckner have gone together like a hot dog and a beer (or perhaps more like oil and water, if you’re a still-mournful Boston Red Sox fan). Mark McGwire and Sammy Sosa are forever joined in grace by their 1998 pursuit of a home-run record, and in disgrace by their reliance on performance-enhancing drugs. And what figure-skating fan can hear about Nancy Kerrigan without thinking of Tonya Harding, the two being linked by a bizarre episode of attempted kneecapping in 1994?

headline: South Sudan Captures Stronghold of Rebels
text: BENTIU, South Sudan — Government troops in South Sudan launched a counteroffensive against rebel forces on Sunday to retake two important northern towns just days after South Sudan’s president told the United States that he would hold talks with his rebel opponent.

headline: Let Slip the Dolphins of War
text: SOUTHAMPTON, England — Fifty years ago, at the New York World’s Fair in 1964, the science-fiction writer Arthur C. Clarke spoke of things to come. He foresaw a 21st century that would witness “the development of intelligent and useful servants among the other animals on this planet, particularly the great apes and, in the oceans, the dolphins and whales.” Clarke saw this as a way of solving “the servant problem,” although he also imagined that the animals would form labor unions, “and we’d be right back where we started.”

headline: We Need Al Capone Drug Laws
text: EDINA, Minn. — AFTER a ruinous 30-year experiment in harsh sentences for narcotics trafficking resulting in mass incarceration, policy makers are having second thoughts. Many states, including Texas, have reformed their laws to shorten sentences. Congress is giving serious consideration to the Smarter Sentencing Act, which would do the same. The United States Sentencing Commission has just adopted a proposal to revise federal guidelines.

headline: Finally, Some Optimism About Obesity
text: EARLIER this year, we got what seemed like the first good news on obesity rates: A study in JAMA found that there had been a 43 percent drop in the obesity rates of 2- to 5-year-old children in the last decade. But then, last month, that news was contradicted by researchers at the University of North Carolina who used the same data to find that obesity rates had remained flat after all.

headline: The Different Way That Boys Learn
In California Race, a Latina Democrat Carries Hopes of Her Party and People
text: SANGER, Calif. — “Ya es tiempo — you have a voice,” Amanda Renteria, a Democratic candidate for Congress, declared one recent Saturday morning at a park in this little city southeast of Fresno. There was no need to translate the Spanish. The park was festooned with “Amanda Renteria para el Congreso” signs.

headline: For Top Jobs, Qualified Women Are Everywhere
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sane Gun Laws
text: To the Editor:

headline: Ending Automatic Defaults
text: To the Editor:

headline: Privacy in the Digital Age
text: To the Editor:

headline: Arms Cache Most Likely Kept in Texas by the C.I.A.
text: WASHINGTON — In passing references scattered through once-classified documents and cryptic public comments by former intelligence officials, it is referred to as “Midwest Depot,” but the bland code name belies the role it has played in some of the C.I.A.’s most storied operations.

headline: Survivors’ Hopes Fade in Aftermath of Afghan Landslide
text: ABI BARAK, Afghanistan — With hope gone that the 2,100 people thought to be buried by a mountain of mud here could be rescued, most efforts in this remote corner of northern Afghanistan have turned toward keeping the rest alive.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 39
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: From Riots and Rebels to Juice Bars and Tapas, a New Brixton Emerges
text: LONDON — They came trotting through the southern entrance of Brixton market, waving handwritten signs to protest the “yuppification” of this notorious South London neighborhood.

headline: Vermont School Districts Consider Consolidation
text: ROCHESTER, Vt. — Tucked into valleys and isolated by mountains and rural expanse, many of Vermont’s 273 school districts serve just a smattering of children. It is an old system, borne of the state’s agrarian history and knotty geography, and many Vermonters like it that way.

headline: Fresh Doubts Raised About Papyrus Scrap Known as ‘Gospel of Jesus’ Wife’
text: New evidence discovered by a skeptical young scholar has raised fresh doubts about the authenticity of the scrap of papyrus known as the “Gospel of Jesus’ Wife,” a relic that has provoked fascination and fury since it was unveiled nearly two years ago by an eminent historian of early Christianity at Harvard Divinity School.

headline: Push to Put Brands in Video Content
text: AS an annual presentation of new digital offerings to Madison Avenue enters its second week, marketers and publishers are focusing on ways to work together to integrate brands and products into video programming in the same way they are woven into the plots of television shows.

headline: More Dead in Colombia Mine Collapse
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — The death toll in a collapse at an illegal gold mine in western Colombia has risen to at least 12 as searchers continued to dig for bodies on Sunday, a local official said.

headline: Libertarians Trail Meter Readers, Telling Town: Live Free or Else
text: KEENE, N.H. — In most places, the parking enforcement officer reflects the municipal compact. Armed only with a gadget that can spit out a ticket at the forgotten drop of a dime, the officer quietly serves civic and commercial life by ensuring that meters are fed.

headline: Key European Forecast on Growth and Inflation
text: KEY EUROPEAN FORECAST ON GROWTH AND INFLATION

headline: Mayweather Unleashes Jabs and Punch Lines
text: LAS VEGAS — Already annoyed that the discourse after his latest victory had veered toward a controversy over his opponent’s gloves, Floyd Mayweather Jr. shot a stiff glare at a man who shouted at him during his postfight news conference Saturday night.

headline: Inventing a Failure
text: Last week, House Republicans released a deliberately misleading report on the status of health reform, crudely rigging the numbers to sustain the illusion of failure in the face of unexpected success. Are you shocked?

headline: First Openly Gay Episcopal Bishop, Whose Election Caused a Stir, to Divorce
text: Bishop V. Gene Robinson, who made history as the first openly gay bishop in the Episcopal Church, has announced that he and his husband are planning to divorce.

headline: After Failed Peace Talks, Pushing to Label Israel as Occupier of Palestine
text: JERUSALEM — More than a year after Palestine was upgraded to become a nonmember observer state of the United Nations, the attributes of statehood exist mainly on official Palestinian letterhead.

headline: An Ever-Curious Spirit, Unbeaten After 111 Years
text: So what is it like to be pronounced the oldest man on earth?

headline: How Should E-Cigarettes Be Regulated?
text: What should the F.D.A. do to regulate e-cigarettes, or is it overstepping in treating them like traditional cigarettes?

headline: Libya Leader Finally Picked but Is Quickly Challenged
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — After a long search, Libya’s transitional Parliament appeared to have finally selected a new prime minister on Sunday, choosing Ahmed Maitiq, a businessman, during a chaotic legislative session.

headline: South Africa President Appeals for Ex-Backers to Return to Fold
text: SOWETO, South Africa — Battling an array of defectors from the African National Congress during a long campaign, President Jacob Zuma, speaking at the party’s final rally in a vast soccer stadium here on Sunday, urged former supporters to return to the A.N.C.

headline: Seaver’s Double Duty for the White Sox
text: CHICAGO — It was right around midnight on the South Side last month, and the White Sox were in trouble. They were tied with Boston in the 14th inning at U.S. Cellular Field, with two Red Sox on base and a rattled pitcher on the mound.

headline: Cooperation With G.O.P. Puts Senator in a Primary
text: ALBANY — G. Oliver Koppell has spent four decades in politics, serving in the State Assembly, on the New York City Council and as attorney general for a brief stint at the tail end of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo’s final term. Through it all, he has been a Democrat — and a liberal one at that — with Republicans as his usual adversaries.

headline: Hearing Help in Theaters
text: Attorney General Eric T. Schneiderman of New York announced on Sunday that three theater organizations — the Manhattan Theater Club, the Atlantic Theater Company and the School of Visual Arts Theater — have agreed to provide listening devices, like headsets or hearing loops, to audience members with hearing loss. As part of the Americans With Disabilities Act, theater companies that use microphones or have amplified sound during performances are to grant equal access to those who are hard of hearing, but the attorney general’s office received complaints from individuals and disability rights organizations that some Off Broadway theaters were not following those guidelines. An investigation by attorney general’s Civil Rights Bureau found that the three theater companies were not providing listening devices, and the bureau is working with other theaters to ensure their compliance with the law.

headline: No Regrets for the Founder of Tumblr After Yahoo Sale
text: When Yahoo bought Tumblr for $1.1 billion a year ago, it sent a ripple of excitement — and anxiety — through the tech industry. Would Yahoo and its recently arrived chief executive, Marissa Mayer, breathe new life into Tumblr? Or would Yahoo smother the start-up, as it did after acquiring popular young services like GeoCities and Flickr?

headline: X Still Marks Sunken Spot, and Gold Awaits
text: The discovery of sunken gold conjures up visions of instant riches: Swiss bank accounts and lazy afternoons on faraway beaches, daiquiris in hand.

headline: The Relief Résumé of a Star Starter
text: Tom Seaver, one of 24 major league pitchers to win 300 games, started 647 games and was a reliever in nine. Tom Glavine is the only 300-game winner who never pitched in relief; he started 682 times.

headline: Kiev Struggles to Break Russia’s Grip on Gas Flow
text: CHASLOVTSY, Ukraine — As Ukraine tries to contain a pro-Russian insurgency convulsing its eastern region, a perhaps more significant struggle for the country hinges on what happens beneath the ground here in a placid woodland in the far west, on the border with Slovakia.

headline: Are Pap Smears on the Way Out?
text: Women who want to be screened for cervical cancer have just received a new option — and a new quandary. The venerable Pap smear, which has been the only screening tool to look for cancer in asymptomatic women for many decades, now has a rival, a genetic test that looks for the viruses implicated in causing cervical cancer.

headline: The Toll of ‘No New Taxes’
text: With the nation’s highway system frayed and running short of funds, the Obama administration has asked Congress to end the current ban on states’ charging tolls to pay for the upkeep of federal interstate highways. The proposal would reverse a proud policy dating to the system’s creation in 1956, when the postwar automobile boom left government flush with fuel taxes and ever bigger highway plans.

headline: Gee Stymies Colorado to Help Prevent a Four-Game Sweep
text: DENVER — The Mets finally shook the demons that had haunted them at Coors Field this weekend, getting a masterly pitching performance and enough offense for a 5-1 victory against the Colorado Rockies.

headline: Policing, on the Safe Side
text: The New York Police Department has been doing more with less for over a decade, with a force that is down about 6,000 uniformed officers from a peak of 40,710 in 2001. During that time crime in the city has fallen to record lows, and New Yorkers’ real worries about their safety have been replaced by more hypothetical jitters — can the trend possibly continue, and do we have enough officers to make sure it does?

headline: A Better Economy, Still Far From Good
text: The good news from last week’s economic reports is this: April was the best month for job growth in quite a while. Employers added 288,000 jobs, bringing the average for the last three months to a respectable 238,000.

headline: At Derby Day With Murdoch, Rand Paul Goes Through His Paces
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — On the afternoon of the Kentucky Derby, Rand Paul, the state’s junior Republican senator and likely presidential candidate, spilled out of an elevator in the exclusive Jockey Club Suites of Churchill Downs with an entourage of women with flower-adorned hats, men in seersucker suits and Rupert Murdoch.

headline: Ukraine’s Reins Weaken as Chaos Spreads
text: ODESSA, Ukraine — Russian-speaking regions of Ukraine spun further out of the central government’s control on Sunday as a mob stormed a police station in this Black Sea port and freed from detention 67 pro-Russian militants, on the same day that Ukraine’s prime minister was visiting the city.

headline: A Key Player in a Scandal, V. Stiviano Feeds the Media’s Appetite
text: Words are sometimes no match for pictures. So when I suggest that V. Stiviano may understand and avail herself of the current American media culture better than anyone, it is worth taking a look at our subject, below.

headline: For Luxury Magazine, an Unusual Exclusive
text: In the week and a half since TMZ published the now-infamous audio recording of Donald Sterling, the owner of the Los Angeles Clippers, he has been perhaps the most elusive interview in America. That is, until Thursday night when DuJour magazine — DuWhat? — ran a piece on its website with the headline, “Donald Sterling Speaks Up.” Mr. Sterling, referring to the woman who taped his racist meltdown, said, “I wish I had just paid her off.”

headline: Conquering Personal Setbacks for Strong Finishes at Wells Fargo
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — The greens at Quail Hollow Club, remade after they became a pocked, blotchy mess last year, set the theme for the Wells Fargo Championship: They bounced back from the abyss to earn rave reviews. By nightfall Sunday, so had three competitors.

headline: Eye-for-an-Eye Incivility
text: The botched Oklahoma execution of Clayton Lockett has called our continued use of the death penalty in this country back into question. In many ways, the death penalty is an abhorrent attempt to sate an irrational cultural bloodlust, rooted in vengeance and barbarism and detached from data.

headline: New Ideas in Lighting Get Closer to Market
text: WOBURN, Mass. — Ever since government regulations began phasing out the traditional light bulb in 2012, the once-simple visit to the lighting aisle has become an exercise in navigating a dizzying array of choices and terminologies, especially for new kinds of compact fluorescents and LEDs.

headline: For a Winning Owner at the Derby, Belief in an Unseen Hand
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Forgive Steve Coburn his brash proclamations about California Chrome. He can sound like a silver-tongued showman when he guarantees victory for his colt. That irritated some backstretch hard boots here in the days before the Kentucky Derby on Saturday.

headline: Heroin’s New Hometown
text: The obituaries have a certain sameness to them: full of praise and regret for lives cut short, marked by telltale details and omissions. The deaths occurred at home, or at a friend’s house elsewhere on Staten Island. The mourned were often young and white, and although how they died was never mentioned, nearly everyone knew or suspected the cause.

headline: Nets Know How to Beat Heat: Unconventionally
text: If there has been one defining characteristic of the Nets since Brook Lopez went down for the season, it is flexibility. Coach Jason Kidd has done well to make the most of what he has, but this flexibility is possible only because of the Nets’ physical skill sets and intelligence. Not only do the Nets have players like Paul Pierce and Shaun Livingston, who can fulfill a variety of needs and defy traditional definitions of their positions, they have a team smart enough to adjust on the fly.

headline: Advertisers Seek a ‘Second Screen’ Connection With Viewers
text: In recent episodes of “Game of Thrones,” viewers have seen scenes of theft, rape, infanticide, cannibalism, beheading, crucifixion, castration, incest, murder and dismemberment.

headline: Old Times There Are Not Forgotten
text: Some people are paralyzed by self-consciousness. The playwright Branden Jacobs-Jenkins is inspired, energized and perhaps even set free by it.

headline: ‘Fun Home’ and ‘Here Lies Love’ Win Lortel Awards
text: The Public Theater was the big winner on Sunday night at the Lucille Lortel Awards honoring Off Broadway works, with three of its critically acclaimed productions dominating the major categories.

headline: Documentary Channel Aims at an ‘Underserved’ Audience
text: LOS ANGELES — A sobering thought for documentarians: In 2013, “Iron Man 3” sold about as many theater tickets in one day as all of their documentaries did all year. Combined.

headline: Prosper, a Peer-to-Peer Lender, Raises $70 Million
text: As peer-to-peer lending — in which borrowers connect with lenders directly online — takes off, one of the biggest players in the field is taking advantage by raising more money.

headline: Birding and Selfies
text: Dear Diary:

headline: A Foothold on Clay May Be Slipping
text: This is all Rafael Nadal’s fault, of course.

headline: Slate Raising Its Investment in Podcasts
text: The digital magazine Slate will start two new podcasts in the next week: The Gist, with the former NPR reporter Mike Pesca, its first daily podcast intended to deliver news and opinion to afternoon drive-time listeners, and Money, hosted by the financial writer Felix Salmon.

headline: Girl Is Killed in Brooklyn by Driver Fleeing Police
text: A 9-year-old girl died after the car she was riding in was struck by a minivan fleeing another accident in Brooklyn on Sunday evening, the police said.

headline: Rush for Deals Before Top Art Goes to Auction
text: In many ways this year’s spring auctions, which begin on Tuesday, follow a familiar pattern: hefty catalogs, more and more art to sell, the promise of multimillion dollar prices for blue-chip names.

headline: Treasury Auctions for the Week of May 5
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
text: Accounts

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 4, 2014
Gary Becker, 83, Nobel Laureate, Dies; Applied Economics to Everyday Life
text: Gary S. Becker, a Nobel prize-winning economics professor and longtime columnist for Business Week whose research illuminated motivations about such aspects of everyday life as marriage, crime, addiction, racial discrimination and birthrates, died on Saturday in Chicago. He was 83.

headline: James Oberstar, 79, Congressman Ousted in Tea Party Tide, Dies
text: James L. Oberstar, an iron miner’s son from Minnesota who spent 36 years in Congress before losing to a political newcomer aligned with the Tea Party in 2010, died on Saturday at his home in Potomac, Md. He was 79.

headline: At Cable Convention, an Industry Tries to Face Up to Its Tarnished Reputation
text: LOS ANGELES — If any industry knows it has an image problem, it is the cable business. Just about every consumer has experienced the anxious wait for a technician who might or might not arrive during the dreaded four-hour “window.” Experiences like that, as well as service failures and rising rates, create a bad reputation that is hard to shake.

headline: Greenlight Asked S.E.C. for Delay on Disclosure of Micron Stake
text: David Einhorn, the billionaire hedge fund manager whose stock picks are closely watched on Wall Street, is not a big fan of so-called copycat traders who simply latch onto his ideas — especially when it costs his investors money.

headline: Former New York Police Officer Charged With Painting Anti-Semitic Graffiti
text: A former New York City police officer was arrested Sunday and charged with spray-painting anti-Semitic messages on more than a dozen cars and several buildings in Brooklyn.

headline: What’s On Monday
text: 8 P.M. (Fox) 24: LIVE ANOTHER DAY The superagent Jack Bauer (Kiefer Sutherland, above) is back, living in exile, and willing to risk life and liberty to avert another global disaster in this two-hour premiere, which picks up four years after the Season 8 finale. Mary Lynn Rajskub has returned as the computer savant Chloe; Kim Raver is Jack’s old flame; and William Devane is her father, a former defense secretary who is now president. Benjamin Bratt and Yvonne Strahovski play F.B.I. agents hot on Jack’s trail. The story line includes a chief of staff (Tate Donovan) concealing information from the president, who could be targeted for assassination, as well as international terrorists and cyberinsurgents à la Julian Assange. “The show is more of the same that filled all the days that came before, and that’s not always desirable,” Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. “Sometimes it’s better to start over completely or let a series end for real, for good.”

headline: India Election Digest: May 5

headline: In Prospect Park, Dog Owners and Bird Watchers Fight for Space

headline: 11 Missing After Cargo Ships Collide Near Hong Kong

headline: China Sentences Accused Spy to 10-Year Prison Term
text: A man in the southern province of Guangdong who sent military documents and photos of military bases overseas has been sentenced to 10 years in prison on a spying conviction, state media has reported.

headline: Nations Planning Next Phase of Jet Search
text: SYDNEY, Australia — With nothing tangible to show for nearly two months of searching for Flight 370, officials and experts from Malaysia, China, Australia and other countries plan to meet on Wednesday in Canberra, the Australian capital, to sort out what to do next, officials said Monday. The focus will be on intensively examining the floor of the Indian Ocean looking for debris.

headline: In Tepid Wage Growth, a Potent Sign of a Still-Fragile Economy

headline: Witnesses Tell of Pistorius’s Anguish After Shooting Girlfriend
text: In dramatic and sometimes tearful testimony, the first people to see the double-amputee track star Oscar Pistorius after he fired the four rounds that killed his girlfriend told his murder trial on Monday that he was torn with anguish as he carried her bleeding body, saying, according to one witness, “stay with me, my love, stay with me.”

headline: Petition Seeks Closure of Extrajudicial Detention Centers
text: More than 100 lawyers, scholars, retired officials and Communist Party members have signed a letter calling for the abolition of “custody and education,” a form of punishment meted out by the Public Security Bureau that bypasses the legal system and can jail people for up to two years. The signatories say the two-decades-old system contravenes China’s constitution and laws, violates citizens’ rights and is out of step with the state’s “law-building spirit.”

Turchynov, said roadblocks were being set up around Ukraine’s capital, Kiev, because of fears of disturbances or violence during an emotionally charged holiday later in the week.

headline: Daily Report: Independence but Little Revenue Growth for Tumblr After Acquisition by Yahoo

Would Yahoo and its recently arrived chief executive, Marissa Mayer, breathe new life into Tumblr? Or would Yahoo smother the start-up, as it did after acquiring popular young services like GeoCities and Flickr?

Buffett, DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced writes.

text: The jury found that some Samsung smartphones and tablets had violated Apple patents covering things like the slide-to-unlock feature, which opens the phone’s features to users. The bulk of the damages — $99 million — were for a patent that covered a method for so-called quick links.

Especially if the composer’s score is as magisterially ambitious as Julian Anderson’s “Thebans,” a commission by the English National Opera, which packed the London Coliseum at its premiere on Saturday.

headline: South Sudan Fighting Rages as Kerry Appeals to Rebel Leader
text: BENTIU, South Sudan — The sound of bullets cracked, whistled and popped on Monday over a United Nations base where 25,000 people huddled for safety. A middle-aged woman was hit by a stray bullet and carried to a clinic in a wheelbarrow. Nyapes Lach, a 4-year-old girl, was struck in the head as she sat with her family, rushed to the clinic in a blood-soaked bandage, and pronounced dead.

headline: U.N. Panel on Torture Presses Vatican Envoy on Abuse

headline: Town Meetings Can Have Prayer, Justices Decide
text: WASHINGTON — In a major decision on the role of religion in government, the Supreme Court on Monday ruled that the Constitution allows town boards to start their sessions with sectarian prayers. The ruling, by a 5-to-4 vote, divided the court’s more conservative members from its liberal ones, and their combative opinions reflected very different views of the role of faith in public life, in contemporary society and in the founding of the Republic.

headline: For Justices, Free Speech Often Means ‘Speech I Agree With’

The church, which is the largest religious denomination in the country, is already about 40 percent Hispanic, and the demographic change is inexorable: Within the next few decades, Hispanics are expected to make up a majority of American Catholics.

headline: Now Screening | Catching Up With the Original Punk Rock Girl of Film
text: Starting May 7 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, a series called “Punk Rock Girls” will showcase the women of the movement in all their pierced, ripped, hairsprayed glory. “The theme is so resonant,” says the programmer Nellie Killian, who conceived the monthlong event as a valentine to the era. “Especially for female viewers, it’s so important to have these types of girl characters, and we wanted to put in the lineage of movies of girls carving out a space for themselves within alternative culture.” Highlights will include a rubber-braceleted, Danceteria-era Madonna brazenly appropriating the Port Authority hand dryers (“Desperately Seeking Susan”); Diane Lane and friends, in slashes of scarlet eye shadow and skunk-striped hair, stepping up to the mike (“Ladies and Gentlemen, the Fabulous Stains”); and Robin Johnson and Trini Alvarado hurling TV sets off Manhattan rooftops (“Times Square”).

headline: How Gary Becker Transformed the Social Sciences
text: Gary Becker was the most important social scientist in the past 50 years and possibly longer, in my view. He was my intellectual hero, and I want to explain why.

headline: An Offbeat Gallery Show With Its Own Soundtrack
text: The painter Mark Ryden made his name creating distinctive, cartoonish record sleeve art, most notably for Michael Jackson’s “Dangerous” album, Aerosmith’s “Love in an Elevator” single, and records by the Red Hot Chili Peppers and Tyler the Creator. Now he is, in a limited way, becoming a record producer as well. While assembling “The Gay 90s West,” a thematic show of his paintings based on 19th-century themes, Mr. Ryden told The Hollywood Reporter, he decided to invite some of his friends in the pop music world to contribute to an accompanying album.

headline: Sounds, And Ideas, That Never Stay Still
text: The rangy terrain traversed by the Nels Cline Singers on Thursday night, in a riveting, sold-out show at Le Poisson Rouge, could be understood a few different ways: as a rejection of fixedness, or an endorsement of flux, or a way of moving the conversation forward. What it all amounted to was a distillation of the musical ideals long embodied by Nels Cline, a guitarist with a knack for wrangling restlessness into coherence.

headline: Picasso Museum Reopening Delayed Until September, For Now

headline: Books to Share on Mother’s Day
text: First of all, go, right now, to the store. Buy a card for your mother, mother-in-law and anyone else you want to receive one this Sunday. Have your children make cards and greetings tonight, and put it all in the mail tomorrow. Don’t spend another year apologizing or justifying your use of priority overnight Saturday delivery whatnot. (Please don’t tell me I’m the only one to do both regularly!)

headline: Document | About a Boy
text: For nearly two years, the Brooklyn-based photographer Dean Kaufman has relished the simple pleasure of watching his son lose himself in a work of art. He began this series when Leo was 4 and started toting a small notebook on family trips to New York art museums. Leo would plunk down near whatever caught his eye and begin to sketch, while his father stealthily captured the moment. Kaufman says the activity — whether sprawling out in front of a Jasper Johns painting at the Whitney Museum of American Art (middle left), or carefully copying Chris Burden’s tower of concrete bags at the New Museum (bottom center) — has nurtured Leo’s love for drawing. Still, he hesitates to interpret the 5-year-old’s curiosity as a sign of future art stardom. “He’s got a limited attention span,” Kaufman says. “He does the drawing and then he says, ‘Let’s go have lunch.'”

headline: Stolen Guitar to Be Returned to Zakk Wylde
text: Zakk Wylde, the guitarist in Black Label Society whose striped and bull’s-eye-emblazoned guitars are as distinctive as his shredding style, is about to be reunited with a custom-built Pelham blue Gibson Les Paul that was stolen from his tour bus in March. The guitar, which bears Mr. Wylde’s distinctive bull’s-eye design, and which Mr. Wylde valued at $10,000 at the time of the theft, was recovered on Friday after a pawn shop owner began to suspect that the instrument was probably worth more than the $50 he paid for it.

headline: France Says It Opposes G.E.’s Bid for Alstom Unit
text: Updated, 4:22 p.m. | PARIS — The French government said on Monday that it would oppose General Electric’s friendly $13.5 billion offer for a large portion of Alstom, the country’s largest industrial conglomerate, saying the deal should be reconfigured on a more equitable footing.

headline: Learning to Laugh Through the Pain
text: I’VE been traveling for business for about 15 years. I’ve always been involved in sports training. I have degrees in physical therapy and exercise science, and have worked with many professional athletes, like football players or mixed martial artists. I was even a member of the United States bobsled team. When I developed my strength and conditioning program, called Training for Warriors, my travel schedule became insane. I’ve been to 25 countries so far doing motivational speaking, training or some combination of both.

headline: Michelle Obama Joins in a Salute to Anna Wintour

headline: Ralph Rucci’s Continuing Homage to Charles James
text: Charles James was one of American fashion’s first couturiers, as well as one of its most influential designers and most notorious perfectionists. His contemporaries, such as Christian Dior and Mainbocher, venerated him; Balenciaga famously called him the world’s best and only dressmaker, and both Elsa Schiaparelli and Coco Chanel wore his designs. Tonight, The Costume Institute of The Metropolitan Museum of Art will pay tribute to the late master’s 30-year career with the gala for “Charles James: Beyond Fashion,” which opens to the public May 8. Nearly 75 of the 200 designs ever completed by James will be on display at the newly christened Anna Wintour Costume Center and first-floor Special Exhibition Galleries. And to accompany this retrospective, an eponymous book has been written by its curators Harold Koda and Jan Glier Reeder, cataloguing the work on view.

headline: Financial Data Company Markit Files for I.P.O.
text: Markit, a financial data company, has been a behind-the-scenes player on Wall Street since its founding roughly a decade ago. Now, it is preparing to make its public market debut.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: May 2-4, 2014
text: Last Monday, 14-year-old Endia Martin was shot and killed in the Back of the Yards neighborhood of Chicago. She and a former friend, a 14-year-old honor-roll student, were in a dispute over a boy, and what started as a Facebook fight erupted into a brawl. The confrontation drew 20 people, some of whom were armed with pipes and bottles.

headline: Ackman Urges Allergan Board to Begin Deal Talks With Valeant
text: Two weeks after unveiling an audacious partnership with Valeant Pharmaceuticals to take over Allergan, the maker of Botox, the hedge fund billionaire William A. Ackman is getting to work.

headline: Red in the Face
text: Q. After I have had a glass of wine, my face heats up and turns bright red. This also happens to my siblings. What is going on?

headline: Crocodile Tears Hit the Spot for Butterfly and Bee
text: A butterfly and a bee were seen, above, sipping the tears of a spectacled caiman (Caiman crocodilus) along the Río Puerto Viejo in northeastern Costa Rica. The insects were probably seeking protein and salt. Tear drinking in the wild may be common but not often seen, said Carlos de la Rosa, an aquatic ecologist at La Selva Biological Station in Costa Rica who witnessed the event.

headline: Helping Small Companies Go Big in China
text: When I encounter other American companies that do business in China, I am often surprised by the relatively small size of their operations in the United States. Many had less than $500,000 in annual sales when they decided to open operations in China.

headline: A 9,000-Year-Old Hunting Cabin, Underwater
text: A 9,000-year-old stone structure used to capture caribou has been discovered 120 feet beneath the surface of Lake Huron. Researchers say it is the most complex structure of its kind in the Great Lakes region.

headline: Dialogue: Nate Lowman and Devon Welsh
text: The artist Nate Lowman discusses the creative process with the musician Devon Welsh of Majical Cloudz in Lowman’s TriBeCa studio.

headline: Woman Found Guilty of Assaulting Officer at an Occupy Wall Street Protest
text: A trial that had become a rallying point for many Occupy Wall Street activists ended on Monday with a jury finding a protester guilty of assaulting a police officer at Zuccotti Park in Manhattan in 2012.

headline: Less Air in Latest Internet Bubble
text: The latest Internet bubble is a mere shadow of the excesses that came crashing to an end in 2000. Sure, even though the run-up may have paused, the feverish signs are unmistakable. Dozens of companies are in line to go public, hubris is rampant, oddball valuation metrics abound, and revenue-free start-ups are still worth fortunes. Even nerd culture has somehow become hip. The latest boom is as absurd as the last, but it’s far smaller.

headline: Film Festival Moves to New York With ‘Think Like a Man’ Sequel and Spike Lee Film
text: The 18th edition of the American Black Film Festival will make its New York debut next month with films directed by Tim Story and Spike Lee bookending the June 19-22 event, organizers announced Monday.

headline: After a Heart Attack, Eat Your Fiber
text: It is never too late to increase your consumption of dietary fiber, a new study suggests.

headline: Nate Lowman and Majical Cloudz’s Devon Welsh Talk Creativity and Music
text: To commemorate its launch tomorrow, the new high-end headphone brand Master & Dynamic commissioned a series of videos that pair two artists from different disciplines together to discuss the influence of sound on their work. The first, making its debut here, offers a firsthand look inside the artist Nate Lowman’s TriBeCa studio, where he discusses the creative process with the musician Devon Welsh, frontman of the indie duo Majical Cloudz.

headline: A New Women’s Issue: Statins
text: Should so many women be taking statins?

headline: Deutsche Bank Hires Consumer M.&A. Adviser
text: Deutsche Bank announced Monday that it had hired Jeff Rose as a managing director of its global consumer and retail mergers and acquisitions group, and the new head of its consumer and retail investment banking coverage in the Americas.

headline: Taking Aim at 12-Step Programs
text: Did you know that the most widely accepted treatments for alcohol and drug addiction — Alcoholics Anonymous and similar 12-step programs — rest on the flimsiest of scientific evidence? I didn’t.

headline: One Million
text: Champagne and other sparkling wines owe much of their appeal to their bubbles. They don’t just set the mouth tingling; bursting bubbles at the surface also help propel the aromas toward the nose.

headline: More Blight for the Palisades?
text: LG Electronics USA has been facing a growing outcry about the company’s plan to build a 143-foot tall headquarters along the Palisades Park in New Jersey. That tower, which will stretch far above the tree line, will permanently deface the view along a once-protected stretch of the Hudson River. Politicians, environmentalists, architectural critics, outraged citizens and even potential LG customers have appealed to the company to lower this tower to the traditional limit of 35 feet.

headline: Boko Haram Leader Releases Video
text: The leader of Nigeria’s terrorist group Boko Haram, Abubakar Shekau, said his group was fighting to reinstate a medieval Islamic caliphate in northern Nigeria.

headline: Box Office Bump for Top Tony Nominees
text: Last week was one of the best yet for the Broadway musical “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder,” with sharp increases in both weekly box office grosses and advance ticket sales following its 10 Tony Awards nominations, the most of any Broadway show.

headline: A Central Banker of a Different Color
text: On Saturday afternoon in Louisville, Ky., a central banker was under scrutiny. Investors with deep pockets were watching his every move, weighing odds on how he would perform under pressure.

headline: Running Food, Taking Photos
text: When his photo career stalled, Robert Larson took a nightclub job – where he discovered new faces and scenes in the blur of action between the kitchen and the club.

headline: ‘Listening’ to Sancerre Tell Its Story
text: Updated | June 2, 2014

headline: Apple-Samsung Jury Sticks With Original Total for Damages
text: The federal jury in the latest patent trial involving Apple and Samsung returned to court on Monday to recalculate some of the damages Samsung owed to Apple. After making the changes, the jury came to the same overall figure: $119.6 million.

headline: Outside Spending Enters Arena of Judicial Races
text: RALEIGH, N.C. — The ad first appeared on television the Friday before last, a black-and-white spot charging that Justice Robin Hudson coddled child molesters and “sided with the predators” in a North Carolina Supreme Court dissent. It has run constantly since.

headline: In Store | Bonpoint Arrives in SoHo With a Capsule and a Collaboration
text: Bonpoint, the Paris-based purveyor of chic children’s wear, will debut a new flagship store in New York’s SoHo tomorrow. In celebration of the opening, the brand’s creative director Christine Innamorato has designed a special “SoHo 2014″ capsule collection, which includes Liberty-print dresses — the designs for 12 of which were sourced from the Bonpoint archive — and bags, brooches, swimsuits, as well as soaps and candles that come packaged inside Liberty-print bags. And as an added incentive for the parents of chic tykes, Innamorato teamed up with the jewelry designer Aurélie Bidermann to create a limited-edition 18-karat gold and lacquer bracelet, featuring Bonpoint’s signature cherry logo, that adjusts to fit both children and adults. A portion of the profits from sales of the bracelet and capsule items will be donated to New Yorkers for Children.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Afghanistan, South Africa, Ukraine and Romania.

headline: A Goal to Combat Malaria With the Help of a Robot
text: In its effort to develop a unique malaria vaccine, the American company Sanaria wants to build a robot that will do what now requires a line of trained humans with microscopes: dissecting half-frozen mosquitoes with tiny needles to extract their salivary glands.

headline: King Cotton and His Bloody Surrogates
text: At first glance, this exhibition might seem a bit quaint, its subject — textiles and the Civil War — evoking Americana more than American history. But this show, “Homefront & Battlefield: Quilts and Context in the Civil War,” which opened last month at the New-York Historical Society after originating at the American Textile History Museum in Lowell, Mass., does much more: It turns Americana back into history.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: In Performance | Vanessa Williams
text: Vanessa Williams, with Adam Birnbaum on piano, sings “I Can’t Give You Anything but Love” from the musical revue “After Midnight,” on Broadway at the Brooks Atkinson Theater.

headline: A Debt to the Future, Face of Pain, Science Meets Fiction
text: Climate Change

headline: Pan-Latin Rhythms, Percussive to Sultry
text: Throughout its 45-year recording career, Santana — led by the great Mexican-American guitarist Carlos Santana — has been synonymous with Latin rock. Yet “Corazón” is the first Santana album with nearly all of its lyrics in Spanish. Gathering much of the album’s material from outside the United States, Mr. Santana now embraces the Pan-American rock and pop that he heralded.

headline: Denny Hamlin Wins at Talladega; Marc Marquez Takes Fourth Race in a Row
text: Denny Hamlin passed Kevin Harvick for the lead on the penultimate lap and then received the checkered flag when a multicar wreck on the final lap froze the finishing order in the Nascar Sprint Cup race Sunday at Talladega Superspeedway in Alabama.

headline: Lonely-Hearts and Action Tales
text: “Swing & Beowulf,” paired one-acts at the Irish Arts Center, both come from the Dublin Fringe Festival, but that’s all they have in common. “Swing,” a portrait of lovelorn Dubliners in a dance class, is rooted in Ireland’s recessionary present. “Beowulf: The Blockbuster,” a phantasmagorical conversation between a father and son, jumps through space and time. O.K., the plays share one more thing: They are both very worth the trip.

headline: Met Opera Contract Talks Stumble to a Start
text: After an unusually stormy overture, the curtain went up Monday on the first round of contract talks between the Metropolitan Opera and the American Guild of Musical Artists, the union representing its chorus, dancers, singers and stage managers.

headline: Mississippi Chefs to Protest State Law on the Eve of Annual Picnic
text: Every June for 35 years, hundreds of New Yorkers and displaced Mississippians have gathered in Central Park to eat catfish, listen to the blues and praise the virtues of that Southern state.

headline: When Playwrights’ Fancies Turn
text: Attention struggling playwrights: Should you need inspiration, avoid Shakespeare, Molière and the like. Their skills could frustrate you. Instead, see “The Spring Fling: First Love,” six short plays so tedious that they may actually serve a purpose: You’ll find yourself thinking, “If that can get staged, my work must have a chance.”

headline: Still Counting Gulf Spill’s Dead Birds
text: After the Deepwater Horizon oil rig blew out in the Gulf of Mexico some 50 miles from the nearest land, responders were left to cope with a search area of nearly 40,000 square miles, as well as wind and currents that kept evidence of damage away from the more easily searchable coastline.

headline: An Artist’s New York Moment
text: Most choreographers have had a long, thankless slog on the way to professional status. (Never mind success.) First come many years of training to be a dancer, then more years performing for others, trying to find time and money to create work, and get it onstage.

headline: Confronting the Inevitable, Graphically
text: Roz Chast feels — and draws — our pain. Our neurotic worries and genuine fears, our mundane and existential anxieties, our daydreams, nightmares, insecurities and guilty regrets. Or, rather, she does such a funny, fluent job in her New Yorker cartoons of conveying the things that keep her up at night that many readers are convinced that she is somehow mapping their own inner lives.

headline: The Animals of Chernobyl
text: Biologist Timothy Mousseau has been studying the lasting effects of radiation on the flora and fauna of Chernobyl, Ukraine.

headline: At Chernobyl, Hints of Nature’s Adaptation
text: NOVOSHEPELYCHI, Ukraine — The clicking sound from Timothy Mousseau’s radiation detector slowly increased as he walked through the forest here, a few miles west of the Chernobyl nuclear power plant.

headline: New Election Model Machinery: A Look Under the Hood
text: John Sides, Ben Highton and Eric McGhee of The Monkey Cage have started Election Lab, a Senate forecasting model at The Washington Post. Their model gives Republicans more than an 80 percent chance of retaking the Senate; that’s much more than the 54 percent chance that Leo, The Upshot’s Senate model, gives the G.O.P.

headline: A Composer Attuned to the Earth’s Swirling Motion
text: John Luther Adams has never been inside the main auditorium of Carnegie Hall. It’s not a fact that distinguishes him greatly in his hometown, Fairbanks, Alaska, where he has lived for four decades. There Mr. Adams, now 61, was first known as an environmental activist who helped secure passage of the Alaska Lands Act in 1980, before dedicating himself full time to music and building a small but fervent following as a composer of hypnotically immersive musical landscapes. But when Mr. Adams attends his first concert in Carnegie Hall’s Stern Auditorium on Tuesday, he will be in the unusual position of doing so as a newly minted Pulitzer Prize laureate hearing his winning work, “Become Ocean,” played there for the first time.

headline: In Search of a Lost Wonder, Off the Rivers of Babylon
text: This is the time of year when weekend gardeners peer into the neighbors’ yards for confirmation of their own superiority or inadequacy. But practically every gardener will feel unworthy upon viewing Tuesday’s episode of the PBS series “Secrets of the Dead.”

headline: Punched Out in Hard Times
text: In James McManus’s overwrought “Cherry Smoke,” Fish (Vayu O’Donnell) is an amateur boxer with what his brother, Duffy (Patrick Carroll), describes as a “serious lunatic streak.” On a set — sandbags, red stucco, ruined tires — resembling an apocalyptic desert but meant to suggest western Pennsylvania, Fish cycles from back-alley bouts to prison stints to riverside encounters with his guileless girlfriend Cherry (Molly Carden). An exploited child-woman, she is prone to statements like, “There useta be a bluebird in my heart, but it flew away.” She also describes a form of birth control so violent it provokes laughter.

headline: To Honor a Master, One Day Won’t Do
text: SARASOTA, Fla. — The Sarasota Ballet’s four-day festival honoring the superlative choreographer Frederick Ashton that ended on Saturday was a triumph of courage, enterprise, enthusiasm, artistic importance, stylish dancing, but, above all, choreographic felicity. Visiting Ashton dancers from the 1950s to the ’70s spoke with awe of how well this young Gulf Coast company reminded them of what they had loved years ago and had thought lost.

headline: Were Ayaan Hirsi Ali and Condoleezza Rice ‘Silenced’?
text: In 2009 a Catholic advocacy group said it was an “outrage” for Notre Dame to select President Barack Obama as its commencement speaker and give him an honorary degree, arguing that it was wrong for a Catholic university to honor a politician whose views on abortion contradicted those of the church.

headline: Franco & O’Dowd: I Met Dr. Ruth
text: Part 5: The actors discuss Chris’s performance in “Bridesmaids,” and talk about the role of improvisation in theater.

headline: Franco & O’Dowd: These Two Guys
text: Part 2: The actors discuss how this production of “Of Mice and Men” came together, and explain how they knew they would make a good team.

headline: Franco & O’Dowd: Gumball 3000
text: Part 3: The actors reflect on the daunting challenge of acting on Broadway, and describe the mental pitfalls of preparing for a Broadway show.

headline: Franco & O’Dowd: ‘Spring Breakers’
text: Part 4: The actors explore James’s performance in the film “Spring Breakers,” and explain how the text of a play is not like a screenplay.

headline: TimesTalks | Franco & O’Dowd: Preview
text: The actors James Franco and Chris O’Dowd discuss making their Broadway debuts in “Of Mice and Men.”

headline: Franco & O’Dowd: Intro
text: Part 1: Carol Olsen Day, director of TimesTalks, introduces the actors James Franco and Chris O’Dowd.

headline: Franco & O’Dowd: Talented Women
text: Part 7: The actors recall the women who have been major influences on their careers.

headline: Franco & O’Dowd: Judd Apatow
text: Part 6: The actors reflect on how “Pineapple Express” changed James’s career, and explain what they’ve learned from working with the “Apatow crew” of comic actors.

headline: Critics’ Circle Names ‘Fun Home’ Best Musical
text: The critically acclaimed “Fun Home” picked up another award for best musical of the New York theater season on Monday, this time from the New York Drama Critics’ Circle, an association of theater reviewers. “Fun Home,” the story of a lesbian cartoonist and her memories of childhood and her father, who committed suicide, also won the Lucille Lortel Award for outstanding Off Broadway musical on Sunday night. The show finished its run at the Public Theater this winter; a Broadway transfer is now in the works for next season.

headline: Franco & O’Dowd: All I Need
text: Part 12: The actors explain the fundamental difference between theater acting and film acting.

headline: Franco & O’Dowd: Professor Franco
text: Part 9: The actors discuss James’s work as a teacher and what he’s gained from both sides of the academic experience.

headline: Franco & O’Dowd: Timeless, Not Timely
text: Part 8: The actors explore what makes “Of Mice and Men” different and more personal than Steinbeck’s other depression-era work.

headline: Franco & O’Dowd: ‘This Is the End’
text: Part 10: The actors talk about James’s role as himself in the film “This Is the End,” and reflect on how comedy can illuminate truths in ways drama can’t.

headline: Franco & O’Dowd: Celebrity
text: Part 13: Chris O’Dowd talks about his writing process, and James Franco shares his thoughts on his public persona.

headline: Franco & O’Dowd: ‘Calvary’
text: Part 11: The actors discuss Chris’s upcoming film “Calvary” and talk about switching between comedy and drama.

headline: Franco & O’Dowd: Riff Raff
text: Part 14: The actors recall their earliest experiences with Steinbeck, and explore the varied audience reactions to “Spring Breakers.”

headline: Franco & O’Dowd: Daniel Desario
text: Part 16: The actors talk about James’s character on “Freaks and Geeks,” and discuss his upcoming film, “Child of God.”

headline: Franco & O’Dowd: Filming Is So Boring
text: Part 15: The actors discuss Leighton Meester’s performance as Curley’s Wife in “Of Mice and Men,” and explain the process of casting the show.

headline: Franco & O’Dowd: Creative Pitfalls
text: Part 17: The actors reflect on the importance of structure in living a creative life.

headline: Met Gala Red Carpet Arrivals
text: Part of the red carpet’s allure is the way that guests interpret (or protest) the theme.

headline: The Mulleavy Sisters Tap an Artist to Reinvent Their Book’s Cover
text: When Nevena Borissova, the owner of Curve — a boutique with locations in Miami, Los Angeles, San Francisco and New York — set out to host an event celebrating Rodarte‘s fall collection, she approached Kate and Laura Mulleavy, the sisters behind the label, to help her think outside the rack. The trio came up with the idea of putting a new twist on the 2011 book they created with the fine-art photographers Catherine Opie and Alec Soth. The Mulleavys then called on their friend, the artist and ceramist Rebekah Miles, to create 27 new individually hand-painted covers, which were unveiled yesterday at an intimate book signing at Curve’s NoHo location. “It’s something that she does really beautifully,” says Laura Mulleavy of Miles’s book-jacket paintings.

headline: Mortality Drop Seen to Follow ’06 Health Law
text: BOSTON — The death rate in Massachusetts dropped significantly after it adopted mandatory health care coverage in 2006, a study released Monday found, offering evidence that the country’s first experiment with universal coverage — and the model for crucial parts of President Obama’s health care law — has saved lives, health economists say.

headline: A Spotlight on Sex Assaults on Campus
The Fervor for Great Books and Big Ideas Isn’t Dead
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Truce at Sotheby’s After a Costly and Avoidable Battle
text: Really, Sotheby’s?

headline: Bill de Blasio Shows Liberals Can Be Pro-Development
text: Last year, I predicted that Bill de Blasio would be “New York’s most pro-development mayor in decades.” The affordable housing plan Mr. de Blasio released Monday is a step in that direction.

headline: Cellphone Searches
text: To the Editor:

headline: U.S. Policy Toward Egypt
text: To the Editor:

headline: Study of Helmet Therapy
text: To the Editor:

headline: After Buffett, Should Berkshire Hathaway Be Broken Up?
text: There is an uncomfortable question hanging over one of the world’s biggest corporations: Should Berkshire Hathaway be broken up when Warren Buffett retires or dies? The answer might be found in the very underpinnings of how American industry is organized and governed.

headline: A Red-Hot Rumor About Apple Falls Apart
text: Don’t believe everything you read online. Especially if you’re reading it on the anonymous social app Secret.

headline: 3 Are Exonerated of Murder in Cases Tied to a Discredited Detective
text: The Brooklyn district attorney’s office will ask a judge to vacate the murder convictions of three half-brothers whose trials relied on questionable evidence produced by a now discredited homicide detective, several lawyers close to the cases said.

headline: The Streamlined Life
text: Every year researchers at U.C.L.A. do a survey of incoming college freshmen. These surveys, conducted over four decades now, show how the life cycle has changed over the past couple generations.

headline: Hotel Boycott Grows Over Brunei Penal Code
text: LOS ANGELES — The response here to the planned imposition of Islamic law in Brunei, with extreme penalties for adultery and gay sex, has become more pointed in recent days as two Hollywood-related charities moved events from the Beverly Hills Hotel, which is owned by the Brunei Investment Agency.

headline: New York City Gives Families of 9/11 Victims One-Week Notice That Remains Will Be Moved
text: New York City has notified families of Sept. 11 victims that the unidentified remains of those killed at the World Trade Center will be moved on Saturday to a specially built repository at ground zero. But like much else in this yearslong process, the news was met with a mixture of anger, confusion and acceptance, reflecting the divisions of opinion, and continued heightened passions, of the relatives.

headline: Soccer Practice, Or Else!
text: Should parents force their children to do extracurricular activities?

headline: The Perfect Essay
text: Looking back on too many years of education, I can identify one truly impossible teacher. She cared about me, and my intellectual life, even when I didn’t. Her expectations were high — impossibly so. She was an English teacher. She was also my mother.

headline: Pride of Italy Takes a Dive as Soccer ‘Ultras’ Gain Control
text: ROME — It was a humiliating moment for Italian soccer, and for Italy: With the final of the prestigious Italian Cup delayed after a fan from Naples was shot outside Olympic Stadium, authorities flirted with canceling the Saturday night match between Napoli and Fiorentina of Florence. Rumors rippled through the stands, and many Napoli supporters seemed on the verge of boiling over.

headline: Big East and Big Ten Announce an Annual Series Beginning in 2015
text: The Big East and Big Ten Conferences announced Monday that they will hold a series of men’s basketball games beginning in November 2015.

headline: Balky Wi-Fi Above the Clouds
text: ATLANTA — When he was involved in marketing, it never occurred to Jack Salerno to fire up his computer during a flight, link to the Internet and dig into work. “I liked the quiet time to think,” he said.

headline: Against the Odds, a South Bronx Swim Team Finds Success
text: The pool is old and small, and scarred by chipped stone and peeling paint.

headline: A Famous Tennis Dad Writes, but Not About Tennis
text: Richard Williams stood outside his Midtown Manhattan hotel Monday afternoon, fighting a losing battle with a gusting wind as he attempted to keep a half-smoked cigarette lit.

headline: She Had to Tell What She Knew
text: Mary Willingham remembers the exact moment when she realized she had to go public. It was at the memorial service in the fall of 2012 for Bill Friday, the former president of the University of North Carolina. During his long career, Friday had championed the amateur ideal — the notion that college athletes needed also to be students, and that academics mattered as much as wins.

headline: Captain Barnes and the Wilderness
text: As night settled on the Wilderness on May 5, 1864, the moans of wounded men still on the battlefield haunted the halting sleep of the men lucky enough to survive the first day of fighting unscathed. Gen. Ulysses S. Grant had chosen the thickly wooded region west of Fredericksburg as his avenue of attack into Confederate-held Virginia.

headline: Another General Motors Official to Leave
text: DETROIT — Another top General Motors official is leaving the company after the automaker’s long-delayed recall of 2.6 million small cars with defective ignitions.

headline: Massachusetts Starts Over on Health Website After Troubles
text: WASHINGTON — Massachusetts will stop trying to fix its deeply flawed health insurance website and instead buy new software to help its residents enroll in coverage, officials there said Monday. But the state will also prepare to join the federal insurance marketplace by the next enrollment period, which starts in November, in case the new system is not working in time.

headline: The Declining Coffee Harvest
text: A fungus called “coffee rust” has caused declining harvests of Guatemalan coffee in the last two years. Luis Antonio, a coffee bean farmer, says the spread of the fungus is threatening his livelihood.

headline: Judge Paves Way for Voting on Detroit’s Recovery Plan as Two Police Unions Settle
text: DETROIT — A federal judge on Monday signed off on a document that cleared the way for tens of thousands of Detroit’s retirees, employees and bondholders to begin receiving ballots on the city’s plan for rebuilding and shrinking its debt.

headline: Banks Sued on Claims of Fixing Price of Gold
text: Frustrated traders and offbeat activists have complained for years in whispers and in online screeds that the price of gold has been subject to collusion. On Monday, these accusations of manipulation found a more august arena for expression: the federal courts.

headline: In Missouri, Republicans Prevail on Tax Bill
text: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo. — In a showdown over tax policy, the Republican-controlled State Senate on Monday overrode Democratic Gov. Jay Nixon’s veto of a major tax-cut bill, setting the stage for sharp reductions in state personal income taxes.

headline: Republicans Have a Grimm Problem
text: Representative Michael Grimm, the only Republican in New York City’s congressional delegation, was indicted last week on charges of tax fraud. He insists he is innocent, but these charges come at a particularly bad time for his fellow Republicans. A former Federal Bureau of Investigation agent, Mr. Grimm was already in trouble with many voters after he was shown on television threatening to throw a NY1 reporter off a balcony. Now he is accused of operating a restaurant illegally.

headline: Complaints of Abuse by Border Agents Often Ignored, Records Show
text: On Feb. 16, 2010, a Mexican teenager caught trying to cross into the United States near Douglas, Ariz., filed a formal complaint accusing a Border Patrol agent of punching him in the face during his arrest.

headline: Bailout Is Over for Portugal, but Side Effects Will Linger
text: LISBON — Europe’s climb out of its debt crisis has been narrated by a long debate on whether the austerity imposed on countries that needed international bailouts would bring more pain than relief.

headline: A Defeat for Religious Neutrality
text: The American values of pluralism and inclusion are central to the First Amendment, which forbids government from favoring or aligning itself with any particular religion or believers over nonbelievers.

headline: Berkshire’s Radical Strategy: Trust
text: OMAHA –“By the standards of the rest of the world, we overtrust. So far it has worked very well for us. Some would see it as weakness.”

headline: Chasing Death Camp Guards With New Tools
text: STUTTGART, Germany — After years of relative inaction, German prosecutors have opened dozens of fresh investigations of men and women suspected of having served as Nazi death camp guards, racing against the clock to bring the aging suspects to justice. Not since the end of World War II have so many cases been initiated at once.

headline: Beard Award Winners Announced
text: California restaurants and female chefs fared well in this year’s James Beard Awards, which were announced Monday night at a ceremony at Lincoln Center attended by more than 1,700 food professionals and others.

headline: Mr. de Blasio’s Moon Shot
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s housing plan is so big that it took not one but two media events, in Brooklyn and the Bronx, to unveil it on Monday, in which the mayor and local pols exulted over the plan’s breadth and ambition. Yet if Mr. de Blasio really is going to keep his campaign promise and end New York’s crisis of inequality and housing unaffordability, he is going to have to go big.

headline: Protectionism Will Only Hurt France
