text: In a bid to encourage more foreign investment in France, President François Hollande in February told executives from foreign companies that the country was “open for business.” Unfortunately, officials in his government appear to be shutting the door in one case.

headline: Ex-State Senate Leader on Trial Again for Fraud
text: ALBANY — The accusations are familiar: no-show jobs, fraud and big money for a horse of questionable value.

headline: N.F.L. Prospect From Princeton Hits Right Notes
text: PRINCETON, N.J. — The window shades were pulled low in the office of Steve Verbit, the longtime Princeton associate football coach. Caraun Reid was about to watch film. The N.F.L. draft was less than a month away, and Reid, a decorated Ivy League defensive tackle, cued the footage: Jets versus Tampa Bay Buccaneers, Sept. 8, 2013.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 5, 2014
Coca-Cola to Remove an Ingredient Questioned by Consumers
text: Coca-Cola is moving to eliminate an ingredient used in many of its citrus-flavored products after consumers expressed concerns.

headline: Judicial Nominee’s Memos on Drones Stirring Bipartisan Concern in the Senate
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s choice for a powerful appeals court appointment is in peril from both the left and the right, highlighting how the fraught politics of an election year are threatening the president’s agenda even among his allies on Capitol Hill.

headline: Marquee Matchup of Playoffs’ Second Round Has Star Power to Spare
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — Before the celebration had stopped in the Los Angeles Clippers’ locker room Saturday night, as the joy of vanquishing the Golden State Warriors in a seven-game series still coursed among the players, a scouting report of the Oklahoma City Thunder sat in each player’s cubicle.

headline: Quashed Case Against Christie Ally Was Foretaste of Scandal
text: Before the bridge scandal, there was Bennett Barlyn.

headline: Lack of Orderly Means to Distribute Aid Is Latest Setback for Afghan Village
text: ABI BARAK, Afghanistan — An outpouring of aid has come to the remote village of Abi Barak, where a devastating landslide is likely to have claimed 2,100 lives and instantly left thousands homeless. Tents, water, food and blankets have streamed in from all quarters, including community donations and international contributions.

headline: A Coffee Crop Withers
text: SAN LUCAS TOLIMÁN, Guatemala — When coffee rust attacked the farms clinging to the volcanic slopes above this Mayan town, the disease was unsparing, reducing mountainside rows of coffee trees to lattices of gray twigs.

headline: A House, and Family, Divided
text: Hester Ferris, the social lioness played by the marvelous Jan Maxwell in the terrific new play “The City of Conversation,” by Anthony Giardina, knows a fellow feline when she sees one. When the pert young woman who has arrived in Hester’s plush Georgetown living room asks innocuously if she can observe as Hester prepares for the power-player dinner party she is hosting that evening, Hester turns on her a glare both amused and assessing.

headline: So the Story Goes
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — One of the crueler tricks in the Mean Older Sibling Handbook that you might have committed when you were young was a little something dubbed “PICK UP STICKS.” In my house, at least, this was a bonus round to the game “KerPlunk,” a strategy game where you had to carefully withdraw wooden (later, plastic) skewers from a cylinder without letting any of the marbles balanced on top fall to the bottom of the cylinder.

headline: U.S. Signs New Lease to Keep Strategic Military Installation in the Horn of Africa
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said Monday that it had signed a 20-year lease on its military base in Djibouti in the Horn of Africa, the only American installation on the continent and a staging ground for counterterrorism operations in Yemen and Somalia.

headline: Obama Meets With Djibouti President
text: President Obama discussed the situation in Somalia at a meeting with President Ismail Omar Guelleh of Djibouti.

headline: High-Tech Push Has Board Games Rolling Again
text: MERCER ISLAND, Wash. — Dan Shapiro sold a company to Google and worked at Microsoft. His name is on nearly a dozen technology-related patents.

headline: PBS Seeks Web Sponsors, but Big Bird Still Won’t Sing Jingles
text: FOR the first time, PBS is signaling Madison Avenue how interested it is to sell sponsorships and other types of advertising for the online video clips and series that are published through its PBS Digital Studios division.

headline: If Nets and Heat Are Not Yet Rivals, Their Players Are
text: MIAMI — Paul Pierce insisted on Sunday that there was not a rivalry between the Nets and the Miami Heat, the teams that will meet Tuesday to begin a much-anticipated Eastern Conference semifinal playoff series.

headline: Now Comes Chapter 5 in Players’ Rivalry
text: LeBron James has tangled with Kevin Garnett and Paul Pierce in the postseason on four previous occasions, all of the battles occurring when Garnett and Pierce played for the Boston Celtics.

headline: Renovator of Victorian Beauties Profits From Preservation
text: In the enclaves of Victorian Flatbush — Prospect Park South, Ditmas Park, Midwood — no two houses look exactly alike, though many share the same grand flourishes, with turrets, wraparound porches and columns inside and out.

headline: Rhode Island: Circus Accident Linked to Metal Fastener
text: Fire officials in Providence said an accident that injured nine performers with the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus on Sunday apparently occurred when a metal fastener snapped, causing an apparatus to plummet 30 feet to the ground. Eight of the performers remained at Rhode Island Hospital on Monday, with two listed in critical condition and the rest in serious or good condition. The circus canceled two performances on Monday but said performances planned for Hartford later this week would proceed as scheduled.

headline: In South Africa, A.N.C. Is Counting on the Past
text: ALEXANDRA, South Africa — In this poor black township on the outskirts of Johannesburg, the campaign posters exhorting voters to return the African National Congress to power in Wednesday’s election reached deep into the party’s glorious past.

headline: New Mexico: New Protests Against Albuquerque Police
text: Protesters in Albuquerque threw fake arrest warrants at the police chief on Monday, prompting the City Council to end debate on a charter amendment that would transfer authority for picking the police chief from the mayor to voters. The protest came two days after an officer fatally shot Armand Martin, the 25th person killed by the police here since January 2010. The Justice Department recently released a report rebuking the Police Department for systematically using excessive force.

headline: Jeter’s Swing, for Now, Is Missing His Final Tour, Raising Questions of Resilience
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Over the course of his 20 seasons in the major leagues, Derek Jeter has played in 79 games at Angel Stadium and done well, despite some painful losses in the postseason.

headline: At Met Gala, Fashionistas Dress Up in Tribute
text: On Monday night, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s annual Costume Institute gala, there were ball gowns, leg slits, white ties and trains. Lots of trains.

headline: Mets’ Bullpen Squanders Lead as Marlins Stage a Late Rally
text: MIAMI — Mets Manager Terry Collins shrugged his shoulders, pursed his lips and averted his eyes. His bullpen had blown another game, wasting a strong start from Jon Niese.

headline: Obama Aides Tell Executives to Skip Forum
text: WASHINGTON — The White House has pressured the chief executives of some of America’s largest energy, financial and industrial corporations into canceling plans to attend an international economic forum in Russia to be hosted by President Vladimir V. Putin this month, the latest effort to isolate Moscow in retaliation for its intervention in Ukraine.

headline: Once Again, Weary Rangers Come Up Empty
text: Their coach challenged Rick Nash, Martin St. Louis and other Rangers stars to “put on their big boy pants” against Pittsburgh on Monday. But the weary Rangers responded in miserable fashion, fumbling and bumbling their way to a 2-0 loss, and falling behind the Penguins in their second-round playoff series by two games to one.

headline: Intersection | Berlin Fashion Boldness
text: In the Kreuzberg neighborhood, Ron Dietze, a musician, loves that you can wear colorful clothing, like his vintage red leather jacket, without getting strange looks.

headline: Syrian Opposition Delegation Is Given Diplomatic Status
text: WASHINGTON — As a delegation of Syrian opposition leaders arrived in Washington to plead for more American support, the Obama administration on Monday granted the group diplomatic status and pledged an additional $27 million in nonlethal assistance.

headline: Breakthrough for Crosby Sets the Tone
text: For Sidney Crosby, it was simply a matter of time.

headline: Rent Board Backs Raises Much Smaller Than Usual
text: New York City’s Rent Guidelines Board voted on Monday night to recommend an unusually low range of possible rent increases for the coming year, even raising the possibility of a rent freeze for one-year leases.

headline: With Death, ’84 Shooting Brings New Charge
text: Carlos Carromero served nearly a decade in prison after pleading guilty to attempted murder in the 1984 shooting of John Pugh, in the Bronx.

headline: Ex-General Vows to End Brotherhood if Elected
text: CAIRO — Abdul Fattah el-Sisi, the former general who led the military takeover here last summer and is expected to become president next month, vowed Monday to eliminate the Muslim Brotherhood, the Islamist group that dominated the previous elections.

headline: India Election Digest: May 6
text: What you need to know on Tuesday about India’s elections: Overseas investors aren’t convinced that the Bharatiya Janata Party will win the balloting, intellectuals are united in their opposition to Narendra Modi of the B.J.P. but divided on the alternatives, and campaigning ends for the next-to-last phase of voting.

headline: With Conspiracy-Minded Intrigue, Life Imitates Fiction in Turkey
text: ISTANBUL — Istanbul as an urban tableau of intrigue is well-worn literary and cultural terrain, traveled by Graham Greene and Ian Fleming and by more contemporary spy novelists such as Joseph Kanon and Alex Berenson.

headline: Beijing Steps Up Campaign Against Pollution
text: BEIJING — The Beijing Municipal Environmental Protection Bureau announced Monday that it had imposed fines of more than $1.7 million against companies and business ventures that violated air pollution standards in the first four months of 2014.

headline: The Narrative of Home
text: As with her novels, the decoration of the Milan apartment belonging to Italian writer Benedetta Cibrario reveals an obsession with moments gone by and objects that mark the passage of time.

headline: From the Design Curator Murray Moss, a Book of Unexpected Juxtapositions
text: For the veteran design entrepreneur Murray Moss, 2012 was a year of turning points. It saw the closing of his fabled SoHo boutique Moss, and it was also the year he was diagnosed with Parkinson’s. He soon discovered that his medication had a number of side effects. “They keep me up late at night,” he says, “and they increase my already compulsive nature.” He sought to turn these new traits to his advantage by combing through hundreds of vintage press photos in the wee hours, and combining them to create surprising, often funny visual conversations. “This is what I used to do, literally daily, for 18 years, with the objects I displayed at the store,” Moss says. “Now I exercise this obsession with juxtapositions I make with press photographs instead of objects. It’s like making a movie and filming multiple endings.” His efforts are showcased in his new book, “Tertium Quid” ($75), due out later this month in a limited print run.

headline: Inside Elena Arzak’s Kitchen
text: Last week we introduced readers to Elena Arzak, one of only two women chefs named to the 2014 World’s 50 Best Restaurants list for her family’s restaurant, Arzak, which she runs with her father Juan Mari Arzak. Here, Elena invites T into her restaurant, perfectly located, she says in the above video, in the seaside town of San Sebastián. Step into her beautifully orchestrated kitchen as she discusses Basque cuisine, the creative and modern influence El Bulli had on her regional cooking and the importance of family — from her secret to working seamlessly with her chef father to the value of a balanced and lip-smacking staff meal. “The staff meal or family meal is really important,” she says. “It has to be very well made, very well cooked, no different from what goes out to the restaurant.”

headline: Getty to Jump-Start Latin American Art Research in California
text: LOS ANGELES — The ambitious regionwide arts collaboration known as Pacific Standard Time, which three years ago focused on Southern California art from 1945 to 1980, will have for its sequel a broader but still relatively underexamined field: Latin American art.

headline: South Korea: Ferry Diver Dies
text: One of the civilian divers searching for victims of the South Korean ferry disaster died on Tuesday after losing consciousness underwater, officials said. The diver, identified as Lee Gwang-ok, 53, was employed by a salvage company that worked with Navy divers in the now three-week-old effort to recover bodies from the 6,825-ton ferry Sewol, which capsized and sank off southwestern South Korea on April 16. The divers have struggled against strong currents and poor visibility to reach the ship and then make their way through a dark maze of corridors and cabins clogged with debris. As of Tuesday, 39 people remained missing, with 263 confirmed dead.

headline: George H. Heilmeier, an Inventor of LCDs, Dies at 77
text: George H. Heilmeier, an electrical engineer who in the 1960s helped invent a kind of screen display that used liquid crystals to project images — technology that is now ubiquitous in telephones, digital watches, computer monitors and flat-screen televisions — died April 21 in Plano, Tex. He was 77.

headline: Word of the Day | typhoon
text: typhoon•\ti-ˈfün\• noun

headline: For Female Filmmakers, Indies Provide More Work Than Studios, Study Finds
text: In case there was any doubt, women fare better when they go independent.

headline: Time to Worry About Stock Market Bubbles
text: With relatively little fanfare, the stock market has become expensive again.

headline: Times Minute | Three Primaries to Watch
text: Jonathan Martin, national political correspondent for The Times, on contests to watch in North Carolina, Georgia and Kentucky for early clues about the 2014 midterm elections.

headline: Times Minute | Three Primaries to Watch
text: In the Video

headline: What’s On Tuesday
text: 8 P.M. (Starz Cinema) ANIMAL KINGDOM (2010) A bleached-blond mama lion (Jacki Weaver, above, with Sullivan Stapleton) with piercing blue eyes and a glinting smile and her brood of armed robbers and drug dealers (Luke Ford, Mr. Stapleton and Ben Mendelsohn) take on rogue cops in Melbourne in this directorial and screenwriting debut from David Michôd. But then a police sergeant (Guy Pearce) on the right side of the law interrogates her grandson (James Frecheville), who has been thrown into the fray after his mother dies of a heroin overdose, and plants the seeds of distrust that force him to fight to save himself. “The film’s depiction of the raw fear lurking below the brothers’ braggadocio is the most pronounced emotion in a movie whose focus on the personalities of its criminals suggests an Australian answer to ‘Goodfellas,’ minus the wiseguy humor,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. “The relative absence of gun battles and car chases helps ‘Animal Kingdom’ build and sustain a mood of deepening dread. It goes out of its way to deglamorize the criminal life and portray its family of crooks as warped psychopathic thugs in a losing enterprise.”

headline: U.S. Air Force Aids Rescue of Chinese Fishermen in Pacific
text: United States Air Force rescue personnel parachuted into the Pacific Ocean 1,100 nautical miles off the Mexican coast to assist in the rescue of Chinese fishermen injured in a fire.

headline: Jack Agüeros, a Champion of El Barrio, Dies at 79
text: Jack Agüeros was an activist. The term is concise, like his many sonnets, but it hardly captures the expanse of his life, which saw him go from a childhood in East Harlem to defending its Puerto Rican people as an antipoverty official, celebrating its culture by expanding and moving El Museo del Barrio, and memorializing its greatest poet by translating the complete works of Julia de Burgos.

headline: Corrections: May 6, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Another Violent Attack at Railway Station in China
text: A man with a knife slashed at least six people during a brazen late morning assault outside a railroad station in Guangzhou, China, on Tuesday, officials said. It was the third such attack by assailants at a railroad station since March.

headline: Yankees Angrily Fall to Angels in First Game of Trip
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Shawn Kelley had just been removed from the game after issuing a walk to Howie Kendrick in the eighth inning, and as he walked off the mound, he yelled something at the home-plate umpire, Laz Diaz, who had already been involved in a nasty argument with Yankees Manager Joe Girardi.

headline: U.S. Said to Seek Records From Anticorruption Panel’s Members
text: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan have issued a grand jury subpoena seeking emails, text messages and other records from all the members of the anticorruption commission that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo abruptly shut down in March, three people briefed on the matter said on Monday.

headline: Hedge Fund Moguls’ Pay Has the 1% Looking Up
text: Hedge fund managers heavily populate the so-called 1 percent in the United States. And they are getting richer.

headline: The Device that Runs the World’s Biggest Election
text: NEW DELHI — Thanks to a device that is the size and shape of a mini piano keyboard, India can boast that the country’s voters, all 814.5 million of them in 543 constituencies, can cast their ballot electronically, even in areas that have just one person.

headline: Earnings Slide at Barclays on Trading Slowdown
text: LONDON – The British bank Barclays said on Tuesday that its first-quarter profit fell 5 percent from the period a year earlier as revenue from trading bonds, currencies and commodities declined.

headline: UBS Profit Rises 7% Amid Restructuring
text: LONDON – The Swiss bank UBS said on Tuesday that first-quarter profit rose 7 percent as it reshaped its business to reduce risk and better navigate future financial upheavals.

headline: Beijing Kebab Vendors Among List of Polluters Hit With Fines
text: China has engaged in a “war against pollution,” as Prime Minister Li Keqiang has said. And in the trenches on the enemy side are legions of roadside kebab vendors, if one takes Beijing officials at their word.

headline: Test Yourself | History, May 6
text: Take the Quiz

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | X Still Marks Sunken Spot, and Gold Awaits
text: In “X Still Marks Sunken Spot, and Gold Awaits,” William J. Broad reports on a discovered shipwreck, decades of legal battles, an arrest warrant and finally a new recovery effort.

headline: Universal Mammograms Show We Don’t Understand Risk
text: In an effort to reduce childhood injuries, the American Academy of Pediatrics issued a policy statement in 2001 recommending that all kids younger than 2 sit in safety seats in airplanes as they do in cars.

headline: Radio Killed the Political Star
text: Mike Rogers keeps telling me how fed up he is with all of the “brand identity politicians” he is serving alongside in the United States Congress. And by this, the Republican from Michigan means those colleagues who would rather raise their profiles and get into the media and “do that celebrity thing” than, say, pass bills or help constituents or win the respect of peers. “They are all about their brand,” Rogers laments, drawing out the word with an extra disdainful beat: “BRAAH-und.” This, of course, is one reason that Rogers has decided to cede his chairmanship of the House Intelligence Committee, and all the loudmouths in the People’s Chamber that come with it, for his very own talk-radio show. In March, he announced his decision to leave behind the “whole celebrity political class in Washington, D.C.” for what is expected to be a nationally syndicated gig with Cumulus Media.

headline: Q. and A. About Birds in New York City
text: Updated, May 8 | Thank you to everyone who participated in our Q. and A. with Gabriel Willow. We are no longer accepting questions for this feature, but his responses about birds are available in the comments section.

headline: Running Food, Taking Photos
text: So, what’s a food runner?

headline: Does Suffering Make Us Stronger and Lead to Success?
text: The writer Alfie Kohn challenges the drumbeat of critics who contend that kids these days get too many rewards, from stickers to trophies, without truly earning them. He disputes the commonly held notion that suffering and conditionally granting awards (e.g., trophies only for the winners) prepare children for real life and teach them resilience.

headline: As Ukrainian Election Looms, Western Powers and Russia Campaign for Influence
text: KIEV, Ukraine — Russia and the West maneuvered on Tuesday ahead of a seemingly inevitable clash over Ukraine’s plan to hold a presidential election on May 25 that Western powers view as crucial to restoring stability and that the Kremlin says will be illegitimate, particularly if the government in Kiev cannot first stabilize the country.

headline: G.O.P. Establishment Sees Its Candidate Win North Carolina Senate Primary
text: WASHINGTON — Thom Tillis’s victory Tuesday in the North Carolina Republican Senate primary sets up a campaign against Senator Kay Hagan, a first-term Democrat, in what will be one of the nation’s most contentious and expensive races in the battle to win control of Congress.

headline: In Our Pages: May 7
text: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: new technology is changing war reporting in 1914; dictators keep Chamberlain from reading crime novels in 1939.

headline: A Festive Curtain Raiser, Yes, But One With Somber Hues
text: Spring for Music opened on Monday evening at Carnegie Hall with a powerful New York premiere: Christopher Rouse’s “Requiem” by the New York Philharmonic and the Westminster Symphonic Choir, conducted by Alan Gilbert. In many ways it was a perverse choice for the occasion. This weeklong festival, in its fourth and — because of a shortage of financing — final year, is a joyous celebration of orchestral excellence and adventurous programming. Orchestras from across North America converge for a good-natured contest of skill and spirits, cheered on by supporters who fill the auditorium with the colors of their hometown band.

headline: Rights Lawyer Detained Ahead of Tiananmen Anniversary
text: A prominent civil rights lawyer has been detained by the Beijing police one month before the 25th anniversary of the deadly crackdown on the Tiananmen protest movement, friends and human rights groups said on Tuesday.

headline: New York Today: Sports Turnaround
text: Good morning on this fair Tuesday.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: 4 Employed by Operator of Doomed South Korean Ferry Are Arrested
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Four officials with the operator of the doomed South Korean ferry have been arrested on charges of overloading the ship with cargo, a senior prosecutor said on Tuesday, as President Park Geun-hye attributed one of her country’s worst peacetime disasters to corporate “greed.”

headline: Editorial Contest Winner | The Wonders of Wandering
text: A video by Lucas Schroeder made to accompany his winning essay.

headline: Bayer Deal to Expand Consumer Business With Merck Deal
text: Updated, 12:06 p.m. | LONDON — The German drug maker Bayer said on Tuesday that it had agreed to acquire Merck’s consumer care business for $14.2 billion, a deal that will make Bayer one of the largest providers of over-the-counter products.

headline: How to Move the Windows Address Book to a New Computer
text: Q. Is there a way to move the information in the Windows XP address book program to a Windows 7 computer so I don’t have to retype it?

headline: Too Hot to Be Safe
text: Unwary smokers of electronic cigarettes may have a new danger to worry about. Those who heat the liquid nicotine and its solvents to very high temperatures to get an especially big nicotine jolt are apt to get a big dose of formaldehyde or other carcinogens as well.

headline: Profiling the City He Knew, and Learned to Know
text: For two years, Michael Powell has written the Gotham column about New York politics and government. In July he will become a Sports of The Times columnist. Before he immerses himself in the world of sports, we asked him to reflect on his time writing about New York and New Yorkers.

headline: Using Mac Notifications and Multi-Touch Gestures
text: Q. I have a new Mac laptop and have noticed that I keep accidentally doing something that opens a list of calendar appointments and new email messages on the right side of the screen that stays there until I click around. What is this?

headline: The First Meeting Was Fabulous. Why Isn’t My Phone Ringing?
text: I believe I’m a good salesperson. I’m good at getting meetings with the right people and getting them excited, but I suffer from recurring attacks of what I call First Meeting Syndrome. My first meeting is red hot, but I struggle to get a follow-up; time passes and the deal goes cold. I’m a great door-opener, but I’m not so good at closing the deal.

headline: Daily Report: Computer Technology Is Reviving the Board Game
text: Technology, by all rights, should have killed old-fashioned games, which can never equal the eye-popping graphics, visceral action and immense online communities of today’s video games. Yet the opposite has occurred. Largely because of new technologies, there has been a creative outpouring of games by independent designers, Nick Wingfield reports.

headline: U.S. International Relations
text: Obama finds himself outnumbered on the international court.

headline: A Big Haul for Hedge Fund Moguls
text: Hedge fund managers, who heavily populate the so-called 1 percent in the United States, are getting richer. The 25 highest-earning hedge fund managers in the United States took home a total of $21.15 billion in compensation in 2013, according to an annual ranking published on Tuesday by Institutional Investor’s Alpha magazine, DealBook’s Alexandra Stevenson writes. The payday, earned in a year when most hedge fund managers fell short of market performance, is the highest since 2010 and 50 percent more than in 2012. No women placed among the top 50.

headline: Words We Love Too Much
text: A colleague noted six uses of the description “deep-pocketed” in our copy in a single week not long ago. There were four more appearances during another recent week: “deep-pocketed investors,” “deep-pocketed donors” and “deep-pocketed tobacco companies” (twice).

headline: In Performance: Vanessa Williams of ‘After Midnight’
text: This week’s video features the actress Vanessa Williams singing the number “I Can’t Give You Anything but Love,” written by Dorothy Fields and Jimmy McHugh, from the Broadway musical revue “After Midnight.” Ms. Williams is performing in the show at the Brooks Atkinson Theater through May 11.

headline: VSCO, a Digital Photography Company, Raises $40 Million From Accel Partners
text: Chances are, if you have used Instagram, you have come across the hashtag #VSCO or #VSCOCam.

headline: AstraZeneca Makes Its Case Against Pfizer’s Takeover Bid
text: Updated, 4:39 p.m. | AstraZeneca, the British drug maker, on Tuesday made an impassioned defense for itself as a stand-alone company, just a day after the American pharmaceutical giant Pfizer again pressed its case for a $106 billion takeover offer.

headline: Pistorius Is Accused of ‘Sinister’ Aside During Break at Trial
text: The trial of Oscar Pistorius, the double-amputee South African track star, took a bizarre turn on Tuesday when a lawyer claimed that during an adjournment, the athlete had asked a close friend of the woman he is accused of murdering, “How can you sleep at night?”

headline: Jimmy Kimmel Gets a Two-Year Contract Extension
text: ABC has affirmed its commitment to its late-night star Jimmy Kimmel, extending the host’s contract for two more years.

headline: Alphonso Mangoes Flood Indian Market After E.U. Ban
text: MUMBAI, India — The Indian mango, and in particular the Alphonso, is a much-coveted and much-fetishized fruit by Indians, loved as much for its flavor as for its scarcity. Because of its rarity the fruit has achieved near-mythical importance in India, where access to mangoes early in the season is a sign of prestige.

headline: U.S. Climate Has Already Changed, Study Finds, Citing Heat and Floods
text: The effects of human-induced climate change are being felt in every corner of the United States, scientists reported Tuesday, with water growing scarcer in dry regions, torrential rains increasing in wet regions, heat waves becoming more common and more severe, wildfires growing worse, and forests dying under assault from heat-loving insects.

headline: Paying for Snacks: An Outrage
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Float, Memory
text: Amid an ocean of style disasters, one man explores the sartorial and psychological conundrums of the swim trunk.

headline: Barclays Technology Banker to Join Evercore
text: The exodus of former Lehman Brothers bankers from Barclays continues as its top technology banker departs the bank.

headline: Fund Founded by Alistair Lumsden Opens to Outside Money
text: LONDON – East Lodge Capital Partners, a London hedge fund founded by Alistair Lumsden, has opened to outside money, according to a letter sent to investors on Tuesday.

headline: Do Critics Make Good Novelists?
text: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Daniel Mendelsohn and Leslie Jamison discuss whether literary critics can also be good novelists.

headline: A List of Those Who’ve Left Barclays This Year
text: Tuesday brought the announcement of another senior banker from Barclays – J. Stuart Francis, chairman of the bank’s global technology group – who is decamping to Evercore Partners.

headline: Join the Debate: Should We Let Kids Quit Activities?
text: It’s me versus  my colleague Bruce Feiler on Room for Debate. (Bruce writes “This Life” for Sunday Styles.) Bruce is a staunch advocate of kid-commitment:

headline: Cornelius Gurlitt, Scrutinized Son of Nazi-Era Art Dealer, Dies at 81
text: BERLIN — Cornelius Gurlitt, the German recluse who captured the art world’s attention last fall after it was revealed that he had kept hidden for decades a collection of 19th- and 20th-century European masterworks amassed by his father under the Nazis in his Munich apartment, died on Tuesday at his home in Munich. He was 81.

headline: Jonny Greenwood to Join Performance of His Film Score
text: Jonny Greenwood, the lead guitarist for Radiohead who has been devoting himself in recent years to experimental orchestral music – an interest he developed as a teenage violist – will join the Wordless Music Orchestra in September for a concert performance of his “There Will Be Blood” film score. The performances, on Sept. 19 and 20 at the United Palace Theater in Washington Heights, will include a full screening of the 2007 Paul Thomas Anderson film, with the orchestra playing the score live. (Besides the sections composed by Mr. Greenwood, the score includes music by Arvo Pärt and Brahms.)

headline: How an Experiment With Dolls Helped Lead to School Integration
text: This 1947 photograph (by Gordon Parks, for Ebony Magazine) may look simply like a child being observed at play, but, in fact, it reveals an experiment that helped lead 60 years ago this month to the Supreme Court’s monumental decision in Brown v. Board of Education, demanding the racial integration of American public schools.

headline: Even With Maturity, Paul’s Inner Defiance Flourishes
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — Do not let the clever commercials with his alter ego fool you. And those bright, expressive eyes? They are not the windows to this soul.

headline: Capus, Once Head of NBC News, Moves to CBS Evening News
text: CBS News announced on Tuesday that Steve Capus, the former president of NBC News, would become the executive producer of its evening newscast, anchored by Scott Pelley.

headline: Plans for Barenboim-Said Academy in Berlin Unveiled
text: BERLIN — The Barenboim-Said Academy unveiled the architectural model for its new headquarters at a news conference on Tuesday here and announced an official opening date of October 2016.

headline: A Merging of Movement Cultures and Subcultures
text: There is no chief curator, no unifying aesthetic and no central headquarters for Danse: A French-American Festival of Performance and Ideas. This citywide undertaking, led by the Cultural Services of the French Embassy, is willfully, delightfully heterogeneous.

headline: Two Ensembles Step Into the Other’s Shoes
text: It’s not unusual for ensembles to have a composer or two in their midst, although it’s certainly more uncommon for all members to be performers and composers. And it’s surely a first for a group to feature a trombone, trumpet, clarinet and baritone, the combination that makes up the ensemble Loadbang.

headline: Today in Small Business: Credit Cards for Small Businesses
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Scent Messaging Wafts In
text: Tuesday begins the slow rollout of oNotes, a so-called “scent messaging platform” from which all sorts of olfactory miracles are supposed to unfurl, including a device, out in early 2015, that will deliver scent messages (via text, tweet or email) and play olfactory “tunes.” Don’t scoff: the oPhone is no overpriced Febreze dispenser. One of its inventors is David Edwards, a bio-engineer at Harvard and the founder of Le Laboratoire, a celebrated “collaboration” hub in Paris, who has been exploring the far edges of food and technology with products like edible packaging and inhalers that deliver shots of taste and aromas. He’s a bit of rock star, or to mix imagery, Willy Wonka with lots of venture capital.

headline: Sotomayor Finds Her Voice Among Justices
text: WASHINGTON — “I am a lawyer’s judge,” Justice Sonia Sotomayor said last year. “I write very technically.”

headline: Why Are We Moving Again?
text: I added up the expenses for our move: the trans-Atlantic move itself, health insurance, house rental and car. I considered the amount, went to the kitchen and opened a bag of chips. My husband, Matt, came in. We usually work at night after we put our two children to bed and then meet in the kitchen for snacks.

headline: The American Scholar Crowdsources a Sonnet
text: Statisticians and late-night dorm-room bull session partisans have long debated whether a monkey banging away at a typewriter for an infinite amount of time would inevitably tap out the complete works of Shakespeare. But can a swarm of people on the Internet write a plausible sonnet in 14 weeks?

headline: Jessye Norman Talks About ‘Stand Up Straight and Sing!’
text: “Stand Up Straight and Sing!,” the memoir by the soprano Jessye Norman that came out on Tuesday, takes readers from her close-knit girlhood community in Augusta, Ga., to Carnegie Hall and beyond. Ms. Norman talks about her childhood in a supportive but segregated world, singing for Rosa Parks, befriending Marian Anderson and “growing up” as an artist. Ms. Norman spoke about her book and her life during a recent interview at Carnegie Hall. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

headline: Morgan Stanley Fined $5 Million Over I.P.O. Work
text: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority has fined Morgan Stanley $5 million, saying that the firm did not follow proper procedures in the initial public offerings for 83 companies including Facebook and Yelp.

headline: G.M. Recalls 56,000 Saturn Auras for Gearshift Cable Defect
text: After resisting federal regulators for about three years, General Motors is recalling about 56,000 Saturn Aura sedans from the 2007-8 model years because a transmission shifter cable could break, which would keep the driver from being able to shift the transmission into park.

headline: Image of the Day: May 6
text: Children eating their midday meal at a government school in Jammu and Kashmir.

headline: New Kidnapping Reported in Nigeria as U.S. Offers Help
text: ABUJA, Nigeria — A second kidnapping of schoolgirls in Nigeria’s northeast by Islamist militants put new pressure on the country’s troubled government, which had been hoping to showcase its emergence as Africa’s largest economy this week but instead has been forced to confront its failure to contain a growing insurgency in its north.

headline: A Conversation With Roz Chast
text: How did you pull this off, Roz Chast? How did you document the last eight years of your parents’ lives, in your distinctively doodle-ish drawings and candid prose, and make the story highly specific to their escape-from-the-Cossacks pasts in Brooklyn and, simultaneously, so universal? And how did you make this memoir — tellingly titled “Can’t We Talk About Something More Pleasant?” — both heartbreaking and snortingly funny?

headline: SAP and VMware Head for the Future Together
text: The big incumbents in enterprise computing are doing a lot of keeping up with the times this month.

headline: A Lost Mendelssohn Song Surfaces
text: The manuscript of a lost song by Felix Mendelssohn that was known to scholars only by its title – “Des Menschen Herz ist ein Schacht” (“A Man’s Heart Is Like a Mine”) – has turned up in a private American collection. Its whereabouts had been uncertain since the late 19th century, when it was listed in Leipzig auction catalogs in 1862 and 1872. It is about to be auctioned again, on May 24 at Christie’s in London. The house’s online catalog gives its expected sale price as £15,000 to £25,000 (about $25,000 to $42,000).

headline: Strolling Through Paris, Solo
text: “It was easy in Paris to surrender to the moment,” Stephanie Rosenbloom wrote in the Travel section this weekend. “But why? What alchemy transmuted ordinary activities, be it a walk across a bridge or the unwrapping of butter, into a pleasure?

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 37
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Missouri Republicans Hand Defeat to Governor Once Called ‘Purplish’
text: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo. — Last September, Gov. Jay Nixon, a Democrat, pulled off a political long shot: He lobbied so successfully against a tax-cut bill championed by the Republican-controlled Legislature that the lawmakers were unable to override his veto.

headline: Times Minute | Climate Change Report
text: Climate change “has moved firmly into the present,” scientists reporting to the White House said. Also on the Minute, South Africa’s national elections and advance bids for top art at spring auctions.

headline: Times Minute | Climate Change Report
text: In the Video

headline: 60th Anniversary of the Four-Minute Mile
text: Roger Bannister broke the four-minute mile 60 years ago today. His time was 3 minutes 59.4 seconds.

headline: The Most Daring Red-Carpet Ensembles From Last Night’s Met Gala
text: Last night, the Anna Wintour Costume Center at the Metropolitan Museum of Art held its annual gala to commemorate the work of the midcentury couturier Charles James. While the red carpet boasted no shortage of on-theme voluminous ball gowns and opera gloves — as worn by Sarah Jessica Parker in Oscar de La Renta, Karen Elson in Zac Posen and Suki Waterhouse in a stunning Burberry — the most interesting looks of the evening deviated from that formula. From Star Wars prints and exposed midriffs to brocade cigarette pants and austere minimalism, T salutes the women who politely declined the dress code and instead demonstrated what a fashion red carpet is really all about.

headline: Ask Well: Polio Vaccine
text: Do you have a question about the polio vaccine? Ask Well. Your question may be answered by our reporter, Donald G. McNeil, Jr.

headline: Major Research Groups Are Given Low Marks on Disclosing Donors
text: WASHINGTON — The conservative-leaning Hoover Institution, based in California, and the liberal Center for American Progress, based in Washington, are polar opposites in terms of political leanings. But according to a first-of-its-kind survey of the world’s most prominent research organizations, the institutions share an important trait: a relatively poor record of disclosing the sources of their financing.

headline: A Singing Nun for a Reality TV World
text: ROME — A true if unlikely tale: Young woman enrolls at a drama school sponsored by nuns, where the artistic director is a former Italian erotic film actress who redirected her career after a religious awakening. The students are selected to perform before the pope at St. Peter’s Square, but during rehearsals the young woman fractures an ankle.

headline: Witnesses on China Train Station Attack
text: Witnesses recalled moments of chaos after a knife attack at a railway station in China’s southern city of Guangzhou wounded six people.

headline: Europe Seeks Tougher Rules on Aircraft Recorders
text: PARIS — Nearly two months after a Malaysian jetliner disappeared, Europe’s aviation safety agency on Tuesday formally proposed a series of new measures aimed at improving the chances of finding the flight recorders of aircraft that crash at sea.

headline: The Party and the Hangover
text: Here are a couple of ideas that didn’t make it into my Sunday column on “Paying For the Party: How College Maintains Inequality,” a rich and depressing new book about the relationship between libertine social life and socioeconomic stratification at a prominent Midwestern state university:

headline: What Tim Geithner Got Right
text: Jennifer Taub is an associate professor at Vermont Law School. Her book “Other People’s Houses” will be published on May 27 by Yale University Press.

headline: Ex-Christie Aide, Testifying in Bridge Inquiry, Portrays a Highly Political Office
text: TRENTON — Providing a vivid, firsthand account of how the George Washington Bridge lane closings exploded into scandal in Gov. Chris Christie’s office, a former aide to the New Jersey governor testified that the woman he cast as the central villain in the scandal was not “a decision maker,” and that she did not believe that woman had planned the closings.

headline: A Mysterious Republican Committee in the Virgin Islands
text: There are a few things you should know about the Virgin Islands Republican Party: It has no full-time staff, has not had regular meetings for nearly two years, and only about 4 percent of the $200,000 it has raised since last fall has gone to party coffers.

headline: Rainbow Room Will Reopen in October
text: Headliner

headline: 101 Places to Find Great Coffee in New York
text: The number of serious coffee shops in New York has exploded. Enter your address to find the shops closest to you.

headline: Wheelies: The i3 Invasion Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: A Tribute to Cannon Ball Baker’s Century-Old Motorcycle Record Hits the Road
text: SAN DIEGO —  A tribute to the  record-setting cross-country motorcycle journey by  Erwin G. Baker, known universally as Cannon Ball, 100 years ago is underway, with a group of enthusiasts retracing Baker’s 11-day ride, May 3-14, from San Diego to New York City.

headline: A Dual Review of What’s New, Starring Raymond Pettibon and Iris Apfel
text: Raymond Pettibon, American artist and counterculture prophet whose drawings for the band Black Flag helped define punk culture, takes on Iris Apfel, style icon, interior designer and self-proclaimed “geriatric starlet” who will return in June to HSN, where she sells her Rara Avis line of chic and affordable accessories. (A new book of Pettibon’s work, “Raymond Pettibon: To Wit,” was just released.) See the chart.

headline: Scene City: Inside (and After) the Met Ball
text: The annual star-filled gala at Met’s newly named Anna Wintour Costume Center, followed by downtown party.

headline: Rap Genius Website Agrees to License With Music Publishers
text: Rap Genius, a popular website that compiles annotations of song lyrics, has reached a licensing agreement with music publishers after being accused of using the lyrics of thousands of songs without permission.

headline: Americans Are Outliers in Views on Climate Change
text: As President Obama sets out to convince the public that climate change requires immediate attention, he has his work cut out for him.

headline: New Venture Envisions Films Based on Gritty Journalism
text: LOS ANGELES — An Oscar-winning screenwriter, a billionaire film financier and a well-known magazine editor have come together to form a movie and television company built on a journalism foundation.

headline: French Set Conditions for G.E. Takeover of Alstom
text: PARIS – The French government, caught between concern about jobs at home and the nation’s reputation abroad for meddling in the economy, is plunging more deeply into the takeover offer for Alstom, one of France’s premier companies.

headline: Netflix Redesigns Logo — Sort Of
text: When Netflix created its first logo — which is black and white and red all over — the company was going for a LOOK AT ME design.

headline: Canny Taste Buds and a Nose for Sleuthing
text: There’s only one recipe in “Delicious!,” Ruth Reichl’s first novel, but it’s a keeper. You have to flip to the back to find it. It’s for a gingerbread cake enlivened by orange zest and fresh ginger and black pepper and cloves and cardamom. It’s for grown-up taste buds.

headline: Missouri Keeps Tumbling Rightward
text: The Missouri legislature had no trouble passing a big tax cut today over the veto of Gov. Jay Nixon. As a Missouri native, I’m probably more irritated by this than most Times readers are, but my state is only one of many that have been sharply pulled to the right in the last few years. What’s happening in Jefferson City is already familiar to residents of Wisconsin, Michigan, Kansas, North Carolina, and many others.

headline: Travel Companies Boycott Brunei-Owned Hotel Group
text: Travel companies are boycotting the Dorchester Collection of hotels this week after Hassanal Bolkiah, the sultan of Brunei, the small, oil-rich country on the island of Borneo that owns the hotel group, began implementing a new criminal code that will allow for homosexuals and adulterers to be stoned to death.

headline: The New Wave of Oyster Bars
text: LOS ANGELES — On the surface, Connie & Ted’s is the sort of hot new restaurant you’d expect in West Hollywood. Its chef and co-owner, Michael Cimarusti, is an established culinary star. Its imposing building looks like a ski chalet outfitted with repurposed NASA parts. The busy valet-parking attendants see few economy cars.

headline: The Garden, Both Muse and Oracle at L’Arpège
text: PARIS — Dinner started with a plate of leafy radishes followed by a small cabbage turnover, and ended with a garlic crème brûlée whose burned-sugar shell had been liberally spritzed with lemon confit. In between came a dozen courses made from turnips, carrots, peas, beets, cauliflower and potatoes. Two see-through bands of lardo on grilled white asparagus and, down at the bottom of vegetable minestrone, some bits of chorizo that would have fit into a gum wrapper were the only visible signs of animal flesh.

headline: You Won 50 Games, Coach? Your Job Security’s Still Zero
text: Last year, it was George Karl, Lionel Hollins and Vinny Del Negro. This year, so far, it is Mark Jackson.

headline: Watching North Carolina for Clues to the Senate
text: Over the last two cycles, the Republican nominating process cost the party critical Senate seats in states like Missouri, Delaware, Indiana, and probably in Colorado and Nevada as well. Similar mistakes in 2014 could easily cost Republicans the chance to take control of the Senate.

headline: How Bayer’s Buy Makes Sense
text: Bayer’s $14.2 billion acquisition of Merck’s consumer care business is less pricey than it looks.

headline: In a Wheelchair, Honing a Defiant Stand-Up Act
text: Can a calamity plus a couple of months at Bellevue Hospital Center equal comedy?

headline: Judge Voids Murder Convictions for 3 Half Brothers Linked to Brooklyn Detective
text: The decades-old murder convictions of three half brothers whose arrests were facilitated by a now discredited homicide detective were vacated in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn on Tuesday, as prosecutors acknowledged that the men had been deprived of fair trials because of a questionable witness.

headline: Twitter Plunges as More Shares Hit Market
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Shares of Twitter went into free fall on Tuesday as early investors became eligible to sell their shares on the market for the first time. The company’s shares dropped 17.8 percent, to close at $31.85, their lowest level since the company’s initial public offering of stock in November.

headline: An Artist Who Let His Ideas (and Others) Do the Work
text: The central action in “Sol LeWitt,” Chris Teerink’s eye-catching and informative new documentary about that great American conceptual artist, is the execution of one of his pieces — “Wall Drawing 801: Spiral” — on the interior wall of a vast, bell-shaped room at a Dutch museum.

headline: Tiny Mouths to Feed, a Path Often Fraught
text: Whether spraying or leaking, massaged by hand or pumped by machine, the breasts of the young mothers in “Breastmilk” are arguably more active than the infants they nourish. Cheerfully exposed or decorously veiled, the functioning of these workhorses may be life-sustaining, but, as Dana Ben-Ari’s admirably agenda-free documentary reveals, it can also be shockingly stressful.

headline: Reports on Alibaba’s I.P.O.
text: Investors are salivating over the initial stock offering of Alibaba Group, the giant Chinese e-commerce company.

headline: A Portrait of the Outsider Artist, Older and Still Unfiltered
text: In more ways than one, Tamar Halpern and Chris Quilty’s documentary “Llyn Foulkes One Man Band” is about not knowing when to stop. The filmmakers are blessed and cursed with a subject who seems to lack the usual filters. We in turn witness Mr. Foulkes in action, at length — revamping his works, railing against the art world and speaking his neurotic mind.

headline: Sterling’s Right-Hand Man Is Placed on a Leave of Absence
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — The N.B.A. took another step in trying to clean up from the Donald Sterling scandal, announcing Tuesday that Andy Roeser, the Los Angeles Clippers’ president and Sterling’s longtime lieutenant, had been put on an indefinite leave of absence.

headline: G.E.'s Bid for Alstom Units Puts Siemens in a Bind
text: FRANKFURT — If the American industrial giant General Electric has a corporate doppelgänger in Europe, it is the German company Siemens. Both are global conglomerates that make trains, medical scanners and — most notably at the moment — the turbines and other equipment that generate and transport much of the world’s electricity.

headline: Scene City: Inside (and After) the Met Ball
text: The annual star-filled gala at Met’s newly named Anna Wintour Costume Center, followed by downtown party.

headline: Lewinsky Breaks Silence About Clinton Affair, Saying She Was ‘Made a Scapegoat’
text: WASHINGTON — Monica Lewinsky says she became reclusive during Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign for president in 2008 for fear that she would be used for political purposes and that she feels “gun-shy” even now as Mrs. Clinton considers another run in 2016.

headline: New Ice Cream Flavors Debut This Season, Houston Pralines and More
text: To Scoop: New Ice Cream Flavors Include Beer and Olive Oil

headline: Chamber of Commerce Makes Ad Buy Supporting Pro-Business Republicans
text: The U.S. Chamber of Commerce on Wednesday is releasing new 30-second television ads for 10 House Republican candidates, in a more than $3 million buy that will last for two weeks and is intended to support candidates who the group believes can win in November.

headline: Knee-Jerk Revivals and Other Punch Lines
text: At the end of a long, bleary season on Broadway, a burnt-out case ducks into a hole in the wall off Times Square, looking for a little sympathetic companionship. Soon enough, he finds it in a woman perched on top of a piano, wearing a little beret and an air of infinite jadedness.

headline: The Stock Market, in Six Charts
text: Recently on The Upshot, we explained why the stock market looks expensive. No doubt some stock traders and analysts will disagree and offer highly technical arguments to the contrary. I’ve often found the debate around stock market valuations can be confusing. So below is a step-by-step guide, with some charts, to help to make sense of the current stock market outlook.

headline: Chinese Giant Alibaba Will Go Public, Listing in U.S.
text: Updated, 9:04 p.m. | The Chinese e-commerce behemoth Alibaba Group filed paperwork on Tuesday in the United States to sell stock to the public for the first time, in an embrace of the global capital markets that represents a coming-of-age for China’s booming Internet industry.

headline: Text to Text | President Johnson’s ‘Great Society’ Speech and ‘50 Years Into the War on Poverty, Hardship Hits Back’
text: President Johnson announced 50 years ago this month his vision for a “Great Society” during two speeches — first at Ohio University and then at the University of Michigan. In those speeches he detailed his grand vision for America, which included not just ending poverty and racial injustice, but also a plan to build the Great Society “in our cities, in our countryside and in our classrooms.” A centerpiece of President Johnson’s Great Society was to free all Americans of the “crushing weight of poverty.” In this Text to Text, we pair President Johnson’s “Great Society” speech with an article by Trip Gabriel describing the new face of poverty in rural West Virginia.

headline: Fanwood, N.J.: A Future Coupled With Transit
text: Every morning, Arbi Zadorian, a software programmer, walks a few blocks into town where he joins scores of other commuters at the Fanwood station to catch trains to Newark or New York. Built in 1874, the Victorian station is the oldest in Union County. It is also what has come to define this borough’s past, present and future.

headline: Where to Find Serious Coffee in New York? Everywhere
text: If you want to see just how much has changed in New York’s coffee scene in the last few years, stop by Gregorys Coffee.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: The Gun Report: May 6, 2014
text: Yesterday, the Supreme Court declined to consider a challenge to a New Jersey law that prohibits residents from carrying guns in public. It would have been the most significant gun control case since the District of Columbia v. Heller decision in 2008, which upheld the right to keep handguns at home for self-defense.

headline: The Curious Case of Milwaukee’s Suburban Voters
text: “The most polarized part of a polarized state in a polarized nation” — that’s how Craig Gilbert of The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel describes the Milwaukee metropolitan area in the masterful first article of a four-part series on the region’s politics. The region is just as polarized as Mr. Gilbert suggests.

headline: Commute for Subway Art Is Three Years, Door to Door
text: Ralph Fasanella’s painting “Subway Riders” has not budged since 1995, when it became the first oil painting to be installed in a New York City subway station. Now it is heading out on the road.

headline: ‘Frozen’ Helps Lift Profit for an Energized Disney
text: LOS ANGELES — The stunning success of “Frozen,” surging theme park spending, strong merchandise sales and higher fees for ESPN combined to deliver quarterly results for the Walt Disney Company that were nothing short of spectacular.

headline: What Is Alibaba?
text: The e-commerce company has seized investor and public interest to an extent that is unusual for a company that does much of its business in China.

headline: An Uncoupling, but the Band Plays On
text: Last month, word of the impending dissolution of the marriage of Chris Martin, frontman of Coldplay, and Gwyneth Paltrow arrived with an emphatic thud on her website, Goop.com. “It is with hearts full of sadness that we have decided to separate,” the brief statement began. The post was credited to “Gwyneth & Chris,” but it did not have the feel of a shared reveal. It ended with a plea: “We have always conducted our relationship privately, and we hope that as we consciously uncouple and coparent, we will be able to continue in the same manner.”

headline: Another Idiot With a Gun
text: One of the many problems with the growing normalization of gun ownership is that a growing number of idiots will want to buy and keep guns for no particularly good reason, and a subset of those idiots will go on to kill people.

headline: European Financial Trading Tax Moves Forward, Despite New Pockets of Resistance
text: BRUSSELS — An effort by some European countries to tax financial transactions met new resistance on Tuesday, as Sweden, Denmark and the Netherlands voiced reservations.

headline: After Huge Alibaba Payday, a Test for Yahoo Executives
text: SAN FRANCISCO — For Yahoo, the initial public offering of stock in the Alibaba Group will unlock the door to a giant trove of cash. Depending on the price of the deal, Yahoo most likely will receive $10 billion to $15 billion for the 9 percent stake in the Chinese e-commerce company that it is required to sell in the offering.

headline: Christie’s to Return Cambodian Statue
text: Yet another ancient statue looted in the 1970s from a single remote temple in the jungles of Cambodia has turned up in the United States, this time at Christie’s, which is voluntarily paying to return it to its homeland.

headline: Beauty on the Met Gala Red Carpet
text: From moody pouts to bird’s nest hair, there were several beauty moments that could not go unaddressed.

headline: Chef Elena Arzak on Basque Cuisine
text: Elena Arzak, joint head chef at Arzak restaurant in San Sebastián, Spain, discusses her training at El Bulli, working with her father and the importance of the staff meal.

headline: Anderson & Fiennes: Gustave H.
text: Part 2: The director and star of “The Grand Budapest Hotel” discuss Ralph Fiennes’s character in the film.

headline: Anderson & Fiennes: ‘Almost Japanese’
text: Part 3: The director and star of “The Grand Budapest Hotel” talk about how the film deals with real history via a story set in a fake country.

headline: Anderson & Fiennes: Academy Ratio
text: Part 5: Wes Anderson, director of “The Grand Budapest Hotel,” explains why the majority of the film was shot in the old square “Academy ratio” format.

headline: Anderson & Fiennes: Inventing a Hotel
text: Part 4: Wes Anderson, director of “The Grand Budapest Hotel” recalls what inspired the look of the film’s titular hotel.

headline: TimesTalks | Anderson & Fiennes: Preview
text: The director Wes Anderson and the actor Ralph Fiennes discuss their film “The Grand Budapest Hotel.”

headline: Anderson & Fiennes: Intro
text: Part 1: Carol Olsen Day, director of TimesTalks, introduces the filmmaker Wes Anderson and the actor Ralph Fiennes.

headline: Egyptian TV Cites ‘Simpsons’ Episode as Proof Arab Spring Was Foreign Plot
text: During a recent broadcast on the Egyptian television channel Al Tahrir, the anchor Rania Badawy alerted viewers to what she called video evidence which “suggests that what is happening in Syria today was premeditated.” She then presented an 80-second clip from an episode of “The Simpsons” first broadcast in early 2001 and later dubbed into French and posted on YouTube.

headline: Anderson & Fiennes: ‘Still Rolling!’
text: Part 6: The director and star of “The Grand Budapest Hotel” describe what it was like working together for the first time.

headline: Anderson & Fiennes: Wes and His Actors
text: Part 7: The director and star of “The Grand Budapest Hotel” talk about the film’s impressive cast, and discuss Wes Anderson’s ability to attract star actors, even for bit parts.

headline: Anderson & Fiennes: Papers and Passports
text: Part 10: Wes Anderson, director of “The Grand Budapest Hotel,” discusses the filmmakers who influenced him the most on this film, and talks about why there are so many train scenes in the movie.

headline: Anderson & Fiennes: Young Owen Wilson
text: Part 12: The director and star of “The Grand Budapest Hotel” explain why they don’t think it’s good to rehearse too much when making a film.

headline: Anderson & Fiennes: Tony Revolori
text: Part 8: The director and star of “The Grand Budapest Hotel” reveal the best thing about working on a Wes Anderson film, and talk about working with the newcomer actor Tony Revolori.

headline: Anderson & Fiennes: A Smashed World
text: Part 9: The director and star of “The Grand Budapest Hotel” explore the influence of Stefan Zweig’s “The World of Yesterday” on the film, and the surreal pre-war feeling they tried to capture.

headline: Anderson & Fiennes: Wes Anderson’s 007
text: Part 11: Wes Anderson, director of “The Grand Budapest Hotel,” reveals his idea for a James Bond movie.

headline: Anderson & Fiennes: The Newcomer
text: Part 13: Wes Anderson, director of “The Grand Budapest Hotel,” describes why he cast Ralph Fiennes as the film’s lead without ever having worked with him before.

headline: Anderson & Fiennes: Make the Thing
text: Part 15: The director and star of “The Grand Budapest Hotel” share their advice for young filmmakers.

headline: Anderson & Fiennes: Treasured Objects
text: Part 14: Wes Anderson, director of “The Grand Budapest Hotel,” talks about what happens to the lovingly created props in his movies after a shoot is over.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Ukraine, India, Philippines and China.

headline: Jets Sued by Cheerleaders
text: The Jets on Tuesday became the fourth N.F.L. team to be sued by their cheerleaders for back wages.

Silence on ‘Honor Killings’

Philip Roth in Class

headline: White House on Climate Change Report
text: In a video released by the White House, President Obama’s science adviser, John P. Holdren, discussed a new study on climate change.

headline: Only Minorities Need Apply
text: SAN DIEGO — THIS year is the 50th anniversary of the Civil Rights Act, which among other things prohibits the use of race in deciding whom to hire, fire, promote or place in the best and worst jobs.

headline: What Can I Do to #BringBackOurGirls?
text: Why is this not mentioned on Motherlode?

headline: Leave ‘Organic’ Out of It
text: The ever-increasing number of people working to improve the growing, processing, transporting, marketing, distributing and eating of food must think through our messages more thoroughly and get them across more clearly. I don’t pretend to have all the answers, but I can say that a couple of buzzwords represent issues that are far more nuanced than we often make them appear. These are “organic” and “G.M.O.'s” (genetically modified organisms).

headline: The Risks of Investing in Alibaba’s I.P.O.
text: The planned initial public offering of Alibaba, the Chinese e-commerce behemoth, has Wall Street buzzing. But investing in the tech behemoth carries a number of risks.

headline: Laid-Back English Country Retreats
text: English countryside hotels have sometimes had a reputation for being overly formal and stuffy, but that may change with several new properties that can be described as laid-back. The trend started in 2009 with the opening of Lime Wood (rates from £255 a night, about $428), a 29-room 18th-century hunting lodge turned upscale getaway in Hampshire, about 90 minutes southwest of London. Instead of the antique décor typical of country retreats, the furnishings are contemporary and eclectic with touches like free-standing bathtubs in the middle of guest rooms. The hotel welcomes travelers in jeans and has a 20,000-square-foot spa and an Italian restaurant with its own smokehouse.

headline: Whispers From Fed Could Lead to Wild Swings, Internal Critic Says
text: Jeremy Stein is in the final weeks of his role as the Federal Reserve’s most important internal critic, and Tuesday night in New York he renewed his warnings that the Fed’s retreat from its stimulus campaign may yet roil financial markets.

headline: Kara Walker on Aerobics, D’Angelo and Her Favorite Hair Haunt
text: This week, the artist Kara Walker will unveil a major new public artwork at at the decommissioned Domino Sugar factory in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, presented by Creative Time, the elaborately titled “A Subtlety, or the Marvelous Sugar Baby, an Homage to the unpaid and overworked Artisans who have refined our Sweet tastes from the cane fields to the Kitchens of the New World on the occasion of the demolition of the Domino Sugar Refining Plant.”

headline: Driver Detained After Following Obama Daughters’ Motorcade
text: WASHINGTON — A driver followed a motorcade carrying the Obama daughters through a security checkpoint near the White House on Tuesday afternoon, leading the complex to be locked down as the car was stopped and searched in a restricted section of Pennsylvania Avenue.

headline: Alibaba, by the Numbers
text: Alibaba, the Chinese e-commerce company, is big. And from its user numbers to its valuation, everything about the company is growing.

headline: The G.O.P. Can’t Ignore Climate Change
text: WASHINGTON — “TO waste, to destroy our natural resources, to skin and exhaust the land instead of using it so as to increase its usefulness, will result in undermining in the days of our children the very prosperity which we ought by right to hand down to them amplified and developed.”

headline: A Name Pronounceable in Nearly Every Language
text: In a world of two-syllable Internet company names, Alibaba stands out.

headline: U.S. Chamber of Commerce Begins Ad Blitz for G.O.P.
text: The U.S. Chamber of Commerce released 30-second television advertisements on Wednesday for 10 Republican candidates for House seats in a broadcast campaign that will cost more than $3 million to run and will last two weeks. The ads will run in the districts of six incumbents — Andy Barr of Kentucky, Dan Benishek of Michigan, Mike Coffman of Colorado, Chris Gibson of New York, Joe Heck of Nevada and David Valadao of California — and in support of the candidates Bob Dold in Illinois, Stewart Mills in Minnesota, Doug Ose in California and Richard Tisei in Massachusetts. The chamber is changing its strategy to focus on the general election.

headline: Paying Homage to Bin Laden, Mosque Re-emerges as Bastion of Militancy
text: LONDON — Rising from the heart of Islamabad, the Red Mosque has long been a barometer of militant Islam in Pakistan. In the 1980s it funneled fighters into the anti-Soviet jihad in Afghanistan. In the ‘90s its leaders made an awe-struck pilgrimage to visit their hero, Osama bin Laden, at his farm outside Kandahar.

headline: Second Top Runner Is Signed by Skechers
text: Two weeks after Meb Keflezighi won the Boston Marathon in Skechers, the brand added another distance star, Kara Goucher, to its sponsorship roster. The deal gives the shoe line, more commonly known for its fashion footwear, two of America’s most established and popular distance runners.

headline: Can a Pope Help Sustain Humanity and Ecology?
text: VATICAN CITY — For four long days, several dozen physical, environmental and social scientists hunkered here with theologians, philosophers, economists and a poverty campaigner to explore ways to balance human ambitions with the planet’s limits. The rare joint meeting of the Pontifical Academy of Sciences and Pontifical Academy of Social Sciences — “Sustainable Humanity, Sustainable Nature, Our Responsibility” — helped demarcate where science leaves off and the rest of society, including organized religion, plays a role in shaping the quality of human life and environmental conditions in this century.

headline: Vatican Tells of 848 Priests Ousted in Decade
text: GENEVA — The Vatican has dismissed more than 800 priests for sexual abuse of children in the past decade and paid billions of dollars in compensation, senior Vatican officials told a United Nations panel on Tuesday, presenting the Roman Catholic Church as a model of reform but drawing the ire of victims’ groups that said it still seeks to dodge responsibility for the harm that priests continue to inflict.

headline: Alibaba Investors Will Buy a Risky Corporate Structure
text: Shareholders have been willing to take a lot of risk in their lust for Internet initial public offerings, but Alibaba’s I.P.O. may take that risk to a whole new level. The reason: Investors in the offering won’t have title to most of Alibaba’s Chinese assets because of Chinese prohibitions on foreign ownership.

headline: Georgia College Seeks Return to Calm After Shootings Taint End of Academic Year
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — After two days of gunfire at Paine College, Tuesday brought a grim and uneasy silence here.

headline: Nigeria’s Stolen Girls
text: Three weeks after their horrifying abduction in Nigeria, 276 of the more than 300 girls who were taken from a school by armed militants are still missing, possibly sold into slavery or married off. Nigerian security forces apparently do not know where the girls are and the country’s president, Goodluck Jonathan, has been shockingly slow and inept at addressing this monstrous crime.

headline: Stanford to Purge $18 Billion Endowment of Coal Stock
text: Stanford University announced Tuesday that it would divest its $18.7 billion endowment of stock in coal-mining companies, becoming the first major university to lend support to a nationwide campaign to purge endowments and pension funds of fossil fuel investments.

headline: Graying of America Is Speeding, Report Says
text: The number of Americans 65 and older is expected to nearly double by the middle of the century when they will make up more than a fifth of the nation’s population, according to a Census Bureau report released Tuesday.

headline: Mocked on Internet, Diet Coke Alters Ads
text: A CAMPAIGN for Diet Coke carrying the theme “You’re on,” which the Coca-Cola Company introduced in North America only three months ago, is being turned off after being mocked in social media.

headline: Jimmy Ellis, a Boxer Long in Ali’s Shadow, Dies at 74
text: Jimmy Ellis, the onetime sparring partner for Muhammad Ali who captured the heavyweight boxing championship after it had been stripped from Ali for his refusing induction into the armed forces, died on Tuesday in Louisville, Ky. He was 74.

headline: Go Big, Get Crazy
text: Up to now, Russia’s president, Vladimir Putin, has been playing a weak hand in Ukraine very well. I mean, how strong are you when your allies insist on wearing masks? But Putin thinks he knows his adversaries better than they know themselves. He thinks the Americans will never be serious about energy, that the Europeans will never be serious about sanctions, that the Ukrainian reformers will never be serious about governance, and that he can control the separatist forces he’s unleashed in eastern Ukraine and dial them up or down as he pleases.

headline: In Speech and Essay, Chiara de Blasio Details Her Depression and Addiction
text: Taking on an unusual role for the child of a sitting mayor, Chiara de Blasio, 19, the first daughter of New York City, traveled to Maryland with her parents on Tuesday to accept an award from the health and human services secretary, Kathleen Sebelius, and published an emotionally raw essay online about her struggle with depression and addiction.

headline: Titles, Not M.V.P.s, Define the Greats
text: MIAMI — Welcome, Kevin Durant, to LeBron James’s world. Enjoy yourself, while being mindful of every competitive stumble. Someone is liable to knock you over, kick you when you’re down.

headline: U.S. Sought Delay of Morsi’s Ouster, Egyptian Leader Says
text: CAIRO — Abdul Fattah el-Sisi, the former general who is poised to be elected Egypt’s president in next month’s elections, said in an interview broadcast Tuesday night that the American ambassador had asked him to hold off “for a day or two” before ousting the freely elected president, Mohamed Morsi of the Muslim Brotherhood, last July.

headline: The Six Banks Leading Alibaba’s Giant I.P.O.
text: The Alibaba Group’s long-awaited prospectus was chock-full of information about the Chinese Internet titan’s business.

headline: With Caution, a Poor Corner of Brooklyn Welcomes an Affordable Housing Plan
text: With its rows of two-family homes and its corridors of auto repair shops and storefront churches, East New York sits far away from the heated debates over density and building height that have roiled other, more sought-after Brooklyn neighborhoods like Williamsburg and Park Slope.

headline: U.S. Imposes First Sanctions in South Sudan Conflict
text: WASHINGTON — In its first use of economic sanctions against combatants in the bloody fighting in South Sudan, the Obama administration on Tuesday ordered asset freezes and travel bans on two individuals, one on each side of the conflict.

headline: 3 Oregon Basketball Players Face Rape Allegations
text: EUGENE, Ore. — The University of Oregon has come under intense scrutiny this week after three men’s basketball players — including one who transferred from Providence after being accused of sexual assault there — were investigated by the Eugene police in connection with rape allegations by an Oregon student.

headline: 2 Apollo Global Partners Are Said to Be Leaving
text: Apollo Global Management has climbed to the pinnacle of the private equity world, reaping billions of dollars in profit and raising a huge new buyout fund.

headline: Boston College Says It Will Return Interviews About Northern Ireland
text: BOSTON — Boston College officials said Tuesday that they would relinquish their secret interviews with former Irish paramilitaries if the interviewees, who spoke years ago under a guarantee of confidentiality, wanted them back.

headline: The Global Polio Threat, Back Again
text: Just when it looked as if polio was headed toward eradication around the world, the disease is once again on the march.

headline: A Conversation About Tests That Educators Want to Have, but Can’t
text: Let’s talk about testing.

headline: They Bought Into a Scrappy Chinese Start-Up, and Now Stand to Reap a Windfall
text: Alibaba’s filing on Tuesday to sell stock to the public for the first time disclosed a handful of winners who are poised to reap big paydays for taking a chance on the company, the once-scrappy Chinese start-up founded by Jack Ma that has become an e-commerce giant.

headline: Independent of the Independence Party
text: New York’s Independence Party survives on confusion. Many who sign up with the party think they are registering as independent voters, unaffiliated with any party. Instead they are unwittingly contributing their names to a bizarre and fractious political group that endorses candidates from the two major parties. The Independence Party should lose its prime place on the state ballot, and Gov. Andrew Cuomo could make that happen by rejecting its endorsement this year.

headline: Rising Temperatures
text: Average temperature in 1991-2012 compared with the 1901-60 average.

headline: Brash Ukrainian Mogul Prepares to Fight U.S. Bribery Charges
text: VIENNA — Arrested on bribery charges at the request of the F.B.I., and freed on more than $170 million bail that a Russian friend paid in cash, Dmitry V. Firtash, one of Ukraine’s richest, most powerful and most secretive businessmen, sat at a conference table here in his office at Centragas Holding, one of the many companies owned by his international conglomerate, Group DF.

headline: Burning the Beret
text: WASHINGTON — Monica Lewinsky says she would meet me for a drink.

headline: Alan Steel
text: Mr. Steel, 64, is the president and chief executive of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, which, along with the Hudson Yards redevelopment and a spurt of new hotels, is helping to redefine the underused Far West Side of Manhattan.

headline: How to Regulate Disruption?
text: Are the growing number of apps and online services that give consumers more direct control cutting-edge conveniences that should be encouraged, or money-making businesses that need more regulation?

headline: Kershaw Pushes the Reset Button for the Dodgers
text: WASHINGTON — The best pitcher in baseball waited more than six weeks for Tuesday, and he was not shy about showing his frustration. Clayton Kershaw, the two-time National League Cy Young Award winner, would bounce a baseball against the outer wall of his manager’s office, every thump a reminder of how much he hated his first trip to the disabled list.

headline: Here Comes Trouble
text: Before anything happens in Alain Buffard’s “Baron Samedi,” the set alone tells us a lot: a sloping, sleek white floor, like a barren hillside, curled up at two corners and slightly warped around the edges. There’s great potential soon to be tapped in that simple design (the work of Nadia Lauro), for highs and lows, for climbing up and sliding down, for stumbling off balance, for falling off the edge. It’s unstable terrain.

headline: Local Policies Help an Indian Candidate Trying to Go National
text: AHMEDABAD, India — To anyone familiar with the quagmire that typically engulfs large building projects in India, the reconstruction of the Sabarmati riverfront — championed for the last decade by Narendra Modi, the leader here in the state of Gujarat — is a startling sight.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
text: RECENT SALE

headline: Busy Arenas Keep Rangers on the Move
text: The Rangers had just played their sixth game in nine days, including two sets of back-to-back games, on Monday night when Coach Alain Vigneault called the team’s schedule stupid.

headline: Rival House Bills Aim to Rein In N.S.A. Phone Data Program
text: WASHINGTON — Senior members of the House Judiciary and Intelligence committees have agreed on similar but rival bills that would restrict the National Security Agency’s ability to collect Americans’ phone call data in bulk.

headline: From Netscape to Alibaba
text: A look back at the Internet revolution’s notable I.P.O.s, and how valuations have fared over the years.

headline: Fiat Chrysler, Unfazed by Quarterly Loss, Pins Hopes on Jeep
