text: AUBURN HILLS, Mich. — The new Fiat Chrysler Automobiles laid out an ambitious business plan on Tuesday that takes on a distinctly American flavor, relying heavily on growing sales of its Jeep sport utility vehicles.

headline: Murder Charge for Driver in Drug-Related Crash at a Manhattan Deli
text: A driver who crashed a car into a corner grocery in the East Village last year was charged with murder on Tuesday, becoming the second defendant in Manhattan to face that charge in recent months after causing a fatal accident while drunk or under the influence of drugs.

headline: Big Profits at Alibaba, but Filing Has Gaps
text: The Alibaba Group opened its books on Tuesday, revealing a company raking in extraordinary profits from its vast online marketplaces in China.

headline: Russia Quietly Tightens Reins on Web With ‘Bloggers Law’
text: MOSCOW — Russia has taken another major step toward restricting its once freewheeling Internet, as President Vladimir V. Putin quietly signed a new law requiring popular online voices to register with the government, a measure that lawyers, Internet pioneers and political activists said Tuesday would give the government a much wider ability to track who said what online.

headline: Reaching Out to Tech and Creative Tenants, Starting With Lunch
text: A factory district does not typically spring to mind as a prudent location for retailing, but some of Manhattan’s successful food vendors have chosen the Falchi Building in a spartan part of Long Island City, Queens, for their next retail ventures.

headline: Witness in Terrorism Case Recalls Being Taken Hostage in Yemen
text: The group of tourists was traveling in December 1998 when their convoy in Yemen was ambushed by armed militants who then took them hostage. The next day, with the sound of gunfire around them, one kidnapper turned to the group and said, “It’s goodbye to you all,” one former hostage testified in federal court in Manhattan on Tuesday.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 6, 2014
Examples of How Clippers Could Benefit From League Takeover
text: When Tom Schieffer became Major League Baseball’s on-site monitor of the Los Angeles Dodgers three years ago, he did not expect huzzahs at Chavez Ravine, least of all from the combative Dodgers owner Frank McCourt. Commissioner Bud Selig’s concerns over McCourt’s financial dealings and personal life had led Selig to take control of the Dodgers. McCourt was enraged.

headline: Scientists See Quake Risk Increasing in Oklahoma
text: A sharp rise in the number of earthquakes in Oklahoma, apparently related to underground disposal of wastewater from oil and gas production, has significantly increased the chances that a damaging quake will occur there, federal and state scientists say.

headline: Pakistan: Province Bars Entry to Those Not Vaccinated for Polio
text: In the wake of World Health Organization travel restrictions imposed on Pakistan to stop it from spreading polio abroad, one Pakistani province said Tuesday that citizens from anywhere else in the country would not be able to enter it without proof that they had been vaccinated. According to the news service Dawn, the health adviser to the chief minister of Punjab Province said vaccination booths would be set up at airports and all roads leading into the province, which includes the country’s second-largest city, Lahore. While many countries impose vaccine requirements on foreign visitors, vaccine requirements within a country’s borders are almost unheard-of. Almost all of Pakistan’s polio cases occur in the northwest frontier areas, where resistance to vaccine is high. Travel restrictions were also imposed Monday on Cameroon and Syria; they must ensure that anyone leaving their borders is vaccinated against polio.

headline: Giant Development in Cambodia Hinges on Chinese Buyers
text: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — There is an island in Cambodia that, unlike others in Southeast Asia, is not the object of an ownership dispute. But it is equally clear whom its current owners would like to land there: Chinese property buyers.

headline: After a Stroke, a Penguins Defenseman Makes an Impact
text: Watching Kris Letang dart up and down the ice, his long black hair waving behind, you would never know that 14 weeks ago, he was lying flat on his bathroom floor after having a stroke.

headline: Focusing on Lesser-Known Open Spaces in New York
text: For the past year, the notion of “park equity” — that all of New York City’s parks should be equally well kept — has emerged as a hot topic in public policy discussions. It was the subject of a City Council hearing last month, and there is even a #ParkEquity hashtag on Twitter.

headline: Words to Live By
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — This one tickles my pop culture nerve endings, although I predict the theme won’t be for everyone. There will be solvers who wonder what the point is of a theme that basically just lists the lines that made four male television stars famous, but for me, this theme by Kurt Mueller reminded me of my family.

headline: At the U.N., a Free-for-All on Setting Global Goals
text: What should the world’s priorities be? Is the most urgent task to guarantee everybody a minimum standard of subsistence? To reduce inequality? To combat global warming, perhaps at the expense of economic growth?

headline: U.S. Plan Aims to Draw Immigrants With Technology Skills
text: The Obama administration, looking to make adjustments to the nation’s immigration system while broader legislation is stalled in Congress, announced plans on Tuesday to allow the spouses of some highly skilled temporary immigrants to work in the United States.

headline: Animated Debate in New York State Capital? It’s About Yogurt
text: The New York State Senate sometimes considers weighty matters like taxes and budgets.

headline: Associates of Kansas Governor Are Investigated Over Fund-Raising and Lobbying
text: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. is investigating fund-raising and lobbying activities of associates of Gov. Sam Brownback of Kansas, an inquiry that follows his efforts to consolidate control of the state’s Republican Party during his first three and a half years in office.

headline: Using Weathercasters to Deliver a Climate Change Message
text: WASHINGTON — Jim Gandy is the chief meteorologist on WLTX in Columbia, S.C., and makes a point of incorporating links between bad weather and climate change into his daily broadcasts.

headline: Roy Thompson Jr., War Hero Who Played Himself in Movie, Dies at 85
text: Roy Thompson, a decorated officer during the Korean War who, while still on duty, starred as himself in a Hollywood movie that was shot entirely on location, died on April 22 in Panama City, Fla. He was 85.

headline: Colon Has One Bad Inning, and That’s Bad Enough
text: MIAMI — Long before he was a Met, Bartolo Colon was considered an enigma. He looked overweight, he served a 50-game suspension after testing positive for synthetic testosterone and, as he approached 40, he was pitching perhaps as well as he ever had.

headline: Alan J. Friedman, Who Revived Hall of Science in Queens, Dies at 71
text: Alan J. Friedman, a physicist who specialized in communicating the tenets of science to nonscientists and as the director of the New York Hall of Science in Queens oversaw its growth from a moribund museum to one of the city’s formidable educational institutions, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 71.

headline: Highlights of The Times’s Alibaba Coverage
text: With the Chinese tech giant Alibaba announcing on Tuesday that it is going public, The Times’s technology and business reporters examine the multifaceted impact of the initial public offering:

headline: Federal Officials Reject Design of California Driver’s Licenses for Illegal Immigrants
text: LOS ANGELES — California’s plan to offer driver’s licenses to immigrants in the country illegally has hit a major snag, with the Obama administration informing state officials that the licenses they had designed violated federal law, California officials said Tuesday.

headline: Yankees May Use Ryan to Replace Jeter Late in Games
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Brendan Ryan joined the Yankees for the first time this season on Tuesday after recovering from a back problem that shut him down early in spring training. And with him came questions about Derek Jeter’s playing time.

headline: Supreme Injustice
text: The Supreme Court’s ruling earlier this spring in McCutcheon v F.E.C., which increased the amount of money donors can contribute to political campaigns for federal office, has added new fuel to an 80-year-old debate between those who contend that the Supreme Court decides cases on the basis of abstract principles of law and those who argue that judicial rulings are based primarily on political and economic considerations.

headline: Heat Snuff Nets’ Hopes of Early Edge
text: MIAMI — Before the Eastern Conference semifinals tipped off Tuesday night, there was a fairly rational debate about whether the Nets might be uniquely suited to destabilize the Miami Heat, the two-time defending champions and a popular favorite to win the title this year.

headline: ‘Fargo’ Recap: A Prayer for the Prey
text: “Let us prosper in the smallest of ways. I’ll be your humble servant the rest of my days.”

headline: India Election Digest: May 7
text: What you need to know about India’s elections on Wednesday: In the next-to-last phase of voting, seven states will go to the polls, with 897 candidates vying for 64 seats in the lower house of Parliament. The states participating in the eighth phase are: Andhra Pradesh (25 seats), Bihar (7), Himanchal Pradesh (4), Jammu and Kashmir (2), Uttar Pradesh (15), Uttarakhand (5) and West Bengal (6).

headline: Insurers Say Most Who Signed Up Under Health Law Have Paid Up
text: WASHINGTON — Most of the people choosing health plans under the Affordable Care Act — about 80 percent — are paying their initial premiums as required for coverage to take effect, several large insurers said Tuesday on the eve of a House hearing about the law.

headline: Christie’s First Spring Sale Drops Prices Back to Earth
text: After all the predictions that prices were only going one way — up — the spring auction season got off to a tepid start at Christie’s on Tuesday night, where some examples of Impressionist and modern art by Picasso, Kandinsky and Dalí brought far less than expected; others barely skimmed by, and two classic works by Degas were left unsold, victims of estimates that were simply too high.

headline: Times Minute | Obama’s California Trip
text: Expect questions Obama the N.S.A. when he stops in Silicon valley. Also on the Minute, new media censorship from Vladimi Putin and a singing nun in Italy become a viral sensation.

headline: The Luxury of Humility
text: Axel Vervoordt designed a penthouse hotel suite based on wabi-sabi, a philosophy that embraces quietude and modesty, in Manhattan, a place known for neither.

headline: Art and Fashion Are at It Again
text: Last October, in Paris, Karl Lagerfeld transformed the Grand Palais into a white-walled art gallery filled with Chanel-themed paintings and sculptures for his spring/summer 2014 runway — a motif which seemed to officially set up this year’s warm-weather fashion landscape as one intertwined and imbued with art. And now that the season has arrived, the connection is undeniable. As fashion editors gear up for art and design shows opening both here and there — New York’s Collective 2 design fair on Thursday and Frieze Art Fair on Friday, and Paris’s Monumenta art exhibition at the Grand Palais on Saturday — obvious outfit choices abound, from artist’s-sketch-covered separates to sculptural bangles fit for a ceramist’s studio.

headline: The Collective 2 Fair Kicks Off a Month of New York Design Happenings
text: This weekend sees the return of two hugely successful contemporary art fairs to New York, Frieze New York and NADA, which are set to fill the streets with collectors and fashionable folk from across the globe. But it also marks the kick-off for a month-long marathon of design events, openings, fairs, conferences and parties. The first is Collective 2, the second annual collectible design fair, which was started last year by the architect Steven Learner. It opens tomorrow at Moynihan Station.

headline: Times Minute | Obama’s California Trip
text: In the Video

headline: Panel Urges One-Drug Lethal Injections
text: Days after President Obama said a bungled execution in Oklahoma was “deeply disturbing” and called for a review of how fairly the death penalty was used, a bipartisan panel of legal experts has urged sweeping changes in what it calls the “deeply flawed” administration of capital punishment.

headline: Early Fitness Can Improve the Middle-Age Brain
text: The more physically active you are at age 25, the better your thinking tends to be when you reach middle age, according to a large-scale new study. Encouragingly, the findings also suggest that if you negligently neglected to exercise when young, you can start now and still improve the health of your brain.

headline: HP Makes $1 Billion Bet on Open Cloud
text: Hewlett-Packard is making its big bet on cloud computing, with a significant change of its own products and business, and the biggest endorsement yet of an open source alternative to the systems of Amazon and Google.

headline: Judge Halts Investigation of Political Spending in Wisconsin
text: A federal judge late Tuesday ordered that officials stop an investigation into political spending by conservative groups in recall elections that took place in Wisconsin in 2012, including that of Gov. Scott Walker.

headline: Word of the Day | illimitable
text: illimitable•\(ˌ)i(l)-ˈli-mə-tə-bəl\• adjective

headline: Jet Magazine to Shift to Digital Publishing Next Month
text: Jet, the pioneering African-American weekly magazine that rose to prominence covering the civil rights movement, is expected to announce Wednesday morning that it will no longer publish a regular print edition, the latest in a growing list of periodicals avoiding print in favor of digital publications.

headline: Masala Dosa to Die For
text: Saravana Bhavan doesn’t look like a house of secrets. Its dining room at the corner of Lexington Avenue and 26th Street is clean and bright and often attracts a line out front. It doesn’t advertise because it doesn’t need to; the fact that it’s one of the world’s largest chains of vegetarian restaurants — 33 in India, another 47 in a dozen other countries — is considered too obvious to its core clientele of Indian expatriates and tourists to be worth trumpeting. In a city overwhelmed with underwhelming north Indian food, Saravana Bhavan is the standard-bearer of the delicacies of the south, but it makes no effort to educate the uninitiated. If you don’t know what a dosa is or how to eat it, you’re on your own.

headline: Corrections: May 7, 2014
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: What’s On Wednesday
text: 2:50 P.M. (Starz Cinema) FAREWELL, MY QUEEN (2012) Sidonie Laborde (Léa Seydoux, above left, with Julie-Marie Parmentier), the reader to Marie Antoinette (Diane Kruger) at Versailles, watches as the French monarchy falls in this drama directed by Benoît Jacquot from a novel by Chantal Thomas. Noémie Lvovsky portrays the queen’s lady-in-waiting; Virginie Ledoyen is the woman rumored to be the queen’s lover. “If the rules and the players of this continuing, increasingly dangerous court intrigue remain obscure, it’s because ‘Farewell, My Queen’ is told through Sidonie’s eyes,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “Tapping her palace sources, notably an archivist (Michel Robin) and a dressmaker (Anne Benoît), Sidonie learns of news known only to the nobility and their trusted stewards: that the Bastille has been seized.” Mr. Jacquot, she added, “has always been a sensitive director of actresses, his sympathies evident in his caressing, sometimes ogling camerawork and the time and space he gives women and their stories. That sympathy is evident here too, though crucially, while he doesn’t demonize Marie Antoinette, he doesn’t turn her into a spurious feminist martyr.” In French, with English subtitles.

headline: Strong Start by Kuroda and Late Homer by Roberts Lift Yankees
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — When Brian Roberts came to the plate with two outs in the ninth inning, the game tied and the Yankees in fairly urgent need of a win, he did not require any fancy scouting reports on the opposing pitcher, the fastball artist Ernesto Frieri.

headline: South Africans Vote as Zuma Seeks Second Term as President
text: MARIKANA, South Africa — Voters cast ballots across South Africa on Wednesday after a long campaign season that betrayed the governing African National Congress party’s internal cracks, highlighted President Jacob Zuma’s deepening unpopularity and hinted at a realignment of the nation’s politics in the years ahead.

headline: Thai Prime Minister Ordered Removed From Office
text: BANGKOK — A Thai court on Wednesday ordered Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra removed from office, a highly divisive move and a victory for a powerful opposition movement that for six months has sought to overthrow the government.

headline: Chinese Train Maker Seeks Up to $1.5 Billion in Hong Kong I.P.O.
text: HONG KONG — China CNR Corporation, one of the nation’s and the world’s biggest manufacturers of trains, is planning to raise up to $1.5 billion in a Hong Kong stock offering this month, a person familiar with the deal said on Wednesday.

headline: Société Générale’s Profit Suffers From Russian Exposure
text: PARIS — Société Générale, the second-largest French bank, said on Wednesday that its first-quarter profit fell from a year earlier, as it wrote down the value of its Russian assets amid the international crisis over Ukraine.

headline: Vietnam Squares Off With China in Disputed Seas
text: HONG KONG — Tensions in the South China Sea intensified Wednesday as Vietnamese vessels confronted Chinese ships that were working to place an oil rig off Vietnam’s coast, and Vietnamese officials claimed that their ships had been rammed by the Chinese vessels three days earlier.

headline: Playing Down Any Alstom Move, Siemens Reorganizes and Makes Other Deals
text: FRANKFURT — The head of the German electronics and engineering giant Siemens said on Wednesday that the company would not be strong-armed into acquiring the power units of its French rival Alstom, displaying notably less ardor for a deal than was shown by its rival General Electric.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, May 7, 2014
text: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

headline: Three Charts on Secular Stagnation
text: Apologies for blog silence — stuff happened. Right now I’m in Oxford, preparing for a talk tonight on secular stagnation and all that; and I thought I’d share three charts I find helpful in thinking about where we are.

headline: Civil Society Activists Detained as Anniversary Looms
text: Updated, 10:28 a.m. |

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Spreading the A.P. Gospel to Nurture Scientists and Engineers
text: In “Spreading the A.P. Gospel to Nurture Scientists and Engineers,” Kenneth Chang writes about a nonprofit organization working with schools to expand the success of Advanced Placement classes.

headline: Indian-Born Tibetans Allowed to Vote, but Few Take Up Offer
text: DHARAMSALA, India — This year marks the first election in which Indian-born Tibetan refugees have the right to vote, but as the state of Himachal Pradesh, including the residents of this shady hill station, went to the polls on Wednesday, there were few Tibetans among them.

headline: Italy’s Independence in Postwar Photography
text: The Italian photographer Ugo Zovetti was known for his sense of realism. In a 1958 photograph, he captured a group of four street musicians, all wearing signs around their necks that declare, “BLIND.” It’s reminiscent of Paul Strand’s “Blind Woman,” a 1916 photo that shows the subject’s affected eye and evokes sympathy. The blind men in Zovetti’s image, in contrast, are simply playing on the street.

headline: Chinese Police to Help With Tourist Influx in Paris
text: France has invited the Chinese police to Paris this summer to help with the pressures of huge numbers of Chinese tourists visiting the French capital, Agence France-Presse reported, citing a French Interior Ministry official. The move comes as Chinese travelers in France have experienced a rising number of robberies and assaults, the French news agency said.

headline: What Messages About Food and Eating Have You Learned From Your Family?
text: How would you characterize your family’s attitudes toward food and eating? What rules or restrictions, if any, do they impose on what or how you eat? How do you think these attitudes have affected you?

headline: Telefónica Offers to Buy Majority Stake in Spain’s Digital Plus
text: LONDON – The Spanish telecommunications company Telefónica has offered to pay about $1 billion for a majority stake in the pay-television provider known as Digital Plus.

headline: New York Today: Allergy Season, Light
text: Good wheezy Wednesday morning to you.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: The Unlikely Ascent of Jack Ma, Alibaba’s Founder
text: HONG KONG — The first time Jack Ma used the Internet, in 1995, he searched for “beer” and “China” but found no results. Intrigued, he created a basic web page for a Chinese translation service with a friend. Within hours, he received a handful of emails from around the world requesting information.

headline: Mary Landrieu’s Very Difficult Re-election
text: A survivor. That’s how some Republicans think of Senator Mary Landrieu, a Louisiana Democrat who seemed to defy political gravity by winning two tough re-election campaigns, even while Louisiana, like the rest of the Deep South, became unshakably Republican.

headline: Vocal Few in Congress Keep Benghazi Issue Alive
text: The 2012 Benghazi attack has become a rallying point for many conservative figures in the news media, but only a handful of Republicans in Congress have continued to call public attention to it. Just six members of the House and Senate mention it regularly in official statements.

headline: The Struggle for Access in War-Torn Syria
text: Anne Barnard, Beirut bureau chief for The Times since January 2013, is covering the civil war in Syria. Before coming to The Times in 2007, she worked as the Baghdad bureau chief and Middle East bureau chief for The Boston Globe.

headline: An Owner Grows Her Business — and Her Family
text: At the most recent meeting of the She Owns It business group, Jennifer Blumin, who owns Skylight Group, talked about the challenges of opening a San Francisco office while awaiting the arrival of her second child, due this month.

headline: Hurt by Asia, HSBC’s Quarterly Earnings Decline 18%
text: LONDON – The British bank HSBC reported on Wednesday that first-quarter profit fell 18 percent amid a slump in its Asian operations, which account for more than half its earnings.

headline: Syrian Rebels Depart Homs District Under Deal
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syria’s third-largest city, Homs, was one of the first to hold large demonstrations against President Bashar al-Assad. Protesters there were among the first to take up arms against the state, and Homs neighborhoods were the first to suffer indiscriminate bombardment by government forces.

headline: Daily Report: Alibaba Files for Public Stock Offering in the U.S.
text: The e-commerce behemoth Alibaba filed in the United States on Tuesday to sell stock to the public for the first time, in an embrace of the global capital markets that represents a coming-of-age for the booming Chinese Internet industry, Vindu Goel, Michael J. de la Merced and Neil Gough report.

headline: Grab a Dream and Sing Out
text: “You’re not going to get us to pull each other’s hair,” Kelli O’Hara said as she and her four fellow Tony Award nominees for best actress in a musical — one of this year’s most competitive races — met recently to discuss life in the theater. But as warm as they were to one another, their words carried some bite about the business.

headline: Indie Music to Return to South Street Seaport
text: The Seaport Music Festival, which has been spicing up New York summers with indie bands since 2002, will return to the South Street Seaport, at Fulton Street between Water and Front Street, for eight Friday evening shows in July and August.

headline: In Our Pages: May 8
text: 1939: Military Pact Concluded

headline: What the Alibaba I.P.O. Means
text: After months of anticipation, it finally happened: The Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba Group filed paperwork on Tuesday in the United States to go public, Vindu Goel, Michael J. de la Merced and Neil Gough write in DealBook. The move, they write, is “an embrace of the global capital markets that represents a coming-of-age for China’s booming Internet industry.”

headline: Councilman Is Accused of Stealing Public Funds
text: The charges brought on Wednesday against a New York City councilman accused of stealing thousands of dollars in taxpayer money had a familiar ring to them: a shell company, pilfered campaign funds, a department-store shopping spree with the spoils.

headline: Mondelez and Dutch Firm Aim to Create a Coffee Powerhouse
text: Mondelez International, the owner of Cadbury chocolate and Chips Ahoy cookies, is carving out its coffee business to combine it in a joint venture with a Dutch company to form a global coffee seller with more than $7 billion in annual revenue.

headline: With Swagger, and Some Gifts, a Candidate Builds a Constituency
text: HYDERABAD, India — Just weeks before elections in Hyderabad, the capital of the southern Indian state of Andhra Pradesh, a would-be candidate sat at a wooden desk in his modest campaign headquarters, unsure which party would give him a ticket to run for a seat in the state assembly.

headline: A Soldier Gets Help on a Cold St. Patrick’s Day
text: Dear Diary:

headline: ‘Daily Show’ Takes on Financial Crisis Cases
text: “The vampires finally got their blood,” Jon Stewart of “The Daily Show” said, mocking those who wanted to see Wall Street punished for the financial crisis. The victim: Kareem Serageldin.

headline: Son of Nazi-Era Art Dealer Left Works to Swiss Museum
text: Updated, 12:30 p.m. | BERLIN – Cornelius Gurlitt left his collection of hundreds of European art works – amassed by his father under the Nazis – to the Kunstmuseum Bern, the museum announced on Wednesday. In a statement, the museum said that the news “came like a bolt from the blue.”

headline: AOL Profit Slides 64%, Sending Its Shares Down 20%
text: Tim Armstrong, the chief executive of AOL, the giant media and advertising technology company, has said that it was poised for significant long-term growth. On Wednesday investors displayed their skepticism — resoundingly.

headline: On Climate, Republicans and Democrats Are From Different Continents
text: Americans are less worried about climate change than the residents of any other high-income country, as my colleague Megan Thee-Brennan wrote Tuesday. When you look at the details of these polls, you see that American exceptionalism on the climate stems almost entirely from Republicans. Democrats and independents don’t look so different from people in Japan, Australia, Canada and across Europe.

headline: Even as U.S. Hispanics Lift Catholicism, Many Are Leaving the Church Behind
text: By all accounts, Hispanics are the future of Catholicism in America. Already, most young Roman Catholics in the United States are Hispanic, and soon that will be true of the overall Catholic population. But the Hispanicization of American Catholicism faces a big challenge: Hispanics are leaving Catholicism at a striking rate.

headline: City Ballet’s 2014-15 Season to Feature Ballets by Peck, Scarlett and Ratmansky
text: New York City Ballet’s 2014-15 season will feature new ballets by Justin Peck, Liam Scarlett and Alexei Ratmansky; a festival of George Balanchine’s cherished Black and White ballets; the principal dancer Wendy Whelan’s farewell performance; and the company premiere of “La Sylphide” by its ballet master in chief, Peter Martins.

headline: A Continuing Murder Mystery Keeps Its Grip on Filmmakers
text: In one form or another, Damien Echols has now been a star of at least five films, but this is not a distinction that fills him with pride.

headline: Yellen Won’t Be Pinned Down on Plans
text: WASHINGTON — Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, told Congress on Wednesday that the economy was growing at a decent rate and that the Fed intended to continue the stimulus campaign that it considered at least partly responsible.

headline: There Are No Mainstream Republicans Left in North Carolina
text: The national Republican Party is exulting that the “establishment” won in North Carolina’s Senate primary yesterday. That’s only because they have redefined the term “Republican establishment” to include adamant adherents of a far-right ideology.

headline: Turner Prize Nominees Announced
text: LONDON — Dances, screen prints, YouTube clips and slideshows are all elements used in the work of this year’s Turner Prize nominees, who were announced on Wednesday by Tate Britain, where an exhibition of the four artists’ work will take place from Sept. 30 to Jan. 4.

headline: Putin Announces Pullback From Ukraine Border
text: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin, faced with rising violence in southeastern Ukraine that threatened to draw in the Russian Army at great cost and prompt severe new Western economic sanctions, pressed pause on Wednesday in what had started to look like an inevitable march toward war.

headline: Feeling For | Decadent Cashmere Blankets With a Planet-Friendly Pedigree
text: Just how much good karma can be packed into a single home accessory? Quite a bit, as evidenced by a new series of limited-edition cashmere blankets made by Jane Palmer of Noon Design Studio — the fashion industry’s eminent natural dye house, which is also known for its popular indigo kits and decorative housewares — and the artist Christy Matson. Carpet-thick yet feather-light, the blankets are hand-loomed by Matson in Los Angeles on the same jacquard machine she uses in her fine-art practice. The lofty cashmere yarn is not only hand-twisted by members of a women’s cooperative in Afghanistan, but also — two degrees of virtuousness — sourced directly from fashion houses that would otherwise have discarded it. The rich, variegated colors are hand-dyed by Palmer using flowers, leaves and minerals; the jet-black hue comes from a dye recipe of roots, bark and indigo that dates back to medieval times. Each is one of a kind; custom designs are also available by special order. Palmer and Matson have set aside a small number of the blankets for T readers, and can ship overnight — just in time for a (very decadent) last-minute Mother’s Day gift.

headline: Mother Love
text: New picture books to help celebrate Mother’s Day include “A Mom for Umande,” about a zoo-born baby gorilla.

headline: In Delivery Rooms, Reducing Births of Convenience
text: San Francisco General is largely a hospital for the poor. It’s the city’s safety net hospital, known for providing free care for all who can’t afford it, and for its display — while you wait and wait — of the parade of humanity in all its glory.

headline: The Home Aquatic
text: Christopher H. Browne and Andrew Gordon spent years on landscaping before planning a house.

headline: It’s a Home. It’s a Shop. It’s ...
text: YES, THE INTERNET IS simply grand, but even as it “connects” us to everything we could possibly want — information, love, bulging Priority Mail envelopes — it has drained much of the color from commerce. Imagine this typical dinner-party dialogue between young moderns.

headline: Today in Small Business: A Pizza Shop Uses Uber to Deliver Pizzas
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: 50 Years Later, Questions Over Who Designed a World’s Fair Dome
text: Imagine an elegant, inverted, 175-foot-wide sieve covering a half-acre of Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens. Within it, long-necked cattle egrets glide overhead. A scarlet macaw scolds loudly from a branch, while northern bobwhite quails rustle the underbrush. Flashes of sapphire blue — the bills of Argentine ruddy ducks — glint against the dark waters of a small pond.

headline: South African Leaders on Election Day
text: President Jacob G. Zuma of South Africa, Archbishop Desmond Tutu and former president F.W. De Klerk said they were optimistic about the country’s future as millions voted in the national election.

headline: Clip: ‘Devil’s Knot’
text: Colin Firth and James Hamrick in a scene from “Devil’s Knot,” directed by Atom Egoyan.

headline: A Scientist’s Defense of Keeping AstraZeneca Independent
text: Updated, 1:13 p.m. | LONDON — It is probably no surprise that Briggs Morrison, head of global drug development at AstraZeneca, has sided with his bosses in opposing the idea of the American giant Pfizer taking over the British company.

headline: The Consumer Revolution of Enterprise Computing
text: Workday, a business software company, released its first product in 2007 and recently came out with the 22nd version of its software. It has a 23rd in the works, but you should wonder why it bothers. After all, what version of Facebook are we on?

headline: House Hunting in ... Dordogne, France
text: A RESTORED 17TH-CENTURY MANOR IN SOUTHWEST FRANCE

headline: A Small Brand Tries to Escape the Confusing Shadow of a Big Brand
text: Hobby Lobby International makes and sells radio-controlled toys, tools and accessories. What started in 1964 as a shop in a building lobby in Brentwood, Tenn., grew into a thriving mail-order business and, later, an online retailer with $9 million in annual sales. The company was owned by the same family until 2003, when it was sold to a private equity firm. In 2009, Mark A. Cleveland bought the company with the goal of opening more stores and expanding its lines of radio-controlled products.

headline: Gehry Honored by Spanish Foundation
text: Frank Gehry, the architect known for the fanciful designs, fluid lines and metallic exteriors of his buildings – which include the Walt Disney Concert Hall in Los Angeles and the Guggenheim Museums in Bilbao and Abu Dhabi – has won the 2014 Prince of Asturias Award for the Arts. The prize includes a 50,000 euro ($69,625) cash award and a sculpture by Joan Miró.

headline: Seeking Tough Justice, but Settling for Empty Promises
text: Don’t get too excited about bank indictments.

headline: In Alabama, a Wide-Ranging Delacroix Show
text: Art lovers are undoubtedly familiar with Eugène Delacroix’s “Liberty Leading the People,” a work that has a place of pride at the Louvre Museum.

headline: What Off-Season? Draft’s Growth Means N.F.L. Has No Downtime
text: Imagine a sporting event that includes no bats, balls or fields, yet compels thousands of fans to wait hours for seats and attracts a larger television audience than many games do. Throw in months of buildup, a red carpet entrance and big corporate sponsors, and you have the N.F.L. draft.

headline: Your Questions, Answered
text: I invited you to ask me anything this week, and you did. Here are my answers to some of your most interesting questions — I only wish I had time to respond to every single one of you!

headline: Obama’s Top Economist Has Some Problems With Piketty’s Book
text: The French economist Thomas Piketty’s book on the future of inequality is the buzz of the economics world this season. Now President Obama’s chief economist has weighed in on its thesis, the first time a senior administration official has discussed it in detail. And he is skeptical of some key assumptions upon which “Capital in the Twenty-First Century,” Mr. Piketty’s sweeping book, is based.

headline: Motion Picture Academy Extends Executive’s Contract
text: LOS ANGELES — The governors of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences agreed Tuesday night to renew an employment contract with the group’s chief executive, Dawn Hudson.

headline: You Are Now Here. Find How to Go There.
text: ONE of my favorite parts of a vacation is flying, but organizing the flights can be overcomplicated and frustrating. It doesn’t have to be this way, as there are many mobile apps that can help you book flights with ease.

headline: Michael Jackson, the Remix
text: “Xscape,” the new album credited to Michael Jackson, revolves around the familiar voice of a ghost mourned worldwide. That voice is airborne and supple, tenderly concerned, playful and percussive; then it grows increasingly tense, distraught, desolate, embittered. Jackson’s voice is a precious digital keepsake; it’s also, on many of the tracks, the only part of his latest songs that Jackson ever heard.

headline: App Smart | Plan Your Next Trip
text: Kit Eaton explores three mobile apps that can help you book flights and plan your travels with ease.

headline: On the Verge | The Razor’s Edge
text: The staggering beauty and abundant resources of Colombia’s Chocó region have been preserved through poverty and neglect. With its natural wonders now being discovered, it stands at a crossroads.

headline: Indictment of Ruben W. Wills and Jelani R. Mills
text: Mr. Wills, a New York City Councilman, was arrested Wednesday on charges of misusing public funds. Mr. Mills, an associate, was charged with conspiring with the councilman.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 36
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Rebels to Ask for Antiaircraft Missiles
text: WASHINGTON — The head of the Syrian opposition says that he will ask the Obama administration to provide antiaircraft missiles and will try to convince American officials that the weapons would not fall into the wrong hands.

headline: What a Great Trip! And I’m Not Even There Yet
text: Wish you were on vacation right now? Don’t. Taking a vacation won’t necessarily make you happier. But anticipating it will.

headline: Hotel Review: 25hours Hotel Bikini Berlin
text: Rates

headline: Huawei Unveils New Phone to Compete With Apple and Samsung
text: Updated, with additional background.

headline: An Incubator for Creativity in Savannah, Ga.
text: The Savannah that most visitors encounter is confined to the historic district between the Savannah River and the trees of Forsyth Park draped in Spanish moss. But several blocks south of the park, beyond the sun-dappled squares and canopied streets, is the increasingly vibrant Starland district. The neighborhood, whose name comes from the defunct Starland Dairy factory it surrounds, has in recent years emerged as an incubator for creativity that overflows from the nearby Savannah College of Art and Design (SCAD). Now a clutch of new shops, galleries and cafes has taken root here, providing a refreshingly rough-around-the-edges respite from Savannah’s polished, Old South charm.

headline: Restaurant Report: Florería Atlántico in Buenos Aires
text: The air at Florería Atlántico, in the Retiro neighborhood of Buenos Aires, is decadent with the scent of fresh flowers. Some pedestrians may wander in looking for a bouquet for an aggrieved girlfriend or wine for a dinner party, but those in the know are aware of what lies beneath the unassuming flower and wine shop. Inside, a hulking refrigerator door swings back to reveal the entrance to a subterranean chamber. This in-vogue restaurant and lounge is underground in every sense of the word.

headline: Street Style in Berlin
text: The central Kreuzberg neighborhood has evolved from one of the poorest in Berlin to one of the trendiest. It is where Ron Dietze (with his wife and two daughters) was walking along the graffiti-lined streets on the way to dinner. Dressed in a fitted black suit, a black turtleneck and a cherry-red leather trench coat, Mr. Dietze said he usually wore more color, higher heels and even the occasional skirt. On this day, however, he said he wanted to dress “a bit classier” for his daughter’s birthday celebration. This interview has been edited and condensed.

headline: What Policies Deter Absentee Apartment Buyers?
text: When you try to figure out how to solve the housing affordability problem in the world’s “superstar cities,” as I did in a recent magazine column, it quickly becomes clear that the market today has been heavily affected by absentee buyers: the global rich who, looking for a safe place to park their cash, are snapping up apartments, in many cases sight unseen.

headline: Growth and Governance in Focus at Alibaba
text: How high will Alibaba be valued in an initial public offering? A Reuters Breakingviews calculator suggests some possibilities.

headline: Send a Handwritten Card by Mail, Via an iPad
text: Two days ago, in my books-for-Mother’s Day post, I urged everyone to “go, right now, to the store. Buy a card for your mother, mother-in-law and anyone else you want to receive one this Sunday. Have your children make cards and greetings tonight, and put it all in the mail tomorrow.”

headline: A Whole New Way to Think of Chicken
text: Cut it into wings, legs, breasts and thighs, and cooking becomes more versatile.

headline: What You Get for ...$3,500,000
text: TUPPER LAKE, N.Y.

headline: It’s a Smorgasbord at the Stage Deli
text: It is safe to say that we are rarely, in a single week, introduced to not one but two Off Broadway productions with sandwich makers as central characters. Three people struggle to keep their franchise shop afloat under a corporate structure, which is at turns controlling or indifferent, in “American Hero,” a dark comedy by Bess Wohl in Second Stage Theater’s annual Uptown Series, devoted to emerging playwrights. Leigh Silverman (a Tony nominee for “Violet”) directs. (Previews begin Monday, McGinn/Cazale Theater, 2162 Broadway, at 76th Street; 212-246-4422, 2st.com.)

headline: How Could Hobby Lobby International Avoid Confusion With Hobby Lobby Stores?
text: We just published a case study about Hobby Lobby International, a 50-year-old company based in Brentwood, Tenn., that makes and sells radio-controlled products and accessories. In 2009,  Mark Cleveland bought the company from a private equity firm and made plans to expand.

headline: Yellen Speaks on U.S. Economic Future
text: Janet L. Yellen, the chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, testified before the Congressional Joint Economic Committee that she expects the economy to expand at a faster pace than it did last year.

headline: Why Republicans Have a 55 Percent Chance of Retaking the Senate
text: We’ve updated the Upshot’s Senate model, which we call Leo, with the results of Tuesday’s elections in North Carolina. Thom Tillis, the State House speaker, won the Republican Senate primary there.

headline: William Forsythe to Join U.S.C. Dance School
text: The choreographer William Forsythe will join the University of Southern California’s Glorya Kaufman School of Dance as a professor in fall 2015, the university announced on Wednesday. The American-born Mr. Forsythe, who has lived in Germany for most of his career and currently heads his own troupe, the Forsythe Company, is widely recognized as one of the most important choreographers working today, with an influence that spans the worlds of ballet and contemporary dance.

headline: Does the Establishment Clause Apply to the States?
text: Monday’s 5-4 Supreme Court ruling giving a green light to routine, explicitly Christian prayers at town meetings was extreme — but not as extreme as the concurring opinion from the Court’s resident reactionary, Justice Clarence Thomas.

headline: Down in the Subway, Swipe Again
text: The subway is the city’s great equalizer, a place where all of New York can jostle peaceably. But in “Dutchman,” the incendiary 1964 play by LeRoi Jones, proximity breeds anger, then danger, then death.

headline: Scientists Add Letters to DNA’s Alphabet, Raising Hope and Fear
text: Scientists reported Wednesday that they had taken a significant step toward altering the fundamental alphabet of life — creating an organism with an expanded artificial genetic code in its DNA.

headline: What’d You Bring Me, Mom? Trouble
text: Mom’s home — first time in eight years — and the long absence has done nothing to dull the sting of her venom.

headline: In Youth’s Death, Some See a Montana Law Gone Wrong
text: MISSOULA, Mont. — Teenagers call it garage hopping. The goal was to sneak into an open garage, steal some beer or other items and slip away into the night. It was dumb and clearly illegal. It was not supposed to be deadly.

headline: A Finger Wag in Good Hands
text: Tony Shalhoub remembers watching an interview with a young Jason Robards decades ago. “He said, ‘If I see an actor put his hands in his pockets, I know he doesn’t know what to do with his hands,’ ” Mr. Shalhoub recalled.

headline: Public Library Is Abandoning Disputed Plan for Landmark
text: In a striking about-face, the New York Public Library has abandoned its much-disputed renovation plan to turn part of its research flagship on Fifth Avenue at 42nd Street into a circulating library and instead will refurbish the nearby Mid-Manhattan Library, several library trustees said.

headline: NBC Extends Olympic Deal Into Unknown
text: NBC Universal agreed on Wednesday to pay $7.75 billion for the exclusive broadcast rights to the six Olympic Games from 2022 to 2032, highlighting with that staggering sum the supreme value that media companies are placing on live event programming in a market disrupted by modern viewing habits.

headline: Image of the Day: May 7
text: A boy, displaced from the simmering ethnic tensions between Bodos and Muslims in Assam, at a relief camp in Baksa district of the state.

headline: Times Minute | How to Watch the Draft
text: Melissa Hoppert, the Times’ N.F.L. editor, on what to look for as teams make their picks this week.

headline: A Crane Is Born
text: There is a new bird at the Central Park Zoo – new to the zoo, and new to the world.

headline: Times Minute | How to Watch the Draft
text: In the Video

headline: Struggling to Score, Rangers May Get Kreider Back
text: Chris Kreider may or may not be back in uniform for the offense-challenged Rangers in Game 4 against the Penguins on Wednesday night, but neither he nor his coach is saying either way.

headline: Store Openings and Fashion Events Starting the Week of May 8
text: Celebrating Charles James

headline: Inside the Met Ball: Sculptures in Silk
text: “I’d never really heard of him,” Florence Welch of Florence and the Machine said Monday, referring to the irascible, petulant, brilliant and beguiling Anglo-American designer Charles James. “It’s nice to see a bit of the history.”

headline: U.S. Trips to Russia Fall Amid Conflict
text: As spring blooms across Eastern Europe, the specter of a widening conflict between the Kremlin and Ukraine is causing some Western travelers to cancel their trips to Russia and spoiling high expectations among hotels and tour operators for the summer travel season.

headline: With Stealth, Congressional Spending on Pet Projects Persists, Report Says
text: WASHINGTON — Congress may have banned earmarks to pay for pet projects in the districts of powerful lawmakers, but pork continues to find its way into spending legislation, though in smaller amounts and with more stealth, a fiscal watchdog group said on Wednesday.

headline: Student Crossword | Space Exploration
text: Test your knowledge of space exploration by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: Patton Boggs Settles Dispute With Chevron Over Pollution Case
text: The powerful Washington law firm Patton Boggs dropped out of an effort to force Chevron to pay a $9.5 billion Ecuadorean pollution judgment on Wednesday, expressing regrets for its involvement in the case and agreeing to pay the oil company $15 million in settlement payments.

headline: Wanted: A Brooklyn Apartment With More Space
text: Eyal and Karen Hen started off as roommates.

headline: What Health Insurance Might Do
text: Alert (or at least health-care-obsessed) readers have no doubt been following the coverage of a new study on mortality in Massachusetts in the years following Romneycare’s coverage expansion, the gist of which — the authors found a striking, Massachusetts-specific decline in death rates for the non-elderly — tends to confirm liberal assumptions about the benefits of health insurance, and undercut the conservative and libertarian argument that insurance doesn’t have the impact on health and mortality that most people expect. The study’s findings are an almost-diametrical reversal of the results from Oregon’s Medicaid experiment, which were much discussed around this time last year (here’s my contribution), and which seemed to strengthen the conservative critique of Obamacare’s pursuit of comprehensive coverage. So now it’s liberalism’s turn to claim vindication, and to press Obamacare’s critics to give ground in the debate.

headline: A Note of Caution in Greek Banks’ Seeming Recovery
text: Greek banks, once seen as the most dangerous investment in the euro zone, have been on a tear of late.

headline: With Update, Snapchats Get a Little Less Private
text: Snapchat just released a major update that’s been getting a lot of attention. But one less publicized aspect of this update is that Snapchat is a whole lot less ephemeral than it used to be.

headline: Photos Trusted but Verified
text: A leading expert on digital forensic analysis has launched a free online service that lets people confirm – or debunk – the authority of online images.

headline: Staying Fit Between Flights With No Time to Spare
text: I cleared Canadian customs after the flight from New York, stashed my passport in my backpack and strode down the wide, brightly lighted corridor of Toronto Pearson International Airport’s Terminal 1.

headline: The 11th Most Fascinating Person Ever
text: On May 16, when Barbara Walters signs off from “The View” for the final time, one of the more remarkable careers in television will come to an (apparent) end.

headline: Hong Kong Publisher’s Prison Sentence Is Called a Political Vendetta
text: HONG KONG — Rejecting defense arguments for leniency, a court in southern China sentenced a Hong Kong publisher to 10 years in prison on Wednesday for smuggling industrial chemicals. The family and supporters of the publisher, Yiu Mantin, has said the charges were a political vendetta brought on by his plans to publish a book condemning the Chinese Communist Party leader, Xi Jinping.

headline: Can You Tweet Like Ruth Reichl?
text: In the magazine’s most recent Talk column, Ruth Reichl, the food writer and former Gourmet editor, discusses her newfound love of Twitter. “I discovered that I really loved the discipline of 140 characters,” she says. “It was a complete surprise to me that you could really paint a portrait of a moment.”

headline: Feeling For | Beauty Products to Whisk Mom Off to the Beaches of Sicily
text: Sue Townsend, one of the original founders of Britain’s Crabtree & Evelyn, lives in a 15th-century palazzo in Florence and creates handsome-smelling products under her luxury beauty label Ortigia. Unlike Townsend, everything about the line is truly Sicilian, from the indigenous, natural ingredients to the scents, which evoke the Mediterranean landscape. Some embody local flora — the slightly stringent yet delicate Zagara, infused with orange blossoms, or the Sicilian Jasmine, distilled from local white flowers — while others transport, like the musky but honeysuckle-sweet Ambra Nera, infused with patchouli and vetiver and evocative of a warm, amorous night on the island. The calming Fico D’India scent is inspired by the cactus of the same name that grows wild along the beaches of Sicily.

headline: Sam and League Share Uncomfortable Scrutiny
text: The N.F.L. draft, an auction of athletic aptitude with primeval roots and prime-time appeal, will begin Thursday night with an unprecedented subplot. An openly gay player with impressive credentials is in the pool of candidates, casting the usually myopic, football-centric draft in a societywide spotlight with resonant cultural significance.

headline: The Evolution of the Draft
text: Once a modest affair with chalkboards and no scouts, the N.F.L. draft has become a major televised spectacle.

headline: House Vote on Former I.R.S. Official Signals Element of G.O.P. Election Strategy
text: WASHINGTON — The House of Representatives voted on Wednesday to hold Lois Lerner, a former Internal Revenue Service official accused by Republicans of abusing power, in contempt, laying bare the bitter divide over which much of the midterm elections will be fought.

headline: Photos Trusted but Verified
text: Fueled by Twitter and Facebook, the enormous growth in citizen journalism — especially photojournalism — has generated intense debate and often skepticism over the authenticity of photographs that purport to document the truth. It has become so easy to digitally manipulate images and post them online that sometimes viewers cannot believe what they are seeing, possibly with good reason.

headline: Putin Withdraws Troops From Border
text: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said troops close to the Ukraine border have pulled back. He also asked separatists in eastern Ukraine to postpone a referendum on independence.

headline: For Older Travelers, a Site from AARP
text: While much of the travel industry is scrambling to satisfy the digital desires of millenials, a new travel website from AARP, formerly the American Association of Retired Persons, aims to build baby boomers a bridge across the digital divide.

headline: Embracing His Inner Thug
text: In the new musical “Bullets Over Broadway,” Nick Cordero plays Cheech, a pitiless mafia enforcer. Cheech’s hobbies include offing rival gangsters and dumping their bodies in the Gowanus Canal. He also enjoys modern drama.

headline: Postpartum Repression
text: “Playing With Grown Ups,” an ominous comedy-drama at 59E59 Theaters’ Brits Off Broadway festival, is the site of one more skirmish in the mommy wars. There are multiple casualties.

headline: The Move Toward Computing That Reads Your Mind
text: Like many people in this modern world, I struggle with the tension between the conveniences offered by the latest technology and the loss of privacy that comes with them.

headline: Apps That Predict What You Want
text: Molly Wood tests out contextual apps that can predict what you may want from your phone depending on the time of day or the activity you’re doing.

headline: Those Keeping a Diet Find Better Signposts to Dining on the Road
text: Melanie Melia, owner of a brokerage company in Glen Cove, N.Y., that represents natural food manufacturers, is a vegan who has found many ways to stick to her diet while traveling for business.

headline: Childlike, but Hardly Child’s Play
text: LOS ANGELES — It started out as a lark. After long days in the studio making his labor-intensive “Butterfly” paintings about a decade ago, Mark Grotjahn would unwind by taking empty supply boxes or beer cartons and gluing on toilet-paper tubes as noses. Then he would paint crude eyes and mouths.

headline: NBC Looks to ESPN for New Executive at ‘Today’
text: The arms race in morning television continued on Wednesday as NBC News turned to ESPN, a sister network of its morning rival, ABC, for the production executive Jamie Horowitz, who will become the senior vice president and general manager of the “Today” show.

headline: The Greening of Business Travel Gains Momentum
text: On a single afternoon recently, Rob Bernard had a meeting in Kenya, one in Ireland and one in Finland — three countries and two continents in less than 24 hours.

headline: Connecticut Students Show Gains in National Tests
text: High school seniors in Connecticut performed better last year on federal math and reading tests than their counterparts did four years earlier, but New Jersey and most of the nation remained flat in both areas, according to exam results released on Wednesday.

headline: Mets’ Pitchers Remain Hitless; Their Hitters’ Effort Is Not Much Better
text: MIAMI — Before his team played the Marlins on Wednesday, Mets Manager Terry Collins sat in his office and discussed how his pitchers had not yet recorded a base hit this season. He did not seem particularly perturbed. If he were to start worrying about his pitchers’ getting hits — that is, if his offense were so inept that he sorely needed his pitchers to produce — then, he said, “we got a real problem.”

headline: Your Digital Trail Follows You to the Border
text: Information, money and jobs flow easily around the world, yet it’s getting tougher for travelers to cross some borders.

headline: A New Single Hits No. 1; Top Album Is ‘Frozen’
text: Yet again, Disney’s “Frozen” soundtrack is the No. 1 album. But there is at least some news on the music charts this week: after a 10-week run, Pharrell Williams’s ubiquitous “Happy” has finally been dethroned as the top song.

headline: Hotels Near the Terminal, Some Even Attached
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — Before the year is over, China will eclipse the United States as the country with the largest number of residents traveling internationally, according to a new study by Oxford Economics commissioned by the travel technology company Amadeus. Similarly, Asia, the Middle East and South America are experiencing increases in the number of people flying long distances, according to the International Air Transport Association. Such robust growth is prompting a construction boom in hotels incorporated into new airports or airport expansions.

headline: Glen Stassen, Theologian, Dies at 78; Championed Nuclear Disarmament
text: Glen H. Stassen, a Southern Baptist theologian who helped define the social-justice wing of the evangelical movement in the 1980s and played a role in advancing nuclear disarmament talks toward the end of the Cold War, died on April 25 in Pasadena, Calif. He was 78.

headline: Beware When the Annual Meeting Is in Moosejaw
text: A handful of annual company meetings draw attention because they are unusually celebratory, like Berkshire Hathaway’s huge gathering in Omaha each May, or because shareholders are able to mount public efforts to curb executive pay or objectionable practices. But most such gatherings are carefully scripted so there are no hiccups.

headline: Financial Regulators See Progress and Threats
text: WASHINGTON — Some of the same weaknesses that contributed to the disastrous 2008 financial crisis persist today, the Financial Stability Oversight Council said in its 2014 annual report to Congress.

headline: Short Stories That Riff Playfully on Some Enduring Forebears
text: The stories in “American Innovations,” the new collection by Rivka Galchen, the author of the 2008 novel “Atmospheric Disturbances,” don’t behave like typical short stories. Sure, they bear strong physical resemblances to selections you would find in an anthology with the words “Best American” in its title. Though Ms. Galchen favors misdirection and indirection, her writing is skillful, imaginative, often funny.

headline: Forget 1960, the Golden Age Is Now
text: If you fly a lot, you have heard the nostalgia about a long-gone Golden Age of air travel. During this fabled time, which is said to have occurred as commercial aviation expanded through the 1950s into the jet age of the 1960s, passengers dressed up to fly on airplanes where glamorous stewardesses wearing white gloves served beef bourguignon on fine china.

headline: Sotheby’s to Reimburse Loeb $10 Million
text: Sotheby’s campaign to fend off attacks by the billionaire activist Daniel S. Loeb has proved costly. But playing nice with Mr. Loeb may be even costlier.

headline: Alibaba’s Acquisition Strategy: Focused Largely on China and Mobile
text: When Alibaba Group’s prospectus finally hit Wall Street on Tuesday, analysts and prospective investors eagerly tore into their fullest look yet at the company.

headline: For Wearable Computing, Software Must Be King
text: Over the last few years, we have heard that there will be wearable devices for almost every part of the body, from face to feet. But people have paid little attention to the software that accompanies these gadgets.

headline: The Gun Report: May 7, 2014
text: Last Saturday, 26-year-old Stephen Guillermo had just returned from a night of drinking when he tried to enter the fifth-floor apartment he shared with his mother and two younger siblings in the South of Market neighborhood of San Francisco. But he mistakenly got off on the third floor, and the apartment he thought was his belonged to Amisi Sudi Kachepa, a 68-year-old retired security guard, who shot Guillermo to death.

headline: A Familiar Refrain: Cut Calories
text: The Times is converting all of its 1964 issues into a digitized, searchable format. Each week, The Upshot will unearth an item from 50 years ago and put it in the light of today. “A Cut in Calories Urged for Nation” appeared on May 7 and can be seen in its original format on TimesMachine.

headline: Footage of Teenage Stowaway
text: Hawaii transportation officials released video of a California teenager hopping from a jet’s wheel well on April 20 after stowing away for a flight to Hawaii from San Jose, Calif.

headline: By Design | Neuehouse Brings Its Artisanal Aesthetic to Frieze New York
text: One of the chief appeals of Frieze New York is its buzzy restaurant partners, which for this weekend’s edition include Roberta’s, Mission Cantina and Frankies Spuntino. This year, the fair adds a different kind of lifestyle partner in the clublike co-working space Neuehouse, which has become a hot location for start-ups and cultural programming since opening its David Rockwell-designed office on 25th Street last year. For Frieze, Neuehouse created the V.I.P. tent, an oasis in the middle of the fair’s whirl of activity on Randall’s Island. “Part of the exploration here is that the place that one works, the place that one creates should be stimulating visually and emotionally, and art is a very important part of that,” says the Neuehouse co-founder Joshua Abram of the decision to partner with Frieze.

headline: Piling On the Luxury
text: For most travelers, flying in style may be a thing of the past, but airlines are determined to bring back some glamour to air travel, at least for those sitting in the front of the plane.

headline: Pictures of the Day: South Africa and Elsewhere
text: Photos from South Africa, India, Washington and Spain.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: Confections of History, Lovingly Decorated
text: The ballets of George Balanchine are fascinating layer cakes of history. The four that returned to New York City Ballet on Tuesday night were choreographed between 1947 and 1975, and they still capture the moments in which they were made.

headline: From Mystical Bells to a Hungarian Folk Duo, the Joys of the Unfamiliar
text: As a rule I do not expect to leave a concert of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center thinking about Donald Rumsfeld. But after Tuesday evening’s brilliant “Music From Three Centuries” at Alice Tully Hall, I was put in mind of the former defense secretary’s most famous dictum about those known knowns, known unknowns and, crucially, unknown unknowns in life: “the ones we do not know we don’t know.”

headline: Feeling For | A Fashion Magazine Without the Gloss
text: “Looking at countless blogs and Tumblrs, the images that we were sharing were much more raw and personal than what I typically see in fashion print,” says the creative director Claudia Bruno, a co-founder of the new fashion and culture magazine Bare. Seeking to strip away the artifice of traditional fashion media, Bruno teamed up with her longtime friends, the writers Emily Lundin and Courtney Saunders, to found a fashion magazine for what Bruno calls “women like us — smarter, intellectual people who aren’t slaves to fashion, but creators of it.”

headline: Nursing a Half-Empty Tankard, the Nebbish Returns
text: What does it say about me that I almost always like shows in the micro-genre of comedians playing themselves — “Seinfeld,” “Curb Your Enthusiasm,” “The Sarah Silverman Program,” “Louie,” “Legit”? That I have a taste for low-stakes misanthropy? That I enjoy other people’s misery and embarrassment?

headline: Out of the Northwest, Through Sea and Desert
text: Among its many impressive aspects, the concert by the Seattle Symphony on Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall, part of the Spring for Music festival, was a publicist’s fantasy.

headline: Fight Over Guggenheim’s Legacy Roils Her Palazzo
text: VENICE — The battle now raging over the Peggy Guggenheim Collection started with just a few words written in brass letters above the sculpted lions that guard the 18th-century palazzo turned art museum here.

headline: Garance Doré: A Half, but Whole
text: Garance Doré is a mistress of the slow reveal. Alongside the fetching fashion sketches and street snaps that she posts on her popular namesake style blog, she spins just enough of her charmingly addictive personal musings to keep her followers engaged and clicking on for more.

headline: A Team in Need Gets a Fourth
text: In the final of the Bermuda Bowl world team championship last year, Italy defeated Monaco by 210 international match points to 126 over 96 boards.

headline: June Festival Adds to New York’s Lively Early Music Scene
text: The latest addition to New York’s flourishing early music scene is a festival meant to hold up a mirror to the field: Early Music Festival: NYC, a new festival that will run from June 13 to 19, will focus on early music performers who live and work in New York City. Most of the performances will be free.

headline: A Sweet Celebration of Kara Walker’s Giant Sugar Sculpture
text: WhoKara Walker was the guest of honor at last night’s Creative Time benefit to celebrate the artist’s 75-foot-high white sphinx sculpture made of sugar in the decommissioned Domino Sugar Factory in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. More than 700 guests, most from the worlds of art and fashion, including Chuck Close, Jenna Lyons, Theaster Gates, Solange Knowles, Chloé Sévigny, André Leon Talley and Walker’s 16-year-old daughter Octavia, dined in its shadow.

headline: Bank of America Shareholders Press Officials After $4 Billion Error
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — This year’s annual meeting was supposed to be a victory lap for Bank of America, with many of its mortgage problems receding and its deposits and credit card business growing.

headline: Infidelity Runs Amok, but the Party Never Stops
text: As the title character of Ed Bullins’s “The Fabulous Miss Marie,” Tonya Pinkins wears a series of dresses cut low and slit high. One gown has leopard spots, another tiger stripes. (Perhaps her ocelot frock is at the dry cleaner’s?) Ms. Pinkins slinks around the Castillo Theater stage, yowling and purring as she sips Ambassador Scotch. When she sees a handsome young man, she toys with him for a while. Then she pounces.

headline: Motorcyclist Deaths May Have Decreased in 2013
text: Based on preliminary data provided by the highway departments of all 50 states and the District of Columbia, motorcyclist deaths in the United States appear to have decreased 7 percent in 2013, according to an analysis released Tuesday by the Governors Highway Safety Association, a nonprofit organization. But motorcyclist safety has not improved over all in the last 15 years, the group said.

headline: It’s Here: Climate Change in America
text: To the Editor:

headline: Restraint in Foreign Crises
Guys, Please Take It Outside
text: One highlight of the Bottega Veneta fall 2014 runway show was its dip-dyed knitwear: luxurious sweaters with cuffs or hems stained in a contrasting color, as if by happy accident (shown here). Bottega Veneta’s colors are autumnal — rust orange, burgundy, forest green — but it’s easy to get a jump on the fall look with any of spring’s array of dip-dyed goods, these in seasonally appropriate nautical colors.

headline: Justices’ Political Biases
text: To the Editor:

headline: Beauty Unmasked for All to See
text: One is accustomed to seeing celebrity profiles beginning with avowals that the subject is wearing “no makeup,” and rolling one’s eyes. Yet, for a few seasons, either on the catwalk, sidewalk or information superhighway, a no-makeup look seems to be emerging as the gold (or beige?) standard.

headline: Debate Over a Papyrus Scrap
text: To the Editor:

headline: Facts & Figures: What Aliens Have to Do With MH370
text: Now we know what percentage of people believe, or at least what percentage are willing to tell a pollster they believe, that space aliens had something to do with the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

headline: 3 Singers Return, Reflecting About Life
text: “Pushin’ on, pushin’ on, isn’t that what I’m supposed to do?” Natalie Merchant sings on her self-titled new album, a set of dark, brave, thoughtful and serenely startling songs that is her first album in 13 years with her own lyrics. Ms. Merchant, 50, had million-selling albums in the 1980s with 10,000 Maniacs and in the 1990s on her own before turning away from a routine pop career after her somber 2001 album, “Motherland.”

headline: A Romp in Gossamer, 8 Tons’ Worth
text: The ceiling has been reinforced. The guards have been retrained. Touching is allowed. Swinging like Tarzan is not.

headline: Crime in Public Housing
text: To the Editor:

headline: Getting Gas to Ukraine
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Ukraine Crisis: Behind the Coverage
text: Kyle Crichton is a regional editor for Russia and Iran on the International Desk. He has coordinated The Times’s coverage of the Ukraine crisis. We asked him about the planning behind the coverage and the impact of President Vladimir V. Putin’s statement Wednesday that Russian troops were pulling back from the Ukrainian border.

headline: Club Echoes, in Sounds and Moves
text: When the doors opened at the Kitchen on Saturday night, the party had already started. Off to one side of the stage, the London D.J.s Elijah and Skilliam were in the midst of spinning what would turn out to be a fabulous, fierce set of Grime music — intriguingly unstable beats with enough bass to make your seat shake whether you wanted it to or not.

headline: Tear Down ‘Deadbeat’ Dams
text: VENTURA, Calif. — OF the more than 80,000 dams listed by the federal government, more than 26,000 pose high or significant safety hazards. Many no longer serve any real purpose. All have limited life spans. Only about 1,750 produce hydropower, according to the National Hydropower Association.

headline: After-Parties: The Gala Was Just the Start
text: Some 90 minutes after the Met Gala let out on Monday night, a stream of celebrities with enough wattage to rival an Oscars after-party converged on the Top of the Standard in the meatpacking district.

headline: More Hugs Please, We’re Chinese
text: Of all the changes to sweep China since the death of Mao Zedong in 1976 — stock markets, private cars, fashion — one thing seemed not to have changed: No hugging. Chinese were physically reserved.

headline: Art Matters | At Frieze New York, Mixing Pleasure with Business
text: The third iteration of Frieze New York, which opens to V.I.P.s on Thursday and to the general public on Friday with more than 190 contemporary art galleries from 28 countries, is one of the world’s epicenters of pleasure for profit. So perhaps it’s fitting that this year the fair’s organizers embraced the pursuit of leisure via the complementary programming installed in and around the tent. “We wanted to interrupt the rhythms of the fair, going from booth to booth,” says Cecilia Alemani, the curator of Frieze Projects, the annual array of artworks commissioned for the fair, and Frieze Sounds, a series of audio works looped in the fair’s V.I.P. shuttles. “It is a marketplace, and we wanted to create a platform where what could be exchanged was also ideas.”

headline: Islamist Militants Kill Hundreds of Civilians in Northeastern Nigeria
text: ABUJA, Nigeria — Islamist insurgents have killed hundreds in a town in Nigeria’s northeast this week, the area’s senator, a resident and the Nigerian news media reported on Wednesday, as more than 200 schoolgirls abducted by the militants, known as Boko Haram, remained missing.

headline: The Tracker
text: AGE 27

headline: The Met Gala: By the Labels
text: On a night when the Metropolitan Museum of Art was honoring Charles James, a designer known for his dramatic, structurally inventive ball gowns, it was not surprising that many of the guests, including two of the evening’s hosts, Sarah Jessica Parker and Aerin Lauder, chose to wear Oscar de la Renta, a designer whose work seems all but ready for a museum retrospective of its own. Or that Marchesa and Zac Posen, both operating in the less-is-never-more school of fashion design, would be well represented. But who would have guessed that Stella McCartney would come close to stealing the night with a posse of young stars, Rihanna and Reese Witherspoon among them, who turned the red carpet into their own personal party, or that the British retailer Topshop would have as many red-carpet credits as Prada? A selective look at who wore what on Monday night.

headline: Can Hashtag Activism Save Kidnapped Nigerian Girls?
text: As my colleague Adam Nossiter reports from Nigeria, President Goodluck Jonathan’s government is under intense pressure to respond to the mass kidnappings of hundreds of schoolgirls by Islamist militants over the past month. Public outrage over the abductions, and the apparent inaction of the authorities, first expressed in small street protests, has been greatly amplified on social networks, where more than a million messages have been tagged with the simple demand: #BringBackOurGirls.

headline: It’s the Viral Season
text: Alas, poor J.D. Winteregg. We knew him ... um, actually not very well at all.

headline: Mother’s Day Beauty Gifts for Edgy Moms
text: Flowery and feminine are the standard Mother’s Day beauty gift go-tos, but chic moms may appreciate it if you went for a punk-rock edge.

headline: Like Mall Browsing, With a Click
text: SAN FRANCISCO — A couple of years ago, Deena Varshavskaya, the founder of a social shopping site, went through what she called a “Steve Jobs phase,” wearing a single T-shirt: a lightweight, cotton J. Crew V-neck in different colors.

headline: Norway’s Leaders Snub Dalai Lama in Deference to China
text: The Dalai Lama, Tibet’s spiritual leader in exile, began a visit to Norway on Wednesday to commemorate the Nobel Peace Prize he received there 25 years ago, but the trip was overshadowed by an uproar over the government’s refusal to meet with him in deference to an increasingly assertive China, which considers the Dalai Lama an unrepentant separatist.

headline: In College, Nurturing Matters
text: I was a college freshman at Grambling State University in Louisiana. It was the middle of the night, the day before a personal essay was due for a writing seminar. I had put it off for days. I had nothing — nothing but writer’s block.

headline: Pictures on the Street? It’s Complicated
text: Mark Cohen has found that his love of taking up-close of pictures of strangers isn’t always requited.

headline: What Can I Do About Our Building’s Ugly Corridors?
text: Q. Our apartment building has ugly corridors. Is there anything we can do to make a better first impression on buyers?

headline: All Angles and Curves
text: Starting next week, furniture by Oscar Niemeyer and Jorge Zalszupin, two of Brazil’s most-celebrated architects, will be available in the United States, through Espasso, a design gallery in TriBeCa. The re-editions include items that Mr. Niemeyer, who died in 2012 at the age of 104, designed in the 1970s with his daughter Anna Maria Niemeyer, including the Rio rocking chaise ($38,400), and Alta armchair and ottoman ($28,450 for both). Espasso will also offer 20 pieces designed in the 1960s by the now-91-year-old Mr. Zalszupin, including his Circa bench ($17,800) and delicately curving Brasiliana armchair ($10,250). The pieces will be displayed at Espasso from May 14 to June 3, and will be for sale, then and after, along with a new monograph, “Jorge Zalszupin: Design Moderno” ($80), by Maria Cecilia Loschiavo dos Santos. Espasso is at 38 North Moore Street (Hudson Street). Information: 212-219-0017 or espasso.com.

headline: Damien Hirst Plants a Flag in SoHo
text: Damien Hirst has brought his ebullient gestures to New York, with the Tuesday opening of Other Criteria, the retail arm of the British arts-based publishing company of the same name. The two-level 3,500-square-foot SoHo boutique was designed by Michel Schranz and is the first Other Criteria shop to break out of Britain (there are two in London, and one in Devon). Jason Beard, the creative director, said SoHo was chosen over other neighborhoods because: “It feels like London. It feels like home.” The shop features versions of Mr. Hirst’s spin art applied to rugs ($66,700), skulls and guitars. It also sells works by 35 other artists, including Gary Hume, Sarah Lucas, Peregrine Honig and Thomas Scheibitz. Offerings extend from tourist bait like key chains to prints, jewelry and artist-designed wallpaper and vases. A dollar will buy you an “I spot DH” pin. 458 Broome Street (Mercer Street). Information: 646-762-0123 or othercriteria.com.

headline: A Classic (Again) Ripe for an Update
text: Lizzy Ratner is a contributor to the Nation, reporting on serious subjects like politics, education and the economy. Jen Nessel is also a journalist, a former political organizer and the communications coordinator at the Center for Constitutional Rights. They are the mothers of Elias, 4, and Oscar, 8, and the authors of “Goodnight Nanny-Cam,” a new parody of the much-parodied children’s book (remember “Goodnight Keith Moon”?) that was first born as an essay in The New Yorker two years ago to skewer the affectations and anxieties of modern parenting.

headline: New Fairs Add to Design Mix
text: Happily for New York designers, the entity once known as New York Design Week now stretches over a goodly part of May. Helping to fill the time are two new design fairs. From May 10 to 20, Wanted Design, an annual furniture show in Chelsea organized by Odile Hainaut and Claire Pijoulat, will open a separate exhibition in the 30,000-square-foot Industry City complex in Sunset Park, Brooklyn. The show, called Industry City/Design, will have three sections: one about objects, like Italian TobeUs cars made from wood salvaged from Hurricane Sandy; one about processes, like the creation of Alpi Group’s decorative woods, and one devoted to local design organizations.

headline: Discounts at Area, Nemati Collection and Jonathan Adler
text: Bed linens are up to 75 percent off at Area, through May 15 (a full/queen Parallel blue cotton duvet cover, originally $225, is $90); 58 East 11th Street (University Place), 212-924-7084, areahome.com.

headline: Your Hand in Marriage
