text: When Lisa Bayne married the first time, her friends baked a wedding cake topped with bride-and-groom cookies. This being 1976, in Berkeley, Calif., the cookie couple was nude, though the same could not be said of Ms. Bayne and her then-husband, who wore his-and-hers tunics that the bride had sewed by hand from vintage fabrics.

headline: Redefining a Beach Share
text: A few years ago, Chad Oppenheim, an architect in Miami, received a run-of-the-mill phone call from a potential client. Debby Lawn, a retired elementary school counselor from San Francisco, had recently bought waterfront property in the Bahamas with her husband, Richard, a semiretired molecular biologist, and the couple, who are in their 60s, wanted Mr. Oppenheim to design a house there.

headline: Old, Good Things Seen Anew
text: A rarity among authors who focus on the relentlessly forward-looking profession of architecture, Witold Rybczynski is generally considered something of a conservative. Born in Scotland, educated in England and Canada and residing in Philadelphia, Mr. Rybczynski wrote in the introduction to his most recent book, “How Architecture Works: A Humanist’s Toolkit” (Farrar, Straus & Giroux), “I consider history a gift, rather than an imposition.” While a few of his 18 books are set firmly in the past, most, like the 1986 best-seller, “Home: A Short History of an Idea,” use a broad historical perspective to better frame the present. His writing has a patient, deliberate quality that is rare at a moment when the dominant medium of architectural discourse is Twitter. Perhaps this is why Mr. Rybczynski, despite himself, is suddenly all the rage. On May 1 he was named a “Design Mind” by the Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum in its annual National Design Awards, an honor generally bestowed on visionary thinkers. On the same day he attended the National Magazine Awards as a nominee for three columns he wrote for Architect magazine in which he revisited significant buildings and neighborhoods that were completed many years ago to see how they’ve stood the test of time. (This interview, which was conducted by phone and email, has been edited and condensed.)

headline: Grandma Never Had It So Good
text: In most cities, adding a second house to a single-family lot would be illegal or would set off an epic battle with the neighbors that could drag on for years. But not in Portland, Ore.

headline: Literary Lions in a New Age
text: The annual PEN American Center Literary Gala, at the American Museum of Natural History, was the social event of the season for the city’s belletrists.

headline: A Celebration of Letters and a Few Characters
text: Anna Wintour and Beyoncé lured the eyes of the fashion world to the shimmering Costume Institute gala at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, but they did not hold exclusive rights to the society spectacle that unfolded Monday night along the perimeter of Manhattan’s common backyard.

headline: Furnishings With Geometric Patterns
text: Rafael de Cárdenas is a big fan of geometric patterns because they’re “a good and relatively easy way to immerse a viewer in a space,” he said.

headline: French Soccer Club Hires Woman to Coach Its Men
text: Helena Costa, whose father did not like soccer and who often had to go to neighbors’ homes to watch games, will become the first woman to coach a men’s professional soccer team in France.

headline: Lawmakers on Benghazi Investigation
text: Representatives from both parties discussed the latest inquiry into the 2012 attack in Benghazi, Libya.

headline: Hamas Executes 2 Men Accused of Aiding Israel
text: GAZA — The Hamas government on Wednesday executed two men convicted of collaborating with Israel, highlighting a stark difference between its rule in the Gaza Strip and the Palestinian Authority’s in the West Bank and demonstrating the complications that can emerge as the two prepare to join forces in a new government.

headline: A Big Win for the Prayer Lobby
text: IF you listened to Justice Anthony M. Kennedy of the Supreme Court and his fellow conservatives on the bench this week, you might think the court’s 5-4 decision in the case of Town of Greece v. Galloway was no big deal. So what if a town in upstate New York typically opens its council meetings with prayers that acknowledge “the saving sacrifice of Jesus Christ on the cross”?

headline: U.S. Issues Safety Alert for Oil Trains
text: Calling the movement of crude oil by rail an “imminent hazard” to the public, the federal Department of Transportation said on Wednesday that railroads would be required to notify local emergency responders whenever oil shipments traveled through their states.

headline: Pakistani Activist Shot Dead; Aided Blasphemy Suspects
text: LAHORE, Pakistan — Rashid Rehman, a veteran Pakistani human rights activist who had received threats for defending people charged under the country’s blasphemy laws, was shot dead on Wednesday night in his office in the southern city of Multan.

headline: American Embassy in Yemen Is Closed
text: The United States has closed its embassy in Sana, the Yemeni capital, to the public because of security concerns, the State Department said on Wednesday, citing recent attacks against Western interests in Yemen as the reason for temporarily suspending operations. Embassy personnel are not being evacuated, but the closing will stop the processing of visas and other services. The department did not say how long the embassy would be closed to the public but stated that the potential threat to the embassy would be evaluated daily.

headline: A Soldier Fights Off the Cold
text: WASHINGTON — On Aug. 4, 2004, while in my Stryker combat vehicle battling insurgents for control of a street in Mosul, Iraq, I was struck by a rocket-propelled grenade. The core of the rocket, a solid piece of metal only a few inches long, sliced open my stomach from right to left, filled my legs and face with shrapnel, tore my intestines, lacerated my liver, destroyed my spleen, punctured my diaphragm, flattened my lungs, shattered my ribs and ruptured discs in my back. As I struggled to remove my smoldering body armor, I watched my stomach tear open and my intestines begin to push their way out.

headline: China: Pollution Fines Multiply
text: By the end of April, the Beijing government had collected 88 million renminbi, or $14 million, in fines levied during the first three months of this year against companies caught violating pollution standards, according to a news release from Beijing officials and a report on Wednesday in Beijing News, a daily newspaper. The amount is 10 times the total levied in the same period in 2013. More than 7,000 companies were fined in the first three months of this year by Beijing environmental protection officials, compared with 2,000 in the same period last year.

headline: Wheelies: The Lane-Minder Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Pakistan: F.B.I. Agent Is Questioned
text: The police questioned a Federal Bureau of Investigation agent under the country’s antiterrorism laws on Wednesday, two days after he was arrested on charges of possessing ammunition and knives as he tried to board a domestic flight. Several news outlets, citing American law enforcement officials, identified the man, who arrived in Pakistan on May 1, as Joel Cox. The Associated Press said that Jen Psaki, a State Department spokeswoman in Washington, confirmed that Mr. Cox was an F.B.I. employee on temporary assignment to “provide routine assistance to the legal attaché at the U.S. Mission” in Pakistan. The local news media broadcast images of a handcuffed man wearing a blue and white striped shirt as he was taken to court on Tuesday. The images were reminiscent of the arrest of Raymond A. Davis, a covert security officer for the Central Intelligence Agency, in Lahore in January 2011 after he shot two Pakistani men at a busy intersection. The killings and arrest of Mr. Davis caused a diplomatic furor, with the United States and Pakistan wrangling over American assertions that he had diplomatic immunity.

headline: Love and Stuff
text: After her mother passes away, the filmmaker Judith Helfand struggles to pack up her things — figuring out what to keep and how to let go.

headline: ‘Love and Stuff’
text: When I was a kid I loved Mother’s Day. I got to make breakfast in bed for my mom. As I got older I started to resent it. I would tell her: this is between us — not you, me and Hallmark. Every day is Mother’s Day. More than gifts, what she always wanted was time. Time with me, with my brothers, with her grandchildren, with my father (may he rest in peace), the guy who made her a mother to begin with. The gift of time always trumped stuff.

headline: How Vanity Fair Landed the Monica Lewinsky Story
text: On Tuesday night, the wife of former Vice President Dick Cheney offered her take on Monica Lewinsky’s essay — “Shame and Survival” — in the June issue of Vanity Fair magazine. It was part of a Clinton conspiracy, she said, an effort to “get that story out of the way” before the 2016 presidential campaign.

headline: Venezuela: Arrests in Shooting of Antigovernment Protester
text: The authorities on Wednesday said they had charged two sergeants in the country’s National Guard in the death of a 23-year-old woman who was shot during antigovernment protests. The shooting of the woman, Geraldín Moreno, in February in Valencia, the country’s third-largest city, provoked outrage and fueled allegations that the protests sweeping Venezuela in recent months had been violently repressed. Witnesses said that Ms. Moreno was on the ground when a soldier shot her in the face at close range. President Nicolás Maduro has said repeatedly that his government defends human rights and that it is vigorously investigating allegations of wrongdoing by security forces. A human rights lawyer, Gonzalo Himiob, pointed to an apparent lack of progress in other investigations and questioned the government’s commitment to holding violators accountable.

headline: For Online Video Publishers, a New Tack on Luring Ad Dollars
text: AS a well-received annual presentation of new digital offerings to Madison Avenue ends, publishers are seeking to keep the momentum going by making it easier for marketers and agencies to spend advertising dollars on online video — whether or not that money is being shifted from television ad budgets.

headline: Amid Tensions, a Gesture From Putin
text: If President Vladimir Putin of Russia means what he said on Wednesday, the dangerous standoff over Ukraine could be moving toward a resolution. After meeting with the Swiss president, Didier Burkhalter, who is the current chairman of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, Mr. Putin said Russian troops have been pulled back from the Ukrainian border, and he urged pro-Russian rebels in southeastern Ukraine to call off a referendum on secession that they had scheduled for Sunday.

headline: Muve Music Service Is Said to Be Up for Sale by AT&T
text: One of the most successful music subscription services in the United States may be up for grabs.

headline: Young Ukrainians Brush Aside the Crisis and Voice Optimism About the Future
text: KIEV, Ukraine — The din of dire news from Ukraine’s restive east and south tends to obscure people like Nataliya Gumenyuk, a spiky-haired bundle of energy who co-founded an online television channel that broadcast the country’s revolution. In spite of the daily chaos, conflict and crisis, she and other 20- and 30-somethings here insist that Ukraine has a brighter future in store, and they say they can build it.

headline: F.C.C. Commissioner Asks for Delay on New Net Neutrality Rules
text: WASHINGTON – A Democratic member of the Federal Communications Commission called Wednesday on the agency’s chairman to delay a proposal for new net neutrality rules, throwing into doubt whether the chairman will be able to muster enough votes at an F.C.C. meeting next week to issue proposed rules.

headline: Philadelphia’s Success in Helping the Homeless Gets a Philanthropic Boost
text: PHILADELPHIA — There’s a straight line that goes from David Drap to David Brown, but you cannot find it in most other cities.

headline: Six Players, Six Countries, One Team
text: On a recent afternoon on a New York golf course, an Italian discussed strategy with a Canadian while a New Zealander laughed alongside a Briton. Nearby, a Spaniard and a Mexican huddled with an American.

headline: For ‘Cleopatra’s Needle,’ a Cleaning to Last 500 Years
text: In the course of history, what’s a few years?

headline: U.N. May Refer Syria Conflict to War Crimes Court
text: UNITED NATIONS — France has drafted a Security Council resolution that seeks to refer Syria to the International Criminal Court in The Hague, tailoring it specifically to address American sensitivities, according to several people who have seen the text.

headline: U.S. Awards 3 Wind Power Grants
text: The long-promised potential of offshore wind development along American coastlines took a step toward fruition on Wednesday as the Department of Energy pledged up to $47 million each to three projects it previously supported.

headline: After Tornado, Obama Visit Puts Politics on Pause in Arkansas
text: VILONIA, Ark. — President Obama’s visit here on Wednesday was in many respects just like the many others he has made to disaster-ravaged communities across the country, but this one came with a bit of political intrigue.

headline: Still No. 1? Golf Rankings Reflect a Longer View
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — In sports, you either win or you don’t — a rigid bottom line underlying the “what have you done for us lately” attitude exemplified by the criticism aimed at the N.B.A. star Kevin Durant days before the formal announcement this week of his Most Valuable Player award.

headline: When Freedom Is the Right to Stay Under Wraps
text: TEHRAN — Cars honked frantically, their drivers in despair as separate columns of Iranian men and women in black chadors fist-pumped their way through the capital’s afternoon rush on Wednesday, shouting for the government to arrest all women who are improperly veiled.

headline: Alibaba Bets on a Growing Chinese Economy and New Consumers
text: When American tech upstarts float their companies on the stock market, they often sell investors on a familiar dream — “disrupting” an existing industry. It doesn’t matter if the industry is advertising, software, commerce or some other sector. The start-up will usually claim that its business is a great technological leap forward that will greatly lower costs and improve service for customers and leave rivals unable to respond. Therefore, buy some stock.

headline: Growing Pains for a Goldman Sachs Fund
text: One of Goldman Sachs’s most notable investment vehicles, Petershill, has been less than extraordinary, effectively saved by one good bet among a number of duds, and the bank even came close to selling it to Credit Suisse in 2012. So when Goldman started a second version of Petershill, which buys stakes in big-name hedge funds, it came as something of a surprise to people in the industry.

headline: Some Investors Bet on Return to Reverse Mortgages
text: Some private investors are betting that reverse mortgages, an investment product aimed at older people in need of cash, will make a resurgence as more homeowners reach retirement age in the coming years.

headline: Americans’ Views on Climate Change
text: Forty-four percent of Americans said they believed that there is solid evidence the temperature on earth is getting warmer mostly because of human activity.

headline: Hostage Testifies About Post-Rescue Meeting With Imam Charged in Kidnapping
text: They each took the witness stand, one after the other on Wednesday in a courtroom in Lower Manhattan: the former hostage and the British imam accused of helping to orchestrate her kidnapping.

headline: Convicted Murderer Who Inspired Film ‘Bernie’ Is Released to Director’s Garage
text: LOS ANGELES — More thrilling than a Golden Globe nomination, and it had one of those last year, Richard Linklater’s darkly comic film “Bernie” helped achieve something truly novel this week: Freedom for a convicted murderer, Bernie Tiede, who was the subject of the movie and, in a bizarre twist, will now live in Mr. Linklater’s garage apartment.

headline: Populist Party Gaining Muscle to Push Britain to the Right
text: GATESHEAD, England — Before winning power, Prime Minister David Cameron once called them “fruitcakes, loonies and closet racists,” and a cabinet minister, Kenneth Clarke, dismissed them last year as “clowns.” But the U.K. Independence Party is showing that it cannot be laughed off.

headline: Prison Time That Ex-Legislator Must Serve Is Reduced
text: There may have been more corrupt politicians in New York than former State Assemblyman Brian M. McLaughlin, even though he admitted stealing from his campaign, the state government, labor unions, even a Little League program in Queens.

headline: Honoring the Missing Schoolgirls
text: When Boko Haram fanatics attacked a girls’ boarding school in northeastern Nigeria, kidnapping several hundred girls whose only offense was to dream of becoming doctors, teachers or lawyers, the Nigerian authorities’ initial response was to lie.

headline: Called by Republicans, Health Insurers Deliver Unexpected Testimony
text: WASHINGTON — House Republicans summoned a half-dozen health insurance executives to a hearing Wednesday envisioned as another forum for criticism of the Affordable Care Act. But insurers refused to go along with the plan, and surprised Republican critics of the law by undercutting some of their arguments against it.

headline: Christie, Visiting Maine, Aids a Colleague’s Re-election Bid
text: PORTLAND, Me. — The S.U.V. had barely come to a full stop before Gov. Chris Christie hopped out and walked briskly under the dusted-white sign on the front of Becky’s Diner. His quick entrance on Wednesday, trotting behind Gov. Paul LePage of Maine, set the tone as Mr. Christie, chairman of the Republican Governors Association, campaigned in public with a candidate for the first time since the George Washington Bridge lane-closing scandal broke.

headline: Smartphones, Smartwatches and, Now, Smart Toothbrushes
text: IN the last few years, sensors have become small and inexpensive enough to make the monitoring of practically everything possible.

headline: The Lawyer Behind the Drone Policy
text: When the White House nominated David Barron to be a judge on the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit, based in Boston, it expected the usual Republican opposition. Mr. Barron, a Harvard law professor, is known as a liberal who was pointedly critical of President George W. Bush’s national security policy. What it didn’t expect — but should have — was that Democrats would have some problems with the nominee, too.

headline: U.N. to Consider Ways to Track Planes Over Seas
text: Frustrated and alarmed by the failure to find any trace of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 after the 250-ton jet disappeared nine weeks ago, the United Nations’ civil aviation arm will convene a meeting in Montreal on Monday to discuss ways to keep track of planes flying over the open sea.

headline: Cable Fees and Football Help Profits Climb at Fox
text: LOS ANGELES — The Super Bowl, new digital streaming TV deals and higher fees for its cable networks resulted in a stronger-than-expected gain in quarterly profit at 21st Century Fox.

headline: Miami Finds Itself Ankle-Deep in Climate Change Debate
text: MIAMI BEACH — The sunny-day flooding was happening again. During high tide one recent afternoon, Eliseo Toussaint looked out the window of his Alton Road laundromat and watched bottle-green saltwater seep from the gutters, fill the street and block the entrance to his front door.

headline: Sunny Region Yields a Shining Young Player
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — While most hockey players have childhood tales of skating on icy ponds and frozen toes, Anaheim Ducks forward Emerson Etem reminisces about surfing along sandy beaches and wolfing down In-N-Out burgers.

headline: Climate Disruptions, Close to Home
text: Apart from the disinformation sowed by politicians content with the status quo, the main reason neither Congress nor much of the American public cares about global warming is that, as problems go, it seems remote. Anyone who reads the latest National Climate Assessment, released on Tuesday, cannot possibly think that way any longer. The report is exhaustive and totally alarming.

headline: Abduction of Girls an Act Not Even Al Qaeda Can Condone
text: ABUJA, Nigeria — As word spread like wildfire on Twitter and Facebook that Nigerian militants were preparing to auction off more than 200 kidnapped schoolgirls in the name of Islam, a very different Internet network started quietly buzzing too.

headline: Another Push to Pay With Smartphones at Vending Machines
text: SEATTLE — If anything should be able to get people to use their smartphones as mobile wallets, it’s vending machines.

headline: Conflicting Rulings Cloud Wisconsin Campaign Finance Inquiry
text: An investigation into possible campaign finance violations involving conservative groups in Wisconsin and Gov. Scott Walker’s campaign committee has become entangled in back-to-back federal court rulings on whether it should continue.

headline: Real Threat in a Known Market for Children
text: When the leader of the Boko Haram extremist group threatened to sell hundreds of kidnapped Nigerian girls “in the market” in a rambling online video posted this week, he was not necessarily making an irrational boast.

headline: Taxpayers’ Bill in Bridge Inquiry Soars
text: The cost to New Jersey taxpayers for Gov. Chris Christie’s internal inquiry into lane closings at the George Washington Bridge is likely to reach several million dollars, outpacing early estimates and touching off urgent attempts to reduce the cost, according to newly available documents and interviews.

headline: China and Vietnam on Oil Rig Dispute
text: Officials from Vietnam and China discussed an incident between the two countries in the South China Sea.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 7, 2014
A Nets Big Man Casts a Long Shadow With His Absence
text: MIAMI — Hello, Brook.

headline: American Legion, Citing Problems, Calls for Veterans Secretary to Resign
text: When the commander of the American Legion, Daniel Dellinger, asked the secretary of veterans affairs, Eric Shinseki, last month about why no one in his department had been fired despite an array of serious problems over the years, he was taken aback at the answer.

headline: Allen Elevates His Game and Heat’s
text: MIAMI — Erik Spoelstra practically rolled his eyes Wednesday afternoon when a reporter began to ask about the video his Heat players were watching inside their locker room on Tuesday night.

headline: Hush Lifted Over Awards for Nation’s Libraries and Museums
text: WASHINGTON — When she was 16, Ashley Gagnay did not know that beets and carrots grew underground or that lemons ripened on trees. She had to learn those lessons at a program sponsored by the Children’s Garden at Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Now 21, she teaches those basics to 4-year-olds enrolled in a similar program at the garden.

headline: Complaints About Pigeons, Mapped
text: Since 2010, more than 2,700 “unsanitary pigeon condition” complaints have been made to New York City’s 311 hot line.

headline: The Most Republican Company? The Makers of Wonder Bread
text: The most Republican-leaning company in the country, based on political donations, isn’t Koch Industries. It’s the company that makes Wonder Bread.

headline: Making a Statement
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — I thought this was a simple yet clever theme that highlights the “Liar’s PARADOX,” but I’ll be honest right up front with you: This theme has run before, albeit with a slightly different reveal.

headline: Nationals Put Trust in Strasburg, Even When He Falters
text: WASHINGTON — When the question came to him, with the cameras on, Stephen Strasburg chose calculated sarcasm. How often does he have all his pitches working the way he did Wednesday?

headline: House Approves Panel to Study Building Women’s Museum
text: The House on Wednesday approved a commission to study building a women’s history museum in Washington, advancing an effort that has been stalled in Congress for more than a decade. Drafted by Representatives Carolyn B. Maloney, Democrat of New York, and Marsha Blackburn, Republican of Tennessee, the bill would create an eight-member panel to examine potential locations, including on or near the National Mall, and construction and maintenance details. The bill must be approved by the Senate, and the museum itself would require congressional approval. Some critics do not want to use taxpayer money on the project, and several conservatives groups have pressured lawmakers to oppose it because they believe it will reflect a liberal bias.

headline: North Carolina: Judge Attacked in Ad Campaign Survives Primary
text: Justice Robin Hudson, who is seeking re-election to the North Carolina Supreme Court, will face Superior Court Judge Eric Levinson in the November ballot after the two received the most votes in Tuesday’s three-candidate primary. The primary received national attention because the Republican State Leadership Committee in Washington, using donations from corporations and individuals, provided more than $600,000 for an ad attacking Justice Hudson, a Democrat. On a day of low turnout, Justice Hudson received 43 percent of the votes while Judge Levinson, a conservative, received 37 percent and a second conservative, Jeanette Doran, received 21 percent.

headline: The Enquirer Is Returning to Where It All Started
text: “Michael Douglas Marked for Death!!” “Angelina Walks In on Brad & Jen.” “Space Platform Circling Mars — Living Creatures May Be Aboard.” “Japs Attack U.S. — Hawaii, Philippines Bombed by Airmen!”

headline: Once Shaky in Postseason, Fleury Continues Steady Play in Goal
text: Marc-Andre Fleury came into this second-round series against the Rangers as a bit of a worrisome commodity for the Pittsburgh Penguins.

headline: Kenneth Tomlinson, Conservative Voice in Broadcast Oversight, Dies at 69
text: Kenneth Y. Tomlinson, a conservative journalist who used his leadership role in federal communications agencies to counter what he regarded as liberal bias, died on May 1 at a hospital in Winchester, Va. He was 69.

headline: Mondelez and Dutch Firm Aim to Create a Coffee Powerhouse
text: Mondelez International, the maker of Cadbury chocolate and Chips Ahoy cookies, is carving out its coffee business to combine it in a joint venture with a Dutch company to form a global coffee seller with more than $7 billion in annual revenue. The joint venture will join Mondelez International’s coffee portfolio with D.E Master Blenders 1753 of Amsterdam, giving the combined company control of coffee brands including Gevalia, Tassimo, Senso and, outside the United States, Maxwell House. The new company will be called Jacobs Douwe Egberts and will be based in the Netherlands. After the combination, Mondelez International, which was spun out of Kraft Foods in 2012, will receive about $5 billion in cash and a 49 percent equity stake in the joint venture.

headline: Sikorsky and Lockheed to Build New Presidential Helicopter
text: Sikorsky Aircraft and Lockheed Martin won a $1.24 billion contract on Wednesday to begin building a new presidential helicopter. The companies were the only bidders in the latest phase of a decadelong effort to begin replacing the aging, white-topped helicopters that alight from the White House lawn. An earlier program run by Lockheed Martin and AgustaWestland of Italy collapsed in 2009 because of technical difficulties and billions of dollars in cost overruns, with President Obama complaining that it was “an example of the procurement process gone amok.” Industry officials said that AgustaWestland, Boeing and Bell Helicopter did not bid this time because they believed that the specifications favored a version of Sikorsky’s S-92 helicopter, which is smaller than most of its rivals. The new contract will cover the development of six aircraft. The Navy, which runs the program, is likely to eventually buy 21 helicopters. Sikorsky, which built the current presidential helicopters, is a unit of United Technologies. It will assemble the new aircraft in Stratford, Conn. Lockheed will install the mission systems in Owego, N.Y.

headline: Night of Lows Has Rangers Down and Almost Out
text: When Henrik Lundqvist broke his stick over the crossbar in disgust after allowing a short-handed goal, he may have provided the defining moment of the Rangers’ ghastly 4-2 loss to the Pittsburgh Penguins on Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Farley Mowat, Author, Dies at 92; a Champion of the Far North
text: OTTAWA — Farley Mowat, one of Canada’s most popular and prolific writers, who became a champion of wildlife and native Canadian rights and a sharp critic of environmental abuse, died on Tuesday in Port Hope, Ontario, where he had lived for several years. He was 92.

headline: Tatiana Samoilova, a Movie Star Behind the Iron Curtain, Dies at 80
text: MOSCOW — Tatiana Samoilova, a movie star who was known in the Soviet Union for her beauty and strong-willed performances but who remained virtually unknown in the West because the Soviet authorities would not let her work there, died here on Sunday, her 80th birthday.

headline: Bill H. Dana, Pilot Who Outflew Bullets and Touched Space for NASA, Dies at 83
text: Bill H. Dana, a NASA research pilot who flew the X-15 rocket plane at record supersonic speeds and tested many of the most innovative and dangerous aircraft ever developed, died on Tuesday in Phoenix. He was 83.

headline: Yankees’ Roberts Stops Trying to Hit Like Cano and Starts to Thrive
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — When the Seattle Mariners were in New York last week, Robinson Cano had a chance to catch up with many of his former Yankees teammates. He spoke with Derek Jeter, C. C. Sabathia and Ichiro Suzuki, among others. He also talked several times with a Yankee he had never played with: the man who took his place.

headline: India Election Digest: May 8
text: What you need to know on Thursday about India’s elections: Rahul Gandhi made a surprise appearance in his home constituency to appeal to voters, an analysis of voter turnout indicates an anti-incumbency mood, and the Aam Aadmi Party’s absence of caste politics is helping it in Varanasi.

headline: Dissident Journalist Held Ahead of Tiananmen Anniversary
text: An outspoken Chinese journalist who was jailed after the armed crackdown of 1989 has been detained in Beijing on charges of obtaining and leaking a confidential Communist Party document, a state-run news agency reported on Thursday. The report said the journalist, Gao Yu, had admitted to the crime and was “willing to accept legal punishment.”

headline: Mediocre Night at Sotheby’s, as One-Third of the Art Does Not Sell
text: It was another bumpy night at the spring auctions, the second of the week’s evening sales of Impressionist and modern art. On Wednesday, many in the art world converged upon Sotheby’s, where nearly a third of the art went unsold. Paintings and sculptures by masters like Degas, Renoir and Picasso were either overpriced or were just not good enough to tempt buyers.

headline: Quaffable Cocktails That Get Their Flavor From Surprising (and Surprisingly Obtainable) Ingredients
text: As the wave of cocktail innovation continues to crest, intrepid bartenders are turning to unexpected ingredients in their quest to make the most delicious drinks imaginable, including imported amaros, eaux de vie and fortified wines. With the latest edition of the Manhattan Cocktail Classic festival descending on the New York Public Library this Friday, we offer six recipes from some of the country’s most renowned bartenders that derive their character from unexpected, but easily obtainable ingredients. Belly up to their bars for a taste, or mix them up yourself at home.

headline: A Passage to India
text: Having cut a stylish swath from Brussels to Bombay, the free-spirited designer and hotelier Loulou Van Damme has returned to her birthplace in the Palani Hills for her latest adventure.

headline: Lost in Paradise
text: The laid-back surf town of Todos Santos, Mexico, serves as a vibrant backdrop for summertime knits that provide cover — and a touch of hippie chic — to any vacation ensemble.

headline: A Photographer Looks to New Horizons
text: In this weekly series, T’s photo editors share the most compelling visual projects they’ve discovered.

headline: ‘The Americans’ Recap: Invisible vs. Invincible
text: Episode 11 of “The Americans” begins in the Soviet Union. It is a depressing, gray morning and the camera pans over a woman, naked, sleeping facedown on a bed. Next to her, the forcibly repatriated scientist Anton Vaklonov wakes and rises. He is still miserable back in his former country. He is, however, working on the Soviet version of a stealth plane – what choice does he have, really? – the radar-evading technology that was an important issue during the Cold War.

headline: Stories as a Window Into Schizophrenia
text: CINCINNATI — The psychologist Lynda Crane found that of the many injuries inflicted by schizophrenia, the greatest could be the pain of being forgotten. Just naming the illness somehow erased the person, something she learned when her 18-year-old son’s doctors said he had schizophrenia. Six years later, he committed suicide.

headline: Word of the Day | incompatible
text: incompatible•\ˌin-kəm-ˈpa-tə-bəl\• adjective

headline: Corrections: May 8, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Ukrainians Favor Unity, Not Russia, Polls Find
text: Ukrainians, including most Russian speakers, want to keep their country united with its current borders intact, but there are concerns about the government. While few Ukrainians have confidence in President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, his reputation has grown considerably at home, with more than 80 percent of Russians trusting his handling of world affairs.

headline: Times Minute | New York’s Iconic Library
text: Culture reporter Robin Pogrebin on the abrupt change in plans for New York City’s landmark central library.

headline: Times Minute | New York’s Iconic Library
text: In the Video

headline: What’s on Thursday
text: 9 P.M. (NBC) AMERICAN COMEDY AWARDS Chris Rock, above, will present Bill Cosby with the Johnny Carson Award for Comedic Excellence at this ceremony honoring funny people in film, television, stand-up and viral video. Nominees — voted on by fans and entertainment industry professionals — include Alexander Payne’s movie “Nebraska” and its star, Bruce Dern; Julia Louis-Dreyfus, for Nicole Holofcener’s film “Enough Said” and the HBO series “Veep”; “The Colbert Report”; Jason Bateman, for Netflix’s “Arrested Development”; “Louis C.K.: Oh My God”; and “Bound 3,” starring James Franco and Seth Rogen. Bill Hader, Johnny Knoxville, Leslie Mann, Stephen Merchant, Aubrey Plaza and J. B. Smoove are among the presenters. The house band is Craig Robinson & the Nasty Delicious.

headline: A.N.C. Leads South Africa Vote, but Others Gain
text: JOHANNESBURG — South Africa’s long-ruling African National Congress was headed to another big victory in national elections on Thursday, though it appeared to fall short of President Jacob G. Zuma’s goal of a two-thirds majority, incomplete results showed.

headline: At Election Season’s End, Sri Lankan Tamil Refugees Forgotten Again
text: PUZHAL, India — As Tamil civilians were increasingly caught in the crossfire between the Indian Peace Keeping Force and the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam in the 1980s, Sasitharan and his parents followed the exodus from the Tamil-majority northern and eastern regions of Sri Lanka.

headline: Jeter Homers to Lift Yankees Over Angels
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Baseball has long been rife with superstitions, whether wearing a rally cap, eating a special pregame meals or avoiding stepping on the foul line. At Angel Stadium this week, the Yankees have discovered a new one: the lucky dugout bathroom.

headline: Test Yourself | English, May 8, 2014
text: Take the Quiz

headline: With Words and Actions, Durant Leads Thunder Past Clippers
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — When Kevin Durant expressed through tears on Tuesday how important his family, his teammates and his fans were to him, he was not just offering thanks for helping him win the N.B.A.’s Most Valuable Player award.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | U.S. Climate Has Already Changed, Study Finds, Citing Heat and Floods
text: In “U.S. Climate Has Already Changed, Study Finds, Citing Heat and Floods,” Justin Gillis reports on a major study that found that water shortages, torrential rains, heat waves and wildfires were worsening.

headline: After Years of Ambitious Growth, Barclays Seeks to Be Leaner
text: Updated, 7:52 a.m. | LONDON – After decades of building a global investment bank, Barclays is sounding a retreat.

headline: Deutsche Telekom Profit Falls Amid Aggressive Spending in U.S.
text: LONDON — Deutsche Telekom’s first-quarter earnings suffered as it continued to spend heavily to expand its operations in the United States, the company said on Thursday.

headline: Pictures on the Street? It’s Complicated
text: After 40 wonderful years, Mark Cohen has abruptly ended his relationship with his muse. It might seem like cold betrayal, but it’s really more complicated than that.

headline: How Well Do You Take Criticism?
text: Do you instinctively get defensive when someone criticizes your work — an essay you wrote, a performance you gave or a layup you missed? Or, are you able to see critique as an opportunity to do even better and push yourself harder?

headline: China Hesitates to Label Guangzhou Attack Terrorism
text: The Chinese state-run news media and government officials have not described the attack on train passengers in Guangzhou on Tuesday, which left six people wounded, as an act of terrorism. Instead, they have described the incident as a “knife attack,” suggesting the possibility that it was the work of a lone assailant with no connection to militants from the northwestern region of Xinjiang.

headline: Blast Hits Pakistani Army Convoy, Killing 9 Soldiers
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A powerful explosion hit a Pakistani Army convoy early Thursday in the North Waziristan tribal region, killing at least nine soldiers while leaving several others critically injured, according to a Pakistani security official based in the area.

headline: An Explosion and a Blockade, and a Syrian Pact Is in Limbo
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A deal to evacuate insurgents from the Old City of Homs in central Syria hit a snag on Thursday when rebels in Aleppo Province refused to allow all of a humanitarian convoy to enter two villages they had blockaded, as called for under a pact between the government and the rebels, opposition activists and a pro-government television channel reported.

headline: New York Today: An Island of Art
text: Good morning on this drippy Thursday.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: The Silence of Doctors Around Alzheimer’s
text: “A fate worse than death,” my colleague muttered to me as we examined an elderly man admitted to the hospital with severe dementia.

headline: Why Do You Watch Birds?
text: Most people go to the top of the Empire State Building to look down. But I go to look up.

headline: Ousted Thai Premier Faces Impeachment Amid Rising Tension
text: BANGKOK — The Election Commission of Thailand on Thursday cast doubt on elections tentatively set for July as proceedings to impeach the ousted prime minister took another step forward, sharpening a political crisis that has already left the country with a hamstrung government.

headline: Prisa of Spain Agrees to Sell Digital Plus Stake to Telefónica for $1 Billion
text: LONDON – The Spanish media company Prisa has agreed to sell its majority stake in the local pay-television provider known as Digital Plus to Telefónica for around $1 billion.

headline: Glencore Names Former BP Chief as Chairman
text: The commodities colossus Glencore Xstrata has named Tony Hayward, a former chief executive of BP who was widely criticized for his handling of the company’s huge oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico in 2010, as its chairman.

headline: Why Do-Not-Call Lists Don’t Work Against Pollsters
text: To stop annoying phone calls, you listed your telephone number on the national Do Not Call registry, and interruptions from telemarketers diminished. So why are you still getting uninvited calls from people in my profession, polling?

headline: Separatists Defy Kiev and Putin on Referendum
text: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine — Pro-Russian militants in eastern Ukraine vowed on Thursday to press ahead with a referendum seeking autonomy, a risky move that seemed to defy their political patron, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, whose motives in urging a delay in the vote came under furious attack by officials in Kiev.

headline: Gail Collins: Staying Busy in the Political Off-Season
text: What does a Times columnist do in a slow political season? Plenty. Our Op-Ed columnist Gail Collins discusses how curiosity, humor and the occasional obsession keep the gears of topical commentary turning. She was interviewed by Peter Catapano, an editor in Opinion.

headline: The Value of Peer-to-Peer Business Groups
text: I’m a big fan of peer-to-peer business groups. They take many forms, and I’ve been involved in more than my share over the last 35 years.

headline: YouTube Founders to Sell Delicious, a Social Bookmarking Site
text: The social bookmarking service Delicious has changed hands twice over the last decade, while failing to attract a mainstream audience.

headline: Police in Deadly Confrontation in Restive Chinese Region
text: HONG KONG — The police in Xinjiang, the far-western Chinese region beset by ethnic tensions, fatally shot one person and captured another on Thursday in the latest of a string of deadly confrontations there, state-run media reported on Thursday.

headline: The Big Reason Republicans Should Hope Jeb Bush Runs
text: Florida has been an afterthought in electoral politics over the last few cycles, but it is positioned to return to the forefront. No state looms larger as the Republican Party mulls its future.

headline: Daily Report: In I.P.O., Alibaba Wagers on a Growing Market: China
text: When American tech upstarts float their companies on the stock market, they often sell investors on a familiar dream — “disrupting” an existing industry, Farhad Manjoo reports. It doesn’t matter if the industry is advertising, software, commerce or some other sector. The start-up will usually claim that its business is a great technological leap forward that will greatly lower costs and improve service for customers and leave rivals unable to respond. Therefore, buy some stock.

headline: Pick to Replace Sebelius Draws Senators’ Praise at Confirmation Hearing
text: WASHINGTON — Sylvia Mathews Burwell, President Obama’s nominee to replace Kathleen Sebelius as secretary of health and human services, charmed senators at a surprisingly cordial confirmation hearing on Thursday.

headline: An Overhaul at Barclays
text: In a sharp retreat from Wall Street, Barclays plans to shrink its investment banking business by cutting more than a quarter of the operation’s work force, Chad Bray and Jenny Anderson write in DealBook. Antony P. Jenkins, the bank’s chief executive, is aiming to reshape the bank and revive its image after a series of scandals.

headline: European Central Bank Says Stimulus Is Likely, but Not Before June
text: FRANKFURT — The European Central Bank on Thursday held interest rates steady, but signaled that it was likely to take action next month to stimulate the euro zone economy, amid growing concern about economic fallout from the crisis in Ukraine.

headline: Just Try Borrowing a Cup of Sugar
text: At an especially stressful moment in their domestic life — they are in the midst of an escalating battle with the fraternity next door, about which more shortly — Mac and Kelly, a married couple with a cute (and notably quiet) baby daughter, have a fight. At issue is who has the right to be irresponsible. Although they have a kid, a mortgage and other trappings of grown-up life, neither is entirely willing to give up the wild, impulsive behavior associated with youth. Mac (Seth Rogen) thinks his gender (and perhaps also his body type) entitles him to be the self-indulgent one. “We can’t both be Kevin James,” he says. And of course, he points out, Kelly (Rose Byrne) is a wife and mother, a bit of biological typecasting she furiously resents, and one that “Neighbors” rejects.

headline: Moving Your Show to Broadway? Not So Fast
text: It’s the most critically acclaimed musical of the New York theater season. It has endearing characters — a hungry protagonist and a colorful family — as well as clever storytelling and tuneful songs. Its creators spent years developing the show, dreaming of Broadway, but tempering their expectations, only too well aware they didn’t have the big-name stars or tourist-friendly material that can keep a multimillion-dollar musical in business.

headline: Apollo Global Reports Sharply Lower Profit
text: The private equity giant Apollo Global Management reported sharply lower first-quarter earnings on Thursday, as it reaped less profit from its investments.

headline: Former BP Chief Is Named Chairman of Glencore Xstrata
text: LONDON — Glencore Xstrata, the big commodities trading and mining company, said on Thursday that it had named Tony Hayward, the former chief executive of BP, to be its permanent chairman. Mr. Hayward has been serving in the role in an interim capacity for the past year.

headline: Reaping Benefits of Expansion, Emirates’ Profit Rises 43%
text: PARIS — Emirates, the fast-growing Persian Gulf airline, reported on Thursday a 43 percent jump in annual profit as its international expansion and the steady introduction of new wide-body jets to its fleet drew millions of new customers through its Dubai hub.

headline: In Our Pages: May 9
text: 1939: Alleged Nazi Leader Freed

headline: Requesting a Handout, in 2 Acts
text: Dear Diary:

headline: JPMorgan Backs an Online Broker, Motif Investing
text: Motif Investing, an upstart online broker, has attracted the nation’s biggest bank as a backer.

headline: After Postponing Its I.P.O., Box Gets a Break
text: Box, an online content storage company that last week had to postpone a much-expected initial public offering, got a little good news on Thursday.

headline: Where Elegance Meets Eros
text: So much for the debate about whether fashion can be art. “Charles James: Beyond Fashion,” a landmark exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s Costume Institute, proposes that this perennial question, which sprang up in the 1970s, was asked and answered in the late 1940s and ’50s. That’s when the Anglo-American couturier Charles James was at the height of his powers, making coats, suits, cocktail dresses and especially ball gowns, creating a sartorial sublime similar to the vaunted abstract sublime of the Abstract Expressionist painters working at the same time.

headline: Big Hands, Small Colleges and the N.F.L. Draft
text: Some say you can take the measure of a man by the firmness of his handshake.

headline: Charlie Chaplin’s Home in Switzerland to Become a Museum
text: Charlie Chaplin spent the last 25 years of his life in Corsier-sur-Vevey, above the shores of Lake Geneva in Switzerland. In an 18th-century mansion on a 35-acre estate he gardened, made films, composed music, wrote books and spent time with his wife, Oona Chaplin, and their eight children. Now three of those children — Michael, Eugene and Victoria Chaplin — have announced their partnership in a new museum, called “Chaplin’s World” in their former family home, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Vaccine Opponents Can Be Immune to Education
text: Vaccines will prevent the deaths of tens of thousands of children born this year over their lifetimes. So why are potentially dangerous numbers of parents in some states opting out of one of the great achievements of modern medicine?

headline: ‘Pinocchio Rex,’ China’s New Dinosaur
text: Scientists have discovered a new species of dinosaur, a relative of the ferocious Tyrannosaurus rex, according to a report in Nature Communications. The story of the discovery of the 30-foot-long Qianzhousaurus sinensis, which began more than three years ago in a construction site in southeastern China, is one of drama and luck, as well as science.

headline: Lopsided Approach to Wall Street Fraud Undermines the Law
text: Mr. Kaufman, a former United States senator from Delaware, is a visiting professor of the practice at the Duke University School of Law.

headline: House Republicans Say Comcast Merger Risks Undue Sway on Channels
text: WASHINGTON — Several House Republicans expressed concern on Thursday that a merger of Comcast and Time Warner Cable would give the new company undue influence over the potential success of cable channels whose programming might compete with Comcast’s.

headline: A Chef in the Field | Microgreens
text: This series by the chef Jeff Schwarz and the photographer Greg Kessler traces the trajectory of seasonal food — from its original source to a place on your table.

headline: In Assam, a Familiar Pattern of Violence
text: BAKSA, India — The Assamese villages of N.K. Khagrabari and Narayanguri border a thickly forested national wildlife sanctuary on one side and the Beki River on another, in the western part of the state.

headline: Cities in India Among the Most Polluted, W.H.O. Says
text: NEW DELHI — New Delhi’s air is the most polluted in the world, according to an international report that quantifies pollution levels, confirming findings by experts confounded by the lack of attention to the city’s problem.

headline: Classical Playlist: Pavarotti, Berio, Shostakovich and More
text: BELLINI: ‘I Puritani’Joan Sutherland, Luciano Pavarotti, Piero Cappuccilli, Nicolai Ghiaurov; Richard Bonynge, conductor; London Symphony Orchestra, Chorus of the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden(Decca; three CDs)There has been almost a mini-festival of bel canto opera taking place at the Metropolitan Opera of late, with the return of Rossini’s “La Cenerentola” and revivals of two Bellini works: “La Sonnambula” and “I Puritani.” In anticipation of “I Puritani,” I took out the 1973 recording featuring Joan Sutherland and Luciano Pavarotti, with Richard Bonynge conducting the London Symphony Orchestra. I can hardly stop listening to it. No matter one’s taste in the art of bel canto, no matter one’s passion for Maria Callas (which we all share), Joan Sutherland and Luciano Pavarotti are thrilling exemplars of the tradition. This recording captures them in their glory. (Anthony Tommasini)

headline: Today in Small Business: Buying American
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Harry Truman’s Formidable Mother-in-Law
text: Here a conspicuously uneasy Harry S. Truman is in the breakfast room upstairs at the White House with his mother-in-law, Madge Gates Wallace. The scene is in the vicinity of Mother’s Day 1946. It appears as if Mrs. Wallace cannot stand to look at him. (Truman’s sister-in-law, Natalie Ott Wallace, sits between the two, in a kind of demilitarized zone.)

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘To My Mother’
text: This week’s Poetry Pairing features “To My Mother” by Edgar Allan Poe and the Op-Ed column “Muddling Through Mother’s Day” by Frank Bruni.

headline: ‘America’s First Queer Jazz Festival’ to Be Held in Philadelphia
text: OutBeat, a four-day event that organizers are describing as the first jazz festival with a lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender focus (its subtitle is America’s First Queer Jazz Festival), will be staged in Philadelphia from Sept. 18 to 21. The festival, which was announced by its sponsor, the William Way LGBT Community Center, at a news conference in Philadelphia on Wednesday, will include panel discussions and receptions as well as performances at several clubs and halls around the city.

headline: China Offers Its Side of Story in Sea Dispute With Vietnam
text: China acknowledged on Thursday it had used a water cannon against Vietnamese vessels in a dispute in the South China Sea, but denied that Chinese Navy ships were present.

headline: Your Vintage Wedding Rings
text: Last month, we asked readers to submit Instagram photos of their heirloom wedding rings or those inspired by the styles of yesteryear. Here, a selection.

headline: Where to Turn When the School Wants to Have Your Child ‘Tested’
text: Dear Mrs. Lahey,

headline: Deflation Threatens Europe. Policy Makers Wait.
text: Europe is staring into the face of the kind of deflationary cycle that has paralyzed the Japanese economy for the better part of two decades. Prices are rising far more slowly than its central bank wants, against a backdrop of astronomical unemployment on much of the Continent.

headline: What I’ve Been Reading
text: Expanding on the bold (terrifying?) experiment in columnist transparency that inspired our recent spate of “ask me anything” features here at Op-Ed, I’m going to begin posting regularly on my current reading (and I believe some of my colleagues may soon be doing the same). My model, in form and at least initially in style, will be Tyler Cowen’s recurring reading lists, except that I’m not quite such a polymath and don’t manage to read quite as many books, so I’ll be listing magazine essays, interviews, and other pieces as well.

headline: The Stars Align ... With the Ensemble
text: It may be that Denzel Washington and Daniel Radcliffe have been doing their jobs too well. As the leading men of the hit Broadway revivals of Lorraine Hansberry’s “A Raisin in the Sun” (Mr. Washington) and Martin McDonagh’s “The Cripple of Inishmaan” (Mr. Radcliffe), they are both offering affecting and astute interpretations — in the case of Mr. Radcliffe, what is surely his best stage work to date.

headline: The Unconventional Earn Their Applause
text: Although it often seems that nothing much changes on Broadway these days — here comes another pileup of celebrities; watch out for the latest movie coming to a stage near you — every season springs a surprise or two. The one just past, while unremarkable in many respects, had more than its share of oddities, as sprigs of unconventionality struggled to take root in the artistically arid ground.

headline: And the Nominees Should Be ...
text: Charles Isherwood makes his Tony Award choices. For the “Should have been nominated” category, the Times’s critics were allowed to expand the potential nominees to Off Broadway productions that were ineligible for the Broadway-only Tonys. (Ben Brantley’s picks are here.) The ceremony for the 68th annual Tony Awards will be broadcast on June 8 on CBS.

headline: And the Nominees Should Be ...
text: Ben Brantley makes his Tony Award choices. For the “Should have been nominated” category, the Times’s critics were allowed to expand the potential nominees to Off Broadway productions that were ineligible for the Broadway-only Tonys. (Charles Isherwood’s picks are here.) The ceremony for the 68th annual Tony Awards will be broadcast on June 8 on CBS.

headline: Wheelies: The Secret Service Security Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Antibiotic-Resistant Germs, Lying in Wait Everywhere
text: The Lechuguilla Cave in New Mexico is a network of chambers stretching 1,600 feet underground. The bacteria that grow on the walls of its most remote recesses have been living in complete isolation for more than four million years.

headline: For U.S. Cities, a 2024 Olympic Competition
text: When NBC Universal agreed to spend $7.75 billion on six Olympic Games through 2032, perhaps it was counting on the added value of having one of those Olympics staged in the United States.

headline: Dan Colen, Art World Bomb Thrower, Gets Respectable. Sort Of.
text: Thirty four is hardly old, but Dan Colen has done a lot of growing up since bursting on the art scene a decade ago, after earning a degree in painting at the Rhode Island School of Design. Colen came to prominence as a member of the Irak crew, a posse of graffiti writers, artists, pranksters and drug users that also included Ryan McGinley and the late Dash Snow. Those formative years are central to “Help,” Colen’s new retrospective at the Brant Foundation in Greenwich, Conn., which opens this Monday. “There’s been an arc in my work and an arc in my life,” says Colen, who still maintains a punkish air, but is now a monied property owner (of a fully operational farm in Pine Plains, N.Y.) with close relationships to art-world power players like Peter Brant, Charles Saatchi, Jeffrey Deitch and Larry Gagosian. The exhibition, he says, is an opportunity “to look at the old work and the new work, and really for the first time to consider what ties it all together.”

headline: Chuck Berry and Peter Sellars Win Polar Music Prize
text: The Polar Music Prize for 2014 has been awarded to the rock ‘n’ roll patriarch Chuck Berry, and to Peter Sellars, the iconoclastic director of operas and staged concerts. The prize, announced on Thursday by the foundation that administers it, is essentially a lifetime achievement prize and carries a cash award of one million Swedish krona ($153,725) and a touch of royalty: though it not a government prize, it is given to the winners by King Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden at a banquet in Stockholm. This year’s ceremony is on Aug. 26.

headline: Red-Hot Web in China Richly Rewards Foreign Investors
text: SHENZHEN, China – It is one of the best investments of the digital age.

headline: A Different View on Risk and Reward
text: This interview with Wayne Jackson, chief executive of Sonatype, a software security firm, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Gillian Flynn: By the Book
text: The author of “Gone Girl” says it’s hard to get over something first read at age 12: “I will probably be clutching ‘Flowers in the Attic’ in my gnarled hands on my deathbed.”

headline: Tough Task for Yahoo: Spending Its Alibaba Windfall Wisely
text: More than ever, Marissa Mayer needs to find the exclamation point in Yahoo’s business. After the company sells around half of its 22.6 percent stake in the Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba, Ms. Mayer, the Yahoo chief executive, could have $12 billion on hand. Spending it wisely will be tough.

headline: Highlights and Analysis of the 2014 N.F.L. Draft, Round 1
text: There was a lot of hype surrounding the first round of the 2014 N.F.L draft, and it didn’t disappoint. From the slide of Johnny Manziel to the unexpected names called in the second half of the round, the first 32 picks in 2014 came with a lot of excitement.

headline: Studio Tours Resume in North Carolina
text: After a three-year absence, EUE/Screen Gems Studios in Wilmington, N.C., has resumed tours at its production complex.

headline: Image of the Day: May 8
text: A man wearing a mask of Narendra Modi, the prime ministerial nominee of the Bharatiya Janata Party, at a protest in New Delhi.

headline: Climate Debate Isn't So Heated in the U.S.
text: Why are Americans less concerned about global warming than are people in other countries?

headline: What Timothy Geithner Really Thinks
text: “This is kind of like a hearing,” Timothy Geithner said, swaying uncomfortably, face scrunched and hair perfectly tousled. “Do you guys always do it this way?”

headline: Off the Record in a Chat App? Don’t Be Sure
text: What happens on the Internet stays on the Internet.

headline: 5 Takeaways From Magazine Article on Geithner and the Financial Crisis
text: Timothy F. Geithner is finally going public. Since Mr. Geithner stepped down as Treasury secretary last year, he has remained largely out of the public eye. Now, with the publication of his book, “Stress Test: Reflections on Financial Crises,” to be published next week, Mr. Geithner is breaking his silence. I caught up with him last month as he was putting the finishing touches on the book. We discussed — and debated — his tenure in government and his prescriptions for solving financial crises. During a series of interviews, he was surprisingly frank. The result of those interviews — and an early look at his book — appear as the cover story in the coming issue of The New York Times Magazine.

headline: Medicaid, Romneycare and Mortality
text: My post yesterday on the new study of post-Romneycare mortality rates in Massachusetts set up a contrast between two policy scenarios: One in which health insurance expansions have a substantial effect on health (as the Massachusetts mortality data suggests), and another in which insurance’s connection to public health is much more limited (as the data from the Oregon Medicaid experiment had indicated).

headline: Snapchat Settlement With F.T.C.
text: The mobile messaging service Snapchat settled with the Federal Trade Commission over charges that the service inaccurately claimed that, once sent, messages disappeared.

headline: 36 Hours in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam
text: Buzz, buzz, buzz. Whether it’s the roar of motorbikes, the near constant opening of bars and restaurants, the chatty nature of its inhabitants, or the abundance of great coffee, there’s just something invigorating about Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam’s largest metropolis. It’s no surprise that Saigon, as most locals call it, exudes a youthful, inventive energy — after all, over half of its eight million dwellers are younger than 35. This dynamic spirit shines through in quirky cafes, innovative cuisine and boutiques selling homegrown fashion. And when you need a breather from all that’s new and fabulous, it’s easy to steal quiet moments in crumbling colonial buildings and contemplative art spaces.

headline: Nate Berkus on Decorating With Souvenirs
text: Ask the interior designer Nate Berkus about a piece of décor in his New York home, and you’ll very likely discover it’s a souvenir from one of his travels abroad.

headline: Predictions and Prejudice
text: The 2008 crisis and its aftermath have been a testing time for economists — and the tests have been moral as well as intellectual. After all, economists made very different predictions about the effects of the various policy responses to the crisis; inevitably, some of those predictions would prove deeply wrong. So how would those who were wrong react?

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 35
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Along the Aegean, a Turkish Town Sees a Revival
text: A Turkish town populated mostly by retirees and known for its prime windsurfing conditions was, without employment opportunities for its young, headed for desertion and disrepair five years ago. But this spot on the Aegean has recently seen a revival as children from Turkey’s big cities who vacationed there in the 1980s grew up and returned to stay.

headline: Times Minute | Ukraine’s Two Votes
text: The Times’s David Herszenhorn reporting from Ukraine on what two votes — one local and one national — could mean for the country.

headline: Times Minute | Ukraine’s Two Votes
text: In the Video

headline: In Odessa, Home-Grown Combatants Keep Pro-Russia Forces in Check
text: ODESSA, Ukraine — In a basement headquarters behind a home electronics store, Ruslan Forostyak pored over a map of the city’s defenses against pro-Russian militants: roadblocks, zones of responsibility, strategic sites to defend.

headline: With Elections Nearing, Republican Senators Take On Yellen on Jobs
text: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans on Thursday sharply questioned Janet L. Yellen, chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, about the persistence of unemployment and the slow pace of the economic recovery during a hearing that highlighted the growing prominence of election-year considerations on Capitol Hill.

headline: Economies of Scales
text: Brad Plumer tells an important, little-known tale. It begins with things going badly:

headline: Footage of Hotel Bombing in Aleppo
text: Video from Shaam News Network, an anti-Assad group in Syria, showed a rebel-claimed bombing in Aleppo that leveled a hotel that government troops used as a military base, near the city’s ancient citadel.

headline: De Blasio’s Budget Raises Spending Without Big Cuts
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio on Thursday announced a $73.9 billion budget plan for New York City that included significant new spending on education, social services and municipal payrolls — but virtually no service cuts or new channels of revenue.

headline: Next Week on Retro Report
text: The use of the herbicide Agent Orange during the Vietnam War continues to cast a dark shadow over both American veterans and the Vietnamese. Visit NYTimes.com on Monday for the full story.

headline: The Push to Keep the Internet Open
text: The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission dropped the regulatory equivalent of a bombshell last month when he proposed new rules that would allow broadband companies to charge fees to content providers for the delivery of video, and other data to consumers, on a preferential basis.

headline: Banksy Emerges From Shadows to Weigh In on Dispute Over Work
text: Banksy, the mercurial street artist, typically keeps clear of the disputes that break out when his graffiti artworks are removed from the walls and doorways where he painted them — and sometimes later sold for enormous prices. But the case of the piece now known as “Mobile Lovers” –  a door-size painting of an embracing couple checking their cellphones behind each other’s backs, painted on plywood and screwed to a wall – has brought the secretive artist out of hiding for long enough to leave a typed, signed note for one of the piece’s potential beneficiaries, the BBC reported.

headline: U.N. Report Documents Atrocities by Both Sides in South Sudan War
text: BENTIU, South Sudan — Two weeks after a massacre here, the stench of dead bodies clung to the walls of the Kali-Ballee mosque. Bloodstains marked the ground; shirts, pants and sandals were still scattered about; and torn pages from the Quran were strewn all over the place.

headline: Patient’s Cells Deployed to Attack Aggressive Cancer
text: Doctors have taken an important step toward a long-sought goal: harnessing a person’s own immune system to fight cancer.

headline: Hal Brooks Will Oversee Pearl Theater Company
text: The Pearl Theater Company, an Off Broadway theater devoted to classic works, announced on Thursday that the director Hal Brooks has become its new artistic director and that he will stage two of the company’s productions next season, Chekhov’s “Uncle Vanya” in September and Molière’s “Don Juan” in May 2015.

headline: Egyptian Tourism’s Message to World: Come Anyway
text: CAIRO — “We’ve missed you,” Egypt’s ministry of tourism says in its new advertising campaign, a plaintive plea for summer visitors from wealthy countries in the Persian Gulf.

headline: This Ship Has Sailed
text: Dior invited roughly 900 people to the Brooklyn Navy Yard on Wednesday evening for its cruise collection runway show.

headline: Unveiling Dior’s Cruise Collection
text: The first time I flew on Air France, knuckles paling well in advance per usual, a friend tried to calm me by invoking the comparative chic of the flight attendants. “They all have these ... scarves,” she said, waving her hands at her throat to indicate the mysterious dexterity of these foreigners.

headline: In California, Spigots Start Draining Pockets
text: SANTA CRUZ, Calif. — The municipal water utility in this city, home to wide beaches, sun-kissed weekend getaways and evocative alternative scholarship, just got tough. Last week it started rationing water — for nonfarmers, the most draconian response to date to California’s debilitating drought.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘The Double’
text: Richard Ayoade narrates a sequence from his film “The Double,” featuring Jesse Eisenberg.

headline: The Case of the Missing Birds at the National Arts Club
text: Not long ago, the National Arts Club was home to dozens of birds, including lovebirds, finches, a Quaker parrot and a raven. They had been acquired by the club’s eccentric president, O. Aldon James Jr., who also collected other animals in the more than century-old club on Gramercy Park, including a chinchilla and a snail discovered by a cook in some corn silk.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
text: In the news: boosting memory, vaccine robots and statin use by women. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Oklahoma, Investigating Failure, Extends Delay of Execution to November
text: Oklahoma on Thursday delayed the execution of Charles F. Warner by six months, to allow time for a review of lethal injection procedures that was started after a bungled execution last week left a prisoner writhing in pain before he died of heart failure.

headline: Yankees Will Retire Torre’s No. 6
text: MILWAUKEE — The Yankees announced Thursday that they would retire the No. 6 worn by the former manager Joe Torre, something they had informally said they would do. They also said that they would put plaques in Monument Park for Goose Gossage, Tino Martinez and Paul O’Neill, and that Bernie Williams would be honored in 2015.

headline: Richard Ayoade Narrates a Scene From ‘The Double’
text: In this video, the director Richard Ayoade narrates a sequence from his film “The Double,” featuring Jesse Eisenberg as an office worker who encounters his doppelgänger.

headline: Enter ‘the Strange City’ of the Artists Kabakov
text: Each year, on the occasion of the annual art exhibition called Monumenta, the sprawling nave in the Grand Palais in Paris becomes a blank canvas for an internationally-renowned artist. In years past, large-scale installations like Anish Kapoor’s enormous balloon sculpture and Christian Boltanski’s mountain of clothing have filled the room. And this Saturday, the Russian-born, Long Island, N.Y.-based artist couple Ilya and Emilia Kabakov will unveil “The Strange City” there for the show’s sixth iteration, which will be on view through June 22.

headline: Hearing Held for Health Services Nominee
text: A Senate committee held a confirmation hearing for Sylvia Mathews Burwell, the nominee to become the next secretary of health and human Services, succeeding Kathleen Sebelius.

headline: Last Minutes on Everest
text: Footage captured minutes before April’s deadly Everest avalanche highlights the Sherpas’ pride and resilience, which support not only Western expeditions but also the Sherpas’ families far below.

headline: An Afternoon at the Improv
text: There is no falafel on the falafel plate at El Rey Coffee Bar and Luncheonette. This is not an error. What appears instead could be described on the menu (but thankfully isn’t) as “evanescence of falafel,” and may be the most low-key — and satisfying — example of culinary deconstruction in the city.

headline: The Making Of | A Camera Bag Designed to Keep Photojournalists Safe
text: The designer Miguel Hurtado’s a-ha moment took place one afternoon five years ago during a visit to Bahia, in northern Brazil. He was snapping pictures at Carnival when a young boy ran up to him and grabbed his camera. The kid wasn’t a thief; he was trying to telegraph a warning to Hurtado that there were some bad guys in the area and that he should put the camera away because he was about to be robbed. Immediately, Hurtado stashed his gear in his potato-shaped canvas Domke, a camera bag that advertises to the world, “I am currently in possession of a very expensive camera.” “Right there I started to wonder, why does a camera bag have to scream luxury?” Hurtado recalls. “Why does it have to make you a mark?”

headline: Kellogg Agrees to Alter Labeling on Kashi Line
text: The Kellogg Company, maker of some of the country’s most familiar breakfast cereals, said on Thursday that it had agreed to drop the terms “all natural” and “nothing artificial” from some products in its Kashi line as part of a settlement agreement ending a class-action lawsuit.

headline: A Case for Rejecting Pfizer’s Bid for AstraZeneca
text: Bill George is professor of management practice at Harvard Business School, former chairman and chief executive of Medtronic and author of “True North,” a book about authentic leadership. He serves on the boards of ExxonMobil, Goldman Sachs and the Mayo Clinic. In the past two years, he has taught custom leadership programs at Harvard for AstraZeneca executives and consulted with the company in 2012-13.

headline: Why Are American Nuns Under Vatican Scrutiny?
text: The 57,000 American women who are working among the needy as Catholic nuns received some words of encouragement this week from a German cardinal, dubbed “the pope’s theologian” because of his close friendship with Pope Francis. “I am also considered suspect!” Cardinal Walter Kasper, an outspoken liberal church writer, said at Fordham University on Monday. He was alluding to a Vatican investigation into “the quality of the life” at women’s religious institutes — code for Rome-appointed busybodies probing nuns for feminist influences and traces of heresy.

headline: A Mother’s Instinct, a Daughter’s Need
text: A little over a decade ago, I made the mistake of taking my mother out to dinner on Mother’s Day. The restaurant’s high ceilings contributed to its poor acoustics, and the servers ran around with a frenetic energy typical of the other days of the year I avoid restaurants, like Valentine’s Day and New Year’s Eve. The clanging of dishes interrupted us midsentence, and occasionally, a baby wailed from the other side of the room. It was the type of environment my mother and I avoid with precision, and yet, there we were, regaling in Mother’s Day splendor with all the other people who mistakenly felt obligated to eat out.

headline: Clip: ‘Rosemary’s Baby’
text: A scene from “Rosemary’s Baby,” with Zoe Saldana and Patrick J. Adams.

headline: ’Tis Pity She’s a ... Busy Young Professional
text: Perhaps a small Pernod would help. Or maybe a large draft of absinthe?

headline: The Real Story About the Wrong Photos in #BringBackOurGirls
text: A photographer is aghast at how her photographs taken in Guinea-Bissau were used – without permission – to represent girls kidnapped in Nigeria.

headline: Man in the Kitchen Is Hungry for Love
text: Food, glorious food! Whatever else it does or doesn’t do, “Chef,” Jon Favreau’s good-natured culinary comedy, works as an appetite stimulant. And where there’s delicious food — plenty is shown being prepared, served and devoured — there’s life.

headline: Kurt Masur’s Son Named Assistant Conductor in Boston
text: Besides getting a new music director when Andris Nelsons takes up his duties at the start of the 2014-15 season, the Boston Symphony Orchestra will have a new assistant conductor as well. The orchestra announced on Thursday that it had appointed Ken-David Masur to the position. In that capacity Mr. Masur will make his subscription debut during the 2015-16 season, the second year of the two-year position, but he has already led the orchestra in a non-subscription program, at Tanglewood in 2012. On that occasion, he split the conducting tasks with his father, Kurt Masur, the former music director of the New York Philharmonic.

headline: The Gun Report: May 8, 2014
text: The attack on prospective smart-gun purveyors continues.

headline: Warren Buffett, Joe Nocera and ’Fessing Up to Readers
text: Mistakes are inevitable. So, too, are newspaper corrections, since newspapers are full of those pesky things known as facts and are produced by human beings, who have a tendency to get things wrong sometimes.

headline: Wine Time in Nantucket
text: The warmer weather may still be holding out, but pourers at the Nantucket Wine Festival won’t be.

headline: A Poker-Faced Nihilist, Stoically Slumming
text: Colson Whitehead’s poker memoir, “The Noble Hustle,” is a throwaway, a bluff, a large bet on a small hand. You can sense that he’s half embarrassed to be writing it. His language is so loose and sarcastic that reading it is like watching a guy try to toss playing cards into a hat.

headline: House Panel Advances Bill on N.S.A. Collection of Phone Data
text: WASHINGTON — The House Intelligence Committee unanimously passed a bill on Thursday to replace the National Security Agency’s program that is systematically collecting bulk records about Americans’ phone calls.

headline: Grand Hotel Reopens, but Only for 4 Nights
text: OVER the last two decades, artworks conceived as participatory events — people eating, sleeping, walking and talking, staring across a table, and doing other real-life things — have become so commonplace in contemporary museums and galleries that a bit of a backlash has set in.

headline: Territorial Disputes in the Waters Near China
text: China has recently increased its pursuit of territorial claims in nearby seas, leading to tense exchanges with neighboring countries. A map of some of the most notable disputes.

headline: Shamus, That’s the Stuff That Wedgies Are Made Of
text: Noir will become much more than a French vocabulary quiz word for adolescents who see “Samantha Spade, Ace Detective: The Case of the Maltball Falcon,” at Tada! Youth Theater. This wry new family musical, starring the talented, mostly teenage members of the Tada! ensemble, successfully tackles a challenge that would furrow even Bogie’s brow: creating a colorful adventure about a black-and-white world that its audience may never have heard of.

headline: A Sherpa’s Final Moments
text: NEW DELHI — The Sherpas setting off up the Khumbu Icefall on the morning of April 18 were young, strong, healthy men. They were also, it is clear from the video that one of them shot that morning, a little nervous.

headline: Holding Auditors Accountable on Reports
text: Rolls-Royce — the jet engine maker, not the car company — used estimates and assumptions in its financial results that resulted in “mildly cautious profit recognition” in an important part of its business. On the other hand, the company was “mildly optimistic” in other assumptions, “resulting in a somewhat lower liability being recorded than might otherwise have been the case.”

headline: Yellen Testifies on U.S. Labor Market
text: Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, said at a Senate Budget Committee hearing that the long-term labor participation rate had declined substantially.

headline: Apollo Seeks a Bigger Role in Europe’s Banking Sector
text: Barclays’ pain could be private equity’s gain.

headline: New Jersey, Once a Rogue State, Is No Longer
text: When it comes to pariah states, some places spring to mind. North Korea. Iran. Syria.

headline: Election Commission Votes to Allow Bitcoin Donations
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Election Commission on Thursday voted to allow political committees to accept Bitcoin donations and outlined the ways that the virtual currency can be used by federally regulated campaigns.
