headline: 12 Ways to Learn Vocabulary With The New York Times
text: One of the winners of our 2017 15-Second Vocabulary Video Contest.

headline: V.A. Officials Subpoenaed for Inquiry Into Wait List
text: A House committee voted Thursday to subpoena the head of the Department of Veterans Affairs, Eric Shinseki, and other top department officials, stepping up scrutiny of the agency amid allegations that secret waiting lists were used to cover up long delays for doctors’ appointments.

headline: Rauschenberg, Before Fame Struck
text: Scratch an art dealer, and you’ll often find a curator. That’s the case with Craig Starr, who seems to operate in the secondary art market mainly to support his persistent curatorial itch. For nearly a decade, he has been mounting sharp-focus shows of historical works by prominent American postwar artists in his jewel-box gallery on the Upper East Side.

headline: This Time, Tappan Zee Bridge Project Proceeds With Neighbors in Mind
text: SOUTH NYACK, N.Y. — This village on the west bank of the Hudson River has never forgotten the original sin: the destruction six decades ago of more than 100 homes and the community’s entire commercial hub to make way for the Tappan Zee Bridge.

headline: Ingredients of Nerve Agent Still in Syria, Official Says
text: UNITED NATIONS — The last of the chemicals to be shipped out of Syria contain the ingredients needed to make sarin, the lethal nerve agent used in the attack on a Damascus suburb last August, the United Nations official who is coordinating the arsenal’s destruction said on Thursday.

headline: The Real Story About the Wrong Photos in #BringBackOurGirls
text: A Twitter campaign using the hashtag #BringBackOurGirls has focused global attention on the plight of some 276 Nigerian schoolgirls kidnapped by the Islamic militant group Boko Haram. Three photos of girls have been posted and reposted thousands of times, including by the BBC and by the singer Chris Brown (who himself has had issues with anger management and violence against women).One problem: The photos are of girls from Guinea-Bissau, more than 1,000 miles from Nigeria, who have no relationship to the kidnappings.

headline: Living With Cancer: Careless Care
text: When I consider what happened to an esteemed friend and colleague, I fume at the mayhem that ovarian cancer wreaks and at the deficient care she received at a university hospital in another town. Do instances of medical negligence sometimes go unnoticed because patients are so debilitated that they cannot testify — especially if they are still in treatment?

headline: Sotheby’s Sales Feature a Mondrian and a Bacon
text: Now that the first week of the big spring auctions is over, Sotheby’s is wasting no time touting its sales in London next month, hanging highlights in its York Avenue galleries for collectors to peruse during the contemporary-art previews this weekend.

headline: Ukrainian Separatists to Hold Referendum
text: Pro-Russian separatists in the Ukrainian regions of Donetsk, Luhansk and Slovyansk said they would hold an independence referendum despite Russian president Vladimir V. Putin’s request to postpone it.

headline: China Presents Its Side in Vietnam Clash
text: Chinese officials offered their side of the story in the dispute with Vietnam over an oil rig operation in the South China Sea.

headline: Darkness Visible
text: (This book was selected as one of The New York Times Book Review’s 10 Best Books of 2014. For the rest of the list, click here.)

headline: Cradle of Civil Disobedience
text: At the end of the 19th century, Mohandas Gandhi was a young lawyer living in Durban, South Africa. He left his house in Beach Grove every morning for an office on Mercury Lane, where he spent much of the day helping his fellow Indian immigrants navigate the onerous colonial bureaucracy. He kept meticulous records, including a logbook of correspondence — from an English missionary and local planters, and a series of letters exchanged with the Protector of Indian Immigrants about the treatment of indentured laborers. In January of 1897, and again a few months later, he heard from another lawyer who was, like him, a Gujarati who had studied in England and then struggled to establish a practice in Bombay. The contents of these letters are unknown. In a remarkable new biography, “Gandhi Before India,” Ramachandra Guha gingerly speculates about what they might have been. Expressions of support for Gandhi’s nascent activism? Or perhaps “explorations of interest in a possible career in South Africa”? Guha wisely stops there. What is not in doubt is the name in Gandhi’s logbook — “M. A. Jinnah,” Muhammad Ali Jinnah, who would become the founder of Pakistan. “All we now know is that, a full 50 years before partition and the independence of India and Pakistan, the respective ‘Fathers’ of those nations were in correspondence.”

headline: Recovering From a Short Sale
text: Borrowers who owe more than their homes are worth can sometimes get out from under by negotiating a short sale with their lender. But short-sellers are branded as higher-risk borrowers, so new loans won’t come quickly or easily.

headline: Pledges of Allegiance
text: Ten days after 9/11, self-professed “Texas loud, Texas proud” Mark Stroman walked into a Dallas mini-mart, pulled out a gun and asked the brown man working behind the counter where he was from. The hesitation in the clerk’s reply was enough to unleash Stroman’s hatred for Muslims, whom he referred to as people with “shawls on their face.” Stroman pulled the trigger, but his victim, Raisuddin Bhuiyan, an enterprising immigrant from Bangladesh — and a Muslim, indeed — would survive. The other two victims from the fortnight’s vigilante shooting spree, immigrants from India and Pakistan, would not. So begins Anand Giridharadas’s “The True American,” a richly detailed, affecting account of two men bound, as it turned out, by more than just an act of violence.

headline: A Surreal Dream, Dark and Deeply Melancholy
text: Christian Rizzo last presented his choreography in New York in 2010, and the afterimage of that ravishing experience, at least for me, remains firmly etched. In “b.c, janvier 1545, fontainebleau,” Mr. Rizzo created a stark black-and-white landscape in which a series of repetitive angled positions grew into a hypnotic movement meditation for the sleek, high-heeled dancer Julie Guibert. Mr. Rizzo, as an interloper or part of the set, wore a rabbit mask.

headline: Sugar, Come Out With Your Hands Up
text: If you are interested in learning the latest on fighting what’s called the obesity epidemic, you may want to avoid the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s website. There, in a section about balancing calories (“Healthy Weight — it’s not a diet, it’s a lifestyle!”), amid tips on reducing and exercising, you can read that “a calorie is a calorie regardless of its source.” The page also features a graphic of a scale with the words “calories in” and “calories out,” as if all calories were equal. The American Beverage Association, as it happens, pretty much says the same thing on its website: “Quite simply, overweight and obesity are a result of an imbalance between calories consumed and calories burned.”

headline: With a Change of Heart, California Senate Approves Smartphone ‘Kill Switch’ Law
text: The California Senate on Thursday voted to approve a state measure requiring smarter antitheft security on smartphones, reversing its decision last month to reject the bill.

headline: An Ohio Troupe Returns, With a Boy-Needs-Girl Story and a Rock Star’s Songs
text: Are you a fan of Peter Frampton, the British rocker behind such late-20th-century hits as “Baby I Love Your Way” (1975)? If so, you might fare reasonably well during “Hummingbird in a Box,” one of three New York premieres that Cincinnati Ballet is presenting at the Joyce Theater. If not, there is unfortunately little to recommend this bafflingly vapid work, choreographed last year by Adam Hougland, the company’s resident artist, to a commissioned score by Mr. Frampton. Fandom is key to keeping the viewer afloat.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: On View | Seven More Temporary Art Destinations During Frieze Week in New York
text: The third installation of Frieze New York is the city’s main cultural attraction this weekend, but there are also plenty of satellite fairs in Manhattan (and one in Brooklyn) to sate your appetite for art. Below, the top destinations to check out.

headline: Glare of a Gilded Age
text: The financial heart of India has long been Mumbai, but it is Delhi, increasingly, that seems to be driven by money, galvanized by it, besotted with it. Delhi is India’s capital. It is where the nation’s networks of crony capitalism converge, where money seeks license to earn more money. Delhi talks to itself about money — about what money can buy, about the cabinet minister pocketing kickbacks, about the suburban swatch of land that a lawyer’s untaxed, all-cash fee has purchased and, in near-reverential tones, about the ingenious and illegal ways more money can be made. This last subject, in particular, exercises the city’s soul enormously. Delhi is flatulent with greed.

headline: Competing Against a Doppelgänger Who Spells Trouble
text: In “The Double,” Richard Ayoade’s energetically stylized adaptation of a Dostoyevsky novella, Jesse Eisenberg plays Simon James, a man so unassuming that he barely exists. The security guard at his workplace demands his ID every morning, and a co-worker cheerfully describes poor Simon as “a bit of a nonperson, really.” His boss (Wallace Shawn) has a vague idea of who he is, as does Hannah (Mia Wasikowska), a fellow employee as well as a neighbor. Simon is hopelessly in love with her, in a creepy way that is also kind of sweet.

headline: Wanting a Child in the Worst Way
text: People moving into new apartments in New York City dread brash, nosy neighbors. In Paris, the nightmare next door is more likely to be an elegant, worldly couple with irreproachable manners.

headline: Bedeviled Anew by a Pregnancy
text: PARIS — “Rosemary’s Baby,” Roman Polanski’s 1968 horror film about a woman impregnated by the devil, may seem somewhat campy in retrospect, but it has influenced scores of filmmakers and spawned innumerable imitators. Now, it has given birth to a remake — set in contemporary Paris, made for television and directed by the esteemed Polish-born director Agnieszka Holland.

headline: The Unkindest Cut
text: Some historical events have such utterly catastrophic consequences that no amount of “what if” counterfactuals can yield a more awful result. World War I, for example, resulted in an enormous number of fatalities, largely entrenched the imperialism that initiated it and paved the way for both Nazism and Stalinism. How could a different path have been worse?

headline: Time Warner Sets Date for Time Inc. Spinoff
text: Time Warner has officially approved the spinoff of Time Inc. into a separate company and set a date of June 6 for the transaction to become effective, according to a filing dated Thursday that was made with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Pearls of Regret
text: Saadat Hasan Manto has a good claim to be considered the greatest South Asian writer of the 20th century. In his work, written in Urdu, he incarnated the exuberance, the madness, the alcoholic delirium of his time, when the country he loved cleaved into two and set upon each other, brothers of all religions murdering their infant nephews and raping their sisters-in-law.

headline: Communing With an Arctic People
text: This winter was especially rough on a Southern expat like the Miser, whose moods seem perilously pegged to the thermometer. So he can only marvel at the example of the Sami, who have thrived in the Arctic region for centuries, fishing, farming and forging a vibrant culture in spite of the climate.

headline: Uneasy Inhabitants
text: One night two summers ago, I was in a car speeding across the border into the eastern Indian state of Bihar. The unlit, pitch-black freeway didn’t deter traffic from barreling forward at breakneck speeds. In the inevitable accident, a young man was shredded by a truck. A politician showed up, but instead of taking charge, he distracted the police with laughter and gossip.

headline: Heeeeeere’s a Tribute From a ‘Tonight’ Veteran
text: It’s no small feat when a performer, without even trying, makes time stand still. But that’s what the 86-year-old vocal powerhouse Marilyn Maye did on Tuesday evening at 54 Below, despite abundant evidence that the years are speeding by at the usual breakneck pace.

headline: A Glimpse of Léger, a Good Look at Lalique
text: JUST BEFORE LÉGER

headline: Upper West Side Facade Snatchers
text: It goes without saying that Broadway on the Upper West Side is a commercial street, a cacophonic corridor of delis, shoe stores, locksmiths and coffee shops. But what is now a retail strip began with quite different aspirations, as a boulevard of residential refinement, which in the early 1900s certainly meant no stores. Big chain stores and huge garish signage overtook this once domestic idyll after World War I, but in the last two decades the Age of Preservation has brought commerce to heel.

headline: Apple Publishes Expanded Report on How It Handles Government Data Requests
text: Apple published a set of guidelines late Wednesday clarifying how, when and why it handles requests from law enforcement or government agencies seeking information about an Apple customer.

headline: China Flexes Its Muscles in Dispute With Vietnam
text: BEIJING — China’s escalating dispute with Vietnam over contested waters in the South China Sea sent new shudders through Asia on Thursday as China demanded the withdrawal of Vietnamese ships near a giant Chinese drilling rig and for the first time acknowledged its vessels had blasted the Vietnamese flotilla with water cannons in recent days.

headline: Dior Cruise 2015 Collection
text: Scenes from the Dior cruise 2015 collection photo diary of Olivia Locher.

headline: Immigrants Working While They Wait
text: The Department of Homeland Security announced proposed rule changes this week to allow the spouses of some highly skilled temporary workers to hold jobs in the United States, and to remove some of the obstacles that make it difficult for some groups of highly skilled workers to remain here.

headline: Putting a Face on Pinot Blanc
text: If it were possible to probe the collective consciousness of wine drinkers for their impressions of pinot blanc, you would be left with little of consequence. Few love it, few hate it, few give it much thought. It’s not the dominant grape in any particular region. An even closer examination reveals pinot blanc to be a phantom grape and wine, a cipher that offers few answers but raises many questions.

headline: Model-Morphosis | Harleth Kuusik at Dior Cruise 2015 Collection
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captured a transformation of the Dior Cruise 2015 collection in New York. Here, the model Harleth Kuusik before (left) and after (right) makeup by Peter Phillips and hair by Guido Palau.

text: Photos from Syria, Venezuela, Pakistan and Brazil.

headline: What Comes of Reading Far Too Many Novels
text: “We will not anticipate the past! Our retrospection will be all to the future!”

headline: A Teenage Tone Poem, Balancing Fear With Rash Impulses
text: The kids in Gia Coppola’s “Palo Alto” move as through a dream. It’s a drifty, appealing story, set in the Northern California city that gives the movie its title, about that twilight period between childhood’s end and the start of young adulthood. Here, under wavering palm trees, teenagers slip through homes and streets with the vagueness that comes with certain visions of adolescence. These aren’t the tireless achievers cramming for tests, and preparing for college and the conformity to come. They are instead the anxious children who have — since the likes of Holden Caulfield and James Dean’s rebel — defined American adolescence as a state of poetic confusion.

headline: Districts Told Not to Deny Students Over Immigration
text: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. and Education Secretary Arne Duncan issued a strong warning on Thursday to public school districts nationwide not to deny enrollment to immigrant students in the country illegally.

headline: Winklevoss Twins to List Bitcoin Fund on Nasdaq
text: Despite cautions and hesitations among regulators about investing in virtual currency, the Winklevoss twins are inching closer to creating the first publicly traded Bitcoin fund.

headline: Frieze, and Other Fairs That Tag Along
text: Frieze New York is the axis of the art world through Monday. But the city is teeming with satellite fairs this weekend that cater to the seasoned collector and curious novice alike. Most run Friday through Sunday, with times subject to change, so check websites. There are often discounts for seniors and students.

headline: Gathering of Far-Flung Friends, and Trends
text: Within the commercial realms of art, the New Art Dealers Alliance, known as NADA, has earned its good reputation. Founded as a nonprofit in 2002 with the conviction that the “adversarial approach to exhibiting and selling art has run its course,” it even has a cool name. (“What are you doing this weekend?” “NADA.”)

headline: This Weekend: Million-Dollar Art on Sale
text: View million-dollar art for sale at one of New York’s auction houses, visit a minimalist retrospective upstate or listen to the new albums of some ’90s music stars.

headline: Unorthodox, Maybe, but Scarcely on the Fringe
text: The Outsider Art Fair has officially outgrown its name. Once held in a Midtown office building during the doldrums of January, it relocated last year to the far more visible Center 548 in Chelsea, the former home of Dia Art Foundation, and also started a Paris edition. And this year, the show occupies a plum spot on the calendar, participating in the glut of early-May events known as Frieze Week — “a high holiday for the New York art world,” as Andrew Edlin, the art dealer and organizer of Outsider Art, writes in his introduction to the catalog.

headline: Songs Assembled From Bravado
text: The costumes were almost as loud as the music when Tune-Yards performed at Rough Trade Records on Wednesday night. Merrill Garbus, the Oakland, Calif.-based songwriter who records as Tune-Yards, was in a dress that was part red vinyl, part patterned turquoise fabric and part gold lamé, along with high sequined boots. Her band members were in a mélange of brightly colored, clashing patterns, not to mention the fluorescent face paint. Ms. Garbus also had a streak of glitter under one eye.

headline: Promises That Can Bend Without Breaking
text: In December my wife and I moved out of our house into an independent-living apartment. Walking through the building, you might take it for a well-kept hotel, until you notice the handrails lining the hallways, the nursing assistants in the common areas and the people pushing walkers in front of them rather than pulling luggage carts behind them. The average resident is close to 80 years old.

headline: The Ghost of a City
text: As rebels in Syria abandon the Old City of Homs this week, little but rubble is left behind.

headline: Spare Times for May 9-15
text: New York Bicycle Jumble (Saturday) On the heels — or wheels — of last weekend’s TD Five Boro Bike Tour, this stationary event in Park Slope, Brooklyn, will set cyclists’ hearts racing in a different way. For the sixth year, buyers can browse new and used bicycles and accessories, as well as clothing, collectibles and other items offered by vendors from across the country. Guests can talk shop with representatives from the Bicycle Messenger Foundation; the environmental organization Times Up!; and We Bike NYC, a biking group for women. They can even take a potential purchase out for a spin. (This is the first of three such planned events in Brooklyn; the others will be in Red Hook on June 1 and Park Slope in the fall.) From 10 a.m. to 4 p.m., Old Stone House at Washington Park, Third Street, between Fourth and Fifth Avenues; nybikejumble.com; free. Squeaky wheels are welcome. (Anne Mancuso)

headline: Concertos as Sounds of Spring
text: Young Concert Artists, which has been fostering the careers of gifted musicians since 1961, mostly presents the winners of its auditions in recitals, including a popular series in New York. But it has become a spring tradition for this essential organization to present a gala concert featuring select winners from recent years in concerto performances. Hearing young musicians in concertos reveals further dimensions of their artistry.

headline: Close, if Not Really Antiques and Not a Road Show
text: ROBERT JAFFE will be one of probably more than 2,000 people lined up on Saturday at the American Museum of Natural History with a mysterious object in hand.

headline: Open House Etiquette
text: Ask Real Estate is a weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: India Explains Itself
text: This week we review several new books on the Indian subcontinent. The last decade has seen a bounty of vital writing both from and about the region. Suketu Mehta’s “Maximum City,” a dense, fast-paced account of life in Mumbai, published in 2004, was arguably the advance scout of this movement. In an email interview, Mehta said the boom in “the country explaining itself to itself” is due to a few significant factors: “Publishers can make money off it (my own book continues to sell well in India, a decade after it came out), the rise of English speakers (20 percent of the population) and the huge crowds at literary festivals” like the one in Jaipur.

headline: The Venting Process
text: I was in a store today, and two people were served before me — out of turn. It happened so quickly, I didn’t say anything; they were already in the middle of their orders. When I got back to my car, I told my husband how annoyed I was. He said, “Maybe you should speak up for yourself.” This made me doubly annoyed, and I lost my temper with him. I’ve asked him many times not to give me advice unless I ask for it. Now I’m asking for yours.

headline: Apple Said to Be in Talks to Buy Rising Music Brand for $3.2 Billion
text: Apple is in discussions to buy Beats Electronics, the company behind the popular Beats by Dr. Dre headphones, for $3.2 billion, according to people briefed on the talks, in what would be the biggest acquisition in Apple’s history.

headline: A Chance to Embrace Your Inner Katniss
text: IT is oddly satisfying to discover that, without question, you would be the first person to die in the Hunger Games.

text: Hurricanes Katrina and Rita significantly increased the number of stillbirths in the Louisiana parishes most affected by the storms, new research suggests.

headline: Cracking a Safe of Painful Memories
text: Paging Dr. Freud? Alex (Jesse Johnson), the haunted, aerosol-huffing antihero of “Chapman,” works as a locksmith. “Every lock has a bypass, a cheat,” he explains to an angry landlord before showing him a foolproof method: kicking in the door.

headline: Not Your Typical Playboy Project
text: The May issue of Playboy features a special section that you find by flipping the magazine upside down and reading from the back. These pages, called the Playboy A-Z special edition, have a different look from the rest of the magazine and feature photographs by such art-world luminaries as Marilyn Minter, Ryan McGinley, Ralph Gibson, Jeff Burton and many others, several of whom have shot for The New York Times Magazine. But in one important way, they look like the usual Playboy issue: The women are naked.

headline: A Plea to Let Those Waters Flow
text: A stirring argument against dams can be made by the outdoors itself: the rivers, trees, wildlife and vibrant contours of an organically forged landscape. “DamNation” begins with such images of nature, often artfully framed, and returns to them as well as to some beautifully fine-grained archival photography. But this documentary (which was funded by the outdoor apparel company Patagonia) also lumps together its grievances and interviews in a way that feels scattered and geared toward those inclined to agree.

headline: At Odds, Omnicom and Publicis End Merger

text: The New York Times film critics on “Neighbors,” “Palo Alto” and “Chef.”

headline: Barcelona in Brooklyn
text: In the Barcelona neighborhood of El Born, home to creative types and the people who love them, is there a stylish American bistro called Greenpoint?

headline: What Housing Recovery?
text: LOS ANGELES — RECENTLY there’s been a lot of happy talk about the nation’s housing recovery. Frequent reports about rising prices suggest that the tens of millions of people whose homes lost value just have to wait until the recovery reaches their neighborhood to lift them out of crisis. But this supposed housing recovery is bypassing many of our cities and towns.

headline: Young Hands Steering the Family Tractor
text: “Bad behavior is pretty rare in our industry,” one of the six young farmers profiled in “Farmland” tells us. Though he doesn’t elaborate, his comment’s lack of detail and depth is typical of a film that plays more like a feature-length advertisement than like a documentary. You keep expecting the camera to zoom in on a packet of bacon or a box of cereal.

headline: Can the Kochs Hold Back History?
text: For a time, the press lord William Randolph Hearst did everything in his vast powers to keep the film “Citizen Kane” from finding an audience. He intimidated theater owners, refused to let ads run in his newspapers, and even pressured studio sycophants to destroy the negative.

headline: Another Tech Company Finds the F.T.C. Looking Over Its Shoulder
text: Updated, 8:42 p.m. |

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: RadioShack Pulls Back on Size of Store Closings
text: RadioShack said on Thursday that it could not come to an agreement with its lenders that would allow it to close 1,100 of its stores, although it said it would still shutter a number of outlets as part of its plan to turn around the struggling company.

headline: Forget Benghazi. Clinton’s Real Problem Is Obama Fatigue.
text: The latest investigation into the Benghazi attack reminds us that the issue isn’t going away any time soon. Pundits are already speculating about potential damage to Hillary Clinton’s presidential prospects, but don’t believe the hype: Scandals rarely matter much in presidential election campaigns.

headline: First a Killing, Then a Code of Silence
text: The occasional narrator of “God’s Pocket” is a Philadelphia newspaper columnist and Jimmy Breslin type who is the beloved voice of the city’s blue collar class. Describing the residents of the rough, seedy South Philadelphia neighborhood that gives the movie its name, this local celebrity, Richard (Richard Jenkins), muses out loud with barbed affection: “Everyone here has stolen something from someone else, or when they were kids, they set someone’s house on fire. They know who cheats at cards and who slaps their kids around. The one thing they can’t forgive is not being from God’s Pocket.”

headline: In Mexico, a Rail Line Splits a City and Views
text: EL PASO — When César Duarte, the governor of the Mexican state of Chihuahua, announced last week that the government wanted to move the railroad tracks that pass through Ciudad Juárez out of the heart of the city, Cristina Jiménez knew that the battle had only begun.

headline: Agreeing to Disagree on State’s Future Water Needs
text: How much more water will Texas really need by 2060?

headline: Now That’s Rich
text: Institutional Investor’s latest “rich list” in its Alpha magazine, its survey of the 25 highest-paid hedge fund managers, is out — and it turns out that these guys make a lot of money. Surprise!

headline: Wicked Witch Is Dead, but Here Comes a Jester
text: The maps included with many Oz books promised bookish completists that there was always another little corner of this flip-side world to explore. That sense of imagination is largely absent from “Legends of Oz: Dorothy’s Return,” a second-rate animated adaptation of a spinoff by Roger Stanton Baum, L. Frank Baum’s great-grandson. Still, the film’s set-piece journey through China Country, ruled over by a tiny, haughty, porcelain princess (a delightful Megan Hilty), is a highlight, the picture of a self-absorbed royal hamlet with its own rules and wigs.

headline: In Dealings on Syria, Security Council Exposes Its Failings
text: UNITED NATIONS — Since the beginning of the year, the Security Council has discussed Syria no fewer than 18 times and devoted 13 more sessions to Ukraine.

headline: Intelligence Policy Bans Citation of Leaked Material
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is clamping down on a technique that government officials have long used to join in public discussions of well-known but technically still-secret information: citing news reports based on unauthorized disclosures.

headline: Dad’s Watching Us? Call Social Services
text: Seldom has wackiness been as tedious as it is in “Moms’ Night Out,” a Christian-themed film that is desperate to make adherents seem wild and crazy but mostly makes them seem incapable of raising children.

headline: Lost in Crowd, Manziel Slips to 22nd
text: The record-setting quarterback out of Texas A&M, the one with the household nickname, the Heisman Trophy, the golden arm, the hyper-quick legs, the ability to attract attention and controversy like flypaper, was trying to hide the fact that his face was flushed.

headline: 17 Human Rights Groups Urge Palestinians to Join World Court
text: A group of 17 human rights organizations including Human Rights Watch and Amnesty International on Thursday urged President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority to “promptly” join the International Criminal Court, a move strongly opposed by Israel and the United States. Palestinian leaders have said the court would be the last of the 63 international organizations, treaties and conventions it might join as part of a new strategy to leverage the observer-state status they won at the United Nations in 2012. Many Palestinians and their supporters say the court could prosecute Israel for building Jewish settlements in the West Bank and demolishing Palestinian homes there; legal experts have warned that joining the court could also expose Palestinians themselves to prosecution for war crimes.

headline: Obama to Give Push on Climate
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama will announce on Friday a handful of executive actions and private and nonprofit groups’ investments in energy efficiency and renewable energy.

headline: Events in New Jersey for May 11-17, 2014
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Dow Jones Acting Chief Is Given Job Permanently
text: William Lewis, who has served as acting chief executive of News Corporation’s Dow Jones division since January, has been named its permanent chief, the company announced on Thursday.

headline: A Coup by Another Name in Thailand
text: A decision by Thailand’s highest court to remove Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra from office is almost sure to send the country deeper into crisis. Pro- and antigovernment groups are already massing for more protests that will further divide the polarized country and further disrupt an already weak economy.

headline: Clip: ‘Stage Fright’
text: A musical scene from “Stage Fright,” directed by Jerome Sable.

headline: Pfizer’s Plan to Go to London Spurs Other Companies to Consider Moving Abroad
text: Pfizer’s attempt to escape the United States corporate tax rate by acquiring a British drug maker has set off a flurry of activity in other big companies across the country, at investment banks on Wall Street and in offices on Capitol Hill.

headline: How to Fix the Mortgage Market
text: In the credit bubble of the last decade, the housing market essentially became a tool of the financial system. To sate the banks’ demand for mortgage-related securities, many loans were made not on the basis of sound lending standards but on the unsound premise that house prices would rise forever — a practice that led to the bust and to the bailouts of Wall Street and of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the federally backed mortgage companies.

headline: Recalled Used Cars Roam the Roads as Federal Legislation Stalls
text: David Clayton was driving 70 miles an hour in his Ram 1500 pickup truck last October when he learned the hard way that it had a serious safety problem. The rear axle locked up, causing him to nearly lose control before wrestling the truck to the side of the highway.

headline: More Tales of the ‘Righteous’
text: Trying to shed light on the darkness of human suffering, Michael King’s “The Rescuers” travels across Europe to chronicle the actions of those who saved Jews during World War II. While the documentary marshals an impressive array of survivors and visits several international locations, it grindingly adheres to an unwieldy tour-style presentation, with more than a few rough spots and, at times, an unpolished look.

headline: ‘Bernie’ Goes Home With Director
text: CARTHAGE, Tex. — Richard Linklater could not have imagined a more bizarre final scene for “Bernie,” the dark comedy film he directed, than the one that unfolded Tuesday in East Texas. After nearly two decades behind bars, the convicted killer on whom the movie was based was driven away from the jail (by Mr. Linklater no less) to a home in Central Texas owned by — you guessed it — Mr. Linklater.

headline: Center Ring at the Republican Circus
text: The hottest competition in Washington this week is among House Republicans vying for a seat on the Benghazi kangaroo court, also known as the Select House Committee to Inflate a Tragedy Into a Scandal. Half the House has asked to “serve” on the committee, which is understandable since it’s the perfect opportunity to avoid any real work while waving frantically to right-wing voters stomping their feet in the grandstand.

headline: Simmons Spends Big on Star Power
text: THE Simmons Bedding Company will introduce two new celebrity-driven advertising campaigns this month, in which Dr. Andrew Weil, an alternative-medicine expert, will endorse the ComforPedic iQ mattress, and the actor and auto racer Patrick Dempsey will promote the Beautyrest Black.

headline: Despite Orders, Federal Tank-Car Safety Measures Are Slow in Coming
text: The derailment of a freight train carrying crude oil in Lynchburg, Va., last week was a reminder that basic safety features of the oil-by-rails business remain vastly inadequate, despite a flurry of emergency orders by federal regulators.

headline: After Barclays, a Former Chief Strives to Revive His Reputation in Africa
text: When Barclays announced on Thursday that it planned to slash the size and scope of its investment bank, the British effectively halted a long campaign to become a true Wall Street powerhouse, one to rival Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase.

headline: Some High Notes Are Just Screams
text: The Canadian musical comedy “Stage Fright” unveils its lone showstopping number early on, as a bus full of kids pulls into theater camp: the one place they aren’t outcasts. As a sad sack sings of being “beaten up a dozen times for singing Stephen Sondheim’s rhymes,” the film offers a glimpse of exactly the sort of demented, toe-tapping sensibility you’d expect from a tuneful summer camp farce — in which a serial killer is on the loose.

headline: Ugly Words From North Korea
text: SEOUL, South Korea — After President Obama and South Korea’s president, Park Geun-hye, warned North Korea of harsher sanctions if it continued pursuing nuclear weapons, the North has responded with harsh invective against both leaders.

headline: Massachusetts Pushes Fix for State Health Exchange
text: BOSTON — The board of the broken Massachusetts health insurance exchange voted on Thursday to support a state plan to buy new software to help people enroll in coverage, while also preparing to join the federal marketplace if the system is not ready by fall.

headline: Marijuana Trade Offered Credit Relief in Colorado
text: DENVER — Seeking to move its growing marijuana industry away from the risk of using only cash, Colorado finalized plans this week to create the nation’s first financial cooperatives for the marijuana trade. But few expect the effort to gain the necessary approval of Federal Reserve officials leery of offering banking services to companies that grow and sell a federally controlled substance.

headline: Venezuela Arrests 243 in Raids on Antigovernment Protest Camps
text: Security forces arrested 243 people in Caracas on Thursday as they dismantled four protest camps set up in the Venezuelan capital by demonstrators opposed to the government of President Nicolás Maduro, and a policeman was fatally shot in clashes that followed, officials said.

headline: The Theater of Tough Beginnings
text: For everyone who “played pretend” as a youth, who concocted elaborate stories of homemaking, piracy or other adventure without needing the rules of basketball or Capture the Flag, something about the Cambodian documentary “Still I Strive” may touch you.

headline: Instant Jerseys for N.F.L. Draft Picks
text: Since 2012 the N.F.L. has added a special touch to draft day: It personalizes the jersey given to each first-round selection.

headline: Politics Seen in Cuban Accusations of Military Plot by Miami Men
text: MIAMI — There was a time not all that long ago that Santiago Alvarez, a Miami developer, fantasized about swinging an automatic weapon over his shoulder and heading back to Cuba to incite an uprising.

headline: Personalizing Jerseys of Top N.F.L. Picks Is a Race Against the Clock
text: The first-round picks that attend draft day at Radio City Music Hall have plenty of reasons to smile: instant renown, multimillion-dollar contracts, the dream job.

headline: The Real Africa
text: In 2005, Binyavanga Wainaina published a brilliantly sarcastic essay in Granta called “How to Write About Africa,” advising people on how to sound spiritual and compassionate while writing a book about the continent.

headline: Obama Addresses the Limits of Using Power in Syria and Nigeria
text: SAN JOSE, Calif. — As President Obama hopscotched the California coast this week on a fund-raising trip for Democratic candidates and other causes, he used one of the glittering events to offer a candid meditation on the powers of the presidency and its limits.

headline: Regulator Suggests End to Banks’ Self-Grading
text: Self-grading has obvious limitations in education. Now, a senior regulator at the Federal Reserve wants to banish it from bank regulation.

headline: All the Way to 2032, Come What May
text: Eighteen years ago, there was no certainty that we would be watching sports and movies on little mobile screens or that outfits like Netflix would engage us by streaming series a season at a time.

headline: Compromise on Gays Pleases No One, Scouts Are Learning
text: SEATTLE — Pascal Tessier is a 17-year-old Eagle Scout in suburban Maryland who says scouting made him who he is today, with its lessons about morality, leadership and responsibility. And those very strengths, this openly gay high school senior said, are what compel and equip him to fight back now against Scout policies on gays that he believes are wrong.

headline: Oscar Murillo: ‘A Mercantile Novel’
text: David Zwirner Gallery

headline: Sherrie Levine: ‘Red Yellow Blue’
text: Paula Cooper

headline: Dona Nelson: ‘Phigor’
text: Thomas Erben Gallery

headline: Jackie Saccoccio
text: Eleven Rivington

headline: Sterling’s Wife Asserts Her Ownership Share
text: The Los Angeles Clippers co-owner Rochelle Sterling vowed to retain her 50 percent share of the franchise as the N.B.A. continued its push to oust her husband, Donald, who was barred from the league for life last month for making racist comments on a recording.

headline: Robert Kinmont: ‘trying to return home educated’
text: Alexander and Bonin

headline: Rather Than Buzz, the Nets Garner a Ho-Hum
text: MIAMI — Whatever drama may have been building between the Nets and the Miami Heat abruptly faded in the fourth quarter on Thursday night, and perhaps even died in the deep left corner at American Airlines Arena.

headline: California: Agreement on Rainy Day Fund
text: Gov. Jerry Brown and state legislative leaders reached a deal Thursday to place a revised plan for a rainy-day fund on the ballot this fall; it would create a cushion against future economic downturns and allow the state to use extra cash to pay down long-term debt. Mr. Brown, who is running for his fourth term this fall, has been pushing for the measure, which he says is the only way to bolster the state’s finances for the long term. Under the plan, spikes in money collected from capital gains taxes would be diverted to the fund, with some money set aside for debt payments on pensions. The Legislature would also be required to set aside 1.5 percent of general revenue for the fund each year, and money could be withdrawn from the fund only if overall revenue did not meet historic spending levels. The Legislature is expected to approve the proposal next week so that the measure can be placed on the November ballot.

headline: Digs in the Snow
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — Well, lookee here; a Friday puzzle that almost looks like it might have a theme. It’s a 68-worder, but take a gander at those long, horizontal entries. I looked at the blank grid before solving and thought, “Huh. A rule breaker.”

headline: Rangers’ Recent Struggles Start With the Top Skaters
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Less than a week ago, the Rangers were reveling in a 3-2 overtime victory in Game 1 against the Penguins in Pittsburgh. Penguins goaltender Marc-Andre Fleury was turning into his erratic postseason self, and the Rangers’ top scorers appeared close to a breakthrough.

headline: At His Trial, Imam Tells of Losing His Forearms
text: Mostafa Kamel Mostafa, the imam on trial on terrorism-related charges, had long been known for the metal hooks he wore as prostheses on his arms after losing his forearms and an eye in an explosion. But how that explosion occurred has been the subject of dispute and even myth.

headline: A Vote Against Violence for Indian Women
text: After a brutal gang rape in New Delhi, something changed in India. But maybe not a lot for the country’s politicians. For Nasreen Jahan, the fight for justice in this election season is personal.

headline: Wild Have a Carousel in Goal, but Not a Turnstile
text: ST. PAUL — The oddest day in the Minnesota Wild’s season of goaltending oddities may have been March 31.

headline: Hachette Says Amazon Is Delaying Delivery of Some Books
text: Amazon has begun discouraging customers from buying books by Malcolm Gladwell, Stephen Colbert, J. D. Salinger and other popular writers, a flexing of its muscle as a battle with a publisher spills into the open.

headline: Big City Book Club
text: Brooklyn today is a destination for celebrities and wealthy creative types, but not so long ago it was the default settlement for young immigrants without money. When the Big City Book Club convenes next, we’ll be reading Colm Toibin’s acclaimed 2009 novel, “Brooklyn,” the story of a young Irishwoman who leaves a fragile mother behind to find herself in Dodgerland in the early 1950s. Brooklyn College and the Fulton Mall both make appearances in a book that explores the conflict between familial obligation and one’s own youthful heart and promise. The online discussion will take place on Monday, May 19, starting at 6:30 p.m.

headline: Times Minute | Car Recall Controversy
text: Also on the Minute, rising tensions in the South China Sea and the longevity of Snapchats.

headline: Times Minute | Car Recall Controversy
text: In the Video

headline: Deadly Illness in Nicaragua Baffles Experts
text: CHICHIGALPA, Nicaragua — During the harvest season, when exhausted workers spend seven days a week cutting sugar cane, the signs of illness were hard to spot at first.

headline: For Yankees’ Tanaka, Batter’s Box Is Anything but Home
text: MILWAUKEE — Masahiro Tanaka’s split-finger fastball, slider and two-seamer, as well as his tenacity, have combined to make him a rookie sensation for the Yankees. But Tanaka struggles in one aspect of baseball.

headline: García Clears His Mind, Then the Water, at the Players Championship
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — The 17th hole at TPC Sawgrass was as tranquil as a yoga studio Thursday morning when Sergio García’s group reached the tee box. The wind was negligible and relatively few fans were on hand to pan or praise shots. The only stress on the players was self-induced.

headline: Schoolgirl Abductions Put Scrutiny on U.S. Terrorism Strategy
text: WASHINGTON — The abduction of more than 200 schoolgirls in Nigeria has led to new scrutiny of the United States’ counterterrorism strategy toward Boko Haram during Hillary Rodham Clinton’s tenure as secretary of state.

headline: Coming Off Rout, Nets Adjust but Are Left Adrift
text: MIAMI — As the racket inside the arena rose to an earsplitting volume late Thursday night, Kevin Garnett hit his palms softly together and stared down at the floor. He burrowed his chin into his chest, bending his neck at what looked like a 90-degree angle.

headline: Documents on Long-Term Care
text: The goal was cost savings, but the state’s sweeping changes in Medicaid spending on long-term services set off a stampede in recent years by managed care companies for low-risk, high-profit enrollees.

headline: Medicaid Shift Fuels Rush for Profitable Clients
text: When Hurricane Sandy flooded two adult homes in Queens, hundreds of disabled, elderly or mentally ill residents were caught in the surge. After weeks in public shelters, they were bused, over their objections, to a dilapidated four-story building called King’s Hotel, in a crime-ridden section of Brooklyn.

headline: Alleging Bias, Employees Sue School Official in Westchester
text: If the claims in a federal lawsuit brought by a principal, four teachers and three other school employees are accurate, the superintendent of the Greenburgh Central School District in Westchester County repeatedly disparaged his staff with bigoted terms, whether they were black or white, Jewish or Muslim, male or female, gay or heterosexual.

headline: Newark Mayoral Race Seen as Referendum on Booker
text: NEWARK — One is a municipal councilman and high school principal, son of a celebrated and controversial black poet, who negotiated a truce among this city’s gangs and urged them to fight a white conspiracy and “seize power, block by block, city by city, place by place.”

headline: Giants Add a Weapon for Manning
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Giants fans saw Eli Manning flailing and failing throughout most of the 2013 season. The Giants’ brain trust apparently saw the same thing.

headline: Jets Select a Safety From Louisville
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Divining the Jets’ draft objectives under General Manager John Idzik has become an annual guessing game, as much because of his guarded approach as the state of their roster. It is more likely that a magician would reveal the secret to his tricks than Idzik would divulge a hint about his intentions for a team that, despite a strong finish to last season, very much remains in transition.

headline: Cuomo and Panel He Shut Differ on Its Independence
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, who has long cast himself as the man who would clean up Albany, offered a blunt defense last month to suggestions that his office had interfered with an anticorruption panel the governor formed last year, then shut down abruptly in March in exchange for enhancements to state ethics laws.

headline: Q & A: M. Taylor Fravel on China’s Dispute With Vietnam
text: The long-simmering territorial dispute between China and Vietnam in the South China Sea had one of its periodic eruptions this week, as Vietnamese vessels confronted Chinese ships that are trying to place an oil rig near the disputed Paracel Islands and off Vietnam’s coast. The rig is run by China National Offshore Oil Corporation, or Cnooc, and lies just 120 nautical miles off the main coastline of Vietnam. Chinese ships have fired water cannons at the Vietnamese vessels, and both sides have said their ships have been rammed by opposing forces. The Chinese military fought with units from South Vietnam over the southern Paracels in 1974, which led to China taking over the islands, though they remain uninhabited.

headline: Key Figure in Fire Department After 9/11 Is to Return as Commissioner
text: Daniel A. Nigro, a former New York City fire official who was thrust into the command of rescue operations on Sept. 11, 2001, when the chief of department was killed by falling debris, will be named the Fire Department’s new commissioner, two city officials said.

headline: Two Cases of Violence, and a Question About the Severity of the Charges
text: Just before midnight last Tuesday, Robert Borrelli stopped for a light on a corner in the village of Pelham, just north of the Bronx. With him was Joseph Felice, a teammate on an adult hockey team in New Rochelle that had just won a semifinal match. They had reached that quiet corner of Westchester County at that precise instant because their game started after 10 p.m., and its length was determined by a combination of whistles and penalties and icing calls.

headline: Suspect Sought in Brooklyn and Queens Hammer Attacks
text: The police are searching for a man who they believe has attacked three commuters with a hammer during robberies in Brooklyn and Queens over the past two months.

headline: Council Committee Approves Expansion by Rockefeller University
text: Rockefeller University, a biomedical research institute and graduate school on the East Side of Manhattan, received approval on Thursday from a City Council committee for an expansion that would include building a platform over Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive.

headline: India Election Digest: May 9
text: What you need to know on Friday about India’s elections: You can’t escape talk of politics in Varanasi, the Bharatiya Janata Party leaders are accusing the Election Commission of bias, and the leaders of the two main national parties mention alliance possibilities.

headline: ‘The River’ With Hugh Jackman, Is Set for October Opening
text: Hugh Jackman’s next Broadway play, Jez Butterworth’s “The River,” will begin performances on Oct. 31 at Circle in the Square Theater, the producers announced on Thursday night.

headline: Twitter Insiders Sell After Lockup Expires
text: Twitter’s stock took a beating on Tuesday, the first day that employees and early investors in the company could freely sell their shares after Twitter’s initial public offering in November.

headline: The Art of Eating
text: The congenial lunchtime ritual of breaking bread with others is becoming a rarity, replaced by snacking on the go or in front of a computer. For a few artists, the midday meal is a chance to bring everyone to the table for pleasure and conversation.

headline: Tribal Beauty
text: The glories of African design, from vibrant patterned prints to regal embellishment, are yet again influencing the arts.

headline: Word of the Day | mnemonic
text: mnemonic•\ni-ˈmä-nik\• adjective and noun

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 8, 2014
Woman Hit and Killed by School Bus Carrying Children
text: A school bus carrying young children struck and killed a woman Thursday afternoon at a busy, construction-narrowed intersection on the Upper East Side, the authorities said.

headline: What’s On Friday
text: 9 P.M. (13) THE SILK ROAD ENSEMBLE WITH YO-YO MA: LIVE FROM TANGLEWOOD This documentary follows Mr. Ma, the cellist, above, and his group — musicians, composers and performing artists from more than 20 countries — onstage and behind the scenes as they celebrate their 15th anniversary with a concert, taped last summer, at the music festival in western Massachusetts. “The interaction between the musicians,” Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim wrote in The New York Times when the ensemble played at Carnegie Hall in October, “turns any performance into a visual spectacle.”

headline: Billy Frank Jr., 83, Defiant Fighter for Native Fishing Rights
text: The crime was fishing. The year was 1945. The boy was 14. It was his first offense, but it would not be his last.

headline: William Ash, Danger-Loving Escape Artist, Dies at 96
text: After his Spitfire was shot down over France in the spring of 1942, William Ash made his way to Nazi-occupied Paris with the help of the Resistance. His plan was to go to Spain, then on to England to resume flying. While waiting, he sauntered through Parisian streets as a tourist, visiting the Louvre and the zoo, dining out and swimming daily.

headline: Communist Party Newspaper Denounces Detained Lawyer
text: A commentary in a Communist Party-run newspaper has criticized the prominent civil rights lawyer Pu Zhiqiang, who was detained in Beijing this week ahead of the 25th anniversary of the deadly crackdown on the Tiananmen Square protests. The article in the newspaper, Global Times, said that Mr. Pu had “clearly crossed the red line of law” by attending a meeting to commemorate the 1989 protest movement.

headline: Maria Lassnig, Painter of Self From the Inside Out, Dies at 94
text: Maria Lassnig, an Austrian painter whose fierce devotion to self-portraiture — in lacerating, darkly funny, often grotesque ways — led her through decades of obscurity to a celebrated late-flowering career, died on Tuesday in Vienna. She was 94.

headline: Corrections: May 9, 2014
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: South Korea’s Leader and Media Face Scrutiny Over Ferry Disaster
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Parents of high school students killed in the South Korean ferry disaster marched on the office of President Park Geun-hye in central Seoul on Friday, as prosecutors tightened their investigative noose around an enigmatic family that controls the operator of the doomed ferry.

headline: The ‘Coming Home’ of Zhang Yimou and Gong Li
text: “Coming Home,” a new film by Zhang Yimou about the ravages wrought on a family by decades of political violence in China and how they (kind of) overcome them, stars Gong Li, his legendary muse. It made Steven Spielberg cry, the Chinese news media reported. Ang Lee, the Academy Award-winning director of “Life of Pi,” was “very moved” by it too, he said on Chinese television.

headline: Swedish Payments Processor Raises $55 Million
text: LONDON – The electronic payments start-up Square may be facing problems in the United States, but a European rival is trying to prove that there’s still a future for the mobile payments industry.

headline: Denials Follow Latest Report on New Delhi’s Pollution
text: In the World Health Organization’s recent report on air pollution, New Delhi ranks as the most polluted city in the world, writes Gardiner Harris of The New York Times, with air pollution far worse than that of Beijing, whose smoggy skies have grabbed much of the international attention.

headline: African National Congress Draws 62 Percent of the Vote in South Africa
text: JOHANNESBURG — As the final ballots of South Africa’s fifth post-apartheid election were tallied on Friday, the results handed the governing African National Congress a victory with 62 percent of the vote — nearly the same share it won in 1994, the year it assumed power under Nelson Mandela in the nation’s f irst truly democratic election.

headline: From Crimea, Putin Trumpets Mother Russia
text: MOSCOW — Putting his personal seal on the annexation of Crimea, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia traveled on Friday to the naval port of Sevastopol, where he used the anniversary of the victory over Nazi Germany to assert that Moscow had the right to take over the Black Sea peninsula.

headline: Test Yourself | Editing Practice, May 9, 2014
text: Use the following question to test your ability to punctuate a quotation.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | A Singing Nun for a Reality TV World
text: In “A Singing Nun for a Reality TV World,” Jim Yardley reports on Italy’s new singing sensation.

headline: Recovering Steel Industry Lifts ArcelorMittal
text: LONDON — ArcelorMittal, the steel and mining giant, said on Friday that it had a loss of $200 million in its first quarter, less than the $345 million loss it posted for the period a year earlier. The report was taken as a sign that conditions were improving in the steel industry, considered a proxy for overall economic activity.

headline: Fire Temporarily Knocks Out Broadcast Service in Kiev
text: KIEV, Ukraine — A fire near a main broadcasting tower briefly disrupted some television service in the Ukrainian capital on Friday morning, as the authorities were on a heightened state of alert because of the country’s political crisis and a major national holiday celebrating victory in World War II.

headline: A Cultural History of Civil Rights
text: Two men sit inside a rural Mississippi community center. One of them, a black civil rights activist, has a shotgun at the ready. Their vigil — in a town where the Ku Klux Klan could strike at any moment — is in a makeshift library whose walls are covered with books.

headline: If You Had Your Own Talk Show, Whom Would You Want to Interview?
text: After more than 50 years on television, Barbara Walters is retiring — but not after interviewing seemingly every famous person. Last week she made waves again by scoring the first interview with V. Stiviano, the now-famous alleged mistress of L.A. Clippers owner, Donald Sterling. If you had the chance to host your own talk show, whom would you want to interview?

headline: Co-operative Bank’s Chairman to Step Down as It Seeks to Raise £400 Million
text: LONDON — The Co-operative Bank said on Friday that its chairman would step down  as the embattled lender prepared to raise another 400 million pounds, or roughly $676 million, to bolster its capital.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: New York Today: Mother’s Day Delays

headline: Votes for Crooks and Cricket Stars
text: WASHINGTON — In America, the period between a candidate’s announcement of his intention to run for office and the party’s primary election is known as the “money primary.” It’s during this time that aspiring candidates must prove to party bosses and the public that they can rake in enough money to win.

headline: Why You Should Pay Frontier’s Carry-On Bag Fee
text: Airlines have found another way to make money: Frontier Airlines is now charging for the privilege of carrying a bag on board. A small “personal item” is still free, but if you need to use the overhead bin, you’ll generally be paying $20 to $50.

headline: Coming Up in the Book Review
text: One of the biggest decisions we make every week at the Book Review is: What will be on the cover? Most weeks, there is a standout novel or work of nonfiction or an extremely commanding review by a prominent author or critic that demands attention. Stephen King on Donna Tartt’s “Goldfinch,” for example. Barbara Kingsolver on Elizabeth Gilbert’s “Signature of All Things.” Or we group a few books together, as we did last week with three biographies about James Madison, John Quincy Adams and Louisa Catherine Adams.Occasionally, we run a theme issue, like one we did in April on money or one last year that looked at writing about sex. This week, we did something slightly different. While we didn’t create an entire issue around a theme, we decided to highlight six new books on the cover that took on the subcontinent as their subject matter. These spring releases really stood out: Rana Dasgupta’s “Capital,” John Keay’s “Midnight’s Descendants,” Ramachandra Guha’s “Gandhi Before India,” Saadat Hasan Manto’s “Bombay Stories,” Anand Giridharadas’s “True American” and Amitava Kumar’s “Matter of Rats.”

headline: Mom Genes
text: Why we love wearing our mothers’ clothes.

headline: Boko Haram Kidnapping Tactics, Explained
text: In Nigeria, more than 200 schoolgirls have been held captive since last April. Some background information on the Islamist group that has been trying to topple the country’s government for years.

headline: Apple’s New Tune
text: APPLE IN TALKS TO BUY BEATS  |  Apple is said to be in discussions to buy Beats Electronics, the company behind the popular Beats by Dr. Dre headphones, for $3.2 billion, Ben Sisario, Brian X. Chen and David Gelles write in DealBook. The deal, which would also include the new Beats Music streaming service, would be the biggest acquisition in Apple’s history and could suggest an effort to shake up its approach to digital music.

headline: Chinese Artist Detained Before Tiananmen Anniversary
text: With little more than three weeks remaining until the 25th anniversary of the Chinese Army’s bloody crackdown on the Tiananmen Square protests, the authorities are policing any attempt to commemorate the event — even those held in private. On Wednesday night, public security agents detained Chen Guang, 43, a former soldier turned artist whose experiences during those tumultuous days have become a haunting inspiration for his work.

headline: Schoolgirls Abducted in Nigeria
text: The militant group Boko Haram has kidnapped more than 200 schoolgirls.

headline: Just Can’t Get Enough of Each Other
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — The director and screenwriter James Gray and his frequent star Joaquin Phoenix both say that they first met shortly after Mr. Phoenix picked up a copy of Mr. Gray’s script “The Yards” at the apartment of Liv Tyler, then the actor’s girlfriend. A meeting was set up at Piadina, an Italian restaurant on West 10th Street in Manhattan. It was January 1997. Since then, they have made four movies together, all set in New York: “The Yards,” “We Own the Night,” “Two Lovers” and now “The Immigrant.”

headline: Earnings at Telefónica and Alcatel-Lucent Reflect Industry Difficulties
text: LONDON — Many of Europe’s largest telecommunications companies are still struggling to profit from consumers’ seemingly insatiable appetite for Internet access.

headline: ‘Fed Up’ Asks, Are All Calories Equal?
text: Americans have long been told that the cure for obesity is simple: Eat fewer calories and exercise more.

headline: As Modi Makes a Last Charge in Varanasi, Tempers and Emotions Rise
text: VARANASI, India — Narendra Modi, the prime ministerial candidate of the opposition Bharatiya Janata Party, arrived on Thursday in Rohaniya, an hour’s drive from Varanasi’s city center. This was to be Mr. Modi’s last campaign rally in Varanasi, where he is locked in a fierce contest with Arvind Kejriwal of the Aam Aadmi Party in a parliamentary race that has gripped India.

text: Dear Diary:

headline: Cost-Cutting Helps Danish Maker of Wind Turbines Return to Profitability
text: LONDON — Vestas Wind Systems, the Danish maker of wind turbines, reported on Friday a net profit for its first quarter of 2 million euros compared with a loss of about €150 million a year earlier as the company’s efforts to reduce costs began to pay off.

headline: Insurance and Freedom
text: These are tough times for opponents of health care reform. They bet everything on a debacle, but Obamacare has failed to fail — and their efforts to deny the increasingly obvious success of the law are beginning to look ridiculous.

headline: Artists on Artists | Michelle Grabner on Christopher Williams’s Vivid, Exacting Photographs
text: Earlier this year, Michelle Grabner became the first artist to co-curate the Whitney Biennial since Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney, the museum’s founder. The floor she organized was the popular favorite, lauded for its emphasis on mature female painters, like Amy Sillman and Louise Fishman, and lushly handmade objects, including several works by the textile artist Sheila Hicks. Grabner also runs two galleries with her husband, the artist Brad Killam: The Suburban, housed in two sheds in their Oak Park, Ill., backyard, and the Poor Farm, a larger space in rural Wisconsin.

headline: U.S. Sells More Shares in Ally Financial
text: The Treasury Department has taken another step to reduce its stake in Ally Financial after the initial public offering of the once-embattled lender.

headline: Eurozone Fiscal Myths
text: Matthew Yglesias has a generally very good piece on the euro story so far; a combination of whatever-it-takes financial intervention and political commitment has stabilized the financial situation, but the real economy and the unemployed have suffered terribly.

headline: Post Office Says It Lost $1.9 Billion in Quarter
text: WASHINGTON — The financially troubled Postal Service on Friday reported a net loss of $1.9 billion in the second quarter, the same amount it lost over the same period in 2013, postal officials said.

headline: U.N. Refugee Agency Says Thousands Fleeing Nigeria Region
text: GENEVA — As international support builds for the search for more than 200 abducted Nigerian schoolgirls, the United Nations refugee agency expressed alarm Friday at the swelling tide of people fleeing their homes in northeast Nigeria to escape attacks by Boko Haram insurgents that it said were unprecedented in their brutality and frequency.

headline: In Beats Deal, a New Direction for Apple
text: Apple has never been one for megadeals. Facebook and Google have spent billions on companies like WhatsApp and Motorola, but Apple has stayed well below the billion-dollar mark.

headline: United Spirits to Sell Whyte & Mackay Whiskey
text: LONDON – United Spirits of India said on Friday that it had agreed to sell its Whyte & Mackay whiskey business to the brandy maker Emperador in a deal that values the business at 430 million pounds, or $726.5 million.

headline: Three Walls in Search of a Ball
text: A century ago, handball was one of the most beloved sports in Ireland, its typical three-walled alley, or court, a fixture in villages and at crossroads. But these were “more than just places where people came to play handball,” says the photographer Kenneth O Halloran, who visited nearly a hundred abandoned courts in Ireland and Northern Ireland last year. “People came to socialize, to dance.” After the game moved indoors around the 1950s, many courts that were not demolished became places for parking or storage. There is little nostalgia among the Irish for handball alleys, O Halloran says. “I don’t think people would value them the way they value a traditional cottage, old crosses or ancient ruins,” he says. “A lot of people see them as eyesores.” Julie Bosman

headline: The Horoscope Diet
text: What not to read before shopping; Cliven Bundy vs. Al Bundy.
