text: SHOULD A CHIMP BE ABLE TO SUE ITS OWNER?

headline: You Should Seriously Read ‘Stoner’ Right Now
text: Fifteen years ago, a friend of mine pulled me aside at the tail end of some sodden grad-school party and pressed a copy of the novel “Stoner” into my hands. I was at the time in the thrall of various junkie authors and thus assumed “Stoner” would be a tale of psychoactive depravity. The book was a different sort of trip altogether.

headline: The Old Switch-a-Brew
text: Sixty years ago, my father worked in a brewery, which produced a “premium” beer and a “regular” beer with a different name and a cheaper price. In actuality, the beers were identical, only with different bottles and labels. The “premium” buyers were getting what they were paying for — a premium beer. The “regular” beer drinkers were paying less for the same thing. While it doesn’t seem that anyone was hurt by the deception, does the fact that there was deceit involved make it unethical? NAME WITHHELD

headline: Addict. Informant. Mother.
text: One day last summer, Ann and her husband, Tom, walked two and a half hours to reach Hazleton, a onetime mining town in eastern Pennsylvania. They had lived there until July, when they were evicted and moved in with Ann’s mother in Sugarloaf, a more affluent township nearby. There was not much to miss about Hazleton, with its decaying downtown and its fading homes spotted with satellite dishes, but to Ann and Tom the town held a shimmering appeal: It had heroin, a lot of it. They had called the usual friends for a ride, with no luck, and their own car had been repossessed. So at midday, the two left Ann’s mother’s condominium by foot and followed the asphalt out of the valley all the way to Hazleton. Eventually they turned onto Alter Street, where, especially in summer, heroin dealers greeted customers outside a packed barbershop and a busy pawnshop, clustering around them, competing for business. Sometimes Ann and Tom joined other users they knew behind a building, where someone had left a tattered couch. Sometimes they got high in an abandoned garage on a side street. Though the walk that day to Alter Street was long, it was worth it to them both: Tom, especially, loved heroin, and Ann loved Tom, and the march to Hazleton was as much about need as it was about love.

headline: Philippe Petit Strikes a Delicate Balance
text: Your new book is called “Creativity: The Perfect Crime.” The first lines are “Make no mistake. I frown upon books about creativity.” How is yours different? Most books on creativity are written by an author who references all the great creators of humanity — very often Einstein, the Beatles. They’re not drawing from themselves, and these books are usually in the self-help department. And very often, at the end of a chapter, they have an exercise for you to do. I don’t frown upon them; let’s be frank, I hate them.

headline: A Nanny’s Love
text: One Mother’s Day many years ago, my younger brother handed Tina a card he made in his kindergarten class. When my mom saw it, she said, “That’s mine.” Tina laughed and handed the card to her boss.

headline: Who Made That Stun Gun?
text: In the summer of 1965, just before riots broke out in Watts, President Lyndon Johnson ordered a study on crime in a “free society.” Among its recommendations was developing a technology for handling unruly citizens. A patrolman ought to have a “nonlethal” way to incapacitate a criminal, one that worked quickly and with little risk of lasting injury. “For example,” the study’s authors wrote, “darts have been used for injecting tranquilizing drugs into animals.”

headline: Goldman Under Investigation for High-Speed Trading
text: Updated, 3:48 p.m. |

headline: Unfrozen
text: “Meteorology is not superfluous to the story,” W. G. Sebald advised the students in one of his final fiction-writing classes. It’s an observation that has never seemed lost on Michael Cunningham. Consider how he introduces Virginia Woolf’s last afternoon on earth in the opening sentence of his Pulitzer Prize-winning novel, “The Hours”: “She hurries from the house, wearing a coat too heavy for the weather.” And his 2010 novel “By Nightfall” ended with some rather Joycean evening snow tapping at the bedroom window of an affluent, troubled Manhattan husband, a man about to have a reckoning with his own self-centeredness. (Another excellent tip from Sebald: “I can only encourage you to steal as much as you can.”)

headline: Captive Rites
text: Contemporary tellings tend to mask the real horrors of the original Brothers Grimm stories and their ilk. We remember the princess and the happy ending. We’d rather forget that a passing stranger raped Sleeping Beauty as she lay unconscious, or that Snow White’s jealous stepmother not only called for her death but wanted to eat her liver and lungs. Roxane Gay’s striking debut novel, “An Untamed State,” is a fairy tale in this vein, its complex and fragile moral arrived at through great pain and high cost.

headline: Skills and Strategies | Engaging in Causes Via ‘Hashtag Activism’
text: Update | May 14, 2014: We have added a contribution from 230 girls and their teachers at a school in Panama City, Panama. Scroll to the bottom of this post to see it.

headline: Rebel Prince Shines a Harsh Light on Morocco
text: PARIS — HE sat in the car, frozen with fear, as gunmen pointed rifles at his pregnant mother in the driver’s seat beside him. They were rushing to the king’s birthday party because they had heard there was a commotion. It was the summer of 1971, and the Moroccan Army killed over 100 party guests in its attempt to overthrow the monarchy. The gunmen spared the pregnant woman and her 7-year-old son. Later that day, the coup failed.

headline: Today in Small Business: Birth of a Food Fad
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Guilty as Sin
text: Bernie Gunther, the sardonic German detective in Philip Kerr’s historical crime novels, survived World War II with life, limb and integrity intact. But Bernie was only up against the entire Nazi high command. In PRAYER (Putnam, $26.95), Kerr introduces us to Gil Martins, an F.B.I. agent with the domestic terrorism unit in Houston who seems to be doing battle with Almighty God himself — or whoever is murdering prominent atheists in his name. As an ex-Catholic and wavering evangelical Christian, Martins is an avid consumer of what he calls “atheist porn” by writers like Richard Dawkins. And when his friend, the worldly Bishop Eamon Coogan, asks him to look into the curious deaths of some prominent atheists, he’s drawn into a mystery that defies both faith and logic.

headline: Patients and Fortitude
text: For the deadliest medical conditions, “cure” is a word even the most optimistic doctors try to resist. Oncologists have seen too often how a few metastatic cancer cells can endure every poison medicine throws at them, chemical or radioactive, only to lurk silently for years before staging a triumphant return. No wonder pharmaceutical companies prefer to ­describe their state-of-the-art cancer drugs in terms of five-year survival rates, with no promises about what happens in Year 6.

headline: Ford Recalls 1.4 Million Crossovers; G.M. Recalls 9,000 Sedans
text: In two actions, Ford is recalling nearly 1.4 million vehicles from the 2013-14 model years for an air bag malfunction and door handles that may not latch properly, the automaker said Friday. The air bag issue covers about 692,500 Escape and C-Max models, including 591,000 in the United States, about 78,000 in Canada and almost 19,700 in Mexico.

headline: When the Boss Calls After Hours
text: We shouldn’t laugh too hard about the agreement announced last month in France that sought to protect employees from after-hours texts and emails but confused a lot of people.

headline: Students and Money, in Their Own Words
text: The college-application essays that four students submitted this year on emerging stronger from economic challenges.

headline: Thrift Store Shame, Then Pride
text: Clare Connaughton, a high school student from Mineola, N.Y., reads from her college application essay about how shopping at thrift stores with her mother has gone from necessity to cherished pastime.

headline: Four Stand-Out College Essays About Money
text: Talking about money is hard. Writing well about yourself may be harder still. So trying to do both at once, as a teenager, while addressing complete strangers who control your future, would seem to be foolhardy.

headline: Beats Deal May Turn Heads in Private Equity
text: With Beats Electronics on Apple’s shopping list, private equity titans are in line to cash in.

headline: The Hamptons-in-Waiting
text: The great Hamptons divide in Hampton Bays is a scenic waterway that offers boats of all persuasions, from blue-collar Boston Whalers to yachts helmed by plutocrats, a fluid north-south link between the Atlantic Ocean and Great Peconic Bay.

headline: Luis Suárez Reaps the Benefits of Good Behavior
text: LIVERPOOL, England — Luis Suárez has made bad choices over the years in much the same way that an overaggressive taxi driver does: consistently and spectacularly.

headline: Memoirs
text: THE LAST PIRATE  A Father, His Son, and the Golden Age of Marijuana  By Tony Dokoupil  Doubleday, $26.95.

headline: A Mother in Absentia
text: In her wrenching new book, a memoir camouflaged as a novel, the prominent French writer Delphine de Vigan sets out to “write my mother,” tracing the life of the woman she calls Lucile Poirier from her early childhood just after World War II to her suicide in 2008 at the age of 61. Woven into this dark tale is the equally absorbing story of a daughter’s quest to research and imagine an elusive woman in order to get close to her, even though her very essence embodied distance: “For all of us, Lucile — her gentleness and her aggression — remains a mystery.” The difficulty de Vigan has in describing her mother, she confesses, “is not so far removed from the distress we felt as children and teenagers when she disappeared.” Which she did, dramatically, in a series of manic episodes, beginning in her early 30s.

headline: Inside the List
text: Life’s Too Short: Greg Iles’s thriller “Natchez Burning,” about racism and murder in the Jim Crow South, is his first new novel in five years. That’s a long time between books for a writer whose previous best sellers arrived as regularly as the Olympics, every two years or so. But Iles has a good excuse. In 2011, when he was putting the finishing touches on an earlier version of “Natchez Burning,” he was in a car crash that tore his aorta, left him in a coma for eight days and resulted in the loss of his right leg below the knee. The accident, along with the death of his father a year earlier, inspired him to have another go at his novel. “I realized that life was too short to pull any punches,” Iles told The Greenville News in South Carolina earlier this month. “I decided there was no room in this book for formula and fluff. The story had to be handled with appropriate gravitas. I had to deal with it not only the way it deserved but in a way that would make my father proud.” The reworked “Natchez Burning” — which enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 2 — clocks in at almost 800 pages, and is the first of a planned trilogy. Among other things, it explores the role of social elites in allowing racism to thrive. “The white lower middle class and lower class did not commit those acts of violence in a vacuum,” Iles told The Greenville News. “They had been given tacit approval by the upper levels of white society.” Nor, he said, is such racism restricted to the past. “Look at the scandal over the comments by the Clippers’ owner,” he said, referring to Donald Sterling. “The legacy of slavery is the greatest psychic wound in the American character. We still haven’t fully dealt with it, and I think it’ll take another lifetime to deal with it.”

headline: All Year Round
text: The seasons of the year tell a tale that resonates deep inside us. No matter where you start in the calendar, the passing of the seasons presents a beginning, middle and end that is hard-wired to our emotional metabolism. This applies equally to adults and children. A year is a drama in four acts. With a plot like that, you don’t even need a story.

headline: Grand Experiment
text: When you’re in middle school, you’re a mess. It’s a world of boys with wispy mustaches and bro-tanks revealing an absence of armpit hair. They make comments like “Damn, that girl is sexy” in cracked voices stuck in the transition between too high and too deep. It’s even worse for girls. The moment they get to middle school they start putting on makeup, and they put it on wrong. Growth spurts make them tall and goofy; acne arrives along with a period they are not sure how to manage. At that exact moment, they develop a dream — more of an obsession, really: to be popular. This is when the pain begins.

headline: Fantasy Island
text: A patrician New England clan decamps to their private island off Martha’s Vineyard for the summer. Of the dozen or so Sinclair family members in residence, “No one is a criminal. No one is an addict. No one is a failure.” Three lies, the first of many, provide an irresistible premise for this ticking bomb of a novel by E. Lockhart.

headline: An Update on 4 Students After a College Year
text: In response to a request from Ron Lieber, the Your Money columnist, asking high school seniors to share their college application essays that covered the subjects of money, class, working or the economy, 66 students last year submitted their work. We picked four to run online. Here’s an update on the students we featured in the column last May.

headline: Out-of-Body Experience
text: As far as I can recall — and it’s been a while — being a teenager is confusing. You have to wrestle with all sorts of ­issues related to your identity, and the biggest struggle is simply feeling comfortable in your skin. That’s why the premise of John Corey Whaley’s young adult novel “Noggin” — outlandish as it is — has such wonderful resonance. It takes the idea of being alienated from your own body and makes it literal.

headline: Heart of a Champion
text: Josh and JB are twins, double trouble on the basketball court, almost 13 years old. When we first encounter them in Kwame Alexander’s beautifully measured novel of life and lines, “The Crossover,” they are deep into a year when everything changes. The story is written in verse, but have no fear: Here, poetry is in service to the interior and exterior worlds of Josh, who plays forward to JB’s shooting guard. Besides being an inch taller and the one with dreadlocks to his neck, Josh is also the brother with the larger vocabulary — by the novel’s end, he will define 12 important words and terms.

headline: Slumber Party
text: I don’t know about yours, but my bedtime reading does not generally — ever, actually — include books about falling asleep. This should seem strange only to young children, for whom the provision of books about sleeping and not sleeping has captured a large slice of the picture book market. Dr. Robert Needlman, who revised and updated Dr. Benjamin Spock’s “Baby and Child Care,” once told me that the purpose of bedtime stories is to give the imagination a kind of way station between wakefulness and sleep that facilitates an easier slip into unconsciousness. (We were talking about young children, but I think this goes for all of us.) So books for bedtime, sure. But why about? Four new books, swaddled in practically identical shades of sleepy-time blue, attempt to make a case for the genre. Some do a better job than others.

headline: Little Sister, Big Plans
text: In literature, as in life, sisters are always compared with one another. There’s the smart one and the pretty one. The shy one and the one who gets invited everywhere. Older sisters are supposed to know better, while younger ones are usually up to something. Little sisters tend to feel left out. Who can forget Amy March tossing Jo’s manuscript into the fire because she wasn’t invited to the play? Or Ramona Quimby baking her doll into ­Beezus’ birthday cake?

headline: Seeing Reds
text: The year might be 1953, but in Megan Frazer Blakemore’s “The Spy Catchers of Maple Hill,” Hazel Kaplansky has to put up with the same baloney that many a contemporary fifth grader faces. She’s sick of dealing with mean-girl bullies and getting stuck playing the triangle in music class. The brainy and impulsive girl thinks that if she exposes the new town gravedigger as a Communist, everyone from her inattentive parents to Senator McCarthy himself will recognize her as the heroine she’s meant to be.

headline: Collapse of Ad Giants’ Merger Deals Blow to Moelis
text: When Moelis & Company began wooing prospective investors for its initial public offering earlier this year, one of its main talking points was its presence on big deals.

headline: While the Battle Rages On
text: The experiences of children evacuated from London to rural England during the Blitz are familiar to fiction readers, thanks in large part to C. S. Lewis’s Narnia chronicles and, more recently, Michelle Magorian’s “Good Night, Mr. Tom.” Less well known is the story of the thousands of children who were sent across the ocean to live with American families. L. M. Elliott brings these reluctant immigrants to our attention in “Across a War-Tossed Sea,” an engaging but uneven tale of two English brothers, Charles and Wesley, who find themselves dispatched to a Virginia farm in 1943.

headline: Where There’s Smoke
text: Listen! Long have we known of the dangers of carbon emissions. But even those of us who believe human activity is forever damaging the climate find it difficult to change our everyday behavior, because the real cost of a short drive to the grocery store just doesn’t register.

headline: One Morning in June
text: On the morning of May 5, 1944, 146 Allied generals, admirals, officers and staff members filed past military policemen into the chilly auditorium of St. Paul’s School in London. German bombs had blown out 700 of the school’s windows; its students had been evacuated to the countryside. The military men sat on hard benches with overcoats buttoned, blankets on laps. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, standing before a 30-foot-wide plaster relief map of the coast of Normandy, announced that if anyone saw a problem with the plan the group was about to hear, he should speak up. “I have no sympathy with anyone,” he said, “whatever his station, who will not brook criticism.” Then the “wiry, elfin” British Gen. Bernard L. Montgomery began, “in his reedy voice, each word as sharply creased as his trousers,” to describe the invasion intended to mortally wound Hitler’s Third Reich.

headline: What It Means When Google ‘Verifies’ an App
text: Q. When Google “verifies” apps during installation on an Android device, what is it doing?

headline: Russia Celebrates Victory Day
text: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia traveled from Moscow to Sevastopol on Friday to commemorate Victory Day, in the process showcasing his nation’s military might.

headline: The College Admissions Essay: My Story
text: Ron Lieber writes the Your Money column for The Times. “The Opposite of Spoiled,” his book about parents, children and money, will be published in February.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Palo Alto’
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Palo Alto.”

headline: Rhetoric About Women’s Issues Outpaces Political Progress
text: At the close of 2012, it seemed that the women’s movement in India would never be the same.

headline: Michael Jackson Returns
text: Ben Ratliff and Jon Pareles discuss “Xscape,” the new album of previously unreleased demos by Michael Jackson.

headline: FedEx’s Price Rise Is a Blessing in Disguise for Amazon
text: No. 1 on the list of chores the Internet has done away with: dragging yourself to the store to stock up on unwieldy items and carting them home. Many e-commerce companies — led by Amazon.com and the sites it owns, like Diapers.com and Soap.com — have made it easy to order even items like toilet paper and diapers without paying a cent for shipping.

headline: A Proposed Merger Brings Out the Thoughtful Side of Congress
text: Lawmakers on the hill, usually eager to score points and yell about imaginary scandals, have been surprisingly thoughtful about Comcast’s $45 billion acquisition of Time Warner Cable, a pressing antitrust issue.

headline: At Evangelical Colleges, Leadership Is Often the Family Business
text: During the past school year, several leading American universities, including Yale, Princeton, Dartmouth and Carnegie-Mellon, welcomed new presidents. These men were leading scholars, and they were experienced administrators; in some cases, they held degrees from the universities they now lead. And none of them — not one — inherited the job from his father or mother.

headline: Grief Lessons
text: When a friend in high school told me “The Catcher in the Rye” was the funniest book he’d ever read, I picked up a copy — and sobbed my way through it. To my friend, Holden Caulfield was a hilarious smart aleck; to me, he was a bereft sibling, falling apart after his younger brother’s death.

headline: That Amherst Belle
text: In the daily lives of most American children today, poetry has gone missing. Almost entirely absent from elementary school curriculums, rarely chosen as bedtime reading by parents, poetry — formerly a joyful accouterment of youth, an inexhaustible gift — seems forgotten. Yet poetry and children belong together. And who, among the great American poets, could be more appropriate for childhood than Emily Dickinson?

headline: Times Minute | Costa Concordia’s End
text: The next chapter in the Costa Concordia tragedy. Also on the Minute, Putin’s flamboyant Victory Day parade and a new comedy, “Neighbors,” opens this weekend.

headline: Rangers’ St. Louis Decides to Play Game 5
text: PITTSBURGH — Rangers forward Martin St. Louis will play Game 5 against the Pittsburgh Penguins on Friday night, a day after his mother died suddenly of a heart attack.

headline: Nothing You Say Will Make Me Pay $375 for a Sandal. But Keep Talking.
text: I fell hard for a French shoe this week: suede sandals, two-tone black and tan. They would have served me well because they’d go with everything. There was no price tag on them, which generally translates to: “What do you care? You’re not some loser who has to work for a living.”

headline: Times Minute | Costa Concordia’s End
text: In the Video

headline: Your Building on an Index Card
text: Every new condo or co-op built in New York — from a modest two-family semidetached house upstate to a shiny Manhattan tower with $90-million penthouses — begins its gestation in the same unlikely place: a shabby office near Wall Street where a handful of beleaguered state employees toil under a deluge of paper, date stamp machines and other vestiges of outdated technology.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Chef’
text: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews “Chef.”

headline: Paperback Row
text: ODDS AGAINST TOMORROW,  by Nathaniel Rich. (Picador, $16.) In Rich’s apocalyptic second novel, an earthquake has leveled Seattle and a brilliant, neurotic mathematician named Mitchell Zukor spends his days calculating worst-case scenarios for a shadowy consulting firm that indemnifies corporations against potential disasters. Mitchell suffers from visions of nuclear fallout and modern black plagues, but his prognostications acquire near-mythic status after a storm engulfs New York City.

headline: A Plan Built on Assumptions
text: This past week, on a day when fast-food workers gathered in front of a McDonald’s in downtown Manhattan to announce that they would strike again on May 15 to demand higher wages, clergy members from various denominations around New York joined hundreds of laborers for a service and pray-in at Riverside Church, calling on state legislators to allow cities to set their own minimum wage. The economic realities of life in New York City so often seem to require holy intervention. According to the Fiscal Policy Institute, a research group, more than 1.25 million residents, 37 percent of all workers living in the city, make less than $15 an hour. More than half of workers who live in the Bronx subsist in this category; in Brooklyn, which has one of the most competitive housing markets in the country, the figure is 41 percent.

headline: When the Clowns Came In, the Rangers Moved Out
text: Rangers fans, it could be worse.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: JAMES MADISON: A Life Reconsidered,  by Lynne Cheney. (Viking, $36.) Cheney’s lucidly written biography clearly, and at times dramatically, brings to life the character and personality of America’s fourth president.

headline: A Synthetic Biology Conference Lures an Intriguing Audience
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — When does a scientific conference warrant the attention of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Department of Homeland Security? When the topic is synthetic biology.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Neighbors’
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Neighbors.”

text: This week, Jyoti Thottam discusses Ramachandra Guha’s “Gandhi Before India”; Anand Giridharadas talks about “The True American”; Parul Sehgal and John Williams on the week’s literary news; Sarah Harrison Smith discusses this week’s Children’s Books section; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Michael Jackson Returns, at Least on Record
text: This week on Popcast: Michael Jackson is still alive — on “Xscape,” the latest posthumous episode in a deal between the Jackson estate and Sony Records reportedly worth $250 million.

headline: Gender in de Blasio’s Cabinet
text: Like no mayor before him, Bill de Blasio has tapped women to serve in key roles in his administration. Here is a breakdown of the mayor’s appointments to top positions so far, compared with the administrations of his three predecessors in the first year of their terms.

headline: The Women of New York’s City Hall
text: With Manhattan still cloaked in early-morning darkness, New York City’s new sanitation commissioner stepped into a semicircle of 40 men holding brooms and dustpans as they finished roll call and prepared to clean the streets of the Village.

headline: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
text: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

headline: A Catholic Dilemma
text: Before I address myself to Cardinal Walter Kasper’s latest remarks on how he thinks Roman Catholicism might change its approach to second marriages and the sacraments, I want to engage with Philip Lawler’s thoughtful responses to some of the issues raised in my column and posts on the possibility of an alteration to Catholic teaching on this front.

headline: Weekend Wheels Calendar
text: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture this weekend.

headline: NPR Picks a New Leader With Lots of Commercial Experience
text: NPR has turned to an unlikely figure from the private sector, Jarl Mohn, who earlier in his career founded the E! cable channel, to become its new chief executive, the organization announced on Friday.

text: As soon as Yeong Park walked into the cellphone store in Flushing, the woman at the counter waved him off.

text: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on “Neighbors,” “Palo Alto” and “Chef.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: Memories of the Paradise Garage, From Those Who Danced There
text: The Paradise Garage crashed onto New York’s nightlife scene like a tidal wave. When it opened in 1977, the dance club, housed in a former parking garage on 84 Varick Street, offered a counterpoint to its glitzier uptown cousin, Studio 54, where the rich and fabulous went to be seen. The Garage, which did not sell alcohol and wasn’t open to the general public, was strictly about the music. For a decade, until the club’s closing in 1987, it was a utopia for New York’s increasingly liberated black and Latino L.G.B.T. communities, who went there to dance until sunrise (and often beyond) to the cutting-edge sounds of disco, soul, funk, R&B, new wave and an emerging genre that would eventually be known as house music.

headline: Hamster Wheels, Sequins and, Yes, a Lot of Singing
text: COPENHAGEN — The crowd of roughly 10,000 fans cheered, and the lights glowed electric blue as a woman in a bright white gown introduced the next act in the giant auditorium here. “Please give it up now for Albania!” she shouted.

headline: Ruling Could Escalate Florida’s Status as Haven for Debtors
text: A MULTIMILLION-DOLLAR dispute between a politically connected Florida billionaire and the brother-in-law of the king of Jordan over a debt involving oil shipped during the Iraq war might seem irrelevant to the lives of ordinary citizens.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘Gandhi Before India’
text: This week, Jyoti Thottam, Anand Giridharadas and Sarah Harrison Smith.

headline: BMW to Expand U.S. Plant in Push for Lighter, More Fuel-Efficient Cars
text: FRANKFURT — BMW said on Friday that it would invest $200 million and double its work force at a factory in Washington State that makes carbon fibers as the company moves to use more of the lightweight material in cars and meet demand for a new electric vehicle.

headline: The Human Factor in Merger Collapse
text: The combination of Publicis and Omnicom looked great on paper, but its idea was sorely misjudged.

headline: Ukrainian Forces Attack Militant-Held Police Station
text: MARIUPOL, Ukraine — Ukrainian security forces in armored vehicles attacked a police station here on Friday, reducing the building to smoldering rubble and killing at least seven people, according to residents who say they witnessed the assault.

headline: Update on the Baby Red-Tailed Hawks at N.Y.U.
text: In a nest overlooking Washington Square Park, two juvenile red-tailed hawks are beginning to poke their heads above the messy tangle of brown branches.

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: A Regiment Redeemed
text: At midday on Sunday, May 8, 1864, two brigades of the Second Division of the 20th Corps — part of Maj. Gen. William T. Sherman’s Union army group — formed a line of battle in a clearing in north Georgia. It was the fourth day of a campaign that would culminate four months later with the capture of Atlanta. The division commander, Brig. Gen. John W. Geary, rode to the front of the line and addressed the soldiers. He ordered them to take the mountain looming ahead of them, which was reportedly held by a couple of regiments of Confederate cavalry. “If you take the hill,” Geary closed, “it will be a feather in your cap.”

headline: In Rwanda, Finding Echoes of Germany
text: I MOVED to Nairobi last year for a challenge and to try something new. I thought that reporting from all over East Africa would be nothing like my previous assignment covering Central Europe from Berlin and I was excited to leave behind the stolid German Finance Ministry and embark on bumpy jeep rides through lush jungles and desert dunes.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 34
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Upper West Side Brownstone With Modern Twists
text: A cleverly conceived hybrid townhouse — the pale front is a historically correct brownstone and the back a bold architectural grid of glass and steel — on a classic Upper West Side block near the American Museum of Natural History is poised to enter the market at $12 million. The annual taxes on the 19-foot-wide, circa-1900 property at 121 West 81st Street, between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues, are $63,679.

headline: The National Pastime, Amid a National Crisis
text: This is one of the earliest photographs ever taken of a baseball game, and it happened by accident. The photographer, Henry P. Moore, of Concord, N.H., was focusing on the well-uniformed Union soldiers of the 48th New York State Volunteer Infantry, but he also captured their baseball-playing comrades in the background.

headline: Bookshelf: Garden Friends and Foes
text: New picture books include “Superworm” by Julia Donaldson.

headline: Does College Pay?
text: Over time, a large and growing majority of incoming freshmen have ranked making more money as a “very important” reason for going to college, as the Times columnist David Brooks mentioned in a recent column.

headline: Clip: ‘Godzilla’
text: A scene from the 2014 film.

headline: Bookshelf: Oh, Behave!
text: New picture books include “Here Comes Destructosaurus” by Aaron Reynolds.

headline: 7 Republicans Named to Panel Investigating Attack in Benghazi
text: WASHINGTON — House Speaker John A. Boehner on Friday appointed seven Republicans to the 12-person committee tasked with continuing investigations into the 2012 attack that killed four Americans in Benghazi, Libya. The move forced Democratic lawmakers to struggle to overcome internal disagreements over how to handle the latest inquiry and whether or not to appoint any of their own members to the new committee.

headline: Face-Lift? Well, You Still Look Like Hell
text: After 60 years of crushing, fighting and roaring, Godzilla shows no signs of stopping. The oversize lizard that has attracted generations of fans returns Friday in a film that harks back to the creature’s roots. The filmmakers behind the latest iteration mainly used the 1954 original, from Toho Studios, as a template for fleshing out the monster’s looks and the movie’s narrative.

headline: Apple’s Midlife Crisis
text: Apple is showing another symptom of a midlife crisis.

headline: In Silicon Valley, Morgan Stanley Reigns
text: The Wall Street analyst-turned-blogger Henry Blodget called it “a disaster.” The Wall Street Journal labeled it a “botched offering.” And after Facebook’s much-criticized initial public offering in May 2012, Morgan Stanley’s vaunted technology investment banking team, the lead underwriter on the deal, looked as if it were down for the count.

headline: Dishes for Digestive Health
text: I’ve long been aware of the term “probiotics” (is there anybody who watches television who hasn’t seen Jamie Lee Curtis touting them in those old ads for Activia yogurt?), the beneficial microbes in our guts, and also in fermented foods like miso and kimchi, that some experts believe play a significant role in gut health and in keeping our immune system robust. But I’d never heard the word “prebiotics” until I attended a talk by the Stanford nutritionist Jo Ann Hattner, who has written (with Susan Anderes) an interesting guide called “Gut Insight: Probiotics and Prebiotics for Digestive Health and Well-Being.”

headline: With Gridlock Comes Piecemeal Tax Legislation
text: Substantive tax legislation is nowhere to be seen. The campaign to overhaul the tax code is on hold, despite a couple of years of concerted effort by Representative Dave Camp, the outgoing chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, and Senator Max Baucus, who left his post as chairman of the Senate Finance Committee to become the United States Ambassador to China.

As the co-founder, with Matthew Slotover, of both Frieze New York and the original Frieze London, Sharp has the inside scoop on what the more than 190 leading galleries have brought to town and what other sights, sounds and tastes await. Here, her tips:

text: The note began simply. “Thank you for the article you wrote. The boy you mentioned is my son, Cooper Stock.”

headline: Nets Need More Than Good Game Plan to Beat the Heat
text: After the Miami Heat blew them out of Game 1, the Brooklyn Nets rebounded with a focused, but ill-fated, performance in Game 2 on Thursday night. As has been the case many times, even the right game plan, executed well, was not enough to beat a team as good as the Heat, the two-time defending N.B.A. champions.

headline: The Paradox of Art as Work
text: There are few modern relationships as fraught as the one between art and money. Are they mortal enemies, secret lovers or perfect soul mates? Is the bond between them a source of pride or shame, a marriage of convenience or something tawdrier?

headline: The Big Wigs of Broadway
text: Getting to the roots of a hair-raising theater season.

headline: After Narcs and Satan, Bad Times
text: For a brief moment, between the ascension of Francis Ford Coppola and that of Steven Spielberg, Hollywood’s hottest young director was William Friedkin. The one-two punch of “The French Connection” (1971) and “The Exorcist” (1973) made the man nicknamed Hurricane Billy a gale-force talent. The successive failures of “Sorcerer” (1977), “The Brink’s Job” (1978) and “Cruising” (1980) sent Hurricane Billy out to sea.

headline: Green Garlic Stirs a Pot of Chicken Soup
text: To me and many cooks I know, the appearance of green garlic shoots at the market is the real spring harbinger on the East Coast. Along with asparagus, fava beans and peas, wild fiddlehead ferns and ramps, green garlic’s arrival means the earth has finally consented to give us something hopeful and verdant while we await summer’s bounty.

headline: How to | Shop an Antiques Market
text: T’s European editor, Rita Konig, brings us to Spitalfields, one of her favorite spots to shop for cookware, linens and friendly shopkeepers.

headline: Film Stars, but With an Asterisk
text: TORONTO — Camels loitered by the curb, but the sheikh arrived by sedan.

headline: Last Stop, Last Drop: Metro-North Bar Cars Chug Into History
text: There are those who sip discreetly on subway trains, reaching for the paper bags in their coat pockets, or pull flasks from their knapsacks in the darkened back corners of a city bus.

headline: Piketty’s Arguments Still Hold Up, After Taxes
text: One critique of Thomas Piketty’s influential new book on wealth accumulation through the ages is that his analysis is solely of market incomes and wealth. He largely ignores systems of taxes and transfers and the extent to which they offset inequality.

headline: Season for a ’Do That’s Special
text: Gender bending, whether playful or politically pointed, or both, is the theme of the IFC Center’s Summer of Drag series, which leads off Monday with Richard Benner’s 1977 cult favorite, “Outrageous!” Its protagonist, Robin, played by the Canadian drag star Craig Russell, who died in 1990, is persuaded by his schizophrenic roommate to parlay his passion for impersonating legendary female stars into a career as an entertainer.

headline: Supersize Motor Homes Can Be a Good Way to Go, or Stay
text: NAPLES, Fla. — Suzi and Edmund Kuehn parked their 41-foot motor home in Flint, Mich., on a Saturday night four years ago. The next morning, Ms. Kuehn’s ex-husband called from Dallas and told her their 31-year-old son, Leslie, who had been fighting plasma cell leukemia, had died.

headline: Shooting in the Bronx Leaves 2 Men Dead, Police Say
text: Two men were shot and killed in the Bronx early Friday morning, according to the police. Both victims, who have yet to be identified, were found in a parked car on Rombouts Avenue.

headline: Three’s a Trend | They’ve Got Legs, They Know How to Use Them
text: An art fair is first and foremost a playground for the senses, but for any visitor pacing Frieze New York’s 1500-foot-long SO-IL-designed tent erected on Randall’s Island today — or any gallerist standing by to explain their inscrutable wares — these long days are as much about lower-body stamina as they are about the eyes or mind. A trio of works found around the fair render legs — the pivots on which all this weekend’s deals depend — as art. At Galerie Jocelyn Wolff, Guillaume Leblon’s pair of ceramic appendages truncated at the knee are poised for action, existentially tensed upon a gnarled, painted clay blanket. Adam McEwen’s anatomical gypsum sculptures peeking out of the wall at the Modern Institute look more like hunting trophies; the feet are tucked into bright plastic buckets. And the showstopping, kinetic piece by Jonathan Monk at Galleri Nicolai Wallner takes a page from the Rockettes with candy-colored, mechanized gams that kick for the pleasure of those who choose to cool their heels there.

headline: A Working Vacation on an Umbrian Farm
text: Pride makes fools of us all. Three days into my stint as a farmer at Monestevole, a 98-acre farm nestled atop a hill in Umbria, I was flooded with feelings of smug accomplishment. I was watering the patch of artichoke and tomato seedlings that I’d painstakingly planted the day before, when a farmhand named Brad walked by with a cow. I wanted to get Brad to acknowledge my efforts, but my Italian is limited to ordering and waxing enthusiastic about eggplant Parmesan.

headline: Echoes of History at a Tuscan Estate
text: Iris Origo was a 22-year-old newlywed Anglo-American heiress — as rich, brilliant and innocent as a Henry James heroine — when she and her husband, an Italian nobleman, decided to buy La Foce. “Treeless and shrubless but for some tufts of broom,” Origo wrote in October 1923 of her first view of the rundown 3,500-acre estate southeast of Siena; it was “a lunar landscape, pale and inhuman.”

headline: Camping in the Caribbean: A Mother-Daughter Adventure
text: On our second date, the man who later became my husband asked me to promise that I would never make him get on a boat. At some point in his 30s, his inner ear ceased to be his friend, and now he was prone to seasickness so bad that he once became nauseated in a rowboat floating on a lake in Switzerland.

headline: Deep Into the Dream World of Kyrgyzstan
text: This was the scene at Pobeda Square in Bishkek, the capital city of Kyrgyzstan. Ahead: a desert of concrete, empty but for a patient queue of newlyweds waiting to have their photo taken next to a guttering eternal flame. Women trilled for joy as doves flapped skyward from wicker cages. In a corner, some wag did handbrake doughnuts in a rust-bucket Mercedes.

headline: Friday Night Music: Sarah Jarosz at Mass Moca
text: I visited the art space for the first time a few weeks ago, and it made me think of this atmospheric performance:

headline: Obama, Aggravated by Gridlock, Stresses Results in Midterms
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — On a fund-raising trip where President Obama acknowledged at one stop that the country was not going “to go where we need to go” despite his many executive actions, he was back in sales mode on Friday before returning to still-gridlocked Washington.

headline: In Stronghold, a Gandhi Finds the Reception Is More Skeptical than Worshipful
text: AMETHI, India — Naimesh Prasad Pandey, a 60-year-old farmer, can testify to the generations of love that people here have reserved for the Gandhi family.

headline: U.K. Finds Way Out of Impasse on Ties to E.U.
text: LONDON — If he wins re-election next year, Prime Minister David Cameron has said he plans to renegotiate British ties to the European Union, then hold a referendum in 2017 on whether to stay in the bloc. But those plans hit a roadblock when Mr. Cameron called for a rewrite of the Union’s governing treaty — a tricky political process many other European nations want to avoid.

headline: Big Ticket | A Sky-High Retreat for $31.67 Million
text: Another of the popular three-bedroom aeries at One57, this one on the 62nd floor of the Extell Development Company’s 90-story Midtown tower, sold for $31,671,075 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Objects From the Lively Past
text: As an antiques dealer, David Duncan is usually focused on the past. But 10 years ago, he looked into the future and concluded the only way to guarantee his survival as a Manhattan shopkeeper was to own his own building.

headline: A Drink as Complicated as Motherhood
text: On Sunday, mothers will be celebrated with flowers, or with breakfast in bed. On Monday, most will return to jobs where they are likely to be paid less than their male colleagues — precisely because they are mothers. Studies have repeatedly shown that women lose career opportunities and earnings after they have babies (even though fatherhood increases men’s earnings.)

headline: Bill Nunn, Scout Who Shaped Steelers’ Super Bowl Teams, Dies at 89
text: Bill Nunn, a scout for the Pittsburgh Steelers whose deep knowledge of football programs at historically black colleges helped many overlooked players find their way to the Steelers and to stardom as part of the team’s dynasty in the 1970s, died on Tuesday in Pittsburgh. He was 89.

headline: Taking a Spin: A Senate Survivor in Alaska
text: It is Friday again, which means it’s time to spin Leo’s Senate wheels: our weekly demonstration of the considerable uncertainty that remains six months away from the election.

headline: Professors Are Prejudiced, Too
text: IN the world of higher education, we professors like to believe that we are free from the racial and gender biases that afflict so many other people in society. But is this self-conception accurate?

headline: When ‘Jet’ Mattered
text: As a grade school student in the late 1950s, I whiled away many Saturday mornings waiting to have my hair cut at Joseah’s Barbershop in Chester, Pa., the once-muscular factory town south of Philadelphia where I grew up. It is unremarkable today to see African-Americans and whites sitting side-by-side in hair salons. But in the age of American apartheid — even in the North — beauty and hair-care services were segregated by race.

headline: Weekend Reading: 5 Questions for Alibaba’s I.P.O.
text: DealBook is attempting to fill in the gaps of Alibaba’s eagerly anticipated filing for a stock listing in the United States.

headline: They’re Stompin’ on Avenue B
text: Squashed into a sliver of an Alphabet City bar, patrons clapped into each other’s chests and tapped their toes long after midnight. Movement in any direction was futile.

headline: Clintons to Meet With Foundation’s Big Donors Next Month
text: The most generous donors to the Bill, Hillary & Chelsea Clinton Foundation will convene on June 6 at the Goldman Sachs headquarters in Lower Manhattan for a daylong event to discuss the family’s philanthropy with the Clintons themselves.

headline: Ex-Leader of Citigroup and Time Warner Is Appointed to Steer Clippers
text: As the N.B.A. pushes forward with its effort to strip Donald Sterling of his ownership of the Los Angeles Clippers, Commissioner Adam Silver on Friday installed Richard D. Parsons, the former chairman of Citigroup and the former chief executive of Time Warner, as the interim chief executive of the Clippers.

headline: A Video Lesson in Antiques Market Shopping
text: T’s European editor Rita Konig visits Spitalfields Antiques Market in London, her go-to shopping destination for vintage kitchenalia and home goods that happen to be affordable. “You find these old things, and I think that really adds to your home rather than everything being brand new,” she says. While there, she finds items like linen pillowcases and a wool blanket, chats with the shopkeepers she has gotten to know on a first-name basis and shares her tips for shopping antiques markets.

headline: Every Social Season Has Its Vortex
text: Bob Colacello has a saying, whenever he is asked about his sexuality: “I believe in going out, not coming out.” And that is just what the Vanity Fair special correspondent and one of the city’s most photographed party animals did Wednesday night.

headline: The Gun Report: May 9, 2014
text: • Following last week’s open-carry demonstration at a Jack in the Box restaurant in Fort Worth, Tex., the chain has indicated that it will enforce its policy prohibiting firearms in any of its corporate-owned stores, which includes the Fort Worth location. “The presence of guns inside a restaurant could create an uncomfortable situation for our guests and employees and lead to unintended consequences,” Brian Luscomb, the company’s vice president of corporate communications, said in a statement.

headline: Raising a Style Icon
text: It was as if Twitter had slipped into a 1968 time warp, and Sharon Tate, the star-crossed ingénue of the flower-child era, was suddenly the hot new thing in Hollywood.

headline: Ask Well: Should I Get a Polio Booster?
text: The World Health Organization has declared polio a global health emergency. The Times’s Donald G. McNeil Jr. answers readers’ questions about the vaccine.

headline: A New Home for New York Theater Ballet
text: The New York Theater Ballet, a small but inventive and often feisty company that was told last September it would soon have to leave its headquarters for the last 34 years because the building was going to be razed, said on Friday it had found a new home. Starting in September, the company will move its offices and its training arm, the Ballet School NY, to St. Mark’s Church in-the-Bowery, on East 10th Street. The company’s current office and studio space is at the parish house of the Madison Avenue Baptist Church, on East 31st Street, and though it was originally told that it had to leave by Sept. 30 last year, the company was given a reprieve while it sought a new space.

headline: Scallops With Sorrel Butter
text: Melissa Clark pan-sears sweet sea scallops and nestles them in a bright, grassy sauce of fresh sorrel and garlic.

headline: Taking Advantage of Sorrel’s Brief Life
text: I’m not much of a gardener, but when tiny green sorrel shoots start inching up from the pots on my deck every spring, I feel an undue sense of accomplishment. That this perennial herb is weedlike and nearly impossible to kill doesn’t matter. I take pride in its vigor. And then I gleefully eat it up.

headline: Hairy Days Onstage
text: If ever there were a season to begin handing out Tony Awards for best wig, it’s this one. There’s big hair, like the Tina Turner meets My Little Pony explosion in “Hedwig and the Angry Inch” (with its showstopping “Wig in a Box” number). But there are also scores of modest but evocative hairstyles, like the frumpy comb-over worn by a loan shark in “Rocky.”

headline: A Battery Warranty With a Warning

headline: The Time of the Tummy
text: “Seven Nation Army” by the White Stripes was pulsating through the dimly lit Ab Attack class at Crunch gym near Union Square on a recent morning. Jewlie Williams, 25, a fashion stylist who lives in the East Village, was in front of the packed room, wearing a tank top and leggings and following the instructor in a 30-minute nonstop sequence of standing crunches with high knees, planks and toe touches with legs raised: all exercises focused on developing the muscles of the midsection.

headline: Globetrotting Ambitions, With a Raw Bar
text: In an era of market-tested menus and copycat cuisines, there’s usually a warm welcome awaiting any restaurant that’s willing to branch out.

headline: For the Love of Being ‘Liked’
text: Walking through an airport newsstand this year, I noticed a novelty. The covers of Inc., Fast Company and Time all had female executives on the covers: Sara Blakely, Angela Ahrendts and Janet L. Yellen. I quickly snapped a photo and sent out a tweet to my modest list of followers: “Women on the cover. Not just for girlie magazines anymore.”

headline: New Twists in Turning Hot Air Into Horsepower
text: In the half-century since it first appeared under the hood of production cars, the turbocharger has gone from a silver-bullet amplifier of horsepower to a device so widely used it seems on its way to becoming a fixture of every new model.

headline: How Powerful? Go Figure
