headline: Owners Who Are Happy When the Engine Doesn’t Start
text: It started at the 2014 Portland Auto Show in Oregon with Dave Barthmuss of General Motors’ West Coast communications office mentioning offhandedly, yet with definite pride, that he had bought a Chevy Volt early last summer — and nine months later, he was still on the first tank of gas.

headline: League Races in European Soccer
text: European soccer brings out its best silverware every May, but this year — because of the World Cup and a few impressive performances — the table has been set early. Several top leagues have crowned their champions, and the rest will do so in the next week before they send their best players home to pack for Brazil. Here’s a look at the status of the title races in Europe’s big-five leagues:

headline: The House of D.I.Y.
text: The drag balls of Upper Manhattan are known for their celebrations of elegance, realness and high-end designers. In Brooklyn they do things a little differently, as Stephanie Keith found out when she shot the second annual Mr(s) Williamsburg competition, a nine-week extravaganza where anything goes. “Brooklyn is very D.I.Y.,” Ms. Keith said. “You don’t have to look like a girl to compete. These are people with a graduate degree from SUNY Purchase who are already performance artists. They’re taking drag to a new place it’s never been before.”

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: Still Feeding the Herd
text: The long, hard winter at last recedes, the heart springs up, and the mouth hungers for the foods of summer. Burger, anyone?

headline: Week in Pictures for May 9
text: A slide show of photographs of the past week in New York City and the region includes the unveiling of the mayor’s housing plan, the exoneration of three men convicted of murder, and the aviary at the Queens Zoo.

headline: Nicolas Ghesquière’s Designs in Monte Carlo, Charles James’s Return and the Brooklynization of Dior
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Ike? They Liked
text: Imagine a time when White House photographers not only had access to the president, but also honored his skills with a camera.

headline: On South Shore, the Lure of the Outdoors
text: In many places, waterfront dining conjures images of beachfront spots and vast expanses of water. On Long Island it often means a deck on a canal, as it does at Reel in East Rockaway.

headline: Water, Flour, Yeast and Salt: A Love Story
text: If there is such a thing as a genius of dough making — and why shouldn’t there be? — David DiBari would certainly seem to qualify.

headline: In the Air | Tribal Beauty
text: The glories of African design, from vibrant patterned prints to regal embellishment, are yet again influencing design, art and fashion.

headline: Cellist With a Feel for the Contemporary
text: The cellist Jay Campbell is part of a generation of young musicians with a fresh center of gravity in its repertory. At this point in Mr. Campbell’s career — he is a master’s student at the Juilliard School — he should, by all traditional rights, be focusing on Beethoven, Brahms and the like, with perhaps a polite nod here and there to modern and contemporary music.

headline: Orchestra Welcomes a Longtime Collaborator
text: Few doubt the skill and experience of the eminent maestro Bernard Haitink, celebrating the 60th anniversary of his conducting debut this season. But there is evidently some question about his consistency.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Russia and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Russia, Central African Republic, Syria and South Africa.

headline: Obama Delivers Energy Speech at Walmart
text: President Obama wrapped up a week promoting energy policy at a Walmart in Mountain View, Calif. The speech focused on energy efficiency and renewable energy initiatives.

headline: Seems Like a Nice Guy. So What if He’s Dead?
text: You probably shouldn’t draw conclusions about a country’s national character from how it approaches zombie stories. But it’s interesting to note that while the American hit “The Walking Dead” is about sheer survival, the British show “In the Flesh” is about acceptance and reconciliation, themes it shares with the French series “Les Revenants.” In America, zombies just want to chow down on you; in Europe, they want to get reacquainted with you and work through all your unresolved issues.

headline: Paul Diverges From His Party Over Voter ID
text: MEMPHIS — Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky broke Friday with fellow Republicans who have pushed for stricter voting laws as a way to crack down on fraud at the polls, saying that the focus on such measures alienates and insults African-Americans and hurts the party.

headline: Colorado Lawmaker to Accept Donations in Bitcoin
text: Jared Polis may be the first politician to accept campaign donations in Bitcoin.

headline: Meteorite Falls on Car, Car Becomes Artwork
text: In 1992 in Peekskill, N.Y., a 4.4-billion-year-old, 26-pound asteroid chunk fell on a 1980 Chevy Malibu. The car soon became famous in meteorite-collecting circles (yes, they exist) and has since traveled all around the world. It will go on view tomorrow for the first time in a fine-art context, at Mark Hagen’s self-curated show at Marlborough Chelsea, “Guest Star,” a title that slyly evokes both the rock that did the damage and to Hagen’s own status in New York (the Los Angeles-based artist is unrepresented in the city). “I love the fact that it’s a man-made object that’s been sculpted by alien hands,” Hagen says of the car. “I believe in alien life.”

headline: Philip Roth Says He Has Given His Last Public Reading
text: Philip Roth made headlines a year and a half ago with the announcement that he had stopped writing fiction.

headline: Fairy Tale Romances, Real and Staged
text: Kiko Zeng and Eric Cheng’s courtship plays out like something out of a storybook. It is love at first sight. Their first touch is a shy, slow-motion handshake, with neither wanting to let go, until friends pull them apart.

headline: In a Mosh Pit, or Maybe a Revolution
text: One by one, they arrived: nine people armed with sticks and facing off as if for a rumble. Rather than striking one another, though, they struck the cymbals on the four drum kits arrayed on the stage and kept striking them. Maud Le Pladec’s “Democracy” started not with one bang but with many.

headline: For Better Credit Score, Max Out Payments, Not the Card
text: CREDIT reports, which track your management of credit cards and loans, increasingly include more details about when and how you pay your debts over time. Whether that extra information will eventually have a broad impact on your credit scores — the three-digit numbers that summarize your credit report and are used by lenders to size you up — remains to be seen.

headline: Letting an Ensemble Complete Him
text: Christian aTunde Adjuah has a firm, cold flash of a trumpet sound, like the glint off a brandished switchblade. For what seems like the entirety of his playing career, since his anointed adolescence in New Orleans, he has deployed that sound with an effortful assurance: rallying support with it, building bands around it, making it the base currency of his brisk economy of style.

headline: Pass the Bong, and Tune Up the Berlioz
text: When the Colorado Symphony announced recently that it would hold a series of bring-your-own-marijuana fund-raisers, called “Classically Cannabis: The High Note Series,” sponsored by the state’s newly legal cannabis industry, the orchestra got laughs on late-night talk shows and was featured in publications that rarely cover classical music, including High Times.

headline: Big Opera’s Den Mother Moves On
text: At the end of a long week of work one recent Friday, Sarah Billinghurst worked some more.

headline: His Psyche Lurks Inside His Scripts
text: Three books sit on a side table at John Logan’s hotel suite on Central Park South: Mark Harris’s “Pictures at a Revolution: Five Movies and the Birth of the New Hollywood,” a history of the best picture nominees at the 1968 Oscars; a collection of English Romantic poetry; and a novelization from the 1984-96 TV series “Murder, She Wrote.” Together, they represent the breadth of this dramatist’s interests.

headline: Swamp Pop and Old Faves in the Countryside
text: The British singer Lily Allen was at her home in the English countryside, baking a carrot cake, complete with marzipan carrots. “This is like my third one with these particular carrots, and I’ve kind of got it down,” she said by telephone. “I’m quite pleased.” She posted a photo of the perfectly turned-out cake, frosted and dusted with powdered sugar, on her Instagram account, with the hashtag Sheezus, the name of her new album. For Ms. Allen, 29, domestic bliss can align with pop stardom.

headline: Top of the Line
text: At American Ballet Theater, where international stars zip on and off the stage like point shoes on a conveyor belt, there is gratification in knowing your corps de ballet. Along with the soloists, these dancers constitute the heart of the company, which opens its spring season Monday at the Metropolitan Opera House.

headline: Today, in the Role of Flower Girl: Grandma
text: Like many good ideas, it started in jest.

headline: The Spring Foursomes in Stratford-upon-Avon
text: Top tennis players travel the world to compete in tournaments. Now the best bridge players do, too.

headline: The Changing of Ethiopia, in Photos
text: From rural villages and urban centers, Michael Tsegaye has been showing how his homeland has been changing, even if outsiders’ perceptions have not.

headline: Concerts of Mystery and Imagination
text: Spring for Music, the annual festival of North American orchestras at Carnegie Hall, was created in large part to encourage adventurous programming and has in its four years produced odd juxtapositions within concerts, typically with some thematic goal in view. But when it comes to juxtaposing whole programs, anything goes, and the results can be mind-bending.

headline: The Older Cling to Jobs, Crowding Out the Younger
text: THE proportion of Americans with jobs fell sharply during the Great Recession, and has barely begun to recover, according to overall figures.

headline: Events in Connecticut for May 11-17, 2014
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: A Storied Rivalry Touching Familiar Bases
text: There’s a clever new offering at the Goodspeed Opera House’s concession counter these days — boxes of Cracker Jack. They help put audiences in a suitable frame of mind for “Damn Yankees,” the wonderful 1955 musical that won a slew of Tonys and taught the world that “you gotta have heart.”

headline: Literary Help Sending a Shiver Down Your Spine
text: Television is clogged with lurid supernatural fare these days — “Salem,” “The Walking Dead,” “American Horror Story,” “The Originals” — so staking out a distinctive place within the genre isn’t easy. “Penny Dreadful” tries to do so with a combination of literary allusion, fine acting, patience and fearlessness, which, at least for the first two episodes, clicks deliciously. Oh dear; another show to add to our ever-growing guilty-pleasure lists.

headline: A Hotel With Spirit From 1971
text: A hotel is an imitation of home, a home once removed. So what would it feel like to spend the night in an imitation of a hotel? And what if that imitation hotel was really a kind of artwork based on an older imitation of a hotel that was itself partly based on a hotel that existed only in a movie?

headline: Simple Pleasures
text: This issue might seem to have little to do with style: walking in nature, swimming in the ocean, eating supper under the stars or setting out to a distant locale.

headline: Who Is That Lady in the Painting?
text: Making its first trip to the United States more than four centuries after its creation, Parmigianino’s renowned, beguiling portrait of a turbaned woman — known since the early 18th century as “Schiava Turca,” or the Turkish slave, from 1531-34 — will go on view Tuesday at the Frick Collection, bringing along the question that has long trailed it: Who was she? Almost certainly neither Turkish nor a slave, an identification that came about in error because of her exotic costume. Some have wondered whether the woman was real at all or maybe just a feminine ideal dreamed up by the painter. But Aimee Ng, a research associate at the Frick and the show’s curator, has a new theory based on subtle clues in the portrait: that she might have been Veronica Gambara, an accomplished poet in Parmigianino’s circle.

headline: Still Elusive: Brahms, in Concert
text: Brahms is naturally grouped with composers from the Romantic era, but many historians speak of Brahms the Classicist, who strove to reconcile the forms and genres of Viennese classicism with the experiments of the mid-19th century. Then again, Schoenberg titled an influential essay “Brahms the Progressive,” analyzing the Brahms who explored daring harmonic paths and, in his late works, even anticipated the breakdown of tonality.

headline: Joyce Theater Goes to the Dog
text: Dance at the Joyce Theater tends to stay at a safe distance, the fourth wall intact. But through a new initiative, Joyce Unleashed, the theater is expanding its reach, presenting work that doesn’t square so neatly with the trappings of a traditional stage. So long, Chelsea. The Joyce is heading to Brooklyn.

headline: Two Singular Sensations
text: Creativity brings disorientation — or vice versa? — in the music of two songwriters and sonic experimenters in town this week: Son Lux and Chad VanGaalen. Ryan Lott, who records as Son Lux, has collaborated widely with musicians like Sufjan Stevens and Lorde. In songs that lean toward the reflective — “What will we do now?/We’ve lost it to trying,” one goes — his music encompasses pinpoint orchestral arrangements as well as electronics that can be glitchy, glossy and dizzying. Son Lux appears Tuesday, sharing a bill with the guitarist Rafiq Bhatia as part of the Undead Music series. (8 p.m., Le Poisson Rouge, 158 Bleecker Street, near Thompson Street, Greenwich Village; 212-505-3474, lepoissonrouge.com.)

headline: In a Blaze of Confusion
text: Documentaries don’t come more sparse or more disturbing than “Let the Fire Burn,” Jason Osder’s examination of the disastrous confrontation between the police and the radical group MOVE in Philadelphia in May 1985.

headline: Grids and Steel Spanning Great Divides
text: The grid was one of the reigning motifs of 20th-century American art, but few artists have treated it with as much versatility as Jennifer Bartlett. Ms. Bartlett came of age in the ’70s, following minimalist artists for whom the grid was a kind of talisman, a model of mathematical consistency that cut through the existential drips and heroic angst of the Abstract Expressionists. Ms. Bartlett added some things that made the grid pleasingly weird, however, several of which are apparent in the 26 works in the grandly titled “Jennifer Bartlett: History of the Universe — Works 1970-2011” at the Parrish Art Museum in Water Mill. (“History of the Universe” is also the title of Ms. Bartlett’s autobiographical novel, published in 1985.)

headline: Hot Ice: The Tortuous Tale of the Pear-Shaped Diamond
text: The thought struck Steven Zaretsky during a party two years ago, when he looked over at his wife and the 7.35-carat, pear-shaped diamond hanging on a thin chain around her neck. It had been a gift from her father to her mother, and later, to her. What was it insured for? When was the last time it had been certified and appraised?

headline: A Second Union, to a Commune and Each Other
text: GUILFORD, Vt. — For Verandah Porche, there was never any question about where the wedding would take place. “This is home,” she said, waving an arm to encompass the rambling house, the rickety outbuildings, the steep fields and the gnarled orchard that make up Packer Corners, the storied commune that Ms. Porche helped found in 1968. It was also the site of her first marriage to the groom, Richard H. Coutant, in 1979.

headline: D.J. Whoo Kid: A Social Media Butterfly
text: D.J. Whoo Kid got his start making mixtapes, so long ago that he actually made them on tapes. He has D.J.’d for 50 Cent and G-Unit, and is currently the spicy-tongued host of the Sirius XM satellite radio program “The Whoolywood Shuffle,” where he interviews rap stars and entertainers as far afield as Willie Nelson (he asked the octogenarian Mr. Nelson whether he still got groupies). Born Yves Mondesir 42 years ago in Queens, he lives in Battery Park City and regularly spends time in New Jersey with his estranged wife and two teenage sons. “I haven’t been called by my real name in 20 years,” he said.

headline: Celebrating Old Times With New: A Premiere
text: New York City Ballet’s spring gala on Thursday at the David H. Koch Theater was, for many reasons, exciting. Above all, it celebrated the company’s 50 years at Lincoln Center. And the evening reached its climax with a sensational world premiere: Justin Peck’s 42-minute new ballet, “Everywhere We Go,” a work both diffuse and brilliant whose rich supply of configurations, phrases and rhythms often (if not always) suggests that young Mr. Peck can do anything he wants with choreography: a virtuoso of the form.

headline: Summer Travel Issue
text: Whether it’s the design of a hotel suite, the search for a perfect pair of swim trunks or the everyday act of getting around on foot, T’s summer travel issue highlights the power of simplicity. We start in Todos Santos, Mexico, a laid-back surf town whose hippie vibes and reliable waves make it easy to pack light — a bathing suit and a few summertime knits should do. We visit India, where the bohemian designer Loulou Van Damme has channeled her effortless style into a guesthouse in the scenic Palani Hills. And in New York City, we step inside the Greenwich Hotel, where the renowned Belgian antiques dealer Axel Vervoordt has introduced modest luxury by way of a three-story penthouse created in his own wabi-sabi aesthetic. Elsewhere, the ladies of the Ferragamo dynasty line up for a special multigenerational portrait; the MoMA PS1 director Klaus Biesenbach parties with friends in Rockaway, Queens, where he’s become the community’s loudest champion; our critic at large Andrew O’Hagan writes about the transformative power of swimming while searching for the holy grail of trunks; and a trio of artists make time to break bread with their staffs. See all stories from the issue >>

headline: A Patent Surfaces Detailing a Facebook Smartphone
text: Over the last several years, there have been dozens of reports about Facebook building a smartphone.

headline: More Opposition to the LG Headquarters Beside the Palisades
text: Opposition keeps growing to a proposed new American headquarters for LG Electronics USA, the tech giant, beside Palisades Park in Englewood Cliffs, N.J. The National Trust for Historic Preservation will announce Monday that it has designated the Palisades as a National Treasure.

headline: Ben Hoberman, 91, Pioneer of All-Talk Radio, Is Dead
text: Ben Hoberman, a radio executive who in 1960 helped start an influential and enduring trend when he transformed the middle-of-the-road music station he was managing, KABC in Los Angeles, into what is generally considered the first 24-hour all-talk station in the country, died on May 3 in Los Angeles. He was 91.

headline: A Successor to ‘Colbert’ Is Named
text: What comes after “The Colbert Report”?

headline: Step Forward Into Past for British Gay Couples: Coats of Arms
text: LONDON — First, same-sex couples in Britain won the right to civil partnerships, then to full marriage. Now, they can have their own coats of arms.

headline: Strolling an Island of Creativity
text: The amazing spectacle that is Frieze New York is up and running on Randalls Island. With more than 190 contemporary art dealers from around the world inhabiting a temporary, quarter-mile-long white tent, it’s a dumbfounding display of human creative industry. Reasoning that in the time allowed, no one reviewer could hope to achieve a comprehensive overview of all there is to see, we both went to look and report. What follows is a sampler of things that caught our attention.

headline: Football, Minus the Draft
text: Should the N.F.L. pool its resources and let players decide where to work, or will some teams inevitably gain an unfair competitive advantage?

headline: The Fiery Return of the Political Son
text: Despite some rough edges, “A View of the Mountains” is an easy enough play to like. Over its 75 minutes this political satire, at the New Jersey Repertory Company in Long Branch, raises a couple of questions, launches a few zingers and features a plot twist or two. Not everything here succeeds. But taken together, enough works to make it all worthwhile.

headline: South Korea: Victims’ Parents Assail President Over Government’s Response to Ferry Accident
text: Parents of high school students killed in the capsizing of a South Korean ferry marched on the office of President Park Geun-hye in Seoul on Friday as prosecutors continued to try to determine who was responsible for the accident that killed hundreds of people. The parents, holding photos of their children, said they had come to ask for a meeting with Ms. Park to demand an inquiry into accusations that a slow and ineffective response by her government drastically increased the number of deaths. Two senior presidential aides met family representatives while hundreds of parents and their supporters staged a sit-in for 12 hours near the presidential palace. Meanwhile, prosecutors said Friday that they were seeking to arrest Kim Han-sik, the head of the Chonghaejin Marine Company, which operated the ferry, on charges of ignoring the overloading of the vessel. They were also looking into a family that owns a company that controls Chonghaejin Marine.

headline: Italy: Berlusconi Begins His Community Service
text: Dodging a scrum of reporters, former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy on Friday began serving his sentence for tax fraud at a nursing home outside Milan. Mr. Berlusconi, 77, was ordered to serve a year of community service, and he will spend four hours a week assisting Alzheimer’s patients. He did not stop to speak with reporters, slipping in and out of the nursing home, which is in Cesano Boscone. On Thursday, he told a radio station that he was certain that he would be able to help “those in need” and that the experience would enrich him. He also said that he had been studying the latest treatments for Alzheimer’s.

headline: Republicans Tighten Grip on Debates in 2016 Race
text: MEMPHIS — The Republican National Committee moved Friday to seize control of the presidential primary debates in 2016, another step in a coordinated effort by the party establishment to reshape the nominating process.

headline: Afghanistan: British Military to Investigate Photo of Soldier Cavorting Next to Dead Insurgent
text: Britain’s Defense Ministry said Friday that it had begun an investigation after graphic photos surfaced appearing to show at least one British service member posing next to the corpse of a Taliban fighter in Afghanistan in 2012. In one of the photos, a member of the military is kneeling next to a body and giving a thumbs-up sign, recalling some previous images of Western personnel in Afghanistan and Iraq that caused widespread offense in those countries. “This type of behavior is unacceptable and will not be tolerated,” said a statement from the Royal Air Force. A defense official confirmed news media reports in Britain that the incident took place after an attack by insurgents on Camp Bastion, the main British military base in Afghanistan’s Helmand Province. The photographs surfaced first on a website called Live Leak and were reproduced on many British newsweb sites with people’s faces concealed.

headline: Funny, You Look Familiar
text: They could have called it “Comas and Clones.” But Hudson Stage, presenting its last production in Briarcliff Manor before moving to Armonk this fall, has chosen a more dignified route and labeled its evening of two British one-acts — one by Harold Pinter and one by Caryl Churchill — “Family Reunion.”

headline: Library’s Change of Plan: Long Overdue, or a Mistake?
text: To the Editor:

headline: 3 Suspended in Oregon Sexual Assault Case
text: EUGENE, Ore. — Three University of Oregon basketball players accused of sexually assaulting a fellow student two months ago have been suspended and will not return to the team, the university president Michael R. Gottfredson said at a news conference Friday.

headline: U.S. and the Rule of Law
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Pulverized Prize Changes Hands, Peacefully, in Syria
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The last busloads of insurgents left the battered Old City of Homs in central Syria on Friday, under a deal handing over the longtime bastion of rebellion to the government after nearly two years of blockade and bombardment.

headline: Events in Westchester for May 11-17, 2014
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: The Environmental and Health Hazards of Gas Drilling
text: To the Editor:

headline: Evening Hours | Petals and Medals
text: Toasting Isabella Stewart Gardner, Charles James and several worthy causes.

headline: Dogs in Parks
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bill Cunningham | The Met Ball
text: The designer Charles James (1906-78) is the subject of a sumptuous new retrospective at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Remembering Charles James
text: The designer Charles James (1906 to 1978), the subject of a sumptuous new retrospective at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, rose to prominence after World War II during what could be deemed the twilight of splendor, with the height of his career roughly from 1948 to 1957. There was never a question that he was a master couturier. A lone eagle in a world of commercial dressmaking, he was an architect and a sculptor whose medium happened to be cloth. He may have been known for his majestic evening dresses, but his real genius was in coats; he even came up with the first puffer coat.

headline: Death Toll Rising, 2 Sides Sign Pact to End South Sudan War
text: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia — President Salva Kiir of South Sudan and the leader of the rebellion against his government, Riek Machar, signed an agreement on Friday to resolve the war that has torn their young country apart.

headline: Review of Marijuana Law Exposes List of Conflicts Between Jurisdictions
text: WASHINGTON — If Congress allows a District of Columbia law to take effect that would decriminalize the possession of small amounts of marijuana, and someone with one foot on the National Mall and another foot on city property is caught carrying the drug, would that person be charged with a crime under federal law?

headline: Events on Long Island for May 11-17, 2014
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Agency Urges Quake Study for Indian Point
text: The Indian Point power plant is one of 10 sites considered most in need for a re-evaluation of earthquake vulnerability, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission announced on Friday.

headline: Where the Girls Are
text: This election season is going to be all about women.

headline: Apple’s Pursuit of Beats May Foretell a Shift
text: Has streaming music’s moment in the mainstream finally come? Or is it here already, and has Apple — once the great innovator of music technology — finally caught on?

headline: Why Divestment Fails
text: LOS ANGELES — TONIGHT, the 20,000 students at Stanford will sleep more soundly. Earlier this week, a group called “Fossil Free Stanford” persuaded the university’s endowment to divest its stock holdings from coal-mining companies. The world will be a better place.

headline: Brunei Ownership Casts a Shadow on a Beverly Hills Hotel
text: LOS ANGELES — For longer than most here care to remember, Arthur Cohn, a producer of “The Garden of the Finzi-Continis,” which won an Oscar in 1972, has staged an intimate pre-Academy Awards dinner for friends, movie stars and others at the Beverly Hills Hotel.

headline: Ford Recalls Vehicles for Air Bag Flaw
text: The three Detroit automakers announced vehicle recalls on Friday, though they said none of the defects had resulted in accidents or injuries.

headline: How to End State Subsidies
text: WASHINGTON — GOV. RICK PERRY of Texas scored a big victory last week in his effort to lure companies from other states to his own, successfully offering $40 million to Toyota to relocate its American sales headquarters (and 4,000 jobs) from California. Texas is also one of five states — along with California, Arizona, New Mexico and Nevada — that are bidding against one another for a new Tesla Motors factory that will employ up to 6,500 people.

headline: Joe Wilder, Horn Player, Dies at 92; Elegance Was His Theme Song
text: Joe Wilder, a lyrical trumpeter who played with some of the biggest big bands in jazz and helped integrate Broadway, radio and television orchestras, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 92.

headline: Reducing Obesity: A Progress Report
text: To the Editor:

headline: Slow Exit of the Midwest’s Winter Buries Gardens in a Deep Freeze
text: MUKWONAGO, Wis. — The freakishly cold Midwestern winter of 2014 has given way to the frustrated Midwestern gardener.

headline: In Ukrainian City Under Blockade, Citizens Go to Ground, and Below
text: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine — Tatyana Vsevolodovna stood in the cool basement beneath her kitchen, displaying a household’s preparations for war.

headline: Experts Seek Smarter Black Boxes for Automobiles
text: A design flaw in the Chevrolet Cobalt and other small cars has led to deaths and injuries for at least a decade, but the analysts at the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration never opened an investigation. All through that period, a few blocks away at a sister agency within the Transportation Department, safety experts were using a program that made extensive use of vehicle data to spot defects and dangerous trends.

headline: Memo Revisits Policy on Citing Leaked Material, to Some Confusion
text: WASHINGTON — The Office of the Director of National Intelligence sent an internal memo to its work force on Friday saying that its new policy on pre-publication review of speeches, books, articles, term papers and other writings permits current and former employees to refer to news articles as long as the officials do not confirm any classified information.

headline: Rare View Into Inner Workings of N.B.A.
text: It is a 78-page document full of mind-numbing legalese, including a four-page glossary and countless references to entities, guarantors and provisions.

headline: Ad Agencies Dust Off and Focus on Future After Collapse of Merger Deal
text: PARIS — The world’s biggest advertising merger had just slipped through his hands.

headline: One Big, Happy Budget
text: The first executive budget of a new mayor sets the tone for an administration. In Bill de Blasio’s case, it’s the now-familiar one of happy optimism, where all the values are progressive, the conversations civil, spending rises freely, and whatever pain is so spread out and mixed in with the good news that you hardly know it’s there.

headline: In High Seas, China Moves Unilaterally
text: BEIJING — It is the pride of China’s state-run oil industry and the nation’s first deepwater drilling rig, a vessel as big as a football field and as tall as a 40-story building, with a $1 billion price tag. Last week, it crawled through the South China Sea, pulled by heavy-duty tugs, and parked in one of the most sensitive spots possible, about 17 miles off a speck of an island claimed by both China and Vietnam.

headline: U.S. Officers Kill Armed Civilians in Yemen Capital
text: WASHINGTON — A United States Special Operations commando and a Central Intelligence Agency officer in Yemen shot and killed two armed Yemeni civilians who tried to kidnap them while the Americans were in a barbershop in the country’s capital two weeks ago, American officials said on Friday.

headline: Squeezed by Poverty’s Grip in California
text: California’s Inland Empire, east of Los Angeles, has attracted people expecting to live out the American dream. But with jobs and services scarce, the region has a high poverty rate.

headline: City’s New Fire Commissioner Vows a Push for More Minorities in the Department
text: The new commissioner of the New York Fire Department vowed on Friday to put an end to an era of lawsuits and court orders over the department’s persistent lack of diversity and to lead an effort to attract more minorities.

headline: Trouble in the South China Sea
text: China has dangerously increased tensions in the South China Sea by deploying an oil  rig for the first time in a disputed area claimed by Vietnam. The move is certain to make countries in the region feel even more threatened by China’s expansionist territorial claims. The rig, belonging to a state-owned oil company, was parked in waters off the Paracel Islands on May 2. After Vietnam objected, China dispatched 80 ships to the area; Hanoi responded by sending 35 ships to obstruct the rig’s operations.

headline: Writers Feel an Amazon-Hachette Spat
text: The world’s biggest bookstore is a bit smaller these days.

headline: Hardship Makes a New Home in the Suburbs
text: MORENO VALLEY, Calif. — The freeway exits around here are dotted with people asking for money, holding cardboard signs to tell their stories. The details vary only slightly and almost invariably include: Laid off. Need food. Young children.

headline: Ex-Deputy in Arizona Kept Cache of Evidence
text: PHOENIX — Evidence bags containing drugs, hundreds of drivers’ licenses and other items were retrieved last week from the home of a former Maricopa County sheriff’s deputy who was found dead there apparently of suicide on Thursday when officers showed up to arrest him.

headline: Blooms Return to Washington Square Park After Years of Renovation
text: The park had changed drastically from the days in the 1950s when Bobby Fischer used to come to play, Lamont Holloway said as he sat in gold-framed sunglasses at a chessboard and waited for a tourist or fellow hustler in Washington Square Park in Greenwich Village.

headline: Like-Minded Russians Visit Occupy Wall Street Inmate at Rikers Island
text: Most people disappear from the headlines into the gray anonymity of Rikers Island after they are found guilty in state court in Manhattan.

headline: Dalai Lama Urges Outside Inquiry Into Spate of Self-Immolations Among Tibetans
text: The Dalai Lama, Tibet’s spiritual leader in exile, on Friday called for an outside inquiry into the self-immolations of more than 130 Tibetans in anti-China demonstrations over the past five years, and he suggested that in some cases, such acts of protest were understandable and not entirely wrong.

headline: Dumbledore in the NICU
text: My daughter is lying in Bed No. 3, a clear plastic box in the neonatal intensive care unit at New York Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn. She is attached to the wall by a jangle of colored wires, each tracking the strength of her uncertain grasp on this world. She is 6 days old.

headline: Germany’s Pursuit of Death Camp Guards
text: With time running out, a new generation of criminal prosecutors in Germany has opened dozens of fresh investigations into long-dormant cases of death-camp guards suspected of culpable roles in the Nazi genocide machine. Men and women left to live in freedom for decades after World War II are finally being scrutinized for their work in the camps, with modern technology like 3-D visualizations of the camps being used to contradict their claims that they never were able to witness the ghastly routines of the Holocaust.

headline: Teams Build on Defense in 2nd Round of Draft
text: Quarterbacks typically dominate the headlines in the first round of the N.F.L. draft, and this year’s edition was no different.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 9, 2014
Slovyansk: An Unlikely Flashpoint in Ukraine Crisis
text: Once a quiet industrial city, Slovyansk is now strained by the conflicting pulls of disbelief, pride, anger, and anticipation.

headline: Hidden From the Opera’s Crowd Is a Human Safety Net
text: Chances are that even devoted regulars at the Metropolitan Opera are not familiar with Donna Racik.

headline: It’s Big in the Suburbs
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — I appreciated the “Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Galaxy” advice at 18 Across: DON’T PANIC, indeed. I must confess that I used to be intimidated by Mr. Silk’s byline; Now that I’m a Big Girl Solver, I find his puzzles to hit the sweet spot between challenging, but solvable and sparkling with entries that are both cleverly clued and fun to write in the grid.

headline: A Performer Whose Love of Baseball Is No Act
text: When Adam Wainwright struck out Carlos Beltran to clinch the 2006 National League pennant for the St. Louis Cardinals, hearts broke all over Shea Stadium. But one fan in the third-base stands rejoiced.

headline: The Power of ‘the Street’
text: The tangled events leading up to World War I are much written about this centennial year, and one striking element is the power of “the street” to push history in unexpected and sometimes tragic directions when popular passions are either deliberately fired by demagogues or aroused by tribal loyalties, ethnic myths, xenophobia or legitimate frustration.

headline: Body of Fashion Designer, Missing Since March, Is Identified
text: A body pulled from the water in Brooklyn has been identified as that of an emerging fashion designer missing since March.

headline: Kings-Ducks Series Grips Southern California
text: LONG BEACH, Calif. — On Thursday night, the competition for sports fans’ viewership was crowded and would seemingly be dominated by the first round of the N.F.L. draft.

headline: With Top Ranking in Play, Two Outsiders Take Charge
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — The world No. 1 ranking was the trending topic early in the week at TPC Sawgrass, with pros turning into amateur statisticians to figure out where Adam Scott, Henrik Stenson, Bubba Watson and Matt Kuchar needed to finish to supplant the injured Tiger Woods from the top spot.

headline: Jets’ Top Pick, Once a Point Guard, Now Revels in His Physical Play
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — When football season ended, basketball came right afterward, and the transition was jarring to Calvin Pryor. His fouls left bruises. He bowled over opposing players. Instead of drawing contact, he inflicted it.

headline: A Hundred Visions and Revisions
text: How did Hitchcock make cinematic gold out of the demons of his private dreams? David Rudkin’s “The Lovesong of Alfred J. Hitchcock” pries the lid off Hitchcock’s psyche, the better to peer in and consider the ghosts and ordeals that Mr. Rudkin sees as the fuel of his art.

headline: Giants Add a Center, the First Taken in the Draft
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Giants went for a flashy pick in the first round of the N.F.L. draft Thursday when they took the swift, dynamic and multifaceted wide receiver Odell Beckham Jr. But the tradition-bound Giants did not live on the edge for long.

headline: Grieving Star Inspires a Rout by the Rangers
text: PITTSBURGH — Facing playoff elimination on the road and inspired by the presence of Martin St. Louis, who was playing a night after his mother died, the Rangers put forth their best effort of the postseason on Friday, thrashing the Pittsburgh Penguins, 5-1, in Game 5.

headline: Grand Prix Blazes New Trail at Indianapolis Speedway
text: In the 105 years since racing began at Indianapolis Motor Speedway, there has never been an IndyCar event quite like Saturday’s Grand Prix.

headline: A Tough Stretch for Tom Wheeler on Net Neutrality
text: Tom Wheeler, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, has had a tough month.

headline: It’s Gadgets vs. Eyeballs as Two Species of Bird-Watchers Clash
text: Pete Dunne and Benjamin Van Doren are devout birders who share a passion for identifying rare species, recording their sightings and competing in birding events known as Big Days.

headline: Two Boys Abducted After Mother Is Fatally Stabbed
text: The authorities in New Jersey issued an Amber Alert on Friday night for two boys who the police say were abducted by their father at school after their mother was stabbed to death.

headline: Tight End Fills Jets’ Needs
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The biggest boon for the development of a young quarterback is a superior tight end, and the Jets believe they found one with their second-round pick.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, May 10, 2014
text: “The two words you don’t want to hear on the bar car. Last call.”

headline: Tanaka’s Bat Is Quiet, but He Makes Sure the Brewers Match Him
text: MILWAUKEE — It was Saturday morning in Japan, and a big day for baseball fans there. NHK, the national television network, was broadcasting the Yankees’ game against the Milwaukee Brewers at Miller Park on Friday night. The Japanese sensation Masahiro Tanaka was starting for the Yankees and looking to extend his remarkable unbeaten streak.

headline: A Soggy Start to the Weekend
text: More showers are expected Saturday, though Sunday is expected to be mostly sunny, just in time for Mother’s Day.

headline: Remembering a Young Grandfather Lost
text: Alexa Cabrera, 7, held a photograph of her grandfather Officer Ronald G. Becker Jr. at an event honoring Officer Becker, who died at age 53 in 2012, and 12 other members of the Police Department who died of illnesses linked to work on the recovery after the Sept. 11 attack.

headline: Shortstop Provides Lift, but the Mets Fall
text: The Mets, starved for runs, appeared to trade offense for defense when they recalled shortstop Wilmer Flores from the minor leagues on Friday. Flores, considered a good hitter, is something of a positional conundrum.

headline: Signatures on Petitions for Conyers Fall Short
text: WASHINGTON — Representative John Conyers Jr., who has represented the Detroit area in the House for almost 50 years, is in danger of not making the ballot for an August primary because his petitions may be disqualified for not containing enough signatures.

headline: What’s on Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (HBO) PRISONERS (2013) Keller Dover (Hugh Jackman), a grief-stricken father in a small Pennsylvania town, contemplates the torture and murder of the man (Paul Dano, above right, with Mr. Jackman) he believes has kidnapped his daughter and her friend in this thriller, directed by Denis Villeneuve. Maria Bello plays Dover’s wife, submerged in despair; Viola Davis and Terrence Howard are the other girl’s parents, whose doubts about Dover’s means of extracting information strike him as weak and irrational; Melissa Leo is the suspect’s aunt, intent on shielding her mentally disabled nephew; and Jake Gyllenhaal is the tormented cop determined to solve the case. “ ‘Prisoners’ is the kind of movie that can quiet a room full of casual thrill-seekers,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “It absorbs and controls your attention with such assurance that you hold your breath for fear of distracting the people on screen, exhaling in relief or amazement at each new revelation. By the end you may be a little worn out, and perhaps also slightly let down by the fussily clever revelations that wrap up the story, but in the meantime you are a willing captive, unable to tell the difference between dread and delight.”

headline: A Second Conversation With: Times Now Editor Arnab Goswami
text: Arnab Goswami, editor in chief of the Times Now television channel, is the only journalist to have interviewed the two main contenders in the Indian national elections: Rahul Gandhi, vice president of the Indian National Congress party, and Narendra Modi, prime ministerial candidate of the opposition Bharatiya Janata Party.

headline: Corrections: May 10, 2014
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Philippines Jails Chinese Sailors in Fish Dispute
text: HONG KONG — Raising the stakes in its confrontation with China, the Philippines said Saturday that it had imprisoned 11 Chinese fishermen who were caught with endangered sea turtles in a part of the South China Sea that is claimed by both nations.

headline: Ike? They Liked
text: There are award-winning presidential photographs — though not lately — and sometimes there are award-winning photographs taken by presidents.

headline: Analytics: The Jungle of the Law
text: The following Analytics appears on the letters page in the May 11 issue of the magazine.

headline: Under Cover: Martin Schoeller on Photographing Timothy Geithner
text: Martin Schoeller, a New York-based photographer who has taken pictures of the powerful and famous for more than 20 years, often bathes his subjects in fluorescent light and shows them in extreme close-ups. The results can be unnerving for viewers, who suddenly come face to face with the likes of President Obama, Clint Eastwood and Angelina Jolie.

headline: Possible Path to Closing Pay Gap
text: It’s 2014, and women are still paid less than men. Does this suggest that a gender pay gap is an unfortunately permanent fixture? Will it still be with us in 50 years? I would predict yes. But by that point, it will be men who will be earning less than women.

headline: The Role of Education and Health Care in Fostering Sustainable Motherhood
text: Sustainable motherhood?

headline: 1914: Lillian Nordica Succumbs to Pneumonia
text: BATAVIA, Java — Mme. Nordica was on board the steamship Tasman when that vessel ran ashore in the Torres Straits of the Gulf of Papua on December 27 of last year. The liner got off and proceeded to Thursday Island, which was reached on December 31. All were well on board, with the exception of the prima donna, who was then suffering from nervous prostration. Finally, on reaching Java, it became evident she could go no further for some time to come. After remaining at Batavia for several weeks, she has succumbed in consequence of her determination.

headline: First Lady Condemns Abduction of Nigerian Schoolgirls
text: WASHINGTON — In a rare venture into foreign policy, Michelle Obama on Saturday condemned the abduction of more than 200 Nigerian schoolgirls by terrorists and said that she and President Obama had been personally touched by what she called an “unconscionable” act.

headline: In ‘Ceremonial Transfer,’ Remains of 9/11 Victims Are Moved to Memorial
text: On the granite plaza of the World Trade Center memorial, families of Sept. 11 victims gathered on Saturday morning beneath mist-shrouded skyscrapers to watch as the unidentified remains of people killed there more than 12 years ago were moved to what may be their final resting place.

headline: An Alluring Summer Song, Echoed Through Eight World Cups
text: The World Cup could never get better than this, but I had no way of knowing it in 1982, my first time.

headline: A Simple Theory, and a Proposal, on H.I.V. in Africa
text: OTIMATI, South Africa — While around the world a vast majority of AIDS victims are men, Africa has long been the glaring exception: Nearly 60 percent are women. And while there are many theories, no one has been able to prove one.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 33
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: A Potent Power Play Does Not Ensure a Path to the Stanley Cup
text: The Rangers went 2 for 3 on the power play in Friday night’s 5-1 victory against the Pittsburgh Penguins after having failed on 36 consecutive chances, the longest postseason power-play drought since 2007. Asked if the Rangers had done anything differently, Coach Alain Vigneault said no.

headline: Carl Galioto, on Sweeping Away the Negative Energy
text: This interview with  Carl Galioto, managing principal of the New York office of HOK, an architecture and engineering firm, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Variety: The Diagramless Puzzle That Wouldn’t Leave
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — I had a little bit of trouble getting started with Fred Piscop’s diagramless puzzle, but once I got my toehold, it seemed like the grid just went on forever. That’s not an opinion on the solve. It’s actually the theme.

headline: A Basketball Life of Harsh Reality, Starkly Revisited
text: As he sat in the darkness watching a new documentary about his life, Allen Iverson conceded that he was initially jolted by the film. It’s one thing to have been an N.B.A. star who lived in the moment, quite another to watch those moments parade, unfiltered, across a movie screen.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, May 10
text: “Investors are longing for growth — and here’s a company that really has it.”

headline: Reading, Writing, Arithmetic, and Lately, Coding
text: MILL VALLEY, Calif. — Seven-year-old Jordan Lisle, a second grader, joined his family at a packed after-hours school event last month aimed at inspiring a new interest: computer programming.

headline: An Upscale Burger Chain From New Zealand Aims at U.S.
text: AUCKLAND, New Zealand — Inside the headquarters of BurgerFuel Worldwide is a spray-painted mural of a skull wearing a combat helmet emblazoned with the slogan “Born to Grill.”

headline: Suspended Animation, on a Hollywood Set
text: The director yelled “Action!” I could feel the wheels of the gurney moving but had no idea where I was headed: I had been instructed to keep my eyes closed. (Was I dead? In a coma? Asleep? Catatonic? No back story was proffered.) There was a quick turn to the left, then a straightaway for 10 feet or so, then another turn, this one to the right.

headline: 2 Yemenis Shot by Americans Are Linked to Qaeda Cell
text: SANA, Yemen — The kidnappers pulled up in a pickup truck outside the Taj barbershop in an upscale neighborhood here in the Yemeni capital. One held an AK-47 assault rifle and the other carried a stun gun. As the men went inside, nearby shopkeepers heard shots.

headline: Craft Brewers, Finding a Better Seat at the Bar
text: There’s a great moment in Steve Hindy’s shaggy little history of the craft beer industry, “The Craft Beer Revolution,” in which Jim Koch, the sharp-elbowed maker of Samuel Adams, loses his temper at the author, himself a brewer of note. It comes after a 1993 industry meeting in which Mr. Hindy and others circulated a petition that questioned Mr. Koch’s marketing claims. As Mr. Hindy describes it, Mr. Koch accuses him of trying to subvert his business, shouting at him over and over and using far more colorful language than I am allowed to relate here.

headline: Two Found Dead After Balloon Catches Fire
text: The authorities searched a wooded area in Virginia on Saturday for a rider believed to have been killed when a hot-air balloon carrying three people caught fire on Friday night and crashed at a festival.

headline: His Passport Took a Two-Year Vacation (Without Him)
text: It’s been a little over two years since the Haggler’s passport vanished. Longtime readers may recall the particulars: While visiting Stanford University, the Haggler had his passport shipped from Manhattan overnight via United Parcel Service, for a quick and unscheduled trip to Canada. Days passed, and no passport arrived. Calls were made. Facilities were searched. More calls were made. More facilities were searched.

headline: Abusing Relativity
text: Jonathan Chait has an extended discussion and takedown of the Fox News All-Star Panel reaction to the National Climate Assessment, which I won’t try to summarize. But I do want to delve a bit more into one point. Chait quotes Charles Krauthammer dismissing the scientific consensus because

headline: Can’t Find It at the Mall? Make It Yourself
text: As a junior in high school, Megan Grassell was disturbed by the choices of bras available for girls and young teenagers. The market, she believed, was dominated by push-up styles with padding and underwires. So last year, Ms. Grassell founded her own company, Yellowberry, and began making colorful, age-appropriate bras herself.

headline: Amid Much Uncertainty, Separatists Prepare for Voting in Eastern Ukraine
text: DONETSK, Ukraine — A day before snap elections to try to legitimize two self-declared new countries in eastern Ukraine, the preparations seemed as ad hoc as the votes themselves.

headline: Man Is Arrested in Killing of His Wife; Sons Are Found Safe
text: LODI, N.J. — A New Jersey man, who the authorities say took his two young sons from their school after killing their mother, was arrested early Saturday after a manhunt through several states, officials said.

headline: Already in the Lowflation Trap
text: Dean Baker, reacting to Neil Irwin, feels that he needs to make the perennial point that zero inflation is not some kind of economic Rubicon. Below-target inflation is already a problem, and a very serious problem if you don’t have an easy way to provide economic stimulus.

headline: Clippers for Sale, and the Owner Who Was Desperate
text: It was San Diego in the spring of 1981, a time of fern bars and yacht rock, big hair and short shorts. The man who owned the Clippers, Irv Levin, told his son that they were going to a lunch meeting at Lubach’s, on Harbor Drive.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: In Yemen, a Counterterrorism Challenge
text: WASHINGTON — After years of a tortuous relationship with Ali Abdullah Saleh, the strongman who was president of Yemen for more than two decades, Obama administration officials hoped to bolster the credibility at home of Mr. Saleh’s successor, Abdu Rabbu Mansour Hadi, seen as critical to the American fight against Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula.

headline: Pennsylvania Governor Faces an Uphill Battle for a Second Term
text: HARRISBURG, Pa. — Since Pennsylvania changed the law in 1968 to allow its governor to serve two consecutive terms, no incumbent has been denied re-election. But Tom Corbett, a Republican, is in danger of becoming the first.

headline: Defending the Open Internet
text: The future of the Internet — which means the future of communications, culture, free speech and innovation — is up for grabs.

headline: Making Ends Meet at Walmart
text: This has not been a good year for Walmart shareholders. Amid a torrid market over the last 12 months, this giant retailer’s stock has flatlined, reflecting a slowdown in sales growth.

headline: The Peril of Knowledge Everywhere
text: Thanks to advances in technology, we may soon revisit a question raised four centuries ago: Are there things we should try not to know?

headline: Picturesque but Pretty Daunting
text: A look at the six holes in one there during the Players Championship and the members of this year’s field with the most career holes in one.

headline: Ceremonial Transfer
text: The unidentified remains of Sept. 11 victims were moved to a specially built medical examiner’s repository at the World Trade Center memorial site on Saturday.

headline: Saving Sergeant Savage
text: In an effort to curb addiction, specialists are looking beyond opiates to treat chronic pain. Shane Savage, an injured military veteran, stopped taking pain medicine and is seeking other ways to cope.

headline: A Hard Sell to Tame a Name in Spain
text: CASTRILLO MATAJUDÍOS, Spain — To outsiders, it might seem obvious that the time has come, or long passed, to change the name of a village that evokes one of the darkest chapters of Spain’s history.

headline: A Soldier’s War on Pain
text: Four years and a lifetime ago, a new war began for Sgt. Shane Savage.

headline: A Roaring Success and an Agent for Change
text: Richard Sherman is the most recognizable cornerback in the N.F.L. And the most outspoken. And, now, the highest paid. His emotional outburst on live television after the N.F.C. Championship game obscured his proficiency as a defensive dynamo, skills that last week earned him a four-year, $57.4 million contract extension ($40 million guaranteed) from the Super Bowl champion Seattle Seahawks.

headline: Tour Players Are in a Hole-in-One Slump. Just Unlucky, They Guess.
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — At a 2010 PGA Tour event in Las Vegas, Jonathan Byrd beat long odds with the golf equivalent of a game-ending home run. Using his 6-iron, Byrd holed his tee shot on the 204-yard par-3 17th at TPC Summerlin to defeat Cameron Percy and Martin Laird in a playoff.

headline: Pfizer Continues to Defend Takeover Bid for AstraZeneca
text: Pfizer on Saturday continued to press its case for a $106 billion takeover of AstraZeneca, the British drug maker, in the face of mounting resistance on both sides of the Atlantic.

headline: Bid for No-Hitter in Texas Is Sullied Before It’s Spoiled
text: In the first game of the World Series at Fenway Park last year, Stephen Drew of the Boston Red Sox hit a high pop fly in the infield. Because of a miscommunication, the ball landed safely on the grass between two St. Louis Cardinals. It never touched a fielder and was ruled a single.

headline: Brothers Battle Climate Change on Two Fronts
text: WASHINGTON — In the New Mexico of the 1950s, the two brothers grew up steeped in the beauty of the landscape, the economics of energy and the power of science. They skied, fly-fished, explored on the family’s 50,000-acre sheep ranch, watched oil towns go boom and bust, and talked of the nuclear weapons up the road at Los Alamos.

headline: A Mini Poll of the Smallest State
text: Only 18 percent of Rhode Islanders said their state was the best or one of the best places to live. A poll found that of all 50 states, Rhode Island was the least appreciated by its own residents.

headline: Caron Butler Finds Rejuvenation in Return to L.A.
text: LOS ANGELES — When the N.B.A. lockout ended late in 2011, the Los Angeles Clippers had grand designs. They were flush with assets: loads of salary-cap space, plenty of draft picks and some promising young players who could be used as trade chips for a franchise player to complement Blake Griffin.

headline: Filling Pages Not Difficult With a Life Lived Large
text: Graphic novels often depict men in colorful garb performing great feats of strength. But the heroes of those stories are usually fictional. That is not the case with “Andre the Giant: Life and Legend,” an illustrated biography published this month by First Second. The cartoonist Box Brown has woven his love of comics and wrestling to tell the life story of Andre Rene Roussimoff, better known as Andre the Giant.

headline: Young Minds in Critical Condition
text: It happens every semester. A student triumphantly points out that Jean-Jacques Rousseau is undermining himself when he claims “the man who reflects is a depraved animal,” or that Ralph Waldo Emerson’s call for self-reliance is in effect a call for reliance on Emerson himself. Trying not to sound too weary, I ask the student to imagine that the authors had already considered these issues.

headline: More Chopsticks, Please
text: HANOI, Vietnam — BY an accident of scheduling, I’ve visited Kiev and Hanoi in the last couple weeks, and it’s been accidentally extremely revealing. Ukraine is a middle power living next to a giant bear, and Vietnam is a middle power living next to a giant tiger. Ukraine is struggling with how to deal with a declining Russia that is looking for dignity in all the wrong places — like in Crimea — and Vietnam is struggling with how to deal with a rising China that is looking for oil in all the wrong places — like in Vietnam’s territorial waters. Russia’s attitude toward Ukraine has been: “Marry me, or I’ll kill you.” And China’s toward Vietnam has been a variation of that line from “There Will Be Blood”: “I have a long straw, so I think I’ll drink my milkshake and yours.”

headline: Real Goal of Abortion ‘Limits’: Bans
text: Anti-abortion groups that saw a chance to get state legislatures to restrict women’s reproductive rights piously declared that all they wanted to do was to make women safer. This argument had little credibility then, and it has even less now. What has actually happened is that in state after state, with the enthusiastic support of Republican lawmakers, it has become increasingly difficult, if not impossible, for women to get safe and legal abortion care.

headline: With Malice Toward Nuns
text: WASHINGTON — SO much for all the cozy hugs and soothing cold calls and fun selfies and humble gestures and talk of mercy, love, inclusion, equality and justice.

headline: The Toxic Brew in Our Yards
text: IN much of the country, it’s time to go outside, clean up the ravages of winter and start planting. Many of us will be using chemicals like glyphosate, carbaryl, malathion and 2,4-D. But they can end up in drinking water, and in some cases these compounds or their breakdown products are linked to an increased risk for cancer and hormonal disruption.

headline: A Health Care Showdown in Virginia
text: In Virginia, there are 400,000 low-income people who can’t afford health coverage but don’t qualify for federal insurance subsidies. If they lived across the state line in Maryland, West Virginia or Kentucky, which have expanded their Medicaid programs, they could get the coverage they need. Terry McAuliffe, the Virginia governor, campaigned on bringing an expanded Medicaid program to Virginia, too.

headline: Of Humans and Nature
text: A metaphysical discussion of our place in the universe and the future of humankind.

headline: Lost Booksellers of New York
text: IN the fall of 1965, I arrived in New York City, flush with somebody else’s oil money, to purchase books for a bookshop I was managing in Houston. The shop was called the Bookman and had several eccentric features: Our safe was the boll of a Louisiana gum tree; there was a room full of rare tobaccos, though smoking was forbidden; and there was even a young Asian man to serve sherry to such bewildered hicks as straggled in from time to time.

headline: Rape and the College Brand
text: IN last week’s column, I wrote about the connection between college social life and socioeconomic stratification, and the way the party scene at many universities, oriented toward heavy drinking and hooking up, creates distinctive challenges for working-class students, whether they’re attracted to its thrills or alienated by its excesses.

headline: What’s So Scary About Smart Girls?
text: WHEN terrorists in Nigeria organized a secret attack last month, they didn’t target an army barracks, a police department or a drone base. No, Boko Haram militants attacked what is even scarier to a fanatic: a girls’ school.

headline: The Marriage Plot
text: BOY meets girl. Boy and girl fall in love. Boy and girl marry, etc., etc., etc. Or. Boy (Girl) meets 25 girls (boys). Boy and girl perform falling in love in front of video cameras, producers and millions of television viewers. It is spring, the feverish time when people fall in love, when people who have fallen in love promise their lives to one another — blushing brides, nervous grooms, extravagant weddings, compressed versions of the overproduced rituals of television shows like “The Bachelor” and “The Bachelorette.”

headline: Daniel Jurafsky
text: Daniel Jurafsky is a professor of linguistics and computer science at Stanford. He teaches a popular freshman seminar course called “The Language of Food,” which is also the title of his forthcoming book.

headline: Lessons in Catholic Judgment
text: “WOULD Pope Francis Sign the New Catholic Teacher Contract?” That’s the question spelled out on a dozen billboards that have gone up around Cincinnati over the last week or so.

headline: The Benefits of Mixing Rich and Poor
text: Whenever President Obama proposes a major federal investment in early education, as he did in his two most recent State of the Union addresses, critics have a two-word riposte: Head Start. Researchers have long cast doubt on that program’s effectiveness. The most damning evidence comes from a 2012 federal evaluation that used gold-standard methodology and concluded that children who participated in Head Start were not more successful in elementary school than others. That finding was catnip to the detractors. “Head Start’s impact is no better than random,” The Wall Street Journal editorialized. Why throw good money after bad?

headline: Rhode Island, a State Sized Just Right to Contain Its Pride
text: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — A lot of people here say that Rhode Island suffers from being the smallest state in the country. Jimmy Saccoccio, manager of the Olneyville New York System, a popular diner, agrees.

headline: Saving Striped Bass
text: MONTAUK, N.Y. — AS summer approaches, the view from Long Island’s easternmost point transforms at dawn as anglers casting for striped bass begin taking their places along the surf. By June, the fish will be racing through these waters on the way to coastal New England as part of their northern migration, a biological spectacle akin to the movement of salmon on the West Coast.

headline: Battles for the Crease Exact a Toll in the Playoffs
text: Boston Bruins forward Jarome Iginla knows the playoffs can be a painful experience. In every game, he is poked, slashed, crosschecked, shoved, punched, tripped, sworn at repeatedly and thrown to the ice.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, May 11
text: Speaker John A. Boehner appointed seven Republicans to a 12-person committee charged with investigating the 2012 attack in Benghazi, Libya, that killed four Americans. Representative Trey Gowdy, Republican of South Carolina, was tapped to lead the investigation and will appear on “Fox News Sunday,” along with Representative Xavier Becerra, Democrat of California, to debate the new committee and whether Democrats should participate.

headline: Advice for a Troubled Teen
text: THE eighth-grade boy I mentor had been suspended for calling his substitute teacher a bitch, loudly enough that a teacher’s aide heard. Until this incident, he had been making real progress with his behavior problems in school. He had vastly improved since sixth grade, when suspensions were a regular part of his life. He disrupted class, taunted boys and hit girls. In seventh grade, his behavior, if not his schoolwork, had slowly improved.

headline: When Music Was Strange
text: BELGRADE LAKES, Me. — IN 1975 it was my friend Daryl — one of the very few African-American students in my mostly white prep school — who was the champion of the new. “Boylan,” he said one day after school. “You have to check this out.” Then he put Miles Davis’s “Bitches Brew” on the turntable.

headline: Why the Kidnapped Schoolgirls Matter
text: My Sunday column looks at the kidnapping of the NIgerian schoolgirls by Boko Haram, and the similar attacks on girls’ education by the Taliban and other militants, and asks why extremists are so afraid of a girl with a book. The basic answer is that nothing can be more transformative for a society than educating girls and then moving those educated women into the formal labor force. And just as Boko Haram and the Taliban are right to fear girls’ education, those of us appalled by extremism should be investing in girls’ education. That’s the way to stick it to Boko Haram.

headline: The Rise of Antibiotic Resistance
text: The World Health Organization has surveyed the growth of antibiotic-resistant germs around the world — the first such survey it has ever conducted — and come up with disturbing findings. In a report issued late last month, the organization found that antimicrobial resistance in bacteria (the main focus of the report), fungi, viruses and parasites is an increasingly serious threat in every part of the world. “A problem so serious that it threatens the achievements of modern medicine,” the organization said. “A post-antibiotic era, in which common infections and minor injuries can kill, far from being an apocalyptic fantasy, is instead a very real possibility for the 21st century.”

headline: Russia Ratchets Up Ukraine’s Gas Bills in Shift to an Economic Battlefield
text: LONDON — Gazprom, the natural gas giant 50.01 percent owned by the Russian government, keeps ratcheting up the bill for Ukraine, increasing the economic pressure on Kiev in tandem with military pressure along Ukraine’s eastern border.

headline: Stowaways Are Stranded in Mexico by Train Ban
text: MEXICO CITY — Hundreds of Central American migrants trying to make their way to the United States have been stranded in Mexico in recent weeks after the freight-train line they ride — labeled the Beast — began enforcing a ban on stowaways, migrant advocates say.

headline: Disease of Pakistan’s Poor Now Worries the Affluent
text: KARACHI, Pakistan — Until recently, polio was considered a poor man’s problem in Pakistan — a crippling virus that festered in the mountainous tribal belt, traversed the country on interprovincial buses, and spread via infected children who played in the open sewers of sprawling slums.

headline: In Indian Candidate, Hindu Right Sees a Reawakening
text: VARANASI, India — Shortly after dawn in the village square here each day, two dozen boys and men dress up in crisply laundered khaki shorts and fall into military-style formation behind a saffron-colored flag, brandishing bamboo sticks as if they were rifles.

headline: Against Penguins, One Line Clicks for Rangers
text: The Rangers’ 5-1 victory over Pittsburgh on Friday was very much about Martin St. Louis and the way his teammates rallied around him after the death of his mother. But among the Rangers who touched helmets with St. Louis as they came off the ice were the three forwards who were perhaps most responsible for prolonging the Eastern Conference semifinal series: Derick Brassard, Mats Zuccarello and Benoit Pouliot.

headline: Going Home With Kenny G
text: In China, Kenny G’s instrumental “Going Home” has been used for years as a way to tell people to leave.

headline: Methodology on Supreme Court Analysis
text: Accompanying Adam Liptak’s article on the Supreme Court’s partisanship is a chart showing every court since 1953. The justices are shaded based on the party of the president who appointed them. They’re arrayed left to right based on their ideology.

headline: Merkel and Hollande Send Russia a Warning
text: STRALSUND, Germany — Chancellor Angela Merkel invites only the most select of visitors to this pretty Baltic Sea port, the center of her parliamentary constituency and a rich symbol of Germany’s centuries of trade with Russia and the country’s revival after the fall of the Berlin Wall almost 25 years ago.

headline: When Politics Approach the Bench
text: The Supreme Court has long included justices whose voting was often at odds with the views of the presidents who appointed them. That mix, including conservative Democratic appointees and liberal Republican ones, ended in 2010.

headline: China Says Goodbye in the Key of G: Kenny G
text: BEIJING — There are many things about modern China that defy easy explanation: parents posing their children next to live tigers, the sight of grown women wearing furry cat-ear headbands while shopping, the performance-art-like spectacle of strangers napping together in Ikea display beds.

headline: The Polarized Court
text: WASHINGTON — When the Supreme Court issued its latest campaign finance decision last month, the justices lined up in a familiar way. The five appointed by Republican presidents voted for the Republican National Committee, which was a plaintiff. The four appointed by Democrats dissented.

headline: A Contest Shifts From Ideology to Résumés
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: A Degree Goal: To Close a Gender Gap That Favors Women
text: When Victor Sáenz, an education professor at the University of Texas at Austin, began to focus his research nearly a decade ago on the plight of men in education, he experienced some pushback, even from fellow academics.

headline: For Mother
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — First and foremost, if you’ve ever been important in the life of a child or a companion animal who depends on you, Happy Mother’s Day.

headline: A Big Spender Aims to Push State Politics Further Right
text: Shortly before the primaries in March, voters in Amarillo, Midland and Odessa received a two-and-a-half page letter in the mail from Tim Dunn, a wealthy local oil and gas developer.

headline: Antiques and ‘Ink Master’ Play Roles in Renaissance of Fading Fraternal Order
text: WAXAHACHIE — Standing in a doorway of their 123-year-old brick lodge, four members of the Waxahachie Odd Fellows welcomed their brothers to a Monday night meeting. In their 30s, the four men were bearded and tattooed and wore black T-shirts that contrasted with the button-down dress of past members whose pictures adorned the lodge’s portrait wall.

headline: In Historic Pick, Rams Take Michael Sam in Final Round of Draft
text: Over seven rounds of the National Football League draft, teams chose more than 200 players, from surefire stars to kickers and all-but-anonymous players from tiny Division II programs.

headline: At 11, New Master Breaks Record Older Than She Is
text: An 11-year-old Californian in March became the youngest American girl to ever become a master, breaking a record that had stood for 18 years.

headline: New York Police Recruit Muslims to Be Informers
text: One man was a food cart vendor from Afghanistan, arrested during an argument with a parking enforcement officer over a ticket. Another was an Egyptian-born limousine driver, picked up in a prostitution sting. Still another was an accounting student from Pakistan, in custody for driving without a valid license.

headline: Houston Is Next for a Nomadic Quarterback
text: Several notable quarterbacks came off the board during Day 3 of the N.F.L. draft Saturday, including Tom Savage of Pittsburgh, who went in the fourth round to the Houston Texans (135th over all). A few years ago, it would have been tough to imagine Savage’s being drafted, as he was in the middle of a meandering five-year career in which he played for three programs.

headline: Spieth Avoids Bogeys to Claim Share of Players Lead
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — For Jordan Spieth, golf-course etiquette extends to how he refers to his elders, which includes everyone in this week’s Players Championship field. Grouped in the final twosome Saturday with the 29-year-old Martin Kaymer — or, as Spieth was tempted to call him, Mr. Kaymer — Spieth, 20, was as patient as a hunter in a deer blind.

headline: With ‘Clean’ Picks, Giants Look Beyond Talent
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Five of the Giants’ seven 2014 draft picks were team captains in college. Two were National Honor Society members. One is an academic all-American who spent an off-season building homes in Haiti’s poorest neighborhoods. Another graduated from college early and is writing a book.

headline: Familiar Path for Mets Against Phillies
text: Not even two weeks ago, General Manager Sandy Alderson’s goal of a 90-win Mets season did not seem so absurd. They finished April with a 15-11 record, and it seemed as if their long rebuilding project might show some results.

text: “In regular classes people are trying to distract you with music videos or saying, ‘Hey, look at this cat playing a piano’ on their phones. Whereas in an A.P. class, they will show you something from the text and say, ‘Hey, this is fun.’”

text: “It’s going to go out of the family. But I think of it this way: It’s not going anywhere. It’s always going to be there, and it really doesn’t matter who owns it.”

text: Halfway through the first quarter of Game 3 on Saturday, LeBron James fielded a rebound, ambled up the court, split two defenders, gathered his feet in the paint, leapt to score and was grabbed from behind over the shoulders with two hands by Nets forward Paul Pierce.
