headline: What’s On Sunday
text: 9 P.M. (NBC) ROSEMARY’S BABY In this two-part remake of the 1968 Roman Polanski thriller, the director Agnieszka Holland transfers the setting from the Dakota on Central Park West to the Eighth Arrondissement of Paris, where Rosemary Woodhouse (Zoe Saldana, above) has moved with her husband, Guy (Patrick J. Adams), a writer with a teaching stint at the Sorbonne. Ms. Holland also transforms the dotty older couple next door, first played by Ruth Gordon and Sidney Blackmer, into French sophisticates (Carole Bouquet and Jason Isaacs) who offer the Americans their friendship and a spare apartment. This being Paris, they discuss the transaction in an elegant sex club. And when Rosemary, eager to get pregnant again after a miscarriage, visits an OBGYN, the examining room looks like the rare-books section of the Académie Française. “ ‘Rosemary’s Baby’ bends to current fashions, and, accordingly, is more straightforward and much gorier than the original film,” Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. “But partly because the story has been so altered, it still has mystery and suspense. And because it’s Paris, it is possible to wonder, at least for a while, if maybe the problem is Rosemary, not her neighbors, who seem so serenely superior and all knowing.” Part 2 will be shown on Thursday at 9.

headline: A Soundtrack Made of Muscle
text: Danse: A French-American Festival of Performance and Ideas is eclectic by design. Each of the institutions taking part in this citywide series has made its own programming choices. For the double bill it presented on Tuesday, Abrons Arts Center gravitated toward the outer edges of conventional definitions of dance. Both of the works — one by Claudia Triozzi, the other by David Wampach — were as focused on the sounds the body makes as on how a body might move. Both began with an open mouth, stretched as in the Munch painting, ready to scream.

headline: Paying Homage, Vivaciously and Somberly
text: “Toccata in D” may sound like an innocuous title, but not for a work by an atonal composer like George Perle, who died in 2009 at 93. After a colleague told him that such a title would be “inflammatory,” Perle removed the offending letter. (Atonal and Serialist composers do not write in any particular key.)

headline: Corrections: May 11, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Vietnam Fails to Rally Partners in China Dispute
text: HANOI, Vietnam — Vietnam’s prime minister, Nguyen Tan Dung, accused China on Sunday of “dangerous and serious violations” in a territorial dispute that has raised anger toward China here to the highest levels in years.

headline: Vows | Grandma’s a Bridesmaid
text: Three spunky grandmothers stole the show as bridesmaids in their granddaughters’ weddings.

headline: Celebrate Mom With a Martian Crater All Her Own
text: If you’re still looking for something special for Mother’s Day, remember: Until this year, there has been no crater love.

headline: In Our Pages: May 12
text: 1914: Germany Seeking Control of Hayti

headline: Front-Runner in Afghan Election Secures a Key Ally
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Abdullah Abdullah, the front-runner in Afghanistan’s presidential election campaign, announced Sunday that he had won the endorsement of Zalmay Rassoul, the third-place candidate, as part of his effort to gather enough support to win in the next round of voting.

headline: Ukraine Vote on Separation Held in Chaos
text: DONETSK, Ukraine — Separatists in two provinces of eastern Ukraine conducted chaotic and sometimes violent plebiscites on Sunday that offered voters just one question about self-rule, while raising many more about where events in the region were headed.

headline: African Rivers May Heighten H.I.V. Peril
text: Gynecologists working in Africa suspect that women there are more vulnerable to H.I.V. because of waterborne parasites. An ambitious research project aims to revolutionize treatment for young women.

headline: Protest of Planned Incinerator Turns Violent in Chinese City
text: SHANGHAI — A huge demonstration against a planned waste incinerator in one of eastern China’s biggest cities turned violent on Saturday with protesters overturning and setting fire to police cars, leaving at least 10 demonstrators and 29 police officers injured, according to Xinhua, the official state-run news agency.

headline: The Premier League Standings if Only Goals by English Players Counted
text: What would the standings look like in a hypothetical league in which a goal does not count unless it is scored by an English player?

headline: Samsung Leader Stable After Heart Attack
text: The chairman of Samsung Electronics, Lee Kun-hee, who helped transform the business into a technology giant, was in stable condition Sunday after suffering a heart attack, the company said.

headline: Manchester City Stands Tall in a Season of Dashed Hopes
text: The institutional memory of sports is typically built one highlight at a time. That is the way we remember players and games and seasons — by what goes right. It is more pleasant that way.

headline: Hamilton Holds Off Rosberg at Spanish Grand Prix
text: Barcelona, Spain — On Saturday, after scoring his fourth pole position of the year and the 35th of his career, Lewis Hamilton said he had never driven a car that was so much faster than those of his immediate competitors.

headline: Podcast: Spiders With Personality
text: Spiders in the Kalahari desert develop personalities that are affected by their spider peers, just like teenagers.

headline: Sabathia Put on Disabled List
text: MILWAUKEE — C. C. Sabathia had swelling in his right knee after his start May 4, but he did not mention it to anyone because the Yankees’ rotation had already been hit with so many injuries. When he felt more pain in his knee in Saturday’s game against the Milwaukee Brewers and encountered more swelling, he spoke up.

headline: ScienceTake | Unlocking Spider Secrets
text: A new look at the social organization of some eight-legged predators.

headline: Hagel ‘Open’ to Reviewing Military’s Ban on Transgender People
text: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel said in an interview broadcast on Sunday that the military should “continually” review its prohibition on transgender people in the armed forces, calling into question whether the Pentagon’s ban may eventually be lifted, as was the ban on gay men and lesbians in the military.

headline: Rubio on a Presidential Bid, and Climate Change
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Marco Rubio on Sunday said that he was ready to be president, becoming the second potential Republican candidate recently to drop big hints about 2016 as he vies for early attention in a crowded field of maybes.

headline: The Lives of Sociable Spiders
text: Of the world’s 43,000 known varieties of spiders, an overwhelming majority are peevish loners: spinning webs, slinging lassos, liquefying prey and attacking trespassers, each spider unto its own.

headline: Seconds That Last an Eternity
text: The seventh game of the playoff series between the Nets and the Toronto Raptors on May 4 was about two and a half hours old and seemingly just about finished.

headline: Rebuilding a Neighborhood, but Not a Community
text: Like relics from a past civilization, tiny chunks of cracked tile and smashed bricks rest in the dirt of parking lots or empty lots along the south side of Delancey Street, near the corner of Clinton Street. They attest to a community on the Lower East Side of Manhattan that vanished 47 years ago, when some 1,800 families, mostly poor and Puerto Rican, were uprooted and their tenement homes demolished in the name of urban renewal.

headline: Austrian Singer Wins Eurovision Contest
text: PARIS — With a shimmering golden gown, trim dark beard and voice made for Broadway, an Austrian drag queen, Conchita Wurst, was the runaway winner of this year’s 59th annual Eurovision Song Contest on Saturday in Copenhagen.

headline: ‘Neighbors’ Tops Weekend Box Office
text: Sorry, Spidey. A raunchy fraternity just threw a bong through your web. The No. 1 movie in the United States and Canada over the weekend was “Neighbors,” an R-rated comedy that rode strong reviews and a well-oiled marketing campaign to an astounding $51.1 million in ticket sales, trampling “The Amazing Spider-Man 2.”

headline: Growing Up Without the One Who Delivered You
text: Mother’s Day weekend can’t be easy for people who lost their mothers at a young age. Many no doubt just lie low, keep quiet and wait for it to be over. But the documentary “The (Dead Mothers) Club,” Monday night on HBO, gives voice to at least a few such people, and their stories will surely resonate with many others.

headline: Newsletter of the Hurt and Lonely
text: Matthew, the chronically anxious 19-year-old played with consummate skill and grace by Gideon Glick in “The Few,” a new play by Samuel D. Hunter, moves with the herky-jerky rhythm of a puppet whose strings are being pulled by someone a little woozy. His long arms end in hands that are forever darting around like little birds, making expressive gestures that suggest Matthew’s inability to fully articulate his feelings.

headline: Chamber Orchestra Works, From Intense to Zany
text: Part of the pleasure of hearing Ensemble ACJW, the group of young professionals formed under the auspices of Carnegie Hall and the Juilliard School, is considering the myriad options that lie before its members. Will they end up as soloists, orchestral players, educators, entrepreneurs?

headline: Traveling Back in Time to Dance Her Case
text: For nearly 30 years, Miki Orihara has been a stalwart member of the Martha Graham Dance Company. Such dedication is an implicit statement of belief in the continued relevance of classic modern dance. But in the program notes for “Resonance,” the solo concert she performed at the La MaMa Moves festival Friday, Ms. Orihara was explicit, arguing for the timelessness of older works and their connections to present-day choreography and concerns. With five short pieces, she danced her case in chronological order.

headline: Raging, Vaguely, Against the Machine
text: A bunch of years ago, Erika M. Anderson made it out of South Dakota to California. Eventually, recording under the alias E M A, she released an album, “Past Life Martyred Saints,” that captured the mood of the move — the terror, the pathos, the relief. A change in place saved her, sort of.

headline: Sugar? Sure, but Salted With Meaning
text: With her stinging, site-specific installation at the former Domino Sugar compound on the edge of the East River in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, Kara Walker expands her imposing achievement to include three dimensions and monumental scale. In the process, she raises the bar on an overused art-spectacle formula as well as her own work. And she subjects a grand, decaying structure fraught with the conflicted history of the sugar trade and its physical residue to a kind of predemolition purification ritual.

headline: A Music Festival Dies, and an Orchestra Mourns
text: The Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra ended the 2014 Spring for Music festival on Saturday night at Carnegie Hall by playing works that shared the theme of spirituality, but of a grim sort, touching on martyrdom, apocalyptic scenes and death and containing an element of gallows humor. This was not just the sixth and last concert of this year’s festival, but the final offering of the whole visionary venture.

headline: Playing on Mother’s Day After His Mother’s Sudden Death, St. Louis Buoys Rangers
text: When Brad Richards learned Thursday that the mother of Martin St. Louis, his Rangers teammate and longtime friend, had unexpectedly died, his instincts were not about hockey.

headline: Albert Dormer at the World Senior Pairs in 1990
text: A few bridge players have better reputations than they deserve. Perhaps more are underrated; one was Albert Dormer, who died at 88 on March 18 in Scotland, where he had moved upon retirement.

headline: A Director’s Tasting Menu Shows Off a Ballet Company’s Strengths
text: PHILADELPHIA — The Pennsylvania Ballet, celebrating its 50th anniversary this season, is in transition. Last weekend it presented what it called a Director’s Choice triple bill, which had been announced last year. Two weeks ago, the company said its artistic director, Roy Kaiser, would step down at the end of the season.

headline: Walter Isaacson to Deliver Jefferson Lecture
text: Walter Isaacson, the best-selling biographer and president of the Aspen Institute, will deliver the 43rd annual Jefferson Lecture on Monday night at the Kennedy Center in Washington. The lecture is sponsored by the National Endowment for the Humanities and considered the federal government’s highest honor in the humanities.

headline: Driven to Accumulate and Dancing Till Nothing’s Left
text: The sidewalk in front of the Club at La MaMa on Friday night was teeming with people needing a fix of Merce past. The lure was a shared program featuring Ashley Chen and Dylan Crossman, two much-admired former members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, in a dual presentation by Danse: A French-American Festival of Performance and Ideas, and La MaMa Moves! Dance Festival. Before the house opened, Mr. Chen joined the crowd to smoke a cigarette; as he put it, “It’s the French warm-up.”

headline: Dance Lineups Announced
text: Dance companies from France, The Hague and Denmark will appear in the Joyce Theater’s fall and winter lineup, said Joyce officials, who recently announced that the National Ballet of Canada would open the season on Sept. 9 with Christopher Wheeldon’s “Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland.” The schedule will also include Pacific Northwest Ballet performing works by Mr. Wheeldon and Alejandro Cerrudo (Oct. 8 to 12), the all-male company Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo (Dec. 16 to Jan. 4), and Royal Danish Ballet principals and soloists (Jan. 13 to 18). The French-Argentinean tango group Cia Unión Tanguera will perform from Sept. 23 to Oct. 5 as part of its “Nuit Blanche” North American tour, and the flamenco dancer Soledad Barrio is slated to bring her company, Noche Flamenca, to the Joyce from Oct. 29 to Nov. 9.

headline: A Memoir From the Eye of a Financial Storm
text: One afternoon in the summer of 2008, as the financial system was careening toward the abyss that would send the United States into the worst economic emergency  since the Great Depression, Timothy F. Geithner — then president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, and later, President Obama’s Treasury secretary — tried to lighten the mood in his office with “an impromptu contest for the best metaphor for what was happening.”

headline: A Night of Gospel, Spanning Generations
text: NEWARK — Consider Erica Campbell, at the McDonald’s Gospelfest Saturday night at the Prudential Center. She’s got the No. 1 album on the Billboard gospel chart, and co-stars in a successful reality show, “Mary Mary,” on We TV. She’s a personage in this precinct, a cross-media star, from whom you’d expect some kind of show. She brought one: herself.

headline: Stepping Up to a Host Spot
text: Larry Wilmore, named on Friday as host of “The Minority Report,” the show that will fill the 11:30 p.m. slot on Comedy Central, thought the time had passed for him to receive his own late-night show.

headline: Making Organ Donations Worthwhile

text: “Quotation is a serviceable substitute for wit.” — Deb Amlen, quoting Oscar WILDE

headline: A Hot Topic at Princeton: ‘Check Your Privilege’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Factory Conversion Moves Forward
text: The effort to turn a century-old sawdust factory in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, into an acoustically sound concert hall, recording studio, nightclub and center for composers is moving ahead, with organizers saying that they have raised the $16 million needed to finish construction. The space on North 6th Street, called the Original Music Workshop, has already drawn respected musicians and celebrities inside its weathered brick walls for concerts, even before it had a roof. Now its founder, Kevin Dolan, said that he had lined up what he called “philanthropic investors” to put up the money needed to finish construction. It is an unusual arrangement. Mr. Dolan said that the investors would become part owners of the building, which they would allow the Original Music Workshop, a nonprofit, to use rent-free. In the future they could then give their shares to the workshop, sell them to the workshop, or sell the building. Mr. Dolan, 62, said this would reduce the risk to people who might be reluctant to put money into a new organization without a long track record. He added that the space could open as soon as the fall of 2015.

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: Latinos and Abortion
text: To the Editor:

headline: A New York Premiere for a Scottish Play
text: “The Events,” a moving drama by the Scottish playwright David Greig, about the aftermath and community response when a tragedy takes place in a small town, will have its New York premiere at New York Theater Workshop next winter, the theater planned to announce on Monday. The show, directed by Ramin Gray, was first presented at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe last summer, where it drew critical praise and won several awards, including the Carol Tambor Best of Edinburgh honor. In Edinburgh, a different local choir was featured at each performance, providing a musical element while also aiding the plot in other ways, much like a Greek chorus. New York Theater Workshop plans to take a similar approach. “The Events,” which makes its United States premiere in June at the International Festival of Arts and Ideas in New Haven, will come to New York in February. The show rounds out the previously announced New York Theater Workshop season.

headline: Protect Our Bats
text: DISEASE and heedless management of wind turbines are killing North America’s bats, with potentially devastating consequences for agriculture and human health.

headline: Thailand’s Dilemma
text: The country runs straight into a fork in the road.

headline: Follow the Money, China-Style
text: BEIJING — Since China introduced a floating exchange rate on July 21, 2005, the Chinese yuan has consistently risen in value against the United States dollar, from a low of 8.28 yuan to the dollar in July 2005 to a high of 6.06 in January of this year. But the appreciation of the yuan has failed to convince ordinary Chinese people that their money buys more; on the contrary, they feel it’s worth less.

headline: Mets Finally Bring a Runner Home and End a Five-Game Skid
text: The only encouraging thing about the Mets’ play recently was that they had been able to put runners on base, which had somewhat tempered the panic of their losing ways.

headline: The Dark Shadow of Agent Orange
text: The use of Agent Orange during the Vietnam War continues to cast a dark shadow over both American veterans and the Vietnamese.

headline: Agent Orange’s Long Legacy, for Vietnam and Veterans
text: Britain was the first to use defoliants as a war tactic in Southeast Asia. That was in the early 1950s in Malaya, then a British colony, before it became the independent Malaysia. British planes sprayed Malayan jungles with chemicals to strip trees bare and deprive communist guerrillas of cover. They also destroyed crops that the insurgents relied on for sustenance. A decade later, in what was then South Vietnam, United States armed forces resorted to precisely the same methods on an enormous scale in their long struggle against Viet Cong and North Vietnamese fighters.

headline: Party Chief’s Downfall a Central Act in Tiananmen Drama
text: In mid-May 1989, Zhang Gang was among a group of Chinese officials and scholars seeking to defuse the student protests that had filled Tiananmen Square for a month. They had been trying to coax concessions from the government and the demonstrators to end the volatile confrontation and protect the embattled Communist Party general secretary, Zhao Ziyang, who was increasingly at odds with the party patriarch, Deng Xiaoping.

headline: A Discussion of the Danger and Promise of Tech
text: Claire Cain Miller of The New York Times recently conducted a series of interviews with seven people who helped provide a glimpse into the not-too-distant future. Last Monday, two of them — Sebastian Thrun and Clara Shih — joined her and readers in a chat on Facebook. Mr. Thrun is a co-founder and chief executive of Udacity, an inventor of driverless cars and a founder of Google X; and Ms. Shih is a founder and chief executive of Hearsay Social. The following are excerpts from the exchange, condensed and lightly edited.

headline: Show Us the Drone Memos
text: WASHINGTON — I BELIEVE that killing an American citizen without a trial is an extraordinary concept and deserves serious debate. I can’t imagine appointing someone to the federal bench, one level below the Supreme Court, without fully understanding that person’s views concerning the extrajudicial killing of American citizens.

headline: HUD, New Jersey and Sandy
text: The Department of Housing and Urban Development’s new review of New Jersey’s mismanaged Hurricane Sandy recovery effort uncovered no violations of federal law. But the report raised troubling concerns about the program’s lack of transparency. And while it could have made the point more forcefully, it did warn that the state could end up violating civil rights regulations if it did not take sufficient steps to ensure that poor and minority households got a fair share of post-Sandy aid.

headline: Secret Pension Fund Deals
text: How could the multibillion-dollar state pension industry be more transparent and less prone to influence and corruption?

headline: A Lesson in Farming, Classroom to Cafeteria
text: HAGERSTOWN, Ind. — Beyond a stack of hay bales, past the site of Indiana’s first soil-judging contest, high school students in this tiny eastern town stroll down a grassy slope to reach their newest classroom: a fenced-in field of cud-chewing cattle.

headline: Trailing by 22, Clippers Rally to Tie Series
text: LOS ANGELES — Arriving fashionably late, as the actor Mark Wahlberg, the singer Rihanna and the boxer Floyd Mayweather Jr. did to their courtside seats Sunday, is a very Los Angeles thing to do. They were, in a way, very much like the basketball team they came to see.

headline: Its Ratings Sliding, Fox Looks for Hope in a Gotham City Before Batman
text: LOS ANGELES — Batman saves Gotham. Can he do the same thing for Fox?

headline: Questions About N.F.L. Draft’s Future Involve Location, Date and Length
text: If the 2014 N.F.L. draft was the event’s swan song at Radio City Music Hall, it was quite a number. From the hysteria around Johnny Manziel on opening night to Michael Sam’s selection near the end of the third day, it was one of the most memorable of the nine consecutive drafts held at Radio City, the venerable theater in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: A Devotion to Language Proves Risky
text: BEIJING — A poet, linguist and globe-trotting polyglot, Abduweli Ayup had a passion for the spoken word, notably Uighur, the Turkic language spoken in his homeland in China’s far northwest. In 2011, soon after finishing his graduate studies in the United States, Mr. Ayup returned home to open a chain of “mother tongue” schools in Xinjiang, the vast Central Asian region whose forced marriage to the Han Chinese heartland has become increasingly tumultuous.

headline: Warnings Along F.C.C.’s Fast Lane
text: The next time the loudmouth in the next cubicle interrupts you with yet another recap of his weekend, just start talking about “net neutrality.”

headline: Democrats Look Dubiously at Joining Benghazi Panel
text: WASHINGTON — House Democrats on Sunday made it clear that they do not expect fair proceedings from the Republican-led panel newly tasked with investigating the 2012 attack in Benghazi, Libya, but offered no definitive answer on whether they would appoint any of their own members to participate.

headline: Charles Marowitz, Iconoclastic Director and Playwright, Dies at 82
text: Charles Marowitz, who brought a thorny iconoclasm to a versatile theater career as a director, playwright, teacher and critic, died on May 2 in Agoura Hills, Calif. He was 82.

headline: A Triumph of Enlightenment ... Eventually
text: By the time I arrived at Radio City Music Hall in Manhattan on Saturday, the sixth round of the N.F.L. draft had started, but Michael Sam had still not been selected.

headline: European Candidates See Opportunity on Extreme Edge
text: PARIS — The campaign  advertisement in the Czech Republic begins with a snake slithering out of a red European Union flag and a montage of pictures of supposed threats to Czech identity, including a 500-euro note, an Israeli flag and a gathering of Orthodox Jews.

headline: Patrick J. Lucey, Governor and Vice-Presidential Candidate, Dies at 96
text: Patrick J. Lucey, who was twice elected governor of Wisconsin and ran for vice president in 1980 on an independent ticket with John B. Anderson, died on Saturday in Milwaukee. He was 96.

headline: Programs on Demand, Just for PBS Members
text: As television viewers increasingly turn to video on demand to watch shows when they want, PBS and its local stations plan to follow them, but with a twist: They are creating a streaming video service that will be available only to members of local PBS stations.

headline: Sterling Offers Apology in Interview With CNN
text: Donald Sterling, the embattled owner of the Los Angeles Clippers, broke his silence Sunday in an interview with CNN’s Anderson Cooper during which he apologized for making racist remarks.

headline: In Ukraine, Vote on Self-Rule Leaves Many Questions
text: Separatists in Donetsk and Slovyansk cast early ballots in support of local autonomy, but the U.S. and Europe condemned the vote.

headline: Legal Alliance Gains Host of Court Victories for Conservative Christian Movement
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — Alan Sears, who has run the Christian legal group Alliance Defending Freedom since its founding 20 years ago, turned to a picture of Abraham Lincoln in his office here and noted the decades of blood and tears it took to abolish slavery.

headline: Island Fixer-Upper, Near the Madding Crowd
text: VENICE — A short boat ride from the elegant tourist horde that is Venice, Poveglia Island could be considered the anti-Venice. There are no souvenir shops, no gondolas and no people. A brick bell tower rises from a jumble of abandoned buildings. The overgrown gardens have been untended for decades.

headline: Nadal Picks Up a Clay Title in Madrid, but the Victory Is Short of Convincing
text: MADRID — Rafael Nadal put his clay-court season back on track Sunday, winning the Madrid Masters 1000 in a final that was cut short when his opponent, Kei Nishikori, retired with a back injury.

headline: Crazy Climate Economics
text: Everywhere you look these days, you see Marxism on the rise. Well, O.K., maybe you don’t — but conservatives do. If you so much as mention income inequality, you’ll be denounced as the second coming of Joseph Stalin; Rick Santorum has declared that any use of the word “class” is “Marxism talk.” In the right’s eyes, sinister motives lurk everywhere — for example, George Will says the only reason progressives favor trains is their goal of “diminishing Americans’ individualism in order to make them more amenable to collectivism.”

headline: Rutgers Player Is Charged With Assault in Minnesota
text: A Rutgers quarterback has been arrested in connection with an assault in southern Minnesota that left another football player in critical condition, the police said.

headline: In Town of Missing Girls, Sorrow, but Little Progress
text: CHIBOK, Nigeria — The women surged forward, anguish creasing their faces. Many were crying. A collective wail went up, but the officials traveling with the visiting local dignitary pushed them back, shushing them so he could speak.

headline: In Washington, Walk on the Grass, but Step Gently
text: WASHINGTON — It has played host to civil rights marches, presidential inaugurations, fireworks displays and decades of picnics. But in recent years the National Mall, envisioned more than a century ago as a lush carpet of green connecting the nation’s most treasured monuments, has looked more like a West Texas dust bowl.

headline: Impunity and the Border Patrol
text: If a Border Patrol agent beats, kicks, threatens or otherwise abuses you, you can file a complaint. What you can’t count on, evidently, is anything being done about it.

headline: Russia Revisits Its History to Nail Down Its Future

headline: The City Council, Playing by Better Rules

headline: A Long Way to Privacy Safeguards

headline: ‘Penny Dreadful’ Recap: Up and Down the Ladder of Wealth
text: Early on in Showtime’s premiere episode of “Penny Dreadful,” a pallid spiritualist named Vanessa Ives (Eva Green) confronts Ethan Chandler (Josh Hartnett) after his third-rate Wild West show comes through London in 1891. She fact-checks his tale of surviving the Battle of the Little Bighorn 15 years earlier and then subjects him to a bit of character analysis. There’s the tell-tale trembling hand of the alcoholic and the contusion that probably came from a cuckolded husband. But she mainly zeros in on Ethan’s “expensive watch but threadbare jacket,” along with a nice pair of boots that he has had resoled several times.

headline: Rarified Perfume: The Perks of Membership at MiN New York
text: As the co-curators of the indie apothecary MiN New York in NoLita, Chad Murawczyk and Mindy Yang take a simple approach to stocking their shelves: “If we can’t find something we want, we make it,” Murawczyk says. So far, that’s lead to such varied creations as atmospheric candles gilded in precious metals, high-performance skin-care creams and hand-ticked silk scarves depicting photographs of Havana shot by Murawczyk himself. The latest addition to the MiN oeuvre: a series of abstract fragrances, called Scent Stories, debuting this week. Composed of notes that normally don’t land in eau, such as pencil shavings and ozone, the collection of 11 unisex scents took a year to develop with a master perfumer in Grasse, France. “The idea was to make each scent like a chapter or a short story: it would be vivid, visceral and disconnected from the others, but take you somewhere,” Yang says. Indeed, many of the fragrances were inspired by the pair’s own memories and journeys. Dahab, for example, evokes the deserts and deep seas of Egypt where Murawczyk spent time. “It’s incense-y, smoky and mysterious,” he says of the saffron-, cumin- and nutmeg-laced blend. Yang, who is also a trained reiki healer, is particularly drawn to Shaman, describing it as a “futurist nomad” scent, with a “mystical air.” The violet leaf note is especially nuanced, she says, and conveys “a sense of clairvoyance.”

headline: What’s On Monday
text: 6:45 P.M. (Cinemax) MAMA (2013) In this modern fairy tale directed by Andy Muschietti, the uncle (Nikolaj Coster-Waldau) of two feral sisters (Megan Charpentier, above, and Isabelle Nélisse), abandoned by their father in the woods, moves them into a home with his goth girlfriend (Jessica Chastain). Then a grotesque figure the girls call Mama appears in the shadows and begins to wreak havoc on their lives. But is the monster simply a coping mechanism for dealing with tragedy? Or is Mama the essence of the girls’ dead mother? “Instead of delivering buckets of guts and gore, this ghost story offers a strong sense of time and place, along with the kind of niceties that don’t often figure into horror flicks, notably pictorial beauty, an atmosphere throbbing with dread and actors so good that you don’t want anyone to take an ax to them,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. And while the director Guillermo del Toro, “the reigning godfather of motion picture horror,” is only an executive producer on the film, she wrote, “it fits with the more successful movies he’s signed on to. Mr. del Toro understands that nothing says terror like a home that’s become a rattling cage.”

headline: Two New Projects at Storm King Beckon Art Lovers Upstate
text: Now that the frenzy of Frieze weekend has passed, art lovers may be feeling the impulse to ditch the crowds, flee the city and light out for the territory. Fortunately, New York’s outlying regions offer abundant reasons to make the reverse cultural commute, and this spring, Storm King Art Center announces two new ones: the just-opened exhibition “Zhang Huan: Evoking Tradition” and a newly commissioned installation by the sculptor Virginia Overton.

headline: A Changing Shape in America’s Age Distribution
text: Demographers have used the image of a triangle or pyramid to describe the world’s population: a large group of young people at the bottom, progressively fewer people in each succeeding generation, with a small number of very old people at the top.

headline: An Electronic Double Bill to Shiver the Timbers
text: The electronic music double bill on Saturday night at the Brooklyn Masonic Temple was a superb clash of aesthetic extremes. The Red Bull Music Academy Festival paired the United States debut of the Haxan Cloak (the English musician Bobby Krlic) with the German musician Robert Henke and his laser project, Lumière. Mr. Henke’s music and light show were crisp, bright, geometric and propulsive, a calibrated barrage. The Haxan Cloak performance was amorphous, ominous and immersive, a transcendent plunge into darkness and overwhelming pressure. Earplugs were available at the door.

headline: Confronted on Execution, Texas Proudly Says It Kills Efficiently
text: HUNTSVILLE, Tex. — If Texas executes Robert James Campbell as planned on Tuesday, for raping and murdering a woman, it will be the nation’s first execution since Oklahoma’s bungled attempt at lethal injection two weeks ago left a convicted murderer writhing and moaning before he died.

headline: Nigerian Girls Seen in Video From Militants

Their fate has become the focus of intense international concern, with Michelle Obama holding up a placard appealing for their safe return and governments across the globe pledging to help track them down.

headline: Had Enough of Handel’s ‘Messiah’? Try Eric Idle’s
text: When the annual parade of “Messiah” performances winds through New York’s concert halls in the weeks leading up to Christmas, even devoted Handelians who are fascinated by the many variant scorings and ways of presenting this great oratorio can get a bit fatigued. The Collegiate Chorale’s solution is to offer a parody, “Not the Messiah (He’s a Very Naughty Boy),” an oratorio based on Monty Python’s 1979 film, “The Life of Brian.” The oratorio has a text by Eric Idle and music by John Du Prez (who was one of the musical contributors to “Spamalot”). Mr. Idle will be among the performers in the Chorale’s shows, at Carnegie Hall on Dec. 15 and 16.

headline: Suvir Saran’s Mushroom and Farro Burger
text: When I was introduced to these burgers, a creation of the chef Suvir Saran, I was struck by the brilliant idea of using sweet potatoes as a binder. I’ve struggled to find ways to hold my burgers together, and this solution was perfect. Try to find light-fleshed sweet potatoes; they are drier, and a little less sweet than orange yams. I also love all the textures in these hearty patties. I have made some changes to Suvir’s recipe, roasting the potatoes rather than boiling them, and I use less oil.

headline: Potato and Pea Patties With Indian Spices
text: This is another one of Suvir Saran’s ideas, which I have adapted. The whole spices in this mix contribute not only amazing flavors, but texture as well. I used a combination of light-fleshed sweet potatoes and red boiling potatoes: I loved the sweetness of the sweet potatoes with the spices, but the mix needed something starchier to hold it together, so I added some red potatoes.

headline: Mollie Katzen-Inspired Potato and Broccoli Burgers
text: The famed vegetarian cookbook author Mollie Katzen has a whole chapter devoted to burgers and savory pancakes in her beautiful new cookbook, “The Heart of the Plate.” Before I’d looked carefully at the chapter I’d bought a bunch of broccoli with the idea that specks of broccoli would be beautiful in a burger. Mollie, with her delicious Walnut-Coated Broccoli-Speckled Mashed Potato Cakes, was way ahead of me on that idea. I loved her idea of coating the burgers with ground walnuts and barely cooking the finely chopped broccoli before incorporating it into the mix. I’ve made a variation on Mollie’s burgers, using red potatoes and sticking with the Indian seasonings I’ve been using in other burgers this week.

headline: Suvir Saran’s Spinach and Potato Patties (Palak Ki Tiki)
text: These are adapted from Suvir Saran’s potato patties called palak ki tiki, from his lovely cookbook “Masala Farm.” They are a striking green because of all of the raw spinach that gets packed into them. The big, spicy burgers are incredibly easy to put together and to cook. Suvir serves them with chutney, either green or tamarind, but we both agree that they’re delicious with plain old ketchup. I made a quick raita to serve with the burgers by stirring sweet pickle relish into plain yogurt.

headline: Sweet Potato, Quinoa, Spinach and Red Lentil Burger
text: You can use blond or black quinoa for these delicate burgers. Black will look striking against the sweet potato’s orange when you cut into the burgers. The red lentils pale to yellow when you cook them; they contribute texture and flavor. The burgers have a decidedly Mediterranean flavor, with feta and mint included in the mix. But I still like to serve them with raita or chutney; a more Mediterranean condiment would be yogurt seasoned with puréed garlic and mint.

headline: Today in Small Business: Why Entrepreneurship Is Like Breeding a Pig
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Putting On the Ritz, Six Words at a Time
text: A chain of luxury hotels and resorts is borrowing from an Internet meme to extend a marketing effort that celebrates the accumulation of experiences and memories rather than the trappings of wealth.

headline: UniCredit Swings to a Profit as Lending Recovers
text: UniCredit, Italy’s biggest bank and a bellwether of the economy, said on Monday that it returned to profit in the first quarter after its backlog of problem loans declined for the first time since the beginning of the financial crisis.

headline: Tetsuya Miyamoto’s KenKen®
text: This week’s challenges were suggested by the Japanese math teacher and puzzle creator, Tetsuya Miyamoto, inventor of the popular KenKen math and logic puzzle. KenKen (“wisdom squared” in Japanese) was developed by Mr. Miyamoto in 2004 as an example of his educational philosophy “The Art of Teaching Without Teaching.” I asked him about this philosophy and received this response by email:

headline: “Coffee” (Helado Negro Remix) by Sylvan Esso
text: A remix of the title track from the electronic duo’s latest album.

headline: Vacancies Pose Threat to the Fed
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve governor Jeremy C. Stein is chairman both of the internal committee that monitors financial markets for signs of trouble and of the committee that watches the way banks treat their customers.

headline: What We Learned From Tim Geithner’s Book
text: Timothy Geithner’s new book, “Stress Test,” runs 580 pages and covers countless moments of crisis and fear during his time as New York Fed president and Treasury secretary. Read our colleague Andrew Ross Sorkin’s magazine article on Mr. Geithner and the book for more on the broad themes it recounts. But in the meantime, here are a few smaller chunks that we found particularly revelatory.

headline: India’s Voters Expected to Give Modi a Mandate
text: NEW DELHI — Exit polls released Monday suggested that voters in India’s parliamentary election will deliver a mandate for the Bharatiya Janata Party’s Narendra Modi, a Hindu nationalist who has promised to create manufacturing jobs and overhaul the country’s infrastructure.

headline: Explosion Is Cited in Deadly Fire on Bus in China
text: HONG KONG — A fire aboard a bus in western China killed one person and injured 19 others on Monday, a municipal press office said, as the state news media reported that the fire was being investigated as possible arson and began with an explosion.

headline: U.S. Asks Stiff Term for Ex-SAC Trader
text: Federal prosecutors did not show much leniency in asking a federal judge to sentence Michael Steinberg, a onetime top trader for Steven A. Cohen’s hedge fund, SAC Capital Advisors, to more than five years in prison for insider trading on stock tips.

headline: Same-Sex Couples in Arkansas Rush to Wed as Court Ruling Provides an Opening
text: Gay couples in many Arkansas cities rushed to get married on Monday as the attorney general asked the state’s highest court to suspend a ruling striking down the state’s ban on same-sex marriage.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Andrew Ross Sorkin on Timothy Geithner, the Bailout and the Banks
text: Andrew Ross Sorkin, a financial columnist for The Times, a co-anchor of CNBC’s “Squawk Box” and the author of “Too Big to Fail,” wrote this week’s cover story about what the former Treasury secretary Timothy Geithner really thought of the bailout.

headline: Image of the Day: May 12
text: The curtains came down on the largest electoral exercise on the planet as India voted in it’s final phase of general elections on Monday.

headline: Potato Heads in the Senate
text: Several United States senators are suddenly professing a keen interest in the nutritional needs of low-income women who are pregnant, breastfeeding or raising children under the age of 5. What the women and children need, they have decreed, is more white potatoes.

headline: Boko Haram Leader Offers Prisoner Swap
text: The leader of the Nigerian Islamist rebel group Boko Haram offered to release more than 200 schoolgirls abducted by his fighters last month in an exchange for prisoners.

headline: Scientists Warn of Rising Oceans From Polar Melt
text: A large section of the mighty West Antarctica ice sheet has begun falling apart and its continued melting now appears to be unstoppable, two groups of scientists reported on Monday. If the findings hold up, they suggest that the melting could destabilize neighboring parts of the ice sheet and a rise in sea level of 10 feet or more may be unavoidable in coming centuries.

headline: Times Minute | Tensions in the Tea Party
text: Also on the Minute, reaction to the Eastern Ukraine’s vote, and FOX hopes its new show “Gotham” will attract advertisers.

headline: Times Minute | Tensions in the Tea Party
text: In the Video

headline: Pay Dispute Threatens Some High-Cost Legal Cases in Britain
text: A ruling from a British court about the inability to find lawyers for a group of defendants charged with fraud calls into question whether the British authorities will be able to pursue complex white-collar crime prosecutions without paying more for lawyers to take such cases. The decision could end up shifting some cases to the United States, which does not face the same issues as Britain in paying for legal defense.

headline: General Barlow and the Bloody Angle
text: After being mauled by the Army of Northern Virginia in the Battle of the Wilderness, which took place in the dense central Virginia woods from May 5 to 7, 1864, Maj. Gen. Ulysses S. Grant pushed his troops southeast toward the small hamlet of Spotsylvania Court House, intending to get between the Confederates and their capital. But Robert E. Lee’s men won the race to the village, thwarting Grant’s designs and setting the stage for the Battle of Spotsylvania, which would rage for 12 days, one of the longest and bloodiest engagements of the war.

headline: When Kids Would Rather Play Computer Games Than Code Them
text: Coding is trending. In schools. Twenty thousand teachers from kindergarten through 12th grade have introduced coding lessons, according to Code.org, a group backed by the tech industry that offers free curriculums. Thirty school districts, including New York City and Chicago, have agreed to add coding classes in the fall, mainly in high schools but in lower grades, too. At home, parents are downloading programs that promise to teach children coding basics, and toys that can be coded in various ways are lining up for the next holiday season.

headline: Listen Up | Sylvan Esso’s Quirky, Caffeinated Synth-Pop
text: “Is it the kind of coffee that makes you feel like a crazy person?” asks Amelia Meath, one half of the Durham, N.C.-based electronic duo Sylvan Esso. The inquiry is directed toward a server at Café Stella, a Silver Lake bistro popular with the indie set (members of the bands Warpaint and the Afghan Whigs have also been known to dine there). “I have a problem with certain coffees,” Meath clarifies. “One sip and I know it’s going to turn me into a terrible person.”

headline: A Slow-Tech Approach to Tracking Spending
text: Ten years ago, I tracked every penny of our family’s spending. That’s good, right? Over time, however, I lost sight of why I was doing it and eventually stopped. Recently, I decided to try it again, and I find myself having the same mental conversation every time I sit down with my receipts.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Another Mercedes 1-2 Finish in Formula One
text: Lewis Hamilton and Nico Rosberg, teammates on the Mercedes-Benz Formula One team, finished one-two, a second apart, in the Spanish Grand Prix on Sunday, continuing Mercedes’s distinct superiority so far this season. Daniel Ricciardo, in the Red Bull Infiniti, came in a distant third, followed by Sebastian Vettel, his teammate and the defending series champion.

headline: Can Andreessen’s View Justify $3.2 Billion for Beats?
text: Attachment therapy is controversial in the field of mental health. It’s far from indisputable in the technology world, too. Venture capitalist Marc Andreessen justifies some high price tags in technology deals, in part, with the idea that huge companies are able to “attach” the products of smaller ones, making them worth far more than traditional analysis would suggest.

headline: China and Vietnam at Impasse Over Rig in South China Sea
text: HONG KONG — China and Vietnam appear to have reached at least a temporary impasse over a giant drilling rig sent by a state-controlled Chinese oil company to a site in the South China Sea between the Vietnamese coastline and a cluster of disputed islands, as the confrontation has continued to raise thorny issues of international law.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | May 6-12, 2014
text: Climate change, the N.F.L. draft, an entertainment trend and more: How many of the topics in this week’s news quiz have you been following?

headline: Weekend Gun Report: May 9-11, 2014
text: Last March, when Facebook promised to crack down on gun advertising by deleting posts from people looking to buy or sell guns without background checks, it was heralded as a victory by some gun-control groups. Others, however, hoped for the outright ban of gun ads, à la Craigslist and eBay. Instead, the social network said it would hide posts peddling guns from minors and remind users to follow local gun laws.

headline: Republican Moderates and the Minimum Wage
text: One of my first columns for the Times was a non-requiem for Arlen Specter’s career as a moderate Republican, in which I argued that the G.O.P. desperately needed “a better sort of centrist” than the Specter-esque, “socially liberal, fiscally conservative” northeasterners to whom the label has usually been applied. One theme in that piece, which has run through my commentary on the Republican Party ever since, is that a moderate wing of the G.O.P. that just imitates the Democrats on a few issues where the liberal line is popular isn’t necessarily doing either its party or the country any great favors. To be truly constructive in their moderation, the G.O.P.’s centrists should be advancing alternatives to popular liberal ideas — trying to create a different center of political gravity, in effect, rather than just looking for ways to take some losing issues off the table.

headline: Saving Your Favorite Videos on YouTube
text: Q. My YouTube mobile app has a nice “+” button for adding a video to my playlist of favorites, but I don’t see a similar button on the desktop browser version of YouTube. How do you do it from the computer?

text: Raquel Reichard, 23, reads an excerpt from her story about how the fear of street harassment keeps her struggling to overcome an eating disorder she has long fought.

headline: Taliban Wage Deadly Attacks in 3 Afghan Provinces
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — On the first day of their “spring offensive,” the Taliban mounted attacks in three provinces that killed at least 11 people on Monday. In a fourth province, the families of two would-be suicide bombers turned them in to the police, helping to forestall what would have probably been another attack.

headline: Being Bullied Is Bad for Your Health
text: Victims of bullying may develop long-term physical and mental health problems, and now researchers have found one possible reason: Being bullied raises the blood’s level of C-reactive protein, or CRP, a marker of systemic inflammation and a risk factor for cardiovascular and other diseases.

headline: Radio Signals Skew Birds’ Internal Navigation
text: Migrating birds may lose their way when exposed to the electromagnetic noise from radio signals and electronic devices, researchers have found.

headline: New Neurons Found to Overwrite Old Memories
text: The inability of adults to recall experiences from early childhood may be linked to the creation of new neurons in the brain.

headline: Moving Against Heart Disease

headline: Marco Rubio Disqualifies Himself
text: If American presidents need to prove a basic ability to accept facts, then Senator Marco Rubio of Florida—who’s publicly mulling a run — just disqualified himself from competition.

headline: Second U.S. Case of MERS Virus Is Confirmed
text: A second case of MERS, the Middle East respiratory virus circulating on the Arabian peninsula, has been found in the United States, federal and state health officials said Monday.

headline: Co-Owner of the Mets Is Said to Be Interested in Selling
text: Saul B. Katz, who owns a majority share of the Mets in a partnership with his brother-in-law and business partner, Fred Wilpon, has expressed a desire to sell his portion of the team because he has grown tired of spending millions to prop it up, according to several people in baseball who have been briefed on the matter.

headline: Pensions vs. Art in Detroit’s Bankruptcy
text: The objection deadline has arrived for Detroit’s reorganization plan. And it seems likely that the “art deal” will be the focus of many objections, especially from bondholders.

headline: Hope for an S-Shaped Back
text: I wore a hard plastic brace around my torso from ages 8 to 16 to treat scoliosis, or spinal curvature. Bracing has been standard treatment in children for the past five decades, and I wore my brace diligently, if awkwardly, in the hope that it would contain my S-shaped curvature and stave off the need for spinal fusion surgery.

headline: Miles Davis Way to Be Unveiled
text: Before he left office, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg signed a bill naming a block of West 77th Street in honor of the jazz trumpeter and composer Miles Davis. The block, between West End Avenue and Riverside Drive, will be called Miles Davis Way. Mr. Davis, who died in 1991, had an apartment in a brownstone at 312 West 77th Street, and lived there for about 25 years, until the mid-1980’s. Now the new street sign is ready, and will have a public unveiling on May 26, the 88th anniversary of Davis’s birth, at noon. Two of Davis’s children, Cheryl Davis and Erin Davis, as well as Vince Wilburn, Jr., his nephew, will be on hand for the ceremony, which will include a block party sponsored by the Far West 77th Street Block Association.

headline: Exercising the Mind to Treat Attention Deficits
text: Which will it be — the berries or the chocolate dessert? Homework or the Xbox? Finish that memo, or roam Facebook?

headline: A Flurry of Bookings to Norway
text: Whether because of Disney’s animated Oscar-winner “Frozen” or interest in climatologically threatened polar bears, travel to Norway has increased this year.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: West Antarctic Glacier Ice Flows
text: A NASA animation shows glacier changes detected in the highly dynamic Amundsen Embayment of West Antarctica.

headline: Not Just Flowers, but How They Got There
text: Residential gardens created by landscape architects and designers can possess an ineffable sense of magic, until the tricks behind their creation are revealed. A few professionals are offering to share their secrets through Garden Dialogues, a national series of garden tours hosted by the Cultural Landscape Foundation. Running now through Oct. 5, each Garden Dialogues event invites a small group to visit a remarkable garden (a few tours include multiple sites), where the house’s landscape designer along with the owner (and in some cases, its architect) describe how they created the environment.

headline: Elevating ‘Ordinary’ to an Art Form
text: Decorating blogs swoon over Hugo Guinness’s graphic black-and-white depictions of ordinary objects. Anna Wintour collects his work. Kate Spade hung his prints of spriggy flowers in her Fifth Avenue boutique. Wes Anderson, a friend of the artist, used Mr. Guinness’s rendition of men’s briefs on the set of “The Royal Tenenbaums” to help establish the film’s quirky mood.

headline: Pulling Big Brother’s Strings Instead
text: The Processional Arts Workshop created a “Procession of Confession” to draw attention to government surveillance.

headline: They’ve Deleted Their ‘Spacebook’ Profiles
text: “Why don’t you join the 21st century?” Annette Rapoport’s friends used to grump at her. They would send around Evites to parties, but they would have to mail Ms. Rapoport a paper invitation. She didn’t know how to use a computer.

headline: Q. and A. | Sterling Ruby on Making It in L.A., His New Show in New York and the Power of the Art Market
text: Numerous New York galleries and museums synced their best shows to Frieze weekend, including Hauser & Wirth, which opened a much-anticipated new exhibition by the Los Angeles polymath Sterling Ruby at its newly renovated West 19th Street space last Friday. It’s Ruby’s first solo show in Chelsea since he parked two menacing, rectilinear forms (a bus and a big brick of human-size cages) inside the Pace Gallery four years ago. This new show, entitled “Sunrise, Sunset,” presents a dense cross-section of recent works the prolific and controversial artist has produced in his fabled studio-cum-industrial-complex on the outskirts of Downtown L.A. — where only weeks ago, a Mack truck veered off the road and through the wall of the building, destroying a number of mammoth spray paintings and Ruby’s studio manager’s car (fortunately, no one was injured). Though the accident was a setback, the grandiose, unexpected destruction of the incident aligned well with Ruby’s expansive practice. The exhibition is full of charged objects, including Corinthian columns dripping with lustrous red polyurethane, a super-size canary-yellow electric chair, infernal stoves and bleached fabrics that evoke everything from Rorschach tests to the American flag. Here, the artist reflects on his intentions for the show and his place in the art world.

headline: Tenures Becoming Shorter at a Short-Handed Fed

headline: For Some in Europe, High Lending Rates Hamper Recovery
text: PARIS — Lúcio Machado’s small business in northern Portugal is finally starting to bustle again after his country’s recession. He hoped to expand his 12-employee business, which repairs autos and creates custom mechanical equipment for trucks and tractors, with a loan.

headline: New York Police to Limit Seizing of Condoms in Prostitution Cases
text: The New York Police Department will significantly limit the practice of seizing condoms for use as evidence in prostitution-related cases, ending a procedure that health officials had long criticized as undermining their efforts to protect prostitutes from disease.

headline: When Taking a Stand Can Mean Taking a Hit
text: Canceling an event at a hotel can be an effective way for a group to raise awareness about a contentious issue, as the recent boycott of the Beverly Hills Hotel showed after the decision by Brunei, whose sovereign wealth fund owns the hotel, to impose a harsh form of Islamic law in the country.

headline: Tony Nominations Continue to Boost ‘Gentleman’s Guide’
text: More audience members have been willing to pay full price for “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder” in the two weeks since the show received 10 Tony Award nominations, the most of any on Broadway this season. According to box office data released on Monday, “Gentleman’s Guide” – a tongue-in-cheek operetta about a British man bumping off his rich relatives – had an average paid admission of $93.91 last week, compared to $82.56 for the week in late April immediately preceding the Tony nominations.

headline: Reading Landai in New York
text: Today, Eliza Griswold reads at the Culture Project in New York from ‘‘I Am the Beggar of the World,’’ a book of landai by Afghan women. Griswold’s translations of the landai — two-line folk poems typically about love and grief — are accompanied by photographs by Seamus Murphy, with whom she traveled to Afghanistan in 2012, a trip that also led to an article for the magazine in April of that year. Griswold wrote about young Afghan women for whom writing landai served as a vital, and in some cases sole, link to a wider world. These young women were often confined to their fathers’ homes in the rural villages where they lived; they would sneak calls to a Kabul-based poetry hotline to read their poems and exchange ideas with other Afghan women — parliamentarians, doctors, professors — whose lives they could only imagine. One young woman, Zarmina, stood out. Her poems were distinctive in their language but also in their fearless questioning of God’s will. Zarmina called as frequently as she could, but she lived in fear of being discovered. One day, as Griswold wrote, she was:

headline: I’m a Cellist, Not a Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtle
text: I’VE been traveling most of my adult life. I’m co-artistic director of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, and I’m one of those musicians who actually like to travel. I’ve hardly ever done any dedicated tourism. In fact, I’ve never been to countries in which I didn’t have a concert, so I’ve never seen Egypt or Tibet, two places I really want to visit.

headline: Snowden’s Story, Behind the Scenes
text: The title of the journalist Glenn Greenwald’s impassioned new book, “No Place to Hide,” comes from a chilling observation made in 1975 by Senator Frank Church, then chairman of a select committee on intelligence. The United States government, he said, had perfected “a technological capability that enables us to monitor the messages that go through the air.” That capability, he added, could at any time “be turned around on the American people, and no American would have any privacy left, such is the capability to monitor everything: telephone conversations, telegrams, it doesn’t matter. There would be no place to hide.”

headline: Recipes as a Guide, Not a Command

headline: Amid Tensions, a New Portrayal of Anne Frank
