text: “Riot,” a new spring space filler on Fox, must be condemned on philosophical grounds. But it sure does have funny moments.

headline: How N.S.A. Recalibrated Its Mission
text: Part 1 of “United States of Secrets,” Tuesday night on PBS’s “Frontline,” is a fine ticktock account of how we arrived at our current information collection quandary, and what makes it so says a lot about this still-evolving issue.

headline: An Immersion in Dvorak, With Operatic Fervor
text: First, full disclosure. I must admit that after attending several adventurous concerts of the fourth, and final, Spring for Music festival at Carnegie Hall, which ended on Saturday night with an engrossing performance by the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra, I was not exactly eager to hear James Levine conduct the Met Orchestra at Carnegie on Sunday afternoon in a Dvorak program.

headline: New York Police Aviation Rescue
text: On Sunday, the New York Police Department’s aviation unit rescued a female hiker who had broken her ankle high on a steep rock trail just north of Alpine, N.J., in Palisades Interstate Park.

headline: Study Finds Being Ignored on Facebook May Lower Self-Esteem
text: Social media promises to make people feel better about their lives and promotes the ability to connect with others and share wonderful moments.

headline: R.B.S. Makes First Move to Spin off Citizens
text: The Royal Bank of Scotland has made the first move to spin off its United States banking operation, Citizens.

headline: Amid Pipeline and Climate Debate, Energy-Efficiency Bill Is Derailed
text: WASHINGTON — A bipartisan bill to encourage energy efficiency in buildings died in the Senate on Monday, derailed by the contentious debate over the Keystone XL pipeline and President Obama’s plans to issue new climate change regulations.

headline: Telling Off the C.E.O., Once a Year
text: As she has done every year since the financial crisis, Judy Koenick traveled from her home in Maryland to Bank of America’s annual shareholder meeting in Charlotte, N.C., last week, a drive of more than six hours.

headline: Christie Vetoes Bill to Improve Storm Recovery Effort; Big Mistake, Top Senator Says
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey vetoed a bill on Monday that lawmakers had unanimously passed to improve the state’s management of Hurricane Sandy recovery.

headline: After Protests, I.M.F. Chief Withdraws as Smith College’s Commencement Speaker
text: A week before she was to speak at the Smith College commencement, Christine Lagarde, chief of the International Monetary Fund, has withdrawn from the event, citing protests against her and the fund, the college said Monday.

headline: More Insured, but the Choices Are Narrowing
text: In the midst of all the turmoil in health care these days, one thing is becoming clear: No matter what kind of health plan consumers choose, they will find fewer doctors and hospitals in their network — or pay much more for the privilege of going to any provider they want.

headline: ‘Courtroom Sketch Artist’
text: I was introduced to the work of Gary Myrick, the subject of this Op-Doc video, when I ran across an article in Texas Monthly magazine that spotlighted his career as a courtroom sketch artist. He was once the go-to artist for television news station — millions regularly viewed his work on the networks. I was intrigued and wrote him immediately, asking if he would consider being filmed for a documentary. He said he’d be glad to help anyone nurture his creativity.

headline: Courtroom Sketch Artist
text: This short documentary captures the rise and fall of a courtroom sketch artist in Texas.

headline: Read, Kids, Read
text: As an uncle I’m inconsistent about too many things.

headline: Rocky Road for Canadian Oil
text: CALGARY, Alberta — With TransCanada’s Keystone XL pipeline snarled in a regulatory and legal struggle south of the border, Canadian oil companies are proposing many new and expanded pipelines that would connect the oil sands fields with new markets in China and across the world.

headline: After Forming Deep Roots in U.S., Man Discovers He Isn’t a Citizen
text: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — After living nearly a half century in the United States — marrying and raising a family here, paying taxes and working for decades for the federal government — Mario Hernandez made a discovery recently that rattled him to his core: He is not an American citizen. In fact, he is not even a United States resident.

headline: Fox and NBC Strut New Shows to Marketers
text: NBC and Fox opened the television upfront week for the 2014-15 season with presentations on Monday that were long on new series, long on new strategies, and just long in general.

headline: The Joys of Trimming
text: My favorite part of writing is taking stuff out. “In writing, you must kill all your darlings,” William Faulkner famously wrote, suggesting that the process of self-editing requires stoicism and the suppression of a natural affection. Samuel Johnson said something similar: “Read over your compositions and, wherever you meet with a passage which you think is particularly fine, strike it out.”

headline: For a Nonesuch Celebration at BAM, Reich and Glass Bury the Hatchet
text: Nonesuch Records used to be a budget classical label that mostly licensed recordings from Europe and released them at prices that made them beloved among cost-conscious college students. But even then Nonesuch was a little quirky: it also had a world music series, long before world music was hot (or even called world music).

headline: Mapping Basketball Nation
text: Find the most popular N.B.A. team in every ZIP code, based on Facebook data.

headline: Which Team Do You Cheer For? An N.B.A. Fan Map
text: Highlights from a map of N.B.A. fandom based on Facebook “likes.”

headline: Qaeda Affiliate Steps Up Video Propaganda Push
text: MUKALLA, Yemen — The large microphone with the fancy logo might have belonged to any television news crew, but these man-on-the-street interviews sounded more like militant lectures.

headline: Reopening of the Washington Monument
text: The Washington Monument reopened to the public on Monday, after an earthquake in August 2011 damaged the 130-year-old stone obelisk.

headline: Met Orchestra Authorizes Strike Vote if Talks Fail
text: This weekend the musicians in the Metropolitan Opera orchestra wore buttons during performances to call attention to the fact that the opera house is seeking concessions from them in contract talks.

headline: Kerry to Meet Palestinian Leader in First Exchange Since Peace Talks
text: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State John Kerry plans to meet in London on Thursday with Mahmoud Abbas, the president of the Palestinian Authority, the State Department announced Monday.

headline: Computing in the Classroom
text: Should coding be part of the elementary school curriculum?

headline: Who’s on Third? In Baseball’s Shifting Defenses, Maybe Nobody
text: For more than 100 years, baseball looked pretty much the same from the grandstands. There were three players spread in the outfield, a pitcher on the mound, a catcher behind the plate, and four infielders neatly aligned, two on each side of second base.

headline: A Deal to Dodge the Tax Man in America
text: Pfizer’s chairman and chief executive, Ian C. Read, is in London this week trying to sell a skeptical public there on his $106 billion takeover plan for rival AstraZeneca. On Tuesday, he is scheduled to testify to a parliamentary committee about a deal that has been described in the British tabloids as “too dangerous” and has raised a bevy of nervous questions about potential job losses.

headline: The Problem With Confidence
text: The current issue of The Atlantic carries a fascinating summary of “The Confidence Code” by Katty Kay and Claire Shipman. The essay runs through the evidence suggesting that women tend to have too little self-confidence. When asked how well they did on tests, women tend to estimate that they got fewer answers correct than they actually did. In one British study, a business school professor asked students how much they would deserve to earn five years after graduation. The women’s estimates were 20 percent lower than the men’s.

headline: Healed, Landmark Again Beckons: Come On Up. The View Is Terrific.
text: WASHINGTON — Nearly 670 feet of cracks are sealed, and loose stones are once again fixed in place at the 130-year-old Washington Monument, which defines the capital skyline. The panoramic views, from about 500 feet above the landscape, are back.

headline: Seeing Future in Fuel Cells, Toyota Ends Tesla Deal
text: Toyota said on Monday that it would allow a battery-supply deal with Tesla Motors to expire this year and would focus instead on building cars running on hydrogen fuel cells, a next-generation technology that rivals Tesla’s all-electric systems.

headline: Detroit Tries to Sell Itself, One House at a Time
text: Having watched for decades as residents of Detroit moved away and neighborhoods emptied, officials in this bankrupt city are trying their own antidote: recruiting new residents themselves, one house at a time, with an online auction of abandoned properties.

headline: Detroit Pension Ballot Poses Tough Choices
text: Detroit dropped tens of thousands of ballots in the mail on Monday, initiating a crucial stage in the city’s bankruptcy case that allows retirees, employees and bondholders to cast votes on a painful debt-shedding plan.

headline: Science vs. Taxes
text: In the United States, most of the controversy over Pfizer’s $101 billion bid for AstraZeneca has been about the potential tax consequences. Last year, Pfizer paid an effective tax rate of about 27 percent. But if it were to succeed in taking over its British rival — and so far, at least, AstraZeneca has shown zero interest in the idea — it would be able to conduct a maneuver called “inversion,” becoming a British company and paying the British corporate tax rate of 20 percent. It would also be able to access cash that resides overseas, which would be taxed at the American rate of 35 percent if it were repatriated into this country.

headline: A New Fire Commissioner
text: In more than three decades as a firefighter, New York City’s new fire commissioner has had a close-up view of the entrenched racial discrimination that led the Justice Department to sue the city, resulting in a court ordering sweeping changes in the department’s hiring policies.

headline: William Coughlin, 91, Editor, Dies; His Newspaper Exposed Fouled Water
text: William J. Coughlin, who after a career as a globe-trotting correspondent landed in a small North Carolina town where he led the local newspaper’s Pulitzer Prize-winning exposure of carcinogens in municipal drinking water, died on Thursday in Bolivia, N.C. He was 91.

headline: Smarter Electricity in New York
text: In one of the most promising moves in the energy sector in years, New York State is proposing a way to get a head start on, and perhaps help lead, a revolution in the world of electricity generation. Starting this week, the main players in the state’s complex electricity business will be asked to comment on a new report from the state’s Public Service Commission that envisions more efficient and climate-friendly ways to produce electricity.

headline: Clippers’ Co-Owner: ‘I Didn’t Do Anything Wrong’
text: As co-owner of the Los Angeles Clippers for the past 33 years, Rochelle Sterling has been a largely silent partner. But now, as the N.B.A. pushes for the permanent removal of her husband, she does not want to go away quietly.

headline: What Mr. Putin Can’t Control
text: If there were questions about the legitimacy of the separatist referendums in eastern Ukraine, the farcical names of the entities on which people were asked to vote — the self-declared People’s Republics of Donetsk or Luhansk — surely answered them. But the gathering rumble of violence accompanying the votes is serious and is driving the Ukrainian crisis in a direction that before long no one — not President Vladimir Putin of Russia, not authorities in Kiev, not the West — will be able to control.

headline: $350 Million Investment Needed to Open Casino Closest to New York City, Panel Says
text: ALBANY — A state gambling panel declared on Monday that business interests seeking to build a casino in Orange County, just an hour from New York City, would be required to invest a minimum of $350 million in capital. Casino industry experts say it is a surprisingly low buy-in for what could be a billion-dollar franchise, and one that could cause serious problems for casino proponents in the Catskills to the north.

headline: Interim C.E.O. of Clippers Sets Out Striving for Stability
text: LOS ANGELES — Richard Parsons stepped up to a lectern Monday as the new, though interim, face of the Los Angeles Clippers, and for 25 minutes, he tried to provide a credible presence at the top of the organization.

headline: A Rescue That Worked, but Left a Troubled Economy
text: The mortgage market was starting to come apart on Aug. 16, 2007, when Federal Reserve policy makers gathered for an emergency videoconference. The worst of the financial crisis was more than a year away, but big problems were emerging.

headline: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,305 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: As Newark Fights Many Woes, Mayoral Candidates Take Jabs at Each Other
text: NEWARK — The mayoral candidate Ras Baraka, a burly man with a two-day growth of gray-flecked beard, was asked during a television debate last week to introduce himself to viewers.

headline: New Parks Chief Brings a City Planner’s Vision
text: Seated at the head of a long conference table in what was once the office of the parks chief Robert Moses, Mitchell J. Silver, New York City’s new parks commissioner, declared himself a World’s Fair enthusiast.

headline: Support for E.U. Improves, Poll Finds
text: BRUSSELS — Attitudes toward the European Union have improved ahead of elections to the European Parliament this month, but there is growing reluctance to cede more power to Brussels, according to a closely watched poll published Monday.

headline: Injuries and Age March On, to the Dismay of the Yankees
text: The Yankees are taking on that same discouraging feeling from last season: old, sad and broken. You look at the names and the salaries and you expect something special. Then you look at the calendar and know better.

headline: Local News Feature
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — My local news happens to come from the New York City television stations and, on CBS-TV, the meteorologist is Lonnie Quinn. Mr. Quinn is your basic, telegenic weather guy with perfect hair who does a very serviceable job explaining why you will need an umbrella this morning, and there is really nothing remarkable about him except for his tendency to panic dramatically about the weather while on the air.

headline: Hikers Spread Democracy in India
text: MARKHA VALLEY, India — Staring up at the steep and lifeless brown ridges looming over the valley, Gulzar Ahmad Dar, a boyish and chatty Kashmiri policeman, sighed at having drawn a short straw.

headline: TV Networks Bank on Future of M.L.S.
text: Everything aligned for Major League Soccer to make deals with ESPN, Fox and Univision worth a combined $90 million annually from 2015 to 2022.

headline: Brooklyn Development Plan Stirs Debates on Affordable Housing and Park Funding
text: The first project at Brooklyn Bridge Park in 2007 was not a playground, but a converted warehouse with some of the most expensive condominiums in the borough.

headline: When Looks Count Way Too Much
text: Sarah Baker may or may not be a fat lady. But she played one on TV.

headline: Family Mourns at Site of a Fatal Beating
text: Wen Hui Ruan, 68, was just a block from his East Village home on Friday night when a man stopped him on East Sixth Street and hurled him against a wall. When Mr. Ruan fell to the ground, the man punched him and began stomping on his head.

headline: In Lundqvist, Rangers Have an Unflappable Master of the Seventh Game
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — When the pressure gets higher, Henrik Lundqvist turns into the Rangers’ resident Zen master. He is 9-2 in elimination games since the start of the 2012 playoffs, and has won four of five Game 7s in his career. He has a remarkable .963 save percentage in those games, having allowed only five goals.

headline: A Long Streak in Decisive Games
text: The Rangers, seemingly preprogrammed to play Game 7s, will play another on Tuesday night, against the Penguins in Pittsburgh. The Rangers have won seven of their past eight Game 7s, most by a single goal. Henrik Lundqvist has been in the net for the last five, winning four.

headline: Book Reveals Wider Net of U.S. Spying on Envoys
text: WASHINGTON — In May 2010, when the United Nations Security Council was weighing sanctions against Iran over its nuclear program, several members were undecided about how they would vote. The American ambassador to the United Nations, Susan E. Rice, asked the National Security Agency for help “so that she could develop a strategy,” a leaked agency document shows.

headline: De Blasio’s Budget Proposal Finds Critics at a Ratings Agency and in Accounting
text: In unveiling his budget proposal last week, Mayor Bill de Blasio repeatedly said it toed the line between fiscal prudence and progressiveness — assuring New Yorkers that teachers and other municipal employees who had long been working without a contract could be made whole, and then some, and that the city could afford the billions of dollars their raises and back pay would cost.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 12, 2014
No Shortage of Finns Flying Down the Ice for the Wild
text: ST. PAUL — The nickname “Flying Finn” goes back more than 100 years, long before Minnesota Wild scouts noticed centers Mikael Granlund and Erik Haula, the latest hockey products from Finland.

headline: Despite James’s Big Night, Nets Stay Close Until End
text: As LeBron James took two meaningless free throws to close out the Miami Heat’s win Monday night at Barclays Center, Chris Bosh and Mario Chalmers stood on the opposite end of the court, far away from the other players, smiling and shaking hands.

headline: Russia Vows ‘Harsh’ Response to Airspace Snub and to Raid of a Delegates’ Jet
text: MOSCOW — It began with a state visit by senior Russian officials to a separatist enclave in another country. It ended with Russia threatening economic retribution against several European nations on Monday, after the plane carrying the delegation was grounded in Moldova and raided by the local police.

headline: In One Eastern City, Ukrainians Find Battle Hits Too Close to Home
text: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine — Roughly midway through an hourlong gunfight that began just after midnight Sunday, six high-explosive mortar rounds narrowly missed the home of Yevgeny Kharkovsky and his wife, exploding around them on Yuzhnaya Street.

headline: De Blasio Looks Toward Sweden for Road Safety
text: STOCKHOLM — Across this Scandinavian capital of graceful cyclists and speed-regulating shrubbery, cabbies who drive Volvos and pedestrians who look over their shoulders before jaywalking, a simple figure rules:

headline: Negligence Charges Brought in Quebec Derailment and Fire
text: OTTAWA — The Montreal, Maine and Atlantic Railway and three of its employees have been charged with criminal negligence in connection with a derailment that killed 47 people and incinerated much of downtown Lac-Mégantic, Quebec, last July, officials said on Monday.

headline: At Least 14 Die as Migrant Boat Headed for Italy Sinks off Libyan Coast
text: ROME — A boat packed with hundreds of migrants trying to reach Europe sank in the Mediterranean Sea about 45 miles off the Libyan coast on Monday. At least 14 people died, but more than 200 were rescued in an operation led by the Italian Navy.

headline: A Death Draws Attention to Afghan Police Methods
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A family’s accusations that the police in Kandahar tortured and killed their son while he was in custody has again focused attention on a wave of disappearances and deaths in the southern province.

headline: Long Fight to Keep a Grand Address on the Upper West Side
text: On a clear, freezing day in January 2013, Marieliz Unwin and Fran Jacobs sat in an office above Times Square discussing the décor in Ms. Unwin’s apartment at the Ansonia.

headline: Spain: Provincial Council Leader Shot
text: A regional politician from Spain’s governing Popular Party was shot dead in the northern city of León on Monday, prompting the country’s main parties to suspend campaigning ahead of the European parliamentary elections this month. Isabel Carrasco, the head of the provincial council in León, was shot at least three times as she crossed a bridge in the city’s downtown, according to local news media reports. Ms. Carrasco, 59, had been running the provincial council in Léon since 2007. The shooting in broad daylight was a shock in a country that has only recently emerged from decades of terrorist bombings and political killings by members of ETA, the Basque separatist group that declared a cease-fire in 2011. An unidentified woman arrested in connection with the crime, according to local news reports, is believed to have recently been fired from her council job.

headline: Somalia: Attack on Former Official Fails
text: Eleven people have been confirmed dead and 20 others wounded after a car bomb exploded on Monday at a cafe frequented by government officials in the town of Baidoa, officials said. The suicide bomber was believed to have been targeting a former regional governor, Abdifatah Ibrahim Gesey, who survived the attack. No group has claimed responsibility. The Somali president, Hassan Sheik Mohamud, and the special representative of the United Nations secretary general for Somalia, Nicholas Kay, condemned the attack.

headline: Nominee for Egypt Ambassador Post
text: The White House moved Monday to fill the long vacant post of the United States ambassador to Egypt by nominating Robert Stephen Beecroft, a career diplomat. Mr. Beecroft currently is the American ambassador to Iraq. Mr. Beecroft’s Iraq post, in turn, will be filled by Stuart E. Jones, the United States ambassador to Jordan, the White House said. Mr. Beecroft will take up his post in Cairo during a tumultuous period. Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, who led the ouster last year of the elected government in Egypt, is expected to be elected Egypt’s president next month. The Cairo post has been vacant since Anne Patterson left in August to become the top Middle East official at the State Department.

headline: Word of the Day | brazen
text: brazen•\ˈbra-zən\• adjective and verb

headline: Silver Issues a Response After Sterling’s Interview
text: It was only a written statement, but his exasperation was clear.

headline: New York City Police Helicopter Rescues Injured Hiker
text: It began as a Mother’s Day hike with family and ended like a scene from some Rocky Mountain adventure film: an injured hiker, unable to get down from a treacherous cliffside trail; a rescuer descending by rope from a hovering helicopter.

headline: Timothy Geithner’s New Book, Chart By Chart
text: The former Treasury secretary talks about some of the charts he included in his memoir and why they are particularly significant.

headline: James Scores 49 Points in Vintage Performance
text: It was almost as if LeBron James were back in Cleveland.

headline: At Christie’s Auction, an Experiment Proves Fruitful
text: Gambling on the boundless appetite and bottomless checkbooks of today’s contemporary art collectors, not to mention their quirky taste for macabre images — an electric chair, a canvas filled with dead flies, and an installation incorporating handcuffs and an illustrated guide to pistols — Christie’s staged a highly publicized experiment on Monday night that was a runaway success.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, May 13, 2014
text: “When you do something a lot, you get good at it. I think Texas probably does it as well as Iran.”

headline: Authorities in Spain Make Arrests in Fatal Shooting of Politician
text: MADRID — A regional politician from Spain’s governing Popular Party was shot dead in the northern city of León on Monday, prompting the country’s main parties to suspend their campaigning ahead of the European parliamentary elections later this month.

headline: Queens Bombers Rally to Beat the Yankees
text: After 17 years of interleague play between the Yankees and the Mets the novelty was bound to wear off. Since 1997, when the concept was introduced with a bang at the old Yankee Stadium, the intensity and buzz had gradually eroded.

headline: George Christie Dies at 79; Steward of His Family’s Opera Legacy
text: It is a truth universally acknowledged that a married man in possession of a good fortune, boundless determination and a wife who is a singer must be in want of an opera house.

headline: Struggling Granderson Has His Say for a Night
text: Curtis Granderson stepped into the batter’s box for the Mets in the sixth inning Monday, to a mixture of boos and polite applause from the Yankee Stadium crowd. He drew a 3-0 count, leaned over the plate and calmly sent a Hiroki Kuroda sinker into the right-field seats for a two-run homer. It was a familiar sight, Granderson rounding the bases here in his usual trot.

headline: Uruguayan Leader Meets With Obama to Talk Trade and Human Rights
text: URUGUAY — President José Mujica of Uruguay met with President Obama in Washington on Monday, pointing to the strengthening ties between the United States and the South American nation, which is advancing an array of socially liberal legislation, including the legalization of same-sex marriage and abortion. True to his laid-back style, Mr. Mujica, a 78-year-old former guerrilla who has farmed chrysanthemums for a living, did not wear a tie to the White House. The leaders discussed opportunities to expand trade as Uruguay, a small ranching nation of 3.3 million people, seeks new markets for its commodities exports. Mr. Obama also referred to the influence of Mr. Mujica in connection to human rights issues in Latin America. Curiously, the two leaders did not publicly refer to Uruguay’s pioneering legalization of marijuana, a sweeping measure that went into effect last week. Focusing on common ground between Uruguay and the United States, Mr. Mujica, a former livestock minister, said, “I embrace all agriculturalists of this nation.”

headline: What’s on Tuesday
text: 8 P.M. (CBS) NCIS Gibbs (Mark Harmon) travels home after his father’s death in this season finale honoring Ralph Waite, who played Jackson, the elder Gibbs, for six seasons and died on Feb. 13. The team, meanwhile, investigates whether a fire on a Navy ship that was used as a secret detention site for indicted terrorists was accidental or cover for an escape. In “NCIS: Los Angeles,” at 9, Callen (Chris O’Donnell) and Hanna (L L Cool J) must find a missing submarine used to smuggle cocaine from Colombia into the United States.

headline: Times Minute | Traffic Safety, Imported
text: New York City imports traffic safety strategy from Sweden. Also on the Minute, confronting Iran’s future warfare capabilities and a slow-motion depletion in Western Antarctica.

headline: Nuclear Talks Will Confront Iran’s Future Capability to Enrich Uranium
text: WASHINGTON — As Iran and six world powers meet this week in Vienna to begin drafting language to resolve their nuclear standoff, negotiators say they are finally confronting a crucial sticking point to a permanent agreement — the size and shape of the nuclear fuel production capability that Iran will be permitted to retain.

headline: Video Notebook: Guarding LeBron James
text: Brooklyn’s Paul Pierce talks bout guarding Miami’s LeBron James on a night he tied a playoff career high with 49 points.

headline: Times Minute | Traffic Safety, Imported
text: In the Video

headline: Video Notebook: Heat Top Nets in Game 4
text: Brooklyn’s Deron Williams discusses the possession that led to a Chris Bosh 3-pointer with just under a minute left in the game that gave the Heat the lead for good.

headline: Bus Driver’s Actions Credited With Saving Lives in Fire
text: The driver of a bus that erupted in flames in southwestern China on Monday afternoon stayed aboard the blazing vehicle as he used a fire extinguisher, smashed a window with a safety hammer to create an exit and then helped passengers leave the conflagration, a municipal government statement said on Tuesday.

headline: Corrections: May 13, 2014
text: NATIONAL

headline: Warning Spreads as Beijing Clamps Down on Illegal Modeling
text: The word is spreading among advocates for better working conditions for international models: There is a crackdown on foreign models working illegally in China, so warn any colleagues or friends there.

headline: India Election Digest: May 13
text: What you need to know about India’s elections, now that the last phase of voting is over: Exit polls on Monday night widely predicted a sweep by the National Democratic Alliance, which is led by the Bharatiya Janata Party, but the spotty record of exit polls casts a shadow over the results.

headline: Former Israeli Premier Is Sentenced to 6 Years in Bribery Case
text: JERUSALEM — Ehud Olmert, the brash former prime minister who was on the brink of a peace deal with the Palestinians when he was forced from office on corruption charges, on Tuesday became the most prominent former Israeli leader to be sentenced to prison, with a judge giving him six years for taking bribes while likening him to a traitor.

headline: BlackBerry Unveils Low-Cost Smartphone With Indonesia in Mind
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — The smartphone maker BlackBerry unveiled a new model on Tuesday that it has hopes of bringing to emerging markets in Asia and South America.

headline: Unbalanced in Basel
text: Ambrose Evans-Pritchard draws our attention to a speech by Jaime Caruana, General Manager of the Bank for International Settlements. It is indeed a quite remarkable speech — and I mean that in the worst way; it’s a perfect illustration of the way permahawks keep finding new arguments for their never-changing demand that we raise interest rates now now now.

headline: Inflation Targets Reconsidered
text: My paper for the ECB research conference (pdf) in Portugal, later this month.

headline: Test Yourself | History, May 13
text: Take the Quiz

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Spiders That Thrive in a Social Web
text: In “Spiders That Thrive in a Social Web,” Natalie Angier writes about new research that reveals how some spiders learn to cooperate.

headline: European Court Lets Users Erase Records on Web
text: Europe’s highest court said on Tuesday that people had the right to influence what the world could learn about them through online searches, a ruling that rejected long-established notions about the free flow of information on the Internet.

headline: The Horse at the Heart of Chinese-Turkmen Relations
text: Natural gas projects may be the most desirable gift Turkmenistan’s president brought with him to China, but a “heavenly horse,” presented to China’s president, Xi Jinping, was definitely more photogenic.

headline: Chinese Police Detain Contributor to U.S.-Based Website
text: The police have detained a Beijing resident who they say fabricated stories about topics including organ harvesting and police beatings and posted them on a North Carolina-based Chinese-language website, the latest in hundreds of arrests in a crackdown on expression on the Internet that began last year.

headline: The Bud Light-ification of Bud
text: There are many things that bother Jon Cooper about the market for marijuana.

headline: What Career or Technical Classes Do You Wish Your School Offered?
text: Automotive mechanics, culinary arts, video editing or computer coding? Do you wish you were able to get hands-on training in a field that interests you while still in middle or high school?

headline: Look Ma, I’m a Star (Photographer)
text: Ron Galella’s mother named her son after her favorite movie star, Ronald Colman, because of his elegant British accent. But she raised him in the Bronx, where he wound up sounding more like Marlon Brando in “On the Waterfront.”

headline: Exit Polls Favoring Opposition Add to Indian Stock Market Rally
text: MUMBAI, India — The benchmark Indian stock market indexes rose to a third consecutive record on Tuesday after exit polls forecast that the opposition Bharatiya Janata Party would win with a large majority, making Narendra Modi, a leader with a business-friendly reputation, the next prime minister of India.

headline: VW Wins Enough Shares to Take Full Control of Scania
text: LONDON – The German automaker Volkswagen said on Tuesday that it had succeeded in coaxing enough shareholders to sell so that it could take full control of the Swedish truck maker Scania.

headline: London Stock Exchange Looking at Russell Investments
text: LONDON – The London Stock Exchange said on Tuesday that it was in talks to buy Russell Investments, the owner of the Russell 2000 stock market index.

headline: At Center of Ukraine Talks, Degrees of Decentralizing
text: KIEV, Ukraine — National “round-table” talks seeking to resolve Ukraine’s six-month political crisis by finding a formula for decentralizing power will begin Wednesday against a seemingly formidable array of obstacles.

headline: New York Today: Talent Underground
text: Good Tuesday morning to you.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: The Loyal Bunch
text: JOHANNESBURG — Late last month, just as the dry winter weather started to bite, the political climate turned yellow, green and black, the colors of the African National Congress. Africa’s oldest liberation party was girding itself for the fifth general elections since the end of apartheid and the most anticipated race since Nelson Mandela walked out of prison.

headline: Your Thoughts, Our Thinking
text: Many readers have praised our question-and-answer sessions, including one with Gretchen Morgenson, the business columnist.

headline: Norwest Raises $1.2 Billion in Venture Capital
text: With investors enthusiastic about hot technology start-ups, a major venture capital firm has raised $1.2 billion for its new fund.

headline: The Orange Underpants Logo and the Value of Testing
text: A few months ago, my company, RJMetrics, proudly released a new logo: an orange dodecahedron. It had everything: a great back story, an alignment with company values and the potential to revolutionize the way our customers perceive our brand.

headline: IBM’s Virginia Rometty on Leadership and Management
text: In an article this week, Virginia M. Rometty, IBM‘s chief executive, described her mission as leading the technology giant through a “transformation” that would leave it healthy and successful through the next decade. “That is not a one-year job,” she said, “not when you’re a hundred billion-dollar company.”

headline: The Climate Legacy
text: What we’ll be leaving to future generations.

headline: In Our Pages: May 14
text: 1939: Rush-Hour Blasts in London

headline: Asymmetric Misinformation
text: A followup to my post about Jaime Caruana at the BIS. One other thing that struck me was his claim that

headline: Prosecutor Seeks 30-Day Psychiatric Evaluation for Pistorius
text: The prosecutor in the murder trial of the athlete Oscar Pistorius formally applied on Tuesday for him to undergo a 30-day psychiatric evaluation following testimony that he suffered from “general anxiety disorder.”

headline: AT&T Pursues DirecTV
text: AT&T is in talks to buy DirecTV for at least $50 billion, and the two sides are said to be actively working toward an announcement, DealBook’s David Gelles writes. If the deal is completed, it would give AT&T, the country’s second-largest wireless carrier, control of the country’s largest satellite television provider, a move that would further reshape the already changing telecommunications and television industries.

headline: When Spell-Check Can’t Help
text: Here’s the latest batch of sound-alike problems, look-alike problems and other word mix-ups.

headline: Daily Report: E.U. Court Orders Google to Grant ‘Right to Be Forgotten’
text: The highest court in the European Union decided on Tuesday that Google must, in some cases, grant users of its search engine a “right to be forgotten” that includes deletion of links to embarrassing legal records, James Kanter reports from Brussels.

headline: Q & A: Evan Osnos on the ‘Age of Ambition: Chasing Fortune, Truth, and Faith in the New China’
text: China today is one of the world’s greatest economic success stories, with hundreds of millions of people pulling themselves out of poverty and enjoying a prosperity and quality of life unimaginable three decades ago. It is also the world’s biggest authoritarian state, which puts dissidents behind bars, closely censors the media and allows average citizens little say in politics.

headline: A Hollywood Princess Returns to the Screen
text: LOS ANGELES — In the spring of 1955, Grace Kelly sprinkled a bit of stardust around the eighth international film festival in Cannes, then headed up the coast to Monaco, where she met, and eventually married, the principality’s reigning monarch, Rainier III.

headline: Lawmakers Mistrust a Marriage Offer Pfizer Won’t Abandon
text: LONDON – Pfizer opened the door on Tuesday to a possible higher offer for AstraZeneca, saying the deal remained compelling. It also urged AstraZeneca’s board to engage in discussions that could result in “a transaction that AstraZeneca can recommend.”

headline: Listen Up | Nearly Two Decades In, Little Dragon Breaks Out
text: The story floating around the blogosphere about the Swedish electro-pop band Little Dragon is that its name was inspired by the epic tantrums that the lead singer Yukimi Nagano used to have in the studio. It’s been told and retold enough times to have taken on a mythical quality. “It was so long ago now that I forgot if it’s true, but I feel pretty Zen these days,” Nagano says. “To maintain a band, you have to be able to disagree on a lot of things, and I can’t explode every single time — it’s kind of exhausting.” She adds, “It’s like a relationship. It’s tricky.”

headline: You’ll Make New Friends. Maybe.
text: “How do you feel about leaving your friends?” I asked Cai one evening.

headline: A Stolen Briefcase, and a Very Calm Victim
text: Dear Diary:

headline: 2 Killed in West Virginia Mine Where Safety Lapses Were Cited
text: WHARTON, W.Va. — Two miners died late Monday in an accident inside a West Virginia coal mine whose long history of safety violations had already brought it under special scrutiny by federal officials.

headline: China’s Sizzling Real Estate Market Cools
text: HONG KONG — After almost two decades of nearly unceasing increases in real estate prices and construction across China, one of the world’s longest-running bull markets finally seems to be stalling, with broad consequences for the country’s economy and possibly its politics.

headline: Labor Market Seems Dented, Not Broken
text: There are two schools of thought about the longer-term prospects for the labor market. The darker view is that the Great Recession wrought permanent damage: The jobs that disappeared aren’t easily replaced, and the skills of the jobless are a poor match for the jobs that remain.

headline: Picasso Museum’s President Is Dismissed
text: PARIS — The French government dismissed the embattled president of the Musée Picasso on Tuesday amid an employee revolt and a bitter debate over delays in reopening the museum, which has been closed for renovation for almost five years.

headline: Lew Urges China to Ease Exchange Rate Controls
text: BEIJING — Treasury Secretary Jacob J. Lew pushed China on Tuesday to let market forces decide its exchange rate, and pressed senior officials here not to undercut the Obama administration’s sanctions on Russia.

headline: How PAC Spending Stays Secret
text: The American Heartland PAC hit the airwaves last week in Iowa with a television advertisement criticizing a Republican Senate candidate, Mark Jacobs, as a “Texas millionaire” who supported Democrats in the past. The super PAC, which lists a Washington address, spent $140,000 on the ad.

headline: Researching Stop Signs in the Skies for Birds
text: Advisory: No birds were harmed in the reporting of this article.

headline: E.U. Court Rules in Google Privacy Case
text: The highest court in the European Union decided on Tuesday that Google must, in some cases, honor requests from its search engine users to delete links to personal information.

headline: Building Blackbeard: A Syndication System Powered By Play, Scala and Akka
text: The NYTimes News Service/Syndicate division distributes content to other publications. Our syndication business is growing and, until recently, was managed with a legacy desktop-based CMS, which did not integrate well with our web publishing system.

headline: What Are the Draws and Drawbacks of Success for Writers?
text: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. Lionel Shriver has said she is “perversely nostalgic” for her “previous commercial failure.” This week, Francine Prose and Mohsin Hamid discuss the draws and drawbacks of success for writers.

headline: A Variety of Performances to Mark  Walker Art Center’s 75th Anniversary
text: The Walker Art Center in Minneapolis will celebrate its 75th anniversary with an expansive season that will include world premieres by the multidisciplinary artist Ralph Lemon, the playwright and director Richard Maxwell, and the performance artist and filmmaker Miranda July. There will also be mini-festivals devoted to the music of Bryce Dessner, the guitarist in the National who also writes for classical ensembles, and the choreographer Steve Paxton.

headline: The Things We Keep and What Makes Them So Special
text: The wedding section of The Times publishes an occasional series of readers’ wedding-related stories and photos, called Wedding Album. This month’s theme is: Wedding keepsakes.

headline: Today in Small Business: Is Entrepreneurship Dying?
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Privacy Group Challenges Surveillance Practices in Britain
text: LONDON — British privacy advocates introduced a legal challenge on Tuesday against one of the country’s intelligence agencies, saying the agency illegally hacked personal computers.

headline: A New Line | Cory Arcangel’s Latest Conceptual Art Project: Fashion
text: Cory Arcangel keeps his laptop perched on a small elevated desk in his Sunset Park, Brooklyn studio. Lately, he’s been trying to stand up while he works — not because it’s physically healthier, but because it helps curtail time-wasting. “I find that when you’re standing, there’s a certain threshold for browsing,” says the 35-year-old technology-based artist. “You don’t go on Facebook. There’s something about having to use physical energy. I’m trying all these techniques so that I don’t fall into a dangerous hole that I’m prone to, that I’ve been prone to for 20 years.”

headline: When Driverless Cars Break the Law
text: There is little doubt that the technology behind driverless cars is nearly advanced enough for mainstream use. Google plans to make its biggest public display yet of its cars on Tuesday, when it takes reporters on spins around Mountain View, Calif. Carmakers like BMW and Toyota are also preparing to sell cars that drive themselves.

headline: In Performance: Gil Shaham
text: This week’s In Performance video features the violinist Gil Shaham in a performance of the Gigue from Bach’s Partita No. 3. On May 18 Mr. Shaham will join the Bavarian Radio Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall for a performance of Berg’s Violin Concerto. His most recent album, “1930s Violin Concertos,” a two-CD set released in February, is a compilation of performances of five works, mostly recorded live with major orchestras.

headline: Nina Stemme to Sing Brünnhilde in Washington Opera’s ‘Ring’
text: One of the world’s most sought-after Brünnhildes, the Swedish soprano Nina Stemme,  will sing the role in the nation’s capital in 2016 when Washington National Opera stages Wagner’s complete “Ring” cycle for the first time, after money woes curtailed a previous effort.

headline: Yiddish ‘Godot’ to Open Beckett Festival in Northern Ireland
text: “Vartn af Godot,” the Yiddish version of Samuel Beckett’s absurdist masterpiece “Waiting for Godot,” turns out to have legs. The production, a collaboration between the New Yiddish Rep and the Castillo Theater that played in New York last fall, has been invited to kick off the Happy Days Enniskillen International Beckett Festival in Northern Ireland. The production opens on July 31 and will run the length of the festival, through Aug. 10.

headline: Sriracha Factory Irritates Some California Noses, but Entices Politicians
text: IRWINDALE, Calif. — Until a few months ago, Sriracha was a mere hot sauce, offering a spicy kick to eggs, soup, grilled cheese or a Bloody Mary.

headline: A Postseason Full of Spotlights, Some Glaring
text: It was much like one of those great New York pro basketball nights in the 1990s, when the best player on the planet would bring down the house and, on very special occasions, close it down for the season as well.

headline: Modern Style in Minneapolis
text: In the Uptown neighborhood of Minneapolis, Qais Munhazim, a Ph.D. candidate in international security, wants to show that Afghan men can be stylish and chic.

headline: AT&T’s Deal Strategy Raises Questions
text: AT&T’s deal dialing is emitting a shaky signal.

headline: Airbus Profit Beats Estimates
text: PARIS — Lower costs linked to production of its A380 superjumbo jet and favorable exchange rates helped lift Airbus Group, the European aerospace giant, to a better-than-expected profit in the first quarter, the company said Tuesday.

headline: Finding Old Ireland in Handball Alleys
text: The most recent Look features handball courts, or alleys, in Ireland. For hundreds of years, outdoor handball was a popular sport there, but now scores of abandoned courts dot the landscape in various states of ruin. The pictures were part of the photographer Kenneth O Halloran’s M.F.A. thesis at the University of Ulster last year. It’s the latest in a series of his personal projects with Irish themes, including Tales From the Promised Land, which documented the collapse of the country’s real estate market. The magazine has featured O Halloran’s pictures of dancers at the World Irish Dancing Championships and, most recently, from his trek up Croagh Patrick. Recently I asked him about this latest project of his.

headline: Professor Trades Harvard for Rough-and-Tumble of Indian Politics
text: KOLKATA, India – One afternoon in April, Sugata Bose, a history professor at Harvard University, set out from his house in Sarat Bose Road to a lower-middle-class neighborhood in Jadavpur, the constituency in the eastern city of Kolkata where he is running for Parliament as a candidate of the Trinamool Congress, the governing party in the state of West Bengal.

headline: Highbridge Capital Continues Hiring Spree in London
text: Updated, 2:06 p.m. |

headline: For Late Arrivals, Airbnb Broadens Its Approach
text: In the popular imagination, Airbnb is something slightly complicated. It is best known, for instance, for making that long-awaited trip to Paris more interesting and less expensive. But how often does one go to Paris? So the company is broadening its ambitions to appeal to other sorts of travelers. It is introducing Tuesday two new features that cater to a different sort of guest: the impulsive type, the dawdler, the last-minute planner.

headline: After Ticket and Arrest, Alec Baldwin Gives New York a Piece of His Mind
text: From the cover of a magazine this year, the actor Alec Baldwin threatened to leave New York City. The place has changed, he said.

headline: NetSuite: Enterprise Software Still Follows a Manufacturing Model
text: The two most contentious of the next generation of enterprise software companies are at it again.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Alternative Therapies
U.N. Mediator on Syria Quits; French Envoy Says Chemicals Were Used
text: UNITED NATIONS — International efforts to end the war in Syria faltered further on Tuesday as the United Nations mediator quit, citing frustrations over the moribund political negotiations, and France’s top diplomat said there was evidence the Syrian government used chemical weapons more than a dozen times after it signed the treaty banning them.

headline: The Brewing M.&A. Bubble
text: Stop worrying about the tech bubble – there may be an even bigger one inflating beyond the confines of Silicon Valley.

headline: From Farm to Firing Range
text: The Iowa Senate candidate who charmed the Internet recently with her hog-castration ad—a disturbing  metaphor for her claim that she would “cut pork” in Washington—has joined the distinguished club of political aspirants who shoot things they don’t like, on camera.

headline: Image of the Day: May 13
text: A man after taking a dip in the sacred Yamuna River in the national capital.

headline: Ambassador From Jordan Freed by Captors in Libya
text: AMMAN, Jordan — The Jordanian ambassador to Libya, who was taken hostage by gunmen in the Libyan capital last month, was freed and returned to Jordan on Tuesday after his government agreed to release a Libyan citizen serving a life sentence on terrorism charges, officials in both countries said.

headline: A Major Lift for Fannie and Freddie
text: WASHINGTON — The federal overseer of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac on Tuesday announced a shift in policies intended to maintain the mortgage finance giants’ role in parts of the housing market, spur more home lending and aid distressed homeowners.

headline: For Morgan Stanley, a Quiet Meeting of Shareholders
text: Morgan Stanley’s annual investor meeting lasted 20 minutes, and no one asked any questions.

headline: Kristin Chenoweth to Return to Broadway in ‘On the Twentieth Century’
text: The Tony Award winner Kristin Chenoweth will return to Broadway in February as the Hollywood diva Lily Garland in “On the Twentieth Century,” the 1978 musical comedy about antics aboard a luxury train trip from Chicago to New York City, the Roundabout Theater Company announced on Tuesday.

headline: Appeals Court Grants Stay of Execution in Texas Based on Mental Disability Claim
text: HUNTSVILLE, Tex. — A little more than two hours before he was scheduled to be put to death here, a convicted murderer was granted a stay of execution by a federal appeals court on Tuesday so the courts could review his claim that he is mentally disabled — a disability, his lawyers argued, that state agencies had long known and concealed.

headline: To Compete With PlayStation on Price, Microsoft Offers Xbox Without Kinect Motion Sensor
text: SEATTLE —A few months ago, Microsoft talked about Kinect, the motion- and voice-controlled sensor for the Xbox, as an integral part of the company’s video game plans.

headline: Stuyvesant Town, Bastion of Affordable Housing, Is on Way Back to Auction
text: Stuyvesant Town-Peter Cooper Village, the largest apartment complex in Manhattan, is most likely headed back to the auction block, in a real estate deal that would represent a test of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s goal to make New York an affordable place to live.

headline: Willie Nelson Donates Collection to the University of Texas
text: Willie Nelson may have spent much of his life on the road, but a good part of his artistic remains will rest forever in Texas, thanks to a donation by the singer to the Dolph Briscoe Center for American History at the University of Texas in Austin.

headline: Voting for Change: Researching the Issues at Stake in India’s Election
text: What happens when you ask 814 million people to decide the future of their country? The answer will be coming soon for India, which this week is concluding a huge, 35-day election for seats in the national Parliament. Observers say the results could be momentous, with polls suggesting that voters are fed up with slow economic or political progress and favor decisive change — even at the risk of upsetting the nation’s fragile balance between its religious and social groups.

headline: After Hours | A Ribald Downtown Auction on Behalf of Creative Freedom
text: Last night offered a classic instance of a time-honored Manhattan tradition: arty downtowners doing a little song and dance to extract crucial funding from monied uptowners. The setting was the opulent subterranean boîte the Diamond Horseshoe, which hosted its annual benefit for the not-for-profit performance space P.S. 122, which has been staging amazing and bizarre shows in the East Village for more than 30 years, with performers ranging from Eric Bogosian and John Leguizamo to Annie Dorsen and Young Jean Lee.

headline: So Much Food, It Fills a Hall
text: Food halls are all about gratification, both immediate (a chorizo and potato taco to eat on the spot) and delayed (a chunky jar of anchovies to take home). These bounteous markets are not new to the city; Macy’s opened its Cellar nearly 40 years ago. In 1997, the former Nabisco factory was transformed into Chelsea Market on West 15th Street, setting off the modern proliferation of indoor markets.

headline: Wheelies: The Wooden Volkswagen Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Times Minute | Newark’s Next Mayor
text: Also on the Minute, new privacy protections in Europe and developing bird-safe glass.

headline: Times Minute | Newark’s Next Mayor
text: In the Video

headline: Churchill Downs Owner Joins Bid for Casino in Upstate New York
text: ALBANY — One of the most recognizable names in horse racing is joining the field in New York’s sprint into big-time gambling.

headline: You Start in Spain, but There’s Room to Roam
text: The name means “the fifth pine,” a Spanish idiom for the boondocks, which was probably a stretch even seven years ago when El Quinto Pino opened on West 24th Street, across from the canyon wall of London Terrace. The thumbnail curve of the sardine-can tapas bar is just the way it’s been since the beginning, packed, every seat there and on the opposite wall a few inches away taken almost any time you show up.

headline: Conservative Pick Set to Win G.O.P. Primary in Nebraska
text: WASHINGTON — Conservatives are poised to declare victory on Tuesday in Nebraska, where their preferred Senate candidate, Benjamin E. Sasse, is well positioned to win the Republican nomination in a race that the Tea Party has made a priority in a year that so far has favored the establishment.

headline: What Exactly Was Donald Sterling’s Offense?
text: We can probably agree that the Los Angeles Clippers owner Donald Sterling made offensive comments. But was his offense thinking racist thoughts? Or saying them out loud? Had he not been recorded, Sterling would have received a lifetime achievement award from the N.A.A.C.P. The victim of his remarks was himself: Sterling managed to (further) trash his own reputation. No one else was really injured. Is purity of thought the expectation for team owners? MARK ALEXANDER, ST. LOUIS

headline: Tech Star Is Leaving Goldman Sachs to Join Hedge Fund
text: At Goldman Sachs, Anthony J. Noto has won some big-name business, including leading the initial public offering of Twitter last year.

headline: A Plush Bike Trip in Tennessee
text: Trek Travel has partnered with Blackberry Farm, a Relais & Châteaux property in eastern Tennessee, to host the Great Smoky Mountains/Blackberry Farm Bike Tour in November.

headline: Detroit, From Both Side of the Coin
text: Bill Rauhauser spent much of his life taking pictures as a hobby while working as an engineer. But those twin tugs gave his work a range and balance few can match.

headline: Lane Closings Were ‘Idiotic,’ Christie Aide Testifies
text: TRENTON — The chief spokesman for Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey testified on Tuesday that he was misled about why lanes leading to the George Washington Bridge were closed last September, and was “shocked and disoriented” when he learned that the motive appeared to be political vengeance.

headline: Observed | At the Echo Park Craft Fair, California-Style Spirituality Rises Once Again
text: As far as Southern California festival style goes, the Echo Park Craft Fair is a long way from the bare midriffs and hippie posturing of Coachella. The biannual design and food festival, which celebrated its fifth anniversary last weekend, has evolved from an intimate backyard bazaar into the see-and-be-seen happening for a certain swath of the L.A. creative class. In a city without much pedestrian activity, the fair — which, despite its name, takes place in Silver Lake — generates plenty of it. And with all that foot traffic comes a uniquely Angeleno sort of fashion parade, one with a distinctly spiritual vibe.

headline: Ex-Barclays Chief’s New Venture to Raise $400 Million in Private Placement
text: LONDON – The investment company Atlas Mara Co-Nvest, backed by a former Barclays chief executive, Robert E. Diamond Jr., is seeking to raise another $400 million to fund its investments in the African financial sector.

headline: In a Shift From Deficit Concerns, the Senate Will Take Up Tax Breaks
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Tuesday shrugged off the deficit concerns that were once an animating force on Capitol Hill, voting 96-3 to take up a package of business tax breaks without offering any way to pay for them.

headline: Talking to Children About Their Disabilities, With Metaphors and Minecraft
text: Year-round, those of us who have kids with disabilities in our lives spend countless hours discussing them: meetings, consultations, casual conversations with friends. And yet we rarely, if ever, talk directly to children themselves about their challenges.

headline: Get Rid of ‘Condom Policing’
text: New York City drove down its H.I.V. infection rate in part by flooding the streets with millions upon millions of free condoms each year. At the same time, the police have undermined this effort by using condom possession as evidence to support prostitution charges — and by simply seizing condoms from sex workers and destroying them.

headline: Aging Tuscan Port Vies to Dismantle Costa Concordia
text: PIOMBINO, Italy — Workers are hurriedly revamping the aged port in this smoggy Tuscan city, trucking in boulders to construct and fortify jetties, and enlarging its facilities to refit and dismantle ships. They are scheduled to dredge and deepen the harbor next month.

headline: Up for Discussion: Offering Parental Leave and Entering a New Market
text: At the most recent meeting of the She Owns It business group, the owners touched on how they handle parental leave at their companies, before moving on to discuss Skylight Group’s expansion into San Francisco.

headline: Governor Christie’s Spokesman Testifies
text: Michael Drewniak, the press secretary for Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, testified before a legislative committee on the investigation into the closing of lanes at the George Washington Bridge.

headline: Top U.N. Mediator in Syria Resigns
text: The United Nations Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon and the Syria mediator, Lakhdar Brahimi, discussed Mr. Brahimi’s decision to step down after nearly two years of seeking an end to the conflict.

headline: At Their Best on the Brink
text: PITTSBURGH — Henrik Lundqvist, the king of Game 7s, stood tall again for the Rangers on Tuesday night. He stopped 35 of 36 Penguins shots — even a couple without his stick in a chaotic goal-mouth scramble in the final minutes — to spearhead a thrilling 2-1 victory that capped a historic comeback from a three-games-to-one series deficit.

headline: Federal Panel Appears Split Over Virginia’s Ban on Same-Sex Marriage
text: RICHMOND, Va. — In sharp exchanges pitting the right of states to set marriage rules against equal protection for gay and lesbian couples, a three-judge federal appeals panel here heard arguments on Tuesday on the constitutionality of Virginia’s ban on same-sex marriages.

headline: Scene City: Art World Field Trip to Greenwich
text: Dan Colen retrospective opens at the Brant Foundation Art Study Center in Greenwich, Conn.

headline: Ex-G.I. Gets Medal of Honor for Lifesaving Acts in Afghanistan
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Tuesday awarded the Medal of Honor to Sgt. Kyle J. White, an Army radiotelephone operator who struggled for hours through enemy fire in Afghanistan to try to save the lives of wounded soldiers during a surprise attack by Taliban fighters.

headline: Marta, a New Pizza Restaurant, Opens
text: Headliner

headline: Cast-Iron Steak
text: To cook a fantastic steak on the stovetop, all you need is a cast-iron pan, a sprinkle of salt and a one-inch-thick cut of meat.

headline: They’re Together, but Not on the Same Wavelength
text: “Intermission,” by the Canadian playwright Daniel Libman, wants desperately to be clever and surprising, but its improbable plot requires too many characters who aren’t credible and conversations that are convenient rather than organic.

headline: Fisherman Likes Sex but Hates the City
text: “Sea Marks” takes place in that distant, storied past before the invention of email. Still, it’s amusing to think of the online personals ad its hero, Colm (Patrick Fitzgerald), might have written: “Single, virginal fisherman on remote Irish island seeks woman for conversation, companionship and whiskey tippling. Likes: Mackerel, the sea, ale. Dislikes: Organized religion, incense, small presses. Fondness for lyrical twaddle and small craft a plus.” (Surely, Colm would have favored the Plenty of Fish site.)

headline: Drugs to Aid Alcoholics See Little Use, Study Finds
text: Two medications could help tens of thousands of alcoholics quit drinking, yet the drugs are rarely prescribed to patients, researchers reported on Tuesday.

headline: The Gun Report: May 13, 2014
text: Last month, 15-year-old Bayshawn Kelly was critically wounded in a drive-by shooting in Lakeland, Fla. Dayquon Raheem Longs, also 15, was wounded in the same attack. Earlier that day, Kelly had been a passenger in car that was fired at.

headline: Lawyers on Olmert’s Sentencing
text: Lawyers for the defense and the prosecution spoke after Ehud Olmert, the former prime minister of Israel, was sentenced to six years in prison for taking bribes.

headline: West Islip: Backyards and Boat Slips
text: Not even a major February snowstorm kept Dragan and Dorota Dejkanovic and their three children, ages 8, 4 and 5 months, from moving into the five-bedroom country Cape on just over half an acre in West Islip, a pretty hamlet on the Great South Bay in Suffolk County.

headline: Steak That Sizzles on the Stovetop
text: Like many home cooks, I gave up on steak a while ago.

headline: A Tragedy of Silence in Badakhshan
text: ABI BARAK, Afghanistan — Hidden in a valley of the Hindu Kush range, the village of Abi Barik went mostly unnoticed for decades. The hour-plus journey it takes to get to the provincial capital from here, along a rugged and unpaved mountain road, ensured that the residents largely kept to themselves.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Ukraine, Iraq, Palestine and South Africa.

headline: Obama Awards Medal of Honor
text: The president awarded Kyle J. White, a former Army sergeant, the Medal of Honor for his actions during combat in Nuristan Province, Afghanistan, on Nov. 9, 2007.

headline: Behind the Poster: ‘Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf?’
text: Julie Furer Knutson didn’t know much about Edward Albee’s 1962 play “Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf?” before she started working on a poster design for the revival now at Seattle Rep. But once she started her research, one thing became clear.

headline: Valeant and Pershing Square Put Pressure on Allergan
text: A day after rejecting an unsolicited $50 billion bid from Valeant Pharmaceuticals and the hedge fund Pershing Square Capital Management, Allergan, the maker of Botox, faced renewed pressure from its suitors to strike a deal.

headline: To Guide the Merger Giants, Strong Hands Are Needed
text: “Oh, never mind.”

headline: Small Comfort as Parents Identify Kidnapped Nigerian Girls on Video
text: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria — When the girls appeared on the screen, parents in the small room at the government compound here dissolved into tears.

headline: The Whiteness of Snow, Reflected in Naked Human Bodies
text: In Melinda Ring’s ambitious new triptych — a dance, “Forgetful Snow,” and two daytime performance installations — the subject isn’t too difficult to work out. Four white walls, including the risers, are painted a dazzling white. (It’s Benjamin Moore’s Super White; the fumes linger.) In the center is a plush white carpet. The dancers are nude.

headline: In Store | A Leather Goods Shop Where Everything Old Is New Again
text: Will Adler discovered the massive, 90-year-old saw blade that hangs in the entryway of Will Leather Goods, the store he’s opening next week in NoLIta, on a hike with his wife in Webster, Ore. “Right by this beautiful waterfall, we spotted an old timber mill, and that’s where we found this,” he says. “We really wanted to bring the woods of Oregon to New York.”

headline: A Youthful Ensemble Turns Up the Intensity
text: Few concerts reach climaxes in the encores. After an hour or two of strenuous playing, it’s certainly not unusual for performers to be reluctant to push themselves too much further. Even if the party pieces unveiled when musicians are called back for more burst with dazzling notes, they often end up being merely pleasant.

headline: Road to Civil Disobedience Began in South Africa
text: When the young Indian lawyer Mohandas K. Gandhi set sail in 1893 for Durban, the main port in Britain’s colony in Natal in southeast Africa, he expected his assignment to last no more than a year. Having found it difficult to establish a legal practice in his hometown in Gujarat, he had accepted a short-term commission to assist a Muslim merchant in Durban who was in a financial dispute with another Muslim merchant in Pretoria, capital of the neighboring Boer republic of Transvaal.

headline: Derivatives Markets Growing Again, With Few New Protections
text: Mayra Rodríguez Valladares is managing principal at MRV Associates, a capital markets and financial regulatory consulting and training firm in New York. She is also a faculty member at Financial Markets World and the New York Institute of Finance.

headline: Newark’s Voters Choose New Mayor and New Path
text: Councilman Ras Baraka, the fiery scion of a militant poet, was elected mayor of Newark on Tuesday, signaling a likely shift in the direction that New Jersey’s largest city had embarked upon for most of the last decade.

headline: Daniel Levy
text: Mr. Levy, 42, is the president and chief executive of CityRealty, a real estate search website that provides information about residential sales and rental listings in New York City, with a focus on Manhattan and Brooklyn. The site also helps to connect buyers with brokers.

headline: Paltry Office Pantries Give Way to Sleek Social Spaces
text: For 12 years, employees of Anbau, a luxury real estate investment and development firm, worked in a walk-up on Fifth Avenue with no kitchen pantry to heat lunches or make coffee.

headline: Bearing Witness, Losing Her Life
text: Camille Lepage, a photographer who considered it her duty to delve into stories in often-overlooked places, was killed in the Central African Republic. Nicholas Kulish rememebrs.

headline: A Renaissance in Rapid City, S.D.
text: In the shadow of monumental Mount Rushmore, Rapid City might suffer from a slight inferiority complex. But this city has always brimmed with resilience. After a devastating flood in 1972, the city landscaped the floodplain with a 10-mile-long bicycle and walking path. In recent years, its once-seedy downtown area has developed a surprising eco-sensibility and a thriving art scene. Along an alleyway, boldly hued murals and graffiti bracket building facades. Main Street Square, the downtown cultural hub, is the site of a newly commissioned public sculpture project. A car-free Memorial Park Promenade will open in June.

headline: Larry McMurtry on the Power of the Plains
text: For Larry McMurtry — the Pulitzer Prize-winning author of “Lonesome Dove” and co-author of the Oscar-winning screenplay for “Brokeback Mountain” — one of the most interesting, and overlooked, aspects of life in the Old West was just how profoundly isolating the “westering” experience could be. “Those plains, those mountains, those deserts were empty, except for the Indians, who didn’t make the settlers less lonely,” said Mr. McMurtry, 77.

headline: A Trail Helps Open Up a Dallas Neighborhood to New Development
text: DALLAS — The din begins around 5 o’clock at the Katy Trail Ice House, as predominantly millennial-age beer drinkers grasping 18-ounce schooners spill out of the metal-framed bar and onto an oak-shaded patio in the booming Uptown neighborhood.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: Concern for Health of 2 Political Prisoners in Egypt
text: Two young Egyptians detained last year during the military-backed government’s deadly crackdown on dissent face serious threats to their health after more than 100 days on hunger strike, according to medical reports made public in recent days.

headline: Morgan Stanley Hires Senior Barclays Banker
text: Morgan Stanley has hired a senior Barclays banker. He is the latest top deal maker to leave the British firm in recent weeks.

headline: Georgia Senate Race Becoming Less of a Long Shot for Democrats
text: New polling from NBC/Marist and The Atlanta Journal-Constitution mixed things up in our Senate model, with our forecasts in Arkansas and Georgia moving in a Democratic direction. The national outcome remains a coin flip, although the new data tipped our forecast from a 54 percent chance that the Republicans will take the Senate this fall to a slightly better than even chance (52 percent) that the Democrats will stay in power.

headline: Miller Theater Season
text: The Miller Theater at Columbia University will continue to emphasize its traditional strengths — new music, early music and provocative combinations of the two — in its 2014-15 season. It will open Sept. 18 with “Heart and Breath,” a production by the new-music ensemble Eighth Blackbird in which the musicians play commedia dell’arte roles and perform 17th-century Italian music filtered through 21st-century sensibilities. The hall’s signature series, Composer Portraits, will offer overviews of the works of eight living composers, four of them women, representing an expansive array of contemporary styles. The series begins with an evening of recent works by Chou Wen-Chung, performed by the ensembles for which he wrote them — the Brentano String Quartet, Talujon and the New York New Music Ensemble. The International Contemporary Ensemble, with Steven Schick conducting, will devote a program to the Israeli experimentalist Chaya Czernowin, and the string quartet Ethel will perform the world premiere of a new work by Missy Mazzoli on a program that also includes her “Harp and Altar,” a paean to the Brooklyn Bridge. Other installments of Composer Portraits include programs devoted to Bernard Rands, Keeril Makan, Stefano Gervasoni, Augusta Read Thomas and Anna Clyne. The Miller’s program also includes a jazz series and occasional pop-up concerts (with free beer), which will announced closer to the performances. The full schedule is at millertheatre.com.

headline: Misstep in Re-election Filings May Fell Veteran Congressman From Michigan
text: DETROIT — For nearly 50 years, John Conyers Jr. has represented Detroit in the House of Representatives. He is the ranking Democrat on the House Judiciary Committee, a founder of the Congressional Black Caucus and the second-longest-serving member of Congress still holding office.

headline: A Tony for the Mantel? Maybe Not
text: A leading theater organization is developing proposals — sure to be unpopular with some producers — to stop selling the medallion-topped Tony Awards to scores of investors who help finance winning Broadway shows.

headline: Latest Airplane Amenity: An Apartment
text: The airline that introduced the Flying Nanny for traveling families just announced more residentially inspired amenities, including a one-bedroom apartment in the air.

headline: Kick-Starting a Season With Frolics and Feats
text: Slowly, cautiously, tentatively, American Ballet Theater is improving its spring gala, the motley extravaganza with which it annually opens its big eight-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House. Until a couple of years ago, this celebration had settled into a rut: a few too many nonerotic bedroom pas de deux; dozens too many fouetté turns from one ballerina after another; and curtain speeches that sounded like shopping lists. Everything onstage encouraged the idea that ballet was the tritest and most predictable of all art forms.

headline: Seeing God in Snakes, Strippers and Tattoos
text: It’s not clear what Aram Garriga thinks he is accomplishing in his simplistic “American Jesus,” but he’s not accomplishing much. Whatever hopes you might have had that this Spanish filmmaker would be able to do for American Christianity what another outsider, Alexis de Tocqueville, did for America as a whole are dashed as soon as the snake-handling minister shows up.

headline: A Look Back at a Year of Top Voices
text: The Metropolitan Opera’s season closed on Saturday with a matinee of Rossini’s “La Cenerentola” and an evening performance of Bellini’s “I Puritani.” On this final day, the Met presented two of the three reigning bel canto tenors who had such success at the house this spring: Juan Diego Flórez as the prince in “Cenerentola,” and Lawrence Brownlee as Arturo in “Puritani.”

headline: First Glimpse of Missing Nigerian Girls
text: Video released by Boko Haram in May 2014 is the first glimpse of the missing schoolgirls since they were abducted on April 14, 2014.

headline: Without a Hit Wallet, Square Tries Another Approach
text: Square, the mobile payments start-up, is a testament to how tough it is to sell people on the idea of a mobile wallet. Even after scoring a big partnership with Starbucks Coffee and offering a futuristic app that lets people pay for things just by saying their name, Square’s mobile wallet gained little traction. Now the company has stopped offering its wallet app in favor of a new approach.

headline: Where Hope Is Scarce, Terrorism Takes Root
text: The residents of Sidi Moumen, a sprawling shantytown on the outskirts of Casablanca, Morocco, live in tin-roofed shacks without electricity, running water or modern sewage disposal. The area sits atop a garbage dump where boys run wild in packs and engage in fierce soccer matches that often explode into violence. Aerial shots depict this slum as a fetid, desiccated wasteland, in which the pickings are thin, even for scavengers. To sell oranges in a market for a pittance, you must fight for space.

headline: Bearing Witness, Losing Her Life
text: I got to know Camille Lepage on my first trip to South Sudan last summer. A jaunty young Frenchwoman who tooled around the rutted dirt roads of Juba on the back of a beat-up old motorcycle, she was hoping to work with me on the story I had come to town to cover, and I had received a slew of email messages from her.

headline: China’s Demand Threatens Rare Hardwoods in Mekong
text: China’s surging demand for luxury furniture and a revived cultural tradition are not only taking a toll on the forests of its Southeast Asian neighbors but also fueling a deadly crime wave across the region, according to an environmental monitoring group.

headline: Walgreen Shareholder Opposes Potential Deal to Reincorporate Abroad
text: As the drugstore chain Walgreen considers a deal that would allow it to reincorporate abroad, many shareholders are elated, saying it could save millions of dollars a year on taxes.

headline: Why Divestment Can Be Successful
text: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Big Data’ and Surveillance
text: To the Editor:
