text: To the Editor:

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
text: RECENT SALE

headline: Raising the Costa Concordia in 2013
text: In September 2013, engineers in Giglio, Italy, worked all day to pull up the Costa Concordia cruise liner, which struck a reef and keeled over, killing 32 people on Jan. 13, 2012.

headline: Different N.B.A. Loyalties for Black and White Neighborhoods
text: It is no secret that the N.B.A. is especially popular among black Americans. About 45 percent of people who watched N.B.A. games during the 2012-2013 regular season were black, even though African-Americans make up 13 percent of the country’s population.

headline: French Minister’s Statement
text: Foreign Minister Laurent Fabius said there were strong indications that the Syrian government had carried out attacks using chemical agents in recent weeks.

headline: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,306 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: The Collections | The Top 10 Moments at Collective 2 Fair
text: Sunday marked the end of the second annual collectible design fair, Collective 2. For the event’s sophomore edition, the organizers chose a new more central venue, Skylight at Moynihan Station — housed in the imposing former James A. Farley Post Office on 33rd Street — and added 17 new dealers. The fair’s founder, Steven Learner, is determined to differentiate Collective from the rest of New York Design Week — and every detail, from the carefully curated roster of galleries to the vintage Cadillac exhibited by the event’s sponsor, reinforced its distinctiveness. Here, a few of the best in show.

headline: Ruling in Airbnb’s Case in New York
text: The Supreme Court in New York squashed a subpoena served to Airbnb by the state’s attorney general that sought information about the start-up’s users.

headline: A Victory for Airbnb in New York
text: Airbnb, the popular apartment-sharing service, won a legal standoff Tuesday when a state judge ruled that the company did not have to give up customer records as part of an investigation by the New York attorney general.

headline: To Dream in Different Cultures
text: WHEN Doug Hollan arrived on the Indonesian island of Sulawesi for his anthropology dissertation fieldwork in a rice farming village, his Toraja neighbors wanted to take turns sleeping with him and his wife.

headline: Ordering Google to Forget
text: In a ruling that could undermine press freedoms and free speech, the highest court of the European Union said on Tuesday that Google must comply with requests from individuals to remove links on search results pages to newspaper articles and other web pages that might cause embarrassment.

headline: Labor Talks Begin at Metropolitan Opera
text: The Metropolitan Opera opened labor talks on Tuesday with the Local 1 of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees, the union that represents the stagehands who build, move and light the sets and props at the opera house.

headline: Eric Schmidt Has an Interest. Is It a Conflict?
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York last month appointed a three-person commission to offer thoughts on the use of technology in schools.

headline: Justice Dept. Criticized on Spying Statements
text: WASHINGTON — Two Democratic senators accused the Obama administration on Tuesday of seeking to “ignore or justify” statements it made to the Supreme Court about warrantless surveillance by the National Security Agency, contributing to what they called a “culture of misinformation” by the executive branch.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 30
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: More Shonda Rhimes for ABC, Plus a Partnership With ESPN
text: AS the 2014-15 television upfront week continued on Tuesday, the presentations ran the gamut from A, for ABC, to U, for Univision, with some notable crossovers in between.

headline: The Politics of Income Inequality
text: The years from the late 19th and early 20th centuries were not the most egalitarian in American history. Robber barons roamed the economy, living off lavish rents generated by powerful cartels and industrial monopolies.

headline: 68 Pakistani Lawyers Are Charged With Blasphemy After Protesting the Police
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — In the latest blasphemy case to highlight growing intolerance in Pakistan, the police in Punjab Province said Tuesday that they had filed blasphemy charges against a group of 68 lawyers at the instigation of a Sunni extremist leader.

headline: An Inconvenient Truth About Our Food
text: “Fed Up” is probably the most important movie to be made since “An Inconvenient Truth,” to which it’s related in a couple of ways.

headline: Rutgers Cuts Quarterback Charged in Minnesota Assault Case
text: Rutgers said Tuesday that quarterback Philip Nelson had been dismissed from the team after his arrest over the weekend in connection with an assault on a man outside a bar in Mankato, Minn.

headline: A Trip in a Self-Driving Car Now Seems Routine
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — Boring.

headline: Punched Out: The Death of Derek Boogaard
text: Derek Boogaard was one of the N.H.L.’s most feared fighters before overdosing on May 13, 2011. The New York Times examined the life and death of the professional hockey player in 2011.

headline: Tunisian Discontent Reflected in Protests That Have Idled Mines
text: GAFSA, Tunisia — Tunisians often say the first uprising of the Arab Spring began not in 2010 after the self-immolation of a fruit vendor, Mohamed Bouazizi, but in 2008, when protests over corrupt hiring practices at the mines of Gafsa ran on for six months. It is a measure of the lingering challenges of Tunisia’s revolution that people here are still in revolt.

headline: Sallie Mae to Pay Fine Over Loans to Troops
text: Sallie Mae, the giant student lender, and Navient, previously a loan servicing unit of Sallie Mae, have agreed to pay $97 million to settle allegations by federal regulators that military service members were charged excessive interest and fees on student loans.

headline: A Trainer in Twilight and a Horse Poised for Its Day in the Sun
text: When California Chrome pulled away for a one-and-three-quarter-lengths victory in the Kentucky Derby on May 3, Art Sherman, 77, became the oldest trainer to saddle a winner in the United States’ most famous horse race.

headline: Fognini Finds His Antics Don’t Play Well at Home in Italy
text: ROME — The Italian Open embraces its natives with more passion than perhaps any other tournament, but the top Italian man did not feel that warmth this week.

headline: Doubts Raised About Off-Label Use of Subsys, a Strong Painkiller
text: Almost overnight, a powerful new painkiller has become a $100 million business and a hot Wall Street story.

headline: The Speaker’s Sand Trap
text: The Speaker is hitting the links.

headline: Common Sense at the Library
text: The New York Public Library has abandoned its plan to renovate its landmark building in Midtown. There will be no hybrid lending-and-research library behind those stone lions on Fifth Avenue, no towering glass atrium looking out on Bryant Park. The dumpy Mid-Manhattan Library, across the street, will not be sold. No books will be banished to New Jersey.

headline: In Season of Protest, Haverford Speaker Is Latest to Bow Out
text: Haverford College on Tuesday joined a growing list of schools to lose commencement speakers to protests from the left, when Robert J. Birgeneau, a former chancellor at the University of California, Berkeley, withdrew from this weekend’s event.

headline: The Square People, Part 1
text: HANOI, Vietnam — I think I’ll plan to go from Kiev to Hanoi more often. It’s only when you go to two seemingly disconnected places that you see the big trends, and one of the big ones I’ve noticed is the emergence of “The Square People.”

headline: Lebanese TV Executive Is Summoned to Hague Court
text: PARIS — An international tribunal that has spent five years and more than $325 million investigating a political assassination in Lebanon without making a single arrest finally got on Tuesday its first look at an accused in the dock. But it was none of the five men charged with complicity in the 2005 murder of Rafik Hariri, the former Lebanese prime minister.

headline: Judge Wants Trials for 3 in Bombing Case to Stay in Boston
text: BOSTON — A federal judge on Tuesday said he wanted to try to find juries in Boston for the trials of three friends of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the suspect in last year’s marathon bombings. But he indicated that if impartial jurors could not be found here, he might seek a jury from Springfield, Mass., about 90 miles west.

headline: To See Baseball’s Best Young Aces This Year, Try Operating Room
text: They are twin poles, for the moment, of a grim trend that has become the story of the baseball season: Matt Harvey and Jose Fernandez, must-see ace right-handers just starting their major league careers, sidelined suddenly by a serious elbow injury.

headline: Around a Sardinian Table, a Fractious Debate
text: LU FRAILI, Sardinia — April was lovely, as always, in Sardinia. The summer tourists had not yet arrived; the island was covered with wildflowers and the wild asparagus was pushing up among the cork trees. This spring felt especially healing after the death and destruction wrought by cyclone Cleopatra last November. The storm had damaged my 84-year-old father’s house, and I had come to deal with the repairs.

headline: Nets Down to Final Shot Against Heat
text: The Nets have several veterans with reputations as clutch performers.

headline: A Call for Justice for Syrians
text: For three years, the United Nations Security Council has failed to end the violence in Syria, largely because Russia and China have stubbornly blocked constructive action and protected President Bashar al-Assad. A new French-led move to have the Council refer Syria to the International Criminal Court for possible prosecution of war crimes won’t end the slaughter either. But it would underscore the world’s revulsion at atrocities by both sides and its insistence that those responsible be brought to justice.

headline: Pets and Medication
text: With the growing popularity of drugs to treat behavioral problems, are pet owners relying too much on medication to fix easily solved problems?

headline: Mets Pitcher Who Made the Most of One Hit Is in Australia
text: In their 52 years of existence, the Mets have had any number of players who had only one base hit in their time with the team, from Calvin Schiraldi to Turk Wendell to Aaron Heilman. Eric Campbell, who made his debut last weekend as a backup infielder, is the newest member of the club, though perhaps not for long.

headline: A Safety Plan With Swedish Logic and City Smarts
text: STOCKHOLM — The quest to eradicate serious crashes here began with a happy accident.

headline: Deadly Fire Roars Through Coal Mine in Turkey
text: ISTANBUL — An explosion on Tuesday in a coal mine in western Turkey killed more than 200 miners and left hundreds of others trapped underground, Turkey’s energy minister said early Wednesday.

headline: Girding for a Fight, McConnell Enlists His Wife
text: WASHINGTON — At Harvard Business School, Elaine L. Chao kept card files on her classmates, then later kept tabs on their careers. As labor secretary, she had gold-colored coins minted with her name in bas-relief and employed a “Veep”-like staff member who carried around her bag.

headline: Heading Out on Its Own, Citizens Bank Faces a Tough Climate
text: Being cast off from a struggling foreign parent company might bring on an identity crisis for some institutions. Not so for Citizens Bank, which is looking to turn its coming independence from the Royal Bank of Scotland into an opportunity to strengthen its consumer banking in the United States.

headline: Sore Right Elbow Puts Beltran on a Long List of Injured Yankees
text: Carlos Beltran received a cortisone injection on Monday after a magnetic resonance imaging test revealed bone spurs in his right elbow.

headline: Barely Enough to Wet One’s Whistle
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Just as I love a book or film that holds its secrets until close to the end, so do I love a crossword puzzle that does the same thing. Victor Barocas’s Wednesday puzzle does just that.

headline: U.S. Envoys See a Rwanda Moment in Syria’s Escalating Crisis
text: WASHINGTON — Speaking at the State Department after being sworn in on Tuesday, Tom Malinowski, the new assistant secretary of state for democracy, human rights and labor, said his daughter quizzed him recently about what role he had played 20 years ago, when the Clinton administration failed to prevent the genocide in Rwanda.

headline: Conservative Wins G.O.P. Senate Nomination in Nebraska
text: WASHINGTON — Conservatives claimed victory on Tuesday in Nebraska, where the Senate candidate they preferred won the Republican nomination in a race the Tea Party had made a priority in a year that so far has favored the establishment.

headline: For Wheeler, 118 Pitches, All of Them a Struggle
text: This was a chance for Zack Wheeler to assert himself, to shake off his recent struggles, when he took to the mound against the Yankees at Yankees Stadium on Tuesday night.

headline: Malik Bendjelloul, Oscar Winner for ‘Sugar Man’ Film, Dies at 36
text: Malik Bendjelloul, a Swedish filmmaker who won the 2013 Academy Award for best documentary with his debut feature, “Searching for Sugar Man,” about a forgotten American balladeer who, unwittingly, had achieved fame halfway around the world, was found dead on Tuesday in Stockholm. He was 36.

headline: Climate Change Deemed Growing Security Threat by Military Researchers
text: WASHINGTON — The accelerating rate of climate change poses a severe risk to national security and acts as a catalyst for global political conflict, a report published Tuesday by a leading government-funded military research organization concluded.

headline: 26 Percent of World’s Adults Are Anti-Semitic, Survey Finds
text: Twenty-six percent of all adults worldwide harbor anti-Semitic attitudes and nearly half have never heard of the Holocaust, the Anti-Defamation League said Tuesday in what it described as an unprecedented and sobering global survey that assessed the level and intensity of hostility toward Jews.

headline: Videos Said to Show Force-Feeding of Detainees at Guantánamo Bay
text: The military has made videotapes of military medical officials force-feeding detainees on hunger strikes at the prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, according to a court filing on Tuesday. The filing asks a judge to issue an emergency order to the military requiring it to preserve the tapes. In 2007, it came to light that the C.I.A. had destroyed videotapes of its interrogation sessions showing the use of the suffocation technique called waterboarding. The military’s practice of force-feeding detainees has been a major issue in habeas corpus lawsuits. The procedure involves strapping a detainee into a restraint chair and inserting a gastric tube through the nose and down the throat, through which liquid nutritional supplement is poured into the stomach. In February, a federal appeals court in the District of Columbia ruled that the courts have jurisdiction to hear challenges of the conditions of confinement at Guantánamo as part of habeas corpus lawsuits.

headline: Ethics Complaint Against Google’s Chairman
text: A consumer watchdog group is arguing that Eric E. Schmidt, Google’s executive chairman, is unethically participating in an advisory panel to dole out billions in funds for educational technology in New York.

headline: A Resort in Galilee Rises Where Jesus May Have Taught
text: MIGDAL, Israel — For the Rev. Juan M. Solana, it was the spiritual equivalent of striking oil.

headline: The Mine Collapse in Turkey
text: The Turkish energy minister, Taner Yildiz, spoke about the fire in a coal mine in Soma that trapped hundreds.

headline: Groups Back Global Plan for Tracking Commercial Flights
text: MONTREAL — Airlines, governments, pilots and aircraft manufacturers all agreed at a conference on Tuesday that a global system for tracking commercial aircraft is badly needed, a United Nations aviation agency said. But the parties sidestepped a key question: whether aircrews should be able to turn off all the equipment that makes them visible.

headline: The Hague: Court to Review British War Crime Inquiry
text: The prosecutor at the International Criminal Court, Fatou Bensouda, said Tuesday that she had reopened a preliminary war crimes investigation into accusations that British officials were responsible for the systematic abuse of Iraqi prisoners by Britain’s military from 2003 to 2008. A similar investigation was closed in 2006, but Ms. Bensouda said she would review whether new information she received in January justified reopening the case. Although Iraq has not signed the Rome Statute, which governs the court’s proceedings, Britain has, and its citizens can in theory be prosecuted for crimes committed in Iraq or elsewhere. However, the court, which is based in The Hague, can proceed only if the allegations are not being properly investigated by the British authorities themselves.

headline: How ‘Person’ Retains Interest at Episode 23
text: The paranoid techno thriller “Person of Interest,” which ended its third season on Tuesday night on CBS, is subject to all the conventional wisdom about why broadcast drama is inherently inferior to cable. It presumably faces network censors and meddling executives; it passed through the homogenizing pilot process; it’s produced by committee over a long schedule (with 13 writers credited for this season’s 23 episodes).

headline: From Vandals to Artists: Time Rouses More Appreciation for Graffiti
text: A few minutes before sunrise on Monday, a train left the subway yard in Corona, Queens, where most cars on the No. 7 line spend the night in slumber.

headline: Theft Charges for 4 With Ties to a Provider of Special Ed
text: Four men with ties to one of New York City’s largest providers of preschool special education services were accused on Tuesday of stealing $12.5 million in state and city funds, according to the Queens district attorney.

headline: List of Names in Sex Assaults Roils Columbia
text: The list of names first appeared last Wednesday, each scrawled in a different hand, on the wall of a women’s bathroom in Hamilton Hall, an academic building at Columbia University.

headline: Arrest Made in Fatal Beating of 68-Year-Old
text: The police arrested a 20-year-old man Tuesday in connection with the fatal sidewalk attack of a 68-old-man on Friday, the authorities said.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 13, 2014
‘Fargo’ Recap: Baring Teeth
text: Updated, 4:58 p.m. | Malvo has never sat more squarely in the driver’s seat – quite literally – than in this fifth episode, the midpoint of the FX series “Fargo.” His dark eyes practically drill holes into the rear-view mirror as he unsettles his blackmail victim, Stavros Milos, by spinning tales of wolves whose only mission is to devour whatever stands in their way.

headline: H. R. Giger, Artist Who Gave Life to ‘Alien’ Creature, Dies at 74
text: H. R. Giger, a Swiss painter, sculptor and set designer who mined his own nightmares in creating phantasmagorical works, including the title character — slimy, eyeless and oddly sexual — in the 1979 hit film “Alien,” died on Monday in Zurich. He was 74.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, May 14, 2014
text: “More and more Internet users want a little of the ephemerality and the forgetfulness of pre-digital days.”

headline: Top Court Champions Freedom to Annoy
text: The criminal defense lawyer William Kunstler used to say, “This is New York and there’s no law against being annoying.”

headline: Cleric Spars With Prosecutor at Terror Trial
text: Under a prosecutor’s rigorous cross-examination, the British cleric who has been testifying at his own terrorism trial in Manhattan turned combative and defensive on Tuesday.

headline: Colin Pillinger, Who Set Europe’s Eye on Space, Dies at 70
text: Colin Pillinger, a British planetary scientist who in 2003 led a shoestring effort to put a European lander on Mars for the first time — a mission that failed to reach its destination but succeeded in elevating the profile of space exploration in a region not known for it — died last Wednesday in Cambridge, England. He was 70.

headline: Judith Cummings, Chief of a Bureau for The Times, Dies at 68
text: Judith Cummings, who was the first black woman to head a national news bureau for The New York Times, serving as chief correspondent in Los Angeles from 1985 to 1988, was found dead on May 6 at her home in Detroit. She was 68.

headline: Lorenzo H. Zambrano, Head of Cement Giant Cemex, Dies at 70
text: Lorenzo H. Zambrano, who turned his family-owned cement company, Cemex, into a giant spanning five continents, and who exemplified a generation of Mexican business leaders as they embraced globalization, died on Monday in Madrid. He was 70.

headline: Changes Announced to Puerto Rican Day Parade
text: This year, the National Puerto Rican Day Parade is returning to its roots.

headline: Former Head of Glaxo in China Is Accused of Bribery
text: SHANGHAI — Chinese authorities sent a strong warning to the pharmaceutical industry on Wednesday, implicating a top Western executive at GlaxoSmithKline in a long-running bribery scheme.

headline: How to Arrange Flowers, the Brooklyn Way
text: Given the Brooklynization of the world, it’s no surprise that when the Little Flower School made its way from Brooklyn to London last month, formally trained florists from as far north as Scotland and as far south as Cornwall made the trek to learn how to craft the stunning, free-form arrangements coveted by New York’s creative elite and fashion set. Sarah Ryhanen and Nicolette Owen hosted the two-day immersive workshop to help British florists “break out of the dome” (think: those compact bridal bouquets). An old courtyard filled with 5,000 cut flowers set the scene for Ryhanen’s opening lecture, in which she challenged their 14 pupils to ditch the flower foam, show no fear and let their imaginations run wild with the bucketfuls of foxgloves and peonies before them.

headline: A Fresh Hub for Young Talent at New York Design Week
text: If locals have one complaint about New York Design Week, it’s that the city can seem over-reliant on foreign brands and ho-hum showrooms for content. In 2010, Monica Khemsurov (a T contributor) and Jill Singer of the online magazine Sight Unseen founded the NoHo Design District to counteract that problem with a neighborhood-wide festival of quirky installations, events and pop-ups that ran during Design Week. The duo, known for their knack for identifying new talent, originally looked to create the same neighborhood feel they had experienced when attending other global design weeks in London and Milan. However, by last year, the trials of securing real estate in a booming market had become overwhelming. “In the end, it proved so difficult to find those spaces that we spent 80 percent of our time doing that, and zero percent curating,” says Khemsurov. “The only way for us to evolve was to let go of Noho and become nomadic.”

headline: Easy Blue-and-White Stripes
text: With Memorial Day just around the corner, the promise of prolonged mornings spent luxuriating in pajamas and warm afternoon naps beneath a cool summer breeze is enough to inspire a wardrobe reinvention. And perhaps nothing says summertime more than stripes — but instead of the usual maritime take, we’re looking to swaths of pale and azure blues, in varying widths, contrasted with ample amounts of white. The effect is reminiscent of the parasols that pepper the beaches of the Italian Riviera. With light-as-air fabrics and loungewear-inspired designs, these little patterned numbers are as easy to wear as neutral basics — and will keep you feeling, and looking, cool all season long.

headline: Exercise ‘Snacks’ to Control Blood Sugar
text: Multiple, brief, snack-sized portions of exercise may control blood sugar better than a single, continuous workout, according to new research that adds to a growing body of evidence about the wisdom of spreading exercise throughout the day.

headline: Health Care Workers Under Attack in Syria, Doctors Say
text: Syrian government forces in the country’s civil war have systematically attacked doctors and other medical workers in rebel-held areas and are responsible for 90percent of the confirmed assaults on health care facilities in the country, Physicians for Human Rights, a leading advocacy group, said in a report released on Wednesday.

headline: The Searchers
text: Alice M. Greenwald, the director of the 9/11 Memorial Museum, talks about one of the artifacts that most moves her - a hand rake used by workers who searched ground zero for human remains.

headline: Where the Twin Towers Stood
text: The Sept. 11 memorial and museum’s location at ground zero in Lower Manhattan is one of its most notable features, according to Steven M. Davis, a partner at Davis Brody Bond, the lead architects for the museum. “If you think about the notion of a traditional museum as an icon which contains exhibits, here we have the inverse,” Davis says. “These are exhibits that are in fact the icon.” The museum opens to survivors and victims’ families on May 15; the public can visit starting May 21. In designing the space, which extends 70 feet below the memorial plaza, Davis says he wanted the experience to be physical — visitors enter by descending a ramp, as if drawn by gravity — but also heavy with symbolism and emotion. How does he hope people will feel when they leave? “Optimistic about the future,” he says. “That we have the wherewithal as a society to create positive results from negative events.” Julie Bosman

headline: Times Minute | John Conyer’s Mistake
text: On the Minute, the congressional career of John Conyers Jr. is in jeopardy after a half-century; a former Israeli prime minister is going to prison; and secrets of a stovetop steak.

headline: The Window Into Her Soul
text: Patricia Fagan died in the south tower of the World Trade Center, where she worked. When her bag was found a year and a half later, her sister Eileen donated it to the 9/11 Memorial Museum.

headline: Everyman’s Grief
text: A teddy bear, a flag proclaiming “We will survive,” and a model of the twin towers are among the objects collected from a post-Sept. 11 vigil that are now on display at the 9/11 Memorial Museum.

headline: The Letter That Survived 9/11
text: A letter that fell from a hijacked Sept. 11 aircraft was picked off the street by a fleeing businessman and posted to its rightful destination. It is now in the 9/11 Memorial Museum collection.

headline: Times Minute | John Conyers’s Mistake
text: In the Video

headline: The Keepers of 9/11
text: As the 9/11 Memorial Museum opens, its chief curator and officials at other New York institutions describe how they selected the objects by which future generations will remember Sept. 11, 2001.

text: throttle•\ˈthrä-təl\• noun and verb

headline: 9/11 Artifacts, and the Stories They Tell
text: At the National September 11 Memorial Museum, artifacts help tell the story of the nearly 3,000 people who died that day. A collection of videos looks at a few of those objects.

headline: The National September 11 Memorial Museum
text: The museum sits below the plaza and extends to bedrock.

headline: The 9/11 Story Told at Bedrock, Powerful as a Punch to the Gut
text: After a decade marked by deep grief, partisan rancor, war, financial boondoggles and inundation from Hurricane Sandy, the National September 11 Memorial Museum at ground zero is finally opening ceremonially on Thursday, with President Obama present, and officially to the public next Wednesday. It delivers a gut-punch experience — though if ever a new museum had looked, right along, like a disaster in the making, this one did, beginning with its trifurcated identity.

headline: On a Long Night at Yankee Stadium, the Mets Look Right at Home
text: Time passed slowly at Yankee Stadium on Tuesday night. It was about 11 p.m. when things wrapped up, 3 hours 58 minutes after the first pitch, and the teams packed their belongings for the short trip to Queens, where things may be a little less weird.

headline: Thomas Piketty and His Critics
text: Many on the left see the popularity of Thomas Piketty’s new book, “Capital in the Twenty-First Century,” as a sign of hope, but both optimists and pessimists share a belief more telling than Piketty’s success: the idea that the traditional Democratic economic agenda is dead.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
text: 7:30 A.M. (FX Movie Channel) STANLEY AND LIVINGSTONE (1939) In the first of two African adventures directed by Henry King, Henry Stanley (Spencer Tracy), a reporter for The New York Herald, travels to Zanzibar in search of the long-missing British missionary Dr. David Livingstone (Cedric Hardwicke). Writing in The New York Times, Bosley Crowther called the lavish production — which helped to immortalize the famous greeting “Dr. Livingstone, I presume” — “intelligent and restrained and dignified.” In “The Snows of Kilimanjaro” (1952), at 9:30, adapted from the short story by Ernest Hemingway, an author (Gregory Peck, above with Susan Hayward) seriously wounded in a hunting accident reflects on the love (Ava Gardner) he lost and the novel he never wrote. Mr. King and the producer Darryl Zanuck “have made a picture that constantly fascinates the eye and stimulates the emotions in small, isolated ways,” Mr. Crowther wrote in The Times. He added: “The shots of wild animals in Africa — elephants, lions, rhinoceroses, giraffes and all manner of lesser creatures — are as magnificent and exciting as any yet, and the atmosphere and beauty of a safari under the snowy peak of Kilimanjaro are superb. Especially one sequence in close-up of a swimming herd of hippopotamuses goes down in this reviewer’s notebook as the best one of game we’ve ever seen.”

headline: Anger Grows in Vietnam Over Dispute With China
text: HANOI, Vietnam — Thousands of workers rampaged through an industrial area in southern Vietnam on Tuesday in what reportedly began as protests against China’s stationing of an oil rig in disputed waters off of Vietnam’s coast.  The riots were some of the worst civil unrest in recent years and appear to have prompted  restraints on the local media by Vietnam’s authoritarian government. An article about the protests that was posted online by a Vietnamese state newspaper on Tuesday was removed by Wednesday morning.  The Chinese Embassy in Hanoi issued a notice on Wednesday that urged Chinese living in Vietnam to “minimize unnecessary outings.”  A staff member at the Chutex Garment Factory north of Ho Chi Minh City said 8,000 to 10,000 workers were involved in the rampage at his factory.  “They burned the office,” said the staff member who agreed to speak on condition that his name not be used. The rioters “burned everything, all of the materials, computers, machines.”  Police units and fire fighters arrived at the factory Tuesday and “disbanded,” the rioters, he said. On Wednesday morning police “captured” around 15 to 20 men who were attempting to loot the premises, he said.  The Chutex factory, located in Song Than Industrial Park 2 in southern Binh Duong Province, is described on its web site as one of the largest garment exporters in Vietnam. Chutex International, the parent company, was founded by a Taiwanese garment executive.  It is unclear why rioters targeted a factory linked to Taiwan. Media in Hong Kong said  workers might not have been distinguishing between mainland China and Taiwan, a self-governing island which also has claims to territory in the South China Sea.

headline: Asian Collectors Give Christie’s a High-Yield Night
text: In a nearly three-hour auction of postwar and contemporary art on Tuesday night, Christie’s managed to sell nearly $745 million worth of blue-chip paintings and sculptures, thanks in large part to the enormous wealth of Asian collectors.

headline: The Clippers Lament Miscues and Bemoan a Costly Call
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — Chris Paul leaned against a corridor wall, his hands in the pockets of his leather jacket as if he were feeling around for a morsel of comfort. He stared straight ahead for several minutes.

headline: India Election Digest: May 14
text: What you need to know on Wednesday about India’s elections: People who are familiar with Narendra Modi of the Bharatiya Janata Party offer insights into his character and possible policy moves if he becomes prime minister, and Indian National Congress party leaders say it’s not Rahul Gandhi’s fault if the party has a poor showing Friday, when the votes are counted.

headline: Angry Turks Demand Answers After Mine Disaster
text: SOMA, Turkey — As hopes began to fade for hundreds of coal miners still trapped underground in a hellish explosion, antigovernment protests broke out across the country on Wednesday while victims’ families demanded answers in what is emerging as perhaps the worst industrial accident in the country’s history.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, May 14, 2014
text: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

headline: A New Story Told at Ground Zero
text: A guided tour of the National September 11 Memorial Museum.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Privilege at Princeton
text: In “At Princeton, Privilege Is: (a) Commonplace, (b) Misunderstood or (c) Frowned Upon,” Marc Santora and Gabriel Fisher write about a much-discussed student essay.

headline: Judge Orders Psychiatric Evaluation of Pistorius
text: In a significant turn in a case that has generated drama and delay in equal proportions, the judge in the murder trial of Oscar Pistorius said on Wednesday that the defendant should undergo a psychiatric evaluation to determine whether he was affected by mental illness when he shot and killed his girlfriend, Reeva Steenkamp, on Feb. 14, 2013.

headline: Detroit, From Both Sides of the Coin
text: Photography was a hobby for Bill Rauhauser for much of his life. Born and raised in Detroit, a city that made things, he worked as an architectural engineer and took pictures on the side. That all changed on a business trip to New York City in 1947, when he caught an exhibit by Henri Cartier-Bresson at the Museum of Modern Art. He was amazed by the pictures, and even more so by the words he read in a booklet about the show.

headline: A Spot of Tea Party?
text: After the warm-up speeches, a hush of expectation fell. The Forum in Bath is an Art Deco movie theater now used mostly for concerts and evangelical services, and on the last Tuesday of April, it had the air of a revivalist meeting. In the foyer, they were selling books, button badges and even tea towels, while inside a lively, if middle-aged, audience nearly filled the former cinema.

headline: Pentagon Weighs Transfer of Chelsea Manning to Civilian Facility
text: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia — The United States Defense Department is considering a request from the Army to transfer Private Chelsea Manning, convicted of leaking national security data to WikiLeaks, to a civilian prison so that she can get treatment for her gender disorder, a Pentagon official said Wednesday.

headline: What Are the Most Memorable Works of Visual Art You Have Seen?
text: The 35-foot-tall sugarcoated woman-sphinx pictured above, an installation at the former Domino Sugar compound in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, is by an artist named Kara Walker. Would you want to see this piece if you lived nearby?

headline: Taiwan Concerned Over Mistaken Identity in Vietnam Protests
text: Taiwan has voiced concern over the safety of its citizens doing business in Vietnam after protesters damaged several factories on Tuesday. The businesses based in Taiwan were targeted in an apparent case of mistaken identity by demonstrators angered by mainland China’s placement of an offshore drilling platform in waters claimed by Vietnam.

headline: New York Today: Meet Your Postmaster
text: Good morning on this cool, cloudy Wednesday.

headline: Fresh Signs Point to Possible European Central Bank Stimulus Plan
text: FRANKFURT — Top officials of the European Central Bank sent strong signals on Wednesday that action to stimulate the economy was all but certain next month. But they also made it clear that the bank was unlikely to make a powerful injection of money into the economy.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: Plenty of Words for India’s Fallen but Questions Are Met With Silence
text: In May 1999, Capt. Saurabh Kalia of the Indian Army’s 4 Jat Regiment, an officer from Himachal Pradesh, led a patrol of five soldiers along the heights above Kargil, in Kashmir. They disappeared.

headline: Unable to Afford Surgery, Farmer Amputates His Own Feet
text: For months, Liu Dunhe, a 44-year-old farmer in the southeastern province of Anhui, watched as what had begun as several seemingly innocuous blisters on his feet deteriorated into severe necrosis. By late April, his feet had become so rotten that he had already dug out several maggots from the dead, odorous flesh, according to a report in The Beijing News.

headline: Pimco Weighs on Allianz’s First Quarter as Profit Falls 3.9%
text: LONDON – Troubles at the giant asset manager known as Pimco weighed heavily on the German insurer Allianz in the first quarter, contributing to a 3.9 percent decline in  earnings.

headline: She Has the Look: Finding the Faces for T Magazine
text: Gina Liberto became the senior photo editor for print for T: The New York Times Style Magazine earlier this year. She has been a photo editor with T since November 2012. You can follow her on Instagram.

headline: A Struggling Start-Up Dives Into the ‘Shark Tank’
text: In March 2013, we wrote about Bon Affair, a start-up in San Diego that makes an all-natural bottled wine spritzer. Its founder, Jayla Siciliano, described it as a lower-alcohol, lower-calorie alternative to wine, with electrolytes added to help, perhaps, with hangover symptoms.

headline: Daily Report: Judge Says Airbnb Need Not Surrender Customer Data
text: Airbnb, the popular apartment-sharing service, won a legal standoff Tuesday when a state judge ruled that the company did not have to give up customer records as part of an investigation by the New York State attorney general, Nick Wingfield reports.

headline: Sears Weighs a Sale of All or Part of Sears Canada to Bolster a Turnaround
text: At its height, Sears was the country’s biggest retailer. But that has not been true for more than two decades and now, the department store chain, struggling to execute on its latest turnaround, is looking to shrink again.

headline: How to Turn Renters Into Savers
text: Some people didn’t like my post on housing-as-food, which illustrated how pro-home ownership policies distorted behavior and the economy. The best pro-housing response I’ve seen (from Megan McArdle, among others) was that homeownership encourages families to save.

headline: Democrats Are Unified; G.O.P. Is Unified Only in Opposing Obama
text: Two prominent Republicans have broken with fellow party members on big issues in recent days: Rand Paul said Republicans shouldn't "go too crazy" with stricter voting laws, although he later softened that stance, and Mitt Romney said he favored raising the minimum wage. Similarly, Jeb Bush and Marco Rubio have indicated in recent years that they would be open to reworking the nation’s laws on illegal immigration, a stand that runs counter to the views of most conservatives.

headline: China Targeted by Vietnamese in Fiery Riots
text: BINH DUONG PROVINCE, Vietnam — Dozens of foreign-owned factories near Ho Chi Minh City lay in charred ruins early Thursday after thousands of Vietnamese workers rampaged over China’s latest efforts to control the South China Sea, this time off Vietnam’s coast.

headline: New Music Meets Early Music in Miller Theater Offerings
text: The Miller Theater will continue to emphasize its traditional strengths – new music, early music and provocative combinations of the two – in its 2014-15 season, which opens on Sept. 18 with “Heart and Breath,” a production by the new-music ensemble Eighth Blackbird, in which the musicians play commedia dell’arte roles and perform 17th-century Italian music filtered through 21st-century sensibilities.

headline: Lessons From a Breakup
text: At a time when companies are reaching for ever bigger deals, the breakup of a $35 billion merger between two advertising giants offers some lessons, Steven M. Davidoff writes in the Deal Professor column. The deal between Publicis of France and Omnicom, based in New York, seemed at first to make good sense, creating a company that would become the largest ad agency in a world where bigger may be better for ad buying. But the merger also raised cultural and integration issues.

headline: Three Long Views of Life With Rising Seas
text: After finishing my post on the inevitability of substantial long-term sea-level rise from Antarctic ice loss, I sent this question to Curt Stager, a paleoclimatologist and author of “Deep Future,” Kim Stanley Robinson, the novelist focused on “cli fi” before that term was conceived, and the astrobiologist David Grinspoon:

headline: Another Breezy Hearing for Obama Health Pick
text: WASHINGTON — Sylvia Mathews Burwell, President Obama’s nominee for secretary of health and human services, appeared Wednesday to be on a swift path to confirmation after she sailed through another cordial congressional hearing without promising significant changes in federal health policy or regulations.

headline: Suitable Swimming
text: Shouldn’t a queen have the right to swim wherever and whenever she likes? It ought to be a perk of the job. But in “Queen Victoria’s Bathing Machine,” by Gloria Whelan, with illustrations by Nancy Carpenter, and “Elizabeth, Queen of the Seas,” by Lynne Cox, illustrated by Brian Floca, two very different regents have trouble doing just that.

headline: Casting Set for Bolshoi Performances at Lincoln Center Festival
text: When the Lincoln Center Festival announced its programming early this year, the Bolshoi Opera and Ballet, appearing in New York together for the first time, was clearly one of the major drawing cards. But though the programs were announced: The Bolshoi Opera would present a concert version of “The Tsar’s Bride,” a Rimsky-Korsakov work better known from recordings than from live performances — at least in the West — and the Bolshoi ballet would offer Khachauryan’s “Spartacus,” Tchaikovsky’s “Swan Lake” and Ludwig Minkus’s “Don Quichotte,” casting was a mystery. Even when the ballet company announced the casts for the first part of its American tour, not long after the Lincoln Center announcement, Lincoln Center was mum.

headline: Some Predictions About the Internet of Things and Wearable Tech From Pew Research
text: Remember the prediction that one day your oven would be connected to the Internet and have the ability to talk to your car? In this world, when you left the office, your car would email the oven to say “warm up dinner — we’ll be home soon!”

headline: Number of People Displaced by Violence Highest in 20 Years, Agency Says
text: GENEVA — The crisis in Syria has pushed the number of people displaced from their homes by violence to the highest level in 20 years, the head of the Norwegian Refugee Council said on Wednesday, criticizing the failure of global powers to take timely to prevent conflicts.

headline: Citi Fires 11 More in Mexico Over Fraud
text: Citigroup is moving quickly to try to put a costly fraud at its Mexican business behind it, firing an additional 11 employees, including four high-ranking executives in Mexico.

headline: 5 Things to Consider in Choosing a Camp for a Special-Needs Child
text: “Special needs” is a broad category, including everything from orthopedic appliances and physical-care needs to speech defects, learning disabilities and behavioral deficits. What all of the children within that broad category have in common with respect to summer camp is that signing up isn’t usually just a matter of filling out the forms.

headline: 10 Ideas for a Smoother Road Trip
text: Road trips can be many things — thrilling, purposeful, strange — yet rarely are they glamorous. You can remedy that by renting a fancy car, but if you’re on a budget or plan to drive your own car, there are other ways to hit the road in style. Below are 10 ideas that, while practical, can also add a touch of luxury for the driver, passengers, even the dog.

text: Tim Geithner is not a creature of Wall Street.

text: Nicolette Owen and Sarah Ryhanen of Brooklyn’s Little Flower School share tips on how to create an effortless, whimsical floral arrangement.

headline: Hagel Urges Gulf Arab States, Divided Over Policy, to Unite for Security
text: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia — Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel on Wednesday urged Gulf Arab states to unite against security threats as the United States sought to strengthen its influence in a region that has been splintering over how to deal with democracy protests in Egypt, the uprising in Syria and Iran’s nuclear program.

headline: Today in Small Business: The Psychology of Buying Online
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Bank of England Tempers Expectations of a Rate Increase
text: LONDON — The Bank of England on Wednesday left unchanged its forecasts for growth and inflation in Britain, and indicated that the central bank was getting closer to the point at which it would need to gradually start raising interest rates. Analysts expect the bank to raise its record-low lending rate of 0.5 percent in the first half of next year.

headline: Peer Pressure Can Be a Lifesaver
text: When we hear that someone succumbed to peer pressure or conformed to group expectations, we are inclined to think about it in negative terms. We imagine a young person smoking his first cigarette or an adult parroting the consensus of her community. We know that these social forces can cause people to act in ways that are harmful to themselves and others; but every day we are discovering more ways that they can be harnessed to solve problems in health, education and other areas. This is crucial. For decades, development organizations have spent billions of dollars developing medicines, installing wells, or building clinics or schools that people have not fully used, if they have used them at all.

headline: Pistorius Ordered to Undergo Mental Exam
text: Thokozile Matilda Masipa, the judge in Oscar Pistorius’s murder trial, said Mr. Pistorius should have a psychiatric evaluation for mental illness, and his uncle, Arnold Pistorius, lauded the decision.

headline: Seventy Years Ago Next Month Came Fury and Death on D-Day
text: Here is a rare color photograph from World War II. Taken 70 years ago next month, it reveals American warriors from E Company, Fifth Ranger Battalion, aboard their landing craft on Weymouth Harbor, Dorset, England. They are setting out to fight the Nazis on Omaha Beach on D-Day — June 6, 1944, one of the pivot points of the 20th century. In the foreground, they are, clockwise from far left, First Sergeant Sandy Martin, Technician Fifth Grade Joseph Markovich, Corporal John Loshiavo and Private First Class Frank Lockwood, with their Bazooka, Garand rifle, 60-mm mortar and Lucky Strikes.

headline: Cannes Film Festival: Nicole Kidman Defends ‘Grace'; Harvey Weinstein Skips Premiere
text: CANNES — As the 67th annual Cannes International Film Festival opened here today, Nicole Kidman diplomatically addressed criticism of the opening-night film, “Grace of Monaco,” in which she plays the title role.

headline: House and Senate Don’t Share Campaign Cash, Even When It Makes Sense

headline: New Rowhouses Help Heal a Long-Open Wound in Brooklyn

headline: As Park Service Culls Deer in Washington, It Helps Charities Fill Bellies
text: WASHINGTON — The government sharpshooters worked so efficiently in the dead of the night in Rock Creek Park that by the end of this year’s short killing season, they had shot 106 white-tailed deer.

headline: Republicans Cast de Blasio as a Leading Liberal Foe
text: Jeb Bush, a possible Republican presidential candidate in 2016, offered to help run a campaign to oust him. Bill O’Reilly, the Fox News titan, said he wanted “to beat him up.”

headline: Cannes Film Festival: Jane Campion Accuses Film Industry of ‘Inherent Sexism’
text: CANNES — Strong women were in the spotlight as the 67th edition of the Cannes Film Festival got under way today. While Nicole Kidman defended her film “Grace of Monaco,” Jane Campion, the president of this year’s main competition jury, said she believed that “inherent sexism” was one reason there were so few female film directors.

headline: Macy’s Profit Rises 3%, Despite Declining Sales
text: Macy’s reported a sluggish first quarter on Wednesday, dampening hopes for more positive spring spending news after an exceptionally frigid, difficult winter.

headline: Rand Paul Walks Back the Truth
text: It is always impressive — by which I mean scary — to watch the Republican discipline machine swing into action. It’s amazingly efficient, even when the target is a guy like Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky, who has staked out so many quirky positions that it’s hard to keep track.

headline: Talks on Ukraine Crisis Open in Kiev Without Representation for Separatists
text: KIEV, Ukraine — Senior Ukrainian officials and leading public figures opened talks here on Wednesday that they portrayed as an effort to end the country’s six-month-old political crisis, but the provisional Ukrainian government offered little compromise and there was no one present directly representing the pro-Russian separatists in eastern Ukraine.

headline: AT&T Will Struggle to Justify a Deal for DirecTV
text: AT&T will struggle to justify buying DirecTV for an enterprise value of some $70 billion. Going headlong into the satellite television business requires some heroic assumptions to make the offer financially worthwhile. To cover its cost of capital, for example, AT&T probably would need to wring more than $2 billion of savings from its target. This deal gives off a whiff of desperation.

headline: Social Experiments: Investigating Questions Related to Personality Attributes
text: Overview | What is the definition of personality, and how have scientists studied its attributes in animals? What can we learn about ourselves by studying the science behind personality? In this lesson, students learn about current research on social structure and personality attributes in a type of communal spider, then design their own research questions meant to investigate traits in humans like shyness, boldness or fear of the new.

headline: Jaipur, City of Jewelers
text: Jaipur, the capital of the Indian state of Rajasthan, is one of the world’s most important centers for the cutting and polishing of precious and semiprecious gems.

headline: Philippines Challenges China Over Disputed Atoll
text: HONG KONG — The Philippines said on Wednesday that it had protested signs of land reclamation by China aimed at expanding a disputed coral atoll near the southern Philippines, the latest in a series of disputes pitting China against its neighbors in the South China Sea.

headline: How Student Debt May Be Stunting the Economy
text: Is student loan debt holding back the economy? There’s some new evidence that the answer may indeed be a big “yes.”

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 29
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: China Responds to Riots in Vietnam
text: China’s foreign ministry spokeswoman responded to the anti-China riots in southern Vietnam that damaged scores of foreign-owned factories.

headline: Image of the Day: May 14
text: Transgender people attended the annual temple festival in the village of Koovagam in Tamil Nadu.

headline: Living Colour and Robeson Opera Among Highlights of New Jersey Arts Center Season
text: The New Jersey Performing Arts Center, in Newark, has announced a schedule of more than 100 events for its 2014-15 season. John Schreiber, the center’s president and chief executive, and David Rodriguez, its executive producer, said in a statement that they also expected to add another 60 performances and special events as the season progresses.

headline: How Hobby Lobby International Resolved Its Trademark Dispute
text: Last week, we published a case study on Hobby Lobby International, a Brentwood, Tenn., company that makes and sells remote-controlled products, such as model airplanes and boats, and their accessories. For years, the company has been mistaken for Hobby Lobby Stores, a national art and craft supply chain with more than 600 stores.

headline: Sony Pictures Buys Film Rights to Book on Snowden
text: LOS ANGELES — After a long, slow haul, the film rights to Glenn Greenwald’s book about Edward J. Snowden and his revelations about electronic surveillance by United States security officials have found a home, at Sony Pictures Entertainment.

headline: That Funny Man of 1,000 Faces
text: The title “Just Jim Dale” might seem to foretell something fairly straightforward. And, yes, this new show will feature the titular star alone onstage, supported only by the pianist Mark York. Yet the wide-ranging career of Mr. Dale has been anything but simple. He made his Broadway debut in “Scapino” in 1974, won a Tony for “Barnum” in 1980 and later appeared in the long-running hit “Me and My Girl.” More recently he was in the revival of Athol Fugard’s “Road to Mecca.” But did you know that Mr. Dale also wrote the lyrics for the title song of “Georgy Girl,” which won him an Oscar nomination in 1967?

headline: Preparing a Veteran of D-Day for Its Return to Normandy
text: GENESEO, N.Y. — The plane has no fixed seats, no flight attendants, no in-flight movie and no bathroom. It is not heated, insulated or pressurized. And on its last tour over France, somebody tried to shoot it down.

headline: An Upper West Side Apartment That Says ‘Us’
text: It wasn’t really a need for a larger apartment that drove Maral Usefi and Neal Cimochowski from their 350-square-foot one-bedroom in the West 90s.

headline: London Production of ‘Miss Saigon’ May Come to Broadway
text: The producer Cameron Mackintosh is considering bringing his new London production of “Miss Saigon” to Broadway next year if the reviews are strong in Britain and a suitable theater becomes available in New York, according to two theater executives with knowledge of Mr. Mackintosh’s plans.

headline: Boy Loves His Mother, and His Mother’s Friend
text: Broadway in the 1950s was extraordinarily good to William Inge until it wasn’t. Then it turned merciless.

headline: Putting Drama to Work to Soothe
text: LOS ANGELES — On a recent sweltering day, the actor and writer Daniel Beaty spent six hours at a high school near Watts, showing the students how their pain could turn into poetry. A few hours later, and about 20 miles north, he walked onstage at the Mark Taper Forum to portray the singer Paul Robeson, Robeson’s wife, the Soviet filmmaker Sergei Eisenstein and 40 or so other characters in “The Tallest Tree in the Forest.” After his performance — Mr. Beaty has all the speaking roles in the show, which he also wrote — he met with a couple from Omaha to discuss bringing his youth workshops there. He finally finished his work around midnight.

headline: Looking for the Final Word on Treatment
text: The medical world is awash in new information.

headline: Brand-New Bags
text: Every season has its “It” bag, but there’s something to be said for foregoing the obvious designers in favor of carrying something more discreet. For spring/summer, a host of under-the-radar new labels — from a revamped Parisian import to a locally sourced line out of Portland — offer some of the most striking and contemporary carryalls around.

headline: Times Minute | Turkey’s Mine Disaster
text: A mining disaster in Turkey kills hundreds. Also on the Minute, Ras Baraka is Newark’s new Mayor and an acclaimed Swedish director is found dead.

headline: Times Minute | Turkey’s Mine Disaster
text: In the Video

headline: Will You Visit the National September 11 Memorial Museum?
text: The National September 11 Memorial Museum at ground zero will open to survivors and victims’ families on Thursday and to the public next Wednesday.

headline: Senators Intend to Amend Federal Student Privacy Law
text: In an effort to beef up protections for the personal details about students that schools may share with app developers and other companies, two prominent senators said on Wednesday that they intend to modernize a decades-old federal education privacy law.

headline: Bill Clinton Rebuts Speculation on His Wife’s Health
text: WASHINGTON — Former President Bill Clinton said on Wednesday that Democrats should not run away from the Affordable Care Act in the midterm elections, and — weighing in on a recent topic of interest for the 2016 election — said his wife’s health was just fine, Republican conjecture notwithstanding.

headline: Use Airbnb, Break the Law?
text: A New York state judge issued a smart ruling on Tuesday that cut through the hyperbole clouding a dispute between the New York State attorney general and the apartment sharing company Airbnb.

headline: 2014 Fantasy Football Preseason Player Rankings
text: Jason and Justin Sablich provide player rankings for standard and PPR scoring formats. They will be updated throughout the preseason.

headline: In Italy, the Targa Florio Rally Keeps an Eye on the Past
text: CAMPOFELICE DI ROCCELLA, Italy — It has been a long time since Nino Vaccarella won the Targa Florio. But Vaccarella, a former sports car and Formula One driver who won the Targa Florio in 1965, 1971 and again in 1975, is still venerated as a hero in his native Sicily. In a hamlet in the Madonie region, Collesano, along a route known as the Piccolo Circuito delle Madonie, huge white letters that spell out Nino can still be seen painted on a pair of concrete walls on one turn of the race course.

headline: New Orleans Art Biennial to Return in October
text: Prospect, the biennial exhibition program founded by the curator Dan Cameron in New Orleans in 2008 as a way to respond to Hurricane Katrina, will hold its third iteration in the city starting Oct. 25 with a lineup of major artists including Theaster Gates, Carrie Mae Weems and Andrea Fraser, as well as historical works by Gauguin and Jean-Michel Basquiat, organizers said on Wednesday.

headline: Whitney Museum to Donate Studio to Socrates Sculpture Park
text: As it prepares for a move downtown, the Whitney Museum of American Art will donate its freestanding educational studio to Socrates Sculpture Park in Long Island City, the two organizations are to announce Thursday.

headline: Roadside Poem Combats Pollution — Literally
text: “Poetry makes nothing happen,” Auden once wrote. But then he never got a chance to read “In Praise of Air,” a poem by Simon Armitage just installed on a building along a busy road at the University of Sheffield, England, and billed as the world’s first bit of air-cleansing verse.

headline: Freedom From Fries
text: There is no better, more reliable restaurant dish than steak frites.

headline: A Day in the Life of a Food Stylist
text: What does it take to make one of the magazine’s recipes come to life? Collaboration, good timing and a kit of tools, says Maggie Ruggiero, a freelance food stylist. She regularly works with a team to produce some of the photos seen in the magazine, including this week’s inventive twist on classic steak frites from Sam Sifton.

headline: A Museum Tour With Blackstone’s Hill
text: J. Tomilson Hill, the vice chairman of the Blackstone Group, is known on Wall Street as a veteran deal maker.

headline: Times Ousts Jill Abramson as Executive Editor, Elevating Dean Baquet
text: The New York Times dismissed Jill Abramson as executive editor on Wednesday, replacing her with Dean Baquet, the managing editor, in an abrupt change of leadership.

headline: Wheelies: The New and Improved Batmobile Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Letter From France | A Family Goes to War Over Napoleon’s Nightshirt
text: A stained, V-neck cotton night shirt has set off a heated family battle in France.

headline: Nationwide Theater Listings
text: ARKANSAS

headline: A Note From the Publisher
text: Arthur Ochs Sulzberger Jr., the publisher of The Times, sent the following email to Times employees this afternoon announcing the appointment of Dean Baquet as executive editor.

headline: Bringing Arts to Brooklyn and Bronx Community Gardens
text: Spring is bringing more than new flowers to the community gardens operated by the New York Restoration Project. The nonprofit group, created by Bette Midler in 1995, is collaborating with the Brooklyn Academy of Music and the Bronx Museum of the Arts on a new series, Arts in the Gardens, that will present music, performance art, poetry, dance and film at four gardens in the Bedford-Stuyvesant and Gowanus neighborhoods of Brooklyn and three gardens in the Tremont, Melrose and Highbridge neighborhoods of the South Bronx.

headline: App Smart | Create Your Own Comics
text: Kit Eaton tests out three apps that can help you get started creating your own digital comic book.

headline: The Best Time to Book July 4 Trips
text: July 4 falls on a Friday this year, giving many a three-day holiday and time to travel. To get the best deal on Independence Day airfares in a potentially crowded season, the travel-planning website Hipmunk advises making plans by the end of May.

headline: Transforming Your Photos Into Comic Strips
text: THE way a comic book artist can convey so much emotion, drama and narrative with just a few simple lines has always amazed me. Now, if you want to put a comic strip together and provide your own drama and emotion, there are many mobile apps that can do the basic artwork for you.

headline: East Village Radio to Close, Citing Licensing Costs
text: East Village Radio, a commercial-free Internet radio station broadcasting from a storefront on First Avenue in Manhattan, said on Wednesday that it would be shutting down next week, blaming the high cost of music licenses.

headline: Why Hedge Funds Don’t Worry About Carried Interest Tax Rules
text: Hedge fund managers don’t use the carried interest tax loophole. They need something more exotic.

headline: Labs Are Told to Start Including a Neglected Variable: Females
text: For decades, scientists have embarked on the long journey toward a medical breakthrough by first experimenting on laboratory animals. Mice or rats, pigs or dogs, they were usually male: Researchers avoided using female animals for fear that their reproductive cycles and hormone fluctuations would confound the results of delicately calibrated experiments.

headline: Copyright Licensing Organization Gets New Boss
text: Creative Commons, whose licensing system encourages the sharing of more than 500 million copyrighted works, on Wednesday appointed a veteran of similar open Internet projects to be its new chief executive.

headline: Scene of the Mining Disaster
text: Diagram of the mine near Soma, Turkey, where hundreds of miners died after an explosion ignited a fire that produced noxious fumes.

headline: The Gun Report: May 14, 2014
text: Two weeks ago, we brought you the story of Diren Dede, 17, a German exchange student who was shot to death after entering a neighbor’s garage in Missoula, Mont. On April 27, Markus Kaarma, 29, who’d recently been robbed, opened the garage door to his four-bedroom home and set up a motion sensor and a baby monitor in an effort to entrap burglars. When Dede walked in shortly after midnight, Kaarma opened fire with a shotgun. It was later revealed that the teenager had not stolen anything from the garage.

headline: Federer’s Tuneup for Paris Ends Stunningly Early
text: An improbable stab forehand cut short Roger Federer’s French Open preparations, as 47th-ranked Jérémy Chardy sprinted across the court Wednesday to run him out of the Italian Open in the second round.

headline: Colorado Symphony’s Marijuana Fundraiser Concerts to Proceed in Private
text: The Colorado Symphony’s “Classically Cannabis” fundraisers will go on — a bit more discreetly.

headline: What You Get for ... $4,250,000
text: SEATTLE

headline: St. Mark’s Bookshop in East Village Signs Lease on New Location
text: The imperiled St. Mark’s Bookshop, which has been on life support because of declining sales and rising rent, has gotten a reprieve.

headline: Fashion and Beauty at Cannes
text: Daily highlights from the 67th annual Cannes Film Festival.

headline: Britain Expands Power to Strip Citizenship From Terrorism Suspects
text: LONDON — Britain has passed legislation that allows the government to strip terrorism suspects of their citizenship even if it renders them stateless, taking the country’s already sweeping powers to revoke nationality a step further.

headline: Scene City: Art Blooms in Auction Season
text: Daniel Craig, Steve McQueen and Maja Oeri were honored at MoMA’s annual garden party.

headline: Spades Strike History in Galilee
text: While preparing to dig foundations for a religious retreat near the Sea of Galilee, archaeologists found the vestiges of first-century Magdala, where some believe Jesus and Mary Magdalene once walked.

headline: Readers Respond on Bags, Airfares and Global Entry
text: For the last few hours, I’ve been wincing, nodding, smiling, cringing, chortling and arguing out loud at my computer monitor, which can only mean only one thing: I’m perusing reader comments.

headline: A Melancholy Stroll Through the Past
text: Edgar Oliver has yellowed teeth, hooded eyes and a sagging jaw. If it weren’t for his gentle smile, you might mistake him for that portrait of Dorian Gray. A writer and performer, Mr. Oliver will put you in mind of the macabre. He has a tendency to turn even the most banal event — like drinking a Shirley Temple — into something out of Edgar Allan Poe.

headline: Q & A: Making Steak on the Stovetop
text: The butcher Pat LaFrieda and Julia Moskin of the Dining section discussed cooking steak on the stovetop with you, our readers. (The master recipe for cast-iron steak is here.) Their replies to questions and comments from readers are below.

headline: A Life in the Shadows in the Cold War Mideast
text: The first thing to understand about “The Good Spy,” Kai Bird’s cool and authoritative new biography, is that while it’s about a C.I.A. operative named Ames, it is not about Aldrich Ames, the United States counterintelligence officer and analyst who in 1994 was convicted of spying for the Russians.

headline: Expressing Schubert With the Voice of Bitter Experience
text: Many singers perform Schubert’s death-haunted song cycle, “Winterreise” (“Winter Journey”), whether well or poorly. A select few — like the Austrian baritone Florian Boesch, at Weill Recital Hall on Friday evening and on a new recording from the Onyx label — seem to inhabit the work.

headline: City Boy Turns Outdoorsy
text: Give credit to Steve Buscemi and AOL: “Park Bench” is honestly named. In every episode, Mr. Buscemi sits on a park bench and talks to someone.

headline: Think Seeing Is Believing? You’re Asking to Be Fooled
text: A few other magicians and illusionists have made television shows by using their skills to punk the unsuspecting, but none have worked the gimmick better than Michael Carbonaro does in “The Carbonaro Effect,” which begins on Thursday night on TruTV.

headline: Budget Agenda Plays Second Fiddle at Fiscal Forum
text: WASHINGTON — If anyone needed proof that Washington has exhausted its interest in deficit reduction, and given up seeking some bipartisan grand bargain, it came on Wednesday: At the annual fiscal summit meeting of the antideficit Peter G. Peterson Foundation, where V.I.P.s and reporters once flocked for budget news, the newsmakers’ talk often veered far from the fiscal. The main news was politics.

headline: House Hunting in ... Antwerp, Belgium
text: A FOUR-BEDROOM HOME IN A CONVERTED CHAPEL

headline: Pictures of the Day: Turkey and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Turkey, Afghanistan, Israel and South Africa.

headline: Turkish Prime Minister Jeered After Mine Disaster
text: Last Updated, Friday, 9:12 a.m. | As rescuers battled Wednesday to save the lives of coal miners trapped underground in western Turkey, more than 24 hours after an explosion killed at least 274 at the site, anger at the authorities boiled over during a visit by Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan, who was booed and briefly forced to seek refuge in a shop in the nearby town of Soma.

headline: California’s Thirst Shapes Debate Over Fracking
text: OROVILLE, Calif. — Enemies of fracking have a new argument: drought.

headline: Looking for a Family That Is Looking to Eat More Vegetables
text: Martha Rose Shulman and the Motherlode are looking for a family of guinea pigs — a family that would like to eat healthier and occasionally vegetarian meals, but needs a push to get there.

headline: The Language of Autism: Disease or Difference?
text: I first wrote about my son, Finn, shortly after his autism diagnosis: his limp, bony body, the distracted doctors and the unrelenting paperwork. And, of course, our grief. But it wasn’t writing so much as keening, a scrawled lamentation that I wouldn’t have shared with my friends, much less the public. Then in 2012 a friend asked me to write an essay for Money magazine on the unique financial burden of raising an autistic child. My research revealed two facts: First, special-needs children pose enormous, long-term challenges to all but the wealthiest of parents; second, my wife and I were utterly unprepared to meet those challenges.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: Dylan Records a Sinatra Hit
text: Is Bob Dylan channeling his inner Sinatra? Or is it his inner Rachmaninoff? On Wednesday, Mr. Dylan’s website, bobdylan.com, posted what appears to be the cover of the singer’s forthcoming album, “Shadows in the Night,” as well as a single track – a gently sung cover of “Full Moon and Empty Arms,” in an ensemble dominated by a country-tinged steel guitar part. The song, written in 1945 by Buddy Kaye and Ted Mossman, is based on a theme from the third movement of Rachmaninoff’s Piano Concerto No. 2, and was a hit for Frank Sinatra in 1946.

headline: Gehry Design for Philadelphia Museum of Art to Be Displayed
text: The architect Frank Gehry’s design for a renovation and expansion of the Philadelphia Museum of Art will be unveiled on July 1 in an exhibition at the museum on Benjamin Franklin Parkway.

headline: ‘Now That’s What I Call Music’ Ends ‘Frozen’ Soundtrack’s No. 1 Run
text: After spending two straight months at the top of Billboard’s album chart, Disney’s “Frozen” soundtrack has finally been bumped from No. 1. The new champion: the 50th volume of “Now That’s What I Call Music!,” a compilation series that has been coming out in the United States like clockwork — and regularly scoring high on the charts — for 16 years.

headline: What We’re Reading Now
text: I suppose we count this as progress: A Florida elementary school has agreed to stop its longstanding policy of giving kids Mountain Dew as brain fuel before the state’s most important standardized test.

headline: Skin Deep: Bold Liners for Bright Eyes
text: Spring looks beg for more color in makeup: Here’s how to handle it.

headline: Good to Be Alive Again, but What’s This Body?
text: When an underinsured office temp from Staten Island and her entitled billionaire boss die in an elevator accident in “Under My Skin,” the new body-swapping comedy at the Little Shubert Theater, an angel from Eternal Affairs restores them to life, each in the other’s physique.

headline: Selecting USA-1 Bridge Team for the Next Bermuda Bowl
text: The trial to select the USA-1 team for next year’s Bermuda Bowl world championship in India continues through Sunday in Phoenix. Sixteen teams entered. The bottom 13 seeds played a two-day round robin to eliminate two teams.

headline: Fleeting Game Says Investing Is Rigged
text: Not long ago, committing to a video game was a costly decision, made deliberately. Largely because of the price, you were going to play only a few games a year, and you were going to spend scores of hours with each one. It was as if Netflix were charging $60 every time you wanted to start bingeing on a TV series.

headline: A Haunting History Lesson With Your Hip-Hop
text: Conundrum, provocation, history lesson, ritual, chamber recital, jazz concert, elegy — the Roots’ performance at the Public Theater on Tuesday night was decidedly not a standard kickoff for a hip-hop album. That was clear when, near the beginning of the show, balloon animals were dropped onto the stage, covering it knee-deep; for the rest of the performance, each entrance and exit was accompanied by balloons popping underfoot like gunshots. Dozens of nooses also hung overhead.

headline: R.V. Life: Getting Kicks at Age 66
text: Jim and Jaylene Myers knew exactly what they wanted to do when they retired in 2008: Go wherever whim and chance might take them in their 45-foot recreational vehicle.

headline: Classics That Throw Time Out the Window
text: It’s an auspicious time at New York City Ballet, with new choreographic voices multiplying. Along with Justin Peck’s well-received premiere last week came the announcement that he and two other young choreographers — the corps member Troy Schumacher and the Royal Ballet’s Liam Scarlett — will create new pieces for the company next season (a first for Mr. Schumacher).

headline: Philharmonic Transformation, From Members to Mission
text: The New York Philharmonic is playing musical chairs in reverse these days, as retirements and a couple of unexpected departures have left it with more seats than players — and the most turnover of principal players, or section leaders, since World War II.

headline: A Funny Name, a Serious Sport. Pickleball, Anyone?
text: GAINESVILLE, Va. — MAYBE it was the whimsical name — pickleball — that got baby boomers to try the game. A hybrid of racket and paddle sports, it was not notably new. Pickleball began on Bainbridge Island, Wash., where legend has it that Pickles, the resident cocker spaniel, would chase the errant ball. It was Pickles’s ball, thus the name.

headline: When Singing the Blues Is a Performer’s Pleasure
text: The singer Carole J. Bufford’s love affair with the blues began when she was 13 years old and discovered Bessie Smith on a two-disc set, she recalled last Thursday at the Metropolitan Room. She has immersed herself in the genre ever since. And this supremely confident performer has brought her accumulated know-how to her new show, “Shades of Blue.”

headline: The Searing Blues of the 9/11 Sky
text: Like many people who were in any proximity to the events of Sept. 11, the artist Spencer Finch often thought later about the color of the sky that day, the kind of crystalline blue that pilots and meteorologists call “severe clear.”

headline: Birds Aren’t the Only Music Amid Nature
text: CALIFORNIA

headline: Family and Church Feud Over an Eakins
text: The family of Msgr. Patrick J. Garvey, a Catholic priest who was once friendly with the realist painter Thomas Eakins, is trying to block the Archdiocese of Philadelphia from selling a valuable Eakins portrait of the monsignor through the auction house Christie’s.

headline: Advocating Pill, U.S. Signals Shift to Prevent AIDS
text: Federal health officials recommended Wednesday that hundreds of thousands of Americans at risk for AIDS take a daily pill that has been shown to prevent infection with the virus that causes it.

headline: For Eyes, It’s the Year of Color
text: A wardrobe update for spring can start at the beauty counter, where this season both candied brights and matte pastels are sprinkled like sundae toppings. Though a rosy lip is still the hardy perennial, eyes have a new focus.

headline: A Country Lament Sinks Into Despair
text: Sturgill Simpson is a top-notch miserablist, from the lyrics that pick at scabs to his defeated vocal tone, leaky even when he’s singing at full power. His second album, “Metamodern Sounds in Country Music” (High Top Mountain), is a triumph of exhaustion, one of the most jolting country albums in recent memory, and one that achieves majesty with just the barest of parts.

headline: Ask Well: New Truvada Recommendations
text: Do you have a question about Truvada? Or the new recommendation that all Americans at high risk for H.I.V. take this drug? Ask Well. Your question may be answered by our reporter, Donald G. McNeil, Jr.

headline: Colorful Pairings From Many Nations
text: CALIFORNIA

headline: Museum Interpreters Breathing Life Into History
text: FOR 62-year-old Kent Brinkley, one day at work is pretty much like the next.

headline: Turns and Romance, Lifts and Commitment
text: With its myriad acrobatic feats — one-arm lifts! dizzying fouetté turns! — “Don Quixote” could trade its setting from a theater to a circus tent without skipping a beat. On Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, American Ballet Theater began its spring season with the company’s well-worn 1995 version, a giddy fireworks display staged by Kevin McKenzie and Susan Jones.

headline: Art Matters | Highlights from a Frieze Week of Art and Revelry
text: The third edition of Frieze New York cemented the second week in May as the highlight of the city’s art calendar. The festivities’ official start date is fuzzy, but if social media is any indication, it might have been Tuesday at the heavily Instagrammed unveiling of the colossal sugar sphinx by Kara Walker at the Domino Sugar Factory in Williamsburg, where Creative Time, the public art organization that commissioned the work, held its annual gala.

headline: Glowsticks, Banjos, Food Trucks for Miles
text: CALIFORNIA

headline: Terms of Employment for Catholic School Teachers
text: To the Editor:

headline: In MoMA’s Garden, a Gala for Patrons
text: On Tuesday night, as the spring art auctions were underway, the Museum of Modern Art held its annual garden party for art patrons who are not necessarily in the market for a $41 million Warhol.

headline: Climate Change: Prophets and Deniers
Chiara de Blasio’s Journey
text: To the Editor:

headline: Speakers on Campus
text: To the Editor:

headline: Organizing Your Photos, Cloud-Free
text: About a week ago, I installed a small device in my home office that has been working to collect and catalog just about every photograph and video I’ve ever captured with a digital camera.
