headline: Q & A: Leta Hong Fincher on ‘Leftover Women’
text: After the 1949 Communist revolution, Mao Zedong declared that “Women hold up half the sky.” It was a phrase that caught the imagination in China and the world. Yet as socialism has crumbled and a Leninist state, married with elements of a market economy, steers the country, women’s position is slipping, as Leta Hong Fincher examines in her new book, “Leftover Women: The Resurgence of Gender Inequality in China.”

headline: Sotomayor and Race
text: To the Editor:

headline: The New York State Independence Party
Get to 100 and Life Actually Doesn’t Feel so Bad
text: MANY studies of very old people seem to boil down to this: trying to figure out what they ate, drank and did, so that other people can try to live that long, too. Daniela S. Jopp, an assistant psychology professor at Fordham University, is more interested in how people actually feel once they approach 100.

headline: Video Message From Jailed Egyptian Journalist
text: Al Jazeera released a brief video message on Wednesday from its detained West Africa correspondent, Abdullah Elshamy, recorded on the 106th day of his hunger strike in an Egyptian jail.

headline: It’s Now the Canadian Dream
text: It was in 1931 that the historian James Truslow Adams coined the phrase “the American dream.”

headline: For a Day, a Reprieve From the New York Art Circuit
text: “Frieze week is a nightmare,” the artist Nate Lowman said. “To have the same limp handshake 400 times? I don’t go to anything except this.”

headline: Still Tinkering
text: Twenty years have passed since Justice Harry A. Blackmun, at age 85 and just months away from retirement, renounced the death penalty. “From this day forward, I no longer shall tinker with the machinery of death,” he declared.

headline: After Prison, No After-Hours
text: At 10:50 a.m. on Monday of last week, outside the Mid-State Correctional Facility in Marcy, N.Y., which looked like an Ivy League school ringed in concertina wire, Michael Alig emerged from a white prison van.

headline: Street Style in Minneapolis
text: In the Uptown section of Minneapolis, young professionals enjoy happy hour, motorcycle gangs hang out at sober coffee shops and true “uptowners” cling to the past with their punky aesthetic. Qais Munhazim, 29, moved there from Afghanistan five years ago to study political science. Wearing a leather jacket, slim-fit pants and combat boots, he said he pays attention to the cut of his clothes. This interview has been edited and condensed.

headline: What Hedge Funds Talk About When They Talk About Money
text: LAS VEGAS — Behind the dancing fountains of the Bellagio Hotel, hedge fund titans mingled with wealth managers at the Hyde nightclub on Tuesday night.

headline: Volunteers Provide Backup to the Uniformed Ranks
text: DELRAY BEACH, Fla. — BERNARD ZARETSKY, 82, co-coordinator of the Delray Beach Police Department’s Volunteer Program, devotes about 100 hours a month to preventing discord in the resort community, but his duties have the added benefit of keeping the peace in his nearly 60-year-long marriage.

headline: Eyeing the Prize
text: In late February, on the second night of Paris Fashion Week, the corporate fashion giant LVMH hosted a cocktail party at its Paris headquarters on Avenue Montaigne to celebrate the LVMH Prize, a new award for young fashion designers. Over flutes of Champagne, fashion world notables like Karl Lagerfeld, Nicolas Ghesquière, Raf Simons, Anna Wintour and a recent Vogue cover subject, Kanye West, were stalking the atrium-turned-designer-showroom. The 30 semifinalists for the award were tucked away in jam-packed booths, accompanied by a rack of clothes, a model or two and a slight sheen of sweat.

headline: Off-Kilter, Off the Racks
text: The current middleweight champion of bombast in Milan is a young designer named Massimo Giorgetti, who founded his label, MSGM, in 2009 on a few key principles: color, youth and energy. His bright, lavishly printed sweatshirts, T-shirts and dresses went wide fast. Label recognition is still on the rise (the mouthful name, the initials of the four founding partners, may not help), but the collection is available in some 500 stores worldwide, including Bergdorf Goodman and Kirna Zabête in New York.

headline: Autodesk Unveils Open-Source 3-D Printing System
text: Autodesk is hoping to kick-start three-dimensional printing in much the same way Google spurred smartphone development, with a free operating system.

headline: High Society, Mutually Admired
text: Slim Aarons’s palmy photographs of celebrities, moguls and society molls could be taken for a rarefied exercise in social anthropology, if he weren’t so deferential to the people he portrayed.

headline: A Swirl of Duality and Dueling Identities
text: You had to watch where you stepped as you entered Zoe/Juniper’s “BeginAgain Installed.” A thick layer of soil covered the floor of the cryptlike space at 3LD Art & Technology Center. Planted in the middle, sprouting out from one wall, was what looked like a massive glass chamber, a sort of triangular aquarium whose walls turned out to be both reflective and transparent. The floor inside was bare, more pristine than its outskirts. The audience sat on either side of this structure, two groups facing each other, just one of many mirror images that appeared over the next hour.

headline: The Trade-Offs of Relocating North to Canada
text: IT’S a nearby country where most natives speak English and there are few major cultural differences from the United States. Yet the number of Americans choosing to head north to retire in Canada has remained low — reaching a high of 1,675 in 2008 (for immigrants older than 49), then dipping to 1,060 in 2011, and rising again in 2013 to an estimated 1,565.

headline: Obama to Attend Investment Banker’s Fund-Raiser
text: President Obama has a rendezvous with Wall Street.

headline: Reaction From Turkey on Mine Collapse
text: The Turkish prime minister, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, discussed the rising death toll in the mining disaster as more bodies were pulled from the rubble.

headline: Laid-Back Summer Fashions
text: In a recent article on Phoebe Philo and the mythology of Céline, the “uniform” of the trendsetting label was characterized this way: large, slouchy trousers; a collarless shirt; flats; a tuxedo jacket. And that collarless shirt — modern, minimal — looks sharper than ever, a perfectly cut everyday top to match with tailored pieces and laid-back weekend wear. The stylist Marina Muñoz had the right idea, effortlessly pairing her oversize tunic-like top with black trousers. Wear the longer styles with boyfriend jeans and loafers, the cropped versions with high-waist skirts and printed pants. And any of them, of course, the Céline way.

headline: Muslim Weavers of Varanasi
text: Haji Mohammed Shamin of the Muslim weaving community on why he was not voting for Narendra Modi of the Bharatiya Janata Party.

headline: Boatman of the Ganges
text: Shyamlal Eshad was born and raised on the banks of the holy river. He sings about the river’s decline and what’s needed to purify and conserve it.

headline: A Day in Varanasi
text: Hindu pilgrims purify their bodies and souls and worship the goddess of the river at night.

headline: Italian Glass, for Your Bidding
text: One of the most comprehensive collections of 20th-century Italian glass is on view in New York just as it is being dispersed. As a preview for a sale next Tuesday in Chicago, Wright auction house has packed its Manhattan showroom at 980 Madison Avenue with glass vessels and sculptures consigned by the photo stylist and art director Dimitri Levas. He’s been acquiring them since the ’70s, focusing on celebrated makers and designers like Venini, A.V.E.M., Gio Ponti and Carlo Scarpa. Many are from the foresighted store Fifty/50. A few belonged to Robert Mapplethorpe, Mr. Levas’s former collaborator. A 1920s globular blue vase by Napoleone Martinuzzi is estimated at $20,000 to $30,000; an Ercole Barovier mosaic cylinder from the same decade, $25,000 to $35,000. Information: 212-585-0200 or wright20.com.

headline: Reaching Back for Its Design Cred
text: Umbra is going back to its roots. This Toronto-based company, which started 34 years ago selling chic window shades to small, independent design stores, has grown into a $130 million global business. But Les Mandelbaum, Umbra’s chief executive, keenly missed its design cred. “You get rich, but you lose your soul,” he said. So Mr. Mandelbaum and the company’s design director, Matt Carr, came up with Shift, a brand of goods being introduced this weekend at the International Contemporary Furniture Fair in New York that are jaunty, relatively affordable and in many cases handmade. The new line includes whimsical works like Philippe Malouin’s wood folding chair with a built-in hanger ($250 each), Harry Allen’s Coiled stool with a thread-wrapped rattan tractor seat ($250) and Paul Loebach’s Cup lamp, a combination desk lamp and pencil caddy ($180). “These are all things we actually want to take home,” Mr. Carr said. Information: 800-387-5122 or umbrashift.com.

headline: She Says ‘God Bless You’
text: If you’re like me, the majority of your spring is spent red-eyed, runny-nosed and violently sneezing. For those seeking allergy relief indoors, the Blueair Sense ($479), a sleek air purifier, promises to eliminate 99.97 percent of airborne irritants like dust, smoke and pollen.

headline: Open Cover; Insert Brilliance
text: Tucker Nichols wanted to be a jotter of ideas, a scribbler of sketches. Part of the Moleskine mafia. But no notebook seemed right. He always ended up with half-filled pages and a vague dissatisfaction. Was it the notebooks? Was it him?

headline: Sales at Luceplan, Ankasa, Haus and Alessi
text: During Luceplan’s moving sale, through Tuesday, all lighting on display is up to 70 percent off (the Mix table lamp, by Paolo Rizzatto and Alberto Meda, originally $550, is $165); 49 Greene Street (Grand Street), 212-966-1399.

headline: Desk Clocks: Faces of Another Era
text: Even in the age of the smartphone, there’s value in a traditional desk clock. True, it’s no longer necessary from a functional standpoint, but as Gideon Mendelson pointed out, that’s not the only reason to have a clock.

headline: Holleywood Ending
text: For years, Helen Klein Ross, a novelist and poet, and her husband, Donald K. Ross, a lawyer, lived on the Upper West Side with their two daughters and were content to spend weekends in an 1810 clapboard farmhouse in Amenia, N.Y. But that was before they were seduced by Holleywood.

headline: You’re Planting That Old Thing?
text: The Catalpa Tree Appreciation Society needs fresh blood. There are no meetings to attend and no dues to pay. All you have to do is appreciate the catalpa tree. Maybe plant one in the yard.

headline: Lifting From Others the Burden of Your Own Death
text: AS you journey toward your end, “dreading and hoping all,” to quote Yeats, there is a lot to ponder.

headline: With Power Comes Ambivalence
text: LIVINGSTON, N.Y. — It took Andrea Tranchita and her husband, Paul, a few decades to fully build out their pine-and-spruce-planked handmade house here. For the first six months, the couple and their two young daughters lived in a tent on the 10 acres of farmland that Ms. Tranchita’s parents gave them as a wedding present in 1970. But now Ms. Tranchita, 63, a third-generation farmer who grows lavender and herbs and raises sheep, alpaca, llamas and Angora rabbits on this patch of land, is worried about her ability to continue to maintain it.

headline: Tangled Identities and Allegiances in Ukraine
text: Alexander Chekmenev’s national and ethnic identities have whipsawed since the collapse of the Soviet Union and right through the current crisis.

headline: The AIDS-Shaming of Magic Johnson
text: The sheer volume of bile spewing from the mouth of the Clippers owner, Donald Sterling, is staggering. But just as awe-inducing, and stomach-churning, is the unrestrained breadth of its variety, which makes putting the offenses in order — if one were inclined to — nearly impossible.

headline: Store Openings and Fashion Events Starting the Week of May 15
text: Openings

headline: The Looks That Go Straight to Their Heads
text: Last week, as designers and their famous muses walked the red carpet at the Metropolitan Museum of Art for the gala opening of the Charles James fashion exhibition, it wasn’t only the parade of elaborate gowns that captured the attention of Twitter, Instagram and dozens of fashion blogs.

headline: Frequent Matchup Yields Familiar Outcome: Montreal Moves On
text: BOSTON — There is so much history between the teams that to term it a rivalry would be an injustice. But history has mostly sided with the Montreal Canadiens, which may have made the Boston Bruins’ fans uneasy even this year, when their team was the better regular-season squad by far.

headline: Social Security at 62? Let’s Run the Numbers
text: FOR many retirees, Social Security benefits are seen as hot money on the table, to be devoured as soon as possible. But as with preparing and savoring a fine meal, a careful approach and delayed gratification may yield the highest rewards from the program.

headline: The Truth About Sparrows
text: Ever since my mother joined the North American Bluebird Society, or NABS, she’s had it out for the English house sparrow — a bird that, when it isn’t devouring butterflies and yellow flowers, is pecking out the brains of bluebird mothers, dumping their lifeless bodies in the grass and then throwing their children out to die.

headline: Playing Catch-Up While Retirement Remains Far Off
text: SO you’re hurtling toward middle age but haven’t started saving for retirement.

headline: Steve Kerr Will Coach Warriors, Spurning the Knicks
text: Steve Kerr stunned the Knicks on Wednesday by agreeing to a deal to become the coach of the Golden State Warriors.

headline: Mirror, Mirror in the App: What’s the Fairest Shade and Shadow of Them All?
text: As any lipstick shopper knows, deciding between tropical coral, peony pink and fairest nude is not a straightforward choice.

headline: With Master Limited Partnerships, Get a Piece of the Pipeline
text: Everything’s coming up roses for the American energy industry. Well, maybe not actual flowers, but the final product is still quite fragrant and valuable.

headline: Don’t Force Google to ‘Forget’
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — THE European Court of Justice ruled on Tuesday that Europeans have a limited “right to be forgotten” by search engines like Google. According to the ruling, an individual can compel Google to remove certain reputation-harming search results that are generated by Googling the individual’s name. The court is trying to address an important problem — namely, the Internet’s ability to preserve indefinitely all its information about you, no matter how unfortunate or misleading — but it has devised a poor solution.

headline: Ganges River: Revered, Soiled and Symbol of an Indian Election Campaign
text: VARANASI, India — For centuries, Hindus have brought their dead to banks of the Ganges River in this ancient city, with the promise that if their bodies are burned on the riverfront, their souls will escape the constant cycle of rebirth and attain moksha, or salvation. Transporting their souls is the goddess of the river, whose ebbs and flows have run through thousands of years of civilization.

headline: The Kidnapping of a Country
text: CHIBOK, Nigeria — THE road to Chibok is eerily quiet, lined with checkpoints manned by civilians, many of them teenagers, wielding rusty rifles and serving as added security for an area that has little. In this northeast Nigerian village, where more than 300 teenage schoolgirls were kidnapped by the militant Islamist separatist group Boko Haram on April 14, their stunned families were still waiting this week for them to come home.

headline: Editor of Le Monde Resigns Amid Discord
text: PARIS — Faced with a newsroom revolt, the editor in chief of Le Monde, France’s most prominent newspaper, stepped down on Wednesday after a 14-month tenure marked by staff resistance to her efforts to push the paper faster and more fully into the digital era.

headline: William Bender, Time Editor and Music Critic, Is Dead at 83
text: William Bender, a critic and editor for Time magazine who covered the gamut of America’s musical scene in the late 1960s and ’70s, from Leonard Bernstein to David Bowie, died on May 4 in Olathe, Kan. He was 83.

headline: At Upfronts, CBS Breaks Up Comedy Block
text: AS the 2014-15 television upfronts draw to a close, Madison Avenue is scrutinizing the decisions that top executives are making as they draw up schedules for the coming season. Those strategies stood in sharp contrast at the presentations made on Wednesday by a leading broadcaster and two large cable channels.

headline: Tales of Escapees in Nigeria Add to Worries About Other Kidnapped Girls
text: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria — Among the lucky ones, there are pensive smiles but not much laughter.

headline: South Sudan Cease-Fire Proves to Be Short-Lived
text: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia — An agreement for a cease-fire in South Sudan that was signed Friday barely made it into the new week before violence resumed in the seething conflict that has already left thousands dead and displaced more than 1.3 million people.

headline: Out for a Run, and Seeking Some Music
text: IF you like to exercise outdoors, you are probably exposing your headphones to sun, wind, rain and sweat. Fortunately, over the years, headphone makers have built plenty of durable options.

headline: Beloved Rivals Endure on Ice and in the Office
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Emergent from the shadow of Wayne Gretzky, two gregarious goal-scorers have been adored as fixtures of the hockey landscape in Southern California for the better part of two decades. Luc Robitaille, 48, now an executive with the Los Angeles Kings, finds himself in the playoffs facing his old friend Teemu Selanne, 43, who still plays right wing for the Anaheim Ducks.

headline: My State’s Prettier Than Yours
text: Our topic for today is state tourism slogans. Perhaps that’s not what you had in mind. Perhaps you are from North Dakota (“Legendary”) or North Carolina (“Beauty Amplified”) and are already so self-satisfied you see no reason to worry about the subject at all.

headline: The Age Premium: Retaining Older Workers
text: At a time when digital skills are prized and businesses place a premium on youth, some employers subtly seek to push out older workers. They deny them raises once awarded routinely, reduce their responsibilities or give evaluations that are cold and complain of waning productivity.

headline: Fast Food Protests Spread Overseas
text: Even though fast food workers have staged several one-day strikes in the last 18 months, the protests have not swayed McDonald’s or other major restaurant chains to significantly raise their employees’ pay.

headline: One Court Ruling on Privacy in Europe, and 28 Regulators
text: LONDON — The ruling on Tuesday by Europe’s highest court that Google can be forced to remove links from certain searches will be carried out by data privacy regulators at 28 different agencies across the European Union.

headline: Forward Has Goals Aplenty but Ground to Make Up
text: PALO ALTO, Calif. — No American in the four years since soccer’s last World Cup has scored more goals in competition than Chris Wondolowski. Few of the other 29 players on the United States men’s national team’s provisional roster can match his story, either, partly because no others have scored three goals in an international game with their names misspelled on the back of their jerseys.

headline: He Lost 3 Years and a Child, but Got No Apology
text: How do you reel back lost years? How do you reconstruct a life turned to dust and rubble? How do you retrieve a love so precious that the mention of it causes your eyes to well?

headline: Women of the Senate Band Together Over Missing Nigerian Girls
text: WASHINGTON — All 20 female senators find themselves in fierce bipartisan agreement on at least one topic.

headline: U.S. Projects Tough Stance to Both Sides of Syria War
text: With Syria peace prospects in a basic state of collapse, the United States sought to project a toughened posture on Wednesday, conducting military exercises with neighboring Jordan and designating two leaders of Syrian jihadist groups as “global terrorists” — a warning that they should be ostracized by other members of the Western-backed insurgency fighting President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: Nitpicking a Lousy Policy
text: Should students with head lice stay in school or get sent home?

headline: A Study on Prostate Cancer Relapses Suggests That Hormone Therapy Can Wait
text: Many men with an early sign of a prostate cancer relapse can safely wait before starting hormone therapy, avoiding side effects without shortening their lives, according to the results of a study released on Wednesday.

headline: No Slowdown in Unfair Marijuana Arrests
text: When Mayor Bill de Blasio took office in January, community groups and juvenile justice advocates hoped that his administration would significantly decrease the numbers of black and Latino young people who are unfairly — and in some cases, illegally — arrested and dragged through the court system for possession of tiny amounts of marijuana. But a new analysis of state arrest data by a nonprofit called the Marijuana Arrest Research Project, which studies police policy, suggests that the de Blasio administration is on track to equal the more than 28,600 low-level marijuana arrests that were made under Michael Bloomberg in 2013. The administration needs to review Police Department policy to make sure these arrests are necessary and being fairly made.

headline: Keeping the Wireless Business Competitive
text: For most of its history, the telecommunications industry has been dominated by a handful of large companies. The cost of laying wires, setting up antennas, signing up customers and getting government licenses makes it hard for new players to get into a business dominated by former monopolies with deep pockets.

headline: Baby’s First Tweet
text: Some parents are creating accounts for their babies on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and other services, long before those children are able to add posts themselves.

headline: In a Democrat’s Efforts on Iraq, a Parallel for Boehner on Immigration
text: WASHINGTON — Shortly before the 2002 midterm elections, Richard A. Gephardt, who was then the House minority leader, infuriated his fellow Democrats when he announced he would help President George W. Bush win authorization for the Iraq war.

headline: Derby Victor a Heavy, and Heavier, Preakness Favorite
text: BALTIMORE — He is the Big Horse, California Chrome. He is the inhabitant of Stall 40 in the stakes barn here at Pimlico Race Course, the stall reserved for the Kentucky Derby winner. He is the 3-5 morning line favorite to win the 139th running of the Preakness Stakes on Saturday.

headline: Discrimination in the Military
text: Three years after the demise of “don’t ask, don’t tell,” an estimated 15,000 members of the military still must lie about themselves in order to go on risking their lives for their country. When Congress eliminated the law against gay men and lesbians serving openly in the military, the Pentagon left in place an equally unfounded prohibition on transgender people.

headline: How Young Is Too Young for a Digital Presence?
text: HEY, new parents. I’m sure you are swamped with this whole feeding, changing, trying to sleep, trying to sleep-train, child-proofing and searching-for-child-care rigmarole. But have you started planning your child’s online presence?

headline: Britain: Former Editor Testifies on Hacking of Royals
text: The long-running trial of the former tabloid editors Rebekah Brooks and Andy Coulson heard testimony on Wednesday that The News of the World had hacked the cellphones of the royal family and its closest associates. Clive Goodman, former royalty editor of the newspaper, which is now defunct, said that before his arrest and conviction for illegal eavesdropping in 2006 he listened to the voice mails of the former Kate Middleton 155 times, of Prince William 35 times and of Prince Harry nine times. Prince William is in line to become king, and Ms. Middleton, now his wife, was then his girlfriend. Mr. Goodman is charged with conspiring to pay officials for royal phone directories, and he said he had not previously disclosed his hacking of royal telephones because the police had never asked him. Earlier in the trial he testified that he had hacked only aides working for the royals, and he has been promised by the prosecution that he will not be further charged for hacking.

headline: Judge Blocks Motion to Defend Oregon Gay Marriage Ban
text: SEATTLE — Oregon’s ban on same-sex marriage, which is under legal challenge, must face its fate alone, to survive or be struck down without anyone defending it in court, a federal judge ruled on Wednesday.

headline: Panel Questions Experts on Closed Reactor Risks
text: WASHINGTON — A Senate committee on Wednesday questioned a panel of specialists about the safety and security of nuclear reactors that have been retired or forced out of business.

headline: France’s Sale of 2 Ships to Russians Is Ill-Advised, U.S. Warns
text: WASHINGTON — In a closed-door meeting in February 2010, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates urged his French counterpart not to proceed with the sale of two amphibious assault ships to Russia because it “would send the wrong message to Russia and to our allies in Central and East Europe.”

headline: Sabathia’s Knee Has a Degenerative Injury
text: C. C. Sabathia has a degenerative condition in the cartilage in his right knee, Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman said, casting more doubt on when Sabathia will be able to return to the team and how much the condition could hamper him.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 14, 2014
Veterans Affairs Secretary to Face Senate Questions on Delayed Care
text: WASHINGTON — For many years, the Department of Veterans Affairs has been criticized for requiring veterans to wait long periods for medical appointments, and for having no foolproof system for holding hospital administrators accountable for those delays. So last year, the department took a fateful step intended to strengthen its oversight of part of the system: It established a goal for new patients seeking primary care to be seen within 14 days of calling for an appointment, with the date of that request logged into a computer file so that it could be tracked.

headline: Aging Bridge Behind Him, Obama Pushes Infrastructure Projects
text: TARRYTOWN, N.Y. — President Obama came to this Westchester County village on Wednesday to use the three-mile-long Tappan Zee Bridge as a backdrop to pressure Republicans in Congress to support infrastructure spending.

headline: Prominent Hollywood Group Opposes F.C.C. Action on Net Neutrality
text: LOS ANGELES — The Caucus for Producers, Writers and Directors, a small but prestigious association of those who create television and new media programs, has staked out a position in the “net neutrality” debate. And it has done so not with a direct objection to proposed new rules that would allow Internet providers to create a so-called fast lane for companies like Netflix that are willing to pay for it, but with a blast at the Federal Communications Commission for the “dictatorial” manner in which it is proposing to alter the Web.

headline: A Yankee Gets a Leg Up by Dropping One Low
text: Masahiro Tanaka introduced himself to the Mets on Wednesday with a captivating four-hit shutout in a 4-0 Yankees victory. Ron Darling, a former Mets pitcher and an SNY broadcaster, had seen something like it before.

headline: Phone Company Pushed Back Against N.S.A.’s Data Collection, Court Papers Show
text: WASHINGTON — In 2009 and early 2010, a telephone company raised questions about the legality of the then-secret National Security Agency program that is systematically collecting records of Americans’ calling habits, according to court documents declassified on Wednesday.

headline: Soaring Earnings of Chipotle’s 2 Bosses Raise Investor Unease
text: In an era of what many perceive as outsize executive compensation, it’s not unusual for a successful public company to lavish its chief executive with a multimillion-dollar pay package. But what happens when there are two chiefs?

headline: The Preakness Draw
text: Post positions for Saturday’s 139th running of the Preakness Stakes.

headline: Lawyer for Ex-Christie Aide Seeks Corrections to Lane Closing Report
text: The lawyer for a former top aide to Gov. Chris Christie issued a scathing statement on Wednesday rebutting assertions in an internal report on the George Washington Bridge lane-closing scandal, as well as the testimony of Mr. Christie’s spokesman before a legislative committee investigating the matter.

headline: Many People in City Lack Proper ID, Lawyers Say
text: When Alec Baldwin took to Twitter to complain about his arrest on Tuesday, he got at least one thing right: “If you don’t have ID in NY when they write you a summons,” he wrote, “they can take you in.”

headline: Misinterpretation of a Biblical Code
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — We continue our biblical theme from yesterday with a crossword puzzle by John Lieb.

headline: After Prevailing in Two Game 7s, Rangers Are Back at Square One
text: The Rangers took a well-deserved day off on Wednesday, luxuriating in the afterglow of rallying from a three-games-to-one deficit and eliminating the Pittsburgh Penguins. There could be no denying their resilient spirit; the brilliance of Henrik Lundqvist, the first N.H.L. goalie to win five consecutive Game 7s; or the team effort that gave the players on the Rangers’ current roster an 83-6 record in Game 7s.

headline: Complaints of Food Poisoning at Citi Field Restaurant Don’t Scare Off Customers
text: The culinary delights at Citi Field — as opposed to the baseball often played there — are hard to dispute, and as the Mets and the Yankees took to the field to warm up before Wednesday night’s game, the smoke from the food court behind center field was already spreading temptation.

headline: Newspapers Hooked Dean Baquet, New Editor of The Times, at an Early Age
text: In November 2006, Dean Baquet stood on a desk in the newsroom of The Los Angeles Times and announced that he had been fired as the paper’s editor after refusing to cut newsroom staff.

headline: Obama Presses Infrastructure Spending
text: The president, speaking at the Tappan Zee Bridge, urged Republicans to support his new transportation program.

headline: For Cisco, Higher Stock Price Is Still Chasing Ambition
text: Cisco was a Wall Street darling after trading hours on Wednesday, but not for the reasons John T. Chambers, the company’s longtime chief executive, wants it to be.

headline: Prosecutor Tells Jurors Not to Be Fooled by a Cleric
text: A prosecutor told a Manhattan jury on Wednesday that Mostafa Kamel Mostafa, the British cleric who testified recently at his own terrorism trial, was “a skilled speaker” who knew how to “work a crowd” and that the jury should not be fooled by him.

headline: High-Power Tug of War Over Teachers’ Deal
text: Publicly, the news trickled out in humdrum fashion, in a jargon-filled statement that City Hall officials were quick to play down: The de Blasio administration would make a $725 million “adjustment” to its big-ticket settlement with the New York City teachers’ union.

headline: Saudi Arabia: 5 More Deaths From Virus Reported
text: Saudi Arabia reported five more deaths on Wednesday from a mysterious respiratory virus that first appeared there two years ago and has since spread to at least 16 other countries, including the United States. The Saudi Health Ministry said the latest fatalities from infections caused by the virus, known as Middle East Respiratory Syndrome, or MERS, brought the total in that country to 157. Saudi Arabia accounts for the vast majority of the 171 deaths and 571 infections from the virus globally. The Saudi announcement came as the World Health Organization said in a statement that its concern about MERS “had significantly increased,” but that there was still “no evidence of sustained human-to-human transmission” of the virus.

headline: Rangel, at Debate, Wields a Phone to Mock His Opponents
text: Representative Charles B. Rangel deployed an unusual weapon against his two Democratic primary opponents in a debate on Wednesday night: his iPhone.

headline: Mayor-Elect of Newark on Election Win
text: The mayor-elect of Newark, Ras Baraka, and his opponent, Shavar Jeffries, spoke after the unofficial returns showed Mr. Baraka outpacing the former assistant state attorney general.

headline: Rebuke of Charter Schools Is Seen in Newark Election
text: As Newark woke up to a new mayor-elect on Wednesday, the groups that backed him declared his victory one for the “progressive” wing of the Democratic Party, saying it was part of a rising tide across the country of voters’ speaking out against charter schools and other incursions against labor unions and public education.

headline: $192 Million Nets Finish Season Empty-Handed
text: MIAMI — The $192 million experiment came to an end on Wednesday.

headline: ‘The Americans’ Recap:  Secrets in the Basement
text: Episode 12, the second to last of the season, begins in Philip and Elizabeth’s secret basement room. They have decoded a secret code telling them to get Jared out and they have a game plan – Elizabeth will deal with Jared, and Philip will get in touch with the Center, to make sure that the rogue U.S. military agent Larrick is still in Nicaragua, and unable to harm them.

headline: Tanaka Gives Struggling Yankees Just What They Need
text: Their pitching staff was in tatters, their spirits at a season low after a four-game losing streak, and their bullpen weary from a heavy workload. With the Yankees teetering in a precarious place, who better to pull them out of their funk than the rookie from Japan who never seems to lose?

headline: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, May 15, 2014
text: “When an institution like the C.D.C. makes a statement, it makes a profound difference to the doctors who are ambivalent.”

headline: South Korea: Murder Charges in Ferry Disaster
text: The captain and three other crew members of the ferry that capsized off the southwestern coast of South Korea on April 16 were indicted on murder charges on Thursday, prosecutors said. The indictments were among formal charges leveled against 15 crew members of Sewol, the 6,825-ton ferry, after weeks of investigations into the causes of the sinking. As of Thursday, 281 people had been found dead and 23 remained missing. All 15 crew members had previously been arrested on various criminal charges, including accidental homicide. But on Thursday, prosecutors brought the more serious murder charges against the captain, Lee Jun-seok, and three others. They were accused of failing to try to rescue people on board and fleeing the vessel even though they knew that people were in danger and would die without their help. If convicted, the four could face death sentences.

headline: The Secret World of the Photographer Mark Cohen
text: In this weekly series, T’s photo editors share the most compelling visual projects they’ve discovered.

headline: Foraging in New Jersey With a Danish Chef
text: The Danish chef and foraging enthusiast Mads Refslund takes his crew on a field trip — to the wilderness an hour outside of Manhattan.

headline: The Elegant, Thoughtful Furniture of Yabu Pushelberg
text: If you’ve had the chance to admire the elegant interiors and furniture design of the Waldorf Astoria in Beijing, the Hazelton Hotel in Toronto or Barneys New York, you’ve been witness to the creative hand of Yabu Pushelberg. Since starting in Toronto 35 years ago, the architecture and design firm has quietly but assertively set the bar for high-end residential, hospitality and retail design. With offices in Toronto and New York and more than 100 employees, Yabu Pushelberg boasts an impressive client list and projects in over 16 countries, including the Edition hotels in London and Miami, the Lane Crawford department store in Shanghai and the Park Hyatt New York and One Madison in New York.

headline: Why Unbundling Cable Would Not Save You Money
text: If you have cable TV, you probably don’t watch most of the channels you get. The average American television household receives 189 channels, up from 123 in 2003. But we’re watching only 17.5 of those channels — nearly unchanged from 11 years ago, according to a new report from Nielsen.

headline: Word of the Day | rant
text: rant•\ˈrant\• verb and noun

headline: Activists Praise Hong Kong’s Destruction of Confiscated Ivory
text: Updated, 5:12 a.m. ET| The Hong Kong government began destroying nearly 30 tons of confiscated ivory on Thursday, a move conservationists said would send a powerful message about the Chinese territory’s resolve to end a trade that had contributed to widespread poaching of elephants.

headline: Debuting on Grand Stage, Montero Shows He Belongs
text: Rafael Montero sat at his locker Wednesday afternoon, hours before his major league debut, checking his phone and keeping to himself.

headline: Times Minute | Wildfires in California
text: Fire forces evacuations near San Diego. Also on the Minute, the response to anti-China riots in Vietnam and the 9/11 Museum’s ceremonial opening.

headline: Hopes of a Generation Ride on Indian Vote
text: Despite a period of rising incomes, a tide of economic discontent helped make Narendra Modi the prime minister-elect.

headline: Times Minute | Wildfires in California
text: In the Video

headline: Corrections: May 15, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: India Election Digest: May 15
text: What you need to know on Thursday about India’s elections: A day before the announcement of the parliamentary election results, a scholar weighs in on Narendra Modi’s possible governance model, Rahul Gandhi skips the prime minister’s farewell dinner, and the Bharatiya Janata Party, anticipating victory, orders 4,000 kilograms of sweets in Mumbai.

headline: What’s on Thursday
text: 9 P.M. (ABC) GREY’S ANATOMY The doctors of Grey Sloan Memorial Hospital bid an emotional farewell to Cristina Yang (Sandra Oh) in this Season 10 finale, as chaos reigns in the emergency room after a possible act of terrorism (above, Kevin McKidd). Meredith (Ellen Pompeo), meanwhile, makes a life-altering decision. In “Black Box,” at 10, Bickman (Ditch Davey) tries to convince Catherine (Kelly Reilly) that, like him, she can never find happiness in monogamy after she introduces Will (David Ajala) as her fiancé.

headline: Lawmakers’ Real Powers Can’t Match Voters’ Local Expectations
text: NEW DELHI — In the ancient city of Varanasi, in the state of Uttar Pradesh, voters said they might pass over the opposition Bharatiya Janata Party because their current lawmaker, Murli Manohar Joshi, hadn’t done much over the past decade to develop the town. And in Amethi, the Uttar Pradesh constituency of Rahul Gandhi, the vice president of the Indian National Congress, voters pointed to stagnant, trash-filled pools of water on the city’s main street and spoke of wanting change.

headline: Don’t Call Me Dude, Boss or Bro. It’s Comrade to You.
text: Even if you think the Chinese official you’re dealing with is a bit of a dude, a bro or a boss — don’t call him any of those things. Such terms are signs of unwanted bureaucratic sectarianism and ganglike behavior, according to the Communist Party discipline inspection commission of Guangdong Province.

headline: After Two Christie’s Auctions Top Expectations, Pace of Sales Slows at Sotheby’s
text: After two consecutive nights of sky’s-the-limit bidding, Sotheby’s sale of contemporary art started out on a high, but quickly fell back to earth, with picky buyers passing up paintings and sculptures by major figures like Rothko, de Kooning and Takashi Murakami.

headline: Anti-Chinese Violence Convulses Vietnam, Pitting Laborers Against Laborers
text: HA TINH PROVINCE, Vietnam — One Chinese laborer said angry Vietnamese workers had stomped on his hands, crushing them. Another said his son had been struck in the head with a metal rod by a Vietnamese mob that had sought out Chinese for beatings. At least one Chinese worker died.

headline: Test Yourself | English, May 15, 2014
text: Take the Quiz

headline: European Sales Help Luxury Group Richemont Balance a Decline in Asia
text: PARIS — Compagnie Financière Richemont, the Swiss luxury goods conglomerate, reported on Thursday a modest rise in annual profit as improved tourism-driven sales of jewelry and watches in Europe and the Americas offset weaker performance in mainland China.

headline: A Grass-Roots Drive for Clean Elections in Karnataka
text: DHARWAD, India — Buying votes in Karnataka, like much of India, is ubiquitous during the election season, especially the one that just ended Monday, which may turn out to be the most expensive in Indian history. The Election Commission said it had seized a record amount of cash, as well as alcohol and drugs, earmarked to buy votes.

headline: Public Discontent Rises as Families Gather to Bury Victims of Turkish Mine Disaster
text: SOMA, Turkey — With passport-size photographs of their loved ones fastened to their chests, family members of men killed in Turkey’s worst mining accident shuffled toward the cemetery on Thursday in a mourning ritual repeated for hours. At least 30 miners were buried as gravediggers toiled to make room for the bodies of many men still trapped underground.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Sept. 11 Memorial Museum at Ground Zero Prepares for Opening
text: In “The 9/11 Story Told at Bedrock, Powerful as a Punch to the Gut,” Holland Cotter reviews the new museum just before it opens to the public.

headline: Who Gets to Graduate?
text: For as long as she could remember, Vanessa Brewer had her mind set on going to college. The image of herself as a college student appealed to her — independent, intelligent, a young woman full of potential — but it was more than that; it was a chance to rewrite the ending to a family story that went off track 18 years earlier, when Vanessa’s mother, then a high-achieving high-school senior in a small town in Arkansas, became pregnant with Vanessa.

headline: Tangled Identities and Allegiances in Ukraine
text: Alexander Chekmenev began his mandatory military service in 1988 as a Russian citizen of the Soviet Union from eastern Ukraine’s Donbass region. By the time he left the army two years later – and after the collapse of the Soviet Union — he was an ethnic Russian and Ukrainian citizen.

headline: Afghan Contenders Accept Results and Move On
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The two remaining candidates for president of Afghanistan said on Thursday that they accepted the final results of the first round of voting, which eliminated their other rivals, and they vowed to campaign hard to win the election in a runoff.

headline: Do You Read for Pleasure?
text: A recent report by Common Sense Media found that a third of 13-year-olds and 45 percent of 17-year-olds say they read for pleasure only one or two times a year, if that.

headline: New York Today: Dedicating the 9/11 Museum
text: Good misty Thursday morning to you.

headline: Dixons and Carphone Warehouse Plan Merger to Create $6 Billion Company
text: Updated, 12:57 p.m. | LONDON – Two large British sellers of electronics, Dixons Retail and Carphone Warehouse Group, said on Thursday that they had agreed to an all-share merger that would create a company worth more than 3 billion pounds.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: Malfunction Causes New Setback in Search for Missing Jet
text: HONG KONG — The search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 suffered another setback on Thursday when the communications system for an American deep-sea submersible broke down, and the Australian vessel that had been towing it in the Indian Ocean was forced to head back to port.

headline: Captain and 3 Officers Charged With Murder in Korean Ferry Sinking
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Prosecutors brought murder charges on Thursday against the captain and three other crew members of a ferry that capsized off South Korea’s southwest coast last month, leaving 304 people dead or missing.

headline: The Wisdom of Partisan Crowds
text: Watching pundits and politicos speculate about what will happen in a coming election can feel like an exercise in futility. Most predict that their side will win, so what do we learn?

headline: Head of Barclays Investment Banking in Asia to Step Down
text: LONDON — The head of investment banking for Asia at the British lender Barclays is stepping down as the bank prepares to radically reshape its business.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up »

headline: The Jerusalem Bureau Says Goodbye to a Four-Wheeled Combat Survivor
text: RISHON LeZION, Israel — The Times’s Jerusalem bureau lost a loyal if not loved member last month.

headline: How Changing My Body Language Helped Me Close Deals
text: In recent posts, I have written about my attempts to get better at pitching for investment capital in general and closing deals in particular. A related issue that I’d like to address is my body language and what it says about me.

headline: A Pina Bausch Revival at Tanztheater Wuppertal
text: WUPPERTAL, Germany — The stage is full of enormous cacti. A couple in head-to-toe leopard-skin outfits, cat-ears perched on their heads, wander around with beatific, fixed smiles. Punk-rock music pounds.

headline: Euro Zone Economy Grows More Slowly Than Expected
text: PARIS — The European economy maintained its feeble overall growth in the first three months of the year, official data showed on Thursday, as relatively strong performances by Germany and Britain were offset by continued weakness in France and a step backward by Italy.

headline: Not On The Mend
text: There have been many proclamations that the euro crisis is over, that Europe’s economy is on the mend. Behind these proclamations lie something very real — a huge convergence in interest rates, thanks to the ECB’s support and growing belief that the political risks to the euro have receded — and something more dubious — a modest uptick in debtor-country growth.

headline: Cleaning House at Citi
text: A SHAKE-UP AT CITIGROUP  |  Citigroup is moving quickly to try to put a costly fraud at its Mexican business in the rearview mirror, firing an additional 11 employees, including four high-ranking executives in Mexico, Michael Corkery and Elisabeth Malkin write in DealBook. On Monday afternoon, the board of the bank was briefed on an internal investigation into the $400 million fraud involving a large Banamex client, and by Tuesday evening, the 11 employees in Mexico were fired.

headline: The Hot Seat
text: He’s written a really good book — we might as well get that out of the way, as so much else about Timothy F. Geithner remains unsettled. Geithner served as president of the New York Federal Reserve from late 2003 to 2008 and secretary of the Treasury from 2009 to 2013, and so sat near the center of the American financial system as it prepared to self-destruct. He then had a courtside seat to the global catastrophe. He has rich material to work with, and he has contrived to preserve its freshness. His inability as Treasury secretary to explain himself, or his actions, or the financial crisis, or his beliefs about financial reform, to the wider public will leave many readers, I suspect, feeling they are hearing his voice on these subjects for the first time.

headline: How Net Neutrality Works
text: The future of protecting an open Internet has been the subject of fierce debate, and potential changes to the rules by the Federal Communications Commission could affect your online experience.

headline: F.C.C. Backs Opening Net Neutrality Rules for Debate
text: WASHINGTON — Federal regulators appear to share one view about so-called net neutrality: It is a good thing.

headline: Pipe Ruptures, Spewing Oil in Los Angeles
text: LOS ANGELES — A ruptured pipeline sent about 10,000 gallons of crude oil spilling into the street in eastern Los Angeles early Thursday morning, with geysers that were at first spurting up to 50 feet into the air.

headline: It Will Have Blood (Mud, Too)
text: Any new production of “Macbeth” has a lot to overcome, including history, tradition, expectation and the participants’ own relationship to the material. For the actor and director Kenneth Branagh, this meant years of thinking about the play, biding his time and concocting and discarding various ideas (some cleverer than others) for how to stage it.

headline: Still Radioactive and Spoiling for a Fight
text: Godzilla shows up fairly late in the new movie that bears his name, and he also shows his age. Though this gigantic monster is, within the film’s own mythico-scientific terms, the long-slumbering reminder of a primordial, prehuman age, by the calendar of popular culture, he’s a baby boomer. And now, roughly 60 years after he first appeared (as Gojira in the still unsurpassed, recently restored Japanese original), everybody’s favorite skyscraper stomper is exhibiting some familiar generational traits. He seems grumpy and underslept, as well as thicker around the jowls and midriff. And though he arrives dragging the usual heavy allegorical baggage, you can detect a trace of wistful worry in his rampages, as if he had begun to doubt his own relevance.

headline: In Our Pages: May 16
text: 1939: Princesses Ride Third Class

headline: Report Says Fewer Bees Perished Over the Winter, but the Reason Is a Mystery
text: Honeybees could be on their way back, according to a new federal report.

headline: Daily Report: Awaiting a Proposal on Net Neutrality
text: Rarely have so many people become so exercised about something they have not seen.

headline: Retailers Feel Economy’s Effects on Their Shoppers
text: A growing chorus of retailers partly blamed the unusually harsh winter for a disappointing quarter on Thursday. But the sluggish results of chains like Walmart also underscored the sustained financial struggles of a lower-income customer base, while retailers that serve higher-income shoppers performed better.

headline: Kindred Healthcare Makes Unsolicited Bid for Gentiva
text: Kindred Healthcare made an unsolicited offer to buy Gentiva Health Services for about $514 million in cash and stock on Thursday, setting up a potential battle over the health care services company.

headline: Bayer Sells a Unit to Boston Scientific for $415 Million
text: The Boston Scientific Corporation said on Thursday  that it would acquire a division of the German drug maker Bayer for $415 million.

headline: RP Martin Fined $2.2 Million in Libor Rigging
text: LONDON — British and American regulators on Thursday fined a small British brokerage firm more than $2 million over misconduct related to the manipulation of global interest rate benchmarks known as Libor.

headline: 3 Officials Were Killed in Xinjiang During Chinese President’s Visit, Report Says
text: Updated, 7:25 a.m. ET| The police in the troubled far-western Chinese region of Xinjiang are seeking assailants who killed three government officials late last month, an act of violence that appears to have been timed to the visit of President Xi Jinping, Radio Free Asia reported on Thursday.

headline: 2 Apollo Global Executives Reduce Their Stakes
text: Two of the three leaders of Apollo Global Management have reduced their stakes in the private equity firm by a small amount, regulatory filings show.

headline: Tasers and Schools Don’t Mix
text: The police rule by fiat in the hinterlands of Texas. Given that reality, no one is surprised that a Bastrop County grand jury has declined to indict the sheriff’s deputy involved in the case of a high school student who suffered permanent brain damage last fall after being shocked with a Taser. But Adam Loewy, a veteran lawyer representing 17-year-old Noe Niño de Rivera, was particularly angry about what he described as a grand jury that “was a sham process from start to finish.” Mr. Loewy asserted in an email that prosecutors never contacted him, and never met with the victim, his parents or an eye witness.

headline: Colson Whitehead: By the Book
text: The author of “The Noble Hustle: Poker, Beef Jerky, and Death” would like to host Flannery O’Connor, “because I don’t think she knew a lot of black people, or got out of the house that much.”

headline: Rearranging Warhol’s Legacy
text: PITTSBURGH — Andy Warhol was, chronologically and by his own description, a nose picker, a pimp and a water guzzler. He was also (or therefore) one of the most various, complex and impressive talents the art world has produced. All those claims, however unlikely, can be confirmed by a visit to the Andy Warhol Museum here in his hometown. In honor of its 20th anniversary, the museum has been rethought from top to bottom, and the results are now being revealed to the public. There may not be another museum that digs as deep into a single artist, and gets as much out of the excavation.

headline: Classical Playlist: Beethoven, Shostakovich, Tigran Mansurian and More
text: SHOSTAKOVICH, KHACHATURIAN: Violin Concertos and QuartetsJames Ehnes, violinist; Melbourne Symphony Orchestra; Ehnes Quartet(Onyx) The Armenian composer Aram Khachaturian composed his Violin Concerto for David Oistrakh. James Ehnes conveys its lighthearted mood, folk elements and virtuosic passages with sweet tone and technical aplomb, deftly accompanied by the Melbourne Symphony Orchestra and the conductor Mark Wigglesworth. Shostakovich’s String Quartets No. 7 and 8, which Mr. Ehnes performs with his quartet, offer a stark contrast in mood — particularly their searing rendition of the Eighth. (Vivien Schweitzer)

headline: With Warriors, Steve Kerr Follows the Path of Least Tumult
text: On the verge of accepting his first head coaching position, Steve Kerr, in late-game negotiations, played it calculatingly cool. Even to Phil Jackson, a renowned sideline stoic and the man considered to be his mentor, Kerr never showed his true hand.

headline: The Electric Neighbor
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 28
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: When Medical Students Make Errors
text: “I’m sorry. I messed up.”

headline: Interest Rates Are Falling. Thank Vladimir Putin.
text: If there was one thing that market analysts thought they could agree upon at the start of the year, it was that interest rates were set to rise. The economy was improving. The Federal Reserve was pulling away from its program of pumping money into bond markets. The era of cheap money seemed to be coming to an end after all these years.

headline: Evil Stalks the Stage: It’s Curtains!
text: Ghost lights. Traps. Bombs. “You killed it.” Hang around theater people long enough, and you might think the industry is a living slasher film. Theater and horror movies have been strange bedfellows since European filmmakers of the silent era incorporated Grand Guignol dramatics and expressionistic stage techniques into early movies like “Waxworks” and “The Hands of Orlac.” More recently, theater makers have tapped into the horror movie canon to concoct stage versions of “Night of the Living Dead” and “The Exorcist.”

headline: Official Says Prosecutors Are Looking at V.A. Lists
text: WASHINGTON — The Department of Veterans Affairs’ inspector general is working with federal prosecutors who are trying to determine whether criminal violations occurred at a medical center in Phoenix accused of falsifying data or creating secret waiting lists intended to hide monthslong delays for veterans to see doctors, a top official told a Senate committee on Thursday.

headline: Deutsche Bank to Sell Cosmopolitan Casino to Blackstone
text: Updated, 11:15 a.m. | Deutsche Bank is finally leaving Las Vegas.

headline: Under Cover: Strength in Numbers
text: This week’s cover story is about an innovative student-retention program at the University of Texas at Austin. For the accompanying cover image, the magazine recruited Bill McCullough, an Austin-based photographer, to shoot 24 students from the program. McCullough recently discussed some of what goes into pulling off a group shot.

headline: Japan’s Constitution and the Military
text: To the Editor:

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘Diluvian Dream’
text: This week’s Poetry Pairing features “Diluvian Dream” by Wilmer Mills and the article “Saying Goodbye to the Farm” by Anne Raver.

headline: Retro-Hugo Prize to Honor Science Fiction of 1938
text: Have you ever found yourself engrossed in a science fiction classic – say, John Wyndham’s “Sleepers of Mars,” C.S. Lewis’s “Out of the Silent Planet” or Edgar Rice Burroughs’s “Carson of Venus” – and thought what a pity it is that they were published before 1953, when the Hugo Awards, one of science fiction’s most prestigious prizes (along with the Nebula Awards) were first given?

headline: In This Election Season, 56 Million Tweets and Counting
text: NEW DELHI – With slightly over 200 million Internet users in India, this election marks India’s first that was contested both on the ground and online.

headline: One Reason Health Insurance Premiums Vary So Much
text: If you live in Jackson, Miss., Obamacare is giving you a raw deal.

headline: Obama Dedicates 9/11 Memorial Museum
text: President Obama on Thursday dedicated the long-awaited museum commemorating the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, with a mournful elegy to the victims, a stirring tribute to the heroes and a firm resolve to never let terrorists shatter the spirit of America.

headline: G.M. Recalls 2.7 Million Vehicles, Bringing Its Total for Year to 11.2 Million
text: It seems that no car, truck or sport utility vehicle in General Motors’ vast product lineup is immune to the automaker’s blitz of safety recalls.

headline: Zendesk Shares Soar in Debut
text: Zendesk, a cloud-based software start-up, had a buoyant trading debut on Thursday, defying a broader slump in the shares of young companies.

headline: At a Memorial, Hundreds Pay Tribute to a Gujarat Human Rights Champion
text: AHMEDABAD — The last time I saw Mukul Sinha, a close personal friend and longtime human rights activist and lawyer, was on March 8 when a local newspaper, The Ahmedabad Mirror, held a special ceremony to designate him as a “hero of Ahmedabad,” the former capital of the state of Gujarat.

headline: Car Bomb Kills More Than 40 at Syrian Border Crossing
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A car bomb killed at least 43 people on the Syrian side of the Bab al-Salam crossing on the border with Turkey on Thursday and wounded dozens more, an antigovernment group said. It appeared to be the latest instance of civilians bearing the brunt of clashes between Islamist groups in insurgent-held territory.

headline: When Your Teenager Wants a Car: The Money Conversations
text: Sooner or later, most teenagers dream of owning a car, and unless you live in a place with terrific public transportation, you’ll probably entertain the idea of letting them have one. One of the biggest questions, then, is who should pay for it?

headline: The Cadets at New Market
text: On the evening of May 10, 1864, on the first anniversary of the battlefield death of Gen. Thomas “Stonewall” Jackson, who had been a professor at the Virginia Military Institute before the war, some 300 V.M.I. cadets paraded the lush grounds in full dress while bands played and nearby townsfolk came to pay their respects. “Groups of girls in filmy garments set off with bits of color came tripping across the sod; and children and nurses sat about the benches at the guard-tree,” one cadet recalled.

headline: After European Court Decision, Google Works on a Tool to Remove Links
text: LONDON – Google will announce by the end of the month a mechanism for consumers to request that links to information about them be removed from the company’s search engine, a leading European regulator said on Thursday. It was one of the first signs that Google was working through how to operate after a court ruling said consumers could make such requests.

headline: Two New Murder Charges Brought Against Hernandez
text: BOSTON — The 2012 New England Patriots were an offensive force, setting a record for first downs in an N.F.L. season while scoring 557 points. Tight end Aaron Hernandez was a big part of that offense, catching 51 passes for 483 yards and scoring five touchdowns. He had 15 more receptions in the playoffs as the Patriots advanced to the A.F.C. championship game.

headline: Happy in a World of Quirk
text: For Mike Myers, it is not the least bit humbling to go from making comedies for millions of viewers to performing for an audience of one, assuming that person is his 2-year-old son, Spike.

headline: Art Matters | The Art World Eyes a New Destination: Gwangju, South Korea
text: Throughout most of the past week, Randalls Island seemed the most far-flung art destination anyone in the New York art world was paying attention to. But a dinner at the West Village club Norwood held during Frieze New York shifted attention to a locale halfway around the world. The curator Jessica Morgan of the Tate Modern in London announced the artists participating in her edition of the Gwangju Biennale in South Korea this fall, which runs Sept. 5 though Nov. 9. Founded in 1995, the event is South Korea’s most important international exhibition, and arguably Asia’s as well, and has put the nation’s sixth-largest city on the map.

headline: Andreessen Horowitz Bets on a Government Software Start-Up
text: The venture capital firm Andreessen Horowitz has invested in a range of software companies, catering to different types of customers.

headline: At Last, Recovery Heads Where the Fed Wants It
text: The Federal Reserve finally seems to be getting what it wants.

headline: What Might Leadership Change Mean for Times Readers?
text: Updated, Friday, 12:55 p.m.Secrets don’t normally last long at newspapers. But this was different: Most of the hundreds who gathered in the Times newsroom Wednesday afternoon were stunned by Arthur O. Sulzberger Jr.’s announcement that Jill Abramson had been fired.

headline: A Summer Dance Program for Children in New York City
text: Some of New York’s best dance companies will be part of Victory Dance, a series over the summer that will provide free dance performances and classes to children in New York City Department of Education day camps and programs. The lineup, between July 16 and Aug. 1, includes Ballet Tech’s Kids Dance, Lil Buck, Michelle Dorrance, Doug Elkin, Full Circle Souljahs, Gallim Dance, Ballet Hispanico, Keigwin & Company, Lava, Monica Bill Barnes & Company and Ronald K. Brown/Evidence.

headline: Hefty Global Goals from a Vatican Meeting: Stabilizing the Climate, Energy for All and an Inclusive Economy
text: A group statement has emerged from “Sustainable Humanity, Sustainable Planet, Our Responsibility,” the Vatican meeting of scientists, economists, theologians and others that I participated in earlier this month. (If you missed it, click here to watch or read the summary I presented as the meeting ended.)

headline: Now on Hotel Lists: Private-Label Wines
text: Guests can order wine just about anywhere they stay, but now they can swirl something a bit more exclusive in their glass: A number of hotels are offering private label vintages as a way to increase cachet and enhance the local dining experience.The Peninsula Hong Kong introduced its own Shaoxing Hua Diao, a 15-year aged Chinese wine made with fermented rice, in late 2013. The group also offers Champagne brut (by Deutz), pinot noir and chardonnay (both by Keller Estate) at all of its properties, served in dark bottles with the hotel’s logo inked on labels.The Ojai Valley Inn & Spa,  north of Los Angeles, offers a “Pink Moment” sparkling rosé in honor of the area’s sunsets.

headline: Philip Roth Receives Yaddo Artist Medal — In Person
text: Philip Roth is back! Well, sort of.

headline: A Father-Daughter Pas de Deux
text: A FEW years ago, more or less out of the blue, I began to take my daughter, Hattie, to dance performances. She’d turned 12, and we seemed to be losing each other, just a bit, to our changing lives and cooing cellphones. It seemed like a way to clear out some time to be together.

headline: Cuomo’s Camp Rushes to Define His Republican Rival
text: ALBANY — Rob Astorino was still more than a month away from announcing his bid to challenge Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo back in January, but a political operative with ties to the governor was already busily researching Mr. Astorino’s past.

headline: Held Hostage in Sudan with Gabriel García Márquez
text: Nearly four years have passed since I was kidnapped and held hostage for 105 days while working to bring education to the children of the war-torn region of Darfur, Sudan. In some respects my captivity seems all but a distant memory. The passage of time, however, will never diminish my fond recollections of my only trusted companion during those long, death-defying days—Gabriel García Márquez. With his recent passing, all of the harrowing and heart-tugging memories of our time together came flooding back.

headline: Clip: Jellyfish Eyes by Takashi Murakami
text: A battle scene from the artist’s first feature film that combines live-action and animation.

headline: Executive Director, Like Artistic Director, Is Leaving Pennsylvania Ballet
text: It’s all change at Pennsylvania Ballet. Just two weeks after the announcement that its artistic director, Roy Kaiser, would leave the company once a successor was found, the troupe has announced that its executive director, Michael Scolamiero, will also depart. He will take up the same position at Miami City Ballet.

headline: Now Screening | Takashi Murakami Makes a Movie
text: Takashi Murakami is one of the few artists alive who might genuinely be considered a household name. The Japanese maestro’s hard-edged, big-featured monsters, beauties and flower-faces — famously executed by a vast network of studio assistants, some of whom have spawned their own cult iconographies under the umbrella of his art production and artist management company Kaikai Kiki Co. — are the progenitors of the self-explanatory art movement known as “Superflat,” which has long since exploded beyond the walls of galleries and onto Louis Vuitton bags, Supreme skate decks and any niche product that can be refashioned as a postmodern canvas.

headline: Wheelies: The Mexican Minis Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Obama Speaks at 9/11 Museum Dedication
text: President Obama delivered remarks at the dedication ceremony for the National September 11 Memorial Museum in New York City.

headline: De Blasio at 9/11 Museum Dedication
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York delivered his remarks during the dedication ceremony in Foundation Hall at the National September 11 Memorial Museum at ground zero.

headline: Times Minute | A Honeybee Comeback
text: Also on the minute, a runoff in Afghanistan’s presidential election and the Times movie critic’s take on the latest return of Godzilla.

headline: Today in Small Business: The Canadian Dream?
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: When Predators Vanish, So Does the Ecosystem
text: Mark D. Bertness, an ecologist at Brown University, began studying the salt marshes of New England in 1981. Twenty-six years later, in 2007, he started to watch them die. In one marsh after another, lush stretches of cordgrass disappeared, replaced by bare ground. The die-offs were wiping out salt marshes in just a few years.
