text: In the Video

headline: Image of the Day: May 15
text: Workers preparing sweets anticipating a victory for the Bharatiya Janata Party in India’s parliamentary elections.

headline: Another Opponent of Obamacare Starts to Soften
text: Another die-hard opponent of the Affordable Care Act may be finding a way to expand Medicaid. Few have stood as firm against Obamacare as Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana, but on Thursday he announced a new proposal that would accept federal funds for increased coverage of low-income state residents — though by giving them access to private insurance plans rather than standard Medicaid.

headline: Scenes of Wildfires in San Diego
text: Firefighters battled blazes in Southern California.

headline: Fire Season Starts Early, and Fiercely
text: LOS ANGELES — The fire season here in the hot, dry West now lasts roughly 75 days longer than it did a decade ago, and nearly three dozen fires have been burning up and down California in the last two days, weeks before a normal season begins.

headline: How It Happens | Forest Fires
text: Fuel, oxygen and heat combine to start wildfires, which destroy millions of acres each year in the United States.

headline: A Senate Battle Over Mortgage Rules
text: Lenders are slowly thawing as the financial crisis recedes, but many families with imperfect credit still find it hard to get approved for a mortgage. And just as winter fades to spring, the thaw leads to calls for  Congress to do more to foster affordable mortgages.

headline: City College to Establish New Arts Center
text: The City College of New York is hoping to transform a $2.5 million renovation of its Aaron Davis Hall – the attractive concert building that opened in 1979, and has presented performances by Ella Fitzgerald, Mikhail Baryshnikov and the New York Philharmonic – into something bigger. Now the college is announcing the establishment of its new City College Center for the Arts, which will produce and present arts events at Davis Hall and elsewhere on the campus. Gregory S. Shanck is the center’s managing director, and David Covington is its artistic director.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘Godzilla’
text: Gareth Edwards narrates a sequence from “Godzilla.”

headline: Egypt Tells 3 They Must Pay to See Evidence
text: CAIRO — An Egyptian court said Thursday that three jailed journalists must pay $170,000 for a copy of the video footage that prosecutors say shows the defendants fabricated news reports to foment unrest.

headline: U.S. Report Addresses Concern Over Obama’s Plan to Close Guantánamo
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration’s legal team has told Congress that if Guantánamo Bay detainees were relocated to a prison inside the United States, it is unlikely that a court would order their release onto domestic soil.

headline: Women and the ‘I Don’t Know’ Problem
text: Katty Kay, anchor of the BBC World News America, and Claire Shipman, national correspondent for ABC’s “Good Morning America,” explore in “The Confidence Code”  how men and women express their opinions differently. Women tend to speak up less on topics they aren’t well versed in, whereas men comfortably hold forth on topics they have little expertise on.

headline: Gareth Edwards Narrates a Scene From ‘Godzilla’
text: In this video, the director Gareth Edwards discusses an action sequence from “Godzilla” involving a military parachute jump over the city of San Francisco.

headline: Images of Turkish Official Kicking Protester Fuel Anger Online
text: Last Updated, Saturday, 9:25 a.m. | One day after Turkey’s prime minister was jeered during a visit to the mining town of Soma, where at least 282 workers were killed this week in an accident, one of his senior advisers was forced to admit that he had kicked a protester being restrained by the police.

headline: Investors Reject Chipotle Chiefs’ Pay Plan
text: Investors in Chipotle Mexican Grill voted overwhelmingly on Thursday against the company’s executive compensation plans, sending a strong rebuke to a company that had awarded more than $300 million to its co-chief executives in recent years.

headline: Error at IBM Lab Finds New Family of Materials
text: As a research chemist at an IBM laboratory, Jeannette M. Garcia spends her days mixing and heating chemicals in pursuit of stronger and more easily recyclable plastics. Recently she followed a simple formula that required mixing three components in a beaker. Somehow she missed a step, leaving out a chemical. She returned to find her beaker filled with a hard white plastic that had even frozen the stirrer.

headline: As Barbara Walters Retires, the Big TV Interview Signs Off, Too
text: On a Wednesday night in early March 1999, Barbara Walters invited a small group of friends and colleagues to her Manhattan apartment to watch her two-hour interview with Monica Lewinsky. During a commercial break, Ms. Walters stood by the window, looking out over Central Park, and noticed something peculiar. “There’s no traffic on Fifth Avenue,” she observed.

headline: Close, Lithgow, Plimpton To Star in ‘Delicate Balance’ on Broadway
text: The three-time Tony Award winner Glenn Close will return to Broadway for the first time in 20 years to lead a high-powered cast this fall in “A Delicate Balance,” Edward Albee’s Pulitzer Prize-winning dark comedy from 1966 about an upper-middle-class family facing terrors both real and amorphous. The producer Scott Rudin announced the casting and performance plans on Thursday. The director will be Pam MacKinnon, an Albee expert who won a Tony last year for staging a revival of his classic “Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf?”

headline: To Campuses Without a Compass
text: The last thing a dad gets to really teach his daughter is how to drive a car.

headline: Mel Patton, 89, Who Shattered a Leg and Then Sprinting Records, Is Dead
text: Mel Patton, who overcame a badly broken leg as a child to become known as “the world’s fastest human” in the 1940s and win two gold medals in the 1948 London Olympics, died on May 9 in Fallbrook, Calif., near San Diego. He was 89.

headline: Times Issues Response on Abramson Pay
text: A day after The New York Times announced that it had dismissed Jill Abramson, its first female executive editor, after only 33 months on the job, its publisher was denying reports that her removal was related to complaints about unequal compensation in comparison with her predecessors.

headline: Reader Idea | Creating Architectural Models of Literary Themes
text: We love publishing ideas from our readers about new ways to teach with The Times, and the project we feature below is one of the most creative we have ever encountered.

headline: This Weekend | The Marvelous Sugar Baby
text: Visit Kara Walker’s giant sugar coated sphinx in Brooklyn, see what a Don Quixote ballet looks like at the Met or check out some medieval stained glass at the Cloisters.

headline: Wine Ingredient May Have Few Health Benefits
text: Resveratrol, an antioxidant found in red wine, chocolate and other foods, has gained wide public attention as a cancer and heart disease preventive.

headline: This Weekend: The Marvelous Sugar Baby
text: In the Video

headline: Workers Seize City in Eastern Ukraine From Separatists
text: MARIUPOL, Ukraine — Thousands of steelworkers fanned out on Thursday through the city of Mariupol, establishing control over the streets and banishing the pro-Kremlin militants who until recently had seemed to be consolidating their grip on power, dealing a setback to Russia and possibly reversing the momentum in eastern Ukraine.

headline: Ousted Director Rejoins GrafTech Board
text: Investors of GrafTech, the small steel company at the center of a corporate governance debate, have re-elected an ousted director to the board, along with his two of his allies.

headline: Rolls-Royce Aims ‘Into the Blue’ With the Waterspeed Collection
text: A limited-edition, deep blue Rolls-Royce Phantom Drophead Coupé, commemorating a 77-year-old world record speed run on water, will be unveiled to the public May 23-25 at the Villa d’Este Concorso d’Eleganza at Lake Como in Italy.

headline: Fantasy Football: Analyzing the N.F.L. Draft Picks, Part 1
text: Success in fantasy football has as much to do with a player’s talent as it does with the state of the team’s roster. The most talented players often earn the best opportunities, but sometimes that takes time.

headline: New York Revives Talk of Hosting the 2024 Games
text: New York City’s bid for the 2012 Olympics ended badly. Might the city’s political leaders try again?

headline: The Right Price for AstraZeneca’s Stock
text: Investors are putting a lot of faith in Pfizer succeeding in its $100 billion-plus quest to acquire British pharmaceuticals rival AstraZeneca. The right price for the target’s share price can be seen as the weighted average of two possible outcomes – a sale to Pfizer or a standalone future. A new Breakingviews calculator shows why the market seems to think a transaction will probably happen.

headline: Convicted of Felonies, Banks Are Allowed to Stay in Business
text: Two large international banks — Credit Suisse and BNP Paribas — are expected to plead guilty to criminal charges within the next few weeks. If that happens, they will pay large fines and officially be felons.

headline: Impossible? Only Until You Prove Otherwise
text: This interview with Rob Gough, president of Eckim, a marketing company, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Created by Hand: Lock, Stock and Barrel
text: The antiques dealer and collector Joseph Kindig Jr. never fired a shot with any of his hundreds of American rifles made around 1800. He was not a hunter; he was a vegetarian who did not like to kill anything. At his store in York, Pa., he would refuse to sell his gun inventory to buyers who seemed snobbish or ignorant. He believed that the firearms represented the first major American artistic innovation.

headline: One Singular Thai Sensation
text: This is it, the only dish on the menu, the reason the restaurant exists: chicken over rice on a paper plate, white on white on white. Pale-skinned moons of cucumber lie to one side, a lone stem of cilantro on top.

headline: France Asserts It Has Authority to Block Mergers
text: PARIS — The French government has formally given itself the power to block foreign takeovers on strategic grounds as it seeks to sway the outcome of a battle between General Electric and Siemens for Alstom, one of France’s industrial crown jewels.

headline: California Chrome Coughs, but Trainers Say He Is Fine
text: BALTIMORE — It is more a tickle than a hitch. At least that is how the trainer Art Sherman characterized the cough California Chrome came up with Thursday morning.

headline: Prehistoric Skeleton in Mexico Is Said to Link Modern Indians to Earliest Americans
text: Most geneticists agree that Native Americans are descended from Siberians who crossed into America 26,000 to 18,000 years ago via a land bridge over the Bering Strait. But while genetic analysis of modern Native Americans lends support to this idea, strong fossil evidence has been lacking.

headline: La Scala to Fire Incoming Director After One Season
text: MILAN — In what Mayor Giuliano Pisapia described as an agonizing decision, the board of La Scala on Thursday voted to dismiss that opera theater’s incoming director general at the end of his first season, amid charges of a conflict of interest.

headline: The Commencement Bigots
text: It’s commencement season, cellphones off please, no texts or tweets. Even with a hangover from debt, alcohol or regret, grads across the land may be lucky enough to hear something on the Big Day that actually stays with them.

headline: U.S. Mines Personal Health Data to Find the Vulnerable in Emergencies
text: The phone calls were part Big Brother, part benevolent parent. When a rare ice storm threatened New Orleans in January, some residents heard from a city official who had gained access to their private medical information. Kidney dialysis patients were advised to seek early treatment because clinics would be closing. Others who rely on breathing machines at home were told how to find help if the power went out.

headline: Letters: Considering James Madison
text: Considering James Madison

headline: The Funeral Buffet and Other Existential Issues
text: A man in a wrinkled sport coat perches on a bar stool. “I was at your daughter’s wake,” he tells the bartender (Evander Duck). Let’s hope the customer (Noel Joseph Allain) likes that sentence. He’ll say it more than 20 times in William Burke’s brief, oblique “the food was terrible,” at the Bushwick Starr.

headline: The Gun Report: May 15, 2014
text: Whenever a child opens fire at a school, wounding and killing classmates and teachers, we want to know why. If the shooter commits suicide during the rampage, all we can do is guess.

headline: Life Could be a Dream (if Your Name Is Alice)
text: “Alice in Wonderland” has been adapted as an all-star Paramount production (1933), with Cary Grant as the Mock Turtle; as a British puppet animation (1949), eclipsed by the Disney animated musical (1951), later embraced as a head film by the drug culture of the late ’60s; as Dennis Potter’s meditation on the old age of the real Alice (“Dreamchild,” 1985); and as Tim Burton’s 3-D extravaganza (2010) starring Mia Wasikowska as a 19-year-old Alice. None, however, is stranger than “Alice” (1988), made by the Czech animator Jan Svankmajer, newly remastered and reissued on Blu-ray by First Run Features.

headline: The March to War
text: In February 1933, President-elect Franklin Roosevelt was nearly murdered in Miami by a gunman whose errant fatal shot struck Mayor Anton Cermak of Chicago. Cermak gallantly told Roosevelt, “I’m glad it was me instead of you.” Today’s Americans should not disagree. Had Roosevelt been killed, the 32nd president of the United States would have been his running mate, Speaker John Nance Garner of Texas, a neophyte in foreign and military affairs, isolationist by instinct and deeply rooted in a Congress determined, notwithstanding the growing threats from Hitler and the imperial Japanese, to keep another president from repeating what a majority of its members considered to be Woodrow Wilson’s catastrophic mistake of needlessly dragging the nation into a distant “foreign war.”

headline: All the Way
text: Over the past century, Congress has passed only a handful of truly transformative pieces of legislation. The Social Security Act comes to mind, as do the G.I. Bill, the Marshall Plan, the laws that created a mammoth military and laid down a web of highways, and the reforms that reopened the nation to immigration. Visionary laws — each and every one — meant to achieve policy aims of striking originality.

headline: Russian Businessman Under Sanctions Fires Broadside at West
text: BERLIN — The president of Russian Railways, Vladimir I. Yakunin, a longtime associate of President Vladimir V. Putin, is persona non grata to Washington. Sanctioned by the United States in retaliation for support of Moscow’s annexation of Crimea, he has been banned from entering the country and any assets there have been frozen.

headline: Rand Paul’s Hard Road
text: It is fair to say, I think, that Rand Paul is one of the most interesting major contenders for the Republican nomination in 2016, and by extension for the presidency. (That’s why everyone at this newspaper keeps writing about him!) It’s also fair to say that his path to both destinations would be unique, at least by the standards of modern G.O.P. presidential contenders: There are no obvious recent historical models for the kind of coalition Paul would need to put together to win either the nomination or the presidency, and there isn’t even a recent near-miss candidate (his father, for all his grassroots success, was just a “miss,” with nothing near about it) whose almost-success he could try to build upon.

headline: Russia Tells Ukraine: Cash in Advance for Gas
text: MOSCOW — Russia said on Thursday that it would stop supplying gas to Ukraine at the end of the month unless the country paid for it in advance, increasing the pressure on Kiev’s financially pressed government as it struggles to contain a growing rebellion in the country’s east.

headline: Bonding Through Time, on Film and in Life
text: Shortly after arriving in New York from France to study film, Cédric Klapisch, then 23, was interrogated by a roommate: “Where do you think you’ll be in 10 years?” Though he knew he wanted to direct, Mr. Klapisch, now 53, recalled: “I couldn’t really answer that question. I knew that my life was ahead of me, and didn’t know what my life would look like.”

headline: As Maman Lay Dying, Her Spirit Became Art
text: Wandering into the sumptuous neo-Gothic chapel of the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, you might think you’d come upon the lovingly arranged setting for a funeral. You’ve actually walked into a work of art by the French conceptualist Sophie Calle, an installation called “Rachel, Monique.” It’s an elegiac but frustratingly oblique meditation on the life and the death of Ms. Calle’s mother, Monique Sindler. (The Rachel in the title was another name by which she was known.)

headline: Relational Unveils Stake in B/E Aerospace
text: Updated, 6:43 p.m. | B/E Aerospace surprised many last week when the company, a maker of airplane seats, announced that it was weighing a potential sale, among other strategic options.

headline: All About Fees
text: Ask Real Estate is a weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: Reverend Billy Brings a New Sermon to Joe’s Pub
text: During Occupy Wall Street a few years ago, the Miser moseyed over to Zuccotti Park for a firsthand look. A singular figure in a white suit over clerical garb and collar, his blond-highlighted pompadour bopping in sync with his sermonizing, stood out.

headline: Home Equity Loans Make a Cautious Return
text: Home-equity lending is making a gradual comeback now that property values in some areas have risen to levels that give homeowners something to borrow against.

headline: This Is How We Roll
text: I’VE toyed with the idea of using a foam roller to help release muscle tension after rigorous workouts. The stretching area at my gym has several of these cylindrical self-massage tools. But I’ve long been unsure about the right way to roll and too time-pressed to figure out how.

headline: Marco Rubio on the ‘Settled Science’ of Abortion
text: Sick of taking flak for his climate-change denial, Senator Marco Rubio tried to change the topic (a classic crisis-management move) by accusing his critics of hypocrisy (another classic).

headline: U.S. Officials Question Ability of Nigeria to Rescue Hostages
text: WASHINGTON — Obama administration officials on Thursday questioned whether the Nigerian military is able to rescue, even with international help, more than 260 schoolgirls abducted last month, giving impetus to a social media campaign calling for the United States to do more to free the hostages.

headline: Federal Officials Ease Travel Rules for Instruments With Ivory
text: After weeks of pressure from musicians, the Obama Administration announced Thursday that it has relaxed rules that would have made it extremely difficult for performers and orchestras to travel abroad with instruments that contained ivory parts.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Turkey and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Turkey, New York, California and England.

headline: Lady Day at Emerson’s Bar & Grill
text: Audra McDonald sings “God Bless the Child” in “Lady Day at Emerson’s Bar & Grill.”

headline: Les Misérables
text: Will Swenson sings “Stars,” in “Les Misérables.”

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: National Gallery Finalizes Agreement to Obtain Much of  Corcoran Collection
text: The Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington – the nation’s oldest privately supported art museum but one that has struggled financially for many years – has completed an agreement with the National Gallery of Art and George Washington University to absorb its building, collection and its art college.

headline: New Yoga Programs at Six Senses Resorts
text: Those looking to travel to a deeper state of consciousness on their next vacation might consider one of Six Senses’ new yoga-based retreats.

headline: U.S. Seeks to Bypass Assad So More Aid Can Reach Syrian Civilians
text: LONDON — Increasingly flustered with the inability of the United Nations to deliver aid to war victims in Syria, Secretary of State John Kerry said on Thursday that the United States was considering ways to increase the delivery of aid without the consent of President Bashar al-Assad’s government.

headline: Brazilian Mogul Starts to Fight Insider Trading Claims
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — The onetime Brazilian billionaire Eike Batista has begun his formal defense against the insider trading allegations brought by Brazil’s main securities regulator.

headline: A Song of the Country With Frog Chorus
text: After 9/11, Audra McDonald no longer felt safe living in New York City. “I had recently given birth, was still quite hormonal and, like everyone else, I was frightened,” recalled Ms. McDonald, now 43, and a Tony Award nominee for her starring role in the Broadway show “Lady Day at Emerson’s Bar & Grill.” “And I kept saying to my husband ‘we have to leave the city, we have to leave the city.’ ”

headline: At Least You Don’t Have to Buy a Gift
text: The son of a very close friend is getting married. My husband and I were not invited. My friend claims that the young couple is paying for the wedding themselves, that money is tight and that even relatives had to be excluded. But I know my friend invited some of her college friends. I have let her know that I will be hurt if I am not included. She seems embarrassed, and I don’t think she wants to lose my friendship, yet I remain uninvited. I’m afraid that I won’t feel the same about her after the wedding. What’s the best way to handle this?

headline: 36 Hours in Washington, D.C.
text: While most Americans associate Capitol Hill with Congressional misadventures and general dysfunction, thousands of people — senators, reporters, congressional aides, artists, working-class long-timers and young families — call it home. Amid the charming rowhouses and grand federal buildings, Capitol Hill is dotted with restaurants and night spots. Its history is vibrant and largely accessible, from the United States Capitol to the Navy Yard, where the banks of the Anacostia River were once lined with military ships, to dynamic H Street, the site of riots after the 1968 assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. And don’t forget baseball. Take in a Nationals game, if possible, among cheering fans and very good stadium chow.

headline: Clip: ‘Words and Pictures’
text: Juliette Binoche in a painting sequence from the film.

headline: British Cede Le Brun Portrait to the Met
text: In 17th-century France, Charles Le Brun was as hot as any artist could be. He created work for the Cathedral of Notre-Dame in Paris, for the Galerie d’Apollon in the Louvre, for Hôtel Lambert on Île St. Louis, for the Château de Vaux-le-Vicomte and for much of Versailles. Louis XIV declared him “the greatest French artist of all time.” Whatever he produced made an impact.

headline: Two Palestinians Killed in Clashes With Israeli Forces
text: JERUSALEM — Two young Palestinian men were killed Thursday in clashes with Israeli security forces during a demonstration for Nakba Day, which commemorates the destruction of Arab villages in battles that led to the establishment of the State of Israel in 1948.

headline: Love, Sex, Marriage and Schopenhauer’s Ghost
text: “The next Proust” is the dubious marketing tag applied to Xavier Rousseau (Romain Duris), a flighty, footloose novelist, by his editor in “Chinese Puzzle,” the French filmmaker Cédric Klapisch’s airborne romantic comedy. So what if there is nothing remotely Proustian about Xavier, the womanizing charmer with an idiot grin from two earlier films — “L’Auberge Espagnole” and “Russian Dolls” — also written and directed by Mr. Klapisch. Xavier, like the other returning characters from those movies, is about to turn 40. But in his carefree attitude, he might as well be 25.

headline: Robert Heinecken, Master of the Photographic Juxtaposition
text: Robert Heinecken is having a posthumous resurgence. The artist — who founded the UCLA photography department and famously described himself as a “para-photographer,” generated photographic images without using a camera — has an exhibition called “Object Matter” at MoMA through Sept. 7, his first since his death in 2006. A second show, “I Am Involved in Learning to Perceive and Use Light,” opens tonight at Petzel Gallery and runs through June 21. The title is taken from a 1974 essay by the artist, which the gallery offers in lieu of a press release. In it, he discusses his intentions, methodologies and views on aesthetic value systems. “My basic tenet is relatively simple,” he explains. “To relate the former to the future, the last to the next.” Heinecken carries out this philosophy quite literally in one of the best known strands of his practice, a related series of double exposures made from the 1960s to the 1990s, in which he culled current events and women’s magazines to find individual pages containing two faces that made unforgettable figurative abstractions when overlaid.

headline: Life in the City as a Jazzy Medley of Movie Themes and Show Tunes
text: A thematically organized social history of New York City told through several decades of movie songs is the concept of Joanne Tatham’s tourist-friendly cabaret show “Soundtrack New York,” heard at the Metropolitan Room on Tuesday evening.

headline: Illuminating and Elevating What Is Familiar
text: Eight members of the St. Luke’s Chamber Ensemble played at the Morgan Library & Museum on Wednesday evening, but one kept catching the ear: the violinist Krista Bennion Feeney. Keen throughout, she followed the intermission with a riveting rendition of the Sonata in C from Jean-Marie Leclair’s “Quatrième Livre de Sonates.”

headline: A Mischievous Half-Smile, Cloaked in Mystery
text: In the midst of a frantic week of art fairs and auctions, a splendid Renaissance portrait made a quiet and dignified entrance at the Frick. Parmigianino’s “Schiava Turca,” a painting of an unidentified woman with twinkling hazel eyes and a mischievous half-smile, invites us to settle in for a restorative session of close looking.

text: 303 Gallery

text: Miguel Abreu Gallery

headline: Highlights and Milestones: Derek Jeter
text: The longtime Yankees shortstop is in his 20th and final season. His many milestones and career highlights are compiled here with related video, and articles and photos from the Times archive.

headline: Rackspace Hires Morgan Stanley to Explore Options
text: Rackspace Hosting, a web-hosting company with a market value of more than $4 billion, has hired Morgan Stanley to evaluate a sale or other strategic options, after being approached by potential suitors.

headline: Paul Taylor Sells Four Rauschenbergs at Sotheby’s
text: Four works of modern art were sold so that many works of modern dance could continue to be performed: the choreographer Paul Taylor sold four of his Robert Rauschenberg pieces on Wednesday and Thursday to help pay for the new center of modern dance he is creating.

headline: Somber Ceremony for Museum Dedication
text: President Obama, former President Bill Clinton and two former mayors, Michael R. Bloomberg and Rudolph W. Giuliani, attended the ceremony at the National September 11 Memorial Museum.

headline: The Internet Isn’t Just for the Young
text: Early in the documentary “Cyber-Seniors,” you might find yourself saying, “Ugh, are they really going to make me watch octogenarians poke fruitlessly at laptops for 75 minutes?” But the film soon stops that torture and becomes a likable intergenerational tale with a bit of unexpected pathos.

headline: Astorino, at G.O.P. Convention, Vows ‘Fight to Save New York’
text: RYE BROOK, N.Y. — Rob Astorino, the Westchester County executive, accepted the Republican Party’s designation to run for governor on Thursday and painted a bleak picture of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s tenure as marked by economic doldrums, stifling taxes and a lack of political courage.

headline: Tilting at Genres
text: DON PEYOTE

headline: Musicians on Speed Dates
text: James Carter, a wildly charismatic tenor saxophonist, and Petra Haden, an equally irrepressible vocalist, had a moment halfway through “A Night of Improvised Round Robin Duets,” at Town Hall on Wednesday. It started almost songlike, with a haunting, wordless vocal melody answered by a limpid saxophone obbligato.

headline: Mirror Images, From Real Life or Fun House
text: The idea is often dismissed today, but one mandate of art is to reflect how we live. I’m not talking about the flat mirrors of nostalgia polished and perfected by Norman Rockwell and Andrew Wyeth — a jagged shard of broken glass is just fine to gaze into — but rather art we can stare in the eye and say, “Yeah, that kind of looks like me.”

headline: Should Young Children Learn Coding?
Cannes Film Festival: Major Deal for Denis Villeneuve Film
text: CANNES, France — In the first major sale at this year’s Cannes Film Festival, Paramount Pictures announced on Thursday that it had acquired distribution rights to “Story of Your Life,” a science-fiction blowout directed by Denis Villeneuve and starring Amy Adams as a linguist hired by the military to determine the intentions of alien spacecraft that have landed on Earth.

headline: Grandes Dames of the Gardens
text: If you start your sojourn through the New York Botanical Garden’s multipart “Groundbreakers” exhibition as you are meant to — looking at a show about photography in the gallery next to the library — then when you finally reach the conservatory displays, you will feel overwhelmed by a mosaic of color, texture and pattern, a fragrant allée of floral extravagance.

headline: Bringing the Wisdom of Middle Age to Punk
text: ASBURY PARK, N.J. — “Life’s rotten,” reasoned Off!’s frontman, Keith Morris, small and bothered, crease-faced, dreadlocked, pacing. This was somewhere around the middle of a 50-minute, 22-song set on Monday night at Asbury Lanes, a bar and bowling alley here with low ceilings and focused sound. And this was his version of crowd riling: bad news first, then a suggestion. “So” he continued, “while you’re out there being abused, used, being treated unfairly, have fun and enjoy yourselves.”

headline: She’s Just Off the Boat. He’s the Wrong Man.
text: In American popular culture, and in the private lore of millions of American families, the immigrant experience of the late-19th and early 20th centuries is often presented as a chronicle of struggle and triumph, a parable of dreams come true. In “The Immigrant,” James Gray (who directed the film and wrote it with Richard Menello) tries to push through this rosy nostalgia and recapture some of the terror and strangeness of the journey from the Old World to the New. The first shot is of the Statue of Liberty shrouded in harbor mist, and the film unfolds in the gap between the promise that lady embodies and the harsh realities a newcomer encounters once she gets off the boat.

headline: See Me. Feel Me. Maybe Drool on Me.
text: The Museum of Modern Art’s sprawling survey of the work of the influential Brazilian artist Lygia Clark has a singularly unpromising title: “Lygia Clark: The Abandonment of Art, 1948-1988” signals something of a letdown, especially if you like art. But once you’ve worked your way through this up-and-down massing of some 300 works, equally fitting and less stark alternatives may come to mind, including “the expansion of art” and “the internalization of art.”

text: To the Editor:

headline: Edie Falco: Meditate. Then It’s Time to Play.
text: For Edie Falco, star of the Showtime series “Nurse Jackie,” Sunday is a day for “free-floating time” with her son, Anderson, 9, and her daughter, Macy, 6. The children’s godfathers may pay a visit. There may be a movie or a play. There’s usually a meditation class. Ms. Falco, 50, has won four Emmys, one for “Nurse Jackie” and three for her role as Carmela Soprano in “The Sopranos.” A single mother, she lives in the West Village with her children and the family’s rescue dog, Sami, a Brussels griffon. Ms. Falco often rides around town on her electric bike.

headline: Charging Into the Minefield of Genes and Racial Difference
text: Few areas of science have contributed more to human misery than the study of racial difference. In the 1920s, eugenicists from top American universities promoted the sterilization of the unfit and later praised Hitler’s racial codes while advocating laws that would exclude thousands of Jews from our shores.

headline: Ideology and the Court
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pace University to Start Performing Arts School
text: Pace University is starting a performing arts school, which the university said will be Manhattan’s first new such school in nearly 50 years. The new school, Pace School of Performing Arts, grew out of Pace’s performing arts program.

headline: A Meal Schedule for Diabetes
text: For people with Type 2 diabetes, eating two large meals a day may be better than consuming the same number of calories in six small meals.

headline: Sommeliers Decanting the Madness of Cannes
text: CANNES — They know how to put on a good show at the Cannes Film Festival, even when forced to make do with an opening-night dud and the lack of a closing-night selection. No matter how serious and aesthetically high-minded, the festival always banks on its stars. This year Quentin Tarantino will help wrap up the proceedings by introducing a restoration of Sergio Leone’s 1964 red-sauce western, “A Fistful of Dollars.” It’s a celebrity event that will bookend the one delivered on Wednesday, when Nicole Kidman — the star of the widely derided “Grace of Monaco” — drifted down the red carpet, reprising her familiar role as a supernova who transcends her every stinker.

headline: A Balanchine Double Bill, With Heart-Stopping Pauses
text: The choreographer George Balanchine is seldom listed among the 20th century’s great dramatists, and yet many of his ballets take us as close to the essence of drama as any playwright. What’s more, few theater artists have anything of his vast expressive range.

headline: Events in Westchester for May 18-24, 2014
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Reading Experience May Change the Brains of Dyslexic Students
text: Among the many challenges faced by children with dyslexia (and by their parents and teachers) is the nagging fear that their difficulties with reading are entirely hard-wired: predetermined by their genes and impossible to change. Recent research offers a balm for that fear. It suggests that experience plays a big role in dyslexia, both in exacerbating reading problems and, potentially, in easing them.

headline: Arrests Made in Assault on Park Redwood Trees
text: Earlier this year I wrote about a spate of criminal assaults on redwood trees in a California park — all targeting the bulbous growths called burls that are prized by woodworkers and furniture makers.

headline: Challenging Authority and Taking the Heat
text: Part of the reason the Chinese artist Ai Weiwei — the subject of a current exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum and of the Danish filmmaker Andreas Johnsen’s new documentary, “The Fake Case” — is such an intriguing figure is that his recent career feels like the latest battle in the very old war between the imagination and the state. Especially since 2008, when the aftermath of the Chengdu earthquake in Western China awakened his conscience and made him a determined critic of his government, Mr. Ai has taunted, mocked and passionately denounced the authoritarianism, corruption and incompetence that he sees around him. He has made more-or-less conventional works of art reflecting these concerns, and made deft use of social media and his own celebrity.

headline: Ireland’s Troubled Peace
text: FORTY years ago this Saturday, three no-warning bombs ripped through Dublin. Less than an hour later, another bomb shattered the rural quiet of the town of Monaghan. In all, 33 people were killed and more than 300 injured. In Dublin, sheets of newspaper were laid over the dismembered bodies to hide them from view. The headlines soaked up the blood: the news in advance.

headline: Theater Listings for May 16-22
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Hapless Meal Tickets, Plucked From India
text: “Baseball isn’t just about business. You should have fun, too.”

headline: Attending Life’s First Breath and Its Last
text: Frankly, “The American Nurse” sounded unpromising. When Carolyn Jones, the director, had breast cancer, she was so touched by the nursing care she received that she wanted to pay tribute to the profession. Sweet, understandable, admirable. But you sort of want to say, Why not just send them a card? Ms. Jones, however, has delivered a solid, worthwhile documentary. If the film is workmanlike at times, it is also elegantly cleareyed.

headline: Clip: ‘Million Dollar Arm’
text: A scene from the film.

headline: Clip: ‘The Discoverers’
text: A scene from the film directed by Justin Schwarz.

headline: At SALT Conference, Stocks Induce Anxiety
text: LAS VEGAS — At the the SkyBridge Alternatives Conference here, hedge fund managers are gathering at the Bellagio hotel to exchange views and ideas.

headline: What Lewis and Clark Inspired
text: On paper, “The Discoverers” sounds like “National Lampoon’s Vacation” crossed with a self-help manual. Lewis (Griffin Dunne) is a struggling history professor in Chicago who, à la Grady Tripp in “Wonder Boys,” is preparing to publish a nearly 7,000-page tome. In the sort of excursion that might generously be described as a getaway, he piles his teenage kids, Zoe (Madeleine Martin) and Jack (Devon Graye), into the car, bound for a conference in Portland, Ore. The road trip’s destination suddenly changes when Lewis’s mother takes a turn for the worse.

headline: Coke and McDonald’s, Growing Together Since 1955
text: It was early 1955 when Ray Kroc, an ambitious milkshake equipment salesman who had bought the right to expand McDonald’s throughout the country, was opening his first restaurant, in Des Plaines, Ill.

headline: Alzheimer’s, a Neglected Epidemic
text: The opening shots of “The Normal Heart,” HBO’s adaptation of Larry Kramer’s 1985 play about the early days of the AIDS crisis in New York, reveal a crew of sinewy and amorous young men disembarking from a ferry on Fire Island on a beautiful July day in 1981. The tableau is meant to suggest the final hour of unburdened desire, the moment before so much youth and beauty would be sacrificed to the cruelest attacks of physiology and cultural indifference.

headline: Remastering, Reflecting: Everything Still Turns to Gold
text: In Boston last week to deliver the commencement address at the Berklee College of Music, Jimmy Page, the founder of Led Zeppelin, learned to his surprise that the school had a course in which his guitar licks were minutely analyzed. “They go into all these things and deconstruct them,” he said, “the harmonies and the voicings and the progressions, the arrangements.”

headline: It Was Open Mike at the Upfront Events
text: HERE is a look at some highlights, lowlights and sidelights of upfront week, which took place from Monday through Thursday as television executives offered Madison Avenue previews of their schedules for the 2014-15 season.

headline: In Nigeria, the Personal and the Political Clash
text: Perhaps the greatest challenge faced by literary adaptations that juxtapose a small group of characters against a seismic backdrop — “Doctor Zhivago,” say, or “The Leopard” — is one of proportion. “Half of a Yellow Sun,” adapted from the 2006 novel by Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie, emerges on screen as a well-acted, finely wrought epic that nevertheless struggles to balance the requirements of melodrama with its drive to capture a historical moment. The movie could easily have been a mini-series, but at just under two hours, it plays like a highlight reel.

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: Pepsi Challenges Coke in the Race to Design a More Tappable Soda Fountain
text: Thanks to new weaponry built with touch screens, Italian design and the latest technology, the cola wars are returning to an old battleground, the soda fountain.

headline: Providing for the Dead
text: Gary Gotlin emerged from his black BMW on Monday at a Staten Island cemetery and approached 10 small white coffins, each topped with a bouquet.

headline: Searching for Quality in Assisted Living Care
text: FINDING the right assisted living option for a family member can be a daunting task, and it’s not always easy to find data about the quality of various facilities.

headline: Texas Chases New Business but Worries About Water
Obamas Had Up to $7 Million in Assets in ’13, Records Show
text: The assets of President Obama and his wife, Michelle, were valued as high as $7 million last year, according to a financial disclosure form released by the White House on Thursday.

headline: Mourners Attend a Mass Burial
text: Hundreds of mourners attended a mass burial for some of the miners killed in the Turkey coal mine disaster.

headline: On the Range, With a Conscience
text: As Kirk Hanna did in life, Mitch Dickman’s documentary “Hanna Ranch” wrestles with ecological concerns. But the biggest problems for Mr. Hanna were very, very human. This Colorado cattle rancher — a featured personality in Eric Schlosser’s 2001 best seller “Fast Food Nation” — was a forward-thinking cowboy who embraced Holistic Resource Management, a fruitful approach that, among other things, encourages herding methods less stressful to cattle and a more frequent rotation of livestock through pastures. Mr. Hanna used earth-friendly natural fertilizer; to attack weeds, he employed hungry goats.

headline: This Week’s Movies | May 16, 2014
text: The New York Times film critics review “Godzilla,” “The Immigrant” and “Million Dollar Arm.”

headline: A Menace Who Chops Up Bodies and Enjoys a Good Singalong
text: With “Wolf Creek 2,” the director Greg McLean returns once more to remind us that the back of beyond — in this case, the Australian outback — is a perilous destination for unwary tourists. But those of us who championed its 2005 precursor, the artfully petrifying “Wolf Creek,” neither need nor want reminding. Like Neil Marshall’s “The Descent,” another crazy-good frightener released in America the following year, “Wolf Creek” deserved to stand alone, a uniquely moody and melancholy blood bath.

headline: Foreclosed, Cantankerous and Heading South
text: Robert Duvall won his Oscar for his finely calibrated portrayal of a recovering alcoholic country singer in “Tender Mercies,” and much of his best work is in service to nuanced roles. Yet his most memorable performances also include some where he goes big, as in, for example, the napalm-loving Lt. Col. Bill Kilgore in “Apocalypse Now.” When he has fun, he lets us in on it.

headline: A Depressed Writer, Distracted by His Ailing Parents
text: Though he’s played a committed writer on television (“October Road”), Bryan Greenberg doesn’t always come across as one in Michael Maren’s “A Short History of Decay.” That makes some sense, as Mr. Greenberg’s 30-something character, Nathan, just switched from being a struggling novelist to being an inactive playwright. But the best parts of Mr. Maren’s well-observed film aren’t always to be found in its accessible setup.

headline: After an Accident, a Test of Forgiveness
text: Atsushi Funahashi’s gloomy drama takes place in a depressed industry town in the aftermath of the 2011 earthquake and tsunami. But the hand of misfortune has yet one more blow in store, as Shiori, who works in a small factory, loses her husband, Kenji, to an accident. A pall is cast over life, felt in her stunned grief and in a dim workplace resembling a cluttered supply closet.

headline: The Thin Line Between a Pest and a Reformer
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: Reports of Gas Odors Surge After East Harlem Blast
text: After an explosion leveled two apartment buildings in East Harlem in March, killing eight people, officials of Consolidated Edison were exasperated that nobody had sounded an alarm until it was too late.

headline: The Case for ‘Soft Atheism’
text: This is the sixth in a series of interviews about religion that I am conducting for The Stone. The interviewee for this installment is Philip Kitcher, a professor of philosophy at Columbia University and the author of the forthcoming book “Life After Faith: The Case for Secular Humanism.”

headline: Telling the Gypsies’ Tale Beyond the Stereotype
text: The subtitle to the documentary “A People Uncounted” — “The Untold Story of the Roma” — might lead you to expect a historical overview of the people known as the Roma, or Gypsies. It’s a fascinating culture, which migrated to Europe from Northern India 1,000 years ago. The word “Gypsy,” derived from “Egyptian,” is a misnomer; equally misleading is a stereotype of joyfully itinerant musicians, dancers and petty thieves that persists in opera, literature, pop hits and movies.

headline: N.B.A.’s Replay Controversies Could Lead to a Review
text: LOS ANGELES — Clippers forward Matt Barnes was parked in front of the television at home Wednesday night, watching the end of the Nets-Miami Heat game while his twin 5-year-old boys busied themselves wrestling.

headline: Travelers Move Past Their Own Limits
text: Traditions may vary, but Passover Seders typically end with the wish that the participants might celebrate again “next year in Jerusalem.” For eight pilgrims from the Jewish Home for the Elderly in Fairfield, Conn. — average age, 91 — next year was 2011, when they toured Israel, along with nursing aides, administrators and a film crew.

headline: Divergent Paths
text: As economies in Northern Europe show signs of improvement, the southern rim nations continue to struggle. The uneven nature of the recovery has weighed on the overall European economy, which will probably take years to truly recover.

headline: Full Recovery Still Years Away for Many in Euro Zone
text: PARIS — Despite recent optimism that Europe’s economy is finally turning a corner, a stark reality remains: The situation is still fragile.

headline: F.C.C. to Help Small Firms Buy Airwaves
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Communications Commission on Thursday adopted new rules governing coming auctions of airwaves for use in mobile broadband, and the agency said it would set aside certain portions of the airwaves for purchase by smaller wireless companies.

headline: News Groups Sue for Data on Missouri’s Executions
text: A group of news organizations sued the Missouri Department of Corrections on Thursday, arguing that the department is violating the First Amendment by refusing to identify the sources of lethal drugs used in its executions.

headline: Points of No Return
text: Recently two research teams, working independently and using different methods, reached an alarming conclusion: The West Antarctic ice sheet is doomed. The sheet’s slide into the ocean, and the resulting sharp rise in sea levels, will probably happen slowly. But it’s irreversible. Even if we took drastic action to limit global warming right now, this particular process of environmental change has reached a point of no return.

headline: M.T.A. Expanding Weekend Service on the L Line to Handle Growing Crowds
text: The math problem of the New York City subway system is no secret, its remainders spilling onto the platforms where luckless travelers watch full trains come and go.

headline: For 160 Years, Always Something New
text: At the Brooklyn Women’s Exchange, a nonprofit, volunteer-run shop selling handmade wares, the atmosphere is instantly soothing. Rows of baby sweaters in Jordan almond colors hang neatly on a rack. A gangly trio of stuffed rabbits shares table space with a stack of crocheted blankets. Nat King Cole music plays softly in the background. Two volunteers murmur to each other as they sort through a pile of tiny hand-knit bootees in pastel green, lemon and pink. The scent of lavender wafts delicately from the soap display. Call it retail tonic.

headline: AIDS Groups Back Anti-H.I.V. Pill Amid Concerns Doctors and Patients Will Resist
text: Despite new federal guidelines urging gay men and others to take a daily pill to prevent AIDS, the idea may prove a tough sell to many doctors and patients.

headline: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,307 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: Times Seeks to Reassure Its Staff After Abramson’s Ouster
text: A day after The New York Times Company announced that it had dismissed Jill Abramson, The Times’s first female executive editor, it found itself mired in controversy, having to reassure employees and rebut reports that her removal was related to her complaints about receiving less pay than her male predecessors.

headline: The Man in a Red Bandanna
text: Among the many moving moments at the dedication of the National September 11 Memorial Museum in Lower Manhattan on Thursday was a story President Obama told about the man in a red bandanna. Bewildered and frightened, the people huddled in the smoke and darkness that day on the 78th floor of the World Trade Center’s south tower heard a voice, clear and calm, leading them to the stairs and to safety. Their guide was a young man holding a red handkerchief over his face.

headline: Spare Times for May 16-22
text: Dance Parade and Festival (Saturday) Why walk down Broadway when you can twist, pirouette and boogie down the thoroughfare with thousands of other quick-stepping souls during this annual free dance celebration? More than 150 groups, demonstrating over 75 styles of dance traditional and contemporary, will be among the professional and amateur hoofers bounding their way from 21st Street to Tompkins Square Park. Setting feet in motion at 1 p.m. will be a ribbon cutting by the event’s grand marshals, the tapper Savion Glover; Jawole Willa Jo Zollar, the artistic director of the Urban Bush Women; and the D.J. and producer Hex Hector. The fun continues in the park from 3 p.m., with performances and lessons. Participants at last year’s spectacle included local members of the Fraternidad Folklórica y Cultural Caporales Universitarios de San Simon, demonstrating Bolivian moves, and the NYC Bhangra Dance Company, displaying Indian styles. The event is free for individuals, but registration is required for participants. Information is at danceparade.org. Now go shine those dancing shoes. (Anne Mancuso)

headline: Classical Music Listings for May 16-22
text: ★ Argento Chamber Ensemble  (Friday and Sunday) This excellent group offers works exploring the possibilities of different instruments, with music for piano, clarinet, viola and voice by Aaron Helgeson, Aaron Einbond, David Fulmer, Berg and Sebastian Currier. Friday at 7:30 p.m., Sunday at 4 p.m., Austrian Cultural Forum, 11 East 52nd Street, Manhattan, 212-319-5300, acfny.org; free, $10 suggested donation. (Schweitzer)

headline: At 9/11 Museum Dedication, Remembrance and Resilience
text: In a vast underground hall beside twisted and graffiti-adorned steel remnants of New York’s twin towers, President Obama and other dignitaries joined rescue workers and families of Sept. 11 victims Thursday to dedicate the new National September 11 Memorial Museum.

headline: Force-Feedings at Guantánamo
text: Nothing comes to light easily at the Guantánamo Bay military prison in Cuba where 154 detainees are held on suspicion of terrorist activities. Some have been incarcerated for more than a decade, in a legal limbo that remains a grave embarrassment to American justice.

headline: A Once-a-Day Pill to Prevent AIDS
text: Federal health officials are urging hundreds of thousands of healthy people at high risk of contracting AIDS to take a pill every day to protect themselves from the virus that causes it. The recommendation could help reduce the stubbornly high number of infections, which has held steady at 50,000 new infections a year in the United States. But the pill carries risks that must be addressed as well.

headline: Detroit Bankruptcy Deadline May Be Missed, Imperiling State Funds
text: The federal judge handling Detroit’s bankruptcy indicated on Thursday that the current timetable for finishing the case might be unrealistic given the many disputes outstanding, raising questions about whether Detroit can exit bankruptcy before the end of its emergency manager’s term.

headline: Japan Moves to Scale Back Postwar Restrictions on the Use of Military Power
text: PUSAN, South Korea — Prime Minister Shinzo Abe may be about to take one of his biggest steps yet to nudge Japan away from its postwar pacifism after a government advisory panel recommended Thursday that constitutional restrictions on the military be eased to allow Japanese forces to come to the aid of allied nations under attack.

headline: Searching for Fairness on the Internet
text: After weeks of being criticized for a proposal that would have divided the Internet into fast and slow lanes, the Federal Communications Commission put forward a new plan on Thursday. While more balanced than its earlier approach, the commission still seems to be leaning toward creating a two-tiered system that could discriminate against smaller companies and restrict consumer choice.

headline: Metro-North Takes Measures on Safety
text: For years, on-time performance figures flashed across monitors inside the offices of the Metro-North Railroad — a conspicuous reminder in an agency that prided itself on punctuality.

headline: Stairway to Wisdom
text: Let’s say you wanted to understand a social problem in depth. Let’s say you wanted to move from a dry, statistical understanding of a problem to a rich, humane one. How would you do it? What steps would you take on your climb toward understanding?

headline: ReBar Owner’s Arrest Is No Help for Ruined Wedding Plans
text: The owner of a popular restaurant and event space in Dumbo, Brooklyn, who abruptly closed the business last week amid rumors of financial difficulties, was arrested and charged with tax fraud and grand larceny on Thursday.

headline: As Jeter Is Honored, So Is His Routine
text: A year ago, Mariano Rivera was the toast of baseball, celebrated around the league for his remarkable career. In each city that he visited for the final time as a player, he would meet with stadium workers and fans in small gatherings hours before a game, and then soak up the adoration in on-field ceremonies to honor him.

headline: New York City Moves to Slow Growth of Popular Green-Cab Fleet
text: The administration of Mayor Bill de Blasio, whose campaign relied heavily on contributions from the yellow cab industry, signaled on Thursday that it would slow the growth of a rival taxi fleet intended to expand street-hail service outside Manhattan.

headline: Answers to Questions About New York
text: Q. There is an allée of trees near the Hudson in Riverside Park around 148th Street, and the trees have these little numbered discs on them. What are they for?

headline: A Decision That Helped Shape Michelle Obama
text: WASHINGTON — She was born into the segregated Chicago of the 1960s, when public schools actively resisted integration. But in 1975, the city, under pressure to comply with the landmark Supreme Court decision desegregating public schools, opened a racially integrated high school for high achievers that changed the young woman’s life.

headline: Spirituality, Poetry and Inequality
text: Captain Kidd helped build it. The organist and the organ builder once came to blows. It granted the land for what became Columbia University. Robert Fulton is buried there. Its yearly rent to the British crown was one peppercorn. “It” is Trinity Church in Lower Manhattan, now celebrated in “Trinity: Near and Far, Now and Then” (Trinity Wall Street).

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 15, 2014
F.D.A. Recommends Lower Dose of the Sleeping Pill Lunesta
text: WASHINGTON — The Food and Drug Administration announced Thursday that people prescribed the sleeping pill Lunesta should be starting with half the current recommended dose, part of the agency’s continuing effort to reduce sleep aids’ risky side effects, such as drowsiness while driving.

headline: Mideast Peace Effort Pauses to Let Failure Sink In
text: WASHINGTON — On May 2, a week after peace talks between Israel and the Palestinians fell apart, senior American diplomats gave an interview to a prominent Israeli journalist in which they said Israel’s aggressive pursuit of new Jewish settlements had sabotaged the negotiations.

headline: Barbara Walters’s Biggest Moments
text: A look back at the memorable interviews that Barbara Walters has done over her 50 years in television.

headline: Ex-N.F.L. Star Who Spoke Out for Women Is Accused of Being a Rapist
text: Darren Sharper, a former N.F.L. standout who won a Super Bowl with the New Orleans Saints, posed with his teenage daughter, his deep dimples framing his wide, bright white smile, her head leaning on his shoulder.

headline: In Colombia, an Election May Turn on a Dirty War
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — With the future of peace talks with Marxist rebels on the line, the presidential election in Colombia has suddenly turned nasty, with the main candidates and their backers leveling damning charges of payoffs from drug traffickers, illegal surveillance and even attempted murder.

headline: Indiana Seeks More Coverage for Poor, but Many Would Pay
text: WASHINGTON — The governor of Indiana, Mike Pence, on Thursday proposed using federal Medicaid funds available under the Affordable Care Act to expand a state health insurance program to cover an additional 350,000 low-income adults. But unlike traditional Medicaid, the plan would require many participants to make monthly contributions toward the cost of coverage.

headline: Mary Stewart, British Writer Who Spanned Genres, Dies at 97
text: Mary Stewart, the British author of romantic thrillers who jumped genres in her 50s to create an internationally best-selling trilogy of Merlin books, reimagining the Arthurian legend from a sorcerer’s point of view, died on May 9 at her home in the village of Loch Awe, on the west coast of Scotland. She was 97.

headline: M.L.B. Panel Beginning Search for Selig’s Successor
text: The announcement Thursday that Major League Baseball has created a succession committee is the latest sign that Commissioner Bud Selig might truly retire next January.

headline: Nancy Malone, Actress and TV Director, Dies at 79
text: Nancy Malone, a child model in the 1940s who became a successful actress as an adult before moving to the other side of the camera as a television producer and director at a time when few women in Hollywood held those positions, died on May 8 in Duarte, Calif. She was 79.

headline: What's Next for Net Neutrality?
text: What should we expect from the F.C.C.'s new rules to regulate Internet providers, and what does the future hold for network neutrality?

text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — There is one place where Henrik Lundqvist is not King, and that is Montreal, where the Rangers will open the Eastern Conference finals on Saturday afternoon.

text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — The way this solve went for me was: Top, then bottom, and I wound up saving the middle for last. I’m glad I did.

text: Secretary of Veterans Affairs Eric Shinseki spoke to reporters after a hearing on Capitol Hill.

text: Poachers and dangerous conditions make it hard for those trained and licensed to collect the expensive treat.

text: A CORUÑA, Spain — Roberto Mahia, 44, was leaning against his car waiting for the sun to rise before pulling on the frayed wet suit at his feet when two vehicles pulled up not far away.

headline: Possible Deal May Bring Money to Repair Pier 40 in Manhattan
text: For years, Hudson River Park officials have tried to generate funds to repair Pier 40, the dilapidated former cargo terminal at the foot of West Houston Street, by proposing an odd succession of projects on the pier: a professional soccer stadium, a $600 million entertainment complex and residential towers.

headline: Facing Roster Questions, Nets Enter Off-Season With a Focus on Continuity
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Now that the business of playing basketball games is over, the Nets will tackle a rapidly growing off-season to-do list.

headline: Beltran Put on D.L. With Elbow Injury
text: Hoping to avoid a surgical procedure that could sideline him for two months, Yankees right fielder Carlos Beltran began taking cortisone orally on Thursday to augment the cortisone injection he received in his right elbow Monday.

headline: Live-Blogging the Vote Count in India
text: Over five weeks and nine phases, 550 million votes were cast in the massive Indian parliamentary elections that will usher in a new government. On Friday, India Ink followed the vote count with regular updates.

headline: Runoff Near, Debate Shifts to a New Set of Issues
text: During the five-way race in the Republican primary to represent a 12-county Hill Country district in the Texas House, two candidates, Rob Henneke and Andrew Murr, largely focused on the state’s water policy and ensuring local control of decisions on education and infrastructure.

headline: Sterling Tells N.B.A. He Will Not Pay Fine
text: Donald Sterling, the embattled owner of the Los Angeles Clippers who expressed contrition this week for making racist comments, does not plan to go away quietly.

headline: Brazil: Troops Deployed to Restore Calm
text: Federal officials on Thursday sent troops to Pernambuco State in northeast Brazil as reports of looting heightened fears that crime could surge during a strike by police officers. Seeking to calm residents, the unspecified number of troops began patrolling cities, including Recife, one of the hosts of the World Cup soccer tournament in June. The police strike in Pernambuco is part of a broader wave of strikes and protests in several large cities around Brazil this month as labor unions representing teachers, bus drivers and street cleaners seek wage increases. Police unions across the country said they were considering a one-day strike next week. Separately, protests against Brazil’s spending on World Cup stadiums drew thousands into the streets on Thursday in São Paulo and other cities.

headline: Iran: Oil Exports Continue to Decline
text: Iran’s oil exports declined in April for the second consecutive month, the International Energy Agency reported Thursday, moving much closer to levels permitted under a temporary accord on the Iranian nuclear dispute that is set to expire in July. Monthly data compiled by the energy agency, a 29-member group of oil importers, showed that Iran’s exports were 1.11 million barrels a day in April, down from 1.29 million barrels a day in March and 1.58 million barrels a day in February. The temporary accord specified that Iran’s monthly oil exports are not to exceed one million barrels a day on average for the six-month duration, and the excesses raised concern among critics of the accord that Iran was violating its terms. Obama administration officials have said they believe that Iran’s May, June and July exports will be lower. Under the accord, some Western economic sanctions were eased in exchange for a freeze on most of Iran’s nuclear activities, for the purpose of giving negotiators more time to reach a permanent agreement. Negotiators for the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council plus Germany are seeking guarantees that Iran’s nuclear fuel cannot be used to make bombs.

headline: Afghanistan: U.S. Repatriates Pakistanis
text: The American military has repatriated 10 Pakistani prisoners whom it had held at Bagram Air Base in Afghanistan. The transfer of the detainees to Pakistani custody was announced by the Justice Project Pakistan, which represents Pakistani detainees at Bagram. It said the International Committee of the Red Cross had told the men’s families about the move. An American official familiar with the matter confirmed Thursday that the transfers had taken place. The military has already transferred to Afghan control the bulk of Afghan prisoners at Bagram but has retained custody of “third country nationals,” whom the Afghan government does not want to deal with. The transfers reduce the number of those prisoners to 39, according to the official. More than two dozen of them are Pakistani. Some of those just released will be detained in Pakistan, while others will be released but subject to monitoring, the official said.

headline: In Rookie Duel, a Met Gets a Loss, and a Hit
text: The first 39 games of the baseball season had already taken their toll on the Yankees and the Mets, and the first three games of the Subway Series had been emotional, exhausting affairs. The Mets had battered the Yankees at Yankee Stadium, and Masahiro Tanaka had stifled the Mets at Citi Field. Everyone seemed a bit woozy.

text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Cam Talbot grew up a Montreal Canadiens fan, watching every move of his idol, Patrick Roy. As a backup to Henrik Lundqvist this season, he has relished a front-row seat to goaltending greatness.

headline: Tale of School Integration Wins Children’s History Book Prize
text: Kristin Levine’s “Lions of Little Rock,” the story of a black girl and a white girl who become friends during the integration of that city’s schools in 1958, has been awarded the New-York Historical Society’s first children’s history book prize.

headline: Tracking Down the Deer Runner
text: Perhaps the biggest new idea in exercise research in recent years has been the endurance running hypothesis, the idea that as humans evolved, adaptations in our bones and muscles, along with an impressive ability to regulate our body temperature, made us good endurance runners. As a result, our ancestors were able to literally run down and kill game animals, providing the high-density calories and protein we needed to feed our ever-enlarging brains.

text: The tempo of corruption investigations in China is so rapid that the cases begin to blur. Pick up a paper and there will be a photo of an official in his better days, a list of alleged misdeeds and a tally of corrupt cash.

headline: Trading Danger for Delicacy
text: On Spain’s Galician coast, generations of licensed divers scrape gooseneck barnacles in roiling surf to serve eager gourmands who pay up to 100 euros a kilo for the cherished crustaceans.

headline: Narendra Modi’s Ambitious Agenda Will Face Difficult Obstacles
text: NEW DELHI — Addressing a euphoric crowd Friday afternoon, Narendra Modi rallied the public to join him in taking on challenges of a vast scale. He has floated the idea of building “a hundred new cities,” of extending a high-speed rail network across the subcontinent and undertaking the herculean task of cleaning the Ganges River.

headline: What’s On Friday
text: 9 P.M. (Starz) CAPTAIN PHILLIPS (2013) Tom Hanks, above, portrays Richard Phillips, the commander of the Maersk Alabama, an American container ship with a crew of 20 sailors and a cargo including supplies from the United Nations World Food Program, that was seized in the Indian Ocean in April 2009 by four armed Somalis. Barkhad Abdi, a first-time actor who received an Oscar nomination, plays Muse, their leader, whose actions lead to the arrival of the American military and its warships. “The existential realities that inform contemporary Somali piracy turn out to be one of the unexpected themes of ‘Captain Phillips,’ which begins as something of a procedural about men at work and morphs into a jittery thriller even as it also deepens, brilliantly, unexpectedly, into an unsettling look at global capitalism and American privilege and power,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times about this best picture nominee, adapted by the director Paul Greengrass from Mr. Phillips’s book, “A Captain’s Duty: Somali Pirates, Navy SEALS, and Dangerous Days at Sea.” “Phillips is unambiguously a heroic figure, but he’s scarcely the sole point of interest in a movie that steadily and almost stealthily asserts the agonized humanity of his captors.”

headline: One Day, One China, 2 Foreign Policy Views

Fang Fenghui, presented starkly different views of their country’s foreign policy.

headline: What Rules Would You Like to See Changed in Your Favorite Sports?
text: Golf holes the size of pizzas? Bigger courts and four-point shots in basketball? Two-hand touch instead of tackle football? Tradition and history play an important role in sports, but like anything else, games evolve to keep up with changing times.

headline: Latin America’s Mutating Cities, in Photographs
text: Evaporados — evaporated — is pasted in huge letters on an expressway wall in Lima, Peru. The artist Eduardo Villanes put them there in 1995, to protest the abduction and murder of nine university students and a professor by a military death squad, as well as the subsequent amnesty granted to the killers by Alberto Fujimori, Peru’s repressive and corrupt president.

headline: Public’s Outrage Over Mine Disaster Casts Harsh Light on Turkey’s Premier
text: SOMA, Turkey — There was no one to treat in the first aid tents near the entrance to the mine, where an old woman nearby wailed, “Our children are burning!” A man and his wife, dazed from a lack of sleep, walked the muddy grounds near here, looking for information about their missing son that no one in the government could provide.

headline: Democrats Have Advantage on Issues, but It Won’t Save Them in November
text: Democrats know they face a difficult midterm campaign landscape, but they can cling to one seeming reason for hope: The public agrees with them more than with Republicans on the issues.

headline: Where Are the Gay Chief Executives?
text: In corporate America, L.G.B.T. employees usually remain closeted.

headline: U.N. Finds Rising Human Rights Violations in Ukraine
text: GENEVA — Armed groups are increasingly undermining the rights and basic freedoms of people in eastern Ukraine, the United Nations said Friday, expressing concern at the rising number of killings, abductions, beatings and detentions of journalists, politicians and local activists.

headline: Daily Report: F.C.C. Advances Plan for Net Neutrality Rules
text: Federal regulators appear to share one view about so-called net neutrality: It is a good thing, Edward Wyatt reports.

headline: Betting That Quality Won’t Feel Old
text: The story behind the cover of this week’s Book Review began almost exactly a month ago, which is actually on the late side when it comes to determining Book Review covers. Because we close our subscriber issues 10 days before they hit newsstands, we often plan our covers months in advance. Given that we are covering books, which generally have a set publishing date, the “news” in the book world is known well in advance. This gives us the luxury of time in planning what we think will be the most powerful and compelling cover for each issue.

headline: Psst. Look Over Here.
text: Look inside your kitchen cabinet and odds are you have a collection of old friends gazing back at you — the Quaker Oats man, the Sun-Maid girl, Aunt Jemima and maybe a Keebler elf or two. The reason they are there may have more do with your subconscious craving for eye contact than the taste of the products.

headline: Big Breaks for Banks
text: BIG BREAKS FOR BANKS  |  If, as expected, two banking giants ‒ Credit Suisse and BNP Paribas ‒ plead guilty to criminal charges in the next few weeks, they will probably pay large fines and officially be felons, Floyd Norris writes in the High & Low Finance column. But, he asks, does it matter that these will be criminal, not civil, punishments? The issue is not that banks may be “too big to jail,” but that, big or small, banks and other corporations are “too inanimate to jail,” Mr. Norris writes.

headline: European Court Lets People Influence Web Search Results
text: The European Court of Justice ruled that Google search results should comply with individual’s right to be forgotten.

headline: Clippers Can’t Believe Their Surreal Season Has Ended
text: LOS ANGELES — One by one, the boulders had been stacked upon their shoulders in recent weeks. If it was not listening to the racist rant by their owner, Donald Sterling, it was wondering what to do about it — were black socks enough? Then there were the camera crews from CNN and TMZ at their practices.

headline: Actress, Artist, Sometimes Both at Once
text: In the new romantic comedy “Words and Pictures,” a rolling office chair becomes a tool for art creation. Juliette Binoche, playing an art teacher whose rheumatoid arthritis affects her ability to paint, lies on her stomach across the chair, grabs a paintbrush and swivels from one part to another of the canvas on the floor. Passion and pain become a part of each stroke, as Ms. Binoche both plays a visual artist and is one.

headline: Amazon vs. Hachette: When Does Discouragement Become Misrepresentation?
text: For months now, Amazon has been trying to put the screws on Hachette, the smallest of the Big Five publishers, by discouraging people from buying its printed books. Amazon’s goal: force Hachette to give it better terms on e-books.

headline: Nigerian Leader Cancels Visit to Village of Abducted Girls
text: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria — A first visit by President Goodluck Jonathan to the village from which nearly 300 girls were abducted by Boko Haram was abruptly canceled on Friday because of security fears, according to an official in the president’s entourage.

headline: Inside Kelly Wearstler’s Studio
text: The designer offers a tour of her Los Angeles studio, where she and her team dream up and bring to life everything in her eponymous line, from home wares to women’s accessories.

headline: Uighur Biker Takes Message of Peace on the Road
text: Dolkun Tunurganjan, 31, a Uighur from the western Chinese region of Xinjiang, is on a mission to promote ethnic harmony.

headline: Darden to Sell Red Lobster in a $2.1 Billion Deal
text: Updated, 8:19 p.m. | Investors argued publicly for months against Darden Restaurants’ plans to spin off Red Lobster, the 46-year-old seafood chain that was the root of the company’s dining empire.

headline: Ejected From the Doughnut Shop
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Made in L.A. | Step Inside Kelly Wearstler’s Sprawling Studio
text: “The key to success is organization,” says Kelly Wearstler. In this video, the designer offers a tour of her Los Angeles studio, where she and her team dream up and bring to life everything in her eponymous line, from home wares to women’s accessories. Having everything created in one place, she explains, encourages the kind of cross-pollination of ideas and inspiration that makes everything in her label, from bangles and scarves to napkins and side tables, feel laid-back yet luxurious — much like the designer herself.

headline: Abbott to Buy Latin American Drug Company for $2.9 Billion
text: Abbott Laboratories has agreed to buy a Chilean drug company for $2.9 billion, continuing a streak of major transactions in the health care sector this year.

headline: Chesapeake Energy to Spin Off Oil Services Unit
text: Chesapeake Energy said on Friday that it would shed of its oilfield services business as the company works to streamline itself.

headline: Ukraine’s Heart of Steel
text: In Mariupol, Ukraine, thousands of steelworkers patrol city streets, routing out pro-Russian militants who seized control several weeks ago.

headline: For Democrats, Texas Push Gets an Early Shove
text: SAN ANTONIO — The instructions seemed simple enough: Knock on your neighbors’ doors and tell them to vote for Wendy Davis in Texas’ election for governor.

headline: Unrest Poses a Risky Choice for Vietnam
text: HA TINH PROVINCE, Vietnam — The hundreds of men on motorbikes who roared into Lee Hsueh Ying’s factory compound north of Ho Chi Minh City were bent on revenge against China. Some clung to red-and-gold Vietnamese flags while they careened around overwhelmed security guards. And in a scene repeated elsewhere in the country’s industrial heartland, they destroyed the building, smashing furniture, snatching computers and shouting “Long Live Vietnam.”

headline: Housing Is Recovering. Single-Family Homes Aren’t.
text: The headlines in the new report on home building activity — which is being closely watched, after many other kinds of data point to a softening in housing — are pretty terrific.

headline: Explosions Kill 10 in Kenya as Western Embassies Warn of Threats
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — Twin explosions hit a market area in downtown Nairobi on Friday afternoon, killing 10 people and injuring 76 others, officials said, adding to a series of deadly attacks in the country in recent months.

headline: Garage Rock’s Latest Nerve Center
text: FULLERTON, Calif. — Eleven a.m. on a Tuesday: time for business to begin at Burger Records, if it ever really ends. The nerve center of fourth-wave garage rock — a record label and a store — is in a small, square space, slotted along with a vaping emporium and a tattoo parlor in a strip mall along a four-lane artery, near industrial parks, a food-service-equipment manufacturing plant and the Anaheim town line. It’s Orange County industrial suburbia, where most of what is visible — parking lots, buildings, grass allotments, signage, Dumpsters — has been city-planned into rectangles.

headline: What’s Next, a Bouncer?
text: When a playroom opened in Michael Reilly’s Upper West Side building two years ago, he asked the concierge for a key to the space so his toddler could play there. The concierge’s answer stunned him: It was out of bounds to him and his child.

headline: In Our Pages: May 17
text: 1889: Pensions Attacked

headline: A History of New York Traffic Lights
text: Tired of cars — and bikes — running red lights? How about no lights at all? That’s the kind of traffic system New York had until 1920, when a series of tall bare-bones towers went up down the middle of Fifth Avenue, flashing red and green lights to the growing onslaught of automobiles. Two years later they were replaced with formidably elegant bronze and granite towers, sumptuous contributions to the City Beautiful, but destroyed within a decade, victims of increasing traffic.

headline: On Mackinac Island, a Celebration of Lilacs
