text: To celebrate its ubiquitous and most fragrant summer blooms, Mackinac Island, Mich., will hold the 65th annual Lilac Festival from June 6 to 15.

headline: Consumer Debt Suggests Growing Confidence
text: CONSUMERS appear to be growing more confident and are less likely to be behind on their bills, according to figures released this week by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

headline: TV Critics Buddy Up for New Book
text: Whether it’s Felix and Oscar, Bert and Ernie, Cagney and Lacey or Simon and Simon, television has consistently provided a home for memorable duos. Now a pair of veteran television critics are partnering up to write a book that will examine various series while chronicling the six-decade history of the medium. Alan Sepinwall, of HitFix.com, and Matt Zoller Seitz, of New York magazine and Vulture.com, will collaborate on a book of essays for Grand Central Publishing about “the most artistically and culturally significant American dramas, comedies, mini-series, variety shows and more,” including hits like “Seinfeld” and “The Sopranos,” as well as cult favorites like “Freaks and Geeks” and “My So-Called Life,” the publisher said in an email.

headline: Upstate, and Back in Time
text: I followed the man off the river and into a labyrinth of creeks behind town, heading deeper into a thickening haze of marsh grass and listing trees. He paddled ahead in his green canoe while I trailed in my rowboat, picking my way around old dredging pipes and doubting that I’d find my way back out of this fractal backwater. Through the trees, worlds emerged: a tiny island of R.V.s, a string of vacation cottages, a far bank of empty-eyed concrete houses.

headline: Professor Simpson
text: Homer explains economics; Adam Silver vs. Silver Surfer.

headline: Scott Aukerman Goes Off-Script
text: The host of “Comedy Bang! Bang!” talks to Willy Staley about the virtues of improvisation, his fellow podcaster Marc Maron and the drudgery of Disneyland.

headline: Reply All: The 5.4.14 Issue
text: THE TALE OF TWO SCHOOLS

headline: Jane Kleeb vs. the Keystone Pipeline
text: Terry Van Housen had a question. What he wanted to know from the 30 or so other Nebraska farmers and ranchers gathered in February at the York Community Center was this: What do you do with 10,000 dead cows?

headline: Jack-and-Ginger, All Grown Up
text: I know I’m not the only one whose first mixed drink was a whiskey-ginger highball. For many, the go-to will always be Jack Daniels and ginger ale — the pleasingly alliterative “Jack” and “ginger” — which is a snap to make and still delicious after all these years.

headline: Who Made That Earbud?
text: In “Fahrenheit 451,” Ray Bradbury described a futuristic radio that could be worn inside the ear. It would be “a hidden wasp snug in its special pink warm nest,” he wrote, and the conduit for “an electronic ocean of sound, of music and talk and music and talk, coming in on the shore of [your] unsleeping mind.” That was more than 50 years ago, but it’s not a bad description of iPod headphones.

headline: Ivy League Degrees, Elite Consulting Jobs, and Now Tea Party Candidacies
text: WASHINGTON — Ben Sasse and Tom Cotton have a lot in common: Republican candidacies for the Senate, Ivy League advanced degrees — a Yale Ph.D. for Mr. Sasse, a Harvard law degree for Mr. Cotton — and a tour of duty in the white-shoe world of management consulting.

headline: Short-Seller Chanos Turns Attention to Valeant
text: Updated, 11:41 a.m. |

headline: G.M. Is Fined Over Safety and Called a Lawbreaker
text: WASHINGTON — Saying that safety practices at General Motors were “broken,” federal regulators on Friday imposed the biggest punishment they could on the automaker and condemned it over its failure to promptly report a defect that G.M. has linked to 13 deaths.

headline: Skills and Strategies | Photo Projects Inspired by ‘Humans of New York’
text: Do your students follow Humans of New York?

headline: Babe Ruth, Knocked Out
text: On a sunny July day in Washington, 90 years ago this July, the Yankees were in Griffith Stadium, playing a doubleheader against the Senators. In the fourth inning of the first game, before 24,000 fans, the home team’s Joe Judge swung his bat; the ball sailed just over the right-field line, heading toward the bleachers in foul territory.

headline: Opera Philadelphia Names Little as Composer in Residence
text: Opera Philadelphia, in a collaboration with Gotham Chamber Opera and the Music-Theater Group, in New York, has appointed the David T. Little as a composer in residence, a three-year position that begins on June 1. The program, which was started in 2011, includes a stipend and health benefits, and involves work with all three companies.

headline: Baghdad Is a Setting, and a Character, Too
text: BAGHDAD — ON an evening just a few days before his novel would win a top Arabic literary prize, Ahmed Saadawi was relaxing with his writer friends at a Baghdad cafe, a place so special to him that he had written it into his book.

headline: Chinese Developers Step Up
text: China-based businesses and investors have been buying into New York City condominiums, hotels and office towers for years, but more recently, these firms have stepped up to take the lead on several major city developments.

headline: Ransom Center Pays $2 Million for Ian McEwan Papers
text: The British novelist Ian McEwan has become the latest top-tier contemporary writer to have G.T.T. — or “Gone to Texas,” as an abbreviation in the rare book trade calls it.

headline: Always Hungry? Here’s Why
text: FOR most of the last century, our understanding of the cause of obesity has been based on immutable physical law. Specifically, it’s the first law of thermodynamics, which dictates that energy can neither be created nor destroyed. When it comes to body weight, this means that calorie intake minus calorie expenditure equals calories stored. Surrounded by tempting foods, we overeat, consuming more calories than we can burn off, and the excess is deposited as fat. The simple solution is to exert willpower and eat less.

headline: Itinerary | Cartagena’s Burgeoning Style Scene
text: The sultry city of Cartagena has for some time been a weekend destination for wealthy Colombians and in-the-know international globetrotters. They come to stroll the cobblestone streets lined with faded colonial homes, dance and drink rum at the always bustling Club Havana, and then sleep off their hangovers on the postcard-perfect beaches on the nearby islands. Recently, though, Cartagena has seen an influx of more stylish restaurants, shops and hotels (the Ritz Carlton and Four Seasons are coming soon), which can make the city worthy of a longer stay. And with a new, direct JetBlue flight available from New York, it’s more convenient than ever.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Godzilla’
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Godzilla.”

headline: The Week in Pictures for May 16
text: Subjects include the National September 11 Memorial Museum, the newly elected mayor of Newark, and a World War II plane embarking on a new mission.

headline: Deal for Zales May Be Done In by Bank of America’s Conflicts
text: Signet’s $1.4 billion acquisition of the Zale Corporation looks increasingly beleaguered in the wake of opposition by the investment group TIG Advisors, Zale’s second-largest shareholder.

headline: East Hampton: Secluded Showplace, $21.5 Million
text: A shingle-style house on 3.2 meticulously groomed acres just a short stroll from the pristine surf at Two Mile Hollow Beach in East Hampton Village is poised to enter the market at $21.5 million. Camouflaged by a berm with mature plantings, the two-story house sits on a bluff and is invisible from the road; its rooftop deck, dominated by a whimsical oversize cedar bench nicknamed “the Giant Lifeguard’s Chair,” has captivating views of the Atlantic Ocean.

headline: One Daughter, One Mother, Two Wheelchairs and Nothing Remarkable
text: While exchanging pleasantries with a woman selling peanut brittle at an open-air market on Mother’s Day, my mom and I were told that we’re really adorable.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘Bending Adversity’
text: This week, David Pilling discusses “Bending Adversity: Japan and the Art of Survival”; Parul Sehgal and John Williams on the week’s literary news; John Schwartz talks about the audiobooks of four new celebrity memoirs; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: In the White House, Debating How Far to Go in Easing Deportations
text: WASHINGTON — At a recent White House meeting with immigration activists, President Obama told the group his hands were tied. Even if he wanted to halt the deportations of millions of illegal immigrants, the president told the group, he could not do so without congressional approval.

headline: G.M. Consent Order Over Ignition Defect
text: Federal regulators announced that General Motors would pay $35 million in a civil settlement with the federal government over its failure to report in a timely manner a defective ignition switch in 2.6 million cars.

headline: Faith-based Freaks
text: Noah Smith isn’t very happy with Steve Levitt, who thinks he was being smart by telling David Cameron that he should scrap the NHS and let the magic of the marketplace deal with health care. Strangely, Cameron wasn’t impressed.

headline: The Bad Nurse
text: There are days I am not the woman I would like to be and when I am very lucky, they coincide with a new episode of “Nurse Jackie.”

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘Bending Adversity’
text: This week, David Pilling and John Schwartz.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Million Dollar Arm’
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Million Dollar Arm.”

headline: Top Horse, From a Place Winners Aren’t Made
text: COALINGA, Calif. — There is no bluegrass here or limestone fences framing postcard-ready landscapes. A drought has drained the San Joaquin Valley of any color other than beige. There is no mistaking the smell in the air, either: It is cow manure from the feedlot of California’s largest beef producer.

headline: Rising Sun
text: Three years ago this March, a 9-­magnitude earthquake, the strongest ever known to hit Japan, created a tsunami that killed more than 15,000 people outright, displaced hundreds of thousands more and removed entire villages from the map. By triggering the failure of the Fukushima nuclear plant, it also left the landscape contaminated and led to Japan’s curtailing of its nuclear-power system.

headline: An Incumbent Falls Afoul of Election Laws Designed to Protect Incumbents
text: Political pros know better than anyone that election laws are typically crafted by statehouse lawmakers with enough hedges, hurdles and moats to insulate party machines and shield incumbents against insurgent challengers. That’s the nature of the power game.

headline: Venerable Poetry and a Premiere
text: Vladimir Jurowski, principal conductor of the London Philharmonic Orchestra, will make his New York Philharmonic debut on Wednesday, conducting two colorful works. The excellent young violinist Janine Jansen will be the soloist in Szymanowski’s shimmering and sumptuous Violin Concerto No. 1, inspired by Tadeusz Micinski’s poem “May Night.” Also on the lineup are selections from Prokofiev’s ballet “Cinderella.” (7:30 p.m. Wednesday and Thursday, 2 p.m. Friday, 8 p.m. Saturday, Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, 212-875-5656, nyphil.org.)

headline: Prime-Time Slice of ‘Baloney!’
text: Fess up: who hasn’t gawked in awe as Judge Judith Sheindlin slaps sense into a freak show of ne’er-do-wells with rejoinders we only wish we had queued up: “Are you trying to justify to me that you are an idiot?” “Don’t try to teach a pig to sing. It doesn’t work, and it irritates the pig.” “Beauty fades. Dumb is forever.”

headline: A Polish Town, Before Its Infamy
text: Most people associate Auschwitz with the death camp. But it is also a town, Oswiecim, once home to a vibrant Jewish community in Poland. Now, the Museum of Jewish Heritage — A Living Memorial to the Holocaust in Lower Manhattan is examining that history in “A Town Known as Auschwitz: The Life and Death of a Jewish Community,” which explores how Jews and non-Jews coexisted peacefully in Oswiecim (Auschwitz was its German name) for centuries before World War II.

headline: Dance Music, With a Warning
text: Last August, two deaths from drug overdoses at the annual Electric Zoo dance-music festival on Randalls Island caused the cancellation of the event’s final day, a reminder of the difficulty of adequately overseeing these sprawling, loosely supervised events. Next Saturday and Sunday, the New York incarnation of the Electric Daisy Carnival, the signature brand in American dance music festivals, takes over MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., and will face the challenge of keeping tens of thousands of revelers safe. The music will take care of itself: The lineup includes pop-minded D.J.-producers like Calvin Harris and Afrojack; Steve Angello, one-third of the disbanded arena-house champs known as the Swedish House Mafia; the Chicago house legend Green Velvet; the pop aspirants Krewella; the teenage phenom Martin Garrix; and the French abrasionist DJ Snake. The festival’s website warns of “zero tolerance for drug use or possession.” Fingers crossed. (201-559-1515, electricdaisycarnival.com/newyork.)

headline: Long-Form Narratives, Without Words
text: We may be witnessing one sea change or several in full-length dance-theater productions. In the last 12 months, three of the world’s leading choreographers — Mark Morris, Alexei Ratmansky, Christopher Wheeldon — have staged new, important, mold-breaking, all-evening works. All three are flawed. But so are the ballets of “Swan Lake” and “Romeo and Juliet” (no matter which version you watch). The full-length “Swan Lake” took over 70 years before it became a mainstay of the international repertory. At what point does a new production turn into a hit, a war horse or a classic?

headline: Temptress Returns to Tweak His Cowl
text: Hey, fanboys, before the superhero glut implodes, toast those who set the 1990s standard: the crew behind “Batman: The Animated Series“ (and its spinoffs “Superman” and “Justice League”), in various TV incarnations from 1992 to 1999. Call it the Bruce W. Timm brain trust, after its producer and character designer; members included the writer Paul Dini and the voice director Andrea Romano. (And salute its writer Dwayne McDuffie, who died in 2011, and its composer Shirley Walker, who died in 2006.)

headline: Trolling the Past for Fresh Insights
text: The latest round of Danspace Project’s Platform series, which explores dance through the lens of a particular idea or theme, is dedicated to the work of the choreographer DD Dorvillier, who helped define contemporary dance beginning in the 1990s. For more than a decade Ms. Dorvillier lived and worked out of the Matzoh Factory, a loft she shared with the dancer and choreographer Jennifer Monson in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

headline: Stealth Lessons Sneak Up on Viewers
text: A tornado slams into Washington with winds exceeding 260 miles per hour. It topples the five-ton bronze statue at the Jefferson Memorial. It churns the roof of the Lincoln Memorial into a Cuisinart of broken glass and tile. It swiss-cheeses the Washington Monument. What will become of the Capitol? “The dome,” one expert predicts, “is toast.”

headline: His Music, Entwined With His Faith
text: “Religion guides all the processes in our lives, without us even knowing it,” the Estonian composer Arvo Pärt said in a recent phone interview. “It is true that religion has a very important role in my composition, but how it really works, I am not able to describe.”

headline: Movie Review: ‘The Immigrant’
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “The Immigrant.”

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Poetry Profiles: Wave Books
text: The latest in a series of occasional profiles of poetry publishers. These questions were answered by Joshua Beckman, editor at Wave Books, and Matthew Zapruder, Wave’s editor at large.

headline: Checking In on Burger Records
text: Jon Pareles and Ben Ratliff discuss Burger Records, the label, store and cultural phenomenon.

headline: Tom Colicchio, Citizen Chef
text: On a recent afternoon, the chef Tom Colicchio was sitting with his staff in his office, on East 19th Street in Manhattan, hashing out the details of the high-end hotel restaurant he plans to open this winter in Miami. What would he name the lobby bar? Would he serve small plates to bathers at the pool?

headline: Big Ticket | An Aerie With Park Views for $30.5 Million
text: One57, the Extell Development Company’s robust 90-story blue glass tower and billionaire magnet, already dominates the Midtown skyline, and in recent weeks has monopolized the city’s closed residential sales: Yet another of its 4,483-square-foot A-line units sold in excess of $30 million, and it was the most expensive sale of week, according to city records.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE SAVAGE WARS OF PEACE: Small Wars and the Rise of American Power,  by Max Boot. (Basic Books, $19.99.) Beginning with Thomas Jefferson’s expedition against the Barbary pirates, Boot, the author of “Invisible Armies,” traces America’s long history of bloody military operations in the name of nation-building and peacekeeping — in the Philippines, Haiti, Cuba and elsewhere. This revised edition includes a discussion of Iraq, Afghanistan and the lessons of the post-9/11 world.

headline: Today in Small Business: ‘Let’s Take This Offline’
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: In Brooklyn, Union Avenue Gets Built Up
text: Once a desolate strip hugged by slightly forbidding warehouses, factories and garages, Union Avenue just north of the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway has seen a significant transformation in recent years into the sort of glass-lined thoroughfare more typically found in trendier parts of Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: BOMBAY STORIES,  by Saadat Hasan Manto. Translated by Matt Reeck and Aftab Ahmad. (Vintage International, paper, $16.) Manto wrote most of these stories out of a longing for his old city, having moved to Pakistan after partition in 1947.

headline: Inside the List
text: Something Different: Fans of long-­running series can have a hard time letting go. When Arthur Conan Doyle tried to kill off Sherlock Holmes in 1893, readers objected so strenuously that Doyle — after trying to mollify them with a prequel — finally gave in and resurrected the character as a cross-dressing mixed martial artist played by Robert Downey Jr. More recently, Charlaine Harris has heard from readers livid at her 2013 novel “Dead Ever After,” which ended her beloved Sookie Stackhouse urban fantasy series (the basis for the HBO show “True Blood”). “I had death threats, and people putting curses on me,” she said in a recent phone conversation. “All the usual stuff.” But Sookie is well and truly finished, Harris insists: “She’s in my rearview mirror. It was not a hard choice. Of course, it’s a little scary when you’re making such and such dollars a year because of a character. But when I’ve told the story I had to tell, it’s time to start something different.”

headline: The Preakness Dartboard
text: The horses for Saturday’s 139th running of the Preakness Stakes are listed in order of post position with comments provided by Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert of The New York Times. Both have also selected their win-place-show horses. The morning-line odds were set by Keith Feustle of Pimlico Race Course.

headline: Cell Lit
text: This week, David Cole reviews Robert A. Ferguson’s “Inferno: An Anatomy of American Punishment,” about what Cole calls our “proclivity for incarceration.” The most enduring literary evocations of imprisonment have been written by those with firsthand experience; books like Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn’s “One Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich” and Dostoyevsky’s “The House of the Dead.”

headline: One Step at a Time
text: First, a confession: Words like “liminal” or “luminous” in a novel’s blurbs or flap copy work for me like flashing hazard lights. Generally, I set the book back down on the new releases table and reach for something else. Experience has taught me that novels so described favor style over story, and I’m an old-school reader who values well-wrought plot and highly developed character more than exquisite voice and stylistic gymnastics.

headline: Digging Out
text: I have a friend, the mother of twin boys, who recently confessed that the only way she had survived those early parenting years was by pretending she was someone else: a long-distance athlete in training, say, while jogging behind a double stroller before work; or a sexy, spaced-out au pair at the playground diddling on her iPhone during lengthy afternoons; or a bearded Bushwick mixologist whenever the clock struck 5. Any of these roles felt more endurable than her own.

headline: Scandalous Women
text: The publication of Gustave Flaubert’s “Madame Bovary” in 1857 and of Émile Zola’s “Thérèse Raquin” 10 years later roused the French literary establishment against two previously unknown authors who had gone beyond the bounds of all that was held to be morally admissible in fiction with their portraits of adulterous women starved by marriage of sex and romance. The state prosecuted Flaubert for gross indecency, despite the terrible punishment he metes out to his wayward heroine. Zola was not subjected to the same ordeal, but critics treated him as a rogue purveying smut in the name of realism. Both novels have appeared in countless editions since the 19th century. Both have been adapted to the screen. Now they are available as audiobooks, read by two gifted English actresses: “Madame Bovary” by Juliet Stevenson and “Thérèse Raquin” by Kate Winslet.

headline: Talk of the Town
text: It would be hard to think of two writers less alike — stylistically and, for that matter, personally — than Truman Capote and John O’Hara, yet they shared many pre­occupations. Both were fascinated by society high and low, by how people climbed or toppled from one rank to the other, and by how sex and money underpinned the entire system. “Breakfast at Tiffany’s,” Capote’s charming 1958 novella about a self-invented cafe society girl and the admiring writer who lives upstairs, is set during World War II. Most of the stories assembled in the recent Penguin anthology of O’Hara’s New York stories were written in either the ’30s or the ’60s, but some are set decades earlier. And yet in the newly released audio recordings of the two books, maybe even more than on the page, the versions of New York that are evoked seem virtually interchangeable: It’s a city of people on the make or else clinging to their former reputations, where everyone drinks too much, and where you can easily wake up in bed next to someone you barely remember meeting.

headline: Acting the Part
text: Let’s be honest: Celebrities don’t usually write great memoirs. But the best ones offer up dish and dirt and some sensationally bizarre yarns.

headline: The Long, Long Road Ahead
text: In my home state, California, we listen to audiobooks mostly while driving. When stuck in freeway traffic, I sometimes wonder whether the guy in my rearview mirror is secretly absorbed in “Harry Potter,” or if the smiling woman in the next lane is hearing Mr. Darcy woo Elizabeth Bennet. When it comes to immersing yourself in the First World War by audio, however, you’ll need more than a short commute. The war was very long, the books about it tend to be very long, and about this cataclysm that so thoroughly changed our world for the worse, surely you don’t want to listen to merely one book? So I suggest you reserve this listening for some road trip of epic length, like that drive you’ve always wanted to take from Alaska to Tierra del Fuego, or from Rotterdam to Vladivostok. Here are some suggestions for the journey:

headline: The Unpossessed
text: In 2008, Rivka Galchen published her first novel, “Atmospheric Disturbances,” about a man who believes his wife has been replaced by a replica of herself. Enfolded into the story was also one Dr. Tzvi Gal-Chen, who shares his name (down to the hyphen) with Galchen’s own father, a meteorologist who died in 1994. Combining aspects of her own biography, the physical sciences and psychiatry — Galchen is herself a medical doctor, trained in psychiatry — she created a vertiginous narrative about the nature of love and loss. Even if the book’s momentum ultimately flagged, it showed Galchen to be a bold, inventive and smart young writer.

headline: Book Review Podcast: How Japan Bounces Back
text: In The New York Times Book Review, James Fallows reviews David Pilling’s “Bending Adversity: Japan and the Art of Survival.” Mr. Fallows writes:

headline: Doctor Doubt
text: Asked to create a list of brain-­shatteringly dull topics for fiction, you might be tempted to include the following things that appear in Joshua Ferris’s “To Rise Again at a Decent Hour”: modern ­dentistry, pseudobiblical esoterica, the death rattle of a relationship, insomnia, shopping malls, other people’s spiritual anomie, other people’s use of social media, the perils of said social media, and baseball.

headline: Every Little Byte Counts
text: In “On What We Can Not Do,” a short and pungent essay published a few years ago, the Italian philosopher Giorgio Agamben outlined two ways in which power operates today. There’s the conventional type that seeks to limit our potential for self-­development by restricting material resources and banning certain behaviors. But there’s also a subtler, more insidious type, which limits not what we can do but what we can not do. What’s at stake here is not so much our ability to do things but our capacity not to make use of that very ability.

headline: Punitive Damage
text: As freedom advances, the severity of the penal law decreases. Or so argued Montesquieu, an Enlightenment philosopher whose work profoundly influenced the drafters of our Constitution. Were he alive today, Montesquieu might need to reconsider. The United States may or may not be the leader of the free world, but it is indisputably the world leader in locking up human beings behind bars. We are less than 5 percent of the world’s population, but we warehouse 25 percent of the world’s incarcerated population. Our per capita incarceration rate is seven times greater than France’s, 14 times greater than Japan’s and 24 times greater than India’s.

headline: Tell No One
text: The first thing we learn about New York tabloid journalism from INVISIBLE CITY (Minotaur, $24.99) is that a body in Gowanus takes precedence over a brothel in Chinatown. Rebekah Roberts, the narrator of Julia Dahl’s first novel, is fresh out of college and considers herself lucky to be working as a stringer for a bottom-feeding tabloid. Amateur sleuths with day jobs on a newspaper’s staff are usually battle-weary veterans, so it’s a treat to hear Rebekah and her friends trade horror stories about fighting for entry-level positions.

headline: Women at Work
text: #GIRLBOSS  By Sophia Amoruso  Portfolio/Penguin, $26.95.

headline: Video: Snowboard Star Mentors Fresh Talent
text: “Higher Unplugged” looks at the making of the film “Higher,” which follows the snowboarder Jeremy Jones and the TGR crew as they ascend and ride peaks in Alaska, Wyoming, California and Nepal. Jones is a professional snowboarder who has been named big mountain rider of the year 10 times by Snowboarder magazine.

headline: Snowboard Legend Mentors Fresh Talent
text: Five years ago, Jeremy Jones invited a young Ryland Bell to join him in Alaska. Since that trip, Bell has traveled to the state with Jones nearly every spring, revealing Bell’s growth as a rider.

headline: Uncertainty About Jobs Has a Ripple Effect
text: THE immediate impact of the recession — widespread buyouts and layoffs — may be fading, but the fear of losing a job hangs over workplaces like a cloud of worry.

headline: Events in Connecticut for May 18-24, 2014
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in New Jersey for May 18-24, 2014
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: The Case Against the Bernanke-Obama Financial Rescue
text: Atif Mian and Amir Sufi are convinced that the Great Recession could have been just another ordinary, lowercase recession if the federal government had acted more aggressively to help homeowners by reducing mortgage debts.

headline: Opera Glasses, Google Edition
text: Opera companies, particularly small experimental ones, have been toying in recent years with immersive performances, in which audiences and performers move through different spaces. Often, these have been new works in English, but for companies interested in reimagining the classic canon, one question regularly arises: How to give mobile audiences the supertitle translations to which they have become accustomed?

headline: Ex-Trader at SAC Fund Is Sentenced to 3 Years
text: Updated, 7:50 p.m. | A federal judge seemed pained at times on Friday in sentencing the former hedge fund trader Michael Steinberg to three and half years in prison for his conviction last year on insider trading charges.

headline: Bruno, Ex-State Senate Chief, Is Acquitted of Fraud in Retrial
text: ALBANY — Standing in a federal courthouse in a city he long called his political home, Joseph L. Bruno, the once-powerful majority leader of the New York State Senate, was found not guilty on federal fraud charges on Friday. The verdict put an end to a legal battle nearly a decade in the making.

headline: Popcast: Checking In on Burger Records
text: On this week’s Popcast, we look at the scene around Burger Records, based in Fullerton, Calif. — a teen-centered, low-budget, hyper-productive explosion of the new garage rock, though it isn’t exactly the scholarly, record-obsessed, semi-antiquarian kind we’ve seen in the past. Lee Rickard and Sean Bohrman, former bandmates in Thee Makeout Party!, started the Burger Records label in 2007 and opened a record store two years later; in that time they’ve become the center of a scene that’s generating excitement, loyalty and a sense of identity, especially among an Orange County contingent that’s under the legal drinking age and hungry for local culture. Burger’s pace has become manic lately — it released 300 items last year, between cassette-only editions or reissues and original albums on LP and CD — but it seems to be working: Burgerama, its annual two-day festival in Santa Ana, sold 10,000 tickets this year, and its bands (including Cherry Glazerr, Together Pangea, Audacity, the Garden and Gap Dream) have started to move onto the national radar. (Although if all Burger records ever did was to produce the wild, messy, energetic weekly videos for its YouTube channel, BRGRTV, it might have served its purpose on earth.)

headline: Countdown to the 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 27
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: My Marriage: A Course in Desert Survival
text: The psychiatrist gestured to a chair. I wore a hospital gown and rumpled cotton robe. To my left, a dirty window muted the glare. Placing his chair directly in front of mine, he asked, “So how will you support yourself?”

headline: Feeling For | The Latest From a Chic Brooklyn Culinary Magazine — and Its Spicy Summer Salad Recipe
text: When Fiorella Valdesolo and Michele Outland first sat down to conceive of Gather Journal — the cult biannual food magazine, which debuts its fifth issue today — they initially envisioned the project’s subject matter to be style. “But every time we came up with ideas,” says Valdesolo, a writer (and T contributor) based in Brooklyn, “we kept coming back to food.”

headline: Wall Street Washes Traders’ Mouths With Soap
text: Wall Street now has its very own Emily Post.

headline: The United States of Metrics
text: The map of the United States that appeared on Nerve.com this year was in many ways similar to the maps that pop up on the Internet during election seasons. States were divided into red or blue, then shaded from light to dark. Only in this case, the color did not indicate political preference; it indicated duration of sexual encounter.

headline: Reaching (Gingerly) for His Inner Killer
text: Call it Method directing.

headline: Times Minute | What India’s Vote Means
text: As Narendra Modi swept into power as prime minister-elect Friday, a look at what India’s vote means.

headline: Summer Burgers, Hold the Meat
text: I come back to burgers in this column every year or two. My quest for good vegetarian burgers has nothing to do with wanting to create something that resembles a hamburger or turkey burger. Why try to mimic meat? Rather, my vegetarian cooking is about produce, which, it turns out, can be the foundation for a great burger.

headline: Times Minute | What India’s Vote Means
text: In the Video

headline: What Is This Child Doing in Prison?
text: LAST month a 16-year-old child was placed in solitary confinement at the York Correctional Institution for Women in Niantic, Conn. She has never been charged, tried or convicted. What is her crime? That she has survived.

headline: All Aboard, for a Trip to the Past
text: It was the tail end of winter, and the trees outside the train car window were spindly twigs. Behind the bare branches, the sky was alight. To my half-asleep, hardly focusing, hung-over eyes, it was a blurry layer cake of blueberry, raspberry and tangerine. I had boarded the train in Chicago at dusk on Friday, three days before, and had rolled down 926 miles of rail. I’d spent 20 frivolous, indulgent hours in New Orleans, where I’d had fried oysters and fried green tomatoes at Upperline, midnight cocktails at the bar Cure and a hedonistic jazz brunch at Commander’s Palace. Then, before I could acclimate to the warmth and the green, the music and the food, I was on the next northbound train.

headline: U.S. Officials on G.M.’s Ignition Defect
text: The transportation secretary and the acting administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration discussed the investigation into G.M.’s vehicle recall for defective ignition switches.

headline: Taking a Spin: Surprises in Georgia and Louisiana
text: It is again time to spin the Upshot’s Senate wheels, in our weekly demonstration of just how much uncertainty remains with six months until the election.

headline: Death of a Hospital
text: In 1935, with the last inmates from the century-old penitentiary transferred to Rikers Island, a site south of the Queensboro Bridge was cleared for the modern Welfare Hospital for Chronic Diseases, which would become known as Goldwater Hospital.

headline: Forgoing Sunrise for Sunset on Maui’s Volcano
text: I was standing at the top of Mount Haleakala at 6 o’clock on a March morning, bleary-eyed and nauseated. During the three-hour journey from sea level to 10,000 feet, a group of wretchedly jet-lagged adventurers and I had scissored through almost 40 miles of hairpin turns holding on to our coffee cups and stomachs, stopping to help a disoriented elderly woman, navigating through herds of cows and glumly watching as rain began to splatter the van’s windshield.

headline: An Intimate View of America, From Above
text: We are rolling down the runway, increasing speed. At 70 knots, my husband lifts the nose of our small plane and we are suddenly airborne. Looking down, I can see the treetops, then the diagram of the town, and soon a panorama of hills and highways. We are heading south and west, toward Mississippi.

headline: Hotel Review: Brewhouse Inn & Suites in Milwaukee
text: Rates

headline: Restaurant Report: Joseph’s of Santa Fe
text: At 7 on an early winter evening, the buzz about Joseph Wrede’s new restaurant, Joseph’s of Santa Fe, had translated into an in-the-flesh dinner rush. The stranger dining next to me, a local who confessed he’d eaten there seven times since the restaurant opened in October, offered me a duck-fat French fry. “You didn’t order them and you have to try one,” he said.

headline: David Balding, Producer Who Adopted an Elephant, Dies at 75
text: David Balding, a producer of Broadway and Off Broadway plays who may have been best known as a circus showman who acted as a parent to an elephant, died on May 9 in Weldon Spring, Mo. He was 75.

headline: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
text: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

headline: On the Market in the Hamptons
text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: A Clash of Ideals and Investments at Swarthmore
text: Kate Aronoff didn’t arrive at Swarthmore College in fall 2010 expecting to be an environmental activist. Nor did she know much about the stock market. She knew even less about asset management and college endowments.

headline: Black-Throated Blue Warbler: Listen, Stop and Watch
text: It has become clichéd to call warblers the butterflies of the bird world, but it is a fair description of these tiny, colorful birds. In breeding plumage, male warblers are decked out in fluorescent reds, brilliant yellows, greens and metallic blues. A long look at a warbler as it flits from branch to branch may last just a few seconds, but even in that brief time, its colors astound.

headline: Elaine Sturtevant, Who Borrowed Others’ Work Artfully, Is Dead at 89
text: Elaine Sturtevant, an American Conceptual artist whose work resembled that of Andy Warhol — and Roy Lichtenstein and Robert Rauschenberg and Marcel Duchamp and Jasper Johns and Keith Haring and a spate of other emblematic figures from the annals of contemporary art — died on May 7 in Paris. She was 89.

headline: Think of Him as a Wingman for Hire
text: All the lonely people, the Beatles sang — identifying a consumer market of vast scale and almost limitless need. Which is to say, an opportunity. On a recent Monday night in the meatpacking district, that marketplace was in full swirl: stylish men and women circling one another, offering a line, a joke, a meeting of cellphones.

headline: Former Executive Sues for Stake in Beats Electronics, Object of Apple’s Desire
text: A week after reports on its negotiations were first published, Apple’s pending $3.2 billion deal for Beats Electronics has still not been completed. But Beats is already finding itself defending a lawsuit against a former executive over what could be a lucrative stake in the company.

headline: Russian Rocket Crashes After Takeoff
text: MOSCOW — A Russian Proton-M rocket carrying a sophisticated communications satellite crashed after takeoff early Friday morning, reviving questions over Russia’s space program after a series of failed launches in recent years.

headline: The Freedom of Boundaries
text: What I remember about boundaries when I was growing up is that I always wanted to violate them. Today, I’m frustrated that I don’t have more boundaries. I say that even though I have consciously built numerous boundaries in recent years, specifically to make up for the fact that technology has made it so difficult to have any.

headline: Kenyans Describe Twin Blasts in Nairobi
text: The Kenyan president, Uhuru Kenyatta, urged citizens to help prevent any future attacks, and witnesses described the scene after two explosions at a packed market in Nairobi.

headline: A Mixture for Geithner: The Moral Hazard
text: Central bankers and finance ministers are a famously sober bunch. That may explain why Timothy Geithner, despite being a senior federal policy maker through the better part of two decades of financial crisis, from Mexico to Thailand, Lehman Brothers to Greece, has, as far as we know, never had a cocktail named for him.

headline: Drama League Honors ‘Gentleman’s Guide’ and ‘All the Way’
text: The Drama League, an association of thousands of theatergoers nationwide, announced on Friday that “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder” has won its 2014 award for best musical and “All the Way” has won for best play. At a ceremony to present its 80th annual awards, the league also named “Hedwig and the Angry Inch” best revival of a musical and “The Glass Menagerie” best revival of a play.

headline: Q. and A. | Marion Cotillard on Her New Role and the Pursuit of Happiness
text: When Marion Cotillard is presented with the notion that after more than 40 films, an Oscar for Best Actress (for “La Vie en Rose”), and roles in some of the last decade’s defining blockbusters, she’s only now leading her first American film, even she seems surprised. Yes, that’s true,” she says with a laugh. “I didn’t even think about it.” But “The Immigrant,” an operatic melodrama directed by James Gray that opens today, hardly feels like it belongs in a 21st century American multiplex. It’s a grandiose throwback to an era when movies dealt with big emotions, not big explosions.

headline: Transition in Leadership for BAM’s DanceAfrica
text: Part lively dance performance and part spirited homage to ancestors, the DanceAfrica festival, founded at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in 1977 by Chuck Davis — who made it the largest such festival in the country — is getting a new artistic director.

headline: Student Loan Calculator
text: A guide to student loans at various universities, and what it takes after graduation to repay that debt.

headline: Fantasy Football: Analyzing the N.F.L. Draft Picks, Part 2
text: Continuing our look at the rookie on each team who will have the most fantasy impact this season, whether for him or for the players around him, we turn our attention to the N.F.C. South and West.

headline: Known for Films Like ‘Ran,’ a Japanese Actor Turns to the Stage
text: Updated, 3:09 p.m. | The last and most indelible image most American moviegoers have of the actor Tatsuya Nakadai probably dates from 1985: haunted, haggard, desolate, more ghost than man, wandering the battlefield at the end of his stupendous performance in “Ran,” Akira Kurosawa’s adaptation of “King Lear.”

headline: A Las Vegas Boutique Hotel With Star Power
text: In a market defined by size, the Cromwell checks into Las Vegas this month as the underdog, competing on style rather than scale.

headline: Driven | Bentley GT Speed Convertible
text: Transportation that says you’ve arrived.

headline: Video: The Bentley Continental GT Speed Is a Terrestrial Space Shuttle
text: I was lucky enough to see a space shuttle launch before NASA retired the fleet. On television, the shuttle seems to leave the ground at a slow, majestic pace. In person, it left the planet at the same violent velocity as the Estes model rockets I shot into the sky during my Cub Scout days. Whoosh! Just like that, it was gone.

headline: Mark Ryden: Drawing a Dividing Line
text: LOS ANGELES — Leonardo DiCaprio is an ardent collector of his macabre paintings. Katy Perry refers to his imagery in Twitter posts, and Amanda Seyfried has practically begged to be his muse. (“I’d love for him to paint a caricature of me with blood trickling down my throat and me holding a dead cat,” she told W magazine.) That gown of raw meat that Lady Gaga donned on MTV a few years ago? Derived from one of his best-known works.

headline: Rhubarb Shake
text: Melissa Clark makes a refreshing rhubarb shake with rosewater and Greek yogurt garnished with chopped pistachios.

headline: Yogurt Drinks, Not Too Smooth
text: When it comes to yogurt drinks, we’ve gotten ourselves into a smoothie rut. Smoothies are everywhere, at every juice bar, street cart and deli, and premixed in bottles lining supermarket shelves.

headline: When Shingles Is Just the Beginning
text: You don’t really need another reason to get the shingles vaccine, for yourself (if you’re over 60) or your older relatives. A painful rash, possible damage to vision and a substantial risk of the condition called postherpetic neuralgia, which can hurt for a long time — aren’t those enough?

headline: Some Wines Are Worth Not Drinking
text: MANY people who collect fine wine talk about it as an investment. But is something that pairs nicely with rack of lamb really an investment — or just a way to justify paying tens of thousands of dollars for a single bottle?

headline: Partnerships That Blend the Skills of Two Generations
text: IN her late 50s, Wickham Boyle left her job as an editor to pursue a project she was passionate about, producing an opera about 9/11 based on a book she wrote. A few months later, when she was ready to go back to work, she discovered it wasn’t so easy to find her next gig. “Our play closed on the day Lehman crashed, and my world dissolved,” she said, recalling the start of the financial crisis in 2008.

headline: For India’s Persecuted Muslim Minority, Caution Follows Hindu Party’s Victory
text: NEW DELHI — Like real estate agents the world over, Rahul Rewal asks his clients if they have children or pets, since both limit options. But there is another crucial but often unspoken question: Are they Muslim?

headline: Facts & Figures: California’s Drought
text: All of California is in “severe drought” or worse, according to the U.S. Drought Monitor, with much of the state in “exceptional drought” — the most extreme level. The National Drought Mitigation Center writes that a heat wave hitting the West “will only serve to exacerbate and accelerate drought impact concerns across the state. Increases on water demand and the increased risk of fire will ramp up as the heat does.”

headline: The Row’s New Home, a Frieze Frenzy and Moschino’s Plans for Men
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Finding the Right Note, Pure and Easy
text: It’s funny what makes a hit: that often once-in-a-lifetime connection between an artist and an audience, or a piece of music and a specific moment in time.

headline: Planners Adapt as Gay Unions Become More Common
text: Not very long ago, having a same-sex wedding was noteworthy enough, and those looking to wed often sought comfort and support in wedding websites and party planners whose orientation closely matched their own.

headline: A Beginner’s Guide to Repaying Student Loans
text: Too many people, including plenty of brand-new college graduates, fall far behind on their student loan payments for no good reason.

headline: Weekend Reading: The Hero and the Wall St. Puppet
text: Updated, 4:23 p.m., Saturday | Timothy F. Geithner’s new book defending his role in the financial crisis is drawing out his detractors and defenders on both sides of the political aisle.

headline: Rainout Puts Yanks in Old-Time 2-Game Set
text: The Yankees and the Pittsburgh Pirates might as well wear throwback uniforms this weekend. The opener of their three-game series, scheduled for Friday night, was rained out, and now they are scheduled to play an afternoon game Saturday and an old-fashioned, single-admission doubleheader Sunday afternoon at Yankee Stadium.

headline: So You’re Not Desirable ...
text: IT is one of the hard truths of romance: Desirable people attract other desirable people, while the rest of us — lacking in attractiveness, charisma or success — settle for the best partner who is willing to consider our overtures. In the scientific literature, this idea is enshrined in the concept of mate value, which determines who gets to mate with whom. In popular culture, it is reflected in the choice of comely contestants to vie for the equally comely spouse-to-be on TV shows like “The Bachelor.” Pairing off, it seems, is just one more example that life isn’t fair.

headline: A Southern Crossroads
text: The El Conejo bus depot in Laredo, Tex., serves as a crossroads for immigrants entering the United States.

headline: James Gray on ‘The Immigrant’
text: The director discusses his film featuring Joaquin Phoenix, Marion Cotillard and Jeremy Renner.

headline: Chipotle Experiments With Disposable Literature
text: The fast-food chain Chipotle announced on Thursday that it had enlisted 10 A-list writers to provide original notes and essays for the cups and bags in their restaurants as a way to foster thoughtfulness, without pushing a coporate agenda. The reviews for these new works of literature have ranged from enthusiastic to harsh.

headline: Friday Night Music: Arcade Fire, Joan of Arc
text: Various stuff keeping me frantic, so not much time to seek out new music. But I keep finding new gems from the latest AF album — or actually from the live performances, especially the stripped-down versions, which I often prefer. In this case the final violin dissonance really does it …

headline: Why G.O.P. Will Shift to Talking About Fixing the Heath-Care Law
text: In response to polling data showing that the Affordable Care Act has become more popular, a prominent Republican pollster said that he expected Republicans to change how they talked about the law.

headline: Brooklyn Cantor Pleads Guilty in Sexual Abuse Case
text: A sexual abuse case that divided the ultra-Orthodox Jewish community in Brooklyn and created rifts in the borough’s district attorney’s office ended on Friday as a once-prominent cantor pleaded guilty to molestation.

headline: The Gun Report: May 16, 2014
text: In the Carolinas, guns are allowed in bars. In Arkansas, you can take a gun into some churches and religious schools. In Indiana, you can keep a gun in your car on school property. In West Virginia, residents with concealed-carry permits can bring firearms into public recreation facilities such as tennis courts and swimming pools. Since the massacre in Newtown, 18 states have passed laws allowing guns in more places—but in only four states can you bring a gun into state legislative chambers.

headline: Brightening the Night With a Spring Palette
text: Walk beneath an animated rainbow, and then head through a tunnel of swirling fog. Meander past luminescent flowers, gigantic glowing mushrooms and a praying mantis towering more than 12 feet tall. Listen to the beat of a backdrop that blends natural noises with music. Welcome to “Lightscapes,” a fantastical garden of light, color and sound on the grounds of Van Cortlandt Manor.

headline: Atelier de Troupe Shows Two Collaborations at Its I.C.F.F. Debut
text: Atelier de Troupe, the three-year-old furniture and lighting studio founded by the Los Angeles-based designer Gabriel Abraham, is exhibiting at the annual International Contemporary Furniture Fair in New York for the first time this year. Abraham will introduce several new styles as well as two new collaborations: Core, created in tandem with the San Francisco-based ceramist Ian McDonald, and a collection of lighting designed alongside Roman Alonso of Commune.

headline: A Dose of Top-Down Tonic to Drive the Winter Blues Away
text: WOODSTOCK, N.Y. — Cabin fever is bad enough. But when you share your extended winter quarters with 8.4 million people, as one does in New York City, it’s no wonder the roommates get a little testy.

headline: Spirited Sedan Inhabited by Pontiac’s Ghost
text: General Motors has a long history of killing off worthy cars. The Pontiac Fiero is the most infamous example, an initially mundane two-seater that developed into a capable performance machine just in time for production to cease forever. A more recent casualty was the 2008-9 Pontiac G8, a rear-drive performance sedan that was canceled when its brand fell under the ax as G.M. approached bankruptcy.

headline: Chevy SS: What Lies Beneath
text: A defunct General Motors division’s last hurrah has returned from Australia wearing a bow-tie disguise.

headline: Pictures of the Day: India and Elsewhere
text: Photos from India, Ukraine, Serbia and Palestine.

headline: Nuclear Talks With Iran Fail to Yield Pact, Officials Say
text: LONDON — The latest round of nuclear talks between Iran and six world powers ended on Friday in Vienna, with Iranian and American officials saying that progress was slow and difficult, with serious gaps between the two sides on basic issues like the size of any nuclear enrichment capability Iran would be permitted to retain.

headline: Leave the Car at Home This Weekend
text: New Yorkers who were thinking about hopping in a car to get about town this weekend might want to think twice. Not only is the annual AIDS walk on Sunday, but between food fairs and street fairs, Norwegian pride parades and dance parades, half marathons and awareness walks, just about every corner of the city will have some street closed for a period of time.

headline: Civilized Without Compromise
text: The 2014 Stingray convertible is simply the best Corvette in the nameplate’s 61-year history, as purely capable as a Porsche 911 Carrera S, but at barely half the price.

headline: Clyde Snow, Sleuth Who Read Bones From King Tut’s to Kennedy’s, Dies at 86
text: With ghoulish geniality, Clyde Snow liked to say that bones made good witnesses, never lying, never forgetting, and that a skeleton, no matter how old, could sketch the tale of a human life, revealing how it had been lived, how long it had lasted, what traumas it had endured and especially how it had ended.

headline: From the International Desk: The Thinking on Ukraine
text: We talked to Kyle Crichton, who is coordinating coverage of the Ukraine crisis for The Times, about the news that steelworkers and miners are taking control of the streets from separatists and pro-Russian militants in Mariupol and some other cities.

headline: On-Site Fixes for What Winter’s Potholes Wrought
text: Jennifer Franz of Sacramento scraped a wheel on her three-year-old Honda Accord last August in an encounter with a curb. To keep her mother from finding the damage, she made an appointment with a local business, Kelly Wheel Repair, that travels to its customers.

headline: Serious Rock Star Fantasies, Fueled by Athletic Footwork
text: Imagine a teenage boy in his bedroom, pretending to be a rock star. He tries out postures. He swings his shirt around his head. It could be cute, right? Now imagine that the boy is actually a grown man and that he makes you watch him fantasize about being a rock star for 95 minutes. Not so cute.

headline: A Scaleback in Die-Cast Cars
text: The decision by the Danbury Mint last month to stop selling die-cast model cars was symptomatic of a more serious shrinkage in a market where the vehicles are already pretty small.

headline: GreenTech Scatters New Seeds
text: In its five-year existence, GreenTech Automotive has manufactured far more headlines than cars. Now, after a merger with another fledgling auto company, VL Automotive, GreenTech promises to deliver an eclectic mix of electric city cars, plug-ins converted into muscle machines and performance-tuned cars for the Chinese market.

headline: Goldman Shareholders Give Pay Plan a Thumbs Up
text: Since the financial crisis, Wall Street has faced pressure to disclose more about how it rewards its top executives.

headline: The Fruit of Feminist Mothers and Michael Jackson
text: After decades of radical questioning and cycles of reaction, which term is more difficult to define neatly these days: “feminism” or “contemporary performance”? That was one question raised by the Minneapolis collective SuperGroup in its smart and inventive New York debut on Thursday.

headline: Straws They’ll All Grasp At
text: What should you serve when you serve drinks?

headline: Week in Pictures for May 16
text: A slide show of photographs of the past week in New York City and the region includes the National September 11 Memorial Museum, the newly elected mayor of Newark, and a World War II plane embarking on a new mission.

headline: Bolshoi Theater Plans Tchaikovsky Celebrations
text: MOSCOW — The Bolshoi Theater announced plans for the 2014-15 season this week, including productions to mark the 175th anniversary of Tchaikovsky’s birth.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: Did Regulators Break the Internet or Did They Save It? Yes.
text: Ten years from now, we’ll look back on this week as the moment federal regulators broke the Internet as we know it.

headline: Feminism, One Conference at a Time
text: It was a month before Gloria Steinem’s 80th birthday, but on a Saturday evening in February, on the cliffs at a resort in Southern California, 500 women were helping her celebrate early. Ms. Steinem, the guest of honor, was flanked by her longtime friends Marlo Thomas and Jane Fonda. The three hugged, and then Ms. Thomas raised a glass. “To Gloria,” she said. “The absolutely perfect leader to our revolution.”

headline: Mahler, Together With an Old Friend
text: It is always a pleasure to check in on a happy marriage of musical artist and repertory after many years and find that it still thrives.

headline: True Crime, With an Analytic Leaning
text: There are several issues to consider regarding the premiere of “The System,” Joe Berlinger’s new eight-part series, which begins on Sunday night on Al Jazeera America. The most obvious and probably most pertinent is that the channel is trying to keep up with one of its cable news rivals: It’s bringing in a recognizable figure (Mr. Berlinger is known for feature documentaries like the “Paradise Lost” series about the West Memphis 3 case and “Metallica: Some Kind of Monster”) to do original documentary-style programming before CNN gets its new shows with Lisa Ling, Mike Rowe and John Walsh on the air.

headline: Kids Are Icebound by ‘Frozen’ Fervor
text: If any parent doubts the power of the Disney animated film “Frozen,” perhaps they should talk to Willie Geist, a “Today” show host.

headline: Within a Ship’s Walls, Songs of War in High Voices
text: Human fragility is a recurring theme in the music of David Lang, and “battle hymns,” an almost hourlong collection of choral songs about war, is no exception. On Thursday, this often moving but occasionally precious work received its New York premiere, sung by the Collegiate Chorale and the Manhattan Girls Chorus under the direction of James Bagwell in the 12,000-square-foot Hangar 3 inside the Intrepid Sea, Air & Space Museum. The performance also included six singers from the Veteran Artist Program, a nationwide initiative to engage former service members in the arts. Mr. Lang sets repurposed Civil War texts by Stephen Foster, Abraham Lincoln and Maj. Sullivan Ballou in his trademark spare vocal lines and crystalline textures. The result is a portrait of the soldier as sleepwalker, caught in a no man’s land between patriotism and private longing.

headline: Parents Respond to the ‘Frozen’ Frenzy
text: We have just a touch of “Frozen” fever at our house. Our spring break trip involved three long plane journeys, and my youngest daughter watched “Frozen” in every available language on the seat-back television screen. We are not big singers of “Let it Go”; we prefer the sprightly “Do You Want to Build a Snowman?”— but my older daughter and the girls we visited over break did engage in vigorous debate over whose version of “Let It Go” was better (“vigorous agreement” might be a better phrase for their passionate preference for the Idina Menzel version over the Demi Lovato one). And anyone, anywhere, can get a laugh at any moment by declaring, “Hi, I’m Olaf, and I like warm hugs.”

headline: Night Out With Emilie and Mika Brzezinski
text: Last Friday night, Tina Brown held a cocktail party in her Sutton Place apartment for Emilie Brzezinski, an 82-year-old artist from Switzerland who carves monumental wooden sculpture using chain saws and chisels.

headline: Hong Kong Cocoons
text: Buildings in Hong Kong are sheathed in colored nets and bamboo while being renovated. Peter Steinhauer tracks these cocoons on the urban skyline.

headline: Where the Sylvan Settings Enhance the Art
text: Spring blossoms, clement breezes and some newborn farm animals make this a particularly delightful time to visit three outdoor sites where artwork is surrounded by the splendors of nature.

headline: Sweetly Taking on Kanye and Double Standards
text: Lily Allen paused in her set at the Highline Ballroom on Thursday night — her first New York City show since 2009 — to autograph an audience member’s eagerly proffered copy of “Sheezus,” her new CD. “You guys think I’m just being a really nice person,” she said. “But actually this is a really good advertising plan!”

headline: Cannes Film Festival 2014, Part I
text: Scenes from the Cannes Film Festival photo diary of Benoît Peverelli.

headline: With Narendra Modi, a Change in India
text: Narendra Modi, India’s presumed next prime minister, and his opposition Bharatiya Janata Party made history by delivering a crushing defeat to the ruling Indian National Congress party, which has controlled Indian politics for most of the past 60 years. Winning more than 272 parliamentary seats, the B.J.P. received the strongest mandate of any party in 30 years.

headline: Recycling the Leftovers
text: Every week, some 14,000 households in Austin, Tex., dutifully roll not just one, or two, but three garbage bins to the curb.

headline: Veterans Secretary Ousts Health Care Official Amid Criticism
text: WASHINGTON — One day after deflecting calls from unhappy senators to shake up his leadership team, Eric Shinseki, the secretary of veterans affairs, ousted the department’s soon-to-retire head of health care. The move came amid snowballing allegations that veterans hospitals manipulated waiting lists to hide long delays many patients faced to see physicians.

headline: Semifinals in the Bridge Trial for the Bermuda Bowl
text: In Phoenix, the trial to select the USA-1 team for next year’s Bermuda Bowl world championship is nearing its conclusion.

headline: For Sandra Tsing Loh, Change Is Good
text: PASADENA, Calif. — “I just joined Twitter,” the writer and performer Sandra Tsing Loh announced into a good old-fashioned microphone. She was deep in the warren of the KPCC-FM public-radio station (wall-to-wall carpeting, office kitchen copiously stocked with herbal teas, a sound engineer who keeps bees), recording a segment for “The Loh Life,” one of her two long-running broadcasts here. Ads for Gold’s Gym flashed noiselessly, reprovingly, on a television screen overhead.

headline: Swiss Prepare to Vote on World’s Highest Minimum Wage
text: BASEL, Switzerland — While Switzerland’s booming economy has made the country synonymous with a superlative standard of living, the government estimates that approximately one worker in 10 struggles to pay rent, despite working full time.

headline: Racially Themed Work Stirs Conflict at Whitney Biennial
text: The YAMS, a collective of artists who made a video on race and black identity for the current Whitney Biennial, have withdrawn the work to protest a project in the show that they contend is racially insensitive.

headline: The Entire Audience Dozed Off? Perfect!
text: It’s the unspoken fantasy of so many theatergoers: a highbrow cultural outing that, somewhere between the opening and the ovation, includes a nap. But most directors and performers conspire to, at the very least, keep their audiences awake.

headline: Greek Bank’s Return to Risky Investment
text: Investing in Greece’s banks was never for the cautious. But for the parade of hedge fund managers who have piled into the Greek financial giant Piraeus Bank, the bank’s latest deal has surely resulted in a dose of heartburn.

headline: Icons at Leisure in Long-Ago Summers
text: A self-possessed little girl named Jacqueline Bouvier walking with her pony. Diana Vreeland wearing striped shorts with matching striped earrings. Gary Cooper impeccably dressed in a sport jacket and trousers as he enters a fashionable beach club. These are among the 30 black-and-white images of the rich and famous in “Southampton Blue Book, 1930 to 1960: Photographs by Bert Morgan,” on view at the Rogers Mansion of the Southampton Historical Museums and Research Center through Oct. 18.

headline: A Pioneer Says Goodbye, Unfiltered
text: Barbara Walters got out while the gets were still good.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Turning Heads
text: The fashion note at the Women’s Committee of the Central Park Conservancy “hat luncheon” was a one-piece fitted dress with a full skirt, replacing the suit.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Turning Heads
text: On May 7, the Women’s Committee of the Central Park Conservancy held its annual “hat luncheon” for 1,200 guests. The event, which garnered $3.5 million and honored Michael Bloomberg, featured whimsical headdresses masking a serious dedication to the restoration of the park and to the judicious spending of the money raised. Lela Rose arrived on her bike, with Gillian Miniter in the sidecar. The fashion note was a one-piece fitted dress with a full skirt, replacing the luncheon suit, and a lovely surprise to the women in orange was the hue of the traditional umbrellas handed out.

headline: Portland, Ore., Sheds Its Walmart Bonds
text: The city of Portland, Ore., announced this week that it had begun divesting itself of its holdings in Walmart, citing concerns over the company’s ethics and labor practices.

headline: Evening Hours | A Blossoming Calendar
text: It’s a busy time, with benefits of all types.

headline: Ask Well | Downsides of Taking Truvada?
text: Readers asked Well about the preventative drug Truvada following a C.D.C. recommendation that all Americans at risk for H.I.V. take this daily pill that has been shown to prevent infection.

headline: Ask Well: AIDS and Truvada
text: New federal guidelines urge gay men and others who have unprotected sex to take a daily dose of the drug Truvada to curb H.I.V. infections and AIDS. Donald G. McNeil Jr. responds to reader questions.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘Godzilla,’ ‘The Immigrant’ and ‘Million Dollar Arm’
text: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on ““Godzilla,” “The Immigrant” and “Million Dollar Arm.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web, What We’re Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up »

headline: Coaxing Lyrical Voices From the Withdrawn
text: The Institute for Music and Health in Dutchess County occupies a big house in a deserted clearing at the end of a long and winding road. The main feature of the house is a room with two grand pianos, each with a so-called reflector — an obelisk-like plywood device that, placed under the piano’s soundboard, is said to direct the sound waves back toward the pianist, easing feelings of isolation.

headline: Bridging the Racial Divide in Tuscaloosa Schools
text: A ProPublica project in Tuscaloosa, Ala., had teenagers document the realities of resegregated schools.

headline: Wheelies: The Top-Shelf Kia Edition
text: ■ Michael Sprague, executive vice president for sales and marketing at Kia Motors America, said on Thursday that the automaker’s K900 luxury car, currently on sale in California, would be available in the Midwest this month. The $66,000 rear-wheel drive sedan is equipped with a 420-horsepower 5-liter V8 engine. (The Detroit Free Press)

headline: Ways to Make a City’s Roads Safer
text: To the Editor:

headline: Hillary Clinton on Nation’s Future
text: Former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton delivered remarks at the New America Foundation conference “Big Ideas for a New America” in Washington.

headline: Understanding Dreams, and Fretting About Sleep
text: To the Editor:

headline: Avoiding Foreclosure: A View From the Treasury Dept.
text: To the Editor:

headline: Uncanny Representations of Humans in Distress
text: Two events from the last decade demonstrate how Edvard Munch (1863-1944) remains relevant in widely varying contexts today. One is the $119.9 million price paid in 2012 for a pastel version of “The Scream” (1895), which made it briefly the most expensive artwork ever sold at auction. The other is a proposal to use a version of “The Scream” to label a nuclear waste storage site, warning future generations — or visitors from other planets — of the toxic dangers lurking within.

headline: Expanding Hydropower
text: To the Editor:

headline: Spain, With a Touch of Denmark
text: American Ballet Theater has settled in at the Metropolitan Opera House, and the guest artists have started rolling through. Nearly a dozen, some well known here, some not, will appear in the next two months. At best, the system brings to New York world-class dancers we might not otherwise get to see. On Wednesday, the choice was especially welcome: Alban Lendorf, a young star of the Royal Danish Ballet.

headline: Abbas Meets in London With Israeli Negotiator
text: JERUSALEM — President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority met Thursday in London with Israel’s justice minister, Tzipi Livni, the first known face-to-face talks between the two sides since the American-brokered peace negotiations collapsed last month.

headline: Bringing Star Power From the Windy City
text: It’s hard not to have great expectations when a celebrity chef comes to town — never mind a pair of celebrity chefs, who together have racked up culinary awards, made dozens of television appearances and cooked at most of the country’s top food and wine festivals.

headline: U.S. Setting Up Emergency Shelter in Texas as Youths Cross Border Alone
text: With border authorities in South Texas overwhelmed by a surge of young illegal migrants traveling by themselves, the Department of Homeland Security declared a crisis this week and moved to set up an emergency shelter for the youths at an Air Force base in San Antonio, officials said Friday.

headline: Clinton Calls for Expanding Economic Opportunities
text: WASHINGTON — Hillary Rodham Clinton weighed in on the debate over income inequality on Friday, calling for policies intended to help the struggling middle class, in a speech that seemed suited to a campaign.

headline: In Sparse Space, Flair for the House-Made
text: When L’inizio took the place of the short-lived Italian Kitchen in January, I thought, here goes, another neo-Italian storefront run by young pioneers conversant in cavatelli, romanesco and semifreddo, with the usual local sourcing and “house-made” this and that. But the new owners, Scott and Heather Fratangelo, are making so many good things to eat with so much confidence that there’s little room left for skepticism. L’inizio means “the start” in Italian and the Fratangelos are off to a promising one.

headline: Slowly Producing a Spirit England Can Call Its Own
text: ROUDHAM, England — Made with barley from a family farm and water from a local borehole, the slightly nutty-tasting single-malt whisky from a small distillery can cost more than similar products from Glenmorangie or Glenlivet. Matured for at least three years in bourbon casks, it is shipped around the world to the United States, Sweden, Russia, Hong Kong and China.

headline: Apple and Google End Patent Fights
text: Updated with more reporting on the two companies as targets of so-called patent trolling.

headline: Next Week on Retro Report
text: Before DNA testing, prosecutors often relied on microscopic hair analysis to put criminals behind bars. But how reliable was it? Visit nytimes.com on Monday for the full story.

headline: Rangers and Montreal Revive Historic Rivalry
text: Over nearly a century of coexistence, the Montreal Canadiens and the Rangers are at opposite ends of the Stanley Cup spectrum. The Canadiens have celebrated a record 24 Cups, though none since 1993. The Rangers have won only four — one in the last 74 years, in 1994.

headline: Italian Food, the American Way
text: When Carl and Marie Ruiz opened Marie’s Italian Specialties in 2011, their intention was to maintain the sane hours of a deli-style restaurant, closing precisely at 6 p.m. Their intention was foiled on Day 1, when a well-dressed man entered the restaurant right at 6 and without even looking at a menu, said he wanted rigatoni with sausage and meatballs.

headline: Mining Disaster Grows Into Political Crisis for Turkish Leader
text: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s response to the deadly mine explosion has fueled antigovernment sentiment.

headline: His Future and Fortune at Stake, Formula One Chief Keeps It Breezy
text: MUNICH — For a man at risk of being rudely unseated from his position as one of the world’s most powerful sports moguls, Bernie Ecclestone seems improbably relaxed as the defendant in a criminal trial accusing him of bribery in the deal that ensured his continued control of grand prix motor racing.

headline: Mother Accuses Doctors of Forcing a C-Section and Files Suit
text: After two cesarean sections, Rinat Dray wanted to give birth naturally.

headline: Colombia and Rebels Agree on Drug Fight
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — Negotiators for the Colombian government and the country’s largest guerrilla group said Friday that they had reached an agreement on ways to fight drug trafficking as part of broader talks aimed at ending five decades of war. The announcement came barely a week before a presidential election that could hinge on how voters view the peace talks.

headline: The Name Is New, the Flavors are Familiar
text: When I announced, “We’re going to Din Din,” my dining companions responded, laughing, with baby talk. In fact, the name of the restaurant comes from the “Chinese baby name” of its owner, Sophia Kang, Ms. Kang told me on the telephone after my visits.

headline: Concerns Fade Over Weather and the Favorite’s Health
text: BALTIMORE — California Chrome galloped in the rain, took his medicine — a glycerin rinse for a small blister in his throat — and was declared fit, fast and ready for Saturday’s 139th running of the Preakness Stakes by his father-son training team.

headline: The Preakness Draw
text: Post positions for Saturday’s 139th running of the Preakness Stakes.

headline: Yearning for a Bigger (Apple) Smartphone
text: I have big phone envy.

headline: As 9/11 Museum Opens, These New Yorkers Will Stay Away
text: The National September 11 Memorial Museum is meant to be an exercise in the cathartic power of memory. At its formal unveiling on Thursday, President Obama gave a somber speech, remarking that the lives of those who died in the terrorist attacks in 2001 would be honored by the stories told “in the footprint of two mighty towers.”

headline: Times Co. Chief Addresses Executive Editor’s Firing
text: The controversy over the firing of Jill Abramson, the former executive editor of The New York Times, continued on Friday as the company’s chief executive sent a letter to senior editors in an effort to further address the reasons for her dismissal.

headline: Beware the City Dolls
text: COMMENCEMENT season is upon us again. In a tenuous economic recovery, many of the 1.6 million graduates at American colleges and universities will be listening intently for a bit of practical wisdom from their commencement speakers.

headline: Producing Goals and Gall for Canadiens
text: BROSSARD, Quebec — Pernell Karl Subban thrives on being the center of attention. And that is what he has been in the N.H.L. playoffs, especially when his Montreal Canadiens faced the top-seeded Boston Bruins in the second round.

headline: Ex-Duke Lacrosse Coach Rebuilds Shattered Career
text: SMITHFIELD, R.I. — There is more salt in the salt-and-cinnamon beard, but otherwise, Mike Pressler is about the same these days, eight years after he left Duke as the most infamous lacrosse coach in the nation.

headline: Michelle Obama Cites View of Growing Segregation
text: TOPEKA, Kan. — Sixty years after the Supreme Court outlawed “separate but equal” schools for blacks and whites, civil rights advocates say American schools are becoming increasingly segregated, while the first lady, Michelle Obama, lamented that “many young people are going to schools with kids who look just like them.”

headline: Passes Are No Longer Needed at 9/11 Memorial
text: The National September 11 Memorial is now truly open — unimpeded and permanently — to the public.

headline: British Candidate Clarifies Just Which Immigrants Disturb Him
text: In a contentious radio interview that sounded at moments like Absurdist theater, the leader of the anti-immigrant U.K. Independence Party, Nigel Farage, denied on Friday that his attacks on foreign-born migrants were racist.

headline: City Now Expects to Authorize More Green Cabs by the Fall
text: One day after signaling that it would slow indefinitely the expansion of street-hail livery cab service outside Manhattan, Mayor Bill de Blasio’s administration said on Friday that it expected to issue new permits for the popular green taxis at the end of the summer.

headline: No Reason to Delay Fair Wages
text: Come Jan. 1, 2015, a new federal rule will require that home care workers be paid at least the minimum wage and time and a half for overtime. This rule would undo an indefensible policy, dating from 1974, that denied home care workers basic labor protections by deeming them “companions” rather than employees.

headline: The Slippery Slope of Secrecy
text: “If you want to keep a secret,” George Orwell advised in “1984,” “you must also hide it from yourself.” So the latest stricture seems to demand from the Office of the Director of National Intelligence, the federal uber-agency of all things secret. The office, which oversees 16 government intelligence agencies, issued a new policy in April that will seriously constrain the existing practice by which officials comment informally to the press and public when obvious issues are stirred by leaked information and unauthorized disclosures.

headline: Little Time Left for Campaign Reforms
text: Gov. Andrew Cuomo is busy running for re-election, but he has yet to make good on a campaign promise from 2010: to clean up New York’s abysmal campaign finance system. He can do that by coaxing the Legislature into passing a reform package that provides public matching funds for small donations.

headline: California Wildfires Spread Across Hills, Leveling Homes
text: ESCONDIDO, Calif. — With fire rolling swiftly down the hill toward their houses on Thursday, Jeff Brown, his brother and his grandmother were forced by sheriff’s deputies to flee the two homes here that the family has occupied since the 1960s.

headline: Robbery Suspect Tracked by GPS and Killed
text: Relying on a GPS device placed in a decoy pill bottle, police officers tracked an armed man suspected of robbing a pharmacy on Friday afternoon and fatally shot him during a confrontation on the Upper East Side, police officials said.

headline: Thousands of Toddlers Are Medicated for A.D.H.D., Report Finds, Raising Worries
