text: ATLANTA — More than 10,000 American toddlers 2 or 3 years old are being medicated for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder outside established pediatric guidelines, according to data presented on Friday by an official at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline: The New Inequality for Toddlers: Less Income; More Ritalin
text: About 15,000 American toddlers 2 or 3 years old, many on Medicaid, are being medicated for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, according to data presented Friday by an official at the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. As Alan Schwarz reports, toddlers from low-income families are disproportionately represented among those medicated.

headline: De Blasio Chooses a City Planner to Lead Landmarks Preservation
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio announced on Friday that he had chosen Meenakshi Srinivasan, an architect and city planner, to be the new chairwoman of New York City’s Landmarks Preservation Commission, an appointment of great interest to developers and preservationists.

headline: Friends of Hillary
text: The American economy has gone through some tough times lately. But, happily, we still lead the world in the production of corn, soybeans, beef, cheese and stories about Hillary Clinton.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 16, 2014
Humanist Foundation Reaches Out to Religious Groups, Testing a Divide
text: Six months after starting a humanist charity in 2010, Dale McGowan unveiled a philanthropist’s version of a beta test. He already offered donors to his organization, the Foundation Beyond Belief, the opportunity to designate their gifts for groups that worked in fields like refugee aid and environmentalism. Then, in an contrarian brainstorm, he decided to try adding a category for progressive religious bodies.

headline: Democracy Triumphs in India, but Falters Again in Ukraine
text: It is often noted, correctly, that elections are not the whole of democracy. But when millions upon millions of people in an enormously diverse and complex land like India vote over several weeks for an orderly change of government, it is a heartening sight. Especially so when set against people taking the law into their own hands in Ukraine, Thailand or Vietnam.

headline: Gray Ones Spark Debate
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Brad Wilber is a librarian at an East Coast college, so it’s not surprising that he knows a lot about a lot of different things. It definitely shows in his puzzles, where solvers can find very sophisticated references to art, music (Mr. Wilber is an opera fan, so that comes up a lot) and literature.

headline: Key Figure in Libya’s Revolution Leads Attack on Islamists
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — A former general who was a central figure in Libya’s revolution led a full-scale ground and air assault on several Islamist militia bases in and around the city of Benghazi on Friday, declaring war against the groups that have been accused of conducting a campaign of lawlessness and assassinations.

headline: Jeb Magruder, 79, Nixon Aide Jailed for Watergate, Dies
text: Jeb Magruder, a former high-level aide to President Richard M. Nixon who went to jail in the Watergate affair and who years later made the startling assertion that Nixon himself had ordered the break-in that set the scandal in motion, died on Sunday in Danbury, Conn. He was 79.

headline: Rethinking Campaign Finance
text: In 2006, shortly after being elected to Congress — indeed, as he recalls it, before he had even taken his oath of office — John Sarbanes was approached by several Washington lobbyists. “They offered to do a fund-raiser for me,” he said. “I thought, ‘I don’t want to start down this road.’ ” So he put the lobbyists off.

headline: In California Race, Pedigree vs. Policy (and Bit of TV Nostalgia)
text: LOS ANGELES — Bobby Shriver, a gregarious Kennedy family transplant running for the county Board of Supervisors here, turned up for a debate in Sherman Oaks the other evening and spotted his main rival, Sheila Kuehl, a child actress who served 14 years as a California legislator, milling around the crowded room.

headline: Jean-Luc Dehaene, Former Prime Minister of Belgium, Is Dead at 73
text: Jean-Luc Dehaene, a former prime minister of Belgium whose deft political deal-making helped hold together his country’s historically divided factions and for a time made him a leading contender to become the European Union’s top official, died on Thursday in Brittany, France. He was 73.

headline: Pakistan: Boy Kills a Jailed Man Who Was Accused of Blasphemy
text: A teenage Pakistani boy walked into a police station on Friday and shot dead a 65-year-old man accused of blasphemy. The boy, a student in the 10th grade, entered the station in Sharaqpur, 15 miles west of Lahore, wearing a fake police uniform and carrying a gun, the police said. He demanded to see Khalil Ahmad, a member of the minority Ahmadi community who was being held at the station. Mr. Ahmad had been arrested Monday after a dispute with a Muslim shopkeeper escalated and the shopkeeper sought help from local clerics, who accused Mr. Ahmad and three other Ahmadis of blasphemy. When the boy was taken to the detainee’s cell, he shot Mr. Ahmad, who died instantly, the police said. The boy was arrested.

headline: Germany: The Flight of the Iguana
text: A bizarre cargo of more than 80 exotic reptiles, including four horned vipers and an iguana, attracted the attention of an alert customs official at Frankfurt Airport this week. During a routine inspection of luggage in transit, the official found 50 turtles, 30 arboreal alligator lizards, the snakes and the iguana in one suitcase. Several reptiles were stuffed into cloth bags or boxes, and the snakes were entangled in women’s stockings, said Hans-Jürgen Schmidt, a customs spokesman. The owner of the bag, traveling from Mexico City to Barcelona, was detained Tuesday before boarding his flight to Spain, Mr. Schmidt said. The passenger, a 44-year-old Mexican, who cannot be named under German privacy laws, is under investigation to determine whether he violated laws on the protection of endangered species and the treatment of animals. Three turtles have died, and most of the reptiles, which have been moved to the Frankfurt zoo, were in bad shape, Mr. Schmidt said. The potential sale value of the cargo was as much as $82,000, he said.

headline: Familiar Result as Nadal and Murray’s Rivalry Resumes
text: ROME — The first match between Rafael Nadal and Andy Murray in nearly three years proved to be worth the wait.

headline: Connecticut G.O.P. Weighs a Full Field for Governor
text: STAMFORD, Conn. — This state’s Republicans, counting on widespread concern over Connecticut’s financial picture to lift their electoral fortunes, descended upon the Mohegan Sun resort in Uncasville on Friday to begin to select a challenger to the Democratic governor, Dannel P. Malloy.

headline: As Usual, Mets’ Hitters Struggle. For Once, So Does Niese.
text: WASHINGTON — Juan Lagares appeared to have lost his starting spot this week. Earlier in the season, he was perhaps the Mets’ best all-around player, making spectacular plays in center field and appearing composed at the plate.

headline: Corrections: May 17, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, May 17, 2014
text: “A billion plus people have announced their mandate in no uncertain terms.”

headline: Judge Orders U.S. to Stop Force-Feeding Syrian Held at Guantánamo
text: WASHINGTON — A Federal District Court judge on Friday ordered the military to stop force-feeding a hunger-striking detainee at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, until at least Wednesday.

headline: Conference Finals Preview: Familiarity in the East and Consistency in the West
text: The conference finals of the N.H.L. playoffs feature a contrast of recent Stanley Cup histories. In the East, two Original Six teams with long Stanley Cup droughts meet. The West involves the winners of three of the last four Stanley Cups.

headline: Air Crash in Laos Kills Top Officials for Security
text: BANGKOK — A plane carrying senior Laotian government officials crashed Saturday morning, leaving at least four people dead, Laotian diplomats said Saturday.

headline: What’s on Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (Lifetime) RETURN TO ZERO (2014) Maggie (Minnie Driver) and Aaron (Paul Adelstein, above with Ms. Driver) try to resume their picture-perfect existence after their son is stillborn, but can’t escape their grief in this drama based on the personal experiences of the writer and director, Sean Hanish. They cope through denial, escape and alcohol, but when Maggie discovers that Aaron is having an affair with a colleague (Sarah Jones), she decides to end the marriage. But just as she believes that she is ready to move on, she discovers that she’s pregnant. Alfred Molina portrays Aaron’s brusque father and boss; Kathy Baker is Maggie’s mother. And Connie Nielsen plays the doctor who, having experienced a similar loss, helps Maggie and Aaron begin their lives anew.

headline: Congress’s Rank and File Lament Demise of Party Once Beloved
text: The leafy boulevard leading up to the Indian National Congress party’s headquarters in the Lutyens’ Delhi neighborhood was deserted early in the afternoon on Friday. Trends in voting were becoming more apparent, and it did not look good for the party that governs the central government. With time, it only looked worse.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s Money Talking
text: There are big changes in store for Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the government-run mortgage financing giants that guarantee about two-thirds of all U.S. home loans. The new head of the agency that oversees the companies wants them to continue to play a major role in the housing market.

headline: Secular Stagnation in the Euro Area
text: Most discussion about the possibility of secular stagnation has focused on US data, partly because most of the new secular stagnationists are American, partly because the data are easier to work with. But as Izabella Kaminska and James Mackintosh point out, the euro area seems closer to Japanification than the US. So are there structural changes in Europe that arguably will lead to persistently lower demand unless offset by policy?

headline: Interest Rates and Inflation and Evidence
text: Just a brief belated note on the “neo-Fisherite” view that lower interest rates lead to lower inflation, which has produced some surprising diffidence from economists you would expect to ridicule it; why doesn’t this debate emphasize the large empirical literature on the effects of monetary shocks?

headline: Bridging the Racial Divide in Tuscaloosa Schools
text: “Skin color doesn’t define your intelligence.”

headline: Tiananmen, 25 Years Later
text: My Sunday column looks back at the Tiananmen student democracy movement in the spring of 1989 and the brutal repression that followed it. I was then a young reporter based in China, and it was a formative and searing experience for me. You don’t forget when a government opens fire at the crowd you’re in.

headline: As Turkish Mine Yields the Last Body, Recriminations Remain
text: SOMA, Turkey — Rescue workers removed the last remaining bodies from a stricken mine here on Saturday afternoon as the death toll in Turkey’s worst mining accident rose to 301 people, according to the prime minister’s office.

headline: Talks in East Aim to Ease Tensions in Ukraine
text: KIEV, Ukraine — Senior Ukrainian officials on Saturday held a second session of national “round-table” talks aimed at ending the country’s political crisis, this time in the eastern city of Kharkiv, in the region that has been besieged by pro-Russian separatist violence.

headline: Unemployment: It’s Not Personal
text: Matt O’Brien has an interesting if depressing piece on long-term unemployment, making the point that long-term unemployment is basically bad luck: if you got laid off in a bad economy, you have a hard time finding a new job, and the longer you stay unemployed the harder it becomes to find work.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, May 18
text: “We are making progress, and we just need to keep moving with speed.”

headline: Taking the Earth’s Temperature
text: Geoff DiMego, 65, is a meteorologist at the National Weather Service in College Park, Md.

headline: Tackling the Limits of Touch Screens
text: Touch screens are ubiquitous on tablets and smartphones, but their flat glass surfaces can hinder close reading and accurate typing. People flipping through electronic pages often retain less of what they read than on printed ones, studies suggest. And typing on a flat surface with no physical keys to guide the fingers requires heightened visual attention to avoid typos, draining concentration from the thoughts being expressed.

headline: Geithner, Staying on Script
text: Timothy F. Geithner, the former Treasury secretary, drew a large and respectful crowd last Wednesday at a Barnes & Noble store in Manhattan, where he was publicizing “Stress Test,” his new memoir about the financial crisis. Mr. Geithner left little to chance at the event: It consisted of a highly scripted chat with a friendly interviewer who screened audience questions. After an hour, Mr. Geithner was whisked from the building.

headline: Invasion of the Nail Clippers, and Other Office Dangers
text: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

headline: 1914: Brilliant Troupe of Dancers from Russian Imperial Theatres To Appear in Paris
text: The Russian ballets have become such an established feature of the Paris season that it seems difficult to realize that they were only introduced to the French public nine years ago. Perhaps it was their novelty and the charm of exotism which attracted western audiences first.

headline: In B-School, Is That a Syllabus, or an Itinerary?
text: One weekend in February, about a third of Sean Pool’s classmates at the McCombs School of Business at the University of Texas at Austin went on a three-day ski trip to Park City, Utah. The event included nighttime, après-ski outings in town, as well as time to relax in a hot tub, according to the itinerary posted on Facebook. The Graduate Business Adventure Team, a student-run group, planned the trip.

headline: Facial Recognition Software in Action
text: Aharon Zeevi Farkash, the founder of FST Biometrics, demonstrates how his company’s technology can identify people from their appearance and movements.

headline: Hannah Paramore, on Keeping Strengths From Running Amok
text: This interview with  Hannah Paramore, president of Paramore, the Digital Agency, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Never Forgetting a Face
text: Joseph J. Atick cased the floor of the Ronald Reagan Building and International Trade Center in Washington as if he owned the place. In a way, he did. He was one of the organizers of the event, a conference and trade show for the biometrics security industry. Perhaps more to the point, a number of the wares on display, like an airport face-scanning checkpoint, could trace their lineage to his work.

headline: The Harmony They Want to Hear
text: Apple’s reported plans to acquire Beats Electronics for $3.2 billion seemed downright strange to some of the people who follow Apple closely. Yet a deal could help jump-start two important industries.

headline: Much Less Room at the Inn
text: The Times is converting all of its 1964 issues into a digitized, searchable format. Each week, The Upshot will unearth an item from 50 years ago and put it in the light of today. “Rush of Tourists Early This Year” appeared on May 14 and can be seen in its original format on TimesMachine.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Americans Claim to Attend Church Much More Than They Do
text: The United States has long been unusually religious for an affluent, industrialized Western nation — in survey after survey, Americans report relatively high levels of belief in God, affiliation with religious institutions and participation in worship services.

headline: Countdown to the 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 26
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Two California Chrome Owners Who Aren’t Fond of Spotlight Choose to Stay Behind
text: BALTIMORE — When California Chrome’s improbable journey reached Pimlico Race Course for Saturday’s Preakness Stakes, two notable people from his entourage were missing.

headline: Variety: A Mistaken Acrostic
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — Well, that was interesting. Today’s acrostic did not fall for me the way I thought it would, although it was perfectly reasonable and I loved the quote. All I’ll say is that by the time I typed in the final answer, I was ready for a GODMOTHER cocktail.

headline: Making Room for Low Cost and High Style
text: On the heels of hotels like Yotel and Aloft, a crop of new brands is designed for millennial travelers.

headline: Victor in India Promises to Make Country Strong
text: NEW DELHI — Narendra Modi, the man expected to become India’s next prime minister, swept into the capital on Saturday morning in a triumphal procession to the colonial bungalows here that still serve as India’s power center and promised that he “will try to make India self-reliant and strong.”

headline: Connecting a Camera to a Tablet
text: Q. Can you connect a digital camera directly to a tablet computer to offload photos?

headline: Inquiry by General Motors Is Said to Focus on Its Lawyers
text: DETROIT — As General Motors faces a number of continuing investigations into its handling of a vehicle safety defect linked to 13 deaths, its legal department has become a focus of a broad internal inquiry into how the company handled the issue, according to two people with knowledge of the inquiry.

headline: In Taking Crimea, Putin Gains a Sea of Fuel Reserves
text: When Russia seized Crimea in March, it acquired not just the Crimean landmass but also a maritime zone more than three times its size with the rights to underwater resources potentially worth trillions of dollars.

headline: West African Nations Set Aside Their Old Suspicions to Combat Boko Haram
text: PARIS — The heads of state of five West African countries, including Nigeria, met Saturday with Western officials and agreed to share intelligence and strengthen military cooperation to combat the regional threat from the extremist Islamist group Boko Haram, which abducted more than 200 schoolgirls in northern Nigeria last month.

headline: A Long-Shared Love of Racing and a Champion
text: BALTIMORE — Even before California Chrome romped in the Kentucky Derby, much had been made about his blue-collar owners — Steve Coburn and Perry Martin — and their tale of landing on thoroughbred racing’s biggest stage with the first horse they bred.

headline: San Antonio Mayor Julián Castro Is Said to Be HUD Pick in Cabinet Reshuffling
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama is preparing to nominate Mayor Julián Castro of San Antonio as his new secretary of housing and urban development, elevating one of his party’s Hispanic rising stars as part of a cabinet shuffle that has possible implications for the 2016 presidential race, Democrats informed about the plans said on Saturday.

headline: A Racing Prodigy Comes Into His Own After Hard Lessons
text: MOORESVILLE, N.C. — The boyish grin has not changed much over the years, although the boy who arrived in Nascar before he was even 18 is all grown up, is engaged to be married and has a hairline that is beginning to thin.

headline: Taste of Postseason Doesn’t Sway Pirates From Their Careful Path
text: Never has competitive balance come into sharper focus than it did early last October, when Yankee Stadium was dark and PNC Park in Pittsburgh crackled with postseason excitement. The teams, who play a doubleheader in the Bronx on Sunday, had been on opposite tracks for two decades. Now, Pittsburgh is not much different than New York.

headline: Vietnamese Officials Intolerant of Violence as Standoff With China Continues
text: HANOI, Vietnam — Vietnamese officials signaled Saturday that further violence over a dispute with China would not be tolerated, declaring that more than 300 people involved in last week’s attacks on foreign-owned businesses would be prosecuted.

headline: Googling While Expecting
text: Web queries indicate that pregnant women around the world tend to crave many of the same things: ice, salt, sweets, spicy foods. But searches (by anyone, men or women) also find differences among countries about pregnancy-related concerns.

headline: Quixotic ’80 Campaign Gave Birth to Kochs’ Powerful Network
text: He backed the full legalization of abortion and the repeal of laws that criminalized drug use, prostitution and homosexuality. He attacked campaign donation limits and assailed the Republican star Ronald Reagan as a hypocrite who represented “no change whatsoever from Jimmy Carter and the Democrats.”

headline: Amid Tumult, N.A.A.C.P. Elects 18th Leader
text: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People elected its 18th leader on Friday night at an annual meeting of the executive board members in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

headline: The World Cup in an Album
text: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — Transactions are made at dozens of established meeting spots here: 122nd Street at 15th; the plaza in Pablo VI; 97th Street at 11th. They are made outside universities, office buildings and supermarkets, by young people, old people, men and women, all in search of stickers. Yes, stickers.

headline: North Carolina Governor Tested by Own G.O.P. as Legislators Return
text: RALEIGH, N.C. — As legislators returned to town last week, 10 months after a tumultuous 2013 session when Republicans passed one deeply conservative bill after another, one Republican seemed a bit like the odd man out.

headline: Thomas Was Alone Moves to the iPad
text: Thomas Was Alone, freshly arrived on the iPad for $9, is a different kind of game app.

headline: Cannes Film Festival:  ‘Timbuktu’ Director on Africa and Fundamentalism
text: CANNES, France — There’s a sad, powerful scene in “Timbuktu,” Abderrahmane Sissako’s well-received new film about that ancient capital’s recent takeover by Islamic fundamentalists, that resonates even more strongly in light of the schoolgirls kidnapped last month as child brides by Islamic fundamentalists in Nigeria.

headline: Johns Hopkins Graduate, and an Umpire
text: TRENTON — A few days each week, before Dan Merzel heads to the ballpark to umpire in the Class AA Eastern League, he tutors high-achieving middle school and high school students participating in a program sponsored by Johns Hopkins. He communicates with them via Skype and email and uses a virtual whiteboard to solve math problems and answer questions.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, May 18
text: Eric Shinseki, the secretary of veterans affairs, fired the department’s head of health care in response to a growing controversy that veterans hospitals in Arizona, Colorado, Texas, Wyoming and elsewhere were concealing the wait time for patients. Last year, Veterans Affairs set a goal for new patients seeking primary care to be seen within 14 days of requesting an appointment.

headline: A Familiar Duel for the West Title
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — The Los Angeles Kings and the Chicago Blackhawks will not surrender the spotlight in the Western Conference.

headline: Poorer Health of Surgery Patients on Medicaid May Alter Law’s Bottom Line
text: WASHINGTON — Surgery patients covered by Medicaid arrive at the hospital in worse health, experience more complications, stay longer and cost more than patients with private insurance, a new study has found.

headline: Medicine’s Top Earners Are Not the M.D.s
text: THOUGH the recent release of Medicare’s physician payments cast a spotlight on the millions of dollars paid to some specialists, there is a startling secret behind America’s health care hierarchy: Physicians, the most highly trained members in the industry’s work force, are on average right in the middle of the compensation pack.

headline: Glass Warfare
text: Welcome, tenant! We trust that your flight from Moscow, Dubai, London and/or Hong Kong was safe, smooth and private. By now you have had the opportunity to explore the palatial condominium in which your financial advisers have decided to park a modicum of your fortune. We are confident that you will enjoy your new home for whatever portion of the year you will be spending in New York, be it three hours or an entire fortnight.

headline: What Farm-to-Table Got Wrong
text: POCANTICO HILLS, N.Y. — IT’S spring again. Hip deep in asparagus — and, soon enough, tomatoes and zucchini — farm-to-table advocates finally have something from the farm to put on the table.

headline: The Promise, and Pitfalls, of Video
text: ADAM NOSSITER’S first response to a now-famous video of the kidnapped Nigerian schoolgirls was caution.

headline: Condi’s Lesson
text: WASHINGTON — THERE has been much mockery of political correctness run amok on college campuses this spring, with knots of know-it-all students and teachers knifing their commencement speakers.

headline: Jan Glier Reeder
text: Jan Glier Reeder is a fashion historian and a co-curator of a retrospective of the work of the designer Charles James currently at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York.

headline: What Do Pregnant Women Want?
text: I AM at the age when many of my friends are pregnant. I thought I had a pretty good idea of what pregnancy entails: the cravings for pickles and chocolate, the abstaining from wine and coffee, the nausea and stretch marks, the aloof but well-meaning husband.

headline: Tears of a Rickshaw Driver
text: AS long as I live, I’ll never forget the rickshaw driver, tears streaming down his cheeks, rushing a gravely injured student to hospital — and away from the soldiers who had just gunned him down.

headline: The Square People, Part 2
text: IN a famous 1995 interview about her dysfunctional marriage and the infidelity of Prince Charles, Princess Diana noted that “there were three of us in this marriage, so it was a bit crowded.” I find myself thinking of that quote lately to describe the new politics and geopolitics that have been produced by “The Square People” — all those newly connected and aspiring middle classes who have gathered in the squares from Cairo to Kiev, Istanbul to Tehran, and Tunis to Moscow to demand a greater voice in their future and better governance. A lot of leaders are discovering that these Square People are like a spontaneous third party that has emerged between themselves and their tame traditional opposition and, as a result, their politics is getting a bit crowded — and a lot more interesting.

headline: Grading Obama’s Foreign Policy
text: SECOND terms are often a time when presidents, balked by domestic opposition, turn to the world stage to secure their legacy — opening doors to China, closing out the Cold War, chasing Middle Eastern peace.

headline: South Sudan in Peril
text: Transforming South Sudan into a viable state after it declared independence from Sudan in 2011 was always going to be a huge challenge. President Salva Kiir and rebel commander Riek Machar have made that task vastly more difficult.

headline: Children Don’t Belong in Tobacco Fields
text: A new report from Human Rights Watch paints a grim picture of child labor in the United States, something that most Americans probably believe was banned years ago. Children as young as 7 are working on tobacco farms in North Carolina, Kentucky, Tennessee and Virginia, and many are said to suffer from the symptoms of acute nicotine poisoning.

headline: Self-Care Strategies
text: Readers discuss a doctor’s call for expanded use of mind-body techniques for both financial and health reasons.

headline: Class, Cost and College
text: THE word “crisis” pops up frequently in “Ivory Tower,” a compelling new documentary about the state of higher education in America.

headline: All Blurbed Out
text: LAST month, a disturbance rippled through M.F.A. programs, publishing houses and certain neighborhoods of Brooklyn. Gary Shteyngart, Emperor of Encomia, Prince of Panegyric, Baron of Blurbs, whose breathless endorsements have graced some 150 books in the past decade, was retiring from writing promotional copy for book flaps and covers.

headline: A Life Beyond ‘Do What You Love’
text: Student advisees often come to my office, rubbing their hands together, furrowing their brows and asking me to walk along with them as they ponder life after graduation. Just the other day, a sophomore made an appointment because he was worrying about whether he should become a doctor or a philosophy professor. A few minutes later, he nervously confessed that he had also thought of giving stand-up comedy a whirl.

headline: The House Ducks on Defense
text: The Pentagon has for too long been in denial about the changes it will have to make in a world of declining resources, skyrocketing personnel costs and changing global threats. This year, however, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel presented a more realistic, though still insufficient, cost-saving budget. Yet Congress seems firmly stuck in the past, loyal to campaign donors and frightened, as always, about local political fallout from closing excess military bases, modifying military compensation, reducing troop levels and cutting nonessential or older weapons.

headline: Too Soon to Assume Anything in Baseball
text: Baseball’s regular season reached its quarter pole on Friday. The 608th game was played, meaning that one-fourth of the 2,430-game schedule was complete.

headline: Third Pick Gives Jets an Unofficial Coach
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The play that ruined Dexter McDougle’s senior season at Maryland did not ruin his life. It dislocated his right shoulder and fractured his scapula and ended his collegiate career and, for a few hours, sent his world tumbling down, as he put it. But he did not pout, and he did not sulk, and he did not withdraw from his teammates, who needed him as much he needed them.

headline: A Powerhouse From the Berkshires
text: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass. — It is the middle of May, and Alison Swain is doing the same thing she has done for the last seven years: preparing her Williams College women’s tennis team to compete in the N.C.A.A. Division III tournament.

headline: Arizona’s All-Points Bulletin: Who Can Take in a Chihuahua?
text: PHOENIX — A pack of 26 stray Chihuahuas rode 2,400 miles in the back of an S.U.V. in late March, a cross-country trip from an animal shelter here to another just outside Philadelphia, where all but one were adopted in days.

headline: Billionaire Democrat Sets Eye on Senate Races
text: Tom Steyer, the billionaire climate activist, recently contributed $5 million to a “super PAC” dedicated to keeping Democrats in control of the United States Senate, cementing his alliance with the party as the 2014 campaign swings into high gear.

headline: Late Recovery Yields an Expected Rematch Between Pacers and Heat
text: It should not be surprising that the two top-seeded teams in the Eastern Conference advanced to the conference finals. Over the 82-game grind of the regular season, the Indiana Pacers and Miami Heat demolished the rest of the conference, and each of their four meetings was billed as a conference final preview.

headline: Warning: The Literary Canon Could Make Students Squirm
text: SANTA BARBARA, Calif. — Should students about to read “The Great Gatsby” be forewarned about “a variety of scenes that reference gory, abusive and misogynistic violence,” as one Rutgers student proposed? Would any book that addresses racism — like “The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn” or “Things Fall Apart” — have to be preceded by a note of caution? Do sexual images from Greek mythology need to come with a viewer-beware label?

headline: Injuries to Key Players Loom Over Spurs-Thunder Series
text: Two left legs may decide this matchup of the best teams in the Western Conference.

headline: Fare Dodging Is an Organized Rebellion in Stockholm, and It’s Winning
text: STOCKHOLM — The first target stumbled through the Hornstull metro station here with her nose in her purse, too harried to notice the man sidling up behind her.

headline: U.N. Seeking More Ways to Distribute Aid in Syria
text: UNITED NATIONS — The United Nations is under pressure to ratchet up aid to nongovernmental organizations that can operate in the vast sections of Syria under opposition control, as most of the humanitarian relief sponsored by the organization ends up in the western slice of the country held by President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: A Rangers Forward Amazes an Economist
text: According to a new study from the University of British Columbia, a typical N.H.L. player reaches his peak performance level from 27 to 29, with his best years ranging from 24 to about 34. After that, it is all downhill.

headline: An Impenetrable Fortress Proves Porous as the Rangers Take Game 1
text: MONTREAL — For years, Bell Centre was a house of horrors for the Rangers. On Saturday during Game 1 of the Eastern Conference finals, it became a house of horrors for the host Montreal Canadiens.

headline: Ukrainians Working in Italy Do What They Can to Help
text: ROME — Mar’yana Tril, one of the more than 192,000 Ukrainians who live and work in Italy, took an unscheduled holiday from her job as a babysitter in February. As the rebellion against the government mounted back home, so did the anguish of being away.

headline: Highlights and Analysis: California Chrome Adds Preakness Victory in Triple Crown Quest
text: BALTIMORE — The Kentucky Derby winner California Chrome easily added a victory in the 139th running of the Preakness Stakes on Saturday at Pimlico Race Course, keeping alive his bid to become the 12th Triple Crown winner and the first since Affirmed in 1978.

headline: Comeback Carries Arsenal to F.A. Cup, Ending a Nine-Year Trophy Drought
text: LONDON — Arsène Wenger is not often an expressive man. Wenger, the longtime Arsenal manager, wears conservative suits while stalking the sideline, and typically has a dour demeanor to match. The Gunners’ last major trophy came in 2005, and over the past nine years, it was occasionally observed that perhaps Wenger’s last real smile was spotted around the same time.

headline: In Connecticut, Republicans Face Primary in Race to Unseat Governor
text: UNCASVILLE, Conn. — It was seemingly the perfect place for the state Republican Convention — the Mohegan Sun resort — given the gambling nature of the vote for a candidate to unseat Gov. Dannel P. Malloy, a Democrat.

headline: Libyans Told to Leave City Amid Clashes
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Armed units loyal to a former general in eastern Libya told civilians to leave parts of Benghazi on Saturday as the troops prepared for a new assault on Islamist militias a day after heavy fighting there.

headline: After Criticism, Times Publisher Details Decision to Oust Top Editor
text: Arthur Sulzberger Jr., the publisher of The New York Times, released a statement Saturday afternoon detailing his decision to fire the newspaper’s executive editor, Jill Abramson. He was responding to a growing controversy over accusations by Ms. Abramson’s supporters that gender played a role in her dismissal.

headline: After Trade to Pittsburgh, a Former Met Finds a Career Renaissance
text: Pittsburgh Pirates Manager Clint Hurdle greets each new player on his team with a meeting in his office. It was no different upon Ike Davis’s arrival, even though he had come from a tumultuous situation with the Mets.

headline: Oh, Who?
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — You can practically hear the shamrocks growing and the Irish coffee (which I know is not really Irish) a-brewing with Joe DiPietro’s puzzle. Also, I hope you like punny theme entries with O’s in them. I know I did.

headline: AT&T Is Said to Be Near a Deal to Buy DirecTV
text: AT&T is poised to announce a takeover of DirecTV Inc. within days, people briefed on the matter said on Saturday, ushering in another sweeping transformation of the telecommunications industry.

headline: Rowing Toward Hope in a Troubled World
text: CHICAGO — When Montana Butsch, the founder of a nonprofit organization that introduces inner-city youth to rowing, visited Daniel Reyes’s school on the Southwest side four years ago, Reyes had never heard of the sport.

headline: Texas Noir, by Directors Who Aren’t From Texas
text: The new film “Cold in July” displays all the hallmarks of a country noir, a subgenre perhaps most famously embodied by Joel and Ethan Coen’s 1984 classic “Blood Simple.”

headline: California Chrome Wins Preakness for Second Jewel
text: BALTIMORE — His big brother Jose was on hand, just as he was two weeks ago for the Kentucky Derby, just as he had always been in the right place at the right time for Victor Espinoza. It was Jose who taught him how to get along with horses when they were children in Mexico.

headline: Caregivers Struggle to Untie a Confining Knot
text: Rose Okoro, a nurse practitioner who specializes in family medicine, opened the Daystar Family Clinic in Katy, Tex., in October. Seven months later, she has only enough patients to work there part time.

headline: U.S. Title Event Could Be the Old Guard’s Last Stand
text: Gata Kamsky is the favorite this week to win the United States Championship for the fourth time in five years. But his nearest tournament rivals are closing the talent gap, and it is clear that there will soon be a changing of the guard.

headline: Freedom to Act as Election Year Draws to Close
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: Time to Exercise, if Not Place to Shower, at State Agencies
text: About 30 employees, from driver’s license examiners to forensic scientists, filed into the gym at the Texas Department of Public Safety in Austin during lunch on Wednesday. The group spent half an hour lifting dumbbells to a heavy metal soundtrack, grunting as an instructor corrected their form.

headline: After Homer of His Own, Lagares Steals Another’s
text: WASHINGTON — Juan Lagares tried to look serious as he puffed his chest and strutted around center field, but he could not help but grin. He had just sprinted, leapt at the wall and robbed Jayson Werth of a home run in a magnificent display of athleticism — after he had already crushed his own two-run homer.

headline: A Restoration Puzzle
text: In China’s Yungang Grottoes, a team is battling to restore ancient Buddhist artifacts broken by vandals and ravaged by pollution.

headline: Outlasting Dynasties, Now Emerging From Soot
text: DATONG, China — The colossal Buddhist statues in the cliffside caves outside this northern Chinese city, carved from golden sandstone by Turkic-speaking nomad conquerors in the fifth and sixth centuries, were so covered in coal dust that when visitors blew on them, black clouds rose up.

headline: Deep Ties, Tested on Mexico’s Border
text: LAREDO, Tex. — The state’s standardized test approached like a spring storm, and Alina Quiroga knew her fourth graders could drown. Here at a school about a mile from Mexico along Interstate 35, most of her students rarely speak English outside class. Many, living with distant relatives, lack the confidence to speak up even in Spanish. Ms. Quiroga circled the room, her pearl drop earrings swaying, as the children read aloud about George Washington.

headline: The Way North
text: Reporter Damien Cave and photographer Todd Heisler traveled up Interstate 35, from Laredo, Tex., to Duluth, Minn., chronicling how the middle of America is being changed by immigration.

headline: William Worthy, a Reporter Drawn to Forbidden Datelines, Dies at 92
text: William Worthy, a foreign correspondent who in the thick of the Cold War ventured where the United States did not want him to go — including the Soviet Union, China, Cuba — and became the subject of both a landmark federal case concerning travel rights and a ballad by the protest singer Phil Ochs, died on May 4 in Brewster, Mass. He was 92.

headline: Five Homers Lift Yanks, but Bullpen Doesn’t Get Hoped-For Relief
text: It seems almost inconceivable that the Yankees, who spent nearly half a billion dollars in the off-season on free agents, are suddenly dependent on converted relievers to fill out their rotation. But that was where things stood on Saturday afternoon.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times poll is based on telephone interviews conducted May 7 to 11 with 1,000 adults throughout the United States. Interviews were in English or Spanish.

headline: McDonagh Returns to Top Form Against the Team That Sent Him Away
text: MONTREAL — They could have loved him here, and they would have, too, had Ryan McDonagh remained a member of the Montreal Canadiens organization. It was not his choice to leave five years ago. A trade was made, he was included, and off he went to New York, the Rangers elated that he had done so.

headline: ‘Orphan Black’ Recap: They Are Family
text: No spoiler warning, no episode description, no preview clip could have prepared me for the latest shocking development on this week’s installment of BBC America’s “Orphan Black”: No Alison! That’s right, everyone’s favorite cloned suburbanite did not even make an appearance on Saturday. But despite that particular tragedy, there were a few events worthy of discussion.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 17, 2014
Quotation of the Day for Sunday, May 18, 2014
text: “The history of the U.S. until maybe the last generation or two was an east-to-west migration. Now, it’s south to north, and it’s on the highways.”

headline: Corrections: May 18, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Yeney Hernandez, Jason Wu
text: Yeney Hernandez and Jason Wu were married Saturday by Gerald E. Williams, a civil magistrate appointed by the Circuit Court of Arlington County, Va., who officiated in his office in Arlington.

headline: Natalie Exner, Ethan Dean
text: Natalie Mae Exner and Ethan Wesley Dean were married Saturday evening at Tupper Manor, an event space in Beverly, Mass. Alan W. Ulrich, a Massachusetts justice of the peace, officiated.

headline: Katie Horn, Samuel Kooris
text: Katie Annette Horn, the daughter of Marjorie E. Horn and Kenneth S. Horn of New York, was married Saturday evening to Samuel Thomas Kooris, the son of Anne L. Levine of Newton Centre, Mass., and Irvin H. Kooris of Marietta, Ga. Rabbi Brian D. Fink led the ceremony at Three Sixty Degrees, an event space in New York.

headline: Kendall Swenson, Alexander Lee
text: Kendall Margit Swenson, a daughter of Michele R. Swenson and Gregory D. Swenson of Shaker Heights, Ohio, was married Saturday evening to Alexander Decker Lee, a son of Judy M. Lee and Christopher P. Lee of Basking Ridge, N.J. Jason S. Morrison, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated at the chapel at Windsor, a residential community in Vero Beach, Fla.

headline: Leigh Ross, Roosevelt Montás
text: Leigh Christine Ross and Roosevelt Bernardo Montás were married Friday at A Voce Madison, a restaurant in New York. Timothy Cassedy, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

headline: Lily Kosner and Douglas Mirabello
text: Lily Josephine Kosner, the daughter of Julie Baumgold and Edward Kosner of New York, was married Saturday to Douglas Robert Mirabello, a son of Donna S. Mirabello and Robert B. Mirabello of Haddonfield, N.J. Maureen Duffy-Lewis, a judge of the Los Angeles County Superior Court, officiated at the home of Elizabeth and Richard Berman in Malibu, Calif., friends of the couple.

headline: Stephanie Herschaft, Daniel Palmadesso
text: Stephanie Michelle Herschaft and Daniel Richard Palmadesso are to be married Sunday at the Woodlands at Woodbury, an event space in Woodbury, N.Y. Cantor George Lindenblatt is to officiate.

headline: Kristina Demas and Enoch Woodhouse III

That evening, Nisha P. Phatak and Nicholas D. Wilson, a sister and the brother of the couple, led a nondenominational ceremony that incorporated the lighting of a unity candle and included a reading from Nietzsche’s “Joyful Wisdom.”

Drake McFeely of Chappaqua, N.Y. James Goodman, an uncle of the groom who received permission from Massachusetts, officiated at the vacation home of the groom’s parents in Truro, Mass.

text: Laura Beth Dowling and Marc Joseph Altshuler were married Wednesday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. Angel L. Lopez of the New York City Clerk’s office officiated.

headline: North Korea Reports ‘Serious’ Collapse at Building Project Believed to House Dozens
text: SEOUL, South Korea — A 23-story apartment building that may have housed more than 90 families collapsed last week in Pyongyang, the North Korean capital, a South Korean government official said Sunday after the North reported a “serious” accident at a construction site.

headline: Libération Covering a Civil War. Its Own.
text: PARIS — What would Jean-Paul Sartre say?

headline: Mapping Our Interiors
text: Sure, that’s your office cubicle. Your corner store. Maybe even the layout of your furniture in your living room. But that doesn’t mean that soon we won’t all be peering at it, too.

headline: ‘You’re Not My Real Mother’
text: In so many ways, my daughter Julia is a young soon-to-be 12-year-old. Though she’s in middle school, she’s unconcerned with fashion, boys or other pre-pubescent experimenting. Julia, adopted from a Siberian orphanage at 8 months old, is on track intellectually but is still catching up emotionally. She is a wonderful violinist and artist and an honor student, but she hasn’t yet learned how to make a BFF, nor (and I suppose I should be thankful) has she attached herself to a clique. My husband and I are her whole world.

headline: Vietnamese Police Block Anti-Chinese Demonstrators After Violence Over Oil Rig
text: HANOI, Vietnam — The Vietnamese government stopped anti-Chinese demonstrators from gathering outside the Chinese Embassy here Sunday, deploying a large number of police officers on the sidewalks around the building and urging the few pedestrians to keep walking.

headline: Vows | Dating Coaches in Love
text: Laurie Davis, an online dating expert, reached out to the professional wingman Thomas Edwards to help build her client list, but they ended up using their pickup skills on each other.

headline: Police Shoot Armed Man in an East Harlem Housing Project
text: Two police officers on routine patrol in an East Harlem housing development shot and wounded an armed man early Sunday morning, the police said.

headline: Marc Andreessen on the Future of Silicon Valley(s), and the Next Big Technology
text: Silicon Valley is starting to feel a little less exuberant these days.

headline: Cannes Film Festival: Strauss-Kahn Film Under Fire
text: Updated, 2:50 p.m. | CANNES — Late Saturday night at a beach club here, revelers gathered on the dance floor wearing unique party favors: white terrycloth bathrobes with black monograms that read “WTNY.” The letters stood for “Welcome to New York,” Abel Ferrara’s graphic and barely fictionalized film about the sexual assault case involving Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former managing director of the International Monetary Fund.

headline: What’s On Sunday
text: 8 P.M. (ABC) 2014 BILLBOARD MUSIC AWARDS Ludacris, above, hosts this ceremony, broadcast live from the MGM Grand Garden Arena in Las Vegas and honoring Billboard chart toppers from March 11, 2013, through March 9, 2014, in genres including R&B, rap, pop, country, rock, Latin and alternative. “Slave to the Rhythm,” a never-released Michael Jackson song, is to be performed by a Jackson hologram. Jennifer Lopez will perform and accept the Billboard Icon award, given to an “enduring legend in music.” Lorde, Miley Cyrus, Ricky Martin, Miranda Lambert, Carrie Underwood, Ariana Grande, Iggy Azalea, 5 Seconds of Summer, Florida Georgia Line, Imagine Dragons, Jason Derulo, John Legend, Luke Bryan, OneRepublic and Pitbull are scheduled to appear.

headline: G.M.’s Ignition Problem: Who Knew What When
text: Events leading to G.M.’s recall of 2.6 million cars because of a defective ignition switch.

headline: Nine Months Later, Still Working to Find a Job
text: Every night, Sharon Cabelly power-pedals on the exercise bicycle in her bedroom, clearing her head of any angst or anxiety. Then, before bed, she recites her favorite psalms, praying first for others in need and finally for her own peace of mind.

headline: A Big ‘Godzilla’ Has a Big Weekend
text: Fatty? Oh, yes. A remake of “Godzilla” took in an estimated $93.2 million in tickets at North American theaters over the weekend, a huge No. 1 total that left this version of the radioactive lizard – mocked online in recent weeks for being too chubby – with the last laugh. (Or at least roar.) “Godzilla,” powered in part by strong Imax and 3-D screenings, cost a reported $195 million to make, with tax credits bringing the net cost closer to $160 million. Legendary Pictures and Warner Brothers collaborated on the picture, but Legendary put up 75 percent of the budget and will thus reap an outsize share of the profits.

headline: California Chrome’s Nasal Strip Could Be an Issue in Belmont
text: BALTIMORE — Would the owners of California Chrome scrap a historic Triple Crown bid over an equipment issue? The trainer Art Sherman raised that possibility Sunday morning, saying the co-owner Perry Martin might decide to hold California Chrome out of the Belmont Stakes if the colt is not allowed to wear a nasal strip for the third leg of the Triple Crown.

headline: Johnson Controls to Spin Off Auto Interiors Unit
text: Johnson Controls, the industrial conglomerate based in Milwaukee, said on Sunday that it would spin off its automotive interiors business into a new joint venture with a Chinese partner.

headline: Countdown to the 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 25
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Court May Hold Fate of Children Knocked Off Citizenship Path
text: Desperate to fill classroom vacancies, New York City school officials sent recruiting teams around the world in the late 1990s, promising jobs and help in obtaining green cards that would be a path to citizenship.

headline: The Dark Guest
text: Will China let the beast into the house?

headline: Swiss Voters Defeat $24.65 Minimum Wage by a Wide Margin
text: Swiss voters resoundingly rejected on Sunday a proposed minimum wage that would have been the world’s highest, a move widely seen as reflecting an aversion to state intervention in the liberal economic policies that are the bedrock of Switzerland’s prosperity.

headline: When ‘Going Lean’ Goes Wrong
text: In recent years, the “Lean Startup” movement, championed by Eric Ries, has really caught on. This philosophy encourages companies to find winning ideas through efficient cycles of building, measuring and learning, which has led to the widespread adoption of popular concepts like “minimum viable products,” “data-driven decisions” and “failing fast.”

headline: G.O.P. Chairman Says Clinton’s Health and Age Are Fair Issues
text: WASHINGTON — Reince Priebus, the chairman of the Republican National Committee, insisted on Sunday that Hillary Rodham Clinton’s health and age were fair targets for inquiry ahead of a possible 2016 presidential run, as both he and Karl Rove, the Republican strategist who injected those questions into the debate, suggested that such scrutiny might dissuade her from running.

headline: Ex-Trader’s Pilgrimage Culminates in Jail Cell
text: PARIS — Two days after suspending what he had billed as an almost spiritual trek from Vatican City to Paris, the convicted rogue trader Jérôme Kerviel crossed from Italy into France on Sunday and turned himself in to the French authorities, minutes before a midnight deadline.

headline: Five Unite So the Future Will Know Their Tunes
text: Jazz at Lincoln Center has not only been commissioning new music but also assembling new, high-concept ensembles. For the New Jazz Standards quintet, which made its debut on Friday night in Jazz at Lincoln Center’s Appel Room, melody was paramount. The quintet is an all-star group of composers whose daunting task was to come up with 21st-century jazz standards.

headline: Deutsche Bank Plans to Raise $11 Billion in Fresh Capital
text: FRANKFURT — Deutsche Bank, the largest German bank, said on Sunday that it would raise roughly $11 billion in new capital from existing shareholders and the royal family of Qatar, responding to regulatory pressure on banks to reduce risk.

headline: Short Pieces That, Together, Span Centuries
text: In his late 50s, Brahms kept threatening to quit composing. But he could not help himself. Among the works he wrote during his last years were four collections of shorter pieces for piano, composed in 1892 and 1893. (He died in 1897, a month before turning 64.) Though these late piano pieces are ingenious, consequential and even experimental compositions, displaying a bit of impishness, Brahms called many of them intermezzos — a category that implies a short piece meant to be performed between longer ones.

headline: Teams Split, as Do Many Fans
text: Shortly after the start of the second game of Sunday’s single-admission doubleheader between the Yankees and the Pittsburgh Pirates, it became evident that neither the teams nor the fans at Yankee Stadium were prepared for a daylong event that was a relic of another era.

headline: Paul Rudd to Play Einstein at World Science Festival
text: After appearing in celebrations of dimwittedness like “Our Idiot Brother,” “Dinner for Schmucks” and “Anchorman,” Paul Rudd is taking on the ultimate high-I.Q. role: Albert Einstein.

headline: AT&T to Buy DirecTV for $48.5 Billion in Move to Expand Clout
text: Updated, 10:06 p.m. |

headline: In Last-Ditch Bid, Pfizer Offers $119 Billion for AstraZeneca
text: Pfizer has again raised its offer for AstraZeneca, making what it said was a final effort to bring the giant British drug maker to the negotiating table.

headline: Sega and Nintendo Wage Battle That Was No Game
text: Video games have emerged as a vibrant, imaginative pursuit, the art form at the intersection of computers and interactivity. But they are also a business, one that was built by people with experience making and selling toys, consumer electronics and coin-operated amusements like pinball machines.

headline: The Mighty Warriors Set Sail: Three Translations
text: TOLKIEN IN PROSE From J. R. R. Tolkien’s 1926 prose translation of “Beowulf,” to be published this week:

headline: Drugs Found to Aid Breathing in a Fatal Lung Disease
text: For the first time, researchers have found drugs that can slow the decline of people with a fatal lung disease, idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis.

headline: Waving His Wand at ‘Beowulf’
text: There’s more to J. R. R. Tolkien than wizards and hobbits. The author of “The Lord of the Rings” and “The Hobbit” was also an Oxford University professor specializing in languages like Old Norse and Old English.

headline: Obama Angry Over Falsification of Veterans Affairs Data, Chief of Staff Says
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama is “madder than hell” about reports that some medical facilities run by the Department of Veterans Affairs have falsified data to hide substantial delays for veterans to see doctors, and he has demanded that the department’s leaders “fix these things,” the White House chief of staff said in an interview aired Sunday.

headline: First, Voices, Then Bodies
text: If you don’t speak Portuguese or French, it’s hard to understand, in the conventional sense, the first half of Emmanuelle Huynh’s “A Vida Enorme/épisode 1.” For about 20 minutes, two disembodied voices, male and female, converse in those voluptuous languages, broadcast from a stack of speakers in the middle of the otherwise empty space. The only activity happens in the form of light, which slowly fades and intensifies, singling out features of the sanctuary at St. Mark’s Church. The program contains English translations of the text, by the Portuguese poet Herberto Hélder, but how necessary are these? The sensuousness of the voices, their texture, say a lot in themselves.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week of May 19
text: MAJOR RETAILERS SET TO REPORT EARNINGS

headline: North Miami Fights to Keep Its Art Museum
text: NORTH MIAMI, Fla. — Anyone looking to meet the director of the tiny but highly regarded Museum of Contemporary Art here has two choices. Head into the museum, where its interim director, Alex Gartenfeld, has an office. Or go next door to City Hall, where the city manager’s appointee to the same position, Babacar M’Bow, is essentially working in exile.

headline: Spotted at Cannes: Ice to Go With Steam
text: CANNES, France — “Gabe! Gabe!” Slava Fetisov, the former ice hockey god, was yelling across the sun-splashed courtyard at the director Gabe Polsky. A loud mechanical noise had begun whirring near Mr. Fetisov as he was being interviewed about “Red Army,” Mr. Polsky’s documentary about the rise and fall of Soviet hockey that is playing at the Cannes Film Festival. Mr. Fetisov — who helped lead the Soviet team to two Olympic gold medals and one silver as well as seven world championships in the 1970s and ’80s — wanted his director to deal with it.

headline: A Spring Season Unfolds With a Youthful Flourish
text: The dancing of New York City Ballet this spring has abounded in debuts and revelations. The illustrious Sara Mearns has reached new heights of eloquence. At two performances over the weekend she finally conquered the lofty ballerina role of the adagio second movement of George Balanchine’s “Symphony in C.” It’s a part she’s danced for years, but with a certain tension that has held her back. This time, partnered superlatively by Jared Angle (making his debut in this part), she demonstrated a tragic glamour and courage that bound everyone in her spell.

headline: Going for Visceral Excitement in Popular Standbys
text: Recent reports on the activities of the eminent Latvian maestro Mariss Jansons raised questions, if not necessarily concerns, about the state of his health.

headline: Cashless Customers Hold Riches for Retailers
text: Standing in line at Starbucks, customers are presented with an array of options beyond just flavors and foam: They can pay with cash, credit, debit, a Starbucks card or with their mobile phone in two different ways.

headline: One Whose Work is Taxing
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Do you hear all the noise? Would someone please pick up that PHONE? It gets a little loud when PHONEs start RINGing inside the confines of a 15 x 15 crossword puzzle, so we’ll just have to shout to be heard.

headline: For Six Hours at a Festival, the Sound of Extremes Colliding
text: “Hardcore Activity in Progress,” a one-night, 15-act concert Friday at the Knockdown Center in Maspeth, Queens, represented an idea. The idea was the sound of extremes — going for it, boundary-testing, hardness — across musical languages. So, for instance, there was the noise band Wolf Eyes, the cello improviser Okkyung Lee, the grindcore group Napalm Death, the rapper Gunplay, the post-minimal piano rhapsodist Lubomyr Melnyk, the free-jazz trio the Thing, and the electronic musician Tim Hecker, presented in overlapping sets, in three different parts of a 50,000-square-foot former door-frame factory.

headline: Slapdash Play Slaps Mets’ Psyche and Dashes Perceptions of Progress
text: WASHINGTON — Not much seemed to separate the Mets and the Nationals on Sunday. Neither starting pitcher was at his best, which created opportunities for both teams as the afternoon crawled along. Ultimately, the Nationals won, 6-3.

headline: A Great Bid in Semifinals for USA-1 in Atlanta
text: In Phoenix, the trial to select the USA-1 team for next year’s Bermuda Bowl world championship, in India, has reached the last match.

headline: Student Debt Grows Faster at Universities With Highest-Paid Leaders, Study Finds
text: At the 25 public universities with the highest-paid presidents, both student debt and the use of part-time adjunct faculty grew far faster than at the average state university from 2005 to 2012, according to a new study by the Institute for Policy Studies, a left-leaning Washington research group.

headline: Sailing Rio’s Spoiled Bay
text: Two years ahead of the 2016 Summer Olympics, sailors on Rio’s Guanabara Bay train in water tainted by sewage runoff and garbage from poor neighborhoods.

headline: How DNA Changed the World of Forensics
text: Before DNA testing, prosecutors relied on less sophisticated forensic techniques, including microscopic hair analysis, to put criminals behind bars. But how reliable was hair analysis?

headline: Note to Olympic Sailors: Don’t Fall in Rio’s Water
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Nico Delle Karth, an Austrian sailor preparing for the 2016 Summer Olympics, said it was the foulest place he had ever trained.

headline: DNA Analysis Exposes Flaws in an Inexact Forensic Science
text: By now — despite the apparent infallibility of detectives from Sherlock Holmes to Lieutenant Columbo, despite the clinical genius of wizards from Dr. Quincy to Gil Grissom — it should surprise no one that forensic science is not the model of exactitude that popular culture might have us believe. The scientific rigor of entrenched forensic disciplines has been challenged for years. Still, we live in a “C.S.I.” world, and television viewers could be forgiven for assuming that laboratory techniques used to catch bad guys are unassailable. In real life, though, the soundness of criminal analysis is being regularly tested, both in America’s labs and in its courtrooms.

headline: Composed Pacers Muscle Past the Heat
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Change the narrative. Alter the perception. Convince the basketball-viewing world that the team with the best record this season in the Eastern Conference could actually make it to the N.B.A. finals.

headline: Blackstone to Sell Boston Office Buildings for $2.1 Billion
text: Updated, 8:37 p.m. | The Blackstone Group has agreed to sell five office properties in the Boston area for $2.1 billion, disposing of part of a sprawling real estate portfolio it bought before the financial crisis, a person briefed on the matter said on Sunday.

headline: Blackhawks Edge Ahead, Creating Traffic at Net
text: CHICAGO — When Chicago Blackhawks Coach Joel Quenneville is asked how to beat top goalies like Jonathan Quick, he preaches traffic in front of the net. That strategy worked twice for Chicago on Sunday, even though the most memorable goal might have been one that did not count.

headline: On Anniversary, a Victory Parade and a Crackdown in Sri Lanka
text: NEW DELHI — Sri Lanka’s government on Sunday marked the fifth anniversary of its victory over Tamil insurgents with a military parade in the south and a broad crackdown on journalists, opposition politicians and students in the once-restive north and east.

headline: BlackBerry’s Partnership With Foxconn Signals Shifting Priorities
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Indonesians have long loved BlackBerry devices. When the company introduced a new phone two and a half years ago, a crowd at shopping mall here became so unruly — in part because of a half-price offer for the first 1,000 buyers — that riot police were rushed in to stand by.

headline: Djokovic Tops Nadal, Closing on No. 1 Spot
text: ROME — Novak Djokovic defeated the world No. 1 and seven-time Italian Open champion Rafael Nadal, 4-6, 6-3, 6-3, in the men’s final at Campo Centrale on Sunday.

headline: Science Standards Divide a State Built on Coal and Oil
text: CHEYENNE, Wyo. — Sitting in the headquarters of the Wyoming Liberty Group, Susan Gore, founder of the conservative think tank, said new national science standards for schools were a form of “coercion,” adding, “I don’t think government should have anything to do with education.”

headline: N.B.A.’s On-Court Leader Embraces Off-Court Mantle Without Fear
text: The N.B.A. might have breathed a sigh of relief last week when the Los Angeles Clippers were knocked out of the playoffs. The loss allowed the league to temporarily brush aside the embarrassing Donald Sterling fiasco. Sterling was barred for life by Commissioner Adam Silver and threatened with the forced sale of his team after the release of recordings in which he chided a female friend for associating with black people.

headline: The Republican War on Workers’ Rights
text: Midterm elections are like fancy software: Experts love them, end-users couldn’t care less. But if the 2010 elections are any indication, we might not want to doze off as we head into the summer months before November. Midterm elections at the state level can have tremendous consequences, especially for low-wage workers. What you don’t know can hurt you — or them.

headline: Walden Media, PG Filmmaker, Seeks Studio Partners Across Cultural Divide
text: LOS ANGELES — William Wilberforce, the English abolitionist of two centuries ago, believed in the power of co-belligerents: those who fight for a common cause while disagreeing forcefully on most everything else.

headline: Horse Racing Holds Its Breath Over a Nasal Strip
text: BALTIMORE — The name California Chrome sounds as if it belongs to a Triple Crown champion — it holds its own alongside Sir Barton and War Admiral, Citation and Secretariat. California Chrome looks the part as well, with his sculpted muscles and shiny-as-a-penny coat.

headline: At F.B.I., Change in Leaders Didn’t Change Focus on Terror
text: WASHINGTON — When James B. Comey was nominated last June to be director of the F.B.I., it seemed to herald the beginning of a new era at the bureau.

headline: Killings Surge in North Bronx, Testing New Police Tactics
text: A teenager gunned down next to a Bronx playground. A U-Haul truck riddled with bullets after a deadly shootout that involved as many as five gunmen. A tattooed 25-year-old from Massachusetts executed, with three shots to the head, one to the back, on a housing project roof.

headline: Political Procedurals Play Starring Role in Fall TV Season
text: IF the 2014-15 television season were to have a theme song, it might be “Hail to the Chief” — no, make that “Chiefs.”

headline: Rangers Show Support for St. Louis at His Mother’s Funeral
text: The Rangers attended the funeral of Martin St. Louis’s mother, France St. Louis, on Sunday afternoon in Laval, Quebec, just outside Montreal.

headline: Poverty Is Not a State of Mind
text: Paul Ryan and Jeb Bush, the didactic-meets-dynastic duo, spoke last week at a Manhattan Institute gathering, providing a Mayberry-like prescription for combating poverty in this country: all it takes is more friendship and traditional marriage.

headline: Some Canadiens Fault Kreider’s Collision
text: MONTREAL — The Montreal Canadiens may need a villain in order to play at their best, and on Sunday, they seemed to find one: the big, fast Rangers forward Chris Kreider.

headline: Springtime for Bankers
text: By any normal standard, economic policy since the onset of the financial crisis has been a dismal failure. It’s true that we avoided a full replay of the Great Depression. But employment has taken more than six years to claw its way back to pre-crisis levels — years when we should have been adding millions of jobs just to keep up with a rising population. Long-term unemployment is still almost three times as high as it was in 2007; young people, often burdened by college debt, face a highly uncertain future.

headline: A Jihadist’s Face Taunts Nigeria From the Shadows
text: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria — He was the quiet one who walked silently to meet fellow disciples in a house by the railroad tracks, declining to greet other men on the street. But when he became agitated — over taking up arms against the government, or about his hatred of Christians and Jews — it was no use arguing with Abubakar Shekau.

headline: A Martial Art, Renewed
text: The ancient martial art of muay boran is making a comeback in Thailand, in the form of the first world championship tournament.

headline: Photos: Old Art, New Title
text: Muay boran is an ancient, unarmed martial art that forms the basis of muay thai boxing, the national sport of Thailand. Muay boran entails strikes with eight contact points (hands, elbows, knees and shins), grappling sweeps and throws.

headline: Europe’s Migration Emergency
text: Italy’s interior minister, Angelino Alfano, has given the European Union an ultimatum: Either step in to help Italy cope with the waves of African migrants who risk drowning in the Mediterranean to reach its shores or Italy will begin sending the people it rescues to neighboring European countries. After the sinking of an overloaded boat last week — 206 people were rescued off the coast of Italy, 17 bodies were recovered, and an unknown number are missing — the European Commission responded. It said Italy should communicate what it expects. This is not an acceptable response.

headline: In Coins, Man Found a Century of Learning
text: In 1918, when he was 7, Eric P. Newman’s grandfather gave him a strange old penny.

headline: Do Better on Predatory Colleges
text: The Obama administration’s proposed rules that would deny federal aid to career training programs that saddle students with crushing debt and useless credentials are a clear improvement over the disastrous status quo. But they will need to be strengthened to fully protect students and taxpayers from predatory for-profit schools that rely on federal student aid for up to 90 percent of their revenue and are well versed in the art of evading the law.

headline: Judges and Justice for Sale
text: Judicial elections have always been a bad idea. The special-interest money unleashed by recent Supreme Court rulings has made them even worse, greatly increasing the influence of political-action committees and supposedly independent groups financed by corporations, unions and other interests with issues before the courts.

headline: Behind the Scenes in Hollywood’s Power Circles, Another Political Adviser
text: LOS ANGELES — Dee Dee Myers, a former Clinton administration spokeswoman, is headed for Warner Bros. Mark Fabiani, another political veteran, has agreed to advise the boycott-plagued Beverly Hills Hotel. And, as it turns out, yet another high-powered political player, Craig Schirmer, has been working behind the scenes at the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.

headline: More Specious Attacks on Reform
text: Conservative critics of President Obama’s health care reforms are engaged in two long-shot lawsuits to overturn the Affordable Care Act or disable one of its central provisions. Both lawsuits should be recognized for what they really are — attempts to use the courts to scuttle a law that Congressional Republicans have repeatedly tried, but failed, to repeal through the political process.

headline: How Strong Is the Tea Party?
text: Has the movement been co-opted or passed by, or is it still a force to be reckoned with?

headline: Front-Runner in Ukraine Election May Be Shifting Putin’s Stance
text: KIEV, Ukraine — On a Sunday in December when the Ukrainian uprising seemed about to tip into wide-scale violence, Petro Poroshenko, a pro-Western billionaire, thrust himself between antigovernment protesters and riot police officers clashing outside the presidential headquarters, climbed on a bulldozer that was threatening to plow through the crowd and grabbed an orange plastic megaphone.

headline: A High-Five Long and Wide
text: Kawhi Leonard is different. Jeff Ayres, a reserve center with the San Antonio Spurs, arrived at this conclusion during a game this season.

headline: Betty Sherrill, Decorator to the White-Shoed and Wealthy, Dies at 91
text: Betty Sherrill, a socialite from the South who helped define the aesthetics of quiet wealth in New York for almost 40 years as the doyenne of McMillen Inc., the city’s oldest interior design firm, died on May 12 in Manhattan. She was 91.

headline: South Korea to Disband Coast Guard, Leader Vows
text: SEOUL, South Korea — President Park Geun-hye of South Korea vowed on Monday to disband her country’s Coast Guard, saying that South Korea owed “reform and a great transformation” to hundreds of high school students who died in a ferry disaster last month.

headline: Glass Ceilings in Statehouses in the Northeast
text: PHILADELPHIA — The industrial Northeast enjoys a reputation as a cradle of liberalism, a region that voted overwhelmingly for America’s first black president, started the push on same-sex marriage rights and can reliably be found at the forefront of causes for equality. But there is a notable gap: The Democratic Party has yet to elect a female governor in Pennsylvania, New Jersey, New York, Rhode Island or Massachusetts.

headline: Turkey Arrests Several Executives Over Mining Disaster
text: ISTANBUL — Under pressure from a public angered by the worst mining accident in Turkey’s history, Turkish authorities on Sunday detained 25 people and arrested at least three mining company executives after an initial investigation suggested that the company had failed to heed safety warnings, the local prosecutor’s office said.

headline: Abramson’s Exit at The Times Puts Tensions on Display
text: Back in 2010, before she became executive editor of The New York Times, Jill Abramson sent me a handwritten attaboy note about a big story. It still hangs in my cubicle: “You wrote a story about the trashing of a once great American institution and people never tire of that.”

headline: Workers at N.Y.U.’s Abu Dhabi Site Faced Harsh Conditions
text: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates — The strike had entered its second day when construction workers at Labor Camp 42 got word that their bosses from the BK Gulf corporation had come to negotiate. Mohammed Amir Waheed Sirkar, an electrician from Bangladesh, scrambled down the stairs to meet them. But when he got to the courtyard, he saw the truth: It wasn’t the bosses who had come. It was the police.

headline: Letter of Termination
text: The visa cancellation for a Bangladeshi worker from New York University’s Saadiyat Island campus, one of hundreds sent home because of “refusal to work” last October. The men, employees of the BK Gulf company, went on strike, which is illegal in the United Arab Emirates.

headline: Patch Sites Turn Corner After Sale and Big Cuts
text: In January, when AOL announced that it was handing over the majority stake in Patch, its troubled hyperlocal news division, to an investment firm, it seemed like the end of a long, tragic story.

headline: Philippine Fishermen Caught in Geopolitical Tussle
text: China’s claim to a coveted fishing area in the South China Sea is endangering the economy of a Philippine fishing town.

headline: A Leviathan Turns Philippine Fishermen Into Desperate Darters
text: MASINLOC, the Philippines — On a scorching recent afternoon, fishermen from this sleepy Philippine town hauled blocks of ice onto a rickety, wooden fishing boat bobbing just off the shore. By nightfall, the boat would be on its way to coveted fishing grounds, and to a cat-and-mouse game with the Chinese Coast Guard.

headline: 2 Heroines Braving Challenges
text: At some time or another, English majors have to deal with character and fate in the novels of Thomas Hardy.

headline: Vacation? The Show Will Still Go On
text: What’s love got to do with it? Audrey Langham, an actress of modest fame and exceptional survival skills, has just set eyes on a man who might do nicely as her sixth husband. Or would it be her seventh? Audrey, played by the remarkable Linda Lavin in Nicky Silver’s “Too Much Sun” at the Vineyard Theater, is fuzzy on personal math.

headline: Ex-General Claims Responsibility for Libyan Parliament Attack
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — A retired Libyan general claimed responsibility for an attack on the Parliament building here on Sunday, two days after his irregular force launched an attack aimed at eradicating powerful Islamist militias from the eastern city of Benghazi.

headline: Long Day at the Stadium
text: The first single-admission Sunday double-header at Yankee Stadium since April 13, 1997.

headline: Popular Demand
text: A strong weekend depends on factors like other potential blockbusters, star power and popular sequels. “Fast and Furious 6” opened opposite “The Hangover III” last year, and in the second week of “Star Trek Into Darkness.”

headline: Scheduling Oddity Is Product of Rainout
text: Two of the oldest franchises in baseball took the field Sunday at Yankee Stadium to take part in one of the pastime’s fading traditions. Fans in yellow Roberto Clemente jerseys and pinstriped Mickey Mantle shirts walked through the turnstiles holding a rarity in their hands: tickets to a single-admission Sunday doubleheader.

headline: Treasury Auctions for the Week of May 19
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Afghan Lovers’ Plight Shaking Up the Lives of Those Left in Their Wake
