headline: Uprising at a French Paper
text: A memo sent to shareholders this year said the paper’s new owners wanted to eliminate the print edition and publish only on digital platforms.

headline: For Long Island Rail Road, a Track Record to Tout: Matching Riders With Lost Items
text: In the corner sits a safe filled with jewelry. Along the walls, shelves are stacked with duffel bags and backpacks. Elsewhere there are piles of lost or abandoned smartphones. And then there is the carbon-fiber leg.

headline: Catastrophic Floods Hit Balkans, Raising Fears for Land Mines and Power Plants
text: WARSAW — At least 33 people have died and tens of thousands have been evacuated in Serbia and Bosnia during three days of torrential rains that fed the most intense flooding the region has seen since records began to be kept more than a century ago.

headline: Chief of Syria’s Air Defense Dies in Battle Near Capital
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The general in charge of Syria’s air defense has been killed in fighting near Damascus, an opposition monitoring group and Syrian security officials said Sunday.

headline: ‘Penny Dreadful’ Recap: Cue the Seance
text: As anyone who ever had a friend with a Ouija board in high school can tell you, there was invariably at least one party that got a little … discombobulated thanks to said friend’s appearance. Not enough to break any mirrors or conjure any succubi or anything, just enough to have some other friends leave early, muttering about that “weird [gender redacted] [name redacted] acting a fool in the basement.”

headline: Divergent Accounts of Plea Negotiations in an Occupy Wall Street Protester’s Assault Case
text: The outrage among Occupy Wall Street sympathizers about the prosecution of Cecily McMillan for assaulting a police officer during a protest in Zuccotti Park has rested largely on a single idea: that zealous prosecutors, seeking to make an example of Ms. McMillan, had refused during negotiations to let her plead guilty to anything less than a felony.

headline: Don Meyer, a Coach With 923 Victories, Is Dead at 69
text: Don Meyer, the head men’s basketball coach at Northern State University in Aberdeen, S.D., was taking his players to a team retreat in September 2008 when his car collided head-on with a truck.

headline: Robert F. Erburu, Who Led Times Mirror Company, Dies at 83
text: Robert F. Erburu, who as chief executive and chairman of the Times Mirror Company helped it become a diverse and powerful media enterprise that expanded well beyond its flagship property, The Los Angeles Times, before the paper and the company were sold, died on May 11 at his home in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 83.

headline: Sidney J. Blatt Dies at 85; Developed ‘Double Helix’ Theory of Depression
text: Sidney J. Blatt, a psychologist whose theory about the origins of depression guided treatment decisions for a generation of psychotherapists and helped deepen scientists’ appreciation of the diverse nature of chronic distress, died on May 11 in Hamden, Conn. He was 85.

headline: Ryanair Feels the Squeeze as Rivals Lower Fares
text: PARIS — A decade of uninterrupted growth for the European budget airline Ryanair stalled last year, the company confirmed on Monday, as the region’s flagging economy and high unemployment drove more rival carriers into the race for cost-conscious travelers.

headline: Reporters on ‘Gutter Oil’ Series Assaulted, People’s Daily Says
text: People’s Daily, the mouthpiece of the Communist Party, says its reporters were attacked and robbed on Sunday while investigating “gutter oil,” waste cooking oil that is illegally recycled and sold to unwitting consumers.

headline: Analysts Have High Hopes for Big Economic Changes Under Modi
text: MUMBAI – Now that the Bharatiya Janata Party and Narendra Modi have won parliamentary elections, voters and foreign investors are expecting Mr. Modi, the front-runner for prime minister, to quickly shore up an economy that has been sputtering for some time.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Schools and Segregation, 60 Years After Brown vs. Board of Education
text: Saturday marked sixty years to the day since the U.S. Supreme Court handed down its decision in the Brown vs. Board of Education case, outlawing “separate but equal” schools for blacks and whites.

headline: Cocooning at Home in Hong Kong
text: A short flight from Vietnam to Hong Kong to renew his visa in 1994 turned into almost a decade of work for Peter Steinhauer.

headline: Should Discomfort Excuse Students From Having to Complete an Assignment?
text: Some colleges and universities are considering how to respond to students who request being excused from certain assignments on the grounds that the content of a book, film or other work may upset them or even trigger symptoms of post-traumatic stress disorder. Some are considering making it mandatory for professors to warn students in advance about texts whose graphic nature could be upsetting.

headline: There’s a Better Way to Measure Who Has Raised the Most Money
text: It seems like a simple question: Who has raised more money this cycle, Senator Marco Rubio of Florida or Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky? But it’s not very simple, although there is a way to tally it that makes sense in the real world of campaigning.

headline: Demography and the Bicycle Effect
text: When Alvin Hansen first proposed the concept of secular stagnation, he emphasized the role of slowing population growth in depressing investment demand (and his warnings were made moot by the postwar baby boom.) Modern discussions return to that emphasis: Japan’s shrinking working-age population looks like an important source of its problems, and slowing population growth in Europe and America are important reasons to believe that we may be entering a similar regime.

headline: After the Election: Writers Weigh in
text: Below are a selection of opinions and analyses on Narendra Modi’s Bharatiya Janata Party winning an absolute majority in the parliamentary elections on Friday.

headline: That 80s Show
text: I’ve been giving various talks and fireside chats here in Oxford, and one thing I keep coming back to is the pivotal role of the 1980s in the development of economic thought.

headline: Among Polling Firms, Only One Got the Indian Elections Right
text: NEW DELHI – After the final vote was cast on May 12, exit polls pointed to a win by the opposition Bharatiya Janata Party led by its candidate for prime minister, Narendra Modi. But only one polling firm, Today’s Chanakya, predicted the magnitude of both the B.J.P.’s victory and the governing Indian National Congress party’s loss.

headline: What to Watch for in Three Primaries
text: Not much matters six months before a midterm election, but Tuesday’s primaries are an exception. Republicans will have an opportunity to nominate candidates in three potentially competitive Senate contests: in Kentucky, Georgia and Oregon. Here’s what you need to know. headline: China’s Pollution Challenge
text: China’s national legislature has adopted sweeping changes to the country’s Environmental Protection Law, revisions that have been hailed as major steps toward saving China’s environment from rampant degradation.

headline: AT&T’s Move for DirecTV
text: AT&T agreed on Sunday to buy the satellite television operator DirecTV for $48.5 billion in a bid to “tilt the balance of power with media companies as the market for broadband Internet and video shifts,” Michael J. de la Merced and David Gelles write in DealBook. With the acquisition, AT&T becomes the latest telecommunications giant seeking to establish an even greater reach.

headline: Boko Haram Suspected in Attack on Chinese Workers in Cameroon
text: Ten Chinese workers in northern Cameroon are missing following an attack last week by gunmen, the Chinese Embassy in the West African country said.

headline: South Korea Searches for Answers
text: The April 16 ferry disaster in South Korea that left 304 people dead or missing did more than cause immediate outrage. It also forced ordinary Koreans to examine themselves and their country, and what they saw was a society and a national government that were not nearly as well put together as they and the rest of the world had believed.

headline: A Navigation Program Switches to Maps Made by Volunteers
text: Crowdsourcing is used to rate restaurants in Rotterdam, dentists in Duluth and contractors in Kalamazoo. But should you trust free, user-generated content to find your way home?

headline: 5 in China Army Face U.S. Charges of Cyberattacks
text: WASHINGTON — In the Obama administration’s most direct confrontation with China over its theft of corporate secrets, the Justice Department on Monday unsealed an indictment of five members of the Chinese People’s Liberation Army and charged them with hacking into the networks of Westinghouse Electric, the United States Steel Corporation and other companies.

headline: A Rare, Partial Victory in Saving Remnants of Old Beijing
text: As a 10-year-old boy, Cui Jinze remembers sitting on the desk of his grandfather, a local Communist Party official in Daxing, on Beijing’s southern outskirts, entranced by a map on the wall that marked the city’s palaces, temples and libraries with the character “gu” (古), or “ancient.”

headline: Syria Death Toll Reported to Rise By 10,000 in Less Than 2 Months
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The death toll in the three-year Syrian conflict has risen to about 162,000, an increase of more than 10,000 in less than two months, according to an antigovernment monitoring group that is one of the few organizations still attempting to keep an exact count.

headline: Two Police Officers Shoot and Kill a Brooklyn Man
text: Hours after police officers shot and wounded a man in East Harlem, two uniformed officers killed a man in a Brooklyn apartment on Sunday, the police said, after he lunged at the officers with a pair of scissors.

headline: Cheating Death, and the Rumor Mill, in North Korea
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Hyon Song-wol is not quite North Korea’s version of Beyoncé. But as a popular singer and leader of the nation’s best-known girl band, which often performs in miniskirts, she attracts plenty of attention. Last Friday, millions watched on national television as she saluted the country’s leader, Kim Jong-un, for his “heavenly trust and warm care” in promoting the arts.

headline: The Education of a Foreign Correspondent
text: Rick Lyman, who has been a reporter and editor at The Times since 1997, is reopening its bureau in Central and Eastern Europe. He will be based in Warsaw and responsible for covering more than a dozen nations in the region, from Estonia and the other Baltic States down to Slovenia on the Italian border. A former international correspondent, based in South Africa, he has most recently been a national correspondent based in New York, but has previously been an editor, a political correspondent and the Houston bureau chief and covered both the movie industry in Los Angeles and the theater in New York. We asked him about his approach to his new beat.

headline: Kremlin Announces Ukraine Pullback, but NATO Doesn’t See It
text: MOSCOW — The Kremlin announced Monday that President Vladimir V. Putin had ordered Russian troops conducting exercises along the Ukrainian border to return to their home bases at the conclusion of the drills, apparently sending another loud signal that Russia is not planning any military action in eastern Ukraine ahead of that country’s presidential elections on Sunday.

headline: Daily Report: U.S. Charges in Chinese Cyberespionage
text: The tensions between the United States and China over accusations over cyberespionage have reached a new level. The Justice Department is expected to announce charges Monday against several individuals in the People’s Liberation Army, accusing them of stealing trade secrets from American companies, Michael S. Schmidt of The New York Times reports.

headline: In Push for Deal, Ackman Aims at Allergan Chief
text: Updated, 8:36 p.m. | William A. Ackman, the activist investor who is trying to bring two drug companies together in a merger, is reaching into his customary toolbox to apply pressure to his target.

headline: In Appeal, Scrutiny on Not One but 3 Confessions
text: WASHINGTON — Even Billy Wayne Cope’s supporters say the police had good reason to think he had committed a depraved murder.

headline: Apiece Apart Debuts With J. Crew
text: Starr Hout and Laura Cramer of Apiece Apart create clothes that allow the wearer to be stylish without all the hassle of styling. The designers of the six-year-old New York-based label (members of T’s Nifty 50 in 2010) offer chic, reasonably priced layers and separates that mix and match to accommodate “a simplified lifestyle,” they write in an email. “We envisioned the wardrobe to go with that life, just a few perfect pieces that could be packed in a single bag.” Slowly but surely, those pieces have developed a following among creative women — the sort who might appreciate the design and architecture on Apiece Apart’s worth-bookmarking blog and in their seasonal printed zine — with better things to do than fret about what to throw on in the morning.

headline: Verizon Wireless Names Faster Part of Its Network: XLTE
text: Data-guzzling smartphones and tablets are so ubiquitous that even Verizon Wireless, the No. 1 American phone carrier, was getting crushed by network traffic last year in big cities like New York. The company now says it has fixed its network in problematic areas, and this week it is introducing an advertising campaign to make consumers aware of improved portions of its network.

headline: Ruling Clears Way for California Chrome to Run in Belmont
text: California Chrome fans can breathe easy: New York regulators will allow the horse to wear a nasal strip in the Belmont Stakes on June 7, when he will try to become only the 12th horse to win the Triple Crown.

The pairings are intended to help foster a new generation of talent.
