headline: AT&T Shareholders on Hold in DirecTV Deal
text: AT&T is putting its shareholders on hold to buy DirecTV. Its acquisition of the satellite TV operator, announced on Sunday, brings with it an unexpectedly robust $1.6 billion of cost savings. Even so, those savings will not quite cover the cost of the premium. In any case, AT&T says it will use the money to roll out rural broadband service. Customers and regulators are getting the first call.

headline: Math for Love’s Primo Puzzle
text: Inspired by the new board game Primo: Multiplication puzzles by the Seattle-based Math for Love.

headline: At Kartell, There’s Still a Great Future in Plastics
text: After 65 years producing plastic furniture, lighting and accessories, it’s safe to say that the Italian company Kartell knows a thing or two about how to elevate the utilitarian material into fashionable design. The trick? Balancing plastic’s cold and industrial characteristics with familiar, classic silhouettes. Philippe Starck’s Ghost chairs for the brand — shaped in the style of French Louis XVI — have reportedly sold over 1.5 million units. Another historically inspired icon, Ferruccio Laviani’s Bourgie table lamp featuring a baroque base and a corrugated shade, celebrates 10 years in production this year. It has also been a best seller in transparent, colored and metallic versions.

headline: Times Minute | Kentucky’s Primary Day
text: Jonathan Martin, The Times’s national political correspondent on Senate minority leader, Mitch McConnell’s challenge in Kentucky’s Tuesday G.O.P. primary.

headline: Indictment Memorandum
text: The Justice Department said that the men were indicted on May 1 by a federal grand jury in Pennsylvania and charged with conspiring to commit computer fraud and accessing a computer without authorization for the purpose of commercial advantage.

headline: Times Minute | Kentucky’s Primary Day
text: In the Video

headline: Canadiens Goalie Carey Price to Miss Rest of Rangers Series
text: BROSSARD, Quebec — Canadiens goalie Carey Price, who injured his right knee in a Game 1 collision with the Rangers’ Chris Kreider, will miss the remainder of the Eastern Conference finals, Coach Michel Therrien said Monday.

headline: The Curious Incident of Pfizer’s ‘Final’ Offer for AstraZeneca
text: In its bid for AstraZeneca, Pfizer is finding out that some merger offers need to be sweet enough for everyone.

headline: To Lift the Poor, You Can’t Avoid Taxing the Rich
text: It’s tempting to think — and hope — that attacking inequality doesn’t mean we have to hurt those at the top. This idea has become a central response from conservatives to the current debate inspired by Thomas Piketty’s book and proposal for a wealth tax.

headline: First Wolverine Comic Art Is Sold for Nearly $660,000
text: The original art for the comic book page that introduced Wolverine, one of the most popular heroes of Marvel Comics, sold on Friday for $657,250 at Heritage Auctions. The superhero is introduced in the final moments of issue no. 180 of “The Incredible Hulk,” from 1974, which finds the green Goliath wreaking havoc in Canada. Wolverine is called in to stop the Hulk’s rampage. As he makes his appearance in the final panel, he proclaims: “If you really want to tangle with someone – why not try your luck against – the Wolverine!” (His first full appearance would be in the following issue of “The Incredible Hulk.”)

headline: Blueberry or Blackberry Compote With Yogurt or Ricotta
text: Modeled on Deborah Madison’s recipe in her lovely book “Seasonal Fruit Desserts,” this simple compote will transform a plain bowl of yogurt or ricotta cheese into a dessert or a very nice breakfast.

headline: Whole-Grain Blueberry Buckle
text: A buckle is an old-fashioned cake that has a crumble topping and fruit that makes the batter buckle, or sink, as it bakes. Or at least that’s what all the recipes I’ve read say is supposed to happen. When I made the cake the blueberries didn’t really cause it to buckle at all, they just formed a layer on top of the cake. This is now a favorite dessert. It’s not traditional at all, as I use whole-wheat flour, and oats and quinoa flour in the topping.

headline: Resentment of China Spreading in Myanmar
text: BANGKOK — A flare-up of resilient hostility toward China among its neighbors has infected central Myanmar, where a Chinese company operating a copper mine has local residents seething over what they call the operator’s arrogance and the project’s seemingly unbridled expansion plans.

headline: Beet and Arugula Salad With Berries
text: Berries and beets: a salad of dark green, blue and purple hues if there ever was one. I threw this together because I had these ingredients on hand – beets that I’d roasted several days earlier, arugula that was bolting in my garden, and berries from the market – and it worked. The sweet-tart flavor of the berries contrasts beautifully with the earthy sweetness of the beets and the pungent arugula.

headline: Cornmeal and Buckwheat Blueberry Muffins
text: Buckwheat contributes a rustic, earthy flavor to these not-too-sweet muffins. They are the antithesis of the cakey blueberry muffins you find in coffee shops. The berry quotient is generous here. If you find the buckwheat flavor too strong, swap the amounts of whole-wheat and buckwheat flours (that is, use 125 grams whole-wheat and 65 grams buckwheat).

headline: Berry Clafoutis
text: Clafoutis, as you may know by now, are among my favorite vehicles for seasonal fruit. I love the way blueberries and blackberries bleed into the batter as this bakes. Let it cool for about a half-hour, or completely, before you serve it, and be careful when you cut into it, as the berries can splatter when they’re warm. My clafoutis are not very sweet, and I enjoy them for breakfast as well as for dessert.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
text: In the news: lab mice, fighting AIDS and exercises for back conditions. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: With Spy Charges, U.S. Draws a Line That Few Others Recognize
text: WASHINGTON — By indicting members of the People’s Liberation Army’s most famous cyberwarfare operation — called Unit 61398 but known among hackers as the “Comment Crew” — the Obama administration has turned to the criminal justice system to reinforce its argument that there is a major difference between spying for national security purposes, something the United States does daily, and the commercial, for-profit espionage carried out by China’s military.

headline: Louis Vuitton Comes to Monaco, Celebrities in Tow
text: On Saturday at 6:30 p.m, a tentlike structure in front of the Palace of Monaco was teeming with fashionistas. In came Carine Roitfeld wearing a snake-skin Givenchy jacket and a tight-as-could-be Rick Owens skirt. After that came Charlotte Gainsbourg and Adèle Exarchopoulos, who were decked out in leather pants and shimmering tops by Nicolas Ghesquière, Louis Vuitton’s recently anointed head designer.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Image of the Day: May 19
text: Villagers, after their daily work, returning home on the outskirts of eastern Bhubaneswar, Odisha.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: May 16-18, 2014
text: Last month, Gama Droiville, 13, was shot twice in the head after getting caught in the crossfire of a gang-related gun battle while he waited for a bus in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn, N.Y.. Eduardo Dolphy, 24, the intended target, was shot in the leg. Police arrested Kareem Potomont, 21, who has 13 prior arrests. Weeks earlier, 39-year-old Angel Rojas was caught in gang crossfire on a bus and killed in the Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood of Brooklyn. His assailant, 14-year-old Kahton Anderson, was aiming for another teenager.

headline: $35 Million for G.M.? That’s Nothing.
text: The General Motors recall story has provided ample proof that federal laws are not strong enough to deal with car defects. Exhibit A is the ridiculously small fine that the Department of Transportation imposed on the company last week.

headline: Asian-Americans Have Had the Sharpest Shift Toward Democrats
text: Asian-Americans make up the racial or ethnic group that has shifted most strongly toward the Democratic Party since 2000. They are also the country’s fastest-growing racial or ethnic group by percentage.

headline: Marco Rubio As George W. Bush
text: While Rand Paul has been trying to map out a heretofore-uncharted path to the presidency, his potential rival Marco Rubio has been playing more of an inside game, delivering a series of policy speeches — on poverty, on higher education, and most recently on entitlement reform — that make him seem more presidential to the kind of Washingtonian “thought leaders” (those are ironic quotation marks, people) who care about such things.

headline: Abramson Touts Resilience After Ouster
text: Jill Abramson, the former executive editor of The New York Times, made her first public appearance since her dismissal, speaking in a commencement at Wake Forest University.

headline: How AT&T’s Deal for DirecTV Could Affect the Industry
text: With AT&T having agreed to buy DirecTV for $48.5 billion, consumer advocates and industry analysts are sizing up how the deal could alter the media landscape.

headline: Art Matters | The Hudson Valley’s Newest Art Destination
text: The last time artwork adorned the walls of the Martin Van Buren school in Kinderhook, N.Y., it had been commissioned at the request of elementary school teachers. On Saturday, however, both new and retrospective pieces by the artist Nick Cave were installed throughout the newly converted 30,000-square-foot building, while dancers costumed in Cave’s idiosyncratic Soundsuits performed outside for a crowd of art-world cognoscenti and local residents. The early evening celebration feted both the opening of what is simply being called The School, Jack Shainman Gallery‘s colossal addition to two gallery spaces in Chelsea, as well as the 30th anniversary of the gallery itself.

headline: Louise Wilson’s High Standards Shaped Young Designers
text: London fashion lost one of its most influential champions this weekend with the death of Louise Wilson, the formidable doyenne of Central Saint Martins, one of the city’s, and indeed the world’s, pre-eminent schools for design. She was 52.

headline: Today in Small Business: When Does Financing Cost Too Much?
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: An Ancient Shrimp’s Big Sperm, Preserved
text: The world’s oldest sperm has been found in tiny shrimp called ostracods that lived at least 17 million years ago in Australia, scientists are reporting.

headline: Travel Magazine Goes ‘Native’ With Lodging Collection
text: It’s spring again, as the song goes, and birds on the wing again start to sing again the old melody. Also starting to sing again at this time of year are marketers gearing up their annual efforts to reach consumers who are making travel and vacation plans, particularly for the summer.

headline: Using a Patient’s Own Blood in Heart Surgery
text: In heart surgery, a patient’s own red blood cells may be a better choice than blood transfusion.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
text: Big River, Richmond, Va., hired two employees. Christina Dick joined as senior content strategist and Daniel Riddick joined as account director.

headline: Parliamentary Wins May Seal Third Term for Iraqi Premier
text: BAGHDAD — Beating expectations, Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki secured the largest number of seats in last month’s parliamentary elections, the first since the withdrawal of American forces at the end of 2011, putting him in a strong position to secure a third term as Iraq’s leader as negotiations begin to form a new government.

headline: Yankees’ C.C. Sabathia to Miss at Least Six More Weeks
text: Yankees pitcher C. C. Sabathia, who received a cortisone shot with stem cells Thursday as treatment for a degenerative condition in the cartilage in his right knee, will be out for at least six more weeks, General Manager Brian Cashman said Monday.

headline: Chinese Vessel Will Map Ocean Floor in Search for Missing Jet
text: HONG KONG — The Malaysian government announced late Monday night that a Chinese vessel would survey the ocean floor at the last suspected location of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

headline: It’s a Must-Have Book, Even if You Never Read It
text: I confess that for a stretch of time, I convinced myself that having The Economist lying around would make me smarter, even if I never picked it up. Just by being in the same room, I’d somehow learn by osmosis about the news in each issue. Also, I liked having people think of me as the kind of person who read The Economist. But the osmosis thing didn’t happen, and I finally stopped my subscription when I realized I’d probably never read it on a regular basis.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Ed Carpenter Wins Another Indy 500 Pole
text: Ed Carpenter hasn’t run an IndyCar race since last October, but was back in top form Sunday as he posted a 231.067 mile per hour qualifying average that earned him the pole position for the 98th Indianapolis 500. Carpenter, who also was the fastest qualifier for last year’s Indy 500, collected a $100,000 prize for his wild ride around the Indianapolis Motor Speedway’s 2.5-mile oval.

headline: Legacy of Hamas-Fatah Killings Complicates Palestinian Unity Efforts
text: GAZA — For 14-year-old Aseel Radi, the promised reconciliation between warring Palestinian political factions is viewed through a forlorn fountain in a crowded market on the eastern side of Gaza City.

headline: In Cannes, Who Needs the Movies?
text: On Saturday night, Vanity Fair (the American edition) hosted a party at the Hotel du Cap-Eden-Roc, just outside Cannes, for a star-packed party that ran until 2 a.m.

headline: Station That Mirrors East Village’s Spirit Is Signing Off
text: For more than a decade, East Village Radio has operated out of a tiny storefront studio on First Avenue near First Street.

headline: ‘Wicked’ Writer Is Among Those Winning Lilly Awards
text: Winnie Holzman, who wrote the book for the blockbuster musical “Wicked” and has been a prolific television and film writer as well, will receive a lifetime achievement prize at the fifth annual Lilly Awards ceremony at Playwrights Horizons on June 2. She is one of 12 winners of a 2014 Lilly, a prize named for Lillian Hellman, and meant to honor women in the theater.

headline: Cleric Convicted of All Terrorism Charges
text: The fiery British cleric who prosecutors said had “devoted his life to violent jihad” and sent young men around the world to train and fight was convicted Monday of all 11 terrorism-related charges against him.

headline: Bookshelf | A Collection of Recipes Meant to Inspire Foodie Gatherings
text: Speaking to Diana Yen about food, it instantly becomes clear that she’s a sucker for not just the fresh and seasonal — the Union Square farmer’s market is her first and favorite stop for groceries — but also for ingredients made great by attention to the smallest of details. “My second stop would be Eataly. I love the way that they take care of their lettuce,” she begins to explain, breaking into a fit of laughter as she realizes how neurotic this sounds. “They have this really sophisticated sprinkling system, so the lettuce never gets too drenched, and it’s never dry — it’s just perfect. I see them pamper their vegetables, so I trust them.”

headline: Podcast: Memory Champs, Lessons of a Deadly Virus, Making Something Go Viral
text:
Scientists are learning that among memory competitors, a key to remembering to knowing how to forget. An image of H.I.V. stirs one writer to remember a pastor’s evolutionary thought, published 50 years before the “Origin of Species.” Why do we share the hilarious and the horrifying online?
Subscribe to the Podcast »

headline: Walkabout: Airlines’ Sticker Prices; Ryanair Competition
text: The Real Deal Should an airline be required to tell you the full price of a ticket before you purchase it? Or should it be able to advertise only its base fares? Two bills in Congress offer different answers. (Bloomberg View)

headline: Anti-Europe Parties at Odds, Despite Shared Cause
text: LONDON — Geert Wilders, the leader of the populist Freedom Party in the Netherlands, told cheering supporters two months ago that he wanted fewer Moroccans in the country. One of his party’s most prominent and charismatic figures, Laurence Stassen, a former television reporter and a member of the European Parliament, promptly quit in protest.

headline: Options for Rivals in Wake of AT&T’s Bid for DirecTV
text: Few industries have been as deeply embroiled in merger mania as the telecommunications industry, particularly after AT&T’s $48.5 billion bid for DirecTV.

headline: Beyond Pretzel Logic
text: For years, lingering at the bar came with a penance: a bowl of stale peanuts or soggy pretzels. Even if you didn’t start out wanting to drown your sorrows, the food made you want to. Bar snacks were meant to lace your mouth with plenty of salt, leading you to reach more often for your thirst-slaking gimlet.

headline: Justices Reinstate Copyright Lawsuit Over ‘Raging Bull’
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday revived a copyright lawsuit against the owners of “Raging Bull,” the acclaimed 1980 movie for which Robert De Niro won an Academy Award as best actor for his portrayal of the boxer Jake LaMotta.

headline: Creation, in the Eye of the Beholder
text: I remember the chill I felt, 27 years ago, when I picked up the latest edition of Scientific American magazine. Pictured on the cover was an object of unnerving beauty — a cutaway of a perfect blue sphere meticulously assembled from tiny identical parts and studded around the circumference with precisely placed green antennas. Inside this flawlessly honed outer shell was a smaller inner sphere, reddish tan in color, and suspended at its center was an ivory capsule, built from hundreds of still tinier spheres.

headline: With World Cup in Brazil, Risk of Spreading a Virus
text: Public health authorities are worried about a confluence of events set to happen soon: Brazil is suffering the world’s worst epidemic of dengue fever, with 1.4 million cases last year. And the country is about to play host to the World Cup, which attracts tourists by the millions.

headline: Met Plans a Gut Renovation of Its Modern Wing
text: The Metropolitan Museum of Art is planning to rebuild its wing for Modern and contemporary art — possibly from scratch — to create new, showcase galleries for its expanded collection from those periods, Met officials have confirmed.

headline: Nissan Recalls About 200 Leaf E.V.s for a Faulty Weld
text: Nissan is recalling 211 Leaf electric vehicles from the 2014 model year for a welding defect that requires the automaker to give owners a new vehicle if necessary, the automaker said in a report posted on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration website.

headline: Mille Miglia Celebrates Cars From Motorsports History
text: ROME — From 1927 to 1957, with time off during World War II, the Mille Miglia was an important race that dazzled motorsports fans around the world, elevating drivers to godlike status and proving what was possible when new technology was pushed to its limits on treacherous mountain roads in Italy. The race planted the seeds of legend, particularly in the parts of Northern and Central Italy where the 1,000-mile race was run.

headline: The Airline Lounge Gets Competition
text: MY first encounter with an airline lounge was in the early 1970s at the Philadelphia airport when I noticed an oak door with a small brass plaque that said “Admirals Club.” I figured it had something to do with the Navy.

headline: A Pastor’s Greeting
text: Marco Linares, pastor of the Living Faith Family Worship Church in Cotulla, Tex., welcomes the congregation and two visitors to a Sunday service.

headline: Police Official in New Hampshire Resigns Amid Uproar Over Slur Against Obama
text: BOSTON — With a terse letter of resignation, a police commissioner in Wolfeboro, N.H., has stepped down after a cascade of complaints objecting to his use of a racial slur to describe President Obama. The commissioner, Robert Copeland, 82, who is also a lawyer, confirmed that he had made the statement. He had said he was exercising his First Amendment right of free speech.

headline: That Hang-Dog Look
text: Q. My dog has been depressed since I left for college and my family got a new puppy. How is depression treated in dogs?

headline: To Lift Up the Poor, Must We Soak the Rich?
text: Over at the Upshot, Jared Bernstein chides conservatives who have responded to the inequality debate by arguing that we should focus on lifting up the poor instead of chopping down the incomes of the 1 percent; the reality, he argues, is that you can’t have any sort of uplift without some good old-fashioned soaking of the rich:

headline: A Guy Walks Into a Chicago Bar, and Sees Darth Vader
text: I TRAVEL all over the world to find geeks, the people who enjoy video games, comic books, science fiction and fantasy, and all other things pop culture. I’m a geek and am obsessed with Legos. I’m also global vice president of ReedPOP, a producer of pop culture events like New York Comic Con; Singapore Toy, Game and Comic Convention; and Star Wars Celebration.

headline: Clock Ticks on Sterling’s Potential Removal
text: The N.B.A. took the next step in its attempt to terminate Donald Sterling’s ownership of the Los Angeles Clippers on Monday by formally charging him with conduct that has adversely affected the league and establishing a timetable for his potential ouster.

headline: President’s Tearful Statement
text: President Park Geun-hye of South Korea vowed to disband her country’s coast guard, and the commissioner general, Kim Suk-Kyoon, responded to her decision.

headline: Sewage in Rio Waters and Other Challenges as Brazil Prepares for Sports Spectacles
text: For the fourth year in a row, a team of graduate and undergraduate communication students at Pace University has created a compelling short documentary focused on efforts to mesh human progress with the environment. (I admit a bias here, given that I co-teach the documentary course that produces these films with Pace Prof. Maria Luskay.)

headline: People With Chronic Illness Fare Worse Under Cost-Sharing
text: Most health care plans ask that you spend some money out of your pocket whenever you use the health care system. This is known as cost-sharing, and it exists because research has shown us that people are, in general, less likely to spend their own money than someone else’s. Cost-sharing works its way into insurance today through co-pays, deductibles and co-insurance.

headline: Cubs’ Last Link to a World Series
text: READING, Mass. — With a sweep of his arm, Lennie Merullo rolled up the sleeve of his cardigan sweater to reveal a faint scar on his left forearm. He was in the dining room of his Victorian house, scrapbooks full of old newspaper clippings from his baseball career spread on the table before him.

headline: Composers Converse Across Centuries
text: In the Miller Theater’s enticing Bach, Revisited series, his works are paired with relevant pieces by living composers. A program on Thursday evening offering Bach’s Cantata “Christ lag in Todes Banden” (BWV 4) and Steve Reich’s “Tehillim,” inspired by this cantata, seemed a natural pairing.

headline: A Math App That Offers an Unusual Human Touch
San Diego Opera Raises Money to Remain Open
text: The San Diego Opera, which was left for dead in March when its board of directors voted to shut it down after 49 years, citing dwindling ticket sales and philanthropic support, will live to see its 50th-anniversary season after all, the company announced on Monday.

headline: In Performance | Jeremy Denk
text: The pianist Jeremy Denk performs Mozart’s Rondo in F (K. 494).

headline: Pop Music Recital With a Classical Veneer
text: The Tribeca New Music Festival is one of the most clearly defined brands in New York’s teeming new-music scene. The festival’s preferred label is “avant pop,” defined as the merging of pop culture taste and classically honed craft. Saturday’s “Poetry in Motion,” an evening of new vocal music presented as part of a five-concert series at the Cell in Chelsea, was in many ways a typical sample. The songs by Andrew Norman, Christopher Cerrone, Jacob Cooper, Eric Shanfield and Ted Hearne were compact, direct and elegant; the soprano Mellissa Hughes performed them with grace and razor-sharp emotional acuity.

headline: How to Censor a PDF File
text: Q. I have a file that I scanned to a PDF so I could email it to my accountant for reference, but the original contains some personal details, like my Social Security number. For email security reasons, is it possible to black out this information in the electronic file before I send it?

headline: A Preference for Republicans, Gun Control and Immigration Reform
text: The new Politico poll of likely voters in swing states and competitive districts isn’t all that bad for Democrats. Yes, the poll found that respondents would prefer to vote for a generic Republican over a generic Democrat, 41 percent to 34 percent. It also found that they’re not happy with Barack Obama: 59 percent said they disapproved of his job performance as president.

headline: What Might Have Been, Expressed in Songs
text: Could Kate Baldwin, the redheaded firecracker who detonated in the 2009 Broadway revival of “Finian’s Rainbow” have been a rock star? That possibility was broached on Friday evening at 54 Below, where Ms. Baldwin opened her new cabaret show with bright, peppy rendition of Ian Axel’s “Rockstar!,” an insanely catchy “what if?” song whose narrator gazes fancifully into the future.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | May 13-19, 2014
text: How many of the stories below have you followed this week?

headline: In This Romantic Parting, Little Drama or Moodiness
text: Take two of the most popular crudités, vegetables that are neither too similar nor too different. (Zucchini and squash, maybe.) Cut a few slices of each, and serve — careful not to mix them — on the same plate.

headline: When Polar Bears Said Goodbye to Brown
text: Polar bears diverged from brown bears less than 500,000 years ago, researchers who sequenced the polar bear’s genome reported in the journal Cell. The researchers also discovered several genes related to fatty acid metabolism and cardiovascular function in the polar bear. These genes may explain how the bear subsists on a high-fat diet without suffering from clogged arteries and cardiovascular disease.

headline: A Victory Lap for a Heretical Neurologist
text: Sweet revenge comes in many delectable forms, among them the receipt of accolades for work long scorned. And then to get to tell the whole story at length and without a single interruption — small wonder that the Nobel laureate Dr. Stanley B. Prusiner, a renowned neurologist at the University of California, San Francisco, writes with a cheerful bounce. Once disparaged, his scientific work is now hailed as visionary, and his memoir takes the reader on a leisurely and immensely readable victory lap from then to now.

headline: Credit Suisse Pleads Guilty in Felony Case
text: Updated, 10:12 p.m. | Credit Suisse has done what no other bank of its size and significance has done in over two decades: plead guilty to criminal wrongdoing.

headline: Documents on Credit Suisse
text: Federal prosecutors demanded that Credit Suisse’s parent company plead guilty to helping thousands of American account holders hide their wealth and evade taxes.

headline: When Doctors Treat Patients Like Themselves
text: Many years ago I spent a lunch hour in a doctors’ dining room eavesdropping on two white-coated men of a certain age idly discussing a colleague who worked at the city hospital next door.

headline: The Big Melt Accelerates
text: Centuries from now, a large swath of the West Antarctic ice sheet is likely to be gone, its hundreds of trillions of tons of ice melted, causing a four-foot rise in already swollen seas.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: Big City Book Club Discusses ‘Brooklyn’
text: That concludes the live conversation on “Brooklyn.” Thank you all who participated, and for those who were unable to make it, feel free to posts comments all week. The book club’s next selection will be announced shortly. Colm Toibin’s novel “Brooklyn” is at once a classic narrative of the immigrant’s conflicted passions and allegiances and a story of female self-questioning that transcends the immigrant-lit genre. It offers a New York that is both a grand escape and a small town. “Brooklyn” is the story of a young Irishwoman named Eilis Lacey whose bookkeeping classes in an Irish village are interrupted when a priest living across the Atlantic sponsors her passage to New York, a voyage that submerges her in the world of Bartucci’s department store on Fulton Street and an Italian-American culture that slowly tempts her away from her own.

headline: Cheers as Officer Hurt in Fire Goes Home
text: The officer’s chances of survival were barely 50 percent, doctors said. Even if she pulled through after the fire, the smoke inhalation was so severe that her commanders were worried she might never speak again.

headline: Summer’s Winners: 20 Wines for $20
text: Drinking wine in the summer is different. Not because people tend to eat lighter, or because it’s hot. It’s the vibe.

headline: Race and the Law
text: To the Editor:

headline: Attention Deficit in Toddlers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Biomedical Research
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Troupe and Its Leader, Bodies Willing, Try to Gain a Foothold
text: From the outside, the Sheen Center, a new arts complex in the West Village, looks inviting, its sleek gold awning standing out along a quiet, leafy block of Bleecker Street. Step inside, though, and the antiseptic interior makes you wonder if you’ve walked into a hospital. Descend the stairwell, and it deposits you in the gloomy black-box theater, where MorDance, a fledgling contemporary ballet company directed by Morgan McEwen, presented a triple bill on Saturday.

headline: Skewering Britain’s High-Tone Scribblers
text: In recounting the story of his semi-autobiographical hero, Patrick Melrose, in a series of interlinked novels (“Never Mind,” “Bad News,” “Some Hope,” “Mother’s Milk” and “At Last”), Edward St. Aubyn established himself as a dazzling writer with an utterly distinctive voice. The harrowing story of Patrick’s life — from being raped at 5 by his monstrous father, to his years as a heroin addict, to his achievement of a measure of perspective and peace in middle age — was simultaneously heartbreaking and funny, devastatingly sad and cuttingly acerbic: painful experience transmuted into art through beautifully hammered, aphoristic prose.

headline: Benefits of Pesticides
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pastoral Voyage Turns Into White-Water Rafting
text: In historical accounts and program notes, you read that of the four Brahms symphonies, the second is the sunny one. After struggling for some 20 years to write his first symphony, a turbulent work that ends in hard-won triumph, Brahms wrote his Symphony No. 2 in D during a few months of summer vacation in 1877. The music, overall, is thought to be genial and, despite some mysterious moments, affirming.

headline: Speaking at Commencement (Maybe)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Wedged Into Warship With Pen in Hand
text: The British author Geoff Dyer is known for being a genre bender — a writer of novels that sometimes read like nonfiction, and nonfiction that occasionally feels invented — and for being what he calls a gate crasher: someone who writes about whatever happens to interest him at the moment. His newest book, “Another Great Day at Sea: Life Aboard the USS George H. W. Bush,” recounts two weeks he spent embedded on an American aircraft carrier, a life for which he was almost comically ill-suited.

headline: De Blasio Tells City’s Tabloids to Apologize to His Wife
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio issued an unusual and stern rebuke of New York City’s tabloid newspapers on Monday, calling on them to apologize for publishing front-page headlines that suggested his wife, Chirlane McCray, had admitted to being a reluctant mother to the couple’s daughter, Chiara.

headline: Rating a Health Law’s Success
text: Scientists will look to certain diseases to measure the effectiveness of the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Ukraine, Syria, Serbia and Egypt.

headline: A Cancer Treatment in Your Medicine Cabinet?
text: WE believe that it might be possible to treat breast cancer — the leading cause of female cancer death — with a drug that can already be found in nearly every medicine cabinet in the world: Aspirin.

headline: Remembering, as an Extreme Sport
text: SAN DIEGO – The last match of the tournament had all the elements of a classic showdown, pitting style versus stealth, quickness versus deliberation, and the world’s foremost card virtuoso against its premier numbers wizard.

headline: Listen Up | In This New Video From Walter Martin, Lily McMenamy Acts Like an Animal
text: After the indie-rock stalwarts the Walkmen went on hiatus last year, the Brooklyn-based group’s multi-instrumentalist and co-songwriter Walter Martin consulted his inner child about what to do next. And also his actual children: He had recently become a dad to two girls, who influenced his musical direction. “I had to step up to the plate and write my own album after being in a band my whole life,” Martin says. “It was hard to figure out what I wanted to do. I went through different styles, and they all seemed kind of phony. Then I wrote the first song that appears on my first solo record, and it didn’t feel phony.”

headline: Why That Video Went Viral
text: There it was, virtual gold: a video of a firefighter resuscitating a kitten trapped in a smoky home.

headline: Packaged Stylishly, Art Forms and Poetry
text: Like many dance start-ups, Satellite Collective springs from honorable intentions: to serve as an “arts incubator,” nurturing creative ventures of all kinds. Its structure is unusually egalitarian, with equal billing given to composers, choreographers, filmmakers, writers and designers. Friday’s program at BAM Fisher featured two multimedia dance works, a stop-motion film, musical performances and a dramatic poetry reading. Twenty-seven artists contributed, including the creative director, Kevin Draper.

headline: Memory Champs
text: Scientists are learning that among memory competitors, the key to remembering to knowing how to forget.

headline: ‘Bridges’ Closes With Big Emotions and a Box Office Upswing
text: While many other Broadway musicals had soft ticket sales last week, “The Bridges of Madison County” had the highest box-office total of its four-month run, with gross revenues of $590,791 as typical theatergoers as well as fans of the bittersweet romance caught its final performances.

headline: With Twitch Acquisition Talks, Validation of Games as Spectator Sport
text: Video games have always been about participation, engagement and interaction. People watch television. They play video games.

headline: New Releases From Conor Oberst and Brantley Gilbert
text: CONOR OBERST

headline: Scoliosis Exercise, Not Braces (1 Letter)
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Pets Driving With a Dog (1 Letter)
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Storytelling via Scenery, vs. Drama in the Steps
text: Ballet comes in many shapes and sizes. At this time of year, you can alternate between America’s two foremost and largest ballet companies, New York City Ballet and American Ballet Theater, as they present their spring seasons on two sides of Lincoln Center. But other local troupes and schools have their performances, too.

headline: A.D.H.D. Treatment Without Drugs (1 Letter)
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: So Rowdy, They Discomfit the Royal Hell-Raiser
text: That man is an impostor.

headline: A Young, Fresh Crowd Comes Out Bouncing
text: A few minutes before midnight on Sunday night, Bria Skonberg was onstage in the ballroom at the Players club, trumpet aloft, playing a punchy solo on the 1930s novelty tune “I’ll Be Glad When You’re Dead, You Rascal You.” Two rooms over, in a parlor overlooking Gramercy Park, the ragtime piano specialist Dalton Ridenhour and the clarinetist Dennis Lichtman were leading an old-time jam. In both rooms, and in a library upstairs, well-turned-out young couples danced among the crowd. It was about 11 hours into the second New York Hot Jazz Festival, and the energy was far from flagging.

headline: An Inconvenient Diet
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: In Georgia, Secrecy Is More Important Than Life
text: Does a citizen have a right to know how his government plans to kill him? In Georgia, the answer to that question appears to be “no.”

headline: Hillary’s Obstacle Course
text: Reince Priebus made a joke on Sunday.

headline: At Ozarks Lodge, Natural History (and Golf)
text: Big Cedar Lodge in the Ozark Mountains in Missouri, will introduce a recreational and cultural complex called Top of the Rock in June that will feature a natural history museum, several restaurants, spa, golf courses and even a chapel.

headline: Former Transportation Secretary to Join Investment Firm
text: The Obama administration’s first transportation secretary is joining Meridiam, an investment concern focused on public infrastructure projects, the firm plans to announce on Tuesday.

headline: New Web Portal Provides Access to Historic Materials on Jewish Life in Poland
text: A new Web portal, Jewish Life in Poland, is making directly accessible thousands of maps, photos, films and other everyday artifacts of what was once the largest community of Eastern European Jews before World War II.

headline: Whisper Redesigns App to Reach Older Audience
text: Until now, using Whisper, the app that lets people anonymously share secrets and gossip, could sometimes feel as if you were driving a car through a maze. When you ran out of things to see on the service, you were forced to turn around and start over.

headline: Hotels Embrace the Campus Nearby
text: College pennant over your bed? Recent graduate available to answer questions? Rooms decorated in the school colors? Hotels near college campuses are gearing up to attract graduation weekend crowds, just as they compete throughout the year to attract visiting high-school families, graduates attending reunions and parents dropping off freshmen.

headline: Georgia Court Upholds Block on Details of State’s Executions
text: ATLANTA — In a legal victory for supporters of capital punishment, the Georgia Supreme Court on Monday upheld a law allowing the state to block from public view certain details about how it administers the death penalty, including the sources of execution drugs.

headline: Extreme Memory
text: The world’s best “memory athletes” in competition.

headline: Questions Remain After Chinese Hacking Indictments
text: The indictments of five Chinese military hackers by the Justice Department on Monday has raised questions of what actions, if any, American officials plan to take against members of the more than 20 other hacking units that American officials and their partners are currently tracking inside China.

headline: Deutsche Bank Vows to Focus on Clients With a New Culture of Ethics
text: FRANKFURT — As the banking sector tries to distance itself from the industry practices that helped plunge the globe into financial crisis, Deutsche Bank is doing its best to show it has learned the lessons of the past.

headline: Photographing, and Curing,the Blues in the Mississippi Delta
text: A road trip that started with heartache and a search for authentic blues led a photographer to the heart of the Mississippi Delta and its families.

headline: Facing Shareholder Anger, Target Cuts Executive’s Pay
text: Target’s former chief executive received $13 million in compensation in his last year at the company’s helm, down from $20 million the year before, according to regulatory documents filed on Monday.

headline: Lost Opportunity for Canadiens Rookie Filling In for an Injured Goaltender
text: MONTREAL — Canadiens lore is steeped with inexperienced goalies, from Ken Dryden to Steve Penney to Patrick Roy, all of whom sparkled during the playoffs as rookies. Another candidate awaited membership in that club on Monday night.

headline: Gordon Willis, ‘Godfather’ Cinematographer, Dies at 82
text: Gordon Willis, a master cinematographer whose work on “The Godfather,” “Manhattan,” “Annie Hall,” “Klute,” “All the President’s Men” and other seminal movies of the 1970s made his name synonymous with that pathbreaking decade in American moviemaking, died on Sunday at his home in North Falmouth, Mass. He was 82.

headline: Miami’s Past and Future Clash at a Building Site
text: MIAMI — Here at the north bank of the Miami River, beside a luxury hotel where the water meets Biscayne Bay, sits Miami’s Plymouth Rock, a recently discovered Indian village where 2,000 years ago the Tequesta people under thatched roofs feasted on shark.

headline: Wiring the Amazon
text: This short documentary chronicles a remote Peruvian village’s four-year struggle to get Internet access.

headline: G.M. Brings Back a Former Executive to Polish a Battered Public Image
text: DETROIT — General Motors on Monday hired one of its former executives to manage public relations and help steer it through a safety crisis linked to 13 deaths.

headline: ‘Wiring the Amazon’
text: This Op-Doc video chronicles the four-year struggle to get a remote Peruvian village connected with the outside world. I began filming the project in 2009, while making a feature-length documentary film about the global spread of information technology. I was following the work of One Laptop per Child (O.L.P.C.), a United States-based nonprofit that has designed inexpensive laptops for primary education. The organization is particularly active in Peru, where the government has purchased and distributed hundreds of thousands of O.L.P.C.'s laptops to its poorest communities. One such village is Palestina, deep in the Amazon rain forest. It has only 65 people.

headline: Writing About a Life of Ideas
text: When an intellectual dies, there are no heaps of flowers or public mournings. The odd wistful editorial will be written in upmarket newspapers; colloquia organized in ivy-clad colleges. Few Americans will know, for instance, that Ronald Dworkin, a formidable figure in American liberal philosophy, died last year.

headline: For Workers, Less Flexible Companies
text: He calls it one of the bright spots of his week: Before Jared Dalton, 32, starts his workday as a manager at Ernst & Young, the big accounting firm, he dresses his 5-month-old daughter, Olivia, and then places her on her tummy to play. Since he works from home on Mondays and Tuesdays, he can spend an extra hour with Olivia and an extra hour working — time that would otherwise be lost commuting into Manhattan.

headline: Now Not Batting for the Mets, a Sorely Needed Designated Hitter
text: The Mets’ Bartolo Colon swung and missed, his body twisting so violently that his helmet fell off and he nearly toppled over. He sheepishly fetched his headgear from the dirt a few feet away, and then he returned to the batter’s box to take another hack. He feebly struck out swinging to end the embarrassment.

headline: Civil Rights Battlefront Is Now Yearning for Jobs
text: SELMA, Ala. — For Allen Green, a native of this rural Alabama city known mostly for a violent confrontation between civil rights demonstrators and Alabama troopers nearly a half-century ago, Selma’s prolonged economic slide began when Craig Air Force Base shut down in the 1970s.

headline: N.Y.U. Apologizes to Any Workers Mistreated on Its Abu Dhabi Campus
text: New York University issued an apology on Monday to any workers on its newly completed Abu Dhabi campus who were “not treated in line with the standards we set,” after The New York Times reported widespread abuses among a labor force that numbered about 6,000 at its peak.

headline: Koseler Counts the Cost of Its New Way of Life
text: The little village of Koseler, Turkey, with a population of 430 and nestled in a mountain valley, lost 14 men in last week’s coal mining disaster.

headline: After Mine Disaster, a Painful Awareness of What Has Been Lost
text: KOSELER, Turkey — The framed photograph showed the smiling faces of 22 men, most of them coal miners, and Ali Toprak pointed first to the unlucky and then the lucky.

headline: What AT&T’s Satellite Deal Might Mean
text: In the telecommunications industry, the big only seem to get bigger. Three months after the nation’s top two cable companies, Comcast and Time Warner Cable, announced they were merging, the nation’s largest telephone company, AT&T, said on Sunday it would buy the biggest satellite-TV business, DirecTV, for $48.5 billion.

headline: Federal Judge Strikes Down Oregon’s Ban on Same-Sex Marriage
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — The cheers erupted at exactly 12:08 p.m. as word filtered through the line of couples, friends and family members, some of whom had been on the sidewalk outside the Multnomah County building here since 5:30 a.m. on Monday.

headline: AT&T-DirecTV Deal Churns Regulatory Waters
text: WASHINGTON — Many supporters of the blockbuster Comcast-Time Warner Cable merger breathed a sigh of relief on Sunday, when AT&T and DirecTV announced plans to merge, thinking the latest pairing would divert some regulatory scrutiny of the other high-stakes deal.

headline: Miami Area Hotel Brings Its Past to Forefront
text: THE BILTMORE, an upscale resort in Coral Gables, Fla., is running its first ad campaign in 10 years to attract guests from the United States and overseas.

headline: Primary Day on the Far Side
text: Wearing a black leather vest that barely covered the cigar tucked into his pocket, a man named Harley Brown was allowed to join the debate among candidates for governor of Idaho last week, holding forth on discrimination against bikers and the presidential seal tattooed on his shoulder after God told him he would one day occupy the White House. Another candidate, Walt Bayes, railed against “a bunch of eastern idiots” pushing the country toward Sodom and Gomorrah. If you thought that this was nothing but a stunt designed by Gov. Butch Otter to distract attention from his real opponent, you’d be right. But you’d also be missing the larger point: Republican primaries around the country have largely degenerated into self-parodies. They may lack the flowing beards of Mr. Brown and Mr. Bayes, but many of the other candidates in the party’s primaries — a large number of which will take place on Tuesday — are running on ideas only slightly less extreme.

headline: In Tax Case, Credit Suisse Is Denied Milder Penalty
text: On the eve of the year-end holidays, Credit Suisse’s top lawyer visited Washington to plead for mercy.

headline: English League Won’t Act on Chief’s Sexist Emails
text: LONDON — The chief executive of England’s Premier League, Richard Scudamore, escaped dismissal Monday after a panel controlled by Britain’s top 20 professional soccer clubs ruled that “no further disciplinary action” was necessary in respect to emails he exchanged with others that were laced with coarse sexual innuendo about women.

headline: In California, Climate Issues Moved to Fore by Governor
text: LOS ANGELES — Portraying California as the front line of climate change, Gov. Jerry Brown said Monday that the effects of man-made global warming were devastating the state, drawing a direct link between climate change and both the record-setting drought that has left the state parched and the early-season wildfires that broke out across California last week. He declared that people must find a way “to live with nature, not collide with it.”

headline: Flood Danger Persists in Serbia, Threatening Power Plant
text: WARSAW — The rain has stopped, at last, but the danger persists in flood-ravaged Serbia, where a lake of water is pushing its way down the Sava River, toward the Danube, threatening the capital, Belgrade, and the power plant southwest of the city that provides half of the nation’s electricity.

headline: General Declares Martial Law Across Thailand Amid Paralyzing Protests
text: BANGKOK — Citing a century-old law, the head of Thailand’s Army declared what he described as nationwide martial law early Tuesday and urged protesters who have paralyzed the government and blocked elections to “stop their movement.” The order also appeared to apply to pro-government demonstrators who are leading a separate protest.

headline: Disabled Boy Found Safe, Days After Leaving School
text: It is a winding six-mile trip from Leon M. Goldstein High School for the Sciences, in Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn, to Eliceo Cortez’s home in Flatbush. But Eliceo, a ninth-grader, never made it home on Friday because he vanished before boarding the yellow bus that usually takes him there.

headline: Camera Maker GoPro Files to Go Public
text: The action camera maker GoPro filed paperwork on Monday to sell shares to the public, offering clues about how it navigated the treacherous waters of the digital photography business.

headline: The Big Debate
text: It’s now clear that the end of the Soviet Union heralded an era of democratic complacency. Without a rival system to test them, democratic governments have decayed across the globe. In the U.S., Washington is polarized, stagnant and dysfunctional; a pathetic 26 percent of Americans trust their government to do the right thing. In Europe, elected officials have grown remote from voters, responding poorly to the euro crisis and contributing to massive unemployment.

headline: Economic Recovery Yields Few Benefits for the Voters Democrats Rely On
text: WASHINGTON — Signs that a long-awaited economic recovery may finally be gaining steam should be welcome news for President Obama and his party as they try to stem losses in this year’s midterm elections. But rising payrolls, lower unemployment and a buoyed stock market, while lifting the fortunes of the rich, are leaving behind major Democratic constituencies, including young women and blacks, just as the party tries to motivate them to turn out to vote in November.

headline: Hibbert’s Turnaround Helps Stabilize the Erratic Pacers
text: INDIANAPOLIS — For the first round of the N.B.A. playoff season, and the beginning of the second, it was difficult to comprehend where center Roy Hibbert’s game had gone. With some retrospection, it was easier to know where he was coming from.

headline: Ukraine Crisis Pushing Putin Toward China
text: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin said Monday that he was withdrawing Russian troops from the border with Ukraine, the second time he has said that in less than two weeks. He also praised the government in Kiev, which he had previously called an illegal, fascist junta, for its willingness to negotiate structural changes.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 19, 2014
Credit Suisse’s C.E.O. Is Called the ‘Teflon Man’
text: Brady W. Dougan, the chief executive of Credit Suisse, has always been something of an anomaly on Wall Street. He is a low-key Midwesterner who prefers long-distance running to New York City’s high-octane charity scene. When he married for the second time a few years ago, it was not to a much younger woman but to his high school sweetheart. He drives a Prius.

headline: Yankees Are Grasping for Starters
text: The first four times through their pitching rotation, the Yankees’ staff was a formidable group, with five starters all presenting imposing challenges for their opponents. But one by one three of those starters fell into various states of ill health, and the one area that had been the most dependable for the Yankees has become the most uncertain.

headline: Video Shows Killing of Palestinians on ‘Nakba Day’
text: Last Updated, Tuesday, 3:47 p.m. | Security-camera footage obtained by the rights group Defense for Children International appears to show the fatal shooting of two young Palestinians on Thursday during a demonstration in Beitunia, a West Bank town outside Ramallah.

headline: Bankrupt Housing Policy
text: The publication of Timothy Geithner’s memoir, “Stress Test,” has caused all the old arguments that were fought during the financial crisis to come rushing to the surface again.

headline: Looking for a Sure Thing in the Belmont Stakes? Bet on NBC
text: Forty-one years ago, CBS broadcast Secretariat’s victories at the Kentucky Derby, the Preakness Stakes and the Belmont Stakes — the last time a single network televised all three victories by a Triple Crown winner.

headline: For Activist Investors, a Wide Reporting Window
text: William A. Ackman seemingly appeared out of nowhere.

headline: Libyans Begin Taking Sides After General Wages Attacks
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Towns, tribes and armed groups across Libya chose sides on Monday in response to a renegade general’s assault on the country’s Islamist militias and lawmakers.

headline: Jack Brabham, 88, Who Raced and Built Formula One Winners, Dies
text: Jack Brabham, who quit school at 15 to work in a garage, became a race driver and won three world championships as a driver and two as a car builder in London, died on Monday at his home in Gold Coast, Australia. He was 88.

headline: Unexpected Expense
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — In my estimation, this one was just … a cute idea. I’ve seen much better from Peter A. Collins, but this one will suffice to get us through to our midweek and eventually our late-week challenges.

headline: ‘Appropriate’ and ‘Octoroon’ Among Obie Award Winners
text: The critically acclaimed Off Broadway plays “Appropriate” and “An Octoroon” dominated the 59th annual Obie Awards on Monday night, with Branden Jacobs-Jenkins winning the best new American play award for writing both dramas. In addition, Johanna Day, star of “Appropriate,” and Chris Myers, star of “An Octoroon,” received Obie performance awards, and Liesl Tommy won a directing Obie for “Appropriate.”

headline: Holder Announces Credit Suisse Plea
text: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. announced that the Swiss bank would plead guilty in a tax evasion case, pay about $2.6 billion in penalties and hire an independent monitor.

headline: M.T.A. Riders May Still Be Swiping in 2020
text: Amid persistent delays in its plans to introduce a new fare payment system, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority may be required to extend the MetroCard’s expected life beyond 2020, according to a presentation made on Monday to members of the authority’s board.

headline: New York City Calls Halt to Overhaul of 911 System
text: New York City’s procurement of a new, state-of-the-art 911 system is hundreds of millions of dollars over budget, years behind schedule and will take at least three more years to complete, Mayor Bill de Blasio said on Monday.

headline: A Political Dynasty in India After a Crippling Defeat
text: NEW DELHI — Ritual mortification is an essential element in Indian political life, and a Monday meeting of the Indian National Congress party, convened three days after the worst defeat in its history, seemed to call for something spectacular.

headline: Court Declines to Review Deal for Gulf Spill
text: A federal appeals court has refused to reconsider a major decision in the long-running battle over the 2010 gulf oil spill, leaving in place an earlier ruling that forces the British oil company BP to pay some businesses for economic damages without the businesses having to prove the losses were directly caused by the spill.

headline: Tongue-Tied on Campus
text: Whether it's 'trigger warnings' or disinvited graduation speakers, are conservative and liberal orthodoxy stifling intellectual debate?

headline: Crisis in South Sudan
text: War has led to the displacement of more than a million people and the death of thousands, as a food crisis intensifies.

headline: Food Crisis Worsens in South Sudan as Civil War Is Displacing Millions
text: WAU SHILUK, South Sudan — At the beginning of the rainy season every year, Nyaaker Onwar, 34, would plant the sorghum and vegetables, while her husband and eldest son herded the cows and caught fish from the White Nile. They ate what they produced, and when the harvest was bountiful, they sold the rest in a nearby market town.

headline: Vigil Marks 1,000 Days of Detention of American Marine in Iran
text: WASHINGTON — Family and supporters of Amir Hekmati, a former United States Marine who is being held in an Iranian prison for “practical collaboration with the United States government,” gathered for a vigil in front of the White House on Monday to mark the 1,000th day of his detainment.

headline: As Pope’s Visit Nears, Hate Crimes a Concern in Israel
text: JERUSALEM — With Pope Francis set to arrive here this weekend, Israeli security officials say they are bracing for possible hate crimes designed to provoke outrage and to sour the atmosphere around the visit.

headline: In New Jersey, a Prosecutor’s Office, an Indictment and Intimidation
text: William McGovern was a prosecutor out of central casting, a tough, careful fellow who has tried murderers and money launderers during a distinguished career in New Jersey.

headline: Viktor M. Sukhodrev, Soviet Leaders’ Trusted Interpreter, Dies at 81
text: MOSCOW — Viktor M. Sukhodrev, the personal interpreter for Nikita S. Khrushchev and Leonid I. Brezhnev, who brought a flair for language and diplomacy to three decades of brinkmanship between leaders of the Soviet Union and the United States, died on Friday at his home outside Moscow. He was 81.

headline: Savoring the Magic, One Run at a Time
text: In the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness, California Chrome dazzled on the racetrack. Afterward, though, his team stole the show. The fairy-tale run of his working-class owners, Steve and Carolyn Coburn and Perry and Denise Martin, has captured even the most casual fan’s attention. At 77, the trainer Art Sherman finally made it to the sport’s biggest stage. His 41-year-old jockey, Victor Espinoza, battled back from a slump to partake in his second Triple Crown run. Most important, they are all having fun. Following are excerpts from their post-Preakness news conference, where they were cracking jokes as if they were part of an improv show.

headline: Rejecting Bloomberg Policies, New York City Will Ease Some Hurdles to Public Assistance
text: The new commissioner of New York City’s Human Resources Administration on Monday announced a set of sweeping changes that would remove some work requirements and other barriers to receiving public assistance, cheering advocates for the poor and underscoring the sharp change in direction by Mayor Bill de Blasio away from the welfare policies of his predecessor.

headline: Pastor Who Tried to Sell Fake Damien Hirst Paintings Is Sentenced to 6 Months
text: A Florida pastor who was convicted of trying to sell fake Damien Hirst paintings to an undercover police officer was sentenced on Monday to six months in jail and five years of probation.

headline: The Netherlands: Heroin Seized
text: Nearly 1,700 pounds of heroin was smuggled into the Netherlands last week hidden in a shipment of Iranian raisins, Dutch police investigators said Monday. The heroin, valued at about $23 million, was seized by the investigators last Thursday after the raisin shipment had been transported from Rotterdam to Hagestein. Two men were arrested. Iran is a major transit point for heroin from Afghanistan. Iran also is believed to be the world’s third-largest exporter of raisins, behind Turkey and the United States.

headline: New York Is a Hub in a Surging Heroin Trade
text: The flood of heroin coming into and going out of New York City has surged to the highest levels in more than two decades, alarming law enforcement officials who say that bigger players are now entering the market to sell the drug here and to feed a growing appetite along the East Coast.

headline: Narciso Rodriguez’s Uniform Designs for Park Hyatt New York
text: The fashion designer — who cites Manhattan’s architecture as one of his main inspirations — created the women’s staff attire for the hotel, set to open this summer.

headline: The Year of the Safari Look
text: This year, the classic safari look abounds, but the latest version sports a sleeker, urban edge. We first saw the style in January in a set of suede, cold-weather resort separates. Now it’s back for spring, thanks to ribbon belts, and utilitarian pockets and a Sahara-inspired color palette of dusty neutrals — all design elements adopted by the likes of Bottega Veneta, Alexander McQueen and Givenchy this season. Worn together in a tonal mix or simply paired with a white linen shirt, these neutral, rugged looks for the city set are investment pieces that won’t go out of style.

headline: Unfazed by Boos, Rangers Pad Lead
text: MONTREAL — The score was 1-1 when Chris Kreider rode the scorn of 21,273 Montreal fans into the Canadiens’ zone. Amid resounding booing, he passed the puck cross-ice to Rick Nash, whose one-time shot beat goaltender Dustin Tokarski. The boos abruptly stopped. Silence filled the Bell Centre.

headline: ‘Frozen’ Will Be a Disney on Ice Show, Too, Riding a Blockbuster’s Wave
text: LOS ANGELES — The Walt Disney Company, scrambling to capitalize on unrelenting consumer interest in anything related to “Frozen,” has disclosed plans for an ice skating spectacular based on the blockbuster film that will begin touring arenas in September.

headline: $5 Million Gift to Endow Director’s Position at Brooklyn Museum
text: The Brooklyn Museum has received a $5 million gift from the Leon Levy Foundation to endow the position of director, the museum is expected to announce on Tuesday. The gift is the largest the museum has received from a donor who was not a member of its board of trustees. Arnold L. Lehman, the director of the museum since 1997, will become, formally, the Shelby White and Leon Levy Director of the Brooklyn Museum.

headline: Word of the Day | sinuous
text: sinuous •\ˈsin-yə-wəs, -yü-əs\• adjective

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, May 20, 2014
text: “We’re kind of the head of the Hydra. This is highly organized, high volume, and it’s being moved much more efficiently and effectively to reach out to a broader user base.”

headline: U.S. Cites End to C.I.A. Ruses Using Vaccines
text: WASHINGTON — Three years after the Central Intelligence Agency set up a phony hepatitis vaccination program in Pakistan as part of the hunt for Osama bin Laden, the Obama administration told a group of American health educators last week that the agency no longer uses immunization programs as a cover for spying operations.

headline: D’Souza Expected to Plead Guilty to Charge
text: A federal court hearing has been scheduled for Tuesday morning in which the conservative author and filmmaker Dinesh D’Souza is expected to plead guilty to a charge stemming from campaign finance violations, according to a notice sent out by the government.

headline: Landmark Status Could Block Luxury Tower Plans at Upper East Side Site
text: For decades, one of New York City’s biggest real estate families has been trying to demolish a pair of historic tenements on the Upper East Side to make way for a luxury apartment tower many times their size.

headline: Corrections: May 20, 2014
text: NEW YORK

headline: Robert Stuart Jr., 98, Quaker Oats Chief and War Foe in 1940, Dies
text: Robert D. Stuart Jr., whose long career as a top executive for the family business, Quaker Oats, was preceded by his founding, with a handful of fellow Yale law students, of the America First Committee, the catalyst for a potent and polarizing movement opposing the nation’s entry into World War II, died on May 8. He was 98.

headline: Times Minute | China’s Wanted Hackers
text: How five men working for the People’s Liberation Army in China ended up wanted by United States authorities.

headline: Times Minute | China’s Wanted Hackers
text: In the Video

headline: What’s On Tuesday
text: 8 P.M. (CBS) JUDGE JUDY PRIMETIME Judge Judith Sheindlin’s verbal slap-downs of a freak show of ne’er-do-wells have made her among the best-paid television personalities, with an annual salary of $47 million, and have held her Emmy-winning daytime series, above, at No. 1 for the last four years. This special deciphers the guilty pleasure to be found in her courtroom drama by serving up new cases and classic Judyisms: “Are you trying to justify to me that you are an idiot?” “Beauty fades. Dumb is forever.” It also offers snippets from the 1993 “60 Minutes” profile that catapulted her from New York family court judge to pop culture fame.

headline: Imposing Martial Law, Thai Military Denies Plans for Coup
text: BANGKOK — Citing a century-old law, the head of Thailand’s Army declared what he described as nationwide martial law early Tuesday and urged protesters who have paralyzed the government and blocked elections to “stop their movement.” The order also appeared to apply to pro-government demonstrators who are leading a separate protest.

headline: Taxi Commission Official Plans to Join Uber
text: At first, they were adversaries — the taxi agency leery of a smartphone app that could upend decades of street-hailing history and the business that responded by hitting the tech-friendly Bloomberg administration where it hurt.

headline: How El Niño Might Alter the Political Climate
text: El Niño is coming. Above-average sea surface temperatures have developed off the west coast of South America and seem poised to grow into a full-fledged El Niño event, in which unusually warm water temperatures spread across the equatorial East Pacific. Models indicate a 75 percent chance of El Niño this fall, which could bring devastating droughts to Australia or heavy rains to the southern United States.

headline: Australian Winemaker Rebuffs $2.8 Billion Takeover Bid by K.K.R.
text: HONG KONG — Kohlberg Kravis Roberts was rebuffed on Tuesday in a nearly $3 billion takeover bid for Treasury Wine Estates, the Australian vintner that owns Penfolds and Beringer Vineyards.

headline: Chinese Defense Statement on the U.S. Cyberspying Indictment
text: The Chinese Ministry of National Defense has issued a statement on its website condemning the United States indictments of five Chinese military officers on charges of hacking into commercial networks to steal corporate secrets. Following is a translation by The New York Times:

headline: Panicked Workers Fled Fukushima Plant in 2011 Despite Orders, Record Shows
text: TOKYO — At the most dire moment of the Fukushima nuclear crisis three years ago, hundreds of panicked employees abandoned the damaged plant despite being ordered to remain on hand for last-ditch efforts to regain control of its runaway reactors, according to a previously undisclosed record of the accident that was reported Tuesday by a major Japanese newspaper.

headline: The Europeans Are Coming, One City at a Time
text: LONDON — For many European start-ups, making it big in the United States remains the pinnacle of success.

headline: London Stock Exchange in Exclusive Talks to Buy Russell Investments
text: LONDON – The London Stock Exchange moved closer on Tuesday to buying Russell Investments, saying it was in “exclusive discussions” to potentially acquire the owner of the Russell 2000 stock market index.

headline: Charges of Chinese Cyberspying, Wanted Posters Included
text: A United States indictment accusing members of China’s military of computer hacking against American companies has put a face on a practice the Obama administration has long complained of, the use of state cyberwarfare capabilities to steal corporate secrets. While little is publicly known about the five indicted members of the People’s Liberation Army, the F.B.I. has released photos and aliases of the men accused of being members of the Chinese military’s computer espionage Unit 61398, also known as the “Comment Crew.”

headline: Psychiatric Tests Raise Question of Pistorius’s Criminal Liability
text: In more than just miles, it is a long way from Olympic Stadium in London to the Weskoppies Psychiatric Hospital in Pretoria, South Africa, but that is the journey that Oscar Pistorius is about to complete.

headline: Test Yourself | History, May 20
text: Take the Quiz

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Science Standards Divide a State Built on Coal and Oil
text: In “Science Standards Divide a State Built on Coal and Oil,” Motoko Rich writes about the debate in Wyoming over the new national science standards.

headline: Vodafone, Under Pressure in Europe, Reports Sluggish Sales
text: LONDON — Europe’s financial woes continue to hurt Vodafone.

headline: Hillary Speaks! (Not Really)
text: Next month, Hillary Clinton’s latest memoir, “Hard Choices,” a chronicle of her time at the State Department, will enter the expanding political subgenre of Inoffensively Clichéd and Calculated Titles Composed of Inoffensive Clichés and Calculations. “Hard Choices,” which reportedly earned Clinton a high-seven-figure advance, will offer the standard promotional- book-tour-cum-possible-campaign prelude. It is “much awaited” in the same way that Vice President Selina Meyer’s “Some New Beginnings” and Senator Al Franken’s “Why Not Me?” were. Of course, one was a fictional spoof on HBO’s “Veep” and the other was real-life satire, but both occupy the broad canon of politician tomes that flicker through our news cycles before settling into our remainder bins.

headline: Photographing, and Curing, the Blues in the Mississippi Delta
text: Brandon Thibodeaux was nursing a broken heart in 2009 when he stopped in the Mississippi Delta to look for a project that might salve the wound of a breakup. He rode his bicycle along a winding farm road, following a series of white, hand-painted signs nailed to trees that read “Travel Rest Mount Baptist Church” until he came to a white clapboard church by a small cemetery.

headline: Does Your School Seem Integrated?
text: While last weekend was the 60th anniversary of the Supreme Court decision Brown v. Board of Education that ended legal segregation in public schools, the federal Department of Education just released a statement announcing that de facto segregation is very much alive.

headline: Credit Suisse Investors Shrug Off Tax Plea
text: Updated, 7:12 p.m. | A day after Credit Suisse pleaded guilty to tax evasion in the United States, the Swiss bank says that it is able to conduct its business as normal despite its criminal conviction. Swiss officials and investors seemed to welcome the fact that the resolution allows the bank to put the matter behind it.

headline: Cobham Acquires Wireless Communications Company for $1.46 Billion
text: LONDON – Cobham, the British aerospace and military contractor, said on Tuesday that it was buying the Aeroflex Holding Corporation for $1.46 billion.

headline: Retaliatory Attacks, Online
text: HONG KONG — Two large American steel makers, United States Steel and Allegheny Technologies, each lost confidential files in online attacks. The largest solar panel manufacturer in the United States, SolarWorld, lost technological secrets, production cost data, cash flow projections and details of its legal strategy.

headline: Daily Report: AT&T-DirecTV Deal Complicates Regulatory Task
text: Many supporters of the Comcast-Time Warner Cable merger breathed a sigh of relief on Sunday, when AT&T and DirecTV announced plans to merge, thinking the latest pairing would divert some regulatory scrutiny of the other high-stakes deal, Edward Wyatt reports.

headline: Killings Revive Fears in Egypt Before Election
text: CAIRO — Three riot police officers trying to break up a student protest against Egypt’s military-backed government were killed in a drive-by shooting in Cairo on Tuesday as early results from expatriate voters confirmed that the military’s former leader, Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, was headed for a big victory in next week’s presidential election.

headline: The Role of Elites in Holocaust Denial
text: Why do misperceptions become widespread? More often than not, they have been spread by elites seeking political advantage. Many of the most significant myths and false claims in American politics were popularized or promoted by elites like Sarah Palin and Michael Moore, for instance. The same logic often applies internationally.

headline: My Eye-Opening Student Loan Moment
text: Last weekend, I wrote a column that I’d been wanting to do for a long time: the basics of student loan repayment.

headline: A Web Platform Connects Start-Ups and Angel Investors
text: Finding angel investors can be an arduous process for start-up founders, involving meetings with hundreds of individuals and groups, most of whom will never invest. A web platform called Gust, introduced in 2011 by David S. Rose, who started New York Angels, offers an easier way for start-ups to share information with angels.

headline: British Insurer RSA to Sell Canadian Unit to Arthur J. Gallagher
text: LONDON – The RSA Insurance Group of Britain has agreed to sell its Canadian insurance brokerage business to a subsidiary of Arthur J. Gallagher & Company for about $460 million.

headline: Veterans Protest U.S. Involvement in Asia
text: A group of People’s Liberation Army veterans gathered at a park in Shenzhen to protest what they called the United States’ involvement in China’s territorial disputes.

headline: What Were the ’20s Like? Allow a Piano Man to Paint a Picture
text: New York City may be crawling with contenders for the coveted imaginary title Mr. Show Business, but my vote would go to Mark Nadler, the hyperkinetic piano man and pop nostalgist who displays such voracious exuberance that it is a wonder he doesn’t collapse onstage from exhaustion. In his rambunctious new show, “Runnin’ Wild: Songs and Scandals of the Roaring ’20s,” Mr. Nadler is out to demonstrate that the hedonistic excesses of today’s New Gilded Age are a prim little tea party compared with the collective bacchanal of the Prohibition era, when New York was home to 32,000 speakeasies.

headline: European Regulators Accuse 3 More Banks of Manipulating Interest Rates
text: European antitrust regulators on Tuesday accused JPMorgan Chase, HSBC and Crédit Agricole of having colluded to fix benchmark interest rates tied to the euro.

headline: McConnell Win Leads Night of Victories for G.O.P. Establishment
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky decisively turned back the first well-financed Republican primary opponent he had faced since being elected in 1984, defeating a Tea Party-backed conservative who claimed the Senate minority leader had been too willing to compromise with Democrats.

headline: A Critical Election in Ukraine
text: It is risky to see hopeful trends in the Ukrainian crisis. But a degree of calm seems to have settled over the rebellious southeast, which may bode well for the presidential election scheduled for Sunday. There are many things Moscow and its minions in Ukraine can still do to derail the election, of course, but President Vladimir Putin of Russia has refrained from publicly endorsing the “people’s republics” proclaimed by secessionists. His spokesman said on Monday that he had ordered Russian troops to pull back from the Ukrainian border, though NATO has not seen any change yet.

headline: Satellite Firm to Release Data on Missing Malaysian Jet
text: PARIS — Amid pressure from the families of the passengers of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 for more transparency about the search for the missing jet, Inmarsat, the global satellite communications company, confirmed Tuesday that it would soon publish a full record of the communications received from the plane the day it disappeared.

headline: In Performance: Jeremy Denk
text: This week’s In Performance video features the pianist Jeremy Denk playing Mozart’s Rondo in F (K. 494). Mr. Denk, who was awarded the Avery Fisher Prize in March, will be the music director of next month’s Ojai Music Festival in California.

text: LOS ANGELES — Helloooo, and welcome to Mr. Moviefone’s new gig.

text: There’s a risk that a focus on small details in these critiques might suggest a lack of perspective, a trees/forest problem. And I realize that proper use of hyphens is a small detail in the broad scope of our journalistic efforts.

headline: Credit Suisse’s Felony Plea
text: Credit Suisse has done what no other bank of its size and significance has done in more than two decades: plead guilty to criminal wrongdoing, DealBook’s Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg write. “In a sign that banking giants are no longer immune from criminal charges, despite concerns that financial institutions have grown so large and interconnected that they are too big to jail, federal prosecutors demanded that Credit Suisse’s parent company plead guilty to helping thousands of American account holders hide their wealth,” they write.

headline: British Officials Welcome Cleric’s Conviction, but Some Britons Are Wary
text: LONDON — The conviction of a radical British Muslim cleric in New York this week drew praise from the British prime minister and home secretary on Tuesday, but some Muslims in the London neighborhood where the cleric once preached said they were troubled by his prosecution.

headline: Rum and Tonic
