headline: Developer Gives $30 Million to Establish City Planning Center
text: The developer Stephen M. Ross is giving $30.5 million to the World Resources Institute in Washington to establish a center that promotes sustainable city planning and growth in developing countries.

headline: Food Matters | An L.A. Chef’s Guide to Adventurous Backyard Cooking
text: “You’ve heard the term ‘food orgy,’ ” says Ben Ford. “I love the loss of inhibition when people get in a big group and enjoy a feast. That’s why I did this cookbook.” The chef and owner of Los Angeles’s Ford’s Filling Station gastro pub (and son of Harrison Ford) has authored “Taming the Feast” (Simon and Schuster, $34.99), a how-to guide for bringing “Game of Thrones”-size banquets to your own kitchen table, whether you’re serving a phalanx of friends or just a family of four. “The idea of working with whole animals, trying to close that proximity between the back door of my kitchen and the farmland, the book came out of that,” says Ford. Readers will have a difficult time finding another cookbook with both instructions for “rigging a pig for vertical roasting” and everyday backyard fare, like grilled beer-braised bratwurst or a simple safflower oil aioli. Alternative, more manageable recipes are offered for each feast — in case you, or your landlord, prefers that your paella come from a Weber or stovetop and not an inferno in the backyard. While such projects as sourcing cedar planks on which to roast sturgeon may sound complicated, for Ford the book is actually about getting back to basics; for instance, he teaches techniques like using one’s hands for testing not only the doneness of meat, but also the temperature level over a fire. Says Ford, “I’m very much a touch, feel, smell kind of chef.”

headline: China and Russia Fail to Reach Deal on Gas Plan
text: BEIJING — President Xi Jinping of China and the Russian leader, Vladimir V. Putin, were unable to announce an agreement on a natural gas deal on Tuesday, despite high expectations that mutual political interests would help finally push through the project.

headline: Target Fires Chief of Unit in Canada, Which Lags
text: In a year of public setbacks and damaging missteps, Target made another move on Tuesday to try to right itself by firing the president of its struggling Canadian division.

headline: Russia’s Relations With China
text: Vladimir V. Putin made conciliatory remarks about Ukraine perceived as being for the benefit of China ahead of a two-day visit there.

headline: Pfizer’s Latest Offer Divides Some of Largest Shareholders in AstraZeneca
text: Updated, 7:20 p.m. LONDON — Some of AstraZeneca’s largest shareholders were publicly split Tuesday on whether the company should continue merger discussions with Pfizer.

headline: Cleveland Hires Leader of Morgan
text: Seven months after David Franklin abruptly resigned as director of the Cleveland Museum of Art, with museum officials later saying he had lied to them about his extramarital affair with an employee, the institution has named a high-profile successor from New York, signaling a new chapter in its 98-year history. He is William M. Griswold, who has led the Morgan Library & Museum for nearly seven years. Mr. Griswold, 53, who will start his new job in the fall, said he decided to leave New York because he relishes running a bigger institution, with one of the most encyclopedic collections in the country.

headline: Young Undocumented Immigrants Growing Disenchanted With Both Parties, Study Finds
text: Only about half of young immigrants who grew up in the United States without legal status identify with the Democratic Party, while nearly half say they are independents or have some other nonparty affiliation, according to a study published Tuesday.

headline: The Demands of Book Promotion: Frivolous or Necessary?
text: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, James Parker and Anna Holmes discuss whether they find the demands of book promotion — author photos, media campaigns, Twitter feeds — frivolous or necessary.

headline: Beard Awards Move to Chicago
text: The James Beard Awards will move to Chicago next year, the first time in the award show’s 25-year history that it will not be produced in New York City, the Beard foundation will announce Tuesday.

headline: Fantasy Football: Analyzing N.F.L. Draft Picks, Part 3
text: Continuing our look at the rookie on each N.F.L. team who will have the most fantasy impact this season, whether for him or for the players around him, we turn our attention to the A.F.C. East and North.

headline: Imagine No Possessions, and No Moving Van, Too
text: Mari folded herself over Bundy, pretending our rabbit’s white fur was a pillow and resting her cheek on it. Bundy squirmed, broke away and scampered around our apartment. Mari used to crawl after her. Now she runs.

headline: To Save the Shore, Putting Hope in the Sand
text: It seemed a little like playing hooky. Micah Citti and about a dozen colleagues from the marketing department of ESPN were kneeling on the beach in the Rockaways in Queens on a gorgeous spring day, the kind of day that makes employees want to flee the office.

headline: No Comment Necessary: The Common Core and Gay Conversion
text: Hysteria over the Common Core has reached new heights. Think Progress reports that, at an anti-Common Core event in March, Florida State Representative Charles Van Zant, a Republican, said the new educational standards were a ploy to make schoolchildren gay.

text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Hotel Lutetia in Paris Auctions Off Historic Items
text: PARIS — The Hotel Lutetia, a Left Bank landmark during war and peace, started auctioning off some of its history this week — 3,000 objects that range from champagne glasses and hotel china to Art Deco settees and the reception desk.

headline: Video Renews Questions on Death of Young Palestinians
text: JERUSALEM — A human rights group circulated a video on Tuesday that renews questions about last week’s killing of two Palestinian teenagers by Israeli forces during a West Bank demonstration.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 23
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Home Depot Leads Weak Retail Sector Ahead of Spring Spending Thaw
text: A variety of retailers reported disappointing earnings early this week, showing the strain of the slow, uneven economic recovery and weighing on the stock market on Tuesday. Home Depot; the TJX Companies, the parent of T.J. Maxx and Marshalls; and Dick’s Sporting Goods all missed earnings expectations.

headline: V.A. Accusations Aggravate Woes of White House
text: WASHINGTON — The White House fought on Tuesday to contain the growing political furor over allegations of misconduct at the nation’s veterans hospitals as Republicans, eager to use the issue in the midterm elections, seized on the reports as new evidence that President Obama is unable to govern effectively.

headline: Wheeler Says F.C.C. Will Examine Peering Arrangements
text: WASHINGTON — The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission said Tuesday that the agency would examine the type of paid-priority arrangements that Netflix recently entered into with Comcast, a deal that created an uproar of accusations that the F.C.C. was allowing companies to buy fast-lane Internet access to consumers.

headline: Gergiev, Under Fire for Support of Putin, Seeks to Reassure Munich
text: Valery Gergiev, the conductor whose ties to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia have sparked protests at his performances in the West — over gay rights in Russia and the Ukraine crisis — wrote a letter on Tuesday seeking to explain himself to subscribers of the Munich Philharmonic, the orchestra he is set to take over as music director in 2015-16.

headline: The Latest in Watches: The Old Way to Tell Time
text: They stop time, ring time, contain time, split its measure into infinitesimally calibrated segments. They are sleek and golden, burnished to Fred Astaire elegance or else bulky and steroidal, as cartoonish as Hulk Hogan. By far the majority of watches fall into some commercially secure Goldilocks middle ground, serviceable mechanical manacles locked in vestigial fashion to millions of wrists.

headline: Lancet Study Calls for Action to Prevent Millions of Newborn Deaths
text: URAGAHALLI, India — About a year ago, Nagarathna, who uses only one name, was admitted to a local government hospital on the outskirts of India’s information technology hub of Bangalore, when she went into labor. A bone-rattling ride on a motorized three-wheeler transported her to the facility located a few miles from her village.

headline: Study Gives E-Cigarettes Edge in Helping Smokers Quit
text: A large study in England has found that smokers trying to quit were substantially more likely to succeed if they used electronic cigarettes than over-the-counter therapies such as nicotine patches or gum. These results offered encouraging but not definitive evidence in the contentious debate about the risks and benefits of these increasingly popular smoking devices.

headline: Cannes Film Festival: The Dogs of ‘White God’
text: Fur flies and blood flows in “White God,” a fierce and beautiful Hungarian parable about a girl, her dog, and the uprising that’s sparked after they are separated. Directed by Kornel Mundruczo, 39, the movie is being presented in Un Certain Regard, a section of the Cannes Film Festival for work that tends to be more adventurous than that in the main competition. Such is the case with “White God,” which goes from melodrama to hallucination after the girl’s father throws the dog into the streets. As she searches for the male dog, Hagen, he takes up with other strays (including a scene-nipping Jack Russell), escapes from dog-pound baddies and ends up doped up with sharpened teeth in a fighting pit.

headline: Checking in With Key Constituencies After the Vote

headline: Modi, India’s Next Prime Minister, Adopts a Softer Tone

headline: McCartney Cancels Japanese Tour Because of Illness

headline: Briere Living Out a Fantasy in the Twilight of His Career
text: BROSSARD, Quebec — Daniel Briere was born in Quebec to Canadiens-adoring parents in 1977, when the best team in Habs history won the Stanley Cup. Montreal won the next year, and the year after that, and again in 1986, when Briere was a hockey-crazed 8-year-old. He watched that series, against Calgary, and yearned to someday wear le bleu, blanc et rouge.

headline: Bryan College Is Torn: Can Darwin and Eden Coexist?
text: DAYTON, Tenn. — William Jennings Bryan earned a permanent place in American history nearly nine decades ago in the Scopes trial, when he stood in a courtroom here and successfully prosecuted a teacher who broke the law by teaching evolution in a public school.

headline: Leslie Thomas, Author of the Novel ‘The Virgin Soldiers,’ Dies at 83

headline: Mixed Signals in a Corporate Felon’s Punishment

headline: Loophole Offers Pfizer a Risky Way Back Into a Deal

text: Why did so many readers wonder about that particular scene in my article, and what does it say about the stigma surrounding the injection of heroin?

headline: Before a Vote, a Challenger’s Reflections in Kentucky
text: WASHINGTON — Kentucky’s Republican voters on Tuesday seemed likely to nominate Mitch McConnell to take on Alison Lundergan Grimes in a Senate contest that will be one of the country’s most watched, and important, elections. Such a result could render Mr. McConnell’s primary opponent, Matt Bevin, to a historical footnote best remembered for speaking after the director of the American Gamefowl Defense Network at a rally where he endorsed legalized cockfighting.

headline: Morricone Cancels North American Concerts
text: The Italian composer Ennio Morricone has canceled a short North American visit in which he was to have conducted concerts of his film music — at Barclays Center in Brooklyn on June 13, at the Nokia Theater in Los Angeles on June 15, and at the National Auditorium in Mexico City on June 18. The concerts, originally scheduled for March, had been postponed after Mr. Morricone, 84, injured his back before he was to have traveled to the United States.

headline: Video of Palestinians Killed at Protest
text: Video of two shootings taken from a security camera in the West Bank was released by Defense for Children International-Palestine, a human rights group.

headline: Ready to Roll With the Punches
text: A bowl of punch turns a backyard of rugged individualists into a group with a mission, says the cocktail expert David Wondrich, who has written a book, “Punch,” on the subject.

headline: Wheelies: The Luxury G.M. Trucks Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: D’Souza, Set for Trial, Pleads Guilty to a Campaign Finance Violation
text: On the morning he was to go on trial in Manhattan, the conservative author and filmmaker Dinesh D’Souza pleaded guilty on Tuesday to one count of making campaign contributions in the names of other people, a violation of federal campaign finance laws.

headline: An Old Flame Reignited
text: Back in the 1960s, when nobody except rats, longshoremen and gangsters needing to dispose of a wayward bookie saw much value in the Brooklyn waterfront, Michael O’Keeffe saw romance. He saw enough flowers for a year of proms, he saw a piano player massaging a Steinway, he saw a curtain of glass framing the Brooklyn Bridge and the lights of Fortress Manhattan on the other side. All of this he saw floating on a barge in the East River. After pleading for permits for 12 years, he persuaded City Hall to see it, too, and in 1977 the River Café dropped anchors.

headline: What Is a Balanced Budget Anyway?
text: For nearly his last five years as mayor of New York City, Michael Bloomberg and the United Federation of Teachers failed to agree on a contract for the city’s public schoolteachers. By the time Bill de Blasio took office as mayor in January, the teachers were demanding billions in retroactive pay increases for the years they didn’t have a contract and therefore didn’t get base pay increases.

headline: A Manufacturer Learns Hard Lessons About Negotiating
text: At the most recent meeting of the She Owns It business group, Susan Parker talked about recent changes at her company, Bari Jay. These included hiring new designers and negotiating new distribution agreements.

headline: A Cross-Atlantic Collaboration Results in Striking, Sculptural Jewelry
text: The spare, witty jewelry of Pièce à Conviction is little-known in the United States, but the New York-based designer Mary Ping has been collecting it for a decade, ever since she first discovered the ahead-of-its-time “floating”-style rings in a shop in Paris. “I don’t remember the name of the store,” says Ping, who designs Slow and Steady Wins the Race as well as a namesake line. “Which is a testament to how struck by the rings I was, because I remember everything.” After years spent wearing the jewelry daily in her Manhattan studio — and getting asked about it “all the time” — Ping worked up the courage to approach the line’s designer, Ghislain Ryckebusch, about collaborating. Ryckebusch invited her to his home and studio in Fontainebleau to work together, and the striking, sculptural results — a five-piece capsule collection including rings, bracelets and a necklace — will debut Thursday evening at Creatures of Comfort in New York, with more designs to follow in future seasons. “These really are pieces that hum and breathe. There is a rhythm, a balance,” Ping says. “They are unique punctuation marks.”

headline: Far-Right Fever for a Europe Tied to Russia
text: LE CHESNAY, France — At a rally last week near the Palace of Versailles, France’s largest far-right party, the National Front, deployed all the familiar theatrics and populist themes of nationalist movements across Europe.

headline: Do Not Resuscitate: What Young Doctors Would Choose
text: The researcher was presenting her findings to a room full of geriatricians, at the American Geriatrics Society annual scientific meeting last week in Orlando, Fla. So a slide revealing one particular statistic didn’t cause an audible gasp or murmur. Talking to geriatricians about end-of-life treatment practically defines preaching to the choir, as a member of the audience told me later.

headline: Florida State Holds Hearing Connected to Jameis Winston Allegations
text: Nearly a year and a half after a student at Florida State accused the future Heisman Trophy winner Jameis Winston of rape, the university on Tuesday held its first student disciplinary hearing in connection with the matter.

headline: Not Enough Room at the Democratic Cash Trough
text: Organizing for Action, the ill-conceived support group for the Obama administration, is finally scaling back its fundraising efforts, and promising to move to the political sidelines.

headline: Bound for the World Cup? Tips to Save You Money
text: The monthlong, 32-country soccer tournament known as the World Cup kicks off on June 12 in Brazil. And guess where the most tickets have been sold, outside of Brazil that is? Defying all logic, it’s the United States, the only country in the world you have to start an article about the World Cup by explaining what it is, when it starts and where it’s being played.

headline: Soccer as Spectacle in the Pacific Northwest
text: The last thing I remember clearly, sometime around 4 a.m., was wondering how many people had fallen down the vertiginous back-hallway stairs that are the only way in or out of the Railway Club, the oldest continuously operating bar in Vancouver, British Columbia, a drinking and former gambling establishment that has seen its share of idiots and drunkards since it opened in 1931.

headline: Obama’s Indecision Points
text: I wrote my Sunday column on President Obama’s foreign policy, which seems to be failing to achieve its objectives just about everywhere one might reasonably look. (And the column went to press before the latest turn of events in post-Qaddafi Libya, the latest sour news on the Iranian nuclear talks, and the acknowledgment from administration officials that actually, in its latest incarnations, al Qaeda may not actually be on “the path to defeat” after all.) In limning these failures, however, I diagnosed without prescribing: I’m not sure I have a grand unified theory of what’s going wrong  — “events, dear boy, events” probably doesn’t count — so it’s hard to offer a clear account of everything the president should be doing differently.

headline: Counting Champagne Bubbles, Sake in Vending Machines and More
text: To Calculate: Counting the Bubbles in the Bubbly

headline: Durbin Lends Support to Pro-Clinton Group
text: Add Senator Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, to the growing list of lawmakers who supported Barack Obama in the 2008 Democratic primary and have now pledged early support to his former rival, Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: Gloria Estefan Musical Planned for Broadway Run
text: “On Your Feet!,” a new musical about the lives of the Grammy Award-winning singer Gloria Estefan and her husband, Emilio, will open on Broadway in fall 2015 under the direction of Jerry Mitchell (“Kinky Boots”), the producers announced on Tuesday. A try-out run is planned for Chicago next summer.

headline: Lower Manhattan Will Undergo a Retail Revival
text: In Manhattan, where most of the city’s stores are small, street-level boutiques, mammoth shopping malls are rare. But next spring, the endless maze of cranes and construction pits that has enveloped Lower Manhattan for more than a decade will be mostly cleared away, making room for not one, but two, massive retail centers.

headline: Judge Strikes Down Pennsylvania’s Gay-Marriage Ban
text: Continuing a rush of rulings that have struck down marriage limits across the country, a federal judge in Pennsylvania on Tuesday declared the state’s ban on same-sex marriage to be unconstitutional.

headline: Inside a Conjurer of Characters
text: Tom Robbins, the author of such pie-eyed and hippie-deluxe novels as “Another Roadside Attraction” and “Even Cowgirls Get the Blues,” is rarely thought of as a Southern writer. But he was born in Appalachian North Carolina during the Great Depression and grew up there and in Virginia. He’s the grandson of two Baptist preachers.

headline: Ian Fleming’s Villa, by the Room
text: The Fleming Villa, a three-bedroom home in Oracabessa on Jamaica’s north coast where Ian Fleming wrote his James Bond novels, is usually available to rent only  in its entirety, but starting on May 28 —  the day that would have been the author’s 106th birthday — travelers will be able to rent a single bedroom.

headline: After Thai Military Declares Martial Law, Protesters Continue Their Rallies
text: BANGKOK — Questions intensified about the intentions of Thailand’s military on Wednesday, a day after the head of the army declared martial law and curbed media freedoms but allowed protesters to continue their demonstrations — which they did with enthusiasm.

headline: The Gun Report: May 20, 2014
text: While there may be a dearth of federal dollars going into gun violence research, journalists are attempting to fill the gap.

headline: Bacchanal and Bâtard Open
text: Headliner

headline: Original Memo From 1964
text: The original memo from Mr. Steele acts as a reminder that the civil rights movement left gay and lesbian Americans behind.

headline: Scene City: Fashion as Child’s Play
text: Ralph Lauren hosts a children’s fashion show, with famous moms in tow.

headline: Drama at The Times: Some Reviews
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tequila Highball
text: How to make this easy tequila drink with soda and lime.

headline: Chilled Tequila Shots With Lime and Salt
text: Tequila shots are always good, but they’re even better chilled.

headline: Frozen Margarita
text: How to make a frozen margarita, relief in a glass on a hot summer day.

headline: Pink Gin
text: How to make this elegant pink drink, which is due for a revival.

headline: Gin and Soda
text: How to make this simple drink: Some gin. Some soda. Done.

headline: Tom Collins
text: How to make a Tom Collins, essentially a ginned-up tall glass of lemonade.

headline: Tequila Shots With Sangrita Chasers
text: How to improve on tequila shots: Chase them with a short glass of spicy, citrusy sangrita.

headline: Margarita
text: How to make a classic margarita: tequila, lime, a touch of orange.

headline: Negroni
text: How to make a Negroni, one of the easiest classic drinks to prepare — even for a crowd.

headline: Cuba Libre
text: How to make this classic highball. Use real cane cola if you can find it.

headline: Gin and Tonic With Bitters and Orange
text: Use bitters and orange peel to perk up a gin and tonic.

headline: Rum and Pineapple Juice
text: How to make this easygoing drink that tastes like the tropics.

headline: Paloma
text: How to make a paloma, Mexico’s most refreshing highball.

headline: Gin Mule
text: How to make a gin mule, which pairs gin and ginger to great effect.

headline: Tequila and Grapefruit Juice
text: How to make this straightforward, pleasingly tart drink.

headline: Piña Colada
text: How to make a piña colada, the irresistible tiki classic.

headline: Rum With Iced Hibiscus Tea
text: Add chilled hibiscus tea to rum for an almost-instant punch.

headline: Classic Daiquiri
text: How to make a daiquiri, which offers tartness and sweetness in just the right balance.

headline: Gin, Juice and More Juice
text: How to make an easy highball with two kinds of citrus.

headline: Tequila and Watermelon
text: How to make this crowd-pleasing highball, which is a little sweet, a little spicy and exuberantly pink.

headline: Gin Fizz
text: How to make a gin fizz. Shake it like mad for optimal effervescence.

headline: Honey Bee
text: How to make a honey bee, a sort of summery hot toddy.

headline: Rum and Tonic
text: There’s nothing wrong with a gin and tonic, but try a rum and tonic — a sweeter, deeper surprise.

headline: Tequila Sour
text: Sours aren’t just for whiskey. Tequila lightens things up.

headline: Rum Julep
text: How to make a rum julep: match rum with mint and plenty of crushed ice.

headline: Planter’s Punch
text: How to make surprisingly subtle planter’s punch, good for one or for serving a crowd.

headline: Martini on the Rocks
text: How to make a martini on the rocks, a good choice for a hot day.

headline: Annette Bening Joins ‘King Lear’ Cast for Shakespeare in the Park
text: When the Public Theater announced that John Lithgow (“The Columnist,” “Dirty Rotten Scoundrels”) would play the title role in this summer’s free Shakespeare in the Park production of “King Lear,” that seemed enough to guarantee long ticket lines at the Delacorte Theater. Now the company has sweetened the deal: Annette Bening, whose last Broadway appearance was in “Coastal Disturbances” in 1988, will join the cast as Goneril, the company announced on Tuesday. It will be her Public Theater debut.

headline: Alarm Over Istanbul’s Building Boom
text: ISTANBUL — “We are invading Istanbul again,” the real estate agent said enthusiastically as she ticked off the selling points of Turkey’s most ambitious development extravaganza to date: Maslak 1453.

headline: NPR Ending a Program With Focus on Diversity
text: NPR will end production of its midday program “Tell Me More” on Aug. 1 and eliminate 28 jobs across the newsroom in an effort to close a $6 million deficit, the public broadcaster said on Tuesday.

headline: From ‘Acid’ to ‘Bonfire,’ an Archive That Sizzles
text: In March 1988, when Tom Wolfe’s “The Bonfire of the Vanities” was parked at the top of the best-seller list, 962 Fifth Avenue was known to seemingly everyone as the gilded home of the mistress of Sherman McCoy, the book’s high-living investment banker protagonist.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Battle Over Darden Leaves Little Room for Compromise
text: Can Clarence Otis Jr., the chief executive of Darden Restaurants, save himself by cutting off his claws?

headline: Kathryn A. Korte
text: Ms. Korte, 51, is the chief executive and president of Sotheby’s International Realty, a residential brokerage firm that specializes in luxury property. The brand was founded in 1976 by the Sotheby’s auction house and includes 41 company-owned offices in 13 markets, including New York. Ms. Korte took the helm of the company in 2006.

headline: Art Matters | When LACMA Sings for its Supper
text: On a rare rainy evening in Beverly Hills last month, the movie producer and New York Giants chairman Steve Tisch was warmly greeting guests, including fellow super-producers Brian Grazer and Bob Shaye, near the entrance to his estate. No one was there to talk shop. Instead, they had come to an exclusive dinner to celebrate the beginning of the Collector’s Committee weekend to benefit the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. The annual fundraising event brings together heavy-hitter donors (who pay a minimum of $15,000 to $60,000 for the privilege of attending) to hobnob and help the museum acquire new works.

headline: Arthur Gelb, Critic and Editor Who Shaped The Times, Dies at 90
text: Arthur Gelb, who by sheer force of personality was a dominant figure at The New York Times for decades, lifting its metropolitan and arts coverage to new heights and helping to shape the paper in its modern era, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 90.

headline: A Life Collecting Chinese Landscapes
text: Lois Conner has devoted three decades to making landscapes of China layered with detail and history.

headline: Harper Lee Asks to Renew Lawsuit Against Museum
text: Harper Lee, the author of “To Kill a Mockingbird,” has asked a federal judge to reinstate her legal case against the Monroe County Heritage Museum, claiming that the museum was attempting to add new terms to an out-of-court settlement reached in February.

headline: Statue Doesn’t Appear to Be Looted, Museum Says
text: The Cleveland Museum of Art said it has determined that an ancient statue in its collection, which Cambodian officials have said they believe was stolen from a heavily looted jungle temple, did not come from that location.

headline: Scott Brown Facing Uphill Fight in New Hampshire
text: Scott Brown, a former Republican senator, is struggling in his race for a Senate seat in New Hampshire. Despite a reputation for having smooth political skills — he handily won election in 2010 to the seat once held by Ted Kennedy in heavily Democratic Massachusetts — our model, which we call Leo, gives Mr. Brown only a 3 percent chance to unseat the Democratic incumbent, Jeanne Shaheen.

headline: Make Mine Cool and Easy
text: There were those tallboys of Miller High Life cadged off picnickers on a Connecticut beach. Spritzers on a splintery deck on Fire Island. Long, cold shandies on suspiciously sunny Dublin days.

headline: Reviews: Mario Kart 8, Child of Light, Kiwanuka and Super Time Force
text: MARIO KART 8

headline: For a Pianist, a Chance to Impress Once Again
text: The players who do well in the Cleveland International Piano Competition are often perceived as thoughtful, introspective, even introverted — not your average finger-crashing young virtuosos. So it is with the Ukrainian pianist Stanislav Khristenko, the winner of last year’s Cleveland contest, who, as part of his first-prize reward, gave an impressive recital on Monday evening at Zankel Hall.

headline: Malnutrition and the Elderly
text: To the Editor:

headline: Met Orchestra’s Players Turn to Social Media
text: Sometimes the musicians post behind-the-scenes tidbits, like some decades-old advice a viola player found penciled into her part for “Andrea Chénier” by one of her predecessors: “whatcha da mice!” — meaning watch the maestro in one tricky passage.

headline: Ghosts Lurk in Some Sounds
text: The Argento Chamber Ensemble has made regular appearances at the Austrian Cultural Forum recently, championing artists like the Austrian composer Georg Friedrich Haas and earlier Viennese composers. Its concert on Sunday was its first there without music by an Austrian; a piece by Alban Berg, of Vienna, was canceled because of a performer’s illness. The show went on with a focus on contemporary American composers.

headline: British Citizenship Law
text: To the Editor:

headline: Immigrant Children
text: To the Editor:

headline: Zico’s New Coconut Water Pitch: Spandex Not Necessary
text: AS soda sales have decreased over the last decade while obesity concerns rose, one of the fastest-growing alternatives has been coconut water. The number of coconut water products introduced in the United States in 2013 increased 92 percent over the previous year, according to Innova Market Insights data cited in Beverage Industry, a trade journal. And the market research firm Euromonitor identified coconut water as one of the United States’ top five beverage trends of 2013.

headline: Dealing With Debt Collectors
text: If you’ve ever been dunned by a debt collector, you’re not alone: Roughly one in seven American adults is being pursued by a collector, for amounts averaging about $1,500.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Kenya and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Kenya, India, Ukraine and South Africa.

headline: Punishing G.M. for Failing to Disclose Defects
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Tale of Two Cities, Carved on Site in Stone
text: Tiny limestone skyscrapers and tenements are rising within eyeshot of Christopher Columbus’s weathered marble face at Columbus Circle, in the shadow of billions of dollars of real estate. On the sixth floor of the Museum of Arts and Design, the stone carver Chris Pellettieri has been chipping away at a limestone block, creating miniature buildings that represent New York’s socioeconomic extremes.

headline: Landmarks Panel Votes to Protect 2 Upper East Side Tenements
text: They might look more abandoned than historic, but two tenements on the Upper East Side will remain standing: New York City’s landmarks board on Tuesday denied the owner permission to tear them down.

headline: Young Iranians Arrested for Being Too ‘Happy in Tehran’
text: Last Updated, 11:00 p.m. | Just days after Iran’s president denounced Internet censorship as “cowardly,” six young Iranians were arrested and forced to repent on state television Tuesday for the grievous offense of proclaiming themselves to be “Happy in Tehran,” in a homemade music video they posted on YouTube last month.

headline: Aftermath of Car Bombings in Nigeria
text: People combed through the debris at the site of back-to-back explosions that killed at least 46 people in a crowded business district in the central city of Jos.

headline: Mutual Admiration, Across the Sea, Across the Years
text: Ella Yelich-O’Connor, better known as Lorde, the New Zealand-born teenage pop star, and Conor Oberst, the solo artist and frontman for Bright Eyes, are separated by 17 years and several continents. But in many ways they cover the same ground as confessional singer-songwriters. Mr. Oberst, now 34, started young, too, releasing an album on tape at 13 in his native Omaha, and earning accolades as a musical prodigy before he graduated from high school. His latest solo record, “Upside Down Mountain,” was released on Tuesday. For a time, Lorde had a quotation from him in her Twitter bio: “No, I am not singing for you.” “It’s my mantra in life,” she said.

headline: Kids and ...
text: 1. Lunch

headline: Safety Commission Recalls Bed Handles After Deaths
text: WASHINGTON — The Consumer Product Safety Commission on Tuesday announced the first recall of adult portable bed handles, devices that are designed to help patients get in and out of bed. The metal handles are widely used in care facilities for older adults and people with disabilities.

headline: 2 Explosions Kill Scores at Central Nigeria Market
text: ABUJA, Nigeria — Two powerful explosions killed scores of people, many of them female vendors, in the central Nigerian city of Jos on Tuesday afternoon, officials and witnesses said. While no one claimed responsibility for the bombing, it occurred as international attention has focused on the Islamist extremist group Boko Haram following the abduction of hundreds of schoolgirls last month and may have been a bloody act of defiance.

headline: What Are You Drinking?
text: Let the author and bartender Rosie Schaap make you a custom summer cocktail.

headline: The Primary Results, via Twitter
text: Not much matters six months before a midterm election, but Tuesday’s primaries were an exception.

headline: Mouse Enjoys Exercise Wheel in the Wild
text: Scientists at Leiden University in the Netherlands set up exercise wheels with motion detectors and automated cameras, and found that animals such as mice ran on the wheels voluntarily.

headline: Mice Run for Fun, Not Just Work, Research Shows
text: If an exercise wheel sits in a forest, will mice run on it?

headline: Inwood: Always on the Brink of Coolness
text: Inwood, in the leafy northern stretch of Manhattan, has never really lacked for natural charms. Centuries ago, Native Americans plied its waterways; later, Gilded Age tycoons built their mansions on its hills for the best views; and today, residents say one of the benefits of living here is its many parks, which are popular for running, concerts and picnics.

headline: Greece’s Austerity Orphans
text: The photographer Nikos Pilos visited an Athens hospital to document the growing problem of child abandonment during the Greek financial crisis.

headline: House Passes Bills Aimed at Stemming Human Trafficking
text: WASHINGTON — The House on Tuesday passed a package of bills aimed at stemming human trafficking, an issue that has slowly begun to gain national attention.

headline: Deloitte Partner Sanctioned Over Conflict of Interest With Casino Client
text: James T. Adams, a partner at the accounting firm Deloitte & Touche, would not ordinarily have gotten in trouble for borrowing money at a casino where he liked to gamble.

headline: The Limits of Armchair Warfare
text: BOTH of us have a deep appreciation for the work of drone pilots. Whether patrolling the Helmand Valley with a sniper team or relying on drone-driven intelligence to plan manned aerial missions, we often prayed that the drone operators supporting us were cool, calm and collected.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
text: RECENT SALE

headline: JPMorgan Committing $100 Million Over 5 Years to Aid Revitalization in Detroit
text: JPMorgan Chase, the nation’s biggest bank, will provide $100 million to help debt-ridden Detroit with housing repairs, blight removal, job training and economic development projects over the next five years, according to two people with direct knowledge of the plans.

headline: For Schools, Long Road to a Level Playing Field
text: In the American national mythology, there are few more revered ideas than the belief in education’s power to provide every child a shot at success and to overcome entrenched inequality.

headline: Four Words Going Bye-Bye
text: The more I read the news, the more it looks to me that four words are becoming obsolete and destined to be dropped from our vocabulary. And those words are “privacy,” “local,” “average” and “later.” A lot of what drives today’s news derives from the fact that privacy is over, local is over, average is over and later is over.

headline: Yum Brands Sets Plan for Transition at Taco Bell
text: Yum Brands said on Tuesday that an insider, Brian Niccol, would take the helm of Taco Bell, its thriving Mexican fast-food chain.

headline: Health Site Under Fire, Nevada Alters Path
text: WASHINGTON — The board of Nevada’s problem-plagued online health insurance exchange voted Tuesday to end its contract with the vendor in charge of building it and to rely on the federal enrollment system for at least a year.

headline: The Military, Again, Takes Over in Thailand
text: Under the pretext of restoring “peace and order,” the military of Thailand imposed martial law in that politically troubled country early Tuesday morning. It’s the latest in a series of disturbing developments that will further undermine the country’s democracy and its economy.

headline: After Fed, Bernanke Offers His Wisdom, for a Big Fee
text: On Tuesday, Ben S. Bernanke spoke in Abu Dhabi; on Wednesday, he was in Johannesburg. By Friday, he was in Houston. That week in March was a particularly busy one for Mr. Bernanke, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve.

headline: Commissioner Details Policing Options and Use of Resources at Council Budget Hearing
text: To address pockets of rising violent crime, some New York City police officers formerly assigned to counterterrorism patrols are being redeployed to affected housing projects around the city, the police commissioner, William J. Bratton, said at a City Council budget hearing on Tuesday.

headline: Uncovered Papers Show Past Government Efforts to Drive Gays From Jobs
text: WASHINGTON — Days after President Lyndon B. Johnson’s election to his first full term, an administration official asked a subordinate to explain the policy on firing gays. In particular, he wondered whether someone with a history of gay liaisons could, through years of marriage, be “rehabilitated” into a trustworthy civil servant.

headline: Albany Expands Effort to Cap Regulated Rents for Older Tenants
text: For years, many older tenants of regulated apartments have been able to freeze their rents through a New York City program that will soon be expanded. But supporters of the program say that it has been underused and that unless the city does more to publicize the benefit, it will fall short of its potential to help older New Yorkers being squeezed by rising rents.

headline: New York Fed President Sees Inflation Drifting Up
text: William Dudley, the president of the New York Federal Reserve, said on Tuesday he expected inflation to drift higher over the remainder of the year, though “excess capacity” in the economy is helping to moderate price pressures. Mr. Dudley’s remarks come as the Fed grapples with several major issues, including when to raise interest rates, and when to start scaling back its more than $4 trillion balance sheet.

headline: Pay Up or Go to Jail
text: User fees are a fact of life in America — those inscrutable “administrative” charges tacked on to everything from checking luggage to buying theater tickets to applying for college. For people with the ability to pay, they are an irritation. But such fees are increasingly being levied on people caught up in the criminal justice system, who are overwhelmingly among the poorest members of society.

headline: For Third Time in 4 Years, Cavs Win Lottery
text: For a group of teams coming off dreadful seasons, the hours before Tuesday’s N.B.A. draft lottery were a time of rare hope. They all had a crack at the grand prize: the opportunity to select a player like Duke’s Jabari Parker or Kansas’ Andrew Wiggins, elite prospects who are expected to be among the top picks when the draft is held at Barclays Center on June 26.

headline: U.S. Imposes New Sanctions on 12 Russians
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Tuesday leveled sanctions against 12 Russians for human rights abuses including the detention and death of a celebrated lawyer who the United States says sought to expose fraud by Russian officials.

headline: Li Qualifies for U.S. Women’s Open, at 11
text: The top female golfers from the United States and around the world will tee it up at Pinehurst in June for the United States Women’s Open. And among the field at that major championship will be Lucy Li, an 11-year-old.

headline: Changes to Surveillance Bill Stoke Anger
text: WASHINGTON — Leaders of both parties in the House of Representatives, at the Obama administration’s request, have changed a surveillance overhaul bill that restricts the power of the government to obtain Americans’ records in bulk.

headline: Ex-Christie Aide Tells of Push to Win Over Fort Lee’s Mayor
text: TRENTON — The administration of Gov. Chris Christie worked to cultivate Fort Lee’s mayor for at least a year and a half before lanes were closed at the George Washington Bridge in an act of political retribution, according to testimony from a former aide to the governor on Tuesday.

headline: Fine Line Seen in U.S. Spying on Companies
text: WASHINGTON — The National Security Agency has never said what it was seeking when it invaded the computers of Petrobras, Brazil’s huge national oil company, but angry Brazilians have guesses: the company’s troves of data on Brazil’s offshore oil reserves, or perhaps its plans for allocating licenses for exploration to foreign companies.

headline: Conflict Fatigue Deepens in East Ukraine, Just Days Before Vote
text: KIEV, Ukraine — Pro-Russian separatists in eastern Ukraine on Tuesday faced an unaccustomed wave of anger from residents who expressed frustration over the violence and instability in the region, particularly recent mortar attacks around the embattled city of Slovyansk that have damaged several homes and terrorized residents.

headline: Madrid’s Mostly Friendly Rivals Face Off for a Big Prize
text: MADRID — The century-old rivalry between Madrid’s two main clubs, Real Madrid and Atlético Madrid, will reach its zenith Saturday when they meet in the Champions League final in Lisbon, the first time that teams from the same city will play for the top prize in European club soccer.

headline: Democrats, Seeing Opportunity, Nominate Businessman for Pennsylvania Governor
text: Tom Wolf, a wealthy businessman and a former Peace Corps volunteer, won the Democratic nomination for governor of Pennsylvania on Tuesday, setting up what his party hopes will be one of its best chances this fall to flip a governor’s mansion now held by a Republican.

headline: After Neutrality Proves Untenable, a Ukraine Oligarch Makes His Move
text: DONETSK, Ukraine — For weeks, a seemingly unstoppable pro-Russian separatist movement steamrollered through eastern Ukraine. The government’s soldiers proved incompetent or switched sides, and the police readily surrendered their weapons.

headline: Inmates’ Newspaper Covers a World Behind San Quentin’s Walls
text: SAN QUENTIN, Calif. — It is not every newspaper editor who can point to a black-and-white surveillance photograph from a 1996 bank robbery and say that he was the robber.

headline: Remember to Forget
text: WASHINGTON — The Right to Be Forgotten.

headline: With Price Out and Lundqvist Hot, All of Quebec Is Singing the Blues
text: MONTREAL — Céline Dion may be Quebec’s most widely known singer internationally, but Ginette Reno, one of Dion’s inspirations, is its best loved back home. And for most of this year’s Stanley Cup playoffs, Reno had been a good-luck charm for the Montreal Canadiens.

headline: Did the Bank Bailout Do Enough for the Country?
text: Did the government miss a historic opportunity to reshape the financial system -- or was its moderate approach correct?

headline: Russia: Train Crash Kills Six Near Moscow
text: A freight train collided with a passenger train near Moscow on Tuesday, killing at least six people and injuring 25. Russian officials said the crash occurred near the town of Naro-Fominsk, southwest of Moscow, when the train carrying about 400 passengers was on its way to Chisinau, Moldova. Russian television said the Moscow-bound freight train was operated by an unidentified Ukrainian company. The poor state of the tracks or the freight train is considered a possible cause of the crash, investigators said.

headline: Long, Long Stories
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Today’s puzzle by Mike Buckley reminds us that if a one-word homophone is punny, then a two-word homophone is even punnier. Don’t you just love a twofer?

headline: Ex-Senators on Both Sides of Aisle Join Forces on Health Care
text: WASHINGTON — As a Republican senator, Trent Lott was among those who successfully dug in against the Clinton-era health overhaul. Tom Daschle, then the Senate Democratic leader, fought Republicans on their prescription drug plan. John B. Breaux, a centrist Democrat who led a blue-ribbon Medicare commission, often found himself at odds with both parties.

headline: Iran: More Than One Million Said to Defy Alcohol Ban
text: Despite an officially enforced Islamic prohibition on alcoholic beverages, more than one million Iranians are drinkers, a medical toxicologist said Tuesday. The toxicologist, Dr. Reza Afshari, president of the Asia Pacific Association of Medical Toxicology, was quoted by the Iranian Students’ News Agency as saying the finding was based on a yearlong study that ended in March 2013. It also showed that 30 percent of the drinkers are women. Dr. Afshari spoke at what the news agency called the first conference on alcohol abuse in Iran, a reflection of the government’s acknowledgment of the problem. Alcohol consumption, possession and production have been illegal since the 1979 Islamic Revolution, but smuggled and homemade liquor is said to be widely available. Government officials have said at least 200,000 Iranians are alcoholics.

headline: Winning the Cup, and Starting to Win Over Critics
text: CHICAGO — On the ice at Boston’s TD Garden, minutes after he had won his first Stanley Cup last year, Blackhawks goaltender Corey Crawford was approached by a local television host for an interview. He had been one of Crawford’s fiercest critics during the season and through the playoffs, repeatedly questioning whether Crawford was a championship-caliber goalie.

headline: G.O.P. Sees Chance as Schneiderman Seeks 2nd Term as Attorney General
text: ALBANY — Eric T. Schneiderman, the state attorney general, has a big problem for an incumbent seeking a second term: Many New Yorkers barely seem to know his name.

headline: Memo Approving Targeted Killing of U.S. Citizen to Be Released
text: WASHINGTON — Facing the potential defeat of an appeals court nominee, the Obama administration decided Tuesday to publicly release much of a classified memo written by the nominee that signed off on the targeted killing an American accused of being a terrorist.

headline: Regulator Wants to Know How Con Ed Is Handling an Increase in Reports of Gas Leaks
text: The chief regulator of utilities in New York demanded on Tuesday that Consolidated Edison explain how it is coping with the sharp rise in complaints about gas odors since an explosion in March leveled two buildings in East Harlem, killing eight people.

headline: House Measure to Change Voice of America’s Mission Is Drawing Intense Debate
text: WASHINGTON — A bill to overhaul Voice of America has prompted an intense debate among supporters of the legislation who say it will better enable the broadcast news service to counter Russian disinformation and opponents who say it will turn the service into an American propaganda tool.

headline: A Close Call for 2 Planes at Newark
text: Two planes at Newark Liberty International Airport had an unusually close call on April 24, the National Transportation Safety Board reported this week. But air traffic control experts said the hazard was reduced because both pilots were aware of the problem and took evasive action.

headline: Nash Gets Hot for the Sizzling Rangers
text: Riding a five-game winning streak and getting close to the Stanley Cup finals, the Rangers are in top form, including one player who was all but invisible until recently: Rick Nash.

headline: 32-Year Streak at the Garden: No Taxes Paid
text: The Rangers hockey team is ripping through the playoffs and is making a hard run for its first championship title in 20 years.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, May 21, 2014
text: “We want to make certain that we view culture through the eyes of faith, that we don’t view our faith through the eyes of culture.”

headline: Plan to Save Decaying Pier 40 Faces City Review
text: A proposal to save a former cargo pier on the Lower West Side of Manhattan by selling air rights to the owner of a huge industrial building must go through the city’s land use review, a top official in Mayor Bill de Blasio’s administration said on Tuesday.

headline: As City’s Elderly Population Swells, Concerns Rise Over Lack of Access to Retirement Plans
text: New York City’s elderly population is exploding: By 2030, the city will have 1.3 million people 65 and over, up from a million today. And few of them are likely to have a retirement plan.

headline: By Rejoining Red Sox, Drew Completes Detour Into Free Agency
text: BOSTON — The Red Sox gave replica World Series championship rings to all fans at Fenway Park on Tuesday. Stephen Drew will be here Wednesday if he wants to pick up the real thing.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 20, 2014
As an Enigmatic Tension Mounts
text: It’s been two years since Liz Santoro presented “We Do Our Best” at St. Mark’s Church, and still, sounds and images from that spartan trio linger in the mind: the repetitive, echoey click of high heels on a wooden floor; an interminable drone that enveloped everyone in the room, locking us into one tense, protracted moment. There was a peculiar placelessness to this world, only intensified by the exacting placement of everything within it.

headline: Massachusetts: 3-Year Sentence for Theft From Marathon Fund
text: A Troy, N.Y., woman was sentenced on Tuesday to serve up to three years in prison after admitting to stealing from the One Fund Boston, which raised more than $60 million to aid victims of the bombing at the Boston Marathon last year. State prosecutors said Audrea Gause, 27, had falsely claimed that she sustained a brain injury in the blasts and collected $480,000 from the fund. On Tuesday, Ms. Gause pleaded guilty to one count of larceny over $250 in Suffolk Superior Court; Judge Carol Ball signed an order to return the money, which has been recovered, to the fund.

headline: California Chrome Shows Star Quality in New York Arrival
text: At 10:40 a.m., outside Gate 6 at Belmont Park, a helicopter circled overhead. Past the security gate, a guard directed the unusually heavy traffic in front of the track kitchen. She smiled wide at passers-by and yelled, “Five minutes until he gets here.” Asked if she was excited, the guard replied, “I’m dancing in my shoes.”

headline: Inmate Who Fought With Another at Rikers Island Dies After Leaving Hospital
text: An inmate at Rikers Island who was taken to the hospital Tuesday morning after a fight with another inmate died hours later as he was being returned to the jail, New York City officials said.

headline: Giants Look to Bolster Offense With Tight End Snubbed in the Draft
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Through three days and seven rounds, Xavier Grimble, a tight end at Southern California, waited with family and friends to hear which N.F.L. team would draft him. He had been advised that he might be selected as early as the third round or as late as the sixth. No one ever mentioned that 256 players would be chosen and he would not be among them.

headline: ‘Fargo’ Recap: Mayhem Fells Molly
text: Updated, 12:32 p.m. | Please tell me Molly doesn’t die and I’ll promise never to eat crispy whole fish again.

headline: Even Absent, a Big Man Looms Over a Series
text: SAN ANTONIO — Only hours before Game 1 of the Western Conference finals, the San Antonio Spurs’ Kawhi Leonard and Tony Parker remained unconvinced that Serge Ibaka, the Oklahoma City Thunder’s starting center, would miss the game with a calf injury.

headline: A Festival for Harlem
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio and former President Bill Clinton introduced a three-day festival starting next May that will commemorate the area’s food and culture.

headline: Tony Palladino, Designer of ‘Psycho’ Lettering, Dies at 84
text: Tony Palladino, an innovative graphic designer and illustrator who created one of the most recognizable typographic titles in publishing and film history, the off-kilter, violently slashed block-letter rendering of “Psycho,” died on May 14 in Manhattan. He was 84.

headline: Tadeusz Rozewicz, Fierce Poetic Voice of Postwar Poland, Is Dead at 92
text: Tadeusz Rozewicz, a defiantly modernist, globally acclaimed Polish poet whose answer to the Holocaust and other 20th-century horrors was a renunciation of literary ornament and a call for poetry of “not verses but facts,” died on April 24 at his home near Wroclaw, Poland. He was 92.

headline: The Great White Hope
text: Three unlikely sources are providing qualified encouragement to Republicans who are either openly or covertly committed to a campaign strategy that focuses on white turnout, as opposed to seeking votes from Hispanics and African-Americans.

headline: In His Second Act, Montero Flops, and So Do the Mets
text: Mets starter Rafael Montero took a step back on Tuesday after a strong debut performance last week, failing to pitch past the fifth inning against the Los Angeles Dodgers on a pristine night at Citi Field.

headline: California Urges Websites to Disclose Online Tracking
text: Every major Internet browser has a feature that lets you tell a website that you don’t want it to collect personal information about you when you visit.

headline: Brain Changes in College Football Players Raise New Concerns
text: The brains of college football players are subtly different from the brains of other students, especially if the players have experienced a concussion in the past, according to an important new brain-scan study that, while restrained in its conclusions, adds to concerns that sports-related hits to the head could have lingering effects on the brain, even among the young and healthy.

text: negligence •\ˈne-gli-jən(t)s\• noun

headline: Times Minute | Scandal at the V.A.
text: On the Minute, President Obama under pressure over mismanagement at veterans hospitals; wheel spinning can be rewarding for lab mice; and the youngest golfer to qualify for United States Women’s Open.
