headline: Late Burst by James Helps Heat Even Series
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Just when it looked as if the Indiana Pacers might have buried the memory of their mysterious bouts of performance dysfunction, they were reminded of an equally unpleasant reality of their Eastern Conference semifinal against Miami.

headline: Second Time Around, Cubs Hand Tanaka His First Loss in Majors
text: CHICAGO — After 21 months and 42 starts in which he never lost in the regular season, Masahiro Tanaka finally felt the sting of defeat. Perhaps it was the rain that poured down upon him, or the fact that for the first time this year his opponent had seen him once before. Or maybe it was just because his teammates could not supply enough offense to bail him out of a substandard effort.

headline: Beltran Will Swing a Bat, and the Yankees Hope He Feels No Pain
text: CHICAGO — Monday will be a critical day for right fielder Carlos Beltran and the Yankees. That is when Beltran, who was found to have a bone spur in his right elbow a week ago and placed on the 15-day disabled list, will try to swing a bat.

headline: N.B.A. Is Said to Allege Duplicity By Sterling
text: As Commissioner Adam Silver vowed to push forward with terminating Donald Sterling’s ownership of the Los Angeles Clippers, the N.B.A.’s case against Sterling came into sharper focus Tuesday.

headline: What’s on Wednesday
text: 10 P.M. (MSG) RAGING BULL (1980) Robert De Niro, above, packed on nearly 60 pounds for his Oscar-winning portrayal of Jake LaMotta, the New York City boxer who pummeled his way to the world middleweight championship in 1948 before self-destructing, in this drama directed by Martin Scorsese. Joe Pesci plays Jake’s brother and manager, Joey, who tries to help him battle his demons; Cathy Moriarty is Vickie, Jake’s second wife, who fuels his sexual rage. “Though it’s a movie full of anger and nonstop physical violence, the effect of ‘Raging Bull’ is lyrical,” Vincent Canby wrote in The New York Times. “To witness Jake’s fury is to swing through the upper atmosphere of the emotions. It’s breathtaking and a little scary.”

headline: Corrections: May 21, 2014
text: NATIONAL

headline: Chinese Company Puts Death Toll in Vietnam Riots at 4
text: The recent outburst of violence by anti-Chinese demonstrators in Vietnam took the lives of at least four workers at a Chinese company, the company said, a count that would double the overall toll previously given by Chinese government officials.

headline: Former Chief of JPMorgan’s China Unit Is Arrested
text: Updated, 7:52 p.m. | The former head of investment banking in China at JPMorgan Chase has been arrested by Hong Kong’s anticorruption agency, a Chinese news report and a person briefed on the matter said on Wednesday, possibly opening a significant front in what has become a  global investigation into JPMorgan’s hiring practices in China.

headline: Volunteers Spend 105 Days in Capsule in Dry Run for Space
text: Three Chinese researchers have emerged after 105 days in a sealed capsule, where they raised plants and ate bugs to help study the requirements for a space station or lunar base. The first test of China’s “Moon Palace 1” was seen as another step in the country’s rapid progression of achievements in space flight.

headline: Extraordinary Elite Delusions and the Madness of Commissions
text: Sorry about slow posting — I’ve been busy drinking too much port at high table both giving talks at Oxford and grading final papers from Princeton. But I did want to weigh in on this Matt O’Brien piece on the problems or lack thereof with democracy.

headline: A Note About Our Test Yourself Feature
text: The tool we use to create our quizzes is currently undergoing an upgrade, so we are suspending our Test Yourself feature until that work is done.

headline: Pakistani Military Says It Killed 60 Militants in Raids
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The Pakistani military said it killed at least 60 militants, and injured at least 30, in aerial raids on terrorist hide-outs across the North Waziristan tribal region near the Afghan border early Wednesday. Local residents, however, said the dead included women and children.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Why That Video Went Viral
text: In “Why That Video Went Viral,” Natalie Kitroeff writes about what researchers are discovering about why certain links are “click bait.”

headline: A Life Collecting Chinese Landscapes
text: Lois Conner calls herself a collector of landscapes. The fascination started in childhood, when she was mesmerized by the panoramas she glimpsed on family road trips. But it turned into an artistic mission over the last three decades as she traveled through China with her view camera in search of images layered with detail and history.

headline: How Have You Handled Being the ‘New Kid’?
text: In a recent Motherlode post, a writer worries about her 6-year-old son making friends when they move to a new country.

headline: Investors Await Cues on Modi’s Economic Policy
text: MUMBAI, India — As the Bharatiya Janata Party and Narendra Modi, the prime minister-elect, begin to discuss the allocation of key cabinet positions, investors’ eyes are on one key appointment – that of the country’s finance minister, who will be responsible for steering India’s foundering economy to calm waters.

headline: Thai Military Gathers Rivals for Talks on Standoff
text: BANGKOK — A day after imposing martial law, the Thai military on Wednesday put leaders of the country’s polarized political camps in the same room in an effort to end six months of political deadlock.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

headline: New York Today: Cuomo’s Show
text: Good Wednesday morning to you.

headline: Gosling’s First Film as Director Debuts at Cannes
text: CANNES, France — “Ryan! Ryan!” fans in the audience called out Tuesday night at the premiere of the actor Ryan Gosling’s directorial debut, “Lost River,” a dark fantasy about a family struggling against loan sharks in a creepy, post-apocalyptic Detroit-like exurb. The ever-dashing Mr. Gosling, dressed in a slim-cut tuxedo, took the stage and said what an honor it was to have his film at this year’s Cannes Film Festival, where it is showing in the Un Certain Regard category.

headline: China and Russia Reach 30-Year Gas Deal
text: BEIJING — China and Russia signed a $400 billion gas deal on Wednesday, giving Moscow a megamarket for its leading export and linking two major powers that, despite a rocky history of alliances and rivalries, have drawn closer to counter the clout of the United States and Europe.

headline: Commerzbank Suspends 2 Currency Traders
text: The German lender Commerzbank has suspended two currency traders in what it said was an “isolated incident,” becoming the latest bank to place employees on leave as regulators continue to examine potential manipulation of the $5-trillion-a-day currency markets.

headline: Daily Report: Microsoft Expands Its Tablet’s Screen, With Work in Mind
text: Many people have both laptop computers and tablets and use them for different tasks. Microsoft on Tuesday redoubled its vision that the two devices should be one and the same, introducing a new version of its Surface tablet with a larger screen, Nick Wingfield reports.

headline: Under Pressure, ‘Naked Official’ Chooses Early Retirement
text: The directive on “naked officials” came down in February in an internal document from the Communist Party’s Central Organization Department: “Bring back your family, or retire early.”

headline: If You Can’t Raise $100,000, Ask for $1 Million
text: In my first post this year, “The Start-Up Vortex of Doom,” I wrote about how I scrounged for cash in 2013, trying to build a company and keep the team motivated. We often came perilously close to running out of money. At one point, I lent the company, Posse, money from my personal savings to make payroll. Other times, I raised $50,000 or $100,000 — enough to stay alive for a couple of months but not enough to plan for the future. Those were not easy times.

headline: Narrow Path to Senate for Michelle Nunn in Georgia
text: The Georgia Republican primary is over, and so are Democratic wishes for their dream outcome.

headline: More Hispanics Declaring Themselves White
text: Hispanics are often described as driving up the nonwhite share of the population. But a new study of census forms finds that more Hispanics are identifying as white.

headline: Mubarak Gets 3 Years for Embezzlement, and His Sons Get 4
text: CAIRO — A criminal court here convicted former President Hosni Mubarak on Wednesday of embezzling millions of dollars of public money for his personal use in private homes and palaces, in a case that rights advocates say could now implicate the current prime minister and spy chief.

headline: Inversion Diversion
text: INVERSION DIVERSION  |  A group of 14 senators introduced a bill on Tuesday that would essentially disallow any more so-called inversions for two years, slowing down the rush by United States corporations to reincorporate overseas to lower their tax bills, DealBook’s David Gelles writes. The bill would give Congress time to pursue broad changes in the corporate tax code that could make the United States rates more competitive with other countries, reducing the incentive for companies to move overseas.

headline: Larry Kramer: The Fighting Heart
text: It took more than 30 years for Larry Kramer’s play “The Normal Heart,” about gay New Yorkers struggling with AIDS, to be turned into a movie. But for the playwright, there is still work to be done.

headline: A Lion Still Roars, With Gratitude
text: Most revolutionaries don’t live to see as much dizzying change as Larry Kramer has.

headline: Netflix Faces Hurdles, Country by Country, in Bid to Expand in Europe
text: LONDON — Netflix, whose digital distribution of movies and TV shows has made it a media force in the United States, now has wide eyes for Europe.

headline: McIlroy’s Engagement Ends as Key Tournament Looms
text: VIRGINIA WATER, England — Appearing at times on the verge of tears, Rory McIlroy kept his date with the news media Wednesday in advance of this week’s BMW PGA Championship, the European Tour’s flagship event, holding a news conference the same morning that he announced the end of his five-month engagement to the tennis star Caroline Wozniacki.

headline: Thane of Cawdor Plays the Armory
text: It’s hard to believe that Kenneth Branagh is only now making his acting debut on a New York stage. Then again, much about Mr. Branagh’s career is difficult to process. He wrote a memoir at the age of 28 (called, to be fair, “Beginning”), and he directed a very silly comedy on Broadway (“The Play What I Wrote”) inspired by the double act Morecambe and Wise. Perhaps the strangest shift is that Mr. Branagh, the wunderkind once considered Laurence Olivier’s heir, is now directing Hollywood action movies (“Thor”). His is a complex, playful career that dabbles in many forms but always returns to what made him famous: Shakespeare. So it’s no surprise that his first starring role here is as Macbeth, in a critically acclaimed production from England, which he directed with Rob Ashford. Ben Brantley of The New York Times called it “utterly assured and intelligent.” “Macbeth” begins performances May 31 in the Park Avenue Armory’s enormous Drill Hall. (Through June 22. 643 Park Avenue, at 67th Street; 212-616-3930, armoryonpark.org.)

headline: Obama Vows a Forceful Response to Veteran Care Issues
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Wednesday expressed outrage about allegations of misconduct at veterans hospitals and said that people in the Department of Veterans Affairs — including Eric Shinseki, its secretary — could be punished if investigations revealed wrongdoing.

headline: Thank You, Musical Neighbor
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Still Hurt by Data Breach and Losses in Canada, Target Lowers Forecast
text: The performance of several retailers on Wednesday put stagnant wage growth and the uneven economic recovery on display. But all eyes were on one company in particular that has struggled under its own additional set of problems in the last six months, and continues to feel the strain: Target.

headline: In Store | An Inspired Space to Shop for Men’s Wear
text: Popular with stylish musicians like Dev Hynes and Adam Bainbridge of Kindness, the Paris-by-way-of-Brooklyn men’s wear brand Études is a line full of bright and patterned separates and colorful, wide-brimmed hats that, when worn together, are the stuff that bold statement dressing is made of. But the co-founders Aurélien Arbet and Jérémie Egry have always seen Études as more than just a clothing company; and with a new summer pop-up shop on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, which opens today, they’re creating a space that embodies the lifestyle their clothes tend to accompany. “The idea with the pop-up space is to create an installation as if you were entering a gallery, with clothes, books, objects, furniture, music,” Arbet says. “We’re a multidisciplinary studio and consider ourselves creative directors, curators. Every detail is equally important.”

headline: Groups Pool Funds to Protect More of Amazon Rain Forest
text: Brazil and a host of governmental and private partners agreed to create a $215 million fund to expand protected areas of the Amazon rain forest by more than 34,000 square miles and to help pay for its management for the next 25 years, the partners announced Wednesday.

headline: Who Best to Plan a Surprise Party for a Teenager? Not Mom
text: I stood way, way in the background, my view of my daughter Hannah’s shock and thrill obscured by a throng of teenagers swarming her and yelling, “Surprise!”

headline: Meet Modi’s Potential Foreign Policy Team
text: NEW DELHI — As India attempts to understand the astounding contours of the electoral victory by the Bharatiya Janata Party last week, Prime Minister-designate Narendra Modi is said to be putting his cabinet together.

headline: Democrats Seek Issues to Lure Midterm Votes After Races Buoy G.O.P.
text: WASHINGTON — With Tuesday’s primaries reinforcing the strength of the Republican establishment, House Democrats are reassessing their electoral strategy based on a major internal research project that shows their candidates stand a better chance when they portray Republicans as uncaring toward working-class Americans while they continue to back policies favoring the wealthy and corporate America.

headline: And What if the Sept. 11 Museum Had to Be Evacuated?
text: What if a bomb went off or a fire broke out in the National September 11 Memorial Museum, 70 feet below ground?

headline: In Our Pages: May 22
text: 1889: Murderer Gets Guillotined

headline: Lundergan Grimes on Winning Primary
text: Kentucky’s secretary of state, Alison Lundergan Grimes, spoke after she won the Democratic nomination to face Senator Mitch McConnell, the Republican, for a United States Senate seat.

headline: Writing for Foreigners (Americans)
text: Quick question: Who is your favorite contemporary Japanese playwright?

headline: Big Meatpacker JBS Plans I.P.O. for Brazil Operations
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil – JBS, the world’s biggest meat processor and owner of international brands like Pilgrim’s Pride and Swift, has filed for an initial public offering of its Brazilian pork, poultry and food-processing operations.

headline: Cheese-eating Job Creators
text: People are pretty down on European economic performance these days, with good reason. But mainly what we’re looking at is bad macroeconomic policy, the result of premature monetary union plus austerity mania. That’s a very different story from the old version of Eurotrashing, which focused on Eurosclerosis — persistent low employment allegedly caused by excessive welfare states.

headline: Hedge Fund Sues McKesson Unit Over Celesio Deal
text: The hedge fund Magnetar Capital sued a subsidiary of the  McKesson Corporation on Wednesday in connection with its acquisition of the German drug wholesaler Celesio, contending that McKesson violated German takeover law by paying more to some holders of Celesio’s convertible bonds than it did to shareholders.

headline: When T.R. Saw Lincoln
text: Look at the open second-floor window between shutters in this photograph, and you will see two little boys. President Theodore Roosevelt’s widow, Edith, identified one of them as her husband at the age of 6, looking down from his grandfather’s Union Square mansion onto the coffin of the assassinated Abraham Lincoln on Broadway in New York in April 1865.

headline: Decades of ‘The Normal Heart’
text: It’s been almost 30 years since Larry Kramer’s play “The Normal Heart,” an angry and autobiographical drama about gay men and the AIDS crisis, opened at the Public Theater. On Sunday, HBO will broadcast its new film version, starring Mark Ruffalo as the outspoken activist Ned Weeks, a character based on Mr. Kramer, and Matt Bomer as Felix, his lover who is dying of AIDS. Read more about it here.

headline: United Nations Forecasts Persistently High Unemployment for the Young
text: The clouds of the global financial crisis may have lifted, but six years later, the world economy is not creating nearly as many jobs as it was before 2008, a United Nations report on Wednesday concluded, nor is it expected to in the near term. That is a particularly worrisome fact at a time when more young people are entering the job market than ever before.

headline: The Koch Brothers Kick Detroit While It’s Down
text: Over the last five months, a deal has come together that would solve some of the most contentious issues in Detroit’s bankruptcy. It would minimize the pension cuts for 30,000 retirees and city workers, save the city’s art collection and give a reasonable amount of money to the city’s bondholders.

headline: McConnell on Winning Republican Primary
text: Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky spoke after he fended off a Tea Party challenger to set up an expensive November contest against the Democratic nominee, Alison Lundergan Grimes.

headline: 22 Afghan Police Officers Are Killed in Attacks by Taliban
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — It was a particularly bloody Wednesday for Afghan police officers, as reports emerged that at least 22 had been killed in four assaults around the country by Taliban insurgents, who also pinned down 40 police officers and officials in a bunker, short on food and ammunition.

headline: Questions About Student Writing
text: 1. How can we incentivize students to stop using “impact” as a verb?

headline: Dodgers’ Puig Is Entertaining Fans and Detractors Alike
text: He hears boos at the opposing team’s stadium from the moment he walks out of the on-deck circle. The fans anticipate his at-bat, and they jeer him with such rancor that it is hard to believe he has not yet been in the major leagues for an entire year.

headline: 2 Brooklyn Pupils Accused of Putting Rat Poison in Teacher’s Water
text: Two Brooklyn elementary school students have been arrested on suspicion of putting rat poison in a teacher’s water bottle, the police said on Wednesday.

headline: Q. and A. | André Leon Talley on Curating Stephen Burrows, Growing Up Southern and a Woman Named Vreeland
text: Yesterday, the SCAD Museum of Art opened “An American Master of Inventive Design,” an exhibition devoted to the career of the designer Stephen Burrows, who achieved legendary status for his dazzling combinations of color and for bringing African-American models, like the ’70s superstar Pat Cleveland, to the runway. The man behind the show, André Leon Talley, is no less a legend in fashion circles. It’s the third exhibition for SCAD overseen by the former Vogue editor. We caught up with Talley, who offered insights into what it means to curate, his Southern upbringing and learning from Diana Vreeland.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an e-mail. Sign up »

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 22
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: From War Zone to Workplace, Can Veterans Fill a Void?
text: I work in human resources. And when it comes to hiring, it’s never easy. Finding qualified people to join company ranks can be a crapshoot. Think hirer’s remorse.

headline: Geithner Book Reveals Consensus, Not Vision, During Financial Crisis
text: What are we talking about when we talk about Timothy F. Geithner’s new book? President Obama.

headline: An Antidote to Overdose, in Time to Save Lives
text: Quincy, Mass., is a pleasant, working-class city of 92,000 people on Boston’s South Shore. It is saturated with history and, for the past decade or so, saturated with opioids.

headline: Grocery Deliveries in Sharing Economy
text: “I hope you realize that you are about to witness a remarkable display in ineptitude,” the technology investor Michael J. Moritz said as he entered a Whole Foods store in San Francisco one recent afternoon.

headline: Today in Small Business: Why Most Successful Start-Ups Are Self-Funded
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Pfizer-AstraZeneca Talks Need a Rest and Then a Fresh Start
text: AstraZeneca should not re-engage with Pfizer in the dying days of the takeover timetable. Talks now would either be fruitless or delay a proper restart later.

headline: McCartney Cancels Seoul Performance
text: The illness that led Paul McCartney to cancel his Japanese tour appears to be more serious than it at first seemed. When he canceled a Tokyo show last Saturday night because of what he described in a statement as a virus, Mr. McCartney optimistically rescheduled the show for Monday. On Sunday, he said that he wanted to perform that evening, but his doctors insisted he stay in bed, and by Monday evening, the rest of his Japanese dates, through Saturday, were canceled as well.

headline: Before Taking Office in India, Modi Sends an Invitation to Pakistan
text: NEW DELHI — India’s incoming prime minister, Narendra Modi, on Wednesday invited his Pakistani counterpart, Nawaz Sharif, to attend his swearing-in ceremony next week, an unusual gesture that has inspired hopes that the change in government will lead to improved relations between the two countries.

headline: One Child’s Quest for Education, in a Burmese Refugee Camp
text: A graveyard is a bizarre playground for a 12-year old boy.

headline: Shinseki in Line of Fire, From the Chief
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama stopped short of dressing down his veterans affairs secretary, Eric Shinseki, during a blunt hourlong talk in the Oval Office on Wednesday. But the commander in chief made clear that a growing health care scandal at the Department of Veterans Affairs had put the future of Mr. Shinseki — a retired four-star general and no stranger to Washington political uproars — once again on the line.

headline: A New Restaurant for Campobello
text: The Roosevelt Campobello International Park is celebrating its 50th anniversary with a new restaurant, the debut of an online reservation system for its popular “Tea with Eleanor” history series, and, later in the summer, a preview of Ken Burns’s coming documentary “The Roosevelts,” which examines the life of Franklin D., Eleanor and Theodore Roosevelt.

headline: 21 Sun Ra Albums Are Released on iTunes
text: Sun Ra, the idiosyncratic jazz pianist and composer, used to say that he did not believe in birth or death, and he was able to keep his date of birth – May 22, 1914 – a secret until shortly before his death in 1993. So presumably, he would look askance at celebrations of his centenary. For admirers of his often theatrical, sometimes experimental music who want to mark the occasion, however, the Sun Ra Music Archive on Tuesday released 21 of the musician’s albums on iTunes, many of them in digital form for the first time (and others remastered).

headline: Reactions to Mubarak Sentencing
text: Not all residents agree with the Egyptian court ruling that sentenced former President Hosni Mubarak to three years on charges of stealing public funds.

headline: Yellen Tells N.Y.U. Graduates to Expect Failure and Learn From It
text: Janet L. Yellen has long occupied a front-row seat as Washington grappled with the financial crisis and the weak economy that has plagued the nation. Standing over second base at Yankee Stadium, where she delivered a commencement speech on Wednesday, Ms. Yellen suggested that playing the game is a lot harder than it looks from the stands.

headline: Image of the Day: May 21
text: Sonia Gandhi, president of the Congress party, and Rahul Gandhi, vice-president of the party, paying tribute at the memorial of Rajiv Gandhi, former prime minister of India, on his death anniversary.

headline: Who Is a Feminist Now?
text: In a recent interview with Time magazine, the actress Shailene Woodley was asked if she considered herself a feminist.

headline: Painless Shipping In a Few Easy Steps
text: PACKAGING and shipping an item isn’t the worst task in the world, but it isn’t exactly fun, either. Say you’re sending a gift to your grandmother. First, you have to find a box. Then you need tape, one of those household items that is almost never where you thought you’d put it. You might also need to weigh and measure the box, and research which shipper fits your budget and delivery preferences. Then you either have to go to the web to order a shipping label or hurry over to the post office to wait in line.

headline: Q. and A.: Conor Oberst and Lorde Find Common Ground
text: Growing up in the suburbs of Omaha turns out not to have been much different than growing up in the suburbs of Auckland, at least to hear Conor Oberst, a Nebraskan, and Lorde, a New Zealander, tell it: both had to make their own fun. The two musicians and mutual fans bonded over their similarly forthright lyrical styles, in a conversation on Monday. They also shared a love for the debut albums of the British acts the Arctic Monkeys and the Streets, a certain distaste for social media (although Lorde, born Ella Yelich-O’Connor, has more than 1.6 million Twitter followers), and discussed the high and low points of touring. Here are more excerpts from their conversation.

headline: Statement Socks in Brooklyn
text: Getting off at the Morgan Avenue stop on the L train in Brooklyn is like stepping into a vintage version of New York City. The area is home to fledgling artists, industrial-looking buildings dripping in street art and the sounds of musicians practicing from nearby studios. Madison Krekel blends in easily wearing a bolo tie she bought at a flea market, socks with sushi printed on them and a Cramps T-shirt. Originally from Oakland, Calif., she moved to the area four years ago and recently dyed her hair green as a way to welcome spring. This interview has been edited.

headline: Frieze Art Fair Brings Auto-Themed Displays to New York
text: “Every spring, the Frieze Art Fair comes to New York, where international art buyers are drawn to a variety of shows and auctions. For luxury automobile manufacturers, it represents an opportunity to reach a select audience through the displays they have set up at the event.

headline: Is There a Coup Underway?
text: WHO WEARS SHORT SHORTS? To quote the old Nair commercial. Specifically, who on God’s earth wears white denim cutoff short shorts for an afternoon stroll through a midtown business district?

headline: Times Minute | Obama on V.A. Scandal
text: Also on the Minute, China and Russia strike a historic gas deal and a new study on the effect of brain concussions in college football.

headline: Times Minute | Obama on V.A. Scandal
text: In the Video

headline: A Green Thumb on the Touch Screen
text: I’M no expert gardener, but I do like to care for the lovely flowers and fruit trees in my garden. And when I gather my tools, I also include my smartphone. This is a trick that has worked wonders, thanks to some helpful apps.

headline: App Smart | Improve Your Garden
text: Kit Eaton reviews three apps that could help make your smartphone as indispensable as gloves and a shovel as you work on your garden.

headline: Spotify Hits 10 Million Subscribers, a Milestone
text: Spotify, the streaming music service, said on Wednesday that it had grown to 10 million paying subscribers around the world, a long-awaited disclosure as the company faces potential competition from Apple and also prepares for a probable initial public offering.

headline: A Survival Course for the Leaders of Companies in Pain
text: TIPP CITY, Ohio — On a Wednesday morning here in March, the owner of a California business explained that his company had enjoyed years of success selling products directly to consumers through TV — until the formula stopped working. “People aren’t watching TV the way they used to,” he said. “We’re Blockbuster.”

headline: Wheelies: The Pony Pricing Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: EBay Urges New Passwords After Breach
text: SAN FRANCISCO — In the latest prominent breach of a company’s computer network, hackers have infiltrated the online marketplace eBay, gaining access to the personal data of 145 million customers, the company said on Wednesday.

headline: A Chef in the Field | Nettles
text: This series by the chef Jeff Schwarz and the photographer Greg Kessler traces the trajectory of seasonal food — from its original source to a place on your table.

headline: Candidates Ace Geography in Their Ads
text: If there is one fact that political candidates wouldn’t seem to need to mention, it’s the state in which they are running. And if there is one fact most relevant to voters during these partisan times, it is a candidate’s political party.

headline: Delightful Difference
text: “When is a moose not a moose?" could be the first line of an elementary-school joke. In Richard T. Morris’s “This Is a Moose,” illustrated by Tom Lichtenheld, a moose is not a moose when he wants to be an astronaut. And in “Froodle,” written and illustrated by Antoinette Portis, a little brown bird causes revolution — or is it evolution? — among her avian friends when she decides to say something other than “Peep!” Both books explore the amusing idea of animals having the kind of free will humans enjoy. By playing up the contrast between people and wildlife, Morris and Portis subtly encourage children to make their own choices, even when told they can’t.

headline: Where Do You Turn for Advice Running a Business?
text: We’ve just published an article about Aileron, a nonprofit organization based near Dayton, Ohio, whose goal is to help business owners shorten their learning curves.

headline: Obama Vows Response to V.A. Issues
text: President Obama said he would take swift action, including punishing people in the Department of Veterans Affairs, if allegations of misconduct at veterans’ hospitals were found to be true.

headline: AstraZeneca’s Shareholders Remain Sharply Divided Over Talks With Pfizer
text: LONDON – AstraZeneca’s decision not to pursue merger talks with Pfizer  has caused a split among the British-Swedish drug maker’s shareholders,  with several large shareholders publicly and privately voicing opposing views on Wednesday on the potential tie-up.

headline: Turning Fashion Into Child’s Play
text: At 7 p.m. on Monday, Alicia Keys took her front-row seat at a Ralph Lauren fashion show, held at the main branch of the New York Public Library. “He’s walking today, my son,” Ms. Keys said. “I’m very excited for him. He has a great personality.”

headline: Loudon Wainwright to Join Father in ‘Posthumous Collaboration’ for Stage Show
text: Loudon Wainwright III has always been a first-class storyteller, but in the 44 years since his eponymous debut album, his métier has mostly been the four-minute, folk-tinged pop song. Now he is broadening his canvas. In “Surviving Twin,” an 80-minute one-man show that opens at the Westside Theater in Manhattan on June 9, Mr. Wainwright will sing favorites from his catalog, as well as several new songs that he plans to include on his next album, “Haven’t Got the Blues (Yet),” due in September.

headline: 9/11 Museum Opens to a Somber Crowd
text: Alone or in groups they emerged from the dark exhibition halls and the even darker subject matter of the National September 11 Memorial Museum, reaching for words like “overwhelming,” “shock” and “gut-wrenching.”

headline: Study Sees Bigger Role for Placenta in Newborns’ Health
text: The placenta, once thought sterile, actually harbors a world of bacteria that may influence the course of pregnancy and help shape an infant’s health and the bacterial makeup of its gut, a new study has found.

headline: 36 Hours in Montevideo, Uruguay
text: Uruguay has made a splash in the news in recent months: Lawmakers allowed same-sex couples to marry less than a year ago, marijuana became legal in December and the country’s folksy president, José Mujica, has appeared in many magazine profiles. While some developments can be seen as a continuation of the country’s track record of economic and social liberalism, they also point to a new, bolder attitude, which can be easily glimpsed in Montevideo, the capital. New hotels, cultural spaces, restaurants and a residential building boom have quickened the city’s tranquil pace. Still, the appeal of Montevideo lies not in novelty but in its timeless backdrop of fin-de-siècle architecture, shady plazas and riverside promenades bordered by sandy beaches — places where laid-back residents indulge in life’s simple pleasures.

headline: The Collaboration as Wrestling Match: Is It a Draw, or Must Someone Prevail?
text: The French dancers Cédric Andrieux and Christophe Ives met each other in the 1990s, when they were both studying at the national conservatory in Paris. I don’t know how chummy they were back then, but a few years ago, they decided to make a duet embodying their relationship and their process of collaboration. That duet, “Les Communs,” does not look like a reunion of old drinking buddies or an expression of fraternité. It looks rivalrous, like a wrestling match.

headline: In Credit Suisse Settlement, a Question of Justice
text: Updated, 3:44 p.m. | Hours after the Obama administration announced the criminal conviction of Credit Suisse on Monday evening, the bank’s chief executive, Brady W. Dougan, publicly reassured Wall Street that the punishment would not do much damage to his firm. The conviction, he said on a conference call, would not cause “any material impact on our operational or business capabilities.”

headline: Stephen Hertz, Corporate Lawyer, Dies at 55
text: Stephen R. Hertz, a top lawyer in mergers and acquisitions as well as private equity buyouts, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 55.

headline: Fed Panel Has Begun to Address How to Gradually Raise Rates
text: Federal Reserve officials have gingerly begun to take on what will be their most difficult task over the next 12 to 24 months: determining how and when to gradually raise interest rates and return monetary policy to a more traditional path, even as they keep trillions in assets accumulated during the huge stimulus efforts of the last five years.

headline: Pelosi Picks 5 Democrats for Panel on Benghazi
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Nancy Pelosi of California on Wednesday appointed a full slate of senior House Democrats to a special committee investigating the 2012 attack on the diplomatic mission in Benghazi, Libya, surprising some in her party by giving legitimacy to an inquiry many had dismissed as a political stunt.

headline: House Hunting in ... Buenos Aires
text: A FIVE-BEDROOM APARTMENT IN THE RECOLETA NEIGHBORHOOD OF BUENOS AIRES

headline: 71 Are Accused in a Child Pornography Case, Officials Say
text: It began in Westchester County with the arrest of a police chief who was teaching classes about sexual abuse at a Roman Catholic church. The investigation soon swept up many others who were swapping files of children forced into explicit sexual acts: two registered nurses, a Brooklyn rabbi, a New York City police officer, a paramedic and a Boy Scout leader.

headline: Against Walter Kasper (I)
text: I’ve referred a couple of times to Cardinal Walter Kasper’s very interesting interview with Commonweal Magazine, in which the prelate/theologian discussed the proposals on communion for remarried Catholics that (apparently with a papal blessing) he’s been promoting in advance of the looming Synod of Bishops, which is dedicated to family life and scheduled for this fall. This is going to be the first of two posts on his argument; the second — which won’t be forthcoming till next week at the earliest, I expect — will deal with the communion-for-the-remarried proposal itself, but first I want to address the frame he puts around his ideas, and particular his claim that a truly remarkable number of contemporary marriages may actually be, in the eyes of the Catholic Church, invalid.

headline: What You Get for ... $1,700,000
text: GLENDALE, MO.

headline: How Much Does That Plane Ticket Really Cost?
text: A group of bipartisan lawmakers in the House of Representatives has been pushing a bill that would make it easier for airlines to deceive travelers about the true cost of flying. As we noted in an editorial last month, the cynically named Transparent Airfares Act of 2014 would allow airlines to advertise base fares that do not include taxes and fees. But not everybody in Washington is on board with that idea.

headline: Drowning Risk Varies by Age and Race
text: Almost 21,000 people under 30 died from drowning from 1999 to 2010 in the United States, and there were substantial variations in death rates depending on age, race and ethnicity.

headline: ‘Titanic’ Musical’s Return to New York Is Delayed
text: A previously announced Broadway revival of “Titanic,” the winner of the 1997 Tony Award for best musical, will not berth during the 2014-15 theater season as planned because a suitable theater was not available, the producers announced on Wednesday.

headline: Cuomo Picks Ex-Congresswoman as Running Mate
text: MELVILLE, N.Y. — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Wednesday named a former congresswoman from Buffalo to be his running mate, a move that completes the Democratic ticket and underscores his courtship of western New York.

headline: In Cybersecurity, Sometimes the Weakest Link Is a Family Member
text: Since I started writing about cybersecurity, I’ve developed something of a  reputation for paranoia.

headline: The Gun Report: May 21, 2014
text: This morning, Rep. Carolyn Maloney of New York and Sen. Ed Markey of Massachusetts unveiled bicameral legislation that would grant the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention $10 million a year to research firearm safety and gun violence prevention.

headline: Art Market | Possibly the Coolest Art and Design Auction Ever
text: “Who needs more things? I think that we all want more experiences,” says David van der Leer, the director of the Van Alen Institute, the public architecture think tank, which hosts its gala benefit tonight. The accompanying online auction, which accepts bids through the end of the week on Paddle 8, features offerings that will occupy space in your memory (and Instagram feed), rather than your home: winning bidders will have the chance to take journeys with 30 noteworthy figures in the architecture and design world.

headline: Browsing in Boutiques Near Venice’s Grand Canal
text: When it comes to shopping, travelers to Venice tend to stick to the big-brand Italian chain stores near touristy San Marco Square, but the city’s homegrown boutique scene warrants far more attention than it gets. The Cannaregio area, for example, is filled with a diverse range of local shops along narrow alleys and in small piazzas. Situated off the Grand Canal and a 10-minute walk from the Rialto Bridge, this is a residential enclave where middle- and upper-class families have lived for generations and to which Venetians regularly flock for retail excursions.

headline: Exploring Cafes and Culture in Downtown Newark
text: The ceramic fire-breathing dragons in the window of Gifts East West, a curio shop owned by Ing and John Watts, have seen neighbors come and go during their 40-year tenure at 57 Halsey Street in Newark. Today the dragons look out to an empty lot and a mural painted on a wall of a shuttered department store, Hahne & Company, which last saw customers in the late 1980s. In two years the building will house a Whole Foods Market, with mixed-income rental apartments stacked above it. Another construction site across the street is for the Prudential Tower, which will give the financial services giant a new home next year, with room for retail as well.

headline: Google S.E.C. Filing Says It Wants Ads In Your Thermostat and Car
text: Updated, with comment from Tony Fadell, founder of Nest, and to cite an S.E.C filing in the headline.

headline: In Search of the Win-Win Solution: Exploring Techniques in Fair Division
text: Overview | How can goods and burdens be fairly divided among groups of people? What are the characteristics of an equitable division procedure?

headline: Former Bronx Assemblyman Sentenced for Corruption
text: Eric A. Stevenson, a former New York assemblyman convicted of bribery and other corruption charges, was sentenced to three years in prison on Wednesday by a judge who said he had sold an assemblyman’s “core function” for money.

headline: A Horse on the Bourse? Of Course
text: Hermès pulled out all the stops at its “All About Women” event at 23 Wall Street.

headline: After Death of a Caddie, Raising Pints and Concern
text: BAGSHOT, England — The table for one with the unopened pack of cigarettes and the untouched glass of cheap red wine stood a few feet from a sign that read, “Book This Room for Your Celebration.” The Tuesday night gathering here on the first floor of the Cedar Tree, in honor of a man who seldom ate alone, drew a crowd that spilled onto High Street with frothy glasses of Guinness.

headline: Cannes Film Festival: From Writers’ Fights Came ‘Winter Sleep’
text: CANNES — In “Winter Sleep,” from the Turkish director Nuri Bilge Ceylan, an older former actor and his beautiful younger wife are caught up in an intense conversation — about the limits of altruism, the responsibilities of the artist, about love and forgiveness and self-deception.

headline: A Horse on the Bourse? Of Course
text: THE HERMÈS WORLDVIEW is nothing short of cosmological.

headline: Prince Charles Passes Comment on Putin, and a Nation Is Aghast
text: LONDON — The poor man may eventually become king of England, but even at 65, every time he opens his mouth, even to utter banalities in private, he seems to get into trouble with the British press.

headline: A Mets Rookie’s Hair and Profile Grow
text: For more than 30 years as the baseball coach at Stetson University in DeLand, Fla., Pete Dunn enforced a strict hair policy. He had served in the Marines, had an old-school type of mentality and wanted his players to look a certain way in class and on the field.

headline: A Family’s Hard Journey, With Disney as a Guide
text: Over the last two decades, Ron Suskind has been known as a hard-hitting, Pulitzer Prize-winning political reporter, a thorn in the side of the Bush administration, a chronicler of the Obama White House. In private, though, Mr. Suskind was Iago the parrot, Baloo the bear, Merlin the wizard: Disney characters whose dialogue, songs and even “wisdom” he borrowed to communicate with his autistic son, Owen.

headline: Black Keys’s Latest Tops Michael Jackson
text: In one of the odder contests in recent pop history, the Black Keys have narrowly beaten Michael Jackson for the No. 1 spot on the new Billboard album chart.

headline: Pennsylvania Governor Won’t Fight Ruling That Allows Gay Marriage
text: Gov. Tom Corbett of Pennsylvania said Wednesday that he would not appeal a judge’s ruling striking down Pennsylvania’s ban on same-sex marriage.

headline: His Peers’ Views Are in the Details
text: Karl Ove Knausgaard, a handsome, rangy, brooding Norwegian author (and father of four young children) has held much of the literary establishment in thrall ever since his 3,600-page, six-part autobiographical novel, “My Struggle,” started appearing in English in 2012. Direct and unguarded in tone, the books combine a micro-focus on the granular detail of daily life (child care, groceries, quarrels with friends) with earnest meditations on art, death, music and ambition. The novelist Jeffrey Eugenides, calling these two elements “auto-fiction” and “rumination,” said that blending them in the way Mr. Knausgaard does is something “nobody’s done before.”

headline: Aaron Schock and His Popular Instagram Persona
text: WASHINGTON — “I love your life.” “You’re the coolest.” “Stud.”

headline: Immersed in Family Business
text: “Gang Related” is a series on Fox on Thursdays about a reverse undercover cop. The hero, Ryan Lopez (Ramon Rodriguez), isn’t a police officer posing as gang member, he is a gang member who has infiltrated the Los Angeles Police Department.

headline: Alex Chapman: The D.I.Y. Hip-Hop Artist
A Return to the Hamptons
text: Growing up mostly in Manhattan, Larry Landau spent his summers first on Fire Island and later in Southampton, where his mother bought a small ranch house. That’s the house that introduced his wife, Susan, who’s from New Jersey, to the Hamptons.

headline: Yellen Speaks at N.Y.U. Commencement
text: Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, told graduates at New York University that a willingness to stand up for principles is a crucial trait.

headline: More Voices Than Usual, Soaring in Service to Bach
text: In recent decades, largely thanks to the early-music movement, audiences have become accustomed to hearing Bach’s major choral works sung by smaller choirs, often with period-instrument ensembles, performances where textures come through clearly, and rhythmic execution can be crisp.

headline: Bending Convention
text: Fifty shades of blue, and a smattering of black and white tuxedos take over the red carpet.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: For Tuxedos, Blue Is the New Black
text: It’s the garment no man ever thinks about until he has to, the suit that strikes terror in an average guy’s heart. Subject to archaic codes of sartorial etiquette, composed of curious components, seemingly too expensive to buy for one-time use and yet vaguely forlorn when rented, it is, of course, the tuxedo — that set of formal clothes even whose name is controversial. (“Dinner jacket” is preferred by fancy folks.)

headline: It’s Difficult to Remain Incognito if You Insist on Taking Your Clothes Off
text: The sensorial effect of dance has much to do with the way performers inhabit a stage, be it spookily, generously or, in the case of the Zurich choreographer Simone Aughterlony, deviously. “In Disguise,” part of Zurich Meets New York: A Festival of Swiss Ingenuity and performed at the Kitchen on Tuesday night, takes place on a pink floor strewn with pieces of wood and rope, moss, knives and axes.

headline: Suite Wheels at AKA in Beverly Hills
text: AKA, the nine-property brand of luxury extended-stay accommodations, recently introduced a mobile suite at its Beverly Hills, Calif., location in partnership with Airstream 2 Go.

headline: Clip: ‘Gore Vidal’
text: A scene from the documentary “Gore Vidal: The United States of Amnesia.”

headline: Medieval Secrets Whispered in Caves
text: CW starts off the summer television season on Thursday night with “Labyrinth,” a “four-hour event mini-series.” “Event” in this case means a two-year-old “Da Vinci Code” rip-off from the Ridley Scott costume-drama factory. Always wanted to know more about Catharism and the Albigensian Crusade? After watching “Labyrinth,” you may actually know less.

headline: Clip: ‘Blended’
text: A scene from “Blended” with Adam Sandler and Drew Barrymore.

headline: For Memorial Day, Channeling the Relaxed Delevingne Look
text: Memorial Day is a reminder to downshift a little, to put your look in a more-relaxed gear. And if the season’s offerings have you at a loss, go with it. Channel the mixed-and-mashed style of the model Cara Delevingne (left), who has a weakness for, among other things, ‘90s street wear, eclectic prints, oversize sunglasses and idiosyncratic baseball caps. Not that we all could or should pull off the Delevingne look (and she’s British, anyway), but we can capture some of the cheerful, nonchalant punch her outfits so often pack.

headline: Clip: ‘The Dance of Reality’
text: A scene from the film.

headline: Clip: ‘X-Men: Days of Future Past’
text: A scene from the film.

headline: Looking Overseas, Google Weighs a Shift in Deal Focus
text: Since 2001, Google has struck more than 160 takeovers, most of them at home.

headline: Voices From Serbian Flooding
text: Survivors recounted the moment floodwaters submerged their homes in the towns of Obrenovac and Krupanj.

headline: The Final Game to Pick the 2015 USA-1 Bermuda Bowl Team
text: The final of the trial to pick the 2015 USA-1 Bermuda Bowl world championship team was played last weekend in Phoenix.

headline: Worries Turn to Disease as Waters Recede in Balkans
text: OBRENOVAC, Serbia — For five days, as rain pelted the Balkans and the waters rose, Jovanka Sreckovic, 85, waited in bed in her tiny house, barely a hut, beside the Sava River. Ms. Sreckovic, unable to walk, had no food, no water, no medicine and no electricity, and felt herself sinking into sickness with nothing but a children’s book about Jesus to pass the time.

headline: 3 Ways to Do Ribs
text: How to braise, grill or smoke them any time of year (but especially now).

headline: Clip: ‘Stand Clear of the Closing Doors’
text: A scene from the film, directed by Sam Fleischner.

headline: ‘Curious Incident,’ ‘On The Town’ Steer Clear of Stars in Casting
text: Not every Broadway show is banking on star power to sell tickets, as the casting of two fall openings, announced on Wednesday, demonstrates.

headline: Deceit, Madness and Love, Imported Directly From Russia
text: WASHINGTON — Is it better to see the Bolshoi Ballet at home or abroad? For decorative splendor, few opera houses can compare with the rebuilt Bolshoi Theater in Moscow — which I visited recently — and fewer with the immensity of its stage. Yet too many performances in Moscow and St. Petersburg are ruined by the partisan clamor of balletomanes and claques who overapplaud individual sections (sometimes individual steps) of each work, turning ballet into a competitive sport.

headline: This Dinner’s Highlights May Be on ‘SportsCenter’
text: The theater group New Georges describes its Jam on Toast festival as a “ ‘performance gym’ for early-career playwrights and directors.” Using that metaphor, it’s safe to say that Kate Benson and Lee Sunday Evans, collaborators on the spectacularly inventive “A Beautiful Day in November on the Banks of the Greatest of the Great Lakes,” are the kinds of people everyone else at the gym stares at with envy.

headline: From a Prison Cell to the Red Carpet
text: “Where’s Nadya?”

headline: In Paris, A Sexy New Swimming Hotel Is Making Waves
text: The just-opened Molitor hotel is making a splash (quite literally) in Paris this season. Even in its new incarnation as a nautically themed 124-room luxury hotel, the site of the mythic Piscine Molitor — a vintage Art Deco public swimming pool — hasn’t entirely lost the aura of erotic possibility that made it beloved, in a tongue-in-cheek sort of way, by generations of Parisians. The three-story cement complex with sleek ocean-liner-like architecture and two pools — one indoor and heated, one outdoor — was originally designed by the architect Lucien Pollet and inaugurated in 1929 in the heart of the silk-stocking 16th Arrondissement, Paris’s Upper East Side, by the American Olympic gold medalists Aileen Wiggin and Johnny Weissmuller — who spent a summer here working as a lifeguard and giving swimming lessons before he went on to win the role of Tarzan in the film of the same name a few years later.

headline: The Parisian Life Beckons, Waiting to Become Unforgettable
text: In 1988, when American Ballet Theater debuted a new production of Leonide Massine’s “Gaîté Parisienne,” one of the most popular ballets of the 1940s and ’50s, some people were shocked by the cartoonish sets by Zack Brown and the clashing colors in the costumes by Christian Lacroix. But the designers had the right idea. If a modern production of this comical character ballet is not to become a quaint evocation of mid-19th-century French cafe culture, it must not be afraid of being vulgar.

headline: For Cannes’s Man on the Red Carpet, a Fade-Out
text: CANNES, France — Each year, as stars ascend the red-carpeted steps here, a reserved gentleman in a bespoke Agnès B tuxedo is there to receive them. He is Gilles Jacob, and after more than 35 years at the Cannes Film Festival, the last 15 as president, he is alighting from those steps and retiring.

headline: Art School Creates a New Reality
text: Andy Warhol, who knocked painting off its pedestal by introducing it to mass production, is not the first person who might spring to mind as a defender of art’s academic traditions, particularly fusty-sounding ones like cast drawing and anatomical study. But he was a classically trained draftsman. And in the late 1970s, he helped found what became the New York Academy of Art, a bastion of figurative training that was swimming decidedly against the current, even at a time when Neo-Expressionism had brought painting the human form back into vogue.

headline: Store Openings and Fashion Events Starting the Week of May 22
text: Openings

headline: Classics Help Broadway Rebound
text: Thanks to an unusual combination of established hits and who’d-a-thunk-it crowd-pleasers from Shakespeare, Beckett and Pinter, Broadway has bounced back forcefully from the flops, flat ticket revenues and thin audiences that battered business a season earlier.

headline: Icon, an L.G.B.T. Nightclub in Astoria, Queens
text: Is Astoria becoming the next Hell’s Kitchen? In the last year, three L.G.B.T. nightspots have popped up in this diversifying neighborhood of Queens, the latest being Icon. Opened in January by a longtime Astoria resident, Nick Lion, Icon occupies a former Greek bar that has been given a makeover, with Swarovski-bedazzled lamps, studded black banquettes and swirly wall accents. One thing missing are big TV screens. “I don’t want a Britney Spears video to be the star,” he said. “I want the crowd to be the main attraction.”

headline: U.S. Sends Troops to Chad to Aid Hunt for Nigerian Schoolgirls
text: WASHINGTON — The United States has sent 80 troops to Chad in Central Africa to support a growing international effort in neighboring Nigeria to help find and rescue the schoolgirls who were abducted by an Islamist extremist group last month, the White House said on Wednesday.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Ukraine, Sudan, Serbia and Palestine.

headline: Why Many Young Chinese Women Are Writing Gay Male Erotica
text: No question, danmei, or ‘‘indulge in beauty,’’ the erotic stories and manga that originated in Japan and have put down deep roots in China, can be strong stuff.

headline: Web Retailer JD.com’s I.P.O. Shows a Hunger for China

headline: Christie Renominates New Jersey’s Chief Justice in Deal With Democrats
text: In a decision long anticipated as an indicator of his political fortunes, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey renominated the chief justice of the state’s Supreme Court on Wednesday, despite his promises to remake what he has called an “activist” and “liberal” court.

headline: Conquering the Closet
text: On the household to-do list my wife and I update whenever we’re orbiting Neptune in our hovercraft, “organize closets” is right up there with “hand-tune our unused piano” and “sort DVD collection by Rotten Tomato rating.” But when we recently had friends over for dinner and I couldn’t fit their coats into the entry hall closet, I figured I had to do something.

headline: Sales at Doris Leslie Blau, Simon Pearce and Ethan Allen
text: All vintage and antique rugs are 30 percent off at Doris Leslie Blau, through Sunday (a late-19th-century Persian Tabriz rug, originally $20,000, is $14,000); 306 East 61st Street (Second Avenue), seventh floor, 212-586-5511, dorisleslieblau.com.

headline: In the Houses Where He Lived
text: From the 1930s until his death in 1980, Cecil Beaton was a pivotal figure in design and fashion, thanks to his photography for Vogue and sets and costumes for “My Fair Lady.” There have been many exhibitions about his work, but none about how he lived. This will change Friday when “Cecil Beaton at Home” opens at the Salisbury Museum in England’s Wiltshire district. The exhibition will be on view through Sept. 19. For Beaton, two homes counted: his Wiltshire country estates Ashcombe, where he lived from 1930 to 1945, and Reddish, which he occupied from 1947 until his death. (The 1950s magazine ad, right, was photographed there.) The show’s curator, Andrew Ginger, has recreated parts of two rooms from those houses, installing Beaton’s Circus Bed, complete with unicorns, sea horses and barley-twist posts. Information: salisburymuseum.org.uk. For a total Beaton immersion, head down the road to “Cecil Beaton at Wilton,” a show of his photos from the 1930s, which runs through Sept. 14. Information: tourism@wiltonhouse.com.

headline: Because Buildings Need Seats
text: William Pedersen, 76, a founder of the architecture firm Kohn Pedersen Fox, has designed some of the world’s most notable skyscrapers, including the cluster of leaning towers under construction at Hudson Yards. Even so, he staffed his own booth at the recent International Contemporary Furniture Fair, presenting his new group of carbon-steel chairs that curve through space like line drawings. In what may look to the observer like a counterintuitive career move, Mr. Pedersen, after 50 years of designing buildings, is diversifying by taking on furniture. The line, called Loop de Loop after the stunts performed by small aircraft, includes a side chair, dining chair, chaise and lounge chair with ottoman. Eventually there will be a rocker. With their knit polyester mesh, they are for outdoor or indoor use. (This interview was edited and condensed.)

headline: Spindle Doctor
text: The Bernhardt Furniture Company in Lenoir, N.C., celebrated its 125th anniversary (yes, it really is that old) by commissioning Noé Duchaufour-Lawrance (French), Ross Lovegrove (Welsh) and Jephson Robb (Scottish) to reimagine classic pieces of American furniture.

headline: Pick a View, Any View
text: When Nina Montée and Harvey Karp first met, at a party in 1992, she mistook him for a nanny. “Here was this good-looking, ponytailed, hippy-ish guy telling me he took care of our hosts’ child,” she said. “It didn’t occur to me he was a doctor.”

headline: Seeking Balance on Mideast Visit, Pope Pleases Few
text: BETHLEHEM, West Bank — Pope Francis plans to give a strong show of support for a sovereign Palestinian state when he makes his first visit to the Holy Land this weekend, becoming the first pontiff to travel directly into the occupied West Bank rather than passing through Israel.

headline: Ruby Beets Dives into Brooklyn
text: Ruby Beets has arrived in Brooklyn. The home décor boutique, founded more than 20 years ago in the Hamptons, opened an outpost last week in Sunset Park, the first nonfood-related retail establishment to emerge in the developing Industry City complex.

headline: Portuguese Design
text: LISBON — Portugal gets a lot of attention as a tourist destination, as the country’s faltering economy has made it more affordable than many other European destinations. And it turns out it’s not a bad place to shop for home furnishings, either.

headline: Fish Need Trees, Too
text: AS a resident of Sitka, in southeast Alaska, I’ve worked in the local commercial fishing industry on and off for the past 17 years. This summer I’ll go out on the boat once more, in search of salmon, which have become one of the drivers of the region’s economic recovery.

headline: California Woman, Abducted at 15, Is Found After 10 Years
text: BELL GARDENS, Calif. — First, he drugged and kidnapped his girlfriend’s 15-year-old daughter, the police in Santa Ana, Calif., said. Later, he said that if she tried to get away, her family would be deported. Eventually, he forced her to marry him, and she had a baby.

headline: How Arthur Gelb Helped Reinvent the Modern Times
text: Arthur Gelb, who died Tuesday at the age of 90, held many titles in his years with The Times. He was a critic, chief cultural correspondent, metropolitan editor, deputy managing editor and managing editor.

headline: The Civil War and P.T.S.D.
text: Edson Bemis was a hard man to kill. Rebel soldiers tried three times, and three times they failed. At the Battle of Antietam, a musket ball ripped through his left arm. Two years later, in the horrible fighting in the Wilderness, he was shot in the abdomen, just above the groin. The ball was never extracted, remaining in his body until the day he died.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The New York Times/NY1/Siena College poll of New York’s 13th Congressional District consists of telephone interviews conducted May 15 through 20 with 678 likely Democratic primary voters throughout that district.

headline: Virtual Rift Leads to Legal Rift for Oculus and ZeniMax
text: A dispute over Oculus VR, the virtual reality start-up Facebook is buying for $2 billion, escalated on Wednesday, as ZeniMax Media said in a lawsuit that it has not been paid for its contributions to Oculus’s virtual reality headset.

headline: Full Results of The New York Times/NY1/Siena College Poll
text: Representative Charles B. Rangel holds a significant lead in the 13th Congressional District primary.

headline: Rangel Has Modest Lead Over Main Challenger in Democratic Primary, Poll Finds
text: Charles B. Rangel, the scandal-scarred Harlem congressman seeking a 23rd term in office, holds a modest but meaningful lead in his Democratic primary battle against State Senator Adriano D. Espaillat, a Dominican-American who is hoping to harness the political ambitions of the district’s surging Latino population, a New York Times/NY1/Siena College poll of likely voters has found.

headline: An Indirect Path to Accuracy in Election Polling
text: Representative Charles Rangel of New York has a nine-point lead over his nearest primary challenger, in a new New York Times/NY1/Siena College poll of likely voters. And there is reason to think his odds of winning the nomination may be larger than that lead suggests.

headline: Depressed, but Not Ashamed
text: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — MOST of our closest friends didn’t know that we struggled with depression. It just wasn’t something we discussed with our high school classmates. We found that we both had taken Prozac only when one of us caught a glimpse of a prescription bottle in a suitcase during a journalism conference last November. For the first time, we openly discussed our feelings and our use of antidepressants with someone who could relate. We took a risk sharing our experiences with depression, but in our honesty, we found a support system. We knew we had to take the idea further.

headline: No Runs Allowed, but Still No Wins for Cubs’ Samardzija
text: CHICAGO — What, exactly, does Jeff Samardzija have to do to win a game? Hit home runs? Throw 200 pitches? Rewrite the rule book?

headline: Fatal Film Accident Prompts Wrongful Death Suit

text: Marilynn K. Yee left Los Angeles to cover New York City during the chaos of the 1970s. Today, she retires as a staff photographer for The New York Times.

text: When America sends men and women to fight, it owes them an enduring debt, starting with competent and timely health care and disability benefits when they leave active duty. President Obama expressed outrage on Wednesday at recent charges of wrongdoing in the Department of Veterans Affairs’ health care system. He also dispatched his deputy chief of staff to Phoenix to assess explosive allegations that government workers falsified data to hide long wait times for veterans needing to see doctors.

headline: The Senate Foolishly Rushes In
text: The Senate is unnecessarily rushing to vote on President Obama’s nomination of David Barron for a seat on the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit in Boston, even though the public has yet to see documents written by Mr. Barron that have raised legitimate concern among civil liberties advocates on both the left and the right.

headline: Testing Time for European Unity
text: The elections to the European Parliament, taking place Thursday through Sunday, are second only to India’s in size. Europe has 380 million registered voters, but turnout has been declining with every European Union parliamentary election since the first one in 1979, and it is likely to dip sharply below the 43 percent of registered voters in the last one in 2009.

This week, more than six years after the park broke ground, a pier will be unveiled for activities that require more energy: five acres devoted to sports including pickup basketball games, roller-skating, bocce and kayaking.

headline: Vigilance Urged for N.Y.U. After Abuses in Abu Dhabi

headline: Prosecutors Investigating Grants for Health Site in Oregon
text: SEATTLE — Unworkable technology pushed Oregon’s health care exchange to the brink, making it the first state to abandon its self-administered system in favor of the federal exchange. But now prosecutors are following the money.

headline: 4 Years After Quake, Some See a Resurrected Chinese City, Others Dashed Dreams
text: YUSHU, China — Gazing out over the gleaming heart of this resurrected city, the young Buddhist monk marveled at how quickly the Chinese government had rebuilt his hometown just four years after a calamitous earthquake shattered every last building, killing at least 3,000 people and leaving more than 100,000 others homeless.

text: “There may be some public employees right now who don’t like me because I’m prescribing tough medicine. But when the pension system gets well in a decade, I’m going to be their favorite governor. I’ll wait to get the thank-you notes then.”

text: On the day the Metropolitan Transportation Authority officially resolved a long-running dispute with its largest transit union, its conflict with employees of the Long Island Rail Road appeared as intractable as ever.

headline: Attack in Xinjiang Kills 31 and Injures 94
text: Explosions at a crowded market killed 31 people and injured 94 others on Thursday morning in Urumqi, the capital of the restive Xinjiang region of China, in what officials called a “violent terrorist attack.” It was the deadliest burst of violence this year, highlighting a growing challenge to Chinese rule in a region that is home to the mostly Muslim, Uighur ethnic group.

headline: Media Companies Join to Extend the Brands of YouTube Stars
text: LOS ANGELES — Simon & Schuster is making a big bet on YouTube stars, an undertaking that could either open up a blockbuster new publishing market or reveal the limitations of Internet celebrity.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 21, 2014
History and Context of an Embattled Department of Veterans Affairs
text: WASHINGTON — The uproar over medical care for military veterans involves one of the nation’s biggest health care systems, a far-flung operation that treats 6.5 million people a year at 151 hospitals and 820 outpatient clinics, with more than 18,000 doctors and an annual budget of more than $57 billion.

headline: Sante Kimes Dies in Prison at 79; Killed and Swindled With Her Son
text: Sante Kimes, the maternal side of a murderous mother-and-son grifter team, died on Monday in her prison cell in Westchester County, N.Y. She was 79.

headline: U.N. Draft Resolution on Syria
text: The United Nations Security Council will vote Thursday on asking the International Criminal Court to investigate war crimes in Syria, but Russia is almost certain to veto the measure.

headline: Appeals Court Orders Qaddafi Son Tried in Hague, Not Libya
text: PARIS — In the extended legal dispute over who has the right to prosecute a son of the former Libyan dictator Muammar el-Qaddafi, an appeals court ruled on Wednesday that the case should be tried, as planned, at the International Criminal Court in The Hague.

headline: A National Team Without a Country
text: GORINCHEM, the Netherlands — The 18 Eritrean refugees arrived in this picturesque, blue-collar Dutch city 20 miles east of Rotterdam earlier this month looking for safety, security and, finally, after 18 months of fear and uncertainty in two refugee camps on two continents, a home.

headline: Vincent Harding, 82, Civil Rights Author and Associate of Dr. King, Dies
text: Vincent Harding, a historian, author and activist who wrote one of the most polarizing speeches ever given by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., in which Dr. King expressed ardent opposition to the Vietnam War, died on Monday in Philadelphia. He was 82.

headline: Prominent Libyans Vow Support for General
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — A Libyan general who has led a violent campaign against Islamist militias and lawmakers drew prominent new supporters to his cause on Wednesday, including the country’s air force commander and its ambassador to the United Nations.

headline: Rent or Buy? The Math Is Changing
text: Billy Gasparino and Jenna Dillon-Gasparino were savvy enough to wait out the housing boom of a decade ago as renters. Not until 2010, well into the bust, did they buy a house in the Venice neighborhood of Los Angeles, less than a mile from the beach, for $810,000.

headline: Young Met’s Career Line: 2 Solid Starts, 2 Losses
text: No matter what Jacob deGrom did Wednesday, it would be hard for him to top his major league debut. Last Thursday, he held the Yankees to one run in seven innings. He got a hit, mercifully ending the Mets pitchers’ hitless streak. And he improved as the game went on, showing maturity and poise and guts, keeping the Mets close in a 1-0 game.

headline: 1-Year-Old Boy Falls to Death From Sixth-Floor Window in Brooklyn

headline: With New Bill, Abortion Limits Spread in South
text: BATON ROUGE, La. — The Louisiana State Legislature on Wednesday passed a bill that could force three of the state’s five abortion clinics to close, echoing rules passed in Alabama, Mississippi and Texas and raising the possibility of drastically reduced access to abortion across a broad stretch of the South.

headline: ‘The Americans’ Recap: Season 2 Ends With an Answer and a Question

headline: India: Former Delhi Leader Jailed in Defamation Case
text: Arvind Kejriwal, who as leader of the Aam Aadmi. or Common Man, Party briefly served last year as Delhi’s chief executive, was jailed on Wednesday after refusing to pay a bail bond of around $171. Mr. Kejriwal was charged with defamation after making accusations of corruption against Nitin Gadkari, the former chief of the Bharatiya Janata Party, which won parliamentary elections last week in a landslide. The news that Mr. Kejriwal was being held set off protests by his supporters outside the prison. Prashant Bhushan, now the Aam Aadmi leader, told reporters that Mr. Kejriwal considered the case to be politically based and refused to pay the bond as a matter of principle.

headline: Conservatives Draft Manifesto to Help Republicans Attract Middle-Class Voters
text: WASHINGTON — Hoping to push their agenda ahead of the presidential election, a group of prominent conservatives has devised a 121-page policy manifesto aimed at giving the Republican Party a message that will attract some of the middle-class voters the party lost in recent White House races.

headline: Dobrica Cosic, First Friend Then Foe of Serbia’s Milosevic, Dies at 92
text: Dobrica Cosic, a novelist and outspoken Serbian nationalist who served briefly as president of Yugoslavia in the early 1990s when its breakup in the midst of sectarian war was already underway, died on May 18 in Belgrade, the Serbian capital. He was 92.

headline: F.B.I. Closes Investigation Into Guantánamo Defense Aide
text: WASHINGTON — An F.B.I. investigation into a member of a defense team for a Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, detainee accused of aiding the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks has been closed, a Justice Department official told a war-crimes court on Wednesday. The court filing is not yet public but was described by several people familiar with its contents.

headline: U.S. Campaign Urges Gay Men to Talk About H.I.V.
text: The federal government began a major AIDS-related public service campaign aimed exclusively at gay men on Wednesday with a message urging them to talk more openly with one another about whether they are infected with H.I.V.

headline: Pushing Climate Change as an Issue This Year, but With an Eye on 2016
text: WASHINGTON — Tom Steyer, a billionaire environmental activist from California, wants to blast the issue of climate change to the front lines of American politics. His “super PAC,” NextGen Climate, will spend about $100 million this year to influence several Senate and governor’s races in which climate change could play a major role.

headline: What’s On Thursday
text: 4:30 P.M. (FX) X-MEN TAKEOVER THURSDAY With the release of “X-Men: Days of Future Past” on Friday, the network presents a trilogy of films about Marvel’s mutant superheroes, as well as interviews with cast members of the latest installment. The lineup begins with “X-Men Origins: Wolverine” (2009), followed by “X-Men: The Last Stand” (2006) at 7:15, and “X-Men: First Class” (2011) at 10. Hugh Jackman, above (who portrays Logan/Wolverine), Ellen Page (Kitty Pryde/Shadowcat), Patrick Stewart (Prof. Charles Xavier), James McAvoy (Charles Xavier), Michael Fassbender (Erik Lehnsherr/Magneto) and Peter Dinklage (Bolivar Trask) discuss the challenges facing the mutants of the future, how they prepare to play their characters and what they took away from the experience of making this latest film.
