headline: Q & A: Adam Segal on China, Cyberspies and the Moral High Ground
text: This week, the United States took its most aggressive step yet in trying to curb what it calls Chinese state-sponsored hacking attacks aimed at stealing trade secrets from American corporations. The Justice Department on Monday announced an indictment against five members of the People’s Liberation Army accused of corporate cyberespionage. United States officials say the five men belong to Unit 61398, which operates out of an office tower on the outskirts of Shanghai.

headline: China Plans Security Checks for Tech Firms After U.S. Indictments
text: HONG KONG — A Chinese state agency that threatened retaliation after the United States obtained indictments of  five People’s Liberation Army officers on charges of cyberespionage announced plans on Thursday for tighter checks on Internet technology companies that do business in China.

headline: Search for Missing Malaysia Airlines Plane Resumes
text: SYDNEY, Australia — The deep-sea underwater search for missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 resumed overnight on Thursday with a remote-controlled submersible scouring the seabed in an area where searchers still believe they detected acoustic signals from the jet’s flight data recorders.

headline: Unilever to Sell Ragu and Bertolli Brands
text: LONDON – Unilever said on Thursday that it had agreed to sell its North American pasta sauce business under the Ragu and Bertolli brands to the Mizkan Group of Japan for $2.15 billion.

headline: Test Yourself | English, May 22, 2014
text: Take the Quiz

headline: Vivendi to Cut Stake in Video Game Maker Activision Blizzard
text: LONDON – The French media conglomerate Vivendi said on Thursday that it would sell half its stake in the video game publisher Activision Blizzard.

headline: South Korean Leader Dismisses More Aides After Ferry Disaster
text: SEOUL, South Korea — President Park Geun-hye’s office said on Thursday that she would replace the head of her government’s intelligence agency and her top national security adviser as she struggled to overcome the political fallout of the sinking of a ferry that left more than 300 people dead or missing last month.

headline: Fringe Parties May Gain in European Parliament Voting
text: BRUSSELS — Starting with Britain and the Netherlands, Europe began voting on Thursday for a new European Parliament, an election in which fringe parties of the right and left are expected to capitalize on low voter turnout and anger over immigration and anemic economies in the wake of the financial crisis.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Li Qualifies for U.S. Women’s Open, at 11
text: In “Li Qualifies for U.S. Women’s Open, at 11,” Lisa D. Mickey writes about a sixth-grade golfer.

headline: Exploring the World, in New York
text: New York City, 1977. Fires raged through the Bronx. Son of Sam was on the loose. Murders were almost as common as street fights and Times Square was dirty, in every way possible.

headline: What Would You Most Like to Learn to Cook or Bake?
text: The New York Times is developing a cooking site through which you’ll be able to search thousands of recipes and watch “learn to cook” videos.

headline: Euro Zone Recovery Is Chugging Along, Driven by Germany, a Survey Says
text: PARIS — The euro zone economy is continuing its steady, albeit slow, expansion, according to a private sector report published on Thursday that showed Germany again driving the region.

headline: New York Today: If It’s Raining, It Must Be Thursday
text: Good morning, drizzly city.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: Where You Live Matters for Lifesaving Liver Transplants
text: Broad-shouldered, deeply tanned and in his 50s, the farmer had ignored his worsening fatigue until the morning he realized that the whites of his eyes had turned yellow. His liver was failing, and when a specialist a few towns over informed him that he might not survive the year, he asked for the closest transplant center.

headline: Myanmar’s Journalists Still at Risk
text: Among the many reasons to cheer when Myanmar’s military junta officially dissolved itself in 2011, beginning a transition to democracy and a more open society, was the end of official censorship. Journalists, including the legendary U Win Tin, who passed away last month and who was jailed for more than 19 years by the military junta, began working freely again. But freedom of the press, apparently, remains unacceptable to Myanmar’s government.

headline: Thailand’s Military Stages Coup, Thwarting Populist Movement
text: BANGKOK — The Thai military seized control of the country on Thursday and detained at least 25 leading politicians in a culmination of months of maneuvering by the Bangkok establishment to sideline a populist movement that has won every national election since 2001.

headline: Sony Says Shake-Up Is Pointing to Profit
text: Sony’s chief executive vowed on Thursday to bring the electronics and entertainment company back to operating profit next year, but he offered few new strategies to put an end to the struggles that have fueled calls for its breakup.

headline: I, Too, Will Stand Up for Tiananmen
text: SYDNEY, Australia — On May 6 three of my friends were arrested in Beijing on suspicion of “picking quarrels and provoking trouble.” They are Xu Youyu, a scholar and former researcher at the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, Prof. Hao Jian of the Beijing Film Academy, and Pu Zhiqiang, a prominent human rights attorney.

headline: Deutsche Bank Vows to Remain a Top 5 Investment Bank
text: FRANKFURT – Deutsche Bank is determined to remain among the top five investment banks in the world, its co-chief executives told shareholders on Thursday at a typically raucous annual meeting, even as other European lenders cut back their profitable but risky trading activities.

headline: The Ethic of The Ethicist
text: Chuck Klosterman is an author, essayist and former rock critic. He writes The Ethicist, a weekly column for The Times Magazine. His responses have sometimes provoked outrage. Klosterman isn’t surprised. We asked him to reflect on writing the column.

headline: As the Delay Continues on Crowdfunding Rules, Concerns About Investor Risks Grow
text: It has been more than three months since the comment period on the Securities and Exchange Commission’s proposed rules for equity crowdfunding ended, and with no sign of final regulations on the horizon, stakeholders are getting antsy.

headline: One Woman’s Lonely Boycott of Amazon
text: Updated with new reporting on Amazon’s relationship with a book publisher, Hachette.

headline: Julia Scott on Discovering What She Smells Like After 28 Soapless Days
text: For the Health Issue this week, Julia Scott tested the claim by AOBiome that a living bacterial skin tonic composed of billions of cultivated Nitrosomonas eutropha, an ammonia-oxidizing bacteria, would make her skin feel cleaner and more hydrated. Part of her experiment included these headshots she took of herself. Scott recently talked about what it was really like not to shower with soap products for a month.

headline: 27 Captured by Taliban Amid Siege
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Taliban insurgents captured 27 of 40 police officers and officials who had taken refuge in a bunker, the government and the insurgents said on Thursday, as the Taliban continued to besiege a district government complex in a remote corner of northern Afghanistan that until last year had been considered one of the safest parts of the country.

headline: Violence and Doubts About Credibility as a Troubled Ukraine Election Nears
text: DONETSK, Ukraine — When two armed men on Thursday afternoon barged into the small yellow schoolroom that has served as Inna Mashenskaya’s makeshift election office, she stood up straight and began to argue. But when one of them, wearing sunglasses, patted the knife that was hanging from his belt, she stopped talking and surrendered control of her polling center.

headline: My No-Soap, No-Shampoo, Bacteria-Rich Hygiene Experiment
text: For most of my life, if I’ve thought at all about the bacteria living on my skin, it has been while trying to scrub them away. But recently I spent four weeks rubbing them in. I was Subject 26 in testing a living bacterial skin tonic, developed by AOBiome, a biotech start-up in Cambridge, Mass. The tonic looks, feels and tastes like water, but each spray bottle of AO+ Refreshing Cosmetic Mist contains billions of cultivated Nitrosomonas eutropha, an ammonia-oxidizing bacteria (AOB) that is most commonly found in dirt and untreated water. AOBiome scientists hypothesize that it once lived happily on us too — before we started washing it away with soap and shampoo — acting as a built-in cleanser, deodorant, anti-inflammatory and immune booster by feeding on the ammonia in our sweat and converting it into nitrite and nitric oxide.

headline: A Revolutionary Approach to Treating PTSD
text: Bessel van der Kolk sat cross-legged on an oversize pillow in the center of a smallish room overlooking the Pacific Ocean in Big Sur. He wore khaki pants, a blue fleece zip-up and square wire-rimmed glasses. His feet were bare. It was the third day of his workshop, “Trauma­ Memory and Recovery of the Self,” and 30 or so workshop participants — all of them trauma victims or trauma therapists — lined the room’s perimeter. They, too, sat barefoot on cushy pillows, eyeing van der Kolk, notebooks in hand. For two days, they had listened to his lectures on the social history, neurobiology and clinical realities of post-traumatic stress disorder and its lesser-known sibling, complex trauma. Now, finally, he was about to demonstrate an actual therapeutic technique, and his gaze was fixed on the subject of his experiment: a 36-year-old Iraq war veteran named Eugene, who sat directly across from van der Kolk, looking mournful and expectant.

headline: A Thirst for China
text: American investors are hungry for a Chinese Internet company, and it isn’t the Alibaba Group, China’s e-commerce giant. Instead, JD.com, an online retailer aspiring to become that country’s answer to Amazon.com, exceeded expectations for its initial public offering on Wednesday, raising $1.78 billion, DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced writes. Even though the company has lost money for the last several years, its stock sale valued the company at $25.7 billion. Shares in JD.com will begin trading on the Nasdaq stock exchange on Thursday under the symbol JD.

headline: Bloomberg, in Israel, Wins a $1 Million Prize, and Then Gives It Back
text: JERUSALEM — Two very, very rich Americans who recently left very, very high-profile jobs flew to Israel this week, each on a private plane. The less-rich one hosted a ceremony Thursday night where the more-rich one got a $1 million prize from a quartet of Russian oligarchs. Then he gave it back.

headline: Eyes Everywhere
text: “My position was straightforward,” Glenn Greenwald writes. “By ordering illegal eavesdropping, the president had committed crimes and should be held accountable for them.” You break the law, you pay the price: It’s that simple.

headline: A Memorial to Personal Memory
text: Why do we memorialize Sept. 11?

headline: Lost Without a Prayer
text: In the town of Mapleton, N.Y., all appears normal. The shops on the Main Street are open for business, and the neighborhoods are full of pristine homes and well-manicured front yards.

headline: Sunday Night Dinner | Tasting Prune’s New Menu
text: In this new food series, the writer Charlotte Druckman and the photographer Melanie Dunea visit New York City institutions and find out what’s new with the people behind them.

headline: Dominicans Begin to Flex Political Muscle
text: The namesake company of one of the wealthiest and most powerful families in the Dominican Republic is backing a multistate effort to register Dominican-Americans to vote and increase civic participation as Dominicans become more active in United States politics, especially in the Northeast.

headline: Turf Wars Seen in Response to High-Frequency Trading
text: Attorney General Eric T. Schneiderman of New York has been vocal about his inquiry into aspects of high-frequency trading, which he calls “insider trading 2.0.”

headline: What I’ve Been Reading
text: Seems like this will be a biweekly rather than a weekly feature …

headline: Courtesy to the Hot-Dog Man
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Hess to Sell Retail Arm to Marathon for $2.6 Billion
text: Updated, 9:03 a.m. | The Hess Corporation said on Thursday that it would sell its retail arm, including its familiar green-and-white gas stations, to Marathon Petroleum for $2.6 billion as it focuses on exploring and drilling for oil.

headline: The Tennis Whisperer Makes His Mark at the Top
text: PARIS — Roland Garros Stadium is sweet-and-sour territory for Magnus Norman. It is the bustling place where he reached his only Grand Slam final, which he lost to Gustavo Kuerten despite saving 10 match points. It is where Norman’s prize pupil, Robin Soderling, became the only man to beat Rafael Nadal at the French Open and later reached two finals of his own, only to lose them both and eventually his health.

headline: Some Privacy, Please? Facebook, Under Pressure, Gets the Message
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Do you know who can see what you are posting on Facebook, including your photos, birthday and personal cellphone number?

headline: Daily Report: Facebook, in Shift, to Tighten Privacy Settings
text: Responding to business pressures and longstanding concerns that its privacy settings are too complicated, Facebook announced on Thursday that it has decided to give a privacy checkup to every one of its 1.28 billion users, Vindu Goel reports.

headline: As Xi Speaks of Conciliation, Neighbors Voice Disquiet
text: Even as President Xi Jinping called this week for a new security concept for Asia, frictions between China and several of its neighbors underscored the challenges facing regional cooperation.

headline: Sears Posts Worst Report of a Bad Lot in Retailing
text: The slide continued on Thursday for the deeply troubled Sears Holdings, whose dismal earnings report not only lacked signs of improvement but also laid bare how few options the company had left.

headline: In Our Pages: May 23
text: A French television news report about the opera singer Maria Callas as she prepared for one of her signature roles, as “Norma,” from May 21, 1964.

headline: I.S.S. Recommends Approval of Signet’s Bid for Zale
text: LONDON – The specialty jewelry retailer Signet Jewelers has gained the support of Institutional Shareholder Services, a leading proxy advisory services firm, in its bid to acquire a smaller rival, the Zale Corporation.

headline: New York Stock Exchange Chief to Retire
text: Duncan L. Niederauer, the head of the New York Stock Exchange who negotiated a sale to an upstart exchange in Atlanta, will retire from his post earlier than expected.

headline: Why Comparisons Between L.B.J. and Obama Can Mislead
text: Lyndon Johnson was not known as a great orator, but 50 years ago today he stood before graduates at the University of Michigan and described his vision of “the Great Society” — a more humane society that “demands an end to poverty and racial injustice.” In his efforts to achieve those goals he enacted programs like Medicare, food stamps and the Voting Rights Act, giving Johnson an image of legislative effectiveness that every president since has been measured against.

headline: Pope Francis: ‘We Are Custodians of Creation’
text: Pope Francis is digging in on the role of faith and science in shaping a smooth human journey in this turbulent century of cresting appetites and global interconnection.

headline: Leah Hager Cohen: By the Book
text: The author of “No Book but the World” says the last book that made her furious was “The Da Vinci Code” — “At the end of every chapter, I’d glance up and announce in increasingly disgusted tones: ‘What schlock!’ ”

headline: When the Water’s Too Cold, Something Else to Dive Into
text: The shredder ate your A.T.M. card. You hear sirens because you butt-dialed 911. Your kid blew up canned cherries in the all-white kitchen because she’s an aspiring filmmaker, and Steven Spielberg once did it — his mother got to like the bloodstained look. You finally bagged the neighborhood pest in a Havahart trap, and it’s the cutest, fluffiest thing, but you never want to hear the deranged hiss of an angry raccoon again.

headline: They Share So Much. Perhaps a Tony?
text: Phoebe, the English ingénue of “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder,” is lovely, noble and pious. She wears tightly corseted gowns and ribbon-trimmed hats. She loves Shakespeare’s sonnets.

headline: Cannes Film Festival: A Belgian Thriller by Way of France
text: CANNES — On a rooftop terrace here this week, the actor and director Mathieu Amalric pulled a frayed robins-egg blue paperback out of his pocket. It was “La Chambre Bleue,” or “The Blue Room,” a thriller by Georges Simenon that the actor-director has just adapted for his film in competition here in the Un Certain Regard section.

headline: British Gambling Company Bwin.Party Reaches Pact With U.S. Activist
text: The British online gambling company Bwin.Party has agreed to work with the activist investor Jason N. Ader, narrowly averting a battle at the annual meeting on Thursday.

headline: India’s Import Limits on Gold Leave Jewelry Artisans Idle
text: NEW DELHI — The alleys of Reghar Pura, in the Karol Bagh district of the Indian capital, are choked with ramshackle buildings. Inside one of these, above a rickety spiral of stairs, a few goldsmiths squatted on the floor and concentrated on the delicate work laid out on wooden tables in front of them.

headline: One Venerable Ad Trade Association Is Acquiring Another
text: Two marketing trade associations, each of them more than a century old, are joining forces.

headline: Modi Exits Gujarat but His Influence Lives on in New Chief Minister
text: A day after Narendra Modi, India’s prime minister-elect, resigned as the chief minister of Gujarat to climb the higher echelons of power in New Delhi, one of his closest aides in his cabinet, Anandiben Patel, was sworn in as the first female chief minister of the state.

headline: China and Russia Block Referral of Syria to Court
text: UNITED NATIONS — Beheadings, torture, aerial bombardments of schools and hospitals: The war in Syria, raging for more than three years with no sign of relief, represents the very excesses of war that the International Criminal Court was designed to take on.

headline: All the Rage | Four Design Trends of the Moment, on View at Last Weekend’s International Contemporary Furniture Fair
text: Design insiders often take a jaundiced view of New York’s International Contemporary Furniture Fair, the less glamorous cousin to the Salone del Mobile in Milan, which took over the Javits Center last weekend, with satellite operations around the city. But while it may be true that there is nothing new under the sun, a survey of items on view revealed four compelling trends worth noting, including a renewed interest in midcentury modern design; an emphasis on materials with warmth and character like copper, brass and marble; the bold use of basic geometric forms; and lighting that explored the limits and possibilities of new technology.

headline: Geithner and Stewart Don’t See Eye to Eye on ‘The Daily Show’
text: If there was one big takeaway from the former Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner’s appearance on “The Daily Show” on Wednesday night, it’s that he and Jon Stewart do not agree on many things about the financial crisis.

headline: Inspired by Dada, a Party for the Death of Privacy
text: The first sign that something was up was the tombstones that appeared around the city last week, from Times Square to Chelsea to Wall Street, proclaiming: “RIP Privacy.” It turned out that they were teasers for an unusual night of Dadaism that was held Saturday night, the details of which are now becoming known thanks to a video hosted by a puppet.

headline: Raging Amid Tears in a Gathering Storm
text: “The Normal Heart,” Larry Kramer’s impassioned j’accuse about the early years of the AIDS crisis, is an entirely different thing from what it was when first staged as a play at the Public Theater in 1985. Back then, it was, above all, a political statement about continuing indifference toward the gathering storm of AIDS; those strident speeches that the central character, Ned Weeks, delivered onstage could just as appropriately have been shouted on the sidewalks outside City Hall or the White House.

headline: To Greeks, the Parliamentary Vote in Europe Is a Test of Their Own Direction
text: ATHENS — This time, there are no predictions of doom, no anguished fretting out of Washington or Berlin that Greek national elections could unravel the European economic order. That was the mood in 2012, when the fate of the euro seemed to hang on the whims of an angry Greek electorate that, in the end, voted to stay the course in the euro zone.

headline: Detroit’s Police Chief Stands His Ground
text: What, precisely, did Detroit police chief James Craig have in mind when he spoke favorably of citizens arming themselves as an extra protection against violence in his battered city? The chief wound up on the cover of a National Rifle Association magazine this month after he stressed his pro-gun position, telling America’s 1st Freedom: that he was celebrating the rise of “good Americans, good Detroiters” carrying firearms because they were “fed up with being victims.”

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘Letter to Brooks: Spring Garden’
text: This is our final Poetry Pairing of the school year. How do you use this feature? What would you like to see next year?

headline: JD.com Has Rousing Start in Trading Debut
text: Updated, 4:04 p.m. | The online Chinese retailer JD.com started life as a publicly traded company with a rousing start, closing up 10 percent on the Nasdaq on Thursday. At that price, shareholders valued the company at more than $28.6 billion, more than other American technology names like Twitter and LinkedIn.

headline: Modi Activists in Karnataka Tell Bangalore Writer to Go to Pakistan
text: At a book launch at a college in Bangalore last September, U. R. Ananthamurthy, an award-winning author of literature in the Kannada language of his home state of Karnataka, said to a crowd of several hundred that he did not want to live in a country ruled by Narendra Modi.

headline: NATO Steps Back Into the U.S.S.R.
text: LONDON — The best line about NATO was always the simplest: If NATO is the answer, what’s the question?

headline: A Big Pile of Fantastic Ideas to Get Kids Outside Making and Doing This Summer
text: It’s May, time for teachers to revisit their bookshelves and think about summer reading selections. This year, I’m considering a different kind of summer reading for my kids, books that will inspire them to head outside and make, do and create. My younger son, Finn, likes these sorts of projects, and while I can provide him with scrap lumber, nails, a drill and some screws, he and I wanted to find some additional inspiration.

headline: Despite Poor Governance, JD.com Is Fast Off the Block
text: JD.com has achieved a rich price despite poor governance. The company, China’s second largest e-commerce group after Alibaba, priced its shares above the expected range on Wednesday, raising $1.8 billion.

headline: Today in Small Business: Detroit Is Doing Something Right
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: The Kings’ Six-Goal Surge Steals a Chicago Night
text: CHICAGO — Wayne Gretzky appeared on a national radio show Wednesday afternoon, and the subject of the conversation was dynasties. Gretzky, of course, knows a thing or two about the topic, having won four Stanley Cups in five years with the Edmonton Oilers during the 1980s. He said if the Chicago Blackhawks won another title this year — it would be their third in five years — they could qualify for the exclusive club.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup: Day 21
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: House Passes Restraints on Bulk Data Collection
text: WASHINGTON — In a rare moment of bipartisan agreement between the White House and Congress on a major national security issue, the House passed legislation on Thursday that aims to end the National Security Agency’s bulk phone records program that had prompted intense domestic debate about privacy and civil liberties.

headline: Pastiche, Parody, Homage and Theft
text: The score for the Broadway musical “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder” has been described as a pastiche of Gilbert and Sullivan operettas. Songs from Jeanine Tesori’s “Violet,” starring the amazing Sutton Foster, like the jaunty “Surprised,” owe an obvious debt to country and gospel.

headline: A Critic Picks Songs of the Broadway Season
text: As someone who thinks a lot about the musical component of musical theater, I wrote an Arts & Leisure piece offering my impressions of some scores from recent shows in New York. I was particularly interested in the technique of pastiche, in which composers, and lyricists, too, evoke older song styles and genres in their new scores.

headline: Door by Door, India Strives to Know More About Death
text: MAGADI, India — M. R. Gundappa, 60, died the way most Indians do: with no doctor present, no monitors beeping by his side and no written record. The only person present was his wife, Sushilamma, 48, who spent the day of his death trying to get him admitted to a government hospital where he could be treated for abdominal pain.

headline: Letters: The Subcontinent
text: The Subcontinent

headline: BlackRock Encourages AstraZeneca to Renew Pfizer Talks at Later Date
text: LONDON – AstraZeneca’s largest shareholder, BlackRock, wants the drugmaker to renew its talks with Pfizer about a potential deal at a later date, according to a person familiar with the discussions.

headline: How Much Would Home Prices Fall if You Couldn’t Deduct Mortgage Interest?
text: On Twitter, a reader, @SquarelyRooted, proposed that we create an alternate-universe version of our rent vs. buy calculator in which there is no mortgage interest tax deduction. Scaling back the mortgage interest deduction — and its inherent subsidy for owning a home — is a crucial piece of some proposals to overhaul the tax code.

headline: Tom Leighton of Akamai, on the Professorial Side of Leadership
text: This interview with Tom Leighton, chief executive of Akamai Technologies, a web content delivery company, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Brassard’s Condition Worse in French
text: Rangers Coach Alain Vigneault likes to make a little joke as English-language reporters clear out of the room before he gives the French-language portion of his daily news briefings.

headline: Exploring the Archives
text: Jeff Roth takes us on a basement tour of The New York Times’s archives, known as the morgue.

headline: Readers Say a ‘Net Neutrality’ Vote Was Reported Upside Down and Backward
text: Should a speedy Internet be available to everyone equally or are some users, in Orwell’s terms, “more equal than others”? Should there be “haves” and “have-nots” on the Internet, with the winners being large corporate or commercial users, as opposed to small businesses or regular people?

headline: Facebook Chat at 2 p.m. About the New Math of Rent vs. Buy
text: Archie Tse, a graphics editor who helped create The Times’s new online Rent vs. Buy calculator, and Neil Irwin, a reporter who wrote about rising home prices around the country and five questions you should ask yourself before buying, are taking questions on Facebook today at 2 p.m.

headline: Times Minute | Military Coup in Thailand
text: Also on the Minute, senators press the N.F.L. to change the Washington Redskins’ name and a New York Times summer reading list.

headline: Times Minute | Military Coup in Thailand
text: In the Video

headline: Koreas Trade Artillery Fire Across a Line in the Water
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Naval vessels from North and South Korea exchanged artillery fire on Thursday, raising tensions along a disputed maritime boundary. Neither hit the other.

headline: Cannes Film Festival: The Bride, the Groom and His Lover
text: CANNES — “Wild Tales,” the Argentine director Damián Szifrón’s raucous anthology movie, which made its debut here, has one of the most memorable wedding scenes in some time: a furious bride spins her new husband’s girlfriend into a mirrored wall.

headline: For Luxury Collection, an Arts Partnership
text: Luxury Collection Hotels & Resorts, a group of more than 85 upscale properties that are part of Starwood Hotels, has a new partnership with the global arts nonprofit Outset Contemporary Art Fund, which gives its guests insider access to highly regarded artists and cultural institutions.

headline: Image of the Day: May 22
text: As summer temperatures soared across India, children in Mumbai find some respite from the heat in the waters of the Arabian Sea.

headline: Geriatricians: Beware ‘Liquid Candy’
text: Bottles of liquid nutritional supplements have become such staples in older people’s refrigerators, in nursing homes and assisted living facilities, and in hospitals, that it’s easy to assume they serve a useful purpose for seniors who are losing weight.

headline: Loving a Sport That’s ‘Totally Alien’ in New York City
text: Eugene Sorenson was plenty busy — he works as a global business manager at Bloomberg L.P. and is on the board of Trips for Kids Metro New York, a nonprofit group that introduces mountain biking to underprivileged children to provide exercise, expose them to nature and teach life lessons about setting and achieving goals. (His wife, Andree Sanders, is the group’s executive director.)

headline: ‘The Star-Spangled Banner’
text: Sebastien de la Cruz sings the national anthem for visitors at his home.

headline: Dance Veterans Join Forces for the Betterment of Ballet
text: The dancer Cynthia Harvey, a principal for many years with the American Ballet Theater, has been coaching and staging ballets since she left the stage in 1996, but lately has had the feeling that there was something amiss in the ballet world – something that she and other retired dancers like Edward Villella, Isabelle Guérin, Ángel Corella and Steven Heathcote could help fix.

headline: The Thai Army Repeats History
text: On Tuesday, the Thai military imposed martial law on the country and insisted it was not staging a coup. On Thursday, the army dispensed with these niceties and took power, overthrowing a government that has been besieged by street protests since late last year.

headline: Pennsylvania Gay Marriage Plaintiffs Suddenly Have a Wedding to Plan
text: SWARTHMORE, Pa. — Getting married was not a pressing priority for Christine Donato and Sandy Ferlanie, despite their being plaintiffs in the case that led a federal judge to strike down Pennsylvania’s ban on same-sex marriage on Tuesday.

headline: Yelp Reviews Help Track Food Illnesses
text: After a particularly bad restaurant meal, you may be moved to post a review on the website Yelp, warning other diners. But now someone else is listening in: New York City health officials, who may try to track you down if you complain that the meal made you sick.

headline: Even Fruit Flies Need a Moment to Think It Over
text: It’s easy to think of fruit flies as tiny robots that simply respond reflexively to their environment. But just like humans, they take time to collect information and to deliberate when faced with a difficult choice, according to a new study.

headline: A Theory on How Flightless Birds Spread Across the World: They Flew There
text: Just a few centuries ago, Madagascar was home to a monstrous creature called the elephant bird. It towered as high as nine feet. Weighing as much as 600 pounds, it was the heaviest bird known to science. You’d need 160 chicken eggs to equal the volume of a single elephant bird egg.

headline: Totokaelo’s Jill Wenger on Seattle’s Best Culture
text: The fashion and design emporium Totokaelo — pronounced Toh-toh-KYE-oh — may be the most innovative boutique in Seattle, but it’s more than just a local institution. The store’s founder, Jill Wenger, has discovered and championed some of the most influential independent designers anywhere, while her elegant e-commerce site is a shopping resource bookmarked by stylish men and women around the world.

headline: Memo From the United States Department of Justice
text: The policy, which applies to the F.B.I., the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, the Drug Enforcement Administration and the Marshals Service and which will go into effect in July, also encourages officials to use electronic recording in other parts of their investigations, like witness interviews.

headline: Songs of Love and Longing, and Retro Sounds From ’60s On
text: Sharon Van Etten

headline: Matthew Warchus Will Lead Old Vic Theater
text: Matthew Warchus, a British director whose work on Broadway includes “Matilda the Musical” and “God of Carnage,” for which he won a Tony Award, will succeed Kevin Spacey as the artistic director of the Old Vic theater in London. He will take up his new position in the fall of 2015, the company announced on Thursday.

headline: In Policy Change, Justice Dept. to Require Recording of Interrogations
text: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department said Thursday that the F.B.I. and other federal law enforcement agencies would be required to videotape interviews with suspects in most instances, bringing the federal government in line with the practices in many state and local jurisdictions.

headline: Thai Army Chief Announces Takeover
text: The Thai Army chief, Gen. Prayuth Chan-ocha, announced a coup after his efforts to reconcile rival political factions failed, and Bangkok residents reacted to the news.

headline: Commencement 2014 | Things to Read, Watch, Debate, Teach and Learn
text: Updated: May 29

headline: What’s New? Ask the Philharmonic
text: The music world has long looked with envy at the art world for the way it succeeds in drawing people to embrace, or at least check out, contemporary works.

headline: Ernesto Butcher, Who Managed Port Authority After 9/11, Dies at 69
text: Ernesto Butcher, a soft-spoken Panamanian immigrant who effectively took over management of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, as its most experienced surviving operations officer, died on May 15 in Maplewood, N.J. He was 69.

headline: Edward Snowden Talks to Brian Williams of NBC
text: The NBC anchor Brian Williams has landed an extensive interview with Edward J. Snowden, the source of numerous revelations about the spying activities of the National Security Agency.

headline: When Madison Avenue Met Pennsylvania Avenue
text: The Times has converted all of its 1964 issues into a digitized, searchable format. Each week, The Upshot will unearth an item from 50 years ago and put it in the light of today. “Advertising: Race for White House Costly” appeared on May 24 and can be seen in its original format on TimesMachine.

headline: The Particular Challenges of Polling Hispanics
text: One of the thorniest issues in polling today is how to capture an accurate picture of the opinions of Latinos.

headline: James Corden in Talks to Return to Broadway in ‘A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum’
text: James Corden, who won critical acclaim and a Tony Award for his comic performance in Broadway’s “One Man, Two Guvnors” in 2012, is in negotiations to star in a Broadway revival of “A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum” next spring, a spokesman for the revival’s producers confirmed on Thursday.

headline: Getting Your Wages, Before Payday
text: Last fall, Stephen Prentice found himself short on money for rent after his girlfriend moved out. He was wary of using a payday lender, having incurred big fees using one previously. Instead, he said, he used a new service called Activehours to get an advance on his biweekly paycheck to help tide him over.

headline: ‘De Que Manera Te Olvido’
text: Sebastien de la Cruz’s rendition of a ranchera standard, written from the point of view of a forlorn lover. The title translates to “How Can I Forget You.”

headline: Troops Move on Militants in Tribal Area of Pakistan
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — Pakistani soldiers seized control of a neighborhood dominated by foreign Islamist militants in the North Waziristan tribal district on Thursday as part of the most concerted military operation in the area in several years, a senior security official said.

headline: Reactions to Market Blast in Xinjiang
text: Residents in Urumqi, capital of the Xinjiang region of China, described the aftermath of a blast that killed 31, and China’s Foreign Ministry spokesman discussed the attack.

headline: Fantasy Football: Analyzing N.F.L. Draft Picks, Part 4
text: We turn our attention to the A.F.C. South and West while completing our look at the rookie on each N.F.L. team who should have a fantasy-league impact this season, whether compiling valuable statistics himself or helping players around him do so.

headline: Type 2 Diabetics Face a Flood of Drugs and Tests
text: At the American Diabetes Association’s traveling EXPO, many exhibitors have their eye on the prize: People with Type 2 diabetes. Clinilabs offers such patients more than $3,500 to join a drug trial. Sanofi-Aventis has 10-foot-tall insulin pens on display. Walgreens offers a free test to check long-term blood sugar levels, a promotion for a new home-testing kit.

headline: At the Kings County Fair, See the Kangaroos
text: Round about August, the Miser often hauls his crew the hundred or so miles up the Taconic State Parkway to Rhinebeck, N.Y., for the Dutchess County Fair. The farm animals, deep-fried vegetables, Ferris wheel and butterfly farm provide a nice escape from the city summer’s oppressive heat, in spite of the drive.

headline: Assembly Speaker Finds Fall Guy: Another Sheldon Silver
text: To Sheldon Silver, the powerful speaker of the New York State Assembly, it was nothing but a simple case of mistaken identity.

headline: Clip: ‘Frequencies’
text: A scene from the film.

headline: Potential Partner for Patton Boggs Suspends Merger Vote
text: Updated, 5:01 p.m. | The anticipated merger of two major legal firms was derailed, at least temporarily, on Thursday after one firm, Patton Boggs, a lobbying and legal force in Washington, D.C., faced a legal complication in trying to end its involvement in a bitterly contested case over damage to the Amazon rain forest.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘Cold in July’
text: Jim Mickle narrates a sequence from “Cold in July,” featuring Michael C. Hall and Sam Shepard.

headline: This Weekend | The 9/11 Memorial Museum
text: This weekend you can visit the new Sept. 11 museum, see art that was made by ordinary people at the American Folk Art Museum or check out the Carpeaux exhibit at the Met before it ends.

headline: This Weekend: The 9/11 Memorial Museum
text: In the Video

headline: There’s No Such Thing as a Free Tax Cut
text: It’s a recurring problem for conservatives: If you propose a tax plan, and it cuts taxes on somebody, it has to raise taxes on somebody else, or raise the deficit. Since conservatives have long been focused on cutting the top marginal tax rate on income without raising the deficit, their tax plans usually involve cutting taxes on the rich — and therefore raising taxes on some nonrich group.

headline: Parents of Victim in Film Set Accident Plan Safety Campaign
text: LOS ANGELES — Speaking by telephone from a lawyer’s office in Atlanta on Thursday morning, the parents of Sarah Jones, who was killed in a film set accident on Feb. 20, said they were planning to create a permanent film safety campaign dedicated to her memory and built around the phrase “Safety for Sarah.”

headline: The Gun Report: May 22, 2014
Safety Agency Says New Tests Are Needed on Boeing Battery
text: Tests on a new kind of battery for 787 planes were inadequate, and new tests should be devised for determining whether batteries with new chemistries are safe for use on airliners, the National Transportation Safety Board said on Thursday.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of ‘Cold in July’
text: In this video, the director Jim Mickle narrates a sequence from “Cold in July.” The film takes place in 1989 and features Michael C. Hall as a man who has killed a burglar who broke into his home. That act sets off a series of events in this twisty thriller. Here, Mr. Hall’s character appears at the funeral of the man he killed, with surprising results.

headline: A Belgian Sculptor Takes Antwerp by Storm
text: A storm is brewing at Middelheim Museum, a sculpture park outside of Antwerp, Belgium. “The Storm,” to be exact. It’s the Belgian sculptor Johan Creten’s newest show, an outdoor installation of 25 monumental works cast in bronze, clay and resin. Creten’s work speaks to the storm within us all, as individuals and as a society, and deals with his usual themes: nature, the female form, power, politics and spirituality. As a preview to what is, to date, his largest and most ambitious exhibition, which opens this Saturday under the moody Flemish sky, the Paris-based artist talks to T about the processes and inspiration behind some of the works on view.

headline: Financial Crisis, Over and Already Forgotten
text: Michael S. Barr, a law professor at the University of Michigan who was an assistant Treasury secretary when the financial crisis was at its worst, is working on a book titled “Five Ways the Financial System Will Fail Next Time.”

headline: Must Conservatism Soak the Poor?
text: As I mentioned in my reading-list post earlier today, some of my friends in the small world of “reform conservatism” have been busy putting together a book of policy essays, which includes (among other ideas) proposals on tax reform and safety net reform that the authors, at least, think might help boost the fortunes of the working class and poor.

headline: The Pen Is Mighty as a Message
text: Are prison movies the most escapist of Hollywood genres — or the least? Don Siegel’s explosive “Riot in Cell Block 11,” released on its 60th anniversary in an extras-laden Criterion dual-format edition, is one penitentiary movie in which busting out is never an option.

headline: Wheelies: The Toyota Trouble Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
text: In the news: extreme weight loss, superior memory and swimming ability. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Small on Space, Big on Flavors
text: Lately, the restaurants I visit seem to have ever tinier and more makeshift kitchens, from which nevertheless issue ornate, ambitious, semi-avant-garde meals. It’s as if a clandestine “Top Chef” challenge were in progress, with young-gun chefs goading one another into using the fewest, crudest tools possible to create spectacle and wonder.

headline: Gavin Schmidt on Why Climate Models are Wrong, and Valuable
text: I’m overdue to draw your attention to two fresh, and very different, discussions of climate science by Gavin Schmidt, the longtime climate modeler at NASA’s Goddard Institute for Space Studies.

headline: Is Work Your Happy Place?
text: Do you feel more stressed out at work or at home?

headline: Preserving a New York Jewelry Legacy
text: The roster of small jewelry workshops in Manhattan’s diamond district keeps shrinking, but at least one company that’s winding down is preserving the history of its designs. After six decades of making jewelry at various addresses in the West 40s, Henry Dankner & Sons is closing and donating its paperwork and molds to the jewelry design department at the Fashion Institute of Technology.

headline: Cuomo Boasts of New York’s Rebirth, but Hits Snags
text: MELVILLE, N.Y. — For three years, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo dominated New York State politics like no other chief executive in decades.

headline: A Boy Lost in the Underworld
text: “Stand Clear of the Closing Doors,” a small miracle of a film, captures the grass-roots swirl of New York City with an extraordinary sensory attuning to urban life. Set largely inside the city’s subway system, it observes the world through the eyes of Ricky (Jesus Sanchez-Velez), a bright but easily distracted 13-year-old boy with midrange autism who gets lost underground. Mr. Sanchez-Velez, the untrained actor who plays him, has Asperger’s syndrome and is a hauntingly plaintive screen presence.

headline: F.H.A. Loans Get Better with Credit Counseling
text: Tight mortgage lending conditions have largely shut out the millions of borrowers with credit scores below 640. In response, the Federal Housing Administration, which insures low-down-payment loans, has taken on the tricky task of trying to expand access to credit without increasing the rate of default.

headline: Minnesota Orchestra Names Interim President
text: The Minnesota Orchestra, which is rebuilding after a long lockout, said Thursday that it had chosen an interim leader to take over after its president and chief executive, Michael Henson, steps down this summer: Kevin Smith, a former president of the Minnesota Opera.

headline: Jason Wu Honored by Parsons
text: On Wednesday night at a black-tie dinner in Greenwich Village, Parsons the New School for Design honored Jason Wu, one of its graduates. The event attracted a crowd of fashion notables, including Donna Karan, Chris Benz and Tracy Reese.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: Jutta Koether: ‘Champrovent’
text: Reena Spaulings Fine Art

headline: Intellectual Dueling at a Prep School
text: Because “Words and Pictures” is a comedy of ideas couched in the format of a Spencer Tracy-Katharine Hepburn movie, the temptation for some critics faced with a film that dares to be ostentatiously smart is to blast it to smithereens. Which more or less describes the critical reaction to the movie when it was shown last year at the Toronto Film Festival.

headline: Yo, Beau. What’s Up?
text: My boyfriend and I have been together for about two years. Last week, I overheard him on the telephone telling a good friend that he would like to break up with me. (Literally: “Bro, I want to dump her.”) He thought I was out of the apartment, so I haven’t said anything about it. It felt like eavesdropping to me. But he’s not acting as if he wants to break up. In fact, he’s been incredibly sweet lately. I’m afraid I’m being delusional. Should I say something to him? And if so, what?

headline: Pictures of the Day: Thailand and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Thailand, Ukraine, India and Turkey.

headline: Attack Kills More Than 30 in Western China Market
text: URUMQI, China — Assailants driving two sport utility vehicles and tossing explosive devices plowed through a crowded vegetable market on Thursday in this city, the capital of the Xinjiang region in far western China, killing 31 people and wounding 94. It was the single deadliest attack here since ethnic bloodletting claimed hundreds of lives five years ago.

headline: 2 Cities Withdraw Bids to Host 2016 G.O.P. Convention
text: WASHINGTON — Las Vegas and Cincinnati have informed the Republican National Committee that they are withdrawing from the competition to host the party’s 2016 convention. The other four finalists, Cleveland, Dallas, Denver and Kansas City, will receive official site visits from the committee’s 2016 site selection delegation, according to a news release.

headline: What I Learned on Paternity Leave: I’m Glad to Be Back at Work
text: I was my daughter’s sole caregiver long enough to know that I was ready for it to be over. That doesn’t mean I regret taking paternity leave. In fact, realizing that I felt that way was one of the best things about it.

headline: Tasting France Through 5 Signature Dishes
text: I’ve always felt that a map of France reads like a menu. The very names of regions can incite ravenous pangs. Each has a signature dish, from Brittany’s butter-crisped crepes, to the generous cuts of pork draped over mounds of tangy sauerkraut in the eastern reaches of Alsace. Provence bursts with a rich soup of Mediterranean fish; the bounty of Languedoc’s flat, dry plains comes alive in the warmth of simmering cassoulet.

headline: Must-Eat Dishes, From Myanmar to Mexico City
text: To accompany our cover article on regional food specialties around France, we asked some food experts to weigh in with their tips for must-eats in other parts of the world. Following is a selection.

headline: How to Prep Before You Grill
text: Ask Real Estate is a weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: A Young Violinist’s Lucky Concerto? First, a Prize; Now, the Philharmonic
text: Two dominant figures from the British music scene made their Avery Fisher Hall debuts with the New York Philharmonic on Wednesday evening. The fiery Russian conductor Vladimir Jurowski, principal conductor of the London Philharmonic Orchestra and music director, for over a decade, of the Glyndebourne Festival Opera, led the Philharmonic for the first time, drawing a strong performance that was especially memorable for the raw power of the music’s climaxes. The 26-year-old Scottish violinist Nicola Benedetti, who had previously appeared only in a parks concert with the orchestra, stepped in to perform Szymanowski’s Violin Concerto No. 1 at a moment’s notice when the Dutch star violinist Janine Jansen had to withdraw on doctor’s orders.

headline: An Intellectual and His Lofty Contempt
text: When Gore Vidal declared in an old television debate with William F. Buckley Jr. that 5 percent of Americans had 20 percent of the income and the bottom 20 percent had 5 percent, he was raising an alarm. That observation may be the most shocking moment in “Gore Vidal: The United States of Amnesia,” Nicholas Wrathall’s admiring documentary portrait of Vidal, who died in 2012 at 86.

headline: Philip Roth to Appear on ‘Colbert Report’
text: So where on television can you get a really substantial discussion of the great American novel?

headline: With Border Reopened, Crossing the Rio Grande to Mexico
text: On a May afternoon several years ago, my friend Drew and I took a day trip from Marfa, Texas, where we both lived at the time, to Big Bend National Park, about 100 miles away. Temperatures often reach into the 90s and 100s in the late spring in Far West Texas, so we were called to the water that day, and headed for the edge of the Rio Grande, at the east end of the park.

headline: 9/11 Museum Fees Don’t Faze Visitors
text: MARY LARSON and her family had come to New York City from Erie, Pa., this week for her son’s graduation. Marlena and Edgar Dupre had flown in from San Antonio to board a cruise. Peter and Kirsten Abitz, from Denmark, were on vacation, as was Linda Christeaen from Belgium. The 40 or so students at Greenwich High School in Connecticut had taken a bus down for the day thanks in part to money raised by the PTA.

headline: Limits of Health Networks
text: To the Editor:

headline: Library Reveals President’s Salary
text: Anthony W. Marx earned $781,000 — including housing, tuition and other compensation — in his first full year as president and chief executive of the New York Public Library, according to the library’s most recent tax returns. According to the library’s Form 990, Mr. Marx’s base salary for 2012 was $491,000, considerably lower than that of his predecessor, Paul LeClerc, who was making $667,000 when he left the library, in 2011. More recent salary figures are not available. Library salaries have been a topic of discussion in recent months as New York City officials review the salary of Thomas W. Galante, who gets about $391,000 as the director of the Queens Library system. Mr. Marx and other officers are paid with private funds.

headline: Family Memoir in a Dreamscape
text: The Chilean-born filmmaker Alejandro Jodorowsky has recently been the subject of a revelatory documentary — “Jodorowsky’s Dune,” directed by Frank Pavich — about a movie he never made. There are a lot of those: Since his heyday in the early ’70s as a midnight cult-film pioneer with “El Topo” and “The Holy Mountain,” Mr. Jodorowsky’s semimythic status as a cinematic wild man has outstripped his productivity as a director. So the arrival of a new feature — his first since 1990 — would be grounds for excitement even, if the movie in question, “The Dance of Reality,” were not something very close to a masterpiece.

headline: In Fields and Stadiums, Like One Long Concert
text: New York brims with summer entertainment, and that includes more choices than ever for those whose idea of it is to escape into a “lost weekend” of music festival revelry. Nearby options include the freewheeling Mountain Jam at Hunter Mountain (June 5-8), the folk and singer-songwriter hub Clearwater’s Great Hudson River Revival in Croton-on-Hudson (June 21-22), the hip-hop- and rock-centric Made in America weekend in Philadelphia (Aug. 30-31) and many more. Here are six of the most-anticipated destination festivals in the region.

headline: Golden Line Adds Tarnish to Sprawling Subway System
text: MEXICO CITY — There is music on the trains of Mexico City’s newest subway, the Golden Line, piped in at just the right volume to be pleasantly audible over the rumble. One recent morning, the playlist came to a classic: “Midnight Train to Georgia.”

headline: 2 Major Time Inc. Magazines Will Run Cover Advertising
text: Time magazine and Sports Illustrated have started selling advertising space on their covers, breaking with a longstanding magazine industry tradition of keeping covers free of ads.

headline: A Confederacy of Mavericks
text: Is there such a thing as artistic genius? In high-culture circles, it used to be taken for granted that there was, and there was a well-established canon of great artworks to prove it, from Leonardo’s “Mona Lisa” to Jackson Pollock’s drip paintings. Then, at the end of the 1960s, scholars like Linda Nochlin, author of “Why Have There Been No Great Women Artists?,” began to wonder why the canon consisted almost exclusively of works by male Caucasians. Is genius something that only white men are capable of? After that, belief in genius pretty much disappeared from serious art-historical discourse, except when it was disparaged as a patriarchal myth.

headline: The Joys of Judging a Book by Its Cover
text: A woman’s melancholic eyes, heavy-lidded with desire, float in the nocturnal sky over a brashly lit skyline and amusement park.

headline: Obama Revels in Quick Trip Through Baseball’s Past
text: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y. — There are a few perks of office for any American president. And for President Obama, his broad smile on Thursday suggested that this was one of them.

headline: The Street Chef of Gulshan
text: Follow a chef in the Gulshan section of Dhaka, Bangladesh, as he makes roti and eggs.

headline: Hidden Lives: Street Chef of Gulshan
text: If our French and global food roundups didn’t get your mouth watering, this might. “Street Chef of Gulshan,” produced by Fred Grace and Gemma Atkinson for Fat Rat Films, is part of the Hidden Lives series that we occasionally run. It takes you on a virtual trip to Bangladesh, and explores the idea that food is a means of understanding a place and its people.

headline: Taiwan Activists Push for Same-Sex Marriage Bill
text: The young man in a Taiwan military uniform, a clear plastic bag over his head, stood before an array of paper tombstones along Ketagalan Boulevard in Taipei holding a sign that read: “I am a soldier. I am gay. I passed the physical. I’m not allowed to give blood.”

headline: Gleeful Museums Unpack a Bequest
text: The final group of paintings, drawings and sculptures bequeathed to museums by Paul Mellon before his death in 1999 have at last begun to arrive. Hidden away for decades, many are rarities that had never been seen by curators.

headline: Women With Diabetes Face Greater Heart Risks Than Men
text: Type 2 diabetes substantially increases the risk for heart disease, but a large review of studies has found that women with diabetes are at much higher risk than men.

headline: Transference? I’ll Take It
text: I was in my early 40s, and my life was finally swinging into shape. I had a steady stream of work and warm, generous friends. But I had yet to find a viable, committed love. I kept falling for handsome artistic narcissists and their beautiful myths, while ordinary guys with decent looks, good jobs and kind natures simply didn’t register on my radar.

headline: Understanding the Thai Coup
text: The Thai military overthrew the country’s elected government on Thursday. It was the second time in a decade that the military has seized control. We asked Thomas Fuller, who is covering the coup for The Times, to recommend what to read on the political dynamics of Thai society. Here is his suggestion:

headline: Architecture for the Upper East Side Horse
text: The legacies of the horse in New York include the stable street, where the well-to-do isolated their private stables to avoid the smells and noise, inflicting them instead on their lesser neighbors. Although the mansions they served are in most cases gone, a few of these stable streets survive, and one of the most significant is 69th Street, from Lexington to Third Avenues.

headline: Lost in the Past
text: Ask a high school senior what the Great War was all about and you’re likely to get a shrug or a stab based on a recent episode of “Game of Thrones.” Hint: its 100th anniversary is this year. Hint: globe-straddling old empires collapsed and new horrors, from genocide to slaughter by poisonous gas, were ushered in. Hint: its repercussions are with us still, from Syria to Russia to the American role as international cop.

headline: Donovan Dropped From U.S. World Cup Team
text: Landon Donovan, widely considered the best male player in the history of United States soccer, was cut from the World Cup team on Thursday as Coach Jurgen Klinsmann trimmed his roster to 23 players.

headline: Sounds of All but Silence
text: The New Museum is alive with the sound of music, as well as talking, chanting, spitting, electronic tics and sputters and, occasionally, the tinkling of 47 small bronze bells. Its six current exhibitions all involve sound. One is almost nothing but sound. This loose, fluctuating connection illuminates some of the many roles sound plays in contemporary art while allowing the shows to, well, amplify one another in unexpected ways. It also mitigates the museum’s dark, awkwardly proportioned galleries.

headline: The Pool Photographer, Literally
text: Marieke van der Velden is a pool photographer. Not the designated shooter, but one who photographs swimming holes – from deluxe to decrepit – around the world.

headline: Events in Westchester for May 25-31, 2014
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: A Summer of TV Time Travel
text: For proof that summer is no longer the silly season of television — or at least not solely silly — just take a look at names involved in some notable shows from Memorial Day to September. Steven Soderbergh, Guillermo del Toro, Michael Bay, John Malkovich and Halle Berry are among the A-listers we’re not used to seeing attached to summer TV, or to TV shows at all.

headline: Excavating the Past to Reshape the Present
text: From now until June 14, Danspace Project is all about DD Dorvillier, with programs exploring the work of that influential choreographer from multiple angles. In June comes a forward look, as Ms. Dorvillier debuts a solo. Starting on Friday are various sideways views, as longtime collaborators present solos of their own, examining shared connections. And the backward glance, befitting such an inveterate questioner of convention as Ms. Dorvillier, is nothing as standard as a remounting of past pieces.

headline: Sunny Cannes Gets Lightning
text: CANNES, France — On Wednesday afternoon, the 83-year-old rock star Jean-Luc Godard shook up the Cannes Film Festival with his latest, a 70-minute 3-D extravaganza, “Goodbye to Language.” Finally, the competition lineup had something it has desperately needed all week: a thrilling cinematic experience that nearly levitated the packed 2,300-seat Lumière theater here, turning just another screening into a real happening. You could feel the electric charge — the collective effervescence — that can come when individuals transform into a group. “Godard forever!” a voice boomed out to laughter and applause, as the congregated viewers waited for their brains to light up with the screen.

headline: Grabbing the Good Songs From Sources All Over
text: In contemporary songwriting, how true is the commonly voiced adage “They don’t write ’em like they used to”? That received wisdom is powerfully challenged in the singer Marissa Mulder’s wonderful new show, “Living Standards,” which had its first performance on Wednesday evening at the Metropolitan Room.

text: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: They Want Your Blood
text: Can you judge the state of an actor’s career based on how he is required to die on camera? If so, Christopher Lloyd has cause for concern.

headline: Ronaldo’s Toughest Move
text: FUNCHAL, Portugal — The roads of Madeira twist together like licorice ropes, their spindly curves beginning at the seashore and rising up the steps of this steep island in a maze reminiscent of Rio de Janeiro’s favelas. The slow climb here comes with a similar feeling to the Brazilian shanties, too: one of utter insulation, a complete removal from the tourist areas that lie below.

headline: Ex-Leader Embodies a German Divide on Russia
text: BERLIN — It was an image that provoked consternation abroad and in an instant captured Germany’s long-conflicted place between East and West: former Chancellor Gerhard Schröder embracing President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia as he arrived last month at a party in St. Petersburg for the German’s 70th birthday.

headline: Japanese Food Firm That Popularized Sushi Looks Globally for Growth
text: The Mizkan Group’s $2.15 billion purchase of Unilever’s Ragu and Bertolli pasta sauce brands is the latest overseas foray by a storied and gutsy vinegar maker, one that helped transform sushi from an obscure delicacy into a global culinary phenomenon.

headline: Saving Their Future, in Bell-Bottoms
text: Even compared with other self-serious superhero franchises — the brooding “Dark Knight” saga, the agonized “Amazing Spider-Man,” the hectic “Avengers” house party — the X-Men series wears its allegorical heart on its sleeve. In chronicling the adventures of a despised minority with extraordinary powers, the movies, like the Marvel comic books before them, poke around in some interesting social and political hot zones. The central conflict is the endless moral and political argument between Professor X and Magneto: in other words, between the accommodationist idea that the mutants should fight for the moral redemption of the humans, and the militant insistence that they should defend their own interests by any means necessary.

headline: Monsters (the Human Kind) Slithering Through East Texas
text: The pulpy neo-noir “Cold in July” should propel the filmmaking team of Jim Mickle and Nick Damici further up the blood-spattered, zombie-infested hierarchy of B-movie auteurs with Hollywood ambitions. Last year, they advanced a few feet with their remake of the 2011 Mexican cannibal fest, “We Are What We Are,” which followed two microbudget cult favorites: the post-apocalyptic “Stake Land” (2011), and “Mulberry St.” (2007), a medical horror flick.

headline: What to Do in New York City in Summer 2014
text: Winter was no picnic, but the amnesia that summer provides is just around the corner. The season’s lodestar, Macy’s Fourth of July fireworks show, is moving back to the East River, guided by the wishes of the Brooklynite mayor, Bill de Blasio. To witness another spectacle, find the camping gear and clear your calendar to ensure a ticket to “King Lear,” starring John Lithgow and Annette Bening, the Public Theater’s free Shakespeare in the Park production. No matter the temperature, New York is the place to be. Here’s a summer guide to make the most of it.

headline: Former Defense Secretary Gates Is Elected President of the Boy Scouts
text: Robert M. Gates, the former secretary of defense and director of the Central Intelligence Agency, was elected president of the Boy Scouts of America on Thursday, formally taking leadership of an organization that continues to be roiled by its policy on gay Scouts and leaders.

headline: Events on Long Island for May 25-31, 2014
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: When Single Parents Collide on a Safari
text: Because life is short and I have other things to be upset about, I will not dwell on the offensive aspects of “Blended,” the new Adam Sandler comedy: its retrograde gender politics; its delight in the humiliation of children; its sentimental hypocrisy about male behavior; its quasi-zoological depiction of Africans as servile, dancing, drum-playing simpletons; its ... I’m sorry. That’s just what I said I wouldn’t do.

headline: Hit by Rivals, Hewlett-Packard Will Cut Jobs
text: Meg Whitman, the chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, has said that it will take a long time to get the company on the right course. The quarterly results released Thursday underlined that a recovery was still in the distance.

headline: Maintaining Hopes of Starting, Jets’ Vick Grapples With Backup Role
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Michael Vick is accustomed to being either the unquestioned starting quarterback or, at worst, knowing he would be given every opportunity to vie for that role. But on Thursday, he sounded very much like a proud but aging star intent on doing whatever necessary to extend a once-brilliant career.

headline: Inside the Ropes, McIlroy Keeps It Together
text: VIRGINIA WATER, England — All Rory McIlroy wanted to do was take refuge on the golf course, inside the ropes, and play the first round of the rest of his life at the BMW PGA Championship, the European Tour’s flagship event.

headline: An 18th-Century Korea, Swarming With Assassins
text: The title of Lee Jae-kyoo’s “The Fatal Encounter” is a misnomer: The film teems with fatal encounters. It is 1777, in the Joseon dynasty in Korea, and King Jeong-jo (Hyun Bin) — known historically as the king of misfortune — is surrounded by enemies. Two factions, the Noron and Soron, are at each other’s throats, and everyone, it seems, has it in for him. Even his trusted clerk, Sang-chaek (an effectively understated Jung Jae-young), a quiet minder of this philosopher-king’s library, was trained in childhood at a kind of assassin school for slaves. He has positioned himself to strike but discovers that the monarch is a benign ruler and a friend.

headline: Dominican Republic Passes Law for Migrants’ Children
text: Under international pressure, the Dominican Republic is poised to create a path to citizenship for tens of thousands of people of Haitian descent whose legal right to reside in the country had been thrown in doubt by a court ruling last year.

headline: Crisis of the Eurocrats
text: A century ago, Europe tore itself apart in what was, for a time, known as the Great War — four years of death and destruction on an unprecedented scale. Later, of course, the conflict was renamed World War I — because a quarter-century later Europe did it all over again.

headline: Too Much Looking, Not Enough Listening?
text: The reviews of the production of “Der Rosenkavalier” that opened this year’s Glyndebourne opera festival in England have gone viral, but not in a way that either the performers or the critics who wrote them probably expected. At issue: the way several prominent male critics harped on the shape, and not just the sound, of the young mezzo-soprano portraying Octavian: Tara Erraught.

headline: Status Quo Gets a Nod, but Arizona Is Changing
text: The Arizona Diamondbacks started so poorly this season that their management team had reason to worry. With only five wins in their first 23 games, after consecutive .500 seasons, some kind of change seemed inevitable.

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: This Week’s Movies | May 23, 2014
text: The New York Times film critics review “X-Men: Days of Future Past,” “Cold in July” and “Blended.”

headline: Finding Central Park’s Hidden Gems
text: I’ve been visiting Central Park regularly since I moved to New York three years ago, but I remain a total novice when it comes to navigating within it. I’ve only intermittently been able to find a beautiful fountain I once stumbled upon, and I was hoping that the recently redesigned app from the Central Park Conservancy, the nonprofit group that runs the park, could help.

headline: Family of Detained Egyptian Journalist Says Leaked Images of Him Were Staged
text: The family of an Egyptian journalist who has been detained for nine months without charge expressed outrage on Thursday that images of him were leaked to a Facebook page run by sympathizers of the Interior Ministry.

headline: Televising Sizzling Meat to Bump Up Sales of a Brisket Sandwich
text: TELEVISION commercials have  grown shorter over the decades, with 60-second spots the norm at the dawn of the medium, 30-second spots growing popular in the 1970s, and 15-second spots catching on in the 1980s. The number of 15-second ads grew more than 80 percent between 2008 and 2012, according to Nielsen, which notes the popularity of mobile devices, where commercials must impress quickly as users toggle among apps.

headline: Competing Visions for Russia’s Economic Future
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — A panel at an annual economic forum here was deeply divided over the direction of the Russian economy. The isolationists in the group favored relying on state banks for its financing needs. Others called for Russia to deepen its ties with China, while a different contingent said global trade and commerce remain critical.

headline: Near-Average Hurricane Season Is Predicted for U.S. as El Niño Develops in the Pacific
text: The Atlantic Ocean and the Gulf of Mexico are highly likely to experience an average or below-average number of hurricanes and tropical storms this year, including fewer of the most dangerous hurricanes with winds above 110 miles per hour, government forecasters said Thursday.

headline: Old Mystery for Clippers’ Fill-In C.E.O.
text: For years, as the business résumé of Richard Parsons swelled, a bit of his early life remained unexplored or ignored: his college basketball career at the University of Hawaii nearly 50 years ago.

headline: Events in Connecticut for May 25-31, 2014
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: $200 Million Could Curb Pension Cuts in Detroit
text: In a series of votes that could be critical for Detroit’s emergence from bankruptcy, the Michigan State House on Thursday agreed to contribute nearly $200 million in state money for a deal to spare Detroit’s retirees from larger pension cuts and to avoid selling artworks from the city’s museum.

headline: Prince Rupert zu Loewenstein, Rolling Stones Money Manager, Dies at 80
text: Prince Rupert zu Loewenstein, a Bavarian aristocrat and money manager who guided the Rolling Stones to riches and through financial crises — helping to elevate them to an economic behemoth — without ever acquiring a taste for rock music, died on Tuesday in London. He was 80.

headline: A Hedge Fund Highflier Comes Back to Earth
text: ENGLISH BICKNOR, England — The chickens of the one percent could roost comfortably here.

headline: Really Good Books, Part I
text: People are always asking me what my favorite books are. I’ve held off listing them because it seems self-indulgent. But, with summer almost here, I thought I might spend a couple columns recommending eight books that have been pivotal in my life.

headline: Wade Is Flourishing in Playoffs Despite His Worrisome Knees
text: MIAMI — Dwyane Wade objected — in unquestionably polite and good-natured ways — to the wording of two questions posed to him by reporters after the Miami Heat’s workout here Thursday morning.

headline: No Gap to Mind
text: French commentators are scrambling to find just the right words to describe a costly bureaucratic blunder that came to light on Wednesday, thanks to some digging by the satirical weekly Le Canard Enchaîné. Was the foul-up only “comically tragic,” as a French transportation minister sheepishly described it, a “vaudeville farce,” as a rail worker’s union saw it, or a howler verging on madness as a leading French newspaper suggested.

headline: Path to an Asylum Request, From Egypt Jail to California Fair
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — As he walked out of a Cairo electronics store the night of April 24, Abdullah Assem, 17, was met by several police officers who told him he was under arrest for creating an antigovernment rebel group and for shooting at a government security building.

headline: Misdiagnosis? You’d Be Angry, Too
text: From the director of “Field of Dreams” comes one of those movies about someone who learns he has a terminal diagnosis and desperately tries to take stock. In Phil Alden Robinson’s “The Angriest Man in Brooklyn,” Robin Williams plays an irascible New York lawyer who gains a sudden window of self-awareness when a doctor says he has 90 minutes left to live. The movie is predictably sentimental at its root, but it’s also meant to be comedy, partly resting on Mr. Williams’s energetic but failed attempt to play a jerk.

headline: The Secret Shame of the Death Penalty
text: Sooner or later, someone like Russell Bucklew was going to come along and throw a big wrench into the predictable back-and-forth debate over the constitutionality of executing people by lethal injection.

headline: Evacuation at Sept. 11 Museum Is Revealed
text: Last week, five days before it opened to the public, the National September 11 Memorial Museum was briefly evacuated, sending dozens of startled visitors scrambling up seven stories to daylight.

headline: Events in New Jersey for May 25-31, 2014
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Fans in Spain Reveal Their Prejudices, and Social Media Fuels the Hostilities
text: MADRID — Spain’s sports fans have given Europe a version of the Donald Sterling racism scandal roiling America.

headline: A Surveillance Bill That Falls Short
text: A year ago, it would have been unimaginable for the House to pass a bill to curtail the government’s abusive surveillance practices. The documents leaked by Edward Snowden, however, finally shocked lawmakers from both parties into action, producing promises that they would stop the government from collecting the telephone data of ordinary Americans and would bring greater transparency to its domestic spying programs.

headline: I.R.S. Delays New Rules on Taxation for Activists
text: The Internal Revenue Service said Thursday that it has delayed and is revamping new rules intended to curb political activity by tax-exempt groups and that were proposed after the agency was accused last year of targeting Tea Party groups.

headline: Keeping Track: Gay Marriage, Patent Reform and Airbnb’s Data
text: Marriage Equality Advances

headline: Twitter Agrees to Block ‘Blasphemous’ Tweets in Pakistan
text: At least five times this month, a Pakistani bureaucrat who works from a colonial-era barracks in Karachi, just down the street from the former home of his country’s secularist founder, Mohammed Ali Jinnah, asked Twitter to shield his compatriots from exposure to accounts, tweets or searches of the social network that he described as “blasphemous” or “unethical.”

headline: Officials Cast Wide Net in Monitoring Occupy Protests
text: When the Occupy protests spread across the country three years ago, state and local law enforcement officials went on alert. In Milwaukee, officials reported that a group intended to sing holiday carols at “an undisclosed location of ‘high visibility.’ ” In Tennessee, an intelligence analyst sought information about whether groups concerned with animals, war, abortion or the Earth had been involved in protests.

headline: The Politics of Breastfeeding
text: Why does the nursing versus formula debate incite so much anxiety and competition among women?

headline: Facebook’s New Privacy Mascot: The Zuckasaurus
text: So why a dinosaur?

headline: Baseball Lords Vexed by Plan for a New King
text: The search for Major League Baseball’s next commissioner has been unusual for an organization that has $8 billion in annual revenue and regards itself as a Fortune 500-caliber company. A search firm has not been hired, and there has been no attempt to vet a wide-ranging list of internal or external candidates.

headline: A Prisoner’s Unflagging Claim of Innocence Meets an Unexplained Intrusion
text: How does time pass for a person in prison who says he is innocent?

headline: Clip: ‘The Angriest Man in Brooklyn’
text: A scene from the film.

headline: From Virginia, Chasing Down Credit Suisse
text: Hundreds of miles from Credit Suisse’s Madison Avenue office tower and an ocean away from its headquarters in Zurich, the bank found an unlikely opponent in Alexandria, Va.

headline: U.S. Case Offers Glimpse Into China’s Hacker Army
text: BEIJING — One man accused of being a hacker for the Chinese military, Wang Dong, better known as UglyGorilla, wrote in a social media profile that he did not “have much ambition” but wanted “to wander the world with a sword, an idiot.”

headline: Life With, and Without, Father
text: Nicolas Mercier’s reassuring “Grand Départ” explores relationships painfully familiar to anyone who has dealt with an aging parent’s declining health and mental faculties. Often, in such situations, fraught connections with siblings — rivalries and unforgiven childhood slights — can be as stressful as tending to a dying loved one.

headline: Nets’ Deron Williams to Have Ankle Surgery
text: Nets point guard Deron Williams will have surgery on both of his troublesome ankles, the team said Thursday.

headline: After Prison, a Life on the Ropes
