text: “Wolf” follows Majid — a second-generation Dutchman of Moroccan descent recently released from prison and back living with his disapproving family — as he works in a warehouse and begins to make a career as a kickboxer in prize fights. His best friend, though, keeps involving him in robberies that grow bigger and bolder, and Majid eventually draws the interest of Hakan, a mob boss who sees potential in him.

headline: Northern Ireland Police Sue for Boston College Interviews
text: LONDON — The police in Northern Ireland said on Thursday that they were taking legal action against Boston College to obtain all transcripts and recordings of interviews with paramilitary members on both sides of the sectarian divide who took part in an oral history project there.

headline: Government Surveillance of the Occupy Protests
text: The following documents are a selection from among about 4,000 pages of unclassified emails and reports about the Occupy protests distributed by people working with counterterrorism and intelligence-sharing offices known as “fusion centers.”

headline: ‘Home’ for the Summer, in a Refugee Camp
text: Exiles at home, the generations of family depicted in the documentary “A World Not Ours” live in Lebanon without completely being part of it. This affecting, humor-tinged debut feature from Mahdi Fleifel goes back to the old neighborhood in southern Lebanon: the refugee camp Ain al-Helweh, a Palestinian pocket of hemmed-in buildings and stifled hopes.

headline: Felony Charges Are Filed in Case of 2004 Disappearance
text: SANTA ANA, Calif. — Ten years after absconding with his girlfriend’s 15-year-old daughter, Isidro Medrano Garcia was charged by prosecutors on Thursday with raping and kidnapping the girl, who subsequently became his wife and the mother of his child and who lived with him for the past decade.

headline: Indictment Details 3 Kidnappings Linked to Coerced Divorces
text: When several rabbis and ultra-Orthodox men were accused in October of being a part of a ring that kidnapped and tortured Jewish husbands who refused to grant divorces to their wives, the top federal prosecutor in New Jersey said the number of victims might run into the dozens.

headline: Jersey City Sues Port Authority Over Taxes on Property
text: After months of threatening and some grudging negotiations, Jersey City sued the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey on Thursday, seeking more than $300 million in unpaid taxes.

headline: If Life Gives You Baloney, Make a Sandwich
text: As the stacks of cold cuts and the sliced Cheddar dwindle, so do the prospects of staying financially afloat for the three beleaguered central characters in “American Hero,” a sweet and sour new comedy by Bess Wohl that opened on Thursday night at the McGinn/Cazale Theater in the annual Uptown series from Second Stage Theater. Cast adrift when the owner of the new sandwich franchise where they work mysteriously disappears, the store’s employees alternate between despair at the latest dead end in their lives and fragile hope that by keeping calm and carrying on making sandwiches, somehow things will turn out all right.

headline: Inside Opening
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — This puzzle by David Steinberg is an optical illusion, a feature I’ve never seen in a puzzle before. It reminds me of this illusion, where two different pictures can be seen, depending on how you look at it. Can you see the two visual aspects of the grid? At first glance, you might see two arrows running in opposite directions, but as you fill in the puzzle — especially as you get to the center of it — you will begin to realize that there is more than meets the eye with Mr. Steinberg’s grid.

headline: We Feel Your Vibe
text: Before summer tent poles are fully erected, and science fiction is dominated by spaceships, superheroes and special effects, “Frequencies” arrives to remind us that all sci-fi truly requires is a slightly surreal twist on life.

headline: Assad’s Forces Break Yearlong Rebel Siege of Prison
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Government forces broke through a protracted rebel siege of one of Syria’s largest prisons on Thursday, dealing yet another blow to their opponents and highlighting the suffering that the country’s war has brought to those caught between the warring parties.

headline: Poll Finds Only Narrow Majority Supports Egypt’s Expected Big Winner
text: CAIRO — The former general who is universally expected to win a landslide victory in next week’s presidential election has the support of only a narrow majority of Egyptians, according to a poll released Thursday by the Pew Research Center.

headline: The Plagiarist’s Love Interest
text: A recent surge in cachet for Daniel Brühl — he played the methodical Formula One driver Niki Lauda in “Rush” and the sniper turned movie star in “Inglourious Basterds” — hasn’t quite blown the dust off “Lila, Lila,” a glossy trifle released in 2009 in Germany that’s belatedly opening in New York.

headline: Anything to Save Their Pensions
text: The French Riviera scenery from this month’s Cannes Film Festival may act as an enticement, but onlookers are advised not to imitate the drastic measures taken in “The Love Punch,” a good-natured if strenuously wacky caper comedy about a divorced British couple who plot a diamond heist to save their pensions.

headline: A Striking Success
text: One week after winning Spain’s top league, Atlético Madrid can add a second trophy on Saturday if it beats its city rival, Real Madrid, in the UEFA Champions League final in Lisbon. But regardless of the result, Atlético has already had the kind of success that any club would envy, replacing players without missing a beat.

headline: The End for Long Island College Hospital
text: Evelyn Valdez, an intensive care nurse at Long Island College Hospital, had already been asked to turn in her identity card. She was taking photos on her tablet on Thursday, to remember the place where she had worked for nearly 30 years and which she called her “second home.”

headline: In Search of Space and Creativity, a Start-Up Is Headed to Brooklyn
text: When 3rd Ward, the educational, art and design work space based in Bushwick, Brooklyn, closed its massive warehouse complex last fall amid financial troubles, the creative community it had housed scattered — some to smaller studios, workshops and schools in Brooklyn, others to strike out on their own.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 22, 2014
Sanctions Imposed Against Boko Haram
text: The United Nations Security Council on Thursday added Boko Haram, the Nigerian extremist group, to its Al Qaeda Sanctions List, a blacklist of individuals and organizations affiliated with Al Qaeda. The designation subjects Boko Haram members to penalties that include a freeze on assets, a travel ban and an arms embargo. Nigeria had sought the designation as part of a broader response to a wave of attacks on schools and other targets by the group and its kidnapping of nearly 300 schoolgirls last month. The Security Council designation announcement cited the group’s avowed affinity and collaboration with Al Qaeda and its “violent insurgency utilizing terrorist tactics.” The designation was welcomed by Samantha Power, the United States ambassador, who said the Council’s action had “helped to close off important avenues of funding, travel and weapons to Boko Haram, and shown global unity against their savage actions.”

headline: Iraq: Bombings Kill at Least 35 Pilgrims
text: Suicide bombers and car bombs killed at least 35 Shiite pilgrims and wounded dozens more in attacks in Baghdad on Thursday, security officials said. The pilgrims were on their way to the shrine of a Shiite saint in Kadhimiya, in northern Baghdad, to commemorate the anniversary of his death. A day earlier, Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki urged the security forces to protect pilgrims traveling to the shrine. The deadliest attack took place in the Ur neighborhood of eastern Baghdad, where a car bomb exploded near a tent for pilgrims, killing 14 people, including four children, security officials said. “We need a new government that is able to protect us from those terrorists that are the enemies of God,” said a man wounded in the Ur bombing, Jafar al-Musawi. An attack in central Baghdad by a suicide bomber killed 12 pilgrims and wounded 26, and in the western Baghdad neighborhood of Mansour, a car bomb killed nine people and wounded 20, officials said.

headline: Guatemala: Ex-President Sentenced
text: Former President Alfonso Portillo was sentenced in Federal District Court in Manhattan on Thursday to nearly six years in prison for conspiring with others to launder millions of dollars through United States bank accounts, federal prosecutors said. Mr. Portillo, 62, who was extradited to the United States in May 2013 after fighting extradition for three years, pleaded guilty in March before Judge Robert P. Patterson Jr. In court on Thursday, speaking through an interpreter, he apologized and said that he felt “profoundly remorseful and embarrassed,” adding, “God and history will know whether I was a good or bad man during my time on this earth,” The Associated Press reported.

headline: Nod, Smile and Wave While You Can (Wink!)
text: MELVILLE, N.Y. — Kathy Hochul bounded up the stairs to the podium, full of vim, vigor and enthusiasm. She’d just been nominated as the Democratic candidate for lieutenant governor, replacing our current Lt. Gov. What’shisname.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Friday, May 23, 2014
text: “There was a huge financial crisis that rocked the world, and it didn’t matter to us if the frauds occurred within the four corners of our district or around the globe.”

headline: Recalling a Title Run and Trying to Stop One
text: Like so many others his age in the New York region, Max Pacioretty became a Rangers fan during the spring of 1994 as the team surged to a title.

headline: Sinkhole Can’t Stop the Pastrami
text: A water main break on Thursday morning flooded the street outside Katz’s Delicatessen, on East Houston Street at Ludlow Street in Manhattan, causing a large sinkhole to form.

headline: Struggling Mets Stand Up to an Ace
text: As Zack Greinke took the mound for the Los Angeles Dodgers on Thursday night, he did not look especially intimidating. He was not particularly tall. He was not overly muscular. His face looked boyish as he paced around the mound, kicked at the dirt, toed the rubber and stared down the first batter.

headline: Obama to Nominate Julián Castro as HUD Secretary
text: CHICAGO — President Obama on Friday will nominate Mayor Julián Castro of San Antonio to be the secretary of housing and urban development, a White House official said Thursday.

headline: Suzuki Would Relish a Chance to Pitch One More Time
text: CHICAGO — On Wednesday, for the first time since 1970, the Yankees used 21 players in a game before the Sept. 1 expansion of rosters to 40 players. They used every position player and every relief pitcher in the 13-inning game. Only the four other starting pitchers did not play.

headline: A Speaker Who May Have Less of a Say
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: Fraud Unit Gone, Some Fear Increased Fuel Tax Evasion
text: Piqued last year over the refusal by the Travis County district attorney, Rosemary Lehmberg, to resign after her drunken driving arrest, Gov. Rick Perry exercised his veto and withheld more than $7.5 million in state money from her office’s public integrity unit.

headline: A Longer, Costlier Grind for Primary Candidates
text: The primary runoff contests on Tuesday might be as much a test of voter memories as a referendum on which candidates made the most successful appeals to the electorate.

headline: Gerald M. Edelman, Nobel Laureate and ‘Neural Darwinist,’ Dies at 84
text: Dr. Gerald M. Edelman, who shared a 1972 Nobel Prize for a breakthrough in immunology and went on to contribute key findings in neuroscience and other fields, becoming a leading if contentious theorist on the workings of the brain, died on Saturday at his home in the La Jolla section of San Diego. He was 84.

headline: Allan Folsom, Whose First Novel Sold for $2 Million, Dies at 72
text: Allan Folsom, a struggling screenwriter whose first novel, an intricate thriller called “The Day After Tomorrow,” was by some accounts the highest-priced fiction debut in publishing history when its rights sold for $2 million in 1993, died on May 16 in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 72.

headline: Catherine M. Abate, 66, a State Senator and Corrections Chief, Dies
text: Catherine M. Abate, a former New York state senator and commissioner of New York City’s Correction Department whose campaign for attorney general was derailed by questions about her father’s connection to organized crime, died on Saturday in Manhattan. She was 66.

headline: Ask Well: For Fitness, 2,000 Calories a Week?
text: Question:

headline: Word of the Day | predetermine
text: predetermine •\pri-di-ˈtər-mən\• verb

headline: Rangers’ March to Stanley Cup Turns Wobbly
text: Greasy goals, they are called in hockey parlance — goals that bounce in off skates and bodies, goals that are not pretty.

headline: A Dominant Return Sinks the Yankees
text: CHICAGO — As Chris Sale worked his way almost effortlessly through Yankee after flailing Yankee, a curious notion began to take shape.

headline: With an Early Hit, the Canadiens’ Agitator Restores Feistiness to a Series
text: There were players skating on the Madison Square Garden ice Thursday night whose best assets were their booming slap shots, or their effortless skating strides, or their soft hands around the net.

headline: Times Minute | Facebook Privacy Moves
text: Also on the Minute, the latest N.S.A. bill is weaker than expected, and A.O Scott reviews “X-Men: Days of Future Past.”

headline: Times Minute | Facebook Privacy Moves
text: In the Video

headline: Corrections: May 23, 2014
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Billionaire Leader of ‘Mafia-Style’ Gang Sentenced to Die
text: A Chinese tycoon and his brother have been sentenced to death for murder and running a “mafia-style” gang that engaged in a two-decade crime spree, accumulating a business empire amounting to more than $6 billion.

headline: Swedish Cable Company Hopes to Raise $830 Million in I.P.O.
text: LONDON – The Swedish cable company Com Hem Holding said on Friday that it was seeking to raise about $830 million in an initial public offering on the Nasdaq OMX Stockholm exchange.

headline: Boeing Agrees to Acquire British Aviation Software Firm
text: LONDON – The aircraft maker Boeing said on Friday that it had agreed to acquire ETS Aviation, a provider of fuel-efficiency management and analytics software.

headline: A Conversation With: Meena Menon, The Hindu’s Former Correspondent in Pakistan
text: On May 13, the only two Indian journalists in Pakistan, Snehesh Alex Philip of the Press Trust of India and Meena Menon of The Hindu, were told by the country’s Ministry of Information that their visas would not be renewed and that they would have to leave Pakistan in a week.

headline: Okinawa Mayor Takes Fight Against U.S. Base to Washington
text: WASHINGTON — To some, the long-stalled agreement to relocate a United States Marine base from a heavily populated area of Okinawa, Japan, to a smaller city might finally be seeing the light of day. During his visit to Japan in April, Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel said, “We look forward to the facility’s construction beginning soon.” A few weeks later at a news conference in Tokyo, President Obama and Prime Minister Shinzo Abe agreed that progress had been made.

headline: Britain’s Discontent Lifts Populist Party to Even Stronger Vote Tally Than Expected
text: LONDON — Voters in Britain sent a forceful message of discontent to established political parties on Friday, as returns from local elections showed an even stronger following than expected for the anti-European Union, anti-immigration United Kingdom Independence Party.

headline: Test Yourself | Editing Practice, May 23, 2014
text: Take the Quiz

headline: A Scholarly Response to ‘Tiger Mom': Happiness Matters, Too
text: It’s a joke among parents in Beijing — where people are acutely aware of the differences between China and the United States and where there are many mixed-culture families and styles of parenting — that when a child scores 99 on a test, an American parent will lavish praise. But a Chinese parent will say: “What happened? Why didn’t you get 100?”

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Young Iranians Arrested for Being Too ‘Happy in Tehran’
text: In “Young Iranians Arrested for Being Too ‘Happy in Tehran,’ ” Robert Mackey reports on the YouTube video that landed six Iranians in jail.

headline: Saga, Seller of Insurance and Travel Packages, Raises $928 Million in I.P.O.
text: LONDON – Saga, the British seller of insurance, travel packages and other products aimed at people over 50 years old, said Friday that it raised about $928 million in its initial public offering on the London Stock Exchange.

headline: Can Students at Your School Talk Openly About Their Mental Health Issues?
text: Two students published an Op-Ed essay in The New York Times on Thursday about the difficulty they had trying to foster an open and honest dialogue about depression in their high school.

headline: The Pool Photographer, Literally
text: What traveler hasn’t gotten off a plane after a long flight and, suddenly trying to adjust to a warm climate, thought about a dip in the water?

headline: German Photographer Wins Prix Pictet
text: LONDON — Waiters passed around glasses of champagne in the grand atrium of the Victoria and Albert Museum here on Wednesday night as Kofi Annan, the former secretary general of the United Nations, announced that the German photographer Michael Schmidt had won this year’s Prix Pictet, an award that asks photographers to contribute work centered on an environmental or social theme.

headline: After Urumqi Bloodshed, China Warns of Increasing Threat of Terrorism
text: As China reels from its deadliest terrorist attack in recent memory, officials and the state news media acknowledged that the frequency of such assaults had grown and called for greater preparedness to deal with the threat of violence against civilians.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: New York Today:  Memorial Day, Writ Small
text: Good morning to you on this damp Friday.

headline: Syrian Rebels Claim Attack on Assad Supporters
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Rebels in southern Syria killed more than 20 people in a mortar attack on a tent put up as part of presidential elections next month, antigovernment activists said on Friday.

headline: Atlas Mara to Acquire Majority Stake in Arm of Rwandan Bank
text: LONDON – The investment company Atlas Mara Co-Nvest, backed by Robert E. Diamond Jr., the former Barclays chief executive, said on Friday that it had agreed to acquire a majority stake in the commercial arm of the Development Bank of Rwanda.

headline: Regulator Fines Barclays Over the Pricing of Gold
text: Updated, 7:53 p.m. | A British financial regulator has fined Barclays $43.9 million after accusing a former trader at the bank of improperly influencing gold prices at the expense of a customer.

headline: North Korea to Send Team to South Korea for Asian Games
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea said on Friday that it would send a delegation to the Asian Games in the South Korean city of Incheon this autumn.

headline: Speaking Their Minds
text: Anger is at the forefront of Sunday’s European Parliament elections.

headline: Daily Report: U.S. Indictments Shed Some Light on China’s Hacker Army
text: One man accused of being a hacker for the Chinese military, Wang Dong, better known as UglyGorilla, wrote in a social media profile that he did not “have much ambition” but wanted “to wander the world with a sword, an idiot,” Edward Wong reports.

headline: Q. and A.: Gardner Bovingdon on Uighur Discontent and China’s Choices
text: Thursday morning a series of explosions ripped through a crowded market in Urumqi, capital of the northwestern region of Xinjiang, killing 31 people and injuring 94. The incident was labeled a “violent terrorist attack,” and President Xi Jinping vowed to “severely punish terrorists and spare no efforts in maintaining stability.” It was the deadliest incident in Xinjiang this year, and it follows a series of attacks across the country carried out by members of the region’s Uighur ethnic minority, some of whom want Xinjiang to break off from China to become an independent East Turkestan.

headline: Thai Military Detains Ousted Leaders as Coup Sets Off Small Acts of Protest
text: BANGKOK — Former Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra and leading members of Thailand’s deposed government surrendered to the military on Friday after being summoned by the generals now leading the country.

headline: On Our Walls
text: The walls of The New York Times headquarters on Eighth Avenue are decorated with news images from the past. Prints by photojournalists hang throughout the building. In this Insider series, On Our Walls, we’ll take you inside the building to see the photographs — many of them rich in history — and the stories behind them.

headline: Are We Ready for H.I.V.’s Sexual Revolution?
text: PRETEND it’s 1960, and the Food and Drug Administration has just done something startling. It has taken a drug it had previously approved for infertility — brand name Enovid — and approved it for the opposite use: birth control.

headline: For Apartment Dwellers, a Memorial Day Barbecue in a Glass
text: It’s Memorial Day weekend, which marks the official start of barbecue season. But as my colleague Neil Irwin has noted, the recent uptick in housing construction is almost entirely about apartment construction. That means, in coming years, a declining percentage of American households will have a backyard to grill in.

headline: As Publishers Fight Amazon, Books Vanish
text: Amazon’s power over the publishing and bookselling industries is unrivaled in the modern era. Now it has started wielding its might in a more brazen way than ever before.

headline: The Brotherhood Will Be Back
text: WASHINGTON — After being ousted from power last July, Egypt’s Muslim Brotherhood, the Arab world’s original Islamist movement, faces an existential moment. The group has been targeted with extreme repression, prompting a wave of commentary about the failure — or even death — of political Islam.

headline: In Our Pages: May 24
text: 1939: Queen Mary’s Limousine Hit

headline: December 2011 Political Awareness Quiz
text: In research about voters who split their tickets, Lynn Vavrek came up with a quiz to test political awareness. These questions, which were fielded in December 2011, asked a representative sample of 45,000 people about legislative and executive branch leaders. Her article is here.

headline: The Power of Political Ignorance
text: Split-ticket voting is quite rare for top offices like president and senator. But those who do choose candidates from different parties on Election Day have at least one thing in common: They know less about politics than people who vote the straight party line.

headline: Class Field Trip Stops at a Local Pawnshop
text: READING, Ohio — The last time Brian Page had to file the paperwork to evict a tenant from a rental property he and his wife own, he noticed all the check-cashing services and pawn shops on his drive home from the courthouse. A clerk tipped him off to what was going on: Every day, lots of people leave court with checks they’ve received in legal settlements. They often stop to cash their checks right away, paying a big fee for the privilege, and then go shopping with the money.

headline: Research on Malaria-Resistant Children in Tanzania Leads to Promising New Vaccine Target
text: The quest for effective malaria vaccines has been long and challenging, so it’s important not to overplay a single study. But there is real promise in fresh findings reported by researchers in Science today. The work centers on a parasite protein, named PfSEA-1 by the authors, that was isolated after analysis of blood samples in resistant and susceptible Tanzanian toddlers. Paul Rodgers has a really nice piece on the paper in Forbes. Here’s an excerpt:

headline: U.S. Gains in a Spat With China Over Tariffs
text: WASHINGTON — The World Trade Organization sided with the United States on Friday in a dispute over punitive Chinese tariffs on American exports of cars and sport utility vehicles.

headline: Spinning Country
text: “Dee Jay Silver” spins country music with a unique mix of multiple music genres.

headline: A Hot Start for JD.com
text: JD.COM STARTS HOT  |  The online Chinese retailer JD.com started life as a publicly traded company with a rousing start, closing up 10 percent on the Nasdaq stock exchange on Thursday, DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced writes. At that price, shareholders valued the company at more than $28.6 billion, more than other United States technology names like Twitter and LinkedIn. Shares of the retailer closed at $20.90 for each American depositary receipt.

headline: What’s On Friday
text: 2 A.M. (LMN) WINTER’S BONE (2010) Jennifer Lawrence received her first Oscar nomination for her role as Ree Dolly, a teenager living in the Ozarks of southwestern Missouri who goes in search of her meth-cooking father after he puts up the family home to cover his bail and disappears. But her efforts to find him place her in a terrible dilemma: either betray the code of silence that keeps her clan proudly on the wrong side of the law or face destitution. (Above from left, Ashlee Thompson, Ms. Lawrence and Isaiah Stone in the film.) John Hawkes plays her uncle, whose silent menace soon erupts into violence, though he’s more compassionate than most. The harshness in Debra Granik’s “regional-realist morality tale,” based on the novel by Daniel Woodrell, “is not there to illuminate a sociological condition,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “Something more primal, almost Greek in its archaic power, is at stake in ‘Winter’s Bone,’ and its visual and emotional starkness do not feel like simple badges of authenticity.”

headline: Country Music Opens Its Ears
text: NASHVILLE — About a year and a half ago, as the country superstar Blake Shelton was working on songs for his latest album, “Based on a True Story ,” he reached out to John Esposito, the president of his label, Warner Bros. Nashville.

headline: Celebrating Memorial Day and Looking Ahead
text: A veteran of the Iraq war finds new meaning in Memorial Day.

headline: From Cheap to Cool, Revamped Car Is Aimed at India’s Young Buyers
text: NEW DELHI — When Tata Motors rolled out a supercheap compact vehicle in 2009, the automaker heralded the car saying it would change the lives of millions of Indians, particularly its aspirational middle class. But the egg-shaped car, the Nano, failed to impress and sales have been sluggish, undercut by an image of poor quality and underwhelming power.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘X-Men: Days of Future Past,’ ‘Cold in July’ and ‘Blended’
text: In this week’s video, Times critics review “X-Men: Days of Future Past,” “Cold in July” and “Blended.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: Back to Normal Swedish Teenage Angst
text: Ingmar Bergman, Sweden’s most celebrated auteur, anointed his countryman Lukas Moodysson “a young master.” Mr. Moodysson was a published poet at 17 and, thanks to his first film, “Show Me Love,” was widely considered the new voice of Swedish cinema before he hit 30. Yet he has reacted with a kind of overgrown teenage disdain for the establishment: He has berated and made obscene gestures toward audiences and critics at awards receptions, avoided the press and once declared himself the most hated man in his native country. The guy was a stone punk.

headline: Location Services in Desktop Browsers
text: Q. The web browser on my computer says a site wants to “use my location.” Why, and how does it know where I am, anyway?

headline: In China’s Far West, a City Struggles to Move On
text: URUMQI, China — They were hard-core bargain hunters, gray-haired bus drivers and bureaucrats on modest pensions who woke up early to find the cheapest produce in this increasingly expensive city. For the driver of the sport utility vehicle seeking to maximize the mayhem, they were the easiest of targets.

headline: Being Called a Plain Jane
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Younger Turn for a Graying Nation
text: THERE are now more young adults than there are baby boomers.

headline: Assuming a Role, Putting the Story First
text: Many actors have heard the dreaded question: “How did you learn all of those lines?” But naturally, there is more to a characterization than memorizing sentences and speaking with conviction; the art of acting is mysterious, as difficult to explain as it is to do.

headline: Target’s Newest Designer Collaboration, Instagram’s Latest Offender and Kate Moss’s Little Sister’s Big Modeling Plans
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Elliott Management Backs Skyscraper Revival
text: For decades, the building at 5 Beekman Street — the site of one of Manhattan’s first skyscrapers — went largely unused.

headline: In the Newly Elected Indian Parliament, Worrying Trends
text: Satish Chandra Dubey faces charges including murder, attempted murder, rioting armed with a deadly weapon, robbery, theft and killing or maiming cattle, to name but a few. Mr. Dubey, who is also suspected of involvement in drug smuggling and has previously been charged in a bank robbery, is one of several criminals-turned-politicians in India. He is known as a “bahubali,” or a powerful person.

headline: Got Nerves of Steel? Meet the Thunderbolt Roller Coaster
text: It may resemble a giant Erector set. But the new Thunderbolt roller coaster, which was manufactured in Italy and Slovakia and shipped to New York in pieces, is not child’s play, at least when it comes to assembly.

headline: Lindy Hop: Celebrating Frankie Manning
text: Swing dance enthusiasts from around the world are arriving in New York to celebrate the 100th birthday of the late Frankie Manning, who helped popularize the dance craze Lindy hop.

headline: The Trends that Helped Sweep B.J.P. to Landslide Victory
text: NEW DELHI – Narendra Modi and his Bharatiya Janata Party’s sweeping success in this year’s parliamentary elections has stunned most political observers, who have scrambled to explain it since the results were announced on May 16.

headline: A Resurrection of Eternal Joy
text: For three decades, the album sat on a shelf.

headline: Terrorists With Familiar Faces
text: Explosions and mayhem are a staple of summer blockbusters, whether brought about by hundred-foot robots or averted by superheroes. But what if the people blowing things up have a political agenda — like the radical environmentalists of Kelly Reichardt’s new drama, “Night Moves”? And what if they’re homegrown, not the stereotypical accented villains? Then it gets trickier: Everyone from moviegoers to producers to politicians can become sensitive when the characters are plausible, their politics real and their tactics deadly.

headline: Countdown to the 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 20
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Fire Island Poetry Festival to Honor Frank O’Hara
text: Frank O’Hara, a founder of the New York School of poets, died at age 40 in the summer of 1966, after being hit by a dune buggy on Fire Island. Now, his reputation only burnished by posthumous publications of several collections of his work, the Fire Island Pines Arts Project is sponsoring the first national poetry festival in his honor.

headline: Must the Captain Always Go Down With the Ship?
text: In light of the South Korean ferry tragedy, I have been thinking about the maxim that the captain goes down with the ship. I find it outdated and in need of re-evaluation. Clearly the captain has a duty and responsibility to ensure the safety of his passengers, and he should do everything in his power as the ship is sinking to save the lives of others. But should he be morally obligated to effectively commit suicide because he made a mistake, even if it was a result of gross negligence and leads to hundreds of deaths? RYAN CAIN, NEW YORK

headline: Tom Robbins, Cosmic Lounge Lizard
text: The author talks to Rob Liguori about "Tibetan Peach Pie," the downsides of conventional wisdom and the reason Hunter S. Thompson never had a real LSD trip.

headline: The Doctor Is In
text: Let me give you some free advice: If you give people free advice for a living, think twice before you tell anyone you know about it. Because when people who actually know you find out that you, of all people, are doling out advice, it can get uncomfortable.

headline: The MacGyver Cure for Cancer
text: Two decades ago, David Walmer went on a volunteer mission with his church to Haiti. He was sent to paint walls at a hospital in the seaside town of Léogâne, but when the people there learned that Walmer was a doctor — he was a fertility specialist at Duke University — they asked him to spend the week with a local obstetrician-gynecologist named Jean-Claude Fertilien. Walmer was shocked by what he saw: Fertilien finishing a hysterectomy with the aid of a flashlight when the hospital generator failed to restart, for instance, or when an anesthesiologist wasn’t available for an emergency C-section, the doctor just numbing the skin and cutting. At one point, Walmer was called to the bedside of a young woman in her mid-20s with undiagnosed cervical cancer who had gone into septic shock. There was nothing to be done for her, and she died right in front of him. Walmer was appalled. In the United States, cervical cancer is considered a preventable disease.

headline: Avian Divorce
text: Meh-levators; Judge Hodgman rules on “loud kissing.”

headline: Who Made That Weather Icon?
text: As a design student at the Norwich School of Art in the early 1970s, Mark Allen watched the weather broadcast every afternoon on the BBC. Back then, TV presenters slid magnetic symbols around a metal map: dots for rain, asterisks for snow, lines to mark off areas of equal pressure. “They were just hieroglyphics as far as everybody was concerned,” Allen says. “Why was a triangle a rain shower?”

headline: Reply All: The 5.11.14 Issue
text: WHAT TIMOTHY GEITHNER REALLY THINKS

headline: On Lockdown
text: The “duck and cover” drills of the 1950s, when American schoolchildren crawled under their desks in preparation for a nuclear bomb, have given way to regular lockdown drills in many states to counter the threat of school shootings. The photographer Alec Soth recently visited the Belle Plaine public high school, an hour outside Minneapolis, to witness its routine. When the principal announced that a lockdown was in effect, classroom doors were quickly locked; students who were in the middle of gym class moved to locker rooms and secured the doors behind them. For several minutes, they sat on the floor, heads lowered. “It was pretty silent,” Soth says. “They were fairly nonchalant about the whole routine.” Julie Bosman

headline: Can the Nervous System Be Hacked?
text: One morning in May 1998, Kevin Tracey converted a room in his lab at the Feinstein Institute for Medical Research in Manhasset, N.Y., into a makeshift operating theater and then prepped his patient — a rat — for surgery. A neurosurgeon, and also Feinstein Institute’s president, Tracey had spent more than a decade searching for a link between nerves and the immune system. His work led him to hypothesize that stimulating the vagus nerve with electricity would alleviate harmful inflammation. “The vagus nerve is behind the artery where you feel your pulse,” he told me recently, pressing his right index finger to his neck.

headline: Joyce’s Town
text: In 1905, James Joyce wrote to the publisher Grant Richards: “I do not think that any writer has yet presented Dublin to the world. It has been a capital of Europe for thousands of years, it is supposed to be the second city of the British Empire, and it is nearly three times as big as Venice.”

headline: True Crime
text: LITTLE DEMON IN THE CITY OF LIGHT  A True Story of Murder and Mesmerism in Belle Époque Paris  By Steven Levingston  Doubleday, $26.95.

headline: Paperback Row
text: FLORA,  by Gail Godwin. (Bloomsbury, $16.) It’s the summer of 1945, and the still, humid days are fraught with impending consequence in Godwin’s 14th novel. Isolated in a decaying family home in North Carolina, two lonesome souls — motherless, 10-year-old Helen and her hopelessly earnest guardian, Flora — wait out a polio scare while Helen’s father is off doing secret war work in Oak Ridge, Tenn.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THE POSSIBILITIES,  by Kaui Hart Hemmings. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) Hemmings’s first novel since “The Descendants” is about learning to move forward, as a Colorado woman struggles with grief over her son’s death in an avalanche.

headline: On the Road Again
text: Much like smell (it’s all very well to say that something smells “like an orange,” but how do you describe the smell of an orange?), music is notoriously difficult to evoke on the page. The fact that language has musical attributes — rhythm, melody, tone — isn’t much help when you’re trying to express Bartok or Captain Beefheart in words. Even when music has lyrics, its essence is antilanguage, or at least in another language — and an inability to translate explains why so many album and concert reviews are unreadable. Thus Stacey D’Erasmo’s most impressive accomplishment in her fourth novel, “Wonderland,” is to write about music well.

headline: By the Booker
text: Edward St. Aubyn is that thing beloved by heritage series from the BBC, a man of ancient and aristocratic pedigree. He writes of an upper-class world so central to the English novel of the 19th and early 20th centuries, it has shaped the modern imagination: You might think we all sprang from big houses with handmade wallpaper and quietly smoldering servants. St. Aubyn cuts through the fantasy of privilege, however, with lacerating precision; once you have read his Melrose cycle of novels, there is no going back. These books — “Never Mind,” “Bad News,” “Some Hope,” “Mother’s Milk” and “At Last” — set a marker in the English tradition by changing our view of what preceded them. The narrator, Patrick Melrose, is raped at the age of 5 by his sadistic, patrician father and later partially disinherited by his cold and foolish mother. After Melrose, the aristocratic novel, from Richardson’s swooning “Pamela” to the affectless cruelties of Waugh, can never look the same again.

headline: Please Turn to the Chapter on Obscurity . . .
text: The woman at the counter in Barnes & Noble had silver hair in a bun and a smile like breakfast. I was with a friend, for whom I was buying a copy of my latest book. I do this often — buy my own books for friends, then wonder why I’m broke. “May I take a moment to sign it?” I asked the smiling woman. “Did you write it?” she asked. “No,” I said. “I just like signing books.” Unmoved, she asked, “Is this your first book?” I shook my head no, and continued inscribing. “It must be fun to write books,” she said. “Superfun,” I said.

headline: A Celebration of the Lindy Hop’s Founder
text: Jana Grulichová came from Barcelona, Spain. Alevtina Kapusta came from Kiev, the Ukrainian capital. Veno Hirosuke, who in this context prefers to be known as Amore, came from Tokyo.

headline: Irrational Rash
text: Every doctor told her it was eczema, but why wasn’t it responding to treatment?

headline: Wedding Q. and A.
text: Done in the Sun?

headline: Billionaire Boys Club
text: In 2010, two of the Koch brothers, Charles of Wichita, Kan., and David of New York, rather suddenly became the top-of-mind conservatives for American liberals. That was partly because at that moment the Democratic Party controlled the White House and both houses of Congress, so there wasn’t a dominant conservative politician to focus on; partly because of a wave of news media attention, notably an influential story on the Kochs’ political activities by Jane Mayer in The New Yorker; and partly because of the rise of the Tea Party movement, of which the Koch political apparatus was a primary backer. The conservative victories in the Congres­sional elections that fall looked like conclusive proof of the Kochs’ power. The very first television ads the Obama re-election campaign ran in 2012 were attacks on the Kochs, not on the Republican Party.

headline: Wielding the Knife
text: At its best, food is a sensory pleasure that also fosters less tangible joys. At its worst, to paraphrase one of the many vivid characters in Simon Wroe’s first novel, “Chop Chop,” watching someone eat is like watching a body convert food to waste right in front of your eyes. The character phrases it less delicately, but many of the book’s funniest moments — and they are plentiful — are also its most unprintable.

headline: Hive Mentality
text: Laline Paull’s ambitious and bold first novel, “The Bees,” follows Flora 717, a sanitation worker doomed by her birth to the lowest caste of her community. She is large and ugly and — oh, yes — a bee. What could feel gimmicky or cute never does; Flora 717 is a brave and spirited soul, and it is a pleasure to follow her through the hive and the air. The brief prologue and epilogue are the only sections of the book with humans, aside from a single scene halfway through in which a man harvesting honey comes off something like Godzilla. Truly, who needs people when bees provide this much pathos?

headline: Britain Proposes Easier Access to Tap Shale Rock Energy
text: LONDON — While most western European governments are opposed to developing oil and gas from shale rock through hydraulic fracturing, the British government continues to plug away at the obstacles inhibiting the country’s fledgling shale industry.

headline: Man With Many Qualities
text: On Page 92 of the slate-gray third volume of the six-part Norwegian novel “My Struggle,” by Karl Ove Knausgaard — an autobiographical work that offers detailed accounts of events like the teenage Karl Ove trying to sneak alcohol to a New Year’s party (Book 1), the paternal Karl Ove attending a children’s birthday party (Book 2) and the child Karl Ove eating, on two different occasions, cornflakes (Book 3) — we learn that the headmaster of Karl Ove’s grade school was a diver who discovered a slave ship sunk off Norway’s coast in 1768.

headline: The Things She Carries
text: When a soldier on the battlefield shoots an innocent civilian, what goes through his or, in this case, her mind? What did she see between the cross hairs, or hear or sense that made her feel she had to pull the trigger, and what becomes of her ­afterward?

headline: Writer’s Retreat
text: A doctoral dissertation not getting written is never just a doctoral dissertation not getting written. It’s always a stand-in for something more consequential (take it from a former grad student who knows). But when we encounter Cressida (Cress) Hartley, the protagonist of Michelle Huneven’s fourth novel, “Off Course,” she doesn’t realize this yet. In fact, she has just persuaded her parents to allow her to live in their vacation cabin in California’s Sierra Nevada for “three months free and clear,” so that she can “bang . . . out” her dissertation in economics. The 28-year-old, high-achieving Cress comes from cautious, stingy stock, a foundation that gives her a natural aptitude for her field: Her father is a “traumatized victim of the Great Depression,” and his “fears and obsessions had imprinted her with thought patterns that, superficially at least, were indistinguishable from the mind-set of a trained economist: What is given up to get this? What is the true cost? Whose self-interest is going to ­prevail?”

headline: Problem Child
text: It’s not that the protagonist of Susanna Kaysen’s novel “Cambridge,” a 1950s elementary-school student also named Susanna, is trying to be difficult. It’s just that getting in the way of herself and others comes so naturally. Bright, sensitive and deeply neurotic, Susanna sees “malevolence” in certain toilets and thinks, as she shucks corn in advance of a dinner with adored family friends, “Something about corn was sad.” Visiting famous monuments sends her into an existential tailspin, and by the time she’s 9 she’s already mourning her lost youth. At school, she’s bored and disdainful. When her sixth-grade teacher gives examples of solids, liquids and gases, Susanna raises her hand to ask, “What about mayonnaise?”

headline: And ... They’re Off (Fingers Crossed)
text: It is easy to spot California Chrome on the racetrack as the sun glistens off his chestnut body and white blaze face. It is even easier to spot him in the barn, when his leg wrappings are removed and his four white feet, or socks in horse parlance, are exposed.

headline: Putin Indicates He’ll Respect Result of Ukrainian Election
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — Addressing an economic forum haunted by the prospect of more sanctions against Russia, President Vladimir V. Putin on Friday gave his clearest indication yet that he would work with the winner of this weekend’s presidential election in Ukraine.

headline: HSBC, Like Rivals, Hears Earful on Banker Pay at Annual Meeting
text: Updated, 12:03 p.m. | LONDON – Banker pay has been a hotly debated topic among shareholders at annual meetings in Europe this year, particularly in Britain.

headline: The Transformative Power of Transparency
text: Doctors don’t traditionally apologize for medical errors; in fact, they usually don’t even disclose them. That is why I have long been interested in how the University of Michigan Health Systems has bucked tradition with its Michigan Model, a collaborative and transparent approach to patient safety and medical mistakes.

headline: An Inconvenient Past
text: During the night of June 3-4, 1989, when the Chinese Army was slaughtering demonstrators in Tiananmen Square, Wang Nan, a young student, was shot in the head. As he lay dying at the side of the road, soldiers threatened to kill anyone, even some young doctors, who tried to help him. In the morning, finally dead, he was buried in a shallow grave nearby. A few days later, the smell of Wang Nan’s body was so great that it was dug up and moved to a hospital.

headline: Foreign Affair
text: There’s a scene in “My Accidental Jihad” in which Krista Bremer visits her husband’s relatives in Libya and sees a wheezing, skeletal old woman lying on a hospital bed in their living room.

headline: Inside the List
text: Dog Days: Jeffery Deaver’s new Lincoln Rhyme thriller, “The Skin Collector,” makes its debut on the hardcover fiction list at No. 8. Part of the perverse allure of this series — which now numbers some dozen books — has always come from the demented nature of its villains, and “The Skin Collector” is no exception: It features a ­serial-killing tattoo artist who makes his own ink out of a slow-acting and painful poison. But a person can spend only so many hours a day inventing gruesome murder schemes, and one of the ways Deaver likes to unwind is by breeding show dogs with a business partner near his North Carolina home. “I’m not as creepy as the things I write about,” he told The Associated Press in 2007. That doesn’t mean you can’t question his priorities — he once passed up dinner with Angelina Jolie to tend to a dog’s matted coat. But Deaver knows what he’s doing: His briards have won Best of Breed more than once at the Westminster Kennel Club show in New York. “Your heart’s pounding,” he told a reporter in 2005, comparing the experience to that of a father watching a Little League game. “You’ll still love the dog just as much if he doesn’t win. But I can’t help it. I hope he wins.” Given the elaborate plot twists and psychological head games in his novels, is Deaver ever tempted to mess with his dogs’ minds, just a little? “I couldn’t possibly do that,” he told The Sun Herald newspaper in Australia in 2006. “The dogs are much cleverer than me.”

headline: Ghosts of Hanoi
text: In “Boat Story,” the first offering from “The Frangipani Hotel,” Violet Kupersmith’s subversively clever debut collection, a teenage girl in Houston, from a family of Vietnam War refugees, asks her grandmother to recount her sea journey to the United States for a school assignment. “Communists! Thai pirates! Starvation!” the girl says. “That’s an A-plus story.”

headline: As Summer Driving Beckons, Gas Prices Are All Over the Map
text: HOUSTON — With the Memorial Day weekend representing the beginning of the summer driving season, it might be a good time to plan a trip to the Gulf Coast or the Rocky Mountains. Gasoline prices in the nation’s midsection should be 10 to 50 cents cheaper per gallon than a year ago.

headline: Guantánamo Inmate’s Case Reignites Fight Over Detentions
text: WASHINGTON — The seemingly unending struggle over Guantánamo Bay — the prison President Obama vowed to close shortly after he was sworn in — is again reverberating over an “anguishing” case of force-feeding a Syrian detainee.

headline: Celebrating Frankie Manning and the Lindy Hop
text: Swing dance enthusiasts from around the world are arriving in New York to celebrate the 100th birthday of the late Frankie Manning, who helped popularize the dance craze the Lindy hop.

headline: Celebrating Frankie Manning and the Lindy Hop
text: Swing dance enthusiasts from around the world are arriving in New York to celebrate the 100th birthday of the late Frankie Manning, who helped popularize the dance craze the Lindy hop.

headline: Today in Small Business: The Rest of America
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Baseball’s Role in J.F.K.’s Life
text: Here a frail 28-year-old John F. Kennedy, still not fully recovered from injuries sustained in 1943 when his PT-109 was struck by a Japanese destroyer in World War II, poses at Fenway Park in Boston in April 1946 with Ted Williams and Eddie Pellagrini of the Red Sox and Hank Greenberg of the Detroit Tigers. The neophyte J.F.K. is about to face nine opponents in a Democratic congressional primary — and he is seeking the reflected glory of being seen in the proximity of baseball stars.

headline: Strangers Come to the Village
text: Great film stylists still roam the earth. For evidence, look no further than the Iranian director Abbas Kiarostami, whose lovely, oblique movie “The Wind Will Carry Us” is being shown at IFC Center, beginning Friday, in honor of its 15th anniversary.

headline: A Desperate Mother’s Search Leads to a Fight Against Sex Trafficking
text: SAN MIGUEL DE TUCUMÁN, Argentina — HERE in the impoverished north of Argentina, sex traffickers search among the vulnerable for targets. Typically, they lure women with deceitful job offers and then traffic them to big cities, mining towns and agricultural regions, where they are forced into sex slavery.

headline: Judge Rules That Harper Lee Can Renew Suit Against Museum
text: The wheels of justice apparently turn quickly in Alabama. When lawyers for Harper Lee filed to reinstate her lawsuit against the Monroe County Heritage Museum for what she says is the unauthorized marketing of merchandise based on her 1960 novel, “To Kill a Mockingbird,” a federal judge said that he needed more information. (The lawyers sought to reinstate the suit because, they said, the museum was backtracking on an out-of-court agreement reached in February.)

headline: No MetroCard Needed
text: It was cheaper rent that initially drew Jesse Warner-Levine, 34, and Hallie Nickelson, 33, to Wallabout, a fairly isolated Brooklyn neighborhood on the fringe of Clinton Hill near the Brooklyn Navy Yard. But it was bicycling that made them stay.

headline: Hague Court Sentences Congolese Warlord to 12 Years for Role in Tribal Massacre
text: PARIS — The International Criminal Court in The Hague sentenced a Congolese militia leader, Germain Katanga, on Friday to 12 years in prison for his role in an attack on a village in 2003 where, within hours, more than 200 civilians were shot or hacked to death, limb by limb.

headline: After Hours | A Family-Style Fete to Honor Robert Longo
text: The New York artist Robert Longo may be most famous for his black-and-white Men in the Cities images of the early ’80s — which became such icons of yuppiedom that they appeared in Patrick Bateman’s apartment in the film adaptation of “American Psycho.” Like other New York art-world royalty, including Cindy Sherman, Philip Glass, Bill T. Jones, Laurie Anderson and Vito Acconci, he has long been a champion of the 43-year-old arts space The Kitchen, where he worked as a video curator for four years beginning in 1977.

headline: New Online Magazine Honors the Mighty Schwa
text: The schwa — the vowel sound at the end of the word “America,” represented in dictionary pronunciation guides with a backward and upside down “e” (ə) — is the most common vowel sound in the English language. And now it is also the namesake of a new online magazine about language and life.

headline: Cannes Film Festival: A Movie That Challenges Putin
text: CANNES — The Russian director Andrey Zvyagintsev’s latest film, “Leviathan,” tells the story of Kolia, a man fighting to keep his seaside house in a justice system all but beholden to a corrupt local mayor. The family drama can be read as the story of Job filtered through Chekhov, but also as a scathing indictment of Russia under President Vladimir Putin.

headline: In Chicago, a Dramatic Expansion of the Riverwalk
text: In an effort to bring people together near the city’s “second shoreline,” Chicago has begun updates to its original Riverwalk with certain sections expected to be completed by summer 2015.

headline: Feeding the Financial District
text: If you’ve spent any time in Lower Manhattan and had a cappuccino at a patisserie, a 10-inch pie at a pizza place, or a pint of Guinness in a wood-paneled pub, chances are you were patronizing an establishment owned by Peter Poulakakos.

headline: Traveling with Elderly Parents
text: Caring for an aging parent can be stressful. And one thing that could help — a long-needed vacation — sometimes only adds to the stress.

headline: Never Mind Stocks. Just Buy the Company.
text: AFTER years of litigation against the side of his family that controlled his grandfather’s coffee business, Steven D. Crowe woke up on New Year’s Day 2004 with a lot of money in the bank — $111 million, according to reports at the time. Having developed and managed real estate for decades, he said he knew little about the stock market, so he invested the money broadly for his mother and sister and his own family.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Saga of the Koch Brothers
text: This week, Nicholas Lemann discusses “Sons of Wichita”; Parul Sehgal and John Williams on the week’s literary news; Louisa Lim talks about “The People’s Republic of Amnesia: Tiananmen Revisited”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Blueberries for All
text: I’ve been saving up blueberry recipes. I know that blueberries won’t show up in farmers’ markets in northern states until mid-June, but there are plenty now available in supermarkets from places like Georgia, which grows 10 percent of the nation’s crop. In California, where blueberry production is a recent thing, begun successfully only in the 1990s, the harvest started in February. So I’ve been biding my time.

headline: Women Alert to Travel’s Darker Side
text: Between sun-seared shrubs and the collapsed remains of Istanbul’s Byzantine city walls, police found the body of an American tourist, Sarai Sierra, 33, in February 2013. Ms. Sierra, a New Yorker and a first-time traveler abroad, disappeared after near-constant contact with her family for two weeks. What happened to her is still a little unclear, but a Turkish man has reportedly confessed to killing her after supposedly trying to kiss her.

headline: U.N. Panel Says Vatican Is Lax Over Abusive Priests
text: GENEVA — The Vatican on Friday faced criticism from a United Nations panel for the second time this year over failures to report priests accused of sexually abusing children to civil authorities or to ensure redress for victims.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Saga of the Koch Brothers
text: This week, Nicholas Lemann and Louisa Lim.

headline: Amazon Unveils Children’s Show
text: Amazon’s deliberate rollout of original online series — comedy series in November, drama pilots in February — continued Friday with the posting of six episodes of its first children’s series, “Tumble Leaf.” The initial episode is free from Amazon Instant Video while the other five require a Prime membership.

headline: At French Open, a Rare Early Meeting Is Possible for the Williams Sisters
text: PARIS — Rafael Nadal, an eight-time winner of the French Open, cringed and smiled nervously as the 25th chip he pulled at the draw ceremony for the women’s singles tournament at Roland Garros set up 29th-seeded Venus Williams into a possible third-round meeting with her sister Serena, the top seed and defending champion.

headline: A Health Nominee Who Can Disarm Republicans
text: Now that Sylvia Mathews Burwell, President Obama’s nominee to head the embattled Department of Health and Human Services, has been endorsed by a bi-partisan majority of one Senate committee and treated cordially by another, the full Senate ought to vote promptly to confirm her nomination. She is extremely well-qualified to handle the department’s most pressing administrative tasks and seems able to reach consensus with, or at least disarm and charm, Republican opponents who are often adamantly opposed to cooperating in any way with the Obama administration.

headline: Pea Salad With Creamy Cheese
text: Melissa Clark makes a salad that is the perfect balance between freshness and richness, featuring crunchy sugar snap peas, pea shoots and ripe, runny cheese.

headline: Peas Love Cheese, and Vice Versa
text: File this under the easiest party recipes you’ll ever make: Take a runny, stinky, washed-rind cheese, scrape the top off with a spoon, then serve the oozing disk as a dip with raw sugar snap peas on the side. It requires about five minutes of effort if you trim the peas (fancy), two minutes if you don’t (rustic). It’s a dish more about shopping than cooking, but the result is voluptuous, unexpected and impossible to stop eating.

headline: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
text: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

headline: A Rare Capitol Hill Sighting: The Legislative Process
text: On Thursday the Senate did something remarkable: it passed a conference report to a bill.

headline: Book Review Podcast: The Saga of the Koch Brothers
text: In The New York Times Book Review, Nicholas Lemann reviews Daniel Schulman’s “Sons of Wichita: How the Koch Brothers Became America’s Most Powerful and Private Dynasty.” Mr. Lemann writes:

headline: Image of the Day: May 23
text: Sikhs celebrated the 535th anniversary of the birth of Guru Amardas, the third master of the Sikhs.

headline: Together Again to Go the Distance
text: On a summer day in 1981, Ray Mancini attended a pool party at the home of Tina Rozzi in Campbell, Ohio.

headline: Apax Partners Selling Majority Stake in Travelex Group
text: LONDON – Funds advised by the private equity firm Apax Partners are selling their majority stake in the Travelex Group, a foreign exchange specialist, to a group led by the billionaire Bavaguthu Raghuram Shetty, Apax said Friday.

headline: European Regulators to Start Inquiry Into eBay Data Breach
text: LONDON — The fallout from the data breach at eBay has reached Europe.

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: HP’s Whitman on PC Decline and Job Cuts
text: Hewlett-Packard, until recently the world’s largest technology company in terms of revenue, released tepid quarterly results on Thursday. They showed a once industry-leading computer maker continuing to limp along in a world increasingly defined by smartphones and cloud computing.

headline: In Era of Humble Pope, Earth Shifts Under Cardinal Dolan
text: Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan lives in a 19th-century Madison Avenue mansion that connects to St. Patrick’s Cathedral. A cook and two housekeepers serve him and three other priests. A driver chauffeurs him around, though in a Chrysler minivan.

headline: Praise Poems: Ellen Bass Talks About ‘Like a Beggar’
text: Ellen Bass’s new poetry collection, “Like a Beggar” (Copper Canyon), pulses with sex, humor and compassion. Ms. Bass takes her cues as a poet, and as a person, from Rilke, whom she quotes to open “Beggar”: “But those dark, deadly, devastating ways,/how do you bear them, suffer them?/— I praise.” Her poetry, and this book in particular, fairly bursts with such praise. Below are edited excerpts from an email conversation with Ms. Bass about poetry and more.

headline: U.N. Chief Urges Aid Delivery Without Syria’s Consent
text: UNITED NATIONS — The Syrian government is “failing in its responsibility to look after its own people,” the secretary general of the United Nations has said in a confidential report to the Security Council, in which he urged it to authorize the delivery of food and medicine to Syria without the government’s consent.

headline: A Farewell, With Beer and Pizza
text: Some people’s version of culinary heaven is tournedos of beef with a supple cabernet at a white-clothed table under candlelight. Others might prefer the offerings at the new Fornino restaurant in Brooklyn Bridge Park: thin-crust pizza and local beer at a picnic table with a view of New York Harbor. On a roof deck, just across the water from Manhattan, this latest outpost of the Brooklyn pizza franchise — its sister shops are in Williamsburg and Greenpoint — has already proved popular with visitors to the park, which opened its manufactured beach and pop-up pool on May 22. On a recent evening, the place was crowded with frolicking families, post-work drinkers and a large party from the Brooklyn Bridge Park Corporation celebrating the imminent departure of one its workers.

headline: Alibaba’s American Aspirations
text: Herb and Martha Oberman have made a good living on eBay for 17 years, selling paper collectibles like a $5,000 limited-edition menu from the Hotel Bel-Air, the Los Angeles hotel once frequented by Marilyn Monroe.

headline: A Quick Take on Ukraine From the International Desk
text: What’s the likely takeaway from the presidential election in Ukraine on Sunday? We asked Kyle Crichton, the editor in charge of coverage there, to weigh in.

headline: With a New Exhibition, the Mexican Artist Gabriel Kuri Makes His Home in L.A.
text: New Yorkers might recognize the work of Gabriel Kuri from the wheat-pasted posters that were plastered around town in 2011, when his signature repurposed tickets and receipts were the graphic identity of that year’s Armory Show. The Mexican artist is known for incorporating a range of detritus and found objects into his practice, combining man-made and organic materials to hint at a borderless global economy of objects. Eight months ago, he became one of a number of prominent artists to relocate to Los Angeles, moving from Brussels, where he’d spent the last decade. His first show at Regen Projects, his new West Coast gallery, opens Saturday.

headline: Report of the Secretary General on Security Council Resolution 2139
text: The strongest push to date for a resolution that would enable United Nations agencies to deliver aid inside Syria.

headline: Fire Engulfs Historic Building at Glasgow School of Art
text: LONDON — Firefighters in Scotland were battling to control a blaze on Friday that engulfed large parts of the Glasgow School of Art, one of Scotland’s most treasured buildings. There were no reports of any casualties, the Scottish Fire and Rescue Service said.

headline: Hagel’s Sex-Assault Remarks Resonate for New Navy Officers
text: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel, speaking to the graduating class at the United States Naval Academy on Friday, told the new officers he was counting on them to “lead in helping eliminate sexual harassment and sexual assault of your sisters and brothers in uniform.”

headline: Go Shop? Go Fish.
text: Shopping till you drop doesn’t really work for merger targets. The so-called “go shop” strategy of seeking higher bids after signing up a buyer is designed to ensure top dollar is paid. More often, it leads to final prices that are lower than they otherwise would be, new research suggests. Tweaks to deals like Media General’s buyout of Lin Media may mean sellers are wising up, though, portending better value for shareholders.

headline: Safety Agency Investigates Ram Pickups; Suzuki Recalls 184,000 Cars
text: After receiving a report that a child was struck and killed, federal regulators have opened an investigation into whether 2004-6 Dodge Ram heavy-duty pickups equipped with manual transmissions can be started without the driver depressing the clutch pedal, causing the vehicle to move. The investigation covers about 110,000 Ram 2500 and 3500 pickups, according to a report posted on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration website.

headline: Country Experiments With Rap
text: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff talk about the overlap of hip-hop and country.

headline: Dick Zigun: Surveying His Coney Island Realm
text: As the unofficial mayor of Coney Island, Dick Zigun, 61, craves the craziness of summer. He is the founder of Coney Island USA, which runs the Coney Island Museum, the Coney Island Circus Sideshow and the Mermaid Parade. He spends Sundays strolling the boardwalk, chatting with locals and tourists, eating hot dogs and checking out the rides. He also spends time with his wife, Patience Mukoro White, 50, who performs in the sideshow as an escape artist, as a glass walker and as Madame Twisto, a contortionist. They live with their cat, Buddy, in a Coney Island loft that is being renovated, a project that was delayed by Hurricane Sandy.

headline: Lucinda Williams, Rufus Wainwright and Norah Jones to Perform at the Clearwater Festival
text: Lucinda Williams, Rufus Wainwright, Richard Thompson and Norah Jones are among the musicians who will perform at the Clearwater Festival – or, more formally, the Great Hudson River Revival – at Croton Point Park, Croton-on-Hudson, on June 21 and 22.

headline: Cardinal Dolan Reflects on the ‘Pope Francis Effect’ in his Life and Work
text: Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan, New York’s archbishop, traveled to Rome for the canonization of two popes, stayed on to speak at a communications conference there, jetted to Jordan to see the work of a Catholic charity he chairs, and once home, spoke at two graduations in the diocese — all in the past month. In other words, it was a typically busy month for him. So when The New York Times asked him, through a spokesperson, how the election of Pope Francis had changed the diocese and his own personal life, he asked that we submit a series of written questions.

headline: Sympathy for the Working Mother
text: One morning recently I received a call from a friend who told me she had decided to leave her job after many years, one in which she commanded a lot of authority and was very well paid, to begin a new and as yet undetermined phase; she was taking advantage of a lucrative buyout her company had offered. I pointed out the fortuitous timing — it was May, which meant she would have the summer off, which meant she could leave the city, which meant she would be envied by a great number of people (arguably this year more than others because The Farmers’ Almanac is predicting a summer so hot, wet and muggy that New York will essentially feel like Biloxi, Miss.).

headline: Kerry Agrees to Testify on Benghazi, as Republicans Squabble Over Rival Inquiries
text: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State John Kerry agreed on Friday to testify before the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform over the 2012 attacks on the American diplomatic mission in Benghazi, Libya, possibly exacerbating tensions between Republicans over competing inquiries.

headline: A Better Way to Measure Fund-Raising? It Depends
text: My recent article offering a more accurate way of judging campaign fund-raising drew several responses, one from Bob Biersack, a former Federal Election Commission employee now with the Center for Responsive Politics. When journalists have needed to understand campaign finance during the past 30 years, Mr. Biersack has often supplied the answer, so his opinion is worth noting.

headline: Bill Cunningham | The Winning Number Is
text: In a year when fashion accessories are the stars, the see-through bag shaped like a Chanel No. 5 bottle is the most whimsical.

headline: William Forsythe to No Longer Run Forsythe Dance Company
text: Starting in September 2015, William Forsythe, widely recognized as one of the most important choreographers working today, will no longer run the company that is named for him. He will continue to be associated as an artistic adviser, a press statement announced on Friday. Jacopo Godani, a former dancer with Mr. Forsythe’s Ballet Frankfurt who is now a freelance choreographer, was named as the new artistic director.

headline: Speaking of Identity: Choosing Between Latino and Hispanic
text: Writers who cover demographics and politics are often confronted with the tricky matter of describing racial and ethnic groups. One particularly challenging question is whether to refer to people from Latin America as Hispanics or Latinos.

headline: Cuban Talks His Way Onto a Limb Occupied by Sterling
text: For nearly a month, Adam Silver, the commissioner of the N.B.A., has managed to isolate Donald Sterling, the owner of the Los Angeles Clippers, on an island. With one salvo of explosive comments, Mark Cuban, the owner of the Dallas Mavericks, has put his fellow team owners on that island as well.

headline: Bill Cunningham | The Winning Number Is
text: In a year when fashion accessories are the stars, the see-through bag shaped like a Chanel No. 5 bottle is the most whimsical. It seemed to sell out immediately and is now a collector’s item. Shown here, it is carried in daytime by all but two of the women. And for those who can’t get enough of the perfume bag, there’s a smartphone cover. We haven’t seen a novelty like this since Schiaparelli’s Surrealist accessories in the late 1930s. There are even Chanel sunglasses, with mademoiselle perched atop the frame.

headline: Weekend Reading: Grading Credit Suisse’s Plea and Memorial Day Travel Spots
text: Credit Suisse pleaded guilty this week to helping American account holders hide their wealth. The Swiss bank agreed to pay about $2.6 billion in penalties, but it kept its license to operate. The bank’s clients and shareholders welcomed the deal, but the Justice Department has been criticized for not pursuing a harsher penalty.

headline: Plan B: Open a Country Hotel in Upstate New York
text: When Rebecca Bales, a real estate agent in Brooklyn, and her husband, Kiley Thompson, assessed their financial and vocational prospects in 2012, they realized how hard it would be to get ahead. “We were either going to double down in our careers to do more than just pay the rent on our Park Slope apartment, or do something else,” said Mr. Thompson, an art director, sommelier and record label owner.

headline: Phone Swindlers Tap Into Fear and a Sense of Duty
text: BEFORE Betty Bell, 88, even got out of bed, the telephone jolted her awake at 7 a.m. The male voice on the line said that a police officer was coming to arrest her for shirking her civic duty.

headline: Game 3 Fallout: Stepan’s Jaw Is Broken, and Suspensions Are Issued
text: There will be no need to manufacture animosity between the Rangers and the Montreal Canadiens heading into Game 4 of the Eastern Conference finals on Sunday. After Brandon Prust’s hit on Derek Stepan in Game 3 on Thursday night, the hostility is there for all to see and hear, and the question is how much it will shape a series that the Rangers now lead by two games to one.

headline: The AmfAR Gala: A Night for Movie Stars, Supermodels and Billionaires
text: AmfAR hosts its 21st annual Cinema Against AIDS gala at Cannes.

headline: Times Minute | Pope Visits the Holy Land
text: Pope Francis embarks on a three-day trip to the Middle East. Jodi Rudoren, the Times’s Bureau chief, on what to watch from the visit.

headline: Times Minute | Pope Visits the Holy Land
text: In the Video

headline: Podcast: Lessons of a Deadly Virus
text:
An image of H.I.V. stirs one writer to remember a pastor’s evolutionary thought, published 50 years before the “Origin of Species.”
Subscribe to the Podcast »

headline: A Creationist’s Influence on Darwin
text: In my last column, about the eerie machine-like nature of the AIDS virus, I mentioned William Paley, the 19th-century theologian best known today for his argument supporting creationism: Something as complex as a mechanical watch clearly would not exist without a creator. Thus we can infer that the intricacy of our bodies — and those of all creatures — is the work of God.

headline: Driven | Mudfest S.U.V. of the Year
text: Finding the best crossovers or sport utilities means getting a little dirty.

headline: Popcast: Country Embraces Hip-Hop
text: On this week’s Popcast: the slow and circuitous loosening of modern country music. The perpetual story of the country music industry, our critic Jon Caramanica explains, is always how well it polices its own borders, how it maintain its core identity and resists assimilation into the rest of popular culture. But his cover story in Arts and Leisure this weekend analyzes how things may be decisively shifting right now, especially around rapping in country songs. The power of hip-hop reached critical mass across the country a long time ago; there are, he writes, “a generation of stars — mostly in their mid-late 30s, old enough to have grown up with hip-hop as a fact of life, even in the small towns they hail from, who think nothing of sprinkling a little bit of it into their music.”

headline: Silver Too Small to See, but Everywhere You Look
text: Several years ago, a mosquito bite on Elizabeth Loboa’s right leg became infected, turning into an oozing sore that refused to heal. Her doctor prescribed a stiff course of antibiotics. But Dr. Loboa decided to try another remedy.

headline: Norman Rockwell’s Art, Once Sniffed At, Is Becoming Prized
text: “Rockwell’s greatest sin as an artist is simple: His is an art of unending cliché.”

headline: Video: Crossovers and S.U.V.s Hammered at Mudfest
text: SNOQUALMIE, WASH. — Pushing a car to its limit is a great way to find its strengths and weaknesses. The only thing better? Doing it with someone else’s vehicle.

headline: When Do Political Endorsements Matter?
text: Voters are generally quick to acknowledge to pollsters that candidates’ stances on issues influence their votes much more than candidates’ personal attributes. However, the impact of political endorsements, pollsters have found, is more ambiguous.

headline: Drilling Down on School Lockdown Drills
text: This week’s Look features pictures taken by Alec Soth during a recent lockdown drill at a high school in Belle Plaine, Minn., about an hour southwest of Minneapolis. I was curious to find out more about these drills, so I put a few questions to Kenneth Trump, president of National School Safety and Security Services, which, among other things, evaluates school security and emergency crisis plans.

headline: A Trick Play to Close Guantánamo Bay
text: The closing of the detention camp at Guantánamo Bay — promised by President Obama in 2008, prevented by Congress ever since — may still be far off, but on Thursday a bipartisan Senate committee laid out a pathway that could make it happen.

headline: Putin to Honor Ukraine Election Results
text: President Vladimir V. Putin announced that Russia would recognize the outcome of Ukraine’s presidential vote this weekend, and said he hoped Ukraine would stop its military operations in the east.

headline: Raised on Racing
text: In its 100 years, Maserati has been owned and disowned by some half-dozen entities, and now, under Fiat Chrysler, is undergoing a resurgence.

headline: It’s the Time You Spend on an Elementary School That Makes It Special (and Hard to Leave)
text: We pull into United Skate for the last school fund-raiser of the year. My friend pulls her minivan in beside mine. “We’re late!” yell the four children between us and we hurry in, pay the $6 per child and head to the skate checkout line. Once all the children are out on the rink, after we have checked our work emails one last time, we turn to lacing up our own skates.

headline: Big Ticket | A Park Avenue Duplex at $25 Million
text: A two-bedroom duplex on the 30th and 31st floors of 515 Park Avenue, held by the estate of Christopher H. Browne, the former managing director of the mutual fund company Tweedy, Browne, sold for $25 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: A Cover With an Artistic Challenge
text: Pamela Paul is the editor of the Book Review.

headline: Rocker of the Rockaways
text: “Just let me put on my Rockaway tuxedo,” said Simon Chardiet, musician, surfer and defender of old-school Rock, Rock, Rockaway Beach, as he grabbed a wet suit draped over the fence of his bungalow.

headline: When the Going Gets Tough
text: The third generation Toyota Highlander provides tranquil, comfortable family transportation and is a good antidote to rough roads.

headline: Over-the-Top Stuff for One-Percenters
text: Gifts for couples who have everything and for gift-givers for whom price is no object.

headline: Taking a Spin: A Democratic Victory With Limits
text: In this week’s spin of Leo’s Senate wheels, we get a forecast in which Democrats have an excellent election night. They hold the Senate by winning every competitive, Democratic-held Senate seat except Louisiana, while pulling off an upset in Montana.

headline: Author Changes His Mind on ’70s Manifesto
text: For more than 40 years, Eduardo Galeano’s “The Open Veins of Latin America” has been the canonical anti-colonialist, anti-capitalist and anti-American text in that region. Hugo Chávez, Venezuela’s populist president, even put a copy of the book, which he had called “a monument in our Latin American history,” in President Obama’s hands the first time they met. But now Mr. Galeano, a 73-year-old Uruguayan writer, has disavowed the book, saying that he was not qualified to tackle the subject and that it was badly written. Predictably, his remarks have set off a vigorous regional debate, with the right doing some “we told you so” gloating, and the left clinging to a dogged defensiveness.

headline: On the Market in the Region
