text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: Independent Music Labels Are in a Battle With YouTube
text: YouTube’s plans for a subscription music service have stalled over a dispute with independent record labels, which contend that the online video giant has offered unfair licensing terms and threatened to block their music from the site.

headline: In Twist, Sterling May Allow His Wife to Sell the Clippers
text: The nightmare scenario for the N.B.A. in its efforts to end Donald Sterling’s ownership of the Los Angeles Clippers has been simmering for weeks: a protracted legal battle against a man who is no stranger to the courtroom.

headline: Dispute Over Banking Group’s Analysis of Mortgage Denials to Blacks
text: The Mortgage Bankers Association, one of the nation’s most influential financial lobbying groups, made a startling claim this week about the access of black borrowers to credit.

headline: A Seaside Escape, Off the Belt Parkway
text: At the first breath of warm weather, the hostess at Clemente’s Maryland Crab House offers diners two seating options: Indoor? Or indoor-outdoor?

headline: Raise Your Hand for an Engagement Selfie
text: It was the stuff of Marie Valencis’ dreams: a 3.9-carat, princess-cut, platinum engagement ring with a diamond band — which her fiancé picked out by himself. But after the initial elation wore off, a seemingly more practical matter popped into her head: What about the selfies she would invariably post on Facebook, Instagram and elsewhere?

headline: The Gun Report: May 23, 2014
text: Some good news going into what will undoubtedly be a violent holiday weekend: A new report from Everytown for Gun Safety found that the number of mental health records submitted to the National Instant Criminal Background Check System (NICS) has tripled since 2011, preventing 65 percent more mentally ill people from purchasing firearms through licensed dealers. The reason? Increased federal funding and stronger record collection laws in 18 states.

headline: A Violent Intruder Is Welcome to Stay
text: Most of “Tamer of Horses” occurs in an old barn, and the Passage Theater Company’s production of William Mastrosimone’s play benefits from the setting designed by Matt Campbell, who neatly incorporates the peaked ceiling and rough stone walls of Trenton’s Mill Hill Playhouse into his beams-and-planks realization of these rustic premises.

headline: The Closest of Strangers
text: EARLIER this month, I helped reunite the fraternal twins Ann Hunt and Liz Hamel, who had been apart for 78 years. Born in England in 1936, they were separated at birth when their unmarried mother decided she could not care for both. Ann, the “prettier” sister, was given away, while Liz, the “less adoptable” baby marked by scoliosis, remained at home. Ann Hunt was unaware that she was a twin until last year, when her daughter made the discovery while researching their ancestry.

headline: Warhol’s Entourage Speaks His Truth
text: Scenes from the 20th-anniversary gala for the Andy Warhol Museum, which is hosting a show about Halston and Warhol.

headline: Opposites Attract, Then Fall Apart
text: Jamie is glad he married Cathy. Really.

headline: King Richard III to Be Reburied in Leicester, British Court Says
text: LONDON — A British court ruled on Friday​ that King Richard III should be ​re​buried in a cathedral in Leicester,​ the city​ where his remains were found in a parking lot two years ago. The ruling was a defeat for the king’s descendants​ who wanted his remains to be reburied in York,​ arguing that he had spent ​much of his life there. But archaeologists who discovered the king’s remains decided to keep the body in Leicester, a decision backed by Britain’s Justice Ministry. The judges said, ​"There were no public law grounds for the court interfering with the decisions in question.”

headline: Warhol’s Entourage Speaks His Truth
text: PITTSBURGH — “Andy would have loved this!” Patrick McMullan, the party photographer, said last Saturday as he boogied with his camera around a dance floor set in a tent outside the Andy Warhol Museum. “Bob and Jane, let me get you together,” said the man who claims to have shot six million photos and to know 25,000 people by name, to Bob Colacello and Jane Holzer, a onetime Warhol superstar.

headline: What Happened to Some Banksy Pieces?
text: Q. Nine years ago, Banksy put a few of his works on walls of several New York City museums. What ever happened to the pieces?

headline: Donation-Induced Amnesia
text: In the business section of The Times today, Floyd Norris had a great column on the amnesia affecting many Republican lawmakers regarding the causes of the Great Recession. Exhibit A was Jeb Hensarling of Texas, chairman of the House Financial Services Committee, who said it was “inconceivable” that a money manager could cause widespread risk to the financial system (forgetting about Long-Term Capital Management) and that insurance companies posed no danger because they are already regulated by the states (forgetting about AIG).

headline: John Duka’s Memorable Pieces
text: John Duka, the former style reporter at The New York Times who died in 1989 at age 39, wrote a series of witty and incisive fashion pieces and celebrity profiles during his tenure at the newspaper from 1979 to 1985. Here are some of his most memorable articles:

headline: Did Thomas Piketty Get His Math Wrong?
text: One of the most common approaches for people writing about Thomas Piketty’s blockbuster book “Capital in the 21st Century,” about global inequality, has been to critique his theories and predictions while effusively praising his data collection. Mr. Piketty, after all, did yeoman’s work compiling data from tax and other records to try to determine a history of wealth inequality around the world.

headline: All Fancy Hat and No Horse
text: WHAT WAS IT? 2002 Lincoln Blackwood

headline: Recalled-Car Bargains May Prove Elusive
text: Used-car bargain hunters hoping to score a deal on one of the 2.6 million General Motors cars recalled for faulty ignition switches may find prices have proved more resilient than they expected.

headline: Maserati’s Image Builds on a Racing Reputation
text: Maserati, one of Italy’s classic automotive nameplates, celebrates its centennial this year in better shape than in any of its first 99.

headline: Reporting for Pothole Duty
text: BETHLEHEM, N.H. — While there are many delights in the White Mountains of New Hampshire, the potholes, broken pavement and launching ramps known as “frost heaves” are not among them. But the reworked 2014 Toyota Highlander offers succor, deflecting impacts and protecting its occupants from the North Country’s rough-rider roads.

headline: Silencing Underhood Complaints
text: Convertibles with balky tops and Scions suffering insect invasions are among the mechanical maladies covered in the latest technical service bulletins.

headline: It’s Cheap, but Is It Overpriced?
text: TESTED 2014 Mitsubishi Mirage

headline: Doubt Comes Knocking
text: They’re a classic odd couple. Mary is all angles, with crisply tailored outfits, quick, sharp elbows and an attitude problem: “There is some chemical in my brain that says, ‘Let ’em have it’!” Her younger sister, Margaret, is soft and fluttery, with unruly strands escaping from her hairdo and a rumpled, distracted air. They live together in the well-worn house where they were raised, each having learned long ago to tolerate the other’s foibles.

headline: John Duka, a Fashion Wit, Returns in Larry Kramer’s Film
text: As she worked on her video about Paul Cavaco, who will be honored by the Council of Fashion Designers of America in June, Nian Fish, a producer of that event, came across an image of her old friend John Duka, a colleague of both herself and Mr. Cavaco nearly three decades ago.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Blended’
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Blended.”

headline: Movie Review: ‘X-Men’
text: The Times critic A.O. Scott reviews “X-Men: Days of Future Past.”

headline: Movie Review: ‘Cold in July’
text: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews “Cold in July.”

headline: Love and All That Comes With It
text: Tyne Daly needed a bowl of rice — but not to eat. No, the six-time Emmy-winning actress (four for “Cagney & Lacey” and one each for “Christy” and “Judging Amy”), Tony winner for the Broadway revival of “Gypsy” and current Tony nominee for Terrence McNally’s new play, “Mothers and Sons,” wanted to submerge her ancient flip phone in a bowl of uncooked rice to leach the moisture from it. “My toilet exploded!” she cried. “Water everywhere. All over my outfit and the phone in my pocket.”

headline: Dropping Donovan, Klinsmann Shows His Clout
text: In most cases, coaches of national soccer teams are like presidents: one four-year term at a time, with little certainty about how re-election will go until the numbers come in. Unlike political incumbents, though, coaching incumbents do not often receive a boost; coaching a team for two World Cup cycles is not the norm.

headline: Amazon’s Tactics Confirm Its Critics’ Worst Suspicions
text: Amazon is confirming its critics’ worst fears and it is an ugly spectacle to behold.

headline: Dorchester Hotels Falling Out of Fashion
text: With the next round of European fashion shows quickly approaching, some of fashion’s biggest names are facing a dilemma: Should they boycott their favorite hotels in Milan and Paris because they are owned by the sultan of Brunei?

headline: Evening Hours | Indoors and Out
text: Off to a garden, or perhaps a dance floor.

headline: Exposing the Foundations of Documented Motion
text: In the prospectus accompanying “Animal Locomotion” (1887), an 11-volume collection of 20,000 photographs documenting human and animal movement, Eadweard Muybridge described how he became interested in the subject in the 1870s and was convinced that he could “demonstrate many novel facts, not only interesting to the casual observer, but of indisputable value to the Artist and to the Scientist.”

headline: Judge Allows Conyers to Be on the Ballot in Michigan
text: Representative John Conyers Jr. of Michigan narrowly escaped a political fiasco on Friday when a federal judge granted him a place on the Democratic primary ballot in August, allowing him to survive a campaign misstep that left him hundreds of valid signatures short on his petitions for re-election.

headline: Wheelies: The G.M. Trucks Hiccup Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: If Liver Doesn’t Strike Fear in Your Heart
text: When it comes to enjoying offal, I have found that one either does or does not at all. There is no middle ground. I’ll confess to have always been a lover of liver — and kidneys, gizzards, hearts, sweetbreads and tongues for that matter. I grew up on chopped chicken liver, and always considered pan-fried chicken livers a treat. I still do.

headline: Pictures of the Day — China and Elsewhere
text: China and More: Pictures of the Day

headline: Warhol at the Dali
text: Devotees of Salvador Dali’s fascination with the world of dreams can now examine his work and contrast it with that of Andy Warhol, whose paintings, drawings, photographs and films of the everyday are on display at the Dali Museum in St. Petersburg, Fla.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: A Ruling’s Chilling Effect on Corporate Litigation
text: In the clubby world of corporate litigators, the hysteria over a change to corporate bylaws that would shift responsibility over legal fees is perhaps one of the more recent strange events.

headline: Weekend Calendar: Muscle Madness and Southern British Charm
text: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend.

headline: Staten Island Gets a Craft Brewery of Its Own
text: The three Staten Island guys — tall and broad, with their hair cut short — stood behind their keg with trepidation and pride, as though they had sent their child into the playground for the first time. They were in a cacophonous event hall in Queens, presenting their beer at the Five Boro Craft Beer Fest, a showcase for New York’s craft breweries. Guests approached with petite tasting glasses, holding the pours to their noses for an aromatic inhale.

headline: Pictures of the Day: China and Elsewhere
text: Photos from China, Ukraine, Afghanistan and India.

headline: Week in Pictures for May 23
text: A slide show of photographs of the past week in New York City and the region includes the National September 11 Memorial Museum, the planting of grass at a beach in Queens, and the sentencing of an Occupy Wall Street protester.

headline: Dark Lullabies and Twisted Witches
text: Putting together a concert of works linked by an overall theme may seem a surefire way to lend coherence to a program. The risk is that in searching for pieces that support a chosen theme, especially unfamiliar scores, you wind up with novelties of lesser musical interest.

headline: Spring Break at Cannes
text: CANNES, FRANCE — Dollars. Euros. Dollars. Euros. By 11 p.m., the bids were coming in so fast that Sharon Stone, who was handling part of the auction, couldn’t even keep the currencies straight.

headline: McDonald’s Indigestible Excuse for Low Pay
text: When Henry Ford realized it was good business to pay employees enough to buy the products they built, it was a breakthrough, not only because the idea challenged the reflex to pay as little as possible, but because the product was a car. He was talking real bucks.

headline: Liu Announces Bid to Unseat Queens State Senator
text: John C. Liu, the former New York City comptroller whose mayoral aspirations fizzled amid a criminal investigation into his fund-raising, declared his bid on Friday to unseat a Democratic state senator in Queens.

headline: Spring in the Air, Wild Leeks on the Table
text: When I saw ramps on the menu of At the Corner Restaurant and Pub, in Litchfield, I knew that spring had arrived in full. Ramps, a wild form of leek, are available fleetingly, from mid-April through late May, and a restaurant that serves them clearly embraces the change of seasons.

headline: Support for Breakup Songs, Even a Vibraphone
text: Forlorn love is transmuted into myth and metaphor in songs by Mirah, who performed her entire new album, “Changing Light,” at the Music Hall of Williamsburg on Wednesday night. Her voice stayed airborne, a sweet soprano with a steadfast core, as the songs moved through laments, recriminations and resolve.

headline: Apps for the Lovelorn
text: Summer is almost here, and if you’re a typical Other Woman, you’ve already wasted precious hours (O.K., months) brooding about it: those romantic summer nights when the man you love will be off on vacation — with his wife (not that they have sex anymore, but just the idea of the two of them at some idyllic beach makes you crazy).

headline: California Chrome Preps for Triple Crown
text: California Chrome’s assistant trainer, Alan Sherman, and his exercise rider, Willie Delgado, talked about how training has been going for the racehorse.

headline: Vocal Birds
text: The squawks and honks of pink flamingos greet Jeremy Sanders, a senior wild animal keeper, at the Bronx Zoo each day.

headline: San Antonio Mayor Is Nominated as Housing Secretary
text: WASHINGTON — Mayor Julián Castro of San Antonio, a rising star in the Democratic Party, is expected to soon have a platform that might kick-start a national political career.

headline: Friday Night Music: Beirut
text: Continuing on the grumpy old man theme, may I say how much I hate what passes for handwriting? Not only did I have trouble making out what they wrote, I had trouble figuring out who wrote it — when the blue book appears to come from a student named “grzzmph”, entering his grade in the spreadsheet is hard.

headline: Under Cover: Body Building
text: To illustrate Michael Behar’s cover story about how electricity delivered through the nervous system might be used to fight disease, the magazine’s art department turned to Kyle Bean, a conceptual artist in London. Gail Bichler, the art director, and Jason Sfetko, a designer, chose Bean because, in Bichler’s words, he “makes graphically striking dimensional pieces.” Bean, for his part, says that after reading Behar’s story, he was inspired by scientific diagrams in old textbooks to make the “electrified body” seen on this week’s cover.

headline: Pictures From the Week in Business
text: A luxury chicken coop, a China-Russia gas deal and more car recalls at General Motors.

headline: G.O.P. Sues for a Loophole to Raise Unlimited Money From Individuals
text: The Republican National Committee filed a complaint on Friday to force federal election officials to allow the party to raise unlimited money from individuals, opening a new front in its legal battle on campaign regulation.

headline: Down to the Sea Again
text: Americans may rhapsodize about their cars or amber waves of grain, but when it comes to putting wind in their sails, nothing does it quite like wind and sails.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up »

headline: Adding Technology to Animal Instincts
text: CLEVELAND — To the pantheon of opera’s unforgettable couples, from Mozart’s Figaro and Susanna to Puccini’s Tosca and Cavaradossi, I’d like to add a pair that lies a considerable distance from them: two foxes.

headline: The Attack of the Killer Theme Weeks
text: Assuming you make it through the weekend, congratulations on surviving Monster Week. Unfortunately, there’s no time to relax. Meat Week and Psych Week start on Monday.

headline: Federal Regulators Seek to Stop Sale of Students’ Data
text: Last month, ConnectEDU, a popular college and career planning portal in Boston that had collected personal details on millions of high school and college students, filed for bankruptcy.

headline: Exhibit A in G.E.’s Case for Alstom Deal
text: VILLAROCHE, France — In a cavernous factory planted in farmland here south of Paris, workers assemble the best-selling aircraft engine in history, in a feat of trans-Atlantic industrial cooperation that has few parallels.

headline: Where Winners Play, and Losers Pay
text: The real way to win many of today’s popular video games is to figure out how to avoid paying for them. This isn’t a matter of stealing or borrowing them. It’s about enjoying them to a limit, of being among the millions who indulge in so-called free-to-play games like Angry Birds or League of Legends only enough to have some fun and not enough to have to pay.

headline: The Frenchman Who Loved Westerns
text: As the Cannes festival has recently reminded us, the French adore movies. And that enthusiasm was on delightful display onstage and in the audience Thursday at Gould Hall, at “The Exercise Was Beneficial, Sir” (“La Loi du Marcheur” is the French title), Nicolas Bouchaud’s solo portrayal of the editor and critic Serge Daney. (It was the end of a two-night run.)

headline: Generations Share a Program Whose Theme Is Follow the Leader
text: New York City Ballet’s program on Thursday at the David H. Koch Theater was titled “Classic NYCB I,” but it might have been called “Masters and Apprentices.”

headline: The Game to Select USA-1 for the Bermuda Bowl
text: We are looking at the last six boards of the final match in the trial to select the USA-1 team for next year’s Bermuda Bowl world championship.

headline: Court Approves F.C.C. Plan to Subsidize Rural Broadband Service
text: WASHINGTON — A federal appeals court on Friday upheld the Federal Communications Commission’s effort to convert its $4.5 billion program that pays for telephone service in rural parts of the country into one that subsidizes high-speed Internet service in high-cost areas.

headline: Powerful Law Firms Patton Boggs and Squire Sanders Will Join Forces
text: Patton Boggs, a Washington lobbying and legal powerhouse for decades, is no longer a stand-alone firm.

headline: A New Critique of Piketty Has Its Own Shortcomings
text: My colleague, Neil Irwin, has written an outstanding account of the charges leveled by Chris Giles of the Financial Times that the conclusions of “Capital in the 21st Century,” Thomas Piketty’s blockbuster book, “do not appear to be backed by the book’s own sources.”

headline: Bike Share’s Rough Ride
text: IT’S been a year since Citi Bike started in New York City, and the program has been a tremendous success, with more than 100,000 annual members and over seven million trips to date. Or, if you prefer, in Citi Bike’s first year, the program has struggled financially and is in urgent need of tens of millions of dollars.

headline: Obama Nominates New HUD Secretary
text: The president tapped Julián Castro, the mayor of San Antonio, to be the secretary of housing and urban development, replacing Shaun Donovan, who was promoted to run the White House budget office.

headline: Victims and Officials on Xinjiang Attack
text: As residents of Urumqi, China, mourned the deaths in the market blast on Thursday, Chinese and Uighur officials and survivors discussed the terror attack.

headline: Giving Small Donors a Bigger Voice
text: To the Editor:

headline: At Pig Roasts, the Guest of Honor Is Edible
text: When Erik Wood started planning a birthday party for his wife, Emily, he wasn’t trying to pick a theme that would help his 50 guests break the ice; they were friends who already knew one another, he said. But the Woods got a conversation starter anyway.

headline: House Inquiry on Grimm Is Deferred as U.S. Pursues Case
text: A subcommittee formed to investigate Representative Michael G. Grimm, Republican of Staten Island, has voted unanimously to defer its work while federal prosecutors in Brooklyn pursue a fraud indictment against Mr. Grimm, the House Ethics Committee said on Friday.

headline: Who Visits the 9/11 Museum, and Who Doesn’t
text: To the Editor:

headline: Studying if Aspirin Helps Prevent Breast Cancer
text: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Don’t Go Away Again,’ He Was Told. But He Did.
text: Kenneth Cory Smith was born 35 years ago, but it was a matter of days before the boy’s father inadvertently set him up for a lifetime of jokes, up to and including this sentence, by changing his name to one that is, well, unique.

headline: A Strong Case for Leaving Room for Dessert
text: Latitude 121 Coastal Grill is a new restaurant that walks a line between the past and its present aspirations. It opened in March, replacing a decades-old Stony Brook favorite, Brook House, an ice-cream parlor and family restaurant.

headline: Leaving Islam for Atheism, and Finding a Much-Needed Place Among Peers
text: ALEXANDRIA, Va. — Women talked about “coming out,” being open with their families, leaving “the closet” at a conference here this month. But the topic was not sexuality. Instead, the women, attending the third Women in Secularism conference were talking about being atheists. Some grew up Catholic, some Jewish, some Protestant — but nearly all described journeys of acknowledging atheism first to themselves, then to loved ones. Going public was a last, often painful, step.

headline: A Gastropub That’s Sophisticated and Homey
text: One of the biggest restaurant trends in recent years is the rise of the gastropub. Combining the comfort of a relaxed, local hangout with a serious, often farm-to-table approach to food, these places can have a high-low combination that is tremendously appealing — but not that easy to achieve.

headline: 2 States Getting More Money for Storm Recovery Efforts
text: The federal government has drawn up plans to send an additional $2.5 billion in aid to New York and New Jersey to help pay for the recovery from Hurricane Sandy, government officials said on Friday.

headline: Iran Is Providing Information on Its Detonators, Atomic Agency Says
text: WASHINGTON — For six years, international nuclear inspectors have been demanding that Iran turn over evidence of experiments that they suspect could have been part of a secret effort to solve the complex science of detonating a nuclear weapon.

headline: Chang vs. Lendl: 25 Years Later
text: In 1989, few people thought a 17-year-old American named Michael Chang would beat the No. 1-ranked tennis player, Ivan Lendl, in the fourth round of the French Open.

headline: Agency Expects More Deaths From G.M.’s Ignition Flaw
text: The number of deaths linked to defective ignition switches in General Motors cars is likely to rise above the 13 fatalities acknowledged so far by G.M., according to the nation’s top auto safety regulator.

headline: From Secret Agent to Hollywood Agent
text: Clark Gregg has been dead before, but he always seems to recover. In his most famous movie appearance, in the superhero blockbuster “Marvel’s The Avengers,” his by-the-book lawman, Agent Phil Coulson, was impaled by the villainous Norse god Loki — only to return, no worse for the wear and in a leading role, in the ABC television spinoff “Marvel’s Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D.”

headline: Charges Against Chinese, and U.S. Policy on Hacking
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Housing Revival in San Antonio
text: Mayor Julián Castro, nominated to be housing secretary, has steered a housing renaissance in the city, getting new apartment buildings built in areas once ignored by developers.

headline: Fear of Job Loss
text: To the Editor:

headline: Anger at Killing of Bystander During Protest in Turkey
text: One day after a bystander was shot to death as he attended a funeral near a protest in Istanbul, there was criticism Friday on social networks in Turkey over the pace of the investigation into his death.

headline: IAEA Report on Iran’s Nuclear Program
text: A report by the director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency details major progress Iran has made in diluting most of its stockpile of medium-enriched uranium.

headline: Budget Woes May Hurt Christie More Than Bridge Scandal
text: For months, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey has kept a low profile, waiting for new headlines to distract from the George Washington Bridge scandal. Now they have: The news has been a dire drumbeat about his state’s economy.

headline: Studying Humans Who Study Apes
text: Krista Knight’s “Primal Play” is really a mother play. “You know what they say, behind every great woman is her mother,” Cynthia Naymark says. And there seems to be nothing Cynthia won’t do for her daughter, Valerie, a primatologist with less self-awareness than the chimpanzees she studies.

headline: It’s No Picnic in the Senate
text: Happy Memorial Day Weekend! Time for summer fun! So let’s discuss Congressional gridlock.

headline: Why I Blew the Whistle on the V.A.
text: PHOENIX — MY decision to become a whistle-blower after 24 years as a physician in a Veterans Affairs hospital was, at first, an easy one. I knew about patients who were dying while waiting for appointments on the V.A.’s secret schedules, and I couldn’t stay silent.

headline: Others Fade, but Judge Judy Is Forever: At 71, She Still Presides
text: LOS ANGELES — Judge Judith Sheindlin, the straight-talking star of “Judge Judy,” peered down at a sassy defendant with disgust. “Listen to me, Miss Fibby,” Judge Sheindlin snapped at a recent taping here. “They don’t keep me here because I’m gorgeous. They keep me here because I’m smart.”

headline: Credit Suisse Gets Off Easy
text: The sham continues.

headline: On the Town, Sort Of: Fleet Week Shrinks
text: Inside his Chelsea apartment on Wednesday morning, Bob Rowen donned a desert-camouflage utility jacket and a sun-stained military cap before heading out onto 26th Street. He marched west, as he has done since the first ships arrived 30 years ago, and took up his regular position along the shore.

headline: Fat-Cat Administrators at the Top 25
text: Confronted with punishing state budget cuts, the public colleges and universities that educate more than 70 percent of this country’s students have raised tuition, shrunk course offerings and hired miserably paid, part-time instructors who now form what amounts to a new underclass in the academic hierarchy. At the same time, some of those colleges and universities are spending much too freely on their top administrators.

headline: G.O.P.’s Foreign Policy Hawks Wary of Paul’s Evolving Views
text: WASHINGTON — Rand Paul had just finished his opening remarks at a private gathering of Republican power brokers at the Four Seasons in Georgetown last fall when Phil Gramm, the former senator from Texas, shot up his hand with the first question.

headline: With 2,583 Games at One Position, Derek Jeter Reaches Another Milestone
text: CHICAGO — It seems that barely a day goes by without Derek Jeter breaking a record or passing a milestone.

headline: Gender Imbalance in the Lab
text: Federal health officials are taking steps to correct a longstanding gender imbalance in laboratory research on potential drug treatments. For the past two decades, federal law has required that women be included in clinical studies funded by the National Institutes of Health in recognition of the fact that drugs often have vastly different effects in men and women. As a result, more than half of the participants in N.I.H.-funded clinical research are women. But there has been no similar requirement to eliminate the sex bias from more basic laboratory research that can lead up to a clinical trial or doom a drug to the discard pile if it seems not to work.

headline: Pfizer’s Ploy and the Porous Tax Laws
text: Pfizer’s $119 billion offer to buy AstraZeneca, the British drug company, is driven largely by its desire to cut its tax bill. It is a ploy made possible by porous tax laws in the United States that encourage corporate tax avoidance and by laws in Britain and elsewhere that abet it.

headline: Jackie Kennedy’s Letters Taken Off the Auction Block
text: BOSTON — It was an unlikely friendship, between a shy, 21-year-old American socialite and a 73-year-old Irish priest. But in 1950, they began an extraordinary correspondence in which the American revealed her private thoughts as she dated, then married, then witnessed the assassination of the president of the United States. Now the fate of their letters, which had been headed for the auction block, is in question.

headline: A $2 Ferry Ride Away, 30 Transformed Acres
text: A broad carpet of new parkland has been unfurled in the middle of New York Harbor and the public is welcome, beginning Saturday, for the price of a boat ride: two dollars.

headline: After Revival in San Antonio, Washington Comes Calling
text: SAN ANTONIO — When Mayor Julián Castro of San Antonio and local officials traveled to Washington in 2012 to meet President Obama’s housing secretary, Shaun Donovan, the agenda was about housing policy. But for Mr. Castro, it was personal, too.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 23, 2014
Ukraine Faces Struggle to Gain Control of Militias, Including Those on Its Side
text: KARLOVKA, Ukraine — In a secluded wood in eastern Ukraine, a group of 120 men who call themselves the Donbass Battalion had commandeered a children’s summer camp to prepare for war.

headline: Cuomo to Earn Over $700,000 From a Memoir, Filings Reveal
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is set to earn more than $700,000 for a memoir that will be published this summer, according to a new ethics filing.

headline: Michael Chang Returns to French Open, With a Protégé
text: PARIS — Twenty-five years later, Michael Chang still has not talked about the 1989 French Open with Ivan Lendl. Nor has he hit another underhand serve in competition.

headline: A Specter of Past Executions Resurfaces in Tennessee
text: A man who had shot to death his four young children, for reasons known only to him, sat in the wooden chair reserved for him at the Riverbend Maximum Security Institution in Nashville. His body was strapped tight and his head was freshly shaved, to enhance the conductivity.

headline: Calm Streets Mask Deep Divisions in Donetsk
text: DONETSK, Ukraine — To the casual observer, this is not a city at war. Masked men are confined to a few buildings in the center of town, where children on in-line skates pass by. City workers tend to flowers in meticulously planted parks. Crowded open-air cafes spill onto sidewalks and into parks. Pfizer is holding a conference at the Ramada, where grilled sea bass is on the menu.

headline: André Popp, French Composer of ‘Love Is Blue,’ Dies at 90
text: André Popp, a French composer whose instrumental “Love is Blue” became a 1960s standard and an easy listening hit in the United States, died on May 10 at his home in Puteaux, France. He was 90.

headline: Cornelia G. Kennedy, a Pioneering Federal Judge, Dies at 90
text: Cornelia G. Kennedy was one of the first women to serve as a clerk at the prestigious United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, and the first woman in the nation to serve as chief judge of a federal district court. Three presidents shortlisted her for the United States Supreme Court.

headline: Civilian Militias Face Russian Foes
text: A group of Ukrainians loyal to Kiev formed the Donbass Battalion to provide a new front against pro-Russian militias that have attacked military units and taken over government buildings.

headline: Pie-in-the-Face Scenes
text: UPDATE: The Across Lite link in the box is not working, and I am trying to get hold of someone to change it. For now, please click here or use the link on the main puzzles page.

headline: Nigeria’s Army Hampers Hunt for Abducted Schoolgirls
text: ABUJA, Nigeria — Intelligence agents from all over the globe have poured into this city, Nigeria’s capital, to help find the nearly 300 Nigerian schoolgirls abducted by the Islamist extremist group Boko Haram more than a month ago — but there has been little or no progress in bringing the young women home.

headline: Jaime Lusinchi, Ex-Leader of Venezuela, Dies at 89
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — Jaime Lusinchi, a former president of Venezuela who caused a national stir by installing his mistress as his private secretary and making her a powerful force in government, then fled with her amid a corruption scandal, died here on Wednesday. He was 89.

headline: As Regimes Shift Worldwide, China Signs Gas Deal With Russia
text: “Someone who tries to blow out another’s oil lamp will set his beard on fire,” the president of China told an Asian regional security forum in Shanghai on Wednesday. The old Kazakh saw, explained the China Daily, was Xi Jinping’s veiled way of telling the United States to get used to China’s rise and to stop interfering in Asian affairs.

headline: Shirley Walton Fischler, Hockey Writer Who Broke a Barrier, Dies at 74
text: Shirley Walton Fischler, who in 1971 became the first woman allowed to report on hockey games from the Madison Square Garden press box, died on May 13 at her home in Manhattan. She was 74.

headline: Mets Try to Lift Public Relations
text: The Mets on Friday hired Harold Kaufman, a former longtime N.B.A. executive, to expand their public relations efforts off the field. Kaufman, who spent nearly two decades as a vice president of communications for the Charlotte and New Orleans Hornets, was named the Mets’ executive director of communications.

headline: Dragons Return to the Bronx Zoo
text: Many of the popular residents of the Bronx Zoo are soft and cute. But you would not want to cuddle its newest stars. Komodo dragons, known for their size and their deadly bite, are returning to the zoo after more than 50 years.

headline: Why Journalists Need to Squint
text: If you squint, and peer into the dark back room of the bamboo hut, you can barely make them out. Women huddled together in a cluster peek out from behind an open kitchen door. As the camera shoots back and forth between a community leader and the only villager with formal English training—both men—the women take turns retreating further into the scenery so they might shush the crying baby.

headline: Europe’s Right and Left on March to Populism
text: ROME — For weeks, Beppe Grillo, the Italian political insurgent, has crisscrossed the nation in what might be called his vitriol tour. He has let loose zesty, bellowing insults against journalists, businessmen, Italian politicians and Angela Merkel, the German chancellor and avatar of European austerity. He has even taken a swipe at Dudu, the fluffy white poodle belonging to former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi.

headline: After a Horrendous Start, an Invigorated Granderson Has Found His Swing
text: Entering the May 12 start of the Subway Series, Mets outfielder Curtis Granderson appeared to be another one of the team’s free-agent busts. Granderson was earning unflattering comparisons to Jason Bay, the former outfielder signed to a disastrous four-year, $66 million contract before the 2010 season.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, May 24, 2014
text: “People take comfort in order. I also move swiftly, as opposed to a justice system and a government that is slow and meandering.”

headline: ‘Happy in Tehran’ Video Spurs Harsher Censorship
text: The judicial authorities in Iran appeared to harden their clampdown on expression Friday, moving to block Instagram, imprisoning the director who made the now-famous Iranian version of the Pharrell Williams “Happy” video and warning women to comply with a police campaign on the proper wearing of mandatory headscarves.

headline: Upheaval in Thailand
text: Thailand’s military leaders tried to tighten their hold on the country a day after a coup, but some signs of defiance emerged.

headline: Turkey Says 2 Have Died After a Protest in Istanbul
text: ISTANBUL — Two men have died after clashes in Istanbul between the police and a group of demonstrators who had gathered to protest last week’s mine disaster in Soma, Gov. Huseyin Avni Mutlu of Istanbul said Friday.

headline: In Letter, Redskins Defend Name
text: The Washington Redskins defended the team’s name in a letter to the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, two days after 50 Democratic senators urged Roger Goodell, the N.F.L.’s commissioner, to support a change.

headline: Dunn’s Homer Ends Game and Closer’s Perfect Season
text: CHICAGO — All closers know that, despite their best efforts, their jobs will inevitably include the dreaded blown save. Even Mariano Rivera blew save opportunities, sometimes in big games.

headline: Corrections: May 24, 2014
text: NATIONAL

headline: What’s on Saturday
text: 10 P.M. (Cinemax) THE WORLD’S END (2013) In the summer of 1990, five British teenagers set out on a pub crawl in the town of Newton Haven, vomiting, fighting and having drunken sex along what is known as the Golden Mile. But they failed to make it through the 12 requisite watering holes, the last of which was called the World’s End. Twenty years later, they give it a second try in this comedy directed by Edgar Wright, the final installment in his Cornetto Trilogy, following “Shaun of the Dead” and “Hot Fuzz.” Nick Frost, Simon Pegg and Paddy Considine, along with Martin Freeman and Eddie Marsan, play the Golden Milers. Four have traded their wild youth for adult respectability; the fifth decidedly has not. Then the robots show up, and these men just may be humanity’s only hope for survival. “The Cornetto Trilogy is named after a popular ice cream treat, and the buzz of ‘The World’s End’ is more like an antic sugar high than a reeling, drunken stupor,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “There are no headaches, dry mouth or crushing shame at the end — no ‘Hangover,’ in other words. I’ll drink to that.”

headline: In Possible Thaw, Pakistani Leader Agrees to Attend Swearing-In Ceremony in India
text: NEW DELHI — Ending days of hesitation, Pakistan’s prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, on Saturday accepted an Indian invitation to attend the swearing-in of the new prime minister, Narendra Modi, offering a fresh opportunity to revitalize the moribund peace process between the two countries, which have had particularly frosty relations since early 2013.

headline: Is Piketty All Wrong?
text: Great buzz in the blogosphere over Chris Giles’s attack on Thomas Piketty’s Capital in the 21st Century. Giles finds a few clear errors, although they don’t seem to matter much; more important, he questions some of the assumptions and imputations Piketty uses to deal with gaps in the data and the way he switches sources. Neil Irwin and Justin Wolfers have good discussions of the complaints; Piketty will have to answer these questions in detail, and we’ll see how well he does it.

headline: Analytics: Blood Dosas
text: The following Analytics appears on the letters page in the May 25 issue of the magazine.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, May 25
text: “We deeply regret the past misconduct that led to this settlement.”

headline: Strikes, Spares and Bruised Shins
text: In high school, I had one of the rarer jobs for a teenager in modern America. The time-honored types of teenage employment — jobs in fast food or in retailing at the mall — didn’t exist in the rural Pennsylvania town where I grew up. The few positions for restaurant servers, grocery stockers and cashiers were filled mostly by older women who needed that work to get by. Strangely, the job readily available to me was at the town bowling alley, where I worked one night a week as a pin boy.

headline: A Custodian of Kauai’s Secrets
text: Robert Miguel, 35, works for Kukui’ula, a second-home development on Kauai in Hawaii.

headline: Pope Calls for Solutions to Conflicts in Mideast Visit
text: ON THE EAST BANK OF THE JORDAN RIVER — After visiting a site on Saturday where Jesus is believed to have been baptized, Pope Francis spoke about Jesus’s humility, “the fact that he bends down to wounded humanity in order to heal us.”

headline: The Ripple Effects of Rising Student Debt
text: What are the roads not taken because students must take out loans for college? A collection of studies shows that the burden of student debt may well cause people to make different decisions than they would otherwise — affecting not just individual lives but also the entire economy.

headline: Home Sweet Headquarters for an App Start-Up
text: A sense of place

headline: The Computerized Voice That Wasn’t
text: Email haggler@nytimes.com. Keep it brief and family-friendly, include your hometown and go easy on the caps-lock key. Letters may be edited for clarity and length.

headline: Maybe There’s Life in the Old Bull Market Yet
text: Worried about the stock market? There’s no shortage of reasons to fret.

headline: Buying Insurance Against Climate Change
text: The third National Climate Assessment report — released on May 6 by the White House, and representing the work of more than 240 scientists — warns us about our hazardous future and offers many good ideas for dealing with it. But a most important point may be lost in the crowd.

headline: For Brett Wilson of TubeMogul, It’s All in the Follow-Through
text: This interview with  Brett Wilson, chief executive of TubeMogul, a video advertising software company, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: 1914: The Most Radiant Stars Shine in the May Skies
text: If May is the spring month par excellence, that personifies the return of fine weather, it is also the month whose mild evenings best lend themselves to reveries by moonlight and contemplation of the star-studded skies.

headline: Video Rant, Then Deadly Rampage in California Town
text: ISLA VISTA, Calif. — A college student who posted videos that documented his rage against women for rejecting him killed six people and wounded 13 others during a spasm of terror on Friday night, the police said. He stabbed three men to death in his apartment and shot the others as he methodically opened fire on bystanders on the crowded streets of this small town.

headline: Gordon’s 736-Race Streak Is in Peril
text: CONCORD, N.C. — Jeff Gordon, the Sprint Cup standings leader and a four-time series champion, said Saturday that back spasms could force him out of Sunday’s Coca-Cola 600.

headline: Easing the Way for East Africa Visitors
text: Visas have long presented a real barrier to ease of travel in many African countries. They can be pricey and require tedious forms.

headline: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — I’ve gone on record as saying that when it comes to cryptics, I’m best at the ones constructed by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon. That’s not a put down of any other constructor of cryptic crossword puzzles; it’s just how my own brain works. I’m more on their wavelength.

headline: The Deal’s Done. But Not the Fees.
text: There was joy on Park Avenue as the news arrived from Warsaw, a small Indiana city.

headline: Inside the Cannabis Factory
text: New federal regulations in Canada make way for the large-scale legal production of marijuana.

headline: When Cannabis Goes Corporate
text: Hershey stopped producing chocolate in Smiths Falls, Ontario, six years ago. The work went to Mexico, but the factory remains, along with reminders of the glory days: A sign that once directed school buses delivering children for tours. A fading, theme-park-style entrance that marks what used to be the big attraction — a “Chocolate Shoppe” that sold about $4 million of broken candy and bulk bars a year.

headline: YouTube Video: Retribution
text: Investigators are reviewing a video posted online by Elliot Rodger, 22, who has been identified as the suspect in the shooting and stabbing deaths of six people near the University of California, Santa Barbara.

headline: The True Cabrera, So the Blue Jays Hope
text: Manager John Gibbons sat in the Toronto Blue Jays’ dugout at Fenway Park last Tuesday and motioned toward the Green Monster, where the American League East standings are updated daily.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 19
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: No Time but Present for the Heat and LeBron James
text: MIAMI — There is a calm about LeBron James now, evident in his interactions with the horde of reporters that surrounded him last week on the Miami Heat practice court and, twice in two days, pelted him with rapid-fire questions on a range of subjects. Each one he answered swiftly, with a practiced grace and panache, deploying disarming tones and the most appropriate facial expressions.

headline: Militants Attack Somalia’s Parliament
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Militants attacked Somalia’s Parliament building on Saturday, with a bomber detonating a car filled with explosives at the building’s entrance followed by several other explosions and an assault by gunmen, witnesses and Somali officials said.

headline: Vigneault’s Firing by the Canadiens Led to His Success
text: In matters of hockey, patience is not a virtue in Montreal, where it is late even when it is early. The Canadiens’ travails determine whether the city beams or frowns. Bearable Stanley Cup droughts are measured not by the season but by the week.

headline: Tempting Europe With Ugly Fruit
text: LISBON — Isabel Soares went shopping for produce on a recent morning, carefully selecting her fruits and vegetables with a discriminating eye. She picked up some spinach whose leaves had turned an unappealing yellow. Then some tomatoes whose skin had been damaged by sunburn and insect bites. Finally, she set on some zucchini that had grown so large and deformed that they curved almost into a doughnut shape.

headline: Observers Go to Ukraine for Election Separatists Plan to Disrupt
text: DONETSK, Ukraine — A delegation of international election observers arrived in this troubled eastern Ukrainian city on Saturday on the eve of a critical national vote, just hours after separatist leaders from several eastern provinces met here and reiterated their promises to disrupt it.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s Money Talking
text: Memorial Day may not be the official start of summer, but it certainly feels like it. This week’s Money Talking kicks back a bit to talk about books on climate change, leveraged buyouts and the Koch Brothers.

headline: Suspects in China Market Attack Identified
text: BEIJING — Law enforcement officials in the western region of Xinjiang on Saturday identified five men they said were responsible for an attack on an outdoor vegetable market on Thursday that killed 43 people and injured more than 90, many of them elderly shoppers.

headline: In a Father’s Footsteps, Chasing a Triple Crown
text: One early morning in late April, the trainer Alan Sherman rested his arms on the rail as he watched one of his horses gallop at Los Alamitos Race Course in California. The call to the post played, but the sound did not come from a bugle. It came from Sherman’s cellphone.

headline: China’s Leader, Seeking to Build Its Muscle, Pushes Overhaul of the Military
text: BEIJING — Driven by ambitions to make China a great power, President Xi Jinping is staking his political authority on a huge task: overhauling the Chinese military, which is still largely organized as it was when a million peasant soldiers mustered under Mao Zedong.

headline: The Immigrant Advantage
text: IF you want to die a successful American, especially in the heartland, it helps to be born abroad.

headline: Memorial Day 2050
text: OF the many things being said about climate change lately, none was more eloquent than the point made by Gov. Jay Inslee of Washington State in the Showtime series “Years of Living Dangerously,” when he observed: “We’re the first generation to feel the impact of climate change and the last generation that can do something about it.”

headline: Nir Kalron
text: The former Israeli commando Nir Kalron is the chief executive of Maisha Consulting Ltd., a security and risk management firm based in Tel Aviv that focuses on deterring environmental crime in Africa.

headline: Read These Lips
text: A KISS is nothing. On the sidewalks, in the park, I see one every few minutes, a real kiss, lip to lip. It barely registers. It’s as unremarkable as a car horn in traffic, as an umbrella in rain.

headline: Fitness Crazed
text: SAN FRANCISCO — I’M no scientist, but I sure like reading about science. I’m always looking through newspapers for the latest research about saturated fat and whether it’s still bad for you, or if maybe sugar is poison.

headline: America, China and the Hacking Threat
text: Over several years of trying to persuade China to stop cyberattacks against corporate America, the Obama administration has gotten nowhere. What officials say is the most aggressive effort by any country to steal secrets from some of the most prominent and successful American companies is still going strong. Losses are estimated at billions of dollars in profits and thousands of jobs.

headline: Graduate of the Year
text: LONG AN, Vietnam — TAY THI NGUYEN is one of the mightiest people I’ve met, at 94 pounds. She has a towering presence, at a bit more than 5 feet tall. She is so strong that she probably could bench press 25 pounds.

headline: Willful Ignorance in Wyoming
text: The year has already produced three alarming reports involving climate change.

headline: Deterrence Revisited
text: WASHINGTON — THE graduation exercises at West Point have long been a moment for American presidents to offer midcourse adjustments — or something more radical — in their strategies for dealing with foreign adversaries. A dozen years ago, George W. Bush offered the first taste of his “pre-emption” strategy from the bluffs over the Hudson River, reviving a 165-year-old concept to warn anyone who might threaten the United States that Washington could act first to neutralize them. It was more than a rhetorical exercise: 10 months later American forces were on their way to Baghdad.

headline: Who Are Women’s Colleges For?
text: FOR hundreds of years, universities excluded women. Denied access to these institutions, they created their own. “Attempt great things,” the founder of Mount Holyoke, Mary Lyon, told her students. “Accomplish great things.” These schools, including the elite Seven Sisters — Mount Holyoke, Barnard, Bryn Mawr, Radcliffe, Smith, Vassar and Wellesley — were where the nation’s most promising young women went to do just that.

headline: The Tea Party Legacy
text: THE Tea Party is finished: smashed, at last, by the power and dollars of the Republican establishment, whose candidates — including Mitch McConnell, the most establishment Republican of all — easily turned back right-wing primary challengers last week.

headline: My First Year
text: Checking in with college students, before and after their freshman year in New York City.

headline: Offer a Caveat Lector?
text: Readers discuss whether teachers should warn students about disturbing literature.

headline: Finding Niche on Other Side of the Bargaining Table
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The windows in his new office face west, away from MetLife Stadium, about a mile away. Mike Tannenbaum could have gone about anywhere to restart his career after being fired as the general manager of the Jets in 2013. But he chose a small office enclave inside the practice home of the Nets.

headline: End Mass Incarceration Now
text: For more than a decade, researchers across multiple disciplines have been issuing reports on the widespread societal and economic damage caused by America’s now-40-year experiment in locking up vast numbers of its citizens. If there is any remaining disagreement about the destructiveness of this experiment, it mirrors the so-called debate over climate change.

headline: Some Like It Hot
text: WASHINGTON — SOME people have such a radical vitality, such an electric consciousness, such a lifelong love affair with the world that when they stop breathing, it’s like a wind dying, like the waning and disappearing of a light.

headline: Faking Cultural Literacy
text: LOS ANGELES — I CAN’T help it. Every few weeks, my wife mentions the latest book her book club is reading, and no matter what it is, whether I’ve read it or not, I offer an opinion of the work, based entirely on ... what, exactly? Often, these are books I’ve not even read a review or essay about, yet I freely hold forth on the grandiosity of Cheryl Strayed or the restrained sentimentality of Edwidge Danticat. These data motes are gleaned, apparently, from the ether — or, more realistically, from various social media feeds.

headline: Poet vs. Novelist
text: The word novel carries for me a weight as ominous, all-consuming and unforgiving as any Job encountered. I was 17 when I decided to write stories as big as cathedrals, overflowing with the kind of memorable and audacious characters Walker Percy, Ernest Hemingway and Saul Bellow created. I stayed up all night, writing description, dialogue, plot curlicues, stories within stories, convinced that anything fewer than 10 pages was wasted time. One wrote the way Thomas Wolfe did, I thought, with fury and hubris, translating everything one read, experienced and felt into glistening, unswerving prose. I didn’t need drugs, cigarettes or caffeine; writing was my drug of choice. And the novel was the high point of literary achievement.

headline: Election of President Seen as a Beginning to Repairing Ukraine
text: KIEV, Ukraine — For some Ukrainians, the election on Sunday to replace their ousted president might be viewed as the triumphant culmination of six months of protests and at times violent upheaval. But for the young journalist whose Facebook post is credited as the virtual trumpet call that ignited his country’s revolution last fall, there is nothing to celebrate — yet.

headline: Why D.S.K. Won’t Go Away
text: HE’S back. It took Monica S. Lewinsky 16 years to face the cameras, but for Dominique Strauss-Kahn, three years was already too long a purgatory.

headline: Iran Billionaire Hanged for Fraud
text: TEHRAN — Iran’s judiciary on Saturday executed a billionaire businessman who had been convicted of playing a central role in a $2.6 billion corruption case that has roiled the country’s banking system and political leaders.

headline: Kid Gloves Off, and a Relief Ace Emerges
text: In 2007, the Joba Rules were the talk of baseball. To protect the developing arm of Joba Chamberlain, the Yankees’ prized 21-year-old pitcher, the team limited how often and how much he could pitch.

headline: On World Fish Migration Day, Recalling When America’s Rivers Ran Silver
text: [If you’re visiting thanks to Tom Friedman’s kind Dot Earth mention in his column on acting with a long-term perspective, here’s a link to the piece he’s quoting from.]

headline: Junta Targets Scholars for New Detentions as Thai Forces Are Sent to Protests
text: BANGKOK — Thailand’s military junta on Saturday ordered two dozen professors and writers to turn themselves over to the military authorities, broadening a sweep in which nearly 200 political officials have already been detained, and sent more troops into the streets of Bangkok and other cities to discourage protests.

headline: Kurt Busch Intends to Drive 1,100 Miles in a Day
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Kurt Busch, discussing why he was planning to race Sunday in the Indianapolis 500 and then in the 600-mile Nascar Sprint Cup event in North Carolina, recalled a week in 1997 “that was kind of my fork in the road.”

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, May 25
text: President Obama made it clear in a conversation on Wednesday with the veterans affairs secretary, Eric Shinseki, that there will be “accountability” for the revelations that veterans hospitals manipulated waiting lists to hide the long delays many patients experienced in getting primary care. Many Republicans and a few Democratic lawmakers have called for Mr. Shinseki to resign.

headline: Lebanon’s Political Standoff Leaves Leadership Vacancy
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Waving to television cameras and assembled dignitaries, President Michel Suleiman departed the presidential palace on Saturday, the last day of his six-year term, leaving behind a political vacuum caused by the failure of the country’s political powers to agree on a successor.

headline: A Wins-First Mentality Has Not Lifted Nascar
text: CONCORD, N.C. — Marcos Ambrose, the Tasmanian Nascar driver and road course ace who has raced for small and midsize teams throughout his six-year Sprint Cup career, has never qualified for the annual playoff. But this may be his year. With a new qualifying format putting stronger emphasis on winning, Ambrose figures he has perhaps his best shot at making the expanded 16-team field for the playoff, the Chase for the Sprint Cup.

headline: Sinn Fein Benefits as Ireland Moves Left
text: DUBLIN — Ireland has taken a decisive step to the left in local and European elections, where early returns on Saturday showed that the big winners were Sinn Fein, formerly the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, and Socialist independent candidates.

headline: Obama to Detail a Broader Foreign Policy Agenda
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama, seeking to answer criticism that he has forsaken America’s leadership role, plans to lay out a retooled foreign-policy agenda on Wednesday that could deepen the nation’s involvement in Syria but would still steer clear of major military conflicts.

headline: Kings’ Coach Says Plenty With Little
text: The Los Angeles Kings have reached three consecutive Western Conference finals, and that means we hear more from Kings Coach Darryl Sutter.

headline: 3 Shot Dead at Brussels Jewish Museum
text: BRUSSELS — An unidentified gunman opened fire on Saturday at the Jewish Museum in the center of Brussels, killing at least three people in what officials said appeared to have been an anti-Semitic attack.

headline: Composers Struck by Homeland Fever
text: A century after the outbreak of World War I, the fervent embrace of belligerent nationalism by educated Europeans continues to puzzle and fascinate historians. The conductor and scholar Leon Botstein investigates this question in a fascinating program of rarely performed works by composers swept up in nationalist movements. The American Symphony Orchestra will be joined by the Collegiate Chorale Singers and three fine soloists: the pianist Blair McMillen, the bass Denis Sedov and the tenor Corey Bix.

headline: One More Round for a Wartime Soap
text: It’s common these days for a made-for-television movie to serve as a test run for a possible series; if the movie draws a decent audience, a series will be created from its characters and setting. The Canadian series “Bomb Girls” received the opposite treatment: an exit movie.

headline: For a Cuban Troupe, a Gift of Rootedness
text: Danza Contemporánea de Cuba, the national modern dance company, first performed in the United States in 2011. The date is noteworthy, since the troupe was founded more than 50 years earlier, in the same year that Fidel Castro came to power. The 2011 visit offered a look, long delayed by American policy toward Cuba, at the official version of modern dance in a dance-mad culture. New York critics praised the Cubans for their virtuosity, versatility and charm. Too bad, more than one wrote, that the choreography was not up to the same level.

headline: When Seascapes Left Stodgy Behind
text: Whether you agree with the Victorian critic John Ruskin that the British painter Joseph Mallord William Turner was a talent on par with Shakespeare, you have to acknowledge that Turner revolutionized the stodgy tradition of marine painting. On Saturday, more than 100 of his seascapes — including his frothy, experimental renderings of wind-whipped oceans — will go on view at the Peabody Essex Museum in Salem, Mass.

headline: Leaping to Honor a First-Name Guy
text: Almost everyone involved with dance knew him, and they all just called him Freddie. Frederic Franklin, who died at 99 last May, was one of modern ballet’s most irrepressible figures. He was always onstage, performing mime roles in his later years. Blessed with an amazing memory and an ability to communicate, he also staged ballets, including American Ballet Theater’s “Coppélia,” the 19th-century comic classic, which the company will dance in his honor. (7:30 p.m. Friday, 2 p.m. and 8 p.m. Saturday, Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center; 212-362-6000, abt.org.) From the Horse’s Mouth, a group that brings dance people together, is presenting three evenings dedicated to Franklin, featuring reminiscences, films and videos. Participants will vary from night to night, and presentations will emphasize his contributions to male dancing. (7:30 p.m. Friday through Sunday, Schimmel Center for the Arts, Pace University, 3 Spruce Street, between Park Row and Gold Street, Lower Manhattan; 212-346-1715, schimmel.pace.edu.)

headline: Young Man With a Horn
text: The jazz trumpeter Theo Croker is the grandson of Doc Cheatham, who played the same instrument with great beauty and economy until his death at the age of 91 in 1997. In a reverse of the typical trumpeter’s story, Cheatham seemed to reach his peak in the last phase of his life. Mr. Croker, 29, may have learned something from his grandfather’s pacing. He started with plenty of promise and made a very good record in his early 20s (“The Fundamentals,” on Left Sided), but rather than speed-track his career, he worked in Shanghai for seven years, in clubs and on TV. He has a new album, “Afrophysicist” (DDB/Sony), showing his breadth, with plush funk and rock idioms, some subtle and complex new-jazz ones, a ballad standard (“Moody’s Mood for Love”) and high-wire soloing. He’ll play this week with his band DVRK Funk, including the pianist Sullivan Fortner and the drummer Kassa Overall, with the singer Dee Dee Bridgewater as guest. (7:30 and 9:30 p.m. Tuesday and Wednesday, Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, 212-576-2232, jazzstandard.com.)

headline: Prepping for Indy 500 and Awaiting World Cup
text: Last year, the veteran Brazilian driver Tony Kanaan won his first Indianapolis 500 in 12 attempts. This year, Kanaan, who won with the KV Racing team, is part of the IndyCar giant Target Chip Ganassi Racing, replacing the retired Dario Franchitti. Kanaan met recently with New York Times editors to discuss the aftermath of his victory, the new season and his interests outside racing. The interview was edited and condensed.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Voices of the Post Soviet Voting Bloc
text: A look at the spectrum of opinions surrounding the hopes and reality of the future of Ukraine as it plans its vote May 25.

headline: The Law of the Land, Edited
text: The Supreme Court has been quietly revising its decisions, sometimes years after they were issued.

headline: Top-Seeded Duke and Notre Dame Advance to Final
text: BALTIMORE — The shootout that was expected between the high-powered offenses of Duke and Denver took about three quarters to develop Saturday in their N.C.A.A. men’s lacrosse Final Four matchup at M&T Stadium.

headline: Final Word on U.S. Law Isn’t: Supreme Court Keeps Editing
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court has been quietly revising its decisions years after they were issued, altering the law of the land without public notice. The revisions include “truly substantive changes in factual statements and legal reasoning,” said Richard J. Lazarus, a law professor at Harvard and the author of a new study examining the phenomenon.

headline: Debussy, Wine and B.Y.O.M. at a Fund-Raiser in Denver
text: DENVER — The musicians stuck to the classics at the Colorado Symphony’s first-ever “Classically Cannabis” fund-raiser on Friday night. They played Strauss and Wagner, not Marley and Garcia. Their only concessions to the evening’s marijuana theme, it seemed, were the bright green ties they wore with their black suits.

headline: As Wars End, Military Gives Its Trademarks New Vigilance
text: WASHINGTON — United States Marine G-string underwear. The Starfleet Marine Corps Academy. And the motto from a human resources company: “The Few. The Proud. The Well-Paid.”

headline: The Fight Against the Slot Parlors Around the Corner
text: LAS VEGAS — Five miles from the flashing lights and scantily clad dancers of the Las Vegas Strip, Dotty’s Gaming and Spirits lounge on Tropicana Avenue hardly resembles a casino. Decorated with red-and-white checkered tablecloths, plastic flowers, knickknacks and old clocks, the place, like most of the other 64 Dotty’s outposts scattered across this metropolis, looks more like your grandmother’s living room — if your grandmother happened to be an avid gambler.

headline: Two Extra Sets, Little Added Drama
text: The N.B.A. continually fights the perception that fans do not need to tune in to games until the second half, or the fourth quarter. At the four Grand Slam tennis events, the opposite is true, especially in the early rounds.

headline: Six Contenders Who Are on Rise or Bouncing Back
text: MEN

headline: Jeb Bush Gives Party Something to Think About
text: As governor of Florida, Jeb Bush flew in Ivy League social scientists for daylong seminars with his staff and carved out time for immersive brainstorming sessions he called “think weeks.”

headline: In the N.B.A., a Billion-Dollar Distressed Sale of the Clippers
text: Six weeks ago, no one would have suggested that the Los Angeles Clippers could sell for as much as $1 billion. The Lakers, yes. The Clippers, absolutely not.

headline: Will Faint for School
text: My Sunday column is about an inspiring young woman who personifies grit—and also underscores the power of girls’ education. Since the Nigerian schoolgirls’ kidnapping, I’ve been thinking about the issue (and writing about it here, here and here). It’s obviously important to educate boys too, but I do think that there’s evidence that the returns for focusing on girls’ education are particularly high.

headline: Gareth Bale’s Goal Helps Lift Real Madrid to Its 10th Champions League Title
text: LISBON — Real Madrid Manager Carlo Ancelotti was in the midst of giving a calm, measured response to a question about his team’s tactics when the door to the news conference room burst open. Suddenly, seven of Ancelotti’s players were on the dais with him, jumping around, singing and spraying Champagne.

headline: Phil Jackson Has at Least Three Great Choices to Lead Knicks
text: Does Phil Jackson want a coach or does he want a marionette?

headline: Change of Program
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — This must have been a tough theme set to pull together. Besides the letter count symmetry, Dan Schoenholz is working with the constraint of having all of his entries be well-known television programs, and then on top of that, he tries to change the names using soundalike words and clue them in a punny way.

headline: Turkish Film ‘Winter Sleep’ Wins Top Honor at Cannes
text: CANNES, France — The 67th Cannes Film Festival came to a restrained close Saturday night when the Palme d’Or was awarded to the Turkish film “Winter Sleep.” Directed by Nuri Bilge Ceylan, the 3 hour and 16 minute philosophical talkfest about life and death, good and evil, the beauty of the natural world and art of conversation, had been a critics’ favorite in a competition lineup many deemed solid if lacking in revelations.

headline: Hitters Erase Deficit, Closer Erases Memory, and Yanks Escape With Win
text: CHICAGO — As much as every closer claims a short memory and a tough skin as part of his skill set, the sting of a blown save can be agonizing, especially if it lingers for days. When a closer gives up a two-run homer on the road to instantly lose a game, as David Robertson did Friday night, the agony can be intense.

headline: Pope Francis Visits Jordan
text: Pope Francis, while visiting Amman, Jordan, called “urgently” for a “peaceful solution” to the Syrian crisis, and a “just solution” to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

headline: Disney Executive Gains Supporters
text: Robert A. Iger began his career as a local television weatherman in upstate New York. Concerned that he was not good enough, he took a job behind the camera at ABC, ultimately climbing to the top of its parent, the Walt Disney Company, as Michael Eisner’s deputy.

headline: Derision and Suspicion Abound Entering Game 4
text: Gamesmanship and mutual mistrust between the Rangers and the Montreal Canadiens ruled at Madison Square Garden on Saturday as the teams prepared for Sunday night’s continuation of the increasingly prickly Eastern Conference finals.

headline: Egypt’s New Strongman, Sisi Knows Best
text: CAIRO — Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, the former army officer soon to be Egypt’s president, promises to remedy Egypt’s crippling fuel shortage by installing energy-efficient bulbs in every home socket, even if he has to send a government employee to screw in each one.

headline: YouTube Removes Video Posted by Shooting Suspect
text: As news spread of a shooting in California that left at least seven people dead, YouTube on Saturday afternoon took down a video clip that the police have connected to the rampage. The website was seemingly caught between its mission and its morals, between making information available to all and spreading material that could be construed as offensive, even dangerous.

headline: Czar’s Winery Faces New Era: Annexation
text: A winery in the Crimean seaside resort of Yalta has been around since Nicholas II. It has survived the 1917 revolution, two world wars and the fall of the Soviet Union. Now it faces new uncertainty.

headline: Down to the Sea Again
text: In the opening pages of “Moby-Dick,” the narrator, assessing the “insular city of the Manhattoes,” notes how even the landlocked are driven to stand and stare out to sea. “But look!” he says, “here come more crowds, pacing straight for the water, and seemingly bound for a dive. Strange! Nothing will content them but the extremest limit of the land.”

headline: For Crimea, It’s Russian Troops In, Tourists Out
text: YALTA, Crimea — When choosing the idyllic setting for an extramarital affair, Anton Chekhov opted for Yalta, and this seaside resort proved so grateful that it erected a bronze statue of the fictional enchantress with her Pomeranian on the main boardwalk.

headline: Vows | Adapting Together
text: Adventurers Eve Hampton and Robert Pratt met while coaching wheelchair basketball at a summer camp. They recently spent 75 days camping together in national parks.

headline: Sisi’s Thesis on Democracy in the Middle East
text: As a student at the United States Army War College, in Carlisle, Pa., during the Iraq war in 2005 and 2006, Gen. Abdel Fattah el-Sisi wrote a 17-page thesis about potential paths to democracy in the Arab world.

headline: Wheeler Shakes Off Early Trouble, but Mets Fall to Arizona
text: Lucas Duda stood at his locker with a blank stare on his face and his hands on his hips. He had come to bat in three crucial moments of the Mets’ 3-2 home loss to the Arizona Diamondbacks on Saturday, with the game close and men on base, and had failed each time. He finished the game 0 for 4, with seven runners left on base.

headline: A Met Finds a Place on the Diamond: Everywhere
text: Eric Campbell had planned to go golfing with his father. It was June 2008, and as a tall, athletic third baseman from Boston College, Campbell was expected to be selected before the 15th round of the baseball draft. But instead of obsessing over where he would be taken, he decided to ignore the thing.

headline: Hacker Helped Disrupt 300 Web Attacks, Prosecutors Say
text: A prominent hacker set to be sentenced in federal court this week for breaking into numerous computer systems worldwide has provided a trove of information to the authorities, allowing them to disrupt at least 300 cyberattacks on targets that included the United States military, Congress, the federal courts, NASA and private companies, according to a newly filed government court document.

headline: Hacker Group Lashes Out Against Informant
text: SAN FRANCISCO — While Hector Xavier Monsegur awaited sentencing for charges that could bring him a lengthy prison term, his former partners in the hacker collective Anonymous and the group’s sympathizers expressed their feelings online.

headline: Using Jailed Migrants as a Pool of Cheap Labor
text: HOUSTON — The kitchen of the detention center here was bustling as a dozen immigrants boiled beans and grilled hot dogs, preparing lunch for about 900 other detainees. Elsewhere, guards stood sentry and managers took head counts, but the detainees were doing most of the work — mopping bathroom stalls, folding linens, stocking commissary shelves.

headline: Finding Tomorrow’s Classical Fans
text: As orchestras see audiences age and dwindle in size, the Cleveland Orchestra is trying to attract the youngest audience of any in America by its 100th birthday in 2018.

headline: Concerns Over Police Brutality After a Bronx Arrest Goes Awry
text: Last Saturday, just before midnight, Javier Payne and a friend stood handcuffed outside a hookah store on a street corner in the Bronx. The teenagers had been arrested, accused of assaulting a 49-year-old man who refused to give them cigarettes.

headline: U.S. Champs Retain Titles in Playoffs After Late Rallies
text: It was a struggle for them, but both Gata Kamsky and Irina Krush successfully defended their national titles on Tuesday by winning three-way playoffs at the United States Championship in St. Louis.

headline: ‘Orphan Black’ Recap: So a Clone Walks Into a Bar…
text: One of the highlights from the first season of “Orphan Black” came in Episode 6, when Sarah (Tatiana Maslany), Felix (Jordan Gavaris), Paul (Dylan Bruce) and Victor (Michael Mando) crashed a neighborhood potluck at Alison’s home. In the midst of this suburban party — while guests congregated in the living room and kitchen, laughing, drinking and listening to ’90s pop hits like “Lovefool” by The Cardigans — the clones and their associates engaged in and/or tried to cover up various forms of torture in the basement and the garage. The resulting juxtaposition from that setup illustrated how different the clones’ lives are from the rest of the general populace. It was also a goldmine for both comedy and dramatic tension.

headline: Francis T. Purcell, Three-Term Nassau County Executive, Dies at 95
text: Francis T. Purcell, a three-term Nassau County executive who in the late 1970s and ’80s promoted the development of downtown business areas and the transformation of Mitchel Field, a former air base, into a recreational and educational center, died May 18 at his home in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. He was 95.

headline: Robert J. Flynn, Shot Down in Vietnam War and Held in China, Dies at 76
text: Navy Cmdr. Robert J. Flynn, who spent five and a half years in a Communist Chinese prison during the Vietnam War, almost always in solitary confinement, after he was shot down on a bombing mission, died on May 15 in Pensacola, Fla. Commander Flynn, one of only two American servicemen known to have been held by the Chinese during the war, was 76.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 24, 2014
Protesters Urge Guggenheim to Aid Abu Dhabi Workers
text: Protesters critical of the Guggenheim Museum’s planned franchise in Abu Dhabi smuggled artworks into the museum on Saturday evening, placing them in an exhibit of Italian Futurism.

headline: Festival Showcases a Lifestyle Lost by Closing a Border
text: LAJITAS, Tex., — Hundreds of people gathered recently along the banks of the Rio Grande for the second Voices From Both Sides festival held along the edge of Lajitas, Texas, and Paso Lajitas, in the Mexican state of Chihuahua.

headline: Candidates on the Right Ride Out Attacks
text: A conservative talk radio host with a history of bankruptcy, litigation and attention-grabbing on-air moments, Dan Patrick is a candidate out of an opposition researcher’s fantasy.

headline: Cost of New Drug Complicates Access for Inmates and the Poor
text: A new treatment for hepatitis C is considered a breakthrough for people with the liver disease. But the high cost of the drug — about $1,000 a pill — has complicated efforts to get the medication to Texans who receive government-subsidized health care.

headline: A Voyage Into Dark Side of Politics
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: Gunman Made Threats in 141-Page Manifesto and YouTube Videos
text: Updated, 12:20 p.m. | Elliot O. Rodger, the 22-year-old gunman who the police said killed six people near the campus of the University of California, Santa Barbara, on Friday night, expressed his frustration with women in multiple YouTube videos and a 141-page autobiography titled “My Twisted World.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, May 25, 2014
text: “In Supreme Court opinions, every word matters. When they’re changing the wording of opinions, they’re basically rewriting the law.”

headline: Melissa Saiontz, Jeffrey Luse
