text: Melissa Ann Saiontz, a daughter of Leslie Miller Saiontz and Steven J. Saiontz, both of Miami, was married Saturday evening to Jeffrey David Luse, a son of Susan Shaskan Luse and Eric Luse of Chevy Chase, Md. Rabbi Gary A. Glickstein officiated at the Ritz-Carlton Key Biscayne in Miami.

headline: Michelle Liszt, Nathan Sandals
text: Michelle Sarah Liszt and Nathan Andrew Field Sandals are to be married Sunday at Beth El Synagogue in St. Louis Park, Minn. Rabbi Alexander M. Davis will perform the ceremony.

headline: Elizabeth Brooks, Nathan Wentworth
text: Elizabeth Brooks and Nathan Benjamin Wentworth were married Saturday at the Seagle Music Colony in Schroon Lake, N.Y. John R. Fulton III, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

headline: Rachel Karnovsky and Sidney Coren
text: Rachel Kaplan Karnovsky, the daughter of Sue A. Kaplan and David M. Karnovsky of New York, is to be married Sunday in Brooklyn to Sidney Alexander Coren, a son of Sara Glantz Coren and Michael R. Coren of Dallas. Rabbi Felicia L. Sol is to lead the ceremony at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, with Cantor Ari Priven participating.

headline: Emily Copenhaver and Daniel Fetter
text: Emily Ward Copenhaver and Daniel Schroeder Fetter are to be married Sunday. Susan N. Herman, a Universal Life minister and the president of the American Civil Liberties Union, will officiate at the Liberty Warehouse, an event space in Brooklyn.

headline: Salvatore Lopes, Brandon Moyer
text: Salvatore Anthony Lopes and Jack Brandon Moyer were married Saturday. Benjamin M. Adams, a minister affiliated with American Marriage Ministries, officiated at the River Café in Brooklyn.

headline: Jon Fox and Darrell Hotchkiss
text: Jon Gilbert Fox and Darrell Alan Hotchkiss were married Saturday. Jean K. Burling, a retired judge of the New Hampshire Superior Court, officiated at the hay farm of Jeanie and Bayne Stevenson in Lyme, N.H.

headline: Juliet Fraser, Wade Gibson
text: Juliet Anne Fraser and Fletcher Wade Gibson IV are to be married Sunday evening at Maguire Gardens in Los Angeles. Robert Gregory, a Universal Life minister and a cousin of the bride, is to officiate.

headline: Elizabeth Graber, Andrew Bentley
text: Elizabeth Paull Graber and Andrew Martin Bentley are to be married Sunday. Judge Jed S. Rakoff of Federal District Court in Manhattan will officiate at the Nicollet Island Pavilion in Minneapolis.

headline: Kiera Butler, Nikhil Swaminathan
text: Kiera Eve Butler and Nikhil Rajesh Swaminathan are to be married Sunday. Kim Triedman, a Universal Life minister, will officiate at the Lawrence Hall of Science in Berkeley, Calif., with Meenakshi Rajachudamani, a cousin of the groom, leading a ceremony with Hindu elements.

headline: Joshua Crouthamel, Kurt Fulepp
text: Joshua David Crouthamel and Kurt Nicholas Fulepp are to be married Sunday at the Hotel Americano in New York. Jeremy Crouthamel, a cousin of Mr. Crouthamel who was ordained by the Church of Spiritual Humanism for the event, will officiate. On Thursday, Wayne Tunnicliffe, a friend of the couple, led a ceremony before family and friends at the Winery in Sydney, Australia.

headline: Shiela Lee and Andrew Chow
text: Shiela Lee and Dr. Andrew Chow were married Saturday evening by Franny A. Civitano, a Universal Life minister and a friend of the bride, at the Golden Unicorn restaurant in Manhattan.

headline: Heidi Skolnik, Michael Glantz
text: Heidi Beth Skolnik and Michael Jonathan Glantz are to be married Sunday evening at the Tribeca Rooftop in New York. Rabbi Kenneth A. Stern is to officiate, with Cantor Margot Goldberg taking part.

headline: Melanese Moody, Chad Richens
text: Melanese Moody and Chad Voit Richens were married Wednesday at the home of the groom’s father, Voit Richens, in Pendleton, S.C. Danielle M. Baker, a minister ordained by First Nation Church in New York, officiated.

headline: Amrita Singh and Sam Bhatia
text: Amrita Singh, the daughter of Surinder Kaur and Gurcharan Singh of New York, was married Saturday to Sam Anil Bhatia, the son of Asha A. Bhatia of Edison, N.J., and the late Anil J. Bhatia. Pandit Prabhakar Sharma, a Hindu priest, officiated at the Pierre hotel in New York.

headline: Jillian Rothstein, Benjamin Solomon
text: Jillian Brooke Rothstein and Dr. Benjamin Alan Solomon were married Saturday night by Rabbi Steven Fink at the Woodholme Country Club in Pikesville, Md.

headline: Sara Mosbrucker, Aaron Hecht
text: Sara Jo Mosbrucker and Aaron Michael Hecht were married Saturday under Pennsylvania’s self-uniting marriage statute at the Sunnehanna Country Club in Johnstown, Pa.

headline: Allyson Davis, Adam Breitman
text: Allyson Jena Davis and Adam Jeffrey Breitman are to be married Sunday at East Meadow Jewish Center in East Meadow, N.Y. Rabbi Marcus L. Burstein is to officiate.

headline: Abigail Coyle, Christopher Caponetti
text: Abigail Marie Coyle, a daughter of Janet M. Coyle and David J. Coyle of West Newton, Mass., was married Saturday evening to Christopher Cartier Caponetti, a son of Paula A. Caponetti and Dr. Richard F. Caponetti of Colts Neck, N.J. The Very Rev. Raymond Collins, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Basilica of Our Lady of Perpetual Help in Boston.

headline: Karen Kucinski, Robin Fukuyama
text: Karen Marie Kucinski and Robin Ann Fukuyama are to be married Sunday, on the 16th anniversary of their first date. The Rev. Dr. Bonnie Bardot, a minister of the United Church of Christ, will officiate at the Jacky Durrell Pavilion in Fairfield, Conn.

headline: Ami Fisher, Justin Lilien
text: Ami Sara-Ann Fisher and Justin Mark Lilien are to be married Sunday afternoon by Cantor Matthew Axelrod at Atrium Country Club in West Orange, N.J.

headline: Eva Talmadge, Mattathias Schwartz
text: Eva Talmadge and Mattathias Schwartz are to be married Sunday evening at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Cantor Lisa B. Segal will officiate.

headline: Rose Karon, Douglas Tilley
text: Rose Leah Karon, a daughter of Cynthia S. Karon and Stuart C. Karon of Newton Highlands, Mass., was married Saturday to Douglas William Tilley, a son of Suzanne Smythe of Essex, Conn., and Christopher W. Tilley of St. Helena, Calif. Stephanie B. Turner, a friend of the bride who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at V Madrone, a winery in St. Helena that is owned and operated by the groom’s father and stepmother, Pauline C. Tilley.

headline: Brian Rubin, Toby Sowers
text: Brian Michael Rubin and Thomas Benjamin Sowers are to be married Sunday at the Hudson Theater in New York. Rabbi Sharon Kleinbaum will officiate.

headline: Jenny Chamoun, Marco Guanilo
text: Jenny Chamoun, a daughter of Georgette Chamoun and Said Chamoun of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, and Marco Guanilo, a son of Rosa Suarez of Lima, Peru, and the late Victor Guanilo, were married Saturday. The Rev. Gabriel Adde, a priest of the Syriac Orthodox Church of Antioch, officiated at St. Vartan Armenian Cathedral in Manhattan.

headline: Yael Buechler, Yair Kramer
text: Rabbi Yael Miriam Buechler, a daughter of Laura A. Buechler and Rabbi Howard R. Buechler of Dix Hills, N.Y., is to be married Sunday to Yair Kramer, a son of Deborah Kramer and Rabbi Michael Kramer. The bride’s father will officiate at the Dix Hills Jewish Center, where he is the rabbi, with the groom’s father participating in the ceremony.

headline: Allison Hayford, Grayson Fahrner
text: Allison Gordon Hayford and Grayson Dane Fahrner are to be married Sunday at St. Christopher Roman Catholic Church in Hobe Sound, Fla., by the Rev. Aidan Hynes, the church’s pastor.

headline: Stephen Billick, Bruce Yolton
text: Dr. Stephen Bates Billick and David Bruce Yolton were married Tuesday evening at L’Église Française du St. Esprit, a French church in New York. The Rt. Rev. Mark S. Sisk, the former Episcopal bishop of New York, performed the ceremony, with the Rev. Nigel J. Massey, an Episcopal priest and the rector of the church, taking part.

headline: Meghan Keck, Matthew Thurlow
text: Meghan Allison Keck and Matthew David Thurlow were married Saturday at the Hay-Adams Hotel in Washington. The ceremony was led by Ray LaHood, the former federal transportation secretary, who officiated with permission from the District of Columbia.

headline: Danielle Veilleux and Ryan Holland
text: Danielle Catherine Veilleux and Lt. Ryan Christopher Holland are to be married Sunday at the Church of St. Joseph in Newport, R.I. Jack Shea, a Roman Catholic deacon, is to perform the ceremony.

headline: A Love Worth the Trip
text: Eve Nicole Hampton and Robert Anthony Pratt are to be married Sunday evening by Rabbi Yohanna Kinberg in the Great Hall at IslandWood, a nonprofit environmental learning center on Bainbridge Island, Wash.

headline: Their Life Is a Laugh Riot
text: Casey Wilson and David Caspe are to be married Sunday at the Ojai Valley Inn in Ojai, Calif. Fletcher T. Wilson, the bride’s brother who became a Universal Life minister for the event, is to officiate.

headline: When City Met Country
text: Eleni Papademetriou Belisonzi and William John Fritze III are to be married Sunday at the St. George Greek Orthodox Cathedral in Philadelphia. The Rev. Spyridon C. Papademetriou, a Greek Orthodox priest and a grandfather of the bride, is to officiate.

headline: Heat Show Glimpse of Their Best, and the Pacers Can Only Watch
text: MIAMI — Even after his team notched a crucial victory Tuesday to tie the Eastern Conference finals at 1-1, Miami Heat Coach Erik Spoelstra did not feel as if his players had expressed their best collective identity.

headline: Corrections: May 25, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Chinese Flybys Alarm Japan as Tensions Escalate
text: TOKYO — In an ominous display of growing territorial tensions between China and Japan, the Japanese Defense Ministry said Sunday that Chinese jet fighters had flown dangerously close to two of its reconnaissance planes in overlapping air defense zones claimed by both nations.

headline: Pope, in Mideast, Invites Leaders to Meet on Peace
text: JERUSALEM — Pope Francis inserted himself directly into the collapsed Middle East peace process on Sunday, issuing an invitation to host the Israeli and Palestinian presidents for a prayer summit meeting at his apartment in the Vatican, in an overture that has again underscored the broad ambitions of his papacy.

headline: Suspects in China Market Attack Are Identified
text: BEIJING — Law enforcement officials in the western region of Xinjiang have identified five men they said were responsible for an attack on an outdoor vegetable market on Thursday that killed 43 people and injured more than 90, many of them elderly shoppers.

headline: Thai Military Moves to Stifle Dissent and Tighten Grip
text: BANGKOK — As protests demanding elections grew in Bangkok, Thailand’s military junta on Sunday warned Thais against opposing military rule, saying “the process of democratization cannot be carried out right now.”

headline: When Hospital Systems Buy Health Insurers
text: Another hospital system wants to buy another health insurance company, and consumers may well wonder what this trend could mean for them.

headline: Pro-European Businessman Claims Victory in Ukraine Presidential Vote
text: KIEV, Ukraine — Caught in a battle for influence between Russia and the West, Ukrainians elected Petro O. Poroshenko as president on Sunday, turning to a pro-European billionaire to lead them out of six months of turmoil.

headline: Change Is Not Loss. It Only Feels That Way.
text: Of course, it was good news. Great news, in fact. What mother wouldn’t be thrilled to learn that her son had won a generous fellowship to study for a semester in Greece? Travel expenses were thrown in too — for visits to Crete and Istanbul (When was he going to study?).

headline: Trail of Violence in Isla Vista
text: Locations of violence in the shooting spree.

headline: In Our Pages: May 26
text: 1914: Part Of Mr. Morgan’s Art Works To Be Sold

headline: Acquitted of Murder, Rapper Is Convicted on Weapons Charge
text: An aspiring Virginia rapper, on trial for the 2007 killings of two men in part because of lyrics he wrote, was acquitted of the murder charges Friday. But the jury found him guilty on related weapons charges and recommended a sentence of 16 years.

headline: What’s On Sunday
text: 8 P.M. (13, 49); 10 P.M. (21) THE NATIONAL MEMORIAL DAY CONCERT 2014  Gary Sinise and Joe Mantegna host this 25th-anniversary broadcast from the West Lawn of the United States Capitol, which will commemorate the 70th anniversary of the World War II D-Day invasion on the beaches at Normandy. The “American Idol” winner Caleb Johnson will sing the national anthem. Danielle Bradbery, Megan Hilty, Jackie Evancho and Anthony Kearns will perform with the National Symphony Orchestra, above, conducted by Jack Everly. Other participants include former Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, the actress Dianne Wiest, members of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, the Army Herald Trumpets, the Army Chorus, the Soldiers’ Chorus of the United States Army Field Band, the Navy Band Sea Chanters and the Air Force Singing Sergeants.

headline: The Manifesto of Elliot Rodger
text: Elliot Rodger, the 22-year-old who the police said killed six people near the campus of the University of California, Santa Barbara, expressed his frustration in an autobiography.

headline: A Role That Blurs the Line Between Drama and Reality
text: Grandma Angelina Nunzio weaves through Times Square in her wheelchair, pushed by a rubber-faced, spiky-haired groomsman and trailed by dozens of revelers on their way to a wedding reception. Like a queen with a scepter, she waves a cane with a dangling red plastic horn.

headline: Obama Makes Surprise Trip to Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The last time President Obama visited Afghanistan, he came to sign a strategic partnership agreement with President Hamid Karzai.

headline: Camping Inside the Indy 500
text: Some fans of the Indianapolis 500 are, for the first time, spending race weekend camped out in luxurious tents on the speedway’s infield.

headline: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, Solidarity’s Foil, Dies at 90
text: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the last Communist leader of Poland, who sent tanks to crush Solidarity’s stirrings for democracy in 1981 and went on to preside over the death of the system that had nurtured him, died on Sunday in Warsaw. He was 90.

headline: Fringe Groups Gain in European Voting
text: BRUSSELS — After four days of voting in a sprawling election with nearly 400 million eligible voters spread across 28 countries, fringe political groups pugnaciously hostile to the European Union scored dramatic gains in voting for the European Parliament and delivered a blow to the bruised but still dominant mainstream parties.

headline: ‘X-Men’ Thrives at Holiday Box Office
text: The strongly reviewed “X-Men: Days of Future Past” gave 20th Century Fox its best opening-weekend result since “Avatar” in 2009, ending a bumpy box office stretch for the studio and demonstrating the ongoing strength of superhero movies. But as strong as ticket sales were – “Days of Future Past” took in about $90.7 million over the first three days of the holiday weekend – Memorial Day 2014 will also be remembered for the crash of yet another Adam Sandler vehicle, “Blended,” which arrived with a dismal $14.2 million.

headline: Venus Williams Subdues a Teenager Mentored by Williams’s Ex-Rival
text: PARIS — Pick a number, any number, to best represent Venus Williams’s first-round match against Belinda Bencic on Sunday at the French Open.

headline: Gunman Covered Up Risks He Posed, Sheriff Says
text: The gunman involved in a killing spree in Southern California on Friday night was able to persuade sheriff’s deputies who visited him in April that he was not a threat to himself or to others, the sheriff of Santa Barbara County, Bill Brown, said on Sunday morning.

headline: My T-Shirt Told Me to Take a Chill Pill
text: My T-shirt tells me things.

headline: Shots Grow Sharper, and the Coaches Deliver Them, Too
text: In two languages — and despite some moments of levity — Rangers Coach Alain Vigneault and his Montreal Canadiens counterpart, Michel Therrien, continued to trade jabs before Sunday night’s Game 4 of the Eastern Conference finals.

headline: Rosberg Wins Monaco Grand Prix
text: MONACO — The Monaco Grand Prix on Sunday was one of the most dramatic in recent years at a track known for its processional racing, with several accidents, two safety-car sessions, many overtaking maneuvers and eight car retirements.

headline: Making Bach’s ‘Symphony for Solo Cello’ Look Easy
text: One of the many enjoyable aspects of concerts in small spaces like the Park Avenue Armory’s recently renovated Board of Officers Room is the chance to enjoy the intimacy of the music making and to see the players up close. Watching Istvan Vardai’s slender fingers dance over the strings during his superb performance of Bach’s Cello Suite No. 6 on Thursday added a fascinating visual component to the experience.

headline: Daring Pass Produces Narrow Victory at Indy
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Ryan Hunter-Reay nearly ran into the infield grass to pass Helio Castroneves with one lap to go and then held on to win by 0.06 of a second in the 98th Indianapolis 500 on Sunday.

headline: Cannes Film Festival: Director Asia Argento on Giving Up Acting
text: CANNES – It’s no surprise that many viewers here saw “Misunderstood,” a funny, free, tough-minded film by Asia Argento, through the lens of autobiography. Set in the 1980s, it centers on a 9-year-old, Aria (Giulia Salerno), the underloved daughter of two monstrous narcissists, an actor (Gabriel Garko) and a pianist (Charlotte Gainsbourg). Soon after it opens, the parents separate and Aria – Ms. Argento’s original name – starts toggling between them even as they reject her, often brutally. Cast aside, she takes refuge in her love of a cat and in her imagination, which soars movingly both in her writing and in some wild fantasies.

headline: A Young Soldier Feels Encouraged, Then Disillusioned, Singing All the While
text: The Saturday before Memorial Day and the centennial year of the outbreak of World War I seemed the ideal occasion to present Nancy Van de Vate’s “All Quiet on the Western Front,” a two-act opera based on the novel by Erich Maria Remarque.

headline: Twists, Turns and Tall Tales on the Path to the Stanley Cup
text: War of attrition, war of wills. That’s what the Stanley Cup playoffs are — more intense, more physical and more prolonged than the playoffs of any other sport.

headline: Bunny Yeager, Pinup Portraitist, Dies at 85
text: Bunny Yeager, a model-turned-photographer whose images of a scarcely clad Bettie Page, embodying feral sexuality and winsome naïveté all at once, helped propel Ms. Page to international stardom as a midcentury pinup queen, died on Sunday in North Miami, Fla. She was 85.

headline: Surrounding a Love Triangle With Spectacle
text: During American Ballet Theater’s spring season, with its panoply of full-length ballets, the business of telling a story can feel more or less urgent, depending on the night. There are works in which the narrative seizes you and sweeps you along, investing you in the fate of each character. And there are others in which the plot, if you could call it that, seems like mere scaffolding for spectacular dancing, an excuse for putting on an extravagant show.

headline: Spotted in a Chic Sand Dune, a Well-Dressed ‘Così’
text: LOS ANGELES — Somewhere, somehow, Gustavo Dudamel has become an opera conductor.

headline: Campaigning for a Desk Job in Late Night
text: When Norm Macdonald was fired from his role anchoring “Weekend Update” on “Saturday Night Live” in early 1998, there was little recourse for his hard-core fans.

headline: Striving for Wealth and Truth in China, in Face of Monolithic Government
text: Evan Osnos appears to be almost as entrepreneurial, intrepid and creative as the strivers whose linked portraits underpin his book “Age of Ambition: Chasing Fortune, Truth, and Faith in the New China.” During eight years of remarkable reporting from China, much of it for The New Yorker, Mr. Osnos ferreted out interesting people to interview, from the billionaire “Queen of Trash” Cheung Yan to a poet sweeping the street outside Mr. Osnos’s home in Beijing. His network included the popular blogger Han Han, whose website has had more than a quarter of a billion visitors, and the dissident and Nobel Peace Prize winner Liu Xiaobo. Others were unknowns, like Michael, who hopes to make his fortune by writing English textbooks; his dreams and self-doubt capture China’s historical moment.

headline: Blood, Toil, Tears, Sweat and Talking Heads
text: It took NBC 26 episodes to cover just the maritime campaigns of World War II in the 1952 documentary “Victory at Sea.”

headline: Drawn Back, Again and Again, to the Flame
text: “The Essential Straight & Narrow,” by the Mad Ones at the New Ohio Theater, is very funny. Then suddenly it isn’t. Created by the company and directed by Lila Neugebauer, the show melds folk-rock, the game show “The $10,000 Pyramid,” schlocky cop dramas and the Nietzschean concept of the eternal return. Ingenious and tricksy, its story lines tantalize and confound. But just when you’re ready to dismiss it as a postmodern goof, it shoots straight at your heart. With excellent aim.

headline: A City’s Simple Joy
text: If there was ever a perfect warm-weather, holiday-weekend city sport, bocce may be it. It requires only a set of bocce balls, which are traditionally made of metal but come in a plastic version these days, and a flat, rectangular space to use as the court. The rules are complicated enough to keep the game interesting, but the skill is simple enough to require no athletic ability. As a bonus, it is a traditional Italian game, commonly played with one hand while the other holds an espresso or a glass of wine.

headline: Doctors, Hospitals and Dollars
Delay Tests Video Game Developer
text: MONTREAL — Imagine living an all-consuming existence as a supremely intelligent yet vengeful, tormented computer hacker who is armed with the technology to control nearly anything and anyone.

headline: Immigration Solutions
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Bull’s-Eye for Marketers
text: To the Editor:

headline: What’s in a Book Blurb?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Gay Chief Executives
text: To the Editor:

headline: Working in Tobacco Fields
Rhinebeck Retreat Selects Musicals
text: Nine musicals have been selected for the 2014 Rhinebeck Writers Retreat, which provides a weeklong residency in Rhinebeck, N.Y, for the writing team behind each project. A total of 26 musical theater writers are to participate, including Mindi Dickstein (“Little Women”), Nathan Tysen (“The Burnt Part Boys”) and Peter Mills (“Illyria”). Among the works to be developed are “Alexander Supertramp,” by Janet Allard and Niko Tsakalakos, a musical based on Jon Krakauer’s book “Into the Wild”; “Stillwater,” a rock theater piece by John Jobson, Ryan McCall and Mr. Tysen, about the residents of a trailer park in Oklahoma; and “At the Beck,” by Chantal Bilodeau, Ms. Dickstein, and Peter Melnick, about two British girls who claim to have taken real pictures of fairies.

headline: It’s Unanimous!
text: The Thai military takes a poll on this week’s coup.

headline: Q. and A.: Chan Koonchung on Tibet, Sex and Censorship
text: The shopkeeper at the small Hong Kong bookstore recognized the author Chan Koonchung right away. The People’s Recreation Community — its initials are a play on People’s Republic of China — specializes in books that are banned on the Chinese mainland, but not in the relatively free territory of Hong Kong. Mr. Chan found his own volumes on the shelf across from the cashier, while the shopkeeper brought over mugs of milk tea.

headline: Dropped at Woodstock
text: UPDATE: Please click here for the Monday, May 26 Across Lite version of the puzzle.

headline: A Film About Film Divides Cannes
text: CANNES, France — There’s a scene in “Clouds of Sils Maria” in which a young American played by Kristen Stewart delivers a beautifully sincere defense of blockbusters to a French star played by Juliette Binoche. They’re talking about movies in a multilayered film from the French director Olivier Assayas that is itself partly an inquiry into cinema. The star, Maria Enders, has become famous in big movies, yet she also voices contempt for them. Given how closely Mr. Assayas cuts to a central tension that plays out yearly at the Cannes Film Festival — a temple of auteurist worship that rolls out the red carpet for industrial cinema — it isn’t surprising that “Sils Maria” wasn’t wholly embraced here.

headline: A Late Rebound at USA-1 Trials in Phoenix
text: Teams led by Nick Nickell almost have a patent on late recoveries, snatching victory from apparent defeat.

headline: For American Men, Long Road to Dominance
text: PARIS — Believe it or not, American men’s tennis may not have struck bottom. Look at the once-dominant Australians, who have no men in the top 40 of the ATP rankings. Look, if you can bear it, at the once-dominant Swedes, who have no men in the top 300.

headline: Bat Meets Crystal Ball as Jeter’s 4 Hits Belatedly Fulfill a Prediction
text: CHICAGO — Brian McCann’s prediction was off by a day, but fairly clairvoyant nonetheless. On Saturday, he told Derek Jeter that Jeter would get four hits in that game.

headline: I.R.S. Bars Employers From Dumping Workers Into Health Exchanges
text: WASHINGTON — Many employers had thought they could shift health costs to the government by sending their employees to a health insurance exchange with a tax-free contribution of cash to help pay premiums, but the Obama administration has squelched the idea in a new ruling. Such arrangements do not satisfy the health care law, the administration said, and employers may be subject to a tax penalty of $100 a day — or $36,500 a year — for each employee who goes into the individual marketplace.

headline: Banner Day Disappoints Before Mets Win Game 2
text: Somber and quiet and shaking their heads, hordes of fans filed out of Citi Field and trudged toward the subway station. The second game of the day’s single-admission doubleheader was about to start, but they had better plans for the rest of their Sunday afternoon. The Mets had found a new way to lose, and their fans had seen enough.

headline: Obama Surprises Troops in Afghanistan
text: President Obama lands in Afghanistan for a Memorial Day visit to thank troops who are preparing to withdraw after 13 years at war.

headline: Jacob’s Pillow Prize Is Announced
text: The contemporary choreographer John Heginbotham, above, will receive the eighth annual Jacob’s Pillow Dance Award. Mr. Heginbotham is to accept the award, which comes with a cash prize of $25,000, on June 14, the opening night of this year’s Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival. His company, Dance Heginbotham, will also perform a new work called “Chalk and Soot” at the festival, from July 30 to Aug. 3. Jacob’s Pillow, in Becket, Mass., established the award in 2007 to recognize outstanding contributions to dance. Previous recipients include last year’s winner, Michelle Dorrance; Crystal Pite; and Bill T. Jones.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 18
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Ukraine Goes to the Polls
text: Ukrainian voters streamed to the polls on Sunday to replace their toppled president, Viktor F. Yanukovych.

headline: Thank You for Being Expendable
text: YEARS after I first returned from Iraq and started having thoughts and visions of killing myself, I’d call the Department of Veterans Affairs. They always put me on hold.

headline: Notre Dame’s Goalie Emerges as Possible Answer to Duke’s Versatile Offense
text: BALTIMORE — Duke needed eight playmakers, six goal scorers, five key defensemen and two goalies to beat Denver on Saturday and advance to the N.C.A.A. men’s lacrosse title game for a third time in five seasons.

headline: Adopt a Dog With a Southern Drawl
text: IF I could be reincarnated as anyone, I’d pick my dog, Landon. He leads a charmed life. Most mornings he gets scrambled eggs for breakfast, which he prefers to hard-boiled. Every afternoon, he takes a long run. Landon sleeps with my husband and me — he’s a 60-pound retriever mix, but seems to expand to five times that size in our bed. In summer, we take him on vacation to Maine, where he frolics on the beach. Not that he cares, but his picture has appeared in the online edition of Vogue.

headline: When California Sang Country
text: LOS ANGELES — Even the vinyl addicts among us have to dig deep for Billy Mize.

headline: Salvaging Steinbeck’s Vessel From a Little-Known Berth
text: PORT TOWNSEND, Wash. — A wooden fishing boat that John Steinbeck chartered in 1940 with a biologist friend, then wrote about in a story of their journey through the Sea of Cortez in Mexico, sits in sad, decaying splendor in a boatyard here, two hours northwest of Seattle.

headline: A Mysterious Map of Louisiana
text: These days the intersection of cartography and Big Data is all the rage: Using information from the 2010 census, countless news outfits, including The New York Times, have created tools allowing readers to make customized maps of everything from trends in ethnic and racial composition to the dynamics of housing development. Indeed, we have come to expect that any large body of data will be visualized through maps and infographics. Such tools help to transform information into knowledge, and at their best allow us to see patterns that might otherwise be lost.

headline: ‘Star Trek’ Prop to Help ‘Reading Rainbow’ Grow
text: LeVar Burton is leveraging a chance to wear the original Visor he sported as the character Geordi La Forge in “Star Trek: The Next Generation” in exchange for a donation to the actor’s more recent venture: an expansion of the revived Reading Rainbow brand that encourages children ages 3 to 9 to read.

headline: Judging Spinoza
text: I.

headline: Speaking the Language of Birds, and Bracing for Their Flocks of Visitors
text: At first light, the pink flamingos stretch their spindly legs, the Inca terns burst into flight and the penguins plunge into their pool. Soon, the air fills with squawks and honks, trills and warbles as hundreds of birds at the Bronx Zoo start their day.

headline: Press Battle in Pakistan Feeds Into Larger Conflict: Government vs. Military
text: LONDON — For a moment, it seemed that a victor had emerged from Pakistan’s news media wars. After a month of mud-slinging between rival television stations, officials from the government media regulator announced last week that Geo News, the country’s most popular news channel, would immediately be closed.

headline: No Time to Text? Say It With Stickers
text: On the messaging app Line, a late-afternoon conversation between colleagues might involve a series of colorful icons, or stickers — a way to invite someone out for a drink or to gently say no:

headline: Slowed Elsewhere, Tea Party Still Wields Considerable Sway in Texas Races
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — This year’s Republican story line may be the declining fortunes of the Tea Party, but conservatives in Texas do not seem to have received the memo.

headline: Lebanon Arrests Radical Cleric Who Backed Militants
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Lebanese security forces on Sunday arrested a radical Islamic cleric who was long prominent in Britain and was wanted here under a new security plan to curb violence in the northern city of Tripoli that has been exacerbated by the war in neighboring Syria.

headline: Hospitals Look to Health Law, Cutting Charity
text: Hospital systems around the country have started scaling back financial assistance for lower- and middle-income people without health insurance, hoping to push them into signing up for coverage through the new online marketplaces created under the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Europe’s Secret Success
text: SINTRA, Portugal — I’ll be spending the next couple of days at a forum sponsored by the European Central Bank whose de facto topic — whatever it may say on the program — will be the destructive monetary muddle caused by the Continent’s premature adoption of a single currency. What makes the story even sadder is that Europe’s financial and macroeconomic woes have overshadowed its remarkable, unheralded longer-term success in an area in which it used to lag: job creation.

headline: Clinton Lauds N.Y.U. Graduates, and Inquiry, in Speech
text: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates — Former President Bill Clinton said on Sunday that he believed that New York University and the Abu Dhabi government would conduct a thorough investigation into worker rights abuses at the university’s new campus here in the country’s capital.

headline: Once Bustling, Syria’s Fractured Railroad Is a Testament to Shattered Ambitions
text: DAMASCUS, Syria — For Younes al-Nasr, a lifelong train lover, the Hejaz railway station here in the heart of the Syrian capital is a repository of shelved ambitions.

headline: Rebutting Mark Cuban on Bigotry
text: Let’s assume, as we always should in the absence of evidence to the contrary, that Mark Cuban, the Dallas Mavericks owner, had good intentions when he confessed to Inc. magazine on Wednesday that he was “bigoted.”

headline: Kings Leading a Series and Dictating Its Play
text: LOS ANGELES — While the counterpunching between the Los Angeles Kings and the Chicago Blackhawks has been hockey’s answer to Hagler vs. Hearns, the Kings have gained an edge on the scorecard that may be wider than it seems.

headline: A Banking Forum in Europe and a Raft of U.S. Economic Data
text: EUROPEAN CENTRAL BANK TO HOLD GLOBAL FORUM

headline: Heat Rely on Cumulative Experience in the Fourth Quarters
text: MIAMI — Basketball players call it winning time, the last quarter in a game, when legs and minds are tired, when all the plays have been called and all the individual tricks and tendencies have been laid bare.

headline: The Pitch of America’s Voice
text: Vladimir Putin’s aggressive return to Cold War propaganda is feeding congressional momentum for a bipartisan overhaul of Voice of America, the federal broadcast outlet that has long jockeyed between providing independent, credible news and meeting its statutory mission as official supporter of the United States. This is not always an easy balance, and a measure approved last month by the House Foreign Affairs Committee would explicitly tighten the definition of the V.O.A.’s mission so that its news “is consistent with and promotes the broad foreign policies of the United States.”

headline: Gov. Christie’s Pipeline
text: Three years ago, Gov. Chris Christie proposed a natural gas pipeline that would run right through the environmentally sensitive Pinelands of southern New Jersey. It was a faulty plan, and the guardians of that area — the Pinelands Commission — wisely rejected the pipeline in January. Now Mr. Christie and his allies are trying to pack the commission with people who will see things his way.

headline: Evan Williams on Medium
text: Evan Williams, founder of Blogger and Twitter, talks to David Carr about his latest venture, Medium.

headline: A Platform and Blogging Tool, Medium Charms Writers
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Evan Williams is at it again. Mr. Williams is sitting in an office here a mile up the road from Twitter, where he is a founder and is still a board member, working on Medium, an amorphous-sounding company that could be one more curio of the Internet age or might end up taking over the world.

headline: Treasury Auctions for the Week of May 26
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes auctions of new three- and six-month bills on Tuesday, after the market closure on Memorial Day, as well as an additional auction of two-year notes on Tuesday. There will also be auctions of four-week bills, one-year bills, two-year floating rate notes and five-year notes on Wednesday, and seven-year notes on Thursday.

headline: Even in a State With Restrictive Laws, Gunman Amassed Weapons and Ammunition
text: ISLA VISTA, Calif. — Even in California, with some of the strictest gun control laws in the country, Elliot O. Rodger was able to amass a stash of weapons and ammunition, despite having struggled with mental health issues for years.

headline: Muslims and the N.Y.P.D.
text: New York City’s police commissioner, William Bratton, made the right decision last month when he said he would disband a unit used by his predecessor, Raymond Kelly, to spy on law-abiding Muslims as they worshiped or patronized businesses in their communities. Beyond proving useless for intelligence purposes, the Demographics Unit undermined the fight against terrorism by alienating Muslims who were understandably angry about being singled out, not for illegal conduct but because of their religious affiliation.

headline: Options Dwindle for Bronx Residents Trying to Escape to the Movies
text: If the Bronx were a city, it would rank about sixth in population in the United States, its 1.4 million inhabitants making it near the same size as Philadelphia, Phoenix or San Antonio. But one glaring difference is especially relevant with the arrival of Memorial Day, the semiofficial start of the summer movie season: Film lovers there have to plan more and travel farther to see their favorite blockbuster.

headline: The Economy, Explored on Film
text: LOS ANGELES — A new film series from Morgan Spurlock and the Microsoft co-founder Paul G. Allen boils down to this: It’s the economy, stupid, and many Americans are stupid about the economy.

headline: Big Travel Day? He Drove 906 Miles in 2 Circles
text: CONCORD, N.C. — The clock showed 3:17 p.m. when Kurt Busch’s No. 26 Honda crossed the finish line at Indianapolis Motor Speedway. He had just completed the Indianapolis 500, racing 500 miles at more than 220 miles per hour in a grueling event that left his back and hands aching.

headline: Music Data Analyst Turns Sights to Books
text: In 2009, Alexander S. White, a former Universal Music Group intern, co-founded a company called Next Big Sound that analyzed vast amounts of data about musicians — from Twitter activity to Wikipedia searches to radio appearances — and showed how it affected sales.

headline: In East, Separatists and Fear Stop Voters
text: DONETSK, Ukraine — Standing in a small park and holding a Soviet flag, Nikolai Brilyov, an enthusiastic member of the breakaway People’s Republic of Donetsk, spent Sunday immersed in civic duties. There was an oligarch to run out of town, and political rallies to attend. None of it, however, included voting in the presidential election.

headline: Political Ad Man Finds the Personal in Democratic Hopefuls
text: WASHINGTON —  Mark Putnam has convinced a Democratic political candidate to swim the Hudson River in February (Mayor Steven Fulop of Jersey City). He has cajoled one to sling luggage on the tarmac at the Baltimore-Washington airport (Senator Ben Cardin of Maryland). And more recently, he persuaded another to ride a snowmobile in subzero temperatures (Senator Mark Begich of Alaska).

headline: In Courtrooms, a Crusade to Give the Flag Its Due
text: For more than 20 years, news organizations in New York City have relied on the chalk-smudged hands of Shirley Shepard and her daughter, Andrea, to draw high-profile courtroom scenes where cameras are forbidden.

headline: Parents’ Nightmare: Futile Race to Stop Killings
text: It was Friday evening when the parents of Elliot O. Rodger clicked open the 140-page manifesto emailed to them from their son and learned of his plans for mass murder and suicide. Frightened and alarmed, they called 911 and then raced to Isla Vista, Calif., in separate cars from Los Angeles, desperate to stop him.

headline: Insurers Once on the Fence Plan to Join Health Exchanges in ’15
text: In a sign of the growing potential under the federal health care law, several insurers that have been sitting on the sidelines say they will sell policies on the new exchanges in the coming year, and others plan to expand their offerings to more states.

headline: Rampage Victims Drawn to California Campus From Near and From Far
text: ISLA VISTA, Calif. — The first time that sheriff’s deputies were called to the apartment of Elliot O. Rodger, the dispute seemed minor, almost laughable.

headline: Popovich: Division III Coach at Heart
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — The euphoria had not yet worn off when Oliver Eslinger, the basketball coach at the California Institute of Technology, walked into his office a few days after his team had won a conference game for the first time in 26 years.

headline: Detroit Plan to Profit on Water Looks Half Empty
text: FLINT, Mich. — As Detroit seeks to settle its debts and chart a viable course for the future, one of its best sources of revenue, clean water for sale, may be evaporating.

headline: Mr. Schumer Backs a Bad Old Idea
text: Senator Charles Schumer of New York wants to outsource the collection of unpaid back taxes to private debt collectors, who would take a cut of the proceeds. The plan is basically a budget gimmick aimed at creating jobs at a handful of collection agencies, two in upstate New York.

headline: Global Digital News Brands See Growth Opportunity in India
text: Newspaper is everywhere in India. Print readership, especially of the country’s vernacular press, is continuing to rise.

headline: On Roller Skates in a Downpour
text: Dear Diary:

headline: As Ballot Count Nears, City’s Teachers Debate Whether to Ratify Contract
text: Jake Rosen said he was not sure what to think. Between co-workers worrying about some of the proposed changes, and others glad for them, between online rants calling teachers “greedy” and others saying they were “robbed,” Mr. Rosen, a history teacher at Beacon High School in Manhattan, said he had no idea which box he would check when it was time to turn in his ballot for the new teachers’ contract.

headline: Colleges Rattled as Obama Seeks Rating System
text: WASHINGTON — The college presidents were appalled. Not only had President Obama called for a government rating system for their schools, but now one of his top education officials was actually suggesting it would be as easy as evaluating a kitchen appliance.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 25, 2014
In Russia, Tune Changes About Leader in Ukraine
text: MOSCOW — Petro O. Poroshenko, the billionaire businessman who won Ukraine’s presidential election on Sunday, was portrayed last month in a bilious campaign profile on Russian television here as money-grubbing, devious, a radical sympathizer — in short, a run-of-the-mill Ukrainian politician to Russian eyes.

headline: Popular Demand
text: Television still dominates the information landscape, with average weekly viewing by adults topping 27 hours. Usage holds across all ages, at 98 percent for 35-to-54-year-olds and those 55 and older, and 95 percent for people 18 to 24.

headline: Beautiful Day at Citi Field, Except for Action on the Field
text: My dad called from Philadelphia late Sunday afternoon. He was leaving Citizens Bank Park, where Josh Beckett of the Los Angeles Dodgers had just pitched a no-hitter against the Phillies. For fans used to more mundane defeats, it was a good day.

headline: Fantasia, Albino Burmese Python Who Inspired ‘Absolute Awe,’ Dies at Staten Island Zoo
text: Like more than a few of the creatures who make their way to the city’s institutions, the python known as New York’s largest snake began public life as an oversize pet.

headline: In Egyptian Town, Cheers for Sisi but Murmurs of Discontent
text: BANHA, Egypt — His face smiles down from campaign banners everywhere, but splashes of red paint have bloodied a few.

headline: Memorial Day Holiday Service Changes
text: Memorial Day

headline: Peace-Talk Critic Takes Lead in Colombia Presidential Vote
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — A harsh critic of peace talks between the Colombian government and the country’s largest rebel group led in presidential voting Sunday but lacked the majority needed to avoid a runoff.

headline: Frank M. Woods, Vintner and Ambassador for Sonoma, Dies at 81
text: Frank M. Woods, who founded the Clos du Bois winery in Sonoma County, Calif., and was instrumental in raising the profile of that region’s wines around the world, died on May 8 in San Francisco. He was 81.

headline: ‘Penny Dreadful’ Recap: Frankenstein’s Monster Wants a Partner. Now.
text: John Logan, the creator of “Penny Dreadful,” has a reputation for not repeating himself, with a resume that includes the screenplays to “Rango,” “Gladiator” and “Hugo” as well as this dependably lurid series. But in “Resurrection,” the third episode, Mr. Logan nods to another of his successes, the film adaptation of “Sweeney Todd,” even at the expense of historical accuracy.

headline: How Nadal Dominates the French Open
text: Rafael Nadal has dominated the French Open as no man has ever dominated a Grand Slam tennis tournament.

headline: Dog Reported Beaten to Death in Front of Owner in Beijing
text: City management officers in Beijing beat a small dog to death in front of his horrified owner, a Briton working at an international school in Beijing, over the weekend, a magazine reported. The officers, known as chengguan, who are a regular feature of Chinese news reports for using violence to enforce regulations like where fruit sellers can ply their trade, attacked the dog because the owner did not have registration papers for his pet, according to the magazine, The Beijinger.

headline: First Win of Year for Johnson
text: CONCORD, N.C. — The six-time series champion Jimmie Johnson failed to win in the first 11 races of the Sprint Cup season. If his fans were panicked, Johnson surely wasn’t.

headline: Return of Brassard Proves Crucial
text: The puck, passed tape to tape from 100 feet away, reached Derick Brassard’s stick on the blue line.

headline: Speaking Up About an Uncomfortable Condition
text: Bowels, especially those that don’t function properly, are not a popular topic of conversation. Most of the 1.4 million Americans with inflammatory bowel disease — Crohn’s disease or ulcerative colitis — suffer in silence.

headline: St. Louis Lifts Rangers in Overtime
text: Martin St. Louis added another chapter to his remarkable playoff journey with a goal in overtime Sunday to give the Rangers a 3-2 victory over the Montreal Canadiens, and a 3-1 lead in the best-of-seven Eastern Conference finals.

headline: What’s On Monday
text: 9 P.M. (Lifetime) PETALS ON THE WIND (2014) This sequel to “Flowers in the Attic” (shown at 7) finds Cathy (Rose McIver), Christopher (Wyatt Nash) and Carrie (Bailey Buntain) Dollanganger struggling to put their sordid past behind them a decade after escaping from their grandparents’ attic. But forbidden desire isn’t easily forgotten, and when tragedy strikes again, Cathy returns to Foxworth Hall to confront her grandmother (Ellen Burstyn) and seek revenge on her mother (Heather Graham, above).

headline: With Ibaka Back in Lineup, Thunder Cut the Spurs’ Lead to a Game
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — Years from now, the story will no doubt have Serge Ibaka crawling off his death bed rather than the training table. He will have rescued a cat from a tree on the way to the arena and handed out free tickets at a homeless shelter.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Monday, May 26, 2014
text: “If you look around the world, there are very few political leaders who are relatively untainted. People want to believe there is somebody good and charismatic, and a good authority figure, out there.”

headline: Mass on Mount Zion Stirs Ancient Rivalries
text: JERUSALEM — The intimate Mass celebrated by Pope Francis on Monday in the Cenacle, the hall on Jerusalem’s Mount Zion venerated by Christians as the room of the Last Supper, capped a Holy Land pilgrimage meant to promote peace and tolerance.

headline: Corrections: May 26, 2014
text: NATIONAL

headline: Chinese Blogger Says He Was Fired After Meeting With Kerry
text: A Chinese blogger says he was fired from his job at one of China’s leading Internet companies for his comments during a February meeting in Beijing with the American secretary of state, John Kerry.

headline: Beijing Seems to Be Warming Toward Aung San Suu Kyi
text: After some courteous flirtation between the Chinese Communist Party and Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, a long-awaited visit by the Myanmar opposition leader to Beijing may be getting closer. The well-traveled Nobel Peace laureate has been to Western Europe, the United States and Australia, but not to China.

headline: Pope Lays Wreath at Tomb of Zionism’s Founder
text: JERUSALEM — A conflict largely defined by dueling narratives became a battle of competing imagery during Pope Francis’ sojourn through the Holy Land, with Palestinians and Israelis both seizing on the pontiff’s strong symbolic gestures to promote their perspectives.

headline: E.C.B. Plots Strategy for Staving Off Deflation
text: SINTRA, Portugal — The European Central Bank was basically intended to do one thing: keep inflation in a cage. But its mission has turned out to be a lot more complicated than that.

headline: After Coup, General Vows to Create A ‘Genuine Democracy’ in Thailand
text: BANGKOK — Thailand’s military junta said Monday that it would stay in power “indefinitely” and that its rule had been endorsed by King Bhumibol Adulyadej, the monarch for nearly seven decades who has semi-divine status in the country.

headline: Ukraine Forces Appear to Oust Rebels From Airport in East
text: DONETSK, Ukraine — The new Ukrainian government struck the separatists in this eastern province with a major military offensive on Monday, battling them over an important provincial airport in ground fighting that lasted for hours. The rebels were left scattered and shaken, just one day after a successful national election they had tried to disrupt.

headline: Pistorius Arrives at Hospital for Psychiatric Assessment
text: Oscar Pistorius traveled on Monday to a state psychiatric hospital in Pretoria for the first day of a mental health evaluation ordered last week by the judge at his murder trial.

headline: Chinese Developer’s Fake Sphinx Has Egypt Seething
text: They say imitation is the sincerest form of flattery, but a Chinese replica of one of Egypt’s most famous icons has gone too far in the eyes of the Egyptian government.

headline: Tiananmen Comment Eyed After Professor’s Microblog Vanishes
text: The popular microblog of a prominent nationalist professor at Peking University has been blocked, possibly in response to a comment he posted about the military suppression of the 1989 Tiananmen protest movement.

headline: Brazil Is Tired of Being Scolded
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — By now, Brazil should probably have been grounded for life, without video games or dessert.

headline: The Jewish Museum in Berlin
text: Images from the Jüdisches Museum and the Memorial to the Murdered Jews of Europe in Berlin.

headline: Bucking E.U. Tide, Italians Endorse Prime Minister
text: ROME — If there was one bright spot for mainstream political parties in the elections for the European Parliament, it came, to the surprise of many, in Italy, where Prime Minister Matteo Renzi and his Democratic Party received more than 40 percent of votes cast, a level no party has reached in any Italian election since 1958.

headline: Voting Opens in Egyptian Election Lacking Suspense
text: CAIRO — Rasha Hazem has brought her two daughters to 10 national votes in the last three years, letting the girls ink their own fingers each time to practice at democracy.

headline: Maintaining a Classical-Music Miracle in Cleveland
text: CLEVELAND — When Milton Maltz looked down from his box seat in Severance Hall — the stately home of the Cleveland Orchestra — he used to fear for its future. “I saw gray hair and no hair,” said the longtime orchestra benefactor. “And I said, ‘Where are the young people?’”

headline: Firefighters Salvage Most of Glasgow School of Art
text: LONDON — Firefighters in Scotland were able to salvage most of the Glasgow School of Art from a fire last week, except for its iconic library located at the top of the building, said Duncan McKenzie, a press officer for the Scottish Fire and Rescue Service on Monday. The cause of the fire, which began on Friday and was extinguished a day later, remained unknown, he said.

headline: Renovation and Controversy at the Roof of the World
text: Four years and $7.2 billion later, Yushu, a city high on the Tibetan Plateau that was leveled by a calamitous earthquake, has been largely made whole, as I reported from there recently. There are thousands of new homes, dozens of schools and impressive-looking museums. The reconstruction effort was made all the more challenging by the city’s isolation and thin air.

headline: Beijing Levels New Attack at U.S. Cyber-Spying
text: A week after United States prosecutors  indicted  five People’s Liberation Army officers on charges of cyber-theft, a Chinese government agency has issued its own lengthy, political indictment of American cyber-espionage, accusing the Obama administration of spying on the Internet on a scale far greater than that of other countries.

headline: Populists’ Rise in Europe Vote Shakes Leaders
text: BRUSSELS — An angry eruption of populist insurgency in the elections for the European Parliament rippled across the Continent on Monday, unnerving the political establishment and calling into question the very institutions and assumptions at the heart of Europe’s post-World War II order.

headline: Astrologers Check Modi’s Stars to Offer Advice to New Prime Minister
text: NEW DELHI – Before the parliamentary elections began in April, opinion polls had pointed to a likely victory for the Bharatiya Janata Party and its candidate for prime minister, Narendra Modi.

headline: Cannes Film Festival 2014, Part II
text: Scenes from the Cannes Film Festival photo diary of Benoît Peverelli.

headline: ‘Mad Men’ Recap: In the Season 7 Finale, Small Steps and Great Leaps
text: Season 7, Episode 7, FinaleWhen Don and Peggy danced cheek-to-chest to “My Way” at the end of last week’s “Mad Men,” it was the capper to an episode so thoroughly satisfying it couldn’t help but make the show’s most diehard fans worry. Already, the final season had been broken into two — for network strategy, not artistic integrity or audience demand — and plenty fretted that it could be followed only by a plot-heavy teaser setting up the real final season: the seven episodes that will run sometime in 2015.

headline: After Much Talk, Rangers Quiet Canadiens With Their Play
text: Montreal Coach Michel Therrien’s recent bravado was missing when he met the news media Sunday night after Martin St. Louis and the Rangers put the Canadiens on the verge of elimination.

headline: In Our Pages: May 27
text: A French television news report about works on the Moselle Canal, hailed as an achievement in European cooperation in 1964. (From the archives of France’s National Audiovisual Institute)

headline: Modi Is Sworn In as Prime Minister of India
text: Narendra Modi became India’s 14th prime minister on Monday, taking the oath of office and addressing foreign dignitaries, supporters of his party, political rivals and corporate leaders in front of the presidential palace in New Delhi.

headline: After Major Title, Wawrinka Exits in Paris Stunner
text: PARIS — Before the French Open began, Stan Wawrinka was asked how different it was to enter a major after winning one, as he did at the Australian Open in January.

headline: Thomas Piketty and Spreadsheets
text: Like Carmen Reinhart and Kenneth Rogoff before him, Thomas Piketty has had questions  raised about his analysis; in his case, his work on wealth inequality. Though I can’t knowledgeably comment on the questions or the analysis, I can comment on the technology that Ms. Reinhardt, Mr. Rogoff and Mr. Piketty chose to do their work: the spreadsheet. This choice can increase the chances of error in complex analysis, but it also can make finding errors by nonexperts easier.

headline: ‘In Eighteen Hundred Sixty Four the Burying Began’ – Arlington Cemetery at 150
text: Where will they go when there’s no more room in Arlington?

headline: Pfizer Abandons Bid for AstraZeneca
text: Updated, 9:36 p.m. | On the final day for Pfizer to decide whether to abandon the plan, it said it did not intend to make an offer for AstraZeneca. Last week, the British company rejected what Pfizer had called its final offer. The cash-and-stock bid, which valued AstraZeneca at about $119 billion, would have created the world’s largest drug company.

headline: ‘Ant-Man’ Movie Loses Its Director
text: The creative team of “Ant-Man,” the Marvel movie based on that size-shifting superhero, has gotten a bit smaller. Marvel Studios announced that Edgar Wright, the British director of “Scott Pilgrim vs. the World” and “Shaun of the Dead,” would no longer be directing “Ant-Man,” about a costumed adventurer who can reduce himself to microscopic size and communicate with insects.

headline: Members of Japanese Pop Group Are Attacked
text: The Japanese pop group AKB48 canceled planned appearances on Monday after two of its band members were attacked at an event on Sunday, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Selling Democrats in Red States
text: Mark Putnam specializes in emotionally appealing TV ads for Democrats trying to get re-elected in primarily Republican states. Ken Goldstein, a professor of politics, explains why they work.

headline: European Green Lanterns
text: Sitting in a room listening to EU officials reacting to the European Parliament elections — and it seems to me that they’re deep in denial. Barroso just declared that the euro had nothing to do with the crisis, that it was all failed policies at the national level; a few minutes ago he said that Europe’s real problem is a lack of political will.

headline: Health Care Cost-Sharing Works — Up to a Point
text: My colleague Aaron Carroll wrote last week that directly charging consumers for part of their health care costs (the practice known as cost-sharing) can harm the health of poorer or sicker people. But for the rest of us, it seems to reduce spending without harming health. This is the basic conclusion of a famous 1970s experiment funded by the RAND Corporation that randomly assigned families to different levels of responsibility for medical costs.

headline: Turbines Popping Up on New York Roofs, Along With Questions of Efficiency
text: A dozen construction workers gathered around a flatbed truck in Long Island City, Queens, one recent Tuesday, marveling at the final piece of a new 15-story apartment building they had just finished assembling. As a mobile crane hoisted the 20-foot-long black contraption over Pearson Street, many of the workers used their phones to film its ascent.

headline: Arcade Fire Addresses Criticism of Video With Transgender Character
text: The rock group Arcade Fire has responded to criticism of a recent video that some viewers felt was insensitive to transgender people, saying that the band put careful consideration into casting and creating the video.

headline: Dave Auckly’s Crunched Charms
text: Our challenge this week was suggested by Kansas State professor of mathematics Dave Auckly. Dr. Auckly was inspired to create this puzzle while writing his recent paper Two-Fold Branched Covers, which appears in the current issue of the Journal of Knot Theory and its Ramifications.

headline: Victoria & Albert Museum Starts ‘Rapid Response Collecting’
text: LONDON — Museums tend to take the long view when it comes to acquiring works, but the Victoria & Albert Museum here has announced that a new gallery opening this summer will be dedicated to “rapid response collecting.” That means the kind of items that can mostly be bought without having an acquisitions committee meeting.

headline: Technology Companies Are Pressing Congress to Bolster Privacy Protections
text: WASHINGTON — A law that allows the government to read email and cloud-stored data over six months old without a search warrant is under attack from technology companies, trade associations and lobbying groups, which are pressing Congress to tighten privacy protections. Federal investigators have used the law to view content hosted by third-party providers for civil and criminal lawsuits, in some cases without giving notice to the individual being investigated.

headline: Grilled Gorgonzola and Beet Green Sandwich
text: This dish is the one that inspired me to devote a week of Recipes for Health to toaster-oven vegetable and grilled cheese sandwiches. I made it one night after a day preparing enough quiche to feed 80 for a book signing. When I got home I had still more quiches to make in my own kitchen, and the last thing I wanted to do was cook dinner for myself.

headline: Grilled Feta and Roasted Squash Sandwich
text: I had a hunk of butternut squash lingering in my refrigerator, and it turned out to be the perfect ingredient for a grilled cheese and vegetable sandwich. I roasted it to bring out its sweetness, and paired it with chopped fresh sage, my favorite herb to use with winter squash. The rest came together quite naturally. The sweet and earthy flavors against the salty feta are perfect. You’ll have more mashed roasted squash than you need for one sandwich. Use it in another, or freeze it for another night when you’re too tired to cook.

headline: Grilled Goat Cheese and Broccoli Sandwich
text: I’ve been finding all sorts of uses for finely chopped broccoli crowns lately (see my burgers from a couple of weeks ago). I make a broccoli and goat cheese spread for this sandwich. I briefly steam the broccoli, chop it finely and mash it with the goat cheese. Then I spread it on country bread, sprinkle with the nut and spice mix known as dukkah and top with the other slice of bread. The dukkah adds the surprise touch. You’ll only use half the chopped steamed broccoli in one sandwich. But you’ll want to use up the rest in another.

headline: Roasted Mushroom and Gruyère Sandwich
text: For this sandwich, you can also pan-fry the mushrooms, which give this sandwich a somewhat meaty quality. But in this case I used the toaster oven to roast the mushrooms. You’ll need only half of the roasted mushrooms for 1 sandwich but you’ll find a good use for the rest of them, I’m sure.

headline: Grilled Goat Cheese, Roasted Pepper, and Greens Sandwich
text: The title of this recipe was getting very long, so I left the last option – roasted artichoke hearts – out of it. I included them in my sandwich because I had some shriveling artichokes in my produce bin (along with the shriveling red pepper I used) and it didn’t take very long to trim and roast them. But it’s not a must; the peppers and goat cheese with the greens are what really stand out. I stir everything together and spread it on the bread. It’s always a good idea to have a roasted pepper on hand for quick dinners like this.

headline: Herb Jeffries, ‘Bronze Buckaroo’ of Song and Screen, Dies at 100 (or So)
text: Herb Jeffries, who sang with Duke Ellington and starred in early black westerns as a singing cowboy known as “the Bronze Buckaroo” — a nickname that evoked his malleable racial identity — died on Sunday in West Hills, Calif. He was believed to be 100.

headline: Podcast: Crowd-Constructing Retinas, World Science Festival, Genetics of Beer
text: Sebastian Seung wants you to help trace the connections in a mouse’s eye — a step toward understanding its brain, and ours. The World Science Festival opens in New York City this week and there’s a little something for every mind. To understand why beer varies in taste, you need to know its yeasts.

headline: Strange Brews: The Genes of Craft Beer
text: SAN DIEGO — Troels Prahl, a brewer and microbiologist at the Southern California yeast distributor White Labs, sits at his company’s tasting room bar with four half-pints of beer. He describes each between thoughtful sips.

headline: Image of the Day: May 26
text: Narendra Modi took oath as India’s prime minister at the Rashtrapati Bhawan in New Delhi.

headline: Obama, Honoring the Fallen, Says V.A. Problems Must Be Faced
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama, just back from a surprise visit to the troops in Afghanistan, honored America’s fallen warriors in a solemn Memorial Day ceremony on Monday and acknowledged the need to confront the widening scandal at the nation’s veterans hospitals.

headline: E.U. Debates Which Nation Will Regulate Web Privacy
text: LONDON — The new European Parliament that was voted into office over the weekend, despite having a different political makeup, is widely expected to reach a final agreement this year on stricter online privacy rules that have long been in the works.

headline: Guarding Against Disease Among Pilgrims to Mecca
text: Going all the way back to a malaria epidemic in A.D. 632, the annual Muslim pilgrimage to Mecca has been vulnerable to infectious disease. Last year the number of pilgrims fell below two million, from the expected three million, because of fears over the Middle East respiratory syndrome virus, or MERS.

headline: Welcoming the Newly Discovered
text: Amid the discouraging headlines about the extinction of wildlife species around the world, there is this bright spot: So many new species of animals and plants are discovered every year that no one knows the number.

headline: U.S. Doctor Is Killed by Gunman in Pakistan
text: LAHORE, Pakistan — An American doctor volunteering at a hospital in eastern Pakistan was shot to death on Monday in front of his wife and 3-year-old son in the latest attack on a follower of the minority Ahmadi faith at a time of rising intolerance across the country.

headline: An Amphibian’s Best Friend
text: Darrel R. Frost, the chief herpetology curator at the American Museum of Natural History, has done fieldwork in Ethiopia, Guatemala, Mexico, Namibia, Peru, South Africa and Vietnam. He is also a sort of gatekeeper for amphibians.

headline: Veterans Fire Back at Letter by Senator
text: WASHINGTON — An “open letter” from a senior Republican senator to the nation’s veterans in which he castigates the leadership of veterans’ organizations prompted a brutal war of words over the Memorial Day weekend, including a promise from the Veterans of Foreign Wars that its “hat in hand” approach to Congress will turn more combative.

headline: Finding Lightness in the Dark
text: Life without sight seems unimaginably bleak to the sighted. No matter that literate guides from Diderot to Oliver Sacks have confirmed that the blind thrive in their separate reality; the gulf between the light world and the dark one persists.

headline: How to Win the Lottery (Happily)
text: If you have won the lottery, or if you plan to do so, please keep reading this column. The information is vital not just to your happiness but also to the progress of social science.

headline: Freud’s Intellectual Wellspring
text: “Becoming Freud: The Making of a Psychoanalyst,” by the English psychoanalyst, editor and writer Adam Phillips, is about the first 50 years of Freud’s 83-year life. This short, dense book is partly a group of abbreviated biographical commentaries, partly about Freud’s career and writings until 1906. It uses both ordinary language and literary terminology to replace traditional psychoanalytic terms and jargon, although Mr. Phillips’s understanding and theorizing are familiar and generally conformable. It is also a less-than-perfect performance.

headline: Young, but Willing to Take On a Challenge
text: The gifted, hard-working and game musicians of the New York Youth Symphony have played some formidable scores over the years, even Mahler’s mighty Sixth Symphony. In some ways, though, Copland’s Symphony No. 3 is harder to pull off in performance than many pieces that may sound a lot more difficult.

headline: Fear Persists in a Divided Ukraine
text: In eastern Ukraine, fear of armed separatists led to low voter turnout in the election that propelled Petro O. Poroshenko to victory as the president-elect.

headline: Syndergaard, a Top Prospect, Is Put on the Disabled List
text: Noah Syndergaard, the Mets’ top pitching prospect, was placed on the disabled list with “a mild flexor-pronator strain” in his arm, the team said Monday.

headline: Look Back, in Danger
text: Peter van Agtmael’s new book is a personal look at America’s recent wars, as well as his own struggles to experience and explain conflict.

headline: Jordan Expels Syria’s Ambassador
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Jordan ordered Syria’s ambassador to leave the country within 24 hours on Monday after accusing him of “repeated insults to Jordan and its leadership, institutions and citizens.”

headline: Protecting Newborns Against Whooping Cough
text: All pregnant women are advised to get the Tdap vaccine, which protects against tetanus, diphtheria and pertussis, or whooping cough. A small study suggests the vaccine may have benefits for newborns as well.

headline: An Alien In His Body
text: Gideon Glick talks about playing Matthew, a chronically anxious 19-year-old who finds refuge in the grungy office of a newsletter aimed at long-haul truckers, in the play “The Few.”

headline: Vision Training to Boost Sports Performance
text: The baseball hurtles toward the batter, and he must decide from its rotation whether it’s a fastball worth a swing or a slider about to drop out of the strike zone.

headline: Hunter-Reay Takes Indy 500 Win; Johnson’s Winless Streak Ends
text: Ryan Hunter-Reay made a breathtaking pass of Helio Castroneves with one lap to go and held on to win Sunday in one of the closest and fastest Indianapolis 500 races ever.

headline: Ukraine’s Next President Vows to Restore Order and Mend Russia Ties
text: KIEV, Ukraine — The president-elect of Ukraine, Petro O. Poroshenko, vowed on Monday to restore order in the country’s east, which is besieged by pro-Russian separatist violence, but said he would not negotiate with armed rebels and instead would demand swifter results from a military campaign that has achieved only limited success.

headline: Pain Medications Can Lose Their Punch
text: Q. WHY WOULD A PAIN MEDICATION LOSE ITS EFFICACY AFTER WORKING WELL FOR SEVERAL YEARS?

headline: Pope Makes Plea for Peace
text: Francis made his first visit to the Holy Land, making strong symbolic gestures to promote the perspectives of the Palestinian and Israeli leaderships.

headline: Reactions
text: Climate Change

headline: Those Mannerisms, Not So Off-Putting Now
text: It’s hard to imagine that the word “yeah” has ever yielded more laughs or more heartbreak than it does in the Off Broadway drama “The Few,” as performed by the actor Gideon Glick.

headline: Candidates Vote in Egyptian Elections
text: Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, a former army field marshal, and his sole opponent, Hamdeen Sabahi, cast their ballots in the presidential elections.

headline: Waggling Bees Give Their Verdict on a Landscape
text: European officials have spent more than $56 billion over the past decade in a program to mitigate landscape change and encourage environmentally friendly practices by farmers. But there is little evidence on how effective these vast expenditures have been. So researchers at the University of Sussex in Brighton, England, decided to seek the opinion of some discriminating judges of environmental quality: bees.

headline: Barbara Walters Gives Archives to Sarah Lawrence College
text: Barbara Walters may no longer be on view to television audiences on a regular basis, but some day it will be possible to review the materials she accumulated in her pioneering journalism career with 20/20 hindsight (give or take the prescription in your corrective lenses).

headline: Lessons of Old Are Still in the Air at the School of American Ballet
text: How does a teenager turn into a cowboy at the School of American Ballet? It’s all in the chest.

headline: Duke Holds Off Notre Dame to Win Third Lacrosse Title in Five Years
text: BALTIMORE — After 59 minutes, the N.C.A.A. men’s lacrosse championship was, in essence, coming down to a face-off, and hobbling in a hurry down Duke’s sideline on crutches, his right leg wrapped in a black cast, was Josh Dionne.

headline: A Diverted Flight Offers Lessons on Keeping Cool
text: I DO a lot of international travel. I used to be annoyed by long flights, and now I look forward to them since I have time to read, work or catch up on some TV I never get to watch, like “Game of Thrones.” I travel so much, I blew through three seasons and am now caught up with Season 4.

headline: De Blasio, at Memorial Day Events, Pays Tribute to Veterans
text: In a day of honoring the fallen, Mayor Bill de Blasio focused on veterans, noting in two emotional speeches that through their stories and tributes they kept alive the memories of those who died at war.

headline: Meeting Rooms Past the Gates
text: About once a month, Therese Hampton flies from Portland, Ore., where her home office is based, to the Seattle-Tacoma International Airport, a 35-minute flight, to meet with co-workers.

headline: Podcast: Science in the City
text: The World Science Festival opens in New York City this week and there’s a little something for every mind.

headline: Science Events: Folded Paper, Kitchen Science and the World Science Festival
text: June events at the intersection of science and culture.

headline: Citizen Neuroscience
text: Crowd-sourced science has exploded in recent years. An Internet game called Eyewire, from Sebastian Seung’s lab at M.I.T., asks volunteers to trace the fine details of neurons.

headline: Podcast: Crowd-Constructing Retinas
text: Sebastian Seung wants you to help trace the connections in a mouse’s eye — a step toward understanding its brain, and ours.

headline: Recruiting Help: Gamers
text: Crowd-sourced science has exploded in recent years. Foldit enlists users to help solve scientific puzzles such as how proteins are put together. Zooniverse hosts dozens of projects, including searching for planets and identifying images of animals caught on automatic cameras.

headline: All Circuits Are Busy
text: H. Sebastian Seung is a prophet of the connectome, the wiring diagram of the brain. In a popular book, debates and public talks he has argued that in that wiring lies each person’s identity.

headline: No Real Hurry to Tell the Joke
text: Abbott set up Costello, and Burns relied on Gracie to finish the joke, but Bob Newhart is the rare straight man who gets laughs all on his own.

headline: Information Not on the Label
text: If you want to know whether the bread you’re about to buy was sweetened with corn syrup, you can check the label. The same is true if you’re concerned about preservatives, caramel coloring or artificial flavoring. By law, all of these ingredients must be listed on food labels.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Michael Behar on ‘Star Trek,’ Acupuncture and Bioelectronics
text: Michael Behar, a science and technology writer, wrote the May 25 cover story about the emerging field of bioelectronics.

headline: Southern Rock, Proudly Revised
text: From Lynyrd Skynyrd to the Black Crowes to the Drive-By Truckers, Southern rockers have been acutely self-conscious about where they come from, writing songs steeped in history, local color, memories, everyday life, expectations and paradoxes. Lee Bains III & the Glory Fires, a four-man band from Alabama, proudly join the Southern-rock tradition of wild-eyed music hitched to serious deliberation. “Dereconstructed,” the band’s second album, ponders Southern identity in a welter of cranked-up guitars, bristling drums and rasping, hollering vocals. It’s pandemonium with a conscience.

headline: A Performer Leaves His Company, With Jewels in His Wake
text: Hail and farewell. George Balanchine’s “Jewels” (1967) — the first big hit he created for New York City Ballet after the company moved to Lincoln Center in April 1964, and now a mainstay of international repertory — returned to the David H. Koch Theater for four performances this weekend as part of the troupe’s 50th-anniversary season. (It will not be danced there in 2014-15.) At its Sunday performance, the principal dancer Jonathan Stafford bade goodbye to the company.  Mr. Stafford, who studied with the renowned Pennsylvania teacher Marcia Dale Weary and then School of American Ballet, joined City Ballet in February 1999; he has been a principal since May 2007. He has been among the most discreet, unshowy of dancers: a true but self-effacing gentleman.

headline: G.E. Chief to Meet With Hollande on Alstom Deal
text: PARIS — General Electric and Siemens are going all out this week to woo France as they compete to acquire the energy business of Alstom, the struggling French conglomerate that makes high-speed TGV trains.

headline: If Chairs Could Talk? These Can
text: Even when I wasn’t sure what I was seeing in “The Chairs,” I always liked what I saw. This “puppet theater response” to Eugene Ionesco’s absurdist play is by turns potent, perplexing, inspiring and weird. Consistently, though, it’s quite engaging to watch.

headline: Battlefield Skills at Work in a City Hospital
text: The medical crises are rapid-fire and improbable, and the doctors who deal with them are easy-to-grasp cutouts in “The Night Shift,” a medical drama starting on Tuesday night on NBC that is akin to beach reading. There is plenty here to get your adrenaline flowing but not much to tax your brain.

headline: Amazon Strategy Raises Hackles in Germany
text: BERLIN — It was German authors, carefully monitoring their Amazon rankings, who were among the first to notice something was amiss.

headline: In a Choreographer’s Series, a Moment to Showcase Her Influences
text: Walk into St. Mark’s Church in the East Village between now and June 14, and look up. About a dozen handmade flags hang from the rafters, each emblematic of a different project by DD Dorvillier, the choreographer and thoughtful iconoclast at the center of Danspace Project’s latest platform, “Diary of an Image by DD Dorvillier.”

headline: Photos on a Plane? Take Note of the Fine Print
text: LET me say upfront that I dislike the pervading notion these days that music needs to fill every formerly silent public place.

headline: Diet Lures and Diet Lies
text: My home is like any other, chockablock with stuff that I wouldn’t want the world to see: trashy books, cheesy clothes, a cache of scented candles so enormous you might think I’m prepping for some epically smelly apocalypse.

headline: When Is Medicating Toddlers the Right Intervention?
text: To the Editor:

headline: From Rich Soil to Your Dinner Table
A Backup Olympic Site
text: To the Editor:

headline: South Sudan’s Plight
text: To the Editor:

headline: ‘A Climate Crisis Is Also a Health Crisis’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Mets Have a Trying Day From Beginning to End
text: Ike Davis bounded through the visitors’ dugout at Citi Field on Monday, wearing all black, a Pirates hat and a shirt that read, “Men of Steel.”

headline: Signs of Diplomacy as Indian Leader Is Sworn In
