text: NEW DELHI — Outside the sandstone palace that was built for the viceroy of British-ruled India, before a crowd that included corporate titans, Bollywood heartthrobs and saffron-robed Hindu holy men, Narendra Modi, the son of a provincial tea-seller, was sworn in on Monday as India’s prime minister.

headline: Advocates Seek to Make Courthouses Off Limits for Immigration Officials
text: Rosario Socope, a Guatemalan immigrant in the country illegally, had an unwelcome surprise waiting for her when she attended a pretrial hearing on a felony charge at a courthouse in Brooklyn this month. As she stepped out of the courtroom into a public hallway, she was approached by immigration agents seeking to deport her.

headline: Applying the Lessons of Politics to Green Power
text: WASHINGTON — Over the years, Tom Matzzie — by working as a political operative on John Kerry’s 2004 presidential campaign and on building the antiwar movement that helped usher President Obama into office — became convinced that the key to creating change was to make it easy for people to participate.

headline: To Prepare for the World Cup, a Host City Could Use Extra Time
text: CUIABÁ, Brazil — The four-day annual rodeo here draws about 80,000 fans, almost twice as many as the state soccer league attracted all of last year. No local team has played in the Brazilian first division since the 1980s.

headline: Djokovic’s Greatest Motivation Isn’t on Court
text: PARIS — Novak Djokovic was safe and dry after his first-round victory at the French Open on Monday, and it was noted that he often seems to play his best when he is playing for a cause higher than tennis.

headline: Dairy Queen Finds a Summer Love: The S’more
text: THEY are not long, the days of wine and roses. Nor, as Madison Avenue knows, are the days of summer selling, which are vital to companies in areas like fast food, beverages and tourism that must gather their rosebuds — and revenue — while they may. For marketers, summer typically runs from Memorial Day through Labor Day; this year, that makes 99 days to wheel and deal.

headline: Really Good Books, Part II
text: On Friday, I offered some of my favorite books, as possibilities for summer reading. The books of Part Two come in two baskets, which we’ll call Athens and Jerusalem. The Athens books fire external ambition; the Jerusalem books focus on the inner spirit.

headline: Leadership on Transgender Civil Rights
text: “We are closer today to creating that open, respectful, inclusive world that we want for all of our children,” Maryland’s Democratic governor, Martin O’Malley, said of the law making Maryland the 18th state to extend civil rights protections to transgender people.

headline: In a New Role, a Champion of the Homeless Looks to Prove His Critics Wrong
text: Not long after Mayor Bill de Blasio appointed him as commissioner of the nation’s largest municipal poverty agency, Steven Banks got a fat raspberry of a hello from The New York Post.

headline: Super Secure, Super Late
text: In the feverish early months of the war on terror, the administration of President George W. Bush thought big when it came to displaying the nation’s muscle and resolve. The White House created the Department of Homeland Security superagency from an archipelago of 22 federal departments with more than 200,000 workers.

headline: Nigerian Military Says It Knows Location of Abducted Girls
text: Nigeria’s military knows the location of nearly 300 girls abducted from school seven weeks ago by Boko Haram extremists, the top commander of the country’s armed forces said Monday. The assertion by the commander, Air Chief Marshal Alex Badeh, was the first time the Nigerian government had publicly claimed to know the whereabouts of the missing girls, whose abduction has provoked global outrage and criticism of the Nigeria military for having failed to find and rescue them.

headline: In Complaint, Activists Seek Audit of New York Police Surveillance
text: Several groups plan to file a formal complaint on Tuesday seeking an audit of the New York Police Department’s intelligence gathering operations, after recent revelations that the department had been monitoring political activists, sending undercover officers to their meetings and filing reports on their plans.

headline: The C.I.A.’s Deadly Ruse in Pakistan
text: The use of a sham vaccination program in the government’s hunt for Osama bin Laden has produced a lethal backlash in Pakistan where dozens of public health workers have been murdered and fearful parents are shunning polio vaccine for their children.

headline: A Cable Merger Too Far
text: There are good reasons the Justice Department and the Federal Communications Commission should block Comcast’s $45 billion acquisition of Time Warner Cable. The merger will concentrate too much market power in the hands of one company, creating a telecommunications colossus the likes of which the country has not seen since 1984 when the government forced the breakup of the original AT&T telephone monopoly.

headline: Governments Await Obama’s Move on Carbon to Gauge U.S. Climate Efforts
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama is expected to announce on Monday an Environmental Protection Agency regulation to cut carbon pollution from the nation’s 600 coal-fired power plants, in a speech that government analysts in Beijing, Brussels and beyond will scrutinize to determine how serious the president is about fighting global warming.

headline: What Did the Framers Really Mean?
text: Three days after the publication of Michael Waldman’s new book, “The Second Amendment: A Biography,” Elliot Rodger, 22, went on a killing spree, stabbing three people and then shooting another eight, killing four of them, including himself. This was only the latest mass shooting in recent memory, going back to Columbine.

headline: Ouster at Rap Genius Over Comments on Shooting Manifesto
text: The authorities say that before Elliot O. Rodger killed six people near the campus of the University of California, Santa Barbara, on Friday night, he left behind a 140-page manifesto.

headline: Reining In the N.S.A.
text: Is legislation to limit collection of phone records strong enough to protect privacy, or should more  be done to limit surveillance?

headline: A Composer’s Other Book
text: With the weather veering between light rain and mist, the Mets fan sitting behind third base at Citi Field kept his score book dry under a plastic poncho, taking it out to make quick but careful annotations — a backward K, for instance, for a batter who struck out looking — with a cedar pencil.

headline: U.S. Training Elite Antiterror Troops in Four African Nations
text: WASHINGTON — United States Special Operations troops are forming elite counterterrorism units in four countries in North and West Africa that American officials say are pivotal in the widening war against Al Qaeda’s affiliates and associates on the continent, even as they acknowledge the difficulties of working with weak allies.

headline: Ibaka Has Overcome More Than Mere Injuries
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — The question was a simple one: Could Serge Ibaka play in a basketball game? His leg was painful, yes, but the swelling in his calf, where the blood pooled, had subsided, and he could move around a little bit. More important, he could see that his teammates desperately needed him.

headline: Gardner’s 11th-Inning Catch Sets Stage for Yanks’ Winning Rally in 12th
text: ST. LOUIS — With some typically crafty pitching, David Robertson earned his 11th save Monday, but it was Brett Gardner who truly saved the game for the Yankees.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 26, 2014
As His Foundation Has Grown, Gates Has Slowed His Donations
text: Bill Gates, who as the richest American has become one of the foremost advocates of philanthropy, has reduced the pace of his own giving to the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation over the last decade.

headline: A Quest to Recognize Forgotten Achievements Still Relevant in Everyday Life
text: New York City has no shortage of formally recognized historic sites, but over the last few weeks it has gained some unofficial markers: gold-colored plaques paid for and delivered by a 44-year-old man who has traveled the country to commemorate overlooked people and places of national significance, especially those connected to the realities of contemporary life.

headline: The Truth Behind a Fatal G.M. Crash
text: Nearly a decade ago, Rhonda Erickson’s son died in a car accident. It is now known his is one of the 13 deaths tied to General Motors’ ignition switch malfunction.

headline: 13 Deaths, Untold Heartache, From G.M. Defect
text: BEN WHEELER, Tex. — For most of the last decade, Candice Anderson has carried unspeakable guilt over the death of her boyfriend. He was killed in 2004 in a car accident here, and she was at the wheel. At one point, Ms. Anderson, who had a trace of Xanax in her blood, even faced a manslaughter charge. She was 21.

headline: Shelf Prop
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — I’ve never constructed a “this reveal is a hint to both parts of the answers of the starred clues” theme, and I can only imagine how difficult it must be to find two-word entries where both words in each phrase can work within the theme constraint.

headline: Bill Clears Way for Blatche to Play for the Philippines

headline: Spain: Village Votes for New Name
text: The residents of Castrillo Matajudíos, which loosely translates as Little Fort of Jew Killers, have voted to change the name of their village to erase any links to the persecution of Jews and a dark chapter in Spain’s history. The name change was approved by 29 residents and opposed by 19, Mayor Lorenzo Rodríguez Pérez said Sunday. The village has only 56 registered inhabitants. The village will be renamed Castrillo Mota de Judíos, or Little Hill Fort of Jews. Historical records have so far failed to yield a definitive answer about how the village got its name. One possible explanation is that Jewish converts to Catholicism in the 17th century switched to a name that would clearly distance them from their Jewish past and reduce the risk of further persecution. Another is that a local clerk mistakenly changed “mota,” or hill, into “mata,” or kill.

headline: What’s On Tuesday
text: 8 P.M. (HBO) THE HEAT (2013) An uppity F.B.I. hotshot (Sandra Bullock) is assigned to work with a loose-cannon Boston detective (Melissa McCarthy, above left, with Ms. Bullock) — the better to temper personality traits that her boss (Demian Bichir) believes are standing in the way of a promotion at the agency — in this comedy directed by Paul Feig (“Bridesmaids”). And voilà! A female version of Felix and Oscar, or Bateman and Galifianakis, is born. “The story is sloppy and thin, many of the jokes are strained or tired, and the level of violence is a bit jarring,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “But the volatile chemistry between Ms. McCarthy and Ms. Bullock is something to behold, and carries ‘The Heat’ through its lazy conception and slapdash execution.”

headline: Another Reason to Consider Renting

That’s clearly unsustainable, and it’s a reminder of how strongly home prices have rebounded in many markets.

The rent was a little higher than we had wanted, but it was on a cul-de-sac, and after apartment living I imagined the kids being in heaven there.

headline: Have You Seen Filming in New York City?

headline: Pharrell Williams and Spike Lee to Team Up at the Apollo

After working behind the scenes for more than two decades as a songwriter and producer, the 41-year-old singer is having his moment, with a hit album (“G I R L”), a single that has been at or near the top of the chart for weeks (“Happy”), a Vivienne Westwood mountain hat that has been an unmistakable trademark ever since he turned up at the Grammy Awards wearing it in January, and a children’s book – plus an online interactive game – in the works.

headline: Rolling Stones Resume Performing in Norway Following Death of L’Wren Scott
text: Was there any doubt that the Rolling Stones would be rolling again? On Monday night, the Stones played the first concert of their European tour at the Telenor Arena in Oslo. It was the group’s first concert since the death of the fashion designer L’Wren Scott, who was also the girlfriend of the band’s singer, Mick Jagger. At the time of Ms. Scott’s death, which was ruled a suicide, the Stones were about to begin a tour of Australia and New Zealand. Those concerts were postponed until October and November.

headline: U.S. Troops to Leave Afghanistan by End of 2016

headline: The Lessons of a Drug Maker’s Failed Deal

headline: Simple Sour: Easy Summer Drinking
text: Almost by accident I discovered a perfect summer beer, light and refreshing yet packed with tangy flavor. Nursing a thirst on one of the first hot days of the season, I had stepped into the Pony Bar, which always has a great selection of American craft beers on tap at its two Manhattan locations. Examining the list, I was intrigued by Peekskill Brewery’s Simple Sour.

headline: Q. and A. | Fujiko Nakaya on Making Sculptures Out of Fog
text: Over the last 40 years, the Japanese artist Fujiko Nakaya has been installing sculptures made of fog throughout the world—in fields and forests, in public plazas and atop parking garages, even in a park designed for kids. A new fog sculpture called “Veil” is on view at the Glass House in New Canaan, Conn., through Nov. 30. To create it, the 82-year-old artist spent nearly a year testing wind patterns and carefully calibrating the 800 mist-generating nozzles that are now installed across the landscape. The temporary sculpture alternately envelops and reveals Philip Johnson’s iconic modernist structure, creating an effect that is at once romantic and contemporary.
