headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Globalizing Wisely
Art and Fashion Stars Toast a Pharrell-Curated Exhibition in Paris
text: WhoPharrell Williams was in Paris last night to fete the exhibition he curated at the new Emmanuel Perrotin space there: “G I R L,” inspired by Williams’s new album of the same name. The multitasking man of the moment referred to the process of putting the exhibition together as “another day of school for Pharrell Williams.” The artists Daniel Arsham, Sophie Calle, Marina Abramovic, JR, Mr. and Laurent Grasso, who contributed works to the show, were on hand, as were the fashion-world luminaries Haider Ackermann, Peter Lindbergh, Alber Elbaz and Vanessa Bruno. The Korean superstar rapper G-Dragon arrived with his entourage, including the stylist Xin Yang, who will be launching his own line of too-cool-for-school men’s wear in Paris next year.

headline: The Bad Father, and Other Childhood Memories
text: Karl Ove Knausgaard, the powerful Norwegian novelist, is a weeper. Life gets to him. He cries all over the place in the first three volumes of his six-part autobiographical novel, “My Struggle,” especially in Books One and Three. His emotions are right on the surface.

headline: Stepan Returns to Lineup And Has Immediate Effect
text: MONTREAL — Derek Stepan, wearing a full plexiglass face shield to protect his broken jaw, returned to practice with the Rangers on Tuesday morning at Bell Centre before Game 5 of the N.H.L.’s Eastern Conference finals. Stepan then returned to the ice after the team’s medical staff gave him the go-ahead to play in the game.

headline: Unit Testing With Block Captures
text: We recently added read-only comments to our iPhone and iPad apps. We have started writing features that can be shared across our apps as CocoaPods, and the comments feature was an excellent candidate for a pod. Going forward, all of our iOS apps will be able to use this feature. We have been striving to add as much test coverage as we can to these pods, and the comments pod was no exception.

headline: Kinsley, Greenwald and Government Secrets
text: Updated, 9:22 p.m. Michael Kinsley’s review of Glenn Greenwald’s new book, “No Place to Hide” hasn’t even appeared in the printed Book Review yet – that won’t happen until June 8 – but it’s already infuriated a lot of people. After the review was published online last week, many commenters and readers (and Mr. Greenwald himself) attacked the review, which was not only negative about the book but also expressed a belief that many journalists find appalling: that news organizations should simply defer to the government when it comes to deciding what the public has a right to know about its secret activities.

headline: Donmar Warehouse to Present All-Female ‘Henry IV’
text: London’s Donmar Warehouse, which attracted considerable attention with its all-female staging of Shakespeare’s “Julius Caesar” set in a high-security prison, will take a similar approach with “Henry IV,” the theater announced on Tuesday.

headline: Now You See It, Then You Don’t
text: When perturbed, Hippopodius hippopus will blanche milky white to make its presence known. It can take a half hour for all of the color to drain from the creature’s skin.

headline: A Breath of Fresh Air From the I.M.F.
text: Some lawmakers in Washington have been exhibiting symptoms of amnesia when it comes to the causes of the financial crisis, as David Firestone wrote last week in Taking Note. Thankfully, another senior Washington-based policy maker – the managing director of the International Monetary Fund — has not forgotten what caused the crisis and why we are still a long way from making sure it doesn’t happen again.

headline: A Designer’s Legacy
text: Massimo Vignelli, who died Tuesday in Manhattan, created a distinctive, Modernist aesthetic.

headline: Ukraine Faces Hurdles in Restoring Its Farming Legacy
text: ZIBOLKY, Ukraine — Like many of her neighbors in this old Soviet collective farm, Maria Onysko prefers to be paid in grain instead of cash for the modest plot of land she rents out.

headline: Detroit Urged to Tear Down 40,000 Buildings
text: DETROIT — A task force convened by the Obama administration issued the most detailed study yet of blight in Detroit on Tuesday and recommended that the city spend at least $850 million to quickly tear down about 40,000 dilapidated buildings, demolish or restore tens of thousands more, and clear thousands of trash-packed lots.

headline: Chilling Images of Gunman at Brussels Jewish Museum
text: The gunman who killed at least three people at the Jewish Museum in Brussels on Saturday has yet to be identified, but investigators have released images of the attacker, captured on security cameras before, during and after the shooting.

headline: A Man Is Missing, and the Toll Is Ever-Present
text: The family in “Gebo and the Shadow,” Manoel de Oliveira’s 2012 film adaptation of a play by the early-20th-century Portuguese writer Raul Brandão, has been stuck in a limbo of anguish and tedium. A young man named João (Ricardo Trêpa) has been missing for eight years, and every evening his father, Gebo (Michael Lonsdale), loses himself in ledgers and business documents. João’s mother (Claudia Cardinale) and wife (Leonor Silveira) bring Gebo coffee and pester him for news of the prodigal. João’s fate is ambiguous, which makes the grief and anxiety of his wife and mother all the more acute, and his father’s evasiveness all the more troubling.

headline: When Assessing Investment Advice, Consider the Source
text: It can be very difficult to separate the good advice from the questionable and the questionable from the downright irresponsible. Unfortunately, good advice doesn’t always walk around wearing a sign, but there are some red flags to help you avoid the so-called advice that’s actually irresponsible.

headline: 70 Years After the Date, Still So Much to Recall
text: The 70th anniversary of D-Day isn’t until next week, but the commemorative programming has already begun. Two offerings in the next few days do a nice job of incorporating some of the few remaining veterans who took part and also remind us just how complex the invasion was.

headline: New Ice Creams and Caramels, and Spreads With an Exotic Touch
text: To Indulge: Surprising Flavors From an Ice-Cream Fan

headline: A Trump Makeover for Washington’s Old Post Office
text: WASHINGTON — The landmark 1899 post office tower on Pennsylvania Avenue — the second-tallest building in Washington — looked out of place in the Federal Triangle of neoclassical government buildings constructed mostly in the 1930s.

headline: The Insider | Kris Kim, Founder of the Online Boutique La Garçonne, on Her Offline Style
text: Too often, online clothes shopping is a task — find your size, pick a color, point, click, buy — rather than a pleasure. One notable exception, however, is La Garçonne — the thinking woman’s e-tailer, whose spare design, offhandedly cool styling and mussed-haired, makeup-free models make its minimalist merchandise come alive.

headline: Holiday Weekend Gun Report: May 23-26, 2014
text: By now, we all know the details. On Friday night, 22-year-old Elliot Rodger stabbed his two roommates and one of their friends to death; shot and killed two women at a University of California, Santa Barbara sorority house; shot and killed a U.C.S.B. student at a deli; shot and wounded five people while driving the streets of Isla Vista, Calif., in his black BMW; and hit four people with his car before putting a bullet in his head.

headline: With a Hashtag, Women Take On Our Fears for Our Daughters and Ourselves: #YesAllWomen
text: Because I never walk through a dark parking lot w/o a second thought, and soon I have to teach my daughters to fear. #YesAllWomen

headline: Such a Charming Old Lady, but Hide Your Diamonds
text: Fleet-fingered jewel thief, compulsive liar, one-woman race crusader, parasite, parent, performer: Doris Payne could be identified in many ways (in addition to her multiple aliases). But she has also clearly had the time of her life. “The Life & Crimes of Doris Payne,” a rough-edged, brief documentary about this octogenarian career criminal, sketches a peppy and beguiling portrait of a convict whose defiant streak of independence has a way of outshining her wrongdoing.

headline: First Lady Rebuts Effort to Weaken School-Lunch Rules
text: WASHINGTON — Michelle Obama turned uncharacteristically political on Tuesday, pushing back against a measure pending in the Republican-controlled House that would let some schools opt out of federal dietary standards for school lunches.

headline: Crowdfunding a Documentary About Moondog, a Departed New York Institution
text: Long before the Naked Cowboy prowled Times Square, wearing nothing but jockey shorts, a broad-brimmed hat, decorated boots, and a guitar, visitors to New York were often startled by a more darkly imposing apparition – a tall, weatherworn figure with long salt-and-pepper hair that flowed from under a Viking helmet, and who stood nearly stone still at the corner of Sixth Avenue and 54th Street holding a hefty spear.

headline: In Minneapolis, a Blueprint for a Bustling Downtown
text: MINNEAPOLIS — The building of a nearly $1 billion Minnesota Vikings stadium has become the impetus for resuscitating a barren stretch of this city’s downtown that Gov. Mark Dayton called “a concrete oasis.”

headline: Who Wants Free Love Anyway?
text: When Misty Terrell turned 28, she happened to see an ad for a special deal on the dating site eHarmony­ and decided it was time to get serious about her love life. Terrell felt pretty optimistic. The site claims responsibility for 542 marriages a day through its “scientific approach” to finding soul mates: an exhaustive questionnaire, the trademarked “29 dimensions of compatibility” algorithm and its clinical labs where psychologists spend hours analyzing couple interactions. For this sort of comprehensive matchmaking, the company charges $60 a month, which is far more than most dating sites, but perhaps something of a bargain when it comes to finding true love. Terrell signed up to receive five potential matches a day for six months.

headline: Walking to Age Well
text: We all know that exercise is good for us, regardless of age. Now a new study, one of the largest and most rigorous to date, proves it. As Gretchen Reynolds writes in this week’s Phys Ed column:

headline: Everything New Is Old Again
text: Artisanal gefilte fish. Slow-fermented bagels. Organic chopped liver. Sustainable schmaltz.

headline: A Test for Mets Hitters From the Fans
text: It is not easy being a Mets fan — in fact, it often makes little sense at all. Consider that the team collapsed in September 2007, then, for good measure, did the same thing in 2008, each time being eliminated at home on the final day of the season.

headline: Detroit Blight Removal Task Force Plan
text: The Task Force’s report is a detailed accounting of the extent of Detroit’s blight, including recommendations for how to both clear up the decay and prevent it from happening again.

headline: Cosmic Sounds, Divine Setting
text: From a critical perspective, the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine is no place to hear a full orchestra perform. For all its architectural splendor, this beloved cathedral has almost impossible acoustics for symphonic music, with an excess of reverberation and echo.

headline: Elections Put Europe’s Centrists on Notice
text: The surprise in elections for the European Parliament over the weekend wasn’t that candidates of the far right and far left made huge gains. The surprise was that it took this long.

headline: Can a Hotel Boycott Change a Sultan’s Policy?
text: There are few hotels as fundamental to a place as the Beverly Hills Hotel. The pink palace, around which the town grew and celebrities flocked, is 102 years old, two years older than the city itself.

headline: Former Goldman Trader Tourre Says He Will Not Appeal
text: Fabrice Tourre, the former Goldman Sachs trader found liable for defrauding investors in a soured mortgage deal, will not appeal his case to a higher court.

headline: How Americans View the Afghan War
text: Polling suggests that most Americans would support the plan President Obama announced Tuesday to keep some United States forces in Afghanistan for a period even as he withdraws most combat troops.

headline: Obama Announces New Afghanistan Plan
text: The president said the United States planned to leave 9,800 troops in Afghanistan after 2014 and complete the withdrawal of all combat troops by the end of 2016.

headline: Pimco Rehires a Former Top Executive
text: Updated, 6:32 p.m. | Before he resigned as chief executive of Pimco, Mohamed A. El-Erian lent the asset management firm a measure of gravitas, opining frequently on the economic issues of the day.

headline: Red Sox Announcer’s Son Gets Life Term After Admitting to Girlfriend’s Murder
text: BOSTON — Wearing a gray sweatshirt and with a relaxed demeanor, Jared Remy, the son of a popular Red Sox broadcaster and former player, went to court on Tuesday to change his plea to guilty in the stabbing death of his girlfriend, Jennifer Martel.

headline: With a Farm in the Wings
text: Gather around the old Victrola, kids. Grandpa wants to tell you a story about wealth, power, real estate, pornography, carrots and a sweet-faced dairy cow named Narcissa.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: Stronger Brains, Weaker Bodies
text: All animals do the same thing to the food they eat — they break it down to extract fuel and building blocks for growing new tissue. But the metabolism of one species may be profoundly different from another’s. A sloth will generate just enough energy to hang from a tree, for example, while some birds can convert their food into a flight from Alaska to New Zealand.

headline: Obama Hosts White House Science Fair
text: The president celebrated the student winners of a range of science, technology, engineering and math competitions from across the nation.

headline: Brunch, From Sleepy to Showoff
text: You’ve seen them on weekend mornings, the long lines of brunchgoers on sidewalks everywhere — the exhausted parents with small children, bleary-eyed late-nighters ready for a hair of the dog, hollandaise addicts. Elsewhere, still in pajamas, are the brunch skeptics — namely anyone who has ever worked an 8 a.m. brunch shift and those who are philosophically opposed to waiting an hour for a Belgian waffle.

headline: Share Your Experience With Veterans Affairs Health Care
text: New York Times journalists would like to hear from veterans about their experiences with health care at Department of Veterans Affairs hospitals and clinics

headline: Fog Sculpture at the Glass House
text: Fujiko Nakaya’s fog sculpture “Veil,” which is generated by 800 mist-generating nozzles installed across the landscape, is on view at the Glass House in New Canaan, Conn., till Nov. 30.

headline: Obama Meets Scientists, One Age 6
text: WASHINGTON — A teenage girl was inspired after dropping her cellphone to create concussion-reducing cushions for football helmets. A team of Girl Scout Brownies designed a bridge that could withstand flooding. And an adolescent boy in a suit and tie told President Obama about his pending patents.

headline: 2014 Sasquatch! Festival
text: Scenes from the 2014 Sasquatch! Festival diary of Holly Andres.

headline: Retiring a Four-Wheeled Combat Survivor
text: The Times’s Jerusalem bureau lost a loyal if not loved member last month: an armored Mitsubishi Pajero.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | May 19-27, 2014
text: How closely did you follow the news this week? Fill in the blanks below to test yourself.

headline: How Careless of Goya to Lose His Head
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — In the musical presentations of the Spoleto Festival USA this year, it’s Minimalism to the max.

headline: BookExpo Keeps It Breezy
text: For enthusiasts of “The Hunger Games,” there will be a trivia quiz on the intricate details of Katniss Everdeen’s dystopian world. Tina Fey and Jason Bateman will be there to discuss turning the humorous best seller “This Is Where I Leave You” into a humorous movie. The best 10-word love story will win a prize. And there will be a book-swapping/speed-dating cocktail hour. (Participants are advised to bring a favorite book and write their name and phone number inside.)

headline: A Designer’s Legacy
text: Massimo Vignelli, who died Tuesday in Manhattan, created a distinctive, Modernist aesthetic.

headline: Fundrise, a Crowdfunding Website, Raises $31 Million
text: Fundrise, a website that aims to draw in a broad range of investors to finance commercial real estate deals, has raised more than $31 million in its first round of funding from a group of prominent technology, real estate and other backers.

headline: Holder of a Cabinet Position
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — I’m worried about Tim Croce. We haven’t seen him since January, and now that he’s back he’s kvetching up a storm about himself. We’re going to have to help him with his self-esteem.

headline: A Vigilante and a Techie, Too
text: To the pantheon of lawbreaking folk heroes in American culture, alongside the mobster and the Wild West gunslinger, we can add the computer hacker. Matthew Broderick’s character in the 1983 movie “WarGames” may have been Patient Zero for this strain, followed by figures from William Gibson’s cyberpunk novels, “The Matrix” and a parade of forgettable 1990s Hollywood thrillers.

headline: As Information Flows, S.E.C. Faces Difficulty Bottling It Up
text: On Wall Street, information is “the most valuable commodity,” to quote a line from the 1987 movie “Wall Street.”

headline: African Dance, Rhythms and Folksy Beats, Pitched to Fill a Basket
text: No matter the lineup at DanceAfrica, one performer always delivers: Charles (known as Chuck) Davis, the revered and beloved master of ceremonies, who founded the festival in 1977 and who, it was recently announced, will step down as director in 2016. Can anyone charm and command a crowd as he does? On Monday afternoon at the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Howard Gilman Opera House, even his “no flash photography” announcement drew wild cheers from the audience. His successor, Abdel R. Salaam, has a tough act to follow.

headline: Some Sparkle in the Noir
text: “Fargo,” on FX, is Billy Bob Thornton’s first television series in two decades. “Crossbones,” beginning on Friday on NBC, is John Malkovich’s first TV show, period (not counting mini-series). Looking for a third movie star to complete the trend? I’d nominate the excellent, underrated actress Thandie Newton, beginning the second season of “Rogue” on Wednesday night on DirecTV.

headline: White House Orders Review After Spy’s Name Is Revealed
text: WASHINGTON — The White House has ordered a review of how officials accidentally revealed the name of the Central Intelligence Agency’s top spy in Afghanistan during President Obama’s surprise trip to the country over the weekend.

headline: Jazz Enigma of the ’60s Has an Encore
text: In the jazz of the 1960s, Eric Dolphy was an original: a hero to some, but also a mystery, a virtuosic improviser searching for ways of expression outside of common practice. He died of an undiagnosed diabetic condition in Berlin in June 1964, at 36, old enough to consolidate his experience and wisdom but perhaps too young to settle his reputation, which had by then taken some knocks from those who found his music abstract or abrasive.

headline: To Get Snowden Interview, NBC News Relied on Secrecy
text: Brian Williams met Edward J. Snowden in the Kempinski Hotel in Moscow last week after months of negotiations between NBC News and intermediaries for Mr. Snowden.

headline: Should the Government Grade Colleges?
text: Should the government rate colleges to hold them accountable for graduation rates, student debt and access for the poor and minorities?

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Ukraine, Thailand, Israel and Washington.

headline: Joseph A. McMillan Jr.
text: Mr. McMillan, 42, is a founder and the chief executive and chairman of DDG, an investment, architecture, construction and development firm that focuses mainly on residential and mixed-use projects. Past developments include the 41 Bond and 345meatpacking condominiums; DDG is currently working on several other downtown projects, among them 325 West Broadway, a former chocolate factory, and 100 Franklin Street.

headline: Prison Terms in Iran Hint of New Reins on Internet
text: Escalating their assault on Internet access, the judicial authorities in Iran have sentenced eight Facebook users to prison terms as long as 20 years and have ordered Mark Zuckerberg, the multibillionaire American founder of Facebook, to testify in a lawsuit that contends the company’s social media applications violate privacy, Iranian news sites reported on Tuesday.

headline: The Sterlings Are Going in Opposite Directions
text: Rochelle Sterling continued to entertain offers from potential buyers of the Los Angeles Clippers on Tuesday as her husband, Donald, sent the N.B.A. a 32-page response in which he strongly objected to charges that he had engaged in conduct that damaged the league and its partners.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
text: RECENT SALE

headline: Pregnant Pakistani Woman Is Beaten to Death by Her Family
text: LAHORE, Pakistan — A pregnant Pakistani woman was beaten to death by her family outside a courthouse in the eastern city of Lahore on Tuesday because she had defied their wishes and married the man of her choice, police officials said.

headline: Army Ousts Commander of Hospital After Deaths
text: The Army ousted the commander of one of its busiest hospitals and suspended three top deputies on Tuesday after two patients in their 20s unexpectedly died in the past 10 days, shortly after they sought treatment at the hospital’s emergency room.

headline: Bringing the Nigerian Schoolgirls Into View
text: The plight of the kidnapped girls has eclipsed a basic question: Who are these young women? A photographer discovered clues in their belongings.

headline: Justices Bar Michigan From Suing Tribe Over Casino
text: WASHINGTON — Michigan may not sue an Indian tribe to shut down a casino opened far from the tribe’s reservation, the Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday in a 5-to-4 decision.

headline: Auction Ends Heated Battle at Philadelphia Newspapers
text: The legal battle over the ownership of The Philadelphia Inquirer ended on Tuesday when its minority owners, Lewis Katz and Gerry Lenfest, prevailed in an auction for the newspaper.

headline: World Bank Revamping Is Rattling Employees
text: WASHINGTON — The World Bank, a famously bureaucratic institution, is undergoing its first restructuring in nearly two decades. The overhaul is intended to keep it relevant at a time when even the poorest countries can easily tap the global capital markets, but with just weeks to go, the process has turned into what several staff members described as a nightmare, stalling their work and sapping morale.

headline: Lawyer on Hacker’s Reduced Sentence
text: Peggy Cross-Goldenberg, the lawyer for the hacker Hector Xavier Monsegur, discussed her client after he was given a reduced sentence of time served.

headline: Dissenters in Egypt Mock Election Turmoil
text: With dissent in the streets effectively banned by law, Egyptians appeared to register their lack of enthusiasm with the presidential election organized by the military-backed government by staying away from the polls in large numbers, some spoiling their ballots or mocking the process online.

headline: Climate Change Doomed the Ancients
text: THIS month, a report issued by a prominent military advisory board concluded that climate change posed a serious threat to America’s national security.

headline: Rebelling Against Abuse, Afghan Women See Signs of Change
text: PUL-I-KUMRI, Afghanistan — Zahra said a neighbor raped her in her home on Friday. It was the most humiliating event in her unremittingly painful life, and the next day she begged her husband, Najibullah, to move their family so the man could not attack her again. He refused.

headline: Why Can’t Doctors Identify Killers?
text: MASS killers like Elliot Rodger teach society all the wrong lessons about the connection between violence, mental illness and guns — and what we should do about it. One of the biggest misconceptions, pushed by our commentators and politicians, is that we can prevent these tragedies if we improve our mental health care system. It is a comforting notion, but nothing could be further from the truth.

headline: Lawyers for Immigrant Youths
text: To the Editor:

headline: After the Rampage in California
text: To the Editor:

headline: Eyes on the China-Russia Natural Gas Linkup
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Girl Gets Mothers to Start Biking Again
text: WHILE women have been flocking to spin classes in recent years, they have shown less enthusiasm for bicycles that actually go somewhere.

headline: When the Justices Alter the Language of a Decision
text: To the Editor:

headline: Putin Blinked
text: There was a moment at the height of the Cuban missile crisis in October 1962 when Soviet ships approached to within just a few miles of a U.S. naval blockade and then, at the last minute, turned back — prompting then-Secretary of State Dean Rusk to utter one of the most famous lines from the Cold War:  “We’re eyeball to eyeball, and I think the other fellow just blinked.”

headline: Tiananmen Square Anniversary Prompts Campaign of Silence
text: BEIJING — Even by the standards of the clampdowns that routinely mark politically sensitive dates in China, the approach this year to June 4, the anniversary of the day in 1989 when soldiers brutally ended student-led protests in Tiananmen Square, has been particularly severe.

headline: Food’s Big-Picture Guy
text: I wish Olivier de Schutter had the power to match the acuity of his analysis, but it’s great that we’ve had an advocate whose vision is as broad as that of the corporations who have for the last 50 years determined global food policy. Since 2008, the human rights lawyer has had the title of United Nations special rapporteur on the right to food. (His second three-year term ends this week.) This is obviously not a genius marketing title and, even worse, the position carries no real power.

headline: The Shrinking Death Penalty
text: Twelve years after it banned the execution of intellectually disabled people, the Supreme Court on Tuesday clarified and thus reaffirmed the essence of its ruling by striking down a Florida law requiring that a defendant claiming that condition show an I.Q. score of 70 or below.

headline: Trapped in Afghanistan
text: For years, the American people have been asking when the war in Afghanistan will end. On Tuesday, President Obama said not for at least two and a half more years.

headline: As Congress Sleeps, More People Die
text: Richard Martinez has a message for the politicians who have been calling to express condolences on the death of his son, Christopher Michaels-Martinez, in the massacre of six people in Isla Vista, Calif., on Friday: “I don’t care about your sympathy,” he said. “Get to work and do something.”

headline: 12 Years Later, a Fund Manager Gets to Give His Side
text: For 12 years, Nelson Obus, a hedge fund manager accused of insider trading, has been waiting — and waiting — to defend himself.

headline: Concentrated Markets Take Big Toll on Economy
text: Nobody believes AT&T’s $48 billion shot at buying DirecTV will be the last attempt by the nation’s communications leviathans to get even bigger. Verizon will inevitably try to bulk up in response to Comcast’s $45 billion grab for Time Warner Cable. Sprint, the No. 3 wireless carrier, is lusting for No. 4 T-Mobile.

headline: With July 4th Fireworks Leaving the Hudson, Jersey City’s Show Will Return
text: Macy’s decision to move its Fourth of July fireworks show off the Hudson River this year will not leave residents of northern New Jersey in the dark on that holiday, Jersey City’s mayor said on Tuesday.

headline: Eyes on Stats, Players Hire Help to Crunch Them
text: MIAMI — For many players, a professional entourage is as much a part of the N.B.A. lifestyle as yacht-size wristwatches.

headline: For Middle East, Region of Religious Conflict, Pope Suggests a Respite in Prayer
text: JERUSALEM — Pope Francis returned home from his three-day sojourn in the Holy Land with the typical bag of ceremonial gifts, including, from the children of Bethlehem’s refugee camps, a mock-up of an identification card in the name of Jesus that lists family members as Mohandas K. Gandhi, Nelson Mandela, Yasir Arafat and Martin Luther King Jr. But the pope also carried with him a promise from the Israeli and Palestinian presidents to come soon to the Vatican for a joint peace prayer, an unprecedented effort to lend a spiritual lift to a desperate political stalemate.

headline: Home Prices Start Easing, to the Relief of Experts
text: A steep gain in home prices in many markets that helped lift millions of Americans out of the red on their mortgages is now markedly slowing, with new data from the Standard & Poor’s/Case-Shiller national home price index on Tuesday showing that the annual growth in prices had eased in March to 10.3 percent, from the previous year’s increase of 11.4 percent.

headline: The Value of College: It’s Not Just Correlation
text: Comparing the earnings of college graduates and nongraduates is an imperfect way of measuring the value of a degree, as I noted in my Tuesday column. Hypothetically, college graduates could earn more because they’re innately smarter — and would have earned just as much if they had never attended college or even any school. As a reader named Shawn posted in the comments section of the column, “The useful comparison is not between those who do and do not attend college but, rather, between equally intelligent students who do and do not choose to attend college.”

headline: Nigeria Denies Formal Talks on Captive Schoolgirls
text: DAKAR, Senegal — With reports swirling in the Nigerian media of a possible negotiation to free hundreds of schoolgirls kidnapped by Islamist extremists, and the country’s top armed forces commander ruling out force to do so, the government’s chief spokesman again denied Tuesday that any “formal, official” talks were underway with the extremist group Boko Haram.

headline: After California Attack That Killed 6 Students, Classmates Pause and Seek Closure
text: ISLA VISTA, Calif. — Across the street from the IV Deli Mart, one of the places where Elliot O. Rodger opened fire on Friday night before killing himself, people wrote mournful and inspiring messages in chalk on Tuesday. On the campus of the University of California, Santa Barbara, students stood by a bike path holding “Free Hugs” signs and shouting “Have a great day!” to cyclists and skateboarders. Flags at all 10 University of California campuses remained lowered.

headline: 21 Die in Fire at Hospital in South Korea
text: SEOUL, South Korea — A fire broke out at a hospital annex in southwestern South Korea early Wednesday, killing 21 people and injuring seven others and further rattling a country still traumatized by a recent ferry disaster.

headline: Finding Some Solace, if Not a Victory
text: PARIS — If love is cruel, how about sport?

headline: De Blasio’s Latest Break With His Predecessors: Ending a Ban on Ferrets
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio prides himself on confronting New York’s knottiest civic problems, such as expanding classroom time for preschoolers and lowering the cost of urban housing.

headline: Win by Far-Right Party Rattles the French Establishment
text: PARIS — The stark victory of France’s far-right National Front in the European Parliament elections has badly rattled the country’s political establishment, eroding support for President François Hollande’s policies within his own Socialist Party and calling into question whether France was in danger of losing its place alongside Germany at the center of the European stage.

headline: Fringe Group in Britain Forces Others to Listen
text: LONDON — Nigel Farage boasts that his United Kingdom Independence Party is now “the fox” in the Westminster henhouse. But in reality, without a single seat in Parliament, he is still prowling the boundaries of the farm.

headline: Giuliani’s Take on Ferrets
text: Voices were raised on both sides in 1999 when David J. Guthartz, the executive president of New York Ferret’s Rights Advocacy, called into Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani’s radio show.

headline: Lieutenant Governor Loses Texas Runoff as Tea Party Holds Sway
text: HOUSTON — Dan Patrick, a state senator who has taken outspoken stands against abortion, same-sex marriage and illegal immigration, won a Republican runoff for lieutenant governor on Tuesday, handily defeating David Dewhurst, the longtime incumbent, in a race that illustrated the continuing power of the Tea Party in Texas.

headline: Columbia Baseball Has Repeating Theme: Team
text: Columbia has achieved success recently by relying on cornerstones of any good baseball team: pitching and defense. But it has also put an emphasis on something else: character over athleticism.

headline: Artist or Gang Leader? Rapper’s Trial Begins
text: To his fans and friends, the rapper known as Ra Diggs was a hero from the Brooklyn projects, a charismatic artist whose music videos chronicled life there.

headline: Etchings at 9/11 Memorial Are Called Both Anguished Tributes and Vandalism
text: The panels at the National September 11 Memorial containing the victims’ names must constantly be inspected for graffiti scratched into the bronze surfaces, a memorial spokesman said on Tuesday.

headline: The Google Car Takes a Step Away From Boring
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — Not so boring?

headline: Google’s Next Phase in Driverless Cars: No Steering Wheel or Brake Pedals
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — Humans might be the one problem Google can’t solve.

headline: Google’s Video of Its Self-Driving Car
text: The company has begun building a fleet of experimental electric-powered vehicles that can’t be driven by people and are summoned with a smartphone app.

headline: Double-Parking Is Exception on Liability in Rear-End Crashes, Judge Says
text: From huge potholes to a taxi door suddenly swinging open into traffic, New York City drivers must routinely avoid all manner of unexpected events and hazards.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 27, 2014
In Schools Where Sports May Be Most Vital, New York City Offers Least Help
text: The pitch screamed through the muggy late-afternoon heat of Rainey Park in the Bronx, and the batter, an infielder with International Community High School, just managed to tip it so that the ball flew over the backstop, in the opposite direction of the field. A toddler, legs churning, grabbed the ball and handed it to Stanley Hernandez, an assistant coach. He gave the boy a big smile.

headline: Retired Officer Fatally Shoots Armed Assailant During Carjacking Attempt
text: A retired New York City police officer shot and killed an armed 18-year-old who tried to rob him and steal his car early Tuesday in Brooklyn, the police said.

headline: How to Catch a Bike Thief
text: Bike theft is a serious problem in San Francisco. Now the police are using every tool they have, including GPS trackers in bikes, social media and thousands of stickers that ask thieves a question.

headline: Police Use High-Tech Lures to Reel in Bike Thieves
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Officer Matt Friedman fights crime with modern tools: Twitter, which he uses to publicize pictures of suspects and convicted criminals, and a GPS device, which he uses to track down stolen property.

headline: Amid Split on Bank Case, U.S. Seeks a Middle Path
text: WASHINGTON — Solicitor General Donald B. Verrilli Jr. faced a legal and bureaucratic dilemma this year: Obama administration officials could not agree about what he should tell the Supreme Court about a lawsuit in which American victims of terrorist attacks in Israel are suing Arab Bank, the largest financial institution in Jordan.

headline: Libya: State Dept. Urges Americans to Leave
text: The State Department issued a travel warning on Tuesday urging Americans against traveling to Libya and asking those already there to leave. The department cited the continuing fighting among militias, including an attack on the Parliament building 10 days ago; the Tripoli government’s inability to stop the violence; and repeated threats against American interests. The United States Embassy, the State Department said, “is only able to offer very limited emergency services to U.S. citizens in Libya.”

headline: South Sudan: U.N. Shifts Focus of Its Mandate
text: The United Nations Security Council unanimously passed a resolution on Tuesday that shifts its peacekeeping operations in South Sudan away from nation-building and toward safeguarding civilians threatened by ethnic violence and political instability. The resolution, which extended the mission until Nov. 30, retains its size but authorizes “all necessary means” to protect civilians, to police rights abuses, to ensure aid delivery and to enforce cease-fires among rival factions in the country, which became independent in 2011. Thousands have been killed, and more than 1.3 million people have fled their homes since December, when fighting erupted between loyalists to President Salva Kiir, an ethnic Dinka, and his former vice president, Riek Machar, a Nuer. A recent United Nations report described atrocities “on a massive scale” by both sides. The United Nations refugee agency reported Tuesday that 76,000 South Sudanese had fled fighting since the latest cease-fire was signed on May 9.

headline: Sierra Leone: Ebola Virus Spreads From Guinea
text: West Africa’s Ebola outbreak appears to have spread to Sierra Leone, the World Health Organization said Monday. One death in a village near the border with Guinea has been confirmed by a laboratory as Ebola, and four other deaths are considered suspect. Sierra Leone health officials told the Voice of America that the confirmed case was a woman who had just returned from the funeral of an Ebola victim in Guinea; the suspect cases included her relatives. The outbreak began in Guinea in March and spread to Liberia; of the 259 cases reported to the W.H.O., 175 have been fatal.

headline: Defining Blight in Detroit
text: More than a fifth of Detroit’s properties are plagued with blight, according to a report by the Blight Removal Task Force.

headline: Holder Hints Reporter May Be Spared Jail in Leak
text: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. hinted Tuesday that the Justice Department might choose not to jail a New York Times reporter for defying a subpoena forcing him to discuss his confidential sources — even as the Obama administration continues to pursue the right to do so before the Supreme Court.

headline: New York Assembly Passes Medical Marijuana Bill
text: ALBANY — For the fifth time in seven years, the State Assembly on Tuesday passed a bill legalizing medical marijuana, backing a measure that would far surpass a program Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced this year.

headline: Questioned About Body, Townsend Rises and Inspires
text: PARIS — Taylor Townsend had found her footing on far slipperier surfaces than the red clay of Court 16 at Roland Garros.

headline: Obama Asks Homeland Security Secretary to Delay Deportation Review
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama has directed the secretary of Homeland Security to delay until after the summer a deportation enforcement review that officials feared would anger House Republicans and doom any lingering hopes for an immigration overhaul in Congress this year, officials said Tuesday night.

headline: Matthew Saad Muhammad, Boxing Champion, Is Dead
text: Matthew Saad Muhammad, a former boxing champion known for his bruising style whose rags-to-riches-to-rags life story began in abandonment and nearly ended in homelessness, died on Sunday in Philadelphia, where for many years he had been a local hero. He was thought to be 59.

headline: Should Ferrets be Allowed as Pets?
text: In a memo from the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, health officials weighed the pluses and minuses of allowing ferrets to be kept as pets.

headline: In Early Voting, Jeter Is on Pace to Start All-Star Game for Ninth Time
text: ST. LOUIS — Derek Jeter is a virtual certainty to make his 14th American League All-Star team in July, whether through fan voting or a selection to the team by the A.L. manager, John Farrell. After the first vote tabulation announced by Major League Baseball, Jeter is on his way to earning the spot through voting by fans who recognize this is his last season.

headline: ‘Fargo’ Recap: Fool’s Paradise
text: Well, Molly did survive. Granted, Deputy Gus Grimly, the haphazard cop and postman wannabe, fired one shot as Molly’s backup, into the blizzard swirling all around them during last week’s gun battle.

headline: Justices, in 2 Cases, Side With Law Enforcement Officials
text: WASHINGTON — In a pair of unanimous decisions favoring law enforcement officials, the Supreme Court on Tuesday ruled for Arkansas police officers who had used deadly force to end a high-speed chase and for Secret Service agents who had moved protesters away from President George W. Bush.

headline: Chased Back to the Garden
text: MONTREAL — There was no celebration for the Rangers on Tuesday night, no triumphant passage to the Stanley Cup finals. Instead, there was nastiness, chaotic defense and uncharacteristically flawed goaltending, with Henrik Lundqvist chased from the nets by a deluge of Montreal goals and with his substitute, Cam Talbot, faring little better.

headline: Times Minute | A U.S. Diplomacy Reboot
text: The White House correspondent Mark Landler on what to watch for as President Obama prepares to lay out foreign policy changes at West Point’s graduation ceremony.

headline: Times Minute | A U.S. Diplomacy Reboot
text: In the Video

headline: Stepan Roars Into Fray With Broken Jaw and Comes Away With Two Goals
text: MONTREAL — Derek Stepan can eat only soft food, and he has been taking painkilling medication. But after the singing of the national anthems Tuesday night, he skated to the Rangers’ bench, placed his gloves on the boards and put on the unwieldy contraption that would allow him to play.

headline: Angelina’s Makeup Artist on How to Use the New Cheekbone-Contouring Products
text: Last month, the British makeup artist Charlotte Tilbury visited the States to introduce her beauty line, which arrives here later this year, and proudly present her Filmstar Bronze & Glow product to a small group of beauty editors. It’s a miracle-working compact designed to make the roundest of facest appear toned, and is filled with two kinds of powder: a darker one, which creates depth when brushed into the hollows of the cheeks, and a lighter, shimmery one, which makes the cheekbones rise and pop. These nature-defying contouring and highlighting products have cropped up on beauty counters everywhere in recent months, like the Nars Contour Blush palettes, introduced back in March, and the MAC Maleficent Sculpting Powder, unveiled earlier this month as part of the brand’s new collection inspired by the Disney blockbuster of the same name, which stars Angelina Jolie and hits theaters this Friday.

headline: Warm, Versatile Minimalism from Calvin Klein’s Latest Furniture Collection
text: Calvin Klein is known for its sleek, streamlined apparel. And since 1995, when the company first opened its flagship store designed by the architect John Pawson, the brand has offered home furnishings with a similar aesthetic. But you don’t have to live in a temple of minimalism to enjoy its latest furniture collection. Individually or together, the brass-plated Radiant accent table ($2,000) and the Facet folding stool made of natural oak ($1,100) possess a warmth and materiality that will find a place in almost any home.

headline: Word of the Day | inadvertently
text: inadvertently •\in-ad-ˈvərt-tənt-le\• adverb

headline: Some Calming News Caps a Tumultuous 24 Hours for the Mets
text: Around 5 p.m. Tuesday, Sandy Alderson finally had some good news to deliver about the Mets. A magnetic resonance imaging exam for Noah Syndergaard came back clean, meaning Syndergaard, the organization’s top pitching prospect, was not in any danger of needing surgery on his sore right arm. A little bit of rest would presumably solve the problem.

headline: Mets Hammer Out a Victory
text: The Mets’ offense did just enough Tuesday to get the team its third win in the last eight games, rapping out four extra-base hits to beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 4-2, at Citi Field.

headline: Phelps’s Return Home Is Short of Sweet as Yankees Stumble in St. Louis
text: ST. LOUIS — When David Phelps walked to the outfield to begin preparing for his first start against his hometown team, the club he adored in his youth, he squatted down and took a moment to absorb his surroundings.

headline: Amazon Defends Itself in Dispute, Suggests Hachette Customers Go Elsewhere
text: Amazon issued a statement late Tuesday defending its right to discourage customers from buying books from Hachette, one of the country’s biggest publishers.

headline: A Fiery Duncan Cannot Rescue the Spurs
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — As the San Antonio Spurs have won admirers and championships over the years, one of their defining characteristics has been the monochromatic mien of Tim Duncan.

headline: Intense Holiday Retires Prior to Belmont
text: Intense Holiday, who finished 12th in the Kentucky Derby on May 3 and was being pointed toward the Belmont Stakes on June 7, was retired from racing Tuesday, the owner Starlight Racing said. The horse had surgery May 26 for a nondisplaced condylar fracture to his right front leg, which he sustained while training at Belmont Park on Sunday. The colt had two wins in nine starts, earning $551,900, including a second in the Louisiana Derby.

headline: Corrections: May 28, 2014
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: What’s On Wednesday
text: 10 P.M. (NBC) INSIDE THE MIND OF EDWARD SNOWDEN In this NBC News exclusive, Brian Williams travels to Moscow to conduct the first interview for American television with Mr. Snowden (above right, with Mr. Williams), the former National Security Agency contractor who leaked documents about the government’s surveillance. Mr. Williams then speaks with Mr. Snowden together with Glenn Greenwald, the journalist and lawyer who published articles based on those documents in The Guardian, his employer at the time.

headline: A Conversation With: Yogendra Yadav, a Leader of the Aam Aadmi Party
text: A scholar of the science of elections, Yogendra Yadav, 50, has become one of the most prominent faces of the Aam Aadmi Party, which won only four seats in the Indian Parliament, a disappointing result for a party that had a surprisingly strong showing in the state elections in Delhi in December. The party was able to lead the state government there, with its leader, Arvind Kejriwal, as the chief minister, but he resigned after only 49 days in office.

headline: Hong Kong Considers Limits on Mainland Chinese Visitors
text: The politically sensitive idea of reducing the number of mainland Chinese visitors to Hong Kong seemed, until last week, a far-fetched notion. But that changed on Monday, when the territory’s chief executive, Leung Chun-ying, was quoted as saying that a 20 percent cut in mainland visitors was one option being considered by a government panel.

headline: Patient Is Held After Fire at South Korea Hospital Kills 21
text: SEOUL, South Korea — A fire broke out at a hospital annex in South Korea early Wednesday, killing 21 people and injuring seven others and further rattling a country still traumatized by a recent ferry disaster. The police were holding a patient in connection with the fire.

headline: Elderly Suicides Reported After City Announces Phase-out on Burials
text: Officials in China have a rule and target for almost everything — the legacy of thousands of years of bureaucratic thinking and the Communist Party’s own planned economy — even for a person’s final resting place.

headline: GlaxoSmithKline Under Investigation by Serious Fraud Office
text: LONDON — The British drugmaker GlaxoSmithKline said late Tuesday that the Serious Fraud Office of Britain had opened a formal criminal investigation into its “commercial practices.”

headline: Test Yourself | Math, May 28, 2014
text: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

headline: Nestlé to Pay Valeant $1.4 Billion for Skin Care Sales Rights
text: LONDON – Nestlé, the Swiss food giant, said on Wednesday that it had acquired the rights to sell certain skin care products in the United States and Canada from Valeant Pharmaceuticals International, based in Quebec, for $1.4 billion in cash.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | U.S. Will Complete Afghan Pullout by End of 2016, Obama Says
text: In “U.S. Will Complete Afghan Pullout by End of 2016, Obama Says,” Mark Landler reports on the president’s plan to withdraw American troops from Afghanistan.

headline: Weir to Drop Takeover Pursuit of Finnish Rival Metso
text: LONDON – The Scottish engineering company Weir Group said on Wednesday that it was dropping its pursuit of a Finnish rival, Metso.

headline: The Smutty-Metaphor Queen of Lawrence, Kansas
text: Just before she took the microphone one soggy night in Portland, Ore., the poet Patricia Lockwood downed a shot of cheap bourbon. She had never had a drink right before a reading, but she often enacts some private joke when she speaks in public. It might be slurping her water loudly into the microphone, or rolling (instead of stepping) onto a stage, or, in this case, ingesting something that tasted to her like a puddle in a forest — anything to erase what she calls the “anxiety kegels” leading up to a performance.

headline: Do You Think You Will Have a Career That You Love?
text: Many students, when seeking career advice from a guidance counselor or teacher, will be told, “Do what you love.” But that isn’t a realistic option for many, if not most, of us. And it may not always be what’s best for our families and communities either, if not ourselves.

headline: Irish Regulator Finds Himself at Heart of Privacy Debate
text: BERLIN — Billy Hawkes might be the most important tech regulator you’ve never heard of.

headline: Bringing the Nigerian Schoolgirls Into View
text: Hauwa Mutah wants to be a biochemist. Monica Enoch loves to sing. Dourcas Yakubu is a shy girl who exchanged hand-written notes with a boy who called her “the remote control of my life.”

headline: Syrians in Lebanon Flood Polling Place, Choosing Assad Out of Fervor or Fear
text: YARZE, Lebanon — Syrians living in Lebanon swarmed their country’s embassy here on Wednesday to cast early ballots in a sharply disputed presidential election that is virtually sure to keep President Bashar al-Assad in power, turning out in numbers that surprised even embassy officials and brought a major highway from Beirut to a standstill for much of the day.

headline: Alibaba to Buy Stake in Singaporean Postal System
text: HONG KONG — The Alibaba Group, the Chinese e-commerce giant, said Wednesday that it would pay about $250 million for 10 percent of Singapore Post, the national postal system of Singapore, extending the Chinese company’s push into the logistics business and into new overseas markets.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: New York Today: Some Animals Allowed
text: Good Wednesday morning to you.

headline: Gone Boy (Prince of Denmark)
text: Gillian Flynn, the author of “Gone Girl,” will write a new version of “Hamlet” for Hogarth, joining a trans-Atlantic roster being put together by the publishing company to present Shakespeare in a more modern, accessible form.

headline: Tibetan Protest Singer Is Said to Be Under Arrest
text: A popular Tibetan singer was arrested in Sichuan Province last week after a concert at which he performed songs from his banned album, according to Free Tibet, a London-based advocacy group.

headline: French Police Expel Migrants From Makeshift Camps
text: LONDON — Days after populist anti-immigration parties scored broad successes in European elections, the French riot police moved in to dismantle makeshift campsites housing hundreds of migrants seeking to reach Britain from the port of Calais in northern France.

headline: Violence Leads Xinjiang to Propose Paying Tourists to Visit
text: The authorities in the far western region of Xinjiang, which has been hit by a series of terrorist attacks targeting civilians, are considering offering cash bonuses to tourists from other parts of China this summer, the state news media reported.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up »

headline: Daily Report: Google Testing a Completely Driverless Car
text: Humans might be the one problem Google can’t solve, John Markoff reports.

headline: A Do-Nothing Congress? Well, Pretty Close
text: After a burst of legislative activity in the past decade, representatives in the House are now proposing fewer bills.

headline: Even Sun Microsystems Had Its Roots at Xerox PARC
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — As a Stanford University graduate student in 1978, Andy Bechtolsheim took full advantage of a consulting appointment at Xerox’s fabled Palo Alto Research Center. He was able to experience the Xerox Alto, a then-revolutionary office workstation which would become the prototype for the modern PC.

headline: My Pricing Problems Continued: Responding to Readers
text: I would like to thank everyone who took time to offer guidance as I addressed my pricing problems. As usual, I received a range of answers after I asked whether it is a good idea to mess with a system that is, on aggregate, producing numbers that allow us to make a profit, but that on closer inspection is not working very well.

headline: Threatening a Proxy Battle, Valeant Raises Its Offer on the Botox Maker Allergan
text: Valeant Pharmaceuticals is prepared to play the waiting game as it pursues what would be its largest and most transformative acquisition yet.

headline: Obama Warns U.S. Faces Diffuse Terrorism Threats
text: WEST POINT, N.Y. — President Obama tried once more to articulate his vision of the American role in the world on Wednesday, telling graduating cadets here that the nation they were being called to serve would seek to avoid military misadventures abroad, even as it confronts a new set of terrorist threats from the Middle East to Africa.

headline: The Fringe Gets Bigger
text: As expected, angry Europeans across the Continent delivered a drubbing to establishment parties in elections to the European Parliament that ended on Sunday. It was not only fringe parties in smaller states that did it: Marine Le Pen’s National Front in France and Nigel Farage’s UKIP (U.K. Independence Party) in Britain each took about a quarter of the votes in their countries, the second- and third-biggest economies in the European Union.

headline: Relational Takes Stake in Magnum Hunter, an Oil and Gas Driller
text: Relational Investors has long been known for its shareholder activism, calling for change at companies like Timken and Genzyme. But the investment firm is trying a different path.

headline: Player Ratings: United States (2) vs. Azerbaijan (0)
text: In the first of its three exhibition matches ahead of the World Cup, the United States national men’s soccer team overcame a lackluster start to defeat Azerbaijan, 2-0, Tuesday night at Candlestick Park in San Francisco.

headline: Jailhouse Blues
text: On a rainy morning in May, six women gathered in the penthouse of a luxury hotel in downtown Manhattan, greeting one another with affectionate hugs and kisses, comparing their designer attire and chatting excitedly about parties they had been to or would soon attend. Then they sat down to talk about their lives in prison.

headline: New Standards for Companies’ Revenue Accounting Will Begin in 2017
text: Accounting for revenue — one thing that every company has, or at least needs if it is going to stay in business — will be significantly changed in 2017, the two boards that set accounting standards for companies in most major countries around the world announced on Wednesday.

headline: What’s News in Washington: Obama to Outline Foreign Policy Agenda
text: Good Wednesday morning from an already steamy Washington. President Obama is on his way to West Point where he is expected to explain during a commencement speech at the United States Military Academy how the withdrawal of troops from Afghanistan will help the administration confront the emerging terrorist threat that stretches from the Middle East to Africa, The Times’s Mark Landler reports.

headline: Valeant Turns Up the Heat
text: VALEANT RAISES BID FOR ALLERGAN  |  Valeant Pharmaceuticals on Wednesday raised its takeover bid for Allergan, turning up the heat in its pursuit of the Botox maker, Michael J. de la Merced writes in DealBook. The new offer comes on the heels of a separate deal in which Nestlé will buy the sales rights to some of Valeant’s skin care products for $1.4 billion. It also arrives a day after Allergan unveiled a more pointed defense against the takeover bid, questioning the sustainability of its unwanted suitor’s business model and stock price.

headline: President’s Choice for South Korea Premier Steps Aside
text: SEOUL, South Korea — A former justice handpicked to be South Korea’s new prime minister stepped aside on Wednesday, dealing a blow to President Park Geun-hye’s efforts to regroup her government in the wake of a fatal ferry disaster.

headline: An Old Friend, Safe in the Park
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Steel, Ex-Deputy Mayor, to Become Perella Weinberg C.E.O.
text: Updated, 6:56 p.m. | Late last year, Robert K. Steel was pondering his next career move as his job as deputy mayor to Michael R. Bloomberg was about to end. He had already worked as a Goldman Sachs investment banker, as the chief executive of Wachovia, and once before in public service, at the Treasury Department.

headline: WikiLeaks-Inspired Recital Among Next Wave Festival Premieres
text: World premieres of new works by the indie classical composers Ted Hearne and Bryce Dessner, the jazz pianist and composer Vijay Iyer, and the choreographers Jessica Lang and Jodi Melnick – as well as the previously announced 50th anniversary celebration of Nonesuch Records – are among the highlights of the 2014 Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The festival runs from Sept. 9 through Dec. 20.

headline: A Lifelong Student of Williams Learns How to Defeat Her
text: PARIS — When Garbiñe Muguruza was growing up in Venezuela and in Spain, her favorite player was Serena Williams.

headline: Mayor of Chicago Seeks to Further Tighten Gun Laws
text: CHICAGO — Mayor Rahm Emanuel outlined a plan on Wednesday to make Chicago’s gun laws, already some of the strictest in the country, even tougher.

headline: Nas Scholarship Fund Aims to Ease Transition From College to Work
text: Just six months ago, the rapper Nas visited Harvard University to put his imprimatur on the Nasir Jones Hip-Hop Fellowship, to be awarded in his name to two musicians or hip-hop scholars every year. But he has also been thinking about how those scholars – and other college students – will put their degrees to use. Koru, a year-old Seattle company that has partnerships with universities and employers, and runs a four-week training program meant to smooth the transition from academia to gainful employment, announced on Wednesday that Nas has become a partner.

headline: Defending His Actions, Snowden Says He’s a Patriot
text: WASHINGTON — Edward J. Snowden said that he still considered himself to be an American patriot even after leaking thousands of classified documents, and that he was frustrated to be “stuck in a place” — Russia — that did so little to protect individual rights when he was trying to help protect American freedoms.

headline: Maya Angelou, Lyrical Witness of the Jim Crow South, Dies at 86
text: Maya Angelou, whose landmark book of 1969, “I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings” — a lyrical, unsparing account of her childhood in the Jim Crow South — was among the first autobiographies by a 20th-century black woman to reach a wide general readership, died on Wednesday at her home in Winston-Salem, N.C. She was 86.

headline: A Thaw in France in G.E. Bid for Alstom
text: PARIS — The French government appeared on Wednesday to be softening its opposition to General Electric’s $13.5 billion bid for the power business of Alstom, the industrial conglomerate that the country’s lawmakers view as a national champion.

headline: CreatureCast: Suddenly Visible
text: Being invisible has its advantages, but also its perils. A marine creature called Hippopodius gets the best of both worlds by transforming from glassy clear to bright white and back again.

headline: Democrats, to Counter G.O.P., Turn Their Focus to Local Issues for Midterms
text: WASHINGTON — In Senator Jeanne Shaheen’s first television ad of her re-election campaign, a Vietnam War veteran talks about how Ms. Shaheen, a Democrat, “cut through the red tape” to help open a veterans clinic in Keene, N.H.

headline: A Marine Magician’s Vanishing Act
text: Being transparent comes with obvious benefits — and some hidden costs. A transparent animal can hide in plain sight from predators that would eat it, and can easily ambush its own prey. But many other animals use sight to navigate their environment, and if you are clear they can bump right into you.

headline: In Our Pages: May 29
text: 1964: Apollo Capsule Put in Orbit

headline: Former Trader at SAC Capital Seeks a Lenient Sentence for Insider Trading
text: Mathew Martoma, the former SAC Capital Advisors trader convicted of insider trading in February, does not think he should get more jail time than the 11 years in prison that Raj Rajaratnam, the co-founder of the Galleon hedge fund, is serving for insider trading.

headline: Massimo’s Last Letters
text: Massimo Vignelli, the acclaimed graphic designer who died Tuesday, reads from letters sent by those inspired by his work. His son put out a call for the letters when his father’s health deteriorated.

headline: Massimo Vignelli: A Master in the Grammar of Design
text: What would it be like to read your own obituary? Massimo Vignelli, the renowned designer who died Tuesday at the age of 83, had that chance a thousand times over.

headline: Turnout Rises in Egypt, but the Vote Raises Doubts
text: CAIRO — Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, the former army field marshal who led last summer’s military takeover, won election as president with more than 90 percent of the vote, according to preliminary tallies Wednesday night. But it was the reported turnout that caught some by surprise.

headline: Maya Angelou at the Clinton Inauguration
text: The memoirist and poet recited her poem “On the Pulse of Morning” in 1993 at President Bill Clinton’s first inaugural ceremony.

headline: Spurning Suitors, ‘This American Life’ Opts for Self-Distribution
text: Five suitors came calling, including satellite radio company SiriusXM, but in the end public radio’s “This American Life” decided to go it alone. The popular weekly program is notifying stations on Wednesday that it will distribute the show itself beginning in July when its distribution contract with Public Radio International ends.

headline: After Pearl Harbor, F.D.R. Showed Confidence That U.S. Would Exist in 1956
text: This is Captain Colin P. Kelly Jr., who was idolized from coast to coast as one of America’s first World War II heroes in the immediate aftermath of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor. As Life Magazine reported in December 1941, “Kelly dove his plane straight into the Japanese battleship, Haruna, released a stick of high explosives almost into the mouths of flaming guns, and then vanished himself in the mighty explosion that ushered the 29,000-ton ship to the bottom of the sea.”

headline: Former Top JPMorgan Banker in Britain Loses Appeal in Insider Case
text: LONDON – A former top banker at JPMorgan Chase has lost his appeal of a ruling by British regulators two years ago that he improperly disclosed inside information.

headline: Monsters, Updated
text: Are today’s children really afraid of monsters? Movies like “Hotel Transylvania” and “Monsters, Inc.” and even shows like “Sesame Street” have made them more sweet than threatening, more funny than ferocious. My own kids, who’ve never mentioned being scared of anything supernatural, fear the same things I do: eels, sharks and home invasion. Try writing a picture book about that! But monsters are a literary commonplace, embodiments of whatever dark and unexpected things lurk in children’s imaginations. “Big Bad Bubble," by Adam Rubin with illustrations by Daniel Salmieri, and “Rules of Summer,” by Shaun Tan, imagine alien landscapes inhabited by monstrous creatures. Whether they strike a chord with — or terrify — children depends very much upon the child.

headline: Highlights of the West Point Speech
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama laid out a foreign policy vision on Wednesday for his final two and a half years in office in a speech at the United States Military Academy at West Point. Here are some of his key points:

headline: Snowden’s Interview With Brian Williams
text: Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor who leaked classified documents, said in his first interview with an American television network that he had been “trained as a spy.”

headline: Koch Subsidiary to Buy Propylene Maker for $2.1 Billion
text: PetroLogistics, a maker of propylene, announced on Wednesday that it had agreed to be bought out by a subsidiary of Koch Industries for $2.1 billion in cash, including the assumption of debt.

headline: Pfizer Gives Up, For Now
text: Pfizer’s  $119 billion plan to skimp on its taxes by buying  AstraZeneca, the British drug company, has expired – for now at least.   But rest assured, there will be another offer, or others like it, unless Congress acts to shut down the tax loophole that Pfizer was trying to exploit in its bid for AstraZeneca.

headline: The Push to End Chronic Homelessness Is Working
text: Sometime in June, the 100,000 Homes Campaign  — an initiative launched four years ago to help communities around the country place 100,000 chronically homeless people into permanent supportive housing — expects to announce that it has reached its goal. It’s a significant milestone: It means that many American cities are currently on track to end chronic and veteran homelessness by the end of the decade or earlier.

headline: A Brief Sampler of Alan Ayckbourn
text: Is anyone still counting? Though the exact total is open to debate, Alan Ayckbourn has definitely written more plays than he has years.

headline: Tony Shalhoub in a Scene From ‘Act One’
text: The Tony nominee Tony Shalhoub performs a scene as Moss Hart from the Broadway play “Act One.”

headline: Thomas Tait Wins the Inaugural LVMH New Designers Prize
text: So the long, breath-bated wait is over and the winner of the richest fashion prize ever has been revealed: Thomas Tait has taken the inaugural LVMH New Designers Prize. Mr. Tait gets 300,000 euros (about $409,000) plus a year’s mentorship from one of the LVMH Group’s uber-execs. The runners-up were Shayne Oliver’s Hood by Air and Miuniku by Tina and Nikita Sutradhar, who each get €100, ooo and a one-year mentorship.

headline: After Months of Infighting, a Major Faction Splits From the Pakistani Taliban
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — Seven years into a bloody campaign to overthrow the Pakistani state, the Pakistani Taliban split in two on Wednesday when a major faction publicly rejected the movement’s leader, Maulana Fazlullah, and said it would continue the fight on its own.

headline: A Return to Rural France, and to Childhood Memories
text: Last summer, for the first time in decades, I turned off a French country road into an allée of tall trees that led to an old brick farmhouse where I spent some of the most joyous moments of my childhood. The farm was in the province of Nièvre, two hours south of Paris, and the family that had lived there years ago had raised Charolais cattle. They had five children; but in the summer of 1979, when I was 12, and again in 1981, they folded me into their household as if I were an honorary sixth. The kids closest to my age, Virginie, Éric and Benoît, treated me like a sister, not like a tourist from Indiana, where I came from. Together we gathered eggs, rode on Mobylettes to the village candy store, set the table when the curé came to lunch, watched the French version of “The Avengers,” and squabbled over who got to ride shotgun on car trips.

headline: Obama Lays Out Foreign Policy Vision
text: President Obama gave a commencement speech at West Point on Wednesday, describing his foreign policy vision as one in which “American isolationism is not an option.”

headline: Obama Discusses Efforts in Afghanistan
text: President Obama followed up on Tuesday’s announcement to withdraw all troops from Afghanistan by 2016, telling West Point graduates that “empowering partners” is a large part of their mission.

text: Following is the full text as delivered of President Obama’s commencement address at the United States Military Academy at West Point.

headline: A Record Week for Broadway
text: Broadway shows grossed $30.9 million last week on sales from 299,090 audience members, the highest dollar amount and best attendance ever recorded for the week leading into Memorial Day, according to box office data released on Tuesday. The comparable gross and attendance figures for the same period last year were $25.5 million and 240,878.

headline: This Time Around, Let There Be Light
text: For six years, Aaron and Jill Ginsberg lived in the ground-floor rental of an owner-occupied brownstone in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn. They had their own washer-dryer and a shared backyard with a grill.

headline: Small Companies Use Low-Cost Technology to Increase Foreign Sales
text: Paul Bennett, chief executive of Context Travel, was concerned that his 400 highly qualified tour guides — including professors and architects — were spending too much time on scheduling logistics. He wanted them focused instead on making customers happy, offering erudite tours in 24 countries.

headline: Making Vegetables the Star in a Meat-Loving Family’s Kitchen
text: Dear Martha and KJ,

headline: What Have You Learned About Selling Into Foreign Markets?
text: We’ve just published a small-business guide that looks at how companies are using new technologies to extend their sales into overseas markets.

headline: Rules of Style | Jenna Lyons on Modern-Day E-Card Etiquette
text: Since Jenna Lyons took the reins as creative director at J. Crew, the brand has launched a seemingly endless stream of covetable designer collaborations in clothing, accessories and beauty products. Now, the brand is bringing its casual-chic aesthetic to the realm of digital correspondence. In a project launched this week with Paperless Post, Lyons has overseen a line of electronic stationery that includes thank-you notes, invites and greetings. The overall tone of the language is one Lyons deems essential for any e-card: “humor and a touch of sarcasm.” A birthday card reads, “Happy… Whatever Age You Wish You Were”; another says, “Thinking of You… But Not in a Creepy Stalker Kind of Way.” The design is quintessentially J. Crew, too, with neon hues, bold prints and carefully chosen fonts that are as tasteful yet playful as the looks in the catalog.

headline: Hachette and Amazon Dig In for a Long Fight Over Contract Terms
text: Amazon and Hachette took their cases to the public on Wednesday as a dispute over contract terms became clashing visions about the distribution of information in the digital age.

headline: Obama on Combating Climate Change
text: President Obama discussed climate change in his speech at West Point, saying he intends “to make sure America is out front in putting together a global framework to preserve our planet.”

headline: Style in Goma, the Democratic Republic of Congo
text: In Goma, in the Democratic Republic of Congo, Sundays are when most people dress up for church. Recently, Kwame Lebon Ekumali Longange, a self-proclaimed sapeur (the Congolese term for a dandy), was wearing a skirt made out of ties. He said he rejects the idea that only Sundays are a day to dress up. This interview has been edited.

headline: Newly Released Books
text: Deep secrets abound in this month’s books: A boy living off the grid in Montana reveals his family’s chilling history, an artist driven to violence tries to cover his tracks, a woman on a British island remembers what caused her to flee her home in Australia, and a soldier helps a captain prepare for a covert mission.

headline: U.S. Seeks to Censor More of Memo That Approved Drone Strike on American
text: WASHINGTON — One week after the Obama administration said it would comply with a federal appeals court ruling ordering it to make public portions of a Justice Department memo that signed off on the targeted killing of a United States citizen, the administration is now asking the court for permission to censor additional passages of the document.

headline: A Plan to Sell Cialis, an Erectile Drug, Over the Counter
text: Men with erectile dysfunction may be able to avoid the awkwardness of a doctor’s visit by buying the drug Cialis without a prescription, under a proposal announced Wednesday by the drug’s maker, Eli Lilly, and the French pharmaceutical company Sanofi.

headline: Severe Report Finds V.A. Hid Waiting Lists at Hospitals
text: In the first confirmation that Department of Veterans Affairs administrators manipulated medical waiting lists at one and possibly more hospitals, the department’s inspector general reported on Wednesday that 1,700 patients at the veterans medical center in Phoenix were not placed on the official waiting list for doctors’ appointments and may never have received care.

headline: The CerviScope in the Field
text: You don’t often hear about cervical cancer killing women in the United States, where Pap smears are routine, but in the developing world, it is one of the most lethal cancers for women. While reporting my article that appeared in the May 25 magazine — about how David Walmer, a fertility specialist, created a device to help prevent cervical cancer despite knowing next to nothing about the disease — I spoke to a gynecologist named Kristina McCain. Her experience abroad using a field-test model of the CerviScope to treat poor women, many of them former sex slaves, hints at how the finished product can be useful.

headline: Coldplay Hits No. 1
text: Coldplay’s latest album, “Ghost Stories” (Parlophone/Atlantic), enters the Billboard 200 chart at No. 1 this week, with sales of 383,000 for the week ending May 25, just six days after the album was released. Of that total, 245,000 (or 64 percent) of the album’s sales were as digital downloads, according to Nielsen SoundScan.

headline: Morning’s Glory
text: John Pizzarelli and Jessica Molaskey, the cabaret artists, have a bit they do about being New York parents who work at night. They’re the ones at school drop-off in sunglasses and pale skin, they say. They’re the ones gripping their coffee cups tight, jittery and yawning.

headline: Dozens of Palestinian Detainees on Hunger Strike Are Hospitalized
text: JERUSALEM — Sixty-eight Palestinians detained in Israel have been hospitalized after refusing food for almost five weeks, a spokeswoman for the Israel Prison Service said on Wednesday.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 15
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: TimesTalks | ‘Hedwig’: Preview

headline: Snowboarders’ Downtime Leads to Pranks
text: Professional snowboarders may pass hundreds of hours waiting for ideal weather. These hours can serve as a catalyst for pranks — and sometimes these pranks go farther than expected.

headline: Gunmen in West Tunisia Attack Interior Minister’s Home, Killing 4 Guards
text: LONDON — Gunmen in western Tunisia attacked the family home of Interior Minister Lotfi Ben Jeddou in the early hours of Wednesday, officials there reported, killing four guards in one of the most brazen assaults by Islamist militants to hit the country in months.

headline: Giuliani’s Take on Ferrets (1999)
State of the Internet: Still Growing but More Mobile Than Ever
text: Mary Meeker puts out an annual report on Internet trends every year that is a sort of farmer’s almanac for the tech industry. It puts all the crucial data in one place, with Ms. Meeker’s particular spin on what’s most important.

headline: Off-Broadway Troupes Will Debut Works by Doug Wright and Neil LaBute
text: Off Broadway’s Atlantic Theater Company will produce new plays by Doug Wright (a Pulitzer Prize winner for “I Am My Own Wife”), Rajiv Joseph and Halley Feiffer during its 2014-15 season, as well as a new musical whose creators include Hunter Bell (“[title of show]”), the theater’s leaders announced on Wednesday.

headline: Cheap Climate Protection
text: The U.S. Chamber of Commerce just came out with its preemptive strike against Obama administration regulations on power plants. What the Chamber wanted to do was show that the economic impact of the regulations would be devastating. And I was eager to see how they had fudged the numbers.

headline: Antidepressant May Ease Hot Flashes of Menopause
text: The hormone estrogen is the recommended treatment for menopausal night sweats and hot flashes, but some women are unable or unwilling to use it. Now a clinical trial suggests that the antidepressant venlafaxine, often used as an alternative, is equally effective.

headline: Valeant’s Latest Move Disappoints
text: Valeant Pharmaceuticals International comes off oddly defensive in its latest advance on Allergan. A sweetened, $49 billion bid for Allergan, the Botox maker, disappointed investors in both companies. The use of a messy financial instrument probably didn’t help, especially after the target pushed back hard on the deal math and compared its suitor to Tyco. Valeant has more work to do to reclaim the role of aggressor.

headline: What You Get for... $2,450,000
