headline: Mobile Companions to Summer Music Fests
text: BACK in the 1990s, the British pop band Pulp sang a verse about summer music festivals that went, “Is this the way they say the future’s meant to feel? Or just 20,000 people standing in a field?” Well, now it is the future, and if you’re a festivalgoer, you have a futuristic tool to add an extra zing to the music, food and fun: apps on your phone.

headline: I.Q. Cutoff Ruling May Spare Some Inmates on Death Row
text: MIAMI — A Supreme Court ruling on Tuesday throwing out Florida’s strict I.Q. cutoff in death penalty cases could increase the number of inmates exempt from execution because they are deemed mentally disabled, legal experts said Wednesday.

text: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s administration wants to repeal New York City’s ban on pet ferrets, which is good news for ferrets, and their outlaw owners, who will no longer have to live a lie.

headline: Syria to Miss Deadline On Weapons, Official Says
text: The United Nations secretary general has for the first time acknowledged that the eradication of Syria’s chemical arms stockpile will not be completed by June 30, the deadline imposed by a diplomatic agreement last September in which President Bashar al-Assad renounced the weapons and avoided a threatened American military strike.

headline: Reaction to President Obama’s West Point Speech
text: President Obama laid out a foreign policy vision on Wednesday for his final two and a half years in office, responding to critics who have said the United States has been rudderless amid crises. headline: A Galaxy Far, Far Away...Will Hit Ours

text: Julianne Moore hosts a tea party for LaTanya Richardson Jackson.

headline: Andromeda and the Milky Way: A Merger of Galactic Proportions
text: The Andromeda nebula, which rarely feels the pull of the social media orbit, had a moment in the spotlight on Wednesday. Astronomers operating NASA’s Swift satellite spied what looked like a giant burst of radiation from Andromeda, the nearest big galaxy to our own Milky Way, about 2.5 million light-years from here. They tentatively diagnosed it as the collision of two neutron stars, the dense remnants of dead stars. Such collisions are among the most violent known conflagrations in the universe, but they rarely occur so close to our own neck of the cosmic woods.

headline: Did Obama Make His Case?
text: Did the president address his critics' fears about America's decline on the world stage?

headline: Trot Out the New Blue
text: Denim is something you can always justify more of. You’ll want a new pair of baggier jeans now that skinnies are finally slipping as the style of choice (as are, it seems, jeans in tutti-frutti colors). Could it be that denim is getting back to its roots? Here are some ways to work blues back into your summer wardrobe.

headline: Classical Playlist: Bang on a Can All-Stars, Meredith Monk, Kojiro Umezaki and More
text: JULIA WOLFE: ‘Steel Hammer’Bang on a Can All-Stars; Trio Mediaeval(Cantaloupe)There’s grit in Julia Wolfe’s “Steel Hammer.” No, really. The blue-collar song cycle is scored for the versatile forces of the Bang on a Can All-Stars and the ethereally pure female voices of Trio Mediaeval, but a recurring sound is that of sand, pouring down the inside of wooden tubes. The result is a fiercely beautiful homage to manual labor, its endless repetitions and occasional moments of magical transformation. (Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim)

headline: A Shrinking Majority Support Capital Punishment
text: On Tuesday, the Supreme Court ruled that a Florida law setting a minimum I.Q. test score for the death penalty was too rigid.

headline: The Gun Report: May 28, 2014
text: The nation, still reeling from last Friday’s rampage in Isla Vista, Calif., is now confronted by the same questions that arise after each mass shooting: How did a future killer go undetected? How could someone so disturbed have been allowed to legally purchase firearms? Why does this keep happening? How can we prevent it from happening again?

headline: Maya Angelou: An Earlier Stage
text: Maya Angelou was best known for her poetry and prose, but she first appeared in the pages of The New York Times in an entirely different context: the stage.

headline: Delay Sought in S.E.C. Case Against Steven Cohen
text: It could be months, maybe even years, before there is a resolution of the Securities and Exchange Commission’s administrative case against the billionaire investor Steven A. Cohen, whose former hedge fund pleaded guilty to insider trading.

headline: After Lundqvist Is Pulled, Rangers Say He Doesn’t Need a Push
text: MONTREAL — Henrik Lundqvist does not get pulled from playoff games often. Tuesday’s 7-4 loss was only the fourth time in 86 postseason starts that he was yanked from the nets. He might have looked bad, but his record and reputation are above reproach, and his teammates harbor no doubts about how well he will play in Game 6 of the N.H.L. Eastern Conference finals Thursday night at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Rihanna Looks Styled by Mel Ottenberg

headline: Where Wild Spirits Make a Home
text: Patricia Lockwood’s sexy, surreal and mostly sublime poems seem to have been, as James Joyce said in “Ulysses” about a batch of folk tales, “printed by the weird sisters in the year of the big wind.” They scatter lightning and lawn debris across your psyche.

headline: Rihanna’s Style Has a Name: Mel Ottenberg
text: When your star client is an internationally obsessed-over, unfailingly photographed clotheshorse, a peculiar problem presents itself.

headline: A Look Into the Lives of Nigeria’s Kidnapped Girls
text: Glenna Gordon photographed some of the belongings of the schoolgirls kidnapped by Boko Haram, providing a glimpse into their lives.

headline: Hanging in a Park With Danish Royalty
text: A small boy in shorts plopped down cross-legged on the stone steps at Bryant Park, between Hamlet and Rosencrantz and Guildenstern, watching intently until an adult crawled over to extricate him. A little girl in a tank dress stood far stage right, so riveted by Ophelia’s funeral that she shrugged off an attempt to pull her back when Hamlet scuffled with Laertes.

headline: The Poconos for a Pittance
text: A few weeks ago, my upstairs neighbors Beata and Mirek Piszczek were helping me fix my door when they started talking about their house in the Poconos. Just 100 miles from New York City, they said. Mirek goes every weekend. “He’s obsessed,” Beata said.

headline: Apple to Pay $3 Billion to Buy Beats
text: CUPERTINO, Calif. — Apple, the company that turned digital music into a mainstream phenomenon, said on Wednesday that it was buying Beats Electronics, a rising music brand, for $3 billion, in a move that will help it play catch-up with rivals that offer subscription-based music services.

headline: In the Wrinkle Wars, a New Weapon
text: As she aged, Sandi Bachom, 69, a filmmaker and producer in Manhattan, tried Botox to keep the inevitable wrinkles away, but she was wary of anything more invasive. She wanted, as she explained recently, to avoid “going under the knife.”

text: BALINESE BUNGALOW

headline: Facebook Wants European Blessing for WhatsApp Deal
text: LONDON — The European Union will have a chance to weigh in on Facebook’s deal to buy the Internet messaging application WhatsApp for as much as $19 billion.

headline: For Tea Party, Senate Race in Mississippi Is the Last Chance to Oust an Incumbent
text: WASHINGTON — The feud between the Republican establishment and the Tea Party has engendered more whimpers than war cries so far. The notable exception is in Mississippi, where the campaign to unseat Senator Thad Cochran has become the nastiest, and most personal, in the nation.

headline: Maya Angelou in Pictures
text: In her writing, Ms. Angelou explored identity and resilience through the multifaceted lens of race, sex, family, community and the collective past.

headline: At St. Regis Hotels, New Family Excursions

text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: A Bunch of Friends? Yeah, Again
text: It doesn’t take much.

headline: Is This Music Ideal for Ballet? A Leaping Reply
text: What could Bach’s Double Violin Concerto have in common with the songs of George Gershwin? George Balanchine, who found both to be appropriate music for ballet, might have answered, “They both got rhythm.” Or at least that correspondence was apparent at the David H. Koch Theater on Tuesday, when his “Concerto Barocco” (1941) and “Who Cares?” (1970) opened and closed a program of New York City Ballet.

headline: Spark Capital Raises $375 Million for Later-Stage Investments
text: Spark Capital has reaped wealth and prominence through its early investments in start-ups like Twitter and the virtual reality headset maker Oculus.

headline: Stefan Zweig, Austrian Novelist, Rises Again
text: In the decades between the two world wars, no writer was more widely translated or read than the Austrian novelist Stefan Zweig, and in the years after, few writers fell more precipitously into obscurity, at least in the English-speaking world. But now Zweig, prolific storyteller and embodiment of a vanished Mitteleuropa, seems to be back, and in a big way.

headline: A Queen’s Accidental Gospel
text: Mariah Carey’s perplexingly titled new album, “Me. I Am Mariah . . . The Elusive Chanteuse, ” begins with a meditation and ends with a sort of confession.

headline: Duda’s Homer Caps Winning Finish to a Trying Stretch
text: At the crack of the bat, there was not a doubt about Lucas Duda’s home run. It sailed high and deep and glanced off the spandrel of the Shea Bridge beyond the bullpens in right-center field, giving the Mets a five-run lead over the Pittsburgh Pirates in the eighth inning Wednesday afternoon.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and More
text: Syria and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: At the Marlton Hotel, Like Moths to a Flame
text: No one can say for sure why the fashion world has migrated en masse to the Marlton Hotel, and its restaurant, the Margaux, over the last few months. It didn’t even exist during last year’s September fashion shows. But everyone does agree: It’s a thing now.

headline: Voices of Syrians Voting From Lebanon
text: Syrian expatriates living in Lebanon discussed Syria’s election as they cast their votes abroad for the country’s president.

headline: The Tonys, a Tea and Toasts
text: Samuel L. Jackson is not used to being arm candy.

headline: Owning a Big Voice, and Willing to Use It
text: Wherever you find boys of a certain age with a gleam in their eye, you will find glittering material girls ready to make them feel like kings — in return for favors, of course. It’s a law of nature that no amount of hand-wringing can overturn. And it’s why Lorelei Lee, the gold-digging siren from “Gentlemen Prefer Blondes,” is here to stay.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Lebanon and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Lebanon, Iran, India and Japan.

headline: How Big a V.A. Scandal?
text: The inspector general of the Department of Veterans Affairs has confirmed allegations that the agency’s medical center in Phoenix kept veterans waiting unconscionably long times to see a doctor and hid the fact by creating fictitious wait lists. However, the report issued today did not address the most explosive charges — that veterans have died because of delays in getting treatment and that hidden delays are endemic throughout the Veterans health care system.

headline: New York Pro-Am Tournament Raises $125,000
text: The 51st UJA-Federation of New York Women’s Philanthropy bridge pro-am, which raised over $125,000, was played on May 20 at the Harmonie Club in Manhattan. It was organized by Tubby Stayman and Marci Miron; Nancy Brown was chairwoman.

headline: Just for Kicks and Company
text: Sneakers are making new footprints.

headline: Sneakers: Where Can’t They Go?
text: If sneakers have cracked the rarefied world of couture, where can’t they go?

headline: The Extremist Organizations ‘on the Front Lines’
text: In outlining his foreign policy priorities at the United States Military Academy on Wednesday, President Obama called on Congress to authorize up to $5 billion to support countries “on the front lines” in the fight against terrorism.

headline: Kirkus Announces 3 New $50,000 Prizes for Literature
text: Kirkus Reviews, the literary journal best known for its pre-publication reviews of forthcoming books, said on Wednesday evening that it was creating three new literary prizes — for fiction, nonfiction and young readers’ literature. The prize in each category, bestowed annually, will be $50,000, a relatively large amount in the world of literary awards.

headline: A Young Company, Yes, but Taking More Than Baby Steps
text: Some dance troupes might need a few years and a few false starts to develop a program fit for international touring. Not the 10-member MalPaso Dance Company, from Havana, which made its United States debut — its first appearance outside Cuba — on Tuesday at the Joyce Theater. Founded less than two years ago by Osnel Delgado and Daile Carrazana Gonzalez, former members of Danza Contemporánea de Cuba, the company already has at least two knockout pieces: “24 Hours and a Dog,” created by Mr. Delgado, the artistic director, in collaboration with the dancers; and “Why You Follow,” a Joyce commission by New York’s much-loved Ronald K. Brown.

headline: A Reinvention by the Sea
text: Yellow tape cordoned off guest rooms, walls were being smashed and paint fumes overpowered the salty sea air. But Jennifer Oz LeRoy exuded calm as she stared out at the Atlantic Ocean.

headline: Cool and Calm at Center of an E.R. Maelstrom in the Bronx
text: The woman, in the midst of a seizure, moaned from a row of stretchers parked in the hallway of the emergency room at Lincoln Hospital in the South Bronx.

headline: Good Enough to See, Maybe Not to Eat
text: “Sartre walks into a Quiznos” sounds like the setup to a glum philosopher’s sorry joke. But it’s actually the inspiration behind the set design for “American Hero,” a new comedy by Bess Wohl that takes place inside a failing, faux-cheery corporate sandwich shop in Anywhere, U.S.A.

headline: Funding Round Pushes Korean E-Commerce Site’s Valuation Above $1 Billion
text: When Bom Kim dropped out of Harvard Business School to start a Korean e-commerce company in 2010, he found it difficult to attract workers. “‘Start-up’ did not have a good connotation in Korea,” he recalled.

headline: A New Way for Silver to Keep Its Sparkle
text: Put away the silver polish. The French silver company Christofle is introducing SilverEver, a coating for its products that it says will significantly delay tarnishing. “It’s a very thin nanometer coating applied to the surface of the product,” said Thierry Oriez, Christofle’s chief executive. The result is safe for food and invisible, he said, and has no effect on the feel of the metal.

headline: A Midcentury Classic, Reissued for the Masses
text: Like many midcentury-modern furniture designs, William Haines’s Malibu Sofa still looks fresh today. Unlike many midcentury pieces, though, it was never intended to be mass produced.

headline: Global Décor in Brooklyn Heights
text: The husband-and-wife designers Paul and Sophie Yanacopoulos-Gross were living in Switzerland but contemplating a move to New York when a real estate listing in Brooklyn Heights caught his eye: a parlor-floor storefront with a fabulous fanlight window on Montague, a tree-lined street that reminded him of his hometown, London. The couple snapped up the lease. This weekend, their new store, HomeStories, opens there, selling contemporary and artisanal wares from around the world.

headline: Bluegrass Portraits, With a Twist
text: Pieter Estersohn, a veteran architecture and interiors photographer, really stretched himself for his new book, “Kentucky: Historic Houses and Horse Farms of Bluegrass Country” ($60; Monacelli Press). For aerial shots of barns and thoroughbreds, as well as portraits of historic homes, he made five extended visits to Lexington over two years. At one point, he insisted on removing the passenger-side door of a helicopter he was riding in. “I was cantilevered out, contorting my body for three hours in 20-degree temperatures to get those images,” he recalled recently during lunch not far from his home and studio near Gramercy Park.

headline: Partnering to Spread the Whimsy
text: The whimsical designs of Rifle Paper Company have embellished many a wedding invitation, phone case and coaster. Now, thanks to a collaboration with Hygge & West, they’ll adorn walls as well.

headline: The Innkeepers
text: At more than 9,000 square feet, the sprawling house that Kathy and Dennis Brekken built on a remote stretch of the Cannon River, miles from the one-stoplight downtown of historic Cannon Falls, Minn., has the feeling of an old-world inn.

headline: A Government Rating of Colleges?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Is This a Hospital or a Hotel?
text: Hospitals today offer even general amenities for patients, like room service and nail salons, more associated with hotels than health care.

headline: Worse Than Jeff Davis?
text: That “Twelve Years a Slave” won the Oscar for best picture is a stunning achievement in Hollywood cinematic history. Solomon Northup’s autobiography, upon which the movie was based, provides a powerful insider’s account and critique of one of the nation’s founding institutions, while the film rendition disrupts the long tradition of derisive and romantic portrayals of slavery in motion pictures.

headline: The Day of Forgetting
text: I was 25 when I lost my memory. It happened on Jan. 16, 2012. I woke up, not knowing where I was. I was lying in bed, sure, but whose bed was it? There was no one in the room, no sound that I recognized: I was alone with my body.

headline: On the High Road Again, With Willie Nelson
text: An exhibit of country music stars explores how photography helped shape the music’s public image. It also sparked memories of a favorite assignment.

headline: Reflections on the Magic of the Journal Gallery, From the Artists Who Show There
text: Julia Dippelhofer had come to the United States from Germany to work as an au pair when she met Michael Nevin in a photography class at the Montserrat College of Art in Beverly, Mass. Then 19, Nevin had recently started a photocopied zine out of his dorm called The Journal that was dedicated to his twin passions: snowboarding and art. The two formed a bond based on their shared aesthetic sensibility, and soon moved to New York and turned The Journal into an effortlessly stylish publication at the crossroads between the city’s downtown fashion and art worlds.

headline: Maya & Me & Maya
text: The news of Maya Angelou’s death arrived with the abruptness of a great twister — violent, without warning, tearing things up and flipping things over.

headline: Polar Vision
text: Almost any commentary on the Supreme Court these days will include an observation about how polarized the court is: how for the first time in history, all the Republican-appointed justices (there are five) are to the right of all the Democratic appointees, and how the two groups diverge (Justice Anthony M. Kennedy occasionally excepted) in many of the court’s most ideologically charged cases.

headline: Finding Space for the Living at a Memorial
text: Some fences have come down at the World Trade Center. The site isn’t finished yet, but there’s no longer the regime of barricades and snaking line to see the pair of matching fountains approximating the footprints of the former towers. The other morning, New York’s police commissioner, William J. Bratton, trailed by seconds, marched under the rows of swamp white oaks toward the newly opened Sept. 11 museum.

headline: Intel Shows Off ‘Smart’ Wearable Shirt
text: In my column this week, I wrote about my new T-shirt, which is connected to the Internet. The shirt, made by the Canadian company OMsignal, can track my exercise, or tell me to take a breath and relax if I’m stressed.

headline: Google Releases Employee Data, Illustrating Tech’s Diversity Challenge
text: Google on Wednesday released statistics on the makeup of its work force, providing numbers that offer a stark glance at how Silicon Valley remains a white man’s world.

headline: Home Is Where the Horses Are
text: DEVON, Pa., the town where I grew up, is the place I loved with all my heart, and that I could not wait to leave. It was there, in a house on Waterloo Road, that I lost my virginity and saw my sons take their first steps, and there that my parents drew their last breaths.

headline: Why License a Florist?

Becoming a manicurist takes double the number of hours of instruction as a paramedic. In Louisiana, the only state in the country that requires licenses for florists, monks were until recently forbidden to sell coffins because they were not licensed funeral directors.

text: BOSTON — Aaron Hernandez, a former tight end for the New England Patriots, murdered two men in the summer of 2012 because one of them had accidentally bumped into him and spilled a drink while dancing in a Boston nightclub, a prosecutor charged Wednesday.

text: MOSCOW — Hundreds of demonstrators occupied the presidential headquarters of Abkhazia, a breakaway enclave of Georgia, on Wednesday, demanding the resignation of the region’s leader and the dismissal of the government in the latest tumult to grip a separatist area supported by Russia.

Video evidence showed that the soldier fired his weapon within seconds of a Palestinian boy’s collapsing to the ground with what proved to be a fatal gunshot wound.

text: WHEN we began our Let’s Move! initiative four years ago, we set one simple but ambitious goal: to end the epidemic of childhood obesity in a generation so that kids born today will grow up healthy.

headline: Health Officials Reverse Diagnosis of MERS in Illinois Man
text: Reversing an earlier announcement, federal health officials said Wednesday that an Illinois man who met with an Indiana man who later fell ill with Middle East Respiratory Syndrome, or MERS, did not pick up the virus from him. Officials from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said a first lung sample from the Illinois man had tested negative for the coronavirus that causes MERS, but two preliminary blood samples had then tested positive for antibodies to it. That led the C.D.C. to announce on May 17 that the man had been infected but had not fallen ill; this would have been the first transmission of the virus within the United States. On Wednesday, they said that a more sensitive blood test that takes at least five days to produce results showed that he never had the virus. The most likely explanation, one of the officials said, is that the preliminary test had cross-reacted with antibodies the man had to a previous coronavirus infection. At least six coronaviruses are known to infect humans: Four normally cause common cold symptoms, while the other two, MERS and SARS, are more serious. Only two MERS cases have been found in the United States — the Indiana man and another in Florida. Both had recently arrived after working in Saudi hospitals where there have been hundreds of cases since March. Thus far, C.D.C. officials said, extensive testing indicates that the two men did not pass on the virus to any family members or health care workers treating them.

headline: Bidders for 2022 Winter Games Are Melting Away

headline: Primary Loss Means End of Era for World War II Veterans in Congress
text: WASHINGTON — Combat veterans of World War II have served in every Congress for the last 70 years, shaping foreign policy and a vision of the United States as the world’s benevolent leader, willing to use its economic and military might as a global force for freedom.

headline: ‘Upset’ G.M. Engineer Spoke in House Inquiry

headline: Trying to Keep Peace at Home, While Losing Her Peace of Mind
text: PARIS — Timea Bacsinszky won it all before she had the chance to decide if she really wanted to.

headline: Adding Delay to Immigration Failure
text: President Obama asked the homeland security secretary, Jeh Johnson, in March to review the administration’s immigration enforcement policies. He was under intense pressure from immigrant advocates, frustrated at Congress’s inaction on reform, who were imploring him to act on his own to end or slow the pace of deportations. Now he’s backing off and asking Mr. Johnson to delay the review.

headline: Santander Bank to Face Suit Claiming Bias in Mortgages
text: As the housing bubble expanded in the early 2000s, mortgage lenders aggressively handed out money in black and Hispanic neighborhoods, though often at exorbitant rates and in ways that made the loans unaffordable to more vulnerable borrowers. Now, the pendulum has swung the other way, raising concerns that some banks are shutting out blacks and Hispanics in favor of white homeowners.

headline: President Obama Misses a Chance on Foreign Affairs
text: President Obama and his aides heralded his commencement speech at the United States Military Academy at West Point on Wednesday as a big moment, when he would lay out his foreign policy vision for the remainder of his term and refute his critics. The address did not match the hype, was largely uninspiring, lacked strategic sweep and is unlikely to quiet his detractors, on the right or the left.

headline: Maine: Ethics Panel Fines Group Opposed to Same-Sex Marriage
text: The state ethics board voted Wednesday to fine the National Organization for Marriage $50,250 for keeping its donors secret during the successful campaign, in 2009, for a referendum to repeal a law legalizing same-sex marriage. The Maine Commission on Governmental Ethics and Election Practices said the group contributed about $2 million to that campaign but did not register with the commission as a ballot committee, in violation of election law. The organization has argued that its donors did not specifically earmark contributions for the campaign and so it did not have to make disclosures about them to the commission. It said it would appeal. The fine is the highest imposed by the ethics board, which will also direct the group to register as a ballot question committee and to list its contributions. Voters in Maine legalized same-sex marriage with another ballot question in 2012.

headline: A Pushback on Green Power
text: As renewable energy production has surged in recent years, opponents of government policies that have helped spur its growth have pushed to roll back those incentives and mandates in state after state.

headline: Suicide Bomber in Syria Was U.S. Citizen, Officials Say
text: WASHINGTON — A United States citizen working in Syria with a militant group backed by Al Qaeda conducted a suicide bombing there Sunday, in what is believed to be the first time an American has been involved in such an attack, American officials said Wednesday.

headline: Belmont Park Hopes Old Song Will Break Triple Crown Drought

In the 36 years since then, though, the 12 horses that won the first two legs of racing’s Triple Crown faltered before they got to the finish line — or even the starting gate — at Belmont Park.

headline: After Attack Near Campus, California Weighs Gun Bill
text: LOS ANGELES — Just days after a 22-year-old killed six college students and himself near the campus of the University of California, Santa Barbara, state lawmakers are championing legislation that would permit law enforcement officials and private individuals to seek a restraining order from a judge that would keep people with a potential propensity for violence from buying or owning a gun. The process would be similar to the one currently used for restraining orders in cases of domestic violence.

headline: Summer Whites with a Peekaboo Twist
text: One of the oldest style rules in the book says that one should only wear white between Memorial Day and Labor Day. While fashion is all about breaking rules, summer’s unofficial start certainly marks the time for a palette cleanse. Lacy cutouts — whether laser-cut or embroidered — turn summer whites into bona fide statement pieces. These ventilated items from the likes of Tod’s, Isabel Marant and Tabitha Simmons allow the wearer to keep cool in the heat, while their graphic patterns prove that eyelet fabric doesn’t always have to be sweet and innocent.

headline: Tests Show Improvements in Crash-Avoidance Systems
text: New test results suggest that automakers are quickly improving the safety systems that aim to keep a distracted driver from rear-ending a vehicle or colliding with an object ahead. The results for 24 models were released on Thursday by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety.

headline: Vitamin E May Harm, or Help, Your Lungs
text: A form of vitamin E found in vegetable oils like corn and canola may worsen lung function, while another form typically found in olive oil may protect it, a new study suggests. The findings may help explain why studies of the health effects of the vitamin have had conflicting results.

headline: Spanish Upstart Party Said It Could, and Did. Now the Hard Part Begins.
text: MADRID — In the wake of Barack Obama’s first presidential election, few slogans became as popular, or arguably overused, as “Yes, We Can.” But since its shattering electoral debut on Sunday, a three-month-old party that adapted the slogan in Spanish — Podemos — might as well consider a name change, to We Did.

headline: Pushed to the Brink, the Blackhawks Rally to Stay Alive
text: CHICAGO — As the Blackhawks have become the N.H.L.’s model franchise in recent years, they have carried the mystique of a champion: steady, smart and skilled. When the odds have been longest, Chicago has been at its best, winning two Stanley Cups in the past four years. In reserve, there has always seemed to be a key goal, an extra gear — even a lucky bounce.

headline: Iran: MERS Virus Reaches Its 20th Country
text: A deadly respiratory virus that originated in Saudi Arabia two years ago has reached Iran, infecting two sisters in the southeast province of Kerman, the health ministry reported. In a statement posted on the ministry’s website, it said two other members of the same family had the symptoms of the disease, known as Middle East Respiratory Syndome or MERS, but their cases had not been confirmed. According to the World Health Organization, 636 laboratory-confirmed cases of MERS have been reported, including 193 deaths. Most of the deaths have been in Saudi Arabia. Iran is the 20th country to report MERS.

headline: Driver in Crash Posted About Speeding
text: An unlicensed teenage driver who struck and killed a 4-year-old girl last year while fleeing from the police in his family’s S.U.V. had driven recklessly before and had bragged in Facebook posts and text messages about speeding, a prosecutor said in court on Wednesday.

headline: Jury Awards $172 Million in Verdict Against New York City
text: A girl who suffered brain damage while waiting for an ambulance won a $172 million judgment against New York City on Wednesday when a Bronx jury determined that Fire Department paramedics could be held liable for giving her mother bad advice.

headline: A Farewell to Maya Angelou
text: Maya Angelou, the memoirist, poet and author of “I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings,” died Wednesday. Her manuscripts are being preserved at the Harlem-based branch of the New York Public Library.

headline: A Juggled Yankees Lineup Turns a Nine-Game Trip Into a Winner
text: ST. LOUIS — Jacoby Ellsbury has some fond memories of St. Louis, the site of two Boston wins in last year’s World Series, when Ellsbury was a member of the Red Sox. On Wednesday, Ellsbury made a new one, helping the Yankees finish a nine-game Midwest trip in style.

headline: ‘Her Face Was a Brown Moon That Shone on Me’
text: In this passage from her memoir “I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings,” Maya Angelou describes three white girls accosting her grandmother, Annie Henderson, known as Momma, in front of her general store in Stamps, Ark., in the 1930s.

headline: Samsung Stakes Claim on Wearable Tech That Monitors Health
text: Smart watches that can predict heart attacks. Personal health information in a database that can give you a “wellness score” of how you’re eating, sleeping and exercising. An always-on connection to doctors that gives them a real-time look at your health. Heck, maybe even a prescription wearable.

headline: Corrections: May 29, 2014
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Malcolm Glazer, Owner of Buccaneers and Manchester United, Is Dead at 85
text: Malcolm Glazer, the owner of the N.F.L.’s Tampa Bay Buccaneers and the renowned English soccer club Manchester United, which he purchased in 2005, creating a furor among its fans, died on Wednesday. He was 85.

headline: With Foul-Plagued James Forced to Sit, the Pacers Remain Standing
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Frank Vogel, the coach of the Indiana Pacers, was asked Wednesday about a positive stretch of play his team had compiled about 48 hours earlier against the Miami Heat. Was there anything the Pacers could build on heading into Game 5 against the Heat that night?

headline: Oscar Dystel, Who Saved Bantam Books, Dies at 101
text: Oscar Dystel, who combined sharp editorial judgments, shrewd marketing and attention-grabbing covers to propel Bantam Books from the brink of collapse to pre-eminence in paperback publishing after World War II, died on Wednesday at his home in Rye, N.Y. He was 101.

headline: Harold Baer Jr., Judge Whose Civil Liberties Rulings Drew Fire, Dies at 81
text: Harold Baer Jr., a federal judge in New York whose expansive interpretation of civil liberties drew intense criticism from Republicans and Democrats alike and became a partisan issue in President Bill Clinton’s re-election campaign in 1996, died on Tuesday in Stony Brook, N.Y. He was 81.

headline: What’s on Thursday
text: 6:05 P.M. (Starz Cinema) BEFORE MIDNIGHT (2013) Nine years after rekindling a romance (“Before Sunset”) in Paris that began nine years before that (“Before Sunrise”) in Vienna, Celine (Julie Delpy) and Jesse (Ethan Hawke, above with Ms. Delpy) are now in Greece, at the end of a summer vacation with their twin daughters (Jennifer and Charlotte Prior) and Hank (Seamus Davey-Fitzpatrick), the son he left behind in Chicago. Jesse wonders if they could move from Paris to the United States to spend more time with Hank. Celine sees his question as a demand to make it happen. And so they will fight about this — and the meaning of love, the nature of time and the difference between men and women — throughout the course of a day. “ ‘Before Sunrise,’ ‘Before Sunset’ and ‘Before Midnight’ are modest, charming movies that together add up to the great romantic epic of a generation defined, in the popular mind and our therapists’ offices, by hedged bets, easy ironies and perpetual confusion,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times of this trilogy from the director Richard Linklater. This final installment, he added, “is a wonderful paradox: a movie passionately committed to the ideal of imperfection that is itself very close to perfect.” “Before Sunset” (2004) will be shown at 8:15 a.m. on Cinemax.

headline: G.M. Engineer on Switch Defect
text: Raymond DeGiorgio, an engineer at General Motors, is at the center of accusations that the company covered up a deadly defect. In these clips from a deposition in April 2013, he answers questions about the faulty ignition switches.

headline: A New Irreverent Spirit at Apple
text: It had been only four hours since Jimmy Iovine had agreed to sell Beats Electronics to Apple for $3 billion, but it was clear that he had already gotten the corporate memo.

headline: Missing Malaysian Jet Believed to Be Beyond Area of Search
text: HONG KONG — The search area in the Indian Ocean that recovery teams have been scouring for more than a month is probably not the final resting place of a missing Malaysia Airlines jetliner, the Australian task force in charge of the operation said Thursday.

headline: China’s Most-Hated Official Is No Surprise
text: China’s urban management officers, or chengguan, regularly make the news, at home and abroad, usually for unpleasant encounters with members of the public. It is not especially surprising, then, that a new report ranks them as the country’s least popular officials.

headline: Test Yourself | English, May 29, 2014
text: Take the Quiz

headline: Activist Resigns Amid Charges of Fabrication
text: HONG KONG — A well-known Cambodian crusader against sex trafficking who attracted celebrity support to her cause has resigned from the foundation she started after being confronted with allegations that she and others connected to her group fabricated stories about their experiences as young victims of the sex trade.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Police Use High-Tech Lures to Reel In Bike Thieves
text: In “Police Use High-Tech Lures to Reel In Bike Thieves,” Matt Richtel writes about one city’s campaign to make thieves think twice before they try to steal a bike.

headline: Russia and 2 Neighbors Form Economic Union That Has a Ukraine-Size Hole
text: ASTANA, Kazakhstan — The presidents of Russia, Kazakhstan and Belarus formally signed an agreement on Thursday to create a limited economic union — an alliance hobbled by the absence of Ukraine but one long pursued by President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to confirm his country as a global economic force.

headline: On the High Road Again, With Willie Nelson
text: With a glowing, handsome face, dramatic eyes and stylish hair, the subject of a Walden Fabry studio portrait looks like a matinee idol. That was in 1964, when Willie Nelson was trying to be a Nashville star.

headline: Do You Consider Yourself a Feminist?
text: What is your reaction to the word “feminist”? How would you define it? Have you heard of the “I need feminism because…” campaign?

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
text: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: New York Today: Manhattanhenge
text: Good chilly Thursday morning.

headline: Can Diet Drinks Aid Weight Loss?
text: Several observational studies have suggested that drinking diet soda may encourage weight gain, but a new randomized trial finds that it is not so.

headline: Go With You to Afghanistan, Tomorrow? Yes, Mr. President
text: At the start of the Memorial Day weekend, the Times photographer Doug Mills got an important call that forced him to adjust his plans. He would be one of four photographers to accompany the president on an unannounced trip to Afghanistan. He shared some of the details with Insider:

headline: Police, Pedestrians and the Social Ballet of Merging: The Real Challenges for Self-Driving Cars
text: Recently at a press event held to showcase Google’s research in self-driving vehicles, project leader Christopher Urmson said that the problems posed by driving on city streets are between 10 and 100 times more difficult than freeway driving. Robot vehicles confronted with other vehicles, pedestrians and bicyclists do seemingly random things, and the roadway can change at a moment’s notice.

headline: How I Learned to Recruit an A-Plus Team
text: I’ve always struggled to hire the right people. Often, candidates who respond well during the interview process turn out to be disappointing after they start. Within two weeks, I know I’ve made a mistake.

headline: Betting on a Brand When Politics Is the Family Business
text: Three business school professors recently set out to discover what accounts for regional differences in product choices by consumers.

headline: A Frontier Farce From the Guy Behind ‘Family Guy’
text: You can’t blame Seth MacFarlane, that one-man comedy juggernaut, for wanting to add movie star to his list of credentials. After all, he has succeeded beyond any sane person’s wildest dreams at building a comedy empire by holding a stinky finger to the racing pulse of the collective id.

headline: Daily Report: In Buying Beats, Apple Bets on a Founder’s Skilled Ear
text: Apple’s new music impresario, Jimmy Iovine, didn’t start out writing code or studying computer engineering, the usual path of a Silicon Valley mogul. Instead, he began his career sweeping the floors of New York City recording studios and fetching tea for John Lennon, Ben Sisario reports.

headline: Ackman Seeks a London Listing
text: The billionaire hedge fund manager William A. Ackman, one of Wall Street’s boldest investors, is building an unusual multibillion-dollar war chest, DealBook’s Alexandra Stevenson writes. While hedge funds typically raise funds privately, the founder of the $13 billion Pershing Square Capital Management is said to be planning to raise billions of dollars for a closed-end fund that could list on the London Stock Exchange as soon as this summer.

headline: U.S. Economy Contracted in a Frigid First Quarter
text: It was an economic quarter no one wants to repeat.

headline: Marcato Capital Urges Intercontinental Hotels to Pursue Merger
text: LONDON – The hedge fund Marcato Capital Management urged the Intercontinental Hotels Group on Thursday to pursue a merger after media reports in Britain this week that it had turned down an unknown American bidder.

headline: What’s News in Washington: Congress Reacts to V.A. Report
text: Good Thursday morning from a misty Washington.

headline: Happenings | A Literary Festival in Paradise
text: Jamaica’s rocky, arid south coast is refreshingly low on tourist traffic compared with the bustling north — which is just how fans of the beloved bohemian hideaway Jake’s Hotel like it. This weekend, 27 modern literary legends will descend upon the rural seaside town of Treasure Beach for the annual Calabash International Literary Festival, a three-day conference consisting of readings and themed discussions with Salman Rushdie, Zadie Smith, Colum McCann, Jamaica Kincaid, Paul Muldoon and other luminaries. It began in 2001, when the novelist Colin Channer joined forces with the poet Kwame Dawes and the producer Justine Henzell, whose mother built Jake’s, to bring a world-class cultural event to their favorite place on the planet.

headline: Bias Claims for Insurers in Coverage of H.I.V.
text: Health care advocates said on Thursday that four insurers offering plans in the new federal marketplace discriminated against people with H.I.V. or AIDS by requiring them to pay high out-of-pocket costs for drugs to treat H.I.V., including generic medications.

headline: Wall St. Braces for Food Fights as Tyson Tops Pilgrim’s Pride’s Bid for Hillshire
text: Updated, 8:13 p.m. | A week ago, many shareholders of Hillshire Brands were complaining about its planned acquisition of Pinnacle Foods, the maker of Birds Eye frozen vegetables.

headline: Santander Bank to Face Suit Claiming Bias in Mortgages
text: The lawsuit will claim that from 2009 to 2012, the number of new mortgages in minority neighborhoods of Providence, R.I., fell 63 percent, Shaila Dewan reports in The New York Times. Read more »

headline: Three American Men in Paris Defy Recent History in Reaching the Third Round
text: PARIS — It was hard to say what was more surprising at the French Open on Thursday: that three American men reached the third round at Roland Garros, or that one of them declared clay to be his favorite surface.

headline: She Sews Actors Into Their Roles
text: As they say, the 18th time is the charm.

headline: Pro-Russia Troops Take Symbol of Ukraine Uprising
text: DONETSK, Ukraine — The revolution was interrupted by a coup on Thursday, with one faction in this self-declared republic ousting another from the regional administration building that had become the symbol of the uprising here.

headline: Nine Scientists Are Awarded Kavli Prizes
text: Beaming in from Oslo via the web, officials of the Norwegian Academy of Science and Letters invaded the World Science Festival in New York on Thursday to announce that nine scientists had won this year’s Kavli prizes. The winners will split million-dollar prizes awarded in three categories: astrophysics, nanoscience and neuroscience.

headline: Submitted: Teenagers Do Not Need Smartphones, So They Should Pay for Them. Discuss.
text: Two weeks ago, I took to this space to ask four key questions about cars and teenagers and suggest four possible ways of paying for what they drive.

headline: The Jobless Rate for Community-College Graduates Is Also Low
text: The federal government’s main educational-attainment categories are fairly blunt. In particular, the “some college” category includes a wide array of people: Those who have dropped out of college without earning any degree, those who have earned a two-year degree meant to lead directly to a job (such as in nursing) and those who have earned an academic two-year degree that is often a first step toward a bachelor’s degree.

headline: Alan Furst: By the Book
text: The author of “Mission to Paris” and, most recently, “Midnight in Europe” is a great fan of John le Carré’s Karla trilogy. “George Smiley is the all-time harassed bureaucrat of spy fiction.”

headline: If a Reference Can’t Accentuate the Positive
text: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

headline: Black Lawyers Lose Ground at Top Firms
text: For black lawyers, the country’s top law firms are lonely places, according to a newly released tally.

headline: Boehner and Pelosi Resist Cries for Ouster of Veterans Affairs Chief
text: WASHINGTON — As the list of lawmakers calling for the resignation of Eric Shinseki as secretary of veterans affairs grew by the hour Thursday, leaders in both parties worked to quiet the politics and find a legislative solution to the crisis of care at veterans’ health centers.

headline: Abbas Seeks a New Government That Would Seal Alliance With Hamas
text: JERUSALEM — President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority asked Rami Hamdallah, the prime minister, on Thursday to form a “government of national consensus” that would unite warring Palestinian factions for the first time in seven years and could send Israeli-Palestinian relations into a tailspin.

headline: What Did You Think of Our Text-to-Text Lessons?
text: Last September we introduced a new lesson-plan format called Text to Text, in which we pair two texts that we think “speak” to each other in interesting ways, then pose questions and suggest a few activities for students to bring the writings together.

headline: Senate’s Legislative Inactivity
text: The House has introduced fewer bills this Congress, but what about the Senate? The number of legislative proposals in that chamber has fallen by 23 percent compared with the last Congress, an even steeper decline than in the House. But in other respects, the changes in bill introductions in the Senate have roughly mirrored what has happened in the House.

headline: Dish Network Says It Will Accept Bitcoin
text: Most of Dish Network’s 14 million subscribers are probably not Bitcoin users. But that will not stop the company from accepting payments in the virtual currency later this year.

headline: Man Group in Deal Talks With Numeric Holdings
text: LONDON – The British hedge fund manager Man Group said on Thursday that it was in discussions to possibly acquire Numeric Holdings, an investment manager based in Boston.

headline: Latest News on V.A. Health Care Scandal
text: Bipartisan calls for the resignation of Veterans Affairs Secretary Eric Shinseki are growing louder — and more bipartisan — and two House committees are meeting on Thursday to discuss the agency’s problems treating veterans. The hearings follow a report that validated accusations that the department’s hospital administrators manipulated patient waiting lists. We’ll be tracking the developments live throughout the day.

headline: Advice From a New Yorker: Mind Your Own Business
text: Dear Diary:

headline: What Brian Williams Should Have Asked Snowden
text: Updated, 11:16 a.m. | I miss Barbara Walters already.

headline: Investment Chief Named for New York City Pensions
text: Scott Evans, a former head of asset management for TIAA-CREF, will be the next chief investment officer of New York City’s $150 billion pension system, according to the city comptroller, Scott M. Stringer.

headline: In Expansion of No. 7 Line, One Problem: An Elevator
text: The fate of the newest addition to the New York City subway system could be traced last summer to the foothills of Appiano Gentile, at a work site beneath the northern Italian sun.

headline: Countdown to the 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 14
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Brad Jefferson of Animoto, on Knowing Your Company’s Heartbeat
text: This interview with Brad Jefferson, chief executive of Animoto, a video slide show service, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Life Beyond the Cancer Clinic
text: Three years.

headline: Deceptive Dip in G.D.P. Points to Perils of Election Forecasting
text: An economic report issued this morning provides a good example of the hazards facing election forecasters. The Bureau of Economic Analysis reported that in the first quarter of this year, Gross Domestic Product, a broad indicator of the health of the economy, shrank at an annual rate of 1 percent. Even worse, an alternative and more accurate measure, called Gross Domestic Income, shrank at an annual rate of 2.3 percent. If that persisted, we’d call it a sharp recession.

headline: Americans More Worried About ‘Warming’ Than ‘Climate Change’
text: Many scientists have come to prefer the term “climate change” over “global warming.” Climate change is a broader term that encompasses not only the warming of the planet in recent years but also the rise of severe storms, droughts and damaging winds. The choice of terms has important implications for polling because Americans give different answers to questions depending on which is used.

headline: A Wine Week in London
text: As Paris, the capital of wine-loving France, wraps up its beer week festival, London, more known for ales and pubs, is uncorking its first wine week.

headline: Elisabeth Moss in Talks to Star in ‘The Heidi Chronicles’ on Broadway
text: On Sunday’s finale of the 2014 episodes of “Mad Men,” the copy chief Peggy Olson was single (but making eyes at the repairman), childless (yet loving to the neighbor boy, Julio) and newly 30 (though only Don knew). Her concerns and conflicts called to mind the life choices of Heidi Holland, the brilliant, lonely art historian in “The Heidi Chronicles,” the beloved Wendy Wasserstein play that won the Pulitzer Prize and the Tony Award in 1989, with Joan Allen as Heidi. If a group of Broadway producers have their way, Peggy and Heidi will have something else in common: the actress Elisabeth Moss.

headline: In Our Pages: May 30
text: 1914: Liner Empress of Ireland Sinks

headline: Rape Allegations in a Haryana Village Underscore a Social Fracas
text: BHAGANA, India — On March 23, M., a 13-year-old girl in this Haryana village, said that she performed a nightly ritual with three of her friends.  She joined them outside their neighboring houses and walked to the middle of the harvest-ready wheat fields belonging to the majority Jat community, where the girls relieved themselves.

headline: Brad Pitt Punched at ‘Maleficent’ Premiere
text: Brad Pitt was signing autographs outside the El Capitan Theater in Hollywood on Wednesday evening, on his way to the premiere of “Maleficent,” which stars his partner, Angelina Jolie, when suddenly, for a few seconds, it seemed as if he were back in “Fight Club.” While Mr. Pitt was signing and Ms. Jolie was posing for photographs, someone jumped over a metal barrier and took a swing at Mr. Pitt, striking him in the face. The alleged assailant, whom the police identified as Vitalii Sediuk, 25, was led away in handcuffs. Gus Villanueva, a spokesman for the Los Angeles Police Department, told Reuters that he was being held in lieu of $20,000 bail.

headline: Sebastian Junger on His Companion Film to ‘Restrepo’
Urban Renewal, No Bulldozer
text: SAN FRANCISCO — It has gone widely unremarked, maybe because it’s so obvious to people here, that tech firms in San Francisco have not (yet) been moving into new buildings; they’ve been taking over old ones. Twitter has leased a onetime furniture mart on Market Street, and AirBnB has renovated a century-old industrial warehouse south of Market. Yelp occupies part of 140 New Montgomery downtown, the magnificent Art Deco former Pacific Telephone tower from the 1920s, lovingly revamped by Cathy Simon, an architect with Perkins & Will, and the developers Wilson Meany Sullivan.

headline: It Rocks When Girls Go Punk
text: There is hardly a shortage of movies about rock ’n’ roll, but there are few as perfect — which is to say as ragged, as silly, as touching or as true — as “We Are the Best!,” Lukas Moodysson’s sweet and rambunctious new film. The setting is Stockholm in 1982, hardly a legendary place or moment in the annals of modern music, but that’s kind of the point. Rock ’n’ roll glory is wherever you find it, and whatever you make of it.

headline: Thomas Piketty Responds to Criticism of His Data
text: Six days after The Financial Times launched an attack on the data behind Thomas Piketty’s much-debated tome on inequality, “Capital in the Twenty-First Century,” Mr. Piketty has offered his first detailed response to the newspaper’s criticism.

headline: Delaying Vaccines May Increase Seizure Risk
text: Childhood vaccinations like those for measles–mumps–rubella carry a small risk of seizures. Some parents postpone their children’s vaccinations because they believe the delay decreases the risk. But a new study finds the opposite may be true.

headline: Laverne Cox: ‘Blending In Was Never an Option’
text: The actress talks to Eric Spitznagel about growing up in the South, the difficulties of writing a memoir and the fortuitous casting decision that landed her on "Orange Is the New Black."

headline: Today in Small Business: A Square Deal?
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Whoever Gets the Tony, He Wins
text: As campaign stunts go in this spring’s race for the Tony Award for best musical, Operation Liza went like clockwork.

headline: A Chicago Hotel Honors a Street Photographer
text: A street photographer who worked in obscurity from the mid-’50s until her death in 2009, Vivian Maier is now the subject of a theatrically released documentary, a BBC special and, most recently, the lobby of the Radisson Blu Aqua Hotel, Chicago.

headline: Director of ‘Happy in Tehran’ Video Is Reportedly Freed
text: Sassan Soleimani, the director of “Happy in Tehran,” a viral YouTube tribute to Pharrell Williams that offended Iran’s conservative judiciary, was released on bail Thursday, according to the International Campaign for Human Rights in Iran, a New York-based advocacy group.

headline: Italy Seeks $1.6 Billion in Damages From Roche and Novartis
text: PARIS — The Italian government is seeking $1.6 billion in damages from two of the world’s biggest drug companies — Novartis and Roche — for losses that it says the national health service incurred from the companies’ efforts to restrict competition in ophthalmic drugs.

headline: Fund Within a Fund Creates a Conflict
text: Updated, 3:00 p.m. |

headline: White House Stresses Widespread Energy Progress Ahead of New Climate Rule
text: The White House has released a report charting progress on several energy fronts that is clearly aimed at setting the stage ahead of President Obama’s expected announcement next Monday of the first regulations restricting carbon dioxide from existing power plants. (It’s been a very long journey — abetted by an important Supreme Court decision — since President George W. Bush tried to restrict carbon dioxide from such plants and quickly reversed course.)

headline: Image of the Day: May 29
text: A boy resting in a boat on a hot summer day in Allahabad, Uttar Pradesh.

headline: Inside In Performance
text: A behind-the-scenes look at the making of our 2014 Tony Awards interactive.

headline: House Panel Advances Bill on School Lunch Options
text: WASHINGTON — The House Appropriations Committee on Thursday passed an agriculture budget bill that included nearly $21 billion for child nutrition that would allow schools to opt out of White House nutritional guidelines passed in 2012. The vote was 31 to 18.

headline: A Special Tony Awards ‘In Performance’
text: Scott Heller is the theater editor and deputy editor for Arts & Leisure at The New York Times.

headline: To Young Minds of Today, Harvard Is the Stanford of the East
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — In academia, where brand reputation is everything, one university holds an especially enviable place these days when it comes to attracting students and money. To find it from this center of learning, turn west and go about 2,700 miles.

headline: Listen Up | Roisin Murphy’s Electronic Covers of Italian Pop Standards
text: “Now is the time for me to make a record only I could make,” says the inimitable Roisin Murphy. The 40-year-old singer is speaking in a charming Irish brogue over Skype, with birds singing in the background, about the full-length album of original material she plans to release later this year after a seven-year absence. But the comment could just as easily refer to her current project, “Mi Senti” — an EP of electronic covers of Italian pop standards made famous by ’60s and ’70s icons like Mina and Patti Pravo, plus one Italian-language original. A remix of a track from the release, “Ancora Ancora Ancora,” debuts here.

headline: Silicon Valley May Be in a Bubble, but It’s Not 2000
text: Mary Meeker says Silicon Valley is not in a bubble.

headline: Lawmakers’ Modest Proposal: To Pass Spending Bills on Time
text: WASHINGTON — The state of Congress is such that the performance of its most basic task — the orderly passage of annual spending bills that fund the government — has become this year a test of whether it can function at all.

headline: International Observers Find Egypt’s Presidential Election Fell Short of Standards
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s presidential election fell short of international standards of democracy, two teams of foreign observers said Thursday, a day after the former military officer who led last summer’s military takeover won a landslide victory with more than 95 percent of the vote.

headline: Turning Sturgeon Into High-Tech Sensors
text: Sturgeon in the Hudson River are being fitted with transmitters to see if noise from pile driving and construction on the new Tappan Zee Bridge is harming imperiled Atlantic and shortnose sturgeon.

headline: Batting Practice Pitcher Cherishes Rise to the Big Leagues
text: On a charter flight from Toronto to New York for the Yankees’ home opener, on April 7, Derek Jeter called Danilo Valiente to the back of the plane.

headline: Times Minute | The Pressure on Shinseki
text: With more findings about extended health care waits and malpractices for veterans, pressure mounts on the Veterans Affairs secretary, Eric Shinseki, to resign.
