My Life in Cartoons,” which is not just a charming memoir but also a charming grab bag of cartoon history, cartoon theory (nothing too woolly) and shoptalk. The title is taken from Mankoff’s best-known drawing. Businessman on phone, consulting datebook: “No, Thursday’s out. How about never — is never good for you?” As its author points out — false modesty is not one of his faults — that line has entered the vernacular, alongside other classics from the magazine such as “I say it’s spinach, and I say the hell with it” (drawing by Carl Rose, caption by E. B. White); “Well, back to the old drawing board” (Peter Arno); and “On the Internet, nobody knows you’re a dog” (Peter Steiner).

headline: Drawn From Life
text: (This book was selected as one of The New York Times Book Review’s 10 Best Books of 2014. For the rest of the list, click here.)

headline: Housing on the Mend, Ever So Gradually
text: ONE way to tell the housing market is beginning to show signs of health would be that builders of new homes are selling more houses than banks do.

headline: They Love Paris
text: Cole Porter isn’t the only American to have fallen in love with Paris in the springtime, which may explain why four books about Europe’s most beguiling city have appeared all at once. By pure serendipity, their four authors have independently succeeded in producing a chronological quartet.

headline: The Dark Side
text: Robert Louis Stevenson’s “The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde” is an oblique and artful Gothic tale framed as a detective story. The truth seeker is Jekyll’s lawyer, Utterson, the book’s most prominent character. Jekyll — the ­gentleman who dabbles in chemical self-­transformation — appears only ­intermittently, never fully speaking for himself until the end, when he discloses the details of the disastrous experiments that unleashed his primitive alter ego. The novel isn’t a conventional horror story, lingering on the macabre for its own sake, but an allegory of the divided self, perhaps also a meditation on addiction. Stevenson dramatizes human duality but doesn’t analyze its causes, treating it as pervasive and fundamental. For him, the Jekyll-Hyde split is the split in all of us, between the animals we evolved from and the angels we aspire to be.

headline: Life Out Loud
text: When Brittney Griner was a senior in high school, a 6-foot-8 center on her way to an all-­American basketball career at Baylor University, she feared telling her father that she was a lesbian. His explosive, curse-filled response upon finding out, Griner writes in a painful, searing and ultimately liberating memoir, “In My Skin: My Life on and Off the Basketball Court,” was exactly what she had dreaded.

headline: Science Fiction
text: In “Annihilation,” the first book of Jeff VanderMeer’s Southern Reach trilogy, readers were introduced to Area X, a stretch of coastal wetland whose conspiracy-theory name is the icing atop a mille-feuille of layered, slow-building, deliciously creepy horror. Twelve teams of ­researchers, stripped of names to somehow protect them from the identity-warping effects of the danger zone, have traveled into Area X; “Annihilation” followed “the biologist” as she seemingly became the only survivor to actually understand what was happening.

headline: Thrillers
text: I had the wrong idea about beach books. It came from “Goodbye, Columbus,” where Neil Klugman tells Brenda Patimkin that his cousin Doris always has “War and Peace” by the pool: “That’s how I know it’s the summer, when Doris is reading ‘War and Peace.’ ” Pool and beach being the same to me back then — an idiot kid forced to sit outside with no TV, uncomfortable with my shirt off as my grandfather paraded around to show off he still had a body — I didn’t see that Philip Roth was mocking Doris, and so for years protected myself from the water and sand I resented and feared by lugging along a classic. This is how I read “Swann’s Way” at the Mamaroneck Beach Club as a guest of Uncle Marty and Aunt Lee. It took many visits. Here I would like to thank them personally.

headline: Success Is in the Eye of the Beholder
text: I smile and sign autographs no matter what. Most fans don’t seem to care much if we won or lost. They don’t know if I had the game of my life or a complete shocker. They say, “Great game! You were awesome!” Sometimes they even tell me I was wonderful when I didn’t play a single minute. I thank them whether I feel on top of the world or have a lump of disappointment in my throat.

headline: Travel
text: Paul Bowles observed that an important difference between a tourist and a traveler “is that the former accepts his own civilization without question; not so the traveler, who compares it with the others, and rejects those elements he finds not to his liking.” This difference also separates writers about travels from “travel writers.” Is the voyaging writer telling us canny stories from a romping trip or using his peregrinations to relocate his place in the world? Sometimes it’s difficult to tell. D. H. Lawrence knocked off travel essays about places in which he had arrived only a few hours before, but he was writing about himself and his intuitions. Bowles, for his part, lived for years in Morocco but traveled through the desert with a suitcase filled with his favorite neckties. Do we read either man for profound and meticulously earned insights about Sardinia or the Sahara, or for their ability to convey something about themselves as they pass through those places? Most writers are “passing through,” and we expect no more of them. It’s part of their charm, if they have any. And part of the sometimes dubious premise of travel writing itself.

headline: Pop Music
text: All rock biographies/memoirs agree on one point. As Gregg Allman tells it in “One Way Out,” an exhaustive oral history of the Allman Brothers Band by Alan Paul, escaping the workaday lot of “a shock-absorber washer-jammer in Detroit . . . is why I became a musician in the first place.” Or as Joey Ramone sang: “It’s not my place in the 9-to-5 world.”

headline: Humor
text: Writing seriously about humor is a tricky proposition. If you approach the subject too analytically, you risk losing sight of what made it worth writing about in the first place. If you try to leaven your analysis with a little humor of your own, there’s a good chance you’ll end up reminding your readers why making people laugh is best left to the people who do it for a living.

headline: One Man, Two Wives and Many Accepted Forms of Violence in Pakistan
text: LONDON — The murder case of Farzana Parveen, it seemed, could hardly have turned more tragic or gruesome: a 25-year-old pregnant woman, bludgeoned to death with a brick by family members on a busy street, for having married the man she loved.

headline: Shall We Dance?
text: All movies are musical, film being as reliant on rhythm and tempo as sonatas are. Only a few movies are musicals, though, and the fewness isn’t going away. Live-action musicals are nearly as endangered a movie species as westerns. Whether you think those few are too many or nowhere near enough will go a long way toward determining your response to Richard Barrios’s “Dangerous Rhythm: Why Movie Musicals Matter.” The subtitle indicates which side Barrios comes down on. The fact of his having written the exhaustively researched and exuberantly argued “A Song in the Dark: The Birth of the Musical Film” (1995) should settle any doubts.

headline: Street Life
text: The flâneur, that feature of the 19th-century urban landscape, stood apart from the city as a wide-eyed wanderer. But when he had a camera in his hands, he became the archetypal street photographer, a curious observer who captured his environment in what Henri Cartier-Bresson called its "decisive moments”: spontaneous, serendipitous, intuitive, singular. In “Unfamiliar Streets: The Photographs of Richard Avedon, Charles Moore, Martha Rosler, and Philip-Lorca diCorcia,” the art historian Katherine A. Bussard explores the genre of street photography, beginning with this dominant definition and then expanding it. The photographers she investigates, whose work here spans the 1940s through 2001, manipulate the viewer’s imagination of the city, or change the way viewers act within it. According to Bussard, accurately representing experiences of city streets “involves addressing issues of gender, commerce, race, collectivity, class, dispossession, sexuality and spectacle.” In other words, street photography isn’t only the magic of capturing a well-composed slice of life; it’s the more complex task of recapitulating or intensifying the economic, class and gender tensions of the city street within an image. The image should galvanize the viewer or, ideally, alter street life as it’s lived simply by the fact of the image having been made.

headline: Minnesota Nice
text: Some writers define themselves by contrasting their talents or sensibility with those of another writer. “Well, I’m no Joyce Carol Oates,” they’ll tell you, false modesty oozing from their pores like musk. “I publish a book every eight years.” Or, “You wouldn’t confuse me with Thomas Merton,” they’ll say, referring to the Trappist monk and mystic. “Kneeling bags my nylons.” The best of these self-conscious comparisons may come from James Thurber, who was once asked to review Salvador Dalí’s autobiography. Comparing his own golden-hued Columbus, Ohio, upbringing with young Dalí’s chiaroscuro of ermine capes and necrophilia, Thurber wrote, “The naked truth about me is to the naked truth about Salvador Dalí as an old ukulele in the attic is to a piano in a tree, and I mean a piano with breasts.”

headline: Appetites
text: Ruth Reichl is known for many things, among them her best-selling memoirs, including “Tender at the Bone” and “Comfort Me With Apples,” as well as her years of reviewing restaurants for both The Los Angeles Times and The New York Times, and as the editor in chief of the seemingly immortal Gourmet magazine — until it folded. With the arrival of Twitter, Reichl added another genre to her résumé: haiku-like paeans to breakfast in any weather: “Sunny in Charlotte. Returned to rain. Gray New York morning. Big bowl of ginger strewn congee. Chiles. Soy. Scallion. So consoled.” The next day, it was still raining, but once again food came to the rescue: “Gray drizzle. Umbrellas up. Sidewalks sloppy. Rye bread, still warm. Herring: pungent, rich. Sour cream. Onions. Solace in the city.”

headline: Five-Card Studs
text: Art is the deliberate transformed by the accidental. If you’re a writer, you brew a pot of coffee, adjust the lights, go over your notes and get started, though you know that something — a phone call, a memory, a random image — is likely to barge in and change everything. Instead of “art,” of course, you could say “science,” “making gumbo” and even “romance”: You show up at Veronica’s apartment with your hair slicked back and a bouquet in your hand, and who answers the door? Betty.

headline: Get Down
text: When I was growing up in Chicago, there was no rowdier time in our house than Friday night, when my mother, my three siblings and I stayed up to watch “Red Hot and Blues” on Channel 26, Chicago’s first UHF station. Part advertisement and part dance spectacle, it was our chance to celebrate the end of the week, listen and dance to our favorite R & B songs and howl at the cheesy commercials delivered by pitchmen selling used cars and ugly furniture: “You’ll do well to see Dell’s — Dell’s Furniture.” (Even hearing the voice was enough to send us all into fits of laughter.) Just as attractive as the music was the lineup of shabbily dressed kids from the West Side who gathered in front of the camera to dance — a great counterpart to us shabbily dressed kids from the South Side. The show was the highlight of our week.

headline: Hit Man
text: Bert Berns the producer is the Phil Spector you’ve never heard of. Bert Berns the songwriter is the Leiber and Stoller you’ve never heard of. Bert Berns the label exec is the Jerry Wexler you’ve never heard of.

headline: Dress-Up
text: Five years ago Ruth Bader Ginsburg, associate justice of the Supreme Court of the United States, flung open her closet to Brian Lamb, the founder of C-SPAN.

headline: Captured Obsessions
text: Over the last 50 years, Mary Ellen Mark has photographed twins, clowns, patients in a mental hospital, Ku Klux Klan members and Liza Minnelli. She likes to look at people who are used to being looked at, and she uses her camera like Wonder Woman’s golden lasso — as a truth-telling device that peels performance from personality. In one of her most famous photographs, “Tiny” (1983), a Seattle street kid poses in her Halloween costume: a little black dress, little black gloves and a hat with a netted veil. It’s the daintiness of Tiny’s dress combined with her defiance that gives the photograph its charge. Tough Tiny looks afraid.

headline: Disillusion
text: According to the oft-repeated statistic, roughly half of all marriages in this country end in divorce — which makes “The Divorce Papers,” Susan Rieger’s epistolary first novel about one couple’s messy split, certainly relatable. But how many people want to relive the emotions of a marriage’s demise, from the initial shock to the ensuing despair, fury and vengeance?

headline: Today in Small Business: The Cost of Paper Checks
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Letters From London
text: This book seems to have been written specifically for me. Which is not quite the same as saying it was written for you. There is a chance, of course, that you too lived in London in the 1980s while studying for a degree in English literature, in which case you will get every cultural and political reference it contains. It’s possible you are actually English yourself. If that is so, you (like me) will laugh aloud at the understated humor while enjoying the nostalgic mentions of TV shows and sporting events of years gone by.

headline: Altar Ego
text: Jen Doll is Emily Post’s worst nightmare.

headline: BNP Paribas Shares Fall on Fine Fears
text: Updated, 12:32 p.m. |

headline: Journey by Rail
text: In an era of railway mediocrity, epitomized by Amtrak, it’s easy to forget that train travel was once a romantic adventure. Riding the rails to Boston in 1924, George Gershwin listened to the roar of the steam engine and the turn of the wheels and found the inspiration for “Rhapsody in Blue,” his hymn to urbanizing, Jazz Age America. “It was on the train, with its steely rhythms, its rattle-ty bang, that is so often so stimulating to a composer,” he told a biographer, describing the moment of creation. “I frequently hear music in the very heart of the noise.” W. C. Handy and other African-American musicians heard a similar sound on the Illinois Central, the Midwestern line that spirited them away from the Deep South on the Great Migration that began during World War I. They married the whistle and drone of the locomotive to the plaintive chants of sharecroppers and invented the “city blues.” Steve Goodman, a little-known composer, was inspired by a ­journey on the same line to write a dirge that became one of the anthems of the Vietnam War era — “The City of New ­Orleans.”

headline: Not Just Laughs
text: Christopher Buckley begins his new collection, “But Enough About You,” with an essay about the perils of being known as a humorist, the fear that people brand him as “trivial” and believe that what he and his literary forebears do is easy. “Well, only five paragraphs in and already wallowing in self-pity,” he writes. “We just can’t get no respect.”

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 13
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Inside the List
text: Hemingway on the Stoop: Near the beginning of “Sons of Wichita,” his biography of the politically influential Koch brothers — it’s No. 17 on the extended hardcover nonfiction list — Daniel Schulman describes the conservative beliefs of the family patriarch, the industrialist Fred Koch. “Father was paranoid about Communism, let’s put it that way,” his son David Koch once told New York magazine, in a quote Schulman cites. Fred’s views filtered down to at least one of his four sons: Charles, the second-oldest and now the chief executive of Koch Industries, spent most of a blind date in the early 1960s railing against the evils of Communism, according to the biography. (“I ended up leaving early and walking home,” his date says.) Charles also let his politics spill over into literary criticism. Schulman, a senior editor at Mother Jones, reports that when a family friend showed up at the Koch house in the 1960s with a copy of “The Sun Also Rises,” Charles eyed the book apprehensively and finally asked the visitor to leave it outside.

headline: Snooping Around
text: The word “spying” now brings to mind boundless digital nets trawling the ether for millions of emails at a time, but Miles Adler-Hart, the young protagonist of Mona Simpson’s sixth novel, practices snooping the old-school way. He plants a walkie-talkie in his parents’ bedroom. He eavesdrops on therapy sessions through a heating vent. He listens to phone conversations by carefully picking up a landline in the next room.

headline: How Sandy Koufax’s Motel Helped Lead to Baseball’s Big-Money Era
text: In 1962, the star Los Angeles Dodgers pitcher Sandy Koufax invested in a West Hollywood motor inn, which was renamed “Sandy Koufax’s Tropicana Motel.” Down Santa Monica Boulevard from the famed Troubadour club, these “74 luxurious air-conditioned rooms” — rented at “popular prices” — came to lodge some of the biggest musical acts of the period: Alice Cooper, Bob Marley, the Mamas and the Papas, Led Zeppelin, Janis Joplin, Jim Morrison and the Doors. “I don’t know which made me more excited,” said one guest, “to be in Sandy’s motel or to be in a room right beside Sly Stone, from Sly and the Family Stone.”

headline: Quantum Teleportation
text: Researchers teleported quantum information between two distant atoms for the first time in 2009.

headline: Trouble in Paradise
text: THE VACATIONERSBy Emma Straub  Riverhead, $26.95.

headline: V.A. Chief Resigns in Face of Furor on Delayed Care
text: WASHINGTON — Eric Shinseki resigned as secretary of the Department of Veterans Affairs on Friday, leaving behind a sprawling bureaucracy embroiled in scandal and burdened with a decades-old legacy of overwhelmed facilities and management failures that his successor must now confront.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE CIRCLE,  by Dave Eggers. (Vintage, $15.95.) Orwell’s Ministry of Truth is transformed into a powerful tech company in Eggers’s dystopian satire. In a not-too-distant future, human existence flows through the Circle, a Google-like, Facebook-like behemoth that aspires to record and quantify everything that happens to everybody, everywhere in the world. Into this digital wonderland steps Mae Holland, an ambitious new hire eager to comply with the Circle’s demands for transparency.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: STRESS TEST: Reflections on Financial Crises,  by Timothy F. Geithner. (Crown, $35.) The former Treasury secretary’s memoir offers an inside look at the government’s response to the financial crisis.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
text: In the news: walking, diet drinks and food labels. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Dissonance in Classical Music
text: Anthony Tommasini, classical music critic for The New York Times, talks about dissonance - the perceived stability or instability of two or more sounds.

headline: Dissonance: Schoenberg
text: Anthony Tommasini, classical music critic for The New York Times, talks about dissonance in the music of Arnold Schoenberg.

headline: Dissonance: Stravinsky, Bach and Mozart
text: Anthony Tommasini, classical music critic for The New York Times, talks about dissonance in the work of Stravinsky, Bach and Mozart. The full, uninterrupted video is available here.

headline: Dissonance: Sondheim
text: Anthony Tommasini, classical music critic for The New York Times, talks about dissonance in the music of Stephen Sondheim.

headline: Dissonance: Schumann
text: Anthony Tommasini, classical music critic for The New York Times, talks about dissonance in the music of Robert Schumann.

headline: Dissonance: Jazz
text: Anthony Tommasini, classical music critic for The New York Times, talks about dissonance in jazz.

headline: Dissonance: Copland
text: Anthony Tommasini, classical music critic for The New York Times, talks about dissonance in the music of Aaron Copland.

headline: Dissonance: Gershwin
text: Anthony Tommasini, classical music critic for The New York Times, talks about dissonance in the music of George Gershwin.

headline: Everything You Need to Know About Thomas Piketty vs. The Financial Times
text: Last Friday afternoon, The Financial Times released an expansive report accusing Thomas Piketty of doing shoddy analysis of data on wealth inequality for his best-selling book, “Capital in the Twenty-First Century.” In the six days since, economists and writers around the world have produced many thousands of words on the controversy. Outsiders have weighed in on the newspaper’s case, the newspaper responded, and Mr. Piketty, on Thursday, provided his first detailed defense.

headline: $5 Million to Endow Yale Poetry Chair
text: Yale University has received a $5 million gift from Frederick Iseman, the founder and chief executive of CI Capital Partners, a private equity firm, to be used partly to endow the school’s first chair in poetry and partly to extend a program that gives Yale students free access to the Metropolitan Opera’s HD broadcasts as well its Met on Demand archives, the university announced.

headline: Shinseki Outlines Actions for V.A.
text: Eric Shinseki, the secretary of the Department of Veterans Affairs, said he is ousting the leadership of the department’s Phoenix hospital after revelations about delays in care.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘Shakespeare in America’
text: This week, James Shapiro talks about “Shakespeare in America”; Parul Sehgal and John Williams on the week’s literary news; Bob Mankoff discusses “How About Never — Is Never Good for You?”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: A Win a Trip Winner Talks with Nicholas Kristof
text: The 2014 Win-A-Trip Winner Nicole Sganga sits down with columnist Nicholas Kristof for a candid conversation about global development and their journey to Myanmar! Follow their reporting trip on the blog and through Nicholas’s columns.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘Shakespeare in America’
text: This week, James Shapiro and Bob Mankoff.

headline: Q. and A. on the Syrian Presidential Election
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syria will hold a presidential election on Tuesday amid a three-year conflict that has killed more than 160,000 people and driven nine million from their homes. The disputed vote is virtually certain to give President Bashar al-Assad a third seven-year term. Opponents of the Assad administration have dismissed the election as a sham, given the government’s violent crackdown on a movement for political rights that began in 2011 and morphed into civil war.

headline: A Cruise to Catch Autumn Leaves
text: Car trips are a popular way to see the picturesque fall foliage in New England and the eastern coast of Canada, but this year, Crystal Cruises has a new sailing in the region that will give travelers a different way to take in the season’s colors.

headline: At Disney Concert Hall, Hadid Picks Up on Gehry’s Tune
text: It was an artistic collaboration delayed by some 25 years: The London architect Zaha Hadid responded as much to Frank Gehry’s Walt Disney Concert Hall in Los Angeles as she did to “Così Fan Tutte” when she designed her undulating all-white set for the Los Angeles Philharmonic’s performance of Mozart’s opera this week (it closes on Saturday). “We were responding to the context, to Frank’s design,” Ms. Hadid said in a telephone interview from London.

headline: Middle-Class Lament: Rent
text: Michael and Melanie Bellanger Boyer, transplanted Parisians who live in a snug one-bedroom in the West 90s, are members of what social scientists sometimes call the “forgotten middle.”

headline: The Art of Setting the Senses on Edge
text: An often-quoted phrase from Milton’s “Comus,” a masque about the god of festivities, describes a roar that emerged from the woods and “fill’d the Air with barbarous dissonance.”

headline: Suicide Bomber Is Identified as a Florida Man
text: WASHINGTON — An American who blew himself up in an attack in Syria on Sunday has been identified by law enforcement officials as Moner Mohammad Abusalha, a man in his early 20s who grew up in Florida and traveled to Syria late last year.

headline: Sam Greenlee, Writer, Producer, Government Agent, Dies at 83
text: Sam Greenlee, a novelist and poet best known for a low-budget 1973 movie made from his novel “The Spook Who Sat by the Door,” which envisioned a black power revolution led by a militant black ex-C.I.A. agent — it was pulled from theaters after a brief box office success — died on May 19 in Chicago. He was 83.

headline: Obama Accepts Shinseki’s Resignation
text: President Obama announced he has accepted the resignation from Eric Shinseki, the secretary of the Veterans Affairs Department, following evidence of mismanagement at the agency’s medical facilities.

headline: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
text: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

headline: Next Week on Retro Report
text: Revisiting the Space Shuttle Challenger disaster. Visit www.nytimes.com on Monday for the full story.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: An Artist’s Priorities Are Shaken From the Abstract to the Concrete
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — PHILIPPE DODARD, often called the Picasso of Haiti, was searching for vibrations.

headline: Book Review Podcast: ‘Shakespeare in America’
text: In The New York Times Book Review, Noah Millman reviews “Shakespeare in America,” a new anthology from the Library of America, edited by James Shapiro. Mr. Millman writes:

headline: Grilled Cheese for Grownups
text: Every so often even I am too busy or tired – or both – to cook. But I’m also too busy or tired to go out. This usually happens when I’ve been cooking all day, as I’ve been doing a lot lately because I’m not only testing recipes for this column but also preparing food for book-tour cooking demonstrations.

headline: When a Young Spouse Becomes the Caregiver
text: For Ivonne Thompson, 36, pulling her husband from his wheelchair to bathe him is a way to find time for their marriage. “It is the only intimacy we have left,” she says.

headline: Image of the Day: May 30
text: Prayers were offered at the Hazratbal shrine in Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir, on the occasion of a Muslim festival.

headline: Sky-High Demand for Luxury
text: Up, up and up. That is the answer to the question I have been posing lately: Where is the luxury condominium market headed?

headline: Douglas Adams Biography to Include Unseen ‘Hitchhiker’s Guide’ Material
text: There are very few things that Douglas Adams did not touch on in his “Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Galaxy” novels, a peculiar blend of science fiction and comedy that began life as a BBC radio series and later had life on television and film as well. Apart from disquisitions on the destruction of Earth, as well as its creation (with special attention to fjords), space travel, alien life forms, depressive robots, celestial bureaucracy, animals that beg you to slice off and eat bits of them, the crucial role of mice and the universe’s loudest rock band, the book asks and answers (well, kind of) the Big Question: What is the meaning of “life, the universe and everything?”

headline: Gallery | Dzine Offers an Artistic History of Boxing, From the Greeks to Pay-Per-View
text: The artist Carlos Rolón, better known as Dzine, has long been a boxing fan, if not a practitioner. “My father took me for boxing lessons when I was 13,” he says. “I was more scared then excited. I developed a hernia.” The injury didn’t dampen his passion, which has led him to produce “Boxed: A Visual History and the Art of Boxing,” an image-driven compendium of the sport, from the Grecian Olympiads to bare-knuckle fighting to today’s megabucks stadium battles.

headline: NYT Now: Shinseki Resigns As V.A. Chief
text: President Obama announced Eric Shinseki, the Department of Veteran Affairs secretary, has resigned amid a scandal.

headline: Why Couldn’t My Kids Clean the Kitchen? They Didn’t Have To.
text: I thought we would be there by now.

headline: In Slightly Less Wealthy Circles, Too, Interest Rises in Private Equity
text: AS a young lawyer in New York, Robert Rich sometimes bought stocks based on tips he received while playing squash at the Yale Club. Most of them did not do well, so eventually he chose to put his money into mutual funds and focus on his work.

headline: Phil Jackson Gives Knicks’ Carmelo Anthony a Plan C
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — With the embers still smoldering from his failed pursuit of Steve Kerr, Phil Jackson has managed to remain in the hunt for another elusive target: Carmelo Anthony.

headline: The Evolving World of Gay Travel
text: In the 1970s gay tours took men rafting in the Grand Canyon and to Rio de Janeiro for Carnival. Gay hotels began opening in Key West, Fla. And destinations like Provincetown, Mass., were creating some of the first marketing to gay and lesbian travelers.

headline: For Gay Destinations, Thinking Outside the Obvious
text: Despite the fact that a sea gull once pooped on me while I was relaxing on a Fire Island beach, I do understand the allure of the place, and that of other idyllic destinations like Provincetown, Mass., and Key West, Fla., which have long been known as gathering spots for gay and lesbian vacationers. Many who identify anywhere along the L.G.B.T. spectrum simply want to go somewhere that is packed with kindred spirits, to relax without having to worry about fitting in with a straight crowd — or, in some places, about the potential perils involved when you don’t fit in. But of course a lot of people who enjoy travel, regardless of sexual orientation or gender identity, want to continuously add new cities to their “places I’ve been” list, so I asked a few gay travel experts to suggest a lesser-known or up-and-coming L.G.B.T. hot spot that we may overlook when making travel plans. Here are some of their suggestions.

headline: Finding Comfort and Safety as a Gay Traveler
text: Nearly every same-sex couple has experienced that awkward moment on vacation. It usually comes at hotel check-in, when you find yourself on the receiving end of a quizzical or disapproving look as you explain that yes, you did intend to book just one bed for you and your “friend.”

headline: Maya Angelou Exhibition Opens at Schomburg Center
text: The New York Public Library is celebrating the life and work of the poet Maya Angelou, who died on Wednesday at age 86, in a free exhibition, “Phenomenal Woman,” at the library’s Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture in Harlem.

headline: Celebrating Gay Pride All Over the Map
text: Ten years ago, my gay friends and I found the perfect spot for watching New York’s gay pride parade. It was near the entrance of a building near Fifth Avenue and 10th Street, with an awning to keep out the sun and a doorman who laughed along with our catcalls to bouncy go-go boys.

headline: V.A.’s Acting Chief: West Point Graduate and Ex-Leader of U.S.O.
text: WASHINGTON — The man who is temporarily replacing Eric Shinseki as secretary of veterans affairs is a West Point graduate, a onetime banker and a former chief executive of the United Service Organizations (known to most Americans as the U.S.O.) who joined the Department of Veterans Affairs just three months ago.

headline: Books to Blankets: Travel Tips for Parents
text: Traveling on a plane with 1-year-old twins would be nerve-racking for any parent. But it was all the more so for Lucas Grindley, the editorial director of Here Media, before he and his husband took their daughters on their first flight. A crying baby is not just a crying baby for a gay parent like him, he said; he feared it would be seen as a commentary on his ability to be a parent.

headline: In Rwanda, Looking to Art to Soothe
text: “There’s no way you’ll find it yourself,” the artist Strong Karakire told me on the phone, when I asked for directions to his studio in Nyamirambo, a lively neighborhood in the Rwandan capital of Kigali where dirt roads climb the steep hills past modest dwellings. “Just wait at the petrol station, and I’ll come get you.”

headline: The Rock Hall’s Class of 2014, Or: The Revenge of Kiss
text: Jon Pareles and Ben Ratliff discuss this year’s inductees and the challenges of creating a rock canon.

headline: Rethinking the Traditional Retirement Community
text: WHEN Rikki Selby began shopping for a retirement home, the 66-year-old sought a community where she could make friends with people her own age. But Ms. Selby had no interest in the kind of sprawling Sun Belt development that offers thousands of houses to older people. “In those places, everybody is old, and you don’t see young faces in the supermarket,” said Ms. Selby, who recently retired as a financial planner.

headline: What the Beats Deal Says About Apple: It Loves Tastemakers
text: There’s one thing executives at Apple would like you to know about their decision to buy Beats Music: Apple really loves humans. It loves us in the general sense — the company believes we’re better than computers at deciding what kinds of music we like — and it loves the specific humans who run Beats, especially the company’s founders, the music impresarios Dr. Dre and Jimmy Iovine.

headline: Artifacts and History, Steeped in Brine
text: The white paint is peeling and the cement steps are chipped at the old public school that houses the City Island Nautical Museum. Inside it’s shipshape. Four Barbaras and a Jane are among the can-do volunteers who maintain the collection of deftly crafted tenders and canoes, photos of sea captains and yachtsmen, models of minesweepers and tools for sail-making and boatbuilding.

headline: Dandelion: A Tenacious Beauty
text: The common dandelion is a reproductive superstar. Though it is hard to remain objective about a plant so familiar as a pesky weed, the little yellow flowers dotting lawns, parks, neglected window boxes or just about any place left unmown for a week have a certain untamed beauty.

headline: Drug Saves Fertility for Women With Cancer
text: CHICAGO — A commonly used drug can help young women with breast cancer retain the ability to have babies, apparently protecting their ovaries from the damage caused by chemotherapy, researchers reported here on Friday.

headline: Journalist-Turned-Spokesman Resigns as Daily Voice of the White House
text: WASHINGTON — Jay Carney, the journalist-turned-press-aide who jousted daily with his former colleagues over issues from the Benghazi terrorist attack to the glitch-ridden health care website, stepped down as the White House press secretary on Friday.

headline: Japan Offers Support to Nations in Disputes With China
text: TOKYO — Saying that his nation will play a larger role in regional security, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan said on Friday that his government would support Vietnam and other nations that have territorial disputes with China by providing patrol ships, training and military surveillance equipment.

headline: Rajat Gupta Loses Bid to Avoid Prison During Appeal
text: Rajat K. Gupta, a former director at the Goldman Sachs Group who was convicted on insider trading charges, has lost a last-minute attempt to stay out of prison.

headline: Taking a Spin: Follow the Map to the Senate
text: The Democrats have many challenges this November, not the least of which are low voter turnout and President Obama’s mediocre approval ratings. But their biggest challenge, by far, is the map.

headline: Love in Its Own Sweet Time
text: Colin David Sutton is just about as connected as one can get. He is the vice president for client strategy at the social media agency SocialCode, and a marketing marvel who can sell just about anything on whatever technological device is nearest him.

headline: Politically, V.A. Scandal Cuts Both Ways
text: WASHINGTON — Eric Shinseki’s resignation as head of the Department of Veterans Affairs was perhaps more welcome in the offices of worried congressional Democrats than in the suites of top Republicans who had pressed the scandal against President Obama.

headline: Where Fresh Is in the Name
text: People once complained that there were no good seafood restaurants in Fairfield County. Not only has that changed, but with the arrival three months ago of F.I.S.H. Restaurant & Bar in downtown Stamford (where the restaurant Boca used to be), there’s also a really good place that specializes in sparklingly fresh fish and shellfish.

headline: What Shinseki Leaves Behind
text: White House Correspondent Michael D. Shear on the challenges awaiting Eric Shinseki’s successor at the Department of Veteran’s Affairs.

headline: Asparagus Soup With Ricotta Crostini
text: Melissa Clark makes a light asparagus soup topped with tender asparagus tips, accompanied by toasted bread coated with creamy ricotta for dipping.

headline: Times Minute | What Shinseki Leaves
text: In the Video

headline: ‘Wimpy Kid’ Author to Open Bookstore in Hometown
text: Jeff Kinney, author of the best-selling children’s series “Diary of a Wimpy Kid,” said Friday morning that he is opening a bookstore in his home town of Plainville, Mass.

headline: Rock Relics With a Signature Swagger
text: After a recent dinner at a restaurant in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, Andrew Savage, the 28-year-old guitarist and vocalist of Parquet Courts, reached into his pocket to check his text messages. The device he pulled out, a beat-up old clamshell model, seemed a pointed rejection of modernity, even among nonconformist New Yorkers.

headline: A Pair of Dreams to Compare and Savor
text: This month, the two most poetic and endlessly rewatchable Shakespeare ballets are to be performed on two sides of Lincoln Center: George Balanchine’s two-act “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” (1962) from New York City Ballet at the David H. Koch Theater (opening on Tuesday) and Frederick Ashton’s one-act “The Dream” (1964) from American Ballet Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House (starting June 30). You might suppose this is to commemorate the 450th anniversary of Shakespeare’s birth this year, but no. The same juxtaposition happened in 2010 and 2012. It’s just the happiest symptom of Lincoln Center’s Ballet Madness each spring, whereby America’s two leading companies play on different sides of the same plaza.

headline: Tips for Those Who Set Their Own Salaries
text: TAYLOR JOHNSON works as a graphic designer, Mary-Kay Demetriou as a marketing consultant and Debra Kling as a color consultant. And they all work as negotiators.

headline: A Spoonful of Spring Asparagus, Green as Can Be
text: In my frenzy to eat enough asparagus every spring, I inevitably take the speedy route to dinner: steaming, sautéing, broiling, roasting. The aim is to get the stalks from raw to cooked as quickly as possible so I can gobble them up.

headline: All Paths Lead to Illumination
text: A young woman hangs sheer white linens on a clothesline. A refulgent angel descends from the heavens while shepherds tend their flocks by night. And an early motion-picture camera captures the fairyland allure of a world’s fair, slowly panning its illuminated buildings.

headline: Popcast: The Rock Hall’s New Class and the Revenge of Kiss
text: The 29th annual induction ceremony for the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame happened at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn mid-April; Jon Pareles was there to report on it for The Times, and the filmed version of the evening will be broadcast on HBO this weekend. The new class includes Nirvana, Peter Gabriel, Cat Stevens (now Yusuf Islam), Kiss, the E Street Band, Linda Ronstadt and Hall and Oates.

headline: On Our Walls
text: The walls of The New York Times headquarters on Eighth Avenue are decorated with news images from the past. Prints by photojournalists hang throughout the building. In this Insider series, On Our Walls, we’ll take you inside the building to see the photographs — many of them rich in history — and the stories behind them.

headline: Dolan Spraying Champagne? It Could Happen With the Rangers
text: In the 17 years since Cablevision took over at Madison Square Garden, James L. Dolan has been an owner without a championship, with no photo of him giddily holding aloft a gleaming trophy.

headline: Big Ticket | A Duplex Above the Park for $48 Million
text: A duplex penthouse perched near the pinnacle of the coveted park-side “House” portion of 15 Central Park West, the twin-towered limestone condominium where resale residences are appreciating in value much like vintage wine, sold for $48 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: After the Guests Have Left
text: Love, romance, infidelity and commitment are only some of the themes that propel “112 Weddings,” an HBO documentary in which 10 couples are asked what they expected of marriage and how they thought their partnerships turned out.

headline: Just Like Taco Trucks, Art Takes to the Road
text: On a recent Saturday, Elise Graham and her 23-year-old son, Aaron, pulled a 12-foot van into a parking spot on West 14th Street in Greenwich Village, swung open the back doors, lowered the aluminum stairs, and welcomed visitors inside their mobile Rodi Gallery.

headline: Rio Violence Spikes Ahead of World Cup
text: In the months before the World Cup, violence in Rio has spiked despite pacification tactics that have drawn criticism from some who live in the favelas.

headline: Rio Grapples With Violence Against Police Officers as World Cup Nears
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Alda Rafael Castilho dreamed of being a psychologist, and joined the police force to pay for her studies. Her dream ended at age 27 when gunmen stormed the outpost where she was on duty in Complexo do Alemão, a sprawling patchwork of slums. A bullet pierced her abdomen, and she bled to death.

headline: In a Surprise Move, Valeant Again Raises Its Bid for a Rival, Allergan
text: Updated, 7:45 p.m. | As a rule, deal makers try not to bid against themselves. But Valeant Pharmaceuticals, exasperated in its pursuit of fellow drug maker Allergan, showed little hesitation in doing just that.

headline: Fine Legal Point Poses Challenge to Appraisal Rights
text: The hedge fund Merion Capital might have hit a roadblock in its multimillion-dollar appraisal proceedings involving the $1.6 billion buyout of Ancestry.com. And it’s a roadblock that just might slow the trend toward exercising appraisal rights.

headline: A Historic Ship Sets Sail From the Mystic Seaport
text: Connecticut’s Mystic Seaport is showing off maritime history – and making it – this summer.

headline: Kim Kardashian’s Wedding Dress, Cara Delevingne’s Bunny Caper and Alexander Wang’s Fro-Yo
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Six Short Blocks With a Lot to Say
text: What do Sid Vicious, Bella Abzug, Auntie Mame, John and Yoko, and the widow of the mysteriously disappeared Judge Crater have in common?

headline: Comics
text: Jaime Hernandez’s “Love Bunglers,” Jesse Jacobs’s “Safari Honeymoon” and more.

headline: Visuals
text: New books that have something to do with portraiture or self-portraiture include a collection of drawings by Kurt Vonnegut.

headline: Not Yet a Star, Taylor Townsend Flashes Star Power
text: PARIS — You may or may not subscribe to Andy Murray’s theory that the American teenager Taylor Townsend is heading for finer tennis moments.

headline: Clinton Takes Responsibility for Benghazi
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton, in her soon-to-be-published memoir, takes responsibility for the 2012 attack on the American diplomatic mission in Benghazi, Libya, while pushing back against accusations that she tried to hinder a Republican-led investigation into the deadly assault.

headline: A Summit Without Russia Needs a Drink to Match
text: The G7 summit that will start next Wednesday in Brussels was supposed to be a G8 summit and was supposed to be held in Sochi, Russia. So this week’s Upshot With a Twist replaces the Moscow Mule with a more characteristically Belgian cocktail for the relocated and reduced meeting.

headline: Keeping Windows 8.1 Up to Date
text: Q. Is it true that the big Windows 8.1 update that came out this spring is now required in order to get future security updates for my PC?

headline: Classic Cars Head to Greenwich
text: The town of Greenwich, Conn., seems proud that its annual Town Party has drawn some top talent during the four years it’s been held in Roger Sherman Baldwin Park, which overlooks the harbor. Paul Simon and James Taylor have performed in the past; last Saturday, it was Carlos Santana.

headline: Scenes From the Dismal Inertia on Immigration
text: This week, implacable forces kept rolling on, and others, frozen in place, refused to budge:

headline: Administration Lays Out Ways Groups Can Support Program for Minority Men
text: The Obama administration announced recommendations on Friday on how public and private entities can participate in a White House initiative meant to support minority men and boys, including a move to focus on summer jobs and recruit adults who can serve as mentors.

headline: The Gun Report: May 30, 2014
text: Recent shootings involving children have rocked two American cities.

headline: Sterling to Reap 15,900 Percent Return on Sale of Clippers
text: Whether he likes it or not, Donald Sterling is poised to sell the Los Angeles Clippers to Steve Ballmer, the former Microsoft chief executive. And, for $2 billion, what’s not to like about it? Sterling bought the Clippers for $12.5 million in June 1981, according to some reports, and he’ll get a tidy 15,900 percent return over 33 years, an annualized rate of 16.6 percent. In fact, he’s probably done even better than that, because of the distributions of profits during the years of ownership.

headline: Weekend Reading: Finding the Best Way to Spend $2 Billion
text: How should billionaires spend their money? While the short answer is “any way they want,” the debate over inequality often focuses on the financial habits of the 1 percent — whether it be conspicuous consumption or charity.

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Driven | 2015 Volvo V60 T5 Drive-E
text: Volvo returns to its wagon roots with style. This time, there’s no looking backward.

headline: A Strip Club in Manhattan Proves That Vice Is Hard to Kill
text: After night falls in the theater district, a burly bouncer takes his post in front of an unmarked red door, revealing nothing about the secret attraction that lurks behind him.

headline: Many Shades of Sorcery
text: Jen Rosenblit’s “a Natural dance”  induces a kind of morning-after haziness, its images revisiting you in the hours after you’ve seen it like scenes from a fitful dream. None of it quite makes sense: Why is Justin Cabrillos wearing that “Where’s Waldo” costume? What are Effie Bowen and Addys Gonzalez doing with all of those microphones? What is the meaning of this monologue about colors?

headline: Big Mac, Thin Wallet
text: IN recent years we have seen plenty of studies of the impact of fast food on our bodies. But what about our psychological health?

headline: Smooth Hip-Hop, Sneering Punk and Muscular Folk
text: Iamsu!

headline: Pulled in Two Directions
text: Ukraine is conspicuously absent from the Eurasian Economic Union, the eastern counterpart of the European Union formed this week by President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and his counterparts from Belarus and Kazakhstan.

headline: Keep Handguns Away From Teenagers
text: In response to the Isla Vista rampage, legislators in California are introducing a bill that would let the police and private individuals ask a court for a restraining order to deny guns to those who pose a threat to themselves or others.

headline: Works of Dvorak, via Budapest
text: Some of the finest performances in New York in recent years — from creative concert stagings of Mozart operas to Beethoven symphonies — have arrived courtesy of the vibrantly theatrical Hungarian conductor Ivan Fischer and his powerful Budapest Festival Orchestra. On the heels of a recent Dvorak-filled concert with James Levine and the Met Orchestra, Mr. Fischer offers two more immersions in that Czech composer, both at Avery Fisher Hall.

headline: Going, Going, Gone to Sleep
text: I’m glad that another baseball season is once again blooming — gathering meaning and texture now as spring deepens — for all of the usual reasons: the crack of the bat, the smack of ball into leather and the heartening prospect of the unpredictable ramble from the optimism of spring, through the grueling summer, to the iron-hard realities of autumn.

headline: Music Makers Invade an Island
text: Three years ago, at the inaugural Governors Ball Music Festival, the Atlanta rapper Big Boi played a set peppered with tunes by his former group, Outkast. He’ll be back this year as part of a sprawling and well-monetized Outkast reunion tour.

headline: 50 Cent Makes TV His Turf
text: A former crack dealer turned rapper who survived a shooting, a stabbing and run-ins with the law, Curtis Jackson — a.k.a. 50 Cent — might very well have inspired the leading character in “Power,” the Starz series of which he is an executive producer.

headline: Small Comfort to a Young Queen
text: In 16th-century Europe, smaller was considered better — more beautiful, more precious — when it came to hand-illustrated books. A high value indeed must have been attached to a 2 ¾-by-2-inch prayer book created around 1517 for Claude de France, the first wife of the King François I. The book, made on commission from a young queen at her coronation by an artist now anonymous, is the centerpiece of “Miracles in Miniature: The Art of the Master of Claude de France” at the Morgan Library & Museum.

headline: ‘Subtle’ Inspiration
text: Al-Latif is one of the many names of Allah; it means “the Subtle One.” That inspired the title of a new work by the choreographer Ronald K. Brown that is receiving its world premiere in the first of two Brown programs that are running Tuesday through June 8 at the Joyce Theater.

headline: The Longtime Lure of Shiny Objects
text: Jewel thieves come in many varieties. Smash-and-grab thugs. The type of dapper gents favored by makers of heist films. But Doris Payne may be in a class by herself. She is a real-life thief, not a Hollywood creation, though Hollywood is interested in making a drama based on her life. For now, though, there’s the documentary “The Life and Crimes of Doris Payne,” playing through June 10 at Film Forum.

headline: A Private Equity Perennial That May Flourish
text: Henry Kravis, a co-founder of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, is cultivating private equity perennials. Buyout shops like his are selling companies to each other at a breakneck pace. It’s easy to be skeptical about these so-called secondaries. But K.K.R.’s $1.6 billion acquisition of the landscaping company Brickman Group may turn out to be an example of how such deals can flourish.

headline: Sisters Strumming in the Darkness
text: It’s just another modern-day discovery story: two Swedish sisters, harmonizing since childhood in perfect twangy English, introduced to the rest of the world via YouTube thanks to their covers of indie ballads and Johnny Cash classics. Klara and Johanna Soderberg were 15 and 17 when that happened, in 2008, and since then, they have toured the globe with their own spare guitar-driven songs, impressing the likes of Jack White (who produced a single for them) and Conor Oberst (who included them on his latest album). The sisters, now 21 and 23, record as First Aid Kit; their third album, “Stay Gold,” a major-label debut that adds the Omaha Symphony Orchestra to their lovelorn country-folk, will be released June 10 on Columbia Records, with a sold-out show on June 11 at Webster Hall.

headline: New Refugee Camp in Jordan Tries to Create a Community for Syrians
text: AL AZRAQ REFUGEE CAMP, Jordan — His face was bright red from the desert sun, and his son’s eyes, blank with exhaustion, gazed into the distance. Bahjat Sheikh, 58, and his family had crossed the Jordanian border to safety after an arduous two-and-a-half-day journey, mostly on foot, from the central Syrian city of Hama.

headline: Pan-Roasted Duck Shows Off a Cherry-Sweet Side
text: Classic French duck recipes, the kind Julia Child swooned for, are now considered old-fashioned, bringing to mind starched white napery and middle-aged waiters in black vests carving tableside.

headline: Print Matters | An Erudite, Fashion-Forward Magazine About Black Gay Culture
text: In 2009, Khary Septh, Kyle Banks and André Verdun Jones founded the Brooklyn creative agency Pink Rooster Studio. But as they made work for clients such as Swarovski and L’Oréal, they also found themselves longing for a project with which they could express the full flower of talent and ideas among gay black men from all cultural walks of life — fashion, art, performance, letters and politics. “We wanted to see what the image of ourselves would look like if we controlled it,” says Septh.

headline: A Preview of Volvo’s Heart-Healthy Future
text: Like a New York City mayor tilting at supersized sodas, several automakers have tried to forcibly wean Americans off their big, bad-for-you V8s. Six-cylinder engines are also being downsized in favor of 4s.

headline: A Swede That’s Not Square to Be Hip
text: Say “Volvo,” and what image springs to mind? A station wagon, right? And not just any wagon, but one as square and imperishable as a Saltine, and as much a staple of the suburbs.

headline: Reviving the Coming-of-Age Movie
text: LOS ANGELES — Confident yet vulnerable, adorable yet wearing an unfortunate trench coat, John Cusack hoisted a boombox over his head in “Say Anything” and, as Peter Gabriel’s “In Your Eyes” reverberated through the trees, delivered a scene that defined a genre: the great 1980s-era coming-of-age movie.

headline: 2015 Volvo V60
text: Volvo’s well-rounded V60 wagon returns for 2015 with a downsized engine and class-leading economy.

headline: Parents on the Rebound and Looking for Love
text: It’s as if someone threw down a challenge to cable outlets of a certain ilk: “Interpret the theme ‘Suddenly Without a Spouse’ in a made-for-television movie.” Lifetime, the Hallmark Movie Channel and Up all unveil films this weekend that seem as if they were responding. One is trashy and stupid. One is weepy and harmless. And one is uplifting and rather good for its type.

headline: Reading Genesis, the Jazz Piano Edition
text: And Scott Joplin begat Jelly Roll Morton, who begat James P. Johnson, who begat Fats Waller, who begat Earl Hines, and on and on. That is a rough sketch of the jazz piano genealogy described by the pianist Jon Weber in his fascinating and essential show “From Joplin to Jarrett: 115 Years of Piano Jazz,” at the Metropolitan Room on Thursday evening.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Pack Mentality
text: The black leather biker’s jacket is hellbent to conquer fashion.

headline: New York Public Library Temporarily Closes Reading Room
text: The New York Public Library’s majestic Rose Main Reading Room, which is nearly two city blocks long and has hosted scholars, students and authors for more than a century, has temporarily been closed after a piece of plaster fell from the ceiling this week.

headline: A Bridge Deal From the Goldman Pairs
text: At the Eastern States Regional, which was held last week in New York City, the winners of the main pair event on the first day, May 21, were Alison Wilson and Chris Willenken. They finished just over two boards ahead of Tori Dauphinot and Judi Radin, with Paul Bethe and David Moss third. (All are of New York City).

headline: Jay Carney Resigns as Press Secretary
text: President Obama announced the White House press secretary, Jay Carney, was leaving his post, in a surprise appearance in the press briefing room on Friday.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Pack Mentality
text: The black leather biker’s jacket is hellbent to conquer fashion. It has already achieved major status for daytime. And this spring, it has zoomed into the evening, topping long dresses, delicate prints and lace. One woman wore one over her long gown. Another woman, above, had a printed jacket that matched her dress.

headline: A Pianist Stands Out as a Leader by Fitting in With the Group
text: The pianist Jacob Sacks is what you might call an inner-workings musician, drawn to the subtler, deeper mechanics of harmony and form. Over the last dozen years, this has made him a superb ensemble player in the expressionist wing of modern jazz, someone who raises the bar for group cohesion without drawing much attention to himself.

headline: Evening Hours | Generations in Harmony
text: Parent and child, young and not-so-young.

headline: Why You Hate Work
text: Editors’ note: We hope you’re not totally miserable at the office tomorrow, but if you are, here’s one article from the archives that may explain why.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: Week in Pictures for May 30
text: A slide show of photographs of the past week in New York City and the region includes Memorial Day celebrations across the city, wind turbines on a Queens rooftop, and sand dunes on Fire Island.

headline: A Cop? No, He Just Played One in Life
text: LOS ANGELES — As if grasping at wisps of a long-forgotten high, Luke Greenfield was trying to remember the first time he did it. Impersonate a police officer, that is.

headline: Help Isn’t What It Used to Be
text: The minions have dwindled. The choreographer Bill T. Jones said: “Mick Jagger tells a story about going to visit James Brown in his dressing room once. James Brown had a valet. He would keep the valet standing next to him, holding Brown’s trousers and waiting to dress him, while Brown held a meeting. It was a show of power.”

headline: A Rom-Com Path Less Traveled
text: The film “Obvious Child” has a curious tag attached to its own marketing materials: “abortion comedy.”

headline: An Art Tour of Salzburg in Sound
text: New music is thankfully a preoccupation of the New York Philharmonic under Alan Gilbert, but glamour isn’t always part of the equation. The orchestra’s new-music series, Contact!, has spent most of its time in no-frills, functional halls like the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium; the basement space SubCulture; and Symphony Space, as oppressively shoeboxy as the much-maligned Avery Fisher Hall.

headline: After Fighting Insider Trading Charges for 10 Years, a Fund Manager Is Cleared
text: Updated, 7:49 p.m. | Standing outside a Manhattan federal court on Friday, Nelson Obus put on his victory tie.

headline: The Desert in Demand
text: It was Dinah Shore Weekend in Palm Springs — or the Dinah, as it’s known — five days of Sapphic revelry that every April draws some 15,000 women from around the country to this sun-washed city 90 miles southeast of Los Angeles. On Saturday evening, however, the hottest ticket in town may not have been the L Word Pool Party, but a relatively low-key cocktail reception hosted by the Palm Springs Art Museum to benefit its new Architecture and Design Center.

headline: Introducing | Brooke Candy, Pop’s Next Superstar
text: To many citizens of the Internet, the rise of Brooke Candy, 24, will sound familiar. A former stripper, Candy’s image proliferated through likes and retweets when a 2012 music video she appeared in — Grimes’s “Genesis” — went viral. A sword-wielding Barbarella for the Tumblr generation, Candy, clad in cyberpunk princess body armor and neon pink braids — then her trademark look — postured and snarled with primal confidence. The mysterious Candy then revealed her true self several months later, when she uploaded the video to “Das Me,” an abrasive yet empowering hip-hop churner that introduced her as a brash, talented M.C.

headline: Movie Review: ‘A Million Ways…’
text: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews “A Million Ways to Die in the West.”

headline: Movie Review: ‘Maleficent’
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Maleficent.”

headline: Movie Review: ‘Night Moves’
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Night Moves.”

headline: Pictures of the Day: Washington and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Washington, South Sudan, Ukraine and India.

headline: Slides From Europe
text: Presentation (pdf) at ECB research conference in Sintra, Portugal.

headline: Friday Night Music: Sun King Edition
text: Indie rock and the palace at Versailles, which is the site of my current meeting, don’t seem to mix. I could do this:

headline: Chilean Miners Recruited to Inspire World Cup Squad
text: Even for a collection of unusually talented soccer stars, the task facing Chile’s national team at next month’s World Cup is daunting: playing the two finalists from the last tournament, Spain and the Netherlands.

headline: Hilaria Baldwin Holds Her Center
text: Even for a yogi, maintaining peace can be hard when you’re married to New York’s most popular enfant terrible.

headline: ‘Jesus Christ Superstar’ Tour Is Abruptly Canceled
text: A high-wattage and eclectically cast new North American touring production of “Jesus Christ Superstar” has been abruptly canceled, just over a week before what would have been its first performance.

headline: ‘Hard Luck Lloyd’
text: 1967: ‘I Blew a Wheel’

headline: ‘How to Be a Good Motorist’
text: I. Motoring

headline: In Print and Bound for the Road
text: If a picture is worth a thousand words, what about a book of pictures? Four of the seven books reviewed here are mostly photographs. Others include a history of the Cord 810 and 812, a biography of the racecar driver Lloyd Ruby and a quirky motorist’s handbook from 1923. The topics range widely, yet with luck, readers will find something of interest, for themselves or as a Father’s Day gift.

headline: Picture This
text: A selection of images from our latest round of automotive book reviews.

headline: For Jefferson Mays: After the Show, the Stairs Await
text: At 10 p.m. on Thursday, a couple of dozen people were waiting outside the Walter Kerr Theater in Midtown for Jefferson Mays, an old-fashioned theater type who is a nominee for a Tony Award as best actor in the musical “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love and Murder.”

headline: Malcolm Gladwell ‘Surprised’ to Become an Amazon Bargaining Chip
text: In the dispute between Amazon and Hachette, neither side is blinking.

headline: A Japanese Buzz in the Bronx
text: The Yankees have three prominent Japanese players, led by Masahiro Tanaka, who is creating a stir in his first year in the majors. As a result, a large Japanese media contingent is often present.

headline: Quantum Teleportation
text: Scientists reported that they were able to teleport quantum information reliably across a distance of about 10 feet.

headline: Higher Scores on Crash Avoidance
text: New test results suggest that automakers are quickly improving the safety systems intended to keep a distracted driver from rear-ending another vehicle or colliding with an object ahead. The tests of 24 models were released Thursday by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety.

headline: Mapping Apps Follow the Crowd
text: Think of it as the hive approach to car navigation systems: One driver, like a worker bee, finds the quickest way from Point A to Point B and then shares that route with all the other drivers. It’s the basic idea behind all crowdsourcing, the sharing of free user-generated content to create information like restaurant ratings and contractor recommendations.

headline: Unappreciated Love, the Russian Variety
text: Regret haunts the memories of men who’ve outgrown their brash younger selves, but oh, what pretty pictures torment makes. A glossy, mirrored wall as dark as anthracite looms over the action in the Vakhtangov State Academic Theater’s arrestingly beautiful “Eugene Onegin,” at City Center, and a cloud of white mist floats above the stage.

headline: Collected Wisdom From This Year’s Crop of Fashion-Industry Graduation Speakers
text: It’s that time of year again, when the world’s most successful people travel around the country to give university commencement speeches. This year, a handful of fashion-industry heavy-hitters joined in the tradition. From the shoe designer Christian Louboutin’s address to the student body at F.I.T. to the lecture given by Steven Kolb of the C.F.D.A. at Kendall College of Art and Design, the speeches of several design luminaries suggested that slow and steady, more often than not, wins the race. Here, some of their collected words of wisdom.

headline: In Way Over His Head
text: “The Twilight Zone” meets media critique meets psychological portraiture in James Scruggs’s “Deepest Man,” a thought-provoking experiment at the 3LD Art & Technology Center. Given that the show comes from 3-Legged Dog — a company known for integrating performance, video and effects — it is unsurprising that the piece, loaded with abstraction and supernatural traces, is a visual marvel.

headline: A Prime View of Sunset
text: Particularly dramatic and romantic at sunset, the view from the Half Moon restaurant’s many vantage points is inspiring. As one of my dining companions observed, there is something about sunset on water that makes one wax Hallmarky. The promenade deck is so close to the Hudson River that when the wind is up, guests might be refreshed by the spray from a crashing wave.

headline: Goodbye, Steinbeck; All Hail, Shelley
text: LONDON — When government shapes a nation’s literary education, politics inevitably plays a role. That has come clear in the case of the influential and controversial British minister of education, Michael Gove, who was accused of jingoism this week for new syllabus requirements that have led to the removal of classic American works like “To Kill a Mockingbird” and “The Crucible.”

headline: Blackbeard as a Geek: Plundering in High-Tech
text: There are absolutists who still believe that everything on the Internet should be free and see themselves as partisans, not parasites. Their motto might as well be “intellectual property is theft.”

headline: Beauty Is in the Eye of Your Fellow Swine
text: Before conducting the staged production of H K Gruber’s anarchic opera “Gloria — A Pig Tale” that opened at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Thursday night, the second event of the 11-day NY Phil Biennial, Alan Gilbert told the audience that he had thought a lot about what to say to prepare people for the wild piece they were about to hear. But, he explained, he had decided to say nothing, other than to warn audience members that this opera might not sound like anything else they had ever heard.

headline: Two New Books on Porsche and Muscle Cars
text: In this week’s Automobiles section, readers will find reviews of a selection of books that delve into topics including design, history, motor sports and vintage motoring advice. Choosing the books to be reviewed is always a hand-wringing task here, a pleasant chore of sorting through publishers’ offerings to provide a balance of interests and formats.

headline: After Losing Time Inc. Business, Distributor Is to Close
text: The second-largest magazine wholesaler in the country, Source Interlink Distribution, which employs about 6,000 workers, will soon cease operations.

headline: Lit Class Field Trip, Movie Star Edition
text: O.K., so one smart aleck asked James Franco to take off his shirt during the question-and-answer session that followed Wednesday’s matinee of “Of Mice and Men.” At that point, the audience at the Longacre Theater was full of teenagers, a lot of them girls, and they were in unusual proximity to a full-fledged movie star.

headline: Under Cover: Paolo Pellegrin on Photographing Srebrenica, 20 Years After the Genocide
text: The June 1 cover story by Scott Anderson about efforts to uncover mass graves in Srebrenica, Bosnia, is accompanied by a series of haunting photographs by Paolo Pellegrin, who has been documenting the process for the past three years. Some of his pictures capture the scale of the genocide; others examine in extreme close-up the people affected by the tragedy — the man searching for remains, the Dutch soldier with PTSD who can’t seem to leave Bosnia. Pellegrin recently shared with me what it was like photographing the annual Srebrenica memorial ceremony and burial of the dead.

headline: Boehner on Shinseki’s Resignation
text: The House speaker, John A. Boehner, addressed the resignation of the secretary of the Department of Veterans Affairs, Eric Shinseki, at a press conference Friday.

headline: Depression-Era Tunes and ‘Those Dancing Feet’
text: One of the songs in “42nd Street,” the popular 1980 musical based on a famous 1933 movie, asks, “What do you go for, Go see a show for?”

headline: In the Temple Dancer’s Story, 3 Important Russian Debuts
text: Three Russian artists made important first appearances on Wednesday and Thursday with American Ballet Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House. The vehicle was Natalia Makarova’s production of “La Bayadère,” which all three had already danced in their native land. Though none of them were new to New York, most people in the audience were watching them for the first time.

headline: Junta Sets Year’s Goals for Its Rule in Thailand
text: BANGKOK — Thailand’s military junta tightened its control on Friday with a far-reaching plan to appoint an interim government, write a new constitution and carry out large-scale public works projects. The junta also disclosed for the first time how long it intended to remain in charge — at least into the second half of 2015.

headline: Prison Program Turns Inmates Into Intellectuals
text: Otisville Correctional Facility is a medium-security state prison, 79 miles northwest of Manhattan, on the site of a former tuberculosis sanitarium — with an equalizing element of portent, near the town of Mount Hope. Many of its prisoners are serving life sentences; they are men whom time, as one guard put it “has mellowed out.” Nearby, but unrelated, is the Otisville federal prison, named by Forbes Magazine as one of America’s “cushiest” incarcerators. Observers have likened it to a college, which is not an analogy you would easily draw at the state prison, where inmates rely largely on encyclopedias for the retrieval of information, in volumes that look as if they were last current when the nation was debating the merits of Dan Quayle.

headline: Two Covers, One Choice
text: Pamela Paul is editor of the Book Review.

headline: Diet Issues: What Is the Path to Weight Loss?
text: To the Editor:

headline: New Jersey Reaches Deal on Hurricane Sandy Aid
text: New Jersey has agreed to spend more federal disaster money to provide housing to people displaced by Hurricane Sandy and to make sure that the hardest-hit parts of the state get a proportional share of the money, according to a settlement reached on Friday.

headline: Get to Know the CFDA Nominees
text: Here’s a tip sheet on the designers up for Council of Fashion Designers of America awards, which will be held on June 2.

headline: John Waters Brushes Up for the CFDA Spotlight
text: If John Waters, the famously dubbed Pope of Trash, does not strike every guest at Monday’s Council of Fashion Designers of America awards show as an entirely obvious choice of host, he has news for these doubters.

headline: A Tavern and a Tribute
text: When J. A. Heneghan’s Tavern opened in Point Lookout in September, I put off visiting it. I thought the restaurant would have the most appeal in warm weather, given its location on the same barrier island as Long Beach. I need not have waited; Heneghan’s is a place for all seasons.

headline: Walesa Among Ex-Leaders at Funeral of Political Enemy
text: WARSAW — With demonstrators chanting on the streets outside and the three surviving Polish presidents in attendance, perhaps the most polarizing figure in modern Polish history was honored on Friday at a funeral Mass in the Field Cathedral of the Polish Army.

headline: Latest Port Authority Roadblock Delays Legislation, Not Traffic
text: The lawmakers planned to gather where it was once, infamously, time for some traffic problems — a symbolic show of bistate unity to help repair a wounded agency.

headline: Medicare to Now Cover Sex-Change Surgery
text: Medicare may no longer exclude sex-reassignment surgery from coverage, a government appeals board ruled Friday. It said the current exclusion was “no longer reasonable” because the surgery is safe and effective and can no longer be considered experimental.

headline: Investor, Bettor, Golfer: Insider Trading Inquiry Includes Mickelson, Icahn and William T. Walters
text: The divergent lives of a championship golfer, a high-rolling gambler and a billionaire investor have collided in a federal insider trading investigation.

headline: De Blasio Remains Mum on Rabbi’s Remarks
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio can lay down a wondrous rhetorical two-step, although some days you wonder if he should just stop dancing and answer a delicate question straight on.

headline: Far From Greece, Yet Bringing Its Flavors Alive
text: Recreating Greek island cooking in New Jersey takes a bit of creativity and compromise. On the island of Karpathos, you would tenderize a freshly caught octopus by beating it about 50 times and rubbing it for about 15 minutes on the sea rocks, says Nikolas Mastrominas, the proprietor of Olive Restaurant. Here, he concedes, you must buy a good imported octopus and boil it — but not for long. If it gets too soft, it will lose its flavor.

headline: Conviction in Terrorism Case in Canada
text: A jury on Friday convicted a former security guard from Toronto of attempting to join a foreign terrorist organization, a first for Canada. Prosecutors and the police said that the man, Mohamed Hassan Hersi, a Canadian born in Somalia, was heading to join the Somali extremist group Shabab when he was arrested at Toronto’s airport in 2011. Mr. Hersi, who was holding a one-way ticket to Cairo, has maintained that he was going overseas to study Arabic. Long before his arrest, Mr. Hersi had been the subject of an extensive police investigation after the company that employed Mr. Hersi as a guard found in one of his uniforms a USB memory stick that contained what were described as extremist materials. Mr. Hersi was also convicted of encouraging an undercover police officer to participate in terrorism.

headline: Scandal and Resignation at the V.A.
text: To the Editor:

headline: Mentally Ill at Rikers
These Cards, Though Rare, Are Not Ones for Collectors
text: With so many businesses moving toward paperless operation nowadays, it would seem to be only a matter of time before the world’s oldest profession followed suit.

headline: Taking Steps to Prevent Future Mass Killings
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bombing Thwarted, Israeli Military Says
text: Israeli troops on Friday detained a Palestinian man who was wearing a belt packed with explosives at a West Bank intersection that has been the site of previous attacks, Israeli military officials said.

headline: G.O.P. Senate Hopeful in Iowa Enlists a Familiar Face
text: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa — Nothing about Joni Ernst’s Senate campaign here has been conventional.

headline: Play Recalls a Broadway Star’s Eccentric Life and Grim End
text: The relationship between the actors Ed Dixon and George Rose was not a casual one.

headline: How Book Publishers Can Beat Amazon
text: AMAZON has caused no small controversy of late by refusing to accept presale orders on books to be released by the publisher Hachette and by understocking Hachette’s titles. These punitive maneuvers, which follow a dispute between Amazon and Hachette about e-book contracts, have led to significant delays in shipments of Hachette’s books to Amazon’s customers.

headline: With Sale Pending, N.B.A. Cancels Its Vote on Sterling
text: One day after the former Microsoft chief executive Steve Ballmer agreed to pay $2 billion for the Los Angeles Clippers, the N.B.A. on Friday said that it would not vote to take away the team from Donald Sterling, the owner of the team, who received a lifetime ban for making racist comments.

headline: Carney’s Quips
text: A compilation of the White House press secretary Jay Carney’s quips to “ridiculous” questions from reporters in the briefing room.

headline: How South Jersey Shaped Glass, and Vice Versa
text: There are those who come away from “NJ350: Through the Lens of Glass,” a new exhibition at the Museum of American Glass at Wheaton Arts and Cultural Center, wondering how they knew so little about New Jersey’s role in the history of glassmaking.

headline: Fed Debate Over Future Beyond End of Stimulus
text: STANFORD, Calif. — The combination of a persistently weak labor market and evidence of a little more inflation is prompting an increasingly vigorous debate among Federal Reserve officials about the future of the central bank’s stimulus campaign.

headline: Amid Moves on Shield Laws, Journalist Tells of a 2011 Subpoena Fight
text: WASHINGTON — A former Fox News journalist disclosed on Thursday that he had been subpoenaed in 2011 for notes and testimony identifying his confidential sources in a leak investigation, adding a new public chapter to the Obama administration’s crackdown on unauthorized disclosures.

headline: Around Seattle, Ballmer’s Other Title Is Superfan
text: SEATTLE — For a taste of the kind of team owner Steve Ballmer will be if his $2 billion offer for the Los Angeles Clippers is approved, it is worth considering his almost legendary status around youth sports games in his hometown.

headline: Dr. Melvin J. Glimcher, Prosthetics Innovator, Dies at 88
text: As a second-year student at Harvard Medical School, Melvin J. Glimcher was assigned to use textbooks to prepare a report on the mechanics of the foot. He quickly concluded that the textbooks were wrong, and his report said so.

headline: Lopsided Games Translate to a Tight Series Between Spurs and Thunder
text: SAN ANTONIO — The Western Conference finals have largely been what one may have expected from the teams with the two best records in the N.B.A. this season. The series between the San Antonio Spurs and the Oklahoma City Thunder has been rife with plot twists, mood swings and accusations of subterfuge.
