headline: In Spanish Riots, Anguish of Those Recovery Forgot
text: BARCELONA, Spain — Four nights of rioting here in Spain’s tourism capital have highlighted the country’s persistent social tensions and belied signs of relief from a fragile economic recovery, which has yet to alleviate rampant joblessness.

headline: Albany Pressed to Honor Coldblooded Flip-Flopper
text: Ostensibly, the goal was to teach students a lesson about democracy, a lesson that can sometimes seem lost on the New York State Legislature.

headline: Dealing With Boko Haram
text: It has been more than six weeks since nearly 300 schoolgirls were kidnapped by the Boko Haram extremist group in Nigeria. The militants have spent the last five years wreaking havoc and killing civilians — about 4,000 have died — in the northeastern section of the country. But it took a horrifying mass abduction to touch hearts around the world and persuade Nigeria — whose president, Goodluck Jonathan, initially rejected outside help — to join with other countries to try to find them.

headline: Bassoon Maker Is Leaving Lower East Side for Cheaper Rent in Maine
text: There are not many places to sit amid the jumble of metal tools, piles of maple and boxwood boards, and bassoons crowding — and even hanging from the ceiling of — Leslie Ross’s studio on the Lower East Side.

headline: Setback in Push to Exonerate Man Convicted in 1990 Manhattan Killing
text: Efforts to exonerate a man convicted in the murder of Brian Watkins, a killing that galvanized public outrage over violent crime in the early 1990s, were dealt a setback on Friday, as the Manhattan district attorney’s office indicated that its review of the case found “no credible newly discovered evidence.”

headline: U.S. Sway in Asia Is Imperiled as China Challenges Alliances
text: SINGAPORE — The Obama administration’s three-year-old plan to shift its foreign policy focus to Asia was supposed to shore up interests in a critical region, push new free trade pacts and re-establish United States influence as a balance to a growing China, after a decade of inattention.

headline: X-Men, Not All Fiction
text: The X-Men movies offer an allegory of 20th-century race hatred that features mutants with special powers as the despised minority and the military industrial complex as the principal instrument of persecution.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 30, 2014
Mr. Shinseki Takes the Fall
text: The resignation of Secretary Eric Shinseki from the Veterans Affairs Department was probably unavoidable, under the principle that a leader should accept full responsibility for a great scandal. But the department’s problem was not Mr. Shinseki. It has been broken for years. No one should expect his removal to be anything but the beginning of a much-needed process of change.

headline: Book Guiding Border Agents on Force Is Released
text: The top official at the federal border agency released on Friday for the first time the full text of its handbook on the use of force by border agents, as well as a 2013 report by an outside group that was sharply critical of the agency’s conduct in cases where agents’ force had resulted in deaths.

headline: Amazon’s ‘Bullying’ Tactics
text: A strong contender for quote of the month comes from Dennis Loy Johnson, of the small publishing firm Melville House. “How is this not extortion?” he said to David Streitfeld and Melissa Eddy of The Times, in a story published last week. “You know, that thing that is illegal when the Mafia does it.” He was referring to Amazon.

headline: In Southern Wisconsin, a Winner Takes All
text: WHITEWATER, Wis. — Lance Leipold, the football coach at the University of Wisconsin-Whitewater, thought briefly about buying a Powerball ticket this week but changed his mind.

headline: Excitement Mounts! Sort Of
text: We’ve learned so much this election season. True, almost nobody has noticed yet that there’s been voting. But trust me, the lessons are mounting.

headline: Nibelungenlied
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Wow, I held on to this one by John Lampkin by my very fingernails.

headline: Changing of the Guards in Front of the U.S. Goal
text: In just over two weeks, when the United States national team plays Ghana in its first World Cup match, the veteran goalkeeper Tim Howard will take his position behind four American defenders who will be among the least experienced in the tournament.

headline: Spiritual and Secular Mix in Case for Sainthood
text: WICHITA, Kan. — Several weeks before he was ordained as a Roman Catholic priest in 1940, Emil J. Kapaun sent a letter from seminary to family friends. With his holy vows imminent, he still sounded like a farmer’s son from a pinprick in the Kansas prairie called Pilsen, a 24-year-old persuaded mostly of his own inadequacy.

headline: Veterans’ Crisis Put Obama on the Defensive as Others Failed to Do
text: WASHINGTON — This time, President Obama did not wait. Confronted by reports of mismanagement and besieged by members of his own party, he gave in to the pressure and performed the sort of ritual Washington sacrifice he has resisted in other times of crisis over the last five years.

headline: Bird’s-Eye View
text: Two cyclists visiting the Little Red Lighthouse in Fort Washington Park along the Hudson River in Upper Manhattan on Friday.

headline: For a Replacement Shortstop, the Mets May Need to Look to the Mound
text: PHILADELPHIA — As he walked through the Mets’ clubhouse Friday, Tim Teufel paused and politely entertained a hypothetical situation. Imagine it was the 17th inning, he was told, and imagine the Mets were locked in a tight game and were suddenly out of shortstops. Would he be comfortable playing Jacob deGrom at shortstop?

headline: Confronting Who We Are
text: For the West, it was a week of self-searching.

headline: After Long Wait for Finals, Rangers Get a Rare Breather
text: Rarer than a Rangers berth in the Stanley Cup finals — they have been there only four times since 1950 — is the team’s having to wait for its opponent.

headline: Few Top Players Can Say Tennis Is Family Business
text: PARIS — Back into the second week for the first time in 24 Grand Slam events, Ernests Gulbis was asked Friday if his feats might one day be equaled by two younger racket-wielders in his family, his sisters Laura Gulbe, 19, and Monika Kavace, 15.

headline: On Death Row With Low I.Q., and New Hope for a Reprieve
text: MIAMI — For Ted Herring, who has spent 32 years on Florida’s death row for murdering a store clerk, signs of intellectual disability arose early and piled up quickly: He repeated first grade and got D’s and F’s through fourth grade. He read like a fourth grader at 14 and did not know that summer followed spring.

headline: Pushing to Change the Triple Crown’s Grueling Schedule
text: Even as excitement builds around California Chrome’s bid to become the 12th Triple Crown winner and the first in 36 years, there may be growing momentum to radically alter the grueling three-races-in-five-weeks format that helps make the feat so rare.

headline: Iran Hackers Dangle a Familiar Name to Fish for Data
text: WASHINGTON — Over the years, John R. Bolton has played many roles in Washington. He was American ambassador to the United Nations, where he famously suggested the place could lose many of its floors — and the bureaucrats who worked on them. He was the State Department’s combative counterproliferation chief during George W. Bush’s first term, and these days he regularly appears on Fox News to denounce the Obama administration as weak and feckless.

headline: Yankees Are Healing, but Not Enough to Overcome Twins
text: When the Yankees were last seen in the Bronx two weeks ago, they led the American League East, albeit by the slimmest of margins — a half-game lead over the Baltimore Orioles and a one-game lead over the Toronto Blue Jays.

headline: U.S. and Arizona Yield on Immigration
text: PHOENIX — The Obama administration has moved to drop its legal fight against what is arguably the most controversial provision of Arizona’s sweeping immigration law, the so-called show-me-your-papers provision permitting police officers to pull over people based on the suspicion that they are in the country illegally.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, May 31, 2014
text: “If these are kids in the schoolyard, they are running around with scissors.”

headline: Access Audit of Veterans Affairs Medical Centers and Clinics
text: This report covers the first phase of a systemwide audit of scheduling and other practices at Veterans Affairs medical centers and outpatient facilities. Many of the 216 sites reviewed were “flagged for further review.”

headline: Heat Calmly Thrash Pacers and Book Annual Trip to the Finals
text: MIAMI — What had long felt like a sure thing was accomplished here Friday with just about as little tension as possible.

headline: What’s on Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (NBC) MARIAH CAREY: AT HOME IN CONCERT WITH MATT LAUER Ms. Carey opens the door to her Bel Air home overlooking the Hollywood Hills to speak with Mr. Lauer about her childhood, and family life with her husband, Nick Cannon, and their twins, Moroccan and Monroe, and perform songs from her new album, “Me. I Am Mariah ... The Elusive Chanteuse.”

headline: Costly Error Leads to the End of the Mets’ Frustrating Night
text: PHILADELPHIA — Rafael Montero turned and watched helplessly in the fourth inning Friday as the ball Domonic Brown had just crushed sailed over the right-field wall. This was a teaching moment, a reminder that Montero still had a way to go. It was his first major league start on the road, and there would be more moments like this to come.

headline: Baptist Missionary Sentenced to Life in Hard Labor by North Korea
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea said on Saturday that it had sentenced a South Korean Baptist missionary to a labor camp for life for allegedly trying to build underground churches in the country, where the government considers such religious activities an attempt to sabotage its rule.

headline: Corrections: May 31, 2014
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: That Old-Time Inequality Denial
text: Brad DeLong links to the now extensive list of pieces debunking the FT’s attempted debunking of Thomas Piketty, and pronounces himself puzzled:

headline: Analytics: Making the Grade
text: The following Analytics appears on the letters page in the June 1 issue of the magazine.

headline: Financial Hazards of a Fugitive Life
text: “Capital in the Twenty-First Century,” Thomas Piketty’s new book, has received a great deal of attention. But we shouldn’t neglect another important new book on income inequality, from a much different perspective. Titled “On the Run: Fugitive Life in an American City,” and written by Alice Goffman, a sociologist at the University of Wisconsin, Madison, it offers a fascinating and disturbing portrait of the economic constraints and incentives faced by a large subset of Americans: those who are hiding from the law.

headline: Quantifying Privacy: A Week of Location Data May Be an ‘Unreasonable Search’
text: When does the simple digital tracking of your location and movements — the GPS bleeps from most of our smartphones — start to be truly revealing? When do the data points and inferences that can be drawn from it strongly suggest, say, trips to a psychiatrist, a mosque, an abortion clinic, a strip club or an AIDS treatment center?

headline: China Accuses U.S. and Japan of Incitement
text: SINGAPORE — China struck back harshly at the United States and Japan on Saturday, as a senior Chinese military official accused Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel and Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan of acting in concert to sow controversy and division in the Asia-Pacific region.

headline: Vows | A Nearly Missed Connection
text: You can find just about anything on Craigslist: an apartment, an old car, even a job. But Sara Mosbrucker never thought she would find her husband there.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 12
text: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Gina Centrello, on Teamwork as Its Own Energy Source
text: This interview with  Gina Centrello, president and publisher of the Random House Publishing Group, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, June 1
text: “We looked at the combination with Beats, and what we saw is a company that has incredible, rare talent.”

headline: Rules of the Fund Road: Watch the Fees, and Don’t Look Back
text: Investing would be easy if you could predict the future. Unfortunately, I can’t help you with that. But I do know a little about what works and what doesn’t work.

headline: There’s Nothing Wrong With Being a Banker
text: I have something unfashionable to say: Banking is a fine career choice for today’s college graduates.

headline: Variety: A Numerical Acrostic
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — Here’s your word for the week: zenzizenzizenzic. It means, of course, something raised to the EIGHTH power, and I have absolutely no shame whatsoever admitting that I had to look that up. You shouldn’t, either. Pull that one out at at the next cocktail party, and see how long it takes the host to ask you to leave. Just kidding. What a fun word!

headline: The iPhone 6 Rumors Heat Up
text: When the iPhone first came out in 2007, it looked like a giant among mobile phones. This fancy new slate-like phone weighed in at 4.8 ounces and had a 3.5-inch diagonal screen.

headline: Through the Google Glass, Now at Hotels
text: When iPads were the gadget-du-jour, hotels often placed them in guest rooms and restaurants. Now that many guests carry their own tablets, hotels are checking in with new Google Glass wearable computers to entice travelers to check them out.

headline: Catching Their Every Word
text: Karla Ray, 39, of Des Moines, is a real-time broadcast captioner for Vitac, a closed-caption and subtitling company in Canonsburg, Pa.

headline: The Surge in Investing by Conscience
text: Financial risk and return may be the main focus of most investments. But strategies with an explicit social component are growing rapidly, according to the most current data from the industry association that supports and tracks this field: US SIF — the Forum for Sustainable and Responsible Investment.

headline: On Win Streak, Mainline G.O.P. Takes Tougher Stance Toward Tea Party
text: NEW ORLEANS — Tea Party thunder fills the Hilton Riverside ballroom with denunciations of President Obama and criticism of congressional Republicans for not being tough enough on him. The atmosphere has the energetic but hostile tone that helped propel conservatives to success in 2010.

headline: Bowe Bergdahl, American Soldier, Freed by Taliban in Prisoner Trade
text: WASHINGTON — The lone American prisoner of war from the Afghan conflict, captured by insurgents nearly five years ago, has been released to American forces in exchange for five Taliban detainees held at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, Obama administration officials said Saturday.

headline: The Enduring Promise of a Thinner You
text: Just in time for bikini season, the syndicated “Rachael Ray Show” featured a new beauty machine with a girly-sounding name: the LiLa Strawberry Laser.

headline: Fixed Soccer Matches Cast Shadow Over World Cup
text: JOHANNESBURG — A soccer referee named Ibrahim Chaibou walked into a bank in a small South African city carrying a bag filled with as much as $100,000 in $100 bills, according to another referee traveling with him. The deposit was so large that a bank employee gave Mr. Chaibou a gift of commemorative coins bearing the likeness of Nelson Mandela.

headline: Not Walking the Walk on Board Diversity
text: Companies today earn points for listening to their shareholders and agreeing to change governance practices that are seen as unenlightened or troublesome. But is there a penalty if a company reneges on its promise of change?

headline: American Businesses in China Feel Heat of a Cyberdispute
text: BEIJING — A top Chinese general was in a combative mood as he presided recently over an international security forum at a historic hotel near the Forbidden City. Among the attendees were a retired American admiral and a former American diplomat.

headline: Unlocking Secrets, if Not Its Own Value
text: Palantir Technologies will not help you share, message, pin, post or chat. It does not exist to make you more social or connected, or even to help advertisers get to you. Its technology is deeply geeky, its work secretive. Nonetheless, it’s one of the most valuable private tech companies in Silicon Valley.

headline: Using Executive Powers, Obama Begins His Last Big Push on Climate Policy
text: WASHINGTON — All but giving up on Congress, President Obama has spent the year foraging for issues he could tackle on his own, and largely coming up with minor executive orders. But on Monday, he will unveil a plan to take on climate change that may be his last, most sweeping effort to remake America in his remaining time in office.

headline: Business School, Disrupted
text: If any institution is equipped to handle questions of strategy, it is Harvard Business School, whose professors have coined so much of the strategic lexicon used in classrooms and boardrooms that it’s hard to discuss the topic without recourse to their concepts: Competitive advantage. Disruptive innovation. The value chain.

headline: Sloane Stephens at a Loss to Explain Winning Ways
text: PARIS — Asked Thursday if being the top American woman at the French Open affected her, Sloane Stephens said, “It means nothing.”

headline: In Hollywood, Even the Trailers Get Awards
text: LOS ANGELES – They are known as the Oscars for the attention-deficit crowd: The Golden Trailer Awards, a 90-minute ceremony honoring promos that run about two minutes and 30 seconds. (And movie theater owners even think that is too long.)

headline: An Impressive Workout by California Chrome Electrifies Belmont Park
text: Well before 6 a.m. Saturday, the news media began to assemble outside Barn 26 at Belmont Park. California Chrome’s connections were there, too, coffee in hand.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s Money Talking
text: June 4 marks the 25th anniversary of the uprising in Tiananmen Square, when student-led protests in China were ruthlessly put down by the country’s government. Today, China is poised to surpass the United States as the world’s largest economy. Perhaps that’s not too surprising for a country of 1.3 billion people that has embraced capitalism and seen its economy boom.

headline: Britain’s New Immigrants, From Romania and Bulgaria, Face Hostilities
text: LONDON — Three days after Andrei Opincaru, a 29-year-old Romanian, arrived in Britain this year, police officers saw him smoking a cigarette on the street. They stopped, searched and questioned him about having marijuana.

headline: Egypt’s Latest Military Strongman
text: There was never any suspense about who would win Egypt’s presidential election last week. Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, until recently the military chief and controlling force behind the government, always had the upper hand — the army’s loyalty, the subservient media and the lack of real competition after he jailed or intimidated all serious opposition. He got more than 95 percent of the vote.

headline: Secrecy That Kills
text: One of the maddening aspects of the General Motors safety scandal is the company’s maneuvering to conceal vital information about an ignition switch defect from government regulators and the public. The defect is linked to 13 deaths and many serious injuries.

headline: A Future Barely Dimmed by Elbow Surgery
text: Jeff Hoffman will watch the baseball draft on Thursday from his home in Latham, N.Y., and for a while, he will not be happy. Hoffman, a junior right-hander at East Carolina, began the season hoping to be selected first over all.

headline: Robert Sallee, Who Survived Smoke Jumping Disaster, Dies at 82
text: Late in the afternoon of Aug. 5, 1949, 15 young men working for the United States Forest Service parachuted into a remote area near the Missouri River north of Helena, Mont., on the eastern side of the Rockies, prepared to battle what they thought to be an easily manageable forest fire. They were tragically wrong.

headline: Our Flinching State of Mind
text: ON Feb. 26, 1972, 132 million gallons of black coal sludge broke through a dam above the Appalachian hollow of Buffalo Creek, W.Va., and spewed onto the 5,000 people who lived in the scattered villages below. “It was a wall of water and debris,” one survivor remembered. “It looked like it was about 25 or 30 foot high coming running at us. And it was just black-looking. It was just rumbling and roaring and the houses was popping and snapping and they was breaking up.” In the end, 125 people lost their lives and more than 4,000 lost their homes.

headline: Bob Bailey, Entertainer Who Helped Integrate Las Vegas, Dies at 87
text: Bob Bailey, a Las Vegas entertainer, television personality and civil rights activist who helped break down racial barriers for decades, beginning when he arrived in 1955 to serve as an M.C. and singer at the Moulin Rouge, the city’s first integrated hotel and casino, died on May 24 in Las Vegas. He was 87.

headline: Art Sherman
text: Art Sherman is a horse trainer and former jockey who at 77 last month became the oldest trainer to have a horse win the Kentucky Derby. Two weeks later, that same horse, California Chrome, won the Preakness Stakes. He will run in the Belmont Stakes on Saturday, vying for the Triple Crown.

headline: A Global Community
text: Readers respond to a May 28 letter from William V. Wishard about the promise of globalization, if done wisely.

headline: The Wild Children of Yesteryear
text: PHILADELPHIA — DINNER with your children in 19th-century America often required some self-control. Berry stains in your daughter’s hair? Good for her. Raccoon bites running up your boy’s arms? Bet he had an interesting day.

headline: This Fugitive Life
text: WE have begun to pay attention to the harmful effects that America’s extremely high levels of incarceration have on former prisoners and their families, particularly in African-American neighborhoods, but we’re still missing part of the story. Our get-tough turn didn’t just send millions of African-American men to prison and return them home with felony convictions. It expanded the scope of policing and court supervision in poor black neighborhoods, radically altering the way life is lived there.

headline: Terry Robinson, Chiropractor and Fitness Trainer to the Stars, Dies at 98
text: Terry Robinson arrived in Hollywood in 1948 with a fortuitous portfolio. A competitive bodybuilder, licensed chiropractor and professed physical therapist, he specialized in treating muscle tension and neck pain — ailments that were increasing in Hollywood during a difficult decade.

headline: How to Get Girls Into Coding
text: WHEN I was 7 years old, I knew the capitals of most major countries and their currencies. I had to, if I wanted to track down a devious criminal mastermind in the computer game “Where in the World Is Carmen Sandiego?” On screen, the ACME Detective Agency would spit out clues like notable landmarks to help players identify the city where Carmen’s globe-trotting henchmen were hiding out. I wouldn’t learn how to pronounce Reykjavik for more than a decade, but I could tell you that its currency was called the krona.

headline: Lamenting a Lost View
text: Two apartment buildings under construction in Weehawken, N.J., steal a momentary pleasure once afforded to commuters.

headline: Giving Killers Coverage, Not Platforms
text: THE stone-faced young man stood on the sidewalk last week near Union Square holding a large, hand-lettered sign on a hot-pink piece of poster board. It read: “I deserve hot blonde women.” I wondered if this could be an ironic piece of feminist political commentary or if it was intended to seem hostile.

headline: Disoriented Baby Beaver Meets Midstream Kayaker…
text: A beautiful piece about a kayaker’s encounter with a baby beaver on the Hudson River is posted on the EarthDesk blog of my Pace University colleague John Cronin.

headline: In Search of Second Chances
text: The defendant had been charged, tried and convicted of a crime. As she neared the end of her prison sentence, a well-known conservative columnist wrote that she was “paying her dues,” and that “there is simply no reason for anyone to attempt to deny her right to leave her troubles in the past and start anew.”

headline: Full Screed Ahead
text: WE no longer have news. We have springboards for commentary. We have cues for Tweets.

headline: Prisoners of Sex
text: IN an ideal world, perhaps, the testimony left by the young man who killed six people in Santa Barbara would have perished with its author: the video files somehow wiped off the Internet, his manifesto deleted and any printed copy pulped.

headline: Abandon Hope, Almost All Ye Who Enter the N.B.A. Playoffs
text: If only the N.B.A. playoffs could have remained as mercurial as the loquacious, litigious team owner who obscured them on the way to his own apparent elimination.

headline: Obama’s Foreign Policy Book
text: SULAIMANIYA, Iraq — When President Obama sits down to write his foreign policy memoir he may be tempted to use as his book title the four words he reportedly uses privately to summarize the Obama doctrine: “Don’t Do Stupid Stuff” (with “stuff” sometimes defined more spicily).

headline: Obama Success, or Global Shame?
text: MRAUK U, Myanmar — AS we hiked on a bamboo bridge over a river, past a police checkpoint, by water buffalo, over abandoned rice paddies, and past a hamlet where 28 Muslim children had been hacked to death, word raced ahead of us. Farmers poured out to welcome us from two besieged villages that for two years have been mostly cut off from the world.

headline: Kings and Blackhawks Build a Series of Thrills
text: LOS ANGELES — Magic Johnson and the Los Angeles Lakers gave the sporting world “Showtime,” but this year, it has been Chicago Blackhawks right wing Patrick Kane who has put on a show.

headline: Lessons From the Smoke Shop
text: MY 30-year-long subscription to The New Yorker ran out a few months ago — pure absent-mindedness on my part — and since then I buy a copy each week at the smoke shop around the corner from my apartment.

headline: Triple Crown Bid Is a Long-Awaited Anniversary Gift
text: When a caller to a 1986 sports talk radio show that I co-hosted asked why no horse had won the Triple Crown in a while, the jockey Eddie Arcaro, a guest on the show, said, “You’ll never see another.”

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: A Past Not Past
text: WASHINGTON — As I walk up to Bobby Van’s Steakhouse to meet Gerry Adams, I’m surprised to see him sitting alone outside. Wearing a dark three-piece tweed suit with a green ribbon on the lapel, the alleged terrorist on the terrace is calmly reading some papers.

headline: French Crowds Love and Hate Their Own
text: PARIS — It has been many years since a French teenager with no Grand Slam experience captivated the Roland Garros crowd the way Laurent Lokoli did last week.

headline: An Unflashy Player Has Numbers That Sparkle
text: He’s 40, a part-time outfielder in New York and among the best in history at reaching base. You are probably thinking of Ichiro Suzuki, but you would be off by more than 500 times on base.

headline: Authorities Find Insider Trading Case Tied to Phil Mickelson Is Slow to Take Shape
text: In the summer of 2011, a series of winning stock trades raised immediate red flags for financial regulators.

headline: As Ties With China Unravel, U.S. Companies Head to Mexico
text: SALTILLO, Mexico — Jason Sauey calls them lemmings — all the American companies that rushed to China to make things like toys and toilet brushes, only to be searching now for alternatives in Mexico and the United States. His own family-owned plastics company, Flambeau, nearly made the same mistake around 2004, he said, when competitors contracting with China undercut prices and seized market share.

headline: Stars, and Nonstars, Keep Aligning for the Miami Heat
text: MIAMI — Shane Battier, a 13-year N.B.A. veteran and two-time champion with the Miami Heat, was the perfect player to provide a bit of context to the happenings late Friday. Although some of his teammates said they would need time to gain perspective on their latest accomplishment — a playoff series win over the Indiana Pacers, a fourth straight trip to the finals — Battier seemed to possess a good deal.

headline: View, Interrupted: The Spoiling of Manhattan’s Skyline
text: MANHATTAN is an island of serious wealth, endless ambition and impossibly expensive real estate.

headline: In Ukraine War, Kremlin Leaves No Fingerprints
text: DONETSK, Ukraine — Not long ago, Alexander Borodai, a fast-talking Muscovite with a stylish goatee, worked as a consultant for an investment fund in Moscow. Today he is prime minister of the self-declared Donetsk People’s Republic, zipping around town in a black S.U.V. with tinted windows and armed guards and commanding what he says are hundreds of fighters from Russia.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, June 1
text: Turmoil continues to rock the Department of Veteran’s Affairs, heightened by the resignation of Eric K. Shinseki on Friday. The Sunday talk shows will examine what’s next for the department, but first, guests will dive into the United States’ foreign policy blueprint, outlined in President Obama’s commencement speech at the United States Military Academy at West Point.

headline: Watson Holds Lead at Memorial, but Mickelson Garners More Attention
text: DUBLIN, Ohio — It is less than two weeks before the United States Open, and Tiger Woods is sidelined with a back injury, Phil Mickelson is involved in a federal insider trading investigation, and Rory McIlroy is dealing with the fallout from breaking off his engagement to the tennis star Caroline Wozniacki after their wedding announcements were mailed.

headline: In Obama’s Speeches, a Shifting Tone on Terror
text: WASHINGTON — Few leaders place more weight than President Obama on the power of the spoken word to clarify a messy world. But after five and a half years and dozens of speeches — most recently at West Point last week — the trail of Mr. Obama’s pronouncements has grown muddier.

headline: You Can’t Tell the Tennis Stars’ Coaches Without a Scorecard
text: PARIS — In the French Open players’ lounge this year, Stefan Edberg notices a change from his glory days.

headline: With the Rohingya in Myanmar
text: My Sunday column, from some remote villages in Myanmar, looks at the ethnic cleansing and crimes against humanity being perpetrated against the Rohingya minority there. Some scholars call it genocide, and it arguably does meet the definition in the 1948 convention. But it’s not comparable to the mass murders in Rwanda, Darfur, Armenia or of course the Holocaust, so maybe ethnic cleansing is a better term in this case.

headline: The Race Not Run
text: NIIKAPPU-GUN, Japan — It was just after noon on a recent day at Big Red Farm, one of Japan’s largest horse breeders, time for Hiroshi Kimura to take the 5-year-old stallion I’ll Have Another for a walk.

headline: Many Veterans Praise Care, but All Hate the Wait
text: WASHINGTON — Marc Schenker, an Air Force veteran in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., is having surgery this month to remove a golf-ball-size hernia — but not at a veterans hospital. Mr. Schenker, 67, said he had given up on the Veterans Affairs hospital in Miami after waiting months to get the procedure scheduled and had turned to a private surgeon instead, using Medicare.

headline: What Veterans Tell Us About Their Care
text: Amid reports of delayed access to care at Department of Veterans Affairs hospitals, The New York Times asked veterans and others to share their stories about the quality of care at the agency’s facilities across the country. A selection of submissions appears below. We invite you to share your story here.

headline: After Tanaka’s Eighth Victory, Most See Him as an Ace. He Doesn’t.
text: Shortly after Masahiro Tanaka signed a seven-year, $155 million contract in January, Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman said in a radio interview that Tanaka, a 25-year-old pitcher, had a ceiling as a No. 3 starter.

headline: Russia’s Reach Into Ukraine’s East
text: While Russian tanks never crossed the border with Ukraine, many of its civilians did, bolstering a pro-Russian agenda that has destabilized the divided east.

headline: Anger for ‘Jesus Christ Superstar’ Cast, and a Black Eye for Its Promoter
text: NEW ORLEANS — Ben Forster, a 33-year-old British actor, was preparing for the biggest break of his career as he rehearsed the title role for an ambitious arena tour of “Jesus Christ Superstar” that was to have its first performance here at the Lakefront Arena on June 9.

headline: U.S. Counts on Altidore to End His Drought
text: For several years, Jozy Altidore has carried expectations of becoming the United States’ next great, or perhaps first great, goal-scoring striker. Yet at the very moment he appears ready to reach his potential, he is in a confounding scoring slump.

headline: Harrah’s Tunica Casino to Close, Hinting at Gambling Glut
text: TUNICA RESORTS, Miss. — At the height of a recent dinner hour at Mississippi’s largest casino, fewer than two dozen patrons were seated in the buffet’s dining room. A nearby jewelry display sat aglow but bare. The hallways were mostly empty.

headline: Aladdin
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — How long did it take you to figure out how the title of Tom McCoy’s puzzle related to the puzzle itself? Hands up if you studied it and pored over it and it still didn’t sink in. Then, just as you were about to walk away, it trickled through your gray matter, hit the right brain cell, and you said “Ooooooohhhhh …”

headline: Grandmaster’s Death Recalls Era of Risks and Rewards
text: The Serbian grandmaster Dragoljub Velimirovic, who died May 22 at age 72, was one of the last players to develop a system or strategy that is so inventive it bears its creator’s name.

headline: Before Syrian Suicide Blast, a Quiet Life in the Suburbs
text: VERO BEACH, Fla. — An American suicide bomber who a militant group said detonated 16 tons of explosives at a mountaintop restaurant in Syria last week was remembered in the suburban Florida subdivision where he grew up for a single thing: his love of basketball.

headline: Spurs’ Experimentation With Lineups Pays Off
text: With two resounding wins at home, the Oklahoma City Thunder seemed to have the momentum going their way. But San Antonio Spurs Coach Gregg Popovich had been preparing his team for this moment all season.

headline: After Deadly Rampage, Sheriff’s Office Faces Concerns About Conduct
text: LOS ANGELES — A week after Elliot O. Rodger’s violent rampage in Isla Vista, Calif., that left six college students dead and 13 other people wounded, state lawmakers are now calling for an investigation of the Santa Barbara County Sheriff’s Office’s previous contact with Mr. Rodger. Some are calling for wholesale changes to how law enforcement officers respond to calls that someone could be a threat to himself or to others.

headline: Bergdahl in Taliban Video (2009)
text: Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl recounted his capture and desire to rejoin to his girlfriend and family in the United States in a video released by the Taliban a month after he was taken prisoner.

headline: The Rangers’ March to the Finals, Step by Step
text: The Rangers were still celebrating their Eastern Conference title late Thursday night when someone asked Coach Alain Vigneault how he would have reacted in October if someone had told him his team would be in the Stanley Cup finals come June.

headline: The Politics of Obama’s Climate Move
text: Assessing the political landscape as President Obama prepares to introduce a new regulation to get states to cut carbon emissions and reduce pollution.

headline: Pentagon Plan to Enlist Young Immigrants Is Delayed at White House’s Request
text: A Pentagon plan to allow a small number of young immigrants who grew up in the United States without legal status to enlist in the military has been delayed by the White House, senior officials there said Saturday, to avoid any conflict with House Republicans considering whether to move on immigration legislation.

headline: Tracing the Origin of Handshake Lines in the N.H.L.
text: One moment Thursday encapsulated the special nature of the N.H.L.’s traditional handshake line after playoff series: The Montreal Canadiens’ Brandon Prust placed his hand gently on the side of Derek Stepan’s head, smiling as he spoke to Stepan, his affection bound with remorse and best wishes as the Rangers were headed to the Stanley Cup finals.
